column2: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Norman Thomas, five times the Socialist party's Presidential candidate, said in an address here tonight that, considering the grave issues of peace and prosperity involved in the current major party conflict, he had never seen a campaign conducted at a lower level.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 24 -No nation at war has ever been "so well prepared economically for the tasks of peace" as the United States is today, Senator Robert F. Wagner, candidate for re-election on the Democratic ticket, declared tonight, in urging a Democratic Congress and the retention of President Roosevelt for a fourth term.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 24 (AP) -- New England's mysterious "Lady in Red," who has been known to place show wagers of $12,000 on a horse race, is a dark-haired little woman who has had nineteen consecutive winning substantial show wagers for a profit of $16,000 in the past ten weeks, William Jubb, an executive of the pari-mutuel system at Rockingham Park, said today.

The excitement of a Broadway "first night" and the glitter of a couturier showing combined yesterday afternoon as the first performance of "Fashions of The Times," third edition, went on before a filled house at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

In the Brooklyn Federal court yesterday, barely a day after their arrest by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents, Simon Emil Koedel and his foster daughter, Marie Hedwig Koedel, were indicted for consipracy to commit espionage. The indictment also named as defendants three German agents now in Germany, and identified five more as co-conspirators but not defendants.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The potentialities of the paint industry after the war are enormous and lie in three main fields, Jesse H. Jones, Secretary of Commerce, declared in a message which the National Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association sent today to its members as part of its third annual "convention at home" program.

ATHENS, Oct 24 (AP) -- Premier George Papandreou announced tonight the formation of a new Greek Cabinet. At the same time his Finance Minister disclosed the arrival of "large amounts" of gold from London to help stabilize the drachma.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Bon Jour, owned by Charles Turner of Toronto, scored his sixth straight victory today in the $4,000 Quantity Handicap at Laurel Park. Carrying top weight of 126 pounds and confidently ridden by Doug Dodson, the 4-year-old son of Sun Beau was an easy two-length winner of the mile-and-a-sixteenth test.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 24 -- Scores of Hollywood celebrities, many of whom had known and worked with Richard Bennett for more than a quarter of a century, attended a funeral service for the stage and screen veteran in All Saints Episcopal Church in Beverly Hills this afternoon. Mr. Bennett died Sunday at the age of 72.
Frank Sinatra spoke in President Roosevelt's behalf before a predominantly bobby socks audience in crowded Carnegie Hall last night -- spoke gravely, and was heard with marked respect.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- President Roosevelt told his news conference today that an amazing number of newspapers which regard themselves as reputable had fallen into the awful habit of quoting only half a sentence in implying that he had departed, in making speaking trips, from his declaration in accepting the fourth-term nomination that he would not campaign in the usual sense.

Pressure on the stock market lifted yesterday, but since the selling wave of Monday was not replaced by any demand of force prices could show only a thin line of recovery and an irregularly firmer closing. Some support was accorded the list when good dividend news appeared, but this was reserved mainly for the rail division.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper announced today he had filed suits in the State Supreme Court in an effort to collect $12,009,790 in tax interest claimed due from five railroads operating in New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The political record of Senator Joseph H. Ball of Minnesota, whose name has come into special prominence because he has taken the unusual course of opposing his party's Presidential nominee, has been generally critical of the Administration on domestic issues closely linked to the war program and in advance of its international policy.

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. At Loew's Criterion, the new attraction will be "Rainbow Island," a Paramount musical filmed in Technicolor. Featured in the cast are Dorothy Lamour, Eddie Bracken, Gil Lamb, Barry Sullivan and Marc Lawrence. . . .

For the ingredients of "Violet" Whitfield Cook has reached to the bottom of the grab bag and has come up with some pretty strange things -- as well as performances. It has occurred to him that a comedy might be written about an often-married artist who is seeking to take unto himself another wife, while the children of his earlier adventures scamper through a Vermont house.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 24 (U.P.) -- "Little Boy Blue," orphaned in England by the war, completed a Presidentially authorized journey to his new home today -- and grinned when his cousin stole his bottle of milk.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 18, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24 (U.P.) -- Football teams from Harvard, Holy Cross, Boston College and Tufts may meet in a round-robin war relief tournament at Harvard Stadium Nov. 18, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Ending of martial law and restoration of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus in Hawaii were announced by the White House today with the assertion that continued improvement in the war situation in the Pacific made no longer necessary the special public safety provisions ordered after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor Dec. 7, 1941.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 24 (AP) -The following are the telegrams, besides those of Messrs. White and Martin quoted in the speech, which Mr. Dewey received from men who he said stood to be the leaders in Congress if the Republicans won in November:

Acting on reports that many resort homes previously used only in summer months were being turned into all-year residences as a result of the housing shortage here, the Office of Price Administration has moved to keep the rentals of such houses in line with its ceiling prices, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct 24 -- Regulations to govern stoppages of production no longer needed in the prosecution of the war were prescribed in an order signed today by James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization and Reconversion. The action was taken on the recommendations of Robert Hinkley, Director of Contract Termination, and of a subcommittee of his office composed of representatives of the contracting agencies and the War Production Board.

The Brooklyn Real Estate, Allied Trades and Insurance Division of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies will inaugurate its efforts on behalf of the current federation fund drive with a dinner on Wednesday, Nov. 1, at 6:30 P.M., at the Park Manor, 450 Eastern Parkway. Supreme Court Justice E. Ivan Rubenstein will be a guest.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 -- The Earl of Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, brought to a climax tonight this city's celebration of the three hundredth anniversary of its founding father, William Penn, by calling for a post-war international order in which justice, "so armed as to be beyond challenge." would prevail.
ROME, Oct. 24 -- A precedent of many centuries was broken this morning when the Pope permitted his Sedia Gestatoria to be carried out of the Hall of Benediction by Polish officers after an audience.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- Grain markets advanced sharply today on a broad buying movement headed by commission houses and professional traders. Closing deals on the Board of Trade were at about the top, with oats in new ground since August and rye since July.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 24 -- Nassau County registration reached a new high of 291,469 this year, according to official figures released today by the Board of Elections. The figure is 12 per cent above the previous high of 257,233 established in 1940, and foreshadows a huge vote in this year's election.

LONDON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Striking the Germans with ever greater fury, Lieut. Gen. Sir Miles C. Dempsey's British Second Army fought tonight into the streets of 's Hertogenbosch, keystone of the enemy's defense system in the western Netherlands, and captured the northeast factory district of that ancient cathedral city.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,391 comared to 1,200 last week and 1,431 in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 904 against 655 last Tuesday.
PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 24 -- Japanese Navy forces have been sighted and attacked by carrier planes of the Third Fleet in the Philippines.

A number of private dwellings figured in realty deals in Manhattan yesterday. Oscar L. Richard of C.B. Richard Co. bought the five-story building at 4 East Seventy-third Street from Mrs. Edward Van Ingen in an all-cash transaction, Douglas L. Elliman Co. were the brokers.

While the question of extending polling hours in New York State remained in abeyance, following a discussion between counsel for Governor Dewey and the New York City Board of Elections, New Jersey acted definitely yesterday against any lengthening of voting hours at the national election on Nov. 7.
The Berlin radio reported yesterday that the "first American woman" had been captured on the Western Front and described her as Mrs. Gertrude Legendre, 42 years old, of New York.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Oct. 23 (Delayed) -- Filipino forces, armed with captured Japanese weapons, deadly bolos and ancient rifles, paved the way for the American invasion of Leyte by gathering detailed information on enemy troop dispositions and killing 3,800 Japanese, it was disclosed today.

The wisdom of wearing some article of red in the field so that a man is less likely to be mistaken for a delectable species of game and thus find himself laid low by an overeager fellow hunter is pretty well acknowledged. However, the question whether sportsmen should be required by law to don such garb is something else again.
LONDON, Oct. 24 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- French circles believed tonight that a result of the Allies' recognition of the de Gaulle Government would be an early visit by Prime Minister Churchill to Paris as a visible sign of the renewal of an Anglo-French entente, which is so desired on both sides of the Channel, and which many consider to be the cornerstone of both countries' future foreign policy in Europe.

ROME, Oct. 24 (AP) -- A flanking threat to Bologna, key German communication and supply center in northern Italy, has been developed by the American capture today of Frassineto and further gains to the east. Frassineto lies five miles southwest of Castel San Pietro, Po Valley town thirteen miles southeast of Bologna on the lateral Rimini highway.

ON TRUMAN TRAIN EN ROUTE TO CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Senator Harry S. Truman appealed to Wisconsin voters today for the election of a "can-do" President, and declared that Democratic chances for farm support had not been hurt by the Political Action Committee's advocacy of the Roosevelt ticket.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 (AP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a series of transactions designed to simplify the corporate structures of the NY PA NJ Utilities Company and a major subsidiary, the Metropolitan Edison Company of Reading, Pa.

The people of this city will vote to fill fourteen judicial positions in the elections to be held on Nov. 7. We present as a trustworthy guide for voters the recommendations of the leading bar associations and of the Citizens Union, where such recommendations have been made, with regard to candidates for these fourteen places.

If the question of American participation in a world security organization under a pledge to use force against aggression without obtaining the approval of Congress in each case had to come before the Senate as now constituted, there would be "a very tough fight" and the issue would be in doubt, Senator Joseph H. Ball said at a press interview here yesterday.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically from Sofia and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Gifts of $247,000 to the New York War Fund were reported yesterday by team captains at a meeting of the women's division in the Carlton House, with Mrs. Vincent Astor, chairman, presiding. The division's total to date is $721,208. Since last week's meeting 1,364 gifts were received, making an aggregate of 2,821.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 24 -Representative Joseph W. Martin, Republican, of Massachusetts and minority leader of the House, addressed several hundred persons at the Passaic County Republican League headquarteres here tonight. Loud speakers were set up to accommodate an overflow of several hundred outside the clubhouse.

George Weller, who was an eyewitness in Greece, Singapore and Java of the fall of bases for which we are now fighting, believes our best guarantee of security lies in the establishment of a permanent world-wide system of American bases.

Supreme Court Justice Frank Murphy was honored yesterday afternoon by the Council against Intolerance in America for the role he has taken in the effort to promote American unity and assure "the just treatment of all peoples, regardless of their race or creed or color."

WITH THE TWENTY-FOURTH CORPS, on Leyte, Oct. 24 (AP) -Soldiers of the Seventh Division, driving spearheads into parts of Leyte Valley, trudged through swamps, densely undergrown banana groves and cornfields today to seize San Pablo airfield in a seven-mile advance under a sweltering sun.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- A charge that President Roosevelt withheld vital information from Congress with respect to Germany's air rearmament during the pre-war years was made today by Representative Albert J. Engel, Michigan Republican.
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 24 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Yesterday the papers had a photograph of the American flag being hoisted over Philippine soil by a naval beach party. The day before there were photographs of the big prefabricated harbors set up by the Allies on the Normandy beaches.

Fourteen stores here won awards in the nation-wide contest for the best window display on clothes conservation sponsored by the American Women's Voluntary Services, Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel, AWVS national director of public relations, revealed yesterday at its headquarters, 345 Madison Avenue.

Refusing the resignations of Dorothy Thompson, columnist, and Rex Stout, author, as president and a director, respectively, of Freedom House, sixteen members of the organization's board of directors expressed confidence last night that both would "close ranks" within the group so that more effective work might be achieved.

ISTANBUL, Oct. 22 (Delayed) -- Out of 270,000 Rumanian Jews who survived massacre, deportations and forced labor camps, 150,000 face starvation or death from cold. They are without clothes or food and without roofs over their heads.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (U.P.) -- The Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee reported today that none of the Democratic or Republican Presidential and Vice Presidential nominees spent any funds to win their nominations.

Tonight will be a memorable one for Howard Lindsay, Russel Crouse, Elliott Nugent, Leland Hayward and the Cullman brothers, Howard and Joseph. At 8:40 this evening these gentlemen will formally inaugurate their ownership of the Hudson (the house was purchased last January for $300,000 from the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank) with the premiere of "Snafu," staged and produced by George Abbott.

Tonight will be a memorable one for Howard Lindsay, Russel Crouse, Elliott Nugent, Leland Hayward and the Cullman brothers, Howard and Joseph. At 8:40 this evening these gentlemen will formally inaugurate their ownership of the Hudson (the house was purchased last January for $300,000 from the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank) with the premiere of "Snafu," staged and produced by George Abbott.
LONDON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

WINNIPEG, Man., Oct. 25 (Canadian Press ) -- Training completed to the satisfaction of Manager Lester Patrick, the New York Rangers tonight broke camp and headed for Toronto, where they will open the National Hockey League season against the Toronto Maple Leafs on Saturday night.

A resolution approving an educational program to explain to the public generally why it should buy through retail stores on credit was adopted yesterday at a meeting of the board of directors of the Retail Credit Institute of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Pamphlets will be prepared for distribution to consumers telling of the advantage of buying a "bundle of services," including the credit privilege, in the purchase of merchandise.
The Japanese fleet has at long last picked up the gauntlet and has met the American challenge.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- At least 750 Japanese naval craft have been sunk or damaged since Pearl Harbor against total American losses in all oceans of 195 warships of all types.

Leadership in the post-war fashion world probably will be furnished by "Paris plus New York," spokesmen for various branches of the industry agreed yesterday. No conflict need arise between the two capitals, 700 members of the Fashion Group were assured at a luncheon at the Hotel Astor.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 25 -- Publishing an election blacklist containing the names and addresses of approximately 4,500 local residents, The Jersey Journal of this city attacked editorially today the permanent registration law in New Jersey and announced that the newspaper would refuse to accept payment for the two and one-half pages of scarce newsprint devoted to the list "as a method of emphatic protest against the evils of permanent registration of voters."

LONDON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- "Unconditional surrender in the sense of no bargaining with the enemy is still the policy of the Government," Prime Minister Churchill reiterated today in the House of Commons.

Opening a War Production Board campaign to counteract the influence of "cut-back consciousness," Lewis S. Greenleaf Jr., regional director, declared yesterday that current war production presents "a much grimmer picture than a great many people realize or would like to believe."

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY AT LIVERGNANO, Italy, Oct. 25 -- This afternoon at 3 oclock, in a fog so thick that the groaning, mud-drenched supply trucks had to slither forward with their breaks on, German mortars beat out a post-mortem on the scene where, fifteen days ago, an American infantry company was lost as a unit.

For the last few years Cheryl Crawford has been much too busy putting on musical hits to pay any attention to straight drama. Tonight she will remedy that oversight by escorting Samson Raphaelson's play, "The Perfect Marriage." as directed by the author, into the Barrymore, with Miriam Hopkins and Victor Jory co-starred.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Alied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 25 (UP) -- Communique 200:
Football attendance this year is slightly higher than in 1943, with all sections of the country drawing more fans, except the Midwest and the East, a United Press survey disclosed last night.

Governor Dewey can hardly wait longer than today or tomorrow to decide whether or not he will call a special session of the Legislature to extend voting hours in this city. Nor need it take him longer to make up his mind. On facts that can be stated in five minutes or less he might have made it up before this time.

The roughest intrasquad scrimmage of the campaign marked New York University's workout yesterday, as Coach Jack Weinheimer started serious preparations for the City College contest on Ohio Field Saturday. The entire squad spent the two-hour session in contact work.

Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic National Chairman, in a double-barreled attack on Republican foreign policy, accused Governor Dewey yesterday of using the voice of a "junior Harding" in his Minneapolis speech and taxed John Foster Dulles, the Governor's adviser on foreign relations, with counseling lenient treatment for Japan after the war.
LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Although business in today's stock markets was light, a cheerful tone prevailed in most sections.

The New York Chamber Orchestra, under F. Charles Adler, gave its initial concert last night in Town Hall. Joseph Schuster, in Town Hall. Joseph Schuster, 'cello, was the soloist, and the assisting artists included William Lincer, viola; H. Gomberg, oboe; W. Polisi, bassoon; R. Puletz, horn, and W. Vacchiano, trumpet.

The nation's crude oil production last week averaged 4,744,900 barrels daily, 18,350 more than the daily figure of 4,726,550 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Output was 36,400 barrels over the recommendation of 4,708,500 daily for October by the Petroleum Administration for War.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- To the accompaniment of what Governor Dewey called "the most tremendous" reception he had ever seen, the Republican candidate came to this Democratic stronghold in mid-afternoon for a speech tonight, ending a three-State tour in the Midwest.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- A survey just completed by the Smaller War Plants Corporation, Government agency set up to assist small business, indicates that many Federally owned war plants can be converted in peacetime into community manufacturing centers, locally owned and financed, Maury Maverick, head of SWPC announced today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in English to North America from Chungking and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The National War Labor Board ended today all possibility of President Roosevelt changing the "little steel" pay formula before election day by postponing discussion on specific wage cases and the general problem of wage stabilization until next Tuesday.

"Marriage Is a Private Affair," a comedy romance produced by Metro, will open this morning at the Capitol. Lana Turner, James Craig and John Hodiak head the cast. Directed by Robert Z. Leonard, the picture's supporting players include Frances Gifford, Hugh Marlowe, Keenan Wynn and Herbert Rudley.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

BUFFALO, Oct. 25 -- Erie County, with more than 400,000 potential voters, the largest number in the State outside New York City, and the division of which may decide whether President Roosevelt or Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, his Republican opponent, will win New York's forty-seven electoral votes, is a good deal of a political puzzle.

The convention of the United Federal Workers of America, Congress of Industrial Organizations, rejected yesterday a proposal that any necessary lay-offs of Government employes be accomplished in such manner as would maintain in jobs the present proportion of Negroes to white workers.

The National Electrical Manufacturers Association launched yesterday a program designed to organize several hundred thousand employes of member plants into a "volunteer army" of unofficial salesmen to stimulate interest in the greater use of electricity and electrical appliances. The program was adopted at the annual meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Morgan Stanley Co. head a nation-wide group of 148 investment banking houses which will offer today $100,000,000 of the American Tobacco Company's twenty-five-year 3 per cent debentures at 101 and interest. This financing will be the largest by an industrial concern since April, 1942, when the same company sold $100,000,000 of 3 per cent debentures, of which $94,045,000 still are outstanding.

Increasing their emphasis on New York State, with its forty-seven electoral votes, Republican campaign strategists yesterday added to Governor Dewey's speaking schedule a major address in Syracuse on Saturday. The Presidential candidate will deliver there the speech on farm issues that he laid aside, on his visit to Minneapolis on Tuesday, in order to answer President Roosevelt on foreign policy.
Reference is made to your editorial of Oct. 14 "National Income Guesses."

TACLOBAN, Leyte Province, Oct. 22 (Delayed) -- The Japanese put on one of the most determined campaigns of misrepresentation in history in their attempt to propagandize the Filipino population in favor of their "Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere" and the Tokyo-Rome-Berlin Axis.

The post-war planning committee of Artists for Victory has approved some projects which are being put into immediate action and which later will be augmented. Some of the objectives of this program are concerned with the fuller utilization of the art and skill of all artists.

LOUISVILLE, Oct. 25 -- Democratic leaders of Kentucky whose faces admittedly were "mighty red" after the Republican victory in the Governorship contest last year, seem confident today of carrying the State's eleven electoral votes for a fourth term for President Roosevelt on Nov. 7.

LONDON, Oct. 25 (U.P.) -- The Russians' capture of Kirkenes, important iron ore and raiding base athwart the Allied lend-lease supply line to Murmansk, wiped out the last German positions in the Arctic east of Tromsoe, Norway.

LONDON, Oct. 25 (Canadian Press) -- Danny Webb, Negro fighter from Montreal, created probably the greatest surprise of wartime boxing in Britain tonight by forcing Jackie Paterson, world flyweight champion, to retire in the third round of a scheduled eight-round non-title bout after giving him a beating all the way.

At least $500,000,000 will be available for small businesses all over the country in the reconversion and post-war periods from groups of banks in principal cities for use in financing business operations outside the scope of "conventional" banking procedures, William Sheperdson, director of the Post-War Small Business Credit Commission of the American Bankers Association, stated yesterday.

Buying at the "convention" showing by members of the Shoe Manufacturers Board of Trade of New York, Inc., at the Hotel McAlpin, indicated that any tendency of dealers to limit their purchases of spring lines in anticipation of further style curb easing has been submerged, exhibitors said yesterday. Buying pressure was extreme, it was pointed out, with the trade, according to estimates, being allotted about 80 per cent of requirements.

In one of the most amusing scenes of "Fashions of the Times," third edition, ten of New York's leading creators of millinery presented their forward-looking hats -- hats created to indicate trends for the coming resort and spring seasons.

Mayor La Guardia made public yesterday at City Hall the text of a telegram sent to him by President Roosevelt thanking him for the "splendid arrangements" made for the President's tour of the city last Saturday. President Roosevelt expressed the hope that the Mayor suffered no ill effects from exposure to the inclement weather that prevailed during the tour.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- Two women have just been designated for seats in the enlarged French Consultative Assembly, which is to meet Nov. 7. Under a decree signed by Gen. Charles de Gaulle they were nominated by the Union of French Women in recognition of that organization's part in the resistance movement.

SEVENTH FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Philippines, Thursday, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Japan lost the first, and possibly the decisive, round in an all-out battle to halt on the Philippines line the American advance toward her home islands.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Newspaper Publishers Industry Advisory Committee recommended today that the War Production Board should retain its control over newsprint until the supply becomes equivalent to the tonnage that was used in 1941.

Robert E. Hannegan, national Democratic chairman, denied here last night that any financial contributor to the Democratic National Committee would be the "recipient of special favors," The Associated Press reported.

Despite the drop of 500,000 barrels in gasoline stocks last week, !the over-all statistical position of the petroleum industry continued to show improvement. Light fuel oil stocks were up slightly more lthan 1,000,000 barrels and now are 5,000,000 larger than they were a1 year ago.

Mrs. Minnie Strobing, mother of Sgt. Irving Strobing, the Army telegrapher who tapped out the last message from Corregidor before the island fortress fell to the Japanese, donated a pint of blood yesterday afternoon in honor of Gen. Douglas MacArthur.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 25. -- Late tonight it was learned that the partly crippled German battleship Tirpitz, which had left Altafjord, in the far northern tip of Norway, to escape being captured by the advancing Russians, has now taken refuge in another Norwegian port much farther south.
As a former forester I was interested in your editorial entitled "Forestry Problem."

ALBANY, Oct. 25 (AP) -- New York State's revenue for the first half of the present fiscal year was more than $50,000,000 above that for the same period a year ago, Rollin Browne, Tax Commissioner, reported today.
Hobby Model Manufacturing Company, model airplane kits, to Ray-Hirsch Company.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 25 -- The Germans were rapidly losing their grip tonight on their strongholds between the North Sea and the British Second Army's salient in the Netherlands.

LONDON, Thursday, Oct. 26 (U.P.) -- Red Army troops, reopening the battle for Warsaw, yesterday broke through heavily fortified German defenses to outflank the Polish capital on the northwest while other Russian troops completed the liberation of pre-war Rumania by capturing the fortress towns of Satu-Mare and Carei.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- While the remnants of the demoralized Japanese Fleet were fleeing from Admiral William F. Halsey's forces in Philippine waters, United States Army Superfortresses today were carrying the war another step closer to the heart of Japan by carrying out a successful mission against the key aircraft assembly plant at Omura on the island of Kyushu.

Among civilian voters, President Roosevelt held a 7 per cent edge over Governor Dewey as the Presidential campaign entered its final two weeks, according to the latest Fortune poll. In making public the results yesterday, editors of Fortune Magazine issued a caution that the margin was unstable, with several possibilities for an upset.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- Westchester County was conceded to Governor Dewey in the November Presidential election this afternoon by Edward J. Murray, Westchester Democratic chairman. He estimated that the Republican's plurality would be 40,000 to 52,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton of this year's growth ginned to Oct. 18 was 6,282,155 running bales, counting round as half bales and excluding linters, compared with 7,792,249 running bales a year ago, and 8,182,596 two years ago.

Biographical narratives of 103 scientists of radio, electronics and television comprise a new volume by Orrin E. Dunlap Jr., a member of the executive staff of RCA. It is called "Radio's 100 Men of Science," and will be published Nov. 8 by Harper.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Pan-American Airways made public tonight details of its proposed post-war transatlantic air service from New York City to include thirty-six departures weekly for London, Paris, Moscow, Calcutta and other points, in planes twice as large as the Lockheed Constellation and at fares ranging from $147 to $332 one way, or less than a third, in most cases, of present fares.

The aircraft industry is not facing what is generally known as conversion problems, but it must accomplish contraction and adjustment, Alfred Marchev, president of Republic Aviation Corporation, declared here yesterday at an Aviation Industry Day luncheon at the Advertising Club of New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- President Roosevelt was told today by leaders of the Liberal party of New York that their surveys and polls indicated that the party's ticket and line on the voting machines would attract "more than enough" independents and former supporters of the late Wendell L. Willkie "to guarantee" the forty-seven electoral votes of the State for Roosevelt and Truman.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- The question of the merits or demerits of the Bretton Woods world currency stabilization agreement has been pushed aside as academic in Great Britain by the more immediate and acute currency problems that threaten the liberated coutnries of Europe.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (U.P.) -- The U.S.S. Princeton, 10,000-ton carrier sunk near the Philippines, is the first American combat carrier lost in two years.

Ralph Brady financial secretary of the Putnam County Fish and Game Association, does not agree with the Conservation Department that there is a shortage of pheasants and hopes to prove his contention. He asks sportsmen who hunted in Putnam during the recent short pheasant season to tell him about the results so that he can prepare a report to be sent to Albany.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Clark H. Minor, president of the International General Electric Company, this afternoon defended cartels as a logical development of international trade and assured the Worley subcommittee of the House Committee on Post-War Economic Policy and Planning that he knew of no "bad" cartels.

The continuance of a victory garden program on a nation-wide scale next year supported by Federal and State bureaus and large industries was assured yesterday at a regional conference of the National Victory Garden Institute, Inc., at the Hotel Lexington.

KANDY, Ceylon, Oct. 25 (U.P.) -- The pursuing Fifth Indian Division is harassing Japanese troops retreating toward Kennedy Peak along mountain roads of central Burma, a Southeast Asia Command communique announced today.

DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 25 (U.P.) -- Gov. John W. Bricker charged tonight that "to all intents and purposes, the great Democratic party has become the Hillman-Browder communistic party with Franklin Roosevelt as its front."

JERUSALEM, Oct. 25 -- Uncompromising opposition to the acts of violence, sabotage and blackmail that small Jewish political extremist groups have been conducting in the Holy Land was voiced in resolutions adopted early today after an all-night meeting of the Inner Zionist General Council, the supreme administrative institution of the World Zionist Movement.

Columbia's football squad had its first scrimmage in almost two weeks yesterday when the entire group reported to Coach Lou Little at Baker Field for an extended workout. Judging by the way the men went through their paces, Little is certain to have his squad at top strength for Colgate at Baker Field Saturday.

George Abbott, who is one of the most voluble spokesmen for the younger generation, is at it again in "Snafu," which he produced and directed for the Hudson last evening. It is not the normal Abbott situation to be fouled up, although strict honesty might compel that charge for this morning; his newest chapter on youth is weak, and beyond a few happy gags it is not particularly funny.

The war draws to the city many a girl from out of town in search of a job. It draws city girls from home likewise -- perhaps from homes which the demands of war have broken up. Most of these girl toilers are self-supporting now, in a day of much work to be done and few hands to do it.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 25 -- The Belgian Government is acting on a series of proposals put forward by the Allied Supreme Headquarters mission to Belgium for relief of the critical food shortage in this country. It is believed new machinery for collecting the produce off farms will yield enough to keep the nation on its feet until the end of January, when food will have to be imported in large quantities.

Dr. Stanley P. Davies, executive director of the Community Service Society of New York since its formation by merger in 1939, will become head of the organization on Nov. 1 when he assumes the newly created post of general director, Bayard F. Pope, president, announced yesterday after a meeting of the administrative committee.

Operations of the International Business Machines Corporation and its subsidiaries in the nine months ended with September resulted in earnings of $27,744,383 before provision for taxes, Thomas J. Watson, the president, reported yesterday. This represented an increase of $839,275 over the $26,905,108 earnings before taxes for the corresponding period of 1943.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Some of the most highly placed of the President's aides who work closely with Congress are among those who have expressed wonder that Mr. Dewey failed for so long to emphasize the point he dwelt on effectively last night. This concerns the relations of Mr. Roosevelt with Congress and the prospect that the next House will be under Republican control, making his going even harder on Capitol Hill.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 25 -- Total registration in Suffolk County for the coming election was announced today by the County Board of Elections as 141,560, an increase of 15,003 over 1940. The increase was mainly in the towns of Huntington, Islip and Babylon, and this was attributed to the influx of workers for the airplane plants in the western part of the county.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -Twentieth Air Force communique 17:

Although a ninety-eight move game, played the other day in the amateur championship tournament of the United States Chess Federation, may look like something of a record to the average chess player, it is not unique, though it is infrequent. Chess Review informs that the longest game of which it has knowledge went to 169 moves.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Two great fleets of Allied heavy bombers, more than 1,200 from the United States Eighth Air Force and more than 1,000 from the Royal Air Force, attacked Germany today. The Ruhr war-industry centers, methodically being devastated, city by city, again took most of the more than 5,000 tons of explosives loosed by the bombers in the daylight assaults.

Hitting the Germans in another sledgehammer blow before they could recover from the defeat of Aachen, British troops have smashed into the communication center of 's Hertogenbosch, the keystone of the German defense line in western Holland, and the entire German front in that area is showing signs of caving in.

More than 1,000 women thronged to the fifth floor of Gimbels yesterday noon to hear Mayor La Guardia open the homemaking show sponsored by the Consumers Service Division of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office of Greater New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 -- Pity poor Pennsylvania. The most-talked-of football team in the country. Navy, is coming to Franklin Field on Saturday to play the Red and Blue in one of the naturals of the year, and Penn has nothing left to sell.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Fifty Washington political correspondents polled by Newsweek Magazine in mid-October found a "Dewey trend" at that time but a majority voted that President Roosevelt still held the lead, that magazine announced today.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Oct. 25 (AP) -- A communique:

With many families apparently planning to give up their apartments for the winter season, the offerings of subleased suites in the city within the last ten days have increased sharply and have tended temporarily to meet at least a part of the heavy demand for living quarters here, according to Joseph Platzker, Deputy Commissioner of Housing and Buildings and head of the city's vacancy listing bureau.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- President Roosevelt directed the Maritime Commission today to prepare "a bold and daring" plan for improving the American merchant marine and maintaining its future position with modern, comfortable, low-travel-cost passenger ships and cargo carriers backed up by adequate freight-handling facilities.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Oct. 25 -- The second round of the battle for Leyte has ended. It ended in a smashing naval victory for the Allied Seventh Fleet under Admiral Kinkaid fighting with the Japanese on two fronts simultaneously.

Plans for organizing protests of property owners in the Yorkville area against the City Planning Commission's proposed amendments to the zoning resolution were taken yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Yorkville Chamber of Commerce in the Croydon Hotel.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 25 -- Endorsing the tentative Dumbarton Oaks program, speakers at the opening of a three-day conference at Lafayette College urged the immediate establishment of a United Nations world peace organization with full power to use whatever force might be necessary to quell aggressors.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a plan filed by the Illinois Traction Company, a subsidiary of the North American Light and Power Company, in compliance with Section 11B of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, which in substance provides for retirement of the publicly held preferred and common stocks of Illinois Traction and subsequent liquidation of the company.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 25 -- Orders to shoot to kill, if necessary, have been issued to United States troops in France in an effort to halt looting and pilfering from Army supplies, including gasoline and food, which are the main concern of the Allied forces at the moment.
PARIS, Oct. 25 -- "Georges Mandel was a great Frenchman and an ardent patriot," said Judge Francois Pailhe today early in the trial of three alleged gunmen of Joseph Darnand's Vichy militia.

ATHENS, Oct. 24 (Delayed) -- According to official information released today, some 1,500 villages have been destroyed by the Germans during the occupation. The figure was said to represent 23 per cent of all houses not situated in the larger towns.

After starting with gains of 2 to 5 points, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange worked up yesterday to gains of 9 to 14 points and closed near the best levels of the day, or up 8 to 12 points net.

Barr Brothers Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of $500,000 of street improvement bonds of Nashville, Tenn., on a bid of 100.279 for $104,000 as 3s and $396,000 as 1.10s, a net interest cost to the city of 1.2217 per cent. The bonds will mature from Aug. 15, 1947 to 1969.
LONDON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The tightly controlled Spanish press accused Russia today of attempting to incite rebellion in Spain and the overthrow of the regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

An air of uneasiness ran yesterday through the stock market and the over-all trend was to an irregular and lower close. Specialties had the backing of some speculative interest, but trading in the standard issues lacked zest. As a result, transfers on the Stock Exchange fell to 638,225 shares, the smallest in more than a week, against 853,820 shares on Tuesday.
ROME, Oct. 25 (UP) -- A communique.

The women's division of the Republican State committee held a "Double the Vote for Dewey" rally last night at the Commodore Hotel. A telegram from Governor Dewey, saying that the women of America would play a "dominant role" in the election, was read by Mrs. Carl H. Hogan, co-chairman of the rally.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- Governor Dewey declared tonight that "for $1,000 laid on the line to finance the fourth-term drive, this Administration boldly offers for sale 'special privilege.'" which includes the "assisting in the formulation of Administration policies."

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- The farm plank in the Republican platform offers nothing but "double talk" and Governor Dewey, rather than clarifying the issue, puts forward proposals "as vague and airy as a wisp of smoke," Senator Robert F. Wagner declared tonight as he carried his campaign for re-election into this city in the heart of the farm area.

Avowing his own desire of keeping the issue of world organization for peace nonpartisan, Senator Joseph H. Ball of Minnesota, 38-year-old Republican, who announced on Sunday that he would vote for President Roosevelt because he preferred the President's views to those of Governor Dewey on this issue, declared that the issue must of necessity be political.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- President Roosevelt exultantly announced late today the receipt of a report from Admiral William F. Halsey saying that the Japanese Navy in the Philippine area had been "defeated, seriously damaged and routed" by our forces.

MOSCOW, Oct. 25 -- Entering their ninth country in less than seven months, Red Army forces smashed across the Norwegian frontier today and liberated the Barents Sea port of Kirkenes and thirty other Norwegian villages just fifty-four months and twenty-one days after the beginning of Adolf Hitler's treacherous invasion of the Scandinavian country.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 (AP) -- An amendment to the registration of securities offerings through which the Monmouth Park Jockey Club, Oceanport, N.J., plans to build a horse-racing plant at Elkwood Park, Oceanport, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the club.

The Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences has proved so useful in providing a forum of common interest for engineers and technical men in the aviation industry that it now numbers more than 5,000 members in this country and abroad. Evidence that its program has been constructive is supplied by the fact that important donations, in money, in real property and in priceless aeronautical collections of many sorts, have steadily accrued to it
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 165:

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Those aerial-minded professional football men, who toss passes around a football field with the greatest of ease, are out to set another record and it looks as though it's going to be easy.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 25 -- Harold J. Grossman, a United States citizen, was arrested in his office here at noon Monday by Argentine police, who seized some of his papers, it was learned today. He has been held incommunicado ever since at police headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- A better supply of top grades of rationed beef and pork will be available to housewives in November, the Office of Price Administration said tonight, but there will be a slight decline in the overall meat supply.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Senator Harry S. Truman, Democratic nominee for Vice President, divided his time today between resting and working on a farm policy address that he will make in Peoria tomorrow night, after renewing a demand that Governor Dewey "repudiate" eight Republican Senators whom Mr. Truman called "isolationists."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Yale football squad ended a nine-day vacation today by driving through morning and afternoon practice sessions which opened their preparations for Saturday's meeting with the University of Rochester in the Bowl.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a liquidation plan representing a compromise of litigated claims for the bankrupt estates of the Commonwealth Light and Power Company and its subsidiary, the Inland Power and Light Corporation.
Following is the text of Governor Dewey's Chicago address, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

The reports are still incomplete. The fight may be continuing. This much is evident. A great part of the remaining Japanese fleet -- Admiral King says "practically all" of it -- has challenged our Pacific Fleet. One force has been almost wiped out. The rest has been heavily punished.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 25 -- Argentine foreign trade statistics for the first nine months of this year show the value of exported goods to have been about $436,000,000, an increase of about 15 per cent, compared with the like 1943 period, when the figures were at a very high level.

Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for the Senate, speaking at a series of Manhattan rallies last night, accused the New Deal administration of failing to have any sympathy for the small business men of the nation. The New York Secretary of State declared that this group had not received a chance to recover from the impact of the depression because of the twelve years of New Deal domination.

Although he is now the skipper of the 1,600-ton destroyer Endicott, Comdr. John D. Bulkeley made clear yesterday that his tactics for destroying enemy ships are still the same as he employed in wreaking havoc among Japanese shipping in the Philippines in the early days of the war.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Oct. 25 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur today called on patriots of the Philippines to attack the Japanese at every opportunity. He warned those outside combat areas to be patient. His message, which was broadcast over the Voice of Freedom radio, follows:

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- At his first press conference since the liberation of Paris, Gen. Charles de Gaulle today said the Allies had not armed any large unit of the French Army since they landed in France last June and that no negotiations had yet been begun concerning the political conditions of the Allied occupation of Germany, although those conditions could not be decided without France.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS ON LEYTE, Thursday, Oct. 26 -- American dismounted cavalry troops have invaded Samar, third largest of the Philippines and last island barrier on the road to Luzon and Manila, while forces fighting on Leyte have punched nine miles inland to seize the key road junction of Burauen.
Winners in the animal-naming contest at the Central Park and Prospect Park Zoos will receive silver medals on Saturday, at 2:30 P.M., at the respective zoos.

Brooklyn's football Tigers, who haven't won a league game this season and nave lost four, regard it as practically inevitable that they're going to win one and they seem to have chosen Sunday's contest with Herb Kopf's Boston Yanks as the one to break the string.
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 25 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

If proof were needed that the dominant interest of the American people in the year 1944 lies in the guarantee of a stable peace, that proof is provided by the fact that a Republican campaign which was designed from the start to play up domestic issues, and to play down foreign policy, now nears its end with the debate on foreign policy in full blast.

The Office of Price Administration moved yesterday to halt immediately a new type of rent gouging which it characterized as a growing menace to residential rent control, nourished on the current shortage of desirable apartments in New York.
LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Trade experts who, at the Government's request, devised the austerity clothing regulations are now holding meetings to plan the best way to get rid of them.

The short dinner dress found new expression in the showing of ready-to-wear fashions presented yesterday by Stein Blaine at the Hotel Pierre. A group of satins, in shades of blue, brown and purple were developed in frocks that were simple in line and free of adornment.

The Ballet Theatre last night dug out of the moth balls the grand pas de deux from Petipa's ballet, "Don Quixote," as a vehicle for Tamara Toumanova, principal guest artist of the current season at the Metropolitan Opera House. The ballet dates back originally to 1869 but has undergone so many transformations over the years that it is impossible to determine how much the present version by Anatole Oboukhoff resembles the Petipa model.

Survivors of more than 300 preliminary bouts participated in the city-wide Police Athletic League boxing championships before 3,000 spectators at the Jamaica Arena last night. Of the eighteen championships contested among youngsters from all boroughs up to 16 years of age, only three were decided by knockouts.

ABOARD ADMIRAL KINKAID'S FLAGSHIP, off the Philippines, Thursday, Oct. 26 -- The Tokyo Express rammed into the American Navy Limited today. The pride of Japan was wrecked so badly it may never make another long run. It was the day our Navy had dreamed about for considerably more than a year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Officials who have the job of maintaining civilian economy alleged today that "high levels" in the War Production Board were holding up programs for the manufacture of electrical refrigerators and washing machines, which are foremost on the board's own list of "most essential'' production.

Shortly before he went into the Army a Rochester high school boy took the part of Abraham Lincoln in a classroom play. Because of that happy chance, says a United Press story, he is now $1,900 richer. Home on furlough, he gave the right answer in one of those jackpot radio quizzes where the prize continues to pile up week after week.

BASEBALL writers at the world series were so completely fascinated by the acrobatic fielding of Slats Marion that they went overboard on the young man and gave him the most extravagant praise they could. They even mentioned him in the same breath with Hans Wagner.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 25 -- The old isolationist-internationalist argument goes on in the Middle West like a stuck whistle and is equally irritating to both sides, but it is a good bet that regardless of how the Presidential election goes a week from Tuesday the Midwest "isolationists," or "nationalists," or whatever you wish to call them, will be well represented in the United States Senate.

Although most householders use cereal with a fair degree of frequency, a nation-wide survey conducted by Elmo Roper, research consultant shows that few understand the distinction between whole grain, restored and enriched varieties.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The text of the statement of J. Howard Pew, president of the Sun Oil Company, before the Petroleum Industry War Council, today, was as follows:

Although Great Britain will be forced by circumstances to continue Empire preference agreements, "multilateral trade must come to the rescue" through increased United States purchases from Empire countries and increased British exports to such markets, Wallace B. Phillips, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in London, declared yesterday.
SALEM, N.H., Oct. 25 (AP) -- The daily double at Rockingham Park today was worth $2,301.60 for each of eleven $2 tickets.

The Imperial Japanese Fleet has been brought to battle. It is suffering a crushing defeat. Two of its divisions have been routed. One has been almost destroyed. Contact has been made with the main force southeast of Formosa by Admiral William F. Halsey's Third Fleet.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Oct. 25 (AP) -- A weak signal from a radio set on the island of Panay, heard in the late fall of 1942, set in motion machinery to aid the guerrillas, aid that culminated in a full scale invasion of the Philippines, Gen. Douglas MacArthur disclosed today.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 25 (U.P.) -- A Japanese rescue column, which crossed the West River nine miles south of Kweiping in an effort to rescue Japanese forces surrounded southwest of the village, "is still being thrown back," the Chinese High Command announced today.

ROME, Oct. 25 (U.P.) -- British forces pushing up the Athens-Salonika road, the backbone of Greece, in pursuit of fleeing German infantry and armor have entered Dhomokos, thirty miles north of Lamia, for the greatest one-day advance yet over enemy-wrecked highways, it was announced today.
LONDON, Oct. 25 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Making his first start in the East, Seven Hearts, a 4-year-old son of the Western sire, Grand Slam, yesterday ran away from the Eastern representatives in the $11,850 Scarsdale Handicap at Jamaica to win by four lengths or more.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- President Roosevelt directed the Navy today to seize and operate the plant of the Lord Manufacturing Company at Erie, Pa., which is making aircraft parts and other essential war products and employing 3,000 workers.

An increase of fifty tons over last week in the Wednesday collection of waste paper throughout the city by Department of Sanitation trucks was credited by officials last night to the growing use of small balers for loose scrap paper by housewives and apartment house superintendents.

THE brilliant leaves are going and, in bare and clean outline, we can now see the granite Bernard Shaw. The whole world has a relationship with this incomparable man, some of us since his memorable, marvelous springtime, when he burst on us over forty years ago. Even then he was no chicken, having been born in 1856, and long ago he was willing to call it a day.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 25 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz reported that the U.S.S. Princeton, a 10,000-ton carrier of the converted cruiser class, engaged in the early stages of the Philippines engagement by a strong force of enemy land-based planes, was sunk by our own forces after being irreparably damaged in the battle.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The War Production Board, moving to speed production and distribution of about 30,000,000 pieces of infants' and children's clothing between Dec. 1 and Feb. 28, 1945, today promised priorities assistance in getting fabrics to manufacturers participating in the program.

Two hundred persons representing civic, philanthropic and welfare organizations in the Bronx paid tribute yesterday at a luncheon at the Concourse Plaza Hotel to Harry Goodwin, managing editor and part owner of The Bronx Home News, who was selected as the outstanding citizen of the Bronx for 1944.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Sword of Damocles, which had hung over Purdue's Western Conference football co-champions since the opening of the season, fell today as the university Naval training unit announced the transfer of seven Boilermaker bulwarks next week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Diplomatic relations with Italy were resumed by the Allies tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Chester Bowles, OPA head, in letter to Senator Davis, Republican, of Pennsylvania today stated that the OPA could not allow extra gasoline rations for private automobiles to take voters to the polls if other means of transportation are available.

"Statistics plainly indicate that forest conservation is an important national problem," says THE TIMES editorial of Oct. 18, which analyzes information in a recent publication of the United States Forest Service titled "Some Plain Facts About the Forests."

One of the guests attending a private preview of the Navy film "Return to Guam" yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art, remarked, after the showing, "It was like seeing something for the first time." The comment came from Warrant Officer George Ray Tweed, USN, whose rescue after hiding out for thirty-one months on Guam was recently disclosed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Anglo-American petroleum agreement was attacked today by J. Howard Pew, president of the Sun Oil Company, in an address before the Petroleum Industry War Council as a "blank check" to the Federal Government, which would embroil the domestic petroleum industry in "a vicious cartel system."

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- A rush of commission-house buying lifted wheat prices as high as 1 5/8 cents a bushel today at the opening of trading on the Board of Trade, but profit-taking developed and much of the upturn was lost, although the finish showed net gains of 1/8 to 5/8 cent.

ROME, Oct. 25 (AP) -- American Fifth Army troops have captured Mount Belmonte, one of the key bastions guarding the southern approaches to Bologna, after a week of bitter fighting, the Allied High Command announced today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in Serbo-Croat by the Free Yugoslav radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- In a frank appraisal of the unfavorable strategic situation in China, an Army Air Forces spokesman acknowledged today that the Japanese are dangerously threatening three important air base areas, and that, if they are completely successful, they will seriously limit, but by no means neutralize, the effectiveness of Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault's Fourteenth Air Force.
KANDY, Ceylon, Oct. 25 (AP) -- A communique:

A four-alarm fire swept a six-story loft building at 153 Hudson Street, near Hubert Street, yesterday morning, destroying the interior of the structure, enveloping the lower West Side with a dense pall of smoke and causing the death of a fire captain.

Coach Jack Weinheimer of New York University said yesterday that he had decided not to use Jim Donovan, regular right end, for the remainder of the football season. Donovan, who suffered a slight concussion while playing basketball two years ago, missed the Boston College game last Friday night because of a headache. Earlier in the week he took practice, and seemed to suffer no ill effects.

SHAWNEE, Okla., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Governor Bricker declared today that the New Deal "scourged" the employer and precipitated "class hatreds, riots, strikes and strained relations" between capital and labor.

PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Senator Truman, Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, was told at a press conference today "there is a story going the rounds that you were a member of the Ku Klux Klan," and the nominee declared the story was a "lie" which had been "nailed" twenty-two years ago.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- A warning against excesses of the purge, since "now that the enemy is gone, half our country rises to accuse the other half," has been given in an address at the Institute de France by Jerome Tharaud, a member of the Academie Francaise.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Amid reports of a great naval victory in the far Pacific, President Roosevelt urged today the unswerving support of the Navy "until the last battle is won."
ROME, Oct. 26 (AP) -- A communique:
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in Serbo-Croat by the Free Yugoslav radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Any legislation proposing to prohibit interlocking interests, ownership or control between beer and whisky manufacturers or wholesalers should bear on future operations and not be made retroactive, according to a resolution adopted yesterday by the New York State Wholesale Beer Distributors Association at its annual meeting in the Hotel New Yorker.

NOT long ago I sat on a caterer's uncomfortable chair in the crowded living room of a New York City apartment. It was hot. The men and women gathered there were a mixture of writers, journalists, Wall Street business men and dowagers of uncertain age. Chairs squeaked occasionally; there were a few coughs. But the intent concentration and respectful reverence of the group never wavered.

Don Meade, erstwhile stormy petrel of the turf, was on the right side of a claim of foul in the Cross River Handicap yesterday at Jamaica, where he was sustained as winner aboard Hal Price Headley's Letmenow. It was only a four-horse race, and when it came to the final test in the stretch it became a duel between Letmenow and Light of Morn.

The Hoffritz Shops, operator of four stores here for the sale of cutlery and gifts for men, has purchased the five-story limestone building at 49 East Thirty-fourth Street for executive and buying offices under a plan of expansion announced yesterday.

Any day now our men of the American First Army operating near the German border in the direction of Duisburg may find themselves in possession of Amerika, as all may see for themselves on the large-scale map. It is a small Dutch place north of Venray.

The uses to which parachutes can be put in camp and sport are told by Belmore Browne, Arctic explorer and artist, who is now adviser to the United States Army Arctic rescue teams, in an interview obtained by The Associated Press. They are passed along herewith, not because the average citizen is likely to find himself the owner of a parachute, but because what Mr. Browne has to say seems interesting.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 25 (Dedayed) -- A special dispatch from Berlin the Bund of Berne today said that French civilian workers and war prisoners in Germany were becoming restive. Combined they number about 1,800,000 and the bulk of them, the report said, are clamoring to return home, where they hope to participate in the building of the new France.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- One branch of organized labor went on record today in favor of the commercialization of television and the development without delay of facilities for immediate post-war operation on a national scale.

Col. Arthur V. McDermott, city Selective Service Director, said yesterday that Rabbi Abraham Feder, formerly of Brooklyn and now a soldier of Fort Meade, Md., had been inducted into the Army "after a most careful scrutiny of the facts in the case."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 26 -- Capt. Burgess Meredith has been placed on the Army Air Forces inactive list so that he may portray Ernie Pyle in Lester Cowan's production of "G.I. Joe," to be based on the war correspondent's book, "Here Is Your War."

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 26 -- When this writer left Paris for Brussels a week ago everyone was envious because the Belgian capital had a reputation of being a place where juicy steaks abounded and hot water flowed. It was a shock to land in the city, where all restaurants were closed and billets with water at any temperature were almost unobtainable.

BOSTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- William Cardinal O'Connell expanded the $2,406,000 bequest left to him in 1923 by A. Paul Keith, Boston theatre magnate, in memory of his mother, by more than three-quarters of a million dollars in eighteen years, according to a statement filed today in Probate Court.
One of the greatest battles in naval history was apparently ending today -- Navy Day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Robert R. Young, chairman of the board of the Alleghany Corporation, criticized certain railroad practices today after a conference with Attorney General Francis Biddle which set off a series of projected conferences to formulate "a constructive solution to the problems discussed."
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Oct. 26 (AP) -- A communique:
AACHEN, Germany, Oct. 26 -- Thanks to Nazi anti-Semitism and an Aachen love affair the American Army will be able to operate the Aachen telephone system.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Characterizing Governor Dewey as "a streamlined Hoover trying to talk like another Roosevelt," Senator Robert F. Wagner warned organized labor tonight that, despite the Republican Presidential candidate's sweeping promises, the Republican party had never been labor's friend and had even been using the war in an attempt to whittle down labor's gains.

LONDON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Slicing across the Tilburg-'s Hertogenbosch highway and railroad, armored vanguards of Lieut. Gen. Sir Miles C. Dempsey's British Second Army reached the town of Udenhout, four miles north of Tilburg, as other British units slashed into the eastern outskirts of the strongly fortified town.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The crushing defeat of the Japanese fleet, combined with the satisfactorily progressing invasion of the Philippines, creates a definite crisis for Japan, but we must not make the mistake of imagining that remnants of the battered enemy fleet will not fight us again or that the end of the Pacific war is in sight, naval and military spokesmen declared here today.

Columbia's football Lions are in for some hard competition at Baker Field tomorrow when they face Andy Kerr's Colgate Red Raiders, who will be fielding their full strength for perhaps the last time this season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Department store sales for the week ended Oct. 21 were 8 per cent above sales in the like week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following table gives percentage changes from corresponding periods of 1943.

Members of the New York Security Dealers Association, at a dinner-meeting held last night at Sherry's, adopted unanimously a resolution outlawing "any effort on the part of broker-dealers to switch their customers from war bonds into any other securities as contrary to the best interests of the public and of the securities industry."
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 26 (AP) -- German terror aimed at smashing the underground was reported today to be sweeping Denmark.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 26 (AP) -- American air raids against the Kuriles, to the north of Japan, Yap in the western Carolines, Japanese holdings in the northern Marianas and in the by-passed Marshalls were reported today in a communique.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 26 -- Gen. Aaro Pajari, commander of Finnish troops on the Torneaa sector that have rolled back the Germans more than 125 miles along the Finnish-Swedish border, has been arrested as a war criminal on the demand of the Russians, it was reported reliably tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Contending that lower railroad passenger fares would stimulate non-essential traveling, the Office of Defense Transportation opposed today a proposal by Chester Bowles, director of the Office of Price Administration, that fares be cut 10 per cent.

ROME, Oct. 26 -- The appointment of Count Carlo Sforza as the Italian Government's choice for Ambassador to Washington was officially announced here today along with the statement that all republics of South America had agreed to resume diplomatic relations with Italy.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Frank J. Lewis, Chicago manufacturer and chairman of the "One Thousand Club" said tonight that the organization was "non-partisan" and had not sought and would not be entitled "to receive patronage from any political party."

ALBANY, Oct. 26 -- Governor Dewey returned to Albany this afternoon from his three-State tour of the Midwest, apparently quite heartened by the receptions he received, particularly in Chicago yesterday, and ready to carry his campaign in its closing stages to New York and New England.

With the idea of having an active contestant heading the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, Robert W. Fraser of the Manhasset Bay Club yesterday afternoon was elected president of the organization at the annual meeting which was held in the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street.

Describing the naval battle of the Philippines as "one of the pivotal actions of the war," Secretary of the Navy James V. Forrestal reported in a radio address over the Columbia Broadcasting System last night that "we estimate that two-thirds of the Japanese battleships have been sunk or damaged."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The new set-up in the Balkans and in central Europe, as gradually built by military events and endorsed by Prime Minister Winston Churchill, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and Marshal Joseph Stalin during their recent Moscow conversations, can be described as follows.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The candy habit was called a special nutrition hazard for children of school age in a revised edition of the Children's Bureau manual on that subject.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 21 were 905,941 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 7,291 cars, or 0.8 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 522 cars, or 0.1 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 2,679 cars, or 0.3 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

David B. Costuma, Republican member of the Board of Elections, asked Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine yesterday to assign a police guard to all offices of the board where voted soldier ballots are stored. At the same time Mr. Costuma accused S. Howard Cohen, Democratic president of the board, of "gross indiscretion" in handling the ballots.

AACHEN, Germany, Oct. 26 -- The ruthlessness and artificiality of Hitler's anti-Jewish policy stand out conspicuously when one talks with the inhabitants of this city who remained behind when the Nazi authorities ordered it evacuated on the eve of our invasion.

The Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House last night presented Argentinita and her three Spanish colleagues in the season's first performance of the "Dancer From Carmen" as the particular novelty of the evening. The work, which was first presented in the spring season of 1943, has undergone considerable change since then.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine stressed the importance of the Police Athletic League as a juvenile delinquency deterrent yesterday, before 250 invited guests at the routine police criminal line-up.
Geoffrey F. Morgan of the Douglas Aircraft Company punctured exaggerated post-war predictions on aircraft yesterday in a talk at the Rotary Club of New York luncheon in the Hotel Commodore.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct 26 (U.P.) -- A Chinese military spokesman today claimed a "major victory" for the defenders of the Kwangsi Province capital of Kweilin, asserting that Chinese troops had annihilated a Japanese column at Sungkiangkou, twenty-two miles to the northeast.

As a part of its investigation of the "growing" practice of selling old furniture to prospective tenants as a condition for leasing of subletting an apartment, the Office of Price Administration initiated yesterday injunction proceedings in Federal Court in Manhattan against Ted Peckham, who formerly operated an escort service here.

ROME, Oct. 26 -- About three weeks ago there was an official announcement in Munich that the Nazi "people's court" had sentenced to death and beheaded for high treason a man whose name was given simply as Alfred Steinmeier.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- With the explanation that restrictions are "no longer necessary to the war effort," the War Production Board today wrote an end to its order setting up specifications for the cutting of fabrics for certain undergarments.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Secretary Stimson made it plain at his press conference today that he intended to meet his responsibilities as charged by law in connection with the Pearl Harbor investigation, but that he was not pressing for any release of the news to the public, immediately or otherwise.

The death of the Princess Beatrice, the youngest daughter of Queen Victoria, brings back many yesterdays. There are references in the Queen's journals to this last child of her union with her "dearest Albert," born in 1857, year of the Crimean War. In 1863 Beatrice was still her mother's "precious little baby, with her golden hair and large nosegay."

Maybe the splendid Delacroix exhibition at Wildenstein's, held as a benefit for the Quaker Relief Society, started what seems to amount almost to a furore along Fifty-seventh Street. On the uptown side of the street in particular, between Lexington and Fifth, you will find gallery after gallery displaying in the sidewalk windows paintings highly romantic in flavor.
Influenced by the weakness in stocks and grains, cotton futures sold off yesterday and closed at the lowest levels of the day on the New York Cotton Exchange, for net losses of 10 to 17 points.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 26 -- The story is told here of a highly successful political forecaster who sat down with pencil and paper a few days ago to figure out how Ohio would go in the Presidential election. He pored over figures and reports for several hours.

Although excess reserves of all Federal Reserve System banks declined $100,000,000 in the week ended Oct. 25 to $800,000,000, New York City banks improved their positions, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Excess reserves in New York rose $15,000,000 to $35,000,000 despite an increase of $57,000,000 in reserve requirements.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Eastchester High's football team scored its fourth victory in four starts by crushing hitherto unbeaten and untied Scarsdale High, 32 -- 0, today. Bob Ferri, fullback, figured in all the touchdowns, garnering three himself.

To fight, win the war and to keep the peace is our objective, Commodore J.K. Richards, commander of the Reserve Officer Training Center of New York, declared yesterday at graduation exercises for the twentieth class of the Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School at Columbia University. The exercises were held at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, with 6,000 guests and midshipmen attending.

Many Thanksgiving dinner tables this year will be without the traditional turkey and cranberry sauce, according to the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, which says in its food forecast for November that military needs will take most of the supply of marketable birds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The many reports that have come out of Russia concerning widespread German atrocities in the country were supported today by W. Averell Harriman, American Ambassador to the Soviet Union, who is now here reporting on the recent Moscow conversations among ranking British, Russian and Polish officials.
James Thompson has leased for a term of years with an option to buy from Edith G. Sullivan the four-story private dwelling at 534 West 114th Street. The Houghton Company was the broker.

"Murder in the Blue Room," a Universal melodrama with music, will open this morning at the Rialto. Featured players are Anne Gwynne, Donald Cook, John Litel, Grace McDonald, Betty Kean, June Preisser, Regis Toomey and Andrew Tombes.
MOSCOW, Oct. 26 -- The Moscow newspapers today published new charges of collaboration by agents of the Polish Government in London with enemy forces.

The directors of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway called yesterday for redemption on Jan. 1, next, its transcontinental short line first mortgage 4 per cent bonds, due July 1, 1958, at 110 and accrued interest. Holders of these bonds, of which $22,545,000 are outstanding, may surrender their securities for prepayment on Dec. 1, at the call price plus full interest to Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- One of the anomalies of this anomalous Presidential campaign is the disparity between test-polls, headquarters reports and press surveys on the one hand and the betting odds on the other. To national, State and local managements of both party candidates, to directors of the polls and to the newspapers there is a steady flow of reports which add up to the forecast of a very close contest.

PEARL HARBOR (Delayed) -- The greatest sea-going fighting machine ever built for the United States Navy -- and probably for any navy -- the 45,000-ton battleship Iowa, has been inspected by newspaper observers in a series of demonstration voyages in American waters as the gigantic fighting unit enters on her shakedown and training period preparatory to joining the battle line.

Unless cotton converters are afforded some measure of relief from MPR 127, the third War Production Board project for stepping up production of infants' and children's clothing will fall far short of its objective in providing maufacturers with approximately 40,000,000 yards of the necessary fabrics, according to downtown converters yesterday.
