MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Leaders of the cotton industry closed a three-day planning conference here today without taking any specific action on a coordinated post-war program but with expression of favor for a variation of the price-adjustment plan of 1935.

The Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service, which Lillian D. Wald founded in 1893, makes its appeal for funds this year under its new name, the Visiting Nurse Service of New York. The change of name results from an expansion of service, so that the old association with a pioneer settlement house could no longer be maintained.

PARIS Oct. 26 -- Continuing its purge of the French press, the Provisional Government today suspended six news agencies, or pseudo-agencies, including the Inter-France Information and Agence Fournier. The other four specialized in economic and literary articles.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 26 (AP -- Notre Dame will lay its No. 1 national football rating on the line against Illinois before a possible record crowd of 70,000 at Memorial Stadium on Saturday.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically from Sofia and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ROME, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Eighth Army troops, smashing forward more than eight miles from hard-won bridgeheads across the Savio River west of Cesena in Italy's eastern Po Valley, have captured Forlimpopoli on the Bologna-Rimini highway, Allied headquarters announced today.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 26 -- Monroe County, which includes Rochester, the State's third city, and which President Roosevelt carried four years ago by 6,221, is likely to go this year for Governor Dewey, Republican Presidential candidate. Impartial estimates of the probable Dewey plurality range from 7,000 to 20,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Baldwin Locomotive Works reported today a net profit of $4.697.862 for the year ended on Sept. 30 after the deduction of estimated provisions for renegotiation of war contracts and taxes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- During the week ended Oct. 25 member bank reserve balances increased $126,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Additions to member bank reserves arose from an increase of $104,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit and decreases of $3,000,000 in Treasury cash and $86,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks, offset in part by increases of $59,000,000 in money in circulation and $9,000,000 in nonmember deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt urged civilians last night to "fight with heir citizenship" as the armed forces are fighting with guns, for "the American dream which lies in our hands." She spoke to 1,000 members of Local 142 of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union at its eleventh anniversary meeting in the Central High School of Needle Trades auditorium, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street.

Samson Raphaelson seems to be gloomily cynical about the tenth year of married life. Let the anniversary roll around, the champagne be opened, the daughter tucked in her little bed at the back of the house -- and all hell can break loose for an apparently happy couple.

"It's not what you spend but how you spend it," say the heads of Altman's decorating department, and to emphasize this often-heard adage, they held a press preview yesterday afternoon of five new living rooms for five budgets -- ranging from $1,000 to $5,000.

Plans should be worked out in Caracas, Venezuela, at a convention of the Bolivarian Cooperative Union on Dec. 15, whereby working agreements between Latin American and North American cooperatives will greatly expand trading and exchange of information between the various groups, representatives of the organization stated yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Norway and Russia tonight proclaimed a common cause against the Nazi invader. King Haakon, in a special broadcast to Norway, declared "the armed forces of Soviet Russia are arriving in Norway to fight against the common enemy."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Donald M. Nelson, former chairman of the War Production Board, gave unqualified endorsement tonight to Franklin D. Roosevelt as the "man with the know-how" for the biggest job in the world, the office of President of the United States.

Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for United States Senator, accused his opponent, Robert F. Wagner, last night of voting against a third term for a President in the Senate back in the Coolidge Administration and now seeking to have his New Deal sponsor, President Roosevelt, elected to a fourth term.

In September the publicity department of the National Republican Committee distributed to wireless stations throughout the country a recording to be broadcast on one-minute paid schedules which contained material of which the following is a sample:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Battle casualties of the United States armed forces total 472,779.

Denials by three prominent Roman Catholic publications that the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations was Communist-dominated were cited yesterday by the PAC as evidence of Catholic protest against "the false charge of communism" brought against the campaign organization by Republican spokesmen.

WITH THE BRITISH SECOND ARMY on Outskirts of Tilburg, Oct. 26 -- Adopting the same delaying tactics that they have been using in 's Hertogenbosch, twelve miles northeast of this point, Germans were hastily blowing up canal bridges leading to the heart of Tilburg today, withdrawing their main defense forces from this communications center and leaving behind skeleton units to try to stave off the city's inevitable capture.

A break-down of trends of the redemption of war savings bonds reveals that holders of bonds of the larger denominations now are selling them at a growing rate. At the end of July, last year, cumulative redemptions of the $25 bonds were 12.6 per cent.

Comprehensive post-war plans for the development of a great medical-dental center in the Bellevue area by the New York University College of Medicine in cooperation with the City of New York and Bellevue Hospital were announced last night at a dinner in the Hotel Roosevelt by Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of the university.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 26 -- Berlin reported today that Allied amphibious forces were swarming ashore on the Schelde Islands, last enemy strongholds dominating the ship channel to Antwerp, while Scottish troops stormed into Tilburg to the east, where the Germans were trying to pivot in a general retreat from the southern Netherlands.
The Regional War Labor Board has granted wage increases to 4,000 workers in the metropolitan area, it was announced yesterday by Thomas L. Norton, chairman.

Speaking under the auspices of the Republican National Committee, William L. Hutcheson, general president of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America, posed six questions last night, which he said labor wanted answered by the candidates for President.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 26 (U.P.) -- Bruce Trimble, member of the University of Kansas city faculty, was the man who started an investigation into charges that Senator Truman once participated in meetings of the Ku Klux Klan.

LONDON, Oct. 26 (U.P.) -- Russian Arctic forces smashed west and south through Finnmark tonight, capturing the frontier highway town of Hoyhenjaervi in a twenty-five-mile advance. Berlin reports admitted that the Germans were faced with the necessity of abandoning all northern Norway east of Narvik.

The victory of the United States fleet over the Japanese off the Philippines will add a "jubilant note to hundreds of ceremonies in observance of Navy Day, which will be held throughout the country today.

In reply to questions on foreign policy submitted to them by the Greater New York Federation of Churches, Senator Robert F. Wagner, Democrat, and Thomas J. Curran, his Republican adversary, have each listed the adoption of domestic policies to stimulate international trade as the "most essential" economic action that can be taken to reduce the danger of war in the future.
WITH FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, Oct. 26 -- No American troops took a worse lashing from the weather than did Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's forces today. And the winter months are yet to come.

A debate between Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, and Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan, over America's Town Meeting of the Air last night offered little hope for lasting world peace. Secretary Ickes was positive that its cause was doomed if Governor Dewey should be elected and Senator Ferguson was equally sure that the re-election of the President would be disastrous to the cause.

In your issue of Oct. 12, Francis Kingsley forcefully presented a view that is gaining increasing recognition -- that the way to end the German menace once and for all is not to be found in international control, de-industrialization or partition, but only in the outright annexation of a substantial area of Germany by each of her invaded neighbors, including Austria, leaving Germany a third-rate country, without manpower or industrial resources adequate for aggression.
THIONVILLE, France, Oct. 25 (Delayed) -- In this part of France one realizes sharply now difficult is the task of knocking Germany out of the war from the air.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- The continued good news from the Pacific theatre of war caused a renewed demand for rubber shares, and a shortage of stock contributed to further rises. Japanese bonds were firmer on the theory that the defeat of the Japanese fleet will bring the end of the Far Eastern war nearer.
A continuance of the demand for housing properties in Manhattan was indicated by deals reported yesterday.

The winds have been shaking little acorns out of the pin oaks, and before long the larger, fatter nuts of the other oaks will be coming down without the help of the squirrels. Mast is the old Anglo-Saxon word for this natural plenty of the oak groves; and hogs fatten and make particularly sweet ham and bacon when they feed on mast.

PEORIA, Ill., Oct 26 (AP) -- Senator Harry S. Truman, Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, called today for the re-election of Senator Lucas and reiterated his challenge to Governor Dewey to "repudiate" eight Republican Senators, referred to as "isolationists."

Subtle changes of silhouette, revealed in rounder shoulders, push-up sleeves and a fuller cut that "wrapped" easily, marked the fur showing presented yesterday by Milgrim's at the Plaza. Beaver, nutria, Persian, broadtail and mink were featured in groups that illustrated the new trends the shop endorses.

I was living in Macon, Ga., on that March day of 1933 when President Roosevelt closed the banks of our country to save them from their own self-destruction. I remember the despair and fear the weeks preceding, the increasing dread in the Southern voice, the reluctance to look and plan; the inability to buy or to pay for what had been bought, the complete collapse of confidence in one's own initiative.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Award of Nobel Prizes in medicine to four scientists now in the United States, three of them Americans, was announced tonight by the Nobel Foundation.

The stock market suffered yesterday its second serious reversal of the week, with prices reduced by fractions to as much as a point and more in a long list of standard issues. The general decline in prices in the two previous sessions which followed the sharp drop of Monday left the market without any major support, so that a resumption of mass liquidation easily moved issues into the lowest ground since mid-September.

A dispatch from London to this newspaper declares that the question of the merits or demerits of the Bretton Woods world currency stabilization agreement has been pushed aside as academic in Great Britain by the more immediate and acute currency problems that threaten the liberated countries of Europe.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Five officers of the Yonkers Local 60 of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union, AFL, were accused here today in a 129-count indictment of systematically looting the treasury of the local of more than $80,000 since 1939.

Both candidates for the State Court of Appeals, the six candidates for the State Supreme Court in the First district comprising the New York and Bronx Counties, and the candidate for Surrogate of Bronx County are qualified for office, the Bronx County Bar Association announced yesterday.

Arpad has brought something fresh and stimulating into the fashion field in New York in the few years that he has been working here -- his light and romantic touch has contributed grace and frivolity to those little things which are important.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 (AP) -- New England Public Service Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amended plan of reorganization designed to merge the company into a subsidiary, New England Industries, Inc. following distribution of securities in its portfolio to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- President Roosevelt was ready tonight to take to the hustings on a second campaign trip which calls for personal appearances in two days in five hotly contested States, commanding 95 votes in the Electoral College.

Mayor La Guardia directed License Commissioner Paul Moss and Markets Commissioner Henry Brundage yesterday to investigate reports that some dealers in second hand clothing were sending letters to the families of service men killed in action, offering to purchase their civilian clothes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Lagging war programs were stressed today by J. A. Krug, chairman of the War Production Board, but he did tell his weekly press conference that he had one "encouraging note" to report.

OFF LEYTE ISLAND, Oct. 27 -- Early yesterday morning I was aboard one of our landing barges going through San Juanico Strait to land troops on northern Leyte. Suddenly eight or ten enemy bombers swept overhead. Our Navy Hellcats and anti-aircraft fire shot down six in flames.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UP) -- Twenty-three battleships are now operating with the fleet, with at least sixteen of them in the Pacific where the Japanese imperial fleet has suffered its greatest defeat in history, the Navy disclosed tonight on the eve of Navy Day.
Roy Utley, for the past two and one-half years head of the Chryster Corporation's Tank Arsenal Training School, has been named head of the service department of the De Soto Motor Corporation.

Walter W. Van Kirk, secretary of the Commission on a Just and Durable Peace of the Federal Council of Churches, informed Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic National Chairman, yesterday that a quotation that Mr. Hannegan had attributed to John Foster Dulles, Governor Dewey's adviser on foreign relations, had never been uttered by him.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Alied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Communique 201:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 166:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Stephen T. Early, Presidential secretary, read to correspondents today the reply of Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic National Chairman, denying charges made by Governor Dewey at Chicago last night that the Roosevelt Administration was offering "special privileges" for sale through the One Thousand Club.

Some of our readers have asked us what more we think Mr. Dewey could do to make it clear, in all sections of the country, that the Republican party no longer stands for isolation. We have suggested some positive things. We can suggest some negative things also.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Liquidation by holders of corn futures induced by weakness in the cash market carried prices off 2 1/2 cents a bushel at one time on the Board of Trade today, December leading, and selling at $1.11 1/2, or 3 3/4 cents under yesterday's high mark.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- The Government's most important program, so far as the women of Britain are concerned, is the provisional housing plan designed to replace the destruction wrought by bombing during the war as well as to catch up on building, which has been at a standstill for five years.

The extent to which Anthracite Industries, Inc., through its "share-the-heat" campaign, helped to overcome the shortage of hard coal for household use by selling the public the idea of coal conservation is revealed in the latest "Advertising Facts" folder issued today by the Bureau of Advertising, A.N.P.A.

SOME thirty years ago he was one of the world's best half-milers. Now he walks slowly, chin still proudly erect, but he stares through almost sightless eyes. Homer Baker is virtually blind. He was in the neighborhood the other day and dropped in for a brief hello, as cheerful and as happy as he used to be in the distant past.

ABOARD ADMIRAL KINKAID'S FLAGSHIP, off Leyte, Oct. 26 -- The crippled remnants of the two Japanese naval forces that tried unsuccessfully to deal a death blow to the American foothold in the Philippines were fleeing westward under full steam today with our carrier planes in pursuit and inflicting additional damage.

Although the Bethlehem Steel Corporation has filled more than one-third of the shipbuilding orders that were on its books at the start of the year its steel division currently is operating at 103 per cent of theoretical capacity, comparing with 102.4 per cent during the third quarter of this year and 101.6 per cent in the third quarter of 1943, according to Eugene G. Grace, president.

ROME, Oct. 26 (U.P.) -- Greek patriot forces cooperating with British troops rushing northward from Athens have occupied Larissa, onetime site of a German air base seventy airline miles southwest of Salonika, it was announced today, and front reports said weary German infantrymen were fighting their own marine and air units for trucks to speed their retreat into upper Greece.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 26 -- By unanimous action the Lafayette College Institute pledged its support today to the Department of State in whatever action may be necessary to put this country in a United Nations organization as proposed at Dumbarton Oaks.

Two corporations and eight individuals were indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges of conspiracy and the submission of false statements to the Army Quartermaster Corps in connection with the renegotiation of 1942 contracts for the manufacture of clothing for soldiers.

Sponsored by the War Department, a tour of four of Long Island's principal factories producing aviation materiel revealed yesterday that the area's war job would still take a great deal of doing and that it could not be done without thousands of additional employes.

The banking group headed by the Chase National Bank received yesterday the award of $7,600,000 of City of Miami, Fla., refunding bonds, due July 1, 1965, on a bid of par for a combination of interest rates which represented a net interest cost to the city of 2.352 per cent.

Within the week word has come of the deaths of two more American correspondents on war fronts. Asahel Bush fell on the island of Leyte while covering the occupation of Tacloban for The Associated Press. In France David Lardner, son of the late Ring Lardner and brother of James Lardner, a former reporter who died fighting for the Spanish Republicans, was killed while reporting for The New Yorker.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

A Japanese broadcast recorded by The United Press yesterday, commenting on the battle of Leyte Gulf, said it was not possible to reveal what further measures would be taken by the Japanese fleet, but "one thing is now clear: America has lost the war."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Senator Joseph H. Ball, Minnesota Republican, who is supporting President Roosevelt, asserted tonight that Governor Dewey had failed to submit to the electorate "a workable, constructive program on the domestic issues of taxation and labor relations" and had straddled the important issues in foreign policy.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Max Wexler's British Buddy, away from the winner's circle since last August, was the medium of a last-minute betting plunge and then ran off with the Seabiscuit Purse at Laurel Park today.

College athletic directors who are wondering how far they should go in making coaching and schedule commitments for the post-war period can take a lot of encouragement from the attendance figures for the current football season.
PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 26 -- Japan's Navy was so decisively beaten in the two-day Battle of the Philippines it no longer figures as a major factor to be reckoned with in immediate American war plans.

Though New York City has not as yet got into its full winter stride, summer blossomed in cottons and rayon crepes on the stage of New York Times Hall this week, during the daily performances of Fashions of the Times, third edition.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 -- The American and Foreign Power Company, a subsidiary of the Electric Bond and Share Company, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan of recapitalization which proposes that in place of the present capitalization of serial notes, debentures, preferred, second preferred and common stock and option warrants to buy common stock, there will be substituted $119,281,200 of 5 per cent debentures and 2,500,000 shares of common stock.

Your editorial "Export Subsidy Results" would have been a complete exposition of the case to the American public if you had also stressed the inconsistency in our national philosophy about the treatment of subsidies in foreign trade.

Wesley F. Wood of 2 Washington Street, Harrison, N.J., pleaded guilty yesterday at his General Sessions trial in the theft of about $60,000 from Local 50 of the Bakers International Union, of which he was Secretary-treasurer until it was absorbed by the teamsters' union last July.

The actual situation in the shoe industry may not be as acute as certain statistical facts taken alone seem to indicate, L.E. Langston, executive vice president, National Shoe Retailers Association, declared yesterday in discussing the recent joint release by the Office of Price Administration and the War Production Board on shoe inventories, and the statement by J.A. Krug, WPB chairman, that leather controls will be continued after V-E day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Secretary Hull paid high tribute today to President Roosevelt as a "farsighted" leader who, in the hour of world crisis with the fall of France in 1940, had "courageously charted a wise course for this nation."

An atmosphere typical of any house in the throes of redecoration, including the heavy smell of fresh paint, greeted Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt yesterday morning when she arrived on the fifth floor of Gimbel's to be guest of honor at the third session of the homemaking show sponsored by the Consumers Service Division of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office of Greater New York.
Like the elephants some of them are in size, the Giants (New York Football Giants, that is) never forget apparently.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- A study of the eating habits of 3,371 families scattered throughout the United States indicates that the average American is not the well-fed person he is generally supposed to be, Dr. Robert S. Harris, assistant professor of nutritional biochemistry at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said today in an address on "A Study of Nutritional Quality of Dietaries by Chemical Analysis" before the annual meeting of the American Dietetic Association.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 26 -- With their usual speed and efficiency, the Germans are creating a hard crust for their western front, a crust that will be difficult to break under the trying conditions of fall and winter warfare.

Some seventy tailoring houses have expressed approval of a recommendation of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the United States of America that such organizations continue to use the 40-square inch sample swatch even though Government curbs are lifted, the producers group reported yesterday.

The Philharmonic-Symphony concert of last night in Carnegie Hall, conducted by Dr. Rodzinski, and full of toothsome details, was prevailingly French, so unmistakably that no political recognition was necessary to prove it. This program advanced as perhaps its most delightful item the juvenile C major symphony of one Georges Bizet.

Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday that the representative of this country on the world council should be given full power to act in enforcing the peace, and said that he was prepared to have our own actions in the international field judged by that body.
LONDON, Oct. 26 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berin and recorded by The United Press:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Sidney Hillman said tonight that the Republican party, "with reckless disregard of the need to concentrate all our thought and energy on the task of victory, has waged a campaign to persuade the American people to write off the war as something over and done with."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Possible withdrawal of American Federation of Labor members from the National War Labor Board was reported today if case discussions involving the "Little Steel" formula proceeded in a manner deemed prejudicial to the federation's interest.

LONDON, Friday, Oct. 27 -- Red Army mountain troops captured the big East Czechoslovak road hub of Mukacevo yesterday and linked up with other Soviet forces cutting across the northeastern corner of Hungary from conquered Transylvania in an offensive that has swept up nearly 18,000 prisoners in a week and overrun two-thirds of Hungarian-annexed Ruthenia.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- The moderate newspaper Aurore, which has not joined in the bitter comments in the press on the American policy toward France, today protested sharply against statements by President Roosevelt and Acting Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr. that France would not immediately take part in Allied discussions of world security.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of commodity prices at the primary market level for the week ended Oct. 21 remained unchanged from the preceding week at 103.8 per cent of the 1926 average. In the past four weeks the all-commodity index has shown little net change.
Manager Mel Ott of the Giants came to town yesterday and immedaitely was fired upon by numerous baseball scribes with a barrage of questions about "next year."

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Governor Dewey will call the Legislature into extraordinary session, probably on Monday, to extend by two hours the time during which citizens in New York City may go to the polls on Election Day, Nov. 7, from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M., instead of 6 A.M. to 7 P.M., it was learned at the capital from an authoritative source tonight.
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 26 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Calling its quest for rooms "our most urgent problem," the Young Women's Christian Association of New York appealed yesterday to families who have never before taken lodgers to help in housing the "endless procession" of young women now coming to the city.
A communique, as broadcast domestically from Tokyo yesterday and recorded and translated by the Federal Communications Commission:

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Banking since 1932 has tended toward "service for the many rather than the few," Lewis F. Gordon, retiring president of the Financial Advertisers Association and vice president of the Citizens and Southern National Bank, Atlanta, Ga., said tonight in an address to the association.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- The United States Eighth Air Force and the Royal Air Force delivered another one-two punch at German industrial and communications targets today. The Americans struck factories and railways at Bielefeld, Muenster, Hanover and the northern Ruhr and one bomber and one fighter were lost from a force of more than 1,200 heavy bombers and 650 escorting fighters.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Friday, Oct. 27 -- Fifteen more communities on Leyte Island have been freed by advancing American forces, who now control a forty-mile sector along the coast and are pushing inland despite increased resistance, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

Merger of three investment companies with aggregate assets of $32,000,000 was announced yesterday by Andrew J. Lord, president of Lord, Abbett Co., Inc. The new company will be called American Business Shares, Inc. This company now has assets of $5,000,000; the Maryland Fund, Inc., has $6,000,000 and Quarterly Income Shares has $21,000,000.

Issues of the Presidential campaign were debated yesterday before the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs in a program that broke a long standing tradition of barring political discussions. More than 700 delegates to the group's convention at the Hotel Astor, asked to make "no outburst or display of personal feeling," showed keen interest in the innovation, although Mrs. Andrew Noe, chairman, revealed that some letters to her had described the departure as "dynamite."

LONDON, Oct. 27 (U.P.) -- Two swiftly advancing Finnish columns threatened tonight the next to the last highway escape route for German troops fleeing Lapland, and Berlin, officially admitting the loss of Petsamo and Kirkenes, claimed twelve Russian infantry divisions supported by tanks and planes were attacking on the Arctic front.

Twenty-five per cent of the retailers of women's and girls' outerwear in this area may be prohibited from making any sales after Nov. 15, Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, warned yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 27 -- Adolf A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, declared in a speech here tonight that this was no time for a change from the Roosevelt administration to an administration by a party that was still dominated by isolationists and had nothing constructive to offer in foreign or domestic affairs.

Another pre-war French film will have its first local showing today. The picture is "Three Hours" and has as its principals Jean Pierre Aumont and Corinne Luchaire. It will be shown at the Forty-eighth Street Cinema.

More than 6,000 war ballots of questionable validity are among the 218,954 returned to the Board of Elections in New York City, it was disclosed yesterday. In most instances officials hope to be able to remove the doubt before election day and are making special efforts to do so.

WITH BRITISH SECOND ARMY in Tilburg, Oct. 27 -- Amid the joyful cheers of the populace British troops walked into Tilburg without much opposition today and immediately began the work of mopping up small pockets of resistance.

Max Rosen gave his first violin recital in several years last night at Carnegie Hall. Although his performances aroused pronounced enthusiasm, they failed to equal those of his younger days when he first captured the attention of the public. This decline is a natural one in Mr. Rosen's case, since no artist, however gifted, can appear before audiences as seldom as he has of late and keep his work at top form.

Failure to include popular-price lines in the third War Production Board program for infants' and children's clothing makes it wholly ineffective in alleviating shortages, Aaron L. Solomon, executive director of the Infant and Juvenile Manufacturers Association, Inc., stated yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 27 -- The Allied High Command will give 4,000 tons of food to Belgium in the first three weeks of November, it was announced tonight by Maj. Gen. G.W.E.Y. Erskine, head of the Supreme Headquarters, Allied Expeditionary Force, mission to Belgium, in a radio address to the Belgian people.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Oct. 27 -- Col. David E. Cain, commanding officer of Camp Upton, accompanied by Capt. Arthur F. Wolf, placed a laurel wreath today at the iron paling that surrounds the grave of President Theodore Roosevelt as a memento of esteem from President Franklin D. Roosevelt on the birthday of his distant cousin.

ABOARD ADMIRAL KINKAID'S FLAGSHIP, Oct. 26 -- Battered remnants of a big part of the Japanese fleet are being attacked and harassed by carrier planes in their retreat to safer bases. Our planes are picking off the cripples.
ROME, Oct. 27 (UP) -- A communiqe:

Mel Rosch of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association shook his head sadly yesterday over the five-and-a-half-day pheasant season that closed last Saturday, saying it was one of the poorest Westchester County had ever experienced.

ALBANY, Oct. 27 -- Acceding to Democratic requests, Governor Dewey issued a call late this afternoon for the Legislature to be convened in extraordinary session on Monday at noon to enact legislation extending the voting hours on Election Day, Nov. 7, and to increase the compensation of clerks and other election officials.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- Russell V. Davenport, adviser to Wendell Willkie in the 1940 Republican Presidential campaign, questioned tonight the credibility of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's declarations in favor of international machinery to enforce peace in a speech before the Rockland County Women for Roosevelt here.
The Polo Grounds, Franklin Field in Philadelphia and Memorial Stadium at Champaign, Ill., are the focal points in college football's heavy program today.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 27 -- Warning of the dangers of a "super state" in this country, Eric A. Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, predicted here tonight that a giant conflict would take place in the world after the war between collectivism and individualism, and between autocracy and democracy.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Communique 202:

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 27 (AP) -- One horse was killed and three jockeys were injured during the running of the steeplechase at Laurel Park today. James Penrod sustained a broken collar-bone and sprained thumb, S. Landes suffered a broken nose and A. Walsh a sprained back.

Aside from apples, one of the best fruit purchases in the present market is grapes. Since the ceiling was lifted from table varieties, dealers have been receiving larger shipments, and a choice of several delicious kinds will be offered from now until after Christmas.

With operations of the oil industry at a record level in the third quarter of the year, the reports of companies so far issued show that net income, despite high taxes and increased operating costs, is running ahead of that of last year. The gain is greater in those companies engaged in large refining operations.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Disturbed by the presence in south France of some 14,000 Spaniards who have fought with the French Forces of the Interior and perhaps three times that number of Spanish Republicans who are refugees there, the French Government is about to devise a special measure for these aliens on the lines of the League of Nations statute for political refugees, it was said in informed circles here today.

Cooperation of twenty Protestant denominations, several Roman Catholic Bishops, the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, the Synagogue Council of America and the Catholic Commission on American Citizenship, was received last year on behalf of tolerance and good-will by the National Conference of Christians and Jews, according to The Religious News Service.

DETROIT, Oct. 27 -- Vice President Wallace told a capacity audience tonight that he believed that the American people under Mr. Roosevelt would make new laws to provide that no healthy American wishing to work should ever again be denied the right to work.

CHUNGKING, China Oct. 27 (AP) -- Japanese troops, sweeping southward from their base at Kiyang, have advanced sixty miles in eight days and captured the Hunan communications center of Ningyuan, 110 miles east of the Kwangsi province capital of Kweilin, the Chinese High Command announced today.

Today's events: PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Grace Castagnetta, piano, Town Hall, 3; Maria WiklerFialko, soprano, and Leopold Terapulsky, 'cello, in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; Joseph Rogatchewsky, tenor, assisted by Valentin Pavlovsky, piano, Town Hall, 8:30; Roth Quartet, Washington Irving High School, 8:30; Juilliard Graduate School Orchestra, Juilliard Concert Hall, 8:15.

New financing continued heavy in the local market here this week, but flotations, though large, fell below the record of the week before. A total of $221,550,000 in five bond issues was offered to the public, $100,000,000 in one industrial loan, $120,950,000 for two public utility companies, and $600,000 for two municipalities.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- Charles E. Johnston, chairman of the Western Association of Railway Executives, announced today that the Western railways "are not negotiating a settlement of the anti-trust suit filed against them by the Department of Justice at Lincoln, Neb," and added that they had not been asked to discuss the case.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- Charging that the Republican party had always supported special privileges, Senator Robert F. Wagner said tonight that neither lasting prosperity nor enduring peace could be attained "upon the narrow foundation of a privileged few."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 27 -- RKO has signed Carol Thurston, the Three Martini of "The Story of Dr. Wassell," for featured roles in two pictures a year. The deal was made through Cecil B. DeMille, to whom the actress has been under exclusive contract.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Lewis C. Daniel of New York received the $200 Philadelphia Water-Color Prize for his tempera painting, "Brethren," the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts announced today. Six other awards were made for the forty-second annual exhibition of water-colors and prints and the exhibition of miniatures on view from Oct. 29 to Dec. 3.

AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Senator Truman asserted here tonight that Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for President, should be compelled "to tell the American people whether he wants a Senate composed of isolationists like Robert Taft and Gerald Nye and the six other isolationists" he said were running on Dewey's ticket.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- W.L. Clayton, Surplus War Property Administrator, today advocated some reduction of American tariffs to stimulate world trade after the war and get into the hands of war damaged countries dollars to purchase American goods.

Plans for an enlarged mid-Manhattan underpass, to cost $75,200,000 and to incorporate a huge underground terminal for buses, taxicabs and other motor vehicles, were announced yesterday by Borough President Edgar J. Nathan Jr. of Manhattan and Alfred B. Jones, chairman of the New York City Tunnel Authority.

It is announced that William H. Davis, who is chairman of the President's Cost of Living Committee as well as of the National War Labor Board, will submit on Monday to his four labor and industry associates his draft of a proposed report to the President on the cost of living.

A printed, eighty-eight-page answer to a Government anti-trust suit instituted here last May was filed in Federal Court yesterday by the Diamond Match Company, William A. Fairburn, its president, and Howard F. Holman, a vice president.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 27 -- This city, which has not elected a Democratic official in more than a quarter of a century, got a political shock today when the results of a student-faculty Presidential poll at the East Orange High School were announced.

Exactly how good is Army? A question football followers have been asking ever since the start of the college season will be answered today when the cadets come to grips with Duke's Blue Devils at the Polo Grounds, 2 o'clock being kick-off time, with the cadet corps scheduled to make its entrance -- always a spectacle in itself -- at 1:10.

TOLEDO, Oct 27 (AP) -- Members of the Mechanics Educational Society of America began a walkout of eleven manufacturing plants today and a union official said that members in Detroit and Cleveland probably would follow soon.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Calling upon the Japanese to surrender now unconditionally, Joseph C. Grew, who was Ambassador to Japan from 1932 to 1941, warned the American people tonight that with the Japanese fleet defeated in a major battle "an enticing peace offer might come from Japan at any time."

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- The grain markets were unsettled today on the Board of Trade. They advanced moderately early, only to break sharply and develop liquidation, but a strong rally came later with wheat in the lead. Closing trades on wheat futures were to 5/8 cent a bushel higher for the day after having shown losses of 1/2 cent at one time.

Holders of Toledo Edison Company 3 1/2 per cent debentures, due April 1, 1960, have been notified that redemption of $181,000 of these bonds at 101 3/4 will be made through the sinking fund on Dec. 1, 1944. Payment will be made at the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

Thirty-five hundred Waves in training at the "U.S.S. Hunter" were reviewed by Vice Admiral Adolphus Andrews, retired, former commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier, in special Navy Day celebrations held at 3 P.M. yesterday at the Women's Reserve Naval Training School at the Hunter College in the Bronx.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Arthur R. Upgren, vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, said today that banks and financial institutions should show precise ways in which they have given and can give financial assistance in creating jobs.

Irked by the general comment that his team is primarily a defensive organization, a combination of football "hitless wonders," Coach Steve Owen of the New York Giants laid emphasis on the attack as he sent his charges through their regular drill at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

A low-grade comedy-mystery, filled with apparitions, secret doors and screams -- and featured by a trio of singers who IMITATE the Andrews Sisters (fancy that!) -- is Universal's "Mystery in the Blue Room," which came to the Rialto yesterday. Let those of high taste in mystery matters -- and in comedy -- heed those temperate words.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Speaking tonight at a Communist meeting for the Paris region, Jacques Duclos, secretary of the party, said that Maurice Thorez, Communist leader frowned upon by Gen. Charles de Gaulle and now in Moscow, would soon be in Paris.
The New York Stock Exchange membership of Harry MacDonald has been transferred to Alan M. Mayer.

ATLANTA, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Georgia Tech repulsed a heavier Georgia Naval Pre-Flight eleven tonight for most of three quarters, and then drove 86 yards to score and win, 13 -- 7, remaining undefeated in five games.
Mr. Robey's letter, published Oct. 21, and your comments thereon point to two fundamental problems: 1. Methods of tariff reduction. 2. Objectives.

Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter directed Col. Maurice Simmons, Police Department property clerk, yesterday to turn over to the United States Government the $27,200 that Frank Costello, slot machine operator and gambler, had left in a taxicab on June 14.

Over-assessments and over-valuation of real estate in some sections of Manhattan particularly are retarding real estate activity and preventing the proper development of much land here, Homer Hoyt, director of economic studies of the Regional Plan Association, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Municipal Forum at Oscar's Old Delmonico.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, France, Oct. 27 -- The British Second Army captured the big Netherland strongholds of Tilburg and 's Hertogenbosch today and raced for the mouth of the Meuse (Maas) in two converging columns to close a corral around the greatest number of Germans to be hemmed in since the Normandy break-through.

Fourteen awards were made yesterday by the Allied Artists of America at their thirty-first annual exhibition, which will be opened to the public tomorrow, following an invitation preview this afternoon, at the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Domestic newspaper publishers will have all 8 per cent cut in their November newsprint orders on Canadian mills, the War Production Board said today, because orders placed with the mills exceed the 200,000 tons a month pledged by Canada.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 27 -- Developments in rubber, gasoline and metallurgy claimed primary interest among the 541 inventions listed as patented this week in the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.
Columbia's revamped line and backfield will be tested in a major game today when the Lions face Colgate at 3 P. M. at the Baker Field gridiron.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- With the call for a special session of the State Legislature for an extension of voting hours on election day out of the way, Governor Dewey resumes tomorrow his campaign for the Presidency with a major address in Syracuse on agricultural problems.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 27 (AP) -- A roaring Alabama Crimson Tide found Kentucky's pass defense weak tonight and thoroughly trounced the Wildcats, 41 to 0. Coach Frank Thomas used his first-string very little after half time.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, France, Oct. 27 -- The Anglo-Canadian offensive to open Antwerp to the Allies' supply ships is progressing with a new rapidity as the result of a British landing on the southeastern coast of Zuid Beveland and continued advances by infantry across the neck of land leading toward the main German defenses at Flushing and along the flat country west of Breskens on the south side of the Schelde estuary.

Eight men, all in their 80s, met yesterday afternoon in a private dining room at the Amherst Club, 31 East Thirty-ninth Street, to keep a pledge made sixty years ago when they were graduated from the college that they would come together at least once every year until only one member of the 101 in the class of '84 were alive.

DENVER Oct. 27 -- James Marshall, member of the New York Board of Education, said here today that it was more important "to create an international office of education than to create an international police force -- more important, too, than an international court."

The nation will look in the postwar period to voluntary hospitals for leadership in bringing to all the facilities for prevention of disease, cure of ills and the maintenance of general health and physical and mental welfare, Roy E. Larsen, president of the United Hospital Fund of New York, said yesterday afternoon in a radio broadcast over station WABC.
PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 27 -- The United States Fleet now rules the Pacific right up to the China Seas and within range of Tokyo itself.

Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, told an audience last night on the lower East Side that he stood unequivocally behind the Republican National Convention's platform to give refuge to millions of distressed Jewish people in Palestine with unrestricted immigration and land ownership.

BOSTON, Oct. 27 -- Declaring that he would not take a chance on changing leadership in the midst of wars, Mayor La Guardia of New York told a Roosevelt rally tonight that the President already has won one war, would win the present one and then had two more to wage.

A conflict of world-wide scope made it necessary to postpone awards which had been made for forty years, in accordance with the terms of Alfred Nobel's will. Now comes the good news that prizes in medicine for 1943 and 1944 go to four distinguished research scientists in this country and that three of these are Americans.

The fifteen-story Hotel Knickerbocker at 120 West Forty-fifth Street, east of Broadway, has been sold by the Prudence Bonds Corporation to Samuel Rosen, owner and operator of the Hotel Bretton Hall. The Knickerbocker, which was built in 1925, contains stores and 381 rooms and occupies a plot 95 by 100 feet.

NINTH USAAF ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, Oct. 27 -- For what is believed to be the first time in this war fighter bombers, guided by ground controllers at the front lines yesterday, dropped 500-pound bombs on Saarbruecken, Germany through solid overcast accurately on the unseen targets.

Modern design, light woods, and pastel fabrics will be among the furniture orders of the future, according to a survey of furniture manufacturers, dealers, and department stores made by La France Industries, weavers of upholstery fabrics, to find out what kind of furniture will be lifted over the welcome mats of post-war homes.

As food retailers warned yesterday that the city's supply of turkeys would be "insignificant -- not even 10 per cent of normal" for Thanksgiving, Patsy D'Agostino, operator of three food stores and former president of the New York State Food Merchants Association, said the "best bet" was to plan on roasting chickens, fryers or broilers for Thanksgiving dinner."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The commission on educational reconstruction of the American Federation of Teachers, meeting here Wednesday night, drew up a resolution to President Roosevelt recommending "whatever measures may be necessary to the national defense," but opposing any "hasty and ill-considered action at this time" in the adoption of a program of universal military training.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- American establishment of formal diplomatic relations with Italy was in recognition of the loyal cooperation of the Italian people and armed forces during the past year, in recognition of the founding of a healthy Government in Rome, and was a move designed to facilitate a return to peace, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Acting Secretary of State, said today.

LEYTE, Philippines, Oct. 26 (Delayed) -- Guerrillas have inflicted more than 1,000 casualties on the Japanese on this island in the last two years. This report came from Illiff David Richardson, 26 years old, of Maywood, Calif., who has been chief of staff for the guerrillas since he became separated from Comdr. John Bulkeley's famed Motor Torpedo Boat Squadron 3 "Expendables."

The Prime Minister who addressed the House of Commons yesterday is by some standards an elderly person. He is, in fact, more than seven years older than President Roosevelt. Nevertheless, people laughed with him, not at him, when he described himself as "traveling from court to court like a wandering minstrel," and there was vigor of language, of thought and of personality in what he had to say.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons today that he hoped to meet with President Roosevelt and Premier Stalin this year to prepare the way for settlement of issues discussed by him and the Soviet Premier in Moscow.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- The approaching winter is causing some anxiety to Francois Billoux, Minister of Health in the Provisional Government. Should it prove severe many problems would be complicated. The general lack of fuel, gaping roofs and paneless windows are not calculated to improve the condition of thousands of men, women and children already reported to be physically deficient.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 27 -- The Argentine Government has applied to the governing board of the Pan American Union asking it to call a meeting of Foreign Ministers of all American States at the earliest possible date to consider the so-called Argentine problem.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The United Nations Service Center, that unique hotel close to Union Station where service men may even check their babies, was one year old today, and soon will receive the millionth guest in uniform.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- This country should not expect its Allies to pay off lend-lease obligations Dean Calvin Hoover of Duke University's Graduate School of Arts and Science, told a House committee today.

Assuming that there is a high level of employment and production throughout the world following the war the United States should be able to grant $2,000,000,000 in credit annually; export $10,000,000,000 worth of goods each year and import products valued at $8,000,000,000, Edward M. Bernstein, assistant director, division of monetary research, Treasury Department, declared yesterday.

ROME, Oct. 27 -- Pope Pius, in a pontifical letter to Francesco Cardinal Marchetti Selvaggiani, vicar of Rome, today calls for "public prayers of penitence and special mission exercises," because of the "moral ruination" that has befallen his vicarate of Rome.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Saturday, Oct. 28 (U.P.) -- By making giant strides at both the north and south ends of the Leyte invasion front, the American hold on the Leyte coast was extended to sixty-four miles.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- The all-Chicago reception committee had completed tonight plans for President Roosevelt's address here tomorrow night. It will be the first major speech he has delivered in Chicago since 1987, and will he given at Soldier Field, where he probably will be greeted by one of the largest crowds ever gathered in this State to hear a political address.

MONTREAL, Oct. 27 -- The immediate creation of an effective international air authority through the medium of a permanent international air convention has been unanimously called for by the British Commonwealth conference that has been meeting here in preparation for the Chicago international conference.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- President Roosevelt, issuing his 1944 Armistice Day proclamation, called upon the people of the United States to rededicate themselves to the tasks of winning this war and establishing an enduring peace.

Promising no mercy to anybody -- social worker, judge, or neglectful parent -- who mistreats the children of New York City, Mayor La Guardia yesterday declared that he will clean up the present confused and inadequate child welfare program, even if it involves the abolition of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, reformation of city courts and social agencies, and enactment of new amendments in the State Legislature.

ABOARD ADMIRAL KINKAID'S FLAGSHIP, off Leyte, Oct. 27 -- Rear Admiral Jesse Barret Oldendorf, reviewing his victory over the Japanese Fleet in Surigao Strait, said today he believed three enemy battleships, five cruisers and six to eight destroyers had come within range of his guns and "I couldn't find any evidence that a single one got away."

LONDON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels, German Propaganda Minister, in a broadcast to the German nation tonight declared the Germans will "go on fighting until a peace is possible that guarantees our people's right to live, their national independence and the expansion of the basis of their existence."

John Southwell, an executive in a large advertising company, announces his intention of entering the circle of Broadway theatrical producers. For that purpose Mr. Southwell has just purchased a play by Emery Rubio and Miriam Ball entitled "The First Stone."

TRENTON, Oct. 27 -- New Jersey inductions and enlistments in the armed services between Oct. 16, 1940, the date of the first registration, and last Sept. 1, totaled 455,526, or 10.95 per cent of the State's 1940 population and about 4 per cent of the total of 11,417,000 in the military services, it was reported today by State Selective Service Director Edgar N. Bloomer, who estimated that 430,526 were still in service.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Saturday, Oct. 28 -- American troops aided by Philippine guerrillas have overrun and virtually completed the occupation of Samar, third largest island in the Philippines, lying south of Luzon, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today.

Quiet satisfaction with this week's reduction of the Japanese fleet off the Philippines, coupled with solemn warning against counting the war nearly won, marked last night's speeches at the Navy Day dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LONDON, Saturday, Oct. 28 -- A powerful Russian mountain army virtually completed the conquest of Hungarian-annexed Ruthenia in eastern Czechoslovakia yesterday by capturing Uzhorod in a fifteen-mile advance. Another Red Army column penetrated six miles into neighboring Slovakia.

The stock market turned steadier yesterday after its sharp retreats of previous sessions and even moved irregularly higher in the afternoon when buyers appeared. The moderate recovery was spotty, however, as the best gains were in special situations where some advances ranged to a point and more, although the average increase remained in a fractional range.

Thirty paintings by children from all parts of the country were judged carefully yesterday by about sixty youngsters who are patients at Bellevue Hospital. An imaginative version of the shoe in which the old woman's children lived and colorful designs in finger paint seemed to be the favorites of pupils at the hour-long art appreciation class sponsored in a hospital meeting room by the Women's National Institute.

The Office of Price Administration yesterday announced that it would hold a public meeting on Monday night in Albert Leonard High School, New Rochelle, to explain to landlords and tenants the housing rent regulations which go into effect in Westchester County on Nov. 1.

The most maligned tree of all time is the Ailanthus, or Tree of Heaven, due in part to the odor exhaled by the flowers of the male tree. If, however, we consider its way of life and study its attributes, we find only praise for it.

Three Japanese ships identified as fleeing from the disaster in the Philippines were attacked off Hong Kong by bombers from General Chennault's Chinese-based air force. A transport was sunk. A freighter and an oil tanker were left damaged. The communique didn't say how many planes took part.

A cablegram from the Philippines, telling how blood plasma was administered to and saved the lives of scores of wounded on the Philippine beachheads, was received yesterday at the Brooklyn Chapter of the American Red Cross, 57 Willoughby Street.

The official day may be Tuesday, but forty-six youngsters proved conclusively yesterday that Halloween can be celebrated at any time. The festivities took place at the James Center of the Children's Aid Society at Hester and Elizabeth Streets.

Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. and Joseph E. Davies, former United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, declared last night in speeches urging the re-election of President Roosevelt that his record at home and in foreign affairs had proved him the best possible servant of American business as well as other groups for the momentous days that lie ahead.

Registration in religious schools in this city had increased since February, 1941, by 100,000 among Roman Catholics, Protestants and Jews, the Rev. Dr. Walter M. Howlett, secretary of the Greater New York Interfaith Committee, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Mayor La Guardia and Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd will be members of the delegation, headed by Adolf A. Berle Jr., assistant Secretary of State, which will represent this country at the International Civil Aviation Conference in Chicago beginning Wednesday which will deal with post-war problems.
LEYTE, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Illiff D. Richardson missed the last plane to Australia by three days. After joining the guerrillas the former naval ensign became a major on Leyte.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- Only 15 per cent of the vitamins bought by the public do any good and the remaining 85 per cent is "an utter waste," according to Dr. Edward L. Tuhoy, chief of medicine of the Duluth clinic who addressed the final session of the American Dietetic Association's annual meeting today.

Greece has suffered approximately 83,000 battle casualties, Nicholas G. Lely, Minister in charge of Greek Government Information Services in the United States, disclosed yesterday in a statement marking the fourth anniversary of the Italian invasion of Greece.

After he had been unemployed and without a cent two days ago, good fortune smiled all at once yesterday on 38-year-old Harry Kerfott He found himself with a $100 bill in his pocket and above all a job.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 27 -- A tip that gold coins were circulating among the inhabitants of Jericho in eastern Palestine led the Palestine police early this month to pick up a trail that resulted in the capture of three German air officers -- one of whom was believed to be of Palestinian-Arab origin -- who parachuted into the wilderness lying west of the Jordan Valley to carry out a sabotage mission in Palestine.

New York University and City College, neither of which has been able to chalk up a victory in three football contests, clash on Ohio Field in the Bronx today, with kick-off time set for 2:30 P.M. Both teams concluded practice with light workouts yesterday.

ROME, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The British Eighth Army bumped against the main German defenses on the Ronco River two miles east of Forli today after a two and a half-mile advance up the Rimini-Bologna highway in northern Italy.
MONTREAL, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The National Hockey League opens its sixth wartime season tomorrow night at just about the point where it left off last spring.

Norway is fighting once more on her own soil. Her Government has proclaimed with Russia, whose Arctic forces are pursuing the enemy, a common cause against the German invader. King Haakon VII, in a special broadcast to his native land, declared: "Norwegian forces will take part in the operations together with the Soviet Russian troops and will thus once more be fighting on Norwegian soil."

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed increase in holdings of United States Government securities and note circulation for the system as a whole to be $174,364,000 and $70,112,000, respectively, while gold holdings decreased $8,500,000.

With early Christmas shopping a factor, retail trade here continued active this week. Gains varied considerably between stores, however, ranging from under 10 to about 20 per cent over the like week of last year.

In line with its wartime policy; of holding its annual meetings in New York, where most of its members are located and others have to come on other business, the Association of National Advertisers will meet Nov. 15, 16 and 17 at the Biltmore Hotel, it was announced yesterday by Paul B. West, president of the association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- In the second of its general summaries of the progress of reconversion under the "Spot Authorization" procedure the War Production Board reported today that 1,278 applications had been approved through Oct. 24, for a total valuation of $202,691,000 for the last quarter of this year and all of 1945.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- A new crop of "larger and better quality" wartime houses, built under higher price and rental ceilings and without restrictions on occupancy, will start coming on the market early next summer, housing officials predicted tonight.

Forty years ago this week the first successful flight of a dirigible airship in this country was made. A. Roy Knabenshue took off from the aeronautic concourse of the St. Louis World's Fair grounds in Capt. Thomas Scott Baldwin's "California Arrow," and after a flight of one hour and thirty-one minutes landed eleven miles away in St. Clair County, Ill.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 27 -- In his first train platform appearance of the campaign, President Roosevelt stood hatless this blustery morning before a cheering crowd of 6,000 to 8,000 persons here and reached back eighty years to another wartime election for the thesis of a brief speech.

HEADQUARTERS AMERICAN THIRD ARMY, Oct. 26 (Delayed) -- The members of one of the toughest units this Army has met in its drive from Normandy to Germany have been from cadet school outfits -- German youths who have been trained to regard Adolf Hitler as the last word in things temporal and spiritual.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Due to a leak of information reminiscent of the old days of the Quai d'Orsay, news that "a zone of the interior," comprising most of France, was to be turned over to the rule of the Provisional Government was published in Paris before details of the transfer of authority and precise delimitation of the army zone had been agreed on between General Eisenhower and the French military command.

On the same day that our Navy in the Philippines was smashing the Japanese fleets General de Gaulle in Paris met the reporters in his first press conference since he came to France. The thing that brings these two distant and seemingly disparate events together in the mind is the theme stressed by General de Gaulle in his recent interview with the Paris correspondents.

Jules Romains, in Mexico City, has completed the twenty-seventh volume of his "Men of Good Will" series, thus bringing to a close a project that Andre Maurois once described as the "boldest attempt to describe completely his own time that any French novelist has made since Balzac."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Airlines Committee for United States Air Policy called attention today to an "effective stop-gap" until regular commercial flights can be resumed. It is provided by an executive order of President Roosevelt permitting the Army's Air Transport Command and the Naval Air Transport Service to carry priority-holding civilian passengers and cargo.

Lillian Bertin, young American pianist, gave a recital at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall last night, including on her program Beethoven's early Sonata in C Major, Op. 2, No. 3; Chopin's Ballade in G Minor and three waltzes, as well as shorter works by Griffes, Prokofieff, Albeniz and Liszt.

The Japanese Board of Information announced yesterday that the Cabinet had abolished the "machinery for advising the Premier" and that Emperor Hirohito had granted the Government's request to establish "a new official advisory system" because "the war situation has become more pressing than ever."

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- From the Polish point of view the feature of Prime Minister Churchill's speech today was his disclosure that Britain had promised to "guarantee" the "independent, sovereign, free Poland" that will emerge from the Russian-Polish negotiations now under way and be ratified at the peace conference.
A communique, as broadcast Thursday from Tokyo in Japanese and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The Texas Company, in its operating statement for the first nine months of this year issued to stockholders yesterday by W.S.S. Rodgers chairman, reported estimated net earnings of $38,884,491 after all charges, including a reserve of $4,000,000 for contingencies growing out of the war.

Net sales of Bloomingdale Bros., Inc., for the fiscal year ended on July 31, last, rose 10.10 per cent to $35,425,591 from the $32,174,475 volume for the preceding fiscal year, James S. Schoff, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Although today's stock market business was again small, most sections were firm. Investment prospects caused buyers to inquire for home rails, and some gains were made. Textiles generally were good, and some support was seen for radios.

ROME, Oct. 27 -- Premier Bonomi, in a statement today to his Cabinet announcing gratefully diplomatic recognition of Italy by the United States, Britain, Russia and Latin-American countries, pleaded that this formal action be given a practical basis. So far as is ascertainable this is the general reaction throughout Italy.

Mrs. Hortense M. Odlum, for four years chairman of the board of Bonwit Teller, Inc., Fifth Avenue specialty store, yesterday tendered her resignation to the directors at their October meeting. Prior to her term as chairman of the board, she was president of the company six years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- President Roosevelt said he looked forward to a free Czechoslovakia in a message tonight to President Eduard Benes in London on the occasion of the anniversary of the independence of the country.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27. -- More than 750,000 persons gave President Roosevelt a roaring ovation this afternoon as the Chief Executive, again braving foul weather, rode for nearly four hours in an open car on a tour of this city and many of its military installations.

Republican National Chairman Herbert Brownell Jr. predicted yesterday the election of Governor Dewey and "an anti-New Deal Congress" and said that the remaining eleven days until the Presidential election would not produce any substantial change in what he termed a strong Republican trend in pivotal states.

WITH AMERICAN FIFTH ARMY Below Bologna, Oct. 26 (Delayed) -- Through the incredible quagmire of this front yesterday rode a sailor whose white cap was not much protection against the rain for all its being turned down over his ears.
A Thursday communique, as broadcast from Sofia and reported yesterday by the Federal Communications Commission:

The city of Seattle, Wash., will be in the market on Nov. 16 with a new issue of $6,000,000 of transportation system revenue refunding bonds, bearing interest at a fixed rate of 1 3/4 per cent. The bonds, dated Jan. 1, 1945, will mature Jan. 1, 1946 to 1956, optional for call at various times at premiums.

Plans for a cooperative tiremaintenance program were sponsored yesterday at the concluding session of the annual convention of the New York State Wholesale Beer Distributors Association at the Hotel New Yorker. Carrying out of such a program through the association was explained in a talk by J.R. Rutherford of the B.F. Goodrich Company.

The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday suspended indefinitely Tami Mauriello, Bronx heavyweight, for canceling a ten-round bout against Lee Oma of Detroit next Friday night at Madison Square Garden, according to The Associated Press.
Eleven juveniles, but no topranking star, are named for the $10,000 added Ardsley Handicap today at Jamaica, where the Empire City Racing Association will conclude the first week of its fall meeting.

ARMY vs. Duke -- The Kaydets have been rolling along at better than a point-a-minute rate this season, an eminently satisfactory speed. But the brakes will be applied to the swift cadets from today on. Duke may slow down the Army machine at the Polo Grounds, but it won't stop it. A couple of votes for Army.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 27 (U.P.) -- The text of the Argentine Government's note to the other American Governments announcing that it has requested the Pan American Union to call a conference of American foreign ministers, as translated by The United Press:

ATLANTA, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Charles E. Wilson, who recently resigned as executive vice chairman of the War Production Board, announced today the cancellation of two post-war planning speeches at the request of the War and Navy Departments.

ATHENS, Oct. 2 (U.P.) -- An Eam [National Liberation Front] member was shot and killed on one of Athens' main streets today by a man uniformed as a Greek Army major while crowds were parading in honor of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- Bail bonds totaling $80,000 were posted here this afternoon in County Court by three of the five defendants arrested yesterday on a 129-count indictment charging a looting of funds from Yonkers Local 60 of the International Hod Carriers, Building and Common Laborers Union, AFL.
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communiqe:

A "wildcat" strike of between 150 to 200 meat truck drivers tied up yesterday deliveries to hotels and restaurants and brought a warning from the Regional War Labor Board that unless they returned to work immediately the board would not give their wage dispute further consideration.

Playtime fashions set against a resort background struck a happy note at Fashions of the Times, third edition, which played the last performance of a four-day run at New York Times Hall last night. That uniquely American tradition, the bathing beauty contest, proved a noval way of presenting a galaxy of bathing suits that predicted colorful beach scenes during resort and summer seasons.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Determined to bring general order to France on democratic lines the de Gaulle Government is engaged specifically in bringing order into the purge of traitors and collaborators with Germany. Its purpose is to assure complete observance of legal forms and prevent abuse.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Saturday, Oct. 28 (AP) -- A communique:

A comparatively steady tone prevailed yesterday in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange, and closing prices were 6 points higher to 3 points lower than on Thursday. The market opened unchanged to 1 point up and at the best levels of the day it showed net gains of 4 to 8 points.

IT would be hard to find a better title than "Caesar and Christ."* It is meant to be instantly provocative, and it produces the desired result. By mentioning two proper names it starts to life the first question in every sensible person's mind, the clash between power and goodness, and brings history down to two supreme representatives of an irreconcilable war.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Addressing a group of correspondents invited to the Quai Dorsay today, an official spokesman of the Foreign Office said that possibly Gen. Charles de Gaulle's press conference Wednesday had proved "disappointing" in some Allied quarters, and the spokesman therefore wanted to add a footnote to what the general had said.
Following is the text of President Roosevelt's address in Philadelphia last night as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Six United States warships were lost in the recent Philippines operations, including the light carrier U.S.S. Princeton, loss of which had been previously announced, the Navy Department reported today.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 27 -- Gov. John W. Bricker called the President's foreign policy an "utter failure" in an address here tonight and declared that for eight years Mr. Roosevelt ignored evidence of German and Japanese aggression.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- A plea for "an adequate supply of low-cost durable clothing" has been put before William Y. Elliott, War Production Board vice chairman for civilian requirements, Mrs. Eleanor Fowler stated today, adding that she made the plea in behalf of the workingman's wife as represented by not only the CIO auxiliaries, of which she is executive secretary, but by the AFL and Railroad Brotherhood auxiliaries.
Yesterday's communque, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 27 -- California Republican leaders pinched themselves today, checked and rechecked results of the third private poll they have taken during the Presidential campaign, then went out to cover some of the money which is being offered at 4 to 1 on President Roosevelt to carry the State.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 (AP) -Bucknell College and Temple University battled to a 7-7 tie tonight at Temple Stadium in a frosty eighteenth installment of their football rivalry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Chester Bowles, head of the Office of Price Administration, will not make a political speech in behalf of President Roosevelt. He is one of several heads of Government agencies who have been invited by the Democratic National Committee to take an active part in the campaign, but who have declined on the ground that the agencies they head are wartime affairs and should remain nonpartisan.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 -- President Roosevelt, in fighting mood, gave tonight to 50,000 cheering Pennsylvanians crowded into Shibe Park an accounting, marked by no apologies or reservations, of his stewardship as Commander in Chief of the armed forces in a war which has led to twenty-seven D-days of "triumphant success" on battlefronts 13,000 miles apart.

The six-story commercial structure at 4808 Bergenline Avenue, Union City, N.J., formerly known as the Millimet Building, has been sold by the New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company, in liquidation, to the 4808 Bergenline Avenue Corporation. J.I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Provision for facsimile broadcasting in the post-war reallocation of frequencies was urged before the Federal Communications Commission today by radio executives, engineers and others, all agreed on the value of the service to be rendered, but differing as to the merits of the methods suggested for encouraging and promoting it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -The present regime in Argentina, which the United States and virtually all other American nations refuse to recognize, appeared tonight to be trying to raise a challenge to this country's role in Pan-American affairs and to break down hemisphere solidarity.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Saturday, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Sixteenth Division, which General MacArthur previously said he was particularly anxious to meet, is in retreat from the east coast of Leyte.
LONDON, Oct. 27 (U.P.) -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Winston Churchill's address in the House of Commons today:

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 27 (U.P.) -- Dr. Clarence A. Dykstra, president of the University of Wisconsin and former Selective Service director, was appointed today provost for the Los Angeles campus of the University of California.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 28 (AP) -- An inspired West Virginia football team ran wild behind Freshman Jimmy Walthall of Princeton, W.Va., today to hand Penn State its first home defeat since 1938, by a score of 28 to 27.

YOUTH, virginity and all the other serial volumes are so obviously bound to triumph that it's not the suspense but the very safety of her stories which is Miss Baldwin's greatest asset and has been responsible for her arrival as dean of the serial-writing ladies.

LONDON, Oct. 1 (By Mail.) WITH Vivien Leigh back from the hospital after her illness, work on "Caesar and Cleopatra" is going furiously ahead. Shaw has written in a new scene, in which the old nurse, "Ftatateeta" (Flora Robson), instructs her charge in the right way to receive Caesar as a queen.

MONTREAL, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens scored a 3-2 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight in a thrill-packed National Hockey League opener that drew a capacity crowd of 12,772 to the Forum. The champions were three goals up halfway through the game, but two quick counters by the Bruins made it a torrid battle from then on.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 28 (AP) -- The upset of the year in the Big Six football Conference was exploded today as Nebraska, a team that had not scored a point in three previous games, won by 24 to 20 from a Missouri eleven that had been favored to beat the Nebraskans by five or more touchdowns.

TORONTO, Oct. 28 -- The Toronto Maple Leafs won their opening game of the National Hockey League's fifth wartime season tonight, defeating the New York Rangers by 2 -- 1 with a last-period rally that produced two goals after the Rangers had tallied in the second.

This should turn out to be one of the tell-tale days of the 1944 season in professional football, especially in the Eastern half of the National League, where first place will be at stake when the unbeaten New York Giants meet the undefeated Philadelphia Eagles up at the Polo Grounds.

IN Paris the liberation of art has coincided with the liberation of the city and today Pablo Picasso stands out as the standard-bearer of the artistic movement.
