In the first place, his attitude during the German occupation has won general admiration. He steadfastly refused to fall for propaganda wiles as did too many French painters and sculptors.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 28 -- United States warships and planes definitely sank two Japanese battleships and wiped out an entire force of four carriers in the Battle of the Philippines, increasing Japanese losses in the Western Pacific last week to more than forty ships sunk or damaged, it was disclosed today.

THE generation to which Charles Peguy belongs (he was born soon after the Franco-Prussian War of 1870-71) gave France four other writers whose fame has long been established outside of France: Claudel, Gide, Proust and Valery.

The problem of post-war surplus tonnage disposal is a knotty one that is going to require much more than merely fixing a dollar value per ton -- such values must be accompanied by governmental guarantee that the bottom is not going to fall out of any agreed-upon value.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 28 (U.P.) -- Bob Nussbaumer and Bob Wiese of Michigan took charge of their going-away party today, scoring five touchdowns between them in an amazingly easy 40-to14 upset victory over Purdue before 50,000 fans.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 28 -- The statement of Representative F. Edward Hebert that in the four years he has been in Congress he has named 150 youths from his district to take qualifying examinations for Annapolis and West Point and that all failed, has aroused school authorities and parents to demand that the standard of Louisiana public schools be raised.

The Seamen's Church Institute of New York, largest shore home hotel, and club in the world for merchant seamen of all nationalities and creeds, is sponsoring the performance of the operetta "Rhapsody," with music by Fritz Kreisler, for the night of Nov. 16 at the new Century Theatre.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- The Netherlands Government in Exile announced tonight that as a result of the extensive destruction and wanton damage in the occupied Netherlands, coupled with the systematic looting by the Germans, the recuperative power of the Netherlands had been gravely impaired.

IT is time to make a plea for the work of William Faulkner. More than that of any other living American author it has been misinterpreted by the critics and, in recent years, neglected by the public at large. Of his seventeen published books -- which include eleven novels, two volumes of poetry and four collections of stories -- not one has had a sale in the trade edition of as much as 20,000 copies.

In an informative pamphlet entitled "College and You in Wartime," President Dixon Ryan Fox of Union College sets forth in lucid terms the case for the civilian student who is undecided as to whether he should enter college or go into a paying job. This is a problem that many boys below draft age are now facing.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 28 -Appointment of four new members of the editorial board of The American Scholar was announced here today following the annual meeting of the senate of the Phi Beta Kappa Society. Five new members also were named to the organization's executive committee.

BOURG MADAME, France, Oct. 26 (Delayed) -- After a laborious personal inspection, I have found no evidence that Spanish battalions of the French Forces of the Interior have crossed the French border into Spain to engage troops of Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

AN AMERICAN ARMY REST CENTER in Belgium, Oct. 25 -- For the first time since D-day American front-line troops are beginning to get some rest. In the past few days several rest camps for battle-weary American soldiers have been established far enough behind the fighting lines to let the men really relax and enjoy themselves.

The 1944 Catholic Literary Award of the Gallery of Living Catholic Authors was received yesterday by Dr. William Thomas Walsh at a reception held in his honor at Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart, 133d Street and Convent Avenue.

COLOMBIA'S series in "Conmemoracion del 75 Aniversario de la Constitucion de la Junta General de Beneficencia de Cundinamarca" (Commemoration of the Seventy-Fifth Anniversary of the Constitution of the General Benefit Association of Cundinamarca) has been received by F-L Stamp Company.

RUSSIA'S fourth wartime winter finds musical life in this country well on its way back to normalcy. Leading musicians and musical organizations are back at their old places and the winter season, which opened last week, again features traditional musical events in addition to new programs.

AS the end of the war in Europe approaches, the conversion of this great arsenal of democracy into a peacetime manufactory becomes one of the most important problems of the day. What will happen to the vast workshops now turning out war material? How can new jobs be provided for the army of workers in those workshops and for the millions of discharged soldiers?

THE caustic criticism of Hollywood's war films which civilized Elliot Paul wrote in the columns of this newspaper a couple of Sundays ago was a little bit more reproachful than a working critic's comments might be -and possibly a little more bitter than the evidence would safely support.

The great air-sea battle of the eastern seas last week crippled a part of the Japanese Fleet, consolidated our invasion of the Philippines and probably advanced somewhat our schedule of operations in the Pacific. But the enemy fleet has not been annihilated; enough of its strength remains as a "fleet in being" to influence future Pacific operations, and the war with Japan still looms as a long and difficult struggle.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Army and Navy Journal, unofficial publication covering activities of the armed forces, today suggested in an editorial that professional baseball and football teams spend their off-season training periods overseas entertaining the members of the armed forces.

While the huge volume of public savings and the likelihood that output of consumer durable goods will be far under demand may lead to restricted use of consumer credit during the first post-war year, trends in subsequent years may push consumer credit volume far above the 1941 peak of 9,499,000,000, of which $5,921,000,000 represented installment credit, according to comment here last week.
EIGHT months ago a 17-year-old red-head who thought she could sing, started West. She was not only ambitious but also resourceful; she took along a return trip ticket -- good for three months.

A WAITER in the most conventional of tail coats gracefully poured wine into a glass. It was Chateau Latour 1938. One of the discoveries of the liberation period is that this was a fair wine year. Napery and silver were as choice as they had been under that roof in the time of the Third Republic or Second Empire.

NEARLY every evening, after the 4 o'clock dinner hour and before the early tropic dark had brought a cessation of all activity on Guadalcanal except fighting, came a certain sound. Typewriter keys were clacking in the fragment-shredded tent at Headquarters of the First Marine Division, where dwelt the newspaper correspondents and the division's public relations officer and official historian.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Chinese announced today that Japanese troops had opened an all-out offensive and reached the outskirts of the Gwangsi Province capital of Kweilin, whose fall would represent a major achievement in the Japanese effort to isolate eastern China.

Because of deadlines subsequent to election day fixed by eight States for the receipt of service ballots, 103 electoral votes may be held in suspense for one to four weeks after the Nov. 7 Presidential election, according to answers received by THE NEW YORK TIMES in a survey of the eight States involved.
The following is the text of President Roosevelt's address last night in Chicago as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
LONDON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

The blue jay has a deserved reputation as a scoundrel, a gaudy thief. He thinks he owns the woods, and he resents all intrusion. It is his woods to dominate, to loot, to guard and to dictate. He is in his element and at his arrogant best when the frost has hit hard, the leaves have largely fallen and the songsters have migrated.

IN the last analysis the thing we are fighting for is the opportunity to continue to live according to our conception of law. We are fighting for it because it has been assailed by the most destructive force ever set against it.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 28 (AP) -Gov. Walter E. Edge issued a statement today lauding Governor Dewey of New York for calling a special legislative session to consider extending voting hours there, but saying "there is no such need" in New Jersey.

Mrs. Frances S. Jenkinson, president of the Young Women's Republican Club .of New York, Inc., will take an active part in the campaign to re-elect President Roosevelt, it was announced yesterday by Russell W. Davenport, chairman of the New York independent Republican Committee.

WE were generously sent tickets by the organization which produced the work to see the eminently successful musical show now running in this town, called "Song of Norway." This musical is built about reputed incidents in the life and the adorable melodies contained in the works of the Norwegian composer, Edvard Grieg.

College and university presidents, faced with financial difficulties as a result of the war-time decreased enrollments, have recommended that their institutions be aided through Federal grants for scholarships, grants for buildings and permanent equipment and low-rate long-term loans to meet war emergency operational deficits.
Following is the text of Governor Dewey's speech at Syracuse as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
Manual Training and Tilden battled to a 7-7 tie, and Brooklyn Tech downed Lafayette, 53 -- 0, in the fourth interscholastic football double-header at Ebbets Field yesterday. A crowd of 6,000 watched.

WITH FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, Oct. 28 -- The influence of the weather on the fighting in Italy is obvious and the fact that the Germans are striking tack furiously at such key points as Livergnano is equally obvious. What is much less obvious, however, is the German motive in turning the battlefield below Bolonga into one of the worst charnel houses this campaign has seen.
After dropping to the lowest levels in a month, stocks ended the New York Stock Exchange week yesterday on a moderately firmer note. Prices moved narrowly and closed a bit firmer in quiet trading.

BOSTON, Oct 28 -- The manpower shortage in New England war plants has reached the serious stage. According to informed officials, war production is being held up at several plants by the lack of male labor.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Coming back strongly in a wild third quarter, Tennessee's Volunteers passed and ran their way to a 26-7 victory over Clemson's Tigers today.

GENE COUGHLIN and Sad Sack must be related. The family resemblance is unmistakable. There are some men who glide through civilian life with the effortless grace of a sea gull, but to whom the Army is incomprehensible -- and vice versa. Mr. Coughlin is among them -- in fact, he is well out in front.

ATHENS, Oct. 28 -- George Siantos, secretary general of the Greek Communist party, and George Talaganis, known as Jean Zevgos, Communist Secretary of Agriculture in the Papandreou Government, called upon British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden yesterday and pledged Communist and Eam [National Liberation Front] support to the Greek alliance with Britain.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The mounting Soviet drive into East Prussia is being watched here with keen interest by United States military observers, who are hoping for a major break-through that would flank strong German defense positions in Poland and, in conjuction with pressure on the Western Front, pave the way for a knockout blow against Germany.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- The recognition of the de Gaulle Government as the provisional French regime this week caused what may be called restrained and qualified rejoicing in Paris. On General de Gaulle's part it was so restrained as to be quite invisible, even when he appeared before about a hundred correspondents on Wednesday at his first press conference in Paris.
BRUSSELS, Oct. 28 -- The first comprehensive progress report on Belgium's anti-inflation monetary plan was made tonight by Camille Gutt, Minister of Finance.

DETROIT, Oct. 28 -- The confidence which Republican leaders long felt over the prospect of carrying Michigan's nineteen electoral votes for any GOP Presidential nominee in 1944, and especially for Thomas E. Dewey, a native son, has been replaced lately by some very grave doubts and misgivings.
BOSTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Boston College came from behind a favored Syracuse University team to win its third straight victory, 19 to 12, at Fenway Park today.

WHEN this picture appeared a fortnight ago in the daily papers the editor had a double reaction. First he yawned. Then he thought it might be interesting to collect what might be called "The Best Yawns of the Year." At any rate what resulted is this page.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Reviewing a thirty-two-year battle in the fur industry over the employers' right to discharge, representatives of fur manufacturers and their union employes battled through a three-hour hearing before the War Labor Board today over the findings of the board's panel recommending acceptance of the union's demands on the issue.

PENGUIN has here published, in a neat little book opening the long way, 138 pages -- eight in color -- of sketches made by American service men in this country and overseas. They have been studiously and well chosen by Aimee Crane, who writes a foreword, and are reproduced to good effect in spite of their modest dimensions.

HERE is another episode in the career of Napoleon Bonaparte, the half-caste Australian detective. This time Bony's antagonist is another half-caste, Rex McPherson, natural son of The McPherson, sole proprietor of an isolated ranch ("station" is the Australian term).

IT would be easy to be flippant about this book and miss its gravity, or be gross and miss its pathos. Christina Stead does not have the stature of D.H. Lawrence, but she has many of his qualities, and her new novel suggests his early and best fiction.

Revision of New York City's civil service salary schedule to meet increased wartime living costs was urged yesterday by Ellis Ranen, Eastern general representative of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes Union, American Federation of Labor.

IN the personage of Sumner Welles, former Under-Secretary of State and author of "The Time for Decision," the ranks of regular radio commentators have gained their most important acquisition in recent years. Gifted with a superb diction and delivery that should be required listening for all practitioners in his new-chosen field, Mr. Welles brings to his assignment (10 P.M. Wednesdays; WOR-Mutual) the authority and intelligence which instantly make it a distinctive quarter-hour.

IN close cooperation with school authorities, the New Haven Railroad has prepared a comprehensive educational program designed to give elementary and high school students in the States in which the road operates a clear picture of railroad transportation and the important part it plays in American life.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Several days ago one of the few surviving reporters covering the mass sedition trial noted that quite a number of the defendants and their attorneys were wearing yellow chrysanthemums. Inquiring of its significance, he was reminded that the day marked the end of six months' continuance of this unprecedented trial.

Retail trade was brisk last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main-floor departments were crowded, while volume in dresses, coats and suits and sportswear was good.

POLITICS is a business, according to Mr. Abrahams, who has written this book to expand that not very novel thesis. The merchandise of that business is votes, he finds, and he who dishes out the money gets the votes.

John Gould's "Portrait of a Country Editor" in THE MAGAZINE brought back memories of pleasant summers spent in New England, I feel sure, to many city dwellers. With what anticipation native and visitor alike looked forward to the painstaking chronicling of the trivia of lawn parties and bazaars, as well as the reports of the endless cycle of vital statistics!

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Approving the United Nations Charter framed at Dumbarton Oaks in its general lines, Ambassador Juan Carlos Blanco of Uruguay, suggested in a statement today a preliminary discussion of the proposals by the nations of the Americas before the full dress conference meets.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- White Plains High remained undefeated with a 20-0 victory, its third of the season against one tie, over Binghamton Central before 3,500 spectators at the Stadium today.

MANHATTAN, Kan., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Iowa State's Cyclones blew only a mild breeze for three quarters in their football game with Kansas State College today before sweepings to a fourth-quarter touchdown that gave them a 14-0 victory over a much-improved Wildcat eleven.

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 28 -- Three of Mississippi's nine Democratic Presidential electors, Frank E. Everett, Clarence E. Morgan and W.G. McClain, said today that they would bolt the Roosevelt-Truman ticket an vote for Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia for President.

RICHMOND, Oct. 28 -- One of the political sensations of recent years in Virginia has been caused by Ashton Dovell, Williamsburg lawyer and former Speaker of the House of Delegates, who has just delivered a scathing attack on the Byrd Democratic organization, with which he was long affiliated.

LETTUCE moved from the garden before frost can be grown in the coldframe for late fall and winter use. It can stand a temperature as low as 25 degrees without damage, but after that it had better be moved under glass.

For the second time within a week Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine and high-ranking police officials were complimented on their efficiency in handling receptions for prominent officials. At special ceremonies yesterday morning at Police Headquarters Commissioner Valentine and Chief Inspector John J. O'Connell each received a Gold Cross of Lorraine as a "token of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's appreciation of their assistance during his stay in this city."

Twenty-five hundred Japanese-American students are enrolled at present in 550 colleges and universities of this country. Most of this number are young evacuees formerly in relocation and assembly centers who wanted college training.

Because production of major household appliances for some time after the cessation of hostilities may represent merely a "trickle" compared with the pent-up demand, it probably will be necessary to continue War Production Board's inventory limitation order L-219 until such time as production catches up with demand, observer predicted last week.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 28 -Yale picked up momentum as it went along in its game with Rochester today and experienced little trouble humbling the Yellow Jackets in the Bowl by the score of 32 to 0.

MANY years ago a Scottish medical man, Dr. Clouston, a mad-doctor as they call him there, or what we should call an asylum physician (the most eminent one in Scotland), visited this country, and said something that has remained in my memory ever since.

TWO years and seven months ago, after the stand at Bataan, Gen. Douglas MacArthur arrived in Australia Next day in a press interview, while the Japanese tide was threatening to sweep over the entire Pacific, he announced to a somewhat incredulous world: "I shall return to the Philippines." Today he has made good his pledge.

Joseph Rogatchewsky, Russian tenor much admired in Paris at the Opera and the Opera Comique, gave a recital last night in Town Hall, where he had appeared last March in a joint recital with the French pianist Emma Boynet. Last night's program consisted entirely of numbers in French and Russian, and the singing evoked continued hearty applause from the audience, made up largely of fellow-emigres from the French capital, including distinguished musicians.

IN November, 1941, Adolf Hitler stated at Munich: "Leningrad will put its hands up. It will fall sooner or later. Nobody is going to free it. Leningrad will have to die of starvation. In terms of cold-blooded military analysis, Hitler should have been right.

Recently visiting Wyoming and Utah, President Fairfield Osborn of the New York Zoological Society was moved to note the precarious position of wildlife in this country. Most of the species of our native animals continue to exist, though greatly diminished in numbers. In Western refuges there still are elk in fair-sized herds.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 28 -- Governor Dewey held out to the farmers of the country today freedom from Government control and dictation, assailed the New Deal's "scarcity theories" and "chattering fear of production," and declared that stabilization of agriculture on a par with industry and labor would yield to it full employment with fair prices and a real market.

STORRS, Conn., Oct. 28 -- Three field goals by Pete Barry, substitute halfback, and a touchdown by Phil LaCourciere gave the University of Connecticut a 15-to-0 football victory at Gardner Dow Field today over Brooklyn Colege. In a previous game at Brooklyn two weeks ago the Huskies also had won, 10 to 0.

ATHENS, Oct. 28 (AP) -- British land forces, cooperating with Greek guerrillas, have made their first contact with retreating German troops in Greece in the area of Koziani, sixty miles northwest of Larissa and forty miles below the Yugoslav frontier, it was announced today. A communique said casualties were inflicted on the enemy.

LONDON, Oct. 28 (U.P.) -- Russian troops, surging fifteen miles west of Kirkenes across difficult water barriers and sixteen miles south along the Polar Circle Highway, have cut off German troops attempting to flee from Lapland, Moscow announced tonight amid indications that the Nazis have evacuated their main Arctic forces to new defenses along the Norwegian west coast.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- "There can be no return of the 'putrid press,'" according to Minister of Information Pierre-Henri Teitgen in an address to a convention of French newspaper publishers just concluded in Paris. The convention was attended by delegates from the capital and the provinces.

Grace Castagnetta, pianist, gave her first recital in two seasons yesterday afternoon in Town Hall before a large and appreciative audience. Since her last appearance on Nov. 23, 1942, Miss Castagnetta's art has shown such growth that she now has definitely taken her place among the outstanding women pianists of the day.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -- In this article, which is based upon observations and conversations with perhaps as many as 200 political figures in nearly every part of the State during the past six weeks, it may be fairly stated that the failure of the Republican organization in Philadelphia to keep pace with its counterparts elsewhere in the State seems likely to cost Governor Dewey Pennsylvania's thirty-five electoral votes.

BUFFALO, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Senator James M. Mead of New York said today that he had it "in black and white" that Herbert Hoover and Governor Dewey, Republican Presidential nominee, initiated "an undercover campaign some few months back to drive the late Wendell Willkie out of the Republican party."

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- The finishing touches are being put on the new and enlarged Consultative Assembly in which the lion of resistance and the lamb of parliamentarianism are expected to lie together in far greater harmony than seemed likely a week or so ago, those who have been struggling for six weeks for this consummation said today.

If cotton is to remain the primary staple in textiles in the post-war period, it must be priced sufficiently under synthetic fibers to allow for the greater difficulty and expense entailed in its handling, Worth Street textile men asserted last week. If this spread is not maintained, the anticipated increase in efficiency in post-war textile spinning and weaving will place cotton in a secondary posiItion, they argued.

EVERY bid carries two messages, one based upon the values it affirms, the other upon the values it denies. A given bid may seem strong on superficial analysis, but further thought will reveal it as a confession of weakness, because with genuine strength the bidder would have made some other bid.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- A new factor delaying sale of surplus war plants emerged today. It was disclosed that the Justice Department had refused to approve the sale of Government-owned aluminum plants to the Aluminum Company of America on the ground that this would contribute to the growth of monopoly.
Mayor La Guardia made a twelve-minute speech in Italian over the radio last night and urged the re-election of President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Argentine proposal in notes to the Pan American Union and to the American Republics that the Union call a conference of Foreign Ministers of the twenty-one republics to consider the so-called Argentine problem is not expected to succeed in its apparent effort to force recognition of the Buenos Aires Government, or to cause a split in hemispheric solidarity over the issue.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Gov. John W. Bricker of Ohio tonight topped off a strenuous one-day campaign through the home State of his rival for the Vice Presidency with a note of caution against "Federal domination of education."

One long run, a 69-yard dash from scrimmage by Dick Kreter, was the difference between Columbia and Colgate yesterday at Baker Field, where some 15,000 sun-drenched spectators witnessed a hard, if somewhat dull struggle between comparatively strong lines.

OMAHA, Oct. 28 -- Although Governor Dewey postponed the farm speech he was to have made at Minneapolis he summed up in a single sentence of his prefatory explanation the answer to any question the Middle Western farmer had in his mind.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The question of the powers that will be vested in the American representative on Security the Council of the United Nations is fast developing into the major domestic issue involved in the formation of the international organization.

The Tokyo radio said yesterday in a domestic broadcast that Japanese troops were attacking about one division of American troops in the Tacloban area and two divisions in the Dulag area of Leyte Island in the Philippines, but added that American reinforcements were pouring in at such a rapid rate that the situation had taken a serious turn for the Japanese.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- Returning to Albany after his Syracuse farm address, Governor Dewey accused President Roosevelt here today of having claimed, in his Philadelphia speech last night, "personal and political" credit for American achievements and victories in the war.

MORE than two and a half million hours of service given to American hospitals since Pearl Harbor is only one item of the wartime record the Girl Scouts have rolled up; and this doesn't include the time spent in tending victory gardens, or saving crops as farm aides, to name only two of the many enterprises in which the girls have shown what they can do for their communities when they get the chance.

OF all the meats in the market at present, mutton is the only one that is both point-free and plentiful. As served in chop houses and restaurants, mutton is aged or ripened to develop tenderness, and in the process the flavor is intensified and often becomes strong.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast by the German-controlled Budapest radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

HERE are twenty separate case histories, many of them dealing with the patients' emotional disturbances with which Dr. Christian must often cope. They bring back many old friends -- the proud spinsters, the prodigal daughter, the roguishly bedeviled sailor and a leitmotif of the romance of Judy Price, the doctor's pretty daughter, with successful, bitter Peabody, returned to the town of his birth to pay off old scores.

FLORIBUNDA roses deserve the consideration of anyone who wants to take advantage of the good planting weather up until the end of November by adding to his collection of America's favorite flower. These sturdy, ever-blooming, fragrant bush roses are perfectly suited to many of the busy wartime gardener's requirements.

WITH AMERICAN SEVENTH ARMY IN FRANCE, Oct. 27 (Delayed) -- Within the sound and sight of the flash of artillery fire ripping through the Vosges forest last night the headlights of my jeep picked up a small sign by the roadside marking the location of the Ninth Evacuation Hospital, manned by the veteran Roosevelt Hospital Unit from New York that has been overseas twenty-five months.

Letters addressed to Army and Navy officers asking them to contribute to the Democratic national campaign fund were sent to them only by coincidence, Edwin W. Pauley, treasurer of the Democratic National Committee, explained yesterday.

An increasing interest in adult education is reflected in the highest registration in its history, the New School for Social Research announced today. Preliminary figures show an increase of 104 per cent over the corresponding period of last year, or 4,463 students registered in 275 full semester courses in the School of Politics and the School of Philosophy, the Graduate Faculty and the Dramatic Workshop.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- An interesting and important factor in the Presidential campaign is the contest headed on one side by the twenty-six Republican Governors and their State organizations and on the other by the trifold combination of the Federal organization, the Democratic machines in the big cities of many of these twenty-six States and the Political Action Committee of the CIO.
LONDON, Oct. 28 (UP) -- A communique broadcast from Berlin:

HOLLYWOOD studios have earmarked upward of $20,000,000 to be used for new construction and the modernization of existing facilities as soon as peace comes, or before that if present building restrictions should be lifted.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

OTTAWA, Oct. 28 -- The tough battle that the Canadian Army has been fighting to clear the Schelde estuary and free the sea approach to Antwerp has been as hard a fight as any the Canadians have fought in this war, and their record for hard fighting at Caen and Ortona already stood high.

THIS year's Christmas Seal of the National Tuberculosis Association will be issued on Nov. 27. The design, by Spence Wildey, art editor of Woman's Home Companion, pictures a postman trudging with letter and packages through the snow.

Our favorite prophet of the moment is Henry J. Kaiser when he speaks, as he did the other night, about the American future. Tremendous work waits to be done in this country toward satisfying the pent-up demands of all of us.

PROBABLY no monkey has ever been left to his own devices in a natural history museum, but, were a member of that tribe to find himself in such an enviable situation, he might very easily behave as did Hooker, the monkey in "Hooker's Holiday," when he was brought to the museum in order that Professor Grampus might find out by studying him why people and monkeys act so much alike.

Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, criticized last night his opponent, Robert F. Wagner, for his alleged failure to be present on the floor of the Senate when votes were taken in the last six years on vital legislation.

THERE has probably never been a time when combing second-hand furniture stores and trekking around to auctions was as tempting a pursuit for homemakers as it is today. What with the shortage of new furniture, the fad for reconditioned attic pieces, and the frequent need of finding a few things to make do for the duration living arrangements, a survey of secondhand sources can well be worth while.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 28 -The twenty-fifth annual Boy Scout pilgrimage to the grave of Theodore Roosevelt in Young's Memorial Cemetery today was the largest since the rationing of gasoline began. Fifteen hundred Scouts, including many from Westchester, Suffolk County, New Jersey, Connecticut and Lake George, took part in the parade and exercises.

SINCE Marconi sent his first feeble letter "S" sputtering across the Atlantic in 1901 the transmitting agency he invented has been known in England as "the wireless." And through two decades of mechanical and scientific progress it remained so.

WHEN Cedric Belfrage published the first part of the story of the life of Claude Williams, his book was taken by many reviewers as a novel. Originally issued in England as "Let My People Go," and in this country as "South of God," it has now been expanded to bring the account down to this year and to the present labors of its hero as Industrial War Chaplain in the Presbytery of Detroit.

Japanese broadcasts said yesterday that Premier Kuniaki Koiso, whose government admitted that "the war situation is more pressing than ever," had named twelve men to a new Cabinet advisory group to participate directly in the council of state rather than serving as merely a consultative body, The United Press reported.
MOSCOW, Oct. 28 -- The Soviet Union today decorated its first fourteen "heroic mothers" -- a group of women ranging from 39 to 62 years of age who had borne and reared ten or more children.

On the western front the spotlight last week focused on the Battle of the Netherlands. A full-fledged Allied offensive was rolling up important gains that were essential to future large scale operations. These gains were shattering the western anchor of the German defense system and threatening entrapment of at least part of the 40,000 Nazis in the area below the River Maas and on the islands of the Schelde estuary.

A new twist to the "man without a country" story developed here yesterday when Master Sgt. Gerhard Neumann, who can make no claim of belonging to any nation, arrived at 90 Church Street, ending the first lap of a journey that already has carried him thousands of miles in search of the answer to how he can become an American citizen.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday lacked a trend and closed 2 points higher to 5 points lower than on Friday.
Probably never in retail history has Christmas gift buying set in so early, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.
THE announcer tells you that the following is transcribed. A mixed quartet breaks into a snappy little ditty. You try to catch the words. They sound something like this:

A transcendent performance of the Fourth piano concerto of SaintSaens with Robert Casadesus as soloist was the outstanding feature of the concert given by the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, under Artur Rodzinski, last night in Carnegie Hall.

MARY LASSWELL shies away from fashionable formulae for being funny though female. Her three Rabelaisian graces who swept "Suds in Your Eye" to best-sellerdom have no niche in the stylish psychological dissecting rooms of current fiction.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28 -Billboards and newspaper advertisements depicting a top-hatted, umbrella-carrying, dour-faced prohibitionist, allegedly bent on sneaking back into Oregon through a back door, centered West Coast attention this week on a spirited fight in which California wine interests were accused of falsifying the issue.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- Favorable war news from both European and Pacific battlefrons, bearish professional sentiment and a lowering of bids on cash corn for deferred shipment from the country resulted today in lower levels of prices for grains on the Board of Trade.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration has restored to 270 pounds, from the present limit of 240 pounds, the limit of heavyweight live hogs entitled to the ceiling price of $14.75 a hundredweight. Chicago basis. The ceiling for swine exceeding 270 pounds will remain at $14. The change will be effective on next Tuesday. Salable receipts of hogs here today were 500 head, scarcely enough to make a market.

WITH FAR EASTERN AIR FORCE, on Leyte, Oct. 27 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Major Richard I. Bong today chalked up his thirty-first Japanese plane five hours after having arrived in the Philippines, to become America's leading war ace in the Pacific. He had come here with his land-based fighters to operate from Philippines airfields.

WASHINGTON, Oct, 28 -- Aid of the War Production Board has been asked by the pulp, paper and paperboard industry to procure enough railroad cars to bring in approximately 450,000 cords of pulpwood from Canadian mills before Jan. 1, the war agency announced today.

ANY xylophone player, any axe-thrower will tell you that Nov. 16, 1932, was the darkest day in all theatrical history. Corroborative evidence in sheaves can be had from any of the army of the doomed -- magicians, jugglers, wire-walkers, acrobats, clog dancers, the men who beat out existence on musical saws.

Field Marshal Gen. Friedrich von Paulus, German commander at Stalingrad, now a prisoner of war in Russia, addressed the German people yesterday for the second time since his capture, to denounce as "infamous lies" propaganda attacks against the Soviet-sponsored Free Germany Committee broadcast by German Interior Minister Heinrich Himmler in connection with his drive to organize a German People's Army.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- "In the coal fields of northern France generally and in the Bethune district particularly, production has been hampered by a purge resulting in the discharge or arrest of many engineers. Can the School of Mines Editor replace them?"

War casualties demand early planning for better training and development of special skills in medicine, surgery, nursing, physical and occupational therapy, says Willard C. Rappleye, dean of the School of Medicine of Columbia University, in his annual report to Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

LONDON, Sunday, Oct. 29 (AP) -Soviet mountain troops invaded Slovakia on a broad front west of conquered Ruthenia yesterday as Berlin announced that four other Russian armies had begun a big new offensive in Latvia, aimed at wiping out thousands of Germans pinned against the Baltic Sea.

ALBANY, Oct. 28 -- With but six campaigning days remaining -- two in October and four in November -before the voters of the nation go to the polls to elect a President whose term undoubtedly will run through the maelstrom of war and into the making of the peace, Republican leaders today looked upon the progress of the campaign thus far and found the results most satisfactory.

The Third Edition of Fashions of the Times was produced in Times Hall last week. This cavalcade of New York styles covered a wide field, both current and future, and was presented in three acts and eight scenes.

Last week the Navy fought and won its greatest battle in the war against Japan, the greatest air-sea battle in history. In the waters of the Philippines, where American invasion forces had struck their heaviest and deepest blow into enemy territory, where the progress of that invasion was heightening the peril to Japan's whole empire of conquest, the long-evasive Japanese fleet tried to answer the American challenge.

IN "Young Mrs. Brand" Mr. Hichens has posed the same problem which D.H. Lawrence advanced in "Lady Chatterley's Lover": the plight of the emasculated hero and his wife. In this case Dorothea Brand is drawn as a woman whose calm, placid exterior conceals volcanic passion.

A national vote "at least as high and maybe exceeding" that of four years ago, when 49,500,000 ballots were cast for the Presidency, was predicted yesterday by Sidney Hillman, national chairman of the Political Action Committee, following the final meeting before Election Day with PAC chieftains from all sections of the country.

MOSCOW, Oct. 28 -- Bulgaria today signed an armistice with the United Nations. Representatives of the former German satellite state, which has now declared war on Hitler, signed the terms this afternoon in the presence of representatives of the Soviet Union, the United States and the United Kingdom.

Some of the first reports of the death of the Archbishop of Canterbury called him in the headlines Primate of England and in the text Primate of All England. The reason was that the headlines were written in this country but the dispatches were written in England, where they would naturally know best.

IN his eighty-ninth year one of the most picturesque figures in English or indeed in modern social life and letters unfolds a scroll of systematic politics embellished in his own inimitable fashion. Familial relations, educational problems, class structures and their implications, economics, politics, religion, art -- all find their place in the range of his observations and in almost 400 pages of artistic writing.

SINCE last March the United States has had no diplomatic relations with the Argentine Government. It had recognized the "palace revolution" of the previous June that unseated President Castillo and established General Ramirez, the Minister of War, as his self-elected successor; but when Ramirez in turn was pushed out by General Farrell, backed by the Colonels' clique, recognition was withheld.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Chester Bowles, head of the Office of Price Administration, confirmed reports today that he would take no part in the Presidential campaign, but explained that his refusal to participate was not due to any antipathy toward the fourth term.

Hailing Senator Robert F. Wagner as a "recognized and outstanding authority" on legislation affecting the economic and social well-being of the nation, Mayor La Guardia urged the Senator's re-election last night primarily on the ground that he has been "a tower of strength in the Senate to President Roosevelt."

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 28 (AP) -Charles Turner's Ben Jour had his streak snapped after six victories in succession as he failed to outrun the Christiana Stable's Megogo in the thirty-first Washington Handicap today. Megogo, 3-year-old gelded son of Menow, thus automatically became eligible for next Wednesday's Pimlico Special.

With 16,133 cases reported up to Oct. 14 by the United States Public Health Service, the 1944 epidemic of infantile paralysis has officially become the second worst in the recorded history of the disease in this country, the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -What their predecessors recently did to the Imperial Japanese Navy out in the Philippines, the future admirals, still learning the tricks of the trade down at Annapolis, today did to Pennsylvania on the gridiron at Franklin Field, where Navy ground the luckless Red and Blue into the turf by sheer power.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Indiana's Hoosiers gained momentum up the Western Conference championship trail today by swamping Iowa's undermanned Hawkeyes, 32 to 0, for their third Big Ten conquest against one loss.

LOUIS BROMFIELD'S restless imagination wanders over two continents, intent on capturing the dramatic, the bizarre, the spectacular elements of story-building. But although he seizes on the brightest of these materials, he seldom brings his stories home alive.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Postponement of Britain's long-deferred general election until next autumn seems to be generally expected as a result of the secret talks that have been going on within coalition circles during this week-end.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- President Roosevelt, in a bid for Illinois' twenty-eight electoral votes made directly to an estimated 110,000 voters filling Soldier Field tonight and to an outside overflow throng of 150,000, pledged himself anew to a post-war security program which would keep the United States a country of high pay and adequate return for farm and factory products.
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted in English by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

In these days it is being said with increasing frequency that if business can't provide jobs in the post-war period, the Government must. Sometimes it goes: if business won't do it, Government will. In the current issue of the Tax Review, Harley L. Lutz, Professor of Public Finance at Princeton University, gives these extravagant promises the kind of hard-headed analysis that has been long overdue.

ABOARD UNITED STATES CARRIER TASK FORCE FLAGSHIP, Philippine Sea, Oct. 26 (Delayed) -- From his topside battle station aboard the light carrier U.S.S. Princeton, Chief Gunner's Mate Clark L. Zeiders saw the first Japanese aerial bomb hurtle down on her, crash through her flight deck and start her on the way to destruction.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Ohio State University's "Scarlet Scourge" blasted Minnesota's Gophers quickly today and then coasted home for a 34-to-14 football victory that gave the Buckeyes their fifth straight triumph of the 1944 season.

In delivering the thirty-second Wilbur Wright Lecture before the Royal Aeronautical Society Sir Roy Fedden presented a monumental review of 60,000 words, a veritable book, on the history of aircraft propulsion and looked into the future.

FOOTNOTE on Girl Scouts: Many of us, unaware that the revised scouting program includes a wide variety of girls' interests, still think of it in terms of camping and tying knots. Mrs. Douglas Gibbons, of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York tells about a young Army lieutenant who shared the general assumption.

Inspired by a new color and refreshed by a glimpse of the future, New York's fashion industry evaluated yesterday "Fashion of the Times," third edition, as the most comprehensive and constructive picture of the field yet presented.

ON Oct. 2 I wrote to the Shubert Theatre for tickets to "Bloomer Girl," which opened Oct. 5. I asked for tickets for Nov. 10, which seemed to be reasonably far ahead. On Oct. 19, more than two weeks later, my check was returned with a note to the effect that the theatre is sold out until December.

The tentative proposals of the Dumbarton Oaks report for an international organization of the United Nations for the maintenance of peace and security are, in the main, an outline of the old League of Nations with the added power to use force for "the suppression of acts of aggression," and an attempt to meet and correct other defects of the League.
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 28 -Great Lakes roared back from its defeat by Ohio State last week to smother Wisconsin's young Badgers today, 40 to 12.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (U.P.) -The War Shipping Administration announced today the torpedoing and sinking of two Liberty ships with the loss of three lives.

Howard S. Cullman, of Cullman Brothers, cigar leaf tobacco dealers, 161 Front Street, yesterday released copies of correspondence with the Department of State, in which he asserted that when 400,000,000 pounds of tobacco were requisitioned by the Commodity Credit Corporation for England and her colonies, it produced "a substantial deficit for our domestic needs, without taking into consideration continuous increased consumption, in an industry that has more than doubled in the last ten years."

Back from a twenty-eight-day trip to England, France and Italy, D. Basil O'Connor, chairman of the central committee of the American Red Cross, predicted yesterday that "it will be a bad winter" in these countries, whose great problem is transportation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge, internationally known patron of chamber music, was honored tonight at the opening of a three-day celebration of her eightieth birthday, which will occur on Oct. 30. For the occasion the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation in the Library of Congress is holding its tenth festival in the auditorium named for her.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Export demand for American machinery, tools and other capital goods will average $3,000,000,000 to $4,000,000,000 annually for at least ten years after the close of the war, according to estimates of Administration advisers who have been surveying world demand for such goods with an eye to the rate at which the nation's post-war economy will operate.

The glamour of Army's highest scoring team of modern times faded under the withering impact of the first real defense it has run into at the Polo Grounds yeterday, but the cadets, trailing 7 -- 6, at the half, came on with whirlwind speed to defeat Duke by 27 -- 7 for their fifth successive victory of the season.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation made public last week a comprehensive plan of procedure for the employment of veterans of World War II, based on legislation affecting men with the armed forces and the merchant marine together with the company's own program, affecting more than 80,000 of its workers.

The Provident Loan Society of New York, a non-profit institution created by the Legislature in 1894, announced yesterday that it has completed a half-century of operations by repaying all funds represented by its certificates of contribution.

ATLANTIC CITY. N.J. IT was not too many months ago that civilians were reading with much interest and some amusement about the special orientation given troops as they headed overseas -- the lectures and booklets which introduced the soldier to the historical background, social customs, economic standards and religious taboos of particular foreign countries in which the men would be stationed.

THE Allans are back, in another novel of the Santa Lucias, that wild Coast country south of Monterey. For those who remember Mrs. Ross' first book, "The Stranger," this announcement alone win be cause for rejoicing.

STUDENTS of cryptography and cryptanalysis should find this story completely fascinating. For others the going may be rough, for the solution depends upon the breaking down of a cipher believed by the man who invented it to be unbreakable.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 28 (AP) -- James J. Carroll, a betting commissioner, today gave odds of 17 to 5 on the re-election of President Roosevelt and 3 to 1 against the election of Governor Dewey.

THE Giants were playing the Eagles several years ago when Kink Richards, one of Stout Steve Owen's most deft operatives, broke loose on a magnificent twisting run. He exploded through the Philadelphia line, nimbly dodged the secondaries and was running out in the clear before the bewildered Eagles were quite aware of what was happening.

ALTHOUGH the temptation may be strong at the moment it is perhaps not strictly fair to say the American theatre consists of John van Druten. The American theatre also includes "Oklahoma!" No one can reasonably deny, however, that Mr. van Druten is doing as well as may be expected of an author who can be in only two places at once.

AMONG the many new exhibitions of paintings, drawings and prints managed last week to make good their claim for attention. There is, for example, a very attractive show of diverse modern French work at the Grolier Club, which brings together a wide variety of black-and-whites by Matisse, Picasso, Laboureur, Rouault, Galinis, Chagall, Masson, Lipchitz and several others.

WARRENTON, Va. -- The Warrenton Hunt Club, Amory S. Carhart, M.F.H., will hold its opening meet for the season on Saturday, Nov. 4. There will be no entertaining, and no hunting cards are to be printed. The place of meeting will only be announced the day before.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Marines have the same benefits and privileges as soldiers and sailors under the established veterans' programs, but the Marine Corps has set up an organization to its veterans for advice and service as long as necessary to assure their satisfactory readjustment to civilian life.

TREES and shrubs, which are an integral part of every property, have come in for more attention this fall than in many a season. While clearing away the storm damage to trees, many gardeners evidently decided that they might as well take advantage of the long autumn season of good planting weather to make improvements in their shrub plantings.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 28 -- Senator Truman declared here tonight that Governor Dewey had failed to repudiate the "isolationist Senators whose re-election would prevent him from carrying out a strong policy on foreign affairs."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- In a letter published today in "Selective Service," Government sponsored organ to supply information to members of that agency, President Roosevelt stressed the importance of aiding returning veterans in finding peacetime employment and expressed confidence that the Selective Service personnel would do their part in helping the veterans.

WITH UNITED STATES THIRD ARMY in France, Oct. 27 (Delayed) -- Most everyone will tell you that everything is quiet on this front at the present moment. It is no military secret. Even the communiques say so. But if you visit this front the picture tells a different story.

KEARNY, N.J., Sunday, Oct. 29 -- Three of eleven shipways at the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company yards here, where cruisers, destroyers and troop transports have been built for the Navy, were being swept by fire at 1:10 o'clock this morning.

I WOULD define isolationism as an attitude of mind that persists in regarding the United States as a self-contained and completely independent unit rather than a powerful but integral part of a world growing daily more interdependent, politically and economically. On the basis of that definition, isolationism is far, far from being dead in these United States.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 28 -Achille (Chick) Maggioli, a slender marine trainee playing his final game for Notre Dame, saved the undefeated Irish from humiliation by a determined, swift Illinois eleven today as he galloped 65 yards for a last-period touchdown that spilled the IIlini, 13 -- 7, before 65,114 fans.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The British Government today announced its delegation of eight members to the International Civil Aviation Conference which will start on Wednesday at Chicago. The United States delegation of ten was announced yesterday.

The Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation had a net profit of $5,174,817, in the six months ended on June 30, or $10.18 each on 508,060 shares of capital stock, after Federal income and excess profits taxes of $20,659,680, but before an estimated post-war tax refund credit of $2,015,968, which has been transferred to reserves.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 28 -- Lafayette College's eleven today scored two touchdowns in the last seven minutes to break a tie and defeat Rutgers University, 19 to 6, in the fortieth meeting of the Middle Three members. The victory gave Lafayette its twenty-sixth victory in the series, which started in 1882. Rutgers won thirteen, while one game ended in a tie.

THINGS are rather complicated. It has been an active and diversified week of openings, several of the shows visited deserving thorough critical attention. Manifestly desert will have, at this moment, to make the best of a bargain fraught with compromise -- there will be room for just so much and no more.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- With the election ten days away, the conviction is apparently widespread in the Central West that the political strategists of the Democratic and Republican parties are convinced that Illinois, with twenty-eight votes in the Electoral College, cannot be counted as assured to either President Roosevelt or Governor Dewey.

HERE at last is a detective who does not drink, smoke or chase women. His name is Sam Tree, and he is a grocer. He becomes a detective because of a disturbing series of events, including two murders, in which both he and his wife appear to be implicated.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 28 -- Onondaga County, long credited with having the best Republican organization in New York State, will return a sizable pluarlity for Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, the party nominee for President, according to all indications.

The British radio said yesterday that Dr. Eduard Benes, President of Czechoslovakia, had declared yesterday, on the twenty-sixth anniversary of the Czechoslovak Declaration of Independence, that the republic would be "restored on the same basis" of democratic principles adopted Oct. 28, 1918, even though "we shall have to introduce fundamental changes in the economic and social sphere."

In a letter bearing the caption "Oleomargarine," printed in THE MAGAZINE, the writer asks: "Why do you encourage the very general mispronunciation of 'oleomargarine' by recommending a soft 'g' instead of a hard one?"

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Soviet Russia and Great Britain will not quarrel over the post-war shape of things inside Europe until the war is won. Some of their differences they have agreed to compromise and about others they have agreed to disagree.
POLITICS as a career is rated lower in America than in any other country that is really devoted to democratic ways. The word "politician" is practically never used except belittlingly.

TOMORROW evening will see the opening of the new Ballet International in its own theatre, renamed the International, at Columbus Circle. Its initial season, scheduled to last six weeks, will have a repertoire of sixteen ballets, of which nine are listed as world premieres.

In the nine months ended on Sept. 30, according to an article in the current issue of The Exchange, publication of the New York Stock Exchange, 561 of 835 stocks on the Exchange gained 15 per cent or more, 236 others gained between nothing and 14.9 per cent and only thirty-eight lost.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Cologne got its worst blasting of the war today during an increasingly ferocious aerial assault on the Reich that began when British Mosquito bombers struck Berlin last night. The attacks sent 2,500 Allied planes over Germany within twenty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -The Republican National Committee reported to Congress today contributions totaling $2,428,321 for the Presidential campaign up to this week. The party has spent $1,688,368. The Republican Congressional Committee also reported a separate campaign chest of $382,669 and expenses of $353,465.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell has been relieved of his command and duties in the Far East and recalled here, the White House announced today. The China-Burma-India area has been ordered divided into two theatres under separate commanders, Maj. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer and Lieut. Gen. Daniel I. Sultan, who held high-ranking posts there.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 28 -- The Argentine Government's note to the Pan American Union asking it to call a conference of American Foreign Ministers too Argentine public opinion as completely by surprise as it apparently did the Governments and people of the other American Republics.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Chattanooga News-Free Press asserted in a copyrighted story today that Representative Estes Kefauver had written to a Tennessee business man that membership in the "1,000 Club" was "all the pass they need here in Washington to go anywhere."

Traditionally the powder keg of Europe, the Balkan countries have during the war become a veritable magazine of political dynamite. Problems of territory and leadership, divisions along racial, religious and economic lines, the political chess games of the ruling houses, bitterness and internecine strife engendered by Quisling activities -- these factors have served to darken the present and make difficult the problems of welding a durable peace.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Communique 203:

THIS week is time to start a food counter for the birds. During October young woodpeckers, chickadees and nuthatches wander about not having as yet selected their winter quarters. The theory is that if they come upon what seems to be a good food supply they will stay in its vicinity as long as it lasts.

A SURVEY designed to provide the New England recreational industry with important data in making plans for post-war competition is nearing completion. The New England Council's recreational development committee, the resort committee of the New England Hotel Association, and several other State agencies have joined in the survey.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -Senator Borah's account of a 1939 White House conference was made public today, quoting President Roosevelt as saying "if we could not do that which would avoid war, we must go in."
ROME, Oct. 28 (AP) -- American Fifth Army troops, working in cold rain, improved their positions today along the line of hills eight miles south of Bologna overlooking Italy's eastern Po Valley.

Gustaf Gustafson of the Hawthorne Chess Club of Brooklyn, after scoring five consecutive victories in the third annual tournament for the amateur championship of the United States Chess Federation, suffered his first defeat in the sixth round yesterday at the Marshall Chess Club.

IN 1914 Pierre Blanchar did his best to convince the French Army that he was just the man the Navy had been looking for all along. The 19-year-old youth from Algiers fancied himself as quite a seaman, having had two years of study at a hydrographic school and a cruise of five months to his credit.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Sunday, Oct. 29 (U.P.) -American troops driving west and south through rapidly deteriorating Japanese defenses have seized control of a sixty-seven-mile front on Leyte Island, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today, as other United States forces on Samar Island to the north reached the last water barrier on the road to Manila, 250 miles away.

Walter Soltow, 17-year-old junior from New Utrecht High School, successfully defended his title in the eighth annual New York University interscholastic cross-country run yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park but his team was unable to duplicate its victory of last year as Harry B. Schneider's strong Morris High School squad, from the Bronx, romped off with the team honors with the low total of 64 points.
The American Jewish Committee made public yesterday a copy of a letter sent to Secretary of State Cordell Hull asking him to take necessary action to stop discrimination against Jews in Rumania.
Recovery of $900,000 as treble damages from six wholesale liquor dealers for alleged over-ceiling prices is sought in suits filed in the Federal Court yesterday by the Office of Price Administration.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, France, Oct. 28 -- British troops smashed within two miles of Breda today and began shelling that escape funnel for eight battered German divisions, while Canadian units tore away the enemy's west flank in the Netherlands by capturing the ancient seacoast fortress of Bergen op Zoom.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 28 -- With the assertion that lasting peace is the most important issue before us, educators and representatives of peace groups, meeting at the Lafayette College Institute this week, called upon America's 1,000,000 teachers to take the lead in winning public support for the Dumbarton Oaks program.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Last Feb. 18 a picked group of nineteen pinpoint Mosquito bombers of the Royal Air Force, led by Group Capt. P.C. Pickard, broke down the walls of Amiens Prison, shattered the Germans' guard houses and enabled most of one hundred French patriots awaiting probable death to escape.

The recent delivery of food to Greece under the auspices of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, in cooperation with the Allied armies of occupation, is an example of the functioning of organization for peace in the midst of war, Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Minister to Washington, declared yesterday.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 28 -Dartmouth's football Indians, most of them under Navy orders to continue their V-12 training elsewhere, stormed from behind in the rain to defeat Brown, 14 to 13, today as they chalked up their first triumph of the season.

Nearly three years after war in the Pacific began with the disaster of Pearl Harbor, the great event for which the American Navy had been preparing, hoping and praying at last took place last week -- the showdown battle between the major American and Japanese fleets.

Charles Rozmarek, president of the Polish National Alliance and chairman of the Polish Congress of Buffalo, announced yesterday in Chicago that he would vote for the re-election of President Roosevelt, according to a statement issued last night by the foreign language division of the Democratic National Committee.
ABOARD ADMIRAL MITSCHER'S FLAGSHIP, Off Philippines, Oct. 25 (Delayed) -- The Japanese Fleet submitted itself to the destinies of war today -- and lost.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- There are at least two plans for solving the future of Germany in official Washington because the groups promoting them are starting from different premises and seeking different goals.

" Turning to spiritualism for a feeling of security is not new to this war," according to Dr. R.S. Woodworth, Professor Emeritus of Psychology at Columbia University. The first World War brought a sharp increase in table-tapping, seances and other "magic" methods of communicating with the dead or seeking information about the living.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Oct. 28 (AP) -- A supplementary communique:

The Men's Fashion Guild of New York, organized last month by twenty-three manufacturers producing all apparel items with the exception of shoes and gloves will, during the first week of December, make a formal presentation of a two-color combination that has been Chosen for spring lines to stimulate style consciousness among the men of the country, it was learned yesterday.

IT has been said -- and perhaps there is some truth in it -- that after five years few of us really know the total meaning of war. Even those who have been closest to it have not wanted to accept the fact of a world completely resolved on the business of death.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 28 (U.P.) -- Twin Japanese columns, pushing southward some ninety miles southeast of Kweilin, have reached Fuchwan and are only about seventy miles from Japanese forces in the south. Junction of these forces would effectively cut China in two from Peiping to Hongkong and establish a direct land route from Tokyo to Singapore.

TULSA, Okla., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Oklahoma A. and M. shoved highly favored Tulsa out of the ranks of the nation's undefeated and untied teams today with a 46-40 victory in the most thrilling battle ever fought on Skelly Field.

THIS book is a keen -- at times a brilliant -- job. It is the study of some of the ideas of men who often, though inaccurately, have been thought of as the founding fathers of fascism -- Carlyle, Nietzsche, Wagner, Spengler.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, ALLIED EXPEDITIONARY FORCE, Oct. 28 -- There is every prospect of a winter war in western Europe. Unless the Germans sag and surrender unexpectedly there will be fighting well into December at least. Beyond that it is not feasible to forecast.

THE author of "Farewell, Pretty Ladies" and "The Green Circle" has written a novel which combines, with slow method, two spheres of horror -the one public, the other private. It is as if Hans Fallada's "Little Man, What Now?" and Henry James' "The Turn of the Screw" had merged in spirit -- so great is the realism, so great is the unrealism.

The Statue of Liberty was hailed yesterday as a symbol of world freedom by Guerin de Beaumont, Consul General of the Provisional Government of the French Republic, as 500 persons met on Bedloes Island to commemorate the fifty-eighth anniversary of the statue's dedication.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- By undertaking an active campaign to "report to the people the facts about matters of concern to them and especially to correct any misrepresentations," President Roosevelt has administered to the Democratic national campaign the medicine which has checked, and perhaps dispelled, symptoms which party leaders feared might become malignant.

THIS is a series of short pieces about American kids who man the guns on Flying Forts and Liberators in the European theatre of operations. It is done factually, without slobbering. The writers, former newspaper men, flew with their subjects and lived with them on the ground.

The biggest upset of the local schoolboy football season was accounted for yesterday when a highly by led Erasmus Hall High School eleven, unbeaten and untied in our starts this season, was topped by Abraham Lincoln High, 7 -- 6, before 5,000 spectators at Lincoln Field, Brooklyn.
Some memories are un-nostalgic, including almost all those evoked by today's date in the hearts of Wall Street, for it was fifteen years ago that the bottom fell out of the financial world.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28 -- There is a chance that this year may bring a break in the solid Roosevelt front which has been maintained by Pacific Coast States since 1932. With thirty-nine electoral votes at stake, evidence gathered by poll takers, amateur and professional, indicates that Oregon is wavering in its allegiance to the President, but that Washington and California will probably support a fourth term, although by reduced majorities.

TWENTY-FIVE years ago a pamphlet was published at Boston which bore the title "Extracts From an Investigation Into the Physical Properties of Books as They Are at Present Published, Undertaken by the Society of Calligraphers."
A communique, as broadcast yesterday from Chungking in English to North America and reported by the Federal Communicatiions Commission:

ON BOARD THE PRESIDENT'S TRAIN, FORT WAYNE, Ind., Oct. 28 -- President Roosevelt left his special train here this afternoon, stood on a high platform overlooking an estimated 24,000 cheering voters and spoke of a possible return visit as President within the next four years.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Oct. 28 -- Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Under-Secretary of State, and Donald M. Nelson, former chairman of the War Production Board, received honorary degrees of Doctor of Engineering at graduation exercises of Stevens Institute of Technology here this afternoon. Mechanical engineering degrees were conferred on fifty-one members of the graduating class, including forty-four Navy V-12 enrollees.

SOME day a President of the United States may be elected "electronically." A system has been devised and is now under development to gather quickly and accurately the opinions of representative groups of Americans on all sorts of questions of interest in our national life. If this can be done, and it seems that it can, it can be used to poll the nation to elect a President.

Exuberant New York University rooters swarmed on to Ohio Field yesterday and within ten minutes had removed every vestige of the goal posts -- and they had reason, for the downtrodden Violet football team had just trampled the even more downtrodden City College team, 45 -- 0, for the first N.Y.U. triumph in four starts.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- Exhibits at the national shoe fair, which opens here Monday, will have more of the appearance of pre-war fairs than at any time since stringent regulations of the shoe industry went into effect, manufacturers arriving for the show said today.

An international scramble for the rich petroleum resources of Iran, formerly Persia, is developing even before the cessation of hostilities. Although negotiations had been going on quietly for months by various interests for concessions in Iran, the fight was brought into the open recently when the Soviet Government applied for concessions covering the northern part of the country.
ATHENS, Oct. 27 (Delayed) -One way in which the Germans tried to safeguard their establishments in Greece with insufficient troops was to divide the population and avert organized revolt.

LOCKED up and stored in a corner of Reynal Hitchcock's editorial offices is a little box containing a manuscript recorded on microfilm. It was delivered one year and seven months ago by the author, a few days before he left this country for Algiers.

Unquestionably the taxation of corporations and their stockholders presents one of the most vital post-war tax problems. In this problem is involved the inclusive question as to whether the corporation or its shareholders should be taxed upon undistributed corporate earnings.

VICTOR PAYNE-JENNINGS has won his gamble! There were many wiseacres who shook quizzical heads when P-J announced that he would produce "Rebecca" on the stage. How could a man in his right mind take a chance with "Rebecca" in four dimensions when millions of people already had read it and seen it on the screen?

When Walter E. Irving raised the question of instinct among fish that draws them together no matter how big the lake, he started Arthur Eilenberg of Brooklyn to reflecting on the thought processes, if any, of our finned and feathered friends.
GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Sunday, Oct. 29 (AP) -- A communique:

The new basic A gasoline ration books will be distributed to motorists at 110 public schools in the five boroughs of the city starting on Tuesday and continuing on Wednesday and Thursday, Nov. 1 and 2, between 3:30 and 7 P.M. Daniel P. Woolley, Regional Office of Price Administration head, announced yesterday that the books would be given to 500,000 motorists in New York City.

FROM the small storm cloud of a short time ago, the war production skies have become threatening and at the close of the week the cancellation of a post-war conference to be held in this city on Tuesday and Wednesday by the General Electric Company was the first flash of lightning.

AS Mr. Brickell points out in a foreword, this anthology begins its second quarter century with the present issue. The twenty-two selections include several old performers, who manage their specialties as easily as any Saturday Evening Post stalwart; there are several new discoveries -- and some discoveries of yesteryear.

Opening of spring lines brought large numbers of buyers to the market, all apparently intent upon placing as much business as they could get down, according to a summary of reports made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying organizations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The thirty-three States not having laws forbidding child labor before 16 years of age were urged by Miss Katharine F. Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau, today to enact such statutes as a means of lessening the threat of post-war unemployment.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs spoiled the Chicago National Hockey League opening here tonight before a crowd of 18,168 as they hammered through the Black Hawks' defense for an easy 11-5 victory.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Sid Luckman-bolstered Chicago Bears virtually extinguished the National Football League title hopes of the Cleveland Rams today with a 28-21 triumph before 23,644 fans, avenging an earlier setback at Cleveland.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Monday, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Americans hold an unbroken coastline on Leyte of 212 miles, from Carigara, on the northwest coast, to Panaon Island, off the southeast coast. General MacArthur announced today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican, of Minnesota, who last week made public his support of the Roosevelt-Truman Presidential ticket, announced today his endorsement of Senator Scott W. Lucas, Democrat, of Illinois, for re-election, Lucas headquarters said.

How puzzled would be the spirit of John Paul Jones were some ghostly boatswain to pipe him aboard the new Iowa, latest and greatest battleship of all our fleet! How he would stare at makeshift masts, lacking yardarms and sails and not a ratline in sight!

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, France, Oct. 29 -- The German front in the southwestern Netherlands was disintegrating today under a series of hammer blows by Canadian, British, Polish and American troops and the opening of Antwerp and the defeat of the German Fifteenth Army south of the Meuse (Maas) River are in prospect.
LONDON, Oct. 29 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 29 -- In the event of a Nazi collapse, the German Navy will take Hitler away in an ocean-roving U-boat and keep him safe, declared a German submarine commander named Bender in a speech to German cadets in the Danish city of Esbjerg, according to private information from Copenhagen.

Lucille Cardin Crain's letter in THE TIMES, Oct. 17, defending continuation of the status quo in regard to our country's method of treaty ratification, fails to convince us. Many are the obstacles to, and great the necessity for, international cooperation -- not only to prevent war but also to solve many other problems involving two or more countries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- In view of predicted limited supplies of evaporated milk in October, November and December the Children's Bureau today advised mothers to take what the grocer has if their favorite brand is missing.

A Christmas message to all men and women in the armed forces from the Episcopal diocese of New York was issued yesterday by Bishop William T. Manning. He also provided a new prayer for use by members of the armed forces.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- A strange coalition of "isolationists" and "liberals" is forming in the Middle West in opposition to the Dumbarton Oaks Security Organization plan. The coalition is unplanned and each faction approaches the problem from a different angle, but the purpose seems to be the same: to defeat the plan when it comes before the Senate.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 168:
WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Holy Cross passed its way to a 26-14 victory over a scrappy United States Coast Guard Academy eleven today to remain among football's unbeaten.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Trading in rye continues to furnish a large part of the business on the Board of Trade here with an advance to a new high since last July in the forepart of last week, but the market developed an overbought condition and reacted to below the finish of last week.

In the remarks of Gen. James G. Harbord at the recent annual meeting of the New York Chapter of the Red Cross there was a pointed suggestion for all Americans. Said General Harbord, "We can't afford to coast now on the comfortable theory that with victory assured the need for real sacrifice has passed."

A bronze and granite memorial to Alfred E. Smith, with a life-size statue of the former Governor as its central figure, will be erected at the entrance to the Governor Smith Houses to be built on the lower East Side after the war, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.

ROME, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Predappio, close to the hilltop hamlet of Verano di Costa, where Benito Mussolini was born, has been occupied by Polish troops of the British Eighth Army, Allied Headquarters announced today as a cold wind and rain swept across the entire northern Italian front.
Mrs. James R. Offield of Chicago is at Hampshire House.
