Holders of Iowa Southern Utilities Company of Delaware 4 1/2 per cent sinking fund debentures due n 1966 have been notified that $200,000 of the bonds has been drawn for redemption on Dec. 1.

To New York State has been assigned a Sixth War Loan quota of $4,226,000,000, representing more than 30 per cent of the national goal of $14,000,000,000 and maintaining the State's position as the largest single financial backer of the war, it was announced yesterday by Frederick W. Gehle, State chairman of the War Finance Committee for New York.

In the old days a wife did not even presume to ask her husband how he was going to vote. She sat quietly at home and listened -- when it was permitted -- as he discussed political matters with an occasional guest qualified to give and take counsel on such lofty matters. She might, before election day, determine in this fashion how he was disposed to use his ballot.

One man was killed and another injured slightly by a patrolman's bullets yesterday morning outside 942 East 173d Street, the Bronx, where the policeman had gone to quell a disturbance shortly after 3 o'clock.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 29 -- In an old music hall off one of the main squares of Brussels this morning a group of men who share the terrible experience of having been imprisoned at Breendonck, worst concentration camp in Belgium, on the outskirts of the capital met to form a society that will carry into peacetime a bond forged among them by German cruelty.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically from Sofia and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

On Oct. 23 you published a letter from Herman A. Gray, a professor of mine at law school and one for whom I have the highest regard, dealing with the subject of life, accident and health insurance and the "Little Steel" formula.

National Airlines announced yesterday that upon delivery of the DC-4 airplanes it has ordered it will fly the great circle course between New York and Miami at a saving of 227 miles, and on a schedule of four hours and thirty-eight minutes as against the present schedules of eight hours.

As the annual meeting of the Child Welfare League's Board of Directors concluded its two-day session at the Gramercy Park Hotel yesterday Dr. Leonard W. Mayo, president, made the point that child welfare was not separate from national welfare, that children sank or swam with their families.

The prophecy of Czechoslovakia's rebirth, made by Johann Comenius, Seventeenth Century Czech patriot, was the theme of a French and Czech service held at the French Church of the Holy Spirit (Eglise du Saint-Esprit), 109 East Sixtieth Street, yesterday afternoon in commemoration of the twenty-sixth anniversary of the founding of the Czechoslovak Republic.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- Oneida County, which Wendell L. Willkie carried four years ago by 3,253, seems likely to go this year for Governor Dewey, Republican nominee, for President, by a larger plurality.

TACLOBAN, Philippines, Oct. 29 -- Tacloban celebrated today the first high mass since General MacArthur's troops came ashore, with prayers of thankfulness and petitions for final victory. The mass was celebrated in the 100-year-old Santo Nino Church, one of the largest of the Leyte Diocese.
A demand for commercial properties, especially garage buildings, in Brooklyn was indicated by sales and leases reported over the weekend.

LONDON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- A communique from Swedish defense staff headquarters early reported that formations of four-engined planes heading toward Finnish Lapland across northern Sweden were American, but a later communique said at least part of them were British.

BRAND, Germany, Oct. 29 (U.P.) -- As German shells dropped on these hills above Aachen, Jewish officers and men of the United States Army broadcast to their co-religionists beck home today the news that religious freedom has been restored in this small segment of Germany.

Mellon Securities Corporation heads the underwriting group which today will offer four series of securities of the Koppers Company, Inc., which is planning to absorb four subsidiaries, the Koppers Company, the Koppers Erecting Corporation, the Fuel Investment Associates and the Koppers United Company.

The role the synagogue must play in helping to reabsorb returning service men of the Jewish faith into their home communities and also in promoting inter-faith understanding, was stressed yesterday afternoon at an organizational meeting of a metropolitan branch of the National Federation of Jewish Men's Clubs.

That many service men are opposed to brand advertising has been revealed following publication of the first of a series of advertisements on such advertising sponsored by Fawcett Publications, the latter reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The goal of 15,000,000 pounds set by the churches, parishes and synagogues in the emergency collection of clothing for liberated Europe will be exceeded, Herbert H. Lehman, director general of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, announced today.

For something like twenty-five minutes against the Philadelphia Eagles at the Polo Grounds yesterday, the New York Giants had the entire flock simply fit to be tied by going into a 17 -- 3 lead over the team supposed to be the class of the Eastern half of the National Football League.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 29 -- The Argentine Government's proposal that its relations with other American Governments should be discussed by a conference of Foreign Ministers has so far been received throughout the hemisphere with official silence and has been the subject of little press comment.

Portia White, the young Negro contralto from Halifax who made an unusual impression at her debut here in Town Hall last March, appeared there again last night before an audience that filled the house, many of whose members probably were attracted by curiosity and a desire to be "in the know" concerning a possible big new musical personality.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- The conflict of authority between the Provisional Government and the National Council of Resistance that for weeks has seemed inevitable broke out today when the council formally took exception to the Government's declaration last night that the so-called Patriotic Guard must be disarmed and dissolved in the interest of order.

Thomas J. Watson, president of International Business Machines, was announced yesterday as chairman of a reception committee comprising some forty-three business leaders to greet foreign representatives coming here to attend the International Business Conference.

With four Broadway premieres to be inspected this week, first-nighters are facing quite a workout. First of the series is "No Way Out" opening tonight at the Cort. In this presentation Robert Keith figures as sponsor, co-director and leading player.

MOSCOW, Oct. 29 -- The Soviet public was informed today that its Government regarded Premier Mohammed Said of neighboring Iran as "disloyal and unfriendly" because of his Government's refusal to grant the northern Iranian oil concessions sought by the Soviet Union and will not in the future collaborate with Premier Said.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- A Dies subcommittee assailed today Sidney Hillman and the two Political Action Committees which he heads, declaring that the two organizations were the "rallying point for the Communist party and its allied groups and organizations to rise to power by taking control of a major political party."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Technological improvements and volume operations, already in sight, appear to assure attainment of a 3-cents-a-mile level of fares for air travel within ten years after the close of the war, Dr. J. Parker Van Zandt reported today in a study of "Civil Aviation and Peace" for the Brookings Institution.

It was with thought of Poland's struggle for existence and the destruction of Chopin's native city of Warsaw that Artur Rubinstein arranged a program exclusively of his countryman's music last night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Rubinstein prefaced the program proper with both the American and Polish national hymns, while the audience remained standing.

GENERAL HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Oct. 25 (Delayed) -- The Japanese bomb that killed Asahel (Ace) Bush, Associated Press war correspondent, in Tacloban today, also wounded Stanly Gunn of the Fort Worth Star Telegram and the Houston Chronicle, John Terry of the Chicago Daily News, who was knocked unconscious, and Clete Roberts of the Blue Network.

One argument made on the Republican side in this campaign is that the election of Mr. Dewey is essential to the restoration of good relations between the Executive and Congress. This has been emphasized as a matter of special importance from the point of view of ratification of the forthcoming peace treaties.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- A guide for buyers interested in the purchase of Government-owned surplus property has been compiled by the Small Business Committee of the United States Senate, Senator Tom Stewart of Tennessee announced today. Purpose of the "guide," he said, is to assure a "fair opportunity for small business" to participate in the sale of surpluses.

Addressing a special combined Reformation Day service of fourteen Lutheran churches in Manhattan, the Rev. Samuel McCrea Cavert, general secretary of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, declared yesterday that Protestantism, through its avowal of religious freedom, made "a dynamic contribution to the spirit of freedom in every other realm."

What, on paper, had figured to be a romp for the Brooklyn Tigers over the Boston Yanks at Ebbets Field yesterday failed to materialize. Perhaps it was because this National Football League game between victory-starved elevens was played on a gridiron and not on paper that the heavily-favored Flatbush forces suffered their fifth straight setback, but whatever the reason the underdog Yanks twice came from behind to triumph, 17 -- 14.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Russia has officially notified the United States that she will not participate in the international conference on civil aviation in Chicago the State Department confirmed today.

For this week, the heaviest of the local art season thus far, nine group exhibitions and twenty-three one-man shows are scheduled. The thirty-first annual of the Allied Artists of America opened yesterday at the New York Historical Society. Paintings, sculpture and other work in celebration of Na tional Art Week will be shown, beginning tomorrow, at the Architectural League, by members of the New York Chapter of the Artists Professional League.

The nineteenth annual world's championship rodeo in Madison Square Garden ended last night with the distribution of prize money totaling $115,000. In addition champions of the six major events received embossed saddles from Ned Irish, acting president of the Garden, while an audience of 15,000 cheered.

DETROIT, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings, opening their National Hockey League season before a crowd of 12,021 fans, defeated the Boston Bruins, 7 to 1, tonight, the second setback for Boston in two days.
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 29 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Army Air Force communique:
The following political broadcasts are scheduled for today:

TACLOBAN, Philippines, Oct. 24 (Delayed) -- It is three days since this little town with its prewar population of 31,000 was liberated by American troops and by now a virtually complete story of its treatment during the twenty-nine months of Japanese occupation has emerged.

Cotton prices in the domestic market last week fluctuated over a rather wide range, but net changes for the period as a whole were small. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 10 points to down 12 points from the level prevailing a week earlier.
The Regional War Labor Board has received its 50,000th voluntary wage adjustment application, Thomas L. Norton, the chairman, announced yesterday.

Brooklyn Prep, New York City's only unbeaten team, had its narrowest squeak yesterday when Mount St. Michael fought the Blue and White to a 13-to-13 standstill, before a capacity crowd of 8,000 on the Mount's field. Trailing 13 to 7, with three minutes to go, Mount St. Michael scored when Ken Oliveri crashed over from the 4 on a quarterback sneak after Howie Smith's lads had recovered a Brooklyn Prep fumble on the 18.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Oct. 29 -- As the Japanese defeat mounts Japanese official propaganda becomes increasingly tenacious. American and Philippine listeners here in Leyte laughed tonight when Tokyo Rose, broadcasting in English, said:

An international agreement and police force will fail to outlaw war if three essential conditions for world peace are not kept in the forefront of Catholic thought, Mrs. Mary Donlon, vice chairman of the State Industrial Board, yesterday told 1,200 persons attending the sixth annual communion breakfast of the Dongan Guild of New York State Employes at the Hotel Commodore.

On the fourth anniversary of the day when Greece rejected a three-hour surrender ultimatum by Italy and elected instead to fight, 2,500 Greek-Americans met yesterday in Manhattan Center to ask that the Allies extend full financial help to Greece, "not in the form of a business transaction, but as a deserved assistance to a nation that gave its all."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The national political situation and the rivalry between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations combine this week to confront the National War Labor Board with the delicate task of choosing between the disputing labor organizations on some outstanding issues.
ROME, Oct. 29 (AP) -- A communique:

ATHENS, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Greek guerrillas have seized the town of Platamona, forty-six miles southwest of the flaming Grecian port of Salonika and at the foot of the natural barrier formed by Mount Olympus, Patriot headquarters announced today.

Calling for true humility by Americans in their approach to world cooperation in the peace, the Rev. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared yesterday that the popular idea of what greatness means required a revision.
Two films, both of which will arrive Wednesday, compose the week's list of new attractions. The programs follow:

Opposition to the announced proposal of the Army to sell at auction 1,000 dog veterans of the K-9 Corps that are not needed further by the armed forces and whose former owners no longer have room for them was voiced yesterday by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals through its president, Alexander S. Webb.

Factory operations on civilian goods declined 11 per cent during September, 1944, as compared with the previous month, according to a report issued by the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers. The main reason, it is explained, was a lack of piece goods.

An investor has purchased the nine-story apartment house for thirty-eight families at 59 to 65 West Seventy-first Street from a syndicate headed by Irving Brodsky, attorney. Assessed at $275,000, the property is 81 by 102 feet and was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $219,450.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Although receipts of hogs at the markets increased last week, this failed to ease the tight situation in cash lard. Distributors were in the market for refined lard and paid full ceiling prices for the few tank cars offered. Soap manufacturers also bought rendered pork fat on a small scale.

Edison Harris, tenor, of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., gave his debut recital in the New York Times Hall yesterday afternoon, singing a program made up mostly of French and German numbers, with four in English at the close. The composers represented were Bach, Monteverde, Schubert, Faure, Chausson, Duparc, Trunk, Brahms, Scott, Shaw, Dunhill and Quilter.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 29 -- Twenty members of an Italian service unit stationed at Camp Kilmer, near here, were listed as absent without leave today, while thirty-eight others who had been absent without leave when a roll-call of the unit was taken on Saturday evening were confined to the camp stockade.

He who has to ride in the IRT Lexington Avenue express during rush hours is sure to be well received in heaven, for he has purged most of his sins on earth. The small number of accidents gives credit to the efficiency of the personnel as well as to the discipline of the public.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Washington Redskins today beat the Car-Pitts, 42 to 20, in a rough game enlivened by fights among the players. Police rushed onto the field to quell a budding free-for-all between the squads late in the first half and four players were ejected.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 29 -- David O. Selznick has bought the screen rights to the Rev. Edward F. Murphy's novel, "The Scarlet Lily," a story of Mary Magdalene. He plans to film it early in the spring with Ingrid Bergman in the starring role.

Expressing regret that he was unable to be present, President Roosevelt sent a telegram last night to Irving Geist, philanthropist, who was guest of honor at a testimonial dinner given by the Home and Hospital of the Daughters of Israel at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Communique 204:

Herbert Hoover signed the document calling for the removal of Wendell L. Willkie from the Republican party, Senator James M. Mead charged last night in challenging either Mr. Hoover or Governor Dewey to deny that they were linked in "an undercover campaign" to achieve this end.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 29 -- The Norwegian Foreign Minister, Trygve Lie, and the Minister of Justice, Terje Wold, arrived here today from London to discuss a number of questions pending between Sweden and Norway in a series of "informal talks."

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Withdrawal of Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell from command of the China-Burma-India theatre appeared here today to have pulled the props from under American activity in this area.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Vice President Wallace today charged Governor Dewey with "double talk" in his campaign for the Presidency.

A triple tie among Edward S. Jackson Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., Gustaf Gustafson of Brooklyn and Irving Stein of The Bronx for first place, each with a score of 6 -- 1, marked the close of play in the eighth round of the annual tournament for the national amateur championship last night at the Marshall Chess Club in Manhattan and the United States Chess Federation headquarters in Brooklyn.

St. John's Prep recorded its fourth victory in six starts by turning back Cardinal Hayes, 20 to 0, yesterday on the winner's field before a crowd of 7,000. After a scoreless first quarter, St. John's struck for a touchdown at the beginning of the second period when Al Scallon intercepted a pass and raced 45 yards to the 5.

MOSCOW, Oct. 29 -- The United Nations armistice with Bulgaria, made public today, requires that the former Axis satellite give up the portions of Greece and Yugoslavia that she acquired in April, 1941, and as the first step in making reparations, to make available immediately food for the relief of the population of Greek and Yugoslav territories that suffered as a result of Bulgarian aggression.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- The Moscow radio announced tonight that Russia would not participate in the international conference on civil aviation in Chicago because "countries like Switzerland, Portugal and Spain, which for many years have conducted a pro-Fascist policy hostile to the Soviet Union, have also been invited."

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- The RAF pounced on the 35,000-ton battleship Tirpitz at dawn this morning after having shadowed her along the ragged northern Norwegian coast for two days and hit the last battleship of the German Navy with at least one 12,000-pound "earthquake" bomb.

ALBANY, Oct. 29 -- Governor Dewey mapped over the week-end the strategy of his final week of campaigning and busied self with his speeches preparatory to his departure for Buffalo on Tuesday and his first invasion of New England Wednesday.
Vesuvius erupted and Mt. Olympus almost toppled Saturday on the most exciting day of action college football has provided in 1944.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- A partita for organ and strings, by Walter Piston, received its premiere here tonight at the third of the four concerts arranged by the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation in the Library of Congress for its tenth festival which honors the eightieth birthday tomorrow of Mrs. Coolidge, distinguished patron of chamber music.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Country offerings of cash corn increased considerably last week as a result of continued favorable weather conditions and the approach of the end of the soy bean harvest. The latter has received special attention from farmers this season and husking of corn has been permitted to lag in consequence.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Monday, Oct. 30 -- The Japanese apparently are seeking to evacuate Leyte and speedy American torpedo boats in the Ormoc Bay area off the west coast of the island are breaking up their attempts. Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today that two-thirds of Leyte and all of Samar Island of the Philippines are effectively under our control.

Supreme Court Justice George Frankenthaler praised Wendell L. Willkie as "a champion of freedom and justice for all" at a memorial service yesterday in the Refugee Temple, 134th Street and Seventh Avenue. Sponsored by the African Academy of Arts and Research, the meeting was attended by 200 persons.

Bishop William T. Manning, preaching yesterday morning at a consecration service in the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany, York Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street, emphasized the need for church leadership after the war. He declared that there could be no true and lasting peace without "obedience to God's eternal moral law."

LONDON, Monday, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Russian troops who fought their way fifty miles across mountainous eastern Czechoslovakia yesterday occupied the strategic junction of Cop, on the upper Tisza River, cutting the enemy's last rail escape route out of northeastern Hungary.

The popular belief that next to pursuing the girls in every port a sailor likes nothing better than to spin tall yarns of the sea appears to have been a fallacy after all. At least that was the discouraged opinion yesterday of the United Seamen's Service, which certainly should know its men of the sea.

Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, announced yesterday that he was considering a new plan designed to establish a consumer services division as a permanent post-war city agency. After studying the plan, submitted to him by Mrs. Nathaniel Singer, director of consumer services for the New York CDVO, Mr. Whalen said he would present it to Mayor La Guardia in the near future.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 29 -- The United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association concluded its twenty-third annual convention today at the Bond Hotel, with the knowledge that organized skiing and resorts will bend every effort to maintain and have all facilities ready for "our boys in the service upon their return to normal living."

Although the war bulletins reported on Wednesday our fleet's great victory in the Pacific, last week's financial markets declined. The average of stocks went on Friday to the lowest of October, losing more than 2 points from the preceding week.

In an election year in which women are expected to cast more than 60 per cent of the total vote, more women than ever before are actively campaigning in the political field, according to a survey of party organizations, nonpartisan and independent voters' groups completed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- A gift of seventy-one Italian paintings and twenty-six pieces of sculpture that will make the Italian collection of the National Gallery of Art one of the most comprehensive in the world, rivaling those of Florence, London, Paris and Berlin, was announced yesterday by David E. Finley, director of the gallery.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- There has been some stirring of activity in the stock markets here, accompanied by a generally more cheerful tone. Although the return of Prime Minister Winston Churchill from Moscow provided some stimulus, the changed sentiment was due principally to the breaking of the lull on all the main war fronts.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- The admittedly small Bronxville For Roosevelt Committee was compelled to move today from its headquarters for two days, a vacant store at 110 Pondfield Road, to the home of Mrs. Frank H. Gervasi of 36 Homesdale Road, who believes that outside pressure in this overwhelmingly Republican community had forced the owner to decide that the building was no longer available for political heretics.

In a final effort to win support among New York City's 3,226,000 registered voters, supporters of President Roosevelt and his Republican challenger, Governor Dewey, have arranged to bring leading spokesmen for each party here for a series of appearances in the closing week of the campaign.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 29 -- Paced by Fullback Larry Higgins, who scored two touchdowns and tacked on two extra points, the St. Cecilia High School eleven gained its twenty-first consecutive triumph by defeating the St. Francis Xavier eleven of New York today, 32 to 0.
The Most Rev. J. Francis A. McIntyre, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, pontificated at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday in observance of the Feast of Christ the King.

EN ROUTE WITH THE PRESIDENT, Oct. 29 -- President Roosevelt extended the personal appearances of his tour to a seventh State today, giving a talk at Clarksburg, W. Va., where John W. Davis formally accepted the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1924, and making a fleeting appearance at Grafton, W. Va., where he waved to a large crowd at the station as his special train made a service stop.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UP) -- The text of the terms of the Bulgarian armistice as announced jointly by the United States, Great Britain and the Soviet Union follows:

Encore, a monthly pocket-size magazine that republishes prose and poetry of the great writers of all time, has been purchased by the owners of The Saturday Review of Literature, according to J. R. Cominsky, executive vice president of The Saturday Review Associates, Inc.

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, Oct. 28 (Delayed) -- Whatever distinction there might have been between the men drawn into the United States Army by the draft and those already in has utterly disappeared during the six months they have fought together in Italy.

Mack Harrell, the Metropolitan baritone, maintained a high level of accomplishment at his recital given yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. His singing boasted expert musicianship and was projected with uncommon grasp of style and interpretive insight.

EN ROUTE WITH THE PRESIDENT, Oct. 29 -- President Roosevelt extended the personal appearances of his tour to a seventh State today, giving a talk at Clarksburg, W. Va., where John W. Davis formally accepted the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1924, and making a fleeting appearance at Grafton, W. Va., where he waved to a large crowd at the station as his special train made a service stop.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UP) -- The text of the terms of the Bulgarian armistice as announced jointly by the United States, Great Britain and the Soviet Union follows:

WITH THE FIFTH ARMY, in Italy, Oct. 28 (Delayed) -- Whatever distinction there might have been between the men drawn into the United States Army by the draft and those already in has utterly disappeared during the six months they have fought together in Italy.

Mack Harrell, the Metropolitan baritone, maintained a high level of accomplishment at his recital given yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. His singing boasted expert musicianship and was projected with uncommon grasp of style and interpretive insight.

Special services for Girl Scout Sunday were held yesterday in churches and synagogues in observance of the opening of annual Girl Scouts Week, in which 30,000 Girl Scouts in New York will participate.

Sales of the General Foods Corporation for the first nine months of this year rose to a new high record of $208,805,658 and compared with the $181,280,507 volume reported for the corresponding period of 1943, Clarence Francis, chairman, will announce today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Favorable war news and a lack of aggressive support resulted in a lower range of wheat prices last week on the Board of Trade, and although December and May showed resistance to pressure the new crop months were under pressure and the September delivery sold at a new seasonal low.

Last week many of us read in this paper an account of an interesting survey of national food habits conducted by the Department of Agriculture's Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics. In this study, comparing what we ate in 1942 with what was consumed in 1936, many changes for the better were noted.

James S. Adams, general chairman of the sixty-third annual United Hospital Campaign, announced yesterday that the campaign had passed the million-dollar mark by $22,640. Contributions from thirteen foundations and trusts, amounting to $56,150, were announced as follows:

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 29 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz made his report to America today on the second battle of the Philippine Sea and the action will stand as one of the outstanding naval events of history.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 29 -- The raw steel rate for the nation dropped last week 1 point to 96 per cent of rated capacity and order volume continued to show signs of fluctuating, although the trend in steel buying was downward, according to trade reports. Some mills indicated an increase in orders, but it was pointed out that such a condition is not significant when previous or subsequent periods offset such expansions.

DETROIT, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers counted two first-half touchdowns here today to score their sixth straight National Pro Football League victory, 14 to 0, over the Detroit Lions before a crowd of 30,844.
LONDON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UP) -- large majority of the newspaper and radio correspondents who accompanied President Roosevelt on his seven-State campaign trip believe he will be re-elected.

The sudden and unexpected relief last week of "Uncle Joe" Stilwell from his multiple and important commands in the China- Burma-India theatre emphasizes the manifold difficulties in that part of the world and may mark the development of a new phase of strategy there.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 29 (AP) -- J.Z. Howard, managing editor of The Memphis Press-Scimitar issued tonight the following statement in connection with Vice President Wallace's comment on the paper's report of Governor Dewey's Seattle speech:

Price increases for a number of farm products caused the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices (1926=100 to rise from the previous week's level of 113.47 to a new all-time high of 113.53. The raw materials index rose from 117.6 to 117.7 because of higher prices for eggs, apples and spring wheat, which were only partly offset by price declines for oats, cotton and winter wheat.

Senator Robert F. Wagner charged yesterday that "the Republican attitude in Congress toward the Government worker has been shameful" and that under the administration of Governor Dewey in this State "the breakdown of the merit system has almost become an open scandal."

"WE should strive for the peace and prosperity of all mankind, and if we fall short of our final goal, as we may, we shall yet do a great amount of good for a great many people." This counsel of reasoned, practical idealism is to be found in "An American Peace,"* by Neil MacNeil, a reasoned, practically idealistic book.

EINDHOVEN, Holland, Oct. 29 -- All the scarred highways running east in France, Belgium and Holland lead to the battleline. But when the front is reached at last it is neither definite nor clearly visible. In this area it is like the raveled ends of a long rope spread fanwise from the estuary of the Schelde to Belfort Gap.
An imaginative collection of dresses, suits and coats opened the Elizabeth Arden Fashion Floor yesterday afternoon.
A new edition of Richard Llewellyn's "None But the Lonely Heart" will be issued today by Macmillan in connection with the release of the movie version of the novel.

Anne O'Hare McCormick in her article about France in your Oct. 11 issue makes a statement which needs some clarification. She says: "France is a rich country with an extraordinarily well-balanced and self-sufficient economy."

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 30 -Two Hungarian couriers and the Szalasi-appointed "Minister Designate" to Berne, were arrested in Zurich early this afternoon and brought to the capital in custody, where they are being held on charges of burglary and usurpation of official functions, following a complaint lodged by the Horthy appointee, Baron Charles Bothmer, Hungarian Minister to Berne, with the Swiss Federal police.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 30 -- District Court Judge Marcelino Romani issued an order today for the arrest of Gov. Rexford G. Tugwell's entire Cabinet for contempt of court in their continuing to spend the $16,000,000 fund of the war emergency program.

OTTAWA, Oct. 30 -- The withdrawal of the Russian delegation from the International Civil Aviation Conference following the announcement of the British Commonwealth program at Montreal has, it is considered here, thrown the latter proposals in high relief as the only effective solution along international lines that the Chicago meeting will have before it.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Shoe retailers and manufacturers attending the National Shoe Fair here paused today to hear Eric A. Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, warn industry against the rising tide of collectivism.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- The grain markets were somewhat unsettled today on the Board of Trade, with a reduced volume of business generally. A feature was the declining tendency that developed in bids for No. 2 yellow cash corn for deferred shipment from the country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Office of Price Administration tightened its sugar rationing regulations today in an effort "to make it easier" to bring enforcement proceedings against wholesalers and retailers whose sugar inventories are illegal.

Breda was the key city guarding the German escape route from southwestern Holland. With Allied troops driving through the historic town and up the rail line toward the great Moerdijk Bridge, all enemy forces south of the Maas River are thrown into reverse. Their slow and stubborn retreat now becomes a scramble by ferry, bridge and plane to get behind the broad Maas estuary as best they can.

Using 1943 as the base year, a survey by the National Paper Box Manufacturers Association estimates the trend of gross sales in the soap and cosmetics industry as showing a gradual rise over the succeeding five years.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- After a three-and-a-half-hour plenary session the National Council of Resistance took a conciliatory attitude toward the Government tonight in the conflict over the so-called Patriotic Guards.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -Representative Edith Nourse Rogers, Republican, of Massachusetts, demanded today an end to what she called the Army's "filtering" of news before it reaches the soldiers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -Relief from the printing paper shortage cannot be expected before mid-1945, the War Production Board announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 (AP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the proposal of the American Gas and Power Company to sell all of the common stock of the Bangor (Me.) Gas Company to Irwin E. and Sidney A. Kane, Providence, R.I., for $122,500 plus net earnings available for common stock from Aug. 31 to the date of sale.

Dr. Joseph M. Skrypski has purchased from Investment Associates, Inc., the two-family dwelling at 2756 Hudson Boulevard, Jersey City, N.J., which he will occupy as offices and residence. J.I. Kislak, Inc., also was the broker in the sale of the two-family house at 252 Hancock Avenue, Jersey City Heights, by Paul Newmann to Wilhelmina Seekamp.

Approximately 20,000,000 men and women in the armed forces have been admitted to Loew theatres at reduced rates, it was announced by the company yesterday. Of this number 19,685,710 uniformed men and women were admitted between July 7, 1941, and Aug. 30, 1944.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Tuesday, Oct. 31 -- American troops drove an iron-tipped spearhead across the northern end of Leyte Island today after capturing Jaro, a mid-island Japanese stronghold, and a final showdown battle appeared imminent along Carigara Bay.

In a novel survey of teen-age opinion on questions of the day that in large part have been stumping their elders, 288 boys and girls ranging in age from 14 to 18, yesterday expressed in no uncertain terms how they would go about curing the ills of the world.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, France, Oct. 30 -- The Allies' line is swinging forward on a fifty-mile front west of 's Hertogenbosch in the Netherlands, driving some 40,000 Germans toward the Meuse (Mass) River, while on the extreme left of the British and Canadian front to the north and south of the Schelde Estuary the final stages of the operations for the clearing of the approaches to Antwerp have begun successfully.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- Robert E. Hannegan, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, declared tonight that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate, had himself done much to insure the re-election of President Roosevelt.

American prisoners of war in Germany will receive mail from home much sooner as a result of a new plan just put into effect by the Provost Marshal General's office, it was announced yesterday by the New York Red Cross Chapter, 315 Lexington Avenue.
LONDON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

A general court-martial composed of thirteen officers started yesterday to hear evidence against Capt. Joseph (Joe) Gould, who until he entered the Army two years ago was manager for James J. Braddock, former heavyweight boxing champion.

In a building that stands where 119 years ago the original Delmonico's restaurant was opened, 3,000 Catholics employed in the financial district paused yesterday to worship in the temporary Chapel of Our Lady of Victory, 23 William Street.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 30 -- A decree that considerably tightens the immigration of foreigners to Mexico was published today in the Official Gazette. The law, which was signed by Miguel Aleman, Secretary of the Interior, gives favored treatment to nationals of the Western Hemisphere countries and of Spain, but restricts the immigration of citizens of other nations.

The new Ballet International, of which the Marquis de Cuevas is the artistic director and moving spirit, made its bow to the world last night in its own theatre, the International (formerly the Park) at Columbus Circle, after months of preparation. The report this morning, unhappily, is not so good.
PARIS, Oct. 30 -- Stephane Lauzanne, editor in chief of the Matin for many years, was sentenced today to twenty years' solitary confinement and the confiscation of all his possessions.

While the textile situation here and in Canada promises to continue most difficult from the standpoint of supply in relation to demand, "the point of real hardship will not be reached," Robert Chisholm, in charge of wholesale and retail distribution for the Wartime Prices and Trade Board in Canada, said here yesterday.

KANDY, Ceylon, Oct. 30 -- British and Chinese forces, moving southward in what appears to be a major new offensive in north Burma, have driven to within twenty-two and eighteen airline miles, respectively, of the important communication cities of Katha and Bhamo, a Southeast Asia Command communique announced today.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 30 (UP) -- Senator Harry S. Truman said today that the foreign policy record of Senator David I. Walsh, Demo at, of Massachusetts, was not unlike that of the eight isolationist Republican Senators whom he asked Gov. Thomas E. Dewey to repudiate, but said he believed that the Democrats had "a chance to reform" Senator Walsh.

SA DIEGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- How two women marines and eleven crew members of a Navy Liberator which crashed at sea existed for four days in Robinson Crusoe style on a deserted island near the eastern coast of Baja California before being rescued by Mexican fishermen was told today by the Navy.

Much confusion might be eliminated from grade labeling terminology by dropping the term "informative labeling," it is revealed in a survey conducted by Dr. Kenneth Dameron of the College of Commerce, Ohio State University.

As American forces wrested Pacific islands from the Japanese two American actors visited them and gave shows, Lew Parker, comedian, said yesterday at USO-Camp Show Headquarters, 8 West Fortieth Street. His companion on the 62,000-mile, seventeen-month tour was Jack Heller, singer, who stands 5 feet 1 inch. Mr. Parker is a six-footer.

Wide differences in the ratio of advertising costs to sales exist in different industries and trades, with the range being from six-one hundredths of a cent for the shipbuilding industry to a maximum of 13.94 cents of the drug and medicine manufacturer's sales dollar, according to a study by the Federal Trade Commission, entitled "Advertising as a Factor in Distribution," which was released yesterday.

ROME, Oct. 30 -- The secret criminal organization known as the Mafia has sprung up again in Sicily in a new and vigorous form, with hold-ups and kidnappings becoming a common occurrence, according to latest reports from Palermo.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization and Reconversion, appealed tonight to the American people not to vote for a change in administration "which would inevitably delay the winning of the war and jeopardize the peace for which our boys are fighting and dying."

In post-war planning for children, American communities will get together as they never have done before, judging by comments from officers and members of the board of the Child Welfare League of America, Inc., attending their recent annual meeting in New York City.
LONDON, Oct. 30 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Tuesday, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The battleship Maryland, originally damaged in the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, was torpedoed during the Saipan invasion last June, but was repaired again at Pearl Harbor in the record time of "less than forty-nine days" and rejoined the fleet in time to help defeat the Japanese Navy in the Battle of the Philippines last week, the Navy reported today.

ATHENS, Oct. 30 (U.P.) -- Greek patriots reported tonight that Salonika had been liberated from the Germans. The report came from officials of Elas [fighting arm of the National Liberation Front] but it was not confirmed here by British headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- A "declaration of gratitude," signed by the President of the United States and other high officials, was presented tonight to Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge for her gifts to the Library of Congress in furtherance of chamber music.

Yesterday's special session of the Legislature did its expected good deed by agreeing unanimously to extend voting hours from 7 to 9 P.M. next Tuesday. With State registration, including service voters, 298,967 above the totals of 1940, with civilian registration alone not far under the 1940 level, and with every promise of heavy voting, nothing less would have been fair.

The editorial comments in your issue of Oct. 14 on "National Income Guesses" afforded timely support to a motion which was adopted by the council of the American Institute of Accountants at its recent annual meeting, and which called for the appointment of a special committee to study the terminology and methods of compilation used in the preparation of statements of so-called "national income.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -Although the Hatch act requires filing of campaign expenditure reports ten days before the election, only thirty-two reports of Senatorial candidates were on record today with the upper house.

Tractors already are replacing Sherman tanks, at least in the city's toy departments. Spokesmen for the toy industry declared yesterday that in this year's Christmas stock, which will be better if not bigger than a year ago, the trend is definitely away from war toys.

Close bidding marked the competitive sale yesterday by the Metropolitan Edison Company of $37,000,000 of its securities. The offering consisted of $24,500,000 of first mortgage bonds due in 1974 and 125,000 shares of $100 par value cumulative preferred stock.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 30 -- Swedish shipowners with more than 1,000,000 tons of shipping ready for post-war competition were shocked today by the Riksdag's first open debate on foreign policy since the war began.

The three outstanding exponents of football's three basic offensive systems -- the T, so much in vogue these days; the single wing and the double wing -- took the stand yesterday at the luncheon meeting of the Football Writers to present their cases.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -President Roosevelt today wired anniversary greetings to President Ismet Inonu of Turkey. His message said:
To help discharged war veterans find their way back into civilian pursuits and pleasures, the Museum of Modern Art has opened a Veterans Art Center at 681 Fifth Avenue, it was announced yesterday.

The United States Senate to be elected in November will face responsibilities such as no other Senate in many years has been called upon to meet. Before that Senate will come the peace treaties ultimately to be signed with new Governments of Germany and Japan.

MOSCOW, Oct. 30 -- The Polish Committee of National Liberation today indirectly informed the Polish regime of Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk in London that settlement of the Polish question was possible only if there were full acceptance of the agrarian land reform decree and if the Constitution of 1921 were substituted for that of 1935, under which the London Poles at present hold power.

When the curtain rises at 8:30 this evening at the National the Theatre Guild will usher in its twenty-seventh subscription season with "Embezzled Heaven." starring Ethel Barrymore. For the National the star has a sentimental attachment, since that is where she had a long engagement as the Welsh schoolmistress in "The Corn Is Green."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Stephen T. Early, White House secretary, cast new doubts today upon the likelihood of President Roosevelt's return to Ohio to supplement his "slow-down" passage through Lima last Saturday en route to Chicago.
The Loft Candy Corporation has leased the entire three-story building at 164-11 Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, from Sim-Ber Realty Company through Albert M. Greenfield Co.
The Kraeuter Trio, which has three transcontinental tours to its credit, made its New York debut last night at the New York Times Hall before an appreciative audience.

LONDON, Tuesday, Oct. 31 -The Red Army, in a new major offensive aimed at Budapest, attacked across the Tisza River at dawn yesterday with masses of tanks, planes and artillery on a wide front fifty miles from the imperiled Hungarian capital, Berlin announced last night.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Before the Matin became German-controlled, Lauzanne was a professional advocate of French-American friendship. In the past two years his editorials have been among the more virulent in attacking Americans.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -Comment of those mentioned by Governor Bricker follows:

The Atlantic Refining Company and its subsidiaries earned almost twice as much in the first nine months of this year as they did in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the statement of operations mailed to stockholders yesterday.

DETROIT, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Gov. John Bricker, seeking to show a tie-up between the New Deal and a "foreign influence," declared tonight that a secretary to President Roosevelt was listed among Federal employes with "subversive records."

ALBANY, Oct. 30 -- Albany County, heavily Democratic since 1922, and the only up-State county to be consistently in the Democratic party's column since that year, is expected to give a large plurality to President Roosevelt, but probably a little less than he received four years ago.

Latin-American countries, by supplying large quantities of their products to the United States and other nations allied against the Axis, have accumulated gold and foreign exchange in this country and abroad of more than $3,000,000,000, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York reports in its current issue of the Guaranty Survey.

A divided Class D event constituted the main attraction on the Empire City program at Jamaica yesterday. The card was hardly an attractive one, but its lack of allure did not matter much, since 20,842 fans turned out for the sport and bet $2,091,412, anyway.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 30 -- Several hundred thousand men, a high proportion of them still possessing arms, played an active part in the Belgian underground during the German occupation. They do not constitute an element in politics, as in France, but this might happen if the Government did not meet their two primary demands.

The stock market followed yesterday the pattern that it had set for Mondays during the last month and went into slightly lower ground. Marked by spiritless trading, stocks made a feeble attempt to hold the firm line established on Saturday.

Two weeks ago the playing personnel and coaching staff at N.Y.U., having suffered through one-sided defeats by Lafayette and Temple, were wondering when, if ever, the Violet football team would break into the scoring column. No one was discouraged, but it wasn't much fun being trampled over, even if this was a young, inexperienced squad going through the noble experiment of restoring the gridiron sport to University Heights.
Distribution of the new basic A gasoline ration books will start at 3:30 P.M. today in 110 New York City public schools.
PARIS, Oct. 30 -- Mgr. Albert Dutoit, Bishop of Arras, was sent to an internment camp today by order of the Prefect of the Pas-de-Calais Department at the instigation of resistance groups.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Chesapeake Ohio Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to sell $3,600,000 of serial equipment trust certificates, to be dated Nov. 15, the proceeds to be used, with other funds, to purchase 1,250 fifty-ton steel hopper cars from the American Car and Foundry Company and five freight locomotives from the Lima Locomotive Works, at a cost of $4,658,373.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The CIO Political Action Committee and the National Citizens PAC presented figures to the House Clerk today indicating joint expenditures of $883,616 and receipts of $735,689 up to Oct. 26.

ALBANY, Oct. 30 -- Both houses of the State Legislature, convened in extraordinary session at the call of Governor Dewey, unanimously passed this afternoon a bill lengthening by two hours the time for civilian voting on election day, Nov. 7. The new hours were fixed at from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 30 -- Fifty-eight former Italian prisoners of war were under questioning at Camp Kilmer near here this afternoon to determine why they went absent without leave on Saturday and scattered to points as far distant as New York City.
KANDY, Ceylon, Oct. 30 (UP) -- A communique:

SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 30 (U.P.) -- Gen. Sir Thomas Blamey, Australian Commander in Chief and commander of Allied land forces in the Southwest Pacific, said today that an estimated 90,000 Japanese troops already had been by-passed by recent advances and warned that hard and bitter fighting would be required to root them out.

I have just read The United Press report of the press conference which was held in Montreal Oct. 18 and which was published in your paper the next day. Since my statements are not correctly recorded in The United Press report, I ask that my viewpoint may be properly construed on a matter so vital to us as our relations with the United States of America.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (U.P.) -- Players on the second, third and fourth-place clubs in the 1944 National and American League pennant races received their share of world series receipts today.
Football turns into the second half of the season this week, and for many teams that have been dependent upon Navy V-12 personnel it is a new season that November ushers in.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, France, Oct. 30 -- Along most of the Western Front the war has gone static. But it is not a stalemate war. The German armies are doing their best to dig in and make it one, but in spite of the mud, the cold and our long supply lines our armies are determined that the enemy shall not have a chance to use the winter to his own advantage.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Russia's absence from the international conference on civil aeronautics will be regretted, but negotiations wth Russia on this subject will be continued through bilateral talks, Edward R. Stettinnius Jr., Under Secretary of State, said today.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, officially opening the civilian Christmas shopping season, yesterday bought fifteen toys in fifteen minutes at Arnold Constable Co., Fifth Avenue and Fortieth Street.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- French women do not like uniforms. Their ultrafemininity rebels at tailored serge and low heels. However, on the streets of Paris and throughout the provinces Army women in tailored navy blue have been appearing.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Tuesday, Oct. 31 -- Last night the long-awaited typhoon hit Leyte. It arrived without notice and as typhoons go it was a mild one. Wind lashed the rain laterally at only seventy miles an hour and it lasted a far shorter time than a big typhoon.

Drawing his adjourned game with Thomas Mahon of Brooklyn from the eighth round at the Marshall Chess Club, Irving Stein, secretary of the Bronx-Empire City Chess Club, yesterday moved up into the lead, with a score of 6 1/2-1 1/2, in the annual tournament for the national amateur championship sponsored by the United States Chess Federation.

Bronislaw Huberman, the veteran violinist, made his first local appearance of the season in recital at Carnegie Hall last night. Despite some uneven playing, the concert found Mr. Huberman in excellent form, tackling an arduous program with zest and vitality.
THE weekly Eating-and-Talking Festival of the Football Writers Association at the Toots Shor A.C. yesterday found the coaches in both good appetite and good voice -which is not at all unusual.

The recognizable face of civilized Europe begins to rise as the dirty waters of nazism recede, just as the earth reappeared after the flood described in the Book of Genesis. In a field near a brick factory, above Aachen, last Sunday, American soldiers of the Jewish faith held a service in honor of Jews who had suffered under the Nazi rule.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Facing a barrage of questions at a National Press Club luncheon today, Sidney Hillman, chairman of the CIO Political Action Committee, issued a "challenge" to "anyone" to prove that he or any of his executive board associates had ever had any dealings with the Communist party.

Revision of the Maximum Export Price Regulation by the Office of Price Administration to allow for adjustment of prices in effect at time of delivery will not cause any spurt in textile exports, exporters said yesterday.

The thirteen-story store and office building at 20-24 Vesey Street, formerly occupied by The New York Post, has been sold by the Mutual Life Insurance Company to an investing client of Harry Mabel, attorney. Isaac B. Wakeman was the broker.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The United States Government will not discourage a meeting of American Foreign Ministers to consider the Argentine question, or any other issue, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Acting Secretary of State, told a news conference today.

General Motors Corporation delivered during the third quarter of 1944 war materials to a value of $923,322,883, bringing the nine months' total to $2,964,723,350, it was announced yesterday by Alfred P. Slosh Jr., chairman. This compares with $927,479,569 and $2,525,280,753 respectively in the third quarter and first nine months of 1943.

There are a good many abbreviated households in the city, if we are to judge by the number of women who took all the available seating and aisle space in Macy's Home Center yesterday to watch a demonstration on twosome cookery given by Mrs. Lily Haxworth Wallace.

Why do not the combined networks set up a round-the-clock pronunciation service for their news broadcasters? Thus if a new tongue-twister crops up, be it in Lithuania or the South Pacific, the broadcaster would have only to refer to the language authority and within the span of a telephone call he would be able at least to approximate the right pronunciation.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 30 -- The "Free State" of Maryland, whose electoral vote, now numbering eight, has been with the winner of every Presidential race for fifty-two years, finds itself the scene of a nip-and-tuck battle this year which, conceivably, could end in favor of either President Roosevelt or Governor Dewey on Nov. 7.

The community, even more than the family, is accountable for juvenile delinquents, Arthur H Crowl, assistant special agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, declared yesterday at the opening of the annual fund campaign of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Net earnings of Marshall Field Co. for the third quarter of 1944 were $1,050,990, compared with $1,023,588 for the corresponding quarter of 1943, Hughston M. McBain, the president, reported today to stockholders.

ALBANY, Oct. 30 -- Governor Dewey, starting out tomorrow on the final week of his quest of the Presidency, has added two States to the schedule of a strenuous and concentrated drive. His tour will take him Thursday into Maryland and Pennsylvania, thus making his schedule cover speeches and appearances in ten cities in four States, with the huge Madison Square Garden rally in New York City Saturday night as the key event.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in English from Chungking to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:
LONDON, Oct. 30 -- The stock markets here opened the week quietly, but the tone was cheerful and there were a number of bright spots.

Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, relieved of his command in China, Burma and India, before leaving Chungking on Oct. 21 made a final swift tour of some of the military bases in his command and then flew directly toward Washington in his silver-colored transport plane facetiously dubbed "Uncle Joe's Chariot."

OLD Man Post, who had fit agin the French and the Injuns and Burgoyne and his men, couldn't get the hang of being a farmer nohow. There didn't seem much use in pulling stumps and breaking his back over crops when there were critters to trap and game to shoot. It was getting so a man could hardly draw an easy breath, what with neighbors so nigh there was no dodging them.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Maritime "M" Award for achievement in production for the Victory Fleet has been awarded to the following:
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted in English by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Pete Cawthon, coach of the Brooklyn Tigers for the past year and a half, yesterday tendered his resignation to General Manager Tom Gallery to take effect immediately. Just who Cawthon's successor will be was not made known, but the presumption is that his two assistants, Frank Bridges, end coach, and Ed Kubale, line coach, will finish the season jointly in charge of the Tigers.

The natural thing these last few weeks, whenever the eye lights on the names of several States in a row, has been to start adding up electoral votes. It happened again yesterday in reading the summary of Admiral Nimitz's report on the great naval victory in Philippine waters.

Prices of cotton futures closed yesterday 3 to 6 points lower than Saturday's final quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange after opening 2 to 4 points lower in a day in which fluctuations were insignificant.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 30 -Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, depicted the New Deal Administration as "no true friend of the laboring man" at a rally at the Masonic Temple tonight. He ridiculed his Democratic opponent, Senator Robert F. Wagner, for the latter's acceptance of the support of Sidney Hillman's Political Action Committee, and other left-wing elements.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 30 (AP) - -Communique 205:

The Argentine Government has offered to place its case for recognition by the other American republics before a meeting of Pan-American Foreign Ministers. Good suggestions often can come from poor sources. On its face such a meeting to discuss such a joint problem would be in order.
Army's unbeaten football horde replaced Notre Dame as the kingpin in the collegiate world in a poll of 101 sports writers by The Associated Press yesterday.
ROME, Oct. 30 (AP) -- A communique:

Bill Goldbeck, Mount Kisco, and Phil Turnesa, Elmwood, scored 36, 39 -- 75 to annex the annual Scotch foursome championship of the Metropolitan P. G. A. at the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Flushing yesterday. Goldbeck won with Alec Watson, Hudson River, at Gedney a year ago, and Turnesa was runner-up with Pat Cici, Salisbury.

Tenants' complaints to the rent control division of the Office of Price Administration here about the failure of landlords to redecorate reached a peak during October, Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of the OPA, revealed yesterday.
Following is the text of Mr. Byrnes' speech as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Federal Trade Commission today ordered an investigation under the Export Trade Act of two New York organizations, Electrical Apparatus Export Association, 70 Pine Street, and its member companies, and Carbon Black Export, Inc., 505 Fifth Avenue, to determine whether they were engaging in illegal practices in restraint of trade.

Earl Wild, pianist, of Pittsburgh, who has played with orchestras under distinguished conductors including Toscanini and Rodzinski and who was honorably discharged from service in the United States Navy last summer, gave his first New York recital last night in Town Hall.

Though the de Gaulle Government has been recognized by the United States and others of the United Nations, evidence of internal discord continues to appear. As is natural, there is some friction between the Frenchmen who fought for France outside the country and those who fought for France inside the country.

A 6-year-old connoisseur of festivities stood in the center of the room munching an apple and watching the hubbub going on around him with a critical look in his eyes. He didn't like the party and he made no bones about it.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 169:

When Japan embarked on her war for the conquest of Asia and Oceania she proclaimed herself the champion of all Asiatics and called upon them to rally around her in a "holy war" for the destruction of the western Powers With all the arts of propaganda, drawing prestige from the initial success of her arms, she sought to pit the whole Orient against the Occident, to rouse race against race, and in this discord triumph.

Failure of the Republican national ticket to enunciate clear-cut plans for the future is the prime reason why President Roosevelt will be re-elected, Adolf A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, declared last night at a rally of the Affiliated Young Democrats of New York State at the Hotel Piccadilly.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 30 -Jack Benny will be starred by Warner Brothers in "Dark Eyes" an adaptation of the Elena Miramova-Eugenie Leontovich play of that title which opened at the Belasco Theatre, New York, in January, 1943. The film will be made in early spring as one of two pictures the comedian will do for Warners' in 1945.

A banking group headed by the Harris Trust and Savings Bank, Chicago, submitted yesterday the high bid for an issue of $3,000,000 city of Portland, Ore., harbor development bonds. Formal award of the bonds is expected to be made today.

By direction of Nathaniel L. Goldstein, State Attorney General, a threefold inquiry got under way yesterday into the issuance of literacy certificates to first voters during the recent registration in New York City. According to a preliminary report of William B. Herlands, Special Assistant Attorney General, there had been "wholesale frauds" in the granting of these certificates, which are a necessary preliminary to registering the first time.

MOSCOW, Oct. 30 (U.P.) -- The Russian news agency, Tass, reported today from Teheran, Iran, that mass demonstrations against the Government of Premier Mohammed Maraghei Said, because of its refusal to grant oil concessions to Russia, had virtually sealed the Government's fate.

LONDON, Tuesday, Oct. 31 -The Royal Air Force Bomber Command, using possibly 1,000 heavy planes, poured thousands of tons of explosives onto burning and battered Cologne last night in an attempt to finish off the great Rhineland city as a communications and industrial center for the German Army fighting only forty miles to the west.

ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 30 -- A Spanish-type building was dedicated today as the permanent inter-American center of Rollins College in ceremonies including an address by Gov. Spessard L. Holland. Attending as guests was a group of Brazilian air officers, headed by Air Brigadiers Ivo Borges and Vasco A. Secco.

BIRMINGHAM, Eng., Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Bishop of Birmingham, Dr. E. William Barnes, predicted today that within five years "the Republican party, with its strong isolationist wing, will be in power in Washington" and he questioned whether an American Army would then remain in Germany.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase last week of 22 per cent over the like week of last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The gain for the preceding week was 6 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Radio frequency space in the spectrum for two-way frequency modulation radio taxicab communication service was requested at today's hearing before the Federal Communications Commission by representatives of the industry, and by Oliver W. Moore, chairman of the Radio Technical Planning Board's taxi-cab committee.

LEYTE, Oct. 30 -- Japanese soldiers stationed in Tacloban, together with their officers, told the local inhabitants that the Americans were "softies" and that because the Americans were so guillible either Japan or her individual soldiers could surrender and be assured of generous terms at any time.

Plans for two office buildings and four apartment houses in Manhattan and a public school in the Bronx were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. Eric Kebbon, architect, filed plans for the Board of Education for the three-story school building to be erected at 325 East 151st Street at a cost of $675,000.

DENVER, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Three Japanese naval prisoners, who more than two months ago failed in a suicide attempt, were shot and killed at Fitzsimons General Hospital last night as they rushed their guards in an attempted uprising, Brig. Gen. Omar H. Quade, commanding officer, announced today.

Charley (Lulu) Costantino, who boxed his way well up the fistic ladder from the East Side in the St. Nicholas Arena, returned there last night for a ten-round bout with Leo Dulmaine of Worcester, Mass., a sandy-haired Bay-Stater. Costantino was awarded the decision.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Chinese troops striking against the right flank of Japanese forces advancing on Kweilin recaptured Tzeyuan yesterday, and seized a large quantity of supplies, the High Command announced today. Remnants of the enemy force fled southward, it added.
ROME, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The battle for Italy simmered down to scattered patrol clashes today as the Germans added to the misery of the Allies' mud-bogged troops by troublesome artillery fire.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 30 -- Third Fleet carrier aircraft ferreted out three enemy cruisers in Manila harbor over the week-end and inflicted heavy damage. Bitter air fights are raging in the Philippines and at sea as American forces add further damage to the beaten enemy fleet and the Japanese in return are trying desperately to penetrate air patrols and bomb our carriers off shore.

MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, Oct. 30 -A dividend of 20 cents a share of common stock for the fourth quarter of 1944 has been authorized by the board of directors of the American Rolling Mill Company, Charles R. Hook, president, announced today.

A statement signed by 250 officials of local unions in New York State endorsing Governor Dewey for President and charging President Roosevelt with prolonging the depression was made public yesterday by the Republican State Committee.

Stepping up the tempo of his campaign, Senator Robert F. Wagner was greeted by enthusiastic crowds as he stumped Manhattan and Brooklyn last night seeking support on the basis of his legislative record during eighteen years in the Senate.

WITH UNITED STATES THIRD ARMY, Oct. 30 -- In an editorial appearing in a captured German Army newspaper, seen today, German soldiers are warned, now that they are fighting in their own country, to cease looting. They are told to hate the Allies with a fanatical hatred but to apply the Golden Rule to their own people in the Fatherland.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Decision to send a Foreign Economic Administration mission to establish strategic bases and to stimulate the production of rubber and war materials in Liberia was announced today by the State Department and the FEA.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast by the Fres Yugoslav radio in Serbo-Croat and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

This newspaper's Chungking correspondent, Brooks Atkinson, just returned from China, was able yesterday to bring out into the open the unhappy sequence of events which led to the recall of Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell. Mr. Atkinson is fully supported by a dispatch sent by Preston Grover, Associated Press correspondent at New Delhi, which is published today, and by much other evidence.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Stanley Gunn, war correspondent for The Fort Worth Star-Telegram and The Houston Chronicle, died on Monday of wounds suffered in a Japanese bombing attack on Tacloban in the Philippines on Oct. 25, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters notified his wife today.

The news from Italy yesterday told again of patrol activity and slow inching advances toward the Po River. The Italian front has been virtually stabilized for some time, and the slow Allied progress is attributable to the same causes that made for delay until the Cassino break-through last May 18.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 170:

Columbia's football team, already weakened by the loss of Wayne Morgan, fullback, suffered another blow yesterday when it was learned that Joe Hall, starting left halfback, and George Watts, substitute right end, were transferred by the Navy to Wesleyan. They are to report there today.

In the five counties of this city there are 246 candidates for the State Legislature in this year's elections. No newspaper could hope to examine adequately the records and the claims of all these 246 candidates for twenty-five seats in the State Senate and for sixty-seven seats in the State Assembly.

WITH A REGIMENTAL COMBAT TEAM of the United States Ninety-second Division on the Italian front, Oct. 30 (Delayed) -- The progress and development of the first Negro combat unit to meet the Germans in the European theatre has been "normal and progressively satisfactory," their commanding general said yesterday.

Adolph Busch, violinist, and Rudolf Serkin, pianist, gave a recital last night, which opened the fifteenth annual Town Hall Endowment Series. They played the Beethoven sonata in C minor, Opus 30, No. 2; the Brahms sonata in G major, Opus 78, and the Schubert Fantasy in C major, Opus 159.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The mythical national championship won't be decided when Penn and Michigan clash on Franklin Field Saturday, but the result will help clear up the 1944 sectional muddle.

Continued trading between Government commissions, rather than through private channels, and a reluctance upon the part of domestic-minded manufacturers to allot quotas for export from early production, were listed by exporters as two of the chief difficulties to be faced in foreign trade in the immediate post-war period, according to a survey made public yesterday by the Export Managers Club of New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 25:

ADVANCE HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Gen Douglas MacArthur's invasion forces have given him a firm grasp on the Philippines, he said today, "and I shall not relax the grip until Bataan and Corregidor once more rise to life."
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People released a telegram yesterday from Senator Harry S. Truman in which he again denied that he ever had been a member of the Ku Klux Klan.

Marvin Bryant, 160 3/4, Dallas, Tex., won a unanimous decision from Frankie Terry, 157 1/4, Brooklyn, in the feature eight-round event at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night before a crowd of 4,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 31 -- Warner Brothers is planning to remake "Three Men on a Horse," with Eddie Bracken, borrowed from Paramount, for the part of the Milquetoast horse picker. Warners previously produced "Three Men on a Horse" in 1936 with Frank McHugh in the lead.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Governor Bricker declared today that the Farm Belt States would go Republican in Tuesday's election, and added that he thought Washington and Oregon would, too.

Increases in money circulation, coupled with a continued shift in deposits to private accounts which has increased reserve requirements, have forced member banks of the Federal Reserve System to borrow heavily in order to maintain their reserve positions, according to the monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
ROME, Oct. 31 -- Monarchy, like all political institutions in postwar Europe, should move to the left, Crown Prince Humbert told me today in a private audience that lasted for an hour.

The twelfth annual observance of American Art Week begins today throughout the country. It is held under the auspices of the American Artists Professional League, Inc., national headquarters of which is in Carnegie Hall. There are chapters in all of the States.

The fourteen-story apartment building at 471 Park Avenue, at the southeast corner of Fifty-eighth Street, one of the earliest "cooperative" residential buildings in that neighborhood and one of the early apartment houses erected there prior to the New York Central improvement and electrification work, has been sold through Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers, for a syndicate represented by Benjamin Mintz.

Sales of 10,000,000 yards of cotton cloth at price excesses estimated at $678,500 were attributed to three corporations and fourteen individuals in criminal informations filed yesterday in Federal court. The charges were made by John F.X. McGohey, United States Attorney.

Women pushing baby carriages and leading older children by the hand were among the applicants who appeared yesterday at 110 public schools throughout the city to apply for renewals of basic A gasoline rations. In many cases the women were applying on behalf of their husbands, who were at work.

Committees representing owners of twelve issues of bonds of the Seaboard Air Line Railway Company announced yesterday that they will give official notice today of the adoption and approval of the plan of reorganization. They will notify holders that bonds not withdrawn from deposit with them by Dec. 1 will be bound by the terms of the plan.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was heavier than in the previous month, and was the largest for a corresponding month since 1939. Sales for October, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, amounted to 17,533,817 shares, compared with 15,945,982 shares in September, and with 13,922,678 shares in the same month in 1943.

The Rev. Guy Howard, who is 52 years old, walks an average of 4,000 miles a year to minister to isolated communities in the Ozarks as pastor, teacher and general adviser. His autobiography, "Walkin Preacher of the Ozarks," is full of homespun stories of the mountain people.

No finer piece of straightforward, unvarnished description of a complicated action has come out of this war than Admiral Nimitz's summary of the Second Battle of the Philippine Sea -- Pacific Fleet Communique 168. Any grade-school pupil, after reading Communique 168, would be able to understand just how the Japanese Fleet was discovered approaching the Philippines, how the United States forces went to work and the well-nigh perfect job they did.

Former Representative Will Rogers Jr. of California, now fighting as a second lieutenant in Holland, got word through to President Roosevelt last night that his paper, The Beverley Hills Citizen, had made its endorsement of Governor Dewey "absolutely without my knowledge or consent."

An outbreak of muggings and hold-ups by Negro youths in the vicinity of City College, Convent Avenue and 138th Street, has led Dr. John L. Bergstresser, chairman of the Department of Student Life, to warn students against walking through St. Nicholas Park, adjacent to the school, where five or six attacks on students have been made during the last two weeks.

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Palace, the new attraction will be "The Master Race," an Edward A. Golden production filmed for RKO. George Coulouris, Stanley Ridges, Osa Massen, Carl Esmond, Nancy Gates and Morris Carnovsky are among the featured players in the topical drama. . . .

It was of especial value to see, at yesterday's showing in the Oval Room of the Ritz Carlton Hotel, just how a designer thinks a woman should look when completely "ensembled" by him in the matter of dress, hat, jewels and other accessories.

Products and services sold the United States Steel Corporation for the first nine months 1944 set a new high record $1,535,783,742 for the period, with steel shipments at a peak of 15 864,466 net tons, Irving S. Old the chairman, announced yesterday.

COMPARED to the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness and other ancient classics of the turf, today's Pimlico Special is strictly a johnny-come-lately to the thoroughbred sport.
