But lack of a respectable old age cannot diminish its importance. In eight brief years it has grown to be recognized as one of the top races of the campaign, an equine world series, so to speak.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined yesterday 1 to 4 points net. Business was limited to small trade operations. After opening 2 points lower to 2 points higher than it had closed on Monday, the market became uninteresting.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 31 -- There are no frontiers in the war zone. One crosses flat gray country from northern France into Belgium and from Belgium into Holland without pause at the demarcation line that ordinarily separates nation from nation. Yet even in wartime, when the military picture superimposed on distinctive features makes the face of every country look oddly alike, the atmosphere changes as perceptibly as if boundaries were still dividing lines.

BUFFALO, Oct. 31. -- Governor Dewey, opening tonight the last swing of his Presidential campaign tour at the Memorial Auditorium here, ridiculed the promise of peacetime prosperity made Saturday night by President Roosevelt and offered, as an alternative, the domestic program which he outlined in broad strokes, rather than in detail, earlier in the campaign.

The total number of visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the month of October was 6,429 against 5,112 for the same month last year, an increase of 25.7 per cent. Buyers for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,561 compared with 1,391 last week and 1,268 for the similar period a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

BOSTON, Oct. 31 -- United States Senator David I. Walsh declared today that he resented being labeled an "isolationist" as he was yesterday by Senator Harry S. Truman, Democratic candidate for the Vice Presidency, in a statement made at Providence.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The National War Labor Board will not take a vote on "collateral" issues in the steel wage case before Nov. 7, it was made clear today by Chairman William H. Davis.

A cart load of baled newspapers, wheeled recklessly along the sidewalks by a masked young man, yesterday gained him last-minute admission to a Hallowe'en party at the Park Hudson Unit Salvage Depot of the American Women's Voluntary Services at 2800 Broadway.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 31 (AP) -- It will be youth versus experience, or Twilight Tear against Devil Diver, in tomorrow's $25,000 Pimlico special at a mile and three-sixteenths.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (U.P.) -- The United Republican Finance Committee for Metropolitan New York received $1,263,476 and spent $981,764 through Oct. 26, a statement on file with the House clerk showed today.

On the first anniversary of residential rent control here, Daniel P. Woolley, regional head of the Office of Price Administration, hailed yesterday the operation of the plan in this area as "an outstanding success in holding the line" on prices charged for 2,000,000 apartments and rented homes and 250,000 rooms in hotels and rooming houses.

The 1944 campaign of the New York Federation of Jewish Philanthropies will open today with 8,000 volunteer workers seeking funds for the 116 hospitals and social welfare agencies served by the federation.

John F. O'Connell, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, yesterday called to the attention of all licensees the provisions of the Alcohol Beverage Control Law that prohibit the sale of alcoholic beverages while the polls are open on election day and said that in event of a violation proceedings to revoke the license of the offender would be instituted.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

A confidential survey of the political situation made by the Greater New York Council of the Congress of Industrial Organizations for the guidance of its union leaders yesterday estimated that President Roosevelt's majority in New York City would be more than 800,000, but warned that a shift of 5 per cent or 150,000 voters to Governor Dewey is possible before next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The campaign issue which will decide the women's vote in next Tuesday's election is war, Mrs. Roosevelt told a press conference today, the last before she will go to Hyde Park to vote.

The fight against cancer, which kills forty persons daily in New York City alone and accounts for 160,000 deaths annually in the United States, should be organized on a national scale, Dr. R.R. Spencer, chief of the National Cancer Institute, Bethesda, Md., declared last night in a speech accepting the Clement Cleveland Award "for outstanding service during 1944 in the effort to control cancer by education."
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically from Sofia and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Rumanian Government of Gen. Konstantin Sanatescu, which signed the armistice with the United Nations, appeared in danger as the Moscow radio early today reported mass demonstrations in Bucharest demanding its replacement by a government organized by the Rumanian National Democratic front.

First Lieut. Albert J. Tepperman, formerly an assistant purchasing and contract officer at the New York Port of Embarkation, testified yesterday at the general court-martial of Capt. Joseph (Joe) Gould at the Army base in Brooklyn that a contract for 3,000 life floats, involving $570,000, was awarded without competitive bidding and against his recommendation to the Cornwall Shipbuilding Company at Cornwall, N.Y.

A twelve-story department store and office building will be erected at 589-91 Fifth Avenue and 3 East Forty-seventh Street under plans filed yesterday by Walker Gillette, architects, for the estate of Robert W. Goelet. The estimated cost is $1,300,000.

The marriage of John B. Flannagan, American sculptor, to Mrs. Margherita L. Flannagan of 329 1/2 West Twenty-first Street, alleged to have taken place in New Jersey in 1936, was declared "bigamous and void" by Surrogate James A. Foley yesterday in a decision re voking letters of administration on the sculptor's estate.

A comic of established reputation in radio, vaudeville and night clubs, Frank Fay is undertaking a straight role as the star of "Harvey," opening tonight at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre. Mary Chase is the author of this whimsical fantasy, which comes here bearing Boston's endorsement.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 31 -- Russia's about-face before the Chicago aviation conference has aroused no more than passing "consternation" among authoritative Swiss circles, which admit, however, that they are at a loss for the "real reason" for Moscow's abstention from a conference on the results of which so much for the immediate reconstruction of wartorn Europe depends.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 31 (U.P.) -- Japanese forces, attacking Kweilin in three columns, have smashed through Chinese defenses to within six miles of the city, a Chinese High Command communique announced today.

The New York War Fund, with only eleven days to go before the scheduled end of its 1944 campaign, announced yesterday that it had raised $7,392,725, less than half the quota. Addressing 500 campaign leaders and representatives of cooperating agencies at the second report luncheon in the Hotel Roosevelt, Richard W. Lawrence, the campaign chairman, urged intensified work to achieve the $17,200,000 goal.

Commenting that it was a case for the wisdom of a Solomon, Magistrate Charles E. Ramsgate yesterday in the Municipal Term Court deferred a decision until Nov. 14 on complaints of tenants in the large apartment house at 277 Park Avenue against Jocko, the 23-year-old parrot of Mrs. Mildred H. Burr on the fifth floor, whose shrieks and whistlings at sunrise each day, they charged, deprive them of sleep.
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Business in today's stock markets generally was on a small scale.

Despite the continued difficulty of obtaining some consumer goods, all the operating companies of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., "are running well both from the viewpoint of sales and operating profits." Jack L. Straus, the president, informed stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Wednesday, Nov. 1 (AP) -- A communique:

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The National War Fund, Inc., and the American Red Cross today benefited from last summer's major league war relief baseball games by a total of $329,555.46, the office of Commissioner K.M. Landis announced.

AACHEN, Oct. 31 -- The new Anti-Nazi Buergermeister of Aachen, chosen by the Allied Military Government, went to work today, ten days after the formal surrender of the city to the American First Army. Under military escort he toured the Aachen area in a captured German automobile, searching for reliable Germans to serve as sub-officials of his puppet government.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Chungking in English to North America and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

Two underwriting syndicates will offer formally today to the public $24,500,000 of 2 7/8 per cent bonds, due in 1974, and 125,000 shares of 3.90 per cent cumulative preferred stock of the Metropolitan Edison Company.
LONDON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

The stock market's effort at recovery made some headway yesterday, but the advance was spotty. The widest gains were in the aircraft division. Buying of these securities seemed to have been inspired by Prime Minister Churchill's prediction of a longer war than had been anticipated recently.
In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 20 a telegram from Stockholm stated that the Nobel Foundation had recommended to the Swedish Government that no peace prize should be awarded for this year.

New funds for post-war expansion totaling $3,312,154 have been received in campaigns by thirty-five Baptist schools, colleges and seminaries, Dr. Luther Wesley Smith, executive secretary of the board of education of the Northern Baptist Convention, announced yesterday.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared yesterday that "there is no justification for any further delay in the rendering of a decision on the part of the United Nations that the Balfour Declaration made twenty-seven years ago, favoring the establishment in Palestine of a national home for the Jewish people, must be given immediate force and effect."

An investing client of L.V. Hoffman Co., brokers, bought the thirteen-story apartment building at 575 West End Avenue, southwest corner of Eighty-eighth Street, for cash above a first mortgage of $384,000 held by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

Japan's armed forces, fighting a passive defense since Guadalcanal, have been forced to "withdraw gradually" and now face a situation that is "regrettably unfavorable to us," Gen. Kuniaki Koiso, the premier, told the Japanese people yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 31 -- Argentine officials still express the belief not only that a meeting of American Foreign Ministers will eventually be held, but that Argentina will succeed in solving all the difficulties between herself and the United States.

The five-story garden-type apartment at 1470 Midland Avenue, in the Fleetwood section of Yonkers, was sold by Kristen Kristenson, as trustee, to the R. Realty Corporation. The property contains forty-one apartments and is assessed at $200,000.

A Chinese Communist spokesman has sent a letter to representatives of the Kuomintang [Government party] in Chungking calling for dissolution of "one-party dictatorship" in China and establishment of a coalition government to carry out "thorough military, political, economic and cultural reforms" as a basis for united front warfare against Japan, the Communists' radio said yesterday.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Wednesday, Nov. 1 -- Troops of the Seventh Division, pushing northward up the central valley of Leyte, last night reached a point eight miles from the west coast of the island on Carigara Bay, where detachments of the First Cavalry, moving down from the north, fought an ebb and flow battle with reinforced Japanese defenders.
LONDON, Oct. 31 (Reuter) -- The liberation of Tirana, capital of Albania, is regarded as imminent in British and Albanian quarters here in close touch with developments in Albania.

Dr. Jan Papanek, Czechoslovak Minister to the United States, proposed yesterday that the peoples in the heart of Europe upon whose destruction Germany concentrated her fury be permitted to take over and help create a stable, peaceful, organized Europe.

WITH AN AMERICAN HOSPITAL UNIT, on Leyte, Oct. 31 -- Army surgeons here have removed from a doughboy's chest a live artillery shell that might have exploded and killed surgeons, attendants and patient. The hardy Yank probably will live.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The War Production Board eased today several restrictions on materials for construction of authorized commercial, industrial and agricultural products.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 31 -- Infantry of the British Second Army have smashed through German rear guards northwest of Tilburg and fought their way to the southern bank of the Meuse (Maas) River, while to the east and west of this spearhead British, Canadian, American and Polish troops are rolling the beaten enemy back toward the river.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- Heavy and light bombers of the Royal Air Force struck two more blows last night in the Allies' obliteration offensive against the German rail and industrial center of Cologne, which the British have bombed eight times since Saturday.

Together with the announcement by General Manager Tom Gallery that Ed Kubale and Frank Bridges, assistants to Pete Cawthon, who on Monday severed his coaching connections with the Brooklyn Tigers, have been signed as co-coaches of the Flatbush football aggregation, the front-office boss yesterday disclosed that Cawthon's resignation had been asked for by Gallery.

Reference here is to the budget of errors which so regularly accumulates in these paragraphs in the course of time, and not such a very long time either. Often we succeed with a single stroke of the pen in eliciting a little flood of corrections which we are glad to acknowledge.

Natura, a new yarn spun from the real hairs of mink, muskrat or silver fox and woven into fabrics, made its debut yesterday at a show held at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The fabric, as it is used in dresses, is made up of 20 per cent of the fur fibers, 70 per cent rayon and 10 per cent wool.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- W.L. Clayton, Surplus War Property Administrator, authorized today the salvaging and scrapping of surplus military aircraft which is unfit for commercial use, has outlived its military usefulness and is "seriously interfering with military operations."
PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 31 -- For the first time in the Pacific war fleet carrier aircraft are destroying enemy fighting planes faster than Japan can build them.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- President Roosevelt told his news conference today that he suggested the formation of the One Thousand Club, which Governor Dewey denounced in Chicago Wednesday night, and that, much to his surprise, he had learned only a few days ago that he was a member of it.

Net sales of the Studebaker Corporation for the first nine months of 1944 set a new high record of $317,150,233, comparing with a previous high of $262,534,622 in the 1943 period, including charges to the United States Government under cost-plus-fixed-fee contracts.

! A new 3-cent purple stamp de-I picting an audience of GI's watch-I ing a movie show near the field ofI battle was placed on sale yester-I day at special ceremonies in the l lobby of the General Postoffice at Eighth Avenue and Thirty-third iStreet.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Eighteen more Japanese vessels have been sunk by United States submarines, the Navy reported today in a communique that served to emphasize that, while our planes and warships are decimating the enemy's battle fleet, destruction of Japanese merchant shipping is proceeding steadily.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Oct. 31 -- The Australian Army's disappearance from the Pacific battlefront was explained tonight by Francis M. Forde, Deputy Prime Minister and Army Minister, on his arrival for Australian-New Zealand conversations.
ROME, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Martha Graham and her company of dancers closed the music festival held in the Library of Congress under the auspices of the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation tonight with the repetition of last night's performance of three new works especially commissioned for the festival both as to choreography and music.

After reading the telegrams the Republican representatives sent to Mr. Dewey, which he used in a recent speech, I would like to know: Are we to assume that these worthy gentlemen will support only Mr. Dewey in the Congress, although the majority of the people may find it fitting to elect Mr. Roosevelt?

WITH BRITISH SECOND ARMY FORCES on Outskirts of Breda, Oct. 30 (Delayed) -- This is an unhealthy spot for everybody -- German forces, Allied fighters and Netherland civilians alike. There are enemy snipers hidden in a wood of stunted fir trees, lining the main highways approaching the city, the last of three immediate goals that the British forces set out to capture last week, the first two being's Hertogenbosch and Tilburg.

WITH THE AMERICAN THIRD ARMY, Oct. 31 -- A German corporal, one of ten men left in his company, which was encircled at the Moselle River near Nancy, sat down and wrote a letter to his wife in which he explained the hopelessness of his situation, said only a miracle would get him home and prayed for capture.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Transcripts of testimony in two cases heard today by a sub-committee of the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures were ordered sent to Attorney General Biddle with a recommendation that a test case be brought against the Ohio council of the Congress of Industrial Organizations because of a pamphlet printed and distributed by the unit attacking Senator Taft of Ohio as pro-Nazi and pro-Japanese.

Assistant State Attorney General John W.M. Rutenberg declared yesterday that the Attorney General's office was investigating a "kickback racket in Wall street," which would involve at least seven customers' brokers. Financial circles were incredulous, however, one official of the New York Stock Exchange asserting that, without attempting to prejudge a case still under investigation, those familiar with the business could hardly help looking upon it as an isolated instance.

Wool growers welcome any constructive suggestion that will aid in solving the existing surplus wool problem, F. Eugene Ackerman, executive director of the American Wool Council, said yesterday in discussing the so-called Hill plan, which will be thoroughly gone into at the annual meeting starting today of the Wyoming Wool Growers Association at the Henning Hotel, Casper, Wyo.

Golfdom's richest winter tour, the P.G.A. sponsored 1944-45 swing from Oregon down the West Coast, through the Southwest and South into the Carolinas, will find the play-for-pay brigade competing for more than $150,000 in war bonds.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 31 -- The removal of Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell as commander in the China-Burma-India theatre, it can be reported today, resulted from a combination of strategy stud diplomacy such as could arise only in the Orient.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- A program for post-war taxation involving the substitution of a new internal revenue code of about 5,000 words for "the present complicated and ambiguous" law was offered today to the House Republican Post-war Tax Study Committee by the American Taxpayers Association.

Walter A. Bowe, formerly advertising and sales promotion manager of Carrier Corporation, has joined Walter Dorwin Teague, industrial designer, as an associate in industrial planning and consultant on sales problems.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Robert H. Hinckley, director of contract settlement, said in his first report to Congress today that contracts covering items valued at $21,000,000,000 had been canceled by the Army, Navy and Maritime Commission, and that victory in Europe would result in terminations exceeding $20,000,000,000, or about one-third of the outstanding war production program.

Five thousand pounds of butter have just been received by Hearns, and are scheduled to go on sale tomorrow in the grocery department in the basement. The first 4,000 pounds to be sold will be allotted to customers on a one-pound-apiece basis, the remainder to be apportioned in half pounds.

Wartime conditions that brought a sharp reduction in capital improvements, repair and maintenance, a substantial drop in the number of city employes because many were called into military service, and a ten-year low for home relief expenditures, resulted in an improvement in the city's financial position for the fiscal year 1943-44, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick declared yesterday in his annual report.

THERE are plenty of other islands in the Pacific Ocean where the marines have landed, fought desperately and gallantly and exterminated Japanese garrisons; but there is only one that marines mean when they speak of "the island." And that is Guadalcanal. The first important land victory won by United States forces in this war may have been pretty small potatoes compared with what we have since accomplished all around the world.

ROME, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Indian troops of the British Eighth Army have consolidated a half-mile-deep bridgehead across the Ronco River near Meldola, seven miles south of Forli, German strong point on the lateral Bologna-Rimini highway, the Allied command announced today.

PARIS, Oct. 31 -- Approximately 2,000 Spanish republicans and Russians, banded together under the insignia of a black skullcap with a white death's head, have established a stronghold in the mountains in France's southern Dordogne Department and are waging a private war against the French Forces of the Interior, an observer just returned from thee region said today.

Today the number of blind civilians registered with the New York Association for the Blind is 4,059, twenty times the number of blind service men who are under the jurisdiction of the Government for complete rehabilitation. Our community problem in New York is much greater.

Ethel Barrymore has been absent from Broadway for too long a time, as for the past several seasons she has conducted Miss Moffat's classroom across the country in "The Corn Is Green." Now she is back, and that fact indeed supplies good news.

In your issue of Oct. 27 Lewis Mayers suggests the dispersal of the German population of each annexed area of the Reich, and the forced immigration of those people into the interior of each annexing nation.

Margaret E. Connors, Bridgeport lawyer and Democratic opponent of Clare Boothe Luce in the Congressional race in Connecticut's Fourth district, predicted she would win the election by 5,000 votes when interviewed yesterday at the National Democratic headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Chinese troops have consolidated their positions in Myothit, twenty-four miles northeast of Bhamo, in the new Allied northern Burma campaign to clear a land route to China, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's headquarters announced today.

Regarding Mr. Petrillo, your editorial of Oct. 12 was very clear on two points: (1) Having used strong-arm tactics on Mr. Avery to enforce a War Labor Board decision, the Administration should have used the same methods on Mr. Petrillo.

Distribution problems in the post-war period, regarded as paramount by officials of companies affiliated with Continental Industries, Inc., will be a major consideration of the post-war products and developments committee appointed yesterday at the close of a two-day meeting of the group at its headquarters here.

Two new issues of bonds of public utility companies, aggregating $30,481,000, were sold at competitive sales here yesterday. The offerings consisted of $16,981,000 of Potomac Edison Company's first mortgage 3 per cent bonds, due in 1974, and $13,500,000 of California Oregon Power Company's first mortgage bonds, due on Nov. 1, 1974.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- President Roosevelt added another political speech to his campaign program today, an address to be broadcast from the White House on Thursday night, but he plans no more traveling until he leaves to keep his last major speaking engagement of the campaign in Boston on Saturday night.

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York has been appointed trustee, registrar and paying agent for $100,000,000 of the American Tobacco Company twenty-five-year 3 per cent debentures due on Oct. 15, 1969.

The New York University football team went through a two-hour session yesterday on Ohio Field, but two regulars were missing as a result of injuries sustained in the City College game last Saturday. Al Fiore, right halfback, came out of the fray with an injured knee and he spent the afternoon having it treated.

The twenty-sixth anniversary of the Czechoslovak Republic was celebrated by the American Friends of Czechoslovakia last night in Carnegie Hall by a concert of Czech music, with Jarmila Novotna as soloist and eighty-eight players of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra conducted by Bruno Walter.
LONDON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The text of Prime Minister Churchill's House of Commons speech:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The best interests of the United States and of the world call for continuance of President Roosevelt in office. Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, head of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and many other Government enterprises, argued in a radio address tonight.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Nazi flying bombs launched from planes using cloud cover over the North Sea shattered on southern England, including the London area, today in the first such daylight attack in more than a month. Crossing the coast from the northeast at several points the robot bombs met so fierce a barrage over East Anglia that houses several miles inland shook from the guns.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- A relief delegation will soon go to liberated Poland, Herbert H. Lehman, Director General of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, said today.

Baruna, a 5-year-old who had not scored in a 1944 race, was the surprise winner of the $10,275 Daingerfield Handicap at Jamaica yesterday, where the Empire City Racing Association renewed one of the longest races run in this country
ATHENS, Oct. 31 (AP) -- British troops and Greek guerrillas, pushing the Germans out of Greece, were reported within seven miles of the Yugoslav border today.

Coming down the center aisle of Madison Square Garden arm in arm, to the cheers of a crowd of 20,000 persons. Senator Harry S. Truman, Democrat nominee for the Vice Presidency, and Vice President Henry k. Wallace made their first and probably their only joint appearance of the Presidential campaign at a mass meeting last night of the Liberal party.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Prime Minister Churchill told Parliament today that it seemed difficult to believe that the war against Germany could be ended before Christmas or even Easter, that he believed it would be unwise to dissolve Britain's coalition government before then, and that there was therefore no likelihood of a general election for seven to nine months from now.

The full importance of the Long Island manufacturing area to the war in the air will be news to a good many New Yorkers. They have, of course, read of the high exploits of Grumman's Hellcats and Avengers and of Republic's Thunderbolts. They are among the stars of the show.

The American Jewish Conference and the World Jewish Congress issued a joint statement yesterday, concurred in by the United Rumanian Jews of America, warning that the terms of the armistice between the Allies and Rumania affecting the status of Jews in that country "will remain an empty gesture unless immediate steps are taken for their implementation."

Organization of the Precision-Built Homes Corporation to promote home sales and construction was announced yesterday by F. Vaux Wilson Jr., president, who also is vice president of the Homasote Company.

The report of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., for the year ended on Sept. 30, showed yesterday a consolidated net income, after operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $32,022,668. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.84 a share on the company's outstanding common stock, and compares with $32,877,256, or $1.91 a common share, in the preceding twelve months.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 31 -- The New Jersey Licensed Beverage Association, representing 7,400 tavern owners throughout the State, voted at its convention here today to petition the Legislature for a law "requiring all persons to register with their municipal clerk upon reaching their twenty-first birthday and to secure a registration card bearing their signature" to certify their right to buy alcoholic beverages.

Because "offensive warfare is rougher on clothing and equipment than the defensive war we were fighting last year," 400 additional paid workers are needed immediately at the Jersey City Quartermaster Depot, 125 West End Avenue, Manhattan, Lieut. Col. William H. Lee, commanding officer, disclosed yesterday.

Expanding Social Security for the nation to include returning war veterans "will mean the difference between prosperity and depression after the war," Senator Robert F. Wagner declared last night in renewing his pledge to extend the Wagner act.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31 -- The telephone rang in the coaches' dressing room at Thompson Field, Chief Specialist Phil Moonves, one of Howie Odell's assistants, took the call.

BUFFALO, Oct. 31 -- Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, summarized his reasons tonight as to why President Roosevelt should not be considered an indispensable man and the New Deal administration should be defeated next Tuesday.

PARIS, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The French people are counting on the United States for meat, milk and cereals and both land and ocean transport to help relieve the food shortage in France and North Africa, Supply Minister Paul Giaccobi said today.

By unanimous vote, the Board of Elections for this city decided yesterday to leave all questions as to the validity of war ballots to the decision of local boards in each election district. At least 6,000 ballots may be subject to question because of mutilation, failure of the voter to sign the required oath, to have it witnessed properly or otherwise to comply with the strict letter of the law.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Baseball's chief bargain hunters -- the major league club owners -- will huddle here tomorrow in their annual draft meeting in the hope of picking up another Grover Cleveland Alexander or another Hack Wilson at low prices.

Giving official expression to revised military estimates regarding the duration of the war, Mr. Churchill has advised Parliament that, barring unlikely domestic upheavals in Germany or Japan, the war in Europe may last till the end of spring or early summer and that the Pacific war must be expected to continue for at least another eighteen months after that.
PARIS, Oct. 31 -- After having clamored for a purge of collaborationists, public opinion, now that it is in full operation, seems rather disconcerted, to judge by the press.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 1 -- Russian troops, smashing toward Budapest in a renewed offensive in which more than 200 Hungarian towns and villages were seized, yesterday drove to within forty-four miles southeast of the Hungarian capital and broke into the streets of Kecskemet, Hungary's fourth city.

Since Admiral Horthy begged for an armistice, only to be choked off the air by his Nazi betrayers, we have had no real news from Hungary. Now Berlin, evidently in some alarm, tells us that Russian armies have driven to the very center of the country and that the roar of Russian guns can be heard in Budapest.

LONDON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The sale of British National War Bonds will be discontinued after Nov. 6 and in their place will be offered a new security known as the 1 3/4 per cent Exchequer bond 1950, Sir John Anderson, Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced today.

The Stacy Trent Hotel Corporation, which operates and has a long-term lease on the Stacy Trent Hotel property in Trenton, N.J., has been sold by Robert R. Meyer, president of the Meyer Hotel chain, to Albert W. Stender, owner of the Park Hotel in Plainfield, N.J., and Otto H. Waechter, general supervisor of plants for the Ruberoid Company of America.

The seventeen-story showroom and office building at 1860 Broadway, northeast corner of Sixty-first Street, has been sold by Frederick Brown to a client of Conrad Smith, lawyers, with Britz Realty Company acting as brokers and Joshua Bernstein representing the seller.

Associated Press Correspondent LONDON, Oct. 31 -- The Kuomintang regime, headed by Generalissimo Chiang, has been -- and is -- more concerned with the inevitable civil war against the 80,000,000 Chinese Communists than in the struggle against Japan.

The post-war world service of The Associated Press provides for the extension of its international news collecting and distributing facilities to all parts of the globe, Kent Cooper, executive director, said yesterday.

Equity Corporation -- Report as of Sept. 30: Net assets were equivalent to $90.78 a share on the $3 convertible preferred stock and to $1.44 a share on the common stock, against $90.74 and $1.47 on June 30 last and $82.22 and $1.14 on Sept. 30, 1943.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- The Glenn L. Martin Company of Baltimore announced today a new airplane with an operating cost so low that it can compete with the railroads.
PARIS, Oct. 31 -- The Government has ordered the complete disarmament of the so-called Patriotic Guard, it was announced after a Cabinet meeting tonight.

Incompetence and inexperience of staff members of the Office of Price Administration has brought about a situation in the underwear manufacturing industry which is gradually driving low-end merchandise from the market, Robert Gregory, former OPA underwear consultant, and at present on the industry advisory committee, asserted yesterday.
Your editorial comment of Oct. 30, "Blood Will Tell," stimulates me to make a corrective addition to your statements and to append a plea.

Open seasons bloom in the fall like flowers in the spring. Today starts the firing for upland game on Long Island. In some instances the seasons for the various species are longer than in the rest of the State, setting the island apart from the mainland.

Criticism of industrial designers efforts in creating post-war models radically advanced over pre-war ofefrings as being "dream designs" was attacked yesterday by Egmont Arens, industrial designer, at a meeting of the packaging group of the American Management Association at the Hotel Sheraton.

Excerpts from the addresses of Senator Harry S. Truman, Democratic nominee for the Vice Presidency, Vice President Henry A. Wallace and Senator Robert F. Wagner at the mass meeting of the Liberal party in Madison Square Garden last night follow:

Investment bankers offered in October the largest amount of new corporate and local Government bonds for any month since January, 1930 -- $724,878,000 in twenty-one flotations. This amount compared with $366,224,000 in twenty-two offerings in the preceding month and $92,515,000 for fourteen issues in October, 1943.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- With the United States and Great Britain holding divergent views on how post-war commercial aviation should be controlled, delegations from fifty governments will open the international civil aviation conference here tomorrow.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Communique 206:

Hope of the Republicans for carrying New York State for Governor Dewey is based largely upon expectation of large pluralities for him in the three suburban counties of Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester.
Seventeen local public housing authorities sold yesterday $29,828, 000 of short-term obligations, all dated Nov. 21, 1944.
LONDON, Oct. 31 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A United States Army Forces in China communique:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The United Corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a brief supporting proposed modifications to its amended plan for an exchange of securities.

Leading Jewish and Protestant ministers gathered yesterday afternoon in a meeting unprecedented in the religious life of this city to explain in detail to the Christian clergy the history and religion of Judaism and promote by mutual understanding greater interfaith cooperation and solidarity.
Following is the text of Governor Dewey's Buffalo address as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Corn dominated other grains today on the Board of Trade. Although bids for cash corn for deferred shipment from the country were lowered 1 cent a bushel todaycountry dealers continued to sell the cash article at prices from 4 to 5 1/4 cents under the permissible limit in Kansas City.

The United States Steel Corporation has no option to purchase the Geneva Works, erected in Utah by the corporation in behalf of the Government and operated at no fee by United States Steel, nor has it discussed purchase of the plant with the Government, Irving S. Olds, chairman, said yesterday after the quarterly meeting of directors.

ATHENS, Oct. 29 (Delayed) -- Gen. Stephan Seraphis, head of the operational side of Elas, who is now in Athens, conferred with Prime Minister George Papandreou yesterday and also saw British military authorities.

Columbia's backfield situation became critical yesterday when it was announced that Wayne Morgan, fullback, will not be on hand for the contest with Cornell Saturday at Baker Field. A shift in Navy orders sent him to the V-7 unit on the Prairie State yesterday instead of next Monday as was anticipated.

Terminations and cutbacks have as yet had little effect in changing the over-all business picture and sales of surplus materials so far have not materially changed the price situation, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents reported yesterday.

A red and gold flag designed for the newly formed Women's Amy Corps company that was recruited and named in honor of Lieut. Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright, a prisoner of the Japanese, was presented to the company yesterday as the highlight of its dedication ceremony.

The City Planning Commission voted yesterday to amend the basic Zoning Resolution by imposing additional restrictions on the height and area of new buildings throughout the city. The amendment, the first substantial change in the basic regulations since 1916, is designed, according to the commission, "to increase the open space, light and air about buildings hereafter erected," thereby decreasing traffic congestion, improving realty values and avoiding "blighted" areas.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Continued weakness in cash corn and in bids for grain to arrive from the country dominated the action of the grain markets today on the Chicago Board of Trade. Although the opening was firm, the buying lacked snap and liquidation, later carried prices off sharply.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- In confirming the "long established rights of cooperative organizations" the United States Tax Court in a recent opinion has destroyed one of the "bogy men" of the National Tax Equality Association, according to John Carson, representative here of the Cooperative League.

Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, made a vitriolic attack upon Governor Dewey's attitude toward the Negro race at a rally last night in the Golden Gate Ballroom, Lenox Avenue and 142d Street He accused Governor Dewey of having walked "hand in hand with the most vindictive enemies of the Negroes" and with having shown "great zeal to assist in the administration of lynch law".

Several major changes in the top management of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana were announced yesterday by Edward G. Seubert, president. They will become effective on Jan. 1, at which time Mr. Seubert will retire from the presidency after serving the company for more than fifty-two years, fifteen of which were as its chief executive officer.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Led by the shifty and elusive Howie Arnold, who raced 48 and then 40 yards on two brilliant touchdown jaunts, the Army Plebes eleven scored an 18-12 victory over the Atlantic City Naval Air Training Station today.

BOSTON, Nov. 1 -- With the rift in the Democratic party in Massachusetts out in the open for the first time in the campaign, Senator David I. Walsh deliberated today whether he would make further appearances for the ticket and join President Roosevelt when the Chief Executive comes to Boston Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Representative Richard M. Kleberg, Texas Democrat, said today that he had cast an absentee ballot for Governor Dewey, the Republican Presidential candidate.

BOSTON, Nov. 1 -- Governor Dewey declared here tonight that the Communists, using Sidney Hillman as a front, were trying to seize control of the Federal Government, and if they succeed, he added, the fundamental American freedoms, particularly freedom of religion, would be endangered.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Thursday, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A communique:

Maxim Schapiro, Russian pianist, now resident in California, was heard in recital last night in Town Hall. Mr. Schapiro has made several appearances in this city since his local debut in 1927. At his most recent previous recital, two years ago, his playing was overly restrained, but understatement was often replaced by the opposite extreme in his performances yesterday evening.

A flat denial was made yesterday by two labor leaders listed by the Republican State Committee as among those signing a round-robin letter endorsing Governor Dewey for President and blaming President Roosevelt for prolonging the depression.

The City Planning Commission adopted yesterday a proposed capital outlay budget of $198,427,226 for 1945 and a capital program for 1946-1950, inclusive, covering $381,618,644 worth of projects not included in the 1945 budget, although part of the city's post-war program.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 1 -- An unconscious point of Japanese humor is in the hands of this correspondent. It consists of an oath the Japanese forced Filipinos to make that they would not join the guerrillas "again." Written in English but with Japanese figures on the back, it illustrates how our Pacific enemy tried to dominate the Filipinos.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Governor Bricker declared tonight that Albert A. Horstman, Democratic National Committeeman for Ohio, had suggested that campaign contributions be sought from concerns "negotiating for or performing a Government contract" and from persons who have received loans from Government agencies.

Within the next two years, 22 per cent of the 1,842 members of the American Home reader-consumer panel who replied to a recent survey intend to buy new rug cushions, it was announced yesterday. Another 22 per cent were still undecided on this point.

War ballots lacking the oath prescribed by State law or minus the required attestation cannot be counted by local boards of election inspectors, Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein ruled yesterday in a formal opinion sent to the State War Ballot Commission.

Lively bidding among investment banking houses continued to feature the new issue market yesterday as the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad and the Mobile Gas Service Corporation placed securities in the competitive field.

ADVANCE HEADQUARTERS ON LEYTE, Nov. 1 -- Six Japanese planes came down against what looked like an innocent fifty-foot landing-boat in the harbor here. Two plunged into the sea and the other four did not return to the attack.

ROME, Nov. 1 (AP) -- American troops of the Fifth Army have hurled back several vicious German counter-attacks south of Bologna in which German infantrymen were supported by flame throwers, Allied Headquarters said today.

The New York War Fund must have $17,200,000 to finance the thirty-one war-related agencies embraced in this one-for-all drive. So far gifts have lagged. More than halfway through the campaign the fund is less than half filled.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- President Roosevelt's speech from the White House tomorrow night will be the briefest of his major campaign addresses, according to a statement made by Stephen T. Early, Presidential secretary, that the President would share his radio time with the Democratic National Committee.

Japanese Imperial Headquarters communique claimed that Japanese "assault troops" landed on the north coast of Peleliu Island, 675 miles southeast of Leyte in the Philippines, at dawn yesterday. Later broadcasts said the landing was made Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- President Roosevelt recalled today the massacre of Czechoslovakian students and professors by the Nazis nearly five years ago, as he paid tribute to the youth of the United Nations which have fought and are still fighting for the future of all.

The Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, the country's largest producer of plate glass, earned $9,963,000, or $4.51 a share, in the nine months ended on Sept. 30, Harry B. Higgins, president, reported yesterday. Net earnings for the first nine months of 1943 totaled $8,732,000, or $3.95 a share.
Mr. and Mrs. Loring Washburn of Old Orchards. Greenwich, have come to the Ambassador to stay until spring.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast to the Soviet Union from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

An acute case of jitters seemed to have seized Japanese radio broadcasters yesterday as they issued a stream of conflicting reports in Japanese, English, French and Urdu concerning a supposed raid by American B-29 Superfortress bombers on Tokyo.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 1 -- The recall to Washington of Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell was called a purely military matter today by the Chinese Minister of Information, Liang Han-chao, who said that for that reason there would be no Chinese comment.

A further sharp advance in the aircrafts supplied another modest recovery in the stock market yesterday. Pre-election influences, however, again prevented the list from rising in unison, and the greater part of the day's trading centered in issues of the plane manufacturers.

The Coordinating Committee of the American Polish Associations in the East made public yesterday a letter to President Roosevelt, urging him to declare for the restoration of an independent Poland and protection of its boundaries. The signers were Joseph H. Kaszubowski, president of the committee, and the Rev. A.A. Skoniecki, executive secretary.
Asserting that two terms is enough for a President, Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, who is a Republican, yesterday endorsed Governor Dewey for President.

Herb Kopf's Boston Yanks may be in for a surprise when they start operations against Steve Owen's Football Giants at the Polo Grounds Sunday afternoon. It could be that even Stout Steve will be surprised.

Men's hat buyers yesterday reported an acute situation in the fur felt hat situation for spring, with sellers rationing available supplies to a greater extent than was the case for the past season. Hat body supplies, it is pointed out, are not available at anywhere near levels required, and the labor situation also is handicapping producers.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 1 (AP) -- A supplement to oday's communique:

Sharp criticism of the administrative policies and "attitude" of the Office of Price Administration in handling rent control here was expressed yesterday by the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee, an organization of property owners and agents.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Thursday, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Low-flying fighter planes blew up a 10,000-ton Japanese tanker, heavily damaged two other tankers and two small freighters and destroyed twelve grounded planes during a raid earlier this week in the Borneo area, headquarters announced today.

This is the story of a recent cold, rainy week-end and how three members of the Metropolitan Rod and Gun Club of Brooklyn fared on a hunting trip to Hudson, N.Y. Taking last things first, the bag consisted of one pheasant, one black duck, two woodcock and two grouse.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Imports from Italy valued at about $1,200,000 and including wine, perfume oils, briarwood and rat poison have arrived recently, the Foreign Economic Administration reported today.

Between July 1, 1943, and July 1, 1944, Brooklyn school children helped raise $25,503,337 in war bonds and stamps, it was announced yesterday by Dr. William Jansen, assistant to the Superindent of Schools. He spoke at a meeting of the Kings County War Finance Committee, which, in cooperation with the Board of Education, is conducting a "Schools at War" program in Brooklyn schools.

Further information on securities trading by New York Stock Exchange members has been asked by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Earlier this year they were required to report all trades for their own or firm account in five active low-priced motor stocks.

Trusting that the skilled fingers of Belgium's 40,000 women lace-makers have not lost their art in the last four years, the Belgian Government has planned restoration of the industry and hopes to see pieces designed specially for the American market being shipped within the next few months, it was reported here yesterday.

DENVER, Nov. 1 (AP) -- United States District Judge J. Foster Symes approved today the plan of the Interstate Commerce Commission for reorganization of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad and its subsidiary debtor, the Denver Salt Lake Western Railroad Company.
LONDON, Nov. 1 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

The first of three thread manufacturers accused of corrupting an Army combat pilot to keep two of their relatives away from active theatres of war was brought in by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday. The G-men are seeking the other alleged conspirators.

With one day still to go, distribution of the new gasoline ration A-books in this city reached a two-day total last night of 271,648. Yesterday 143,104 books were issued in the five boroughs, as follows: Manhattan, 15,622; the Bronx, 22,663; Brooklyn, 46,825; Queens, 50,578; Richmond, 7,416.

The seventeen-story and penthouse apartment building at 955 Fifth Avenue, which was erected in 1938, has been sold by the Cassian Realty Company to the Betalba Realty Corporation for investment. The house occupies a plot 62.6 by 120 feet, adjoining the southeast corner of Seventy-seventh Street, and contains thirty-one apartments of five to eight rooms.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- The United States and Britain have been able to solve the very difficult question of conflicting shipping interests during the war and will be able to solve the problem of surplus tonnage after the war by the same means, Philip J. Noel-Baker, Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of War Transport, told the House of Commons during a shipping debate today.
KUNMING, China, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- The Yunnan Daily News today branded the Chinese Government as "Fascist" and said that the "military crisis in China is caused by gravity of the political situation."
PARKERSBURG, W. Va., Nov. 1 (AP). -- Governer Dewey was described tonight by Senator Truman, the Democratic Vice Presidential candidate, as a "political faker" and "scoffer."

ABOARD CARRIER FLAGSHIP IN PACIFIC, Oct. 28 (U.P.) (Delayed) -- Analysis of the Battle of the Philippines today made plain that the Japanese, in their desperate effort to destroy our Leyte beachhead, were prepared to sacrifice several capital ships to achieve their objective.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Thursday, Nov. 2 -- American artillery today smashed Japanese-held Carigara, on the north coast, where the enemy is seeking to hold open a line of retreat to Ormoc.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The play-for-pay boys of the National Football League, whether by accident or design, appear to be blasting the theory of the out-of-bounds kick-off as a strategic weapon.

The householder who heeded the Government's plea to convert his fuel oil burner to the use of coal during the 1942-43 petroleum crisis may start next week to reconvert to oil heat, if he finds a licensed oil installation man to make the necessary equipment changes and has the money to pay for them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Operations of the Fourteenth Air Force, under Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, and the Twentieth (Super-fortress) Bomber Command, under Maj. Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, will not be affected by the division of the China-Burma-India theatre following Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's recall, an Army Air Forces spokesman said today.
H. Adams' letter suggesting a "pronunciation service" for news broadcasters prompts me, in turn, to suggest a method whereby he can avoid the "confusion" of multiple pronunciations.

Accusing the Republican leadership of making "wild exaggerations" and "easy promises" in a bid for votes, Senator Robert F. Wagner declared last night that this campaign strategy was no accident but a well defined plan to becloud the real issues.

MEMPHIS, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The cotton industry awaited today outcome of an appeal to War Mobilization Director James F. Byrnes for assignment of 5,000 soldiers to Mississippi Valley cotton compresses and warehouses for sixty days.

Harry G. Eilers, previously manager of the electric accounting machine division in Minneapolis of International Business Machines Corporation, has been named western manager in charge of all IBM territory west of Ohio. His headquarters are in Chicago.

Our correspondent Frank Kluckhohn reports from Leyte one firm belief held by the Japanese soldiers who occupied that unhappy Philippine island for two and a half years. They told the Filipinos that even if Japan finally was forced to surrender she still could win the peace from the gullible Americans, who could be hoodwinked by bland smiles and low bows into a bargain granting generous terms.

HE was a mild-looking little man with bright eyes, a closely cropped mustache and an erect bearing which belied his 77 years. "My name is Jack Jacobs," he began, "and I have a story which might interest you." He was instantly invited to make himself comfortable and fire away.

MOSCOW, Nov. 1 -- In a news article commemorating next week's twenty-seventh anniversary of the Russian Revolution, President Mikhail I. Kalinin reported today the expulsion of the German Army from the territory of the Soviet Union and predicted that the time was not remote when troops of the Soviet Union, Britain and the United States would meet on the territory of Germany, thus completing the final victory.

Alex Rose, chairman of the administrative committee of the Liberal party, yesterday charged Tammany with being apathetic in its support of President Roosevelt and declared that the members of the Liberal party were particularly shocked at lack of loyalty shown by Tammany toward the candidacy of Senator Robert F. Wagner, a veteran member of the Tammany organization and for years a leading speaker at Tammany rallies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- John Dickinson, general counsel of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, pleaded today before the Interstate Commerce Commission for restoration of freight rate increases and said the opposition tactics of the Office of Price Administration were aimed at driving the railroads into bankruptcy.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 1 -- E.T. Weir, Pittsburgh industrialist, has demanded a retraction from Secretary Ickes of an inference which the latter made in a radio broadcast that steel men helped to build up Japan's war machine by shipping thousands of tons of scrap steel to that country prior to the outbreak of hostilities.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 1 -- The German Catholic Bishops of western and southwestern Germany have addressed a joint pastoral letter to their congregations requesting them to stand loyally behind the troops at the front now that the war is entering on its final and decisive stage.

With active buying of overseas soldiers' gifts a feature, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 13 per cent during October over the like month last year, according to a survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 -- Quadruplets, three girls and a boy, were born in the Philadelphia Lying-In Hospital today to Mrs. Kathleen Cirminello, wife of Joseph Cirminello, an analyst on the staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and for the first time on record in such a multiple birth a Caesarian operation was performed.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Notre Dame and Navy come to a climactic football meeting here Saturday with the usual last-minute scramble today for tickets to the fray even at double the cost and more prices for squatters' rights seats near the goal line.

Broadway has missed Pauline Lord for the last three years. Tonight the star will return in "Sleep, My Pretty One," opening at the Playhouse. Charlcie and Oliver Garrett (a husband and wife writing team) are the authors of this psychological melodrama, revolving around a crippled and neurotic mother who stops at nothing in keeping a middle-aged son tied to her apron strings.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 1 -- If the result of Tuesday's Presidential election in Pennsylvania is anywhere as close as many observers and political leaders now predict, the nation will have to wai tuntil some 225,000 war ballots are counted on Nov. 22 to know whether this possibly decisive State has given its thirty-five electoral votes to President Roosevelt or Governor Dewey.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Major league bosses, with three exceptions, planked $137,500 on the line in "grab-bag" fashion for nineteen league players -- three more than last year -- at their annual draft meeting today. In 1943 $110,000 was gambled on sixteen players.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- A proposal to set up a radio telephone service to permit communication between fixed and mobile units from one end of the country to the other was made at today's hearing before the Federal Communications Commission.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 1 (UP) -- Communique 207:

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- The principal difference of opinion in the International Civil Aviation Conference will be laid on the green baize tables of the conference rooms tomorrow. Success or failure of this meeting of nations will thus be put to an early test.
Attendance at college football games has increased nearly 25 per cent over 1943, a national survey by The Associated Press showed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 171:

ROME, Nov. 1 -- An international plot against Britain in 1938; the corruption of the French Army, involving Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain; the assassination of King Alexander of Yugoslavia and Louis Barthou; the plan to invade Greece in 1940 -- these and other startling details have been uncovered by Count Carlo Sforza's High Court for the Punishment of Fascist Crimes in following the threads of the assassination of the anti-Fascist.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 1 -- A new light gauge steel, expected to rival wood in the building of post-war homes, was announced today to the twenty-second annual convention of the American Institute of Steel Construction.
WITH UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY, Nov. 1 -- Adolf Hitler is blamed by the German people not so much for starting the war as for losing it.

The election of Cyrus S. Ching, director of industrial and public relations of the United States Rubber Company, as board chairman of the China-America Council of Commerce and Industry, and of William Gibson Carey Jr., president of the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company, as president of the council, was announced yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 1 -- The decision of the governing board of the Pan-American Union to transmit Argentina's request for a meeting of American foreign ministers to the American Governments for their consideration was received today with unconcealed pleasure in official circles.

Winter fashions, as viewed by Sally Milgrim, will be bright with color. She endorsed soft jade green, hard royal blue, brilliant rose and gold yesterday noon at the fashion show held by Milgrim's in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.
ABOUT ten months after the fall of France, Jacques Chardonne produced a book, "Private Chronicle 1940," which bowed to the subjection of France and made a plea for the subjection of Europe to Hitler.

The Franklin Savings Bank filed plans yesterday for a sixteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 301-03 West Fifty-first Street and 851-65 Eighth Avenue to cost $1,110,000. H.I. Feldman is the architect. The latter also filed for a sixty-family apartment building to cost $210,000 at 250-54 West Twenty-third Street, owned by the Swanson Realty Corporation of 475 Fifth Avenue.
Tuesday's communique, as transmitted in English by the Free Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 -- Here at the University of Pennsylvania, where pre-season football prospects were rather on the bright side, despite the youthfulness of the Red and Blue squad, the second-half collapse against Navy last Saturday has left everyone "stunned" -- and the world is Coach George Munger's own.

PARIS, Nov. 1 -- While Parisians were engaged on a "pilgrimage of martyrdom" today, commemorating on All Saints' Day the execution of 75,000 men and women during four years of occupation, two trainloads of German shells and other munitions exploded on a siding in a "suburban station" from an unknown cause.

Speaking as chairman of the American Palestine Committee, Senator Robert F. Wagner declared last night at a meeting under the auspices of the Zionist Organization of America in Carnegie Hall that the objective of the Balfour Declaration -- the creation of a Jewish homeland in Palestine -- constituted "an important element of a just peace," and predicted that its realization may be expected as a consequence of the certain victory of the United Nations.
ROME, Nov. 1 (UP) -- A communique:
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Here is the text of President Roosevelt's message to the International Civil Aviation Conference:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The governing board of the Pan American Union voted unanimously today to transmit Argentina's request for a conference of American Foreign Ministers to discuss Argentina's "present misunderstanding" with the American republics to the twenty other Governments for study and recommendation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The National War Labor Board temporarily suspended today its discussion of the demand of the United Steel Workers, CIO, for a guaranteed annual wage and requested Lloyd K. Garrison, public member, to write a report for submission to the board later when a decision will be made.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The greatest commercial use for women pilots in this country in the future will not be on main airlines but on feed lines, and in such projects as aerial photography, fire-watching, crop-dusting and aviation instruction "in which they have well proved themselves," Miss Jacqueline Cochran, Wasp director, said today in an interview on the coming deactivation of the Wasp on Dec. 20.

Stocks of all major oil products increased last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gasoline supplies at the end of the period were 79,058,000 barrels, an increase of 692,000 over the 78,366,000 a week earlier. A year ago they were 69,092,000 barrels.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 31 (Delayed) -- Dignified ceremonies in the British colonial tradition, but made intimately Palestinian by association with leading figures of the Jewish and Moslem communities, were held today as Field Marshal Viscount Gort assumed office as High Commissioner and Commander in Chief in Palestine two months after the departure of his predecessor, Sir Harold MacMichael.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Functions of the War Production Board's Office of Civilian Requirements, official guardian of the non-military economy, were broadened today to give the agency a more authoritative voice in the determination of cutbacks of war contracts and the selection of new civilian production.

A person who has read the newspapers during the past three days can understand President Roosevelt's reasons for minimizing the crisis in China, but the recall of General Stilwell, the resignation of Ambassador Gauss and the further changes in American personnel in China which were authoritatively indicated yesterday raise questions that must be faced.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP) -- A revamped Black Hawk team found itself in the second period tonight to score six goals in fifteen minutes and hand the Rangers an 8-to 3 defeat before 10,324 fans in the first meeting between the two teams in the new National League hockey season.

BOSTON, Nov. 1 -- Crowds in the streets estimated by police at 250,000 to 400,000 greeted Governor Dewey here today as he finished a 200-mile tour of Massachusetts which carried him into the industrial cities of Pittsfield, Springfield and Worcester.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Twilight Tear, the smooth-striding 3-year-old filly from Warren Wright's Calumet Farm, tacked up another claim to horse-of-the-year honors today when she ran and hid from two rivals in the eighth Pimlico Special.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Nov. 1 (AP) -- With 35,000 spectators looking on, Civil Code, speedy 4-year-old gelding from the Charles S. Howard Stable, today captured the Premiere Handicap, feature six-fur-long sprint, as Hollywood Park inaugurated a thirty-four-day racing season, the first in southern California since Pearl Harbor.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- Japanese troops are storming the gates of Kweilin from the north, east and south, a Chinese High Command communique disclosed today, and street fighting is expected momentarily -- if it has not already begun -- in the heart of the ancient city.

Demand for tickets for the closing campaign rally for Governor Dewey at Madison Square Garden Saturday night already has exceeded ticket requests for similar rallies in the 1932, 1936 and 1940 Presidential camapigns, George H. Sibley, chairman of the committee on arrangements, announced yesterday.

Your recent editorial "Decline in Patents" begins with the statement "The National Association of Manufacturers is alarmed at the fall in the number of patents issued since this country declared war." It ends with the statement, "That there should be less inventive ability in these war years than sixty years ago is simply incredible."
Deferment of Congressional action on post-war conscription until the war has ended was urged yesterday in an official statement of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America.
Branch Rickey, who took over the destinies of the Brooklyn Dodgers two years ago when Larry MacPhail re-entered the Army, has become a part owner of the club.

Issuance today of a five-cent United States stamp honoring the long struggle of Korea for independence from a Japan that has enslaved and brutalized one of the finest of Asiatic peoples for forty years offers as good an opportunity as any to point out the bitter fruit that ripens for us all when aggression is allowed to go unchecked anywhere in the world.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 1 -- Commandos of the British Army and Navy splashed ashore onto the Island of Walcheren, last German bastion commanding the approaches to Antwerp, early this morning under cover of a thunderous bombardment from field guns firing across the Schelde and from the main batteries of the battleship Warspite and the monitors Erebus and Roberts.

While post-war trade in electrical appliances is likely to be enormous, it is not expected that sales by the public utilities will exceed the pre-war figures of 15 per cent of all sales of these items, C.E. Greenwood, commercial director of the Edison Electric Institute, said yesterday.

Indications are that stores selling nothing but frozen foods will have a definite place in communities from now on. The trend in that direction was further emphasized yesterday when an agency of the Deepfreeze division of Motor Products Corporation opened such a shop at Bethesda, Md., which is the first of its kind near Washington and among the first in the East.

In a head-and-head battle from the head of the stretch to the wire, William Ziegler Jr.'s Breezing Home yesterday captured the $10,975 New Rochelle Handicap, which was the main attraction for 21,947 persons at Jamaica.

Net sales of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. for the first nine months of 1944 amounted to $463,824,121, a new high record, compared with a previous high of $427,189,325 in the 1943 period, and total revenues were at a new peak of $483,079,611, against $449,264,198, according to the quarterly report issued yesterday.

The need for community agencies to supplement the Army program in helping veterans adjust to civilian life and a warning that agencies must not "bungle" in the handling of veteran problems were emphasized yesterday at a conference sponsored by the Vocational Advisory Service at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The United Light and Railways Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan for the liquidation of American Light and Traction Company.

A tribute to the War Fund drive, marked by urgent pleas for liberal support of the campaign because of its importance in many service-connected activities, was presented yesterday on the steps of the United States Subtreasury at Broad and Wall Streets by the Division of Drama of the New York City Federations of Women Clubs.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 1 -- Debate on the wisdom of adopting a new State Constitution neared the boiling point in New Jersey today and it appeared to be holding precedence in public interest over the Presidential and United States Senate campaigns, with balloting on all three issues less than a week away.

Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for the Senate, asserted last night at various meetings in the city that he had been a better friend of the working man than had his opponent, Robert F. Wagner. He listed his own record in behalf of labor as proof that he would be a better servant in the United States Senate.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 1 (AP) -- A United States Army Forces in China communique:

Two municipal agencies announced yesterday that henceforth their efforts to fill the demand for apartments during the current wartime shortage would be directed to service men, veterans and their families.

If a rabbit, six feet one and one-half inches tall, sits down beside you at Charlie's, that will be Harvey, and you may count yourself fortunate. Harvey appears to those who are happy, and to those who have taken a drink now and then through the years and are the better for it.

Probably the most puzzling problem in planning a one-room apartment is to find a bed that will be comfortable at night and look like a sofa in the daytime. All kinds of solutions have been offered, but usually the kind of convertible unit that looks trimmest in a living room, calls for a tiresome job of bedmaking before it can be used for sleeping.

LONDON, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- Premier Joseph Stalin announced tonight the final clearing of Germans from the entire nickel-rich Petsamo region as Berlin prepared the Reich for news of the abandonment of all Finland.

ADVANCE HEADQUARTERS ON LEYTE, Oct. 28 (Delayed) (AP) -- Embarking on a program to wipe out every vestige of Japanese influence, President Sergio Osmena and the Philippine Commonwealth Government reopened postoffices today and issued "victory" currency based on the American dollar, worth 2 pesos.

The demobilization of our war economy will present many intricate problems. In one segment, however, we are accumulating a large amount of experience while the war is still in progress and thus should be in a position to handle this phase with a minimum of dislocation after V-E day.

LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 2 -- The Red Army thrust within thirty-two miles of Budapest yesterday in a great drive rolling rapidly northwestward across the Hungarian plains between the Danube and Tisza Rivers.

WITH AMERICAN TROOPS, in the Netherlands, Nov. 1 (AP) -- A real-life version of Gary Cooper's bridge-blowing feat in "For Whom the Bell Tolls" was enacted by a daring young American second lieutenant on this front.

The annual harvest luncheon of the New York and New Jersey regions of the Mizrachi Women's Organization of America, at the Commodore Hotel yesterday, netted $10,000 for the summer camp fund to provide vacations for underprivileged children in Palestine.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- Formation of a committee to standardize Eastern college football rules and officiating so that "everybody will be playing the same game and understanding it," was announced today by Chairman Ray Morrison, Temple gridiron coach.

BRAZILIAN EXPEDITIONARY FORCE HEADQUARTERS, In Italy, Oct. 31 (Delayed) -- There is no tendency among Brazilian or American liaison officers here to claim that the Brazilian expeditionary force has established itself beyond a doubt as a combat unit equal to an enemy as experienced and stubborn as the Germans.
The Office of Price Administration went lyrical last night about price control.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Ships of the Royal Navy during the past six weeks have sunk thirty-one enemy warships and transports of various sizes and forty small craft, such as lighters, in the Aegean. In addition, sixteen warships and merchant ships and fifteen small craft have been severely damaged.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- The International Civil Aviation Conference opened today with a message from President Roosevelt urging the fifty participating nations to reach an agreement which would bar "great blocs of closed air" in the post-war world.

The eighteenth annual "booth campaign" of the New York City Cancer Committee began yesterday when Mrs. Francis J. Rigney, metropolitan commander of the Women's Field Army, and volunteer workers from that group opened in the main concourse of Pennsylvania Station the first of 100 booths planned for the city.

Two French films are slated to have local premieres this month. "Moulin Rouge," a musical starring Lucien Baroux and Rene Dary, will open within the next two weeks at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse. "Marthe Richard," described as the "story of France's greatest woman spy in the First World War," will arrive next Wednesday at the Fifth Avenue Playhouse.

Declaring that there had been "some trouble" lately in Iran on the subject of oil concessions, the British radio said yesterday that the United States and Great Britain were in accord with the decision of the Iranian Government to grant no oil concessions until after the war.

The New Zionist Organization of America made public yesterday an open letter to President Roosevelt declaring that his "recent statement on Palestine is not satisfactory to those seeking a just and speedy solution to the Jewish question."
OTTAWA, Nov. 1 -- Col. J.L. Ralston, Defense Minister, has resigned from the Federal Cabinet, it was learned reliably tonight.

The second quarter of next year supplies of collapsible metal tubes will be large enough to satisfy normal civilian demand, W.M. Rose, president of the Sun Tube Corporation, Hillside, N.J., stated yesterday at the sixth annual meeting of the Packaging Institute in the Hotel New Yorker.

HEADQUARTERS, FOURTEENTH UNITED STATES AIR FORCE in China, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault in his first interview since creation of a separate China theatre, said today he hoped it would be possible in the future to "shuttle-bomb" the Japanese between China and the Philippines.

The first major challenge to the frequency-modulation system devised by Maj. Edwin H. Armstrong was offered last night by the Radio Corporation of America in the presentation of details of a new receiver designed by George L. Beers, staff engineer for RCA.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Harvesting continued virtually uninterrupted under favorable weather conditions in most parts of the country during the last week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- A Senate campaign investigating committee, which delved into charges by Senator Taft against the CIO's Political Action Committee, announced today an inquiry into CIO complaints against him.

Details of the debt adjustment plan of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company involving $498,000,000 of that carrier's obligations were mailed yesterday to its security holders. This plan of adjustment, which is to be carried out under provisions of Chapter XV of the Bankruptcy Act, was approved by directors on Sept. 20, last.
PARIS, Nov. 1 -- At Patou's opening today emphasis was laid on the sports note in striped or tartan fabrics.

Eight hundred men representing a substantial cross-section of American industry met here yesterday at a luncheon sponsored by the National Rehabilitation Committee, Inc., to pledge their support to a nation-wide program to provide the fullest opportunity for restoration of wounded war veterans to civilian occupations.

Thirty-eight women -- leaders in education, politics, clubs, social work and society -- made public yesterday an open letter to women voters urging the re-election of President Roosevelt on the basis of his foreign policy. The signers include Democrats, independent voters and registered Republicans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Army Air Forces, as of yesterday, consisted of about 74,500 aircraft, of which about 12,000 were first-line planes actually in combat overseas, with 6,000 first-line combat planes behind these as a ready reserve, an official AAF spokesman disclosed today.

In addition to Douglas S. Freeman's final volume in his "Lee's Lieutenants" series, three biographies of Civil War leaders are on the fall list. They are "Fighting Joe Hooker," by Walter H. Hebert, to be published tomorrow by Bobbs-Merrill; "'First With the Most' Forrest," by Robert Selph Henry, published Tuesday by Bobbs-Merrill, and "Ranger Mosby," by Virgil Carrington Jones, a University of North Carolina publication.

Representatives of industrial plants in the metropolitan area received last night from the Greater New York Safety Council plaques and certificates of merit for outstanding accomplishments in preventing lost-time accidents. The presentations were made at the council's second annual award dinner, held at the Hotel Commodore.

The 2,200-ton super destroyer Bole, named in honor of the late Lieut. Comdr. John A. Bole Jr., USN, who went down with the submarine Amberjack in the Pacific on March 22, 1943, was launched yesterday at the Bethlehem Steel and Shipbuilding Company's yard at Mariners Harbor, S.I., in the presence of high-ranking naval officials, a delegation of students from the New York School of Printing and 700 shipyard workers.
