WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Prohibition party leads other minor parties in the number of candidates for President, Congress and Governor this year with seventy-three. It has also succeeded in getting its Presidential electors to the total of twenty-six, on the ballot in more States than any other non-major political group.

Italian monarchists, writes Herbert Matthews in his story of a long audience with Crown Prince Humbert, want a plebiscite to determine their future government. There is good reason, or at least a very good precedent, why anti-republicans should not shrink from a popular vote.

Emphasizing that the Communist question in China is not responsible for the recall of Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, Lin Mousheng, Chinese author, declared yesterday that the incident occurred because of the "clash of personalities" between the general and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.
Following is the text of Governor Dewey's speech, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Increases were reported last week in the stocks of all major oil products. Despite the heavy demand for war purposes, the supplies of each of these products now are above a year ago. The accumulation of these stocks is causing some concern lest there should develop a shortage of storage space.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange eased slightly yesterday. It closed unchanged to 4 points lower than Tuesday's final prices as a result of hedge selling after opening 1 to 5 points higher on buying by mills.

Marshall Field disclosed yesterday his intention of furnishing capital for intensive development of a book publishing program and for related projects that may be considered in the future, under an arrangement just completed by which Pocket Books, Inc., and Simon Schuster, Inc., will become part of Field Enterprises, Inc., a corporation organized by Mr. Field.

Bonds called before maturity for payment in October aggregated $160,486,000, compared with $145,480,000 in the preceding month and $168,294,000 in the corresponding month in 1943. As in the preceding month, retirements by public utility companies featured the bond prepayments.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Nov. 1 (AP) -- British troops have driven two more miles down the Myitkyina-Mandalay railroad in northern Burma to within one mile of Mawlu, sixty-five miles southwest of Myityina, the Allied Command announced today.

The battle that has been going on for nearly two months to clear the approaches to the port of Antwerp is now drawing to a victorious close. With the few Germans remaining south of the Schelde estuary compressed into a small and isolated pocket, British and Canadian forces have begun the final assault on the last German stronghold barring the way to the port.
Secret wartime evacuation ended yesterday morning for $20,000,000 worth of the rarest books, prints and manuscripts owned by the New York Public Library.

An underwriting group headed by W.C. Langley Co. will offer today $16,981,000 of first mortgage and collateral trust 3 per cent bonds, due in 1974, of the Potomac Edison Company. The bonds are to be priced at 102 1/2 and accrued interest.

The old Chatsworth Apartments consisting of a twelve-story and penthouse building and an eight-story building at 340 and 344 West Seventy-second Street, between West End Avenue and Riverside Drive, have been purchased by the Jennico Corporation, Harry Lefrak, president, from Paul S. Hitlin, operator and builder.

STOCKHOLAM, Sweden, Nov. 1 -- So long as the victorious powers have not yet defined who is a war criminal, "it cannot be expected that we make our own definitions," Thorvald Berquist, Swedish Minister of Justice, said in an interview today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Chungking in English and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- A feature in today's stock markets was a sharp jump in Argentine railway stocks following a report from Buenos Aires that the new decree authorized a 10 per cent increase in freight rates will stabilize the position for the next two years.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 1 -- Victor McLaglen has been signed by Columbia to star with Chester Morris in "Man of the Deep," a story of the training of divers for the United States Army salvage corps, by H. Vernon Dixon. The picture will be put into production within three weeks under the direction of Del Lord.

The Brooklyn Museum has opened in its Egyptian department an exhibition of seals and other objects, the most important item being a basalt weight inscribed with the name of King Khufu or Cheops, the builder of the Great Pyramid.

UNITED STATES NINTH AIR FORCE ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, Oct. 29 (Delayed) -- With a German civilian aircraft mechanic at the controls, a Junkers 188 was shot down today on a forward fighter field of the Ninth Air Force. The pilot, in civilian dress, said he had never before flown a plane.

Last night the Ballet International in its season at the International Theatre added another world premiere to its repertoire, this time in the shape of Simon Semenoff's "Memories" set to music of Brahms in an arrangement by Maurice Baron.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 1 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today that several warships of the United States Third and Seventh Fleets were damaged in the Battle of the Philippines last week. Having previously announced the sinking of six Ameri can ships in the action, he said neither the names nor the amount of damage sustained to the other vessels would be disclosed at this time.

S.A. Seaver bought for investment from the Groton Realty Corporation the twelve-story loft building on a plot 64 by 98 feet at 29-33 West Thirty-sixth Street in its first change of ownership since the building was erected in 1915. The Cross Brown Company negotiated the sale of the property, which is assessed at $330,000.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 1 (AP) -- In again, out again, Bob Kelly's out and -- now he's in again.

LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- Germany rocked under almost continuous Allied air blows yesterday for the fifth straight day as an estimated 1,000 Royal Air Force planes struck in the evening from the western front to Berlin after American heavy bombers had hammered Ruhr and Rhineland oil and railway centers by day.

Mr. Webster, succinct and direct as usual, says: to turn up, break up, or trench; to proceed laboriously. As any farmer will tell you, there is plowing and there is plowing. In a field studded with stones, seen and unseen, plowing becomes a sort of wrestling match, with the odds favoring the stones.

Robert S. Field's letter in your Oct. 28 issue purports to offer a new justification for "fair protective tariffs," hitherto ignored by free traders. The justification which he expounds is, I suggest, neither new nor valid.

Tomorrow night's departures from the Broadway sector have jumped to four with the addition of "No Way Out" and "Meet A Body." The other two, as previously announced, are "The Visitor" and "The Merry Widow." Only the last one will take to the road.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The "liberation" of Lithuania has virtually turned the country "from Axis enslavement into a new domination by the Soviet invader," Povilas Zadeikis, the Lithuanian Minister, declares in a note left with the State Department.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 28 were 916,446 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 10,505 cars, or 1.2 per cent more than for the preceding week, 32,719 cars, or 3.7 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 25,886 cars, or 2.9 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

The New Jersey Fish and Game Commission promises sportsmen who hunt that State for upland game when the season opens a week from today an abundance of pheasants, quail and rabbits. It backs the promise with some figures of what has been done in the restocking line during the past year.

Perhaps there are among your readers a few who are not wholly stunned into insensibility by the political din which is raging, and who may be interested in this bit of historical knowledge: It seems that on July 4 1776, Congress became interested in the subject of flints; in fact, it became so interested that it passed the following resolution:

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Wiliam G. Woolfolk, president of the United Light Power Company, announced today plans for construction of a $70,000,000 natural gas pipeline from the Hugoton fields of Kansas and Oklahoma to serve cities and towns in Iowa, Illinois, Wisconsin and Michigan.

PARIS, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The de Gaulle Government faced a showdown today on one of the most difficult issues raised in its relations with French Communists -- whether to permit the return from Moscow of Maurice Thorez, secretary general of the French Communist party.

James Paul Donahue, 29-year-old cousin of Barbara Hutton and himself heir to a part of the Woolworth fortune, has been notified in Florida, where he has been flying for two years with the Civil Air Patrol, that he has been classified 1-A by his draft board here and will be inducted next Friday, it was disclosed yesterday by Col. Arthur V. McDermott, City Selective Service Director.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- President Roosevelt expressed hopes for freedom for the Korean people today in a message sent to participants in a ceremony where a new 5-cent Korean commemorative stamp was issued as a tribute to the resistance against Japanese oppression.

Mack Trucks, Inc., reported yesterday in its operating statement for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a net profit of $2,185,595, after provision of $7,680,000 for Federal income and excess profits taxes and a $375,000 reserve for contingencies.

Mrs. Thomas E. Dewey and Mrs. John W. Bricker greeted 3,000 Republican women campaign workers at a reception yesterday afternoon in the grand ballroom of the Roosevelt Hotel, Madison Avenue at Forty-fifth Street.

In spite of what other people who saw the Giants pick up seventeen easy points against the Eagles last Sunday and then lose the game, 24 -- 17, Coach Steve Owen still remains optimistic about the whole thing.

Reluctance of cotton mills to fix prices on any more cotton than is necessary to cover current orders and a greater amount of hedge selling than the trade expected led yesterday to a slightly easier cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange, and final prices were unchanged to 6 points net lower than on Wednesday.

A 4-year-old fox terrier came to the aid of its mistress yesterday on Riverside Drive between 114th and 115th Streets and fought off a slim Negro attacker about 26 years old who escaped after the dog chased him two blocks.

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- The open break between the Communists and Gen. Charles de Gaulle, which has long seemed inevitable, came today when the political bureau of the French Communist party declared that it refused to "associate itself in any way' with the Government's decision to disarm and dissolve the so-called Patriotic Militia.

There has been an increase of $107,000,000,000 in the liquid assets of individuals and corporations in the past three years, according to the Federal Reserve Bulletin. These liquid assets are represented by currency, demand and time deposits and Government securities.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Easton Purse for $2,000, over a mile and a furlong at Rockingham Park, went to Level and Gorman's High Name, in a photo finish with R. McKeever's General Jack today. Irving Gushen's Unknown Reward was third. The winner's time was 1:55. High Name paid $9.40 for $2.
Ned Calmer, CBS correspondent, reported from the front of the United States First Army yesterday, that the percentage of soldiers sending in their votes varied greatly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Max Swiren, special counsel for the Office of Price Administration, told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that "rail earnings were being held at shocking levels in the face of the fact that the country was engaged in a terrible war."

ALBANY, Nov. 2 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein made it plain today that employes must have sufficient time to vote on Election Day and if a plant closes down for part of the day, the employer would still be required to give the employe two hours off.

BOSTON, Nov. 2 -- If future wars are to be avoided, the United States and Great Britain must collaborate closely with the Soviet Union in the immediate years ahead, faculty members of twenty-nine colleges and universities reported today. Under the auspices of the Universities Committee on Post-War International Problems, they have been deliberating on "Post-War Relations With the Soviet Union."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Donald M. Nelson, former chairman of the War Production Board, was asked by President Roosevelt today to return to China at the earliest possible date and organize a WPB in that country to increase the output of its war industries.

In the weary months of waiting before the attack on the Normandy beaches last June it must have seemed to Americans at home that little progress was being made toward victory. Part of this attitude was attributed to the confusion of voices over the efficacy of the Allied air assaults on the Continent and a considerable division of opinion as to how badly the German Luftwaffe had been punished.

Managers of 197 hotels in the Hotel Association of New York City were urged yesterday to limit the stay of civilian transients to five days in an effort to move closer to the solution of the rooming problem.

MURDO, S.D., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Representative Francis Case, Republican of South Dakota, said here last night that "it is now clear that Harry Hopkins, chairman of the Munitions Assignment Board and former WPA director, was responsible for the recall of Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell and Ambassador Clarence E. Gauss from China."

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed increase in holdings of United States Government securities and note circulation for the system as a whole to be $344,210,000 and $188,680,000, respectively, while gold holdings decreased $10,000,000 and the ratio of reserve went to 51.2.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A supplement to today's communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- The War Food Administration is expected to recommend to the States some time this month 1945 food and fiber crop goals totaling 363,000,000 acres, or 4,000,000 more than the acreage planted this year.

Satirical eyebrows have been lifted and quizzical smiles have been smiled over the presence of Frank Sinatra and Bill ("Bojangles") Robinson on the hustings in support of their Presidential candidate. Yet nothing could be more fitting in a democracy.
Following are excerpts, from Governor Dewey's speeches yesterday as reported by The Associated Press:

Declaring that the functions of the Protestant Church are being crowded into an increasingly narrow area, the Rev. Dr. Roswell P. Barnes, associate general secretary of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, appealed yesterday for a clarification of the church's duties and responsibilities toward the community.

Forty-second Street Fotoshop, Inc., has leased the five upper floors at 20 East Forty-second Street from the Guaranty Trust Company through Tankoos, Smith Co. The firm now occupies the entire adjacent building at 18 East Forty-second Street and will use the additional area of approximately 10,000 square feet for the expansion of its business.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 2 -- The bitter struggle for Walcheren Island, last important German position denying the use of Antwerp to Allied shipping, continued successfully today, with British marines and infantry fighting their way into the heavily defended enemy gun positions at Flushing and Westkapelle.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Communique 208:

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- The policy of the United States Government on the organization of post-war international commercial aviation on the basis of freedom for competitive private enterprise was officially stated for the first time today by Adolf A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State and chairman of the United States delegation, at a plenary session of the international civil aviation conference, which had just elected him permanent president.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 2 -- Paulette Goddard has been named by Paramount for the co-starring lead with Ray Milland and Sonny Tufts in "The Well Groomed Bride," a comedy by Robert Russell, author of "The More the Merrier.'' Miss Goddard will start the picture on Jan. 15 instead of "My Favorite Brunette," which she was to have done with Bob Hope.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Directors of the Chicago North Western Railway Company declared today a dividend of $5 a share on the preferred stock for 1944. They also declared one of $5 a share on the common stock, payable from earned surplus accumulated since Jan. 1, 1939, the effective date of the plan of reorganization.

Sixty thousand American soldiers who received types of wounds since Pearl Harbor from which they would have died in World War I, are now alive and well as the result of advances in modern military medicine, Maj. Gen. Norman T. Kirk, Surgeon General of the Army, told the annual meeting of the Association of Military Surgeons yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
LONDON, Friday, Nov. 3 -- Seven new American Eighth Air Force records were set over Germany yesterday:

Tax refunds must be speeded up by the Government if they are to be helpful in building up reserves for American business to cover post-war expenditures such as deferred repairs, dismissal pay to war workers, inventory losses and scraping of special equipment, Maurice Austin, chairman of the Federal taxation committee of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants, declared last night.

If the Oliver H.P. Garretts -- man and wife -- are to be credited, Gramercy Park belies its stately reputation. Behind those Stanford White facades lurk the furies, cracking their fingers, pouring poison, pushing girls out of the high french windows.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- President Roosevelt by proclamation today set Nov. 23 as Thanksgiving Day, thus following the law enacted by Congress Dec. 26, 1941.

ROME, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- British forces, narrowing the Vardar Valley trap into which they are herding the Germans, have pushed beyond the northern Greek port of Salonika in pursuit of the Nazis, who are even using stolen fire engines in their flight, an Allied communique announced today.

LONDON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The London Star declared in a leading editorial today that Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek must be persuaded to recast his government so that the Chinese armies could be drawn into combined action.

Designed to give superior service to customers and to provide many jobs in hotels "during the critical reconversion period," a six-point post-war program has been adopted by the American Hotel Association, it was announced yesterday, which is based on the organization's belief that post-war activity and the problems of re-employment are largely in the hands of American business men.

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- The story of how Paris was saved from threatened destruction and at the same time liberated from German occupation by the happy concurrence of an unexpected circumstance has just been told in detail to this correspondent by the principal French and neutral participants.

PARIS, Friday, Nov. 3 -- An important decision by the French Government regarding finance is impending after a conference last night between Gen. Charles de Gaulle and his Ministers of Finance and National Economy. Much mystery surrounded this meeting and an announcement was expected at any moment until 1 o'clock this morning, when it became known that nothing would be made public before late today.

With the prediction of a sweeping victory for President Roosevelt, Vice President Henry A. Wallace outlined before an audience of business men last night the program which the Administration plans to carry out on the domestic land international fronts to provide full employment and assure a stable peace.

An international agreement dividing up the cotton export markets on a quota basis is forecast for the post-war period by the National City Bank of New York in its monthly review of business. Such an agreement, the bank believes, would be the alternative to subsidized dumping of cotton surpluses in the export market.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- E.M. Ebert, director of the bureau of inquiry of the Interstate Commerce Commission, asserted in a brief filed today with the commission that the Alleghany Corporation has violated Paragraph (4) of Section 5 of the Interstate Commerce Act, and that the commission should take such action as, in its judgment, is warranted to prevent further continuance of such violation.

Emily Cunningham Myles, 18 years old, daughter of Mrs. Van Henry Cartmell of Roslyn, L.I., and Robert C. Myles, a lawyer in this city, was adjudged a youthful offender yesterday by Judge Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. in General Sessions and placed on probation for one year on her admission to participation last Summer in the theft of $2,600 in wearing apparel from Lord Taylor's Fifth Avenue store.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- After weeks of inaction while Allied bombers methodically laid waste to German cities the Luftwaffe rose today nearly 500 strong against 2,000 United States Eighth Air Force planes to bring about the biggest air battle ever fought between fighter forces.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Led by higher prices for oats and rye and seasonal advances for five poultry and eggs, the Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of commodity prices in primary markets rose 0.1 per cent during the last week of October.

Replying to the criticism of the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee and its charge that he and the Office of Price Administration had been unfair and had stirred up landlord-tenant friction in their administration of residential rent control here, Daniel P. Woolley, regional head of the OPA, issued a statement yesterday branding the fair rent committee as "a landlords' lobby dedicated to breaking down the rent ceilings."

A Yorkville plot was acquired for future development yesterday when a row of five four-story apartment houses at 229 to 237 East Eighty-fifth Street, near Second Avenue, was sold by the 229 Realty Corporation to an investing client of Hardy, Brauneis Naumann, Inc.
LONDON, Nov. 2 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, declared last night that the power and dignity of labor had been weakened by New Deal regimentation, manipulation and exploitation. The Secretary of State asserted that New York, by comparison, had been comparatively free of both labor strife and strikes during the Administration of Governor Dewey.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 2 -- Only the official returns of Tuesday's election can show whether Governor Dewey, by his trip to the anthracite coal regions today or as a result of other recent developments, has gained extra force which, according to observers, he needed to capture Pennsylvania's thirty-five electoral votes.

Accusing Governor Dewey of "desperate, contemptible fanning of the flames of religious hatred," Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, charged last night that "this Dewey smear campaign of hate and prejudice follows the pattern contrived by Adolf Hitler and the unspeakable Goebbels."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- James Lawrence Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today that he had resigned from the Government service, effective Nov. 15, to resume the practice of law in New York.
The long battle to open the sea approaches to Antwerp was nearing its end yesterday, as British Army and Marine Commandos, landed from the sea, commenced the conquest of Walcheren Island.

THIS column has studiously refrained from printing letters from readers where the personal side is stressed. But one arrived the other day from Pvt. E.R.A. Buetow of the University of North Dakota which was so unusual and so amusing that it seemed worth passing along, even though this reporter has a suspicion that the lad from North Dakota is pulling his leg. Here is his letter:
DETROIT, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings poured in the goals tonight before a crowd of 7,223 in handing the New York Rangers their third straight defeat, 10 to 3, in the National Hockey League.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 2 -- Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City and his "stooges" were accused today by Gov. Walter E. Edge and other advocates of the proposed State Constitution of resorting to misrepresentation and appeals to class, racial and religious prejudices in their efforts to have the document rejected at the referendum next Tuesday.

The First National Bank of Chicago was the successful bidder yesterday for $27,000,000 of refunding bonds of the Chicago Sanitary District, receiving the award on a bid of 100.45 for 1 3/4s. The financing consisted of $25,500,000 of refunding bonds, due Jan. 1, 1965, optional for call Jan. 1, 1946 to 1964; and $1,500,000 of construction bonds, due Jan. 1, 1964, optional Jan. 1, 1946 to 1963.

MONTREAL, Nov. 2 (Canadian Press) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs, who pinned the only home-ice defeat of the league campaign on the Canadiens last spring, gave Montreal its first whipping of the young National Hockey League season, 4 -- 1, at the Forum tonight.

Fresh eggs are scarcer at this time of year than any other, according to a spokesman for the trade, who explains that during November the farmers kill the hens that are poor layers and replenish their flocks with new birds. This season the shortage is further aggravated by the fact that the Government is buying heavily for its needs, which leaves few large, medium or small sizes for consumers.

HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Fist fights broke out on the floor and three groups chanted "We want Roosevelt" during a thirty minute speech tonight by Senator W. Lee O'Daniel. The talk was sponsored by the Texas "Regulars an anti-Roosevelt faction.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- During the week ended Nov. 1 member bank reserve balances increased $143,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Additions to member bank reserves arose from an increase of $366,000,000 in reserve bank credit and a decrease of $13,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks, offset in part by increases of $193,000,000 in money and circulation, $13,000,000 in Treasury cash and $29,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The stock markets again were cheerful today although the volume of business done was slightly lower than of late.

ROME, Nov. 2 -- In his first press conference since the early days of the Anzio beachhead, Gen. Sir Harold R.L.G. Alexander, Allied commander in the Mediterranean theatre, acknowledged that Allied troops in Italy were "rather stuck" right now, but declared that drives of the Fifth and Eighth Armies would not be over until the last Germans had been cleared out of Italy.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Friday, Nov. 3 -- American troops overwhelmed Carigara, bulwark of the enemy retreat route on the north coast of Leyte, this morning, and Gen. Douglas MacArthur said that "the end of the Leyte-Samar campaign is in sight."

ABOARD HEADQUARTERS SHIP, in North Sea, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- With her hold plugged and her deck dented, this vessel today was led back to port from Walcheren Island by a straggling convoy of battered ships that survived what probably was the greatest short-range ship-to-shore gun duel of this war.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Testimony before the Interstate Commerce Commission today opened the way for a ruling on the legality of the Alleghany Corporation's control of the properties of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad.
Clark Brothers Company, Inc., to Fuller Smith Ross, Inc., effective Jan. 1, bringing to three the divisions of Dresser Industries now being served by the agency.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 2 -- In a series of speeches in Fairfield County today, Vice President Henry A. Wallace urged the voters of the Fourth Congressional District to replace Representative Clare Boothe Luce with Miss Margaret Connors, Democratic candidate.

Sharing a nation-wide broadcast with President Roosevelt, Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic national chairman, accused Governor Dewey and his Republican supporters last night of building their campaign on hate, lies, disunity, division and bigotry.

Looking and feeling quite chipper, Ed Barrow, veteran president of the Yankees, was back in his office yesterday after his twenty-three-day vacation devoted mainly to hunting and fishing on Tom Yawkey's estate near Georgetown, S.C.

The John Eichler Brewing Company has purchased from the 110 Seventh Avenue Corporation the three-story building at 3544 Third Avenue, the Bronx, formerly occupied by the Mayer Brewing Company. The building, on a plot 37 by 150 feet, will be altered for use by the purchaser.

One of the sharpest reductions in assessed valuation ever recorded for a large Manhattan property has just been ordered by Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer on the apartment building at 845 Fifth Avenue. The cut amounted to more than 50 per cent.

Collectors of American Art will open the fall season with a reception on Sunday from 5 to 7 P.M. at the Contemporary Arts Gallery, 106 East Fifty-seventh Street. Emily A. Francis, director of the gallery, will speak.

ROME, Nov. 2 -- Anecdotes about himself, Lieut. Gen. Carl A. Spaatz and Alexander E. Bogomoloff, Ambassador to the French Government in Paris, enlivened Gen. Sir Harold R.L.G. Alexander's review of the Italian campaign at his press conference today.

ROME, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- Eighth Army units, joining their bridgeheads to the southeast and southwest of the Via Emilia, city of Forli, crashed through weak German defenses today with tanks and infantry divisions to gain more than half of the Forli airport.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 2 -- The United States should accept the suggestion of Argentina that a Pan-American conference be held "to face frankly the present impasse," Dr. Samuel Guy Inman, author and lecturer on Latin-American affairs, declared here today at a meeting of the Jersey City Rotary Club.

Screen rights to "Forever Amber," the recently published novel by Kathleen Winsor, have been purchased by Twentieth Century-Fox for $200,000, one of the highest prices ever paid by a film company for a novel. According to Annie Laurie Williams, the author's agent, the deal is contingent on the Hays office's approval of the screen treatment of the book now being prepared by the studio.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 2 (AP) -Rocket engine-power forms the basis of large new post-war industries, G. Edward Pendray, assistant to the president of Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, said tonight, reporting that engines already developed could cover the 260 crow-flight miles between here and Pittsburgh in five or six minutes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The President and his advisers now have under consideration, and are discussing with a British delegation here headed by Lord Keynes, a supplemental, "second-phase" lend-lease proposal made by Prime Minister Churchill to Mr. Roosevelt at the last Quebec conference which, if agreed to, will permit Great Britain to acquire at least $2,500,000,000 of nonmilitary supplies for resale in its export trade.
LONDON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Snooky, the City Hall cat, has been missing since Halloween and Tom Halton, the night custodian, is in a dither. The cat, a tortoise shell hued animal with white markings is the apple of Tom's eye and the disappearance of Mayor La Guardia, the Board of Estimate and the City Council could not have upset him more.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Students of the University of Texas, led by Malcolm Wallace of Dallas, a former marine, cut classes today and marched on the State Capitol in howling protest over the ouster of President Homer P. Rainey. Dr. T. S. Painter, Professor of Biology, was named acting president by the Board of Regents.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- Here are the highlights of the speech before the International Civil Aviation Conference in which Adolf A. Berle Jr. outlined the United States' position with respect to post-war world air transport:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Maury Maverick, chairman of the Smaller War Plants Corporation, said today that employers of fewer than 100 wage earners would be exempt from labor clearance requirements of the spot authorization (reconversion) plan, but that some Government quarters which he would not identify were opposed to the exemption at this time.
ROME, Nov. 2 (UP) -- A communique:

Representatives of the Army Air Force School of Applied Tactics at Orlando, Fla., spread out before the annual meeting of the Association of Military Surgeons yesterday a feast of exotic dishes such as no maitre d'hotel in any of New York's cuisines had ever dreamed of.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- OPA price controls have not been perfect, Koppel Kekselblatt, supervisory price analyst of the consumer goods price divisions of the OPA, admitted today in answering complaints that in many instances prices of both new and old lines of merchandise were above the March, 1942, level.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Just before the House of Commons began a two-day debate on the Government's social insurance plans Dr. Edith Summerskill, M.P., went to the bar of the House today and presented to the Speaker a petition signed, by thousands of working housewives asking for legislation to make the housewife an equal partner, not only in social security but in the whole income of the home.

ON BOARD THE DEWEY SPECIAL TRAIN, Nov. 2 -- Governor Dewey carried his campaign today from Massachusetts to Maryland, then back to Pennsylvania, seeking to bolster the Republican chances in those politically doubtful States as the contest draws to a close.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Friday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- American forces completed a junction at Carigara, key town on the northwest coast of Leyte, and another column thrust across this central Philippines island in the south to tighten a gigantic clamp on Ormoc -- last Japanese escape port.

Mrs. Sidney Hillman of 237 East Twentieth Street, wife of the labor leader, left her alligator handbag in a Jamaica train of the IND system yesterday afternoon, and owing to the honesty of a subway employee she recovered it an hour later at the Church Avenue subway station.
The four-story dwelling at 348 West Twenty-first Street has been sold by Marie Demuth to Hyman Bernstein for occupancy through Louis Schrag, Inc.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden will set a formal mark upon the recognition of the French Provisional Government by visiting Paris in the near future at the invitation of Gen. Charles de Gaulle and the French Foreign Minister, Georges Bidault.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Allied Military Commission in Italy reported tonight that by the end of this year 2,300,000 tons of food and other supplies will have been furnished to war-stricken civilians.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 2 -- Although they have appointed a special medical commission for the purpose, German authorities have been unable to check the ravages of "Russian flu," which for some time has been slowing up war production and the construction of new fortifications in the Reich.

ANTWERP, Belgium, Nov. 2 -- The port of Antwerp, gateway for supplies essential to the conquest of Germany, will be ready to handle thousands of tons of ammunition, fuel and food and the troops that will flow to the American and British Armies soon after mopping-up operations along the river Schelde are completed.

Morgan Stanley Co. head a group of twenty-four underwriting firms which will offer today, subject to authorization by the Interstate Commerce Commission, $40,000,000 of Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad Company's first and refunding mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds, due Aug. 1, 1974. The bonds will be priced at 100 3/4, to yield 3.71 per cent to maturity.

President Roosevelt's removal of Gen. Joseph Stilwell as commander of the China-Burma-India theatre was "the only correct thing possible in the circumstances," Dr. C.L. Hsia, director of the Chinese News Service, said in a statement issued last night, The Associated Press reported.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte Nov. 2 -- The Japanese have made their big naval play for the Philippines and lost, and henceforth either must virtually abandon the vast stretch of ocean between Singapore and the South China Sea or face the dangerous alternative of draining their home waters of what remains of the Imperial Home Fleet and opening the road for our ships to strike directly at Formosa, the Ryukyu Islands and Japan herself.

Joel D. Marder, architectural engineer, formerly with the Washington office of the facilities bureau of the War Production Board and with Vermilya-Brown Company, has opened an office at 155 East Forty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- From now until the first of next year grade B eggs, now 16 to 19 cents lower a dozen than Grade A eggs, will continue to be one of the best food-value buys on the market, according to experts of the War Food Administration.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 2 -- Challenging President Roosevelt's stated belief in the principle of free enterprise, Gov. John W. Bricker asserted tonight that the President's expressions of friendliness toward business were contradicted by the record of the New Deal and the philosophy of some of its principal proponents.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 2 (AP) -- A Sampson naval training center sailor and his wife won today their fight to vote in Tuesday's Presidential election when the Appellate Division, Fourth Department, directed the Seneca County Board of Elections to register them election day and allow them to vote.

After more than a decade of sponsoring various school lunch programs, most often in cooperation with another agency, the New York City Board of Education will take over exclusive supervision of the current program "sometime before the end of this school year" and will operate it on a centralized basis to encourage greater attention to the teaching of proper food habits, it was learned yesterday.

BOSTON, Nov. 2 -- Senator David I. Walsh accepted today a personal invitation of President Roosevelt to join the Presidential party in Massachusetts on Saturday and appear with the Chief Executive for a major campaign address here.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2 -- The Cirminello quadruplets, three girls and a boy, who were born yesterday to Mrs. Joseph Cirminello in the Lying-in Hospital, were reported today to be in good condition, with all of the infants expected to live.

The old adage that "truth will out" took a severe beating yesterday afternon during the observation of United Seamen's Day of the New York War Fund, in the International Building in Rockefeller Center. In fact, lies were at a premium and the bigger the lie the more welcome its teller was -- all in good, clean fun, though, as part of the USS Tall Tales Contest.

Great Britain, according to London newspapers, is increasingly lagging behind the United States in matters of post-war economic preparedness. While declaiming British needs for overseas trade, a growing press chorus chides the Churchill Government for its unwillingness to help British manufacturers and exporters to cultivate foreign markets.

A last-hour buying wave which almost bridged the gap of losses over the past two weeks produced yesterday on the stock market the strongest rally in approximately a month. Gains in the industrials averaged a point, although the aircrafts, favorites of the two previous sessions, suffered from profit-taking.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- A meeting of United Nations representatives to perfect the mechanism for keeping the peace which was outlined at the recent Dumbarton Oaks conference will be held "as soon as practicable" after Congress reconvenes, Nov. 14, Senator Connally, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, said today.

The two four-story apartment buildings at 148 and 158 Linden Boulevard, Brooklyn, have been sold by the Sanemo Realty Corporation to an out-of-town investing client of Byrne, Bowman Forshay, Inc., brokers in the transaction.

Too long a time had elapsed since Pierre Monteux, conductor of the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra, had appeared in this city as leader of a major symphonic body in a subscription performance. But last night in Carnegie Hall Mr. Monteux appeared as the season's first guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, and his opening performances of Beethoven's Third Leonore overture and Brahms' Third Symphony were things to delight in and remember.
Following is the text of President Roosevelt's address, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIES:

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- Senator Harry S. Truman, winding up an 8,000-mile campaign tour in Pittsburgh with a final bid for the labor vote, said tonight that working people knew better than to rely upon the Republican party to safeguard the social reform fostered by, the New Deal.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Sigourney Thayer, 47 years old, of Delafield Island, Darien, Conn., a flier in the first World War and an executive at the Allentown plant of the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation, was killed today in an automobile collision near here.

Eddie Arcaro got 100 per cent at Jamaica yesterday when he rode three winners in three tries to the delight of his supporters, who feel that the Covington, Ky., lad, who now hails from Rockville Center, L.I., is one rider who "bats a thousand."

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- Chinese defenders of the walled city of Kweilin are fighting bitterly at the north and south railway stations, but have been forced to give ground to Japanese troops in the northwestern suburb, a High Command communique reported today.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A United States Army Forces in China communique:

BALTIMORE, Nov. 2 (AP) -- M. Gilbert's Morgil's Lad, a $25.30 for $2 shot, and Rough Feathers, owned by M.J. Meyers, took the daily double at Pimlico today, paying $1,194.60. Apprentice Dick Meade piloted Morgil's Lad to victory in the first race.
LONDON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Lieut. Thomas Radonski of Milwaukee, Wis., bombardier, shot down a jet-propelled German plane as his Flying Fortress came off the bomb run.

Lehman Brothers, the Wisconsin Company and Hallgarten Co. head a banking group that offered yesterday the unsubscribed part of 99,960 shares of Kimberly-Clark Corporation common stock of no par value not subscribed for by common stockholders.

A uniform test in modern European history, to replace the examination formerly given by the Board of Regents, is being planned by the New York City high school division, it became known yesterday. Because of a change in the State history curriculum, the Statewide test formerly given by the Regents has been dropped.

BAINBRIDGE, Md., Nov. 2 (AP) -- The No. 13 jinx hung over the undefeated players from Bainbridge Naval Training Center today as they prepared to make their major bid for national football recognition against unbeaten North Carolina Naval Pre-Flight on Sunday at Chapel Hill, N.C.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Twenty-two of the 125 combination passenger-cargo vessels in the pre-war American merchant marine have been sunk during the war, according to a report by the Office of War Information, discussing the role of the merchant ship during the conflict.

Spring lines of the Manhattan Shirt Company will be alloted strictly, it was reported yesterday by the company, continuing a policy in effect since the beginning of the war. Salesmen are leaving for the road following a meeting here of all sales personnel.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- Strength in corn based on a forecast for rain or snow in the northern main corn belt and a better demand for the cash article imparted considerable strength today to the grain markets on the Board of Trade. Commission-house selling and professional pressure caused a small decline early, but short-covering developed and prices advanced rapidly, with corn showing net gains of 1/2 to 1/8 cents a bushel, May leading.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Because the world-wide textile shortage has reduced housefurnishings, the Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics has for the first time issued an instruction handbook to housewives on carpet and rug repair.

American architects, including a well-known group of New York designers and city planners, have joined hands in a post-war reconstruction enterprise that they believe will put the imprint of our architecture and structural methods on rehabilitated war-torn areas throughout the world, it became known last night.

Going to Europe or beyond by air for a brief business trip or an extended week-end will not only tempt the average American, after the war, but apparently will be within the range of his purse. In a study of civil aviation and peace made for the Brookings Institution, Dr. J. Parker Van Zandt foresees the attainment within ten years of a three-cents-a-mile level of air fares.

In a reply to Governor Dewey's Boston speech, which he characterized as "a piece of bare-faced political hypocrisy," Sidney Hillman, chairman of the Political Action Committee, charged yesterday that Republicans planned to feed the public "lies and more lies" during the rest of the campaign.

The formal offering to the public yesterday of 120,000 shares of $5 par common stock of the Wyandotte Worsted Company was greeted with such a brisk demand that the bankers announced early an oversubscription of the offering and the closing of the books.
Plans for construction of a large new "streamlined" branch store in Jamaica, Queens, as a post-war expansion move were announced yesterday by Macy's, New York, a division of R.H. Macy Co.

LONDON, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- A junction between Red Army and Finnish troops squeezing the Germans out of Lapland appeared imminent today, with the Germans also reported in full flight down the Norwegian coast, abandoning all Finnmark to the advancing Russians.

Announcing his support of Governor Dewey, William J. Schieffel Jr., president of Schieffelin Co. said yesterday that our country needed a President tested in capacity and administrative ability and not found wanting.

WITH UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY in Germany, Nov. 2 -- A sign in the rubble on the edge of the roadway said: "Front line 400 yards ahead. Are you lost?" Capt. James Marshall of Newport, R.I., commander of a company of 4.2-inch mortars, had paused down the road to load his battered BX camera, and he stopped to take pictures of the sign.

Because of the slight indisposition of Viola Essen, last night's program by the Ballet International at the International Theatre underwent considerable revision at the last minute. In place of "Swan Lake" and "Brahms Variations" the schedule contained "Les Sylphides" and "Bolero," leaving only William Dollar's "Constantia" of the original bill and making a very short evening.

Gertrude Lawrence has just signed a contract with Doubleday, Doran (who published yesterday "Middle East Diary," by Noel Coward, Miss Lawrence's colleague in the theatre) to write a book of informal reminiscences. It will include an account of her overseas tour last summer when she helped to entertain soldiers in France.

A group of two and three-story buildings occupying the entire block bounded by Gansevoort, Washington and Little West Twelfth Streets has been sold by the Guaranty Trust Company to a client of John Avlon, broker. The property is assessed at $262,000 and is occupied by concerns in the wholesale meat business.

Lewis S. Greenleaf Jr., regional director for the War Production Board, placed yesterday a ban on any publicity on plants allowed to resume civilian goods output under the spot authorization plan "or any other form of reconversion," it was learned.

LONDON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- For the fifth consecutive week note circulation reached a new high of 1,171,010,000, an increase of 6,643,000 over the previous total, the Bank of England reported in its statement for the week ending Nov. 1.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Nov. 2 -- Governor Dewey did some pretty effective prospecting up here in the Appalachians tonight and he has undoubtedly dug into the President's traditional lead in this area, but the general consensus is that Mr. Roosevelt will go out of the five main anthracite counties with a majority on Tuesday night.

Banks of the city continued in the week which ended on Nov. 1 to sell Government securities and to increase loans, according to a tabulation by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York of the positions of sixteen reporting New York City member banks.
PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 2 -- Pacific Fleet headquarters announced today a small enemy attack on one of our beaches on Peleliu Island in the southern Palaus a week ago.

Both Lou Little and Carl Snavely have been compelled to do some patchwork in their respective line-ups for the thirty-second meeting of Columbia and Cornell, which will start with a 2:30 P.M. kick-off at Baker Field tomorrow.

If freedom in America eventually is lost it will be because of public ignorance of the dangers involved in outright government planning and economic control, H.W. Prentis Jr., president of the Armstrong Cork Company, said last night in a debate with Norman Thomas, Socialist party Presidential candidate, in Town Hall on "Is There a Satisfactory Substitute for the Profit Motive."
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 1 (Delayed) -- The Brazilian-United States Mixed Trade Commission convened yesterday and launched a tentative program.

KANDY, Ceylon, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten, Allied Supreme Commander in Southeast Asia, disclosed today that Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell had sent his best wishes for "great success in your forthcoming operations."

A program of three ten-round bouts will be presented at Madison Square Garden tonight, with Rocky Graziano of the East Side and Harold Green, Brooklyn welterweight, heading the bill. The entire card is an almost exclusively local one, and for that reason Promoter Mike Jacobs is confident that his show will draw a crowd of 12,000 or more fans.

There are, of course, worse jobs than shelling corn. Cleaning the hen house, for example, has just about the lowest possible priority rating in a teen-ager's list. But at the turn of the century, when Northeastern farmers still raised fields of dent and flint instead of driving to the feed store for a load of grain, shelling corn was one of those jobs that had to be done.

Two days ago a news commentator conjecturing on the reason for General Stilwell's recall, suggested that it was meant as a public "spanking" of China's Generalissimo. Yesterday a reporter wrote: "Hurley and Nelson has demanded that Chiang reorganize his Cabinet."

LONDON, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- Indications that the Germans are preparing to "write off" Yugoslavia increased today with the announcement by Marshal Tito that high Nazi staff officers were being evacuated from Sarajevo and Berlin's acknowledgment that the Germans had lost a vital stretch of the Dalmatian coast.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Government of India and the provincial governments of that area are now considering a post-war educational development program that would aim to give every child in India a minimum basic education and enable promising youth to pass on through high schools and colleges, thhe Government of India Information Service announced here today.

Establishment of an international commercial-policy organization as part of a world-wide movement to eliminate such "trade barriers" as high tariffs and foreign exchange control was recommended yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York as one of the pivotal points in a comprehensive program for resumption of international trade after the war.

More than a month of "undercover operations," brought on by consumers' complaints, have revealed "a black market at its worst" in the women's rayon hosiery field, Markets Commissioner Henry M. Brundage disclosed yesterday.

Elsewhere in THE TIMES today there is a full-page political advertisement -- the only political advertisement to which we have allotted a full page of white paper during the whole campaign. In this advertisement Robert Moses has something to say about our editorial endorsement of the Democratic party and Mr. Roosevelt in this election.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A new fishing rod may be one of the first signposts pointing the way back to recreational normalcy from wartime conditions.

OTTAWA, Nov. 2 -- Gen. Andrew G.L. McNaughton, who commanded the Canadian forces in Europe until last December, has been appointed Minister of National Defense in place of Col. J.L. Ralston and charged with the task of getting adequate reinforcements to the Canadian Army within the terms of the policy of the Mackenzie King government that there should be no conscription for overseas service.

Twenty years ago Adam Walsh and Rip Miller were playing along-side of each other as two of the Seven Mules opening the way for the Four Horsemen of Notre Dame. Adam was captain and center of the most glamorized of all Rockne teams and Rip played a guard.

In a slashing attack on Governor Dewey's record at Albany, Senator Robert F. Wagner told a crowd of 5,000 at an open air rally in Manhattan's garment district yesterday that it could only be described as "just terrible * * * so far as human rights are concerned."

Hoping to present a more understandable financial statement of its current expenditures, the Board of Education issued yesterday its 1944-45 budget report in primer form, entitled "The Children's Budget." How New York City is going to spend the $134,700,000 allocated for the public schools is illustrated in simple terms.

The world that stretches before the disabled veteran must be something more than a land of dreams, and the sponsors of the National Rehabilitation Committee deal in realities when they bring together leaders in industry to inform them of the problem and to enlist them in the part they, too, may play.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- Selective Service headquarters announced tonight that it had authorized local boards to reclassify as available for induction discharged servicemen who wished to volunteer.

Investment company managers turned cool to the oils in the last quarter, according to a report on the portfolios of thirty leading funds, compiled by the National Association of Investment Companies. Eight concerns sold 64,700 shares of Pure Oil and none bought any.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- Tokyo reported today that a small United States Navy task force had been sighted 200 miles east of Luzon in the Philippines and at the same time claimed an attack had been made on Gen. Douglas MacArthur's invasion fleet by a new suicide plane -- "a V-1 with a pilot."
LONDON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 172:

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Representative Walter H. Judd, Republican of Minneapolis, declared in a statement today that Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell was relieved as American commander in the Far East because Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek refused to accept a White House ultimatum, delivered by General Stilwell, demanding that General Stilwell be made commander of all of China's armies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Ambassadors of the United States in Latin American countries have already undertaken conversations with Foreign Ministers under instruction from the State Department on the request of Argentina for a conference of Foreign Ministers of the American Republics to consider her relations with them.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, France, Nov. 2 -- The penalty for fraternization with Germans in occupied areas of the Reich has become known to American soldiers as "the $65 offense."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The impression this correspondent has brought back from a visit to the headquarters of the two national committees of the major parties is that the Democrats are nearer to a state of confidence than the Republicans, but that the Republicans will have caught up with them by election day.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- Rex Stout, novelist, invaded a Republican rally in Grange Hall tonight and nearly caused a riot when he demanded the right to question Representative Hamilton Fish, Republican candidate for reelection.
B.C. Ohlandt, former president of the Grocery Store Products Company and subsidiaries, has joined the executive staff of Schenley Distillers Corporation.

Refusal of paper manufacturers to divulge the composition of their various types of paper has stymied all attempts to standardize packaging procedure by manufacturers who must use labels on bottled products, P.J. Mertersteck, director of purchases for Joseph E. Seagram Sons, declared yesterday.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Abe J. Greene, president of the National Boxing Association, said today that the title bout between Sal Bartolo of Boston, world featherweight champion, and Willie Roach of Wilmington, Del., has been indefinitely postponed because of a serious nose injury suffered by Bartolo.

Team matches in the combination class of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association went into their second session of the winter season yesterday with play on five courts. The Princeton Club, defending titleholder and winner of its opening match against the Bronxville Field Club, played on its home courts against the Harvard Club and won, 4 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- President Roosevelt reported to the American people tonight that the advance toward Japan was "many months ahead of our own optimistic schedule," and that the enemy in Europe would be kept on the move without a winter lull, but he added that here at home the Republican opposition was threatening "to build a party spite-fence between us and the peace."

ATHENS, Oct. 31 (Delayed) -- Under the German occupation arrests were made indiscriminately and persons were subjected to torture on unstated or only veiled charges. It follows, therefore, that revenge equally indiscriminate and counter-charges lodged against those thought to be guilty on the flimsiest evidence are hurled about, often at random.

Sugar supplies are so low in the city that many grocers who resumed five-pound sales two weeks ago are again limiting customers to one or two pounds at a time and issuing IOU's against consumers' five-pounds ration stamps.

Sixteen-year-old Paul Nelson of 67 McCombs Place was committed without bail to the Tombs Prison yesterday by Magistrate William Klapp in the Homicide Court. He is accused of having shot and killed Donald Blackman, 44, an IRT motorman, soon after midnight last Wednesday during a gang fight in front of 2849 Eighth Avenue.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Less favorable weather conditions for drying corn in parts of Illinois, Iowa, Minnesota and the southwest and smaller country offerings of that grain resulted today in advances of 3/8 to 5/8 cent a bushel in futures on the Chicago Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Robert R. Young, chairman of the boards of the Alleghany Corporation and the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad, testified today before C.E. Boles, examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission, in the commission's inquiry into Alleghany's right to control railroad properties.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Sofia and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The War Production Board reported today that production of 12,400 domestic electric ranges had been authorized in a special program for the fourth quarter of the year. The new output was divided among five manufacturers, three of whom are already producing under the program, while two are making the ranges for the first time since their production was stopped two years ago.

Leaders in international peace movements will discuss topics in this field at the annual meeting of the World Alliance for International Friendship Through the Churches from 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M., next Friday at the Biltmore Hotel.

Since the summer of 1940, when the country's vocational program for national defense was introduced, nearly nine million men and women have been trained for war jobs in factories and plants. So quietly has this program been adapted to the classroom that frequently the work done by the schools and colleges is overlooked.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- The forthcoming visit of Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden to Paris, which will be a form of recognition of the de Gaulle government that is regarded here as far more important than the official notes, is especially interesting to the French as affording a possible opportunity to get information that their Ambassadors and diplomatic agents in London and Washington so far have been unable to supply.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- Though they failed to gain an interview tonight with Gen. Charles de Gaulle, who left on a trip, members of the National Council of Resistance will visit him later to ask his acceptance of their compromise plan regarding the so-called Patriotic Militia.

With Europe and Great Britain planning to take most of the paper products and raw woodpulp from Sweden and other Scandinavian nations the United States can look for little relief from her current paper shortage until some time after the end of the war, it was declared yesterday by the American Newspaper Publishers Association in a study of statements by various Government agencies.

Business leaders here should carry on their "distinctive public service" by devoting substantial portions of their advertising to information necessary for continued home-front cooperation in all necessary war measures, it was emphasized yesterday by Harold B. Thomas, chairman of the War Advertising Council, at a meeting at the Biltmore Hotel.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick is planning to call next week for bids to be considered about Nov. 14 on various blocks of New York City bonds now held in the various city pension funds, according to reports in financial circles yesterday.

Ballots received from members of the armed services may decide the winner of the Presidential contest in at least sixteen States next Tuesday, according to a survey made by The Associated Press. In these States, which have a total of 235 electoral votes, the estimated number of ballots to be received from those in military service exceeds the margin that separated winner and loser in the 1940 Presidential contest.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Week-end influences had a restraining effect on today's stock markets here and business was on only a moderate scale.

Preston Sturges, it is understood, is interested in obtaining screen rights to "Harvey," Broadway's new hit comedy starring Frank Fay. Mr. Sturges' interest was aroused long before the play went into production. In fact, it started during a chat with Brock Pemberton, the stage producer, in Hollywood many weeks ago.

A charge that Brooklyn residents were "lying down" on the vital job of giving blood plasma to the armed forces was made yesterday by spokesmen for a group of 110 naval veterans who visited the Brooklyn Red Cross Blood Donor Center, at 57 Willoughby Street, to give blood.

The Republican leadership in general and Governor Dewey in particular were accused yesterday by Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, of "burning the fiery cross" in an effort to win the election by dividing the people through the spread of racial prejudice and bigotry.

About 400 indictments charging election frauds were returned yesterday by a New York County grand jury on the basis of an inquiry conducted by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan and the Police Department. This investigation has no relation to the inquiry that Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein has ordered into other alleged violations of the election law in New York City.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Secretary Ickes said tonight that the Republicans had conducted a purely negative campaign based on "reckless charges" and "crooked talk" against the party in power.

The Monsanto Chemical Company reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $3,574,156 for the first nine months of 1944, equal to $2.32 a share for the common stock, comparing with $2.77 a share earned in the 1943 period, when net profit was $4,107,906.

The American marine insurance market has taken up the challenge of Vice Admiral Emory . Land, UN, retired, to provide coverage not only of American vessels but also of foreign-owned hulls after the war. As chairman of the Maritime Commission, Admiral Land is planning the rehabilitation of our merchant marine and the development of our foreign commerce, in which he regards the existence of a strong American marine insurance market as of great importance.

The Fritz Kreisler operetta "Rhapsody," which had been scheduled to make its Broadway debt at the Century Theatre on Monday evening under the auspices of Blevins Davis, in association with Lorraine Manville Dresselhuys, has been postponed until next Saturday, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission took under advisement today the question whether higher railroad freight rates should be restored on Jan. 1 or further suspended or canceled. This course was taken after one Government spokesman deplored the willingness of some interests opposed to the increase to rely on Federal agencies to make their case for them and thereby let those agencies become "scapegoats" for the railroads.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Sofia and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The New York Little Symphony, under Joseph Barone, presented its first concert of the season last night in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. The ensemble, composed of members of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra and the N.B.C. Symphony Orchestra, was heard in Bach's "Komm, suesser Tod" and furnished support for the three young artists granted debuts, Mary Mishna, pianist; Emily Orther, contralto, and Hubert Tillery, composer.

MOSCOW, Nov. 3 -- A death sentence for the first Polish "traitor and Hitlerite" tried in liberated Poland was reported today in a Soviet press dispatch from Lublin that said six Germans would soon be tried for their part in the administration of the Maidanek death camp where it is estimated 1,500,000 persons were executed.
The Appellate Division yesterday unanimously affirmed a ruling of Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan approving increases for officers and employes of the Bronx Surrogate's Court.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Civilian production totaling $92,000,000 by the end of this year and $361,000,000 through 1945 has been authorized by the War Production Board under the "spot" authorization plan, WPB disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Leo T. Crowley, Foreign Economic Administrator, said tonight the choice of a President should be made on three issues only, the winning of a quick victory, the making of a durable peace and the development of domestic prosperity.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Alied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Communique 209:
Yesterday's communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

The Japanese should have timed that "V-1 with a pilot" propaganda for Halloween. It might have been more frightening that evening. The truth is that suicide in war doesn't pay. The man who does his job and lives to fight another day, which is the motivation of the Americans, is much more valuable than one who goes in waving his samurai sword with the intention of dying.

Accusing Governor Dewey of repeated inconsistency, Dean Alfange, vice-chairman of the Liberal party, said last night in a speech from radio station WABC that ever since Mr. Dewey became old enough to have Presidential aspirations he has been on both sides of every great public issue.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 3 -- Judge Emmet H. Wilson ordered in Superior Court today that Local 9 of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, the largest CIO union here, cease using union money for political purposes.
This will be a long, hard year for Santa.

ARMY vs. Villanova -- The cadets could see a whale of a game at West Point this afternoon -- but only if Red Blaik let his third-stringers handle Villanova on some back lot while he scrimmages his well-matched first and second teams in Michie Stadium. That last one could be slightly on the primitive and bone-crushing side.

The Moscow radio accused the Iranian Government of Premier Mohammed Maraghei Said again last night of "pursuing an anti-Soviet policy," but asserted that "none of the agitators of intrigues can affect the deep-rooted friendship between the Iranian nation and the Soviet peoples."

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- Spanish Republicans in France are preparing to assist in the liberation of their country after having helped to liberate France by fighting for her in the ranks of the French Forces of the Interior. Their determination is being voiced in Toulouse during a convention of the Spanish National Union, which opened yesterday and will continue until Sunday evening.

The Appellate Division voted 3 to 2 yesterday to affirm a decision of Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins, who in May, 1944, declared constitutional Sections 61 A and 61 B of the General Corporation Law, in a derivative stock suit against the Corn Products Refining Company in 1940.
Fourteen, including the top-weighted Western star Seven Hearts, are named for the $30,000-added Westchester Handicap on the final program of the Empire City Racing City Association at Jamaica today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Greater use of airborne rockets has been recommended by the United States Ninth Air Force, through its operational research section, as a result of the destruction wrought on enemy ground targets in Europe by rocket-carrying P-47 Thunderbolts, the War Department disclosed today.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Saturday, Nov. 4 (U.P.) -- Japanese troops and tanks, landed on the west coast of Leyte during the night from four big merchantmen, opened a desperate bid today to break the Ormoc pocket and a show-down battle was believed imminent.

David Fine, 38 years old, manager of the Stanley Theatre, at 586 Seventh Avenue, paid a $250 fine yesterday in the Municipal Term Court to avoid going to the workhouse for thirty days for permitting 380 standees to crowd the aisles and stairways of the theatre last Oct. 28 when all 625 seats were occupied.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 --Robert P. Patterson, Under Secretary of War, sent a telegram today to Matthew Smith, secretary of the MESA, demanding that the strikes by the union be stopped "at once."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A communique today from the Allied Southeast Asia Command Headquarters said Eastern Air Command planes yesterday scored hits on the central Burma-Rangoon oil pipelines at Sinbaungwe. The important rail bridge at Dara, Thai-land, also was struck and was heavily damaged during a low-level attack Wednesday, the bulletin said.
Maj. Leslie E. Morrissett, Army Medical Corps, and Mrs. Morrissett, have come to the Savoy-Plaza from Washington.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- More and more the American proposals as submitted to the International Civil Air Conference are echoing, although in all politeness, the concept of a mass market in international air transport which, according to American technicians, seems not as yet to have been envisioned by the representatives of other countries.

Twelve local draft boards in Manhattan will function from a consolidated office at the Bible House, 45 Astor Place, beginning Dec. 1, it was announced yesterday by Col. Arthur V. McDermott, city director of Selective Service.

Sarah Moore, 30 years old, was sentenced to a thirty-day workhouse term yesterday in Special Sessions on her recent conviction by Justices Troy, Wieboldt and Bayes of striking Capt. Thora LeFevre in the Women's House of Detention while being disciplined for an infraction of the rules.

The election-day closing of the city's district Magistrates' Courts will result in an extension of the authority and the working hours of several of the lower courts, it was announced yesterday at the office of Henry H. Curran, Chief Magistrate.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 3 (AP) -- William L. Brooker, counsel for the Mechanics Educational Society of America, asserted today that the international officers of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, had "refused to agree to even a technical compromise of the Toledo situation and have bragged that they will be upheld by the War Labor Board on any stand they take."

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Japan's homeland has been left pretty wide open by reduction of the enemy to a fifth-rate naval power and practical elimination of Japanese naval aviation, Vice Admiral Marc A. Mitscher, Task Force 58 commander, said today on his return home on leave.

Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, promised last night that if Governor Dewey were elected President the people of the country could expect a shorter war. The New York Secretary of State took issue with the statement of James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization and Reconversion, that a change in the Administration would mean a longer war.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Output of some needed types of war planes was "sharply below schedule" in October, according to a statement by the War Production Board today.

This war will have been fought in vain if in its wake the old evils are allowed again to take root. A recent dispatch to this newspaper from its Near East correspondent, Joseph M. Levy, says that in Rumania the cessation of fighting has brought little peace and restored few rights to the Jewish citizens of that unhappy Balkan country.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 3 -- In New Jersey today Russell W. Davenport, who is supporting the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate in New York, made a speech in behalf of the Republican candidate for the United States Senate in New Jersey, and Henry W. Jeffers, formerly chairman of the New Jersey Republican Committee, made a statement in behalf of the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate in New Jersey.
Yesterday's communique as broadcast from, Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 3 -- Fred MacMurray has been given the lead in "The Bandwagon," the Twentieth Century-Fox screen version of the old George Kaufman-Howard Dietz stage musical. MacMurray, who is currently appearing in the musicale, "Where Do We Go From Here?" will do the picture after the Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker biographical story, now titled "First, Last and Always.''

ALBANY, Nov. 3 -- Sixty-two cities in the State have received about $9,000,000 in July and October distributions of the 2 per cent tax on utility services, Rollin Browne, president of the State Tax Commission, said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Shortage of seamen and officers to man merchant ships is threatening to delay supplies to the European and Pacific war zones, according to a joint statement today by Vice Admiral Emory S. Land, War Shipping Administrator, and Paul V. McNutt, Chairman of the WMC.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- President Roosevelt, in a statement tonight, urged all employers to give to their workers "adequate" time off to vote Tuesday and asked that any employe who does not receive enough time off "inform me of the circumstances, together with the name of his company and any other pertinent facts."

Once again I want to record my appreciation for an enjoyable nostalgic dream I had when I read the recent editorial "Nuts." As I have written you before, I always enjoy these editorials, but this one carried me back to the old days in the chestnut world, because, as New York and New England people know, there have been no chestnut trees for nearly thirty years. Beginning about that time, the blight took them.

President Roosevelt's record of "antagonism to business" and Governor Dewey's "fairness toward all segments of our economic fabric" were offered yesterday by Walter Hoving, president of Lord Taylor, as the reasons he is supporting the Republican nominee-for President.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- A motion approving the British Government's plan for far-reaching social insurance was carried by a cheering House of Commons today without a division after Sir William Beveridge, author of the report on which it was in great part based, had approved the plan in principle, but criticized it in detail.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The "One Thousand Club of the United States of America," supporting President Roosevelt for reelection, informed Congress today that it had received contributions of $94,100 to Oct. 31, including $1,000 from the President.

There can be no question but that the promotion of small libraries both in North America and perhaps all over the English-speaking world will receive a gratifying impetus after the war. The popularity of "Books for Soldiers" has made our people so book-minded that it is estimated there are 30,000,000 to 40,000,000 books in our military camps.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 3 -- After the war when new home freezers again become available housewives will fall heir to the improved techniques already developed in commercial food freezing, Miss Katharine Fisher, director of the Good Housekeeping Institute, told food and household equipment editors attending a home food freezing conference held here today at the General Electric Consumers Institute.

Thursday's communique, as transmitted by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
