WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 173:

VERVIERS, Belgium, Nov. 3 -- Two worried German civilians --the first to be arrested on capital charges in conquered enemy territory -- were tried here today for having sheltered three members of the Wehrmacht from American troops in a farmhouse on the edge of the town of Horbach near the Netherland-German border.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 3 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops under Gen. Hunag Chieh today captured the old Burma Road city of Lungling after five days of heavy fighting and drove the Japanese southward along the Burma Road toward Mangshih, thirteen miles away.

The Rev. William J. Kelley, chairman of the New York State Labor Relations Board, characterized yesterday as "a presumptuous and inaccurate representation of the facts" an attack by Senator Robert F. Wagner in a political talk that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey had retarded the functioning of the board by his delay in appointing a new member over a period of "many months."
KANDY, Ceylon, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A Southeast Asia Command communique:

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 3 -- Japan, desperately and vainly attempting to regain a semblance of air control over her dwindling empire in the western Pacific, has succeeded in damaging several vessels in one of our carrier groups.

Senator Robert F. Wagner, Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, his Republican opponent, and thirty-three of fifty Congressional candidates in New York City have promised to support the earliest possible formation of a United Nations security organization before final peace settlements, Americans United for World Organization announced yesterday in a statement issued at headquarters, 5 West Fifty-fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The "battle of the Statler" got into Federal District Court today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 3 -- In a brisk run-down of signals and formations, with emphasis placed on overhead plays, Navy completed preparations for the big football game with Notre Dame at Baltimore tomorrow. Forty-five players will make the trip, leaving in the morning.

W. Averell Harriman, United States Ambassador to Russia, urged the re-election of President Roosevelt last night on the ground that his defeat would impair the confidence of the Allies in America's leadership and would engender doubts and suspicions that might take considerable time to down.

The Non-Partisan Citizens' Committee for the Election of Supreme Court Justice George Frankenthaler announced yesterday the formation of a real estate committee, with William H. Quinlan as chairman. It also announced that the joint executive board of local 32-B, Building Trades Service Employes Union, American Federation of Labor, had endorsed Justice Frankenthaler's candidacy.

ANTWERP, Belgium, Nov. 3 -- Visitors to Belgium after the war is over will never see that tiny hamlet on the Antwerp waterfront that really is not there at all. One can pick it out from the air today without any trouble, a scattering of ancient houses with dormer windows snug against their roofs and two churches, the larger of them with a most graceful tapering spire.

Investigation by the Camp Fire Club of America has called attention to the large number of fires in the undeveloped areas of Long Island. According to figures of the State Conservation Department, there were 340 such fires during the first nine months of this year. They burned over 13,596 acres. The club's committee on conservation of forest and wildlife has urged upon the Long Island Railroad its cooperation in abating this fire loss.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Germany was bombed during October, one of this year's worst flying months, at the rate of more than two tons of bombs every minute, with the United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe -- the Eighth in Britain and the Fifteenth in Italy -- dropping more than 56,700 tons on oil plants, railway centers, bridges and factories.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (U.P.) -- Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, administrator of veterans' affairs, estimated today that the number of persons throughout the world who will need rehabilitation by the war's end might reach 20,000,000.

KATONAH, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- A nice thing about being a rod-and-gun reporter is that a man can go fishing and call it an investigation. Today we "investigated" the fall bass fishing situation at Muscoot Reservoir. Nothing would be more pleasant than to be able to say that it was wonderful, but the grim truth is that all we got was a sore arm.

Under the stress of war the development of airpower has been so rapid that one is apt to lose sight of the astonishing strides which have been made in radical design, while more conventional and highly perfected flying machines have been determining the fate of nations. Aircraft resembling only the fantastic brain-children of imaginative artists before the war have already reached the stage of flight.

The sixteen-story building containing three stores and ninety-four apartments at 245 East Twenty-first Street, at the northwest corner of Second Avenue, has been sold by Aaron Rabinowitz, James L. Clare and Adrian P. Burke, trustees of mortgage series F-1, to a client of William Himlyn, attorney.
Slight changes have been made in the regulations governing the Sixth War Loan drive and are incorporated in the forty-four-page circular sent to banks by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 3 (AP) -- A five-point research program for the Cooperative Grange League Federation Exchange was outlined today by its founder, H.E. Babcock of Ithaca, as stockholders voted to increase common capital stock from $5,000,000 to $10,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The United States and its Allies have achieved "substantial" accomplishments in Italy along economic and other lines since the liberation, Dean Acheson, Assistant Secretary of State, informed Humberto Gualtieri, national secretary of the Mazzini Society of 1775 Broadway, New York, in a letter tonight.

I feel impelled by THE TIMES editorial "The Jay" to present some facts which have come under my observation during intimate association with two jays. The first one was found under our trees after a storm, just out of the nest and unable to fly.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 3 -- Off to a flying start when Don Panciera broke loose and ran 80 yards for a touchdown in the opening period, La Salle Academy of Providence conquered the Fordham Prep eleven of New York City, 20 -- 0, before 11,000 spectators at La Salle Alumni Field tonight.

The Blackfriars Guild, which has been devoting itself to the drama on West Fifty-seventh Street since 1941, opened its new season last night with a domestic comedy called "Don't, George!" by Katherine Laure and, amidst the usual assembly of friends, this twelfth Guild production had a warm reception.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Tomorrow's world will be a strange but practical place in which to live, in the view of the forty youthful scientists who were finalists in the third annual science talent search. Each wrote an essay on "My Scientific Project" and these essays are gathered into a book, "Scientists of Tomorrow," published this fall.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, France, Nov. 3 -- The long, grim struggle to open Antwerp to Allied shipping is over. British marines and infantry overran most of Walcheren Island today, including the bulk of the important gun positions, and the Canadians mopped up the last German units holding out south of the Schelde estuary this afternoon, after the bulk of the German garrison had surrendered at 7:30 o'clock this morning.

Heinrich Ludwig Suhl, 55-year-old cork importer, was arrested yesterday at his farm on Lafayette Avenue, Peekskill, on a charge of conspiracy to violate the Federal espionage statute in wartime. The crime is punishable by death, or imprisonment up to thirty years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The dismissal of Dr. Homer P. Rainey as president of the University of Texas "bodes ill" for that institution, the American Association of University Professors declared today in a statement issued by Dr. Ralph E. Himstead, executive secretary.

It is most unfortunate that at the present juncture there has been a difference between Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and General Stilwell, but believe there is no need for our American friends to be overwrought by this change.

CLARKSDALE, Miss., Nov. 3 -- Cotton planters from Tennessee, Arkansas and Mississippi, meeting yesterday at the Coahoma County Court House voted indorsement of mechanical farming, as demonstrated at the Hopson Plantation earlier in the day, and authorized appointment of committees to press for steel and labor allocations for production of a greater number of pickers, mechanical choppers and other machinery needed next year to industrialize cotton.
Bronislava Nijinska's ballet version of the Mussorgsky "Pictures at an Exhibition" had its first presentation last night at the International Theatre at the hands of the Ballet International.

ATHENS, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Fast-traveling British units pursuing the withdrawing Germans in northwestern Greece have captured the town of Florina, only five miles from the Yugoslav frontier, after inflicting casualties on enemy rearguards, Allied headquarters announced today.

Angel Reyes, a violinist of exceptionally brilliant, if uneven qualities, the son of A. Reyes Camejo, the Cuban composer, and Cultural Attache to the Cuban Embassy in the United States, gave his second New York recital last night in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- India-based B-29 Superfortresses, carrying the largest bomb loads per aircraft ever known to have been lifted in aerial warfare, attacked railroad yards at Rangoon in Japanese-dominated Burma today, Twentieth Air Force Headquarters here announced.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Twenty national women's organizations joined today in a nonpartisan appeal to women throughout the country to go to the polls and vote Tuesday. They pointed out that 65 per cent of civic responsibility rests this year on women's shoulders.

The first one-man exhibit of the paintings of Eugene Delacroix in New York is on view at the Wildenstein Galleries. It has been assembled to aid the Quaker Emergency Service in its splendid work in France and the occupied countries. Since comparatively few paintings of Delacroix, the master of color, are owned in America, this unique collection should be seen and enjoyed by all lovers of art.
SYRACUSE, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Four trophies were presented tonight to first prize winners in high school publication writing contests sponsored by the Empire State School Press Association.

ROME, Nov 3 (AP) -- British infantry and armor fought bitterly tonight for Forli airfield, two miles southeast of the highway junction of Forli at the edge of the Po Valley, while the season's most violent rains virtually halted action on the American Fifth Army front south of Bologna.

OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 3 -- Henry J. Kaiser, the shipbuilder, who heads a nonpartisan "register and vote" organization, was told in a round-robin telephone conversation with ten Mayors or their representatives today that their citizens would establish votings records on Tuesday.

CHICAGO, Ill., Nov. 3 -- A survey among thirteen industries has revealed that three-fourths of them will go into immediate peacetime production with no unemployment between production of war and peacetime products, it was announced here by the Wirebound Box Manufacturers Association.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 3 (AP) -- T.V. Soong, Chinese Foreign Minister, declared today that China and the United States were in "complete agreement" on closer military, political and economic cooperation and denied reports that the United States had exerted pressure on China to settle her Communist problem.

Postponement of starting a system of universal military training in this country for the post-war period was advocated last night by Dr. George F. Zook, president of the American Council on Education, until it could be ascertained that the coming peace is deficient in preventing future hostilities.

Although the total was the smallest in three weeks, public offerings of new bonds this week again were in excess of $100,000,000 and more diversified than in recent weeks. PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 -- Charging that America was enjoying "a foxhole prosperity" which had been won only through "the blood and toil" of our fighting men on every battlefront, Governor Bricker called tonight for the election of Governor Dewey to guarantee that in the post-war era our foreign policy would be underwritten by "a strong domestic policy."

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Emil (Dutch) Leonard, Senators' pitcher, said today a bribe had been offered to him by an unknown telephone caller early in the morning of Oct. 1, the day the hurler knocked the Tigers out of the American League pennant race with his final game triumph.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- The women of Britain today won a partial victory in their battle to get equal rights under the Government's social security plan when Richard Austen Butler, Minister of Education, announced in the House of Commons that the Government had decided that family allowances should be paid to either wife or husband.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 3 (U.P.) -- Tank-led Japanese troops have surrounded Kweilin but the Chinese defenders, equipped with American bazookas, flame-throwers and anti-tank guns, appeared to be holding the attackers at the gates of the walled city, a Chinese communique reported today.

ALBANY, Nov. 3. -- The traveling phase of the Dewey campaign was officially ended today as the Governor and his party returned to Albany at 9:30 A. M. Mr. Dewey devoted the day to rest and also to some work on his Madison Square Garden speech of tomorrow night, the speech in which he is expected to sum up his case against the Roosevelt Administration and restate his own program.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 3 -- Foreign Minister Paul-Henri Spaak will leave here tomorrow on an important diplomatic visit to London. He will take to the British capital a number of problems, the chief of which are the future relations of Belgium with the western Atlantic powers, food and weapons for the Belgian Army.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Col. C.V. Whitney's Monsoon won the Johnny Podgajny Purse before 10,000 racegoers at Pimlico today by a neck from William L. Brann's Gallorette. Connie's Girl was third, three lengths farther behind. Monsoon, ridden by Arnold Kirkland, drove up on the outside to win in 1:12 for the six furlongs.

UNITED STATES FOURTEENTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, in China, Nov. 3 (U.P.) -- China-based American bombers, pressing their search for the surviving units of the beaten Japanese Fleet, sank another enemy destroyer and damaged a large transport in the South China Sea, a communique said today.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine announced yesterday that unprecedented problems may arise in New York City's polling booths Tuesday due to a police manpower shortage, the inexperience of many election clerks and the spirited campaign being waged by the rival political parties.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- By means of a great "Liberation Loan," Gen. Charles de Gaulle hopes to be able to avoid devaluing French currency, on the Belgian model, or having recourse to a forced levy. But the Government makes it clear that its future financial policy will depend in great measure on the reception given to the Liberation Loan by the public as betokening "what confidence the nation has in itself."

Both Columbia and Cornell will field revamped line-ups when they meet in their traditional football contest at Baker Field today. The game will feature Alumni Reunion Day and the kick-off will be at 2:30 P.M.

OMAHA, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Three tee-totalers, a former W.C.T.U. worker and two prohibition era State officials, are leading the fight against adoption of a Statewide prohibition law on which Nebraska will vote Tuesday. Harold (Three Gun) Wilson, a former enforcement officer, heads the drys.

Republican campaign charges that the Wagner-Murray-Dingle bill, liberalizing social security, impairs the pension and retirement rights of civil service employes in State and municipal government were branded by Senator Robert F. Inability of the nation's linen supply companies to obtain replacements for cotton textile items such as towels, sheets, pillowcases and table napery will force them to make further sharp curtailments of service, with a consequent hazard to public health, industry spokesmen declared yesterday.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Governor Edward Martin, Republican, said today he was "heartened" by almost complete Pennsylvania registration totals which gave an approximate 300,000 lead to Republicans, while David L. Lawrence, Democratic State chairman, predicted his party would carry the State in Tuesday's election.

Prospects for deliveries of civilian overcoats have been further dimmed by an invitation for bids by the Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot for 480,000 Army overcoats, producers stated yesterday. Deliveries on the quartermaster invitation are to be one-third each during January, February and March.

With Jim Spence leading, Poly Prep crushed Horace Mann, 20 -- 7, yesterday on the loser's gridiron. Spence accounted for two touchdowns as the Brooklyn forces gained their first triumph in four starts.

In his recital at Town Hall last night, Fritz Jahoda, Austrian pianist who was making his American debut, provided an evening of clean, competent playing, and showed an unquestioned mastery of the keyboard as a vehicle for his talents.

DETROIT, Nov. 3 -- A strike of members of the Mechanics Educational Society of America in more than a score of Detroit area war plants began at 10 o'clock this morning. It was called, according to Matthew Smith, MESA national secretary, in sympathy with MESA members who are on strike in a jurisdictional dispute with the United Automobile Workers, CIO, at the Toledo plant of the Electric Auto-Lite Company.

Slowness with which cotton is entering the Government loan stocks and congestion of the staple in the interior of the South continued yesterday to bring in a greater volume of hedge selling than generally is expected in the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange and final prices there were 4 points lower to 5 points higher than on Thursday.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Troops of the Fifth Indian Division, driving southeastward from Tiddim, in northwestern Burma, have cleared Japanese road blocks twelve miles from Tiddim and are forming a three-pronged attack on enemy positions at Vital Corner, on the Tiddim-Fort White road, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Election day weather in ten East Central States, including pivotal New York, Pennsylvania and Ohio, will be clearing and cold with snow flurries in mountainous areas, the United States Weather Bureau reported tonight in a tentative forecast.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 3 -- A new way to reduce "cross talk" in long distance telephone calls, a three-dimensional device for aiding airport safety and a camouflage paint aimed at baffling infra-red photographs are among the 544 inventions listed as patented in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

CARIGARA, Leyte, Nov. 3 -- The Japanese abandoned Carigara, northern key to the central valley of Leyte and doorway to Carigara Bay and the Visayan Sea, without firing a shot. The first squadron of the Seventh Cavalry regulars from the Mexican border entered the town of 5,000 population at 10:30 A.M. yesterday, spearhead of an assault force of Americans and 400 Filipino guerrillas, to find it deserted.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Nov. 3 -- Following the expression of doubts as to whether Bermuda might find the space necessary to accommodate headquarters of the United Nations league, the Legislative Council today approved a motion for the appointment of a joint committee of the Assembly and Council to investigate the possibilities.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:Marshal Stalin declined to participate in the air conference at Chicago. As the official version goes, Russia does not like the presence there of certain countries, among them Switzerland. Russia feels that Switzerland always was anti-Communist and pro-Fascist. In my opinion, this is half right and half wrong.

The stock market labored yesterday over an irregular course, as the list settled down into a rather tight situation to await the results of the election on Tuesday. The rails, a handful of industrials and scattered specialties showed some zest, but the rest of the market moved in such a narrow range as to prevent any real direction.

Held scoreless in its first four games, City College's football team will try again today to show an attack when it meets the University of Connecticut in a return game at 2:30 P.M. in Lewisohn Stadium.
Holcombe Ward, president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, has been nominated for his ninth term of office.

The Rev. Beverley M. Boyd of Grace and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, Richmond, Va., editor of the Southern Churchman, an Episcopal weekly, will become executive secretary of the Department of the Church and Social Service of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America on Dec. 1, it was announced yesterday.

The plan of the recently organized Joint Army-Navy Disciplinary Control Board to reduce and suppress "conditions inimicable to the morals and welfare of service personnel" brought immediate action yesterday at its first formal session in the board room at 52 Broadway.

Except for light workouts today, both the Giants and the Tigers have completed their preparations for tomorrow's games with the Yanks and the Eagles at the Polo Grounds and Ebbets Field, respectively. Gifts to the sixthy-sixth annual United Hospital Fund Campaign for the support of seventy-seven volunteer non-profit hospitals in New York City have brought the total to within 80 per cent of its goal of $1,554,931. Thus far, according to an account made public yesterday at the fourth report meeting of the Manhattan-Bronx Women's Committee at the Hotel Pierre, total funds collected amounted to $1,211,213.

The estate of Samuel Klein, founder of "Klein on the Square," at Union Square, had an appraisal value of $6,076,491 at the time of his death on Nov. 15, 1942, according to schedules filed last March and approved yesterday by State Appraiser David C. Krakaur.

While the more fantastic predictions of "super-buses" in the post-war period are not likely to be fulfilled any more quickly than the highly radical changes in automobile design which are a favorite subject in lay circles, nevertheless important improvements in both long distance and city buses already are past the drawing-board stage.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, who was recently recalled from his command of American troops in the China-Burma-India theatre after disagreements with Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, arrived in Washington today, but immediately withdrew behind a wall of silence.

We hear a good deal about what children should eat, but very little concerning the diets of those at the other end of life. And yet the number of persons more than 65 years of age is steadily increasing, according to the United States census, which reported in 1940 that there were 36 per cent more elderly persons in the country at that time than there had been a decade earlier.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- The United States today relaxed a two- and-a-half-year blackout on business communications with France to pave the way for gradual resumption of ordinary Franco-American commercial relations. At the same time resumption of letter mail of all kinds up to one ounce at 5 cents postage, but still subject to censorship, was permitted beginning tomorrow.

ON BOARD THE PRESIDENT'S TRAIN, Nov. 3 -- President Roosevelt was headed for New England tonight on the final tour of his active campaign "to correct misrepresentations." His crowded schedule called for four speaking appearances in "doubtful" Connecticut and Massachusetts, including a last major address in Boston tomorrow night.

Harper reports that "T.V.A.: Democracy on the March," by David E. Lillienthal, will be translated into nearly twenty languages. Hebrew, Belgian, French and English rights have been sold. Negotiations are under way for Spanish, Portuguese, Chinese, Danish, German and Italian translations.

LONDON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Sir Oliver W.H. Leese tonight was appointed commander of the newly organized Eleventh Army group which includes some American troops formerly commanded by Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell and will operate in southeast Asia under the direction of Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 3- Flight Officer Grosvenor Gilbert, son of Cass Gilbert Jr., the architect, and the late Elizabeth Jarvis Wyeth Gilbert, was killed in an airplane accident on Wednesday at the Army airfield in Amarillo, Texas, according to a message received by Mr. Gilbert from the War Department today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 -- Members of Local 1304 of the CIO United Steel Workers, more than 2,500 of whom are abstaining from machinist work on eighty-two ships in San Francisco Bay, were described as "enemies of labor and of the nation" in a statement today signed by officials of all of the other major CIO unions in Alameda County on the bay opposite this city.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 3 -- As leader of the opposition to the proposed State Constitution to be voted upon next Tuesday, Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City was under attack again today from Gov. Walter E. Edge and others who favor discarding the "archaic" charter under which New Jersey has been openrating for a century for a document they consider fitted to cope with modern conditions.
MADRID, Nov. 3 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco said in an exclusive interview today that Spain had never been Fascist or Nazi and never had been allied secretly or otherwise with the Axis Powers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- The International Civil Aviation Conference adopted a resolution today accepting the principle of international collaboration in post-war commercial aviation and expressing the hope that an organization for that purpose might be established.

Conceding that Chiang Kai-shek has not conducted the war against Japan with enough energy and speed, it may be that to some extent the fault rests with us here in the United States, and especially among the best friends of the Chinese people.

A 6.7 per cent increase in retail sales of furniture and house furnishings during the third quarter compared with the similar period of last year was reported yesterday by Arthur Fertig and Company, retail advisory service.

LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 30 (Delayed) -- Under the sympathetic and skillful guidance of Col. Frank E. Fraser, deputy commander of Civil Affairs for the United States Army, under a Supreme Headquarters, Allied Expeditionary Force mission, the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg is slowly restoring the democratic form of government, all but eradicated by the Germans during four years and three months of occupation.

The Lawyers Building, one of the best known business structures in the Journal Square section of Jersey City, has been sold by the National Commercial Mortgage Company to Louis N. Rosenbaum, New York operator, who owns several other properties in that section of Jersey City.

ON BOARD THE PRESIDENT'S TRAIN, Nov. 3 -- President Roosevelt was headed for New England tonight on the final tour of his active campaign "to correct misrepresentations." His crowded schedule called for four speaking appearances in "doubtful" Connecticut and Massachusetts, including a last major address in Boston tomorrow night.

ALTHOUGH airplanes now cleave the skies as they never did in the days when Kipling wrote his famous locomotive story "007," trains and engines still fascinate children. Small boys wait at a country crossing absorbed in counting a string of freight cars, and many a child's favorite walk includes a bridge across the tracks or a visit to the station where a puffing locomotive may be seen and admired.

National campaign managers for both President Roosevelt and Governor Dewey predicted victories for their candidates by overwhelming majorities in next Tuesday's election as the 1944 Presidential contest came virtually to a close last night.

AS the Presidential campaign of 1944 races headlong in a driving finish of oratory and invective, one segment of our population is watching this democratic phenomenon with amazement That section consists of former Europeans who remember the fear, bitterness and, frequently, bloodshed that accompanied pre-war elections in some parts of the Continent.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- Westchester County will elect on Tuesday a Sheriff, eleven legislators and vote for a Ninth District Supreme Court Justice, but the issues in the campaigns are so few that public interest rests almost wholly in the Presidential race.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 4 -- Representative Clare Booth Luce's chances of returning to Congress depend primarily on the vote on Tuesday in Bridgeport, according to seasoned political observers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The bald untruthfulness of the Japanese propaganda line continues to astound observers here. It has reached such an exaggerated stage that some qualified military and naval sources are convinced that Japan now is not only attempting to delude her people, her subjects and her soldiers, but actually has been taken in herself, to her military disadvantage, by false reports reaching Imperial Headquarters from the field.
SUPREME HEADQUAETERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Communique 210:

I WOULD like to reply to Mr. Max Liebl's letter, "Re-educating Germany," in your theatre section of Oct. 22. On many points I agree fully with Mr. Liebl. First of all, he is right when he proposes a rigorous censorship of radio, theatre and movies.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 4 -- It is conceded that President Roosevelt will carry North Carolina in 1944 by a substantial plurality in the election Tuesday. There are serious differences of opinion, however, as to the probable size of that plurality.

Civilian prospects for Thanksgiving turkey were brightened yesterday by an arrangement between the War Food Administration and the Army Quartermaster Corps. With all requirements of the armed forces for the Thanksgiving bird already met or on the way to being filled, the WFA announced that turkeys processed after today may be sold through the usual trade channels without being offered first to the Army, which supplies all the armed services.

In footing the bill for Robert Moses' full-page advertisement in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Friday the Republican party "let the cat out of the bag" with regard to its true intentions for world peace, Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican, of Minnesota, and Russell W. Davenport, chairman of the Independent Republican Committee, charged yesterday in a joint statement.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- While Democratic and Republican party leaders are making their customary eleventh-hour forecasts of victory, few impartial observers of political trends hereabout are predicting that either President Roosevelt or Governor Dewey is certain to capture Illinois' twenty-eight electoral votes.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 4 -- Posters have appeared in Brussels and other Belgian cities demanding the resignation of the Government and the establishment of Allied military control over civilian affairs.

The American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute of Arts and Letters opened to the public yesterday an exhibition illustrating the development of Washington, from forest to national capital, as shown in plans and models arranged by Frederick Law Olmsted.
OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 4 -- An Iowa farmer was explaining the state of mind with which he will go to the polls Tuesday.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES IN GERMANY, Nov. 4 -- Doughboys of Lieut. Gen. Courtney H. Hodges' American First Army, who fought their way into the hamlet of Schmidt yesterday afternoon, were forced out of it this morning in a determined German counter-attack strongly supported by tanks.

Pierre Monteux made his second appearance as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. The program he led featured the Brahms concerto in D minor with Leon Fleisher, 16-year-old pianist from San Francisco, as soloist.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (U.P.) -- Russia's food situation is "unbelievably difficult" and the Soviet Union will need United States food imports for at least three years after the end of the European war, Lieut Col. Ralph W. Olmstead, deputy War Food Administrator, said today.

The Florence Crittenton League, Inc., an organization that provides shelter and aid for delinquent girls, will be the beneficiary of the performance of Fritz Kreisler's operetta, "Rhapsody," on the night of Nov. 20 at the Century Theatre.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 4 -- A sharply fought State prohibition issue along with mounting partisan feeling in the Presidential race have combined to produce registration records in most of Nebraska's largest voting centers.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Gov. John W. Bricker declared tonight as he ended his campaign for the Vice Presidency, that a Republican victory on Tuesday would bring "a return of confidence and enterprise" to the American people.

Last week in Europe the preliminaries for the Allies' final great offensive were under way. In the west British and Canadian armies made a sweep of the Netherlands coast, clearing all approaches to Antwerp, one of the first ports of Europe, virtually intact and only fifty to 100 miles from the main fronts.

YEARS ago in Cardiff, Wales, a young butcher's boy named Howard Spring sought for the words which would set him free from his environment, and choosing fantasy as his escape, wrote a short story on English public school life. It netted him 1 16s 10d and began a long distinguished writing career.

THE many admirers of Nino in Valenti Angelo's book by that name and its sequel, "The Golden Gate," will be happy to meet him again in "The Rooster Club." the youngest member of a group of Boy Scouts who hike, camp, sail and help harvest beans, with gusto, vigor and good humor.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 4 -- Despite the fact that thousands of Alabama citizens are opposed to the re-election of President Roosevelt, citizens of the State will turn out Tuesday to keep Alabama in the Democratic column.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Receipts of salable hogs today were 500 head. scarcely euough to make a market, but pricel were called nominally steady, with $14.15 as the quotable top. Compared with a week ago hogs weighing 340 pounds and less were unevenly 25 to 75 cents lower. Some underweights were off as much as a dollar.

Margaret Shedd does this in "Inherit the Earth," a disturbing story of conditions in one anonymous -- and, doubtless, composite -- Central American republic.

National War Labor Board policy on the question of arbitration of grievances is clear and indicates that the board expects all parties, even in the absence of established grievance machinery, to settle such grievances through direct negotiation and, if necessary, voluntary arbitration, Thomas L. Norton, regional WLB chairman, declared yesterday.

Five young singers who have had featured roles in productions of the New Opera Company will be honored at the first autumn luncheon under the auspices of the Musicians Emergency Fund, which will be held on Thursday on the St. Regis Roof.

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 4 -- Four years ago Wendell Willkie had a margin of slightly more than 7,400 votes over President Roosevelt in a record total poll of 324,000 for Maine. If maximum and minimum predictions of the vote on Nov. 7 are averaged.

THIS novel will appeal particularly to young readers -- and to older readers for whom the dream of life in the green forest, according to Rousseau's concept of Utopia, is still possible. It is not a cloying romance, however; it suggests rather the hardy realism of "Robinson Crusoe" or "The Swiss Family Robinson." Its theme is the ancient one that God helps those who help themselves.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The newest and fastest all-purpose bomber of the Army Air Forces, the A-26 Invader, is now in action, the War Department announced today.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 4 (U.P.) -- A group of Polish Roman Catholic priests has assailed the "secret diplomacy" with which Prime Minister Churchill conferred with Premier Stalin on the Polish problem.

THE Eastern States Chrysanthemum Society, organized at a recent meeting of amateur chrysanthemum growers held in New Jersey, is the most recent addition to the list of organizations built up around gardeners' interests in a special flower.

MOSCOW, Nov. 4 -- Renewing its attack on the Iranian Government for its refusal to grant oil concessions to Russia, Izvestia implied today that the Iranian Government had favored British and American oil interests and raised the question of American troops' presence in sovereign Iran without any treaty.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 4 -- Yale took the high road in its game with Dartmouth today and, while the Elis didn't exactly reach Scotland before Dartmouth, they did manage to eke out a 6 -- 0 victory over the Indians to keep their season's record unsullied.
PARIS, Nov. 4 -- The French press explained American election procedure today and guessed the outcome.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 3 (Overseas News Agency (Delayed) -- The text of the press interview that resulted in the arrest of Gen. Arturo Rawson in Salta Province Oct. 29 was received here today, disclosing that General Rawson had condemned opposition to the United States as "criminal" and had called for Argentine participation in "this Continent's unity and defense without making difficulties."

Col. Kenneth R. Collins, district supervisor of the Army Air Forces Eastern Procurement District, appealed yesterday to workers in eleven Eastern States to speed production on the uncompleted portion of the more than 1,700 war contracts awarded by the Air Forces in this district during the last six months.

AMERICAN FIRST ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Nov. 4 -- The first American shells to fall on German territory were fired by boys from the Bronx, members of the 991st Field Artillery Battalion, formerly the Second Battalion of the 258th Field Artillery, the "Washington Greys."

CLEVELANDERS now on Bougainville, who have been fondly dreaming of home, will shortly have those dreams brought into sharper focus through the concerted efforts of the Cleveland Press and the Army Pictorial Service.

FOR the third time since their inauguration the music festivals sponsored by the Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge Foundation in the Library of Congress have included the dance in their schedule, and for the third time have done so with distinction.

But in this election, they are about the only ones who are throwing caution to the winds.

WILMINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The election is expected to be close in Delaware this year, but veteran political observers express the belief that President Roosevelt will win although his majority of 13,000 in 1940 will probably be cut to less than 5,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Inter-Departmental Executive Committee on Post-War Economic Policy, headed by Dean Acheson, Assistant Secretary of State, has reported to the Cabinet level on recommended national policies regarding cartels and commodity agreements.

With the return of substantial numbers of ex-service men to the colleges and universities of this country, the problem of how to meet their special needs is receiving the attention of educators and administrators. RENO, Nev., Nov. 4 -- Nevada, it is strongly indicated on the eve of election, will remain in the Democratic column Tuesday. Besides the Presidential contest there are two major offices to be filled.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 4 -- Although Republicans and independent Democrats have bidding for support, all indications point to Georgia remaining decisively in the Democratic column Tuesday.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 4 -- President Roosevelt, who received 63 per cent of Utah's popular vote in 1940, is certain to win the State's four electoral votes this year, but by a reduced majority. Indications are that his 61,000 margin of four years ago will shrink to 30,000 or less this year.
LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 4 -- New York University's all-civilian football cast, dominated by freshmen and sophomores, yielded to a Navy-trainee powered Bucknell University eleven by a 26-0 count today.

The arrest of six railroad employes at the Army and Navy Consolidated Depot, 660 West Thirty-seventh Street, on a charge of theft of $50,000 of supplies for troops overseas was announced yesterday by E.E. Conroy, regional chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
THERE will be no post-war unemployment for nylon. Scientists plan to put the "coal, air and water" synthetic to more jobs than ever.

THE visibility had been zero-zero for two days. The task force was ghosting along through the muck looking for a break in the weather to resume the widespread air searches that were its best protection. With not even the closest ships visible, only a few hundred yards away air activity had been almost nil.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 4 -- In an exclusive interview, Arturo Alessandri, former President of Chile and an outstanding political figure, declared that Argentina's proposal for a meeting of American Foreign Ministers should be carried into effect before the scheduled meeting designed to study post-war, problems.

TULSA, Okla., Nov. 4 -- The Iowa Seahawks broke through Tulsa's defenses for four touchdowns before the Hurricanes could manage a serious threat today, then stood off a fierce Tulsa rally to win, 47-27.

Ripley, chairman of Harriman, Ripley Co., Inc., said here last week in an address before the Cornell Society of Engineers.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Another great fleet of 1,000 Royal Air Force heavy bombers struck Germany tonight hard on the heels of daylight assaults by more than 1,100 "heavies" of the United States Eighth Air Force and somewhat smaller formations of RAF Lancasters and Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Fifteenth Air Force from Italy.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 4 -- Although the Republican national ticket may attract the largest vote in Arkansas this year since the Hoover-Smith campaign, there seems little likelihood that President Roosevelt and other Democratic candidates will fail to carry the State by a substantial margin.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- The newspaper Combat published today extracts from a letter addressed to its editor by Emmanuel Cardinal Suhard, Archbishop of Paris, protesting the paper's reproduction of an article by Georges Bernanos, a Catholic, assailing the church generally for its acceptance of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's regime and alleging specifically that the Archbishop acted as an intermediary when Pierre Laval was restored to office in 1942.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 4 -- A Roosevelt victory in West Virginia appears certain.

United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey filed yesterday four criminal informations, containing thirty-nine counts, against three of the largest Bronx kosher slaughterers and wholesalers of live poultry, and five of their officers and one employe.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- Mayor La Guardia of New York, before an audience packing memorial Auditorium, called tonight for the re-election of President Roosevelt to win the war, the peace and American economic security.

PHILATELISTS are still regarding with some amazement the public sale of United States revenues conducted by Harmer, Rooke Co. on Oct. 25. For one thing, it was the first time in their memory that an auction had been devoted exclusively to this class of stamps.

The National Association of Manufacturers is speeding up its program of studying the distribution problems attendant upon the possible attainment of post-war goals, it was learned yesterday. Three closed meetings on the subject, two in Chicago and one here, were held within the last two months.

After sailing the seven seas for more than half a century as a ship's carpenter on fast clipper ships, New Bedford whalers and modern steam vessels, William Samuel Clark, 100 years old, yesterday entered Sailors Snug Harbor, a home for retired seamen, on Staten Island.
TRENTON, Nov, 4 -- Two factors, together or singly, may determine whether President Roosevelt or Governor Dewey garners New Jersey's sixteen electoral votes in next Tuesday's balloting.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- President Roosevelt, in ordering the Army today to seize seven war plants and part of another in Toledo, placed in operation the criminal provisions of the War Labor Disputes Act, under which individuals accused of encouraging an interruption of war production may be prosecuted.

A NOTEWORTHY contribution to THE NEW YORK TIMES' war coverage has been the excellent daily situation and feature maps prepared by its staff. The issuance of these aids to the understanding of global war as an atlas with accompanying text was a welcome step.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 4 -- Lehigh University, in losing to Rutgers, 19-6, today before the season's biggest crowd, averted a shut-out on the last play of the game. It climaxed the Engineers' only real drive during which passes for substantial gains were mingled with a running attack in advancing 80 yards for the touchdown.

Barrett, Republican, will be re-elected over Charles Norris, Democrat.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The whole philosophy and meaning of treason under the Constitution will be discussed before the Supreme Court Monday in the case of Anthony Cramer of New York, convicted in lower courts of giving aid and comfort to two of the eight Nazi saboteurs who walked out of the sea in June, 1942, bent on a mission to destroy this country's aluminum industry.

LONDON. LONDON'S Lord Mayor-Elect, Sir Frank Alexander, will be inaugurated on Nov. 9 -- two days after our election day -- and many American service men here will see his famous "show," or pageant, through the streets.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 4 -- The Presidential campaign in Oregon is so close as it enters its final phase that any one of several unknown factors, such as the soldier vote, may decide the outcome. The trend, however, has been to Governor Dewey in recent weeks and he appears not unlikely to take Oregon's six electoral votes by a slim margin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Chairmen of the Democratic Senate and House Campaign Committees voiced confidence today of a continued Democratic majority in both houses, but late-hour election predictions were not immediately forthcoming from their Republican opposites.

BOSTON Nov. 4 -- President Roosevelt, in the final major, round-up speech of his campaign for re-election at Fenway Park tonight, declared that his opponent, Governor Dewey, had revealed in his campaign "a shocking lack of trust in America" and "faith in democracy."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 4 -- Ohio State University took fifteen minutes to get warmed up to its work today, then turned loose all of its vaunted power to wallop Indiana University's Western Conference title-hungry Hoosiers, 21 to 7, before 56,380 spectators.

It is also a preoccupation for tens of millions of ordinary Americans.

Activity in specialties resulted yesterday in swollen volume on the New York Stock Exchange and the market saw the heaviest Saturday volume in a month. Stocks were moderately firmer and closed irregularly higher. The turnover was 358,030 shares, against 296,150 for the preceding Saturday.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 4 -- Violent, abusive and fantastic has been the Presidential campaign in the deep South. There has been no more than a token Republican Democratic combat. Retail trade was good last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors were busy and toy departments, in many instances, were crowded.

John J. Loughlin, steward at the Chemists Club, 52 East Forty-first Street, was honored yesterday for the fifth time for meritorious home front service, when Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York presented a citation to him for collecting $5,080 toward the current War Fund goal.

Bolles, chairman of Continental Industries, Inc., a management and finance company organized last April, with four companies completely owned by it.

As motorists bound to the Southern resorts, they must have wondered, as they trundled those indifferent roads, where those special qualities were to be found.

THE little heroine of "Dulcie and Her Donkey" has figured in an earlier book called "Dulcie, or Half a Yard of Linsey Woolsy." She is appealing and amusing, with a happy faculty of getting out of difficulties as readily as she gets into them.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- A revolution in the French press was brought about today by a decision of the Minister of Information compelling newspapers in the Paris district to print their total circulation each day.

LONDON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. A.C. Critchley, director general of the British Overseas Air Corporation, told a group of his fellow experts today that "we shall beat him (the American competitor) because we know how to look after our customers better than he does, and we have the men to do it." The discussion was arranged by the Royal Aeronautical Society on Civil Aviation.

TWO letters to the drama editor last Sunday described the writers' disappointed attempts to obtain tickets for "Bloomer Girl." Both correspondents suggested that the ticket scarcity might have been caused by the management's favoring ticket agencies above the public.

VLADIMIR NABOKOV is not only a poet and novelist possessed of an extraordinary bilingual ear, who writes with distinction in our own language as well as in Russian, but he is one of Gogol's firmest admirers (his own novel, "The Real Life of Sebastian Knight," bears many evidences of this, much as he may disclaim it).

WILLIAM SAROYAN once remarked that there is a special kind of writing, not only for every writer but for every special set of circumstances in which he might find himself. "If you lose a leg, there's a kind of writing for that," he said.

While mild weather was not particularly conducive to expanding sales of heavier apparel, retail trade here last week was active. Main floor, accessory and gift departments were busy. Department store volume was estimated at about 15 per cent above the like week of last year.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Hotels are planning holiday menus around turkey and the elusive cranberry sauce as well as lobby displays of huge chrysanthemums and autumn leaves for Armistice Day and Thanksgiving. Advance reservations already indicate fall visitor records will be broken.

DETROIT, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Henry Ford today advocated the earliest possible elimination of wartime controls over materials, production and distribution and asserted that the future is "none too bright as things stand right now" for "the millions of young men and women whose world this will be in a few years."

LONDON, Nov. 4 (U.P.) -- British carrier planes and warships routed a German submarine pack in a fierce Arctic battle on the Murmansk convoy run, the Admiralty disclosed today, sinking at least three submarines and taking a highly important convoy from Britain to Russia and back again without the loss of a single merchant ship.

FOR months the mighty American Fleet had been eager for Japan's Navy to come out and fight. It did come out and when the vital action was over a new name had risen to take its place in American naval annals -- that of Vice Admiral Thomas C. Kinkaid, a veteran of most of the major Pacific sea battles.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- American troops were driven back today from the high-water mark of their invasion of the Reich, the town of Schmidt, but held their lines to the north firmly tonight while Allied troops in the southwestern Netherlands plunged ahead and the German radio said the battle of Walcheren Island was near its end.

OAKLAND, Neb., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Alfred M. Landon declared here tonight that President Roosevelt had "the ambition of a Caesar" but in handling foreign affairs he had "fizzled the same as he has in domestic affairs."

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 5 -- The Red Army yesterday completely collapsed the main enemy defense line east of Budapest and, according to enemy broadcasts, stormed into the southern suburb of Soroksar and launched a mighty assault to encircle the Hungarian capital.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 4 -- The bombshell that Argentina threw into Pan-American machinery by its request that a meeting of Foreign Ministers be held to consider her relations with the other American republics (sixteen of which have not recognized President Edelmiro Farrell's Government) exploded with such a loud report that its reverberations can still be heard in the farthest corners of the continent.

President Roosevelt declared last week that our operations in the war against Japan are months ahead of schedule. His statement was supported by the smashing naval victory won by our fleet in the second battle of the Philippine Sea and by the consolidation of our beachhead on the island of Leyte into a base for further operations against Japan.

The managing editor told him to go out to Marion, Ohio, to talk with the Republican Presidential candidate, Senator Harding. A telephone call to the Senator, whom the correspondent knew personally, brought a cordial invitation to come out and spend an afternoon.

" IN SECRET BATTLE" shows how the selfish interests of certain Americans can be more dangerous than a regiment of German spies. It begins with Pearl Harbor Sunday in the Chicago house of Stuart Baldwin. This rich and respected industrialist is listening to the advice of Marshall Trumbull, an American with an unsavory past in the pay of the Nazis.

LONDON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Russia has turned down Swiss proposals for the re-establishment of diplomatic relations between the two nations after a lapse of more than twenty years because "the Swiss Government, up to now, has in no way disavowed its former policy hostile to the Soviet Union," the Moscow radio declared tonight.

The Rumanian Premier, Constantin Sanatescu, has reshuffled his Cabinet, eliminating the leaders of the Peasant and Socialist parties and himself taking over temporarily the portfolio of Minister of War, the Bucnarest radio said last night in a domestic broadcast reported by the Federal Communications Commission.

Some time ago Herman Forster, president of the New York State Conservation Council, made recommendations on what could be done now to prepare for the war's end and the day the service men descended on fields and streams. At the same time he asked for suggestions.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 4 -- Air blows between the American and Japanese air forces have grown in intensity. American Lightnings and newly arrived Kittyhawks have been busily attacking armored reinforcements recently landed at Ormoc, on the west coast of Leyte, while Japanese planes have made more and more persistent night raids in our east coast area, although achieving little in the way of direct results.

In the nine months ended on Sept. 30, net income of the Borg-Warner Corporation and its subsidiaries was $5,774,072, equivalent to $2.47 each on 2,336,735 shares of common stock, according to a report issued yesterday. For the corresponding period of last year net profit was $7,348,588, or $3.15 a common share.

Making her last public addresses in New York City before the election, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt yesterday appealed to Americans to make fullest use of their voting franchise because this nation's responsibility for peace is the greatest in the world.

CHICAGO, Ill., Nov. 4 -- After months of preliminary negotiations, the International Civil Aviation Conference opened here this week with delegations from fifty-one countries present for the purpose of reaching agreements on a proposed multilateral air convention, provisional air routes for the immediate post-war world, technical standards and an interim council to work out plans for a permanent international air body.
HELENA, Nov. 4 -- Two Montana's election contests are nip-and-tuck, with the odds changing almost daily on the outcome of the races for the State's four electoral votes and the Governorship.

IN tune with their times, children chant of war and the election campaign, giving a contemporary turn to the jingles, rhymes and taunts -- some of them of very ancient lineage -- passed down by uncounted generations of children.

BOSTON, Nov. 4 -- The primary issue of the 1944 political campaign from the New England viewpoint is the winning of the war, the peace and the quickest possible return of our servicemen. Right behind this issue comes the problem of employment for all and a chance for citizens to get ahead in life without delay.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 4 (AP) -- A determined Georgia eleven, decidedly the underdog, scaled the heights today to upset a vaunted Alabama team, 14 -- 7.
Generous applause, mingled with a few faint "boo's," greeted Governor Dewey as he passed through the Times Square area last night after his Madison Square speech.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- September war production was 5 per cent below the goals set at the beginning of the month and 2 per cent below the monthly average for the year, the War Production Board announced today.

The body of a man identified as Fillip Rappa, 52 years old, of 105 East Fifteenth Street, was found yesterday afternoon partly submerged in an open storm sewer at Seventy-ninth Street and Sunrise Highway, Ozone Park, Queens. The body was identified through a pistol permit, issued to him as a partner in the Morgan Coat Company, 109 Ingraham Street, Brooklyn, which was found in one of the pockets along with a pistol.

THIS new version of Homer's greater work is a truly extraordinary achievement. The "Iliad" is a poem of more than 15,000 lines. To "English" such a work at all is a large undertaking. To render the poem into English verse of any metre is a much harder job. Of all English verse-forms the dactylic hexameter is probably the most ornery.

The Japanese Domei agency declared yesterday that every Japanese realized that the current battles in the Philippines would "decide his future" and it warned that the "optimistic belief that the enemy some day will falter" was not "permissible."

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 4 -- The upper South considers the issue of winning the war and the peace to be primary in the Presidential campaign. Except for its strong feeling on this issue, the region's traditional allegiance to the Democratic party might be less rock-ribbed in Tuesday's election.

IOWA CITY, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The University of Iowa, given a tremendous lift by substitute Nelson Smith's offensive thrusts, swept into the football victory column for the first time this season by crushing Nebraska, 27 to 6, today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- As the historic 1944 Presidential race roars to a close in the Central States, the outstanding Issues, so far as reports from the man in the street are concerned, have boiled down to three: the continued efficient conduct of the war, the winning of the peace and the maintenance of the advances made by labor.

When autumn winds and lashing rains have beaten the leaves from maples, birches, elms and beeches, when the thick mat of grass in the meadow and the thin carpeting of the upland pasture are crinkled by black frosts, there remain banners of red to accentuate the browns and grays and tans of the countryside.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- Grain markets on the Chicago Board of Trade were slightly higher in the early trading today, but later they broke sharply, with corn in the lead, on reports that 350,000 bushels of cash corn had been purchased for deferred shipment from the country and talk of a material increase in receipts next week as the result of dry, cold weather in the main producing section.

Cornell spotted Columbia a touchdown a little more than a minute after the start of the game yesterday, but the Big Red team from Ithaca thought little of this handicap. The up-State eleven got the score back, and another one to boot, before the first period ran out and went on to score a convincing, and hardly unexpected, triumph over the Lions by 25 to 7.

THE problem of selecting and planting a street tree is more widespread this fall than usual because the recent hurricane caused so much havoc. Of the many shade trees suitable for planting near the street line, there are some for almost any set of conditions the gardener may have to face in making replacements.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS ON LEYTE, Sunday, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Veterans of the Twenty-fourth Division drove by land and sea yesterday against Pinamopoan, key highway terminus on Carigara Bay, in preparation for a larger-scale assault against Ormoc, twenty miles southward, where the Japanese have prepared new defenses for a last-ditch stand.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 4 -- Successful conclusion of the twin offensives by the Twenty-first Army Group in the Netherlands, first, to clear the approaches to Antwerp, and second, to drive the Germans north over the Maas and broaden the base of the salient which points northeastward toward the North German plain, should enlarge and accelerate Allied operations throughout the sectors of the Twenty-first and Twelfth Army Groups.

Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick is one who speaks, and here, in twenty-five sermons, delivered since Dec. 7, 1941, is his response to the misery, frustration and despair resulting from international slaughter.

BOSTON, Nov. 4 -- Two months ago Massachusetts was considered safely in the Democratic Presidential column for the fifth time. And today the State still appears to be for President Roosevelt, barring a startling, last minute development.

A Berlin Foreign Office spokesman indicated yesterday that Germany was taking steps to determine whether an American correspondent's interview with Generalissimo Francisco Franco, who was quoted as saying that Spain could never ally herself with Germany, was "authentic," the Trans-ocean agency reported.

THIS year marks the centennial of Temple Emanu-El, which stands as a monument to the faith and fervor of a few Jewish migrants from Germany. The story of this congregation is closely linked to that of New York. It is a story of change, growth, progress and stability. In a sense it is a story of Americanization.

Steps toward the development of a uniform order blank covering billions of dollars in merchandise purchases by retailers were seen as greatly advanced last week by the announcement of Irwin D. Wolf, vice president of the Kaufmann Department Stores, Pittsburgh, and chairman of the vender relations committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, that studies of a standard form to be presented to the annual convention next January for approval would be started shortly.

BOSTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- President Roosevelt tonight awarded the Distinguished Service Medal posthumously to Sir John Dill, senior British representative on the combined Chiefs of Staff, who died in Washington today. Not since the war began have so many nurses been needed in so short a time as they are today. At present there are approximately 40,000 women in the Army Nurse Corps, 9,000 in the Navy Nurse Corps. By July, 1945, the Army must have 10,000 more nurses; the Navy 4,000.

GARDEN chrysanthemums have been subject to so much breeding and improvement during the last dozen years that now one may enjoy nearly any color one chooses from late summer until November. Few gardens, admittedly, have a constant display of bloom, but this is not so much for lack of available material as for failing to choose a broad enough assortment of varieties.

From a GI Joe now fighting in Italy, the New York War Fund has received an account of an incident he witnessed recently. It is a story about a little Yugoslav refugee boy who took three-quarters of an hour to eat a gumdrop the soldier had given him.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 4 -- The first open break between the Finnish Government and sections of the army over the latter's unwillingness to comply with Moscow's armistice conditions has occurred, according to private information from Helsinki.

Abraham Lincoln High defeated Tilden, 12 -- 6, and James Madison beat Lafayette, 13 -- 6, in a school football double-header at Ebbets Field yesterday before a crowd of 5,000. Lincoln won its fourth game. It has lost one and tied one.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 4 -- Missouri which has voted for the winner in every election since 1904, gave President Roosevelt a margin of 460,693 in 1932 and of 413,152 in 1936. In 1940 this majority was cut to 86,567, chiefly in St. Louis.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 4 -- South Carolina, proclaimed America's most Democratic State, will have seven tickets to vote in the 1944 general election. Spokesmen for the "Regular Democrats," backing President Roosevelt, are estimating they will get up to 98 per cent of the ballots but the anti-New Dealers are highly vocal.

A SURVEY of the radio industry on the question of broadcasting direct from the floor in Congress, conducted by Nathan Straus, president of WMCA, reveals that 69.2% of stations polled endorse such broadcasts while 13.5% are opposed and 17.3% are undecided.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 4 -- Except for a few optimists among Republican leaders, veterans and newcomers in political forecasting expect President Roosevelt to carry California next Tuesday, though it will be surprising if his majority matches his 526,000 in 1940.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Dr. Frank P. Graham, public member of the War Labor Board, condemned today as an "outrage" the dismissal of Dr. Homer P. Rainey from the presidency of the University of Texas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Although the country's birth rate in 1943 was 4.3 per cent higher than for 1942, there were seventy fewer maternal deaths in 1943, according to figures issued by the Bureau of Census, Department of Commerce, today.

NOT fully believing the United States will dissolve formally by 10 o'clock Tuesday evening -- as both sides have charged -- the Broadway theatre has been engaged in one of its most active periods in a long while. Among the theatre's legends is a nice one that pre-election days are bad for the drama, that the public stays home biting its fingernails and listening to the speeches.

The Stilwells sent a telegram to their "Uncle Joe" yesterday, expressing their "love and best wishes." They had hoped to shake his hand and clap him on the back and spend a quiet afternoon with him, but "Uncle Joe" -- officially known as Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell -- couldn't attend the family dinner so they sent him the telegram instead.

ROME, Nov. 4 -- The old question of shipping will apparently seriously complicate the question of the Allies' relief in the Mediterranean and it is becoming more apparent that the Allies' authorities in Greece are eager to counteract the suggestion that unlimited relief materials will be poured in.
EASTON, Pa., Nov. 4 -- Five runs, ranging from 15 to 72 yards, enabled Lafayette to register a 34-21 victory over the Ursinus eleven today in a game replete with thrills.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Details of the sinking of an American transport by a submarine in the North Atlantic with heavy loss of life early in 1943 were revealed for the first time today.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- Aime Lepercq, Minister of Finance, said today that the Liberation Loan, subscriptions to which will be opened on Monday, had been floated not because the Government needed funds -- the Treasury having gained 11,000,000,000 francs since the liberation through Treasury bonds and taxes -- but to reduce the circulation of currency, which is too great.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 4 (AP) -- A spirited West Virginia University football team stabbed for a second period touchdown today and then kicked a strong Temple eleven into innumerable holes while doggedly turning back every enemy scoring threat to win, 6 to 0, on Mountaineer Field.

WHENEVER the Chicago Bears and the Green Bay Packers collide on the gridiron it's a bit difficult to concentrate elsewhere. The Monsters of the Midway and the Ponderous Pachyderms have been blithely belting each other so long and so enthusiastically that their series shows more scars and wound stripes than any other in football.

THE 5,638,000 persons who ride the subways every month may not know what art is, but a large number of them know what they like. They have had a chance to make up their minds, for in the past two years the subway has been alive with touches of great art.

LAWRENCE K. FRANK thinks that in the prevailing discussion of the teen ages we might pay more attention than we do to the physical changes that occur with puberty, the uneven rate at which they come, and the part they play in behavior at the so-called "awkward age."

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 4 -- President Roosevelt has a slight edge over Governor Dewey in New Hampshire, by a private consensus of leaders. Mr. Dewey is expected to cut the 15,000 margin the President rolled up four years ago, when 238,000 votes were cast for a new record, but not enough to put the State's four electoral votes into his column.

UNITED STATES NINTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, in France, Nov. 3 (Delayed) -- The Luftwaffe seems to be making the greatest use of rocket and jet propelled fighter planes now. United States Ninth Air Force headquarters revealed today at least eighty observations of these aircraft during October, operating solely in the skies over Germany.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- Political observers of the reconstituted Twenty-ninth Congressional District speculated today on the possibility that Representative Hamilton Fish, Republican candidate for re-election for a thirteenth term, might win by a narrow margin in the toughest fight of his career through the indirect assistance of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, who has twice repudiated Mr. Fish.

SEATTLE, Nov. 4 -- There is a bare chance that the State may not be in the Roosevelt column, despite the predictions of national surveys. Results of one gambler's straw vote show Dewey leading, although only by one-half of 1 per cent. The betting odds continue to favor Roosevelt.

AMONG the things to think about in tomorrow's world besides electronic cook-stoves and family helicopters will be a new responsibility: learning to live with the disabled. With the "wounded" columns of casualty lists lengthening, we will probably see an increasing number of books and articles telling us what to do, individually and collectively, about and for our disabled service men -- and telling the disabled man what he can do for himself.

IN this place last week there appeared a discussion of Wendell Willkie's last message to the American people. The heart of that message was Mr. Willkie's belief that democracy had an international responsibility, that it must accept that responsibility or it would die; that a system of freedom and a system of slavery could not both survive on this earth.
ST. PAUL, Nov. 4 -- Minnesota still looks like a fifty-fifty gamble in the Presidential race, with the weatherman having very much to say about the outcome.

The leaders of Dai Nippon last week were having to reassess their situation in the light of recent developments in the Pacific war. Compared with their original aims, the prospect was bleak. Tokyo's plan had called for the conquest of East Asia and the large islands of the Pacific, sources of vital raw materials, and for the occupation of smaller islands which would screen the expanded empire against any threat from American sea power.

Instruments of the Orchestra. (Columbia, album X-250, two twelve-inch records). Brief excerpts from the orchestral repertoire designed to demonstrate the capabilities of various instruments and to help the musically unitiated find his way .hrough the intricacies of the orchestral texture.

Placing seven men in the first ten, Bishop Loughlin romped off with the C.H.S.A.A. cross-country championship for the eleventh consecutive year yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. Only Kevin Delaney of Brooklyn Prep, second; John Lynch of Fordham Prep, seventh, and Frank O'Sullivan of St. Augustine, tenth, prevented George Eastment's lads from making a clean sweep of the meet, a feat that has never been accomplished.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Boris (Babe) Dimancheff, 178 pounds of civilian dynamite from Indianapolis, personally conducted Purdue's Boilermakers back into the Western Conference victory column today by scoring four touchdowns in 51 minutes and pacing the charges of Cecil Isbell to a 35-to-0 triumph over Wisconsin.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- The French say almost daily that the Allies, especially the Americans most of whom have seen the war from afar, do not understand the extent of France's sufferings during the occupation and today. If the Allies did understand they would do more to diminish those sufferings, the French think, even in the midst of a war that exacts such herculean efforts.

Authorization of the payment of $428,333 to Agwilines, Inc., of New York City, for the loss of its Clyde-Mallory liner Henry R. Mallory, built in 1916, was announced yesterday by the War Shipping Administration. The ship was sunk by a torpedo, with a heavy loss of life, early last year.

DENVER, Nov. 4 -- Although each major party declares that the State's six electoral votes will go to its Presidential candidate, impartial observers are still listing it as "doubtful." Republicans contend, however, that there is a pro-Dewey trend and point to 1940 when Mr. Willkie, with 279,576 votes, carried Colorado by 14,022.

Irving Stein of the Bronx regained the lead in the national amateur chess championship by defeating J.S. Battell of Brooklyn in the tenth round last night at the Brooklyn headquarters of the United States Chess Federation. Stein resorted to a French defense to score in thirty-two moves.

ROME, Nov. 4 (U.P.) -- British Eighth Army troops consolidated gains in the Forli sector today, battling strong German armor at the city's airfield in one of the hardest rainstorms of the year, while to the west the Fifth Army's American soldiers holed up in their mountain positions, awaiting more favorable weather for continuation of the inch-by-inch advance on Bologna.

BOISE, Nov. 4 -- Idaho, which three times has given its four electoral votes to President Roosevelt, entered the campaign's closing week in the conjectural column.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- While Lieut. Col. Earl Blaik was more or less enjoying himself watching Navy triumph over Notre Dame at Baltimore today his juggernaut Army team ran at will against Villanova on Michie Stadium field, scoring an 83-0 victory for the third highest Cadet score in Army football history.

SANTA FE, N.M., Nov. 4 -- Even the most conservative polls align New Mexico with the Solid South.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- Pennsylvania's young and inexperienced football team, not quite fully recovered from last week's beating by Navy, tried hard to come back at the expense of Michigan today at Franklin Field, but the Wolverines, bursting power from all seams, had other ideas and at the finish the Western Conference representatives were on top, 41 -- 19.

SAN FANCISCO, Nov. 4 -- Tabulation of West Coast votes next Tuesday will show whether the electorate on this slope has been sold on the argument that President Roosevelt's leadership in running the war and his equipment to lead the nation at the peace table outweigh the Administration's domestic shortcomings as reflected in widespread criticism of bureaucracy and Federal encroachment on individual and State rights.
