AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The country's natural rubber income is likely to "equal outgo" early in 1945 for the first time since Pearl Harbor, John T. Collyer, president of the B.F. Goodrich Company, predicted today.

Public school systems in various parts of the country are turning to the radio to supplement their teaching. Reports indicate that new materials have been introduced into the classroom as a result of extended radio programs. In some instances lectures, symposiums and general discussions go over the air.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- Three of the five members of the Yonkers Common Council took the first step today in a move to oust City Manager William A. Walsh by filing with the City Clerk resolutions calling for his suspension. They contend that he lacks an "energetic" and "understanding" approach to problems the municipality faces now or will face after the war.

ON BOARD THE PRESIDENT'S TRAIN, Bound for Boston, Nov. 4 -- When the President's train rolled into Bridgeport in a pea-soup fog this morning he went to the rear platform of his car and stood before a crowd of several thousand persons who had gathered to greet him in that hub of the home district of one of his most vocal Congress critics, Representative Clare Boothe Luce.
DETROIT, Nov. 4 -- An advance look at the election in Michigan discloses a few certainties and as many imponderables.

" STRIKE him down, Lord!" says an angry man in South Dakota -- and launches an "amazing international movement." Twenty minutes past the hour (in whatever meridian it is noon) anti-Fascists pause silently for fifteen seconds as they call on God to strike down Adolf Hitler.

EUPEN, Belgium, Nov. 3 (Delayed) -- This border town, close in behind the American battle lines, is a political no man's land between Belgium and Germany. Its population of 16,000 is predominantly German. Its administration is again Belgian for the second time since 1918.

" THESE four plays represent the main bulk of my serious writing for the theatre during the last six years," says J.B. Priestley in the preface to this collection of his dramatic works. "Whatever the faults and merits * * * nobody can say they are smooth drawing-room comedies filled with peers, butlers and pretty jewel thieves."

In emphasizing that 97 per cent of wounded American soldiers were saved, a substantial proportion through the use of blood plasma and whole blood, Lieut. Col. Douglas B. Kendrick Jr. of the Army Medical Corps said yesterday that the offensives by our forces called for a greater contribution of blood from the American people.

ROME, Nov. 4 -- Former Premier Vittorio Emanuele Orlando, one of the "big four" of the first World War, came out of his retirement of twenty-five years today and delivered one of the greatest speeches of his career to appeal for Italian unity on this anniversary of the Italian-Austrian armistice.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- A joint statement setting forth interim policies which will be followed in the disposal of surplus property pending appointment of the Surplus Property Board provided for under the law adopted by Congress in September, was issued here today by W.L. Clayton, Surplus War Property Administrator and heads of interested Federal agencies.
DES MOINES, Nov. 4 -- Iowa, which gave Wendell Willkie a 53,000 majority in 1940, appeared certain to put its 10 electoral votes in the Republican column again Nov. 7.
THE opening three-bid, used as a weak shut-out bid, is usually quite effective, so much so that no one has ever devised a wholly adequate answer to it.

A GREAT many parents and a great many decorators make the mistake of assuming that a child's room has to be cute," thinks Frieda Diamond, home furnishings designer, who proposes some ideas for junior furniture that she believes would offer more comfort and enjoyment for the growing child than the pastel-painted, small-sealed pieces that seem so attractive to doting adults.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein announced yesterday that "every resource" of his office would be used to enforce the election laws and to prevent illegal voting and that he would have 3,500 special investigators and special deputy Attorneys General, in addition to the New York City police, at the polling places throughout the city.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 4 -- In a fine display of offensive football, but with both teams showing a marked defensive weakness, Northwestern battled Minnesota to a 14-all deadlock today in the Gophers' annual homecoming contest.

What are the issues in the 1944 campaign as the two candidates have developed them? This article is an attempt to answer the question. It is based on the speeches made by President Roosevelt and Governor Dewey in the course of the campaign since Mr. Dewey opened it on Sept. 7 in Philadelphia.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Canada may be called upon to provide wheat for markets formerly supplied by Australia, the Canadian Dominion Bureau of Statistics says in a survey of the world wheat situation. Australia is expected to harvest its smallest wheat crop since 1919, production being estimated at 50,000,000 bushels, barely enough to meet feed requirements.
AUSTIN, Nov. 4 -- Despite the appearance of a third party, Texas is expected to remain safely in the Democratic column.
HANFORD Calif., Nov. 4 (AP) -- A passenger plane crashed and burned three miles northeast of here tonight, and twenty-four bodies were found scattered over a mile of fields near by.

OF the exercises given by beauty specialists to improve the figure there are some that are classic, others that are new variations of basic principles. Into the classic category falls the first of the following exercises -- for the upper arms, chest and shoulders.

IF you wish to cope with your enemy you must learn to know him. That is why I spiritually exposed myself to a dangerous opera the other day. "Madama Butterfly" was scheduled for the San Carlo Opera in Naples and, recalling that the Metropolitan in New York had interdicted the work after Dec. 7, 1941, I decided to have a look, to see where lay its sting.

Tales of pharmacist's mates on submarines who save lives, heal wounds, mend broken bones and serve as "the doctor, dentist, nurse and even the chaplain all rolled into one," were related yesterday at the annual meeting of the Association or Military Surgeons of the United States in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 4 -- Connecticut's eight electoral votes appear to be assured for President Roosevelt as the current campaign comes to a close. Some political observers think, however, that Governor Baldwin, Senator Danaher and others on the Republican State ticket have an even chance of being returned to office.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 4 -- Despite some strange political cross-currents which possibly may affect the outcome, Virginia Democrats who go to the polls Tuesday are expected to give President Roosevelt their traditional majority.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- Despite a last-minute drive by the local Republican organization to intensify and widen the support for Governor Dewey, it was apparent today that President Roosevelt stood the better chance of winning the thirty-five electoral votes of Pennsylvania.
SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Nov. 4 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The composite opinion of fifty-six political reporters for newspapers in the forty-eight States of the Union, as collected and pooled by the Washington Bureau of THE NEW YORK TIMES, is that the following will be the approximate results of the votes cast in Tuesday's general election which, to be counted, must be in the boxes before the polls close that day:

THE words "unconditional surrender," which President Roosevelt used at Casablanca to describe the terms on which the Axis must accept defeat at the hands of the Allies, have of late been subject of discussion, objection -- and confusion.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 4 -- Political observers here agree generally that the election result in Wisconsin will be close, with Governor Dewey probably having a slight edge. The situation appears to parallel closely that of four years ago, when President Roosevelt won the State by 25,000.

THE vigorous and caustic comments of Writer Elliot Paul regarding the general treatment of war subjects by Hollywood were given some warm consideration (you may remember) in this column last week, with citations from some recent pictures to support his argument.

DR. A.J. CRONIN, who quit his medical practice at 34 because he wanted to write novels instead of prescriptions, was lamenting the other day that his chief purpose in life -- to "improve" as a writer -- is a desire "clearly handicapped by success," which must mean that he was decidedly pained by the sales of "The Citadel" and "The Keys of the Kingdom."

Seven Hearts, a son of Grand Slam, captured the $34,100 Westchester Handicap at Jamaica yesterday as the regular New York racing season ended with financail records victoriously doubled in spades. Some world betting marks were smashed on this final day of 180, the wagering going toward a grand total for the year of $388,995,250.

MORE than 3,000,000 babies were born in the United States in 1943 -- 126,175 more than in 1942, and the largest increase on record, the Department of Commerce reports. Patriots cheer the rising population, but students of nomenclature regard the 3,000,000 infants with shuddering pleasure.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Syracuse University's Orange eleven took its worst drubbing of the season today from Penn State's Nittany Lions, failing to score as Penn State rolled up six touchdowns and five place kicks for a 41-to-0 total.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Superfortresses flew their first mission with fighter escort from the Eastern Air Command, when they dropped the greatest bomb load ever carried in this theatre on enemy installations in Rangoon and the vicinity, it was announced here today.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 4 -- Louisiana is expected to remain safely in the Democratic column Nov. 7 in spite of a prospective protest vote against the New Deal and a fourth term for Roosevelt.

Some weeks ago there was a luncheon in Wall Street. True, the days have passed when the mere fact that anyone in Wall Street was eating could be classed as news, but this luncheon nevertheless had an importance of its own. It brought together men who will have a good deal to say as to the method by which American money will be made available for the rebuilding of the world.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- A new and potent spark plug in the design of opportunity for disabled veterans is the National Rehabilitation Committee, Inc., started in New York City this past week.

CLEVELAND, NOV. 4 -- Ohio is expected to elect a Democratic Governor, re-elect Senator Robert A. Taft to the United States Senate and remove three or four Republican Representatives from office in Tuesday's election, but the disposition of this State's 25 electoral votes in the Presidential contest remains a toss-up.
ROME, Nov. 4 -- British troops and Greek patriots have driven the Germans completely from Greece, Allied Headquarters announced today.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 4 -- Declaring that unemployment is a "curse second only to war," Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President, asserted tonight that the post-war programs of both major parties constituted a reversion to a wide-scale policy of unemployment and the "historic form of boondoggling" that has characterized European militarism.

The completion of plans for a program of improved shipboard feeding in this country's vast merchant marine, which includes food control and accounting, stowage and preservation, menus and preparation, and personnel training education, was announced here yesterday by Harold J. O'Connell, director of the War Shipping Administration's Food Control Division.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee disclosed today that it was making preliminary charges of partisan political activity by insurance companies and by radio commentators on sponsored broadcasts.

The completion of plans for a program of improved shipboard feeding in this country's vast merchant marine, which includes food control and accounting, stowage and preservation, menus and preparation, and personnel training education, was announced here yesterday by Harold J. O'Connell, director of the War Shipping Administration's Food Control Division.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Senate Campaign Expenditures Committee disclosed today that it was making preliminary charges of partisan political activity by insurance companies and by radio commentators on sponsored broadcasts.

GREENPORT, L.I., Nov. 4 -- The body of a man washed up off Orient Point last night was identified today by his widow as that of Capt. John M.L. Gorett, 50 years old, an inspector of nautical instruments for the British Merchant Marine.

WORD came to Frank Fay not long ago that Dorothy Parker had called him "a genius -- with guts." A friend acting as Mr. Fay's agent set out to verify the quote. The friend found Miss Parker in the Stork Club.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The following Foreign Service changes since Oct. 28 were announced today by the State Department:

Last night Franklin Delano Roosevelt in Boston and Thomas Edmund Dewey in New York made the speeches which in effect wound up their campaigns for the Presidency. Each will take to the microphones again for election-eve talks; party workers will be busy until the polls close.

Last week delegates of fifty nations gathered around the green baize tables in the huge, flag-bedecked ballroom of a Chicago hotel in an attempt to arrive at a mutually acceptable policy to govern post-war international aviation. Their task was complex and delicate; areas of disagreement were wide. The need for agreement was urgent.

IT is now almost thirteen years since William Walton's huge choral work, "Belshazzar's Feast," was written, and almost nine since it was first performed in this country. Since that time it has been hailed as one of the most important modern choral works produced in England, a country noted for its penchant for this kind of music.

THE mutations of daily history reflect nowhere more clearly than in the newspapers the influence of men -- and especially of particular men -- upon events. This war, like all wars, will be remembered by the names of men -- Hitler, Chiang Kai-shek, Wavell, Churchill, Eisenhower and a host of others. Men make events; leadership is history.
THE young sergeant with the old face sat on the sunny porch of the red brick building and watched some soldiers file quickly into a big bus.

CULPTURE came into its own this week with five shows of work by artists in that field. A large and highly diverse group show at the Clay Club brings together pieces by de Creeft, Hovannes, de Marco, Lu Duble and other welt known sculptors as well as pieces by comparative or complete unknowns, in a range from ultra-academic to ultra-abstract and from bronze to plastic.

Despite a week-end report by the War Food Administration that fresh pork supplies in this city were "considerably improved," the Meat Trade Institute warned yesterday that New Yorkers might experience next week the most severe pork shortage of all.

PIERRE MONTEUX, the distinguished French conductor, who is currently making one of his infrequent New York appearances as guest conductor with the Philharmonic-Symphony, arrived in New York last week preceded by an enviable reputation as a musician, accompanied by his charming wife and bringing with him tremendous enthusiasm for San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Messages for liberated American prisoners and civilian internees in the Philippines will be accepted by all Red Cross chapters during November, Basil O'Connor, chairman, announced today.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 4 (AP) -- An American communique:

The national retriever field trial championship meeting, originally scheduled for Nov. 17 and 18, has been set back to Dec. 1, 2 and 3 at Saugatuck, Mich., according to word from Chicago. The original dates allowed only four days between the closing of the Eastern meeting on Long Island and the national.

KALAMATA, Greece, Nov. 4 -- The Peloponnesus, which before Greece's liberation was recognized unofficially as Eam territoy in which political parties and resistance groups other than those with close Communist affiliations were not allowed to operate, remains the same although the Germans have been out of the entire area a month.
Argentine business representatives will take part in the international business conference of fifty nations at Rye, N.Y., Nov. 10 to 18, it was announced today.

Reefs lie ahead for some of the professional teams today, especially in the West, where the Packers, who, up to now anyway, have had things pretty much their own way in their half of the National Football League. They're up against the Bears again and the old Bruins are growling.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 4 -- Two hours before they were to "show cause" before the regional War Labor Board why they had ignored WLB orders to return to their jobs, CIO machinists today ended a strike which had halted machinist work on eighty-two ships in yards of Oakland and vicinity in the East Bay.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Fifteen executive officers of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America were described as "Communist conspirators" whose aim is "to destroy the American system of free enterprise" and set up "a communistic dictatorship," in a suit in equity filed in Common Pleas Court here today.

IN a time when books have naturally been much occupied with passing events -- with the reporting of them and with discussion of their import -- it is refreshing to have a book from one of the world's foremost men of letters which is concerned with literature as an art and with its relation to life.

FOLLOWING the food, monetary, peace and aviation discussions, the international business conference starts sessions at Rye, N.Y., later this week and perhap it is not too much to say that the horse is finally being harnessed to the cart of world affairs where he belongs, and not at the rear or the sides of the vehicle.

Collections topping the 1943 figure for the first three days of the New York City Cancer Committee's annual booth campaign by $1,000 were announced yesterday as the first contingent of Navy wives and mothers who have volunteered to man booths reported at Pennsylvania Station.
MELBOURNE, Nov. 4 -- The drought now gripping southern and eastern Australia in range and intensity has been paralleled only by those of 1914, 1902 and earlier calamitous visitations.

If representatives of America commerce and industry abroad are to cope successfully with representatives of European industry they must master foreign languages, Jaun Godoy, manager of W.R. Grace Co., told 800 teachers yesterday at New York University's eleventh annual Foreign Language Conference in the university's auditorium.

DURING a nation-wide tour recently I found people everywhere worried about a post-war crime wave. They didn't know exactly how or where it would start, but they appeared to be certain of one thing: When GI Joes lay down their guns for Uncle Sam, many will pick up new ones and run amuck.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Senator Harry S. Truman, Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, closed his country-wide campaign tour tonight with an appeal to his fellow townsmen to "send Franklin D. Roosevelt to the peace table" and "not betray American boys who have made the greatest sacrifice a man can make for his country."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 4 -- One of the most savage German generals has been appointed to command the crucial East Prussian front. He is Col. Gen. Grasser, who sacked Tallinn, Estonia's capital, on Sept. 21 as his troops moved out and the Russians moved in.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The recent refusal of the National War Labor Board to recommend an upward revision of wage scales is regarded by experts here as having delayed until some future date any crisis in the fight against inflation and as concentrating attention upon the uncertain factors which will manifest themselves at the end of the war in Europe.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 4 -- The State's twelve electoral votes are expected to go for Roosevelt despite the aggressive campaign for the Dewey ticket and for John W. Kilgo, Greeneville attorney, who is opposing Representative Jim Nance McCord of Lewisburg, Democratic nominee for Governor.

AN electoral campaign has now reached its climax -- with the New Deal holding the spotlight as an issue. But this is definitely not a campaign book, although it can be of more use to anyone interested in making an appraisal of the New Deal than most of the recent campaign oratory.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Nov. 4 -- Chesapeake Bay dogs won three of the four trophies today in the first stake contested in the annual meeting of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club on the grounds of the Timber Point Club.

Unbeaten in two years, Walter Soltow of New Utrecht sped to victory in the P.S.A.L. cross-country championships yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. Running his best race of the year, the 17-year-old junior covered the two and one-half miles in 12:57.8, crossing the tape about forty yards ahead of Bill McGuire, George Washington High.

To combat the "quick money" point of view of high school boys and girls whose wartime earnings in summer and after-school jobs have been out of all proportion to the skills required, the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies has set up a new type of free vocational guidance service, George Z. Medalie, president, disclosed yesterday.

POLITICS and love, intrigue and romance, history and adventure are the ingredients of this meaty historical romance. This is the time when George I ruled in England and the Lords Proprietors controlled the fate the rich Carolina lands -- the melodramatic moment in the pageant of the past when pirates plundered trade ships loaded with New World goods and found protection in the coves and inlets along the Carolina shore.

DURHAM, N.C., Nov. 4 -- The battle-scarred Blue Devils of Duke had their moment of gridiron glory today when, after four week-ends of denial, they rose in all their rugged might to hand Georgia Tech's engineers their first defeat, 19 to 13.

" Somewhere in London" last week, Prime Minister Churchill addressed the members of the House of Commons. He asked twelve months' prolongation of the present Parliament on the ground that "the coalition of parties ought not be broken before nazism is broken," that "this was the purpose for which we came together in the present National Government."

HEADQUARTERS OF THE FIRST CAVALRY, on Leyte, Nov. 4 -- The famous First Cavalry Division, which includes some of the oldest regiments of the United States Army, veterans of the Civil War and Indian fighting under Gen. George A. Custer, has slowly begun to remount itself -- with the assistance of the Japanese.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- UNRRA announced tonight that it would send a delegation into liberated Poland soon to arrange for shipment and distribution of relief. supplies.

The famous masterpiece of Renaissance painting, the "Madonna and Child" by the Italian artist Fra Filippo Lippi, which has been in many world-famous collections since its origin in the fifteenth century, was sold at auction yesterday to an undisclosed private collector in this city for $30,000.
Can the President authorize the use of American armed forces to carry out the Dumbarton Oaks proposal?

The Presidential election next Tuesday is the thirty-ninth held in the United States since the one in 1788. Then Gen. George Washington was elected Chief Executive of thirteen scattered, diverse States with a population of approximately 3,500,000.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 4 -- Dewey's lead in straw polls varies from 52-48 to 60-40, but many voters have replied that they are still undecided.

THE house must cease to be divided if we are to prevent one of the ice ages of history from coming upon us. But it will have to be a house of many mansions, not an enormous, room where bored and frightful prisoners regret the varied life they have known.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Viewed in retrospect, the national campaign of 1944, now approaching its end, posed for the voters of the United States one over-all issue, and on this the decision will undoubtedly be based. The Republican spokesmen have insisted that "it is time for a change" in the control of the government at Washington, and the Democrats have contended that the midst of war is not "the time for a change."

Cotton futures held within a narrow range yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and final prices were unchanged to 1 point lower than on Friday. There was no feature to the trading. The volume was restricted by uncertainties regarding the Federal export sales plan and the election.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4 -- After eight years of perseverance Navy found the road to victory over Notre Dame again today and sailed through full steam ahead, pouring broadsides into the outgunned and outmanned Fighting Irish.

TULSA, Okla., Nov. 4 -- In Oklahoma's closest Presidential contest in twenty years Roosevelt is expected to win despite defection in the past four years. In 1940 he carried the State by 125,000, in 1936 by 255,000 and in 1932 by 325,000.
TORONTO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The league-leading Toronto Maple Leafs kept their winning streak intact by downing the Boston Bruins, 7 -- 2, in a National Hockey League game tonight before 13,580 fans.

MOSCOW, Nov. 5 -- The Russian press charged today that Iranian soldiers in Tabriz had opened fire on a peaceful anti-Government demonstration, killing one man and wounding another who were among the crowd protesting against Premier Mohammed Said's government's decision to postpone action on Russia's oil-concession proposal.

The criminal folly of the Hungarian Nazis in thwarting Regent Horthy's effort to get his country out of the war while there still was time has now caught up with them. It may have helped them to stave off their doom for a few weeks, but it has also exposed their country to further ravages of war, in what Horthy called an "alien interest."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- B-29 Superfortresses bombed Singapore today, it was announced here in a War Department communique.

An underwriting group headed by the Union Securities Corporation and W.C. Langley Co. will offer today $2,800,360 of 3 1/2 per cent sinking fund debentures, due in 1956, of Goodall-Sanford, Inc., at $103 and accrued interest. The same banking group also will offer 226,566 shares of common stock of the company at $22.75 a share.

Declaring that preservation of tolerance at home was "the first requirement for a friendly world," Senator Robert F. Wagner denounced yesterday the injection of this issue into the current campaign as an attempt "to stir up race against race and faith against faith."

The three signatory powers to the Teheran Declaration, granting Austria full independence, seem to plan joint occupation by American, British and Russian forces for the period of transition. In view of the importance of Vienna, it is obvious that none of these powers wishes to see any other of the Big Three in single-handed control of this vital European center.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Miss Winifred Stanley, Representative-at-large, who has campaigned for the Republican national ticket in fifteen States, told members of the Young Women's Republican Club of New York yesterday that she had encountered strong opposition to the New Deal everywhere.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Japanese, pressing their south China offensive, converged on the Kwangsi Province railway city of Liuchow from three directions today, with the nearest column only forty-five miles away on the southeast.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- Election day at the front is just another fighting day. A visit to the American combat zone on the eve of the Presidential election reveals that neither the GI's nor their officers talk much of party issues or candidates. But they get a surprising amount of satisfaction out of the fact that the people back home are voting as usual.
Saturday's communique as broadcast domestically from Sofia and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Nov. 4 (Delayed) -- One of the men in this army who really talks firmly about making the Germans feel the consequences of the war is, oddly enough, a Methodist minister. And he expects within the next few months to put his preaching into practice with hundreds of thousands of German civilians.

A score of new exhibitions are on the art calendar for the present week. The annual exhibition of the Associated Artists of New Jersey began yesterday with a private view at the Riverside Museum and will be open to the public daily, except Mondays, until Dec. 10.
LONDON, Nov. 5 (UP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

SALONIKA, Greece, Nov. 5 -- Among the Elas bands are German and Italian soldiers, some of whom were taken prisoner by Greek guerrillas, but most of whom gave up with the avowed purpose "of fighting fascism" in Greece. Today, Fascists seem very far from being in power, and those in power are very far from being Fascists.

Mgr. Edward Roberts Moore, pastor of old St. Peter's Church in Barclay Street, marked the silver jubilee of his ordination to the priesthood with a solemn mass of thanksgiving yesterday morning at St. Peter's.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 5 -- Extreme dullness characterized most of the trading in cotton futures last week on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange as the industry awaited Washington's plans to function in the cotton market. Modest daily reactions accompanied growing complaints about the difficulties of getting the Commodity Credit Corporation's buying plan under way as more and more gins and compresses imposed embargoes on further handling of the staple.

The fiftieth anniversary of the founding of Town Hall on Nov. 16, 1894, will be marked by a series of events beginning on Wednesday at 11 A.M. with the opening of the lecture program. Lieut. John Mason Brown, USNR, former drama critic, will discuss "What We Should Have Learned From the War."

The New York Alumnae Club of Sarah Lawrence College has taken over the performance of "A Bell for Adano," with Fredric March and Margo, on the evening of Dec. 18. The proceeds will benefit the Constance Warren Scholarship Fund, named for Miss Warren, who is retiring after fifteen years as president of the college.

The four-story business building at 1435 Broadway, adjoining the northwest corner of Fortieth Street, in the Times Square area, has been sold by the Mutual Life Insurance Company to Jerome Greene, operator, for cash over a mortgage of $52,000.

Nine areas in New Jersey have been given permission to remodel or convert existing buildings to ease the apartment shortage, Charles S. Ascher, regional representative of the Administrator of the National Housing Agency, announced yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

In a country such as ours, where freedom of the press exists, no Administration can be held responsible for the editorial views expressed by the nation's newspapers. In a land like Russia, however, where freedom of the press is not present, the views expressed are the "party line," and even though mistakes happen in such countries and opinion is at times out of line, it remains in a sense official until corrected.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 5 (AP) -- American Liberator bombers on Thursday attacked nine transports and two destroyers at Chichi Island and one large transport at Haha Island, all in the Bonin group some 600 reties southeast of Tokyo, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.

Asserting that if any one of the women who signed a recent appeal for the re-election of President Roosevelt know what his foreign policy really is she must be a crystal-gazer, a group of women in politics, serve clubs, social work and education endorsed Governor Dewey in a statement issued yesterday through the Republican State Committee.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Monday, Nov. 6 -- Battle veterans of the American Twenty-fourth Division yesterday captured Pinamopoan, strategic town on Leyte Island's northwest coast, and immediately turned southward toward the besieged Ormoc sector, which American long-range artillery began shelling.

New York City school teachers gave 62,339 hours of free instruction in forty-eight different courses to men and women in the armed forces in the last year, according to the annual report of the Teachers Voluntary Service Organization, made public yesterday.

A demand for the removal of Daniel P. Woolley, Regional Administrator of the Office of Price Administration for this area, has been made by the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee, which disclosed here yesterday that last Saturday it had addressed a letter to Chester A. Bowles, OPA Administrator, requesting the ouster.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Redskins beat off a last-minute rally by the Cleveland Rams today to triumph, 14 -- 10, before a crowd of 35,540.

SALONIKA, Greece, Nov. 5 -- The American institution in Salonika, a farm school on the outskirts of this city, was used as a Luftwaffe headquarters during most of the German occupation. Here, too, was situated the telephone central office serving German establishments everywhere in the Balkan areas.

Mr. Dewey has chosen to end his campaign on a note that does not do him credit. He accuses Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau of prolonging the war needlessly at the cost of American lives. He says that the publication of reports of Mr. Morgenthau's plan to de-industrialize Germany "was just what the Nazi propagandists needed."

The first voter will have no difficulty casting his ballot tomorrow if he follows a few simple instructions with regard to recording his choice on the voting machine, which is in use everywhere in New York City.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Most of the smaller European nations would back the proposal of Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. for depriving Germany of her industrial and military potentials after the war, the Foreign Policy Association reported today.

KWEILIN, China, Oct. 28 (Delayed) (AP) -- The principal advanced base for United States air power in the Orient blew up tonight in a series of mighty explosions, touched off by Americans pulling out of Kweilin ahead of the on coming Japanese.

David Smith, 20-year-old pianist from Portland, Ore., made his New York debut last night in Town Hall before a large audience which included prominent musicians. From the point of view of technical pianism, the young artist lived up to the reports of his prowess.

ALBANY, Nov. 5 -- Health conditions in the State for the first nine months of this year indicated that the civilian population health has not deteriorated, but in some respects has even been bettered, according to figures released by the State Department of Health today.

HOLYOKE, Mass., Nov. 5 (U.P.) -- The radio program, Truth or Consequences, told a studio guest last night that a buried $1,000 bonanza was his for the digging in Holyoke, but 1,500 Holyoke residents, armed with everything from spoons to a bulldozer, beat him to the spot.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 5 -- John Carroll and Ruth Hussey have been borrowed from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer by Andrew Stone for the leads in the producer's United Artists picture, "Bedside Manner." The film based on a magazine story by Robert Garson about a Woman physician in a small town, will be Carroll's first picture since his discharge from the Army.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Nov. 6 -- Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff's accusations of undemocratic practices and pro-Fascist sympathies against the Swiss nation have aroused a storm of indignation throughout the country, both in the press and among the public.
CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- The Latin-American countries participating in the International Civil Air Conference organized today as a group and adopted a policy.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 5 -- World hopes for a settled and lasting peace rest upon the continued leadership of President Roosevelt, former Attorney General Homer S. Cummings declared here tonight in urging re-election of the President and the entire Democratic ticket in this State.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 175:

LONDON, Nov. 5 (Reuter) -- O.M. Green, a leading interpreter of the war in China, defended Generalissimo Chiang in The Sunday Observer, describing him as a "desperately tired" man but "supremely a statesman and a patriot."

Field Marshal Sir John Dill's fame shone brightest in Britain's darkest hour. When the British were driven out of France it was Winston Churchill who promised that Englishmen would fight "on the beaches, on the landing grounds, in the fields, in the streets, in the hills," but it was Sir John who organized the force to do so.

From 4,000 to 5,000 names of registered voters have been placed on official challenge lists as a result of the three-phase inquiry into illegal registration conducted by William B. Herlands, Special Assistant Attorney General, it was disclosed yesterday when Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein made public a second interim report of his Election Frauds Bureau.

Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, announced yesterday completion of negotiations on an agreement to be signed by thirty-eight Atlantic and Gulf coast steamship companies and two unions of merchant marine licensed officers.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Detroit Lions, paced by Frankie Sinkwich, Bob Westfall and Art Van Tone, won their second National Football League contest today, defeating the Pittsburgh Steeler-Chicago Cardinal combination, 27 -- 6.

A vote for either the Democratic or Republican candidate for President will be defeatist and a confession of failure on the home front, Brig. Gen. Herbert C. Holdridge, retired, said yesterday in a statement released by the Independent Committee for Norman Thomas and Darlington Hoopes, Socialist candidates for President and Vice President.
As a result of pronounced price increases of farm products and foodstuffs the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices (1926=100) rose 0.2 per cent to a new all-time high of 113.8.

DETROIT, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Murph Chamberlain's easy shot that slid past Goalie Connie Dion with only a minute and seven seconds left to play gave Montreal a 3-to-2 National Hockey League triumph over the Red Wings tonight before a crowd of 13,379.
The Philadelphia Americans, champions of the American Soccer League, came to Starlight Park yesterday and set back the hitherto undefeated Brookhattans in the seventh round of the series, 3 to 1.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Tokyo radio said that "enemy planes" in unspecified numbers and of unnamed design scouted over the eastern sea coast of the main Japanese home island of Honshu today.

The American Field Service, volunteer ambulance corps whose members have served wherever British and French troops have fought in this war, was cited yesterday by the British and French Governments during the first public ceremony to honor the AFS in its thirty-year history.

When I took my degree in medicine from Bellevue Hospital Medical College in 1887 the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association of New York City was only eight years old. That infant organization became the United Hospital Fund of New York on Jan. 10, 1916 and by that time I was established as a practicing surgeon in this city.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- With American cooperation after negotiation with the local German military command, the French Red Cross today completed the evacuation of nearly 14,000 civilians from the St. Nazaire pocket on the Atlantic coast.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull have been invited by the Provisional Government of France to pay an official visit to Paris.

SATURDAY was Vindication Day for the vast army of experts and near-experts. Every last one of them had been so awed by Navy's overwhelming strength in pre-season surveys that none ever mentioned the midshipman powerhouse unless he spoke in superlatives. But the boys were a trifle red-faced for the first month as the middies floundered and fell.

Solemn vespers and benediction in memory of New York policemen and American service men who have died were held yesterday afternoon in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presided at the ceremony.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, France, Nov. 5 -- Soldiers of four Allied armies drove the Germans back beyond the Meuse (Maas) River today, and tonight, save for a few isolated units, some of whom are eager to surrender, the Allies command a fifty-mile front along the Meuse from 's Hertogenbosch to the North Sea.

LONDON, NOV. 5 -- Riding through what one flier described as a "hell" of flak, more than 1,200 heavy bombers of the United States Eighth Air Force blasted the great war factories and railway yards of Ludwigshafen, Frankfort on the Main and Karlsruhe today in the aerial offensive that has seen nearly 5,000 Allied bombers and 3,000 fighters over Germany during the weekend.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast by the Free Yugoslav radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- The French plan for the Rhineland and the Ruhr is military occupation to be followed by international ownership and control of the industries in that key coal, steel and chemical producing region, it was explained authoritatively here today.
HANFORD, Calif., Nov. 5 (AP) -- The crash of a Transcontinental and Western Air passenger plane, in which twenty-four persons were killed here last night, remained unexplained today.

There was continued tightening up in the wholesale markets last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices, with emphasis on staple merchandise. Buyers, it was pointed out, are anxious to get additional coverage on their requirements, both seasonal and for spring.

The Non-Partisan Citizens Committee for the Election of Supreme Court Justice George Frankenthaler called attention yesterday to what it termed an "inadvertent" error by Mayor La Guardia who, it understood, said in his weekly broadcast that the judicial candidates of the American Labor and Liberal parties were the same.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 -- Tokyo radio reported tonight that Japanese aircraft, attacking two separate American task forces east of the Philippines Saturday, sank one carrier and damaged two. The broadcast, heard by NBC, was unconfirmed from Allied sources.

LONDON, Nov. 5 (Reuter) -- Election fever has gripped Britain, and the majority of Britons these days seem more interested in the outcome of the American election than in the progress of the Allied armies.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES in Germany, Nov. 5 -- German troops have been ordered to hold on to the village of Schmidt, at the entrance to the Cologne plain, at all costs. Accordingly they fought again today with stubbornness and ferocity at most points on this cramped and bloody field.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (U.P.) -- The Right Rev. Mgr. Patrick J. McCormick, rector of Catholic University, warned today that world peace cannot be achieved "in a day" and said that solution of world problems requires a "happy combination of idealism and realism."

The Jacques Gordon String Quartet and three assisting artists of high rank inaugurated the ninth season of the late-afternoon concerts of chamber music given by the New Friends of Music yesterday in Town Hall. The program was fortunately arranged.
An hour before game time Saturday the Navy and Notre Dame coaches were gathered together near the dressing rooms in the Baltimore Municipal Stadium.

Perhaps in the wonderful, plastic, post-war world when sections of houses are skidding off the assembly lines there will come a time when house and foundation are so closely welded that no cold, searching drafts can work through to plague ankles and knees. But until that time country houses in the northern half of the nation will continue to be banked.

Anyone with a fondness for French and Italian bread will find a trip to the establishment of the Zampieri Brothers at 17 Cornelia Street (between Fourth and Bleecker Streets) well worth while. The unpretentious shop -- actually a small retail outlet of a wholesale concern -- is as stark as can be except for the counter full of rolls and bread, which are among the best of their kind to be found in the city.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Communique 211:

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 5 -- Chalking up his fifth best-in-show award, the fawn boxer, Ch. Warlord of Mazelaine, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Kettles Jr. of Glen Head and shown by Walter C. Foster, took the final honors in the annual fixture of the Union County Kennel Club today.

The guiding principles embodied in Pope Leo's encyclical on the condition of the working class, promulgated in 1891, as against "the false teachings of old-order capitalism and Marxiam socialism," were stressed yesterday by the Rev. William J. Kelley, chairman of the New York State Labor Relations Board.
Seven films, including importations from France and Mexico, are on the list of new attractions arriving this week in first-run theatres. The programs follow:

The Office of War Information announced here yesterday that two of its most powerful East Coast transmitters would be turned over tomorrow to the armed forces radio service to broadcast election returns to Europe for four hours, beginning at 9 P.M.
Beginning with the United Hunts Racing today, there will be a victory Meet at Belmont Park with seven named for the $15,000 added Temple Gwathmey Steeplechase Handicap.

Unwilling to become entangled in another censorship controversy, one which Lee Shubert fears might ultimately bring about the revocation of his license on the Cort Theatre, which he controls, Mr. Shubert told us yesterday he would not permit "Trio," which deals with Lesbianism, to open at his house on Wednesday, as advertised, unless License Commissioner Paul Moss gives the play a clean bill of-health.

Scoring in three periods, Cardinal Hayes vanquished Malden Catholic of Massachusetts, 19 to 7, yesterday on the winner's field. Soon after the opening kick-off George Hoolihan recovered a fumble and Frank Reynolds ripped off left tackle for 28 yards and the tally.

A syndicate headed by David Vogel, apartment house builder, has purchased a plot, 100 by 110 feet, at the southeast corner of Ocean Avenue and Avenue O, in Brooklyn, for improvement with a six-story apartment house. The site was a holding of the Mary G. Leggett Estate, which owned it for many years.

Reflecting the present unfavorable market situation and limited early buying interest, the new fur season will be slow in getting started, and opening prices on many furs will range substantially under a year ago, the United Fur Brokers, 258 West Twenty-ninth Street, predicted yesterday.

" Buy for Keeps" would be a good slogan for the Sixth War Loan drive to get under way officially on Nov. 20. Perhaps some courageous units among the innumerable groups elaborately organized to put this $14,000,000,000 drive "over the top" will adopt such a motto.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Rye continues to be the speculative favorite in the grain markets, but the volume of business last week on the Chicago Board of Trade was smaller than it had been recently, due in part to increased interest in corn.

While synthetic elastic is still not plentiful, the main reason why in the coming months there will be fewer foundation garments than ever before in the city's stores is an acute shortage of cotton for civilian uses, spokesmen for the corset industry said yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Britain must export $4,500,000,000 worth of goods annually after the war to balance her accounts on the basis of pre-war trade without making any allowance for the increased living standards at which she aims under proposed social security, education, health and other schemes, Sir Stafford Cripps, Miniister of Aircraft Production, said today.

The church must maintain and extend a broad base at home and must carry its message to the ends of the earth, the Rev. Dr. Samuel M. Shoemaker declared yesterday in his sermon in Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.

ALBANY, Nov. 5 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, Republican Presidential nominee, who returned this afternoon from New York City, will broadcast from the Executive Mansion tomorrow night over four radio networks between 11 and 11:15 o'clock, it was announced today.

ABOARD A UNITED STATES CARRIER, With the Third Fleet, Oct. 30 (Delayed) (AP) -- Eight American pilots, who unhesitatingly attacked a flight of sixty to seventy-five Japanese planes, saved two crippled American warships during the early October battle off Formosa and routed the entire enemy formation after shooting down twenty-six planes.

HOWARD SPRING has been compared so often to Dickens and other Victorian novelists that he has evidently decided to give his new book a typically Victorian title. If Charles Reade called one of his novels "Hard Cash" and Charles Dickens one of his "Hard Times," why shouldn't Howard Spring call one of his "Hard Facts"*? There being no reason why

Opening a home safety week program, members of the Bureau of Health Education of the city Health Department will give home accident prevention information today to passers-by from the Civilian Defense Volunteer Information Center in Pershing Square.

To enable the numerous changes which the war has brought in costs, products and technique to be worked into the post-war price structure more easily, the committee on International Economic Policy urged yesterday selective rather than general price control during the post-war readjustment period.

The arrest by the Soviet authorities of three Polish Cabinet members and a former Polish Under-Secretary of State was protested in a letter to Secretary of State Hull sent yesterday by the National Committee of Americans of Polish Descent.

In a speech delivered in Minneapolis on April 9, 1943, L. Welch Pogue, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, indicated the policy which this country would probably follow in dealing with international aviation. At the Chicago Conference, Adolf A. Berle Jr. followed much the same line of thought. We are to relinquish none of our sovereign rights in the air above us.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- The after-harvest movement of corn got under way last week, primary receipts exceeding 1,000,000 bushels daily, and it is expected that with favorable weather conditions there will be a gradual enlargement as farmers increase field work.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Butler Brothers, national distributors of general merchandise, announced today that shareholders will be asked to authorize a program to refinance the company's preferred stock, provide additional capital for post-war growth, and raise the par value of the common stock from $10 to $15 a share.

Though the week-end performances of the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House and the Ballet International at the International Theatre offered no novelties, they made it possible for those who have been dividing their attention perforce between the multifarious activities of an intensive dance season to catch up on their home work, so to speak.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The United States should adopt a policy of compulsory universal training for young men in peacetime, member organizations of the United States Chamber of Commerce have voted by "substantial majorities," the chamber announced today.

WITH AMERICAN TROOPS, East of Bruyeres, France, Oct. 31 (Delayed) (AP) -- Trapped behind German lines in the Vosges foothills for more than a week, 270 American infantrymen of the Seventh Army were rescued today by other doughboys who fought their way through the German encirclement ring.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The welfare of the country demands a permanent and comprehensive system of production, credit for farmers to supplement the advances by commercial banks and other lending agencies, the Brookings Institution declared today.

UNITED STATES NINTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, France, Nov. 5 (AP) -- American Marauders and Havocs bombed a big ordnance depot at Homburg today and crews experienced a unique sensation, caused probably by unusual atmospheric conditions but possibly, according to the fliers, by some new German secret weapon.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 5 (UP) -- Secretary Harold L. Ickes asserted tonight that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, Republican Presidential candidate, was engaged in a campaign of "incitation to disunity," which would make international arrangements for world peace "impossible" if he were elected President.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- The convention of the Spanish National Union, which has pledged itself to restore liberty to Spain, ended today in Toulouse, headquarters of the Spanish Liberation Movement in France.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Paul V. McNutt, War Manpower Commission Chairman, said today it is of the utmost importance "that we make the most effective utilization possible of our scientific and professional groups in the reconversion period."

While total advertising in New York City newspapers dropped 2.2 per cent in October compared with last year, financial advertising showed a 35.5 per cent rise, it was revealed by a compilation yesterday of Media Records figures. Last month total advertising reached 9,823,457 lines, while financial's figure was 256,782 lines.

Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, in a message to The Associated Press, his first statement for publication on the withdrawal of Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell from the China-Burma-India theatre, said yesterday that the "prospects of effective and close Chinese-American military, political and economic cooperation are now excellent."
PARIS, Nov. 5 -- The Minister of Supplies, Paul Giaccobi, confirmed today that the material situation of France was improving slowly but steadily.
For the second straight week Mount St. Michael was involved in a tie, battling undefeated Iona Prep of New Rochelle to a 13-to-13 standstill yesterday on the Mount's field.

The holding of a national election in the midst of war is evidence of the dignity of American citizenship and the strength of our political institutions, derived from the basic faith in the sovereignty of God, declared the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman in his sermon yesterday in Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

Many young women will be presented to society at dinner parties in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton on Dec. 9 before the Grosvenor Debutante Ball to be held at the hotel. The Misses Lisa Leighton, Virginia Clark and Patsy Cromwell, co-chairmen, are assembling a debutante committee to assist with plans for the event, an annual benefit for the Grosvenor Neighborhood House.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that the north tube of the Lincoln Tunnel would be opened to traffic on Feb. 1, 1945, for westbound vehicles to New Jersey. This will provide four lanes under the Hudson River, as on the same date the south tube, which now carries both eastbound and westbound traffic, will be converted into a one-way, two-lane eastbound roadway from New Jersey to New York.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears, sparked again by Ensign Sid Luckman of the Maritime Service, broke up the Green Bay Irv Comp-Don Hutson pass combination to give the Packers their first National Football League defeat today, 21--0, before 45,553 fans.

Russell W. Davenport, friend and supporter of the late Wendell L. Willkie, last night added "recklessness" to the reasons why, though he always has had a preference for the Republican party, he would not support Governor Dewey, Republican nominee for President, and would vote for President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The National Association of Real Estate Boards and the National Association of Home Builders of the United States tonight made public a joint letter they have written to John B. Blandford Jr., Administrator of the National Housing Agency, asking that he assign to the private home building industry all priorities for the construction of houses under the recently authorized program for resumption of home building.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Bronze Star Medal has been awarded to the following New York State members of infantry units: Col. William J. Mullen Jr., 448 Sixth St., Brooklyn; Major William F. McCahill, 765 Riverside Dr., New York; Capts. James L. Ammon, 80 Colfax Rd., Buffalo; Donald M. Neuman, 37 Clinton Pl., Mount Vernon; Maurice M. Scheibner, 21-27 24th St., Astoria; First Lieuts. As you point out today in reply to Mr. Moses, Mr. Dewey is quite as committed by his own words as is the President to a system of prevention of aggression which will function under the authority of the Executive without the necessity of referring back to Congress for authority every time a decision has to be made.

The arrival in Italy of a huge private relief shipment, to supplement United States Army allotments for civilians, was announced yesterday by Justice Juvenal Marchisio, president of American Relief for Italy, Inc. The organization, a member of the National War Fund, is the only non-government or non-military agency certified by the War Relief Control Board to send supplies to liberated Italy.

When John Citizen goes to the polls tomorrow to help in determining the political course of the nation for the next four years he will have more company than he may suspect. The line of voters ahead of him may be long, and the line behind him too.

Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for the Senate, yesterday afternoon accused the New Deal Administration of creating more disunity in the United States than any other major political unit. Addressing a Harlem audience, he charged that the Roosevelt Administration was not a real friend of the Negro citizen.

A dispute over policy between the Staten Island office of the rent control division of the Office of Price Administration and the New York area office concerning an increase in rentals allowed to a housing project on Manor Road off Victory Boulevard, West Brighton, S.I., has resulted in the resignation of one of the local officials and the transfer of another to the New York office, it became known yesterday.

BOSTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- "Our first responsibility is to re-establish understanding and contentment at home so we can be organized to assume a position of world leadership," Gov. Walter E. Edge of New Jersey asserted tonight. "With Dewey and Bricker we will have unanimity of thought and action."

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- With only last minute talks scheduled for tomorrow to wind up the shortest of his four Presidential campaigns, President Roosevelt rested today at his family home here after his one-day tour of New England yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 5 (Reuters) -- Far-reaching changes may occur in Britain's political life after the war -- and women will be behind them.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 4 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Political tension appeared today to be approaching a climax over Russia's demand for oil concessions and political quarters predicted that Premier Said might resign within a few days. Representatives of Russia here, who include Vice Foreign Commissar Sergel I. Kavtaradze, have severed contact with Mr. Said's Government.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (U.P.) -- Tonight, on the first anniversary of the passage of the now historic Connally Peace Resolution, Sen. Tom Connally, Democrat of Texas, called for "big public sentiment" to spur Congress toward a realization of the peace goal.

Leon Kushner, New York pianist, was heard in recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The chief offerings on the program were the Beethoven sonata, Op. 110, Mendelssohn's "Variations Serieuses" and Ravel's "Gaspard de la Nuit."

Six prominent liberals joined yesterday in endorsing Assemblyman MacNeil Mitchell, Republican candidate for re-election in the First Assemmbly District, the Non-Partisan Citizens Committee supporting him announced yesterday.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Nov. 5 -- The Bainbridge powerhouse rolled along to its thirteenth consecutive victory today as it overwhelmed an alert but overpowered North Carolina Pre-Flight eleven, 49 to 20, before a crowd of 22,000.

MOSCOW, Nov. 5 -- The newspaper Izvestia said today that President Roosevelt's re-election was assured and declared that there were rumors "current in some United States journalistic circles" that the Republicans, in a desperate effort to win votes, were preparing to carry out at the final hour "an attempt on Dewey," the responsibility for which would be laid to American Communists.

Beyond the choice that will confront the American electorate on Tuesday is the even greater choice for the world that already is being formulated and must be acted upon when victory is achieved, the Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers declared in his sermon yesterday at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (U.P.) -- The Supreme Court, in its first formal opinion day this year, has up for decision tomorrow a case having a relationship to Tuesday's national elections -- especially for candidates who wind up on the losing side.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- The wheat market has failed to show a definite trend for several weeks and fluctuations last week were largely a reflection of the action of other grains, with corn coming to the fore as a factor in influencing professional buying or selling of wheat futures.

There are no constitutional amendments or propositions to be voted on tomorrow. The machines will show only a list of candidates for public office -- Federal, State and Judicial. We summarize here the recommendations which this newspaper has made to its readers.

One thousand members of the Catholic War Veterans and their women's auxiliary from Eastern Seaboard States were asked yesterday by the Rev. Ignatius Smith of the Catholic University of America to follow the leadership of "the best-informed statesman in the world, Pope Pius XII," in asking for "a peace without pacifism based on a revision of our attitude toward social facts that are basic, and individual living that is vital."

A PIONEER FIGHTER GROUP HEADQUARTERS, In France, Nov. 4 (Delayed) -- In its first ten months of combat, this group of Mustang pilots, known as the "hottest bunch in the European theatre," has run up a formidable score against the best fighter opposition that the Germans have been able to offer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- A complaint charging N. Erlanger, Blumgart Co., Inc., 354 Fourth Avenue, New York City, large converters and distributors of acetate rayon fabrics, with violation of those sections of the Robinson-Patman act which prohibit the payment of allowances and the furnishing of services to favored customers unless available to other customers on proportionately equal terms, it was announced today by the Federal Trade Commission.

For nineteen hours yesterday a steady stream of Negroes filled and refilled the Holy Baptist Church in Brooklyn, fasting and praying that "God's will be done at the polls" tomorrow with the re-election of President Roosevelt and Senator Robert F. Wagner.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (U.P.) -- The Office of Price Administration announced tonight upward revisions of ceiling prices of crude oil produced by thirty-three pools in Louisiana, Kansas and Texas.

Fifty million American citizens, casting their secret ballots in a nation-wide poll in the midst of a world war and abiding by the decision of the majority, will provide inspiration for the entire world and especially for those peoples who for many years have not had the voting privilege, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UP) -- Twentieth Air Force Communique 201.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 5 (AP) -A United States Army Forces in China communique:

Perhaps in view of what amounted to an impending double holiday, perhaps because of traditions surrounding financial markets on the eve of a Presidential vote, last week was a period of inactivity. Prices were firm but little changed.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 6 -- Moscow announced last night that Russian troops, hurling back enemy counter-attacks, had driven to within four and one-half miles southeast of Budapest by capturing the suburban town of Andrassy in a three-mile advance in twenty-four hours.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Nov. 5 -- The national steel ingot rate dropped last week one and one-half points to 94.5 per cent of rated capacity. The decline was due, according to trade reports, to strikes, repairs and also to the tendency for many mills to adjust their operating rates to incoming orders.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Cirminello quadruplets, born Wednesday at Lying-In Hospital, are "doing nicely," the hospital reported today.

ALBANY, Nov. 5 -- The State War Ballot Commission reported today that it had received 407,440 completed war ballots, of which 970 arrived at the commission offices today. The deadlines for acceptance of such ballots is noon tomorrow.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- The British Admiralty announced today that casualties and losses in landing craft were "severe" during the assault on Westkapelle last Wednesday. Twenty of twenty-five of the ships of an inshore support squadron, all of them landing craft of one type or another, were sunk or seriously damaged by heavy German coastal guns.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Emil Hurja, political analyst who predicted the Roosevelt victories of 1932 and 1936 and who furnished a forecast in the 1940 giving the victory in that campaign to Wendell Willkie, today said that Thomas E. Dewey should be elected next Tuesday by a popular majority of 2,000,000 votes, and an electoral vote of 364 to President Roosevelt's 167.

Up to 900 additional women volunteers are needed immediately in ninety workshops of the American Women's Voluntary Services to make children's garments for overseas relief, Mrs. Gorham Godwin of the Greater New York AWVS announced yesterday.

Bishop William T. Manning officiated yesterday afternoon at a service honoring the merchant seamen of the Allied Nations and paid tribute to the "courageous crews who are the very life-line of the combat forces." Four thousand persons, including 1,000 United States Merchant Marine cadets, attended the services at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- The economist's index of British commodity prices based 1927 as 100 was 117.9 on Oct. 24, unchanged from a fortnight before, comparing with 113.6 a year ago and 70 at the end of 1939.

Adding two points after play in the eleventh and twelfth rounds of the third annual tournament for the national amateur championpionship sponsored by the United States Chess Federation. Edward S. Jackson Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., yesterday moved up into the lead with a score of 8 -- 1 at the rooms of the Marshall Chess Club.

An analysis of the second battle of the Philippine Sea, fought two weeks ago, shows that the Japanese probably still have a fleet of two to seven combat aircraft carriers and seven to ten battleships.

ROME, Nov. 5 (U.P.) -- A new Italian army equipped with modern weapons by the United States and Britain will soon go into action in Italy beside the Fifth and Eighth Armies, it was announced officially today as the comparative lull continued on the fighting fronts despite a break in the rainy weather.

To the surprise of absolutely no one, the Giants beat the Boston Yanks, 31 to 0, yesterday at the Polo Grounds, using the National Football League's newcomers as stepping stones to keep themselves within reach of both the Eagles and Redskins, who are battling for first place in the Eastern Division.

Three of the seven books named as November selections of The Book Clinic of the American Institute of Graphic Arts are publications of the Heritage Press: Mark Twain's "Life on the Mississippi," Stephen Crane's "The Red Badge of Courage" and Dante's "The Divine Comedy."

LONDON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Lord Robert Vansittart, who advocates a "hard" peace for Germany, said today in an interview there would be no peace conference seats for neutral nations, not even those whose neutrality was beyond question.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Nov. 5 -- For the second day a Chesapeake Bay dog carried off the chief trophy in the annual meeting of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club, which was concluded this afternoon on the grounds of the Timber Point Club.
LONDON, Nov. 5 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

DETROIT, Nov. 5 -- The Detroit-Toledo strike which affected forty-nine plants and made 10,000 key workers idle was called off today by Matthew Smith, national secretary of the Mechanics Educational Society of America.

The domestic cotton futures market was rather dull last week, with prices irregular. At the close of the market on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net changes ranging from a decline of twenty points to an advance of eleven points.

OTTAWA, Nov. 5 -- Making his first authoritative public statement on the disputed Canadian reinforcement position, Gen. Andrew G.L. McNaughton, newly appointed Minister of Defense, said at Arnprior today:

General reductions of tariff and trade barriers as a necessary step in again achieving a free international exchange of goods after the war were advocated yesterday by Dr. Hans Sulzer, head of the Swiss delegation to the International Business Conference, which will open on Nov. 10 at Rye, N.Y.

General reductions of tariff and trade barriers as a necessary step in again achieving a free international exchange of goods after the war were advocated yesterday by Dr. Hans Sulzer, head of the Swiss delegation to the International Business Conference, which will open on Nov. 10 at Rye, N.Y.

Those may be sleigh bells you heard after all, for Santa Claus is coming to town somewhat early this year. It is all part of the "Shop for Christmas in November" program being sponsored by the Retail Dry Goods Association, this pre-Thanksgiving appearance of the good Saint Nick at a number of the city's department stores.

CAIRO, Nov. 6 (U.P.) -- A mob stripped and almost lynched the assassins as they tried to flee shortly after the attack on Lord Moyne today. The crowd pounced on the wounded assassin, beating him and tearing the clothes from his back. Farther down the street another mob caught the second assailant, a dark-haired young man, and was threatening to lynch him when police arrived.

TOLEDO, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Possession and operation of eight Toledo war plants by the War Department ceased tonight following the end of a strike which had affected twenty-five Toledo concerns and a score more in the Detroit area.

The practice of allowing a larger advertising credit to well-known retail stores was explained yesterday by spokesmen of the rayon weaving industry as one which is in keeping with sound advertising principles. In discussing Federal Trade Commission action against violations of the Robinson-Patman act, it was pointed out that the factor of prestige always was uppermost in the mind of a space buyer in making advertising appropriations.

The Maria Moors Cabot Medal for distinguished achievement in advancing international friendship in the Western Hemisphere has been awarded to three Latin-American editors, Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Graduate School of Journalism of Columbia University announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Supreme Court, by an 8-0 vote, reversed today the refusal of the Court of Claims to consider a damage suit in compliance with a special Congressional act. The Court of Claims had protested that the act encroached upon its judicial rights.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 6 -- Two gunmen shot and fatally wounded Lord Moyne, British Resident Minister in the Middle East, and killed his chauffeur today as the diplomat alighted from his automobile at his residence.
When our men-of-war put into New York Harbor, the Ships Service Committee is on the job to provide a reception and planned entertainment for blue-jackets and officers.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Premier Stalin, naming Japan and Germany as typical aggressors, urged tonight the creation of a special post-war armed organization of peace-loving nations empowered to act immediately "to avert or suppress aggression."

Army plays Notre Dame at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday and three-quarters of a million tickets could have been sold for the game, but nothing seems to matter much in intercollegiate football until Army and Navy get together at Annapolis on Dec. 2 before ten or twelve thousand indigenous customers.

With President Roosevelt touring Dutchess and adjoining counties and making a final radio appeal from his home in Hyde Park, according to his custom, and with Governor Dewey broadcasting a speech from the Executive Mansion at Albany, the 1944 Presidential campaign drew to a close last night.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Today's hog market continued the improvement started late last week after the sharpest break of the season. Weights under 270 pounds reached a top of $14.40 in a fairly active trade that cleared the supply of 12,000 salables.

Parents and others interested in the New York City public schools have the opportunity this week of visiting the classrooms and seeing education in operation. By action of the Superintendent of Schools, this week has been designated as "Open School Week." Through Friday the "Welcome" sign will be over the door of every school building in the city.

The Ohio Oil Company and its subsidiaries showed a net profit in the first nine months of this year totaling $11,962,277 after all charges, including taxes, depreciation, depletion and cancellation of leases, the report disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Britain, Russia and the United States have opened conversations with Turkey on the future of the Dardanelles, narrow waterway linking the Black and Mediterranean Seas, a usually reliable source said today.

An explosion, caused by illuminating gas touched off under circumstances that detectives were still investigating early today, led to the discovery of the body of Mrs. Erika de Balogh, 31 years old, just before 9 o'clock last night in her wrecked apartment at 405 East Fifty-fourth Street.

VAALS, the Netherlands, Nov. 6 -- In a convent in this southeastern Netherlands town within sight of the Siegfried Line, a young English woman spent more than four years of the war as a virtual guest of the Wehrmacht while studying art and music.

Sausage is as much a part of the fall season as mince pie, pumpkin and steamed puddings. This year it happens to be one of the few meats available in any butcher shop at any time. It is delicious when sauteed for breakfast, as what good cook does not know, and it also combines well with other things such as oysters, corn and rice.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 176:

Importers and the consuming industries will protest an agreement arrived at between the United States and Great Britain whereby cattle hides will be furnished to four European countries during the next ninety days, it was learned yesterday. This agreement, to become operative through the Combined Raw Materials Board, covers shipments of hides to France, Belgium, Holland and Norway on a 3 1/2-to-1 basis, with this country furnishing the higher figure.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday that he would ask the Board of Estimate on Thursday to advance his project for the reclamation of large areas in downtown Brooklyn, in connection with the proposed civic center in that borough.

Trade covering and a dwindling volume of hedges brought about yesterday a steadier tone to the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange, and final prices were 8 to 12 points net higher than Saturday's close.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- Following the example of almost every organization in France the Socialist party is preparing its purge, it was revealed today preliminary to the opening of the party's convention here Friday.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically from Sofia and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:...

Dipping into his extensive library of folk-lore, J.J. Shubert has selected "Robin Hood" as an appropriate item for R.H. Burnside to revive. At 8:30 this evening the comic opera by Reginald de Koven (music) and Harry B. Smith (book and lyrics), last seen here a dozen years ago, will relight the Adelphi, Fifty-fourth Street East of Seventh Avenue.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Brooklyn College will rule a distinct favorite to repeat an early season victory over City College when the two interborough rivals take the field at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon at Brooklyn College Stadium. The underdog Beavers hold a 9-to-5 edge in the series, with one contest ending in a tie.
LONDON, Nov. 6 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Tuesday, Nov. 7 -- Maj. Gen. Franklin C. Sibert's Tenth Corps continued yesterday to press forward into the last Japanese foothold on Leyte, the narrow coastal strip that runs from Carigara Bay in the north to Ormoc. Advance elements of the Twenty-fourth Division pushed four miles southward along the Pinamopoan-Ormoc highway running through a mountain pass.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- The invitation to President Roosevelt to visit France was decided on at the same time that Prime Minister Churchill was asked, official circles said today. Secretary of State Cordell Hull and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden were invited at the same time.

TRIPOLIS, Greece, Nov. 4 (Delayed) -- Such motor vehicles as one sees traveling over the main thoroughfares throughout the Peloponnesus, with the exception of British Army transport and an occasional Red Cross truck, belong to the Elas.

Several hundred public schools here have planned for this week consumer education classroom exhibits illustrating the dangers of post-war inflation, it was disclosed yesterday by Dr. Edward Reich, who heads consumer education at the Board of Education.

Whether the Federal Housing Administration should exert greater control over the design and planning of homes when it resumes the financing of private home building after the war is the subject of a symposium in the latest issue of "Tomorrow's Town," just released by the National Committee on Housing, Inc.

The paradox of the democratic process is that by election morning, and probably much sooner, the nation knows whom it is going to vote for, and yet it doesn't know. The knowledge is down in the national subconsciousness until that psychoanalytical instrument, the ballot box or voting machine, brings it to the surface.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 6 -- A 21-year-old Jewish youth who arrived here today told of outsmarting the Gestapo for four years until he finally reached safety in Sweden.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 6 -- The Yonkers Common Council voted tonight to suspend City Manager William A. Walsh as the first step in an attempt to remove him from office. Under the law he has fifteen days to demand a public hearing before any further action can be taken.
