Plans for a six-story apartment building on the Grand Concourse at the northwest corner of 150th Street, the Bronx, were filed yesterday with the Bronx office of the Department of Housing and Buildings. The cost is estimated at $140,000. The 212 West Twenty-second Street Corporation, of 825 Gerard Avenue, the Bronx, is listed as the owner.
Maximilian's fur showing yesterday at the St. Regis presented new ways of manipulating furs as well as new interpretations of accepted fur styles.

The outlook for the New York Rangers hockey six underwent a slight stimulus yesterday when Manager Lester Patrick announced that Phil Watson, for ten years sparkplug of the Blueshirts, has become available to the club and will be seen in action Thursday night in the opening game of the local professional season at Madison Square Garden when the Rangers tackle the Toronto Maple Leafs.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Communique 212:

Brief ceremonies at the headquarters of the Third Naval District yesterday marked the departure of Rear Admiral William R. Munroe, commander of the district since April 1, for a command at sea. He was succeeded by Rear Admiral Monroe Kelly, who assumed the command in addition to that of the Navy Yard.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leytc, Tuesday, 2ov. 7 (AP) -- comuiqltd :

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Chinese troops have halted a Japanese drive forty-five miles north of Liuchow, Kwangsi Province rail center and site of the last United States air base in eastern China, the High Command announced tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 -- The proposed preferred stock retirement plan of the United Corporation was defended today in oral argument before the Securities and Exchange Commission by Richard J. Smith, counsel to the holding company, as the "best step that could be taken at this time."

Five law enforcement agencies are cooperating in New York City today to prevent any fraudulent voting and to block any attempts to intimidate qualified voters into staying away from the polls. About 3,200,000 persons, more than half of them women, are expected to record their votes at the city's 3,700 polling places between the opening of the polls at 6 A.M. and the closing at 9 P.M.

WASHINGTON Nov. 6 -- The War Production Board announced today that it would continue and extend restrictions on the delivery and use of worsted yarns in an effort to assure an adequate supply of worsted fabric for Army and other military needs.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission shortened today from ten to seven days the period for competitive bidding on Central New York Power Corporation's $48,000,000 principal amount of general mortgage bonds, due 1974.
CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- Evening up by shorts in anticipation of the election day holiday gave grain markets a strong undertone today on the Board of Trade.
In a final plea to be returned to the Senate, Senator Robert F. Wagner declared last night that he "could not change" his record if he would and "would not change it if I could."

A little more headway toward recovery was made yesterday by the stock market. The advance was spotty, however, and generally confined to a brief period in the final hour. Even then, though, the list was subjected to some selling in the closing few minutes but the industrials managed to retain their modest gains.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as trustee, has invited tenders for the sale to it at prices not to exceed 105 and accrued interest the St. Louis Division first collateral trust mortgage bonds of the Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago St. Louis Railroad in an amount sufficient to exhaust the sum of $56,630. Sealed proposals will be accepted until noon, Nov. 16.

WITH SEVENTH ARMY NURSES CORPS, Vosges Mountains, France, Nov. 5 (Delayed) -- Many nurses receive letters from friends and relatives back home asking them to look up the wounded son of a friend or member of the family. It is not always easy.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- With the objective of making Palestine into a "self-governing Jewish State on both sides of the Jordan with dominion status within the British Empire," a Jewish Dominion League was formed today under the presidency of Lord Strabolgi, Labor peer.
Intercollegiate football in America observed its seventy-fifth birthday anniversary yesterday.
LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Marshal Stalin, in his order of the day, told the Russian armed forces "We now stand on the eve of complete victory."

"Irish Eyes Are Smiling," a Twentieth Century-Fox romantic musical based on the career of the composer, Ernest R. Ball, is the new film attraction opening today at the Roxy. Monty Woolley, Dick Haymes and June Haver head the cast of the Technicolor film. Produced by Damon Runyon and directed by Gregory Ratoff, the picture's featured players include Anthony Quinn, Beverly Whitney, Maxie Rosenbloom and Veda Ann Borg.

Thomas J. Curran, Republican candidate for the Senate, went back to the lower West Side last night and asked his neighbors to send him to Washington. The applause of the crowd indicated that a large percentage of those present wanted him to succeed the Democratic incumbent, Robert F. Wagner.

According to information obtained from the Dutch Consulate General here, it is incorrect in serious reporting to mention places or districts outside of Holland as if they were within that chief province of the Netherlands.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Supreme Court, taking up the first treason case in its history, heard arguments today that framers of the Constitution deliberately made convictions of alleged traitors extremely difficult in order to protect citizens of the new Republic from false charges and perjury.

Old English examples of silverware are features of an exhibition at James Robinson, 716 Fifth Avenue, opening today. Although the display includes many rarities from the famous George Scott collection, on public display for the first time, such as a two-century-old tankard valued at $7,500, there also are hallmarked serving spoons, tea spoons and sugar tongs at values beginning below $10.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Supreme Court held invalid under the Fair Labor Standards Act today "a split-day plan contract" for wage payments. Justice Murphy delivered the unanimous decision.

The possibility that Brazil might supply the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration with as much as 90,000,000 yards of cotton textiles as revealed by Roy F. Hendrickson, director general for supply, was looked upon with considerable doubt by Worth Street mill men yesterday.

Delays in price adjustments believed essential through the Bankhead amendment to the Emergency Price Control Act were hit yesterday by M.J. Lovell, counsel-director of the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers and of the House Dress Institute. "Over four months has passed since the extension of EPCA, with its Bankhead amendment," he said, "and the cotton textile price picture still is lost in total darkness.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, France, Nov. 6 -- The formation of a new tactical air force on the western front, called the "First Tactical Air Force (Provisional)" was announced here today.

A probable electoral college landslide for President Roosevelt was predicted yesterday in last-moment declarations by Elmo Roper, who conducts the Fortune survey; William Lydgate, representing the Gallup Poll, and Archibald Crossley of the Crossley Poll.

I would like to correct an error in the report published in your paper this morning of my testimony yesterday befort the Foreign Trade and Shipping Subcommittee of the House Committee on Post-War Economic Policy and Planning. The report states:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Dr. John R. Steelman director of conciliation of the United States Department of Labor, has resigned, effective Nov. 25, it was announced today by Secretary Perkins.

United States Attorney General Francis Biddle, speaking last night at a celebration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Italian Dressmakers Local 89 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, declared himself sure "that America by its vote will fulfill the pledge that Woodrow Wilson made to insure for our children and the children of all nations a lasting peace."

ELSHOUT, The Netherlands, Nov. 5 (Delayed) -- Detachments from various battalions comprising one of the famous British Army divisions completed the work of cleaning up the villages of Elshout, Drunen, Nieuwkuik and Haarsteeg late today after an exciting crossing of the Aftwatering Canal during the night that a Scottish major burringly described as a "braw wee exercise" and a Londoner, with equal understatement, referred to as a "nice little party."
SALEM, N.H., Nov. 6 -- Mrs. J.H. Quinn's Singing Heels moved in front on the stretch to win the featured $2,000 Elray Purse by half a length over Mrs. M.R. Lewis' Mattie Sue today at Rockingham Park.

It was one of those "happiest-of-my-life" moments yesterday for Comdr. Oscar Hagberg who, after submarine service, was installed as Navy's coach this year and flew to New York to be guest of honor at the regular Monday luncheon of the Football Writers' group at Toot Shor's.

The magic of New York's "Lucky Corner" was invoked last night by Mayor La Guardia and other speakers in behalf of President Roosevelt, Senator Robert F. Wagner, and a number of other candidates seeking public office and hoping for victory in the election today.

Post-war athletics, juvenile delinquency and compulsory athletics for the youth of the country will be among the outstanding matters up for discussion at the fifty-sixth annual meeting of the Amateur Athletic Union.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 6 (AP) -- A protest to Gov. Coke Stevenson against the action of the Texas Board of Regents in discharging Dr. Homer P. Rainey, president of the University of Texas, Nov. 1, was issued today by Chancellor William P. Tolley of Syracuse University, on behalf of the commission on academic freedom and academic tenure of the Association of American Colleges. He is chairman of the commission.

LONDON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The mystery as to the whereabouts and condition of the long-silent Adolf Hitler gained new piquancy today with a rumor that a brain specialist had been called to his current hideout near Berchtesgaden.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in English by the Free Yugoslav Radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Premier Gen. Kuniaki Koiso of Japan declared last night that "Anglo-American inordinate ambition to deny the right of existence to Japan" had forced the island empire into "the present horrible war of unprecedented magnitude."

WITH AMERICAN FORCES, in Germany, Nov. 6 -- The Germans held grimly to Schmidt today and at the same time struck determinedly at Vossenack in what appeared to be an effort to cut into the rear of our forces in front of Schmidt.

Joseph Emmet Kelly, Yonkers architect, was sworn in yesterday by Daniel P. Woolley, regional director of the Office of Price Administration, as area rent director for Westchester County. Born in Pittsfield, Mass., fifty-one years ago, Mr. Kelly is a graduate of Catholic University in Washington and has been associated with realty concerns in Westchester County for the last twenty-two years.

New York's regular 180-day racing season ended Saturday with a stratospheric $388,995,250 poured into the mutuel machines, an increase of $122,559,585 over 1943 and up $285,735,891 from 1940 when betting was legalized.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 6 -- One concern "above all others" on the eve of "our American election day," President Roosevelt said tonight over the radio in his final campaign utterance, is for "all our American fighting men."

KUNMING, China, Nov. 6 (U.P.) -- American Flying Tigers in East China have been able to stay in the air during the desperate battling of recent months largely by means of a primitive supply line stretched across China by the American Army service forces, which have pushed an uninterrupted flow of materiel over coiling roads across six Chinese Provinces.

ROME, Nov. 6 (AP) -- German patrols jabbed hard at Allied positions in Italy today and enemy artillery laid down heavy fire as a long spell of bad weather broke and gave front-line troops their first view of the sun in days.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 6 (AP) -- A capacity crowd of 6,000 turned out in the Coliseum tonight, where Sgt. Joe Louis gave a three-round exhibition of the boxing skill that carried him to the world's heavyweight championship, and Middleweight Holman Williams won a unanimous verdict from Kid Tunera of Havana in the ten-round feature.

For almost three years Singapore, once the strategic center of the Far East, has been only a dark spot on the map of Japanese conquest. Suddenly it leaps into the news as the target of the longest daylight flight our Super-fortresses have ever made. These giant planes are not wasted on nuisance raids.

FORT MYERS, Fla., will be in the market on Nov. 16 with $2,800,000 of refunding bonds for which bidders are to name a rate of interest not exceeding 3 per cent. The bonds, dated Oct. 1, 1944, will consist of $1,300,000 of series A due on April 1, 1946 to 1970, and $1,500,000 of series B due on April 1, 1978.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 6 (AP) -- The observance today of the seventy-fifth birthday of intercollegiate football in America recalled to Frank Butterworth, who starred on the great Yale teams of 1892-93-94, that it was just fifty-five years ago this season that the late Walter Camp inaugurated the "All-America" team.

Appointment of Stanley P. Davies as general director of the Community Service Society is a good step. Mr. Davies has been its executive director since the organization was formed by merger in 1939, and has been giving active leadership to its program, which reaches in direct service nearly 75,000 persons in this city each year.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- The provision of food supplies for Belgium, the equipment of the Belgian Army on a lend-lease basis and the achievement of closer economic and defensive collaboration among the countries of western Europe are the subjects of conversations between British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and the Belgian Foreign Minister, Carl Spaak, that began here today.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Navy's "ghost" ship came home today.

Many ready-to-wear buyers will return to the local market during the next two weeks to place orders for women's coats, lines of which are still incomplete, and to view the showings of better dresses for spring by leading creators, it was reported here yesterday.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase last week of 3 per cent over the corresponding period last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The 1943 week, however, included election day. For the week ended Oct. 28 the bank had reported a gain of 21 per cent.

Two games, adjourned from the tenth and twelfth rounds and played to a finish yesterday, caused another shuffle among the four leaders in the third annual tournament for the national amateur chess championship at the Marshall Chess Club and Federation headquarters in Brooklyn.

"Overhead, more than 2,500 American and British war planes have pounded the Hamburg and Ruhr areas of western Europe." Thus our favorite news broadcast. One of the things that are ruining Hitler is the overhead.

After coming out of the Boston fracas with nothing other than Len Younce's charley-horse, the Giants are ready to start work preparing for their return engagement with the Eagles at Philadelphia Sunday, while the Tigers have to look forward to their coming engagement with the Redskins with no Frank Sachse to help them.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Tuesday, Nov. 7 (AP) -- General MacArthur in a supplemental communique told of an unopposed seventy-two-ton Liberator attack on the Lahue airfield during raids on Negros and Cubu airdromes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Twenty-eight additional firms have won the Army-Navy production award for excellence in the manufacture of war materials. They are:

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Twosy and Mrs. P.A.B. Widener's Polynesian proved the best of their respective lots today in the two divisions of the $7,500 Added Sagamore Stakes at Pimlico, Twosy winning by a nose and Polynesian by a length.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (U.P.) -- Japanese broadcasts said today that United States reconnaissance planes that flew over the Tokyo end of Honshu Island yesterday were B-29 Superfortresses and indicated an expectation that bombing attacks would follow.

Your editorial "Korean Ally" is a fine tribute to the valor of the Koreans in their struggle for independence from Japan. It goes right to the heart of the Korean situation. I am greatly encouraged by it.

Celebrating the twenty-seventh anniversary of the Russian Revolution in the dawn of Allied victory in Europe, Marshal Stalin has made a speech which puts its main emphasis on the necessity of continuing and strengthening the alliance among Russia, the United States and Great Britain. This alliance, he declared, has already thrown the enemy back behind his own frontiers and brought Germany' to the "verge of disaster."

The unaccustomed feature of the concert that Leopold Stokowski led with his wonted brilliancy last night in the City Center of Arts and Sciences was Samuel Barber's Violin Concerto, played with splendid virtuoso spirit and comprehension by Roman Totenberg, concertmaster of the New York City Symphony.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- President Roosevelt and Acting Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr. today cabled greetings to the Soviet President and Foreign Minister on the occasion of the twenty-seventh anniversary of the founding of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

LONDON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The European Inland Transport Conference faced adjournment in failure today with American and Russian delegates deadlocked over a proposal to grant authoritative power to the new Allied transport organization.

ALBANY, Nov. 6 -- Governor Dewey, closing his campaign with a fifteen-minute broadcast speech from his study in the Executive Mansion, declared tonight that the argument against a change of administration during a great ordeal "comes down to the bald plea for the re-election -- so long as he lives -- of whoever happens to be President."

THE clan had assembled once again for the weekly fork-raising exercises of the Football Writers Association and the conversational chatter was concentrated mostly on the awesome job Navy had done against Notre Dame. It was eminently proper therefore that Comdr. Oscar Hagberg, skipper of the midshipmen, should hold the center of the floor.
PARIS, Nov. 6 -- In the Luxembourg Palace, where the Senate used to sit and where the Germans had a defense point a few weeks ago, the new Provisional Consultative Assembly will meet tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- A youth welfare commission to study needs and problems of young people in suburban Glencoe, Kenilworth, Wilmette and Winnetka has been established on an experimental basis for one year, the International City Managers Association stated today.
MOSCOW, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The text of Premier Stalin's speech, on the eve of the twenty-seventh anniversary of the Soviet revolution:

LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 7 -- Marshal Stalin announced early today that the Red Army had killed or captured more than 790,000 Germans during its summer offensive, increasing enemy casualties in more than three years of war on the Eastern Front to 8,590,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- A new Navy Inventory Control Office, which in the last four months has accomplished the diversion or elimination of at least $286,000,000 worth of materials, has been set up in the Office of the Chief of Naval Operations by direction of Secretary Forrestal, the Navy Department disclosed today.

LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 7 -- The around-the-clock schedule for the devastation of Germany's war potential from the air was maintained and even stepped up yesterday, with very little opposition again from the Luftwaffe.

The consumer rush for vanishing popular brand cigarettes virtually had depleted stocks on independent retailers' shelves yesterday as the shortage in New York City became more acute than at any time in recent months. Little hope for immediate relief was held out by manufacturers, who blamed a lack of manpower in cigarette factories as one of the principal causes for the situation.

Six properties in North Bergen, N.J., have been purchased for investment by Anthony S. Ghio, Hudson County motor dealer. They include the one and two famliy houses at 24 Seventy-fourth Street, 7214 and 7615 Park Avenue and 8216 and 8220 Hudson Boulevard and the gasoline station at 9200-14 Hudson Boulevard.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- In one of its first decisions of the present term, the Supreme Court unanimously held today that canned milk products of the Carolene Products Company, Litchfield, Ill., are not legal under the Federal Filled Milk Law. Convictions in a lower court of Charles Hauser, president of the company, and William H. Hartke, vice president, for violation of the law, were upheld.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- Manufacturers of men's and boys' wear reported today that buyers attending the showing of their spring and summer lines of goods were taking a more conservative view of future inventory needs and were seeking mainly the higher quality goods.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- Brig. Gen. Armand Pinsard, 57, retired French Air Force officer, was sentenced today by a Paris Court of Justice to forced labor for life after conviction on a charge of intelligence with the enemy. Doubtless because of his war record, the jury of one woman and three men accepted a plea of attenuating circumstances and refrained from the death penalty.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 6 -- Carrier planes of Admiral William F. Halsey's Third Fleet blasted Manila harbor on Saturday (Sunday, Philippines time) in a major raid that left behind a trail of shattered Japanese warships, merchant vessels, ripped airfields and a badly cut up enemy air force in southern Luzon.
In its editorials on the China crisis of this past week THE NEW YORK TIMES has struck a constructive note that needs sounding.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 6 -- Phyllis Thaxter, who appears in the feminine lead in the current "Thirty Seconds Over Tokyo" has been named by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to play the central character in the forthcoming "Alter Ego." This picture, which will go into production next Monday, will be based on a radio play by Arch Oboler, about a girl whose dual personality incites her to murder. It was done on the air by Bette Davis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Loss of time by women working in the war industries, due to injuries or illness, is greater than similar absences by men, according to a report issued today by the Office of War Information. The summary, at the same time, stressed the need for more health and safety measures so that the country can use, to its utmost, all available supplies of industrial personnel.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 6 (AP) -- John W. Bricker appealed to the people of Ohio tonight to order a continuation of "the kind of government" he had given during his six years as their Governor.
ALBANY, Nov. 6 -- The State War Ballot Commission announced today that a minimum of 411,342 service men's votes would be counted at New York's polls tomorrow.

Daniel P. Woolley, regional director of the Office of Price Administration, avoided yesterday any direct reply to demands for his ouster, made by the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee in a letter to Chester A. Bowles, national administrator of the OPA.
The Second Battle of the Philippine Sea was a heavy blow to Japanese carrier-based aviation.

Referring to an article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 23, quoting Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase as fearing post-war "inflationary enrollment," it would seem that, far from being "inflationary," a post-war expansion of education promises to be a period of sound prosperity for the cultural development of the country as well as, more narrowly, for the growth of the institutions of higher learning.
ROME, Nov. 6 (AP) -- A communique:

Your editorial of Oct. 25 stated that all six candidates for the Supreme Court, First District, in tomorrow's election have been described as qualified by the leading bar associations. However, in your final summary today of recommended candidates you omit the names of Irving L. Levey and James B.M. McNally from your list. Will you kindly explain this omission?

A Japanese Imperial Headquarters communique issued yesterday claimed that Japanese submarines, planes and the "Kamikaze special attack corps" sunk two "enemy" aircraft carriers and had "heavily damaged" two others in action east of the Philippines Sunday and last Friday.

As if to demonstrate that he came out of his latest ring engagement none the worse for wear, Jimmy McDaniels, Los Angeles welterweight, yesterday engaged in a spirited boxing workout at Stillman's Gymnasium in preparation for his ten-round bout Friday night in Madison Square Garden against Sammy Angott, former world lightweight champion.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 6 (AP) -- A United States Army Forces in China communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The current national political debate has been especially bitter, despite the fact that the war was being desperately fought by American troops at the same time. That has dismayed many who realize the importance of a unified front in this country in the difficult days to come.

The end of the Republican party, unless its control can be wrested from Governor Dewey and his supporters after the election and a liberal and internationally minded leadership established, was predicted yesterday by Russell W. Davenport, chairman of the New York Independent Republican Committee and friend and political associate of the late Wendell L. Willkie.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Twenty large railroads were ordered today by the Supreme Court to show cause why the high tribunal should not grant judgment and damages against the carriers for charging "discriminatory" freight rates to Georgia and the South, as alleged by Gov. Ellis Arnall.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- The best feature in today's generally firm stock markets here was Argentine rails. An active demand for these s curities arose on reports from Buenos Aires that the railway companies are to be granted an improved exchange rate. Supplies of stocks in the market were small and prices went ahead.
Walter Edward Guinness, first Baron Moyne of Bury St. Edmunds, was an Irishman, a son of the late first Earl of Iveagh and a member of the famous Dublin brewing family that produces Guinness' Stout.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (U.P.) -- American officials are hoping for the best and preparing for the worst in the Big Three crisis developing in Iran over oil concessions.
MOSCOW, Nov. 6 (AP) -- An editorial in War and the Working Class, Russian trade union magazine, declared today that Japan's future was grim.
LONDON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

The Harlem Savings Bank sold the six-story public garage at 207-211 West Seventy-sixth Street to the 207 West Seventy-sixth Street Corporation. The property, accommodating 300 cars, is assessed at $245,000 and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $205,000 for ten years at 3 and 4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- To familiarize business with the official interpretation of the relief provisions of the excess profits tax on corporations as prescribed by Congress in Section 722 of the Internal Revenue Code in 1940, the Bureau of Internal Revenue made public today a bulletin of more than 200 pages, prepared for the guidance of its personnel in the administration of the law.

The New York Stock Exchange yesterday requested all members and member firms to submit data on all their transactions in listed shares each week. Until further notice, beginning with yesterday's market, they are to give the time of each transaction and the position in each stock traded in at the opening of each day.

Testimony that a special account to pay Army contract officers for aid in obtaining Government war business had been set up by the Cornwall Shipbuilding Company, was given yesterday by Victor S. Fox, a former partner of the company, at the general court-martial of Capt. Joseph (Joe) Gould, former prize fight manager until he entered the Army Transportation Corps two years ago.
ALBANY, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Mrs. Thomas E. Dewey has cleared her own decks so that, for election day, she is free to act as a sort of second-run secretary to her husband.
With a huge Times Square election night crowd in prospect for tonight, police prepared yesterday or their annual task that becomes particularly strenuous every four years.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, France, Nov. 6 -- The Allies' campaign in western Europe reached one of the punctuation marks of history today with the completion of the German retreat north of the Meuse (Maas) on the front of the Twenty-first Army Group and the stiffening of enemy resistance on the front of the American First Army where that tempered weapon is hacking at the stout enemy defense in the forest of Huertgen.

Burma Road captured the $15,900 Temple Gwathmey Steeplechase at Belmont Park yesterday, and it is going to be pretty hard to fault him as top steeplechaser of the year, since the bay gelding was the winner just about a month ago in the country's richest jumping event, Belmont's $17,400 Grand National. He thus becomes the third horse in history to bring off the double.

TACLOBAN, Philippines, Nov. 6 (AP) -- President Sergio Osmena announced today the creation of a board to investigate charges of disloyalty to the Philippine Commonwealth and the United States among Filipinos.

It has been one of the most pleasant features of life in Bournemouth during the past year or so that we have had such opportunities of meeting members of the United States armed forces. I have personally been privileged in making the acquaintance -- and, I hope, in achieving the friendship -- of many splendid representatives of your great country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The searching inquiry by the British Government into the "origin and associations" of Lord Moyne's assassins will throw needed light on the disturbing conditions that for many months have obtained in Palestine.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- In answering an open letter from real estate and home builders' representatives urging the assignment of all priorities to private home-building interests, John B. Blandford Jr., administrator of the National Housing Agency, declared today that assignment would be carried out in accordance with the wartime policies broadly determined by Congress.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 (AP) -- A plan for recapitalization of the Indiana General Service Company, Marion, Ind., and its dissolution, following its merger with the Indiana and Michigan Electric Company, South Bend, Ind., was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the two companies and their parent, the American Gas and Electric Company.

SAN FRANCISCO, Wednesday, Nov. 8 -- California's twenty-five electoral votes were captured by President Roosevelt in yesterday's election. Washington's eight apparently went to the same candidate, but early this morning it looked very much as if Oregon, with six votes in the electoral college, had successfully resisted the President's efforts to make the West Coast solidly his for the fourth consecutive time.

WITH THE TWENTY-FOURTH DIVISION, on Leyte, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Some units of this division, trapped by Japanese, suffered heavy casualties as the enemy brought captured American machine guns into action against them yesterday near Pinamopoan, where the Carigara coast road bends south toward Ormoc.
DETROIT, Nov. 8 -- Predictions of a photo-finish between President Roosevelt and Governor Dewey were made early today as the returns from Michigan's 3,840 precincts began to trickle in.

Jan J. Letsch, a representative of French motion-picture interests, said here yesterday that box office receipts in Paris theatres dropped 30 per cent when German films were shown and that frequently the boos of the audiences forced the managers to turn on the lights.

BOSTON, Wednesday, Nov. 8 -- Massachusetts swung its sixteen electoral votes to President Roosevelt again early today and all indications from the unofficial returns were that the surge would give the commonwealth a Democratic governor for the first time since 1939.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- The eloquence called forth by reports that lights were on again in London was a little premature. The dimout still prevailing in narrow country lanes and shadow-filled city streets of this long-darkened island is hardly distinguishable from the blackout of the worst war years.

PARIS, Nov. 7 -- The new Consultative Assembly, formed of political parties and resistance groups to advise the Government, was formally opened today in the Senate chamber with a long speech by Senator Paul Cuttoli, who was chosen by virtue of his seniority, he being 80 years old.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7 (AP) -- In a four-way blanket finish that resembled the fight to the wire in a short sprint rather than the mile and five furlongs of the $10,000 Added Governor Bowie Handicap, Harford, owned by Miss Ruth McClanaghan of Philadelphia, was a driving winner at Pimlico today.

LONDON, Nov. 7 (U.P.) -- The problem of getting milk into the mouths of babies in view of the shortage of rubber nipples in Britain again engaged the House of Commons today. One woman member accused Hugh Dalton, president of the Board of Trade, of wanting "to eliminate women and children."

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Five per cent of the South Dakotans who voted Republican for United States Senator crossed over the party line to cast their ballot for President Roosevelt, returns from approximately one-fourth of the State's precincts indicated tonight.

ST. LOUIS, Wednesday, Nov. 8 (AP) -- After trailing since early last night as rural precincts came in first President Roosevelt early today took the lead over Thomas E. Dewey when the big city vote from Kansas City and St. Louis began to roll in.

ROME, Nov. 7 (AP) -- British Eighth Army troops, stalled for days outside Forli on the important Bologna-Rimini lateral highway, moved toward the town today, aided by a powerful attack by medium bombers.

The Republican party retained control of both houses of the State Legislature despite cross currents arising out of the Presidential contest, but as the tally rolled in at 3:10 A.M. today at least one major upset was certain and possibly others in the making.

An investing client of L.V. Hoffman Co., brokers, purchased from the Keasbey Realty Corporation the two loft buildings at 139-41 and 143-49 West Nineteenth Street, eight stories and seven stories in height.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

That unusual bond of friendship that grows up between soldiers who fight in the same units played a part in electing Harry S. Truman Vice President of the United States. A nephew of Tom Pendergast had served in the Kansas City battery of field artillery that Captain Truman commanded through St. Mihiel and the Argonne battles of World War I.

War relief and other charities gained at least $50,000 as 29,637 persons turned out for the second of nine programs scheduled at Belmont Park under the auspices of the Turf Committee of America to watch Dove Shoot and Bardia take the two halves of the Constitution Handicap.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Britain's new House of Commons will not be changed to any extent from the chamber destroyed by German air raids if the report of the select committee considering the rebuilding is adopted. Issued today, the report preserves the traditional dimensions and essential features of the old House, but provides additional comforts for members, such as secretarial and reception rooms.

Supplies of canned fruits and vegetables for civilian consumption will be considerably less this winter than they were last year, according to all indications. The quota of the 1944 pack for the trade, which is moving to market now, is far short of requirements in most instances.

Fieldston became the only unbeaten and untied scholastic football team in the city, routing Barnard School, 13 -- 0, yesterday at Fieldston. In marking up their fourth straight triumph, the victors were in command throughout, their strong defense preventing Barnard from making any serious threat.

If an invading army had overrun this country and still occupied several of our chief ports, say Boston, Baltimore, New Orleans and Seattle, as well as a slice of territory as large as New England, we might hesitate to regard ourselves as "liberated." Yet that is pretty much the condition in which France finds herself today.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Gov. John W. Bricker, Republican Vice Presidential candidate, voted with Mrs. Bricker in a little booth at Precinct B, Ward 6, today.

The Continental Oil Company reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $8,767,078, equal to $1.87 a share on the common capital stock, after taxes, charges and a provision of $11,499,463 for intangible development costs.

The majority given to President Roosevelt by civilian voters who went to the polls throughout the nation yesterday was increased by the count of war ballots marked, some of them as long as two months ago, by members of the armed forces in camps here and in far-flung theatres of operations.

The Hollywood-backed "Violet" will vacate the Belasco on Saturday night. Having opened here on Oct. 24, Whitfield Cook's dramatization of his own magazine stories in Redbook, which the author directed, will have received twenty-three performances.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Senator Harry S. Truman, Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, cast his ballot -- it was No. 102 -- at 9:35 A.M., Central war time, in today's general election.

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Governor Dewey held a commanding lead over President Roosevelt in the unofficial tabulation of 610 of the 627 Maine precincts in today's Presidential election. The vote was: Roosevelt, 138,988, and Dewey, 153,734.
Times Square's first wartime national election crowd, numbering from 250,000 to 500,000 persons predominantly and noisily pro-Roosevelt, strained a large police detail last night.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 7 -- President Roosevelt has carried Kentucky by a substantial majority, Senator Alben W. Barkley is running right along with him, and Kentucky's Congressional delegation is likely to be composed of eight Democrats and one Republican, returns indicate.

Net sales of the American Viscose Corporation for the nine months ended with September increased 6 per cent to $79,102,706 from the $74,613,636 volume for the corresponding period a year ago, William C. Appleton, president, reported yesterday in the operating statement to stockholders.
Morris Reif, 146, Brooklyn, defeated Sol Stewart, 144, Providence, in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Broadway Arena last night before a capacity crowd of 4,000.

LONDON, Nov. 7 (U.P.) Viscount Cecil of Chelwood, winner of the Nobel and Woodrow Wilson Peace Prizes, said today that the Dumbarton Oaks conference was "a very solid and serious contribution" to the cause of international peace.

Brooklyn College's football team, far from being a powerhouse, still packed too much of a punch for a weaponless C.C.N.Y. squad yesterday on Kingsmen Field over in the heart of Flatbush. Meeting for the second time this season, exactly a month after their first encounter.

CHICAGO, Wednesday, Nov. 8 -- President Roosevelt appeared early this morning to have won a smashing victory over Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, his Republican opponent, in yesterday's contest for Illinois' 28 electoral votes.

WITH THE BRITISH SECOND ARMY, in the Netherlands, Nov. 7 -- Lively interest over the outcome of the United States Presidential election is being displayed today by British fighting troops, the great majority of whom favor President Roosevelt's re-election principally because officers and men alike feel that this is a bad time to change Presidents.

Eight hundred poliomyelitis victims of the summer and fall epidemic in New York are being treated in hospitals here, it was reported yesterday by George L. Shearer, chairman of the Greater New York Chapter of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, 17 East Forty-second Street.

LONDON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A trade survey disclosed today that a slight majority of British business leaders answering it favored the cancellation of any British-owed lend-lease balances after the war and approved the negotiation of export-sphere pacts with American traders.

INWOOD, L.I., Nov. 7 -- Mrs. Ellen Cleary, 70 years old, of 482 Doughty Boulevard, died at her home here today, after a long illness, unaware that her son, Pfc. John R. Cleary, USMC, was killed during the invasion of Roi Island, in the South Pacific, last Feb. 1.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Strong Allied air fleets roared out toward Germany today on the eleventh consecutive day of round-the-clock bombardment of Nazi war industry, and it was revealed that RAF Lancasters deal the vital Dortmund-Ems Canal its second crippling blow in less than two months last Saturday night.

WELLINGTON, Nov. 6 (Delayed) -- Advocacy of the principle of trusteeship for all colonial peoples was proposed by Prime Minister Peter Fraser tonight as one result of the Australia-New Zealand conversations, which closed this afternoon.

ALSDORF, Germany, Nov. 7 -- There aren't any signs saying "This is Germany." There is a customs shed, but not a barrier, and there are no inspectors -- just a couple of M.P.'s with carbines slung over their shoulders, such as can be seen at almost any cross roads all the way across France, Belgium and Holland.

FREEPORT, L.I., Nov. 7 -- Tallying in the first period, Baldwin High School's unbeaten eleven defeated its traditional foe, Freeport, 6 -- 0, before 5,200 persons at Municipal Stadium today in their twenty-first meeting. Baldwin has won five games and tied one this season.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Fighting along the Eastern Front slackened generally today -- the twenty-seventh anniversary of the Russian Revolution -- with Moscow announcing only that "there were no essential changes on the front" and that yesterday sixteen German tanks were knocked out in scattered local engagements.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- At least $1,500,000 was spent for political broadcasts on the four major networks in the Presidential election campaign. This was indicated today by preliminary and incomplete figures released by three chains. The total may be much higher when final tabulations are made.
WILMINGTON, Del., Wednesday, Nov. 8 -- President Roosevelt held a lead of 8,000 votes over Governor Dewey in a rising tide of Democratic votes in Delaware shortly after midnight.

In the final reckoning of this wartime election, which has found women more active politically than ever before, New York City's ballots were counted last night at local polling places by boards on which women predominate.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 7 -- In an irritable mood the Belgian Senate listened for an hour today while Henri Borginon, Flemish Nationalist member accused of collaborating with the Germans, defended himself. He was the only one of six Senators so charged to appear.

President Roosevelt carried Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx yesterday to win a margin that may go above 740,000 votes over Gov. Thomas E. Dewey in New York City, despite the loss of Queens and Richmond to the Republican challenger.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- President Roosevelt told several thousand Hyde Park villagers from his front porch at 11:40 tonight that it was too early to make any statement on election returns, but expressed confidence he would continue his custom of commuting here from Washington for another four years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Donald M. Nelson, former chairman of the War Production Board and now an industrial trouble shooter for President Roosevelt on an international scale, announced today the names of five iron and steel experts who will accompany him on his next trip to China to step up industrial output under a Chinese WPB.

Marshal Stalin's denunciation of Japan as an aggressor on a par with Nazi Germany has found a warm welcome among all the United Nations fighting in the Far East. His statement must be accepted both as an expression of Russia's consciousness of her own strength and as part of Russia's considered foreign policy.

The Japanese home radio announced that two B-29 Super-fortresses flew over the main Japanese home island of Honshu for an hour yesterday and that forty B-29's raided Iwo Island in the Volcano group on Sunday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 7 (UP) -- The Swiss Government adopted an open-door policy today on its resumption of relations with Russia after a lengthy meeting of the Federal Council. A communique reviewing negotiations and developments to date said:

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 7 (AP) -- President Roosevelt was in the lead tonight for Minnesota's eleven electoral votes, but Republicans were leading their Democratic-Farmer-Labor opponents in four of six contests for state posts.

R.H. Burnside, who conducts a sort of one-man campaign to keep the operettic classics alive, turned his attention to "Robin Hood" last evening at the Adelphi. This is the Reginald de Koven-Harry B. Smith tale of Robin, Friar Tuck, Will Scarlett and the others, and it has not been revived here since 1932.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS ON LEYTE, Nov. 7 (AP) -- A supplement to today's communique:

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 7 -- The widely advertised political revolt in Texas failed to materialize and President Roosevelt was carrying the State by an overwhelming plurality by late tonight despite the bitter pre-election fight that developed within the Democratic party.

Braving the competition of election night, the Philadelphia Orchestra gave its second Carnegie Hall concert of the season last night and drew a capacity audience which displayed its obvious approval of the musical goings-on with vociferous applause. William Kapell, the 22-year-old American pianist, was the evening's soloist and Eugene Ormandy, the conductor, provided an evening of Russian music.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 7 -- Admiral William F. Halsey's Third Fleet carriers spread death and damage over southern Luzon Island in the Philippines for the second successive day on Sunday, sinking another five ships and destroying 249 additional enemy aircraft.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 7 (U.P.) -- Sullenly refusing to answer questions by high political and police authorities, the two assassins of Lord Moyne. British Resident Minister in the Middle East, said today that "we will not talk until we are in court."
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 7 (AP) -- President Roosevelt and Governor Dewey were running a close race on the basis of early unofficial returns in today's election.

If Germany had possessed a secret weapon capable of eliminating or paralyzing hostile populations by the millions instead of by the thousands, she might have won the war. Japan has such a weapon. For the past twelve years she has been using it as an arm of national policy.

To improve the health of refugees in Palestine, Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America, will open a drive for $900,000 at its thirtieth annual convention opening next Monday at the Cleveland Hotel, in Cleve land. The sum will be used to expand the public health program and also to start a building fun for a 250-bed tuberculosis hospital as part of the Hadassah Medical Center in Jerusalem.
Army and Randolph Field, rulers of the collegiate and service divisions of The Associated Press football poll a week ago, continue to set the pace in the present compilation.

This was the first wartime election since 1864. We can take profound satisfaction in knowing that there were few other respects in which the two contests were alike. In 1864 a civil war was going on. In 1944 the nation is united. In 1864 the opposition candidate ran on a platform demanding "that immediate efforts be made for a cessation of hostilities."

PARIS, Nov. 7 (U.P.) -- Georges Carpentier, former French heavyweight boxer, said today that he was bringing suit against a Bordeaux newspaper for reporting that he had been arrested as a collaborationist. To the manager of the Lido Night Club, where Jack Dempsey visited him recently, he said:

Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commander of the New York Guard, commended yesterday a former guardsman. Capt. Henry Ashton Crosby, 32 years old, of 19 East Ninety-eighth Street, for the manner in which he performed his duties in battle.

GENERAL NATHAN BEDFORD FORREST is known to most of his countrymen today for something he never said. His magnificent military record and his spectacular personality are alike familiar only to students of the Civil War, who admittedly are a goodly company. But a sound simplification of the commander's art in war, to "git thar fustest with the mostest men," remains Forrest's greatest claim to fame and his contribution to American folklore.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 7 -- Reinforced Japanese troops dug in yesterday along the Pinamopoan-Ormoc road, where elements of the American Twenty-fourth Division had pushed four miles south of Carigara, and apparently were preparing for a fierce stand along their line of communication back to Ormoc Bay.

Heyman Belinky, 71 years old, one of the founders of the Hebrew Educational Alliance of Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and who was well known in charitable and religious activities of that section, died Monday night as the result of a fall from his sixth-floor private room at the Harkness Pavilion, Fort Washington Avenue and 168th Street.
Potpourri from the New York State Conservation Department:

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 7 -- A hard, bitter battle is raging between American and German infantry in the Forest of Huertgen, where, while the rest of the Allied armies devote themselves to cleaning up unfinished business, Lieut. Gen. Courtney H. Hodges' First Army is striking for a small but important bit of high ground overlooking the Roer River and Dueren.

PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, Nov. 8 -- On the basis of partial returns from all but three of the sixty-seven counties in Pennsylvania, it appeared early that President Roosevelt for the third successive time had captured the State's electoral votes.

Total advertising in all New York newspapers during the first ten months of this year totaled 79,967,375 lines, a decline of 6.60 per cent, compared with 85,616,271 during the corresponding period last year, according to a compilation of Media Records figures. All classifications showed losses as follows: Classified, 30.03 per cent; automotive, 10.86 per cent; general, 10.86 per cent; financial, .86 per cent, and retail, .69 per cent.

The nine-story apartment building at 125-29 West Seventy-sixth Street was sold by Sidney Heim and Fanny Omin to James M. Rice through A.M. Druckman, broker, with the Lawyers Title Corporation insuring the title. Joseph Rosen was attorney for the seller and Charles A. Conner for the buyer.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, (Wednesday), Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Dewey-Bricker ticket was running strong in Ohio and Republicans also were leading for all State-wide offices except Governor early today as returns came in from almost two-thirds of the State's 9,306 polling places.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- If the enemies of the United States seek comfort or solace in the manifestations of our robust political rivalry, they are due for a sharp awakening, Eric A. Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, declared tonight in a broadcast over the Blue network.

BALTIMORE, Wednesday, Nov. 8 (AP) -- President Roosevelt won Maryland's eight electoral votes by a plurality of about 20,000 votes yesterday, with his margin dropping steadily as final returns trickled in from the twenty-three counties early today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Clarifying the British proposal for a strong international authority to regulate post-war air traffic, Lord Swinton, Minister of Civil Aviation and chairman of the delegation from London, said today that it was needed to provide security against another world war.

HARTFORD, Conn., Wednesday, Nov. 8 -- Representative Clare Boothe Luce, Republican, was re-elected yesterday in a close race. Miss Margaret Connors of Bridgeport, her Democratic opponent, conceded defeat just before 4 o'clock this morning.

ROME, Nov. 7 -- For a variety of reasons, many of which apply throughout the fighting world, United States soldiers in Italy showed little excitement or interest other than casual in today's election. The basic reason here is that fighting conditions on the Fifth Army front bring the realities of warmth and shelter -- or their lack -- much closer than political pluralities.

A new pajama set has been designed by Harry Berger, consisting of five pieces that are interchangeable, it was disclosed yesterday. Tailored of rayon satin, each ensemble consists of a bra and shorts, a pajama set and a tommie coat.

LONDON, Nov. 7 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister Churchill, announcing to the House of Commons today the death of Lord Moyne "at the hands of foul assassins," said that he had received no official information that fixed the authorship of the crime or gave a clue to its motive.

ROME, Nov. 7 -- In an extraordinary Cabinet meeting to avoid a possible crisis over an article on Crown Prince Humbert in THE NEW YORK TIMES, the Italian Government issued a communique today saying that the Italian constitutional problem must be settled by a constituent assembly, not by a plebiscite, as the monarchists desire.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- Governor Dewey carried Westchester County in the Presidential contest by 66,213.
Your editorial of Nov. 2 "Japan Expects a Bargain" seems to me for the most part admirable, but it contains a confusion of thought regarded as both dangerous and important.

HARTFORD, Conn., Wednesday, Nov. 8 -- President Franklin D. Roosevelt maintained his monopoly on the vote of the fifteen large Connecticut cities by a lead of 81,883 in these industrial centers, to gain the eight electoral votes of the State in his quest for a fourth term.

Edna Ferber has written a new novel, her first since "Saratoga Trunk" appeared in 1941. It is called "Great Son" and is the story of four generations of an American family in Seattle, Wash. The time: from 1851 to the attack on Pearl Harbor.

The return to Manila of the planes of Admiral Halsey's Third Fleet should be sufficient answer, if one were needed, to continued extravagant claims by Japan of multiple sinkings of our carriers and other vessels off Formosa and in the Battle of the Philippines.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The enemy warship score exacted over the week-end increased to at least seventy-two the total sunk, probably sunk or damaged in actions related to Gen Douglas MacArthur's invasion of Leyte on Oct. 20.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Emulating the Germans at Lidice, Japanese have wiped out at least two villages of the Netherlands Indies with virtually their entire populations, headquarters of Netherlands forces in the Far East announced today.

Legging it home with a strength that was surprising at the end of such an endurance test over hill and dale, Armand Osterberg, 17-year-old freshman, product of Stuyvesant High School, yesterday led New York University to its fourth straight team triumph in the annual metropolitan intercollegiate cross-country championship over the five-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

DETROIT, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Packard Motor Car Company said today that it had closed its entire plant, which employs about 39,000 workers, because a dispute involving several hundred polishers had produced an "unbalanced material condition" making impossible the production of aircraft and marine engines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Vice Admiral Jonas Ingram, who as ranking naval commander in the South Atlantic has been the Navy's unofficial "Ambassador" to South America, will head the new board which is being created to make a thorough study of the attitude of reserve officers toward remaining in the post-war Navy, it was reliably learned today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Responsible military, naval and diplomatic observers in the Capital today greeted Premier Joseph Stalin's Soviet anniversary address with general approval and felt that the Japanese should have cause for worry in the section of the speech that linked them with the Nazis in the category of aggressors.

LONDON, Nov. 7 (Reuter) -- A call to all Hungarian organizations and individuals abroad to rally in support of a national uprising in the country, the formation of a national government and the adoption of a far-reaching program of democratic reconstruction was sent out today by Count Michael Karolyi, the former Hungarian President and democratic leader in exile, and the Hungarian Council in Britain.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- An Army Nurse Corps analysis of the current nurse shortage shows that 3,753 are needed in Army hospitals in this country and 1,000 are needed abroad.

Opening their home season before a crowd of 2,842 at Madison Square Garden last night, the New York Rovers of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League lost to the Boston Olympics, last year's champions, 11 -- 2. Theo Hamel had the most fun with three goals and four assists.

PROVIDENCE, R.I, Nov. 7 -- President Roosevelt carried Rhod Island for a fourth term today, defeating Governor Dewey 158,814 to 114,108, with only one of the 261 districts missing. The potential soldier and absentee vote in Rhode Island is only 41,723.

Thirty of the 400 persons indicted by the New York County Grand Jury on charges of illegal registration were arrested yesterday when they attempted to vote, but thirteen subsequently were released after investigations by assistant district attorneys at the police stations to which they were taken.

LILOAN, Panaon Island, the Philippines, Nov. 7 -- American soldiers and sailors in the Philippines, or at least the luckiest of them, are gaining weight through the revival of the most ancient system of trading -- native barter.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 7 -- An American civil service mission to Brazil to reorganize the public service and all Government departments is a feasible possibility, according to recommendations made by the chief of the Brazilian Public Service Administration, Simoes Lopes, that already has been approved by President Getulio Vargas and endorsed by the American State Department, which latter will name those to come.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Wednesday, Nov. 8 -- Representative Hamilton Fish, for twelve terms a Republican member of the House and a leading isolationist and critic of President Roosevelt's foreign policy, conceded his defeat by Augustus W. Bennet just before 1 o'clock this morning.

By defeating Irving Stein in 55 moves in the thirteenth and final round of the annual tournament for the amateur championship of the United States Chess Federation at the Marshall Club yesterday, Edward S. Jackson Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., regained the title he held two years ago and which was won last year by Dr. Ariel Mengarini of Washington, now in the Army.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 177:
SOMEWHERE IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC (AP) -- Island champions were crowned here as the American Division completed its biggest boxing tournament, and 5,000 G.I. fans howled their approval.

Alfred E. Kahn, in comment today on my letter in your Oct. 28 issue, implies that I offer tariffs "as a weapon for maintaining short-run equilibrium in balances of payments and preventing fluctuations in exchange rates." On the contrary, the measurement of national price levels to which I referred would seek to determine only long-run differentials.
The voters of New Jersey decided yesterday to muddle along with their century-old Constitution.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Communique 213:

GREAT RIVER, L.I., Nov. 8 (Wednesday) -- Suffolk County, long a Republican stronghold, fulfilled party expectations by giving Governor Dewey a plurality that will approach 35,000 when vote tabulations, running far behind schedule early this morning, have been completed.
CONCORD, N.H., Wednesday, Nov. 8 -- President Roosevelt captured New Hampshire's four electoral votes early today.

In a letter addressed to Mayor La Guardia, the New York City League of Women Voters approved yesterday reports recently issued by the Mayor's Committee on Juvenile Delinquency and pledged continued study and support of its work.

Judge Marvin R. Dye of Rochester, who was elected to the Court of Appeals, had been appointed Court of Claims Judge by Governor Lehman in 1940, to fill a vacancy caused by the death of Milton E. Gibbs of the same city. In 1934 and 1938 he had served as Monroe County attorney.

Franklin Delano Roosevelt, who broke more than a century-old tradition in 1940 when he was elected to a third term as President, made another political record yesterday when he was chosen for a fourth term by a heavy electoral but much narrower popular majority over Thomas E. Dewey, Governor of New York.

ANOTHER Army-Notre Dame battle lurks just around the corner and, for a change, the Kaydets have slightly more than an even chance of winning it. This has been an extraordinary series in that the Fighting Irish have dominated it completely and still it's the outstanding football drama of each and every campaign, a sure-fire sell-out season after season.
LONDON, Nov. 7 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 7 (U.P.) -- Japanese forces, driving along the Hunan-Kwangsi railway, have advanced to within twenty miles of the important railway city of Liuchow, a Chinese High Command communique said tonight.

WITH THE UNITED STATES THIRD ARMY, Nov. 7 -- Although the National Socialist party still holds a firm grip on the German people through its terror, real or implied, great cracks have been made in its structure and gradually widening crevices are spreading from East Prussia southward to Alsace, which, for the first time in history, is now considered strongly anti-German.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Robot bomb attacks against the continental United States are "entirely possible," the War and Navy Departments said in a joint statement issued late this afternoon in response to press queries.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Daniel I. Sultan, in his first speech to American troops as their commander in the India-Burma war theatre, said today, that "recent developments," such as the recall of Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, had changed "neither our mission nor our strategy."

MOSCOW, Nov. 7 (U.P.) -- Diplomatic circles today attached considerable significance to Marshal Stalin's first public classification of Japan among the aggressor nations, although it generally was noted that there never had been any secret how the Russian people and the Red Army always had felt about Japan.

The two-story eight-family apartment house at 189-18 State Street and 35-19 190th Street, Flushing, Queens, assessed at $59,000, has been sold by Martin Treitel and Frances Block to the H.D. Construction Corporation. Henry Baker Co. were the brokers.

Robert E. Hannegan, Democratic national chairman, announced the re-election of President Roosevelt at 11:49 o'clock last night when he approached a group of newspaper men at the committee's headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore and handed them a mimeographed statement headed "Overwhelming Victory of President Roosevelt."

Premier George Papandreou's government has ordered the dissolution of the Elas and the Edes, the two largest guerrilla organizations in Greece, the Athens radio announced last night in a domestic broadcast reported by the Federal Communications Commission.

FIRST UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Nov. 7 -- This was another day of heavy but inconclusive fighting in wind-driven rain and icy mud in the Huertgen Forest. The only appreciable progress was in the village of Vossenack, where we gained.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 7 -- Nassau County voters -- 13 per cent more than the number that cast ballots in 1940 in the last Presidential election and the largest electorate in the history of the county -- went to the polls in 318 election districts of three townships and two cities as early today as if they had not known of the two-hour extension of time.

Erasmus Hall High, one of the metropolitan district's strongest school boy football combinations, struck resolutely in the last two quarters after trailing at the half to down Manual Training, 24 -- 7, in the annual fixture at Ebbets Field yesterday. A crowd of 10,000 witnessed the game.

LONDON, Nov. 6 (Delayed) (AP) -- Adolf Hitler may be on the verge of committing his gretest blunder of the war through the use of hate weapons. They are coming on the scene at least two years too late in this war, but, by using them, Hitler possibly is making the absolute subjugation of Germany a matter of utmost necessity.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared a personal holiday this election day. Her calendar showed only one errand, and that was to the Village Hall in Hyde Park, where she cast her ballot about noontime, following the President into the booth.

While Stout Steve Owen was approaching Sunday's return engagement with the Eagles at Philadelphia in a state of calmness there was a bit of excitement among the always-trying-but-never-winning Tigers.

Despite greatly reduced pluralities in Hudson County, Democratic stronghold of New Jersey, lieutenants of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, Democratic boss of the State, predicted shortly before 4 A.M. today that the State's sixteen electoral votes would be delivered to President Roosevelt, largely by virtue of an estimated plurality of 75,000 votes in Hudson. In 1940 Mr. Roosevelt carried the county by a plurality of 100,877.
Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for President, conceded defeat at 3:12 o'clock this morning.
PARIS, Nov. 7 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle has decided to permit Maurice Thorez, French Communist leader now in Moscow, to come to France, as the Communists have long demanded.

KANDY, Ceylon, Nov. 7 (U.P.) -- Continuing their advance in the Chin Hills sector of southwestern Burma, British Fourteenth Army troops have captured stubbornly defended Kennedy Peak and pushed on to clear another eight miles of the Tiddim-Fort White Road, it was announced today.
A prediction that the Congress of Industrial Organization's Political Action Committee would continue its activities after this election was made early this morning by Sidney Hillman, its chairman.

LONDON Nov. 7 -- Sentiment on the stock market here was influenced favorably today by Marshal Joseph Stalin's speech pledging support for world security. Although business was not on a great scale, a general all-round improvement was seen.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 1, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

Your report about the Foreign Language Conference at New York University, showing the necessity for Americans to master languages in order to successfully compete in world markets, is of vital importance. The speakers pointed out the advisability of studying Spanish, Portuguese, Italian, French and German, but failed to mention Russian.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 7 -- President Roosevelt carried Arkansas, as expected, by the usual large majority, despite a strong Republican and anti-Roosevelt Democratic campaign.
We were interested in the letter of H. Adams, in THE TIMES of Oct. 31, suggesting a pronunciation service for radio stations.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- On account of the time difference between the continents, Britons went to bed tonight lacking any indication of the outcome of the United States Presidential election which has mattered more to them than any before in history.

Democratic gains of from eleven to twenty seats in the House and a possible new place or two in the already one-sided Senate, appeared on returns received up to 5 A.M. today to have followed in the wake of yesterday's fourth-term landslide for President Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -The War Labor Board has upheld the right of employers to make their vacation plans uniform in various plants.

" Considerable tightness" of liquor toward the end of the year was forecast yesterday by Gerald F. Dunne, executive director of the Metropolitan Package Stores Association at a meeting of that organization at the Park Central Hotel.

The training grind became a memory yesterday for Sammy Angott, former world lightweight champion, and Jimmy McDaniels, California welterweight, who are to clash in the feature ten-round bout tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- The result of yesterday's national elections was construed today by grain traders as an indication of continued governmental price support. This led to sufficient short covering and professional buying to push rye futures up to a new high in about two weeks, despite profit-taking and selling by a commission house that frequently acts for a Northwestern cash concern.

Gen. Tomoyuki Yamashita, new Japanese commander in the Philippines, pledged a last-ditch defense yesterday as both the Tokyo radio and the Domei agency declared that "the future of Japan" rested on his ability to repel the invading armies and thwart the Allies' threat to Japan's vital north-south sea communications.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- A joint statement issued through the American consulate general and the United States War Shipping Administration said today that Australian brides of United States servicemen who travel to the United States must be prepared to accept the accommoda tion provided for United States Army and Navy personnel.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 8 -- The Belgian Government's financial policy has led to a slight drop in the prices of consumer goods, though it is still too early to ascertain the full measure of this success. Prices are bound to remain high as long as there is a dearth of merchandise and raw materials, according to a Government expert on economic affairs.

Importers of Panama hats are looking for the inflationary price trend that recently developed in Ecuador to be submerged as a result of the Office of Price Administration ceiling action effective yesterday.
The tragic irony of Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's recent relief is that the strategy he backed in Burma may be, at last, on the eve of fulfillment.

HYDE PARK, Nov. 8 -- President Roosevelt said in a statement tonight that what is "really important" about the election results is that "we have again demonstrated to the world that democracy is a living, vital force; that our faith in American institutions is unshaken, that conscience and not force is the source of power in the government of man."
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted by the French Press Agency and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Creation of an organization known as the "Veteran's Advertising Council" to aid in mobilizing the country for post-war and peace problems was proposed yesterday by Edward N. Scheiberling, national commander of the American Legion, at a meeting of Ad Men's Post 209 of the Legion at the Advertising Club.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- President Roosevelt is expected by farm leaders to stand pat -- at least until the end of the war -- on present farm policies and the top personnel in farm and food agencies.

Operations of the Childs Company and its subsidiaries in the first nine months of this year resulted in a net profit of $741,680 after all charges, according to the report of the trustee, issued to stockholders yesterday. In the corresponding period of 1943 the profit was $491,605.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, in his first interview since his arrival in Chungking to succeed Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, described the military situation in China as unfavorable "but not irretrievable," and he made it clear that he would not interfere in Chinese politics in any way.

Your editorial of Nov. 4 on the tragedy in Rumania deserves very serious thought, as it concerns a vital issue. We all seem to agree that victory and peace depend wholly on unity and real understanding between our country, Great Britain and Russia.
BOSTON, Nov. 8 -- With the majesty of the Roman Catholic ritual, the Most Rev. Richard J. Cushing ascended to his throne today as Archbishop of Boston.

Directors of the New York Central Railroad Company, at a meeting held here yesterday, voted to call for redemption on Dec. 27 at 102 1/2 and accrued interest, all of the company's outstanding fifteen-year secured 3 1/4 per cent bonds, due on May 1, 1952.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 8 -- The Swedish Academy's Nobel Committee met today to choose the winner of this year's literature prize. Three American writers are to the fore in the advance guessing -- John Steinbeck, Willa Cather and Ernest Hemingway.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Labor eaders who commented on the election results today hailed the e-election of President Roosevelt as a victory for labor's aims and aspirations.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- The proposal of New Zealand and Australia for a global corporation to own and operate all international commercial airplanes and facilities was eloquently proposed and just as eloquently buried today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in English from Chungking and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:
DETROIT, Nov. 8 -- Governor Dewey continued tonight to hold a slim lead over President Roosevelt in Michigan as nearly all the State's 3,843 precincts were reported.

Dr. Joseph J. Schwartz, European chairman of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, has left the United States for Switzerland to resume direction of the committee's activities abroad, the organization announced yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 8 -- Breaking Roosevelt's twelve-year grip in the closest State contest in half a century, Gov. Dewey has apparently won Ohio's twenty-five electoral votes with a popular majority of about 20,000.

BOSTON, Nov. 8 -- The New England States ran close to the expected pattern in yesterday's election with the exception of Massachusetts, which named a Democratic Governor, brought in a split in other State offices and enhanced today the prestige of Governor Saltonstall as a Republican leader.

Crosby T. Smith has been appointed trust officer of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, it was announced yesterday. He returned recently from service overseas as a major in the Ninth Air Force and on Oct. 16 was reap pointed assistant trust officer, the title he held before he entered military service in May, 1942.
Puccini's "Manon Lescaut," with Dorothy Kirsten in the title role, will open the New York City Center Opera Company's third season at 8:15 tonight at the Center, 131 West Fifty-fifth Street.
LONDON, Nov. 8 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin:
Millinery and diamonds met in a sparkling fashion duet yesterday noon in the Cotillion Room of the Hotel Pierre. The hats were the work of Helene Garnell, the jewels were from Van Cleef Arpels.
PARIS, Nov. 8 -- Here are some random notes on the current mode, based on visits to the openings of the chief couturiers.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Gov. Henry F. Schricker, the only Democrat to win State office when Wendell L. Willkie carried Indiana four years ago, conceded defeat today in his race for the United States Senate.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- Although President Roosevelt failed to win a plurality yesterday in any of the eighteen towns and six cities of Westchester County, he received a strong vote from soldiers and sailors, in some districts exceeding the war ballot vote given to Governor Dewey.

The returning veteran passes through a critical transition period during which he is neither a civilian nor a service man, but a "man from Mars, a stranger in a strange land," who needs expert guidance, it was declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 8 (AP) -- West Virginia added up its 1944 election returns tonight with President Roosevelt secure in a 70,000-vote majority and a lone Republican among the major office winners.

Production of complete portable lamps under spot authorization is being hampered by the inability of producers to obtain rayon and taffeta for shades outside the black market, a spokesman for the industry charged yesterday. Efforts of the Office of Price Administration to "scotch" this market, it was said, have proven of little value as far as shade manufacturers are concerned.

The official opening at Georg Jensen's decorating department yesterday afternoon of a permanent showing of Dorothy Liebes' hand-woven fabrics rounds out a unique type of decorating service started by the store a few months ago.

NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- Augustus W. Bennett, Newburgh lawyer, carried Rockland County by 7,383 votes against Representative Hamilton Fish, with the result that the Republican party in Rockland is in open revolt and may not be consolidated until next year when new committeemen will be elected.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- President Roosevelt is expected to participate in a number of important conferences in Europe on the conduct of the war and the planning of the peace before he takes the oath of office for a fourth term on Jan. 20.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Standard Gas and Electric Company amended today for the second time its recapitalization plan pending before the Securities and Exchange Commission by eliminating the $200 of new debentures in the proposed distribution to holders of each $1,000 of outstanding notes and debentures and substituting $200 cash.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Brig. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler received today from Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, the Legion of Merit for "exceptionally meritorious conduct in the performance of outstanding service."

James A. Farley, who refrained from making any comment during the Presidential campaign, was a guest and speaker at a dinner of the Jewelry and Allied Trade Division of the New York War Fund campaign at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night, and, during the course of his remarks for the War Fund, said he believed that the United States was all right.

ALBANY, Nov. 8 (AP) -- An appeal for tightening of administrative policies to preclude "mustering-out pay" to war-duration civilian employes who do not intend to work after the war was made today by the Citizens Public Expenditure Survey.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- It is a significant sign of the Communist attitude toward Gen. Charles de Gaulle that L'Humanite, Communist newspaper, today does not even publish the news of General de Gaulle's pardon for Maurice Thorez, French Communist leader who was convicted of desertion from the French Army in 1939 and is now in Moscow.

OTTAWA, Nov. 8 -- Of the 750,000 men in Canada's armed services, all but 68,000 are volunteers, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King said tonight, explaining the manpower situation that has led to a popular demand that all home defense men should be compulsorily sent overseas.
