POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was up and about early in the Hyde Park homestead, presiding at the breakfast table and speeding parting guests, while the President and the rest of the family got their beauty sleep after the endurance contest of the previous night.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 8 -- The attention of Chileans, more than on any previous occasion, was concentrated on the election in the United States, with thousands crowding the newspapers all night or clustered around public loudspeakers listening to the results.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 8 -- Claustrophobia, springing from the growing realization that "the historic lesson that positional or fortress warfare invariably tends to impress the defenders," was the new bugbear raised for the German home front by Lieut. Gen. Kurt Dittmar in an analysis of the military situation broadcast last night.

While the Redskins have not exactly pinned back the ears of Brooklyn's Tigers in two encounters this season, George Preston Marshall's stalwarts, locked as they are in a first-place tie with the Eagles for top Eastern honors in the National Football League, are heavily favored to win Sunday at Ebbets Field.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that the cotton crop this year was 12,320,000 500-pound bales. This compared with 11,953,000 bales indicated a month ago, 11,427,000 bales produced last year and a ten-year, 1933-42, average production of 12,455,000 bales.
The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company ordered a dividend of 50 cents a common share, payable Dec. 1. The current dividend will bring 1944 payments to $2.50, compared with $2 in 1943.

LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 9 -- Berlin reported last night that a great Russian winter offensive was "directly imminent" and that the offensive, perhaps the last winter drive of the war, was expected to flame into action within a few days with the resumption of the Red Army's frontal assault into East Prussia.

Just as in Germany, the masters of Japan are desperately striving to keep up with military and industrial demands in the face of continued setbacks and the accelerated shrinkage of Japan's Greater Asia Co-Prosperity sphere.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- Georges Suarez, editor in chief of Aujourdhui, a collaborationist paper founded in Paris during the Nazi occupation, will be shot at dawn tomorrow, his plea for pardon having been rejected by the commission that advises Gen. Charles de Gaulle, President of the Provisional Government on such matters, it was announced tonight.

A group headed by Hemphill, Noyes Co. will offer today to the public $3,400,000 of the Pittsburgh Coke and Chemical Company's first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds, due on Nov. 1, 1964, at 99 1/2 and accrued interest. The company was formerly known as Pittsburgh Coke and Iron Company.

The Republican party emerged from the first election held under the reapportionment it had feared with firmer control of both Houses of the State Legislature than it has had in years. A final recheck on the returns showed last night that the party had added five to its Assembly majority and had picked up four of the five new seats in the enlarged Senate.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Senator Harry S. Truman spent most of today receiving friends and reading congratulatory messages upon his election as Vice President and made plans to return to Washington Sunday to resume his Senatorial duties.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday the granting of a temporary increase in rates of the Brooklyn Borough Gas Company, amounting to an average rise of slightly less than 10 cents a month to the company's 90,000 consumers in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Women will be stronger in numbers in the coming Congress.

Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, in a telegram of congratulation sent to President Roosevelt at the White House last night, declared that in returning Mr. Roosevelt to the Presidency for another term, the American people were "but expressing in their way what every people in every land feels regarding your vision and passionate concern for the common men."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- The time is coming when thousands of American bombers will visit Japan daily, Gen. Henry H. Arnold said tonight a few hours after Tokyo announced that perhaps millions of civilians would be evacuated from eleven of Japan's papier mache cities as a precaution against anticipated large-scale American raids.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- The Germans claimed today to have been bombarding London for several weeks with their V-2 weapon, reported through Swedish sources to be a long-range rocket projectile. Tonight Berlin began to dress the Nazi High Command an nouncement with a lurid story of the new robot's power and the devastation it was allegedly causing here, much as the foe built up the V-1 flying bomb for his own people.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Addition of passenger automobiles and civilian planes to the list of items which could be manufactured under the "spot" authorization plan is under study by the War Production Board. No immediate production would be expected, but the move would clear away obstacles to piecemeal reconversion of the two respective industries when machines, parts and labor finally become available.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 -- With President Roosevelt an obvious winner in Pennsylvania by a comfortable margin, voters centered their main interest today in the nip-and-tuck race between Representative Francis J. Myers and Senator James J. Davis, which is not likely to be decided until the soldier vote is counted on Nov. 22.

Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, Resident Commissioner of the Philippine Commonwealth to the United States, talked yesterday about the reopening of public schools in Tacloban and other liberated areas of Leyte, which had previously been announced by Gen. Douglas MacArthur.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Greece's plight, now that the Germans have left the country, was detailed by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden in the House of Commons today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- An announcement by the War Production Board of another thirty-day holiday during which distillers of liquor may turn out potable spirits is expected within ten days. The holiday, or "furlough" as distillers prefer to term it, has been forecast for some time and, according to officials, is justified in view of the rise in stocks of industrial alcohol for war uses.

While marked shortages of toys are foreseen for the latter part of the Christmas selling period, retail volume this year is estimated as likely to come within 10 per cent of the $220,000,000 figure in 1943, trade reports here yesterday indicated.
TROUPING for the troops is a fashion in this war. Hundreds of entertainers are doing it, and little books of reminiscence may become as common as war babies.

Five hundred million dollars will be distributed to 7,000,000 Christmas Club members by 4,800 banking and savings institutions and other organizations during the Post-War Prosperity Week, starting Nov. 27, according to an estimate released yesterday by Herbert F. Rawll, founder and president of Christmas Club, a corporation.

Purchasers of billions of dollars of automobiles, radios and other durable goods to become available as soon as wartime needs are filled will be able to buy on the lowest rates ever offered, Arthur O. Dietz, president of the Universal C.I.T. Credit Corporation, said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 8 -- Veteran infantrymen of Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's American Third Army today smashed eastward across the water-soaked hills of Lorraine, crossing the River Seille and driving the enemy from twelve small towns and villages in a swift lunge forward.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 8 -- The American election results were learned here too late this morning to be the subject of more than cautious editorial comment elaborately bowing to both candidates. Early reports of tomorrow's press, however, show a tendency toward "explaining" President Roosevelt's victory.

More than 1,000 apartments found and 400 applications to fill was the score announced yesterday for the City Vacancy Listing Bureau after its first seven weeks. Its director, Joseph Platzker, assistant Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, broadcasting over WNYC from the bureau's headquarters at the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office Pershing Square Information Center, characterized the search for medium-priced housing accommodations as "frantic, like a treasure hunt of old."

ROME, Nov. 8 -- It is not surprising that the American soldiers who took the election of a fourth-term President with vast disinterest should have utterly forgotten that today was the second anniversary of an event far more important to the Mediterranean world.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- The stock markets here were further cheered today by the result of the Presidential election. Although business as a whole was not active, the general tone was good. The gilt edge market showed further gains under the influence of the new Exchequer bond issue.

The election returns make it clear that Mr. Roosevelt has achieved something more than a sectional triumph, and that, in a very real sense, he has won a national victory. He has carried all of New England with the familiar exceptions of Maine and Vermont. He has swept the entire mid-Atlantic seaboard. He has held the South.

After two years of research, Fred G. Clark and R.S. Rimanoczy of the "Wake Up, America!" radio program have completed a 39-page book on economics, called "How We Live." Sales have reached 100,000 copies in advance of publication, which D. Van Nostrand has scheduled for Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Price belief was in sight today for manufacturers directed to produce stable work clothing under War Production Board regulations as the Office of Price Administration ruled producers could apply for an increase in their ceilings under terms of the so-called Vinson directive.

No complete picture of the service vote in this election can be had until the States of North Dakota, Washington and Rhode Island make their counts on Dec. 5. About all we can be sure of now is that Mr. Roosevelt would have been elected if there had been no service vote at all.

The success of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York will be such that the project will serve as "a great demonstration of what should be done for the entire country," Mayor La Guardia predicted yesterday in an address before the New York Counties Registered Nurses Association at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

Every year Hitler and his Nazis used to celebrate on this day the anniversary of what they hailed as their first great victory -- the abortive beer-hall putsch of Munich on Nov. 9, 1923. The putsch was a farcical failure because some Germans had the gumption to oppose it, and when the bullets began to fly, Der Fuehrer fled.

Here is one woman who has definitely decided to prepare herself for taking a part in politics or, preferably government, since the mud-slinging and currying of favor that are ramps in political campaigns disgust me.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 8 -- New Jersey's sixteen electoral votes went into the Democratic column tonight by a safe margin when unofficial returns from all but eleven of the State's 3,657 election districts gave President Roosevelt a margin of 27,000 over Governor Dewey in yesterday's balloting.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Another Beveridge plan, this time to provide full employment in a free society by the socialization of demand but not production, is set forth in a book that will appear tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A proposal to ban closed union shops apparently had won approval in Florida in Tuesday's election, and a similar measure was ahead in Arkansas, but voters in California rejected such an amendment.

The most indignant prisoner in the line-up at Police Headquarters yesterday was Frank Hayes, 57 years old, who described himself as a barber, but for whom police records show fifty-one arrests and thirty-nine convictions on various offenses over the last thirty years.
Starting today, ceiling prices for oranges and other citrus fruits sold in the New York metropolitan area will be set on a pound basis.
Don Enrique A. Jimenez, the Panamanian Ambassador, and Senora de Jimenez have arrived from Washington and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 8 (AP) -- This is to introduce Young Arnold (Chuckin' Tuck) Tucker of the Army football team to the Notre Dame forces, to the 72,000 spectators expected to see their clash in New York City's Yankee Stadium on Saturday and to other gridiron fans.

President Roosevelt received a higher proportion of the soldier votes tallied in New York City than of the civilian vote, according to a compilation made yesterday. The same situation appeared to prevail in other sections of the country, although the soldier and civilian ballots were separated in only a few isolated instances.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 8 -- Brazilians rejoiced today over the re-election of President Roosevelt, all the morning newspapers carrying editorials and banner headlines. "Superb Example of Democratic Faith," one headline said. Never before had a Presidential election in the United States so thrilled Brazilians, who almost gave the impression that Mr. Roosevelt was one of their own, whose election was vital to their national pride.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Bill Klem, the Old Arbitrator, put a word or so today into the current debate over the relative baseball-playing ability of Slats Marion, the Cardinals' fancy shortstop, and John Honus Wagner, the Flying Dutchman of former days.

At the close of business on Oct. 31 there were 1,246 stock issues aggregating 1,481,150,942 shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange, with a total market value of $53,086,843,093. This compared with 1,242 issues aggregating 1,480,633,821 shares and a market value of $52,929,771,152 on Sept. 30.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Communique 214:

Custom tailors believe that with expectations of a longer war there will be little opportunity for further easing in men's and boys' clothing order L-224. Recent elimination of some curbs, it was pointed out yesterday, are about as much as can be expected with war prospects as they are.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, Nov. 8 (AP) --Eleven Japanese planes raided American-held Saipan and Tinian Islands in the Marianas soon after midnight yesterday without inflicting damage or casualties, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Nov. 8 -- Breaking its tradition as the only Democratic stronghold of Nassau County, this city voted yesterday to send a Republican Assemblyman to the Legislature and turned down a new charter for the city which had been supported by the Democratic administration.

Voting this year was "only the beginning" of a citizen's duty, for an all-out effort to win the peace must start immediately, Edward N. Scheiberling, national commander of the American Legion, declared yesterday. He outlined a program of mobilizing for peace in an address at a joint luncheon of the Advertising Club and Advertising Men's Post 209, American Legion, at the club's headquarters, 23 Park Avenue.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- The United States Eighth Air Force went gunning for the Luftwaffe today, but the Luftwaffe was not having any of it. With the vast Leuna synthetic oil works at Merseburg, usually defended with desperation, as the main target, 350 Flying Fortresses and Liberators took along an escort of 850 fighters.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The police announced today that two Jewish prisoners had confessed that they had assassinated Lord Moyne, British Minister of State Resident in the Middle East, on orders from the Stern group of extreme Jewish nationalists.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A supplement to today's communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Two groups of Government engineers agreed today on some phases of a proposed billion dollar water development program for the Missouri River basin, but left to Congress the major decisions.

Everyone knows there's an acute theatre shortage these days. Despite the scarcity Trebuhs (that's the name of the Shubert realty subsidiary spelled backwards) has sold Daly's Sixty-third Street to William Brandt, who said yesterday he would take possession on Nov. 17.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 9 to 15 points net higher on active months than Monday's final quotations, influenced by some new outside buying and price-fixing in near months against sales of cotton to Spain.

CHICAGO, Ill., Nov. 8 -- Adolf A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State and chairman of the United States delegation at the International Civil Aviation Conference, returned today to resume negotiations on behalf of Washington's program for free competition in the post-war world airways.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 8 -- Latin America as a whole is well pleased with the results of yesterday's Presidential election, which has been watched this year with closer attention than any similar event in the past.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Administration leaders were confident tonight that the chances of Senate approval of the Dumbarton Oaks security organization proposals in the next session of Congress had been greatly enhanced as a result of yesterday's election.

Early election returns from those States and communities which voted on proposed new bond financing indicate that most of the propositions will be approved. Financing aggregating approximately $252,000,000 was placed for approval before voters at the Tuesday election, but the fate of only a few of the proposals is yet known.

LONDON, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- Late tonight, after a steady stream of propaganda regarding V-2, German radio stations broadcast that tomorrow morning's newspapers would advise the Germans to check their gas masks regularly, keep them clean and dry and make sure they fitted well.

WITH UNITED STATES THIRD ARMY, Nov. 8 -- In a move designed to straighten the line in the Metz-Nancy sector of this front, Maj. Gen. Manton S. Eddy's Twelfth Corps launched an attack early this morning in the wake of one of the severest artillery barrages of the war. Advances were made all along the line despite stiff resistance and knee-deep mud.

Incomplete returns of Tuesday's national election, but much nearer to the final totals than those that were available on election night, indicated that the President was chosen for a fourth term by an electoral majority and popular vote reduced from 1940, when he broke the two-term tradition that was more than a century old.

One of the heaviest fines in the history of the Brooklyn Magistrates' Court was levied yesterday against the grocery concern of Thomas Roulston, Inc., which was charged with 421 specific violations of Office of Price Administration ceiling price regulations.

More accidents in the home occurred during October, 1944, than in October, 1943, Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins, New York City Commissioner of Health, said yesterday in opening "Home Safety Week." Fatalities from such accidents for the first ten months of this year, Commissioner Stebbins revealed, totaled 1,399.

It takes ingenuity to conduct an American-girl beauty contest in the drab surroundings of a German prisoner-of-war camp, but the men in our Army have done it. The National Council of the Young Men's Christian Association reported yesterday the outcome of such a contest held at Oflag 64, a prisoner-of-war camp in Poland, where 1,000 American Army officers are captives of the Germans.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 -- President Roosevelt's victory on the West Coast was emphasized today in mounting election returns, which showed the Democratic sweep in California to be assuming landslide proportions, reflected the probable defeat of Washington's Republican Governor, Arthur B. Langlie, and even gave the President a lead in Oregon, where seasoned analysts of election figures early this morning had put the State tentatively in the Dewey column.

The results of the national elections failed yesterday to alter the course of the stock market, and, although prices tended to weaken after the opening, the list steadied in the afternoon. Comment by brokerage houses for the last two weeks had indicated the probability of no change in the national Administration, therefore no demonstrations for or against the results were found in the post-election session.

New York University's football squad has lost two more players, it was discovered yesterday. Ed Bizlewicz and Bill Ocenasek are out for the remainder of the season. Bizlewicz, regular center, hurt his right arm in the Bucknell game last Saturday and it has not responded to treatment.
The Japanese Domei agency "made public without comment" yesterday the full text of Premier Marshal Joseph Stalin's Monday speech, the Tokyo radio reported.
ROME, Nov. 8 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- W.L. Clayton, Surplus War Property Administrator, reported today that $465,207,000 in surplus property was on hand as of Sept. 30 and that disposals amounted to $85,007,000 in the four months ended on that date.

The most severe shortage of candy since the beginning of the war is now being evidenced, representatives of the confectionery trade agree. They assert the scarcity will last through the holidays, if not for the duration.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 -- After three days of rest to recover from the bruising effects of successive games with Navy and Michigan, the Pennsylvania football team went back to work today in preparation for the coming of Columbia to Franklin Field on Saturday.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 8 -- The Government issued a decree today establishing strict control over Axis firms operating in Argentina. Special Government controllers will be placed in their offices with the duty of seeing that all firms' commercial, industrial or financial activities are supervised "in an integrated manner."

COLFAX, Calif., Nov. 8 -- A section of The Challenger, all-coach train of the Southern Pacific Railroad westbound from Chicago to San Francisco, left the tracks near here before dawn today and nine persons were killed and more than seventy-five injurd.

Charging black-market operations involving 150,000 pounds of steel wool between October, 1943, and March, 1944, in violation of War Production Board priorities regulations, the A. Tozzini Tile Works, Inc., 103 Park Avenue, Peter Bratti, president, and the Hi-Glo Products and Langport Tile Company, Inc., 1452 Webster Avenue, the Bronx, owned and operated by Isidore Thorn and Jerome Cohen, have been suspended by the WPB for a three-month period.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Merchant Mariner Bill Paschal, the rapid Georgian who had to be slowed down to hit the right National Football League pace, is back doing business at the same old stand -- on top of the league's ground-gaining column.

SALEM. N.H., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Eugene Beecher's Rose Mountain, with Trainer Johnny Convey up, today won the first running of a special race for retired jockeys at Rockingham Park. Rose Mountain, 13-10 favorite, survived a stretch drive against Easy Blend, ridden by Herb Fisher. Aldridge was third.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- The biggest news in Paris today was President Roosevelt's re-election. It might even be called the biggest war news, for the French regard the apparent endorsement of Mr. Roosevelt's foreign policy by the American people as a guarantee that the military victory will be consolidated by a secure peace.

The Society of American Etchers will open its twenty-ninth annual exhibition tonight with a preview in the galleries of the National Academy, 1083 Fifth Avenue. The show opens to the public tomorrow and will remain through Dec. 5.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 8 -- With the national and State election of 1944 in Connecticut now a matter of history, political observers are scanning some of the unusual features of an election which, on the whole, ran fairly true to form.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 8 -- The Japanese appear ready to take the initiative from their pivot on the Ormoc Plateau, on the west coast of Leyte just south of the north coast, where their last organized stand may be made on this island.

President Roosevelt has escaped by a wide margin the misfortune that befell President Wilson in the close election of 1916: instead of losing his majority in the House of Representatives, he has added a comfortable margin to it. In the Senate there was never the least chance, as this newspaper pointed out, that the Republicans could win the twenty-four seats in thirty-five contests that would have been needed to give them control of the Senate.

Selma Kramer, pianist, was heard in recital last night at Carnegie Hall. She was warmly received by a large audience in a program which had as its chief offerings the infrequently presented sonata, Op. 1, in C major of Brahms and a Chopin group composed of the Ballade in F minor, the posthumous Nocturne in C sharp minor, and the "Tarantelle."

In their concentration on election returns Tuesday night many New Yorkers may have forgotten to put out their waste paper for yesterday's weekly collection and that, according to Deputy Sanitation Commissioner William J. Powell, could be the reason why a total of only 379 tons, or fifteen tons less than the preceding week, was picked up by Sanitation Department trucks.

Vera Appleton and Michael Field, duo-pianists, gave their first recital of the season at Town Hall last night, in a program which listed several contemporary and several rarely heard pieces. The major work was a Toccata by Anis Fuleihan, which was heard for the first time.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A strike of 600 trainmen on two electric lines which serve 75,000 Chicago commuters and the huge naval training center at Great Lakes, Ill., has been set for 4 A.M. Friday, a representative of the lines said he was notified tonight.

The nation's gasoline stocks at the close of last week amounted to 78,409,000 barrels, consisting of 13,396,000 of unfinished, 39,596,000 of civilian-grade automotive and 25,417,000 of aviation, military and blending stocks, currently indeterminate as to ultimate use, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Nov. 8 -- Our front-line troops have lost the village of Kommerscheidt, whence they had been launching their repeated attempts to retake Schmidt, a thousand yards to the southeast.

No more Poles are left in Warsaw, the Polish Telegraph Agency reported yesterday in a dispatch from London, quoting the resistance radio inside Poland. The broadcast said that the Germans, carrying out a plan they announced last month, had deported more than 1,000,000 Warsaw inhabitants.
LONDON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Britons interpreted President Roosevelt's re-election today as a triumph for internationalism in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Certificates of label approval, authorizing the marketing of prominent whisky brands of different character than those on which the brand names were originally approved, were issued by the United States Treasury Department today to a number of distillers.

After seventy-four years of uninterrupted and exclusively masculine peace, the Lotos Club, 110 West Fifty-seventh Street, dedicated yesterday the first women's lounge and card room in the club's history. Leonard Liebling, editor of The Musical Courier, presided.

WITH UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY in Germany, Nov. 8 (AP) -- With the Presidential election decided, the strict Army censorship that has prevented any sort of poll or questioning of the troops on its political aspects was relaxed today.

Complete disruption of textile distribution and elmination of fabric styling will result from any pricing order which utilizes gray goods prices only as a basis for computing the markup of converted fabrics, downtown converters asserted yesterday.

Coach Lou Little yesterday continued to experiment with the Columbia backfield in preparation for the Penn game in Philadelphia on Saturday. Throughout the ninety-minute workout at Baker Field, Little made switches until he finally chose a quartet that will probably take the field against the Red and Blue eleven.

LONDON, Nov. 8 (Reuter) -- Leaders of all political parties, Conservative, Labor, Communist, Liberal and Independent, all expressed the greatest satisfaction today at President Roosevelt's reelection.

With the aid of the American Labor party in some instances and of the Liberal party in others, the Democrats made almost a clean sweep of judicial offices at stake in New York City in Tuesday's elections, according to tabulations completed yesterday.

With the War Production Board currently conducting a survey of the delivery situation on the Army field jacket procurement of some 5,000,000 garments there seems to be little belief that time lost to date, due mainly to lack of labor, can be made up in the future unless the Government channels needed workers to producers' plants, industry spokesmen said yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 8 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is preparing to film the James M. Cain novel "The Postman Always Rings Twice" with John Garfield and Lana Turner starred. The company has owned screen rights to the book for several years but has held it from production due to censorship difficulties.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Thursday, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The United States Twenty-fourth Infantry Division fought in mud and slime yesterday along the winding road to Ormoc against

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Neil Dalton, former assistant to the president of the Louisville Courier Journal and Times Company, has been appointed to succeed George W. Healy Jr., who retired today as director of the domestic branch of the Office of War Information.
Ted Atkinson made a one-man show of the Victory meeting conducted at Belmont Park yesterday. The veteran jockey rode in all seven races and piloted his way first past the wire five times.

DETROIT, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- Air operations against Germany will be continued until Germany gives up, Gen. H.H. Arnold told members of the Economic Club today. Although badly beaten, the Luftwaffe was struggling to make a comeback, he added.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- Japanese troops launched three violent attacks on encircled Kweilin and appeared to be making some headway in the eastern and western suburbs, the Chinese High Command announced today, while other enemy troops to the south captured Hsiujen and were developing a new thrust toward Liuchow.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A United States Army Forces in China communique:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 178:

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Representative Clare Booth Luce, successful in her campaign to return to Congress from Connecticut's Fourth District despite direct aid given to her opponent by President Roosevelt and Vice President Wallace, said today that "the purge that failed leaves us without rancor or malice."

The Ballet International last night presented a program at the International Theatre consisting of "Swan Lake," "Sebastian" and "Constantia." Of the last two opinions have already been expressed in these columns, but last night's "Swan Lake" was the first to be seen by this reviewer, what with conflicting performances elsewhere and numerous changes of the present company's schedule.

Riding high on the electoral vote landslide for President Roosevelt in Tuesday's election, Democratic candidates for Congress swept forward today to what amounted to the most impressive victory they had scored since 1934 and the heyday of the New Deal.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 8 -- Suffolk County Democratic leaders, scanning the election picture today, found cause for elation only in the State and national results, while their political opposites in the county's dominant and strongly knit Republican organization discovered a bit more than cold comfort in that party's complete sweep of this Eastern Long Island area's 196 election districts.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Christopher T. Chenery's Hornbeam turned on the heat in the stretch to take the Masked General Handicap before 9,000 race-goers at Pimlico today. The 4year-old son of Whiskaway was a going-away winner with Doug Dodson up.

ROME, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Polish troops "continue to make good progress" south of Forli, near the eastern end of the Italian battle front, the Allied command announced today, but the Germans still clung to shattered buildings on the Forli airfield.

President Roosevelt's sweep of his home State of New York was not only a great personal victory for him but also a decided victory for Sidney Hillman, chairman of both the Political Action Committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the American Labor party, and the leaders of the newly organized Liberal party.

Since there was no Velasquez at hand to paint the scene, it remained for THE NEW YORK TIMES camera man to step into the breach. And he did it very successfully in yesterday's photo of the children of Breda, in the Netherlands, welcoming the Allied troops as they entered that former Nazi stronghold on the river Merk.

ROME, Nov. 8 -- The news of President Roosevelt's triumph was received here today with relief and satisfaction, but what most impressed the Italians was the fact that, in the midst of a great war, the Americans could give such an example of democratic procedure.
WITH THE CANADIAN FIRST ARMY (Reuter) -- Lieut. Gen. H.D.G. Crerar was back again today in command of the Canadian First Army after almost a month's illness.
City College's basketball team will see action in sixteen games this season, Anthony E. Orlando, manager of athletics, announced yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- The Finnish Government struggled today to solve a cabinet crisis apparently involving Finnish relations with Russia and unconfirmed reports said Juho K. Paasikivi, pro-Russian former Premier, might head a new goverment.

Analysts of the election returns are already busy, and for a while their deductions, with statistical proofs they have compiled themselves, will share whatever public interest there is in such matters with the alibis of those who guessed wrong: for instance, that the next House of Representatives would have a Republican majority, whatever the outcome of the Presidential contest.

As a result of "guarded pronouncements" by food manufacturers, who have given indications that hundreds of new products will be available in the post-war period, wholesale grocers are watching carefully for new lines offering reasonably general sale through grocery channels, the National-American Wholesale Grocers' Association reported yesterday.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in English by the Free Yugoslav radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Nazi propagandists released yesterday for foreign consumption a flow of election "commentary" that took the line that President Roosevelt's victory had come as no surprise to German leaders and that the German General Staff had made its military plans on the assumption of his re-election, the Office of War Information reported.

Following are comments from leading newspapers of the country on the result of the Presidential election as gathered by The Associated Press. A notable feature of the expression of opinion is the emphasis put on the unity of the people despite the stress of the quadrennial conflict.

Investment bankers and investors have a welcome breathing spell this week from the volume of new corporate financing that has been pouring steadily into the market for two months. This week probably will be the lightest in new financing since midsummer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Diplomats, Government executives and other prominent persons, including Acting Secretary of State Stettinius, turned out tonight for the Soviet Embassy's annual reception celebrating the Russian Revolution.

Governor Dewey said yesterday that he declined "even to speculate" on the 1948 campaign. He made the statement in a press conference in his suite at the Hotel Roosevelt, when asked whether he might make another try for the Presidency.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 8 -- President Roosevelt's election was welcomed unanimously in Mexico. It was pointed out that the main reason for this was the fact that Mr. Roosevelt, as far as Mexicans are concerned, has been the vigorous supporter of the good-neighbor policy, which has brought about the closest relations between the Governments of the two neighboring powers in recent times.

EAST GRANBY, Conn., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Five Army fliers lost their lives and seven others were injured when a B-24 Liberator bomber crashed tonight in a pasture in the south part of the town, State Police Commissioner Edward J. Hickey said.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
Following are summaries of Tuesday's election results in all the States. Detailed figures of the Presidential vote in each case will be found in a table elsewhere.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- The news of President Roosevelt's re-election produced editorial admission by British newspapers tonight that they had wanted to see him elected.

Despite their sad showing in their National Hockey League games to date, the Rangers hopefully await their clash with the Maple Leafs tonight, a clash which will mark the first appearance of the Blue Shirts on their home ice at Madison Square Garden this season.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The pre-war nickel cigar is coming back, but you will pay 7 1/2 cents for it.

The Maria Moors Cabot Gold Medal for distinguished achievement in advancing international friendship in the Western Hemisphere was awarded to three Latin-American newspaper editors at the sixth annual convocation held yesterday afternoon in the Low Memorial Library of Columbia University.

" San Diego, I Love You," a Universal picture starring Louise Allbritton and Jon Hall, is the new attraction opening today at Loew's State. Among the featured players are Edward Everett Horton, Eric Blore, Buster Keaton, Florence Lake and Chester Clute.

Pollution of fishing waters is expected to be one of the most important of the problems that will be discussed at the annual New York State Conservation Council convention, scheduled for Bear Mountain, N.Y., on Dec. 1 and 2. Herman Forster, the organization's president, says that each pollution problem is different, all are complex and a lot of study and fact-finding are necessary to keep sportsmen from going off half-cocked on the subject.
Colen-Gruhn Company, New York, distributors of Majestic radios, has been appointed a distributor for the Royal vacuum cleaner line manufactured by P.A. Geier Company of Cleveland.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
Following are summaries of Tuesday's election results in all the States. Detailed figures of the Presidential vote in each case will be found in a table elsewhere.

Yesterday's communiqu6, ae ,brom/ast lrorm Moscow to the Boviet lYion and reporteg by the Ireqtera aommnictio lTommiton: During Nov. 9, between the Rivers Tisza and Danube, our troops fought actions and occupied more than fifty inhabited localities, including the large inhabited localities of Zrezoecsat, Xgriei, GeleJ, Mezoekeresztes, Szentiatvan, Egerfarmos, ?fezoetarkany, Besenyoetelek, Poroezlo, Koemloe, Tiszanana, Ils-Koere, Bessenszoeg, Rekas, Cegledbercel, Trsa-and Alberti, and the railways stations of rezoecsat, Poroszlo. Kis-Koere and Zrsa.

A seasonal decline in loans and further selling of Government securities during the week ended on Wednesday was revealed yesterday in the statement of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York based on figures given by the sixteen reporting member banks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- (AP) -- Uruguay, in urging that the League of Nations be recognized to handle post-war world security, voiced the first official criticism of the tentative Dumbarton Oaks plan by a small nation.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Friday, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A communique:

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, France, Nov. 9 -- It cost one American soldier $1,100 for the privilege of participating in the liberation of Paris and at the rate he's now obliged to pay off his debt he will be all square with the United States Government in about eight years.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- H.J. Symington, president of Trans-Canada Air Lines and acting chairman of the Ottawa delegation to the international civil aviation conference, urged the United States today to agree to the British-Canadian proposal for an international air authority with regulatory powers on the basis of Canadian compromise suggestions favoring competition on routes and fares.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- "Victory in the war and the restoration of popular sovereignty represent the aim and, I will add, the end of our task," said Gen. Charles de Gaulle today in addressing the new Consultative Assembly that will begin its work tomorrow.

Ted Atkinson, who at 104 pounds doesn't weigh as much as one of those shells they put in a cannon, was dynamite again yesterday at Belmont Park, where he added a triple to his five winners on Wednesday to draw nearer than ever to his cherished goal as America's leading rider.

Jimmy McDaniels, Los Angeles welterweight who has made himself a local favorite recently, will appear in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. He will tackle Sammy Angott, Washington (Pa.) battler who once held the lightweight championship of the world.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- Following rejection last night of his plea for clemency Georges Suarez, 53-year-old editor of the collaborationist newspaper, Aujourd'hui, faced the firing squad this morning in the moat of Montrouge Fort in the suburbs of Paris. No reporters were permitted to witness his execution, but the official account emphasized that M. Suarez had died bravely.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- More warnings that victory on the European and Asiatic fronts can be achieved only by the most desperate fighting against stubborn enemies came today from Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War.

As a result of the truce in the strike of journeymen and salesmen in the fish industry, food is once more available in good quantities. According to both the Fishery Council and the Fish and Wildlife Service, deliveries yesterday totaled between 500,000 and 600,000 pounds, which is close to an average day's receipts.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 9 (AP) -- A supplement to today's communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- A plea for guarantees for small States to be incorporated in the world-wide security organization projected at the Dumbarton Oaks Conference was made in a proposal submitted on behalf of Uruguay today, when Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Acting Secretary of State, discussed the proposed organization with Ambassadors of the Latin-American republics.

Taking the witness stand in his own defense, Capt. Joseph (Joe) Gould, who was a manager of prize fighters until he entered the Army Transportation Corps two years ago, made a separate denial yesterday to each of four accusations that he violated the Ninety-sixth Article of War.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Federal Communications Commission today authorized the construction for experimental purposes of five Class 2 radio stations, two by the International Business Machines Corporation and three by General Electric Company.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Independent weakness developed in the corn market today on the Board of Trade and influenced other grains, although short covering and closing of spreads between May and July wheat resulted in the new crop months of the latter grain showing a strong undertone.

Joe Labrum, veteran Pennsylvania athletic publicist, over-stepped the bounds of hospitality yesterday by stating that the Red and Blue, which started the season so beautifully only to trip over Navy and Michigan on successive Saturdays, hopes to get back into full stride against Columbia tomorrow at Philadelphia.

American industry in the postwar period will have to live in a "cartelized world," despite the "lip service" given by other nations to the principle of free enterprise, James V. Hayes of the law firm of Donovan, Leisure, Newton Lumbard said yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The stock markets here generally were firm today, with further support for selected industrials and fresh investment of funds in gilt edge issues, which showed new gains.

BUFFALO, Nov. 9 -- A wife's breaking of a promise not to resume her pre-marital career does not give her husband sufficient ground for annulment of their marriage, Referee Thomas H. Noonan of the Supreme Court ruled today.

It is true that Nathan Bedford Forrest, the brilliant Confederate cavalry leader, attributed his success in the field to the fact that he always tried to get to the crucial spot first with the most men. It is not true, according to the author of the new biography of the general, that Forrest tried to git thar fustest with the mostest.

There was action aplenty at the Polo Grounds yesterday morning as Stout Steve Owen ran his Football Giants through the entire gamut of practice in continued preparation for Sunday's encounter with the Eagles in Philadelphia -- a highly important game for the Mara forces.

The more closely the election returns are studied, the brighter become the prospects of successful cooperation between the President and the Senate in writing a treaty which will guarantee the full participation of the United States in a new league to enforce the peace.

Premier Mohammed Maraghei Said of Iran has resigned and his resignation has been accepted by Iran's 25-year-old ruler, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, the Turkish home radio said yesterday, quoting a broadcast by the Teheran radio.

A detective's belief that the death of 4-year-old William Drach, who was found strangled on Oct. 29 in the basement of his home at 825 Eagle Avenue, the Bronx, was not caused by the boy's 8-year-old brother, Robert, won complete vindication yesterday for the latter with the arrest of a 16-year-old youth who had no motive for the crime other than to try out something he had seen in a motion picture.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- Japanese troops at dawn today opened an all-out drive to capture encircled Kweilin, while ninety miles to the southwest six Japanese columns converged on Liuchow from the north, south and east and had reached points only fifteen and twenty miles from that strategic air-base city.

Sir Roy Fedden, president of the Royal Aeronautical Society of Great Britain, in a cable to the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, made public yesterday, said the society wished to dissociate itself from the criticism of American airline personnel made by Brig. Gen. A. C. Critchley, director general of the British Overseas . Corporation, at a discussion on civil aviation held by the society on Nov. 4.
ALBANY, Nov. 9 -- Governor Dewey slipped quietly into the routine of State business today, showing no signs of rancor or depression over his defeat for the Presidency.

Victor Payne-Jennings has joined forces with Barney Klawans of the Warner Brothers' New York Staff to produce a dramatization of Emile Zola's novel, "Therese Raquin." Whether the picture company eventually would participate in the offering could not be learned.
Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National Chairman, pledged the Republican party to national unity for victory in a statement recorded yesterday for broadcasting to civilian populations overseas.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 9 (AP) -- In tip-top shape, but with little hope of upsetting mighty Army, Notre Dame's thirty-five-member football squad today began a two-day exodus to New York for Saturday's battle with the cadets at the Yankee Stadium.
HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Bob Hope says he is probably the first actor in Hollywood who ever "suspended" a studio.
EAST ISLIP, L.I., Nov. 9 -- Three Chesapeake Bay retrievers cleaned up today in the opening event of the fourteenth field trial meeting of the Labrador Retriever Club at the Timber Point Club.

Things look just about the same for the New York Rangers. Making their National Hockey League season's debut at home against the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden last night, the Blue Shirts were not up to the task of winning.
KANDY, Ceylon, Nov. 9 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The re-election of President Roosevelt despite increasing opposition of the country's newspapers since 1932 was cited today by Secretary Ickes as evidence that these newspapers were "out of step" with the people.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The last lap of the struggle against Germany may be the hardest, Prime Minister Churchill warned a Mansion House audience at the Lord Mayor's luncheon today.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The Germans continued to fill the air today with fanciful tales of their V-2 and implied it was being fired at Paris as well as London. The first note of caution crept into the bombast, however, with a Berlin military spokesman saying it was too early to judge what effect the new weapon would have on the outcome of the war.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The Government initiated another attempt today to make the London blackout a little less black, but Home Secretary Herbert Morrison's announcement that London now may use the higher standards of street lighting allowed in other parts of Britain apparently will have little effect.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- A sharp divergence of opinion between spokesmen for the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations on the President's Cost of Living Committee was indicated today when William H. Davis, chairman, submitted to the labor and industry members his proposed report to President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The War Production Board relaxed its restrictions on the quality and output of moderately priced ration-type footwear today in an effort to encourage production of grades badly needed on the retail market.
The following editorial from a leading Luxembourg newspaper should be meaningful to all and to the Americans back home:
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically from Sofia and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 9 -- Both of Buenos Aires greatest democratic daily newspapers, Nacion Prensa, this morning expressed their deep satisfaction at President Roosevelt's re-election and underlined the great lesson in practical democracy that the United States had taught all other peoples on Tuesday.

The Moscow domestic radio reported yesterday that the Soviet Embassy at Paris had protested to the French Foreign Ministry against the internement of "a considerable number" of Russian nationals in French prison camps and the "hard and sometimes downright scandalous" treatment accorded them in these camps.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The New Jersey Republican Finance Committee has reported to the House that its receipts from contributions for the period Oct. 29 to Nov. 2 were $20,235 and that expenditures were $31,140.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Four Nobel prizes, each worth approximately $29,000, were awarded today, two of them in physics going to scientists now in the United States, one in chemistry to a Hungarian now in Stockholm and one in literature to a 71-year- old Danish novelist and poet.

Representatives of the Officers Service Committee, the Navy Leagues of Manhattan and Brooklyn, the New York City Defense Recreation Committee and other organizations met yesterday and organized the Temporary Housing Council of New York City as a means of coordinating the efforts to find suitable living quarters for service men and their families.

In combat which rings the world the tempo of the air warfare of the United Nations continues to rise. While the huge B-29 Superfortresses were making the longest daylight mission ever flown by military airplanes to strike Singapore and Sumatra from a base somewhere in India, other Allied planes bombed the Bonins, Volcanoes, Marianas, Manila, Burma and Indo-China.
DETROIT, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Michigan's nineteen electoral votes for President slipped into the Democratic column tonight on the basis of unofficial returns from all but sixteen of the 3,841 precincts.

The New York Stock Exchange membership of Ernest Vail Stebbins was transferred yesterday to John Clifford Folger, president of the Washington, D.C., investment firm of Folger, Nolan Co., a partnership consisting of Mr. Folger and James Parker Nolan.

Full cooperation by the public in the Sixth War Loan drive commencing Nov. 20 was urged yesterday by Acting Mayor Newbold Morris at ceremonies in City Hall Plaza marking the first use of the "bond wagon," a mobile sales unit that will tour the city during the campaign.
LONDON, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Churchil's talk at the Lord Mayor of London's luncheon today:

The second New York War Fund campaign, started Sept. 20 and scheduled to end today, was 29 per cent shy of the $17,200,000 goal last night and Richard W. Lawrence, campaign chairman, told workers at the Hotel Roosevelt that volunteers will stay on the job until the full amount has been raised.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Almost three years of war have cost more than a half million American battle casualties -- dead, wounded, missing or prisoners.
Wesby Parker, formerly responsible for marketing Iglehart grocery specialties, has been named general sales manager of Iglehart Brothers, Inc., subsidiary of the General Foods Corporation.

ROME, Nov. 9 -- Military police have just smashed two criminal gangs whose polyglot membership included seven American and two Canadian soldiers and whose storybook adventuring over many weeks has contributed heavily to the growing uneasiness in the streets of this traditionally orderly capital.

Reflecting the new high operating revenues registered in the third quarter of this year, the net income of United Air Lines totaling $2,269,672, or $1.43 a common share, almost doubled the $1,151,741 net income for the September quarter of 1943, according to the report of W.A. Patterson, president, mailed to stockholders yesterday.

Germany will not starve this year "even if cut off from all imports," according to John M. Cassels, special assistant to the director of food programs of the Foreign Economic Administration, who returned yesterday from an overall survey of the European food situation.

There can be a great difference between the respectful revival of an old score and the re-creation of the music of a by-gone day in its composer's image. This difference was strikingly demonstrated when Pierre Monteux interpreted Beethoven's First symphony with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall.

Mrs. L. Bonnar, president of the Bonnar-Vawter Fanform Company, has purchased for occupancy the five-story dwelling at 124 East Thirty-seventh Street, near Park Avenue, from Mrs. Dora H. Weiss through the Madison Realty Company.

SYOSSET, L.I., Nov. 9 -- Robert E. Tod, retired banker, Commissioner of Immigration in New York under President Harding in 1921-23 and Navy commander at the Port of Brest during the first World War, killed himself with a pistol in his home on Burtis Lane here this morning, according to Nassau County police.

At their initial report meeting, the women's division of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York yesterday turned in $35,457 to the chairman, Mrs. Eli Whitney Debevoise. Reports from the Queens group and from the men's and special gifts' chairmen brought in an additional $18,283, making a total to date of $53,740.

As a "positive" step toward widespread revival and increase in post-war foreign trade, Swedish business men are willing to abandon uneconomic war-developed industries in favor of importations, J. Sigfrid Edstrom, chairman of the Swedish delegation to the International Business Conference, declared yesterday.

A new legal political party, the Liberal party, which may prove to be a decisive factor in next year's New York City's election, is in the making as a result of the 320,000 votes it received in New York State in last Tuesday's election.

The General Motors Corporation, one of the nation's largest producers of war materials, disclosed yesterday that it had reduced from $1,000,000,000 to $500,000,000 the revolving bank credit available to it under its V-Loan agreement. This reduction, which will become effective on Jan. 31, next, is in accordance with an understanding reached when the credit was arranged whereby the corporation was permitted to reduce the maximum credit available upon ninety days' notice to the banks.

General Vandegrifc, commandant of the Marine Corps, was sitting one night on the balcony of the Grand Pacific Hotel in Suva, the Fijis, talking of the men of the Corps with his Chief of Staff, Brig Gen. Gerry Thomas, and a newspaper man. He was on his way back to Australia to reassume command of the First Division he had led into the Solomons.

There is a real possibility in the post-war years of a revival in full force of the Ku Klux Klan, or the creation of similar hate organizations under a different name even in more virulent form, the annual meeting of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, at the Hotel Pennsylvania, was warned yesterday by Dr. H. Scudder Mekeel, associate Professor of Anthropology at the University of Wisconsin.

With reference to the Tass report from Riga in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 8, concerning the appointment of one V.I. Valeskaln as Latvian Commissar for Foreign Affairs by decree of the Presidium of the Latvian Soviet Socialist Republic, I, as the legal representative of the Latvian nation, here by declare that this form of government was not freely chosen by the Latvian people in accordance with the stipulations of the Atlantic Charter.

WALLKILL, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- At Wallkill State Prison for Men today the Right Rev. William T. Manning, Bishop of New York, dedicated the new St. Peter's Chapel, constructed over a cell block under the auspices of the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society.

WITH UNITED STATES THIRD ARMY, Nov. 9 -- Mud and swollen rivers delayed the progress of the Third Army's line-straightening operation along the Metz-Nancy front again today, although several new crossings of the Moselle were achieved and eight additional towns taken.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Demonstrations and experiments on "an objective, competent and impersonal basis," which might open domestic service as a worth-while employment to women after the war were urged today by Miss Frieda Miller, director of the Women's Bureau of the United States Department of Labor.

Efforts by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick to get the Board of Estimate to ask the City Planning Commission to make recommendations on his proposal for rehabilitation of blighted areas in downtown Brooklyn were balked yesterday by Mayor La Guardia and City Council President Newbold Morris.

The organization of medical care to improve the standard of health of the nation through the extension of benefits to individual communities according to their needs was advocated yesterday by leaders at a forum held under the auspices of the New York Board of Trade at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ROME, Nov. 9 -- August Cardinal Hlond, Polish Primate, whom the Nazis arrested and carried off to Germany, is interned in the little Westphalian town of Widebrueck, between Muenster and Bielefeld, it was learned here today. It is understood that the Vatican Secretariat of State is attempting to get him released or exchanged.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 9 -- It seemed as though all Newport turned out this afternoon at the Art Association to pay homage to Mrs. Maud Howe Elliott, daughter of Dr. Samuel Gridley Howe and Julia Ward Howe, upon the occasion of the ninetieth anniversary of her birth.

Christmas shopping has started on schedule. Public response to the new war-born timetable which called for gift-buying to begin on Nov. 8 has been "immediate," and "gratifying," it was announced yesterday by J.E. Davidson, chairman of the executive committee of the Retail Dry Goods Association of New York.

Three adjoining parcels having a combined frontage of 240 feet on Jerome Avenue, at the northwest corner of Clark Place, the Bronx, have been assembled by Joseph G. Platzner, broker, who sold them to Bridge Motors, distributors of Dodge and Plymouth automobiles.
Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Barret and Miss Hermione Barret have come to the Carlyle from Orchard Hill, their place in Ardmore, Pa.

President Roosevelt will return triumphant to the capital today after his fourth electoral vote landslide within twelve years, this one achieved in the closest division of popular ballots in any Presidential election since 1916.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Treasury is thinking seriously of abandoning its simplified redemption policy for war bonds, it was disclosed tonight. The program has backfired, it was said, although officials would not permit quotation on it.
LONDON, Nov. 9 (UP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

Manager Mel Ott, in the city while waiting to go overseas as a member of one of the USO baseball units, announced yesterday that the Giants had released Gus Mancuso, veteran catcher, unconditionally. Almost immediately came the report that the stocky Texan, who will be 39 years old on Dec. 5, likely would be signed by the Phillies as a coach.

No immediate decision on the proposed compromise with the Office of Price Administration on inclusion of the 6 1/2 per cent wage increase in dress costs was reached yesterday at the special meeting of the Popular Price Dress Manufacturers Group at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

Walter White, head of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, has written a first-hand account of the status of Negro soldiers in this war. As preparation for the book, which Doubleday, Doran will publish in February, Mr. White visited Negroes in all branches of the armed services in this country and on the fighting fronts in Europe.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The Polish Government in London has refused to accept the settlement of its eastern boundary demanded by Premier Stalin and approved by Prime Minister Churchill without a comprehensive agreement embodying the other points in its dispute with Russia.

In an effort to place newspapers in a more favorable position to combat post-war competition from other media for advertising, the committee in charge of the Bureau of Advertising, the American Newspaper Publishers Association has evolved a plan for expansion of the bureau under a budget of $1,000,000 annually, it was announced yesterday.

It is no accident that where there is a press jealous of the people's rights and militant in their defense there also is a democracy. The three latest recipients of the Maria Moors Cabot Gold Medals from Columbia University were happily chosen. The Commercio of Quito, Ecuador, the Diario Latino of San Salvador, El Salvador, and The Star and Herald of Panama City long have preached democracy from their editorial pulpits.
LONDON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England today reported an increase of 3,872,000 in note circulation to a new record.

The New York City Housing Authority will be in the market on Nov. 20 with an issue of $1,115,000 of refunding bonds, for which bidders are to name the rate of interest. The bonds, due on Aug. 1, 1944, will mature on each Feb. 1 from 1945 to 1980, with those maturing after Feb. 1, 1951, redeemable on Feb. 1, 1950, or on any interest date thereafter.
ALBANY, Nov. 9 -- President Roosevelt's New York State plurality was raised by 55,000 votes today with the discovery of an error of that amount in the transmission of returns from Lewis County.

WITH POLISH TROOPS at Moerdijk, the Netherlands, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- Polish infantrymen, wet to the waist after a five-hour march in the dead of night through the marshlands along the Meuse [Maas], today seized Moerdijk, home of the great bridges over the Hollandsch Diep, from sleepy-eyed Germans who gaped almost without comprehension at the sight of Allied soldiers and tanks outside their billets.

Gen. Tomoyuki Yamashita, new Commander in Chief of Japanese land forces in the Philippines, told Jose P. Laurel, puppet Philippine President, that he would demand "unconditional surrender" from Gen. Douglas MacArthur, the Tokyo radio declared yesterday in an English-language broadcast to the United States.
Pushing through the damp heat of the tropics, British, Chinese and American forces continued their drives yesterday to free North Burma and Yunnan Province, China, of the Japanese.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- With every member of the squad except one in prime shape, Lieut. Col. Earl Blaik put Army through its final workout today before shoving off for the thirty-first annual football game with Notre Dame at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday.

The people of Italy, when given the opportunity, will assert themselves in a democratic way -- if bread is not used by the Allies as a controlling weapon -- and the House of Savoy will never again rule the country, George Baldanzi, executive vice president of the Textile Workers Union of America, Congress of Industrial Organizations, declared yesterday at a luncheon given by the National CIO War Relief Committee at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The New York University football team held a two-hour drill yesterday on Ohio Field in preparation for the Swarthmore" game here tomorrow. At the end of the session Coach Jack Weinheimer said he had decided on the line-up except for the center position.

About 200 bankers, representing the State banking associations of New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware, met yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria and endorsed the program of the postwar small business credit commission of the American Bankers Association for providing adequate credit to small business in the post-war period.

Paramount Pictures, Inc., reported yesterday to stockholders that it estimated earnings for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 at $12,476,000, after interest and all charges, including estimated provision for all Federal normal and excess profits taxes.

A jury before Federal Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn yesterday found Isidore Fried, 51-year-old former general manager and sales agent of a Brooklyn liquor manufacturing company, guilty of thirty-one charges of Office of Price Administration ceiling-price violations, in what Government officials said was a major black market liquor case.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Justice Department recommended to the Supreme Court today that The Associated Press be required to adopt an "explicit" by-law which would admit new members without regard to local competitive situations.

A fire in the basement storeroom of Loew's Sheridan Theatre, in the heart of Greenwich Village, halted the snow at 8:45 o'clock last night but 2,000 patrons walked calmly out of the thirty exits at the direction of an unflurried assistant manager.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- President Roosevelt left his family home for Washington tonight after a day of relaxation. According to reports, he will be received in the capital tomorrow with enthusiasm rivaling that of four years ago, when he returned as the first man in history to be elected to a third term.

Works of art valued at $50,000, contributed by painters and sculptors, were distributed by lot last night at the Grand Central Art Galleries, 15 Vanderbilt Avenue, among eighty-five lay members of the galleries who had contributed $350 each, a total of $29,750. This was the twenty-second such annual drawing at the galleries, which are a non-profit organization.

A petition demanding that Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine assign additional patrolmen to the Thirtieth Precinct, aid in obtaining additional recreational facilities for youth in the neighborhood, and help work out a program to encourage interracial good-will and understanding among the residents of the area, was circulated yesterday on the upper West Side by the Washington and Hamilton Heights Neighborhood Association.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed increase in holdings of United States Government securities and note circulation for the system as a whole to be $352,042,000 and $192,326,000, respectively, while the ratio of reserve went to 50.6, the lowest figure reached since March 15, 1933.

To "correct errors and inequities" in existing Federal tax laws, twenty-one changes were recommended yesterday by the committee on Federal taxation of the American Institute of Accountants in a communication sent to members of Congressional committees and officials of the Treasury and other governmental departments.

The regulation forbidding domestic users of coal to lay in more than three-fourths of their normal annual supply of anthracite or Eastern coke before Jan. 1 may soon be changed to permit the stocking of that amount by Dec. 1, it was said yesterday by C.J. Potter, Deputy Solid Fuels Administrator.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 9 (AP) -- Top executive officials of the Trumbull Electric Company at Plainville and the founder of the business in 1899 presented their formal resignations at the board meeting today. They are John H. Trumbull, former Governor of Connecticut, who was president; Frank T. Wheeler, who was vice president; Henry Trumbull, treasurer, and Stanley S. Gwillim.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9 -- With all of the West Coast's thirty-nine electoral votes safely in President Roosevelt's column, tabulators of election results, nearing completion, figured today that the President's plurality in California would finally rest around 475,000, as compared with 526,000 in 1940, that his 1940 Oregon lead of 38,000 would be cut in half and that his Washington plurality would be a little above 100,000, as compared with 140,000 four years ago.

An increase in fuel oil rations for householders throughout the East Coast and Middle West, possibly next month or in the first quarter of 1945, was indicated last night on the basis of a survey of supply and distribution and related factors.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- The Paris press, which moves with less speed than ours, really got going today on the subject of the United States elections. President Roosevelt was the hero of large headlines and of sometimes long but always enthusiastic editorials.

ROME, Nov. 9 (AP) -- British Eighth Army troops, overcoming bitter German resistance, fought across a wide canal forming the eastern boundary of the Forli airfield and advanced to within 500 yards of the village of Bussecchio, a mile southeast of Forli, it was announced today.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 9 -- The permanent committee of the Republican Cortes of Spain met this evening to discuss the convening of a general assembly of the Republican Cortes with a view to forming a Spanish government-in-exile.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 9 -- Dr. Stern said tonight that he had not been advised officially of receiving the 1943 Nobel award, but assumed that the honor resulted from his research in molecular physics.

Deliveries of war materials and authorized civilian products by the Chrsyler Corporation for the first nine months of 1944 reached a record total of $762,318,365, comparing with $651,008,540 in the 1943 period, with $423,622,115 in 1942, and with a peace time high of $665,525,555 in first nine months of 1941, a statement by K.T. Keller, president, disclosed yesterday.

I have just seen your editorial of Oct. 23 mentioning my recent talk to the American Chamber of Commerce in London. Your comment is of more importance than my personal opinions, and as this seems to have been based on misleading short extracts from my words and likely to create misunderstanding I venture to clear up a few points.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Friday, Nov. 10 -- Weatherbeaten doughboys drove over rain-lashed ridges for extensive gains south of Carigara Bay today as the Japanese poured reinforcements into Leyte Island to replace an estimated 35,000 men lost in the campaign that Gen. Douglas MacArthur termed the key to the Philippines.

Announcement that the Government's cotton-buying program was under way all over the Cotton Belt and expectations that the export sales program will be announced soon, induced enough trade covering yesterday in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange to bring about a rally.

More than 2,500,000 persons, in 500,000 different families, have been helped by the Jewish Social Service association since it began its work in 1874, the association announced in its anniversary booklet "70 Years," published yesterday.

LONDON, Friday, Nov. 10 -- Russian troops have battled across the Tisza River, the main German defense line northeast of Budapest, and have established a forty-five-mile-long west-bank bridgehead that threatens to split enemy armies defending the Hungarian capital and eastern Slovakia, Moscow announced last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- In this silver jubilee year of the Nineteenth Amendment to the Constitution, which gave women the right to vote, they are estimated to have east 50.3 per cent of the ballots in this Presidential election, although wartime dislocations would indicate that they actually surpassed that figure.
ROME, Nov. 9 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 2 were 893,333 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 23,113 cars, or 2.5 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 138,594 cars, or 18.4 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 63,670 cars, or 7.7 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

An underwriting group headed by F. Eberstadt Co. will offer today 177,689 shares of common stock of the Gleaner Harvester Corporation at $18 a share. These shares do not represent new financing by the corporation, as they were acquired from the Commercial Credit Company, which has been the largest stockholder of Gleaner Harvester, with 59 per cent of the 300,000 shares of common stock outstanding.

General Eisenhower, speaking to the Parliament of liberated Belgium, voiced the real issue of this war. "We are fighting an enemy," he said, "who understands only one thing -- force -- and we intend to apply force to the utmost." The exaltation of naked force, systematized by German intellectuals into a philosophy of might, has been the tragedy of Germany.

Musicians have earned more than $2,600,000 through engagements obtained by the placement bureau of the Musicians Emergency Fund, Mrs. Lytle Hull, president, announced yesterday at the fund's first fall luncheon at the St. Regis Roof.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- One important impression of the election results is widespread here: that Congress will heed the fate of the isolationists in all parts of the country, and that the Senate, which is the Executive's partner in international matters, will particularly note what happened to them.
MOSCOW, Nov. 9 -- Pravda, the only Moscow newspaper published today after a two-day holiday commemorating the revolution's anniversary, reported President Roosevelt's re-election without comment.

SAMPSON, N.Y., Nov. 9 (AP) -- Comdr. Gene Tunney, officer in charge of the Navy physical training program, predicted tonight that many professional football stars of the immediate future would step from the Army and Navy gridirons and battle fronts without varsity experience.

Two of Harlem's most dangerous criminals, against whom seven hold-up murder warrants are pending in Maryland and Virginia, were sentenced to State prison terms yesterday by Judge George L. Donnellan in General Sessions for first-degree robbery.

The Japanese Domei Agency declared yesterday that the Japanese people were "surprised and offended" at Premier Joseph Stalin's characterization of Japan as an "aggressor nation," but contended that "Government circles are refraining from expressing any opinions or from making any comments."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 9 -- Dana Andrews will remain with the Samuel Bronston-Lewis Milestone organization for the top role in the picturization of the Oscar Ray novel, "Borrowed Night," after the completion of "A Walk in the Sun," according to an announcement by Bronston.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- German submarine activity in October was materially lower than in any other month of the war, a British-American Government statement said tonight.

Just because a dress bears a tag saying "dry clean" does not mean that it will not stretch, shrink or pull at the seams when cleaned unless the tag also says that the fabric has been tested for this purpose, Mrs. Louise Huston of American Bemberg Corporation told an audience of Spars attending the second lecture in the Spar post-war home training course held at the Herald Tribune Auditorium last evening.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 9 -- What looked like another "Oklahoma!" to a delighted audience of more than 3,000 in Bushnell Auditorium was presented for the first time here tonight, under the title of "Swing Out, Sweet Land!" by the Theatre Guild.

A set of anti-Nazi textbooks, designed to replace the books now used in the schools of Germany, is being prepared by German scholars and educators who fled to this country after Hitler came into power, it was learned yesterday. The educators hope the new texts will help direct the German mind toward democracy.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 9 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Supreme Allied Commander, received the warm thanks of the Belgian people today in a formal visit to Brussels. In the course of a busy five hours he visited the Royal Palace, addressed the Parliament, laid a wreath on the tomb of the Unknown Soldier and was cheered by thousands on the streets.

Steel production in the first ten months of 1944 set a new high of 74,777,771 net tons for the period, but was only 0.77 per cent above the 74,209,247 tons produced in the 1943 period, the previous high, with October output falling below that of the same month of last year for the third consecutive month, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

YOUNG Clifford Harper lied about his age and joined the marines at 16. When he enlisted he was an athletic, mechanically minded, likable, normal American boy. When he was discharged not quite two years later he was a small part of the vast problem that has already aroused so much concern in so much of the world, the readjustment to civilian life of men who have been transformed by combat experience.

The Horticultural Society of New York presented its thirty-seventh annual autumn exhibition at its headquarters at 598 Madison Avenue yesterday.
