The two-day show, which is open today from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., offers the garden-conscious public the finest array of autumn flowers and vegetables seen in New York since the war temporarily halted the society's large show.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 9 (AP) -- United States Army Forces in China communique:
BOSTON, Friday, Nov. 10 -- Edward McNamara, well-known stage and screen player who sung himself off the Paterson, N.J., police force on to Broadway, died at 8:15 o'clock last night in South Station.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 9 -- The northern wing of Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's American Third Army smashed across the Moselle River, flanking the great fortress of Metz on the north and south today as divisions of the Third Army took the offensive in three areas along a fifty-five-mile front, stretching from the Luxembourg frontier in the north to the Rhine-Marne Canal in the south.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- Baron Henri de Rothschild is again a French citizen with every right attached to such citizenship. As a corollary he can claim all his possessions confiscated by the Vichy Government. So decided today the Council of State, which is the supreme court of administrative law in France.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 9 (AP) -- President Chiang Kai-shek, in a message to President Roosevelt today, said his re-election was a "welcome guarantee" of final victory and an augury for closer Chinese-United States relations.

Full endorsement was expressed here yesterday by an official spokesman of the Polish Government in London to the announced United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration's plan to send a delegation soon to the liberated area of Poland to arrange for the entry and distribution of relief supplies.
Paul Ullman, 38-year-old American artist, was wounded fatally on Aug. 25 while leading a French underground force behind the German lines, according to word received here by his family.

Belief that the Olympic Games could be held in 1948 was expressed yesterday by J. Sigfrid Edstrom of Sweden, acting chairman of the International Olympic Committee and president of the International Amateur Athletic Federation.

The development or a richer spiritual and cultural life by American Jews as one means of combating racial prejudice was stressed as an essential need in an address last night by Rabbi Robert Gordis at the annual dinner of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

International machinery to "suppress every threat of new aggression" was endorsed by Albert Victor McGeachy, editor of The Star and Herald of Panama City, Panama, at a dinner last night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where he and two other winners of Maria Moors Cabot Gold Medals for distinguished achievement in advancing international friendship in the Western Hemisphere were honored.
MONTREAL, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens found their scoring eyes tonight as they whipped the Chicago Black Hawks, 9 -- 2, before a crowd of 11,275 at the Forum.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The production of "critical munitions," which has caused official worry by falling behind estimated requirements, showed improvement in October, but still remained far behind schedule, J.A. Krug, chairman of the War Production Board, told a press conference today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Annual earnings available for dividends on preferred and common stocks of a proposed consolidated operating company to emerge from the reorganization of the Buffalo, Niagara and Eastern Power Corporation were forecast today at $6,400,000 at a hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission on two reorganization plans.

MOSCOW, Nov. 9 -- The Soviet press reported today that Bulgaria had broken off diplomatic relations with Japan. Bulgaria thus followed the example of Finland in breaking with the Japanese immediately after the conclusion of an armistice with the powers carrying on the war against Germany.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- The capital tonight was preparing a gala welcome for President Roosevelt when he returns tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Secretary Stimson intimated today that Sir John Dill, the British Field Marshal, expressed a desire or a willingness to be buried in Arlington National Cemetery where the burial took place yesterday.

KANDY, Ceylon, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Allies, campaigning to open a land route to China, have driven a third prong into Japanese-held territory in northern Burma, crossing the Irrawaddy River midway between Bhamo and Katha and threatening to outflank both of these enemy strongholds, the Allied command announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Weekly department store sales increased 6 per cent for the week ended Nov. 6 compared with a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Percentage changes from like periods of 1943 are indicated in the following table:

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 9 -- The United States Senate contest in New Jersey, in doubt yesterday, was decided definitely today in favor of H. Alexander Smith, Republican, of Princeton, over Representative Elmer H. Wene, Vineland Democrat, who did not concede until most of the soldier ballots had been counted.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- (AP) -- The paper industry has recommended a reduction in control over pulp and paper after VE-Day in Europe through revocation of some orders and modification of others, WPB announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- During the week ended Nov. 8 member bank reserve balances increased $76,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Additions to member bank reserves arose from an increase of $390,000,000 in Reserve bank credit and a decrease of $59,000,000 in Treasury cash, offset in part by increases of $265,000,000 in money in circulation, $98,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $9,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.

A group exhibition of forty-seven paintings by members of the Associated American Artists Galleries is being held at the galleries in conjunction with publication of a simplified pamphlet of painting techniques by Frederic Taubes, one of the painters represented.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- The French Government has just signed an agreement with the Belgian Central Bank to pay back to the Belgian institution gold valued at 230,000,000 francs that the Belgian bank had deposited with the Bank of France before the war and that fell into German hands at Dakar.

After hearing an Army instruction officer pronounce the GI way of teaching superior to civilian methods, representatives of education, labor and business disputed last night the contention that military systems would be successfully applicable to civilian classes.

IN THE SIEGFRIED LINE, Nov. 7 (Delayed) -- Geilenkirchen was bombed from the air and shelled by artillery today. Great fires were started there. I know, because I was flying over the city in a Piper Cub while the attack was in progress.

If you haven't been doing well with ducks so far, the reason could be that most of the birds are still basking in superb Indian summer weather in the Canadian West, filling up on the abundant grain supply of the prairies and getting fat and succulent as a result.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Seasonal advances in market prices for eggs and certain vegetables, with higher quotations for cows, live poultry and foreign wools, caused the Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of commodity prices in primary markets to rise 0.1 per cent during the first week of November.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- New evidence of an intensified effort to conquer the Japanese Empire was presented today through the designation of Admiral Royal E. Ingersoll to become Commander of the Western Sea frontier and in that capacity to ac celerate the enormous flow of necessary supplies across the Pacific, just as he has managed the supply problem for three years in his present post as Commander in Chief of the Atlantic Fleet.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- In informed official circles it was said today to be virtually certain that the next French Ambassador to Washington would be Henri Bonnet, formerly Commissioner of Information in the French Committee of National Liberation in Algiers and earlier director of the Institute of Intellectual Cooperation in Geneva. M. Bonnet has been in the United States frequently and has made numerous addresses there.

Sparked by a high degree of interest in the aircraft and railroad issues, the stock market moved forward yesterday on a fairly broad front, with gains of 1 to more than 2 points. It was obvious to observers in Wall Street that investors and traders, having cleared their path of the election factor, had settled down to work out their financial programs on a more permanent basis.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Communique 215:

The victories of the Red Army in driving its enemies out of the Soviet Union and the prospect of continued cooperation between Russia and her Allies were toasted yesterday evening at a reception at the Soviet Consulate, 7 East Sixty-first Street, marking the twenty-seventh anniversary of the Bolshevist revolution.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- In 1940, Vichy, under German prompting, decreed that Armistice Day should be marked by mourning and mortification. Now that France is liberated all its former significance is to be restored to the anniversary, with Allied participation.

The Savings Banks Association of the State of New York received the State Association Award at the annual dinner of the American Trade Association Executives last night for their outstanding service in promoting greater wartime savings.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 -- Determined to shake off its two-game losing streak, Pennsylvania acts host to Columbia in the twenty-seventh game of their series on Franklin Field tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- President Roosevelt said at a news conference today that he, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin wanted to meet whenever they could arrange it, but that nothing had been worked out, nor the time or the place fixed.

As a means of "tightening the administration of residential rent regulations in this district and providing better supervision over the seven branch rent offices," the New York area rent headquarters of the Office of Price Administration was moved yesterday from 535 Fifth Avenue to the Empire State Building, which also houses the OPA regional offices.

A "pressure campaign" to force the Board of Transportation to grant six major demands of the Transport Workers Union, Local 100, was launched last night when 600 members of the union, all city employes, met at the Hotel Diplomat, 108 West Forty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Navy Department communique 553:

Ray Lev, young American pianist, made her first appearance of the season in a Carnegie Hall recital last night. Miss Lev, as usual, tackled an extremely ambitious program and played it with great energy and fire. There was a large audience on band which showed its appreciation of the artist's efforts at every opportunity.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 10 (UP) -- Communique 216:

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Identifying Germany's V-2 officially as a long-range rocket, traveling at a speed faster than sound and carrying about one ton of explosive, Prime Minister Winston Churchill announced to the House of Commons today that rockets had been falling on "widely scattered points" in Britain for the last few weeks, causing casualties and damage, which so far have not been heavy.

The system of free enterprise in this country, particularly so-called big business, should be protected against unjustified political attacks, Col. Bradley Dewey, former Federal Rubber Director, and president of Dewey Almy Chemical Company, said last night at a joint meeting of the Society of Chemical Industry, the American Chemical Society and the American Institute of Chemical Engineers at the Hotel Roosevelt.
KANDY, Ceylon, Nov. 10 (UP) -- A communique:

Members of the acting profession yesterday took up the cause of Lee Sabinson, whose presentation of "Trio," the Dorothy and Howard Baker play, was not permitted to open at the Cort on Wednesday by Lee Shubert because he objected to the work's subject matter.

The purchase by a syndicate of a large site in the Penn zone for improvement after the war was announced yesterday when the buildings and vacant ground covering thirteen lots at 314 to 338 West Thirty-first Street were acquired from the Guaranty Trust Company. The syndicate is headed by Frank Caspar, operator of Bonat's French Restaurant in one of the buildings on the site.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, France, Nov. 10 -- American Third Army tanks and doughboys drove through meager German defenses northeast of Nancy today as the three-day offensive mushroomed out across the Lorraine plain, threatening Metz to the north and the rich Saar basin to the east.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A committee of holders of preferred stock of the Long Island Lighting Company called today upon the Securities and Exchange Commission in a unique action to reinstate its jurisdiction over the company.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Hoarding and black-market operations in the distribution of cigarettes were described today as factors contributing to the acute shortage of virtually all brands.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- The stock markets here generally continued cheerful today although business was on a small scale.
Thursday's communique, as broadcast from Paris and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- A strike of 400 trainmen over wages tied up all service today on the Chicago, North Shore Milwaukee and on the Chicago, Aurora Elgin Electric Railroads.

Frank Nuccio of 265 Elizabeth Street, who is under $5,000 bond as a material witness in the unsolved murder of Carlo Tresca, was among five men arrested yesterday and accused of conspiracy to operate a large still at 2 East First Street.
WELLINGTON, N.Z., Nov. 10 -- A more dynamic policy of socialism in New Zealand was indicated by the recent national conference of the Labor party here.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 10 (U.P.) -- The Japanese claimed today they had stormed and captured the cities of Kweilin and Liuchow, former sites of United States air bases, but a Chinese communique said hand-to-hand fighting was in progress in the heart of Kweilin and that the Japanese were in Liuchow's suburbs.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Saturday, Nov. 11

ALBANY, Nov. 10 -- October formations of stock corporations broke a three and a half year record when 1,162 new concerns were given charters. In October, 1943, 711 companies were formed. In the past ten months 9,109 charters were issued, compared to 7,056 in the corresponding period in 1943 and 7,641 in 1942.

ARMY vs. Notre Dame -- The first parade of the Cadets is scheduled for 1:10 P.M. The second one is listed for 2 P.M. when Army's whirlwind backs begin to operate. But it's not quite as simple as all that. The annual battles between the Kaydets and the Fighting Irish have seen the form charts overturned time and time again.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- The forthcoming visit of Prime Minister Churchill to Paris, while in part and in a sense primarily a gesture of courtesy and a tribute to liberated France, will be the occasion for broaching numerous subjects of both immediate and long-range interest to the French Government, circles most directly concerned said tonight.
LONDON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Churchill's statement to the House of Commons on German use of V-2 long-range rockets:

Police of the Hunters Point station believed last night they had captured a youth, known as "The Creeper," who has been terrorizing women and children in the Laurel Hill and Thomson Hill sections of Long Island City for several weeks.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies in October showed a rise of 9.3 per cent over the like month of 1943, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The figure compared with a gain of 12.1 per cent in September.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administra tion has instructed its field offices to crack down on what it terms a "growing black market in cigarettes."
Thursday's communique, as transmitted in English by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ADVANCE HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Saturday, Nov. 11 -- Three Japanese transports and seven destroyers were sunk in Ormoc Bay on the western coast of Leyte yesterday as fighters and medium bombers backed by far ranging Navy patrol torpedo boats swooped down on a Japanese convoy that landed further reinforcements for the hard pressed enemy troops fighting in the narrow valley that runs south from Carigara Bay to Ormoc.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 10 -- Premier Urhu Jonas Castren of Finland has resigned and the President, Field Marshal Baron Carl Gustav Mannerheim, is expected to ask Dr. Juho K. Paasikivi, former Premier who played a leading part in the negotiations
RENO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Doris Duke Cromwell, testified in a deposition filed here today that James J.R. Cromwell demanded an "endowment" of $7,000,000 in consideration of a divorce.

ABOARD A PT COMMAND TENDER OFF LEYTE, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Throttled at full speed, two American patrol torpedo boats roared out of the darkness to within a few hundred yards of Japanese shipping that packed Ormoc Bay early this morning and scored torpedo hits on enemy destroyers.

A 26-year-old ex-sergeant from El Dorado, Ark., the first blinded soldier to complete four months' training provided by the Army rehabilitation center at Avon, Conn., started a new career yesterday as school teacher.

ALBANY, Nov. 10 -- Asking for a change in the place of trial of a key figure indicted in the extraordinary investigation of crime in Albany County. Special Prosecutor George P. Monaghan introduced tapped telephone conversations today purporting to show that certain members of the Supreme Court bench in the district were under undue political influence.
Complete figures from all States were still not available last night, but enough returns were in to throw more light on the shift in the popular vote which took place in Tuesday's election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Individual adjustments of ceiling prices will be open to manufacturers of specified types of knitted underwear who are producing at a loss under a War Production Board conservation order, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- President Roosevelt returned victoriously to Washington today to be greeted by an enthusiastic crowd of many thousands which stood in the pouring rain for at least a half hour to welcome home "the Chief."

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- The conviction is growing in London that there is something wrong with Adolf Hitler. Whether it is that he was seriously injured physically by the bomb explosion in his headquarters last July, or his paranoia has become too acute to allow him to appear in public, is becoming a matter for serious discussion in official circles.

High praise for the "serious manner" in which volunteer workers of New York took on the responsibilities of their unpaid wartime jobs was expressed yesterday in an address by Welfare Commissioner Harry W. Marsh at a ceremony in which a group of Civilian Defense Volunteer Office workers were presented with service pins and other awards for their work in the Department of Welfare.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- George Meany, secretary-treasurer of the American Federation of Labor, speaking over the National Broadcasting Company's network, originating at Station WRC in this city, tonight warned that the nation is "headed for deflation and depression" after the war "unless

Sister Elizabeth Kenny, the Australian nurse who came to the United States four years ago to extend the teaching of her concept and treatment of infantile paralysis, declared yesterday that there was a pressing need for the establishment in this city of a medical institute staffed by doctors, nurses and technicians fully trained in her methods.

Violin playing of the first rank was heard from Joseph Fuchs at his recital last night in Town Hall. His performances throughout a long and extremely exacting program were highly distinguished, whether considered from the standpoint of technique, tone or musicianship, and equally remarkable from the interpretive angle.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -The American Association of University Professors called today upon Gov. Coke Stevenson of Texas to fill vacancies on the State's University Board of Regents with individuals of "judicious temperament."

The eyes not only of Texas but of every other State in the Union and every other place now occupied by the armed citizenry of this nation will be focused on the Yankee Stadium today when Army's unbeaten and untied eleven meets Notre Dame.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Soldiers may add six battles and campaigns to the decorations upon their uniforms, the War Department said today, adding that the number of battle honors now comprises twenty-six.

The 1944 peanut crop of 2,500,000,000 pounds, grown on about twice as many acres as were utilized before the war, has been harvested, and is moving in various forms to retail stores. Service men have evidenced such a liking for the nut, which is actually a legume like dried beans and peas, that the Government has set aside a sizable amount.

Special exhibits of house plants, berried shrubs and gourds drew as much attention as the lavish displays of chrysanthemums and greenhouse orchids during the two-day autumn exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York that closed yesterday at its headquarters, 598 Madison Avenue.
ALBANY, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The death of a 60-year-old Chautauqua farmer, the first victim of rabies in up-State New York since 1930, brought renewed warning today from the State Health Department.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The War Production Board today ordered The Chicago Sun to reduce its consumption of newsprint by 886.89 tons by the end of September, 1945. The agency contended that the newspaper was in "willful" violation of an order limiting the use of newsprint. Its formal order said:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -Venezuela has suggested in a critique on the Dumbarton Oaks proposals stronger guarantees be given to the "middle and small" nations and that three LatinAmerican countries be represented on the security council, it was learned today.

ROME, Nov. 10 -- The government commission of inquiry into the lynching of Donato Carretta, former vice director of the Regina Coeli prison, published a report today completely vindicating Carretta's character. An investigation showed that he even took the gravest risks to favor anti-fascist prisoners in Regina Coeli, that the accusation screamed at him in the court room came from a pathologically hysterical woman and that he had done nothing to provoke the crowd.

Countering a belief that the Sixth War Loan, which starts Nov. 20, would find it difficult to achieve its quotas, Frederick W. Gehle, chairman of the New York State War Finance Committee, announced yesterday that a survey just completed by his office had disclosed that current income in the State is the highest in history.

MOSCOW, Nov. 10 -- Col. Gen. Janos Voeroes, Chief of the Hungarian Army General Staff, has escaped from the German occupiers of his country and made his way inside Soviet lines. General Voeroes has appealed in the name of former Regent Nicholas Horthy to all

As a result of higher salaries offered by industry and the inability in many instances to get domestic help, a record number of New York City school teachers are retiring and resigning from the school system, it was learned yesterday. Officials are worried lest the unprecedented exodus lead to a serious teacher shortage in the local schools.

THE Basques are an anomaly in the modern world. They form a real nation, intensely aware of themselves, but so small that their desire to exist as a nation comes into modern politics like a figure out of "Green Mansions." The Basques are extraordinarily fine-looking people, and they live in that lovely country that flows down from either side of the western Pyrenees.

The speed with which the Bureau of Internal Revenue is issuing rulings on income tax deductions for those receiving pensions from profit-sharing plans indicates, according to Adrian DeWind of the tax legislative counsel's office, Treasury Department, that further extensions will not be necessary.

Urging that "several hundred young Palestinians" be given arms to put down the small band of Sternist terrorists, Dr. Nahumm Goldmann, member of the executive committee of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, declared yesterday that the problem could be solved more quickly in this way than in leaving it entirely in the hands of British Middle East police.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Bread, the Federal Trade Commission ruled today, has greater nutritional value than beer.

The Rev. Nelson LeRoy Chowenhill and his wife will be guests at a formal reception of welcome by the parishioners of the Holyrood Episcopal Church, Fort Washington Avenue and 179th Street, next Saturday evening in the parish house.
ALBANY, Nov. 10 -- Governor Dewey will leave Albany tomorrow for a post-election rest at Sea Island, Ga., where he will try to forget about politics for several weeks.

The Federation Bank and Trust Company has sold the two-story taxpayer structure at 30-12 Thirtieth Avenue, Astoria, Queens, to an investing client of John J. Reynolds, broker. The property, assessed at $105,000, occupies a plot 80 by 100 feet and contains stores, bowling alley and meeting rooms. Solon Peck represented the purchaser and Beldock Meadows were attorneys for the bank. Title was insured by the Lawyers Title Corporation.

The New York Rangers will try to square accounts with the Detroit Red Wings in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The sextets have met once this season, with the Wings scoring a top-heavy triumph.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 -- Twelve law firms, four bond-holders' committees and nine individuals asked the United States District Court today to approve payment of $1,134,650 in fees incurred during the reorganization of the Philadelphia Reading Coal and Iron Company, a $61,000,000 concern which has been operating under bankruptcy laws since 1937 and for which Federal Judge William H. Kirkpatrick recently approved a plan to reduce the capitalization to less than $12, 000,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The country's highest group award, the Presidential Unit Citation, has been awarded to the Fourth Marine Division for its capture of the islands of Saipan and Tinian.

LONDON, Nov. 10 (U.P.) -- Striking for the second consecutive day in support of American Army drives along Germany's western frontiers, more than 750 United States heavy bombers, escorted by 600 or more fighters, dropped an estimated 40,000 bombs today on military transport, industrial plants and four enemy airfields in the regions of Frankfort on the Main and Cologne.

An appraisal and presentation of all information that can be gathered concerning conditions likely to govern reconversion of the textile industry will prevent the "grief" experienced at the end of the last war, Dr. A.M. McIsaac, Department of Economics, Princeton University, asserted yesterday.

Reconversion problems have been greatly exaggerated and American industry can start production of civilian goods almost immediately after termination of war contracts, Brig. Gen. Albert J. Browning, assistant director of material of the Army Services Forces, said yesterday at the conclusion of the annual meeting of the American Trade Association Executives at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- President Roosevelt disclosed today that his pre-election estimate of the number of votes he would win in the Electoral College was ninety-seven short, according to the present tabulation, with returns incomplete.

Representatives of prominent religious and educational organizations that have been instrumental in the formulation of world peace plans praised yesterday the Dumbarton Oaks Conference as an important step toward this goal and urged that members of affiliated organizations strive to influence public opinion in support of the proposals made at the conference.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 10 -- An improved method for obtaining a follicle-stimulating hormone, an apparatus for administering blood plasma and a highly resistant wartime steel are among the 534 inventions listed as patented in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.
A rivalry begun before the turn of the century, but broken off in 1902, will be resumed today on Ohio Field when New York University clashes with Swarthmore. The kick-off is set for 2:30 P.M.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- French newspapers generally, and in Paris particularly, are at grips with the censorship. This morning, for instance, the newspaper Franc-Tireur, the organ of the advanced parties, appeared without an editorial "for reasons beyond our control," while the conservative Figaro announced that the "censors had seen fit at the last minute to defer publication of its editorial."

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- The suspension by the Common Council of William A. Walsh as City Manager resulted today in the resignation of Deputy Public Safety Commissioner W. Chantler Arbuckle, before whom Police Chief William A. Kruppenbacher and four other members of his department were scheduled for trial on neglect of duty charges.

The stock market struck yesterday a stronger and broader recovery note, and, while the gains did not approach those of the previous session, the breadth of the rally was impressive. Spurred by the heaviest turnover in two months, the list reached the best levels so far this month.

ALBANY, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- Fifty registered nurses and forty graduate physical therapists are urgently needed for after care of more than 1,000 victims of this year's infantile paralysis epidemic, the State Health Department said today.

The report of the North American Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday by Edward L. Shea, president, shows a consolidated net income of $19,491,377 after operating expenses, taxes and other charges.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Chinese troops have expanded their bridgehead on the south bank of the Irrawaddy River near Shwegu, in North Burma, both to the east and the west, the Allied command announced today.

During the election campaign the President came out flatly in favor of "a delegate who can act" on behalf of the United States to decide, without stopping to get the consent of Congress, whether the United States shall use its share of the United Nations' so-called "police" forces to make war against a nation which that delegate, in agreement with others, declared to be an aggressor.
LONDON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- A communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

The shortage of stainless steel for household cutlery has brought up the question of which is the more desirable -- a knife with a permanently shining blade or a knife that will cut. While housewives have deplored the loss of pre-war cutlery that never caused a moment's worry about rust or stains, cutlery experts hold a different view.

Twenty-six years ago this morning, the eleventh hour of the eleventh day of the eleventh month of 1918, the guns fell silent on the Western Front. An armistice had been signed. All over the world people rejoiced. That hour and that day marked the end of the greatest war in history to that time, a war that was fought, we said, to put an end to all wars for all time.

City parents showed increased "school consciousness" at the twenty-third annual Open School Week that ended yesterday, it was agreed by principals and teachers in several neighborhoods. While the Board of Education does not have exact figures, an informal survey pointed to a record of visits -- including a "surprising" number from fathers.

The Citizens Zoning Committee, now comprising fifty-one civic, trade and labor organizations, adopted a program yesterday favoring "immediate, more effective zoning" and added restrictions on residential and business buildings, but opposing the zoning revision plan approved by the City Planning Commission and now before the Board of Estimate.

The Sixth War Loan Drive is about to start. The major test of its success will be found in the sales of Series E bonds. In this drive the goal will be sales of $2,500,000,000 of Series E bonds, or somewhat lower than the actual sales in the last drive. As we start the new War Loan Drive, however, it is reported that redemptions of outstanding war bonds have reached a new peak.
The twenty-sixth anniversary of Armistice Day will be marked today with services in memory of American fighting men who gave their lives during the last war and in the present conflict.

To raise $3,500 for the purchase of a summer camp site, 3,000 Camp Fire Girls in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens will attempt to sell at least four dozen doughnuts each during a special one-day drive next Saturday, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Martin J. Eberhardt, executive director of the Greater New York Council.

ROME, Nov. 10 -- In the most notable success since the capture of Rimini on Sept. 20, Lieut. Gen. Sir Richard L. McCreery's Eighth Army yesterday completed occupation of Forli, provincial capital, thirty-nine miles from Bologna along arrow-straight Highway 9.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 10 -- Marcel Pilet-Golaz, chief of Switzerland's Political Department, or Foreign Office, resigned and retired from the Federal Council today, ostensibly to permit the introduction of "new and unimpaired political forces" into the
The report of the Standard Oil Company of Ohio mailed to stockholders yesterday disclosed a net profit of $5,323,363 for the nine months ended on Sept. 30.

The performance of Puccini's "Boheme" last night in the City Center of Music and Drama was so lively and youthful in spirit, and was sung with so much feeling and gusto, that the audience enjoyed it immensely and tasted the real savor of Puccini's libretto and score.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- Four bids to lease and operate Westchester County's new $4,000,000 Federal-built airport in Purchase were opened today by the County Board of Acquisition and Contract. The bidders guaranteed payments ranging up to $60,000 a year for use of the mile-square field.

Ten juveniles, including the Florida flash, Bertie S., and War Date, are named for the $10,000 Nellie Morse Purse at a mile today at Belmont Park, where the Victory meet will reach one of its high points. The nine-day session will end next Wednesday and by that time it is believed by Manager John J. Coakley that war relief will have gained by a record $650,000.
SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Eleven women and twenty convicted of conspiring to preach and practice polygamous marriage were sentenced today to one year in jail each.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Nov. 10 -Stilrovin Katherine, golden retriever bitch owned by Mrs. James M. Austin of Old Westbury and handled by James Briggs of Minneapolis, won the open all-age stake today at the field trial meeting of the Labrador Retriever Club at Timber Point.

" The Great Moment," Preston Sturges' latest Paramount production, will open this morning at the Globe. The cast is headed by Joel McCrea, Betty Field, Harry Carey and William Demarest. The story deals with Dr. William Morton, the Boston dentist who discovered anesthesia a century ago.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- The Chicago Sun denied today that it had willfully violated the provisions of Limitation Order L-240, and through its business manager, Clem J. Randau, asserted that it had operated on a day-to-day, uncertain basis because of delay on the part of the printing and publishing division of WPB in fixing a base quota for its newsprint consumption.

Officials at the Grand Central Palace Induction Station announced late yesterday that James P. Donahue, 29-year-old cousin of Barbara Hutton and himself an heir to part of the Woolworth fortune, had been sworn into the Army.

Joseph Wood Krutch's biography, "Samuel Johnson," to be published Tuesday by Henry Holt, contains four indices. One is a general index; one deals exclusively with the events of Dr. Johnson's life; another is an alphabetical list of all his works, and the fourth is a list of his character traits and habits, opinions and sayings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Hawaii is so eager to receive the first Waves to be allowed to serve overseas that a sign has already been put up, reading: "To Wave Barracks, We Hope," Capt. Mildred H. McAfee said today at a press conference presenting Lieut. Comdr. Jean Palmer and Lieut. Comdr.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- On the basis of incomplete reports available to the Senate, the successful campaign of Senator Wagner, Democrat, of New York, was the most expensive among Senatorial candidates.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 10 -- The position of non-Jews under the proposed Jewish State for which most Zionists are striving was explained publicly for the first time today in a letter from Dr. Leo Kohn, political secretary of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, published in the Palestine Post.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 11 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The presidency of the Allied Commission for Italy was transferred today from military to civilian direction with the appointment to that office of Harold MacMillan, British Resident Minister at Allied Forces Headquarters in Italy, the State Department announced.

ROME, Nov. 10 -- A recommendation that the entire police system of Rome be overhauled and reconstituted as one homogeneous force rather than a loose organization of separate units will be laid before the Italian Government by American Military Government public safety authorities, it was learned today.
Michael Bachman, formerly with the Meadowgold Ice Cream Company of Brooklyn, has been appointed general sales manager of the Blue Ribbon Ice Cream Company, Inc.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 10 -- Paramount has bought for $50,000 the screen rights to "Feature for June," an unproduced play by Graeme Lorimer and Eileen Tighe, former editors of national women's magazines. The comedy, which is earmarked for Diana Lynn, deals with complications in the romance of a small-town prospective bride and groom between the time they sit for wedding pictures for a magazine layout and the actual ceremony three months later.

AN AMERICAN AIR BASE ON LEYTE, Nov. 10 -- American pilots came back to their bases tonight with stories of Japanese transports blowing up in thirty seconds, destroyers going up in clouds of smoke, Japanese bodies littering the surface of Ormoc Bay, and a score of three enemy transports definitely sunk and seven destroyers destroyed in a twenty-four-hour attack by planes and PT-boats.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Some fourscore Senators and House members will be missing from Congress next year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -Petroleum Administration for War sources said today there was no possibility of an early increase in fuel-oil rations to householders in the Middle West and on the East Coast.

Japanese broadcasts late yesterday said that "several scores" of China-based American planes -- presumably giant B-29's -- had raided northern Kyushu in the Japanese home islands, site of the strategic iron and steel center of Yawata, which had been bombed by B-29's four times previously, according to The United Press.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture's report of a small net improvement in national farm prospects during October issued today, makes it probable that this year's crops will be the largest ever harvested. The previous record output was in 1942.

The major security and commodity markets throughout the nation will be closed today in observance of Armistice Day. A few miscellaneous markets will operate as usual. Exchanges in Canada will function for their short session.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has started proceedings in Bronx Supreme Court for a sharp reduction in the assessed valuation of Parkchester, its residential community housing more than 12,000 families in that borough, it became known yesterday.

Sammy Angott's plans as a welterweight title contender were jarred last night in Madison Square Garden, where, before 10,430 fans, the doughty little ex-lightweight champion from Washington, Pa., went down to defeat before hard-hitting Jimmy McDaniels, Los Angeles fighter, in a ten-round bout that furnished a distinct upset without being exactly a throbbing spectacle.

FRASCATI, Italy, Nov. 9 (Delayed) -- How Ettore Muti, former Secretary of the Fascist party and Italy's No. 1 Fascist gangster, was killed, frustrating a plot that would have prevented the armistice with the Allies, was told to me today by the man responsible for the act.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told her news conference today that she viewed the four years ahead as probably the most difficult years "the world has ever seen," since it involved "winning the war, making the peace and rebuilding the world."

Walter Gellhorn, vice chairman of the regional War Labor Board, announced yesterday that income tax disallowances totaling more than $50,000 would be assessed against thirteen concerns in New York City and northern New Jersey and one in Rochester, N.Y., for violations of the Wage Stabilization Act.

Sergeant Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion on furlough from the Army after overseas service, yesterday received permission from the State Athletic Commission to engage in an exhibition bout as part of his current tour. The exhibition will be against Johnny Davis, Brooklynite, in Buffalo on Tuesday night.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 10 (AP) -- An untried Princeton football team opens its three-game season in Palmer Stadium tomorrow afternoon against Muhlenberg, which has a record of four victories and four defeats.

Prose and poetry have sung paeans to the glory of the covered bridges that reached their heyday a few decades ago and are now almost collectors' items. But sparse has been the praise and little the recognition of the humble plank bridges that span the brooks, creeks and slough spots of the land.

Unless the 100,000 teachers now serving with the armed forces are returned to the nation's classrooms as soon as possible, the schools of the country will not be able to play their part in the solution of the veterans' problem, Dr. Willard Waller, associate professor of sociology at Barnard College, declared yesterday.

Newspaper scareheads on the German V-2 rocket bomb are hardly justified by this weapon's actual destructive force, according to John H. Van Deventer, president and editorial director of the trade publication Iron Age, who saw a V-2 crater south of London this month.

WITH AMERICAN THIRD ARMY in France, Nov. 10 -- Maj. Gen. Horace L. McBride's Eightieth "Blue Ridge" Division took Delme Ridge today. The ridge was one of the most important objectives in Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's attack and just had to be taken if the Metz-Nancy line were to be straightened.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- That British M.P.'s are divided over the question whether the German people as a whole are responsible for war crimes was demonstrated by a debate in the House of Commons today, brought to an abortive end by the discovery that no quorum was present.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 10 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho was understood today to have told Diego Martinez Barrio that the Mexican Government would raise no objections to the desire of the Spanish Republican Permanent Political Committee to hold a general assembly in Mexico.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 10 -- Morven, the former home of the Stockton family in Princeton and one of the most historic structures in the nation, has been purchased by Gov. Walter E. Edge for ultimate transfer to the State as a Governor's Mansion or historic shrine, it was announced today.

Christmas Trade Starts Well Marked by favorable consumer response to the early Christmas shopping campaign launched by the stores here, retail trade here was active this week. Election Day volume was particularly good and department stores had gains ranging up to 20 per cent for the week.

Some time ago Jule F. Marshall of Larchmont sent this department the June issue of Archery in which Arnold O. Haugen of the Michigan Department of Conservation had an article on bow-and-arrow hunting for deer. We've held it until now, waiting for the subject to become more timely.

Fox, Reusch Co. and associates were the successful bidders yesterday for an issue of $656,000 of refunding bonds of Wickliffe, Ohio, receiving the award on their bid of 101.39 for 2 1/2s. The bonds will nature June 15 and Dec. 15, 1946 to 1960.

A new advertising campaign appearing in trade publications reveals that Lear, Inc., formerly Lear Avia will enter the home radio field after the war with an "all-new" set. Included will be portable, table, console and other styles fully equipped with FM, television and other new features.

New York's favorite football spectacle, the Army-Notre Dame game, moves into the Yankee Stadium today along with the West Point Corps of 2,500 cadets, and in wartime as in peace it continues to be the biggest of all gridiron box-office attractions.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- From the Continent, where the military mind predominates, England appears as a kind of backwater. This is the result of the transfer of the Supreme Military Headquarters to France, which has been accentuated lately by the preparations for the new drive opened this week by the three-pronged thrust of the American Third Army toward the Saar.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 10 -- A plea for concentration on the rural apostolate in the decades after the war to meet the spiritual, economic and social needs of city as well as country people was made today by the Most Rev. William A. Griffin, Bishop of Trenton, at the opening session of a four-day national meeting of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference.

Although there was a fairly good volume of trading in cotton futures yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, fluctuations held within a 7-point range and final prices were 4 to 7 points higher on the day.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Seventeen candidates for the Senate and 120 for the House of Representatives supported by the Congress of Industrial Organizations-Political Action Committee were elected, according to an incomplete report prepared and made public today at the CIO national headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Distillers were formally notified by the War Production Board today that they may take in January a second "holiday" from the production of wartime industrial alcohol and make liquor.

Perhaps it is because we have been so absorbed with politics that Secretary Stimson warns the nation once more that heavy casualties will be the price of victory. Speaking at his press conference he reminds that desperate fighting has occurred in battles just past, and desperate fighting is certain to occur in battles just ahead.

The well-known apartment building at 1010 Fifth Avenue, occupying large frontage at the northeast corner of Eighty-second Street, has been sold by the Greenwich Savings Bank to a group acting in the name of Fifth Avenue Estates, Inc., of 36 West Forty-fourth Street, according to deeds filed yesterday in the Register's office. The head of the purchasing group is Oscar R. Chalk.

Mrs. Sophie McCreary, whose husband was killed in action with the Navy in the South Pacific on July 15, and Mrs. Elizabeth Berry, wife of a sailor now on active duty in the Pacific, will be arraigned in Brooklyn Felony Court this morning on charges of abandoning their children.

" World Order Day" will be observed by thousands of Protestant churches throughout the country tomorrow under the sponsorship of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America. Its purpose is "to rally the Christian forces of the nation in a united effort to win the peace."

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- General agreement was reached at today's meetings of the International Civil Aviation Conference that the interim council to be formed, pending establishment of a permanent international aviation organization, shall be of a technical and advisory nature and so constituted as to protect the juridical equality and sovereign rights of all nations, large or small.
LONDON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- A United States Eighth Air Force communique:

The actuarial reserve basis of the Church Pension Fund of the Protestant Episcopal Church has been reduced by its trustees from 3 1/2 per cent to 3 1/4 per cent because of declining interest rates on investments supporting it, according to Bishop Cameron J. Davis, president of the fund.

A united drive by voluntary health organizations against medical "quacks" was urged by Dr. Iago Goldston, executive secretary of the Medical Information Bureau, New York Academy of Medicine, in an address at the academy, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, last night.

SALEM, Mass., Nov. 10 -- The slayer of Marie Rose Lacombe, 14 years old, was identified tonight by District Attorney Hugh A. Cregg as a 20-year-old discharged soldier who committed suicide in a lodging house here.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 9 (Delayed) -- The great Krupp arms plant in Essen suspended production a few days ago as a result of Allied bombing damage, according to private information from Germany today. There was no indication of when work could be resumed.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- Aime Lepercq, Minister of Finance in the de Gaulle Government; his political secretary, Jean Ricquebourg; his private secretary, Vincent Raoux, and his chauffeur, Justin Renaudie, were dead in their seats when an automobile in which they had been riding was hoisted this morning out of a canal at the village of Harnes in the Pas-de-Calais Department.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- A Department of Agriculture estimate that corn production this year aggregated 3,258,378,000 bushels, by far the largest on record and 61,000,000 bushels more than promised a month ago was construed today as somewhat bearish by grain traders, although the total was about in line with general expectations.

Elected President of Guatemala in 1931, Gen. Jorge Ubico remained in office until last June contrary to the provisions of his country's Constitution. He was a dictator. Popular will meant nothing to him. The Constitution became an interesting antique. Limited by law to a term of six years, with a twelve-year interval before he could be re-elected, he had a so-called plebiscite extend the term for six years more.

The service men's vote appeared last night to be the vital factor in determining the outcome of the close Senatorial contests in Pennsylvania and Missouri, and in the latter State four House seats also are unsettled pending the war ballot count, according to reports, mostly from The Associated Press.

LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 11 -- Russian infantrymen, extending their Tisza River bridgehead northeast of Budapest in advances of up to seven miles, cut the vital trunk railroad linking the Hungarian capital with eastern Slovakia yesterday and slogged over sodden plains to within fourteen miles of Miskolc, Hungary's fifth city.

MOORESTOWN, N.J., Nov. 1 -- The National Convalescent Service for the Army and Navy, a volunteer organization that provide week-end visits to private home for wounded soldiers and sailor in government hospitals, will expand its activities and become a independent agency, it was announced today by Mrs. Horace T. Greenwood Jr. of Moorestown chairman.

Charles P. Cooper, president of the board of managers of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, 168th Street and Broadway, announced yesterday that the hospital would institute a pension plan that would not require any contribution from employes, effective Jan. 1.

At some point in his fourth term will he become Franklin Roosevelt? Or will he round out the four years as he did the preceding three terms as Franklin D. Roosevelt? The chances are that he will remain Franklin D. His supporters in the campaign liked to end their speeches with a tribute to Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

A lawsuit in which Baron Nathaniel Mayer Victor Rothschild of Cambridge, England, sought to recover money paid to Gabriel Wells for a copy of Henry Fielding's famous novel, "Tom Jones," has been settled without trial, it was disclosed yesterday in Federal court.

RYE, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- Two predominant fears of foreign traders were quieted today when Robert Gaylord, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, speaking before the opening session of the international business conference, declared that American manufacturers are prepared for the return of exported capital "in the shape of goods and services" and are ready to export the means of production to raw material countries to speed world industrialization.

Two six-story apartment buildings at 1661 and 1671 Andrews Avenue, the Bronx, accommodating 144 families, have been sold by Isaac Prussian to Biwad Realty Corporation, Abraham D. Wiseman, president. The buildings occupy a plot 305 by 100 feet.

Thanks to the resourcefulness of the University of Cincinnati leather chemists, GI Joe is the best-shod soldier in history. What is more, American civilians are already buying wartime shoes with leather soles approaching the wearing durability of pre-war soles.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- China aligned herself today on the side of the United States in favor of limiting the proposed international air authority to technical, advisory and consultative functions, and against the British-Canadian proposal to give it broad regulatory powers over routes, frequencies of service and rates.

Teachers throughout the country have the important duty of utilizing the classroom to help remove prejudice and improve racial understanding, Dr. Leslie P. Hill, president of the Cheyney Training School for Teachers, Pennsylvania, declared yesterday, at the final session of the New Jersey Education Association convention at Manhattan Center.

DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The history of the country for the next twenty years and the happiness of every American for the next two generations depends on efficient settlement of current Government contracts, Lieut. Gen. William S. Knudsen, director of the far-flung Air Technical Service Command, declared today.

JUST when it began to appear that Hollywood was about ready to admit that it couldn't get along without New York, the weatherman had to demonstrate his contrariness by enveloping fair Manhattan in blankets of vaporous mist for mornings on end.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- Armistice Day brought no halt in the purge of collaborators with the Germans. Dr. Paul Bertrand, Vichy's Mayor of Lyon, was arrested on a charge of having been instrumental in handing over to the Germans several physicians who were later shot.

William Richards Castle, former United States Ambassador to Japan, called for "a hard as well as a just peace" and one "that punishes criminals," in a luncheon address at the Hotel Capitol yesterday afternoon, attended by more than 400 members of Episcopal churches.

ANNE THAXTER EATON believes that all living things have their share of Christmas, and she has collected fable, legend, folklore and poetry to prove her point. Tenderly she reminds us that even the humblest creatures have contributed to the miracle of the Nativity.

Dr. Lionel S. Marks, Professor Emeritus of Mechanical Engineering at Harvard University, in a recent lecture at the Battelle Memorial Institute discussed gas turbines, jet propulsion and rockets. At the outset he explained differences in principles and operation. The rocket plane used by the Germans at the front is merely a rocket projectile supported by wings.

GEORGE MARDIKIAN, the chef who has made famous a foreign cuisine that is little known in this country -- the Armenian -- was in town recently in connection with his new book, "Dinner at Omar Khayyam's," to be published tomorrow by the Viking Press.

A benefit theatre party which has drawn the support of a large group of patrons and patronesses is that arranged under the auspices of the Youth Consultation Service for the performance of "Embezzled Heaven," starring Ethel Barrymore, on the night of Nov. 20 at the National Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Using secret instruments to locate their targets through clouds. B-29's today bombed a Japanese homeland aircraft manufacturing center and transportation and storage facilities in two enemy-held Chinese cities.

Because of the postponement of the opening date of the operetta "Rhapsody" until Nov. 22 at the Century Theatre, two philanthropic organizations which had arranged benefit theatre parties have set new dates for the performances they will sponsor.

Drs. Earl R. Miller and Mary B. Olney (University of California Medical School) have extended and improved the technique of making X-ray pictures so that the blood supply of the heart and body structures may be studied. This enables the physician to diagnose congenital heart defects in children with higher accuracy and to determine whether or not an operation would do any good.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- The International Civil Aviation Conference, which opened here on Nov. 1, is now at what is officially regarded as the half-way mark in its deliberations. Delegations from more than fifty nations, large and small, are still faced with serious problems regarding what kind of control should be exercised over the post-war air traffic among nations.

Twenty years after the Four Horsemen rode to lasting fame the proud pennants of Notre Dame were ripped to tatters and trampled under the thundering caissons of Army yesterday in the worst disaster the Fighting Irish have suffered on the football field.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 11 -- In a move tantamount to a sea blockade of Sweden's Baltic coast, Germany has threatened to cut all Swedish shipping routes with Finland and Russia. The Swedish Foreign Office has delivered a strong protest in Berlin, branding the German threat as harmful to legitimate Swedish interests and placing the responsibility for any consequences on the Reich.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Nov. 11 -- In a field of twenty a young Labrador retriever bitch captured the opening event of the annual meeting of the Women's Field Trial Club today on the estate of Charles L. Lawrance under excellent conditions.
ROME, Nov. 11 (AP) -- A communique:

ROBERT SELPH HENRY, who some years ago, in his "The Story of the Confederacy," gave us the most readable and probably the best one-volume military history of the Confederate States, has now written a comprehensive and masterful biography of the Civil War's greatest cavalryman, Nathan Bedford Forrest.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, France, Nov. 11 -- Six divisions of the American Third Army broke through German rear guards holding the approaches to the Saar Valley and Metz today and cut the main enemy railroad and highway communications with Metz in a day of swift and sure advances.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Nov. 11 -- The Labor party's endorsement of sweeping proposals for the nationalization of industry and its mobilization of unanimous support of a national conference for plans to create a State bank were gained in the absence of Prime Minister Peter Fraser, who entered a private hospital a few days ago for the third time in little more than a year, it was learned today.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Sunday, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Yesterday's account of the Thursday-Friday attacks on the earlier convoy underlined the fact that General MacArthur's land-based air arm still is somewhat limited on Leyte.

THE end of the war will bring not only economic but artistic and commemorative problems. There will be war memorials, many of them. Some communities are already considering what these are to be, others will soon be discussing it. It is an opportunity and also a challenge.

ATLANTA, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Combining the brilliant running of Allen (Dinky) Bowen and the accurate passing of Frank Broyles, Georgia Tech made another bid for its third straight Bowl invitation by overwhelming versatile Tulane, 34 -- 7, today before 22,000 spectators.

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Russian troops, in a wheeling drive on Budapest, yesterday moved to within forty-three miles southeast of the capital, and also struck to within eleven miles of Miskolc, Hungary's fifth city in the northeast, as they steadily expanded their wedge between the German defenders of the two prize cities. President Roosevelt, in a message yesterday to Nathan Straus, praised the purpose of "Night of Stars," a show to be presented Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the United Jewish Appeal.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 11 -- After getting off on the wrong foot by losing the opening kickoff, Colgate's stubborn Red Raiders waged a courageous uphill battle before bowing to the Holy Cross Crusaders by a 19-13 margin today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 11 -- Paced by Frank Raba, who scored three touchdowns, Lafayette clinched the mythical Middle Three championship today by routing Rutgers, 39 -- 0, before a Homecoming Day crowd of 6,000. The Loopards registered in every quarter but the third, tallying three times in the last period.

Establishment of an Industrial Relations Center as a means of providing university-wide service in industrial relations for management executives, union leaders, Government officials, faculty members and students has been announced at the University of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The War Production Board announced today that it has added six pieces to the list of types of silver-plated, chrome-plated and stainless flatware that may be made under Limitation Order L-140-B and has permitted the use of copper base alloy for "blanks" for silver-plated flatware.

The progress made by the medical profession of the Soviet Union during the war years is a forecast of greater development in the fields of medicine and surgery in the post-war period, Prof. Vladimir V. Lebedenko, U.S.S.R., representative of the Red Cross and Red Crescent in this country declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The Battle of Japan is being fought in the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- A proposal to block an automatic $1,500,000,000 increase in Social Security payroll taxes will be offered when Congress reconvenes Tuesday, Senator Vandenberg of Michigan said today.

RYE, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- Two sharply divergent views on the settlement of lend-lease obligations were brought to light today at the international business conference when delegates disclosed that one of the chief reconversion problems Great Britain faces is posed in the attitude the United States will take on the disposal of machine tools.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The polyglot population of California, Washington and Oregon will make them the "racial frontier" of the country in the post-war era, Carey McWilliams, former California Commissioner of Housing and Immigration, told a press conference today.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- The overwhelming view among Europeans who have had time to think about it is that the American elections on Tuesday destroyed whatever vestige of hope of negotiated peace the Germans might still have entertained and supplied the most convincing evidence yet available that this time the United States would help to maintain the peace after helping to win the war.

MOSCOW, Nov. 11 -- Col. Gen. Philip I. PICKPOCKETS love crowds. That is something for people to remember as the Christmas shopping season opens. Crowds are the natural habitat of bag-openers and bag-snatchers.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 11 -- Scoring six touchdowns in the first quarter, Bucknell's Bisons stamped to a 78-to-0 victory today over an outmanned C.C.N.Y. eleven which never advanced beyond the Herd's 45-yard line.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 11 -- Richard Turnbull's 4-year-old chestnut horse Sirius, one of the most heavily backed Melbourne Cup favorites in years, dashed to the front of the field of twenty-three nearly three furlongs from home in the two-mile Cup race before an estimated 100,000 at Flemington today and, in a hard finish, beat Peter by a half length.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Sunday, Nov. 12. -- Navy planes from the fast carriers of Admiral William F. Halsey's Third Fleet wiped out a Japanese convoy this morning as it attempted to ferry further reinforcements to the enemy's hard pressed troops fighting stubbornly to form a defensive line in the Ormoc Valley on northwestern Leyte.
MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Alabama overpowered a fast and spirited University of Mississippi eleven today for a 34-to-6 victory.

Fifteen competitive scholarships ranging in value from $50 to $250 per term will be established at Colgate University starting with the March term. THE Minneapolis Symphony under Dimitri Mitropoulos, which opened its season recently in its home city, is scheduled for eighteen evening subscription concerts, a series of seven Sunday afternoon "Twilight" concerts, six concerts for young people, three performances with the Ballet Theatre and several extra concerts. Antal Dorati and Arthur Fiedler will appear as guest conductors during a fortnight in December.

The Finish radio said yesterday that former Premier Juho K. Paasikivi had accepted the Premiership in a new Finnish Government replacing the Administration of Urho J. Castren and that the members of the new Cabinet were expected to be decided upon shortly.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- The Allied air forces went after German oil again today. About 450 heavy bombers of the United States Eighth Air Force attacked, with their main target the synthetic oil plants at Gelsenkirchen. A slightly smaller fleet of Lancasters of the Royal Air Force blasted similar plants at Castrop-Rauxel, also in the Ruhr.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 11 (U.P.) -- Hugh Baillie, president of The United Press, gave the City Club of Cleveland a comprehensive report today on his recent visit to England and the Western Front in Europe.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Scoring almost at will against the University of Maryland, Michigan State capped its football comeback schedule today with a 33-to-0 victory before 8,000 home-coming visitors.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Penn State's three substitutes came through today to score all the points for the Nittany Lions as they turned back Temple, 7 to 6, in the closing game of the Owls' 1944 football season before 12,000 at Temple Stadium.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 11 -- All Belgium celebrated Armistice Day today with prayers and rejoicing. Prince Charles, Regent of Belgium, laid first a wreath for his brother, King Leopold, who is still a prisoner in Germany.

Mayor of Santiago. the capital of Chile.

However, a few things were wilfully forgotten and fairness pushed aside. * * * Age was completely forgotten; dependents other than by marriage were also forgotten. * * * It is very hard to understand why our plan differs so much from the British plan.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 11 -- West Coast educators were told today that it was their duty to democracy and civilization to demonstrate to those returning service men and women intent on completing their education the value of a strong foundation in the liberal arts.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Minnesota closed its home football season with a 19-to-14 surprise Western Conference victory over Indiana's powerhouse today, turning in its most consistent performance of the year on Memorial Stadium turf.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 -- Election results in the three West Coast States indicated that the voters went to the polls determined not to be wooed by issues which threatened to distract from the job of winning the war and building a stable peace.

LAST spring Artists for Victory assembled and placed on view at the Grand Central Galleries an exhibition of contemporary American paintings, prints and sculpture. It was arranged as a good-will gesture, designed to acquaint the British public with what was afoot over here.

Experts on teeth and public health recently met at the New York Institute of Clinical Oral Pathology to discuss the promise that fluorine, found in some drinking waters, may prevent tooth decay. It was agreed by five authorities that we shall have to wait ten or twelve years before a final decision can be reached.

Specific recommendations for the development of audio-visual programs in the schools of this country have been made by the American Council on Education in its newest publication on "A Measure for Audio-Visual Programs in Schools." This is the first attempt to outline a comprehensive plan for the development of such programs on all organizational levels.

LAST week, at the press opening of a new fashion floor, Elizabeth Arden, in stressing the relationship between a well-proportioned, well-poised figure and a well-designed dress, introduced her conception of "the new American figure."

Ethel Barrymore was reported last night by her physician to be making a normal recovery from an attack of influenza. So well did she exemplify the tradition of her profession, "the show must go on," that she played in her new show, "Embezzled Heaven," Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday with temperatures ranging from 101 to 102.

WASHINGTON. LAST Tuesday the nation chose a man for what is certainly America's toughest job and probably the toughest job in the world. Year by year it has been getting harder and there is no sign of any let-up. When we elect a President we are in effect assigning him to a seven-day week, with days that often end at midnight or later.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 11 -- Out of a welter of rumors on Adolf Hitler's health since he failed to speak on the anniverary Wednesday of the Munich beer-hall putsch it has been impossible to to pick one story that sounds more plausible than another.

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, scored a complete victory in the two-year-old row over "canned music" last night, as the record subsidiaries of the Radio Corporation of America and the Columbia Broadcasting System bowed to the union's demands and signed contracts with it running to the end of 1947.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- No wheels turned for a second day today on the strikebound electric railways which serve 75,000 Chicago-area commuters.

AN Ohio farmer, Louis Bromfield (1,000 acres in the neighborhood of Mansfield), was in town the other day and to this department, which went around to call on him, he said that he is writing a book for Harper's about his life as an agriculturalist.

The Hospitalized Service Men's Committee, Inc., 9 De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn, announced yesterday the opening of its drive to obtain funds to provide potted plants and Christmas trees for veterans in the Army, Navy and Veterans Hospitals in the New York area at Yuletide.

A BLOCK of eight stamps described by Walter S. Scott, veteran auctioneer, as "the greatest showpiece in all philately" will be sold here at public auction tomorrow through Harmer, Rooke Co. Comprising copies of the 1918 United States 24-cent air-mail stamp with inverted centers, the block is the only one of its size existing and has never before been on the market.

THERE is still a telephone shortage. But there is hope in sight for the 190,000 wailing, waiting, phoneless folk in New York State. Slim hope, but hope. The War Production Board recently authorized the making and allocation of a number of new residence telephones.

THIS book is an "In Memoriam" to Clark Poling, who died in this war. Written by his father, Dr. Daniel Poling, it began as a letter to Clark Poling's year-old son (nicknamed Corky) to give him a living picture of the father he would never see again -- a touching thought that will grip at the heartstrings of many people.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 11 (AP) -- U;elker Cochran gained 12 points on Willie Hoppe in the eighth block of their world championship threecushion billiard match tonight, besting the champion, 62 -- 50, in seventy-seven innings.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 11 -- Yale University and close relatives of employes of the New York Central Railroad will be beneficiaries of an unusual bequest in the will of the late Frederick E. Williamson. He was a member of the class of 1898 at Yale and had been president of the New York Central System until his retirement last August.

The Citizens National Committee has performed a useful public service in publishing a sixty-eight-page handbook called "Federal Agencies." It lists 428 agencies in detail and its index contains more than 1,100 entries. It provides information concerning each functional unit of the Federal Government as of June 30, 1944; it gives the year of each agency's creation, the number of employes, appropriations, and so on.

COMPIEGNE, France, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Two hundred American soldiers participated in ceremonies today in the Forest of Compiegne, where the armistice that ended World War I was signed -- and where Hitler, in June, 1940, imposed his armistice terms on France.

FROM Paris have come the photographs of the recent couture openings. They represent the gallant spirit of such French designers as have carried on during the war years. Many of the leaders of pre-war days are either absent from Paris or have not been reported as contributing to the openings.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 11 -- The Bulldog has not lost his bite. A Yale football team met Brown for the forty-ninth time and beat the Bruins in the Yale Bowl today, 13 -- 0, for Eli's thirty-eighth triumph in the series.

AMERICA had to be made before it could be lived in, and that making took centuries, took extraordinary energies and bred an attitude to life that is peculiarly American. It bred the temper of the pioneer, the temper of the gambler, the temper of the booster, the temper of the discounter of the future who is to some extent bound to be a disparager of the past.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- More than 100 golfers will tee off today in the opening of the 6,700- yard-long championship course at the Southern Pines Country Club. Many of the golfers will be officers and soldiers from near-by Camp Mackall, who are given special rates.

KURT SEVERIN is a photographer who first won a professional reputation by managing to click a camera just as a bullfighter got his pants torn off by a bull. Aided by this happy incident, he wandered as free-lance photographer for fifteen years through the cities, plains, jungles and mountains of Latin America.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- There is a catch line in the section of the Selective Service Act guaranteeing re-employment rights to veterans -- the stipulation that it applies only to men with discharges "other than dishonorable" -- which evidently is not understood by large numbers of men in the armed services or by many already discharged.

WITH THE UNITED STATES THIRD ARMY, in France, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Two confessed German spies who were convicted by a military commission Oct. 18 were executed by a firing squad today. The execution was the first announced in the Third Army's sector.
The people of the United States demonstrated last week that political democracy can function in wartime. Close to 48,000,000 Americans went to the polls.

BOSTON, Nov. 11 -- While the New England States cast their ballots along expected lines, it was clearly apparent from the election that the region has more interest in the war and the peace than in purely domestic policies.

BOYS want war books; they will continue to want them for some time. These two will be eagerly devoured, especially by younger readers. Mr. Reck's volume of separate stories describes the different men of the Army who have won the Medal of Honor (sometimes called the Congressional Medal), the highest decoration awarded by this country. and how they won the award.

In "The House," Marjorie Hill Allee regards her audience of young people with respect. She assumes that they live in a real world in which they are familiar with birth and death love and war, fear and sorrow, as well as happiness.

SOMETHING like a sense of impending disaster falls heavily on the hearts of many earnest citizens these days whenever the thought of "race" comes to mind. It is a feeling of hopeless inevitability, as though presentday relations between groups and races were almost, if not quite, beyond successful handling.

The Piccadilly Arcade, a colorful mart that has been operated at 6 East Fifty-seventh Street since the autumn of 1941 by the British War Relief Society, will move to new quarters at 870 Madison Avenue on Tuesday. The shop, which offers for sale antiques and objets d'art from New York homes and from communities as distant as California, had been closed for the summer and early autumn.

A TOLERABLY busy fellow (publisher, columnist, radio performer). Bennett Cerf is also a brave one, as anyone would have to he when setting out to record a lot of stories some of which practically everybody has read or heard, occasionally in a presentation more expert than Mr. Cerf, who is not by profession a raconteur, can manage.
