WITH NORTHERN GROUP of Armies in the Netherlands, Nov. 11 -- The twenty-sixth anniversary of Armistice Day that wound up World War I meant nothing today to front-line fighting troops, but behind the lines, wherever possible, troops observed the customary minute silence at 11 A.M. and many attended brief religious services.

Anthrax germs, which are so tough that they resist most killing chemicals, apparently yield to penicillin, Dr. F.R. Heilman and Dr. W.E. Herrell of the Mayo Clinic have found. Mice at least receive some protection when penicillin is used against 10,000 times the lethal dose of anthrax germs even when treatment is not started until sixteen hours after inoculation.

British exports of cotton textile will be under a strict quota system for at least two years after the war with the possibility of rigid Government control for a much longer period, it was learned last week from importers familiar with the situation.

FOR his seventh novel in fourteen years Dr. Cronin offers us "The Green Years," a slice of Scotch-Irish autobiography that teems with quiet charm and the special brand of heartache that this painstaking author is so adept at fashioning.

When victory is here and I come home I hope I will not run into a phony pacifism. I hope the average man will be awake to the task that lies ahead for educating the world for peace. The Allies have spent much to win the war (it was worth every cent of it); they must now spend much to teach the way of peace.

The fifty-second annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, opening on Wednesday morning at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, is expected to attract 2,000 of the nation's leading marine industry figures to the various technical sessions, four of which will be held on Thursday and Friday.

What is Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's political future? He is still young -- 42 -- ambitious and energetic. Will he be able to maintain his position as titular head of the Republican party, and if so, will he seek the Republican Presidential nomination in 1948? What will be his course during the remaining two years of his Governorship?

SEVENTY-FIVE years ago this month the first two intercollegiate football games were played in this country, the beginning of a great sport that ever since has tested young men's courage and stamina and turned spectators into mildly insane dervishes. It has become our greatest sport spectacle, a circus of color and sound, of deep roaring from tens of thousands of wild-eyed men and women, of flashing movement and human drama.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Northwestern's stubborn Wildcats held Boris (Babe) Dimancheff scoreless, but the Western Conference scoring leader's mates supplied punch enough to give Purdue a 27-7 football triumph today.

THE Army Air Force is today carrying out a phase of rehabilitation work that was a dream during the first World War. Under the supervision of Mrs. Lillian Bettinger men who have lost fingers, hands, arms or toes in combat may now have these parts replaced so that the casual observer will scarcely detect the difference between the synthetic substitute and the real thing.

" Armistice Day," said Rabbi Louis I. Newman in Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, yesterday, "following so closely upon the battle of election day, should bring a truce in political warfare in the United States. Now is the time for Americans to display a united front not only to their enemies but also to their Allies, the United Nations."

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- Prime Minister Churchill surprised Paris today by appearing beside Gen. Charles de Gaulle at an Armistice Day celebration and by bringing with him the Allies' long-awaited invitation to the French Government to sit with the other three major Allied powers in the European Advisory Commission.

Col. C.V. Whitney of the Army Air Forces named his current crop of young racers from his experiences in the North African campaign and turned loose two of them yesterday, Recce and Big Push, with the former capturing the $10,000 Nellie Morse Purse, feature of the Victory meet program at Belmont Park.

JAMES P. WARBURG has written an interesting book, and many of his observations, notably those on the political and diplomatic developments here and in Europe during the past decade, are worth pondering. His thesis is a highly controversial one, as will be seen.

We can now begin to see that last Tuesday's election was important to ourselves and to the world in far more than the partisan sense. The re-election of President Roosevelt for the fourth term was, of course a victory for a man and a party. But the results of the voting spoke for much more than a single man and a single party.

IN an article that will appear in the November issue of the American Steamship and Tourist Agents Association News, A.L. Simmons, vice president of Simmons Tours, writes on the future of travel as he sees it after nearly a quarter century of selling tours to and arranging cruises for the American public.
Maj. Raymond R. Camp, who conducted this column for THE TIMES before he went to war, got a couple of days off in Italy to go duck shooting. This is his report:

The picture painted for international aviation in the brave, new post-war world is a bright one. Routes will literally circle the globe bringing world capitals that were days or weeks apart by sea and land travel only hours apart. No place on the globe, aviation experts contend, will be more than Sixty hours distant by air from any other.

One of the epics of American military history is the role played by the Third Army in the liberation of France. After the break-through at Avranches during the first week in August Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's troops spearheaded the assault which carried the Allied armies across France in one month to the very borders of the Reich.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- The German V-2 rocket bomb, described as a thirteen and one-half ton wingless projectile that cuts through space at a maximum speed of 3,500 miles an hour, has been falling in Allied sectors in Belgium and France as well as in Britain, front dispatches approved by Army censors said tonight.

The last regularly scheduled school football double-header at Ebbets Field yesterday brought victory to Abraham Lincoln High over James Madison, 12 -- 0, and to Lafayette over Samuel J. Tilden, 20 -- 19. A crowd of 5,000 watched.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 11 -- A conference to be held this week-end between the Belgian Cabinet and the Supreme Headquarters Allied Expeditionary Force mission to Belgium on the means by which industry can best be restored illustrates the difficulty of setting the country back on its feet. Developments here are being closely watched by other powers confronted by roughly the same situation.

SINCE last week's column was written, I have returned to Gide's "Imaginary Interviews," and have found them to be, throughout, provocative and stimulating reading. I think they must be so for anyone who is interested in literature as an art.

PUT all the well known names in the field of entertainment into a hat, mix well and pull out about half a dozen. Write a program around them and put it on the air for half an hour. Do it once a week. And you'll have a slight idea of what "Command Performance" is like and what the men in uniform all over the world are getting in the way of radio entertainment.

The fantastic story of an American-built merchant vessel returning from a sea voyage in two parts, the bow and stern at different times, her repair and return to war sevice, was disclosed yesterday by the War Shipping Administration. The vessel, now operated by the American Mail Line, Ltd., is the Alexander Baranoff, formerly the Valeri Chkalov.

The Old Farmer's Almanac is out again, for the 153d time, and as usual taking busy people's thoughts away from what they ought to be doing. This year it has a feather in its cap, for wise old Mr. Weatherwise, who runs a competition with the Weather Bureau, predicted a mild winter, and the winter, in fact, was mild.
MOSCOW, Nov. 11 (Reuter) -- Russia may soon startle the world with mass seaborne landings on German soil on the Normandy model.

AFTER an election which has demonstrated that imported propaganda methods do not work so well in this country, business interests last week were rather generally agreed that the long rear-guard action against certain social and economic reforms is nearing an end.

At Dayton, Ohio, Col. Donald J. Keirn has received the Thurman H. Bane Award for 1944 for his contribution to the development and utilization of the new jet-propulsion aircraft engine. The award, which is presented annually for the most important technical achievement by an officer or civilian of the Air Technical Service Command, was established in 1942 by Major R.H. Fleet, president of the Institute of Aeronautical Sciences.

A FIRST-DAY (Oct. 24) cover from Buenos Aires brings the stamp promised in commemoration of establishment of "Universal Savings Day" on Oct. 31 by the International Savings Congress which met in Italy in 1922.

Arthur Truxes yesterday led the Black and Gold clad harriers of West Point to victory in the sixth annual Heptagonal championship cross-country. Making the pace to suit himself and winning as he pleased on the five-mile run over turf, macadamized road, hills and trails of the taxing Van Cortlandt Park course, Truxes repeated his victory of last year.

MARIE HALL ETS has given us that rare thing, a book of shared delight for adults and children. As effortless and unself-conscious as a child's own make-believe, it takes the reader of any age along with the little boy as, with his new horn and a paper hat, he goes for a walk in the forest.

Liberty of the press, as guaranteed in the Bill of Rights, was no new idea, but the culmination of a century-old fight between printers and officials. MOSCOW, Nov. 11 -- Moscow's three leading newspapers -- Pravda, Izvestia and Red Star -- today published their first editorial reaction to the election of President Roosevelt to a fourth term, declaring that the decision of the voters of the United States was greeted with satisfaction by the Soviet public.

AFTER the broadcast of Dec. 3 the "Radio Hall of Fame," which has been starring talent selected by Variety, will revert to a straight musical show under the direction of Paul Whiteman. FUEL or no fuel, there is no reason for neglecting use of the greenhouse this winter. It can be run cooler, if necessary, or only for a few months at the end of the season. For a greenhouse is too much fun and too big an investment to stand idle.

BASLE, Switzerland, Nov. 11 -- Hitler's failure to mark Nov. 8 and 9 with even so much as a proclamation, coupled with his radio silence since immediately after the July 20 bomb plot, has led to a state of nervousness about him among the German people that may force the Nazi party hierarchy and the Gestapo to reluctant revelations, according to information here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The National War Labor Board ruled today that it could not recognize a wartime strike as "legal" even though the employes involved had observed the thirty-day notice and election provisions of the War Labor Disputes Act.

ROME, Nov. 11 -- The Allies' troops marked Armistice Day today in the Piazza Venezia and at St. Peter's.

A MAN dies horribly with the strains of the wedding march ringing in his ears. Who that man was we do not learn until much farther along in the story. What we do learn is that the wedding march is being played for Lola Blithe, who is to marry Red Kerrigan, recently divorced from his first wife, Kathy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Franklin D. Roosevelt is back at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, about the only man in town with a secure four-year lease on a well-situated house, and the question that is being asked now is: Which Roosevelt is this, the crusading Roosevelt of the first New Deal or the cautious Roosevelt of 1944?

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 11 -- Developing a scoring punch that it had lacked in the first half, the Princeton football team came from behind to defeat Muhlenberg in Palmer Stadium today, 16 to 6. The Pennsylvanians were out in front, 6 -- 0, at the intermission, but the Tigers won the first game of their 1944 season by scoring two touchdowns and a field goal in the closing periods.
PARIS, Nov. 11. -- While American planes assured their security from above, Parisians celebrated the anniversary of the armistice of 1918 today as a token of recovered sovereignty.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 11 -- Within a few weeks after the first of the year the powerful Pacific carrier force will have twice the strength it had just before the opening of the Marianas campaign last Spring, Rear Admiral George D. Murray, USN, disclosed today.

LINCOLIN, Neb., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Gene Phelps, a second-string quarterback for Iowa State until this afternoon, led the Cyclones to a 19-to-6 victory over Nebraska today with three touchdowns scored on runs of five, four and ten yards.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- France was formally invited today to sit in the European Advisory Commission in London in full membership with the "big three" powers, Great Britain, Russia and the United States. The invitation admits French counsels in the war settlement with Germany and other problems of the coming peace.

HOWARD HAWKS is the latest recruit to that growing company of top-notch Hollywood personalities to declare in favor of independent production. The director has been busy the last couple of weeks with his attorneys, setting up the financial structure and other details for his new company.

JACK PEARL and Harry Green, those redoubtable comedians, are going to try again. Last year the pair put up most of the finances for "All for All" and by way of insurance appeared in the show. "All for All" managed to amble along for eighty-five showings and then just ambled out.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Estimating that 350,000 Japanese had been flung into the sprawling battle for Kwangsi Province, the Chinese High Command admitted tonight that the enemy had broken into Kweilin and also was pushing a menacing drive in the south toward important Yungning [Nanning].

The educational level of the men in the armed forces is considerably higher today than it was during the first World War. This fact will prove of significance to the schools and colleges of the country.

ROME, Nov. 11 (AP) -- British Eighth Army troops grinding slowly forward from captured Forli in the eastern Po Valley were halted today just outside the city at the Ravaldino Canal, which they found the German tanks and infantry defending in considerable strength.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 11 (AP) -- With Stan Weiner, ex-Yale freshman sensation, and Tommy Dorsey, formerly of Brown, stealing the show, the Coast Guard Academy squared last year's defeat by decisively beating Darthmouth today, 19 -- 0.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Nov. 11 -- The Japanese on Bougainville having rejected a surrender demand and an offer of honorable terms, anti-Japanese air offensives have been resumed at all possible strength, the Air Department said today.

Heralded as "a benefit show that is different," an entertainment entitled "CSA Varieties" will be presented the night of Nov. 21 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria to raise funds for the Child Study Association of America and its program of counseling families confronted with wartime problems.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- George P. Monaghan, special prosecutor, following up his charges that four of the Supreme Court justices of the Third Judicial District were subjected to undue political influence, said today that he would move "swiftly and vigorously" to bring to trial the indictments returned by the special grand jury investigating the Albany County Democratic organization.

Efforts to make up a $5,021,875 deficit in the $17,200,000 goal of the New York War Fund will be undertaken this week under the joint leadership of Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker, president of Eastern Airlines, and Newbold Morris, President of the City Council.

The United States must do its share in keeping world peace, Bishop William T. Manning of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York declared yesterday morning at the consecration of St. Martin's Church, Lenox Avenue and 122d Street, where he officiated.

The New York Photo-Engravers Union, Local 1, Celebrating its fiftieth anniversary last night with a dinner dance at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn, was told by Mayor La Guardia that the gathering typified "not only the success of your organization but the success of the workingman and woman in the country."

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 11 -- The result of the national election indicates rather definitely that the chance of the two-party system becoming established in Louisiana is not as remote as might appear on the surface. The returns show that Mr. Roosevelt carried every parish in Louisiana, but Mr. Dewey received the heaviest Republican vote recorded in this State since the Rutherford B. Hayes election in 1876.

Stocks of merchandise at retail do not reflect the vast shortages that are apparent in the wholesale markets, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

SEED planting is a fall as well as a spring accomplishment and need not be considered a thing of the past this year. During this month, before the ground freezes, certain annuals may still be sown. By selecting the spots where we wish these annuals to flower, pictures are created for next spring, summer and fall.

Twelve high school students have won first prize of $200 each and honorable mention awards have been made to 200 others in an art competition conducted by the Women's National Institute of New York. The Garnet, with a number of fine runners in its backfield and a line that ably held off the Violets' strongest efforts to advance, made an impressive showing against the local eleven.

ALBANY, Nov. 11 -- Users of gas, electric and telephone services are more than $1,000,000 in pocket in the last year because of lowered rates which have been agreed to through the efforts of the Public Service Commission, according to records just released here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- President Roosevelt led the country in observance of Armistice Day today when he stood at attention before the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington National Cemetery at 11 o'clock this morning, just twenty-six years after the guns ceased firing in the last World War, and a wreath was deposited in his name before the tomb.

WITH the crisp competence which distinguished her previous biographies Mrs. Baker presents a figure of especial interest today. Walk in the woods or through the November meadow and you scuffle them underfoot, a magnificent rustling of crisp browns and purples and reds and yellows.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- Central Westerners, analyzing Tuesday's Election returns in Illinois, have not failed to note the political trend indicated by the severe drubbing the voters administered to Republican candidates for national office who had been denounced in the campaign as "arch-isolationists."

ON that somewhat awesome day when the historians get around to poking their grimy fingers into what is the now current theatre they will come on a name which may give them considerable concern. It is Harvey, of course.
Gov. Herbert O'Conor of Maryland and Mrs. O'Conor have come from Annapolis to the Biltmore.

IS the listener himself willing to pay directly in cash for a radio program service free from advertising? That provocative question, carrying with it broad challenges from every standpoint to the accepted system of broadcasting in this country, has been advanced in a project submitted to the Federal Communications Commission.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 11 --Stopping Illinois' speedster left halfback, Claude (Buddy) Young, except for a pair of midfield sprints in the first period, Michigan defeated Illinois, 14 to 0, for its fifth straight football victory today before a crowd of 42,200.

AFTER an eight-month sojourn in the Army, Erich Leinsdorf, the young Cleveland Orchestra conductor, has returned to New York's musical life with a fresh slant on our problems and new hopes of finding solutions for them.

ROME, Nov. 11 -- The Bonomi Government stands very shakily today, with many signs pointing to an open crisis. Both the Communists and Christian Democrats held party meetings this week and issued resolutions today that bode ill for the Government, while Pietro Nenni, Socialist party secretary, in this morning's issue of the Avanti accepted the Catholic party's challenge with a challenge of his own.

RAFAELLO BUSONI is best known to lovers of fine children's books as an illustrator. Here, in words and pictures, he tells his story of Henry Stanley, whose employer thought it would be a good newspaper stunt to "rescue" Dr. Livingstone in Darkest Africa.

A model grocery store will be opened under Office of Price Administration auspices tomorrow on the fourth floor of the Empire State Building, but not to supply housewives with bacon, sugar, butter and other hard-to-get staples. The store, whose shelves will bear some real foods and some dummy packages, is to be a feature of Anti-Inflation Week and is intended primarily to demonstrate to retail grocers how to post ceiling prices properly.

ON that somewhat awesome day when the historians get around to poking their grimy fingers into what is the now current theatre they will come on a name which may give them considerable concern. It is Harvey, of course.

Enrollment of civilian students at the University of Kansas is 10 per cent greater than it was a year ago. The university has its greatest female enrollment in history. A six-point post-war program has been announced: establishment of a Bureau of Veterans Service a new test and guidance program, establishment of new courses to fit modern needs, improved instructional techniques, an improved arrangement for more personal guidance of students and reorganization of academic requirements.

Although about 400 spot authorizations have been granted to produce inner-spring mattresses there is little likelihood that any sizable number of such mattresess will be available for some time, it was learned last week.
BY its recent season at the Metropolitan Opera House the Ballet Theatre proved beyond peradventure that it has nothing to fear from its rivals in the field at the moment.
ROME, Nov. 11 -- The British Navy has cleared a route through the heavily mined Aegean Sea to Salonika just ten days after the strategic city's liberation, a naval communique revealed today.

THE artist who brightened countless Christmases with "The Tall Book of Mother Goose" and "The Tall Book of Nursery Tales" has done it again with this perfect children's book. His 200 color illustrations are exciting, prickle with action, evoke easy laughter.

An official appeal to schools, libraries and youth groups was made yesterday at the opening of Children's Book Week by the book committee of the Women's Council for Post-War Europe, Inc., for books to be included in Treasure Chests to be sent as Christmas gifts from the children of this country to children of devastated areas.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -- After rolling up a 35-to-0 lead on Columbia's hapless and helpless Lions in the first half of today's game, George Munger, coach of the Pennsylvania eleven, suddenly remembered what day it was and declared an armistice by yanking his regulars and finishing with his third and fourth stringers.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 11 -- The Japanese landing on the west coast of Leyte in the Ormoc region represents a third and last attempt to knock us off the island, but the bid is too late. The first major move to smash the American operation was the triple-prong move by the Japanese southern and home fleet to defeat our Navy and erase the beachhead.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 11 --Stopping Illinois' speedster left halfback, Claude (Buddy) Young, except for a pair of midfield sprints in the first period, Michigan defeated Illinois, 14 to 0, for its fifth straight football victory today before a crowd of 42,200.

THE lovely prayer that Rachel Field wrote for her own little daughter, out of a deep and sensitive understanding of childhood, has been illustrated by Elizabeth Orton Jones with so much tenderness and imagination that anyone who has ever known and loved a child will be touched and charmed.

WORDSWORTH was once described as "childish." "infantile,'' "silly," "affected," "driveling" and several other uncomplimentary things. Victor Hugo was supposed to be vilely indecent "The Scarlet Letter," according to the North American Review, was a work of pollution and vice.

The Rangers finally crashed the victory column in the National Hockey League last night. Defeated in all four previous outings this season, the New York purchasing aggregation came into its own by defeating the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden 5 to 2.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- American merchant ships delivered 500,000 tons of supplies and 30,000 troops at Leyte Island in the three weeks after the invasion, the War Shipping Administration announced today.

IN a recent article by Leopold Schwarzchild called "Six Delusions About Germany," which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine, the author quoted Bismarck as saying: "If Austria did not exist, it would have to be invented."
LONDON, Nov. 11 (UP) -- A communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

Pierre Monteux, conducting the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night, presented what seemed on the face of it a curious program, but what turned out to be a peculiarly well-chosen and satisfying one. There were two features, the first being the noble violin concerto in D minor of Sibelius, Opus 47, with Michael Rosenker, Russian violinist, who is assistant concertmaster of the orchestra, as the soloist.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 11 -- The trend toward political independence in the Upper South was continued in this week's Presidential election, even though all the States maintained their Democratic allegiance. Mr. Roosevelt carried Virginia, the Carolinas, Kentucky and Tennessee by sharply reduced majorities from those he polled four years ago against Wendell Willkie.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 11 -- Baron Bernt von Goessler, nominally chief official of German Tourist Bureau in Stockholm but more privately considered the Gestapo branch manager in Sweden, has been arrested by Stockholm security police and will be deported immediately as undesirable alien dangerous to Sweden, the police announced today.

TACLOBAN, Leyte, Nov. 8 (Delayed) -- American troops have been in the Philippines nearly three weeks now and already a comprehensive pattern has begun to emerge of the civil administration they are attempting to re-establish with the enthusiastic aid of a people suddenly restored from military tyranny to democracy.

BOONTON, N. J., Nov. 11. -- With the material and methods of manufacturing at hand today in the plastics industry, the all-plastic automobile is "just an engineer's dream," declares George K. Scribner, president of the Society of the Plastics Industry, who maintains that in the post-war world plastics and metals will be "collaborators rather than competitors."

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 11 -- Allan J. Shafer, 17-year-old freshman quarterback of the University of Wisconsin football team, died in a hospital early tonight, a few hours after he had participated in the Badgers' 26-to-7 Dad's Day triumph over Iowa's Hawkeyes.

THE somewhat terse announcement that Lily Pons would not be at the Metropolitan Opera next season because she will be doing "war work," has been amplified, and we now learn that she and her husband, Andre Kostelanetz, the conductor, are going on another fifteen-week overseas tour to entertain service men.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 11 -- With the regulars in action less than half the game, Navy's gridiron forces, their guns trained on that Dec. 2 date with Army, made merry today at the expense of Cornell. Among the crowd of 25,000 persons at Baltimore Stadium none could possibly deny that Carl Snavely's Ithacans were thoroughly outclassed, even more than the 48-0 score indicates.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- A country-wide celebration on Sunday, Nov. 19, of the fiftieth anniversary of the World's Y.W.C.A., with better relations between races as its theme, was announced here today.

When the King of Denmark came to spy out Gotland in the year 1360 a boy and his goose played a strange part in his unmasking. When the king came back with his army to plunder the riches of Visby it was the peasants of Frabo, Gylf's village, and of countless other villages, who stood outside the city gates in vain but gallant defense of their island.
LONDON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

THE biggest news of the new Moscow drama season is the controversy raging about the production and performance of Alexei Tolstoi's "Ivan the Terrible," which Moscow audiences saw only a few times before it was withdrawn for drastic improvements in the staging and acting technique.

Having increased by 500 within the past four months, labor management production committees are now operating in more than 5,000 war plants throughout the country, T.K. Quinn, director general of the War Production Drive of the War Production Board, announced yesterday.

" PHANTOM VICTORY," a fictional history of the Fourth Reich from 1945 to 1960, leaves the reader with the shuddery after-feeling of a particularly gruesome nightmare. The story opens with the last meeting of the German General Staff as the Allies are about to enter Germany proper.

NOMENY, France, Nov. 11 -- The combination of Armistice Day and Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's birthday may have been a contributing factor psychologically, but in any event all indications pointed to a German withdrawal in this sector of the American Third Army front today.

WHEN Dorothea Capper, an impecunious spinster, learns that she has fallen heir to the considerable fortune of Everard Hope on the sole condition that she be alive thirty days after the will is read she is warned that efforts will probably be made to see that she does not live so long.

PROFESSOR RUDIN'S thoroughly documented study of the armistice in 1918 is particularly timely. It confirms the old saying that it is much easier to begin a war than to end one, and easier to end a war than make a peace.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Two Government-owned and operated cross-country pipelines, which transport petroleum and petroleum products at lower rates than ocean tankers or tank cars can carry them, probably will be available for sale to private industry after the war, with reasonable allowance for depreciation.

NOMENY, France, Nov. 11 -- The combination of Armistice Day and Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's birthday may have been a contributing factor psychologically, but in any event all indications pointed to a German withdrawal in this sector of the American Third Army front today.

WHEN Dorothea Capper, an impecunious spinster, learns that she has fallen heir to the considerable fortune of Everard Hope on the sole condition that she be alive thirty days after the will is read she is warned that efforts will probably be made to see that she does not live so long.

PROFESSOR RUDIN'S thoroughly documented study of the armistice in 1918 is particularly timely. It confirms the old saying that it is much easier to begin a war than to end one, and easier to end a war than make a peace.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Two Government-owned and operated cross-country pipelines, which transport petroleum and petroleum products at lower rates than ocean tankers or tank cars can carry them, probably will be available for sale to private industry after the war, with reasonable allowance for depreciation.

Senator Ball points out in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine that Senator Robert A. Taft voted against the Lend-Lease Act and is, nevertheless, in favor of an international organization to insure peace. Senator Ball's observation is confirmed by the excellent article on the formation of such an organization written by Senator Taft and published in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Feb. 6, 1944.

In the appeal issued this month in behalf of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies there is no closing of eyes to the gravity of the years that will fellow military victory. It is not enough, says the federation, to meet the responsibilities of today, great though they are.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, France, Nov. 12--Maj. Gen. Manton S. Eddy's Twelfth Army Corps, fighting on the right flank of the American Third Army's battleline in Lorraine, swung inexorably to the northeast today, slicing through German communications with Metz, while the northern wing of the offensive, extending from four miles north of Metz to the German frontier, pinned down the Germans along the Moselle Valley.
A three-goal lead with only half a period remaining failed to stand up for the New York Rangers in their National Hockey League game with the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden last night.

The inter-racial program introduced at Sydenham Hospital last December was pronounced out of the experimental stage last night by speakers at a rally sponsored by the Sydenham Hospital Fund at the New York Times Hall. The meeting reopened the hospital's drive for $350,000.

Two smashing air blows at enemy convoys attempting to reinforce the Japanese on Leyte Island should not unduly elate us. Both were defensive victories. One at least did not prevent a substantial addition to the enemy army at Ormoc. Nor should we underestimate General Yamashita or the forces at his command.

LONDON, Nov. 12 (Reuter) -- Britain has taken defensive action against Hitler's V-2 rockets by switching large forces of heavy bombers to pound targets vital to the Germans' offensive -- synthetic oil plants and the few remaining natural oil refineries in the Reich. The V-2 burns about 2,500 gallons of gasoline a minute and carries 12,500 gallons.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast by the Free Yugoslav radio in Serbo-Croat and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

In a desperate gesture of defiance, the Nazi regime staged yesterday what it described as nation-wide induction ceremonies for the newly created Home Guard, which were also represented as a belated anniversary celebration of Hitler's Munich beer-hall putsch of 1923.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Life-saving whole blood will be available to wounded service men as far away as Leyte Island 48 hours after being drawn from a donor in San Francisco, under a new aero-medical program beginning here this week.

ONCE upon a time there was an Irishman who toiled as a laborer on a road-building job. His task consisted of splitting boulders with a sledge hammer. He was smashing away at one particularly stubborn rock without even denting it. Along came the foreman, very much annoyed with the obvious failure of his hired hand.

A small, red-and-gold bound book explaining the meaning and construction of Chinese written characters will be published Nov. 21 by Pantheon Books. The author is Rose Quong, a Chinese actress and lecturer who was born in Australia and has lived in both England and China.

The orderly growth of New York City after the war will be retarded unless a single agency like the City Planning Commission is formed to coordinate the functions of the twenty-seven governmental groups now functioning in the field of planning and building, according to a report just issued by the Committee on Civic Design and Development of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

SEA ISLAND BEACH, Ga., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York, seeking rest and relaxation after his hard but unsuccessful campaign for President on the Republican ticket, arrived here today for a vacation of possibly two weeks.

Luckily for "On the Town," the Metro-backed musical doesn't have to come to grips with the booking jam. The International Theatre, located in Columbus Circle, is waiting to receive it on Thursday night, Dec. 28. Today the Oliver Smith-Paul Feigay offering will commence practicing, George Abbott directing.

A lasting peace will only be achieved when nations and individuals, seeking to end repeated public and private wars, learn to accept established rules of law, Chief Judge Irving Lehman of the Court of Appeals asserted yesterday at the opening of the lecture series celebrating the centenary of Congregation Emanu-El.

Even though municipal and corporation bonds do not meet the statutory tests provided, the State Banking Board may allow savings banks to invest in them, according to a decision made public yesterday by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein. The decision was made at the request of Elliott V. Bell, State Superintendent of Banks.

At least fourteen points will be added to the city's present basic real estate tax rate of $2.79 in the course of the next three years, it was predicted yesterday by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick in a report on the proposed capital budget for 1945, as recently adopted by the City Planning Commission.
Five films, including one importation from France, comprise the list of attractions arriving in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 13 -- Red Army tanks and infantry advanced up to thirteen miles in a wide outflanking movement east of Budapest yesterday and hammered to within seven miles of Jaszbereny, a major enemy stronghold guarding the eastern approaches to the Hungarian capital.

The reoccupation of the island province of Leyte by United States forces revives memories of the two years during which its capital, Tacloban, was this writer's headquarters as a member of the Philippine judiciary. He found it an interesting region, rich in agricultural products, especially abaca (hemp), and with a preponderantly friendly population which had elected an American Governor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (U.P.) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, appealed today for support of the sixth War Loan, which will begin Nov. 20 and run through Dec. 16, and especially asked civilians to sign up as workers in the drive in their communities.

In a sermon yesterday at Christ Methodist Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, Bishop Herbert Welch, chairman of the Methodist Commission for Overseas Relief, called for "brotherhood between China and the United States."
A UNTED STATES B-29 BASE, in West China, Nov. 11 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Hollywood-GI feud is over so far as American Superfortress jockeys are concerned.

VUGHT, the Netherlands, Nov. 12 -- On the outskirts of this recently liberated town there is a "housing development." Newly built brick buildings line its little streets. There are nurseries and playgrounds, flower beds here and there and a large square that looks like an athletic field but is a parade ground.
PARIS, Nov. 12 -- French and Polish women who endured nightmarish months in a German concentration camp operated by women of the SS, tell stories of sadism equal to most of the camps with men guards.

The British radio, in a special program beamed to Austria, reminded Austrians that yesterday was the twenty-sixth anniversary of the founding of the Austrian Republic and broadcast messages from two Austrian organizations in England, the Free Austrian Movement and the Austrian Council.

Members of the foster home committee of the Children's Aid Society will meet today for a tea at the home of Mrs. John Holme Ballantine, the chairman, to discuss plans for the society's annual opera benefit, which is being resumed after a lapse of several years.

I should like to supplement my letter which you published Nov. 11 by stating a few positive reasons in favor of consulting Congress at any time we are called upon to make the grave decision regarding whether our armed forces should be sent against those of any "aggressor" nation.

ONE of the most popular novelists in the world today is a Scots doctor of Irish descent named A.J. Cronin. Some fourteen years ago, during an enforced rest from his busy London practice, Dr. Cronin wrote furiously and soon produced a long and powerful novel about an egomaniac, "Hatter's Castle." The rest is publishing history, if not quite literary history.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12 -- Despite fluctuations owing to repairs, strikes and other market factors, the national rate of production of steel ingots regained 2 1/2 points last week and climbed to 96 per cent of rated capacity, the level of two weeks ago. Indications are that raw-steel output this week will be about equivalent to last week's tonnage.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Although there was never any real doubt here that President Roosevelt would obtain re-election, his triumph has nevertheless come as a relief to financial London. Gone are the days, however, when Presidential elections in the United States provide excitement in the market.

Difficulty can be stimulating, arousing in the individual, character and effort that easy days do not call out, but to produce that effect there must be some relevance and proportion between the size of the problem "and our ability and resources," the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, the pastor, declared yesterday in his sermon at the Riverside Church.

The twenty-two-story Starrett-Lehigh Building in the block bounded by Eleventh and Twelfth Avenues, Twenty-sixth and Twenty-seventh Streets, on the West Side of Manhattan, and the fourteen-story Lehigh-Bronx Building, at Girard Avenue and East 144th Street, in the Bronx, have been sold by the Lehigh Valley Railroad, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- The after-harvest movement of cash corn to terminal markets is well under way, primary receipts exceeding 1,000,000 bushels daily. Although there was much good-quality grain received at the same time, the warm weather of last week resulted in many cars arriving at leading markets out of condition, due to fermentation, high moisture content and lack of ventilation.

The Citizens Transit Committee, headed by former Corporation Counsel Paul Windels, announced yesterday its intention to renew its efforts to get the Legislature to pass a bill under which the city, by local law, could create a Transit Authority with power to rehabilitate the subway system and to charge a self-sustaining fare not to exceed 10 cents.

ABOARD A CARRIER WITH THE THIRD FLEET, Off the Philippines, Nov. 7 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Navy's great flying ace, Cmdr. David McCampbell of Los Angeles, has increased his total of Japanese planes destroyed in the air to thirty-two.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The United States Government is urged to preserve the existing structure of the World Court at The Hague as a part of the United Nations international security organization in an appeal to Secretary of State Cordell Hull signed by some forty leaders of the American bar.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- Just when all seemed lost save honor for the New York Football Giants in today's all-important game with the Eagles, the blue-jersied warriors resorted to the weakest link in their chain of offensive armor to score two touchdowns in the closing moments of a thrill-drenched contest and wind up in a 21-21 tie.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $51,573,430,397. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, non-interest bearing discount bills and notes as follows:

Edna Belgum, pianist from Minneapolis, was heard in her second New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The program she presented comprised the Bach-Liszt Fantasia and Fugue in G minor; three of the Beethoven's "Bagatelles''; the Chopin sonata in B minor; Franck's "Prelude. Aria and Finale"; Debussy's "L'Ile joyeuse," and two Rachmaninoff preludes.

In your Nov. 4 issue you headline a United Press dispatch "Franco Says Spain Is Not Pro-Fascist." In 1937 Franco told The United Press another story. I quote from THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 14, 1939:

Adolf Hitler's proclamation, as carried by DNB and reported by the Federal Communication Commission, opened with the assertion that the "requirements of total war have caused me to postpone celebrations commemorating Nov. 9 to the next available Sunday." The proclamation continued:

The Collins Aikman Corporation and its subsidiaries, excluding the Canadian subsidiary, showed a net profit of $935,020 after Federal and State income taxes, for the six months ended on Aug. 26, according to the report to be released today.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- In a possible effort to quiet suspicions aroused inside and outside Germany by Adolf Hitler's non-appearance in public since July 21, when he announced his survival of the bomb plot, a proclamation alleged to have been composed by him was read to the German people today by Heinrich Himmler.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Daniel I. Sultan took command of Chinese armies in Burma officially today, succeeding Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, under direct deputization from Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 12 -- In a small parish church at Putte, not far from Antwerp, are two bells, the pride of that district for many years, and now a Belgian tradition because of an incident during the occupation.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of the first major experimental air cargo flight in the United States will occur tomorrow, it was announced yesterday by the Air Express Division of the Railway Express Agency.
PARIS, Nov. 12 -- The four-day convention of the Socialist party ended this evening with a very definite political stand.
The American Committee for the Yugoslav Relief Ship, 465 Lexington Avenue, has been organized in response to an appeal from the Yugoslav Government, it was announced yesterday.

The countryman knows that winter is sharpening his knife when the neighborly, hustling, black-capped chickadees begin to appear in the old apple trees behind the barn. There's something heart-warming and appealing about the little fellows as they scrabble around the trunks and limbs, poking into the crevices of the weather-frayed bark.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, France, Nov. 12 -- German garrisons totaling between 110,000 and 130,000 troops are still holding St. Nazaire, Lorient, La Rochelle and the mouth of the Gironde, where they hinder the full development of the Allies' supply system, form a small but constant drain on men and equipment, and constitute one of the many barriers to the economic recovery of France.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 12 (AP) -- David G. Newcomb, president of the Wright Aircraft Supervision Association, said today that members of the group, representing 1,800 supervisors at five plants of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation in this area, had voted to walk out tomorrow at 10 A.M.

Unprecedented wartime increases in child labor, both legal and illegal, with consequent decreases in school enrollment and lowering of legislative standards, have reversed a prewar trend, the National Child Labor Committee announced yesterday in its fortieth anniversary report, by Mrs. Gertrude Folks Zimand, the general secretary.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Indicating that moves within the Government had been lost for complete cancellation of all lend-lease, the NAM News revealed today that the Government is demanding a "reasonable, businesslike settlement" in final negotiations for more than $110,000,000 in machine tools shipped to the British.

Among the largest processors of glaceed fruits in America is the firm of E.C. Rich at 29 Ninth Avenue. This company, which had its start in 1860, sells its wares in fine food shops throughout the country. The prunes, figs, cherries and so on are shipped from California, to be prepared here.

ROME, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Troops of the British Eighth Army have established a small bridgehead across the Nuovo Canal, running north from Forli, against strong German resistance, Allied headquarters announced today.

You have been a loyal supporter of the sanctity of treaties. Such sanctity is obviously a principal essential to stability in international relations, although I think John Foster Dulles is right in saying that treaties should be drawn up for shorter periods in a changing world like this.

An investor has purchased from the Albany Savings Bank the two-story store and loft building on a plot 78 by 83 feet at 577-85 East Fordham Road, in the Bronx, for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $31,000. Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., as agents; Albert D. Phelps, Inc., and Frank Masetti were the brokers.

The five-story forty-three-family apartment building, known as Wales Court, at 93 Fairview Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., has been sold by the Fairview Avenue Corporation to the Edna Corporation. The property is assessed at $150,000.

The most important fact about the recent election is not in anything that has been finished but in a possibility that is only just begun, the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie said yesterday in a sermon in the St. James Memorial Chapel at Union Theological Seminary, in which he is a professor.

Clarification of the War Production Board's regulations governing promotion of new post-war product designs developed under the recently relaxed regulations covering experimental models may start a copy trend in which accurate portrayals of post-war models will be emphasized, sales managers stated yesterday.

RYE, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- Displaying the same interests their government counterpart showed at the Bretton Woods meeting, members of the Indian delegation to the International Business Conference here said today they would press for a declaration by Great Britain on the extent of its dollar holdings.
The twenty-first annual Women's International Exposition will open tomorrow at Madison Square Garden for a six-day show ending Nov. 19, from 10 A.M. to 11 P.M. daily.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Fresh but still dim hopes of an eventual compromise between the Government of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and the Chinese Communists flickered in Chungking today with the unexpected return of Gen. Chou En-lai, who formerly was stationed here as representative of the Communists.
LONDON, Nov. 12 (U.P.) -- My first impression was: "These Americans must love fighting, they even do it for fun."

KANDY, Ceylon, Nov. 12 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces in northern Burma, advancing on the Japanese base of Bhamo against determined Japanese resistance, killed thirty-five enemy troops in patrol actions near Shwegu, midway between Bhamo and Katha, a Southeast Asia Command communique announced today.

Materialistic education by "godless educators" was assailed yesterday by the Rev. George H. Guilfoyle of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral. He called such education a violation of American democracy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Chester Bowles, administrator of the Office of Price Administration, made public today a reply to a request by the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee of New York that Daniel P. Woolley be removed as administrator of the New York regional OPA office.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Max Hymans, French director of air transport and head of the French delegation to the international civil aviation conference, hopes that France will be able to resume the high place held before the war in the development of civil aviation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Coyote shooting in peacetime Montana helped Tech. Sgt. Henry Schauer win the Medal of Honor in the Italian campaign, the War Department said today.

The Office of Price Administration, it was learned yesterday, is investigating the cigarette price and supply situation in the metropolitan area following complaints by smokers that they were charged more than ceiling prices for popular brands at some stores.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 12 -- Continued strength of the farm bloc in Congress as a result of the Democratic victory in the election of Tuesday and a report that the President was considering asking Congress for an additional $2,000, 000,000 for the Commodity Credit Corporation's price-raising schedule were important factors which offset another boost of 367,000 bales in indicated yield figures by the Government as of Nov. 1.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Comparatively little change was reported on the lard situation last week, spot offering remaining small and insufficient to take care of the domestic demand. Only moderate sales were reported, with both prime steam and refined moving at full ceiling prices.

ROME, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Forty-four flight nurses and forty-eight flight surgeon technicians of the 802d and 807th Medical Evacuation Squadrons, who have helped in aerial evacuation of 170,000 sick and wounded from forward areas since March, 1943, received air medals today from Maj. Gen. John K. Cannon, commander of the Twelfth Air Force.

A TWENTIETH UNITED STATES BOMBER BASE, China, Nov. 11 (Delayed) (AP) -- Super-fortresses raided the Omura aircraft center in the Japanese homeland today in the teeth of a hurricane so violent that the big bombers were stood on their wing tips and some of the attacking force was shunted off for blows at Nanking on the Chinese mainland.

Verdi's "La Traviata" was presented for the first time this season by the New York City Center Opera Company last night at the City Center before a large and appreciative audience. The popular work was excellently sung, and a performance was accorded it that moved smoothly and boasted real mood and atmosphere.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Sharp-shooting Sid Luckman pitched three touchdown passes, one covering 86 yards for the longest pay-off toss of the season, to hand the Bears a 21-7 triumph over the Boston Yanks, before 19,374 today.

Headed by the Whitney Museum's annual exhibition of contemporary American painting, which opens tomorrow, some forty new art exhibitions crowd the local calendar for this week. Other museum events include a showing of Oriental rugs and Islamic glass at the Metropolitan on Wednesday and the Brooklyn Museum's selection of European paintings in its own collection, already opened to the public.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 12 -- A warning against groups that will seek to continue wartime economic and social controls after the war was sounded today by the Most Rev. Joseph H. Schlarman, Bishop of Peoria, in his presidential address before 3,000 clerical and lay delegates and members of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A United States Army Forces in China communique:

WILMINGTON, N.C., Nov. 12 (AP) -- C. McD. Davis, president of the Atlantic Coast Line railroad, said last night that "certain holders" of first and refunding mortgage bonds of the Florida East Coast Line had requested the A.C.L. to permit revised reorganization plans to be presented to the Interstate Commerce Commission so that the A.C.L. could operate the Florida East Coast Line.
A service in celebration of its 125th anniversary was conducted yesterday morning at the Unitarian Church of all Souls, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- In a report tying together the problems of cartels and post-war control of German war potentials, the subcommittee on War Mobilization of the Senate Military Affairs Committee recommended today that not only Germany's direct munitions industry but all "primary indirect munitions industries, including the metallurgical and chemical industries," be dismantled and removed to the devastated areas of Europe.

In honor of the 400,000 men and women of New Jersey now in the armed forces of the nation the Garden Club of that State has planned a unique and enduring memorial, a living token of gratitude that will grow with the years.
The offensive of the Third American Army and the Germans' V-2 rocket bombs shared the headlines last week.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command admitted tonight that radio contact with Kweilin had been broken since Friday and that the Japanese were engaged in brisk fighting in the suburbs of Liuchow. Both are prime objectives of an enemy South China offensive.

RCA Victor resumed the manufacture of records yesterday in its studios at 155 East Twenty-fourth Street following the agreement reached Saturday night with James C. Petrillo's American Federation of Musicians. The agreement, giving Mr. Petrillo a complete victory, ended the union's two-year ban on the production of new disks by RCA and the Columbia Recording Corporation.
For the past four weeks the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices has been rising steadily. Last week it rose from 113.80 to a new all-time high of 113.88.
George Munger took time out from nursing his Michigan headache last week to lay in an extra stock of sedatives for the coming of Army to Franklin Field this Saturday.

Eight million Americans, of whom more than one-third are school children, have impaired hearing, Raymond H. Greenman, managing director of the American Society for the Hard of Hearing, said last night at the society's silver anniversary dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

As was to be expected, Wednesday's stock market made little response to the Administration's success in Tuesday's vote. Like the average citizen, the market, after reading its newspaper headlines seemed to prefer to talk about something else.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 12 -- Toyland in Brussels would be any child's paradise these days, when the first hint of Christmas is in the air. But it would be a paradise, too, for weary American parents who, come December, will tramp empty toy departments trying to match junior's letter to Santa Claus with reality.

Queens College, anticipating a doubled student enrollment after the war, has completed plans for an expansion program in service to the borough and in aid to veterans to keep pace with the "fastest growing community in the United States," it was announced yesterday by Dr. Paul Klapper, president of the college.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Mr. Churchill's visit to France gives as much satisfaction to the British as to the French. This is saying a good deal when it is remembered that the last Chief of State to go to Paris was Adolf Hitler, and that the French are welcoming the first head of an Allied Government they have seen since Churchill crossed the Channel in 1940 in a last desperate attempt to prevent the surrender.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Don Hutson snared two touchdown passes and kicked six extra points as the Green Bay Packers swamped the Cleveland Rams, 42 to 7, today in a National Football League game before 17,166 fans.
ROME, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A communique:

GUATEMALA, Nov. 12 -- The first Government-in-Exile in this hemisphere has been established here by Judge Miguel Tomas Molina, who was to have become Provisional President of El Salvador when Col. Osmin Aguirre y Salinas forced the resignation of Gen. Andres Menendez, ousted President.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Nov. 12 -- Coming down to the center of the island from the Hamptons, which is practically the second home of the Chesapeake Bay breed of dogs, Buddy Brown carried off first honors today in the open all-age stake which featured the annual field meeting of the Women's Field Trial Club.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in Bulgaria and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

A quick turnover of a Washington Heights property was made over the week-end when a syndicate represented by Glekel Drimmer, attorneys, resold the six-story apartment building at 65 Fort Washington Avenue which it bought two weeks ago.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 12 -- Belgians are embarrassed at having to admit that some things done by the Germans in their country had merit during the occupation and are indispensable even now. The work of erasing all trace of the enemy was so thorough in the early days of the libreation that the authorities today are occupied with the distasteful task of restoring Nazi creations, often disguised under new names.
Cotton prices, after five weeks of gradual recessions, turned firmer last week and made fair net gains, 28 to 40 points, by Friday night. The more distant positions made the best advances.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- After four hours of diplomatic discussion with Gen. Charles de Gaulle and his foreign-affairs advisers, Prime Minister Churchill said today that the British Government felt that the "establishment of a strong French Army as soon as possible is absolutely necessary to balance and sanity in Europe."

BOSTON, Nov. 12 -- Overcoming a half-time deficit of nine points, Boston College came from behind in the final period to edge out Brooklyn College, 24 -- 21, in a high-scoring contest today before 6,500 chilled spectators at Fenway Park.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Action of the oats and barley markets last week on the Board of Trade here was a reflection of that of other grains. Oats prices, however, averaged higher, due more to lack of pressure of cash grain than to aggressive buying.
In a fast and hotly contested American League soccer game, the New York Americans held the Brookhattans to a 1-1 tie at Starlight Park yesterday before a crowd of 4,000.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ROME, Nov. 12 -- The same inability or unwillingness, or both, of the vast majority of American soldiers in North Africa to master even the rudiments of French is painfully noticeable here in their indifference to learning Italian, though many have been in this country fourteen months.

ABOARD A P-T TENDER IN SAN PEDRO BAY, Leyte, Monday, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Japanese fighters and dive bombers made a spectacular mid-afternoon vengeanc strike against American shipping crowding San Pedro Bay today, quite obviously in retaliation for the heavy shipping losses, the Japanese suffered during the previous forty-eight hours at Ormoc.

George Zoritch, now rehearsing in the Broadway musical, "Rhapsody," was guest artist yesterday at both performances of the Ballet International at the International Theatre, appearing in the single male role in "Les Sylphides." He danced well, but not well enough to overcome the temptations to be over lyrical which beset the role.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- Charles A. Robbins of Andover, Conn., former University of Connecticut star, now pharmacist mate third class, stationed at Chelsea, Mass., Naval Hospital, won the national A.A.U. marathon championship in his second attempt today. He covered the twenty-six-mile, 385-yard course, which starts and ends at the Empire City race track, in 2 hours, 40 minutes, 48 and 6/10 seconds.
DETROIT, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Detroit Lions, scoring in every period but the third, handed the Car-Pittsburgh combination its seventh straight reverse, 21 to 7, today before 13,239 fans.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Most buyers of post-war automobiles will not be aware of the improvements made in operating accessories as a result of wartime experience and experiment, automotive parts manufacturers declared today.

AN AMERICAN SEAPLANE BASE, in the Philippines, Nov. 12 (Reuter) -- The first Japanese transport plane to be destroyed in the Philippines was shot down yesterday about eighty miles southeast of Manila by a Seventh Fleet Ventura search bomber, with a probable bag of ranking Japanese Army and Navy officers.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- Two German prisoners of war, who have wandered at liberty in the United States and Canada since their escape from a prisoner-of-war camp at Scotts Bluff, Neb., last July 11, were captured today aboard the Spanish merchant ship Castilla Ampudia at a South Philadelphia pier, it was disclosed by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents.

The execution by the Germans of more than 3,000,000 Jewish captives in gas chambers in Tremblinka, a German death camp in Poland, is described in a clandestinely printed booklet received yesterday and made public here by local representativs of the Underground Jewish Labor Movement of Poland.

E.G. McKeever, executive vice president of the Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company has been elected president of that company, effective Jan. 1. He will succeed Robert E. Wilson, who on that date will become chairman of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, which owns a controlling stock interest in Pan American.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- New construction activity in 1944 will fall to "less than half" the volume of 1943, the War Production Board predicted today on the basis of a report on October building and a consideration of seasonal factors and the expected continuation of construction controls.

German Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels, boasting of a huge German Home Guard equipped and trained in the last three months, proclaimed yesterday that Germany was resolved "to defend herself house by house and street by street," The Associated Press reported.
All horse racing should be suspended until the end of the war to cut down industrial absenteeism, useless travel and the wasting of gasoline, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday.

Dean Russell of Teachers College, Columbia University, in his annual report deplores the unrealistic attitude of educators toward the possibilities of war. During the period when pacifism swept the college campuses, repeated polls showed a sizable group who declared they would never bear arms for their country under any circumstances.
DETROIT, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Red Wings broke a six-game Toronto winning streak tonight, handing the Maple Leafs their first setback of the National Hockey League season, 4 to 2, before 13,384.

Twenty-two hundred enthusiastic French persons yesterday celebrated Armistice Day at France Forever ceremonies at which the motion picture, "Liberation," was presented for the first time in America, and the work of the underground was described by Jean Vinzant, resistance leader who escaped to England in 1943.

Charles R. Driscoll purchased the nine-room house on a plot 83 by 100 feet at 363 Glenbrook Avenue, in the Park Hill section of Yonkers, in Westchester County, from the City Bank Farmers Trust Company. Thomas S. Burke, Inc., was the broker in the sale of the house, which the buyer had been occupying under lease.
Yesterday's communique, as recorded in New York by The Associated Press from a Berlin broadcast:

TACLOBAN, Leyte, Nov. 8 (Delayed) -- Psychologically, the problem of prices in the liberated areas of the Philippines is complicated by the wild inflation fostered by the Japanese. During enemy occupation, wages rose 200 to 300 per cent, but prices rose to astronomical figures. Rice -- the basic foodstuff of the Visayans -- rose from 30 centavos per ganta -- six pounds -- to 50 pesos -- $25 in pre-war value.

LONDON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Wang Ching-wei, 62, President and Premier of the Japanese-sponsored puppet Government of China at Nanking, died Friday in a Japanese hospital of diabetes, the Tokyo radio announced today.

Brooklyn's final home game of the National Football League season was its best and most exciting, but the result was no different from all the others, the Tigers bowing, 10 -- 0, to Slingin' Sammy Baugh and his Washington Redskins before a crowd of 20,404 at Ebbets Field yesterday.

With the return of the Edwardian influence on fashion so widely felt this season, no revival has been accepted more readily than the "dog collar." Whether expressed in several rows of pearls tied with a black ribbon, or with brilliants studding a velvet ribbon or with the simple gold circlet, each mood has its development of the fashion.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 12 -- Barbara Stanwyck and Paul Henreid have been named by Warner Brothers for starring roles in the screen version of the Martin Vale play, "The Two Mrs. Carrolls." Robert Buckner will be the producer.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 12 -- The shifting of the investigation of the murder of Lord Moyne to Palestine has again focused attention on the activities of those two tiny groups of Jewish terrorists calling themselves the National Military Organization and Fighters for the Freedom of Israel.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Monday, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Japanese made no new attempt to send fresh troops ashore, after losing four transports, six destroyers and most of 8,000 reinforcements in the complete destruction of a convoy off Ormoc by American carrier planes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- William H. Davis, chairman of the National War Labor Board, has offered his resignation to President Roosevelt to become effective Jan. 1, it was learned today.

The sugar shortage, described by the War Food Administration as local and temporary, has reached such proportions here that the Society of Restaurateurs advised its members yesterday to take the sugar bowls off the tables and have the waiters serve the sweetening sparingly.

One hundred and seventy-four dogs of fifteen breeds were exhibited yesterday afternoon and last night in the twelfth annual all-toy show held by the Progressive Dog Club on the roof of the Hotel Pennsylvania for the benefit of the Seaman's Church Institute of New York.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- American heavy bombers of the Eighth and Fifteenth Air Forces had blasted German industrial and military targets with 638,880 tons of explosives through Oct. 31, the United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe announced today. Of this volume 330,000 tons were dropped on targets in the Reich.

LIOCOURT, France, Nov. 12--There has been a general withdrawal by the Germans from the Twelfth Army Corps area southeast of Metz and a systematic evacuation of civilians of military age in a broader area in front of Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's advancing American Third Army.
ROME, Nov. 12 -- One of the greatest mass demonstrations in the history of modern Rome was held today by the Communists and Socialists in celebration of the Russian October Revolution.

In an oblique reply to Marshal Stalin's characterization of Japan as an aggressor nation, the Tokyo radio last night included Russia among aggressor powers in a broadcast on "What is the aggressor?" recorded by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The champion Montreal Canadiens, breaking away from a 1-1 first-period deadlock, won their fifth game of the National League hockey season tonight by beating the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 -- 2, before 16,363 fans.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Monday, Nov. 13 -- Troops of the Twenty-fourth and First Cavalry Divisions pushing southward down the Ormoc Valley of Leyte and the sharp jungle-capped hills to the eastward hammered out gains yesterday against strong Japanese resistance.

LONDON, Nov. 12 (U.P.) -- Sixty thousand football-starved Yanks were "back home" for three hours today when they saw a United States Army team loaded with former college stars defeat a Navy eleven, 20 -- 0, to win the European championship.

Many buyers were in the wholesale markets here last week placing last-minute holiday and spring orders. Retailers completed their purchases of women's better-grade swing suits new styles in medium-price dresses were bought actively.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Weak and emaciated but "in surprisingly good condition," a 9-year-old boy was found in a tool compartment of an abandoned auto trailer today after six days of confinement without food or water, police said.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Continuation of Government support to the wheat market which may spread to other grains is forecast by members of the Chicago Board of Trade as the result of the Presidential election last week, and this view was reflected after the election in a short covering movement in the July and September deliveries of wheat.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Communique 218:

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Heads of the American, British and Canadian deelgations to the International Civil Aviation Conference began a series of meetings today in an effort to reconcile their conflicting views regarding the powers to be delegated by the various countries to the proposed international aviation body.

UNITED STATES 317TH INFANTRY REGIMENT COMMAND POST in France, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Tanks and infantry moved across one sturdy Nied River bridge toward Germany today largely because a lieutenant died and a captain lived.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- An urgent appeal for additional blood donors was issued today by Basil O'Connor, chairman of the American National Red Cross, who said that the plan of flying whole blood to the South Pacific announced today by the Navy had already brought instructions to the Red Cross blood donor centers to make every effort to maintain their quotas.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast by the New Yugoslav Radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

AMERICAN THIRD ARMY FRONT, in France, Nov. 13 -- The first of the twenty-two German-built forts facing west from formidable Metz, which has never been captured by frontal assault, was captured today. Its garrison had fled, leaving a weak link in the chain designed to keep out an enemy.

The towns of Zmigrod and Tarnowiec and twenty-two surrounding villages in south central Poland have been burned to the ground by the Germans, the Polish Telegraph Agency reported yesterday in a London dispatch.

Store Sales Here Up 9% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 9 per eent last week in comparison with the like week of last year, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A $1,673.90 daily double, largest of the current Pimlico meeting, was returned today to eighteen holders of tickets on Mrs. G. O. Russell's Church Supper and Mrs. L. M. Hanson's Lee Jimmie, winners of the first and second races.

Rapidly expanding industrial and agricultural developments in Palestine, ready to spend from $40,000,000 to $50,000,000 to replace worn out equipment, will furnish a vast market for American goods after the war, Harry Viteles, general manager of the Central Bank of Cooperative Institutions in Palestine, Ltd., declared yesterday in an interview.
SALEM, N.H., Nov. 13 (AP) -- The English-bred Page II, owned by W.L. Guinasso, came from far off the pace today to win the Granville Purse before a crowd of more than 6,000 at Rockingham Park.

Maintaining that American designers must safeguard their claim to originality by prophesying trends before the Paris openings, Walter Florell presented his spring collection of hats yesterday at the St. Regis. Silhouettes were exaggerated, he said, because that is the way to establish a trend.

Ben Lewis, brother of Nat Lewis, Broadway haberdasher, was found dead at 10:55 o'clock last night in the bedroom of his penthouse apartment atop the twelve-story building at 333 East Fifty-third Street, in the Sutton Place neighborhood.

Despite stepping up of spot authorization programs there will be no increase in allocations of priorities for machinery for plastics manufacture, at least until the end of the first quarter of 1945, J.D. Houghton, equipment branch, War Production Board, told members of the Society of the Plastics Industry yesterday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (AP) -- There'll be a total of $115,000 in both war bonds and cash on golf's golden trail during the winter and early spring.
After World War I one of the large publishing houses asked me to write a small book on my experiences in that war. I did so and devoted one chapter to the "Importance of Universal Training."

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- The Count of Paris, pretender to the French throne, was reported tonight to have been arrested in Perpignan on the Mediterranean coast near the Spanish border, and to have been wounded in the shoulder by a pistol shot in the course of his arrest.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- The American position at the International Civil Aviation Conference was described as technically superior at a press conference here today by Edward P. Warner, member of the Civil Aeronautics Board and of the American delegation.

Reiterating his accusation that savings banks had filed building plans to "beat the gun" before new zoning amendments become effective, Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, threatened last night to ask Governor Dewey to intervene and asserted that there was a legal ban against such activity.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- The Tirpitz has finally been sunk, the Air Ministry jubilantly announced tonight, and the hulk of the Germans' last big battleship lies on the bottom of Tromsoe Fjord in northern Norway.

J.L. Rosenthal has purchased for investment from Frederick Brown the six-story business building at 16 West Fortieth Street, occupied as an addition to the main building of Lane Bryant, Inc. The building occupies a plot 23.6 by 98.9 feet on the south side of the street, near Fifth Avenue and opposite the New York Public Library.

RYE, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- Charging that cartels have stood in the way of attempts to industrialize India, the delegation of Indian business men to the International Business Conference voiced today their opposition to the continued use of international cartels as a trade restrictive device.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, said at a press conference today that Sidney Hillman, who was present, would soon leave for London to attend a preliminary world Trades Union Congress Dec. 4.
Close bidding featured the competitive sale yesterday of $30,000,000 Houston Lighting and Power Company first mortgage bonds. The company received bids from three banking groups.
OTTAWA, Nov. 13 (Canadian Press) -- Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King announced tonight that the House of Commons would assemble on Nov. 22 instead of the previously decided date of Jan. 31, 1945.

President Edward G. Barrow of the Yankees said yesterday that he had heard of no plan officially to transfer the Army-Navy football game to the Yankee Stadium and declared that a transfer at this late date would be a physical impossibility.

Twenty-five after-school play centers are being operated or supervised by the Play School Association this winter, Mrs. Adele S. Mossler, director, reported yesterday at the twenty-seventh annual meeting of the organization at its headquarters, 119 West Fifty-seventh Street.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Tuesday, Nov. 14 (AP) -- A communique:...

Roman Totenberg, who, as concertmaster of the City Center Symphony Orchestra, had given a few nights earlier a brilliant solo performance of the Barber violin concerto, appeared in recital last night in Carnegie Hall. His performance of the concerto is mentioned here because the sum of Mr. Totenberg's performances last night suggested a comparison with the sum of certain opera singers' performances when they leave the stage and give a concert.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Though Prime Minister Churchill exhorted the French to consider national unity the basis of restoration, various elements continued today to urge that a complete purge of collaborationists was the most urgent prerequisite of union.
ABOARD AN LST HOSPITAL SHIP, Leyte, Oct. 28 (Delayed) (AP) -- It looked like any other snub-nosed LST [landing ship, tank], beast of burden in the Navy's trans-Pacific caravan.

LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 14 -- The Second Ukrainian Army of Marshal Rodion Y. Malinovsky swept northward along two railways yesterday in an outflanking move against Budapest, capturing the terminal of Jaszapati and, according to a German announcement, breaking into the important communications center of Jaszbereny, thirty-seven miles east of the Hungarian capital.
