Long before the United States was engaged in a shooting war with Germany, Italy and Japan, men of the merchant navy were sailing their slow cargo vessels through combat zones delivering the supplies that kept the British Empire and Russia in the war. Since Dec. 7, 1941, they have been delivering the goods to our own Navy, Marine and Army forces in all the seven oceans, to all the continents.
With the final tabulation on the electoral and popular votes waiting until Dec. 5 for the completed reports from all the war fronts, we find ourselves engaged in what we call election analyses.

Lack of confidence in this country toward China's role in the war was criticized last night by Dr. James L. McConaughy, president of the United China Relief, Inc., who assailed "those Americans who with the best of intentions but not the best of wisdom had attempted to dictate to the Generalissimo."

Opposition to the zoning resolution amendment is voiced in a letter sent to members of the Board of Estimate by the Midtown Real Estate Association, which declares that "the roughshod attempt by the City Planning Commission to railroad this ill-conceived and ill-advised amendment through over the united opposition of property owners affected, is particularly reprehensible."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Senator Walter F. George of Georgia, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, intimated today that pressure might be expected from Administration forces to prevent any further freezing of the Social Security tax rate, which will be proposed tomorrow as Congress reconvenes after the election lull.

Sam Jacobs, president of the Rex Trading Corporation, which did little or no trading, according to Assistant District Attorney Lawrence J. McKenna, wept copiously yesterday in Special Sessions as he was sentenced to one year in the penitentiary and fined $10,000 for conducting an unlicensed, usurious loan agency under the cloak of a check cashing business.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Substantially increased use of industrial alcohol for a long list of civilian products other than beverages was promised by the War Production Board today with a supplemental allocation of approximately 2,000,000 gallons of 190 proof ethyl alcohol to the regular fourth quarter allotment.

ST. LOUIS' Nov. 13 (AP) -- Challenger Welker Cochran of San Francisco won both blocks of his match for the world three-cushion billiard title from Champion Willie Hoppe of New York today and shaved Hoppe's cumulative margin for the match to five points.

FREDERICK, Md., Nov. 13 -- the home of Barbara Fritchie, made famous by John Greenleaf Whittier's poem, and long a subject of controversy whether Dame Barbara really waved the Union flag from its windows in Stonewall Jackson's face, was sold on the auction block today for $5,000.

Spectacular Allied offensives on land and sea have somewhat obscured in recent weeks the war in the air. The knights on the wing, who saved Britain from invasion, who turned the Japanese back at Midway and thus saved Hawaii from a Japanese invasion, are still at it -- in increasing numbers, and with better, more powerful and much farther-reaching machines.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Secretary Stimson has rejected a suggestion that some three thousand members of the Thirty-fourth Division, now resting at their homes, be relieved of further combat duty.
PARIS, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The American cigarette shortage has spread to the European war theatre. Enlisted men in Paris were informed today they would get no cigarettes this week.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 13 -- The Fourteenth United States Air Force disclosed today that it had destroyed its Liuchow air base, last important group of Allied airfields in eastern China, under steady pressure of fast-moving Japanese troops closing in from the northeast and southeast.

Scientists and laymen have followed with interest the conference of cancer specialists held recently at Bar Harbor, Me. Although no world-startling discoveries were announced, although no specific path for future research was revealed, the conference has been hailed as a great forward step.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Harold L. Ickes, as Petroleum Administrator for War, described as "unfounded and regrettable" today published reports that fuel oil supplies were ample enough to permit larger rations in the near future. He outlined "four facts" in an effort to refute them:

"Dishonored and despised" is Chungking's epitaph for Wang Ching-wei. His death is a reminder that there were quislings before Quisling. The original model, indeed, was made in Japan. Henry Pu Yi, so-called "Emperor" of Manchukuo, may have been the first.

Four groups of modern synthetic yarns and fabrics arranged by the Celanese Corporation of America were included in the plastics exhibit that opened in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, in connection with the annual fall convention of the Society of the Plastics Industry.

BOSTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Lawyers for the Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the recommendation of a court-appointed investigator that legal proceedings should be brought by the International Hydroelectric System against International Paper Company.

A block of postage stamps described as "the greatest show-piece in all philately," which was sold by the estate of Col. E.H.R. Green, brought $27,000 at public auction yesterday through Harmer, Rooke Co. The block comprises eight copies of the United States 1918 24-cent bicolored airmail stamp with the center design, an airplane, inverted on each.

Congress is expected to take up proposals for compulsory military training after the present recess; and it is further reported from Washington a bill may be approved before the present Congress expires on Jan. 3.

We shall have to wait for complete technical information on the thirteen-and-one-half ton wingless German V-2 rocket bomb before we can accept at their face value some of the accounts which have reached us. An alleged speed of 3,500 miles an hour and a trajectory that curves as high as fifty-five miles are the chief reasons for delaying judgment.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Gestapo Chief Heinrich Himmler's reading yesterday of an alleged statement by Adolf Hitler having failed to satisfy the world or the German people that all was well with Hitler, the German Transocean agency today reiterated that he was enjoying complete health. The statement was attributed to "competent German quarters."
Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin R.B. Townsend have come from Sewickley, Pa., to the Plaza.

Pre-election misgivings over reconversion problems in the event of sudden ending of the European war returned yesterday to plague the stock market. Under moderate but persistent pressure, with almost complete lack of support, prices dropped major fractions to 2 points.

Vogel Rotkin, operators, have sold the six-story store and apartment building at 666 East 233d Street, the Bronx, to a client of Irving L. Levitt, attorney. The building contains eight stores and sixty-eight apartments and occupies a plot 150 by 100 feet.
From here on to the end of the season, everything else in college football is secondary to the aproach of Army and Navy to the game of games at Annapolis on Dec. 2.

ALBANY, Nov. 13 -- Supreme Court Justice Parton Swift, presiding over court proceedings arising from the special grand jury investigation of the Albany Democratic machine, refused today to strike from the record tapped telephone conversations purporting to show an improper link between Daniel P. O'Connell, Albany Democratic boss, and members of the Supreme Court bench in this district.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- Proposed Westchester County operating, district and capital budgets for 1945 totaling $15,530,997 were submitted to the Board of Supervisors this afternoon by County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach. They were $517,862 larger than budgetary expenditures in 1944.

Observance of Anti-Inflation Week started yesterday with the opening of a model food market on the fourth floor of the Empire State Building. Set up in the midst of rows of Office of Price Administration desks, the twenty by twenty-five foot grocery was visited during the first few hours by 150 men who manage real stores and by 100 women who buy in them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Congress which will resume its session here tomorrow includes a number of "lame ducks" -- this in despite of the Twentieth Amendment which sought among other things to prevent that situation. But its life will be only a few weeks long instead of three months, as in the past.
ROME, Nov. 13 (Reuter) -- Pope Pius today declared that no power on earth had authority to annihilate human life except in execution of a death sentence against a guilty person.

Bendix Aviation Corporation yesterday announced that introduction of the Bendix line of AM and FM radios and radio-phonograph combinations will be backed up by an aggressive merchandising campaign based on national and newspaper advertising.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A renewed drive to shift the Army-Navy football game from Annapolis to a big city stadium started on Capitol Hill today, with a direct appeal to the President in prospect.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A surprise move to revive a modified version of the Murray-Kilgore bill for more liberal post-war benefits for unemployed developed today. Backers of the bill are sounding out members of the Senate military committee to determine whether they would support another attempt to pass the legislation which Congress rejected after a bitter fight three months ago.

With a preview for artists and their friends, the Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, opened yesterday afternoon the first section of its 1944 annual. The show, which will continue until Dec. 12, is made up entirely of oils. The second section, which opens Dec. 18, will contain sculpture, water-colors and drawings.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today set Tuesday, Dec. 5, as the new date for hearing oral argument on the Government's civil anti-trust suit against The Associated Press.

That "spot authorizations" and other relaxations by the War Production Board of restrictions governing civilian production are enabling some manufacturers to resume making civilian goods was evident yesterday at the opening of the twenty-ninth National Hotel Exposition at the Hotel Commodore.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 13 -- Paul Herten and Joseph Hoogeveen, convicted of turning their fellow countrymen over to the Gestapo, were executed here this morning. They were the first collaborators to pay the supreme penalty, after due process of law, in Belgium.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Department of Agriculture warned civilians today not to expect any noticeable increase in food supplies after the end of the war in Europe, pointing out that non-civilian needs will continue to take "a substantial portion" of the total production next year.

Holding within a 6-point range, prices on the local cotton futures market displayed a steady undertone yesterday. They closed 1 point lower to 3 points higher than Saturday's final figures on the New York Cotton Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Authenticated reports to the Norwegian Embassy here concerning the first weeks of Russian occupation of the northern section of Norway "liberated" by the Red Army indicate close collaboration between the Norse and Soviet forces.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- C.W. Whittemore, trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board, in an intermediate report filed today, declared that A.B. Salant of the New York firm of Salant Salant, Inc., had "condoned and acquiesced in violence and threats of violence" against union organizers and had furnished misinformation which was sent to members of Congress from Tennessee.
ALBANY, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The low point in public school enrollment has passed for many New York State localities, an Education Department spokesman said today.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Robert G. Kaslow, 21-year-old former Army Air Forces officer, who escaped from the Craig Field (Ala.) guard house Friday night and fled in an Army plane, was captured here tonight by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The first indication that Field Marshal Gen. Karl von Runstedt may not try to hold Metz came in a broadcast early today from the German commander's headquarters in the west.

A program of indoctrination similar to the kind used by the Army and Navy should be introduced into schools in this country after the war, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College declared yesterday at the first of a series of Junior League luncheon meetings on the subject of post-war planning, held at League headquarters, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

SEVENTH FLEET HEADQUARTERS, in the Philippines, Nov. 3 (Delayed) (AP) -- A single patrol torpedo boat carrying three New Yorkers fired three torpedoes at a Japanese battleship and came back to tell the story.

Plans for the $7,000,000 Lillian Wald housing development on the lower East Side, for which State funds will be used, were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings by Frederick L. Ackerman, architect, of 25 West Forty-fourth Street, for the New York City Housing Authority.

New York racing for the year moved into its last three days with betting over the $400,000,000 mark, a total which had never before been reached. This became known at Belmont Park yesterday, where the seventh-day wagering of the Victory meet for war relief hit $2,419,195.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- James Lawrence Fly resigned today as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, effective Wednesday night, to resume the practice of law. President Roosevelt accepted the resignation "with great reluctance" and said that he would look upon the FCC chief, after his five years' service in that post, as being only on "furlough."
I write this brief rejoinder to Robert S. Field's letter, not in order to have the last word, but because the issue involved is an extremely important one.
ROME, Nov. 13 -- The British Eighth Army has crossed the Ghiaia Canal south of Ravenna, it was announced today.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 13 -- This country, Great Britain and Russia must share responsibility for the final settlement of the Palestine problem, Dr. Abba Hillel Silver of Cleveland tonight told 500 delegates to the thirtieth annual convention of Hadassah, women's Zionist organization of America.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Federal Judge John P. Barnes dismissed today the suit of Montgomery Ward Co. which sought to nullify a War Labor Board order providing for arbitration of grievances between the company and the CIO United Mail Order, Warehouse and Retail Employes Union.

Chester Bowles, national chief of the Office of Price Administration, has just written a letter which throws a new and startling light on one important phase of government by bureaucracy; and if the head of OPA isn't a bureaucrat, it is hard to say who is.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Almost all of the Latin-American countries have accepted the basic objectives of the United Nations security charter, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Acting Secretary of State, said at a news conference here today.

Teachers College Columbia University, will mark its fiftieth year as one of the nation's leading teacher-training institutions with exercises to be held at 3:30 P.M. tomorrow in the Horace Mann Auditorium, 520 West 120th Street.

A general court-martial of thirteen officers counted ten yesterday over Capt. Joseph (Joe) Gould, former prize-fight manager, when they found him guilty of four violations of the Ninety-sixth Article of War and ordered that he be dismissed from the service, fined $12,000 and serve three years at hard labor.

Army, by drubbing Notre Dame Saturday, not only tightened its grasp on first place in yesterday's Associated Press poll to determine the country's top-ranking football team, but also knocked the Irish out of the elite ranking for the first time since Oct. 12, 1942.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A United States Army Forces in China communique:

Fines totalling $2,535 were assessed against violators of Office of Price Administration ceilings yesterday at the opening of the new War Emergency Court in the Criminal Courts Building to handle price violations in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx. During the day nearly 700 cases were disposed of by Magistrates Charles E. Ramsgate and Morris Rothenberg.

"Golden Rose," a novel laid in modern India, by Pamela Hinkson, English novelist, is the November selection of the Catholic Book Club. Knopf published the book in September. Miss Hinkson recently returned to England after making a tour of this country on behalf of the British Ministry of Information.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 13 -- Federal Judge William C. Coleman today ruled that the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Warehousemen and Helpers of America, an American Federation of Labor trade union, is doing business in Maryland and is therefore subject to legal service here.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Prime Minister Churchill's promise that the British Government would support the French desire for a separate French zone of occupation in Germany when the subject arose before the European Advisory Commission was the outstanding concrete result of the Prime Minister's visit to Paris over the week-end, informed French circles said tonight.

Reporting on operations of the United Aircraft Corporation for the nine months ended with September, Frederick B. Rentschler, chairman, revealed yesterday that shipments of aircraft, engines and propellers increased 10 per cent over the first nine months of last year, while the net income before renegotiation and earnings on common stock increased only 5 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- A plan for liquidation of the Portland (Me.) Railroad Company was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Central Maine Power Company. Liquidation would follow retirement of the securities.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Joe Louis, world champion, an Army sergeant on furlough, cuffed Jimmy Bell, Washington, 180, around tonight in a three-round boxing exhibition.

A card party to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the Winfield Day Nursery will be held on Thursday in the Roof Garden of the St. Regis, with John Kieran and H.I. Phillips as masters of ceremonies.

Tech. Sgt. William Schneider of the Army Air Forces, whose home is at 34 West Sixty-fourth Street, received the Distinguished Flying Cross last week for his services as a radio operator and gunner on the B-24 Liberator bomber, My Achin' Back.
Yesterday's communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

The Public Health Research Institute is a quasi-public laboratory which was established to conduct research for the benefit of the city's Department of Health in particular and of the city as a whole. Its administrators and experimental scientists rank with the best in the country.

A UNITED STATES FIGHTER BASE, England, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Col. Hubert Zemke, 31-year-old fighter pilot from Missoula, Mont., known as the "fightingest" American pilot commander in Europe, has been missing since Oct. 30, it was announced today.

KANDY, Ceylon, Nov. 13 (U.P.) -- Japanese resistance has stiffened in northern Burma, but Chinese troops converging on Bhamo in two columns and British forces advancing along the Myitkyina-Mandalay railway have made slight gains, it was announced today.

With applications swamping War Finance Committee headquarters, enlistments during the first day of the one-week intensive recruiting campaign for Blue Star Brigaders for the Sixth War Loan campaign reached 100,000 yesterday.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 13 -- Chile had its radio "invasion from Mars" last night and in some quarters Chileans ran in panic into the streets while others at home were reported to have suffered nervous upsets and heart seizures.

It has become more or less of a widespread practice among actresses of a literary bent to write their own plays. Ilka Chase is one of them. Not only did she dramatize "In Bed We Cry," opening tonight at the Belasco, but she also is the author of the best-selling novel upon which it is based.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Tuesday, Nov. 14 -- Japanese preparations for a counter-attack with five divisions to break out of the narrow Ormoc Valley -- the last bit of enemy-held territory on Leyte Island -- have been frustrated and Gen. Tomoyuki Yamashita, Japanese commander in the Philippines area, has been compelled to throw in his forces piece-meal, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's communique said today.

LONDON, Nov. 13 (UP) -- Three recent United States Eighth Air Force bombings of Hamburg damaged the great Blohm Voss ship-building and seaplane works, dock areas and the Rhenania-Ossag oil refinery, one of Germany's prime sources of synthetic oil, although the bombs were dropped through clouds, Strategic Air Forces headquarters announced today.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- The feature of today's stock markets here was the renewed demand for Argentine railway stocks. Debentures were favored most, with gains up to one and a half being recorded. Preference issues also benefited, with gains of a half, and the ordinaries were in some places as much as a quarter better.

There have been greater chess players than Frank Marshall, but none that loved the game more than he did. He gave to it a lifetime of devotion; not grudgingly, but with his whole heart, never regretting the choice. And his energies were not shared with any other occupation; all went for chess.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 13 -- A widespread extension of the powers of the Government to intervene in the economy as a means of dealing effectively with economic problems after the war was predicted today by the Most Rev. Vincent J. Ryan, Bishop of Bismarck, N.D., in an address before the closing session of the war-time meeting of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference.

ROME, Nov. 13 -- The Cabinet will meet tomorrow in one of the stormiest periods of Premier Ivanoe Bonomi's Government, but signs pointed tonight to a general agreement to avoid a crisis for the present.

THE professionals not only outnumbered the collegians at the weekly eating and talking exercises of the Football Writers Association at Toots Shor's yesterday, but they also outweighed them with plenty to spare. There were Steve Owen, Red Smith and Jack Lavelle of the Giants, Curly Lambeau and Don Hutson of the Packers and Dud DeGroot of the Redskins.

SAMUEL JOHNSON is the subject of the world's most celebrated biography. But Boswell did not know much that modern research has unearthed, and he did not set down all he knew. If the great men of the past need re-interpretation for each ensuing age, then there should be room for a new biography of the peculiar, paradoxical, pompous dean of eighteenth century English letters.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 18 -- Participation in profits, the owning of their own homes and the perpetuation of employment after five years' service, were the high spots of a petition addressed to President Getulio Vargas by the commercial employes of Brazil today.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Tuesday, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Advance elements of the United States First Cavalry Division are consolidating positions they seized on Mount Catabaran and Mount Cabungangan, dominating peaks east of the Pinamopoan-Ormoc highway.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Although corn showed a heavy undertone in the early trading, with December breaking around 1 cent a bushel to within 3/8 cent of the seasonal low, other grains showed stubborn resistance to pressure and rallied sharply today in the late trading on the Board of Trade.

Coffin Burr, Inc., will offer to the public today $1,800,000 of Keyes Fibre Company first mortgage sinking fund 4 1/2 per cent bonds due on Oct. 1, 1959. The bonds will be priced at 102 1/2 to yield approximately 4.025 per cent.

WITH AMERICAN INFANTRY in the Huertgen Forest, Germany, Nov. 13 (U.P.) -- Two American companies, isolated in a 150-yard by 500-yard patch of dense wood for three days, during which they fought off numerous German counter-attacks, were rescued today when the rest of their battalion fought their way to them.

The official ruling that deprived the Giants of victory over the Philadelphia Eagles when Ken Strong's 43-yard "pressure" field goal was not allowed was still a topic of discussion in professional circles yesterday.

CALLANDER, Ont., Nov. 13 (U.P.) -- The Dionne quintuplets, dressed in pink flowered dresses, sat on a sofa in their home here and told in French what they think of such widely assorted subjects as Santa Claus and Americans.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 13 (U.P.) -- Fernando Menichelli, latest "wild bull" from Argentina, made a successful United States' debut tonight in the same ring where Luis Angel Firpo started twenty-two years ago. Menichelli won a 10-round decision over Laurient Bouchard of Montreal before 4,000 fans at Laurel Garden.

Billy Arnold, Philadelphia welterweight, registered his twenty-eighth knockout triumph when he stopped Bob Wade of Newark in the scheduled eight-round feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. Arnold, engaging in his thirtieth professional contest, halted his foe in 2:03 of the second heat when Referee Jack Appell intervened to spare Wade further punishment.

Following conferences with representatives of the International Alliance of Theatrical and Stage Employes, a spokesman for the Metropolitan Opera Association announced yesterday that differences between the association and labor organizations, which threatened for a time to affect the opening of the new opera season on Nov. 27, "appeared to be on the way to settlement."

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 13 -- A Japanese force has retaken the small island of Ngeregong, about a dozen miles northeast of the upper tip of Peliliu in the southern Palaus, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced here today.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A supplementary communique:

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 13 -- A strike of 1,800 supervisory employes, described as having virtually halted production on engines for B-29 superbombers at four plants of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation, resulted today in a War Labor Board order to return to work immediately and settle a dispute over union recognition by further discussion.

ON THE AMERICAN THIRD ARMY FRONT, in France, Nov. 13 -- A new newspaper, published, edited and circulated by the Germans, has appeared on the Western Front. Its circulation manager is obviously an artillery man.

AT A LEYTE AIR BASE, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A successful low-level attack on a Japanese transport, a miraculous escape from the middle of a Japanese fleet, a hide-and-seek game with battle-crazed enemy sailors, a sea fight between a flying boat and small Japanese boats and eventual rescue gave a Mitchell bomber crew enough thrills to last a lifetime.

The National Theatre Conference, cooperative organization of directors of community and university theatres, will hold its annual three-day convention at the Piccadilly Hotel beginning Friday afternoon, Nov. 24. Under the chairmanship of Hallie Flanagan Davis, dean of Smith College and head of the college's Department of Theatre, leading members of the non-professional theatres in this country will meet with professional representatives of the theatre to discuss this year's aim and theme, "One Theatre."

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. l3 -- Despite an increase in expenditures of $396,005 over last year's net budget and an increase in the gross budget of more than 6 per cent, Nassau County will be able next year to maintain its $1.05 tax rate in the proposed $20,883,040 budget submitted to the County Supervisors today by County Executive J. Russell Sprague.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- The Army newspaper Stars and Stripes in an editorial today said "there just isn't enough blood being given by the folks back home" for the bloodbank in the European theatre of operations.

The Government's export subsidy program on cotton is ready to be put into effect, it was said here yesterday. The initial export prices and the differentials for both these farm products are scheduled to be announced at 3 P.M. tomorrow.

Army passed up a glorious opportunity to gloat yesterday -- the first it has had in thirteen years. Entering the portals of Toots Shor's fodder emporium to attend the Football Writers' weekly luncheon, one naturally expected to encounter yards and yards of braid on uniforms adorning pouter-pigeon chests, for hadn't the cat just partaken of a canary cocktail?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- American forces on the European and Pacific fronts are using up materiel so much faster than was expected that "a superhuman effort" must be made to increase production in five specific categories, from 17 to 40 per cent over September figures, Robert P. Patterson, Undersecretary of War, told his press conference today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- The deadlock in the International Civil Aviation Conference continued today over the powers to be granted to the proposed international body for post-war commercial aviation. Adolf A. Berle Jr., Lord Swinton and C.D. Howe, chairman, respectively, of the American, British and Canadian delegations, continued the series of meetings which they began yesterday in an effort to reconcile differences among the proposals made by the three countries.
KANDY, Ceylon, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A communique:

WITH UNITED STATES INFANTRY, near Vossenack, Germany, Nov. 13 (A.P.) -- The fighting was so intense there was no time to bury the dead, but what was worse was the fact that fifty-four American wounded had lain unattended for a day and a half in German territory under American and German fire.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
BELMONT, Mass., Nov. 13 (AP) -- "America is a damn good country, and don't let anyone tell you otherwise."

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 13 -- Old Nassau's ivy-covered campus, steeped in the rich tradition of the Poes, the Edwardses and the Slagles, to mention only a few, is taking the current football campaign in calm stride these Indian summer afternoons.

President Roosevelt again has named Nicholas M. Schenck, president of Loew's, Inc., as national chairman of the film industry's 1945 March of Dimes campaign. This will mark Mr. Schenck's fourth term as chairman of the infantile paralysis drive. It is scheduled to start next January.

A provision of the laws of Switzerland and other countries that has enabled German nationals and others to conceal beneficial ownership of certain American concerns whose products are "of vital wartime necessity and great peacetime value" was cited yesterday in a presentment handed up by a Federal grand jury here, which suggested that Congress consider legislation to thwart such action, and proposed increasing the penalties for violation of the anti-trust laws.

Officials of Calgary, Alberta, will be in the market on Nov. 20 with an issue of $3,000,000 of refunding bonds, dated Jan. 1, 1945, and maturing Jan. 1, 1946 to 1962. The bonds maturing from 1946 to 1951 will bear interest at 3 percent, and those due from 1952 to 1962 will carry a 3 1/2 per cent rate.

Since the ration value of butter was raised to twenty points a pound on Oct. 1 consumption of margarine has increased. Paul T. Truitt, president of the Association of Margarine Manufacturers, told this column yesterday that 13 1/2 per cent more was sold last month than in September and 60 per cent more than in August.

The War Department Office of Dependency Benefits in Newark got a candy box yesterday -- a two-pound box marked "candy" in gold letters, but containing no candy. In the box were pieces of the war agency's family allowance and allotment-of-pay checks, torn to shreds in a train accident near Brandy, Va.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- William H. Davis, chairman of the National War Labor Board, disclosed today that, besides himself, two other public members of the board, Dr. George W. Taylor, vice chairman, and Dr. Frank P. Graham, had submitted their resignations.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 13 -- The attention of many Chileans switched today to the domestic and political situation in Peru with the publication here of two statements referring to the reported persecution of Aprista party members and its possible repercussions on the concept of Pan-Americansm.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet Communique 181:

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 13 -- "Black Cats," the old slow Catalinas that in single-handed raids from bases in New Guinea and Morotai, just north of Halmahera Island, already have accounted for more than 100,000 tons of Japanese shipping, now are poised in Philippine waters to resume their strikes at enemy key communications to the west of the liberated province of Leyte, it became known today.

The American Broadcasting Station in Europe helped spread the Hitler rumors yesterday, quoting London newspapers as having said that it was "extremely likely that Hitler must be incapacitated," according to The United Press.
ROME, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The War Labor Board today directed striking supervisory employes in Paterson and Wood-Ridge, N.J., plants to return to work immediately and settle a union recognition dispute by "peaceful procedures."

Middle West Corporation A capital distribution of $2 a share out of surplus was voted yesterday by directors of the Middle West Corporation, payable Dec. 20, subject to the approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Another dividend of 30 cents a share from earned surplus also was declared for payment on the same date.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The Irish Government's reply to representations by the British Government on the question of refuge for war criminals, which was read to the House of Commons today, "simply evades the issue," The Star said in an editorial today.

Issues involved in "shaping the economic future" will be considered today at the Hotel Astor at the sixty-fourth annual meeting of the Academy of Political Science, a non-partisan and scientific organization.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 14 (AP) --"Homemaking can no longer be bounded by the four walls of the home." Frances Scudder, State leader of home demonstration agents, said today before the New York State Federation of Home Bureaus.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- S. Sydney Silverman, M.P., head of the United Kingdom delegation to the War Emergency Conference of the World Jewish Congress, made a statement today condemning the murder of Lord Moyne in Cairo.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Senator Robert F. Wagner, Democrat, of New York, introduced legislation today which would extend rent control by the Office of Price Administration to business property in defense areas.
If the logbook of the Tirpitz could be retrieved and its last entry translated that entry probably would read:

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The strengthening of the Anglo-French entente despite all that German propaganda had done to undermine it during the occupation was stressed by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden in a statement in the Commons today on his return from Paris.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte. Nov. 14 (AP) -- A supplementary communique:

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe, world three-cushion billiard champion, bounced back into a commanding twenty-point lead tonight over Welker Cochran, San Francisco challenger, by stroking out a 50-to-33 victory in forty-four innings in the twelfth block of their 1,500-point challenge match.

Dorcey Smith, pianist, and Louise Behrend, violinist, made their New York debut as a team last night in the New York Times Hall, playing four sonatas. The first of these was one in B-flat major in two movements by the eighteenth-century Italian composer Luigi Boccherini, which, according to the program, received its first New York performance.
CHUNGKING. China. Nov. 14 (AP) -- A United States Army Forces in China communique:

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 15 (AP)--A barrage of flying bombs rocked parts of southern England during the night, causing a number of deaths. London had short alerts. The sharp raid came after two comparatively quiet nights.

" Thirty Seconds Over Tokyo," Metro's picturization of the story of the air raid on the Japanese capital written by Capt. Ted Lawson and Bob Considine, will have its world premiere at 9 P.M. tonight at the Capitol. Admission to this showing is by purchase of war bonds only. Spencer Tracy, who plays Lieut. Col. James Doolittle, and Van Johnson, who appears as Captain Lawson, head the cast of the drama.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Wednesday, Nov. 15 (AP) -- A communique:

We have been glad to read some of your recent editorials on the Chinese situation. We appreciate very much the wisdom and sympathy shown in them, and we earnestly hope that this kind of healthy friendship between the United States and China will increase with time.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 14 -- Elements of the British Second Army and the American Seventh Army plunged forward through German defenses today, while infantry of the American Third Army fought its way into the suburbs of Metz to the west and south and tanks smashed steadily northeastward over the Lorraine plain toward the Saar and the main German defenses.

JOE FALCARO walked into a bowling alley in Cleveland, limbered up, and a complete stranger inexplicably challenged him to a match for a $10 side bet. Since that was the equivalent of finding money, Joe took the bet, the stranger and the $10. The beaten kegler was annoyed.
Capt. John Sheridan Reilly was killed in action in Holland on Oct. 25, according to a telegram received Saturday by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. John S. Reilly of 1 Lexington Avenue and Rye, N.Y.

BUFFALO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Frank R. Bortner, 60, ill and unable to adjust himself to life outside prison, wants to return to Auburn prison, where he served twenty years for killing his wife. But he has found it difficult to get readmitted.

A special exhibition of oils, water-colors and drawings by Esther Goetz, entitled "Painting the Town," opened yesterday afternoon with a preview at the Museum of the City of New York. It will continue through Jan. 7.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The War Production Board took advantage of mounting supplies of once-critical metals today in three measures designed to improve to "prewar serviceability" the quality of civilian goods which have been hard hit by wartime material shortages.

An underwriting group headed by Dillon, Read Co. will offer today to the public $30,000,000 of first mortgage 2 7/8 per cent bonds, due in 1974, of the Houston Lighting and Power Company. The bonds twill be priced at 102 1/2 and accrued interest.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- Japanese forces in Kwangsi province, successful in attempts to knock out the major Fourteenth United States Air Force bases at Kweilin and Liuchow, appeared today to be starting twin drives to the northwest on Kweiyang and to the southwest on Nanning, last American airfields east of Kumming in Yunnan province.

Mrs. John Schlutter, who took 6-month-old Barbara Anne Goggin from her cot in the New York Foundling Hospital last July, was sentenced to a penitentiary term up to three years yesterday by Judge John A. Mullen in General Sessions on her guilty plea to endangering the life of the infant.

Plans for extending the welfare services of Bundles for America to enable the volunteer group to see "that the GI has a real home to come home to" were discussed yesterday at the opening session of the organization's first national conference being held at Sherry's.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Little business was transacted in today's stock markets here and prices tended to ease in most sections.

Hoi polloi purred contentedly in the presence of royalty yesterday as two-month-old alley kittens romped beside seasoned champions and Inky Dinky and Pin-Up Girl of Bagdad vied with Angel of Fairyland and Princess Onyxess. It was opening day of the Brooklyn-Long Island Cat Club's two-day fourth annual championship cat show, held in Manhattan, at the Hotel Woodstock, 127 West Forty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 8, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

LONDON, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- A Viennese surgeon has operated on Adolf Hitler to remove a dangerous throat tumor that developed from his chronic throat trouble, a prominent German arriving in Switzerland said today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- America's professional golfers, driving, putting and chipping for the pot of gold at the end of each of the myriad rainbows scattered along the tournament trail, are expected to raise between $400,000 and $500,000 for war relief agencies during the next year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Let any gob presume to disparage the Navy's mess now and the sea-going chefs are apt to make it hot for him, quite literally. (Achoo!) For President Roosevelt informed both houses of Congress today that Admiral King's boys had sequestered 1,013,000 pounds of pepper for Navy use between April and October of this year.

In the first NEW YORK TIMES book meeting of the current season seven leaders in the book field will debate "The Future of Books" at a round-table discussion to be held tonight at 8:30 o'clock in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

A radically new type of synthetic rubber, in which silicon, main component of sand and glass, takes the place of carbon as the backbone of the molecule, was demonstrated here yesterday by the General Electric Company at the Engineers Club, 32 West Fortieth Street.

A series of new fabrics, spun and woven by Ponemah Mills, in Taftsville, Conn., were shown yesterday in the Perroquet suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. All were of a new 1-dernier American Viscose rayon staple, said to be the finest rayon fiber produced to date.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- President Roosevelt voiced at his news conference today renewed recommendation of a division of the country into seven watershed areas for the development of navigation, flood control, irrigation and hydroelectric power on the pattern of the Tennessee Valley Authority.
ROME, Nov. 14 -- Another strong attack on Soviet Russia from Polish sources has been issued here in Rome under ecclesiastical -- but not Vatican -- auspices, it can be stated today.

The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation announced yesterday that it intends to ask the Federal Power Commission for approval of rate increases in charges for gas sold wholesale to associated companies. Increased costs of well drilling and in other operations were cited by the corporation as necessitating higher rates, despite the fact that the Columbia system has contracted to receive gas deliveries outside of the fields in which it operates.

The Women's International Exposition opened its twenty-first annual show yesterday at Madison Square Garden where three general groupings demonstrate the work that is keeping women on the home front busy in the third year of war.

The stock market duplicated yesterday the losses suffered on Monday but there was even more emphasis on the selling. Declines of 1 to 2 points and even more were well scattered through the industrial issues, and some of these gave way on comparatively moderate liquidation.

To round out requirements for Army relief in liberated areas, the Procurement Division of the Treasury Department announced yesterday that it will buy women's and misses' ready-made coats in large quantities for delivery before the end of the year.

The Russian market for American industrial production would solve our unemployment problem during the post-war period and for a long time to come, provided Russia receives assurance of security through international organization for the maintenance of peace, Admiral William H. Standley, former American Ambassador to Soviet Russia, said last night.

ALBANY, Nov. 14 -- George P. Monaghan, special prosecutor in the grand jury investigation of Albany County, prepared affidavits today in support of planned applications for additional changes of venue for trial of indictments arising from the investigation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- James F. Byrnes, director of War Mobilization and Reconversion, consented today, at the personal request of President Roosevelt, to remain in that post "until the elimination of Germany from the war."

Army production programs, contrary to popular belief, must be stepped up sharply to meet the demands posed by the changes in the global conflict that have now created a need for more material than has been required at any time since we entered the war, two hundred war contractors and sub-contractors were told yesterday by officials of the armed services.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday about the lows of the day and at net losses of 13 to 19 points on active months.

VERNY, France, Nov. 14--The fall of Metz, never before captured by frontal assault, appeared imminent tonight as another link in its outer chain of forts fell, and infantry was pressing within two miles of the ancient gate of Metz on the south. Meanwhile, a vise was being tightened also from the north and west, leaving a rapidly narrowing escape gap.

This morning launches the deer season in several of New York State's Catskill counties and in Westchester County for a two-week run that closes on Nov. 30. Bucks only may be taken in the Catskills, but through a special ruling last spring does also are legal quarry in Westchester.
The biggest mural of one of the greatest battles in ring history was unveiled yesterday in a setting that bridged the gap between an old and a new generation.

Nine persons were killed and nine were injured in the crash of an Army Air Transport Command C-54 plane, containing passengers and cargo, when it struck the side of a 1,000-foot mountain, thirty miles west of Harmon Field, Newfoundland, early Sunday morning, five and one-half hours after the plane left La Guardia field, it was officially disclosed at the field last night by the ATC.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, denied today that cigarettes would be added to the list of rationed commodities and simultaneously called upon the public to assist the OPA in stamping out black-market transactions.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 14 -- Delegates at the thirtieth annual convention of Hadassah, women's Zionist organization of America, authorized tonight a drive for funds to finance a fight against tuberculosis, typhoid, plague and other epidemic diseases which threaten to become a health menace to the entire Middle East.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Congress reassembled today after a recess of eight weeks, dealt briskly with a few routine matters and recessed again until Thursday, pending organization of the program for the brief remainder of the session.

Wage scales and market prices should be permitted to find the levels that will produce maximum employment and national income through a return to the pre-war bargaining processes of private industry, F. D. Newbury, vice president of the new products division of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, said yesterday.

The resignation of the chairman of the War Labor Board creates an opportunity to correct a basic error in the organization of the board. This error lies in merging two sharply distinct and even conflicting functions -- the settlement of labor disputes and the administration of wage stabilization.

LONDON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- British concern over post-war markets flared in the House of Commons today, with Sir Patrick Hannon, Conservative, declaring that "careful plans are in progress in the United States to seize practically the whole of South American trade."

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- French reverse lend-lease within three months will be saving the Allies as much transatlantic shipping space as does British reverse lend-lease at present, two high American Army officers said today.

ROME, Nov. 14 -- Premier Ivanoe Bonomi's ship of state remained afloat tonight after a stormy session of the Ministers Without Portfolio, but it is considerably battered and it looks as if some repairs were going to be required soon.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Countering what looked like an Argentine pressure move on Bolivia, the United States has sent a shipload of wheat to meet a threatened shortage in Bolivia.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in English to North America Federal Communications Commission

A treble damage action to recover $577,560 was filed yesterday in the Brooklyn Federal Court by the Office of Price Administration against two partners and a former sales manager of the Hercules Liquor Products Company of 360 Furman Street, Brooklyn, it was announced last night by Daniel P. Woolley, regional OPA administrator.

Both Chairman George of the Senate Finance Committee and Chairman Doughton of the House Ways and Means Committee have indicated that they expect no major change in tax rates during 1945. An analysis of the Government's expenditures and revenues indicates they are on good ground in this prediction.

RYE, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- The American delegation to the International Business Conference began today "to put sandbags in the ballooned loan demands" which are obviously being sought here by many of the business groups representing fifty-two countries.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 14 -- Belgian Communists, giving voice to the reluctance of the resistance forces to give up their weapons, rocked the national ship of state today. In a three-hour emergency Cabinet meeting Premier Hubert Pierlot won his point on merging some of the former underground units into the regular army and disbanding the rest, and postponed the collapse of his Government, which many have felt to be inevitable.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- The deadlock in the international civil aviation conference was virtually broken tonight when an official spokesman for the conference said that material progress had been made by the American, British and Canadian delegations toward a solution of the controversy over the powers of the proposed international air body.

ATHENS, Nov. 14 -- American Legionnaires of the Athens Post today assisted Red Cross workers in loading British Army trucks with clothing and shoes supplied by the Greek War Relief and the American Red Cross for distribution in the provinces. Most of the shipments were destined for the mountainous areas, where winter has set in.
Four little ships, all lost, may have saved the American invasion of the Philippines from a major setback or even from disaster in the Second Battle of the Philippine Sea, three weeks ago.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- A chain drug store bought 218 1/2 cartons of "name brand" cigarettes for $903 at a postoffice auction today, and arranged to deliver the packages to a Loop store tomorrow on an armored truck.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Eire's reply to a United States Government request for assurances of refusal of asylum to war criminals has been received, according to a State Department spokesman today, and "does not go as far as we would like in all particulars."

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 14 -- Carrier planes from the Pacific Fleet delivered a shattering blow against the harbor works of Manila and Cavite on Sunday [Monday, Philippine time], blasting enemy shipping and docks and destroying twenty-eight more Japanese planes, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced this afternoon.

Reports about the agreements reached between the British and the French Governments during Mr. Churchill's visit to Paris are still vague, and the agreements themselves can be only preliminary pending the assent of the United Nations involved, including Russia and the United States.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Wednesday, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Sweeping wide areas of the southwest Pacific, American bombers poured bomb loads on Philippine airdromes and sank one -- and probably two -- Japanese freighters. General MacArthur announced in a supplemental communique today.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- For exactly five years tomorrow the British War Relief Society of America, through its London headquarters directed by Bertram de N. Cruger, has helped the people of Britain through the generosity of thousands of Americans.

FORT MADISON, Ia., Nov. 14 (AP) -- C.R. Sheaffer, president of the pen company said today that the concern did not hire Upton Close direct, but arranged for his services through the National Broadcasting Company.

Only a fifty-fifty chance exists that Germany will be defeated by next spring or summer and it will take at least one and a half to three years of deadly warfare in the Pacific to vanquish Japan, Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker, president of the Eastern Airlines, predicted yesterday in an appeal for increased civilian participation in the war and the New York War Fund.

One of the most important facts about the war in the Pacific has been our inability to make contact at any one time or in any one place with any large number of Japanese. It has been like a land campaign where one strong point after another has had to be overcome, with the added disadvantage that hundreds of miles of water lay between each island fortress.

Responding to a plea by Surgeon General Ross T. McIntire of the Navy for blood donors, 665 officers, enlisted men and civilian personnel of the naval air station at Floyd Bennett Field gave the mobile unit of the Brooklyn Red Cross blood donor service its busiest day yesterday when they took time off to donate blood for shipment to the fighting fronts.

COMBAT HEADQUARTERS, Allied Troops in North Burma, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Chinese troops, pushing across North Burma toward their native land, have by-passed Japanese fortified Bhamo and may bring Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's two-year-old dream of a road to China to realization within weeks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Taxpayers can look forward to no further increases in Federal war-time taxes and may, on the contrary, expect some decreases when victory in Europe sets the signals for some downward revision. This, in substance, appeared to be the censensus of Government tax experts as Congress reconvened today.

For a while there was a hotly contested tug-of-war between Herbert H. Harris and John C. Wilson, producers of "The Man Who Had All the Luck" and "The Streets Are Guarded," respectively. Each claimed a prior right to present his offering here next Monday night. Well, Mr. Wilson won out, so "The Man Who Had All the Luck" had to be shifted to Thursday night, Nov. 23.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Proposals for supplementary appropriations totaling more than $415,000,000 for the current fiscal year were laid before Congress today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Mrs. Florence Kerr, director of war public services of the Federal Works Agency, told the first meeting of the new National Advisory Committee on Child Care of FWA today that despite war production cutbacks there was a rapidly growing demand for more child care centers and war nurseries.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Wednesday, Nov. 15 -- American troops in two wide enveloping movements from the northwest and east yesterday threatened both flanks of the Japanese Yamashita Line in Ormoc Valley on Leyte where an estimated 35,000 of Gen. Tomoyuki Yamashita's soldiers have been fighting doggedly for the past week to maintain their last foothold in the first liberated province of the Philippines.

Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh disclosed yesterday that 200 summonses for smoking had been served this week on shoppers in department stores in Manhattan and Brooklyn. The drive, he said, would be extended to stores in the Bronx and Queens.

The young ladies of the theatre are energetic and more and more are becoming double threats and triple. They write their own plays, they act in them and sometimes they direct and produce. Now it is Ilka Chase, who, discontented with her lot as a sardonic hatchet woman on other people's stages, has written a play of her own -- after first doing the novel from which it is taken.

ROME, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The British Eighth Army has won the coastal highway bridge over the Ghiaia Canal before Ravenna and, in important gains ranging to two miles in the Forli area, has captured the village of San Tome, Allied Headquarters announced today.

WITH THE UNITED STATES SECOND ARMORED DIVISION, on the Western Front, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Nazi party has advised all German soldiers to shoot anyone contemplating surrender -- "whether he be a superior officer, an ordinary fellow or a close buddy" -- according to the party publication Scorpion, which is distributed to German troops.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 14 -- Here in this nerve center for much of the war against the Japanese there are no illusions about the job ahead in the Pacific. Arriving here on the first lap of a tour of Pacific war zones sponsored by Navy Secretary James V. Forrestal, this correspondent, after talking with key naval and military figures, formed the following impressions:

Brooklyn's righteous wrath exceeded borough bounds yesterday as the citizenry, bursting with indignation at Noel Coward's slur upon Brooklyn soldiers in his new book, "Middle East Diary," sought ways to strike back at the English playwright-authormusician-actor through representatives in the City Council and Congress.

BOSTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Bruins set off a five-goal burst in the second period to open their 21st National Hockey League home season with a 7-5 triumph over the Black Hawks tonight before a sell-out crowd of 13,500 at the Boston Garden.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Tom Tunstall and Bester William Steele, Negro locomotive firemen on two southern railroads, appeared through counsel before the Supreme Court today and argued that, while the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen represented all the firemen on the two systems as exclusive bargaining agents, it barred Negroes and even made agreements with the carriers that resulted in demotion and unemployment for Negro firemen.

Fourteen waste paper dealers against whom injunction suits were filed in Brooklyn and Manhattan Federal courts yesterday were accused of "salvage sabotage" by Daniel P. Woolley, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- A flurry of requests for new legislation greeted Congress today as it reassembled for a six-week session before giving way to the newly elected Congress in January.

WITH AMERICAN ARMED TROOPS in Germany, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Seven soldiers were called today from the bleak frozen mud of their foxholes and told that the impossible dream of nearly every fight- Lug man was true for them -- they were going back home.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Communique 220:
LONDON, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- Text of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's statement to the House of Commons today:

The New York Life Insurance Company announced yesterday that it would grant a one-day "furlough" to each of its employee who sells twelve or more bonds as a "Blue Star Brigades" in the Sixth War Loan.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin reported by The Associated Press:
PARIS, Nov. 14 -- Rene Pleven, Minister of Colonies, will become Minister of Finance to replace Aime Lepercq, who was killed last Thursday, it was officially announced tonight.

The number of handicapped veterans after the present conflict will be larger than after World War I because improved medical technique will have saved more men with serious wounds, Maj. Gen. Norman T. Kirk, Surgeon General of the Army, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The reasons advanced by the President to James F. Byrnes, Director of the Office of War Mobilization, for remaining at his post "until the elimination of Germany from the war" could operate against certain Government replacements of high officials which have been anticipated in Washington and urged on Mr. Roosevelt.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Sunday morning's successful attack on the Tirpitz was the culmination of two months' preparation by the Royal Air Force Bomber Command to sink the great German battleship, which had survived five bomb and torpedo blows from the British and Russians.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- Although the week-end talks between Prime Minister Churchill and Gen. Charles de Gaulle emphasized the questions of France's military strength and diplomatic position and sidetracked the question of her economic recovery, informed circles said today that a tentative scheme for the resumption of French production even during the war was under study by the French the Allies' authorities.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- A few hours after the Tirpitz had been sunk by the Royal Air Force, the British Navy sank, shattered or burned nine out of a convoy of eleven ships on Sunday night within a few miles of the fortified shores of southern Norway, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Under an order appearing in a War Department circular issued today, women in military service will be entitled to about the same type of prenatal safeguards which the War Department already accords to its more than 500,000 civilian employes under its industrial medical system, plus the same kind of confinement and post-natal care given to soldiers' wives under the Emergency Maternity and Infant Care Program.

Plans for a twenty-story office building to be erected at 15-17 Rector Street and 90-92 Greenwich Street were filed yesterday by Harold L. Young, architect, for Henry Goelet, owner. The estimated cost is $525,000.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 15 -- Red Army troops wiped out the last enemy bridgehead on the Danube River's east bank south of Budapest yesterday and battled forward seven miles in an outflanking movement east of the Hungarian capital as Berlin reported that violent street fighting had flared again in the city's southeastern suburbs.

Commercial radio service between the Philippines and the United States was re-established yesterday with the opening of a Press Wireless circuit direct from the islands to Los Angeles, the first commercial communications link to be put in operation since the Japanese invasion of 1941.

John F. Cassidy, who was acquitted in Brooklyn Federal Court in 1940 on a charge of conspiracy to overthrow the Government, was barred yesterday from the practice of law in a decision by the Brooklyn Appellate Division. After his acquittal by a jury as an alleged leader of the Christian Front, Cassidy was inducted into the Army.

Indications are that the railroads will be prepared for postwar passenger transportation. An instance is that of the Great Northern Railway, which has ordered five streamlined trains at a cost of $7,000,000 for the Seattle-Chicago run.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 14 -- In the normal course of human events Yale would be getting ready at this time for its climactic football games with Princeton and Harvard, and Old Blues would be cluttering up the Taft and remembering back to the deeds of Larry Kelley and Clint Frank.
ROME, Nov. 14 (AP) -- A communique:

A banking group headed by Allen Co. received yesterday the award of $18,000,000 of refunding bonds of the city of St. Petersburg, Fla., on a bid of 98 for the obligations at 2 3/4s. The issue consists of $12,000,000 of serial bonds maturing Oct. 1, 1945 to 1979, and $6,000,000 of callable term bonds due Oct. 1, 1979, optional for call Oct. 1, 1945 to 1978.

Four church leaders who have been active in the work of the Brooklyn Church and Mission Federation for twenty-five years were honored at a dinner last night celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the initial meeting to organize the federation.
LONDON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- A Joint Air and Home Security Ministries communique:

WILLIAM B. ZIFF, who publishes magazines and books as a business, writes books as a contribution to the discussion of current affairs. In his "The Coming Battle of Germany" two years ago Mr. Ziff pleaded eloquently for the dominant importance of air power. In his "The Gentlemen Talk of Peace"* Mr. Ziff has raised his voice in the most important, the most general and the most contentious argument of our time.

Announcement of the new Boeing Stratocruiser is a by-product of the war. In other circumstances it might have been many years before a plane of the announced performance of this new passenger liner of the post-war airways would have been developed. The "bugs" that it might have taken years to iron out of a peacetime model, if any company had the reserves to finance experimentation, have already been surmounted under the urgency of wartime.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 14 -- The Seventh and Third American Armies plunging across the soggy Lorraine plain are heading toward the Maginot Line, the most formidable barrier yet encountered by either army.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Production of another new American airplane for use in international air transportation was revealed here and elsewhere today by the Boeing Company. The new machine is a peacetime adaptation of the B-29, which has been employed in raids on Japan.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The echoes of the Anglo-French talks and the Moscow conversations that are reverberating here give some point to a remark of A.J. Cummings in this morning's News Chronicle to the effect that Mr. Churchill's visit to Paris is "one indication of the British Government's slow release from the domination of the State Department."
LONDON, Nov. 14 (Reuter) -- This is the first story from inside Germany of how Gestapo Chief Heinrich Himmler exploited the July 20 plot against Adolf Hitler to gain supreme power in the Reich.

LONDON, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- The German convoy sailing northward, was intercepted by the British squadron, under the command of Rear Admiral Rhoderick R. McGrigor, in the 10,000-ton heavy cruiser Kent. The German ships fled to the protection of shore batteries.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- A plan for the establishment of self-government in Burma after its liberation from the Japanese, including a proposal for an interim period of reconstruction under British administration, was advanced today by a committee of seven Conservative Members of Parliament.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communiqu 182:

An exhibition of sculpture by Herbert Haseltine will open at 9 o'clock this evening at the Wildenstein Galleries with a $5 preview arranged in behalf of the war program of the Musicians Emergency Fund. Beginning tomorrow, and until Dec. 9, the show will be open to the public free of charge, daily, except Sundays.

The Central New York Power Company offered yesterday at competitive sale $48,000,000 of general mortgage bonds, representing what is likely to be the last major piece of corporate financing to be undertaken before the official opening of the Sixth War Loan drive on Nov. 20.
Monday's communique, as broadcast from Sofia and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Because Jocko, the 23-year-old parrot of elderly Mrs. Mildred R. Burr, had become law-abiding, ceasing his annoyance of other tenants by his shrieks and whistling every dawn in her suite on the fifth floor of 277 Park Avenue, Magistrate Charles E. Ramsgate. sitting yesterday in the War Emergency Court, dismissed the summons proceeding against the bird, taken up two weeks ago.

The Moscow report of the Religious News Service in your issue of Nov. 5, which deals with the passing in Lwow of the Ukrainian Metropolitan Archbishop, Count Andrew Roman Sheptycky, gives a distorted picture of this distinguished personage.

The joint appeal by the American Theatre Wing War Service and the Actors Fund of America to patrons of summer theatres last summer for funds to be used in maintaining canteens for service men and to assist indigent members in the theatrical profession has brought in a total of $4,323.69, according to Vinton Freedley, treasurer of the fund.

Five hundred stars of stage, screen and radio, whose vocal and histrionic talents were aided by 200 musicians, performed last night before a packed assemblage of 20,000 persons at Madison Square Garden. The occasion was the eleventh annual "Night of Stars," for the benefit of the United Jewish Appeal for Refugees, Overseas Needs and Palestine for which $110,000 was raised.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,741, against 1,203 last week and 1,445 in the like period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 1,147, compared with 457 last Tuesday.

LONDON, Nov. 14--Norwegian troops who were trained in Britain are fighting with the Red Army in northern Norway and a Norwegian military mission is attached to the Soviet command on the Arctic front, it was announced here tonight.

Marcelle Denya, soprano, who sang leading roles at the Paris Opera and the Opera Comique before the present war, was heard in her third New York recital last night in Town Hall. The possessor of a magnetic personality and an attractive stage presence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- President Roosevelt's fourth inaugural will be one of the simplest and soberest in the nation's recent history and will break precedent when it is held on Jan. 20 on the south portico of the White House. A decision to that effect was announced today by the Joint Congressional Committee in charge of the inauguration, headed by Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia.

Moscow and Berlin statisticians are doing their best to bolster up each other's morale, obviously without meaning to. Soviet estimates of Nazi losses on the Russian front have now mounted to 8,600,000 men killed, wounded or captured.

When dried garbanzo peas, costing about 15 cents a pound, are used in meat or poultry stuffing, they have the taste and texture of chestnuts, which, at about $1 a pound, are not too plentiful. Sometimes known as chick-peas, they are a variety of legume that is round, beige in color and about the size of the tip of a man's small finger.

The War Advertising Council is planning to carry on its activities for some time after the war, it revealed yesterday in a message to industry leaders throughout the country, in which it stressed the need for continuing in the reconstruction period the public service rendered by business during the war "in mobilizing its advertising power to enlist public cooperation on home front problems."

The Metropolitan Museum of Art will open to the public today two exhibitions called "Great Rugs of the Orient" and "Enameled Islamic Glass." They will be continued through Dec. 31. These examples of Near Eastern art and craftsmanship are from the museum's permanent collections, with the exception of a few rugs that are loans.

Consolidated net earnings of the Columbian Carbon Company in the first nine months of this year amounted to $2,315,426 after all charges, including provision of $1,225,000 for estimated Federal taxes on income, Reid L. Carr, president, reported yesterday in a statement to stockholders.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 14 -- Both the Fronda and Cabildo today dedicated long comments to THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial on Sunday about Argentina to show that the skepticism with which the Argentine Government's recent measures have been received was unjustified.

Tonight's events: "Tosca," City Center Opera, 8:15 o'clock; concert by Boston Symphony, Koussevitzky conducting, William Primrose, viola, assisting artist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; piano recital, Max Kotralsky. Town Hall, 8:30; piano recital, Mabel Rippel, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30; joint recital, Ralph Kirkpatrick, harpsichord, Alexander Schneider, violin, Lexington Avenue Y.M.H.A., 8:40.

Man, who has learned to conquer matter, must now learn to conquer the human spirit, Sir Norman Angell, winner of the 1933 Nobel Peace Award, declared yesterday at a meeting of the American Nobel Anniversary Committee, held in the Little Theatre, 444 West Fifty-sixth Street.

Kunigunde Duncan and D.F. Nichols, authors of "Mentor Graham: The Man Who Taught Lincoln," traveled 7,000 miles and interviewed 200 descendants and pupils of Mentor Graham to gather material for their biography. The book, scheduled for publication on Monday by the University of Chicago Press, is the first full-length portrait of the pioneer village schoolmaster in New Salem.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 14 (AP) -- The formation of Norseman Air Transport, an organization of men serving in various capacities in the Army Air Forces and the Air Transport Command, and the group's desire to operate a New England airline was announced here today.
LONDON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Foreign Secretary Eden's remarks strengthened belief in London that Britain was bent on formation of a western European bloc to guard against post-war German aggression.

Twelve, including Bolingbroke, are named for the $10,000 Victory Handicap, feature today at Belmont Park, where the nine-day war-relief meet and the 189-day New York racing season will end. The card filled better than any other for the Victory session, and as many as 25,000 persons may turn out.

Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commander of the New York Guard, was appointed yesterday to succeed the late Alfred E. Smith as president of Empire State, Inc., the company that operates the Empire State Building. Selection of the new president by the board of directors was announced by John J. Raskob, vice president of the corporation, who said Mr. Smith and General Drum were lifelong friends and had many interests in common.

Thanksgiving Day diners were advised yesterday by Markets Commissioner Henry M. Brundage to tighten their belts and prepare for a "turkeyless" dinner. Other poultry and meats that have been popular substitutes for the holiday bird will be scarce, too, he warned.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt revealed officially for the first time today that the White House is considering renewed proposals to switch the Dec. 2 Army-Navy football game -- the gridiron classic of the century -- from the relative privacy of Annapolis, Md., to a larger city.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- Louis Friedman, State Senator-elect from New York City, and Magistrate Anna M. Kross of New York today urged 250 delegates to the State Federation of Women's Clubs' golden jubilee to "get across to Governor Dewey" their demands for a State plan of delinquency prevention.

Still rankled by what they regard as an unpardonably bad decision that cost them so heavily at Philadelphia last Sunday. Steve Owen's Giants launched preparations yesterday at the Polo Grounds for the next order of business, which happens to be Sunday's clash with the Green Bay Packers under Coogan's Bluff.

LONDON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Norwegian troops, swarming ashore somewhere in the far north, joined the Russians as the Germans prepared defense lines in the south against a possible Allied invasion from the west linked with an all-out Soviet drive.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 14 -- James Craig has been named by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the male lead in "Twice Blessed," a comedy to be based on a story by Mort Braus and Michel Kraike, in which the Wilde twins, Lee and Lynn, are to be featured.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Many innovations of chemical origin in textiles, automotive fuel, home construction and furnishings and other consumer products will emerge after war security measures are lifted, Walter J. Murphy of the American Chemical Society told the Investment Analysts Club of Chicago today.

The board of directors of Union Theological Seminary voted yesterday at its annual meeting to raise a $500,000 endowment fund honoring the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, who will retire in June, 1945, after forty-one years of service, it was revealed by Thatcher M. Brown, president of the board.

Dr. Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra returned to Carnegie Hall last night for their first New York concert of the season, and made the occasion memorable by the constitution of the program and their playing of it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, CIO, made public today a proposed program for re-employment of veterans which will be the subject of negotiations soon with General Motors Corporation.

Describing efforts of the Office of Price Administration to go back to the 1942 price level as "not only economically unsound but a political blunder," Walter Morrow, acting president of the American Retail Federation, said yesterday that if the OPA persists in its policy "this vital matter will be taken before Congress."
ROME, Nov. 15 (AP) -- A communique:

In your editorial "Argentina's Position" you state that "some Americans in Argentina believe the Government (of Argentina) -- or at least some of its Ministers -- is sincere in its attempt to live up to the hemisphere commitments and re-establish good relations with the United States and the other nations that have been critical of its policy and skeptical of its intentions."

Fifty years ago a group of women met in the Fifth Avenue home of Mrs. Eleanor Butler Sanders. Doubtless they wore the high-necked, long-sleeved, trailing dresses of the day. But if their clothes were in the fashion of the day, their ideas were not. They wanted to vote.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- The British Government, in the person of its Foreign Secretary, Anthony Eden, and its Minister of Aircraft Production, Sir Stafford Cripps, denied today that a great power dictation was envisaged by the close association of the United States, Russia, Britain and France in the peace plans.

Sam Elkin, 44 years old, of 80 Clarkson Avenue, Brooklyn, died in Beekman Hospital yesterday soon after 10:30 A.M., at about the time he was to have been sentenced in Federal court for mail fraud. Dr. Benjamin Morgan Vance, chief assistant medical examiner, said it was his belief that Elkin had taken poison, and that this would be checked by Dr. Alexander O. Gettler, city toxicologist.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The post-war years will call for a shift in agricultural emphasis from production to marketing problems, the New York State Farm Bureau Federation was told today by Fred B. Morris of Ithaca, State county agent leader.

Aluminum, magnesium and plastics will have an important part in post-war construction of all types, Harry D. Watts, chairman of the board of James Stewart Co., international engineers and contractors, said yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Adelard Lamoureux's Momo Flag, withstanding a stretch challenge from Miss Ruth McClanaghan's Harford, won the grueling two-mile-and-seventy-yard Exterminator Handicap today by a nose before a Pimlico crowd of 11,760 persons.

Twenty-two years have elapsed since the late Jeanne Eagels first electrified Broadway with her performance in "Rain," the John Colton-Clemence Randolph play taken from Somerset Maugham's South Sea story, "Miss Thompson." Since then several prominent actresses have given their interpretations of the famous character.

TORONTO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Red Wings scored their second straight victory over the Maple Leafs in the national hockey league tonight, winning, 8 -- 4, before 12,347 fans in a game featured by a three-goal outburst by the Red Wings in 28 seconds of the third period.
