ALBANY, Nov. 15 -- Supreme Court Justice Gilbert V. Schenck, alleged to have discussed pending court matters over the telephone with Daniel P. O'Connell, Albany Democratic boss, was subpoenaed today to appear before the extraordinary grand jury investigating alleged crime in Albany County.

Puccini's opera "Tosca" received its first performance of the season at the City Center last night and though the production has many commendable traits, this year's version is not quite as effective as last year's. The performance as a whole has lost some of the pace, excitement and enthusiasm which characterized last year's, and the orchestra, while it played all the notes, seemed to have lost some of its original sheen and brilliance.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Mayor La Guardia was the man to startle the International Civil Aviation Conference today with another measure of the size to which the United States expects civil aviation to grow. He told Adolf A. Berle Jr.'s press conference that Idlewild Airport would eventually accommodate 300 flights an hour.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- Again one of baseball's major wartime questions has come up and the answer is still "no" -- major league baseball teams will not do their 1945 spring training in the South. Director J. Monroe Johnson of the Office of Defense Transportation and the commissioner of baseball's office were in accord today that there be no change.

The scarcity of poultry in local markets and the attendant price racketeering reached the point yesterday where the War Food Administration and the city Department of Markets said that ceiling prices on live poultry shipments no longer represented "actual values."

The board of directors of American Airlines, Inc., declared yesterday a cash dividend on the common stock of $2 a share on the present $10 par common stock, or $1 a share on the $5 par stock that will be outstanding if the stockholders approve at a special meeting to be held Dec. 6, a proposed two-for-one split-up of shares.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- One look at the array of mighty men in football togs, cavorting on the spacious field hard by the Bear Mountain Inn today, left the observer with the feeling that nothing but trouble impends for Steve Owen and his Giants at the Polo Grounds Sunday.

"V-1," a new short subject about the robot bombs, produced by the British Ministry of Information, will be released today to theatres by the film industry's War Activities Committee. The picture is being distributed through RKO. The film, which runs nine minutes, is the first photographic report on the bomb since censorship was lifted.

Magistrate Charles E. Ramsgate, sending eleven black market food dealers to jail yesterday, excoriated violators of Office of Price Administration price ceilings who paid fines out of "a roll of bills that would choke a horse" and walked out of court "probably to continue their chiseling of the suffering public."

Shoes from leading manufacturers, all developed in kid, were shown yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton in a presentation by the Kid Group of the Tanners Council of America, Inc. It was called "Things to Come," as most of the shoes will not be on sale until shoe restrictions have been lifted.

Eleven years ago today the Government of the United States extended formal recognition to the Government of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. By proclamation of Lieutenant Governor Hanley the anniversary of this event is observed in New York today as "American-Russian Friendship Day."

Charging the Board of Education with evading responsibility, the New York Teachers Guild called yesterday for the formation of a citizens' committee to investigate conditions within the school system that have caused an unprecedented number of retirements and resignations in the last two years.

ROME, Nov. 15 -- Archduke Otto of Habsburg is due in Rome around the end of this week, it was learned today, and an audience already has been arranged with the Pope. It is also understood that he will see Crown Prince Humbert.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES in Lorraine, Nov. 14 (Delayed) -- American combat engineers completed a link tonight between their divisions of armor and artillery and elements of their infantry that in four and a half days of fighting on the other side of the Moselle River had captured nearly 1,000 prisoners and driven the enemy four miles back from the river bank.

Edwin F. Jaeckle resigned yesterday as Republican State chairman without giving any advance notice of his intentions to Governor Dewey or two other top-ranking Republicans in New York, such as J. Russell Sprague, the national committeeman, or Herbert Brownell Jr., the national chairman.
CHEYENNE, Wyo., Nov. 15 (AP) -- The parents of 3-year-old Forest (Nubbins) Hoffman hope Sunday will be one of his "good days" so he can enjoy "Christmas."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- Katharine F. Lenroot, chief of the Federal Children's Bureau, and Lee C. Dowling, deputy Commissioner of the State Department of Social Welfare, attacked today "domestic isolationists" who could see only those problems affecting their own neighborhoods or agencies.

Tribute to the work of Bundles for America, a relief agency serving members of the armed forces and their families, was paid last night by Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker and Lieut. Gen. George Grunert, commanding general of the Eastern Defense Command, at a dinner at Sherry's, 300 Park Avenue.

C.J. Devine Co. will offer today $6,994,000 of bonds and corporate stock of New York City, maturing from 1946 to 1952, as 3 1/2s, 4s and 4 1/4s. Yields will range from 0.45 per cent for the 1946 maturities to 1.35 to 1.45 per cent for the obligations due in 1952.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- In view of the unrest in Spain -- and, possibly, because of the recent activity of French monarchists -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle has sent policing forces into the tiny republic of Andorra, which lies between France and Spain in the eastern Pyrenees.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 15 (AP) -- The Bureau of Census reported today that consumption of cotton during October was 795,379 bales of lint and 125,722 bales of linters. This compares with 793,096 bales of lint and 121,430 of linters in September, and 846,993 of lint and 117,299 of linters in October of last year.

POUILLY, France, Nov. 15 -- The troops of the American Third Army could see the towers and cathedral spires in Metz today as they approached Magny, one and three-quarter miles due south of the fortress city. At this point they met stiff resistance ahead and on both flanks, but there were no indications that the drive would be stopped.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle will go to Moscow very soon for his first meeting with Premier Stalin, it was announced today after a Cabinet meeting. Georges Bidault, Foreign Minister, will accompany him. A personal message has come from President Roosevelt thanking General de Gaulle for his invitation to visit Paris, which, the President said, he was happy to receive.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 15 -Yielding to pressure from the War Labor Board in Washington, striking supervisory employes of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation voted at a mass meeting late tonight to return to their jobs tomorrow morning. The first shift will report at 7:15 A.M.

A nation-wide underwriting group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will offer today to the public $48,000,000 of the Central New York Power Corporation's 3 per cent general mortgage bonds, due in 1974. The bonds are to be priced at 103 and accrued interest.

A truce among educators was urged by Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, speaking at the fiftieth anniversary convocation of Teachers College, Columbia University, held yesterday afternoon in the Horace Mann Auditorium of the college.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- A ban on the use of corn for distilling purposes, which has been in effect since June, 1942, was partly lifted today by the War Production Board and the War Food Administration in order to provide a market for grain that is in danger of spoiling.

ALAMEDA, Calif., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Swashbuckling Navy Air Group 31, whose pilots in nine months blasted 148 Japanese planes from the sky and sent 48,000 tons of enemy shipping to the bottom, has returned to the United States on leave, fresh from the Philippines Sea battle.

Passage of the Lanham Trade-Mark Registration Bill in its present form is urged by the Association of National Advertisers in a statement filed with the Senate Patents Committee, Eric Haase, legislative representative of the association, revealed yesterday before the thirty-fifth annual meeting at the Biltmore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The people of Albania, where several resistance groups are fighting for freedom of the country, were urged today by Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Acting Secretary of State, to be guided by a spirit of cooperation in working out their problems.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -Time was rapidly running out tonight on the possibility of the Army-Navy football game being shifted from Annapolis to a big city stadium.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Ohio State University has reopened the fight to have the Western Conference permit its members to play in the Rose Bowl football game, but an unofficial poll of Big Ten schools was not encouraging to supporters of the plan.

The Cities Service Power and Light Company, main utility unit in the Cities Service Company system, has repaid more than one-third of its $20,000,000 bank loan incurred last March to facilitate its simplification and integration under the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.
LONDON, Nov. 15 -- The "almost magical" effect on British war production of the rationing of civilian goods was described today by Oliver Lyttelton, Minister of Production.

Senator Vandenberg has properly called attention to certain conflicts in the present Social Security Law. On the one hand, the law provides that the Social Security reserve shall be sufficient when it is three times the highest contemplated annual expenditures for the next five years. On the other hand, an automatic increase from 1 to 2 per cent is provided for 1945.

The Museum of Modern Art has opened a small, permanent gallery on the first floor for special displays of new and timely developments in architecture and industrial design and past achievements that illustrate basic principles. The first exhibition opened yesterday, "Building With Wood".

ALBANY, Nov. 15 -- Hiram C. Todd, special prosecutor in the grand jury investigation of legislative spending, declared in court today that testimony before the grand jury had disclosed that the late William Minsky, burlesque producer, on his deathbed turned over to Assemblyman Irwin Steingut's attorney "a large package of money containing about $75,000."

RYE, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- In the first definite step to be taken at the International Business Conference the section on raw materials and foodstuffs adopted today a report calling for establishment of "a single international bureau of standards as a department of a general international organization" which would act as a clearing house on all types of business information.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and reported by The Associated Press:

A U.S. FORTRESS BASE IN BRITAIN, Nov. 15 -- Three enlisted gunners, who stuck with a doomed Flying Fortress in an attempt to rescue a fourth, died with him when the bomber crashed and exploded recently behind the Allied lines in France.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Gov. Forrest Donnell today gained an insurmountable lead over Roy McKittrick, State Attorney General, for the Senate seat now held by Bennett Champ Clark, and Mr. McKittrick said in a statement that it appeared he had lost by 500 to 800 votes but that he believed there had been some irregularities in counting absentee votes.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- An indirect assurance that the British Government was not being hoodwinked by Generalissimo Francisco Franco's "belated lip-service to democracy" was given in the House of Commons today by Richard Law, Minister of State, who also rejected General Franco's request for a voice in the peace settlement.

Charged with causing the death of Francis Gallucci, 2 1/2 years old, the son of his common-law wife, Betty, by beating him on the head, face and body with his clenched fist, Leo Yurkowski, 27, a deserter from the Navy, was held without bail yesterday afternoon by Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney in Felony Court at Stapleton, S.L., on a charge of homicide.

Piano playing far above the average in musical insight, imagination and sensitive tinting was heard from Max Kotlarsky at his recital last night in Town Hall. The program he presented contained as its principal offerings the Bach-d'Albert "Passacaglia," and the Schumann "Phantasie."

An advertising agency is preparing a campaign for a client and is planning to use a series of drawings by artist-war correspondents, but has decided not to use any drawings of the war in Europe because they say "It is over in Europe."

Christmas cards of American design, which once trailed behind the European variety in popular esteem, are now the best in the world, one stationery expert said yesterday. The notable improvement and variety in this year's designs may account for the unusually heavy sales that began right after Labor Day and, according to store reports, show signs of reaching a 40 per cent increase over last year.

A fifteen-point Federal tax plan which includes the immediate repeal of declared-value excess profits and capital stock levies, substantial reduction in existing graduated surtax rates on individual incomes at the cessation of hostilities and establishment of a permanent program was released yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- Reported plans of the War Department to convert Fort Slocum here into a prisoner-of-war camp caused consternation today in residential areas near the fort. Demanding cancellation of the plans, Mayor Stanley W. Church contended in a telegram to Under-Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson that the safety of homes here was at stake.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Consideration of the St. Lawrence Seaway proposal must await determination whether it requires a treaty between the United States and Canada.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Everybody in the Army Air Forces from the GI Joes on up through the men with decorated shoulders will have a chance to exercise their grievances or to make suggestions at a "personal conference hour" soon to be established at every post, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- A revived proposal to permit ratification of treaties by a majority vote of House and Senate ran into opposition today in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

Reflecting a heavy volume of orders, numerous spring lines of women's popular-price two-piece suits have now been withdrawn, it was reported here yesterday. Both the piece goods and linings situations continue very tight and there are no indications of any easing later in the season.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- There is no cigarette shortage here.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Marvin Jones, War Food Administrator, called for a 1945 food-production program today which would assure a supply about equal to this year's total.

New York is not unaware of the needs of her own service men and women and of the strangers in uniform within her gates for rest and relaxation, nor of the obligation to build anew where the shock of war brought want and misery in its wake. But for some unfathomable reason the money-raising effort of the New York War Fund finds itself $5,000,000 short of its goal.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- County Judge Frederick G. Schmidt of Westchester declared invalid today a Yonkers city ordinance adopted to stiffen the punishment fixed by the State War Emergency Act for persons violating price ceilings of the Office of Price Administration.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- A significant new step in the Nazification of the back-to-the-wall German Army -- with the apparent intent of making it a "never-surrender" force to fight on as guerrillas after defeat -- was announced today by Berlin.

The results of the national election were hailed last night by Sumner Welles, former Under-Secretary of State, as a victory by the "overwhelming mass of the people of the United States." Republicans as well as Democrats, over "the tenets of isolationism."

On Nov. 3 there appeared in your paper a plea from the Army for nurse's aides holding Red Cross certificates and having credit for 150 hours of hospital work. To such persons was offered a salary of $149.50 a month and civil service rating.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 15 (AP) -- A United States Army Air Forces in China communique:

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The rate of death from combat wounds in this war has been reduced to little more than half what it was in World War I, Maj. Gen. Albert W. Kenner, chief medical officer on General Eisenhower's staff, said today.
PARIS, Nov. 15 -- The French Cabinet today ordered the confiscation of all properties belonging to the Renault automobile corporation, thereby raising important points of law.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Further progress was made today in reconciling the differences between the American, British and Canadian points of view at the international civil aviation conference on the powers to be granted to an international air organization.

More than four fateful years have passed since Hitler invaded Norway. Now Norway rejoins the battleline, to prove that another conquered nation can rise to fight again. Her tiny token army, sheltered under the shield of Russia, is only 500 strong. But it is evidence of greater strength to come.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 15 (AP) -- A supplementary communique:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 -- The Federal Water and Gas Corporation, New York, and its subsidiary, the Ohio Water Service Company, Struthers, Ohio, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application asking approval of a plan for Federal Water and Gas to sell to an underwriting group all of its stock interest in Ohio Water Service, amounting to 66.53 per cent of the outstanding capital stock.

The dispatch of your correspondent Milton Bracket, published Nov. 13, in which he reveals the inability or unwillingness, or both, of our soldiers to learn the elements of the Italian language is interesting because it proves once again the mistake our American educators have made in discouraging high school and college students from studying modern foreign languages while at school.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Portugal, as well as Eire, has made a reply that is not entirely satisfactory to the State Department, to the request of the United States for assurances that Axis war criminals would not be permitted to find refuge in that country, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Acting Secretary of State, said at his press conference today.

When a buyers' market succeeds the present sellers' market in exports to Latin America, United States shippers do not wish Government guarantees on credit and exchange, it was brought out yesterday at the twenty-fifth anniversary conference on international credit and finance of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
PARIS, Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- What became of all those American cigarettes?

The new Liberty party, which on Nov. 7 polled more than 300,000 votes in New York City for President Roosevelt, decided last night through its administrative committee to take an active part in next year's municipal elections but did not commit itself on candidates.
T. Webster Matchett of Robins Conveyors, Inc., Passaic, N.J., has been appointed secretary; John T. Hoyt, treasurer, and Harold E. Murken, controller and assistant secretary.

New life insurance written last month was 3.3 per cent more than in October a year ago, while the total for the first ten months this year was 6.2 per cent correspondingly above 1943, according to the Association of Life Insurance Presidents in a report yesterday to the United States Department of Commerce.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Arguments favoring adoption of a program of compulsory military training "must be scrutinized carefully," Miss Lenroot today told the nearly 2,000 persons attending the New York State Conference on Social Work. She added:

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- A Fourteenth Air Force communique said a flight of P-51's and P-40's penetrated Japanese positions and supply lines in the Changsha, Hengyang and Lungling areas Nov. 11 and 12 and attacked river shipping, railroads and enemy aircraft.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The War Food Administration announced today that it would offer a subsidy of 4 cents a pound, gross weight, on export sales of American cotton until further notice.

THEY met for the first time in a hotel elevator at the Packers' training camp in Rhinelander, Wis. Significantly, the elevator was going up. And the two of them were to make a mutual ascent in the records of the National Football League for the next few seasons. One was Arnie Herber, Green Bay's veteran forward passer, and the other was Don Hutson, Green Bay's sensational rookie end.
Twelve tobacco wholesalers scrambled yesterday to buy nearly 10,000 packages of popular-brand cigarettes, knowing they would lose money on the deal.

The necessity for dramatization when advertising electrical appliances if salesmen are to obtain the maximum benefit from such advertising was stressed yesterday by two speakers at the annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 15 -- The Germans launched a series of desperate but futile counter-attacks against the United States Third Army front from Koenigsmacher to the Forest of Chateau Salins today in an effort to check the methodical advance of Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's armor across the dreary Lorraine plain and delay the forging of an iron ring around the fortress of Metz.

In an all-day series of raids in Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens police and Federal agents rounded up yesterday twenty-eight men, including the head of a former international gang of automobile thieves, a man with a police record of seven arrests since 1930 and twenty-six gasoline station operators, to smash what the Office of Price Administration described last night as the biggest gasoline black market combination uncovered in the Middle Atlantic States.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 15 -- President Edelmiro J. Farrell's decision, announced last night, to appoint a committee charged with the drafting of a "statute of political parties" which would allow political parties to be reconstituted, although laying certain restrictions upon them, has, on the whole, produced a favorable impression in Argentine political circles.

Six thousand Hunter College students became sponsors of five LSM (landing ships medium) yesterday at a ceremony in its assembly hall. Lieut. Comdr. Thomas W. Walsh of the Navy said the college was chosen for the honor because of the patriotic achievements of its students, including sale of $1,500,000 of War Bonds since Pearl Harbor.
One hundred and thirty-nine more persons found out yesterday that the city means it when it says that smoking by customers in department stores must stop.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The National Football League seems likely this year to explode that old theory of offensive perfection, the balanced attack, so that an effective defense would be difficult to develop.

MOSCOW, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Col. Ivan Tolchenoff, veteran Soviet army officer and military authority, declared today that Japan had "risked fighting two great powers, the United States and Britain, as a consequence of her long-time policy of expansion," and said that the war in the Pacific was developing unfavorably for Tokyo.

ROME, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The British Eighth Army, advancing from small bridgeheads established across the Montone River west of Forli, drove forward to a general line two miles north of a loop of the river and made good progress elsewhere along the eastern sector of the Italian front, the Allies' Command announced today.

On a recent search for Thanksgiving foods, the only shop we found offering a prepared cranberry sauce was the Maison Glass, 15 East Forty-seventh Street. The brand is Tebbetts, made by the Sandune Products Company, and a fourteen-ounce jar costs 60 cents.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 15 -- A seven-star mother, two of them gold stars, was the sponsor today of "LSM 283" (a landing ship, medium) at its launching at the Port Newark yards of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.

Lewis W. Douglas, president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, has announced a nation-wide mortgage-lending program to increase and diversify the company's mortgage holdings. The loans are to be on FHA-insured mortgages on medium-priced owner-occupied dwellings, conventional loans in the residential field and on commercial properties of moderate size, and special loans in other categories meeting the company's standards.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- President Roosevelt met today with legislative leaders for the first time since his re-election and discussed with them their agenda for the remainder of the Seventy-eighth Congress. He offered no suggestions for action on measures other than those on their lists, they reported later.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Rumors that Red Cross blood plasma is being sold to members of the armed forces were denied emphatically today by Basil O'Connor, chairman of the Red Cross, in a statement which declared that possession and control of the plasma passed to the Army and Navy when it was shipped from Red Cross centers to processing laboratories, and that the services administered it to wounded personnel without charge.

The selling which has marked recent sessions of the stock market was halted yesterday when prices reached a level at which resistance to further declines was encountered. Generally, prices firmed moderately with quotations mixed at the close and the best recovery in the aircrafts.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Reflecting the recent intensification of the Royal Navy's campaign against the Japanese, the Admiralty announced tonight the sinking of twenty-three more supply ships and an anti-submarine vessel by British submarines in Far Eastern waters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- When the formally declared wars end, as eventually they must, and peace makes domestic political issues dominant again, the party line between Democrats and Republicans may once more become visible and divide voting groups as effectually as it did for many years.

The strike of 1,800 supervisors at the Wright Aeronautical Corporation's five New Jersey plants, which has kept over 32,000 other employes from work and completely halted since Monday the production of engines for the B-29 Superfortresses that are so desperately needed in waging the war against Japan, is exactly the kind of labor difficulty that the men in the armed services just cannot understand.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 15 (AP) -- After losing 15 points to Willie Hoppe of New York, three-cushion billiard champion, in the afternoon session of their 1,500-point challenge match, Welker Cochran, three-time former titleholder from San Francisco, defeated the champion tonight, 62 to 50, in 56 innings. Hoppe leads in the match, 700 to 677.

Autumn doffed its hat to spring yesterday afternoon at the St. Regis Roof Garden, where a glamorous collection of hats was presented by the Millinery Creators Guild, composed of eight members. The milliners united in a "salute to the liberated nations," launching eight new colors, each named for one of the thus distinguished countries.

SAYBROOK, Conn., Nov. 15 -An excellent open all-age stake for cocker spaniels featured the start today of the oldest spaniel trials in America, the twenty-first English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association meeting, at Ingham Hill Game Farm.

LONDON, Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- Planes of the escort carrier Pursuer, operating with a striking force of British warships off Norway, sank one and probably two enemy armed trawlers in the Trondheim harbor yesterday, the Admiralty announced today.

OKLAHOAMA CITY, Nov. 15 -- Development of uniform State policies of taxation and regulations are necessary to prevent hamstringing of aviation development, authorities attending the second annual National Aviation Clinic asserted here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Workers are leaving essential war jobs in such great number that production of vital items for the fighting services is being handicapped and post-war employment, upon which President Roosevelt has set a goal of 60,000,000 jobs, is being endangered, Henry J. Kaiser, West Coast industrialist, declared today after a conference on re-employment problems with the President at the White House.

DETROIT, Nov. 15 -- Addressing more than 200 Detroit automotive and advertising executives in the Recess Club, Brig. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, vice president and general manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES, made a plea today for tolerance and understanding of the problems of the returned veterans.

WITH THE SIXTH ARMY GROUP, in France, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The French First Army of Gen. Jean de Lattre de Tassigny launched an attack today on a twenty-five-mile front covering both banks of the Doubs River, on the approaches to the Belfort Gap, and scored advances of four to five miles.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Two committee groups of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners composed of State regulatory officials completed today and released the final draft of a legislative proposal designed to preserve the existing State regulation of the insurance business.
KANDY, Ceylon, Nov. 15 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Revisions in methods for pricing women's, girls' and children's woven underwear will be forthcoming with the completion of conferences between the Office of Price Administration and representatives of the industry, the pricing agency announced today.

Public demand for books will decline from present levels just after the war but reading habits acquired the past few years will help to maintain a demand greater than that before the war, seven leaders in the book publishing field predicted last night.

Nursery schools should be part of public education, Dr. Ruth Andrus, chief of the Bureau of Child Development and Parent Education of the State Department of Education, declared last night. She spoke at a meeting of the New York City chapter of the New York State Association for Nursery Education in the Elisabeth Irwin High School.

The fate of the zoning amendments recently adopted by the City Planning Commission, imposing additional restrictions on the height and land coverage of all new buildings throughout the city, remained undecided last night after a six-hour public hearing before the Board of Estimate.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's Command announced today that in Northwestern Burma troops of the Fifth Indian Division, advancing eastward toward Kalemyo from the Tiddim area, had met East African forces who fought their way down from the north.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- The volume of business in today's stock markets again was on the small side. There was some activity in a few of the more popular industrials, but there were only minor price changes.

New York's most successful racing season ended yesterday at Belmont Park, where 27,369 persons watched Dora Dear win the $10,500 Victory Handicap for the chairman of the Jockey Club and contribute her bit toward a record-breaking war-relief total.

The Distillers Corporation-Sea-grams, Ltd., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended with July a net profit of $11,436,782 after all charges, including $17,236,413 provision for income and excess profits taxes.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 15 -Saturday, Dec. 2, a date that is uppermost in the minds of most football fans is, at the moment, just another Saturday on the calendar, so far as Lieut. Col. Earl (Red) Blaik, Army's head coach is concerned.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Ernest L. Olrich resigned from Government service today as "the ethical thing to do" in view of charges made by the Office of Price Administration against Munsingwear, Inc., of Minneapolis, of which he is president.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Attorney General Biddle announced that eighteen steel corporations and six of their officers were indicted in Trenton, N.J., today on charges that ever since 1934 they had engaged "in an unlawful conspiracy arbitrarily to fix and maintain uniform and non-competitive prices, terms and conditions for the sale of stainless steel finished products sold in the United States."

Towering high above Times Square, a reproduction of the Statue of Liberty, to serve as a focal point for noon-hour War Bond rallies throughout the Sixth War Loan, will be dedicated tomorrow noon with the lighting of its torch, a "Salute to the Navy" and an all-star show.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 15 -- Dismissal by public schools of such problems as race hatred, juvenile delinquency and growing fascist tendencies among American youth as "kid stuff" was partly responsible for undercover campaigns to discredit democracy as a form of government, Miss Marie Syrkin, New York author and educator, declared tonight.

The nation's gasoline stocks at the close of last week amounted to 78,091,000 barrels, including 12,877,000 of unfinished supplies, 39,321,000 civilian automotive and 25,893,000 aviation and blending stocks currently indeterminate as to ultimate use, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

Richard Morley, 52-year-old yard foreman for the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, died at 5 P.M. yesterday in a Bronx surface car after a fist fight with a Negro youth on the rear platform of the car. The youth escaped after being chased two blocks by other passengers.

Sgt. Andy Rooney, co-author with Sgt. Bud Hutton of "Air Gunner," recently published by Farrar Rinehart, has returned from the European theatre and been assigned to the New York office of The Stars and Stripes, Army newspaper.

Most of the feline aristocrats showed by their delicate yawns yesterday that they found the business of being exhibited rather tedious. It was the second and last day of the Brooklyn-Long Island Cat Club show, held at the Hotel Woodstock to finance a shelter and clinic for strays, and for many of the entries it was only one more in a long series of shows.
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted today in English by the Free Yugoslav Wireless and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 16 -Red Army tanks and infantry, battering down Budapest's crumbling defense system, yesterday captured the shell-torn stronghold of Jaszbereny, thirty-one miles east of the Hungarian capital, and advanced to within nine miles of Miskolc, Hungary's fifth city.

If you had trudged the Westchester woods with bow and arrow yesterday during the first day of the deer season and did not so much as see a buck or a doe, to say nothing of getting a shot, you may derive some consolation from the fact that archers in a part of Michigan, where the hunting normally would be better, have not done too well, either.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
Reversing the trend of Tuesday's session, the futures marked on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong yesterday and closed at the best levels of the day and at net gains of 9 to 16 points.
The New York Public Library has received a new gift of precious literary manuscripts from Gabriel Wells and Dr. Albert A. Berg, to be added to the already notable Berg collection.

BEHIND THE JAPANESE LINES, on Leyte, Nov. 15 -- Filipino guerrillas, the native version of Wacs and plain citizens of Leyte, have guarded several patrol torpedo boat crews -- and this correspondent -- in the heart of the Japanese-held section of Leyte for seventy-two hours.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Japanese offensive in south China, now threatening to include invasion of the hinterland province of Kweichow, confronted the Chinese tonight with the gravest military crisis in more than seven years of war.

The Board of Education at its meeting yesterday disclosed that it had made its first "wartime" appointment. This announcement was met with a round of applause. The board appointed Corp. John Rosene, for the last thirty months in Europe in the Ninth Air Force, as an attendance officer at a salary range from $1,800 to $3,000 a year.
LONDON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- An Air Ministry and Ministry of Home Security communique:
In the hearts of many people Thanksgiving this year will be pretty bleak, but they won't let the world know. With victory in sight, no one is going to put on anything but the brightest face.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 16 (U.P.) -- Donald M. Nelson and thirteen American industrial experts and advisers to China's new War Production Board arrived here today to step up production in China's war industries.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 16 -- Production of airplane engines was resumed in full force this morning in the five north New Jersey plants of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation, marking the end of the three-day general stoppage.

Sir William Beveridge, noted British economist, has just advanced a new proposal to achieve post-war "full employment'' and prosperity. A key part of his plan is the purchase of surplus supplies of essential goods by the Government in order to provide jobs. Such supplies would be resold at a later date.
Yesterday's Soviet communique, as broadcast from Moscow and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

November is a halfway month, halfway between fall and winter; halfway between the reds and golds of October and the grays of December. In the Northland the earth lies cold and shivering, waiting for the snow to blanket its bareness. Not that November is a dreary month.

MEMPHIS, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Asserting that "we can't reap profits from the use of taxpayers' money or Government power without the penalty of the loss of freedom," W. Randolph Burgess of New York, president of the American Bankers Association, today urged farmers and bankers to "do a lot of thinking about the long-term consequences before we request or acquiesce in Government interference."
PARIS, Nov. 16 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle's visit to Moscow is expected to be the first step toward a French alliance with Russia, it was said in informed circles tonight.

Leo J. Walsh has been appointed manager for General Mills vitamin product sales, with Frank Dowe Jr., named sales manager of vitamin products of Distillation Products, Inc., owned jointly by General Mills, Inc., and Eastman Kodak Company.

HEUSDEN, The Netherlands, Nov. 16 (AP) -- How the Germans deliberately blasted to death 135 women and children they had lured into the basement of the Town Hall "for safety" was described today by the Burgomaster of this medieval town of 2,000 people.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Soviet Union desires peaceful relations with all nations regardless of their political systems and has no desire to intervene in their internal affairs, a spokesman says in an official publication.

With all heavy work preparatory to the Brooklyn College game on Ohio Field tomorrow completed and the soggy gridiron discouraging outdoor work, the New York University football team moved indoors yesterday for review of each player's assignments.

Financial aid for States, cities and other political subdivisions in a public works construction program throughout the nation was assured yesterday by Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Federal Works Administrator, in his first public address since his return from a study of post-war planning programs in England, France and Russia.

Sales of the International Paper Company and its subsidiaries for the nine months ended with September increased to $173,995,224 from $158,780,385 in the corresponding period a year ago, Richard J. Cullen, chairman, reported to stockholders yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

After several weeks of virtual stalemate, as the customary fall rains of northwestern Europe made a sticky mess of the roads and fields of France, Germany and the Low Countries, the Western Front flamed into action under clear skies yesterday along its whole 450-mile length.

A concept of the shattering devastation wrought in England by the German "buzz bombs" and a high tribute to the people who have endured them are contained in the one-reel film "V-1," a short made by the British Ministry of Information, which was released in theatres here yesterday.

RYE, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- A battle on parliamentary procedure, in which the American delegation to the international business conference was overruled, brought to light today the conflict between the approaches of British and American business men to postwar international trade problems.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- President Roosevelt nominated Paul A. Porter, director of publicity for the Democratic National Committee, today, a member of the Federal Communications Commission. He is expected to succeed James Lawrence Fly as chairman.

ALBANY, Nov. 16 -- Supreme Court Justice Gilbert V. Schenck testified for two hours today before the extraordinary grand jury investigating alleged crime in Albany County soon after Supreme Court Justice Parton Swift ordered the trial of John J. Murphy, treasurer of the Albany County Democratic Committee, transferred to New York County.

AN ADVANCED OBSERVATION POST INSIDE GERMANY, 6 P.M., Nov. 16 -- Man and the works of man disintegrated before my eyes today as the United States First Army unleashed its attack within the borders of Germany. It was the most terrifying and destructive cataract of exploding, splintering steel warfare that Germany had ever seen.
I've often heard that honesty is not merely its own best reward but a good policy -- let alone being on the highest plane, a true principle of ethics. Now feel it is so.

CRITICISM of contemporary literature is often more apt to resemble a trip to the Donnybrook fair with a shillelagh in one hand and a knobkerry in the other than the practice of an art. Although critics have been trying to agree on some sort of standards since the days of Aristotle no noticeable progress has as yet been made.

LONDON, Friday, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Russian tanks and shock troops cracked the main German defense line ten miles east of Budapest yesterday in a bitterly contested three-mile advance, and far to the northeast struck to within five miles of Miskolc, Hungary's fifth city now exposed to Red Army artillery, fire.

The market for Port of New York Authority and Triborough Bridge Authority bonds proved again yesterday that it is just about immune to the time-worn agitation on the part of the Government to tax the income from those obligations.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 16 -- Five enemy warships were sunk last Sunday when carrier aircraft of the Pacific Fleet attacked Manila and Cavite harbor areas to blast shipping and port facilities, revised reports showed today, increasing warship sinkings by three.

ALBANY, Nov. 16 -- Hiram C. Todd, special prosecutor in the extraordinary grand jury investigation of legislative spending, said today that the Democratic minority leaders of the Legislature, Senator John J. Dunnigan of the Bronx and Assemblyman Irwin Steingut of Brooklyn, would be invited to appear before the grand jury in "the near future."

Two five-story and penthouse apartment buildings on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 13-15 East Sixtieth Street have been sold by the Gerdelle Real Estate Corporation, M.E. Hill, president, to an investor. They are assessed at $169,000 and were sold through Walter Samuels and Berley Co.

If the authorities carry out their threat to bring criminal prosecutions against all dealers in black market gasoline they will go far to break up the racket. That was the promise made after Wednesday's raids in widely scattered sections of the city, bringing about the arrest of twenty-eight persons as thieves and distributors alike.
LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Business generally again was quiet in most sections of today's stock markets.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 16 -- A small force of Americans has seized the Mapia Islands, enemy lookout post off the northwest New Guinea coast. The new invasion, a protective operation to remove Japanese spotters, was about 919 miles southeast of Leyte.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- American Catholics would "ever resent" their countries being made a party to the de-Christianization of Poland, the Baltic States and neighboring Catholic lands, the Catholic Archbishops and Bishops of the United States said in a resolution adopted today at their general annual meeting at the Catholic University of America.

The Acker, Merrall Condit Company plans to return to the general food business and has leased a store at 2357 Broadway, at Eighty-sixth Street, which is to be the first of a new group of food shops in Manhattan. It will specialize in foods, steamer baskets and epicurean items.

MOSCOW, Nov. 16 -- The Polish Committee of National Liberation, which has been established as the civil authority in the approximately 60,000 square kilometers of Poland already liberated, reported today that agrarian reforms now were being carried out after initial failure and that 365 estates had been broken up into twelve-and-a-half-acre plots for landless peasants.

SAYBROOK, Conn., Nov. 16 -- The twenty-first meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association ended today with the open all-age stake for springers, splendid work marking the third series called by the judges, David Wagstaff and Henry L. Ferguson.

KANDY, Ceylon, Nov. 16 (AP) -- British East Africans, advancing six miles in a day down the Kabaw Valley of Burma, captured Kalemyo and joined Indian troops who fought over the Chin Hills from Tiddim, Allied headquarters announced today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- President Roosevelt denounced as "an unqualified falsehood" today rumors that blood plasma, given to the Red Cross by volunteer donors, was being sold to injured fighting men.

The present day "calls for men who can take a moral ideal and translate it into practical proposals," declared Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the New York Methodist Area at a ministers' luncheon yesterday afternoon under auspices of the American Bible Society, starting a drive for $2,932,000 for its needs the next four years.

The city's post-war construction program was criticized by the Citizens Budget Commission yesterday as "a grandiose scheme which, if carried through, will run the city into a financial blind alley," entailing higher real estate taxes and heavy debt charges.

Leading educators concerned with planning post-war instruction for 15,000,000 service men and women will discuss the situation in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, at 8:30 o'clock tonight. The meeting is sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES in cooperation with the New York Adult Education Council.

A resolution urging the Department of Justice to withdraw the civil suit filed in Lincoln, Neb., against major railroad interests accused of violations of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act, was adopted yesterday by members of the National Industrial Traffic League.

New York architects and real estate boards of the metropolitan district are indignant and are preparing a formal concerted protest to Mayor La Guardia against a new city policy, which they say excludes from virtually all further municipal work the realty men and architects who have testified for property owners in condemnation actions or tax certiorari proceedings against the city, it became known last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 11 totaled 839,489 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today This was 53,844 cars or 6 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 8,483 cars or 1 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 12.794 cars, or 1.5 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

LONDON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- For the seventh consecutive week note circulation established a new high to the total of 1,177,311,000 an increase of 2,429,000 over the previous week, the Bank of England reported in its statement for the week ended Nov. 15.

The latest novelty in the season of Ballet International at the International Theatre was revealed last night in the shape of "Prince Goudal's Festival," choreographed by Boris Romanoff to music from Rubinstein's "The Demon," with scenery and costumes by Mstislav Dobujinsky.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization and Reconversion, served notice tonight that unless manpower shortages were remedied in critical war producing areas within "a reasonable time," he would order the suspension of authorizations for new civilian production.

ROME, Nov. 16 -- An extraordinary session of Ministers Without Portfolio was held for three hours this afternoon to seek a solution for the latent political crisis. Although no decision was made today grounds were laid for a reshuffle of the Cabinet under Ivanoe Bonomi.

An analysis of the laws and decrees promulgated by the Nazis and their puppet governments in the conquered areas of Europe has been made by Dr. Raphael Lemkin, a Polish lawyer now in this country, in a book called "Axis Rule in Occupied Europe."

Directors of the International Harvester Company increased the 1944 payments on the common stock to $2.85 a share from $2.50 distributed last year, with the declaration yesterday of a year-end dividend of 55 cents, payable Dec. 15.

Two new films will arrive in! midtown theatres this morning. At i the Palace the attraction will be 'one lat the Lonely Heart," an RKO adaptation of the Richard LleweUyn novel starring Cary Grant and Ethel Barrymore, who returns to the screen after an absence of twelve years.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 16 (AP) -- A communique of the United States Army Air Forces in China:

Denying the charges of "distortion" and "misrepresentation" leveled at the Board of Education by the New York Teachers Guild, Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, asserted yesterday that the figures for class size contained in the "Children's Budget," attacked by the guild as false, are entirely accurate.

Three United States Senators participated last night in a symposium in Town Hall on the question of "Should the American representative in a World Organization have the power to commit us to use force?" Answering in the affirmative were Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican, of Minnesota, and Senator Claude Pepper, Democrat, of Florida. Opposed was Senator Chapman Revercomb, Republican, of West Virginia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Greater chances for babies to survive the first year of life and greater life expectancies for the people of this country, especially women, were reported today by the Census Bureau, which has just completed vital statistics comparisons for the last census.

An easier tone developed yesterday in the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange and prices lost 4 to 11 points net. After opening 2 to 4 points lower, the market held steady for a time, but met December liquidation, and a few hedge selling orders in the afternoon.

The coming three-power conference between President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin will -- like Teheran -- be of great importance to the military and political development of the war and to the making of the peace.

SPORTS terminology contains many odd expressions but none is more strange than hockey's famous "hat trick." Most fans are aware of what it represents -- the scoring of three goals by one individual in a single game. Few of them, however, are aware of how it crept into the hockey language, and it took some research work by the Amateur Hockey Association to produce one seemingly sound explanation of the origin of the term.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Whether the Political Action Committee, CIO, will be continued or abandoned by the CIO is expected to be determined tomorrow after Sidney Hillman, chairman of CIO-PAC, makes the committee's report to the National CIO Executive Board.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Cash corn advanced 5 to 10 cents a bushel today on the Board of Trade following announcement late yesterday the movement of corn to this market would be regulated by the permit system. Traders regarded this as indicating smaller receipts in the immediate future and elevator interests showed more desire to purchase futures.

WITH THE UNITED STATES NINTH ARMY in Germany, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Tired of long weeks of stationary warfare, begrimed American soldiers in frozen foxholes and mud-caked tanks carried out their promise to make the United States Ninth Army's initial attack against Hitler's Westwall a success today by breaking through the German crust of defenses to take many initial objectives after the assault started.

WITH BRITISH SECOND ARMY at Meijel, the Netherlands, Nov. 16 -- This shell-torn village with its ruined church and wrecked houses and shops was safely in British hands today as Allied forces smashed steadily ahead toward the German frontier, only a few miles away.

UNITED STATES NINTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Nov. 16 (U.P.) -- Allied headquarters today broke the secret that German intelligence has tried, apparently without success, to solve since the fall of Brest, and announced that Lieut. Gen. William H. Simpson's United States Ninth Army was in action in the German-Netherland-Belgian area.

Muzio Clementi will never be forgotten by generations of perspiring piano pupils for his "Gradus ad Parnassum." Last night, at the Philharmonic-Symphony concert conducted by Dr. Rodzinski in Carnegie Hall, the audience made the acquaintance of Clementi as the composer of a very estimable symphony.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 16 -The Government's plan to make surplus transport planes available to friendly foreign countries on a non-discriminatory basis after the war, 'qs the only policy we could honestly adopt," Lieut. Col. William Barclay Harding, Director of the Aviation Division of the Surplus War Property Administration, said here today.

Not everyone can buy rare books and manuscripts but ownership comes to all when such treasures are presented to the public. Only the very rich may purchase such literary rarities as the manuscripts of Scott's "The Siege of Malta," Barrie's "The Little Minister" and "Peter and Wendy," Shaw's first play, "Widowers' Houses," but the New York Public Library announces these new accessions and so they become the property of all.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- A survey of the shoe industry to determine the need for new price regulations will be undertaken as soon as the Bureau of the Budget has approved the project, the Office of Price Administration disclosed today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Gerald R. Trimble, manager of the Hotel Claridge and president of the Atlantic City Hotel Association, told Office of Price Administration officials today that the Atlantic City hotel industry did not want them and would not entertain them during a projected conference they planned holding here Nov. 26.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Communique 222:

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- French military quarters revealed today that the Germans had begun to evacuate the 7,000 troops who had occupied Pointe de Grave on the Giponde estuary northwest of Bordeaux. The French said the Germans were blowing up the great docks at Verdon and were moving their men across the estuary to Royan in barges.

An apparent act of bravado by a 16-year-old boy wielding a pistol in a crowded bus as it reached its Bronx terminus at 5 P.M. yesterday resulted in the death of a high school boy, also 16, who was shot in the chest. The youth with the pistol escaped but the police have his name and address.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 16 -- Diego Martinez Barrio officially announced today that he would convene the Spanish Cortes in Mexico City on Jan. 10. Senor Martinez Barrio, who was the last President of the Cortes in Spain, made this announcement after a two-hour meeting last night of the permanent committee of the Cortes, attended by twelve of its members.

A program devoted entirely to contemporary songs was presented at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall last night by Janet Fairbank, soprano, assisted by Paul Meyer at the piano. Giving a whole evening of new music is something of a daring enterprise, and that it was a pleasant and enlightening one is a tribute both to Miss Fairbank's intelligent artistry and the craftsmanship of our composers.

Raincoat manufacturers must guard against encroachments of retailers who are turning to producing their own garments, Simon Cohen, president of the New York Raincoat Manufacturers Association, declared last night at a testimonial dinner tendered him by the organization at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed note circulation for the system as a whole to have increased $88,978,000 during the week, while holdings of United States Government securities were $16,390,000 lower. The ratio of reserve again declined slightly.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 16 -- Henry Kaiser's streamlined nurseries, which created nation-wide controversy when they were opened here a year ago, this week sketched an outline of their operations which may well provide a model for child care in the post-war world. The ultra-modern plants, whose effectiveness was questioned loudly by many industrialists and child care experts, have, according to the company's report, released sufficient mothers in the past year to build four Liberty ships.

ATHENS, Nov. 16 -- Requests made by the Greek Government to political factions to refrain from further demonstrations, on the understanding that all will receive a sympathetic hearing later, have re-party slogans on Athen's walls and in greater vociferating of politica, doctrines on street corners by Communist party members or by persons taking their side.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Word went around the capital today that the Administration would support a bill like that of Representative Charles S. Dewey, Republican, of Illinois, for expansion of the Export-Import Bank so that it could help to handle the demand for foreign credits expected on the end of the war in Europe.
A couple of reports from New England of strange animals encountered in the fields brought the reminder that our "what is it?" department had been neglected for some time.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 16 -- Premier Pierlot's statement tonight was one of the strongest he has made since assuming the Premiership. He spoke as a man confident that he would be supported by those around him. After warning resistance fighters to obey the law he also warned "political groups" not to impede the war effort of the nation.

MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands, Nov. 13 (Delayed) -- The people in this part of liberated Netherlands are awaiting the return of their Queen and their Government with no great enthusiasm. To a large degree it is the same story as in France and Belgium, where members of the underground resistance feel that they are better qualified to govern than the Governments that have carried on in exile during the German occupation.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 16 -- When Japan sees and admits that her war situation is hopeless, the Tokyo war lords will attempt to offer a compromise peace, but the United States must hold to its terms of unconditional surrender, Joseph E. Grew, former Ambassador in Tokyo, declared emphatically here today.

Bobby Ruffin, Long Island City welterweight, will tackle Johnny Greco of Montreal in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The rivals boast large local followings, and their clash is expected to attract a crowd of 15,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics weekly index of commodity prices at the primary market level rose 0.1 per cent during the week ended Nov. 11 to the highest point reached since the end of June. Continued seasonal advances in prices for fruits and vegetables and for eggs accounted for the rise.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- All shipyards of the United States Maritime Commission were ordered today to refuse employment to experienced sea-going applicants for shore jobs by Vice Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the commission, in a move to counteract the critical shortage of qualified men to man vessels of the Merchant Marine.

Preparations by banks and borrowers from banks for Treasury exchange financing played a large part in changing the statistical positions of New York City banks in the week which ended on Wednesday, according to an analysis of figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Warning against high pressure salesmen who would sell "cast-iron soldiers" to communities throughout the country as war memorials was sounded last night at the Architectural League of New York, 115 East Fortieth Street, at a dinner forum on the subject, "War Memorials: Should they be purely memorial in character of designed primarily for use?"

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (U.P.) -- The only thing certain tonight about the Army-Navy football game is that there will be one come Dec. 2, but whether it will be played at Annapolis, Md. -- as originally scheduled -- or shifted to some big city stadium was the $64 question that not even the President of the United States would answer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced today the terms of an exchange offering to holders of $1,036,692,400 of 4 per cent Treasury bonds of 1944-54, which were called for redemption, and holders of the $3,539,755,000 of Series G-1944 certificates of indebtedness, which will mature on Dec. 1.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- The compromise American-British-Canadian plan for an international organization to deal with post-war commercial aviation is expected to be presented to all fifty-two nations participating in the International Civil Aviation Conference tomorrow or Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Australian troops will undertake the task of clearing islands of the Southwest Pacific of Japanese who have been by-passed in the drive to the Philippines, Sir Frederic W. Eggleston, the new Australian Minister to the United States, said at a news conference today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Half of the 1,500 non-operating employes were laid off indefinitely by the Chicago, North Shore Milwaukee and the Chicago, Aurora Elgin Electric Railroads tonight at the end of the first week of the strike of 500 operating employes.

A new proposed American standard of practice and certification procedures on consumer goods has been issued by the American Standards Association, it was announced yesterday. The standard, designed to protect the public and covering the issuance of seals or other certification of the quality or safety of goods, was proposed to the ASA by the Association of Consulting Chemists and Chemical Engineers.

The eminence of West Point and Annapolis in wartime football, it seems to be agreed by all hands, is a good thing for college football, and is the way the fighting forces all over the world like to have it.

A quick turnover of a midtown business property was made yesterday when David S. Meister, operator, resold the two six-story loft buildings on a plot 43 by 98 feet at 4 and 6 West Thirty-seventh Street after a brief ownership. Samuel Franco, linen merchant, is the new owner of the property, which is assessed at $120,000. Robert K. Demarest was the broker.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Although unconditional surrender is still the Allied policy toward Germany's political and military leadership, broadcasts from London are making it clear to those ordinary Germans who listen that capitulation holds no special terrors for them.

The box office of the Metropolitan Opera will open next Monday at 10 A.M. for the sale of tickets for the first week of the opera season, Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association announced yesterday.

Wm. Filene's Sons Company has received an offer for purchase by the City Stores Company of the R.H. White Company, Boston, according to joint announcement here yesterday. Filene's, controlled by Federated Department Stores, will recommend to preferred stockholders that the offer be accepted at a meeting scheduled for about Dec. 10, it was said.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 16 -- Ambitious plans for the industrial recovery of Belgium have been made in the past five days by a new joint committee with representatives of the American, British and Belgian Governments and Supreme Allied Headquarters.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- In pursuance of the purge of collaborators with the Germans a warrant was issued today for the arrest of Guy Bunau-Varilla, publisher of the now defunct Matin, on a charge of intelligence with the enemy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet Communique 183:

A mother unwittingly led to the arrest of her 14-year-old son yesterday who was wanted by the police for questioning in the death of Richard Morley, 52-year-old yard foreman for the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, who died Wednesday in a Bronx surface car after a fist fight with a Negro boy who escaped after being chased two blocks by other passengers.

Urging American engineers and industry to adopt international standards for screw threads, William J. Batt, Vice chairman for International Supply of the War Production Board, disclosed yesterday that differing standards in the United States and Great Britain have already added at least $100,000,000 to the cost of the war as well as "incalculable production and repair delays."
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- The subcommittees of technicians at the International Civil Aviation Conference are rapidly reaching a series of agreements on the technical control of international flying.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 16 -Van Johnson and Lucille Ball are to be starred by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in a domestic comedy, "Early to Wed," based on an original screen story by Dorothy Kingsley. The picture, to be produced by Jack Cummings, is expected to be started on the completion of Miss Ball's part in the Spencer Tracy-Katharine Hepburn film, "Without Love."

How craftsmanship can help our disabled veterans as well as serve the fashion and home furnishings industries was discussed by Mrs. Dorothy Liebes, national director of arts and skills for the American Red Cross, and Rene d'Harnoncourt, director of the Department of Manual Industry, Museum of Modern Art, during the luncheon program presented by the Home Furnishings Division of the Fashion Group at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nev. 16 -- As the war tempo increases United States war agencies in Brazil are thinning out. To date nearly 500 American employes have gone home. A high Government official declared today that the weaning program would be continued until only what personnel was absolutely necessary would remain.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- Jean Schneider, son of the late Eugene Schneider, leading French ironmaster, was killed yesterday with his wife and nine other passengers when a plane coming from Algiers crashed into a hillside near Autun during a snowstorm.

Continuing his campaign against the food black market, Magistrate Charles E. Ramsgate suggested yesterday that the courts be empowered to close shops whose owners have been repeatedly convicted of violating price ceilings.

A first mortgage of about $2,000,000 has been arranged by Ivor B. Clark, Inc., for the Knott Hotels, of which David H. Knott is chairman of the board, with the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank at 4 per cent interest and 3 per cent amortization, for fifteen years.

Alice Menaker is an invalid girl who has been confined for the last two years to bed in her home at 1265 Gerard Avenue, the Bronx. There does not seem to be much which she could do to help win the war.

New Yorkers who converted their home heating equipment from fuel oil to coal at the Government's request during the 1942-43 fuel oil crisis are showing no great enthusiasm to reconvert to oil now that the liquid fuel supply has improved.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

Dr. Alexander Loudon, the Netherlands Ambassador, told members of the Holland Society of New York last night that his people look hopefully to the United States and its industrial genius for aid in rebuilding their country. He spoke at the sixtieth anniversary dinner of the society at the Hotel Plaza, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 16 (AP) -- R. Sterling Clark's Colchis, a son of Happy Argo, scored a thrilling nose victory over Henry L. Straus' New Moon in a four-horse field that contested the eighth running of the $5,000 added Heiser Handicap at Pimlico today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Among the casualties of the election was the most recent effort in Congress to submit a constitutional amendment limiting Presidential tenure. This correspondent has asked Congressional veterans of the 1944 campaign whether they expect to seek passage of any restrictive measure such as that drawn up some months ago by Senator Bailey of North Carolina.

Excerpts from the addresses delivered by Edward R. Stettinius Jr., acting Secretary of State; Ambassador Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union, and the Earl of Halifax, the British Ambassador, at a rally of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship in Madison Square Garden, follow:

CARMEL, Calif., Nov. 16 -- While China is facing one of her gravest military crises of the war, Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, former chief of staff to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, reads about it in the newspapers at his home, high above the Pacific here at Carmel.

The Allied Supreme Command announced last night its readiness to support the Belgian Government with troops, the Brussels radio reported, after Premier Hubert Pierlot had insisted in a nation-wide broadcast, following the resignation of three Cabinet members, that resistance forces observe Government rules incorporating them into the Army.

The stock market threw off yesterday a bit more of its bearishness, and, under selective leadership, made some progress toward recovery. Recent favorites came under profit-taking, especially in the aircraft division, while previously neglected issues attracted some bidding.
THE TIMES' recent editorial "Decline in Patents" was both timely and foresighted in regard to a serious situation that may affect the future progress of our country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Dr. John R. Steelman, whose resignation as the chief of the United States Conciliation Service becomes effective soon, was quoted in The United Mine Workers Journal today as making an attack three years ago on the conduct of William H. Davis, then chairman of the National Defense Mediation Board, in his handling of the "captive" mine case.
A banking group headed by Allen Co. will offer formally to the public today an issue of $18,000,000 of 2 3/4 per cent refunding bonds, dated April 1, 1944, of the city of St. Petersburg, Fla.

Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, declared at the regular meeting of the National Industrial Conference Board at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night that the nation should work out its economic problems at home and not rely too much on the stimulus to domestic prosperity that may result from world trade.

Richard Equities, Inc., has purchased the six-story ninety-three-family apartment house at 2065 Grand Concourse, near Burnside Avenue, the Bronx, from a client of Philip Smith, attorney. The property, assessed at $310,000, was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $200,550 held by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, Leyte, Nov. 16 (AP) -- A supplement to commuique 953:

When Lou Little sends his Columbia Lions, along with their four-game losing streak, against the Brown Bruins on Baker Field tomorrow afternoon the locals will be facing another "best" opposing back, it was revealed yesterday at the weekly luncheon at the Men's Faculty Club.

LONDON, Nov. 16 (U.P.) -- Relations between Sweden and Germany have reached the crisis point, and Hans Thomsen, German Minister at Stockholm, has been recalled to Berlin to report, it was disclosed today.

ROME, Nov. 16 -- Gen. Mario Roatta, Chief of the Italian Army General Staff during the negotiations for the armistice with the Allies and a close associate of Premier Pietro Badoglio during the latter's Premiership in southern Italy, was arrested this morning by a commission for the punishment of fascist crimes.
KANDY, Ceylon, Nov. 16 (AP) -- A communique:

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command announced tonight that Japanese, driving through Kwangsi Province in a resurgent westward offensive, had advanced to within four and a half miles of the walled city of Ishan from the northeast and that Chinese units were engaging the invaders in heavy battle.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 16 -- Six Allied armies smashed eastward in Germany, France and the Netherlands today as the great offensive to break the German field armies west of the Rhine reached tremendous proportions with the launching of assaults by the American First and Ninth armies in the area between Geilenkirchen and Roetgen.

At its final victory meeting yesterday at the Ritz Carlton Hotel, the women's division of the New York War Fund turned in $82,213 in gifts, bringing its total to $1,337,335. The sum represents 133 per cent of the division's quota, Mrs. Vincent Astor, chairman, said.
A large apartment house near Prospect Park and two commercial buildings were among deals in Brooklyn reported yesterday.

Possibly Mr. Kahn's views and mine on tariff and exchange policy, outlined in these columns, are not so very far apart after all. He would fix post-war exchange rates at levels which "mirror price parities," by which I presume he means levels that would counteract excessive differences between national price levels.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- During the week ended Nov. 15 member bank reserve balances increased $398,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank announced today.

The Giants will have added help on the field during Sunday's game with the Packers -- a fellow by the unusual name of Smith. No, not Capt. John Smith nor the fellow with the large and sinewy hands who stands under the spreading chestnut tree.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Friday, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Infantrymen of the Twenty-fourth Division and dismounted First Division cavalrymen are tightening their grip on the Japanese salient at Limon, four miles south of Carigara Bay, on Leyte Island, headquarters reported today.

MOSCOW, Nov. 16 -- Editorials that in the warmest tones express gratification at the closer relations developed between the Soviet Union and the United States during the war, and point out the necessity for even closer collaboration to insure a stable peace and mutual prosperity after the war, were featured in the Soviet press today on the eleventh anniversary of the reestablishment of diplomatic relations between the two countries.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Commissioner Elmer Layden tonight ordered National Football League field judges to equip themselves with whistles and gave them equal authority with referees to stop play on all violations of the thirty-second rule.
ROME, Nov. 16 (AP) -- A communique:

An Associated Press dispatch from Washington reports that the revived proposal to permit approval of treaties by a majority vote of House and Senate has run into opposition in the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations. Two fears are expressed there. One is that prolonged debate over this question might arouse bitterness that would threaten the peace treaties themselves.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Central Legislative Assembly of India has approved unanimously measures depriving non-Indian citizens of the Union of South Africa, living in India, of certain legal privileges in reprisal for discriminatory practices against Indians in South Africa, according to word received here today by the government of India Information Services.

The Harris Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago has called a special meeting of stockholders for Dec. 13 to vote on proposals to increase the capitalization of the bank and to establish a retirement pension trust for employes.
A small offering of ranch mink for the account of the American National Fur Breeders Association was auctioned yesterday by Lampson, Fraser Huth. The top was $26.50 on sales of 100 per cent.

OSSINING, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- Mrs. Helen Fowler, Negro, of Niagara Falls, went to the electric chair at Sing Sing Prison tonight for a hold-up murder in Ransomville, Niagara County, on Oct. 30, 1943. Also put to death was her accomplice, George F. Knight, Negro.

Inadequate education, public health care and help "for those persons unable to scramble for themselves" must be corrected in this country with "remedies we already know," Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins yesterday told a Founders' Day audience which filled Town Hall on the institution's fiftieth birthday.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 16 -- Warfare raging throughout the world has intensified rather than mitigated racial prejudice and sharpened the edge of anti-Semitism, Dr. James G. Heller of Cincinnati, chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, told delegates at today's closing session of Hadassah, Women's Zionist Organization of America.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Senate confirmed James F. Byrnes as Director of War Mobilization and Reconversion today within a half hour after President Roosevelt had sent his nomination from the White House.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- Howland G. Shaw, assistant Secretary of State, told delegates today to the forty-fifth annual New York State Conference of Social Work that if they were to make headway in preventing delinquency they must get the support of areas from which delinquents come and of potential delinquents themselves.

The recent Presidential election did more fundamental damage to the traditional Democratic organizations throughout the country than it did to the Republican organizations, Raymond Moley, associate editor of Newsweek, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the National Association of Public Relations Counsel, held at the Lexington Hotel.

Declaring that no better tribute could be paid to our allies than to continue working "in ever-growing accord to establish a peace that will endure," President Roosevelt promised last night, in a message to the American-Soviet Friendship rally at Madison Square Garden, that other steps would be taken to follow up the work of the Dumbarton Oaks conference.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Japan is pouring a formidable army into south China, well trained and equipped, with the intention of fighting out the war on the Asiatic mainland rather than on her home soil, Maj. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, newly appointed commander of United States Forces in the China theatre, told The Associated Press in an interview today.

MEDITERRANEAN ALLIED AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, Rome, Nov. 16 -- Capt. John J. Voll of Goshen, Ohio, destroyed four enemy aircraft on a mission over northern Italy today and, with twenty-one planes to his credit, became the leading fighter pilot ace of the Mediterranean theatre.
