Americans are not congenitally stupid in learning foreign languages. When they are interested they learn fast enough; but they are not as often interested they might be. A rather disconsolate dispatch to this paper from Rome a few days ago spoke of a general neglect among our boys to avail themselves of facilities to learn the language of the people for whose liberation they are fighting.

The observance of International Students Day, commemorating the massacre of 156 students of Prague University in Czechoslovakia by the Nazis in 1939, was begun yesterday by students in all the United Nations. It will continue throughout the week.

Are you not unconsciously a little unfair to Henry Pu Yi, "so-called Emperor of Manchukuo," in describing him as a Quisling? Pu Yi is not a Chinese but a Manchu. He was 6 years old when his guardians agreed to the abdication of the dynasty, under a so-called Agreement for Favorable Treatment.
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted in English by the Free Yugoslav wireless and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Because United Nations Relief and Rehabilition Administration supplies and personnel for the relief of Poland must pass through Russia the Soviet Government will have a certain veto power over their distribution, it was gathered from statements made today at a press conference by former New York Governor Herbert H. Lehman, who is in London en route for the continent of Europe.

MOSCOW, Nov. 16 -- There was good news from the farm front today for the many millions of Soviet people who during the three and a half years of the war have lived on reduced rations to insure a sufficient supply of food for the Red Army and the people at a time when the primary agricultural regions of the Soviet Union were overrun by German armies.

The appeal for a $250,000 Modernization Fund for the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, 25 South Street, was opened yesterday at a luncheon at the Whitehall Club, attended by 100 representatives of steamship lines serving this port. Emmet J. McCormack, vice president of Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., and executive chairman of the fund, presided.

BOSTON, Nov. 16 -- President Roosevelt hailed New England's contributions to the home and war fronts today in a message sent to the opening of the New England Council's twentieth meeting and third war conference.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The War Production Board, in an effort to check lagging production of critical war weapons, has decided to send squads of industrial "trouble-shooters" to plants falling behind the schedules set up by Government war planners.

Since that distant day when Somerset Maugham first found her in the South Seas, Sadie Thompson has had a varied, ambitious and successful career. She has been the heroine of a short story, of one of America's best known plays, of innumerable movies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Upon the request of President Roosevelt, William H. Davis, chairman, and two of his associates on the National War Labor Board have consented to remain at their posts rather than to press for acceptance of their resignation, it was announced by the White House today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. said today that if the Army-Navy football game, scheduled Dec. 2 at Annapolis, were transferred to a stadium in New York, he believed the Treasury could sell about $50,000,000 in war bonds on the occasion for the Sixth War Loan Drive.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP) - Committees of the American and National Leagues will meet here tomorrow to "give consideration to the major league agreement which perpetuates the office of baseball commissioner," Will Harridge, American League president, announced tonight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP) - Committees of the American and National Leagues will meet here tomorrow to "give consideration to the major league agreement which perpetuates the office of baseball commissioner," Will Harridge, American League president, announced tonight.

Service in the three dining rooms and the cocktail lounge of the Hotel Ambassador, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street, virtually was at a standstill during the dinner hour last night when 100 employes walked out, asserting that the management had persisted in its refusal to negotiate a contract with their union, the New York Hotel Trade Council.

A statement issued yesterday by the Chemical Foundation, Inc., regarding the anti-trust proceedings brought against it and other defendants by the Department of Justice on Wednesday declares that "the implications inherent in the use of the term 'co-conspirator' with reference to the company, eighteen steel companies and six of their officers are both unjust and unwarranted."
Vice Admiral Emory Scott Land, War Shipping Administrator and chairman of the Maritime Commission, and Mrs. Land have arrived from Washington and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

By pushing a button on his desk in Washington, President Roosevelt at noon today will light the torch of the Statue of Liberty reproduction on its "island" crossing at Times Square and Forty-third Street and thus dedicate an activity center to stimulate bond purchases for the Sixth War Loan Drive.

Pullman, Inc., reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $6,663,962 for the nine months ended Sept. 30, equal to $2.06 a share, comparing with $7,434,252, or $2.25 a share, in the same period of 1943.

Michael Myerberg, producer of the Pulitzer Prize play, "The Skin of Our Teeth," becomes a theatre owner today. He will take title to the Mansfield in West Forty-seventh Street, which he leased in October of last year. The property was taken over from the Mutual Life Insurance Company at a reported price of $325,000.

A number of plain, ordinary GI Joes, who have dreamed of college educations but were not quite certain of when or where they would obtain them, will find themselves enrolled upon the cessation of military hostilities, in some of the finest European universities, Maj. Gen. F.H. Osborn, director of the Information Education Division of the Army Service Forces, disclosed last night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 17 -- John Hodiak has been named by Twentieth Century-Fox for the lead in "The Red Quarter," a story by Stephen Weidt dealing with the civilian opposition to the Nazi occupation of Marseilles. The film was scheduled for production last summer but was postponed for a more propitious time.

Expansion of the city's post-war program has increased the estimated cost of land acquisition from $80,000,000 to a total of more than $120,000,000, according to a report made public yesterday by Corporation Counsel Ignatius M. Wilkinson.

" The Thurber Merry-Go-Round," i a collection of James Thurber's I stories and drawings previously :announced as a reserve selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club, will be the club's February selection. Harper is the publisher.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Housewives who learn to save time by cutting down motions are demanding a better home plant and better home equipment, several speakers told the work simplification sessions being held here as part of the farm outlook conference.
LONDON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Mysterious constructions, believed to be starting bases for a new German secret weapon, are being erected in the mountains of central Norway, it was reported today.

New York University and Brooklyn College, each of which has made City College its sole victim -- the Kingsmen turned the trick twice -- meet today on Ohio Field in the closing game of the season for both elevens. Starting time for the contest, the first in history between the two schools, is set for 2:30.

Van Wyck Loomis of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club of Greenwich, Conn., last night was elected chairman of the Atlantic Class Association, and C.H. Vanderlaan of Horseshoe Harbor, Larchmont, was made secretary. Mr. Loomis succeeds Mills H. Husted, who was chairman two years.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Each of four American armies driving toward Berlin on the western front has its own supporting air unit, it was announced officially today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 17 -- For the first time a Communist was included in the Finnish Government when Premier Juho K. Paasikivi announced today that Yrjoe Leino, 47-year-old newspaper man, had been named Assistant Minister of Labor in his revamped Cabinet.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- Although Gen. Charles de Gaulle's Government insists that the revolution should be "within the law," as represented by special courts, extremist elements are manifesting a tendency to get out of hand and revert to the conditions that obtained in July as the Allies advanced swiftly.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- President Roosevelt made clear today that his projected meeting with Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin would take priority over his hope of visiting Paris.

This week brings to an end the most active period in respect to new corporate financing in modern financial history. Seldom, if ever before, has such a huge volume of new bonds and stocks been offered to the public in such a brief time as during the four-month span since the conclusion of the Fifth War Loan drive in early July.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The football fans get their wish -- it was announced tonight that the Army-Navy game, Dec. 2, will be played in Baltimore as a Sixth War Loan feature.

OTTAWA, Nov. 17 -- As the purpose for which it was set up in 1940 has now been accomplished -- "to provide the personnel to secure and maintain air superiority and air supremacy in every theatre of war" -- the British Commonwealth Air Training Plan will be wound up on March 31, 1945, which was the normal expiring date, it was announced today by Air Minister C.G. Power.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- First-hand accounts of barbarous treatment of Allied war prisoners by the Japanese in the southern areas of the Far East, under which the lowest death estimate was one in five were cited by Sir James Grigg, War Secretary, in the House of Commons today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- The Portuguese delegation was disturbed here today by reports from Lisbon that certain newspapers there had characterized the Latin-American bloc at the International Civil Aviation Conference as formed to protect the sovereign rights of Latin America from incursion by the air power of the United States, and that Great Britain was forming a cooperative air line to prevent control of an American "trust" of the air.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Eleven 2-year-olds were named today for the twenty-second renewal tomorrow of the rich Pimlico Futurity, a usually reliable barometer of how racing's speedy juveniles will perform when the chips are down in the big money stakes next season.

Christmas Buying Gains With Christmas gift buying an increasing factor, retail trade continued active here this week. Department stores had increases ranging up to 15 per cent or more over a year ago.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Joint committee of the American and National Leagues, expressing confidence in the twenty-four-year baseball rule of Kenesaw Mountain Landis, voted today to recommend the re-election of Landis for another term of commissioner and to extend the present agreement between the two circuits.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Chinese troops of the Thirty-sixth Division isolated the Japanese stronghold and Burma Road feeder junction of Bhamo and scored other gains in the North Burma offensive to clear a land route to China, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's command announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Our great victory in the second battle of the Philippines with the Japanese Fleet, which may prove to be among the decisive engagements of modern times, will greatly cut the future losses of men and material in the Pacific campaign, the Navy Department said today in a communique presenting for the first time the Navy's own "chronological and diagrammatic" story of its three fateful days.

A banking group headed by Paul H. Davis Co., Chicago, will offer today a new issue of $1,000,000 first mortgage 5 per cent sinking fund bonds of the Jessop Steel Company at par and accrued interest. The bonds will mature on Nov. 1, 1954.

KANDY, Ceylon, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Appointment of Lieut. Gen. Raymond A. Wheeler to succeed Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell as deputy commander of the Allied Southeast Asia Command was announced today, along with completion of a new set of British commanders from European theatres to direct the Allied land, sea and air efforts.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Saturday, Nov. 18 (AP) -- A communique:

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 17 (AP) -- The nation's debt to twenty-seven war bond owners went up in smoke today when members of the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation's "Bond Fire Club" voluntarily tossed $675 worth of certificates into a blaze.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Nov. 17 -- Kindness of the big heart of America is all but overwhelming 3-year-old Forest Nubbins Hoffman, 22-pound wraith of a once robust boy for whom Christmas will be observed next Sunday because, doubtless, he will not live until Dec. 25.

Mrs. Eileen Mowen, 26-year-old paralyzed mother who left her iron lung for twenty-seven minutes Thursday for a Caesarean operation performed in a corridor of Kingston Avenue Hospital, Brooklyn, was doing well yesterday and her three and one-half-pound daughter was given a better-than-even chance to live.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Air Chief Marshal Sir Trafford Leigh-Mallory, who had been ordered into battle against the Japanese after making a major contribution to the initial Allied victories in the west, was officially reported as missing tonight. The air craft in which he was traveling with Lady Leigh-Mallory on his way to his new post as Air Commander in Chief in Southeast Asia, has not arrived at its destination.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- Established social agencies must take up where the Army leaves off on the job of adjusting discharged service men to civilian life, Col. Raymond J. Kelly of the Army Service Forces told delegates to the forty-fifth annual New York State Conference of Social Workers at their closing session today.

Between 20 and 25 per cent of the membership of the Bureau of Advertising, A.N.P.A., have accepted the suggestion to enlarge the bureau under a budget of $100,000 annually, Irwin Maier, publisher of The Milwaukee Journal and general chairman of the expansion committee of the bureau, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 17 (Reuter) -- In a short debate following the Prime Minister's statement a Labor Deputy, William Thorne, today asked whether the two men who had shot Lord Moyne would be tried by a military or civil court, adding: "I dare say that some time or other he (Mr. Churchill) has read about the Spanish Inquisition and will he put that into operation?"
Johnny Greco, Canadian ring favorite, celebrated his local debut as a welterweight last night in Madison Square Garden with a victory over stout-hearted Bobby Ruffin, Long Island City gladiator.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- The old Senate Chamber in the Luxembourg Palace rang with jeering cries of "Vive Laval" and raucous laughter today as the French Consultative Assembly threshed out the issue of the exclusion of Parliamentarians who had voted to give Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain full powers in July, 1940, and heard the venerated, white-maned Louis Marin appeal for measured judgment and declare that he "would understand" the vote of many of those Parliamentarians.

Joseph Riccobono, 50 years old, whom the authorities had charged off as "among the missing" of the fourteen men that had been indicted seven years ago with Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro in the $1,000,000 extortion racket in the garment industry, "came to life" yesterday when, accompanied by his lawyer, former Judge Francis X. Mancuso, he walked into the District Attorney's office.

With further improvement noted in the condition of Ethel Barrymore, the Theatre Guild made known yesterday the date of the actress' expected return to "Embezzled Heaven," which had to be called off after the evening performance of Nov. 9 because of her illness.

Undoubtedly the most versatile item of furniture in anyone's home is a good looking screen, whether it is put to functional use or plays a purely decorative role. On the functional side, screens are not limited to hiding unsightly corners. They can be angled to deflect annoying noise. They can be arranged near bedroom windows to keep out early morning light as well as uncomfortable drafts.

ROME, Nov. 17 -- Vatican City is an embarrassed host today to two German soldiers who escaped from an Allied concentration camp and somehow got over the walls into the safety of one of Europe's neutral States.

Revivals of the French musicals, "Beethoven," starring Harry Baur, and "Three Waltzes," with Yvonne Printemps and Pierre Fresnay, will be presented at the Forty-eighth Street Cinema, today through Friday. . . . Holdovers: Entering fifth weeks today are "Summer Storm," with Linda Darnell and George Sanders, at the Gotham, and the Soviet drama, "The Rainbow," at the Stanley.

ATHENS, Nov. 17 -- Lieut. Gen. Ronald M. Scobie, British commander in Greece, issued an order today stating that if armed Elas patrols continued to enter Athens and its environs, contrary to agreement, they would be required by British troops to disarm. If they refused, the order said, they would be handed over to Elas authorities.
LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Although week-end influences kept today's stock markets subdued, the undertone remained firm.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 17 -- Recent developments in aviation have outmoded the conventional propeller-driven fighter plane, in the opinion of some experts, and foreshadow the development of silent, vibrationless aircraft for use in civil aviation, Lieut. Gen. Barton K. Yount, chief of the Army Air Forces, training command, told aviation industry representatives here tonight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- In a message today to the National Conference for Palestine, Secretary Ickes asserted that accomplishments in the reconstruction of the Jewish homeland in Palestine must serve as an inspiration to those who will have the responsibility of rebuilding Europe after the war.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- A plan of reorganization and liquidation filed by trustees of Commonwealth Light and Power Company and Inland Power and Light Corporation, both subsidiaries of the Middle West Corporation and hangovers from the utility regime of Samuel Insull, was approved today by Federal Judge Philip L. Sullivan.

Glenn Johnston, formerly assistant sales manager, has been appointed sales director of Pocket Books, Inc., a division of Field Enterprises. Robert E. Haig has been named circulation manager with headquarters in New York City.
KANDY, Ceylon, Nov. 17 (AP) -- A communique:

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- Agreement on international standards for pilots and mechanics was reached by the technical subcommittee concerned today at the International Civil Aviation Conference, but on the somewhat vexing question of airworthiness standards for aircraft the subcommittee recommended that the subject be referred to a permanent body to be set up as the result of deliberations here.

It has been interesting to notice how the various proponents of universal military training resort to the specious reasoning that universal military training is some magic formula for the improvement of the health of our youth.

DETROIT, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Welker Cochran, San Francisco challenger, defeated Willie Hoppe, world three-cushion billiard champion, 50 to 49, in forty-two innings in tonight's block of their 1,500-point challenge series for the world's title.

The proponents of peacetime universal military conscription are extremely anxious to push such legislation through Congress in short order. Yet a proposal so alien to the democratic standards for which America has long stood at the least deserves calm and unhurried consideration.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- Keen interest was displayed here today, especially by resistance groups, in the Belgian crisis in which issues are identical with some of those that Gen. Charles de Gaulle has faced and the Pierlot Government's action regarding armed groups was the same as General de Gaulle's.

Although Gerald R. Trimble, president of the Atlantic City Hotel Association and manager of the Claridge Hotel there, has told the Office of Price Administration that the Atlantic City hotels did not wish to entertain the OPA regional rent conference, the meeting will be held in that city "as scheduled" on Nov. 27 and 28, Daniel P. Woolley, Regional OPA Administrator, announced at his office here yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The mass tactical bombing that preceded the Allied armies' spring eastward toward the Rhine yesterday included, on the Royal Air Force side, the biggest bomb tonnage ever dropped in a single operation.

The larger cities of the nation should encourage private enterprise to undertake building projects which will supplement publicly financed operations in this field and thus aid their own financial status, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick declared yesterday at the annual conference of the New Jersey League of Municipalities in the Hotel New Yorker.

Today Frank C. Ferguson completes ten years of service as chaiman of the Port of New York Authority and twenty years as a Commissioner. The occasion is one that his colleagues have commemorated by appropriate ceremonies and the presentation of a silver medallion which testifies to a length of service unprecedented in the Port Authority's history.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- Repeal of the Federal Reserve Board's Regulation W, which limits the extension of credit by lenders and sellers to consumers, was urged yesterday by T.D. Hammond, vice president, Central National Bank, Cleveland, in an address at the New York State Bankers Association's Consumer Credit Clinic here.

WITH THE UNITED STATES NINTH ARMY, in Germany, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Streams of battle-shattered German prisoners of war dotted the roads leading to the rear of American lines today. Several hundred prisoners have been counted at Ninth Army cages, and more keep pouring in.

ROME, Nov. 17 -- Italian Partisan reaction to Gen. Sir Harold R.L. G. Alexander's order, in effect calling off their military activities for the winter, has not been enthusiastic. As Ettore Sighieri, commander of one patriot brigade, writes in this morning's Italia Libera, the war against the Nazis is not "a summer sport" and it is up to the Allies to make it possible on a year round basis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Office of Price Administration today announced establishment of dollars-and-cents price ceilings for fifteen types of raw furs and peltries. The new prices are in line with the general level of prices charged during the base period from October, 1941, through April, 1942, for the same kind of furs, OPA said.

BOSTON, Nov. 17 -- Declaring that the "danger of the post-war era to our form of government lies in unemployment," Representative William M. Colmer of Mississippi outlined to the New England council's third war conference today an eight-point program which will be recommended to Congress to help provide jobs after the war.

Giant hopes that looked pretty forlorn earlier in the week when it was believed both Bill Paschal and Joe Sulaitis would be on the inactive list for the all-important game with the Eagles tomorrow at the Polo Grounds bounced upward yesterday when Bazooka Bill, their offensive star, ran through the hour-land-a-half drill with his mates.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Representative Clarence J. Brown, Republican, of Ohio, describing the War Production Board's limitation on newsprint use by small newspapers as "asinine," said today that he would seek a House committee investigation unless changes were made.

Amid a flurry of last-minute preparations, New York took a three-day head start in the Sixth War Loan Drive, with the dedication at noon yesterday of the huge reproduction of the Statue of Liberty in Times Square, and the opening of bond sale booths in the base of the statue and in 700 theatres of this area.

CALIFORNIA vs. Southern California -- The Trojans have their eyes glued firmly on the Rose Bowl. Occasionally a team will set its sights off in the distance and immediately stumble over a nearer opponent it has overlooked, thus causing a great deal of embarrassment for the party so concerned. Risking that hazard, one vote for Southern California.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 17 -- City agencies, "through municipal inadequacies," must share some responsibility for the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey circus fire and panic July 6, Mayor W.H. Mortenson's Muncipal Board of Inquiry reported today.

A sentence of three to five years in Sing Sing was imposed yesterday in General Sessions on Wesley Wood, 40 years old, of Harrison, N.J, on his recent guilty plea to the theft of $60,000 of the funds of the former Local 50 of the Bakers International Union, when he was its secretary-treasurer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- A dozen unions of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, represented by rank-and-file workers as well as officers, made an all-day presentation to a Senate subcommittee today in support of the Pepper resolution under which any wage below 65 cents an hour would be recognized as substandard.
If ever Sidney Hillman finds himself in a low state of mind, as he must sometimes do, being human, he need only pick up the newspaper and read what his Republican opponents and critics say about him.

Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., had a net profit of $6,048,047 in the quarter ended on Oct. 31, after providing $3,850,000 for Federal and State income taxes and $7,265,000 for the Federal excess profits tax, equivalent to $1.09 each on 5,217,147 shares of common stock after allowing for dividend requirements on the class A stock.

LONDON, Nov. 16 (Delayed) -- The deportation of tens of thousands of young and middle-aged Netherlanders to Germany in an effort to break the resistance movement was reported today from the Netherlands.

The Young Israel Synagogue of Bronx Gardens has purchased a plot 100 by 100 feet on the west side of Stratford Avenue, 100 feet north of Westchester Avenue, the Bronx, from the estate of John Straton O'Leary and plans to build a synagogue and youth center on the site.

In other years planning the Thanksgiving dinner and buying the ingredients for it have been delayed till a couple of days before the holiday, but this season, with turkeys practically non-existent and other poultry none too plentiful, preparations are being started farther in advance.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The text of Navy communique No. 554, detailing the recent naval action in the Philippines:

The recent feeble efforts at recovery made by the stock market appeared yesterday finally to have been virtually in vain. Except for scattered strength in special situations, narrow price movements prevailed, but while emphasis was on the lower side, it was not sufficiently pronounced to indicate a definite reversal, and some firmness entered the list toward the close of business, under the leadership of the rails.

According to an Associated Press dispatch from Washington, Attorney General Biddle has asked Congress for "legislation allowing the arrest without warrants of persons suspected of being aliens violating immigration laws."

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- The Executive Board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, after hearing reports from CIO Political Action Committee officers and staff men today, voted unanimously to continue and "broaden" CIO-PAC activities and redesignated Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, as its chairman.

The Right Rev. Walter Hubbard Baddeley, Lord Bishop of Melanesia, Taroaniara, British Solomon Islands, will preach tomorrow at the 11 A. M. service in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, and at the 4:30 vespers in St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

Several large flotations of public utility and municipal bonds lifted the total of new financing this week to $109,815,000 for ten issues, compared with $3,400,000 for a single offering the week before. This week a year ago, $32,800,000 representing four new bond issues reached the market.

The magnitude of our air operations is revealed not only in the huge totals of 638,880 tons of bombs dropped and 15,210 enemy planes destroyed by the American Air Forces in Europe. American troop-carrier forces of the First Allied Airborne Army have now cascaded more than 50,000 parachute troops and more than 9,000,000 pounds of equipment for combat and supply behind the enemy lines.

An early conference is being sought by the International Association of Garment Manufacturers with the Office of Price Administration to discuss application of the Vinson directive as it affects the garment field, it was learned yesterday.

RYE, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- Deferring a stand on the proposals made at Bretton Woods until the American Bankers Association, the New York State Bankers Association and National Foreign Trade Council submit reports on the currency stabilization and international bank measures, the American delegation to the International Business Conference refused today to endorse the international bank for reconstruction and development.

Fifteen hundred delegates from Catholic schools, charitable and social welfare agencies throughout the country, attended sessions yesterday opening the thirtieth national conference of Catholic Charities at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn. The four-day conference is being held in conjunction with the annual meeting of the Society of St. Vincent de Paul.

WITH THE AMERICAN FIRST ARMY in Germany, Nov. 17 -- It was slow, hard fighting in the mud and rain along almost the entire front of Lieut. Gen. Courtney H. Hodges' American First Army today. Our men pushed ahead nearly everywhere, but German positions are strong and most gains were nibbling ones of a few hundred yards.

ROME, Nov. 17 (AP) -- British and Indian troops, closing on the highway center of Faenza southeast of Bologna, occupied the road junction of Modigliana nine miles south of the city without a fight. They also gained up to a mile the past twenty-four hours along Route 9 from Forli, it was announced tonight.

The eighteen-story apartment house for eighty-three families on a plot 90 by 100 feet at 7 to 11 West Ninety-sixth Street has been sold by the Lawyers Mortgage Corporation to the Associated Holding Corporation through Samuel L. Sohn, broker.

Certain textile machinery parts needed by both American and Latin-American textile manufacturers have been obtained more readily from Great Britain than from American machine manufacturers, according to downtown textile machinery dealers yesterday.

James B.M. McNally, Justice-elect of the State Supreme Court and until recently United States attorney here, made a brief return yesterday to the Federal Court, in his part-time capacity of seaman second class in the Coast Guard's temporary reserve.

The critical time in any great attack such as that set in full motion Thursday morning by the Allied armies against the German Westwall is when the men and the machines that launched it begin to run down. By that time the weaknesses, if any, in the enemy's defenses and in the attackers' plan will have begun to appear.
Domei, Japanese news agency, said yesterday that a formation of "about forty" American Liberator bombers and P-38 fighter planes had raided the Labuan sector of northwestern Borneo Thursday morning.

It ought to be understood that baked beans is not a subject for unanimity of opinion. Down East in Maine they favor a medium-sized onion in each pot. Vermonters snort at such heretical goings-on and use a little maple syrup instead of molasses as sweetening. Both Maine and Vermont outwardly agree that brown bread plentifully studded with raisins is the natural complement of a plate of beans.

THOSE who have already acquired a taste for Frank O'Connor, no vast army as yet, must turn to "Crab Apple Jelly"* with a pleasant crinkling of whatever the organs of taste are. Is Frank O'Connor growing, or has he learned to cheat? Is he still the most accomplished short-story writer in Ireland?

A New York cotton broker heads the syndicate which has acquired the old "Munsey newspaper block" at Telegram Square in the downtown section of Manhattan, it was learned last night. The purchase was made from Museum Estates, Inc., representing the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which had received this and other valuable New York properties under the will of Frank A. Munsey.

ALBANY, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley today proclaimed Thursday, Nov. 23, as Thanksgiving Day and urged the people of New York State "to observe it in the God-fearing spirit of those who first established it."

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- The grain markets were easy early today on the Board of Trade due to selling induced by favorable war news, but the decline brought in buying, especially in wheat, and a good rally followed. Corn showed independent strength as the result of prospects for smaller receipts and advanced 1 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel from its early low point and closed with net gains of 3/8 to 1/2 cent.

We wish that the President had been more explicit yesterday at his press conference on the subject of post-war military training, but we welcome what he said as being helpful to the prompt enactment of legislation to achieve this purpose. Both General Marshall and Secretary Stimson have already spoken strongly in favor of this plan.
WOODS HOLE, Mass., Nov. 17 -- Mrs. Constance L. Todd, writer, died here on Wednesday at the home of her son, David. Her age was 62.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- With the end of the war in sight, farm families may well begin to question whether "farming as a way of life necessarily means for most of them poor schools, inadequate medical care, lack of household facilities and conveniences and bad housing," according to the annual report of the Department of Agriculture on the outlook for farm-family living.
POTTSTOWN, Pa., Nov. 17 (AP) -- The board of directors of Jacobs Aircraft Engine Company today elected J.A. Harris 3d to serve as president as well as board chairman.

CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 16 (Delayed) -- In a report to the Government the Secondary Industries Commission expresses the opinion that Australian industry should be able to produce a popular automobile for 300 [the Australian pound was quoted in New York yesterday at $3.24].

MAGNY, France, Nov. 17 -- While troops of the American Third Army were fighting in the outskirts of Metz tonight, less than a mile from the besieged fortress city, town after town fell as the pincers were tightened and three more forts were surrounded.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Fear that the wholesale dropping of production controls might cause ruptures in the price ceiling structure after VE-day is slowing preparations for the reconversion of industry.

One hundred and five persons, fifteen of them women, who had received summonses in Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh's campaign against smoking in department stores, paid $10 fines in Municipal Term Court yesterday after pleading guilty before Magistrate Morris Rothenberg to violations of the Administration Code.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 18 (AP) -- General MacArthur today permitted mention for the first time of a fifth division now on Leyte Island -- the Thirty-second, veteran of some of the toughest of all the tough battles in the Southwest Pacific jungles.

Perpetuation of the War Advertising Council in some form "to help win the peace" was advocated yesterday by Chester J. LaRoche, vice chairman of the Blue Network and director of the WAC, in an address before the annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers at the Hotel Biltmore.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Saturday, Nov. 18 -- American troops moving down from the northwest yesterday accomplished their envelopment of the Japanese defenders of the northern end of Leyte's Ormoc Valley.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- President Roosevelt, in his news conference discussion today, indicated that he had in mind a more general program than the year of peacetime military training which some are advocating to create a trained Army reserve.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- Off to a flying start when Bob Jones made two touchdowns in the first period, Scarsdale's eleven subdued Bronxvfile, 18 -- 7, in the twenty-fifth meeting between the schools today. The contest marked the close of the campaign for both squads.
For the fourth time in as many games, Columbia will start a new backfield combination when the Lions face Brown at Baker Field today. The kick-off is scheduled for 2:30 P.M.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Nov. 17 -- Fighting ripped up and down the Western Front like wildfire today as tanks and infantry of six Allied armies hammered out substantial gains on the second day of the general offensive along a 450-mile front.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Japanese forces captured the walled city of Ishan, forty-three miles northwest of fallen Liuchow, and pushed up the Kwangsi-Kweichow railway in an apparent thrust toward Kweichow Province and the provisional capital of Chungking, the Chinese High Command announced today.

If farmers are to maintain production of basic crops such as cotton, they are entitled to a stable price guarantee, H.L. Wingate, president of the Georgia Farm Bureau, declared yesterday in a plea for understanding of the farmer's position in the current problem of high parity loans with resulting oversupply of raw cotton.

The one team the Rangers have beaten in National Hockey League competition this season, the Red Wings, will skate against the local puck-chasers at Madison Square Garden tonight. And the Rangers, refreshed by a week's rest, welcome the appearance of Jack Adam's crew of athletes.
Two games in the East and two in the Middle West hold the center of interest on the football program today and should set the stage for the climactic clashes of the college season.

LONDON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- More than 50,000 tons of explosives already have cascaded on the Reich this month from the bomb racks of 16,000 Flying Fortresses, Liberators, Lancasters and Halifaxes which await only a break in the weather to pass the 100,000-ton mark.

Twenty inspectors of the Office of Price Administration, assigned to the city's poultry receiving terminals for the last two weeks, have not as yet, it was learned yesterday, caused the issuance of any summons against the black marketers whose grip on the holiday supply of all kinds of fowl has been publicly noted by other Government agencies.

ALBANY, Nov. 17 -- The Appellate Division will convene here Monday to pass on the unusual question of whether Supreme Court Justice Gilbert V. Schenck, a former member of that court, can be compelled to reveal to the grand jury investigating alleged crime in Albany County deliberations of the division on a case.
Provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 were invoked yesterday in a suit filed by Park Tilford, Inc., in Federal court to recover $500,000 from Arthur D., John S. and David A. Schulte Jr.

Ely Jacques Kahn, nationally known architect, designer of many skyscrapers, a fellow of the American Institute of Architects and chief architect for Fort Greene Houses in Brooklyn, no longer is "eligible" or "qualified" to do work for the city under its revised system for selecting realty experts and architects, it became known last night.

A "Festival of Nations," for children 8 to 14 years old, will take place this morning at 10:30 o'clock in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street. The meeting is held in conjunction with the observance of Children's Book Week.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- Arrangements for the conversion of Fort Slocum here into a rehabilitation center for United States soldiers who have violated the Articles of War were announced today by the Second Service Command.

SAYBROOK, Conn., Nov. 17 -- The annual meeting of the Connecticut Spaniel Field Trial Association, sponsored by the Cooker Spaniel Field Trial Club of America, started today at the Ingham Hill Game Farm with the open all-age stake for cocker spaniels.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 17 (AP) -- A supplementary communique:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 17 (AP) -- A fast-spreading strike of operators crippled telephone communications in several Ohio cities tonight. Operators left their boards in sympathy with Dayton operators who walked out suddenly this morning as the climax of a dispute with the Ohio Bell Telephone Company over importation of out-of-town personnel.
LONDON, Nov. 17 (AP) - -A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

Inadequate supplies of heavy bombers, heavy artillery, heavy trucks and tires, cotton duck and radar equipment are threatening to prolong the war, we are warned by War Mobilization Director Byrnes. Two factors have apparently contributed to these shortages: the dynamic changes in the types of materiel required on the battlefronts and inadequate supplies of manpower.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 17 (Reuter) -- Of the 12,000 Jews in Belgrade before the war, about twenty remain alive in the city today. About 1,000 escaped.

The sugar shortage became so critical yesterday on Long Island that Representative Leonard W. Hall appealed to the War Food Administration for emergency shipments over the week-end lest Nassau County bakers be compelled to stop making cake and sugar rolls by Monday.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 17 -- Gen. Gustave Constant Bourgingnon, commander of the Belgian Gendarmerie, resigned this morning after his men had failed to halt a demonstration by resistance fighters in Brussels. The general withdrew from public life with the approval of Fernand Demets, Minister of National Defense.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Prime Minister Churchill demanded today that the Jewish community of Palestine -- "every man, woman and child" -- destroy the terrorist elements responsible for the recent assassination in Cairo of Lord Moyne, British Resident Minister in the Middle East.
Yesterday communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- The winter offensive in the west gains weight, stride and shape as four American armies, flanked by the British in the north and the French in the south, strike together on a front extending from the lowlands of Holland to the icy passes of the Vosges.
DETROIT, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Circuit Judge Guy A. Miller today ruled unconstitutional a statute under which the State of Michigan permits horse racing at the State Fair Grounds track here.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 17 -- Vice President Juan Peron announced today a new "organic law of the army," whose fundamental characteristic distinguishing it from previous ones is that it establishes the duty of all Argentine citizens, regardless of sex and from 12 years of age onward, to prepare themselves for the defense of their country.

Shortage warnings alheady have been sounded about Christmas tree ornaments, but hope for relief came yesterday from an unexpected quarter when a nine-page brochure in which home-made non-priority decorations are described was issued by the New York War Finance Committee.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 17 (UP) -- Communique 223:

LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 18 -- Russian troops captured the key Hungarian rail junction of Fuezesabony yesterday, advancing up to four miles on a sixty-five-mile front and hurling the enemy back into the Matra and Buekk Mountains northeast of besieged Budapest, a Moscow communique announced last night.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- The International Civil Aviation Conference reached another delay today, when it was learned that Lord Swinton, chairman of the British delegation, had cabled London asking his government for instructions.

Soon after the turn of the year, when the new Congress convenes, legislative machinery will start rolling on a proposal to lower the reserve ratio of the Federal Reserve System, according to expectations in that group. Banking circles consider this a "must," for, it is explained, heavy Government spending has been increasing money in circulation and inflating reserve requirements for the banks.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 17 -- Two developments in sterol chemistry, an improved method of obtaining ethanol from molasses, and several inventions in the field of cellulose are among the 523 patents listed as granted in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- After having listened to proposals of Pierre Mendes-France, Minister of National Economy, for strict Government control of the country's industries in the interest of deflation, the Cabinet announced today it had "approved" those proposals.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 17 (AP) -- For the second time in history the Army and Navy will settle their annual gridiron feud in Baltimore, but it was just as much of a mystery as ever tonight what the public would pay to see the Cadets and Middies go after each other Dec. 2.

On Nov. 3 your paper published a report from Stockholm, sent by George Axelsson, containing certain statements about conditions in Estonia purportedly made by Oscar Maend, an Estonian newspaper man who recently escaped from Estonia to Sweden. One paragraph of this report reads as follows:

MOSCOW, Nov. 17 -- More than 40,000 Polish peasants and agricultural workers have now received twelve-and-a-half-acre plots of ground as their own under the Committee of National Liberation's agrarian reform program being carried out in liberated districts of that country, it was reported today.

MOSCOW, Nov. 17 -- The Soviet Government today began a new crack-down on wartime chiselers. The first targets in the propaganda campaign are those repair shops for clothing, shoes, electrical appliances and similar articles that proclaim their inability to accept new work at the low, fixed State price but which are willing to make private deals to do repair jobs, but at open market prices.
ROME, Nov. 17 (UP) -- A communique:

The cotton market on the New York Cotton Exchange opened yesterday 1 point lower to 1 point higher than the previous close, eased to losses of 4 to 10 points, rallied and closed steady with net losses of 1 to 4 points.

On May 7, 1913, Dr. Frederick L. Hoffman read a paper before the American Gynecological Society in which he pleaded for the organization of an American society for the study and prevention of cancer. His proposed society was to educate the public at large in the absolute necessity of early operative treatment, to induce hospitals and health authorities to compile better statistics and to stimulate research.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- President Roosevelt said today that he would press this winter for Congressional adoption of compulsory universal service for the country's youth. He countered questions concerning the degree to which such a system should involve purely military training.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Food production next year may fall far short of record output recommended by War Food Administrator Marvin Jones because of an increasing shortage of farm machinery and tractors, authorities in the farm equipment industry said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- What is the immediate future of the National War Labor Board?
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Plans to furnish more detailed and rapid information to the relatives of Army casualties were announced today by the War Department.

It is a bitter thing for an unbeaten air force to bomb and blast its own airfields ahead of an advancing enemy. Yet that is what General Chennault's pilots have had to do ever since the fall of Henyang. Swept back in the ebb tide of a military collapse which they did not share and could not check, they have finally been driven from eastern China.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 18 -- The gradual infiltration of Japanese-Americans back to their former West Coast homes, with Army permission, is focusing popular attention on a problem which promises to get more and more notice in coming months.

VINCENT SHEEAN, back from China and India, where he served as a lieutenant colonel in the AAF, is now out of uniform and on the Army's reserve list. He doesn't plan to stay put long, though; any day now he'll go overseas again, this time to gather material for a new book, about the war in Europe and the Pacific and about the peace to come.

The contract for construction of the $6,000,000 Riverton housing project of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company was signed yesterday in Mayor La Guardia's office at City Hall. Mayor La Guardia and Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick signed for the city, and the signatories for Riverton Redevelopment Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the insurance company, were Frederick H. Ecker and James P. Bradley.

THIS war is so vast and complex that leaders and participants alike are in constant danger of losing sight of its potential over-all meanings. Here is a single volume that comes as close as any I have seen to combining the particular and the general, the fate of an individual and his family, that of a nation and that of the principles laid down in the Atlantic Charter, into a single unifying image.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 19 (Reuter) -- Capt. Peter Riedel, assistant air attache at the German Legation, has renounced the Nazi party after a dispute with a higher ranking military attache of the legation, known as an active member of the Gestapo.

In several recent editions of THE NEW YORK TIMES Overseas Weekly, prepared primarily for the overseas forces of the United States, there appeared an invitation to men in the armed forces to write letters to THE TIMES on current social, economic and political problems, or any other subjects they might be thinking about. Excerpts from the first group of letters received appeared last Sunday. Here is another group. Others will appear later.

ROME, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Polish troops of the British Eighth Army, battling forward more than a half mile through the snow in the mountains before the Po plain, have seized Monte Fortino, five miles south of the highway town of Faenza, a prime objective, Allied headquarters said today.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 17 (Delayed) -- A credit agreement involving about $12,000,000 will be discussed by Foreign Minister Paul Henri Spaak and Finance Minister Camille Gutt in Paris next week, it was learned here today. Another urgent question under review will be that of redeeming Belgian francs in France, which is made difficult by Belgium's monetary policy.

SOMEWHERE on the way from Africa to England is a new star, whose arrival is eagerly anticipated at Denham. She is coal black and her name is Eseza (anglicized to Esther) Makumbi. Her father is an East African clergyman.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 -- Philadelphia's fiftieth anniversary dog show came to a close tonight with an enthusiastic gathering proclaiming the pre-eminence of the Dalmatian, Champion Reigate Bold Venture, from the Reigate Kennels of Franklin, Va., and handled by his owner, George Lane.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 18 -- Duke's four Horsemen of the South galloped today to a 34 -to-7 victory over South Carolina before 11,000 fans to continue a winning streak which had started two weeks ago with an upset of unbeaten Georgia Tech. The half-time score was 27 -- 7.

The prime fault in the modern theatre, Channing Pollock says, is a faulty system of financing. Once that is remedied and we permit only select and "cultivated' audiences (preferably in formal attire, I presume) to attend our playhouses, then the drama will be restored to the pristine and virginal state of "The Easiest Way."

Russian women may lead American women in constructing a pattern by which careers may be more easily combined with responsibilities for home, husband and children, Dean Virginia Gildersleeve of Barnard College, yesterday suggested to the Committee of Women of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship, Inc., in the Hotel Commodore, Lexington Avenue and Forty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The CIO executive board voted this week to continue and expand the activities of the CIO Political Action Committee. The committee's leaders believe it is here to stay, as long as there is work to be done, and they see a great deal to do.
EASTON, Pa., Nov. 18 -- Lafayette defeated its traditional rival Lehigh today, 64 to 0, in an all-civilian football game, marking the end of the season for Lafayette.

Senator Owen Brewster of Maine said last night he was amazed and disturbed at the statement of Prime Minister Winston Churchill last Friday because of its implication that all Jews in Palestine would be held responsible for the assassination of Lord Moyne, British Residential Minister in the Middle East, by two members of the terrorist Stern gang.

Two goals scored 50 seconds apart by Fred Thurier enabled the Rangers to avoid defeat in their National Hockey League game with the Detroit Red Wings at Madison Square Garden last night. For these tallies lifted the New Yorkers on level terms at 2 to 2 toward the end of the second period.

MORE than fifty true stories of the human side of aerial warfare from El Alamein to the liberation of Rome, crisply told and magnificently illustrated, have been collected in this book at the instance of Lieut. Gen. Ira C. Eaker, commanding general of the Mediterranean Allied Air Forces.
Retail trade continued brisk last week in the major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

ALBANY, Nov. 18 -- The extraordinary investigation of crime in Albany County serves to point up the struggle between the Republican State organization of Governor Thomas E. Dewey and the local Democratic regime of Daniel P. O'Connell for control of the State's capital city.

Most of the discussions of post-war unemployment deal in terms of national aggregates. Too little attention has been directed to the fact that the demobilization of the war economy will fall with varying impacts upon different regions of the country. The current Cleveland Trust Company Bulletin shows the number of war workers and members of the armed forces who will be demobilized in each of eighteen States.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 18 -- Belgium's disarmament of her tough resistance fighters proceeded smoothly today after the political tempest of the past week had subsided.

NINTH USAAF ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, Oct. 30 (Delayed) -- The crew of a Ninth Air Force Black Widow night fighter on patrol over Germany last night witnessed what was believed to be a launching of a V-2 rocket-propelled bomb shortly before midnight.

FAR away and long ago -- an excursion into the mists of ancient China -- Mr. West's novel recreates, with controlled humor and much discernment, the intricacies of the overrefined, corrupt, effete civilization of the T'Ang Dynasty, its violences, delicacies, almond-eyed humanity.

CHEYENE, Wyo., Nov. 18 (U.P.) -- Three-year-old Forest "Nubbins" Hoffman hung up his small stocking tonight in a house bulging with presents and good wishes from a nation which opened its heart to help him celebrate a Christmas speeded up by more than a month to circumvent fast-approaching death.

HAVING paid at least part of the tribute due to the distaff side of Ballet Theatre in these columns last week, it is no less than fitting to say a word now for the male contingent. Even with the recent defection of Anton Dolin and Andre Eglevsky it is still incomparably superior to that of any other organization in the field.

SEVEN physicians are present when Joyce Prentiss is murdered during a belated wedding reception for Dr. Carstairs and his wife, Mona, who have been secretly married for more than two years and have only just discovered that it was all a mistake.

A NEW entry in the "none today" class at stores is that common commodity, the match. Match manufacturers, under Government orders, are serving the armed forces first. With 90 per cent of penny boxes and 25 per cent of book matches scheduled for shipment overseas in the next six months, only kitchen matches will be plentiful at home.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 18 (U.P.) -- Ohio's crippling communication's tie-up spread to the vital war centers of Cleveland, Akron, Canton and Youngstown tonight as 2,000 operators and supervisors in the northeast voted to strike.

THE struggle against the Nazi way of life will not end with our military victory over Germany. There will be the collaborationists in nearly every occupied country to expose. There will be the war criminals to bring to justice and to punish. There will still be traces of Nazi and Fascist thought to uproot and to exterminate.

Al Veling, Brooklyn Tech quarterback, set a New York City modern scholastic scoring record for a season's play when he led the Engineers to a 25-7 decision over Manual Training at Tilden Field in Brooklyn yesterday. Veling registered three touchdowns to raise his total to 120 points and to surpass by three points a mark set by Jack James of Poly Prep in 1928.

LIVINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- In this quiet Hudson Valley town between the Catskills and Berkshires, Wacs, Waves and torpedoed seamen, mustered out because of tuberculosis, are being restored to health and economic usefulness at the Potts Memorial Institute, whose leaders feel they may be blazing the trail for solution of an important post-war problem.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Nov. 18 -- Against a front of only thirty miles Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Supreme Allied Commander, has thrown in the terrifying strength of three armies in the most concentrated offensive the world has ever known.

Young women comprising a junior committee will serve as waitresses on Saturday afternoons during the winter at La Tasse de The, maintained at 390 Park Avenue by the Committee of French American Wives for the benefit of French children.

IN Harper's Magazine for November C. Hartley Grattan, writing under the caption "Salute to the Litterateurs," takes stock of the ideas and attitudes which he sees as currently agitating the literary world. He ends his survey with a guess regarding the general character of the reading which will be offered us during the years immediately ahead.

OTHER important questions were discussed at the International Business Conference at Rye, N.Y., during the week, but the paramount issue of free enterprise versus the cartel was not resolved. The American delegation pressed for an expression which would check government and cartel control in world commerce, but Great Britain, Argentina, France and Belgium were registered against any hampering of their future decisions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- William H. Davis, chairman of the National War Labor Board, gave his personal endorsement in principle today to a 65-cent minimum wage, but he refrained in testimony before a Senate subcommittee from an outright endorsement of the resolution proposed by Senator Pepper, Democrat, of Florida. He said that he was not speaking for the WLB.

In a game in which the gridiron fairly sizzled at times, New York University defeated Brooklyn College yesterday on Ohio Field, 13 to 7, as 4,000 partisan rooters from the two boroughs yelled themselves hoarse repeatedly.

ALL responsible people connected with industry today agree that women are equal to men as far as being able to do almost any industrial job goes. Aside from the relatively few operations where mechanical devices have not been invented or installed to lift heavy weights, women who have been given equal chances with men at training and promotion have proved beyond doubt that they can turn out the goods as fast and well as anyone.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Communique 224:

Figuratively and literally, the Navy ran the shirts off the Army yesterday in the thirty-sixth annual cross-country championship of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America over the five-mile trail at Van Cortlandt Park.

The help of the home, the church and the community would be needed to meet the problems of intergroup relations arising from our inconsistencies, Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday in an address at the nineteenth annual luncheon of the Protestant Teachers Association at the Hotel Astor. Fifteen hundred teachers were present, including many of the Roman Catholic and Jewish faiths.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- The British Second Army jumped into the battle inside Germany today alongside the United States First and Ninth Armies, and the American Third Army, in a new invasion of the Reich, crossed the border in force and tanks and infantry fought street by street into Metz.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 18 -- Adolf Hitler's silence on the Nov. 9 anniversary of the Munich beer-hall putsch opened wide the sluice gates of speculation as to what might lie behind this sudden and dramatic departure from a twenty-one-year-old Nazi tradition.

Slow but steady progress in the control of cancer through public education is revealed by picture and text in the "History of the American Society for the Control of Cancer, 1913-1944," written by Mrs. Francis J. Rigney, and published by the New York City Cancer Committee.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 18 -- Chile has sent no note or memorandum to the United States or other American countries supporting the idea of a conference of Foreign Ministers recently suggested by Argentina, the Under-Secretary of Foreign Relations, Carlos Aliaga, said tonight.

WITH UNITED STATES ARMY, WUERSELEN, Germany, Nov. 18 (U.P.) -- Ninth Army troops who pushed into this ruined town few miles northeast of Aachen today encountered what they described as "the worst mess of mines and booby traps of all kinds we've ever seen in our life."

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- Cornell's football forces defeated Dartmouth, 14 -- 13, on Schoellkopf Field today as Paul Robeson Jr. converted his two chances with place kicks after touchdowns. Lazarus Lewis, Dartmouth's quarterback, missed his first placement opportunity and had to kick his second extra point twice to make it count.

THERE is a bulletin board at the Merchant Seamen's Club at 109 West Forty-third Street which is more eloquent of the dangers men face at sea in this war than many words. It is where sailors on the beach leave their addresses for friends, and it is always covered with slips of paper.

THE International Society for Contemporary Music, United States Section, will hold a reception in honor of the seventieth anniversary of Arnold Schoenberg, next Sunday at 8:45 P.M., at the Dalcroze Auditorium in the City Center, when a program will be presented by Edward Steuermann and Fritz Jahoda, pianists, and Ethel Luening, soprano.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Probably none of the wartime shortages to date, including butter, gasoline and nylon stockings, has caused public concern equal to that aroused by the scarcity of cigarettes in the Central West.

WITH his book under review, suddenly Archbishop Temple, brave prelate in activity and opinion, succumbs to the strain of a terrible time. We have here the last of his millions of words, uttered and written, which are woven today within the instincts of the British people and so spread throughout the world.

The "dirt" farmers, the men who operate small or family-sized farms, and their leaders are apprehensive of what is in store for the country economically when the war ends, and are virtually unanimous in the conviction that such planning as has been undertaken by business and by the Government is unrealistic and inadequate.

The putting into effect last week by the United States Government of a subsidy payment of 4 cents a pound on all cotton exported from this country marked another important change in policy with respect to that farm product, which since the formation of the ill-fated Federal Farm Loan Board in 1929 has undergone a series of changes.

George Z. Medalie, president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, asserted yesterday that the "in-between veteran" will represent the bulk of the reintegration work that voluntary hospitals and social service agencies will do in post-war days, "judging by trends so far noted at vocational guidance, family welfare and medical institutions" of the federation.

WITH SIXTH ARMY GROUP in France, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Alexander M. Patch's doughboys rolled up gains totaling two miles and captured the key town of Raon-l'Etape on the Muerthe River today as French troops hammered within four miles of Belfort in a large-scale advance rapidly assuming the proportions of a breakthrough.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- During recent weeks British Government Ministers and members of Parliament have discussed at every opportunity the post-war treatment of Germany, but it is doubtful whether many of them have informed themselves with the views of the ordinary British man and woman.

MR. ADAMS has set himself the large-task of appraising American fiction (and to a negligible extent, poetry) of the present century, of reaching certain critical conclusions and of prophesying a happier literary situation yet to come.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 18 -- The Scarlet Scourge of Ohio State, still hoping to play in the Rose Bowl, survived a game-opening score by the University of Illinois today to drub the Illini, 26 to 12, for the undefeated Buckeyes' eighth consecutive football victory of the season.

CORTLANDT STREET -- onetime repository of nearly everything from a tube socket to a complete radio station: paradise of set-builder, amateur and kitchen tinkerer -- is emerging from the trade doldrums of war.

EVER since Pearl Harbor the Musicians Emergency Fund has been devoting every penny it could to making music for men in our armed services. In order to make good use of these funds the MEF has done a two-fold job: First, it has provided talent for concerts for service men, and, second, it has provided free instruction to music-minded soldiers and sailors.

IN the wake of prairie schooners headed westward has trailed a formidable succession of stories replete with Indians, pioneers and earthy struggles. John Selby's latest novel incorporates the movement and adventure of its many predecessors.

In his speech on foreign policy delivered on Oct. 21, President Roosevelt declared that the peace organization proposed at Dumbarton Oaks was "just another chapter in the long process of cooperation with other peace-loving nations -- beginning with the Atlantic Charter, that's a long time ago, and continuing through conferences at Casablanca and Moscow and Cairo and Teheran and Quebec and Washington."

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Defenseless Rotterdam, deliberately subjected to German terroristic bombing after it had been declared an open city in May, 1940, now has had its port, the second largest in Europe, systematically ruined by German demolition crews.

NOT all of the six short stories in this volume are detective stories, but all have to do with crime and punishment. In the title story a murderer whom the law cannot touch is forced to condemn and execute himself. The manner in which this is accomplished is highly ingenious and most dramatic.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Unbeaten Tennessee gave another shove forward to its bowl chances today, coming from behind to defeat Temple University, 27 -- 14. The Vols were trailing 14 -- 12, when they turned on the steam in the final period for two touchdowns and forced a Temple safety with a blocked kick.

HOLLYWOOD, according to present indications, will depend on so-called "red meat" stories of illicit romance and crime for a major share of its immediate non-war dramatic productions: The apparent trend toward such material, previously shunned for fear of censorship, is traced by observers to Paramount's successful treatment of the James M. Cain novel, "Double Indemnity," which was described by some producers as "an emancipation for Hollywood writing."

Senators Harold H. Burton of Ohio and Homer Ferguson of Michigan, both Republicans, endorsed yesterday the proposal that America's representative on the world security organization be authorized to vote with other nations in resisting aggression without first referring issues to Congress for its two-thirds vote of approval.

Contending that the required 12,000,000 increase in post-war jobs will depend in large measure upon "what industry does about distribution," Fenton B. Turck of Turck, Hill Co., said in an interview yesterday that the magnitude of the task will compel broad application of engineering principles to the flow of goods from producer to consumer to insure the steady, calculated employment of productive labor.

RYE, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- Businessmen from fifty-two nations attending the international business conference, endorsed today a report on cartels calling for immediate inter-governmental study of governmental and business agreements which regulate production, marketing, prices and patent exchanges.

VERY few mathematical physicists are literary men with the gift of revealing the discoveries that have been made in recent years with the clarity and dramatic effect that we find in any story well told. Sir James is one of these few.

Mischel Cherniavsky, Russian 'cellist, was heard in his second New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The artist, who toured this country often in former days with the Cherniavsky Trio and later reached prominence in England as soloist, again proved his ample gifts as technician and interpreter at this latest appearance here.

The new export subsidy program represents the latest action in an ever-widening circle of control over agriculture. Measures to support agricultural prices have been extended considerably since the first abortive efforts of the Federal Farm Board under a Republican Administration.

Richard Dyer-Bennet, hitherto known as "Twentieth-Century Minstrel," who has been heard recently in Town Hall, made his first appearance last night in Carnegie Hall before an audience that filled. the house and overflowed with enthusiasm.
The Office of Price Administration cracked down yesterday on twenty-two hotels, most of them in midtown, and on six apartment houses in the five boroughs that it accused of rent overcharges.

The resignation of Ferdinand C. Smith as national secretary of the National Maritime Union, Congress of Industrial Organizations, was announced yesterday by Joseph Curran, NMU president. Mr. Curran gave as the reason for the Negro official's resignation that he held office in violation of the union's constitution, since he is not a citizen of the United States. He will remain as a member of the union.

THE need of rebuilding our cities presents one of the greatest challenges to post-war America. If we meet it we shall have forged the strongest link in national prosperity, for no other project can rival its potentialities for widespread stimulation of production and employment.

If the United States is to invest in the future of the world outside its borders, its Government must take a more realistic view of credit, in the opinion of R.D. Kellogg, for thirty years a specialist in South American investment and commercial banking.

BIRDS are the gardeners best helpers in food production. Those of the winter season are just as important as the greater number of birds who dwell in the garden during summer. Ornithologists have proved that a single chickadee, for example, will eat from 200 to 500 insects a day and up to 5,000 insect and worm eggs.
Our harvest being gotten in our Governour sent foure men on fowling, so that we might after a more special manner rejoyce together after we had gathered the fruit of our labour.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The special committee appointed by President Roosevelt to survey the rise in the cost of living reported to him today that "the final figure for the over-all increase in the cost of living from January, 1941, to September, 1944, would thus be found to be 29 to 30 per cent".
Information about other lands was presented at a "Festival of Nations" yesterday morning in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

Committees representing three widely known philanthropic agencies have taken over performances of Billy Rose's forthcoming musical show, "The Seven Lively Arts," starring Beatrice Lillie, which is scheduled to open Dec. 7 at the Ziegfeld Theatre.

The Columbia Lion couldn't unsheath his claws at Baker Field yesterday against the Brown Bruin, with the result that the Blue and White losing streak was stretched to five games as Brown triumphed, 12 -- 0.

WHEN the outside world is reduced to gray and brown it is pleasant to have indoors plants with bright fruit of gold and yellow, coral and red. Small citrus fruit trees, the variegated aglaonema, Cleveland cherry, ornamental pepper and coral ardisia bear fruit which on healthy specimens stays fresh and attractive for many months.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Sunday, Nov. 19 -- Stubborn fighting continued on Leyte in occasional rains as elements of the Twenty-fourth and Thirty-second Divisions further squeezed the Japanese pocketed at the northern end of Ormoc Valley where a reinforced enemy regiment is isolated by flank attacks.

IN the musical comedy hit "Bloomer Girl," Horatio Applegate, prosperous hoopskirt manufacturer, is proudly surveying five of his daughters dressed in the cumbersome skirts, his best advertisement, when he receives a surprise visit from his sister-in-law, Miss Dolly Bloomer.

With a number of skating stars already established as popular favorites in this city, together with several brilliant newcomers, the Ice Follies of 1945 will open in Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night.
The Giants squared off against the Eagles last week, today's it's the Packers and after that it will be the Tigers, and then the Redskins here and then in Griffith Stadium, Washington.

THAT the author of "The Song of Bernadette" should be something of a religious philosopher is not surprising. That he should present his philosophy in a form other than fiction, which to him has been so rewarding, only proves the strength of his conviction that mankind cannot go on living on the empty rewards of mere technology.

THE Smith family is in trouble. Martin Smith has been murdered, and the only person who might possibly know who killed him is his widow, Irene, who has lost her memory. There may be a clue in the novel that Irene is known to have been writing, but the manuscript has not been found.

A great Allied attempt to end the war with Germany this year started last week and the Reich is now facing the long-anticipated winter crisis. Six Allied armies -- the spearhead directed toward Cologne -- joined in a general offensive, and despite mud, rain and snow made immediate, though limited, gains.

THE second of Germany's "vengeance weapons." V-2, is now in action. V-2, the rocket, has much in common with V-1, the robot plane. Both are pilotless. Both are jet propelled -- that is, they have "reaction motors"; they depend for their forward motion on the reaction to the explosive jets of gas that stream back from them at great speeds.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Tulane's Green Wave discarded their power plays to outscore an inspired team of Clemson Tigers, 36 to 20, in a wide open offensive game today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 -- Roswell Magill, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury and now a member of the law firm of Cravath, Swaine Moore of New York, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today at its hearing on reorganization of the Buffalo, Niagara and Eastern Power Corporation that the excess-profits tax would be repealed probably as of Dec. 31, 1946, and possibly as of Dec. 31, 1945.

Proponents of post-war tax plans which favor the abolition of the income tax in respect of corporations recognize that if earnings are made tax-free to corporations some form of penalty tax should be imposed for failure to distribute the earnings.

FIRST impressions, I think, are valid as far as they go. In writing about the painting annual at the Whitney Museum in our column of Tuesday last I expressed some amazement at finding the place overrun with various brands of fantasy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- A tight supply situation for tin, nickel, malleable iron and lacquers has precluded any possibility that restrictions on the use of these products in the manufacture of hardware would be relaxed in the near future, the WPB reported today.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Sunday, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Limon, four miles by road from Pinamopoan on Carigara Bay, was being defended by hundreds of Japanese, entrenched in the mountain fortress town. Evidently, they intended to hold out as long as possible, while Japanese forces farther south on Ormoc highway rushed defenses for future battles.
