That the newspapers of France find inspiration in the example of American newspapers in presenting a full and impartial news report, even in the stress of a national electoral campaign, was urged in an editorial yesterday in Pour la Victoire, a French weekly published in New York.

TACLOBAN, Leyte, Nov. 17 (Delayed) -- A special board of inquiry, established by President Sergio Osmena to investigate cases of supposed collaboration with the Japanese, held its first public session yesterday, hearing Bernardo Torres, who was appointed Governor of Leyte Province under the late President Manuel Quezon and who continued to hold office during almost the entire enemy occupation.

Last week the western Allies hurled their massed strength against Germany in what appeared to be a bid for a victory in 1944. Six great armies drove hard into the Nazi lines; two more were available. Planes, guns and tanks by the thousands, tough infantrymen in the millions poured into the attack.

MY last contribution to this page took the form of a panegyric on the repertory season of the Old Vic company, with Ralph Richardson and Laurence Olivier at its head. Now I have to write in very similar terms about another repertory season instituted by John Gielgud at the Haymarket, and I find myself a little short of superlatives.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Eleven days of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's winter offensive showed today that, whether or not Hitler is at the helm in Germany, enemy soldiers resolutely are obeying his instructions to resist to the end.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- There was no pressure today on the grain markets on the Board of Trade, and when fairly general short covering developed late to even up commitments for the week-end it lifted prices to the best levels of the day.

THE principal actors in this story of the British Secret Service are Roger Fleming and Stephen Murray. The former is the leader of a group whose task it is to run down the spies and saboteurs who are trying to hamper the war effort by destroying food dumps.

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Eighty-six German planes were shot down or destroyed on the ground yesterday by 400 hard-hitting American fighter pilots who hung up the second longest such mission on record -- 1,200 air miles to Munich and back.

THE criminal career of Butch, the butter-fingered burglar, collected now in book form, proves that crime pays in rich entertainment when arranged by Sgt. Larry Reynolds. Sergeant Reynolds created his Raffles in barrel form, added a milk-toast conscience, a rigid sense of decorum, a dollop of sentimentality, and called the whole thing Butch.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- Marshal Joseph Stalin's invitation to Gen. Charles de Gaulle to visit Moscow -- which was suddenly extended and instantly accepted only a few hours after General de Gaulle had bowed out Prime Minister Winston Churchill after his historic visit to Paris -- caught the French press not only short of paper but also short of superlatives.

ON THE OUTSKIRTS OF METZ, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Quite a few people got to the outskirts of Metz today and some Americans are gradually moving farther into the city in a house-to-house fight, but five men actually got to the heart of one of Europe's most famous fortress cities and got back to tell about it.

A significant indication of substance beneath nebulous talk about Anglo-American amity after the war is revealed in the close liaison that Worcester, England, has established with Worcester, Mass., to help the latter community observe All-British Week, which opens in the New England city today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Acting Secretary of State, said today that the United States was still consulting the other American republics concerning the advisability of a conference of Foreign Ministers to discuss post-war problems and possibly the Argentine question.

An altered attitude toward the adolescent and a greatly expanded program to utilize youth's talents were advocated last night by Howland G. Shaw, assistant Secretary of State, as the means of saving teen-age youngsters from becoming a lost generation. He spoke at a meeting closing the second day of the four-day Thirtieth National Conference of Catholic Charities at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn.

THE four networks are sending the Sixth War Loan Drive off to a flying start tonight when each will take a half hour's time to present specially written and produced shows furthering the sale of bonds.

ROME, Nov. 18 -- The arrest of Gen. Mario Roatta yesterday -- the most important arrest made by the Purge Commission -- is to be connected with the whole involved circle of international plots that included the assassinations of King Alexander of Yugoslavia and the anti-Fascist Rosselli brothers, it was learned today.

First of its kind to be established in the country under the sponsorship of more than one institution, the Veterans Guidance Center in Providence, R.I., has been planned as a joint project in which the seven colleges of Rhode Island will cooperate. The center will provide a comprehensive testing and vocational guidance service for returning veterans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Chairman Arthur J. Altmeyer of the Social Security Board has called on the Governors and Legislatures of forty-four States whose law-making bodies convene during 1945 to improve State laws on unemployment insurance and public assistance along lines of expansion of benefits, prolongation of benefit periods, and removal of qualifying restrictions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Christmas gift parcels for the armed forces overseas reached the "phenomenal" total of between 82,000,000 and 85,000,000, Postmaster General Frank C. Walker said tonight. He announced that the last packages had been turned over to the military authorities for dispatch overseas.

Although the full development of this nation's foreign trade awaits the end of the war, the Government must prepare now for its responsible participation in this phase of international affairs, Wayne Chatfield-Taylor, Under-Secretary of Commerce, told a conference of industrial management officials yesterday.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 18 -- The climax of the strategic air war should come this winter in a battle which the Germans, fighting under more advantageous circumstances than they did a year ago, will make a desperate attempt to halt the Anglo-American air assaults on the German oil and armament industries.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Michigan's Wolverines, with a pair of lightning-like touchdown sprints of 84 and 56 yards, defeated a fighting Wisconsin eleven, 14 to 0, today, to run their victory streak to six games and carry their Big Ten title hopes into next Saturday's game with Ohio State.

WAYCROSS, Ga., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Fifteen cars of the Atlantic Coast Line's fast New York-to-Tampa West Coast Champion left the rails near Hortense, Ga., about 8:30 A.M., today, injuring at least eighteen persons, none seriously. Only the three-unit diesel engine and three rear cars of the eighteen-coach train remained on the tracks.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., Nov. 18 -- Responding to the pleas led by J. Carlton Ward Jr., president of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation of New York, a stepson of whom was killed in this war, the National Aviation Clinic held an overtime session here today to adopt a resolution urging compulsory peacetime military service.

A BIT belatedly but with no less enthusiasm, the management of the Capitol celebrated the theatre's twenty-fifth anniversary last Wednesday night in conjunction with the premiere of "Thirty Seconds Over Tokyo." Actually, however, Messmore Kendall, president of the Capitol, should have sliced that six-foot birthday cake on Oct. 24.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 18 -- Swarthmore's football team scored its first triumph over Princeton today, a third-period field goal by Dave Work providing the Garnet with its 3-0 victory. In nine previous meetings between the two colleges, the first of which was held in 1902, the Pennsylvanians had never been successful.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- The French resistance movement, judging from party meetings held yesterday and today, seems to have come to the conclusion that after all it may be preferable to face the electorate next February as a bloc rather than as dispersed elements.

AFTER twenty-seven months, the musicians' union ban on the making of new recordings has ended with the capitulation of the two major recording companies -- RCA Victor and Columbia -- and most collectors are wondering what these companies are going to do with their new lease on life.
MANY of the thirty exhibitions cited below deserve much more extended comment than space permits. Herewith are offered some signposts in the flood.

LONDON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Marshal Tito's National Committee of Liberation and the Yugoslav exile Government in London were reported tonight to have agreed to establish a regency in Yugoslavia soon and to hold a plebiscite after the war to determine whether King Peter is to return to his throne.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 18 -- There never was a moment when Yale's unconquered football team, in its encounter with the Tarheels of the University of North Carolina before 10,000 chilled spectators in the Bowl today, was in danger of being upset.

Disclosing that the speed of our advances in the European and Pacific war theatres has imposed a heavy drain upon reserves of certain vital supplies, Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet, called last night for unabated war bond purchases to continue the manufacture of tools of victory, now falling behind "mounting requirements."

GREAT LAKES, Ill., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Great Lakes' sturdy Bluejackets, playing reserves most of the way and minus Coach Paul Brown, rolled over Marquette University by 32 -- 0 today for their eighth triumph of the season against a lone defeat by Ohio State and a tie with Purdue.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 18 -- So pleased are Louisiana Republican leaders over their party's vote in this State that they have commenced perfecting new organizations and strengthening old ones in every parish.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Uprooting of the ideologies which violate the rights of man in countries which America is liberating, and justice for all nations secured by law are among the fundamentals for a world security organization as set forth in a statement today by the Catholic Bishops of the United States at the close of their annual meeting here.

DAWN POWELL has extended her claims to versatility in this new novel of Ohio. "My Home Is Far Away" is a considerable accomplishment in an area distinguished for its mediocre products. Stories of American family life of a few decades ago have enjoyed a tremendous vogue both in fiction and on the stage for some time now, but, for one reason or another, have failed to produce more than one or two memorable examples.

The speed of this latest bomb is 3,500 miles an hour, we were told with a straight face, and the altitude attained is fifty miles. More recent accounts give 1,000 miles an hour and fifty-five to sixty miles as the height attained.

EVERY resource of the motion-picture industry, both theatrical and non-theatrical, has been mobilized to help put over the top the $14,000,000,000 Sixth War Loan Drive, which starts tomorrow and continues through Dec. 16.

DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 18 -- Roundup time in Texas and the Southwest this year sees ranges teeming with cattle, a parade of millions of dollars' worth of sirloins on the hoof, and a fairly bright outlook for civilians hoping to decorate their winter dinner tables with good red beef.

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 19 (U.P.) -- Soviet tanks and infantry yesterday tore three breaches in the eighty-mile long German-Hungarian defense line running northeast from Budapest to Miskolc and hammered through stubborn resistance to within three and one-half miles of the latter city.
BOSTON, Nov. 18 -- Educators in the New England States are beginning to wonder if there will be enough school teachers to go around a few years hence.

TWICE during the performances the Boston Symphony Orchestra gave at its first New York concert of the present season in Carnegie Hall, the audience threatened to get out of hand. It ignored the conductor's back, after movements of both the Beethoven "Eroica" and Berlioz's "Harold" symphony, and commenced to applaud.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 -- The amended plan of recapitalization of the Standard Gas and Electric Company was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Heller, national chairman of the United Palestine Appeal at the opening session of the National Conference for Palestine.

WILLIAM STEIG'S faintly terrifying Small Fry are not, of course, drawn for the attention of eight-year-olds but for their harassed parents and other elders. What they prove to the parents and elders is that eight-year-olds do not change from one generation to another, that the world of childhood is compounded of miniature terrors and glorious day-dreams, and that Mr. Steig -- not to put too fine a point upon it -- is wonderful.

Shortly after he had moved into the somber, paneled office where the boss of New York's Finest holds sway. I went to see him and he outlined some of the things he hoped to accomplish.

Now that most of the leaves have been grounded, the autumn pilgrimages of the squirrels are plainly visible to those who would watch the treetops. They have been there all summer, those graceful aerialists, doing their amazing acrobatics as they followed familiar treetop highways; but now they are in plain sight as they travel from hickory to oak to walnut to beech.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 18 (Reuter) -- Belgium, overrun by war twice within a generation, has officially renounced forever her pre-war policies of neutrality and independence, Paul-Henri Spaak, the Foreign Minister, said today on his return from London and before his departure on Tuesday for vital conversations with the French Government.

ON THE OUTSKIRTS OF METZ, France, Nov. 18 -- For the first time in history Metz was entered today by a frontal assault. American troops stormed their way into the northern and southern parts of the ancient fortress and held while supporting units in the arc on the north, south and west kept up the pressure.

Dr. Charles Farnham Collins, 84 years old, consulting pediatrician at St. Luke's Hospital, was critically injured at 7:25 o'clock last night when he was struck by an automobile turning into Seventy-seventh Street from Park Avenue. The accident occurred a few steps from Dr. Collins' home and office at 863 Park Avenue. The car was driven by Albert Schwab of 22 East 125th Street.

THE experts who have been following the fortunes of the Washington Redskins this season insist that the secret of their success rests in the finest collection of four-leaf clovers, rabbits' feet and horseshoes in America. Be that as it may, however, no one has vanquished them yet and the closest anyone has come to it has been the zany 31-31 tie with the Philadelphia Eagles.

IT'S Thanksgiving on the farm. From our warm kitchen we look across the countryside at rolling fields, stretches of woods, clusters of buildings set in a hollow, at the crest of a knoll or hugging the road. We see the house, barn, tool-shed and corncrib, which in this quiet Virginia district mean a working enterprise, a family, a home.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Relations with Bulgaria and Rumania were re-established today when the State Department announced the appointment of two foreign service officers who are specialists on southeastern Europe as United States representatives in Bulgaria and Rumania with the personal rank of Minister.

AMERICAN history is moving fast. The political platforms written at Chicago only a few months ago were the ambiguous products of politicians uncertain of themselves in a crisis. But in the recent election the American people reached a bold and fundamental decision, and the Seventy-ninth Congress, which will represent them for the next two years, holds a mandate that would have seemed unlikely six months ago -- the mandate of a broad international foreign policy.

Election of Albert E. Watts as executive vice president of the Sinclair Oil Corporation was announced yesterday, along with several other changes in personnel. These included the naming of Sheldon Clark as chairman of the executive committee and Leland V. Stanford to the board of directors.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Syracuse University Football Coach Ossie Solem was carried from sunny Archbold Stadium in triumph today after his Orange gridders piled up seven touchdowns to upset favored Andy Kerr-coached Colgate in the teams' forty-fifth meeting, 43 -- 13.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 18 (AP) -- The rubbery right arm of Bob Hoernschemeyer, the Western Conference's leading passer, hurled Indiana University out of a two-game football losing streak today and completed the Hoosiers' home season with a 47-to-0 triumph over Pittsburgh.

An acute shortage of better dolls for Christmas looms, as manufacturers are shipping only about 80 per cent of the orders they took, which were allotments of purchases in previous years, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

THE Maffia, the old Italian secret society devoted to murder, blackmail, bombing and theft, has again sprung to vigorous life in Sicily just sixteen years after Benito Mussolini declared it dead forever. The violence of the new outburst of holdups and kidnappings reported from Palermo is reminiscent of the wave of gang terrorism that swept New York from 1899 to 1916, when the criminal Maffiosi, or Black Hands, preyed upon the city's 600,000 Italian immigrants.

RICHMOND, Nov. 18 -- Many observers have been puzzled to explain the fact that Virginians voted in the recent Presidential election in considerably larger numbers than ever before, whereas there was a decrease in the total vote of the four States in the upper South.

A program which will materially assist New York City industries in the reconversion period has been formulated by the war contracts division of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, according to the forty-seventh annual report of the organization released yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- As a result of the financial discussions of the past few days -- including that at a Cabinet meeting yesterday when Pierre Mendes-France, Minister of National Economy, lost his battle against the Ministry of Finance on the issue of drastic deflation -- it can now be indicated on high authority what the French Government's financial policy will be in the immediate future.

ROME, Nov. 18 -- Marshal Tito has asked London Yugoslav Government authorities to send twenty military chaplains, Catholic and Orthodox, to be enlisted in his forces, it was learned today. As far as Catholic chaplains are concerned the Vatican has given its permission.

The pace of gift shopping increased here last week, while colder iweather spurred the call for seasonal merchandise, including furs. Sales gains over last year by department stores ranged to 15 per cent or more.

WITH ALLIED FORCES in Germany, Nov. 18 -- The British troops who entered this part of Germany soon after the latest Allied push began yesterday were making a determined attempt late today to cut off Geilenkirchen from the rest of the Reich.
