TORONTO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Maple Leafs retained first place in the National Hockey League by coming from behind tonight to beat the Black Hawks, 5 to 4, before 13,162 fans.
IOWA CITY, Iowa, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Minnesota, packing a punch similar to those carried by the Gopher powerhouses of the prewar era, routed Iowa, 46 to 0, today.

BOTH artist and author of this story-picture book eater heartily into the child's mind when he indulges in a game of make-believe with toy or imaginary animals. In this case, "Katy No-Pocket" is an unfortunate kangaroo without a pocket in which to carry her baby.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Presentation of technical subcommittee reports at a plenary session of Committee II of the International Civil Aviation Conference here today, together with discussion of them, revealed that the United States is in a position to start world-wide air service on high standards of safety and efficiency this spring if war conditions permit.

BEING a man of industry, A.L. Berman is busy hatching a series of plans that will carry him well into 1945 and box-office receipts permitting, perhaps beyond. Mr. Berman, for instance, is hoping to get into production with "Moonlight Mazourka," a product from the L. Bush-Fekete -- Mary Helen Fay team. The book should be ready for Mr. Berman right after the first of the year.

IN May, 1940, when the Nazi plane-tank team broke through at Sedan and crushed France beneath its irresistible might, Dwight David Eisenhower was a lieutenant colonel in the Regular Army, on duty as the regimental executive officer of the Fifteenth Infantry at Fort Lewis, Wash.

IN the Spring of 1942 the United States faced a serious condition along the Atlantic coast. The German submarines had come. Ships were being sunk by the score off the New Jersey beaches where the steamer routes of all the world converge on the port of New York, off Florida where the oil tankers make the turn out of the Gulf of Mexico, and off the Virginia Capes.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 -- The old gray mare may not be what she used to be, but there's nothing wrong with Army's mule. In fact, she's still plenty speedy, as Pennsylvania discovered to its utter dismay here on Franklin Field today before 66,000 spectators who sat in awe and "oh'd and ah'd" as Army's plethora of speedy backs raced to nine touchdowns to continue their point-a-minute-plus pace.

Among the highlights of the fifty-second annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, which closed Friday evening in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, was a paper delivered by John E. Slater, executive vice president of the American Export Line, in which he undertook to analyze the economic considerations in the design of future combination passenger and cargo ships.

LET the fanfare be sounded this morning for the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and a young Englishman named Lister Sinclair, writer and allow in Mathematics at the University of Toronto. Last Sunday over the Trans-Canada network which is operated by the Dominion government, they presented as vigorous and courageous radio spousal of democracy as has ached these ears since the war's start.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Nov. 18 -- It has now been confirmed by responsible Swiss church circles that about 400 Roman Catholic priests have been arrested in Germany since the beginning of October. All of them were members of the former Catholic Center party.

DECORATIONS for the Thanksgiving table have come a long way since the first New England gardener celebrated his first harvest. Technically, of course, we date Thanksgiving from the Pilgrims, but spiritually it is the gardener's own day, and as old as Adam.

Predicting a $507,016,000 post-war passenger car market in the area covered by New York City, Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk Counties, Harry M. Williams, president of the Automobile Merchants Association of New York Inc., said yesterday that women's influence on the purchase of these vehicles will increase, it is estimated, from 15 to 20 per cent over the pre-war period.

FOR the first time in several years Broadway now finds itself aroused over the question of censorship. For many months, while such plays as "Men to the Sea" met difficulties in New Haven and Boston, New York sat easily in the smug feeling it could not happen here.
LONDON, Nov. 18 (UP) -- A communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

EMILY KIMBROUGH'S heart was "young and gay" long before she met Cornelia Otis Skinner and they made their maiden voyage to Europe together; long before they followed their "hearts" to Hollywood to film their reminiscences of that mis-adventurous trip.

IT seems to rain at least once every day here. Sometimes it is only a light drizzle that American farmers call "a sod soaker." Sometimes it is a heavy, driving rain known to farmers as "a gully washer." It may rain for only a few minutes or it may rain for hours.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- The British delegation at the International Civil Aviation Conference received word from London tonight that the British Cabinet had approved in principle the American-British-Canadian agreement here on the degree of power to be delegated to the proposed international body to deal with post-war commercial aviation.

From Moscow comes an account of Soviet Science cabled by Prof. Valentine Dityakin which emphasizes the importance of planning research for a period of five years. Major planning of science is done by the Academy of Sciences, which is as much a part of the Government as the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

THEY took him from abject misery to the pound, a shabby wreck of a horse who could barely remember his better days. There is no more moving theme in horse stories than that of the neglected has-been, especially if, as in this one, it is based on fact. Mr. Brown, however, doesn't dwell too long on the painful side of life.

THIS is the latest in a series of occult writings which Arkham House has been exhuming from the pages of Weird Tales, Wonder Stories Strange Tales and Astounding Stories, to be enshrined in book form. This one, even more than its horrifying predecessors -- the collected works of H.P. Lovecraft, Henry S. Whitehead and Donald Wandrei -- deserves to be put on the shelf and admired; it cannot be read.

THIS is an important volume and it is also one of the most delightful books this reviewer has ever read. Printed on a format a little larger than usual, and in large print, it contains 200 photographs portraying as nothing else could the majesty of the TVA undertaking and its many-sided stimulation of the life of the valley people.

Thirty additional inspectors were assigned yesterday by the Office of Price Administration to try to find the black marketers whose grip on the Thanksgiving poultry sales in this city had been brought to light earlier in the week by the War Food Administration and other official agencies.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- In case the Germans still are wondering what happened to their submarine U-570 back in August, 1941, they are not going to like this.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Jim Brennan, 155 pounds of backfield dynamite, gave 48,000 fans cause to forget the loss of Bob Kelly, Notre Dame's ace half-back, as he exploded twice in the first seven minutes of play to lead the Fighting Irish to a 21-0 victory over Northwestern today.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- The 1944 hunting season, with the Moore County Hounds, will get into full swing Thanksgiving Day, starting what promises to be an active hunting year. Thursday's fox hunt will start from the Mile-Away Farms of Mr. and Mrs. W.O. Moss and will be over a rugged hunting country of black jacks, slash pines and swamps.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 18 -- Argentina's plan for "pre-conscription" military training beginning at the age of 12 for both boys and girls is aimed at improving youth health standards rather than the formation of "infantile battalions," a special communique said tonight.

WITH AMERICAN FIRST ARMY IN GERMANY, Nov. 18 -- It was just hard slugging again today along the whole American First Army front, with gains of varying depths, none of them spectacular. Today, however, the sun shone brightly all day, and our air force made up for yesterday's almost total blank with terrific onslaughts on every sort of target from assemblies of German infantry to moving railroad trains.

IN reference to the program of French chamber music to be given this afternoon by the New Friends of Music in Town Hall, Hortense Monath, who guides the organization's artistic policies, explains that in presenting French chamber music as a unit in the current series of concerts the New Friends were animated by the conviction that the characteristics of the musical resurgence in France are particularly clearly defined in this category.

SINCE books are mental food, just as meals are food for the body, there ought to be an analogy in these terms for every book. Under these rules Maura Laverty's novel resembles a cup of coffee and a doughnut at 11 A.M.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 18 -- Firing a double salvo that sank Purdue's hopes midway in the opening quarter, Navy scored a 32-0 victory in the Municipal Stadium today to end the formalities preliminary to its game of games with Army on the same field two weeks hence.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- Ed Faillace, diminutive half-back, thrilled 10,000 fans as the undefeated White Plains eleven gained a 21-to-7 victory over New Rochelle High School's W.I.A.A. champions today.

THE amazing current-day demand for American postage stamps which rank among the recognized classics resulted last week in one of the most spectacular auctions in philately's annals. The estate of Col. E.H.R. Green offered at public sale through Harmer, Rooke Co. another section of the Green $1,700,000 collection.

THIS first novel, winner of the third Dodd, Mead Intercollegiate Literary Fellowship, reveals a bright, sharp talent. Catherine Lawrence's mind is equipped with a complete set of scalpels. She opens her worlds and her people as expertly as a surgeon and probes as tenderly and as carefully for the source of irritation.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS ON LEYTE, Nov. 18 -- All the American and Japanese naval strength as well as all the ground power that can be mustered and brought to bear by both sides are concentrated in the Battle of Leyte. On the outcome depends in considerable measure the future progress of the campaign in the northern Philippines and beyond.

Plans adopted by the Combined Raw Materials Board for the distribution of cattle hides, sole and upper leather to liberated countries of Continental Europe, tentatively placed on a ninety-day basis, are regarded by leather interests and the consuming industries in the United States generally as being indicative of additional drains on already critically short domestic supplies that will submerge hopes for an end to shoe rationing for an indefinite period.
PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Eniwetok Atoll in the western Marshall group is being used by the United States Navy as a ship repair base.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Alabama's Crimson Tide got the jump on Mississippi State today in the first minute of play and was never threatened as it rolled to a surprise 19-to-0 victory to knock the Maroons off the unbeaten list.

Recalling that Premier Marshal Joseph Stalin had termed artillery the "god of war" and had always "paid great attention to its development," the Tass Agency said yesterday that today would be celebrated throughout the Soviet Union as "Artillery Day."

THIS is an album of nightgown and union suit art, based pretty much on the short and simple annals of tenement house dwellers. Most of the cartoons have appeared in Esquire, College Humor, Collier's and The New Yorker.

PANAMA, Nov. 17 (Delayed) -- El Salvador now has an underground newspaper, the Gazette of the Strike, that appears daily and gives news of civil resistance against the Government of Col. Osmin Aguirre y Salinas. All newspapers except the Gran Diario, former mouthpiece of the dictator, Gen. Maxundiano Hernandez Martinez, and th Diario de Hoy, have suspended publication and the latter has been boycotted by the public.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Sofia and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

FROM London comes word that Syria overprinted four postage stamps and one air-mail item with "Abu-Ula Ma'ari, Commemoration of the 1,000th Year 363-1363" in Arabic, to celebrate the millenary of Abu-l-Ala Ul-Ma'ari (973-1057), poet and philosopher.

WILLIAM SAROYAN has had another affair with his heart, and he calls the little one "Dear Baby." It is somewhat underweight (117 pages) and not so lusty as the others have been, but it's a Saroyan, all right.

Broad changes in the Government's housing policies for the post-war period, aimed at providing decent homes throughout the nation for all families in the low-income brackets, were announced here yesterday by Philip M. Klutznick, Commissioner of the Federal Public Housing Authority.

TODAY any casual social group which makes an attempt at conversation that is general but also responsible is constantly impeded by the sense that no member can possibly claim competence in more than one or two very limited fields.

The Musicians Emergency Fund, which for several years has sponsored the opening performance of the Ice Follies at Madison Square Garden, again will be the beneficiary of the premiere of the annual skating show, which occurs Tuesday night.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

BALTIMORE, Nov. 18 -- In a bristling finish, reminiscent of the most famous Pimlico Futurities, the Calumet Farm's Pot o' Luck today won the $40,130 renewal of the mile and a sixteenth test which is Maryland's greatest race for young horses.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- It's the Treasury and War Finance Committee of Maryland that you're looking for -- if you want a ticket to the Army-Navy football game at Baltimore on Dec. 2.

To Washington observers the atmosphere on Capitol Hill last Week suggested the post-mortem talk after a football game, or the cracker-barrel discussions at a country store. After an eight-week campaign recess the Seventy-eighth Congress was back for its final, or lame-duck, session.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Under the present form of the law providing for loans to veterans to buy homes, farms and businesses, there is the possibility that future pensions paid to disabled veterans may be attached by the Government if they should default on their obligations.

BOSTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Coastguardsmen rescued eleven men and a twelfth saved himself during a howling northeast storm yesterday off Sandwich, on Cape Cod, when a barge foundered and a tug, attempting a rescue, was driven hard aground.
The cotton market continued yesterday to hold steady, although the trading range on the New York Cotton Exchange was narrow. Final prices were 2 points higher to 2 points lower than on Friday.
The Tokyo radio declared yesterday that the Cabinet of Premier Kuniaki Koiso was ready for the "decisive battle."
What has happened to Adolf Hitler?

A STORY with convincing outdoor atmosphere, fine family relationships and a mystery that is solved in a perfectly credible manner by three unspoiled, natural young people. The background is supplied by the building of the Ashokan Reservoir.

ANITA PETTIBONE'S second historical novel redemonstrates her graceful ability to write about "tough" men in a warm, humorous manner. This quality makes "Johnny Painter" -- both the character and the book -- quite likable: the vein of subdued wit that runs in both lifts this novel somewhat above much picaresque fiction of its sort.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 18 (AP) -- A United States Army Forces in China communique:

AGAIN this year the Office of Defense Transportation asks the public to refrain from traveling during the Christmas holidays. An official communication has been sent by the ODT to all Federal bureaus requesting that leaves be not granted to employes between Dec. 15 and Jan. 8.

WHAT sort of feast shall we savor this Thanksgiving? This was the question we put to four gourmets, after telling them that turkeys and cranberries would be scarce and even roasting chickens might be hard to come by. To judge from their ready replies, our experts were not stumped by the holiday food shortage.

By applying Gregor Mendel's laws of heredity, poultry breeders years ago produced a far better turkey than its ancestor which strutted in colonial barnyards. The poultry breeders were taught their trade by specialists in our paternalistic national and State departments of agriculture.

It occurs to a serious-minded person that there ought to be a law regulating imponderables. They are everlastingly messing things up in this uncertain world. A general staff plans a battle to the last detail and along comes an imponderable and knocks trhe plan for a loop.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Oklahoma, Big Six defending champion, battered its way to a 20-0 triumph over the Jayhawkers of Kansas today and assured itself of at least a tie for first place in the conference this year.

Since Washington has let down in its opposition to him, General de Gaulle has made considerable strides in establishing his provisional government of France. With an army fighting before Belfort and with his admission to a degree into the councils of the leading United Nations, the French leader is about to go to Moscow to confer with Stalin and his aides. Very much may hinge on the outcome.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The President at his Friday press conference endorsed compulsory national service for American youth and thereby advanced the date when Congress will consider legislation. His statement also greatly improved the prospect that this consideration will be favorable. But the President declined to take sides on the chief point in dispute, which is whether this national service shall be of military nature and under military controls.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Arrivals of hogs today were 7,500 head, but only 500 were salable, the remainder going direct to packers. Receipts were too small to make a market and prices were nominally steady. Compared with a week ago, hogs weighing 270 pounds and less were 10 to 25 cents lower; those over 270 pounds and sows were steady.

Reflecting the influence of the Army program, colleges and universities throughout the United States are now experimenting with new methods of teaching foreign languages. Typical institutions report that drastic revisions are being made; during the post- war period still further reforms can be expected.

" THEY DREAM OF HOME" is a novel with few literary pretensions. In treatment and in effect, it's remarkably like a picture magazine feature. It sets out to study a topical problem: the American soldier's readjustment to civilian life.

MEDFORD Mass., Nov. 18 (U.P.) -- Harvard's sailor-studded football team put the finishing touches on its informal season today by nosing out a spirited Tufts eleven, 12 to 6, before 5,000 shivering spectators at Tufts Oval.

Describing himself as "more or less a sailor," although he arrived here yesterday morning in the uniform of a British Army chaplain he is permitted to wear as an honor, the Right Rev. Walter Hubert Baddeley, Lord Bishop of Melanesia, an Anglican missionary diocese in the South Pacific, told of his problems in islands inhabited by natives speaking thirty-one distinct languages.

Mail-order, amusement and coal shares were the strongest features in a directionless session of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Stocks drifted irregularly and closed mixed. THE NEW YORK TIMES rail average rose 0.02 to 31.23; the industrial average, 0.14 to 172.05, and the combined average, 0.08 to 101.64.

Although we all realize that Germany is not yet defeated, constant discussion goes on as to what is to be done about Germany. Some persons seem to have an idea that the Allies themselves will be able to set up a democratic or liberal government in Germany and maintain it. Of course that is nonsense.

THIS brief, early novel by the author of the eleven-volume "Men of Good Will" was first published in 1911. In France a movement called Unaminism was going on, and Jules Romains was the acknowledged chef d'ecole.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 18 -- Maj. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, commander of United States forces in the China theatre, said today he had made recommendations to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek for dispositions -- "simple and I hope sound" -- to meet the enemy's capabilities in China.

Boys and girls and some of their elders largely filled Carnegie Hall yesterday morning for the first Young People's Concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra; Rudolph Ganz conducting, in the twenty-second season of these events.

Plans are rapidly nearing completion for the annual bazaar, known as "Ye Old English Faire," to be given in behalf of the Victoria Home for Aged British Men and Women on Nov. 29 and 30, and Dec. 1 in the main ballroom of the Biltmore under the auspices of the State organization of the Daughters of the British Empire.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Penn State smashed out a 34-to-19 victory over the University of Maryland today, scoring in every period, despite the absence of running star Johnny Chuckran sidelined by injuries last week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Robert Doellner of Hartford, Conn., and Camargo Guarnieri of Brazil were judged the winners in the first Western Hemispheric contest for the composition of the best string quartet, Marcel Ancher, founder of the Washington Chamber Music Guild, announced today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
KANDY, Ceylon, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A communique:

BALTIMORE, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Maryland War Finance Committee, announced tonight that Army Navy football tickets available to the public would be sold on a first come first served basis beginning tomorrow.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 19 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor today unanimously refused the invitation of the British Trade Union Congress to attend a world labor conference in London on Feb. 8 to discuss labor's role in the peace and the formattion of an all-inclusive world labor federation to include the Soviet trade unions and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

A syndicate headed by Irving Brodsky, attorney, purchased from the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank the four-story and penthouse apartment-building for thirty-two families at 306-10 Huguenot Street, New Rochelle, in Westchester County.

PARIS, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Parisians got their first glimpse of American football today when the United States Ninth Air Force Thunderbolts defeated the First General Hospital Terrors, 6 to 0, before a 22,000 crowd.

The Hotel Stratford, a twelve-story and penthouse building containing two elevators and 175 rooms at 11 East Thirty-second Street, adjoining the corner of Fifth Avenue, has been purchased by an investor through Adams Co.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- The railway bridge across the Loire River at Orleans will be opened for traffic within a few days, thanks to the work of French engineers and to steel provided by the Engineers Corps of the United States Army.

The Grosvenor Debutante Ball, which will be given Dec. 9 in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton, will be preceded by many dinners in the Oval Room serving to introduce to society some of the debutantes of the new season.

A plan for a periodic "merit review" system for wage increases for workers within "specific rate ranges has been adopted by the Regional War Labor Board, Thomas L. Norton, the chairman, announced yesterday. Public and labor members of the board concurred in adoption of the proposal, with industry members dissenting,

Mayor La Guardia, speaking yesterday morning at the Community Church service in Town Hall, pleaded for "right thinking and right living, and, above all, a complete understanding of your fellow-man" as the approach to a full and lasting peace.

Jan Smeterlin, pianist, gave the first of a series of three Chopin recitals yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The program comprised the four Ballades; all of the twenty-four Preludes; the Waltzes in F major, Op. 34, No. 3, and in A flat, Op. 64, No. 3; Nocturne in G major, Op. 37, No. 2, and Ma zurka in A minor, Op. 17, No. 4.

Bishop William T. Manning of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, speaking yesterday at the centennial service of the Church of the Holy Apostles, Ninth Avenue and Twenty-eighth Street, said the stress of the times calls for the utmost in service and loyalty from church leaders and the laity.

ABOARD LORD ASHBOURNE'S TASK FORCE FLAGSHIP in Mapia Islands, Pacific, Nov. 15 (Delayed) (AP) -- An officer of the British Navy commanded an American amphibious operation for the first time in the Pacific war when United States troops swarmed ashore and occupied Peguri, largest island of the Mapia group, ying between Netherland New Guinea and the Philippines, today.

The thirty-eighth annual Christmas Seal campaign will get under way today with the delivery of 66,000,000 of the penny stickers to homes throughout the city. The appeal, which ends on Christmas Day, is conducted locally by the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association simultaneously with some 2,500 other communities throughout the nation. The local organization's goal is $350,000, which finances a year-round anti-tuberculosis program, rehabilitation of patients, X-rays, and social and mental hygiene.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

ROME, Nov. 19 -- The situation of the Italian Partisans in German-occupied Italy is going to become tragic as a result of Gen. Sir Harold R.L.G. Alexander's orders to patriots to cease operations until further notice, according to information from northern Italy received by Rome SI agency.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Sharp criticism of the War Labor Board and of the National Labor Relations Board was expressed by Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, in a report prepared for presentation to the convention of the CIO made public today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Accounts handled by the Army's Office of Dependency Benefits represent more than 14,000,000 persons, a tenth of the population, and cover $6,500,000,000 in a little more than two years.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Total net profits after taxes increased 10 per cent in 1943 over 1942 in sixteen industry groups manufacturing wartime products, according to the second part of a Securities and Exchange Commission study on profits and operations of American listed corporations.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman formally dedicated and blessed the new St. Joseph's Branch of the Cathedral High School for Girls yesterday afternoon in a ceremony at the former parochial grammar school, 109-111 Washington Place.

Army and Navy -- there they stand. Come Dec 2, even a nation at war will pause for a few breathless hours as two of the mightiest football forces ever to come out of West Point and Annapolis have it out for national supremacy in good, clean fun, but hard.
Santa Claus left yesterday from La Guardia Field, speeding North, not in a sleigh drawn by reindeer but in a four-engine transport plane.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A statement issued today by Fred M. Vinson, Director of Economic Stabilization, was viewed here as an indication that the Administration is not contemplating a general upward revision of the "Little Steel" formula governing wages.

HAVANA, Nov. 19--Sugar producers are still firm in their refusal to accept less than 3.25 cents a pound from the United States for the 1945-46 crop, according to Senator Delio Nunez Mesa of Oriente Province and Dr. Tomas Puyans, treasurer of the National Cane Planters Association.

All markets moved uncertainly last week, as a rule going lower. In stocks, transactions were fairly large; on Tuesday they exceeded 1,000,000 shares. Although there was much of interest in the week's foreign dispatches, nothing in the actual war bulletins gave definite trend to values.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet Communique 184:

LONDON, Nov. 19 (U.P.) -- Germany must now depend on her own food resources, German Food Minister Herbert Backe said today in a gloomy, threatening speech that indicated that there was widespread passive resistance to Nazi appeals for increased farm production.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Cleveland Rams, using power plays for the most part, scored in every period today as they rolled over the hapless Chicago Cardinal Pittsburgh Steeler combination, 33 to 6. It was the Rams' fourth league victory and their second over the Car-Pitts, who have yet to win a National Football League game.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- As an earnest of the De Gaulle Government's determination that the revolution must "remain within the law," the Commissioner of the Republic in Lyon, Yves Farge, has removed the warden of Annecy prison in upper Savoie and replaced the officer commanding the French Forces of the Interior in that region.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Some Senators, including Senators who dislike the idea, expressed the opinion today that President Roosevelt would revise the Little Steel formula upward. They cited the Davis report of a wartime living-cost increase of 29 to 30 per cent and voiced the view that the report would provide a vehicle for early White House action.

A patrolman on duty in the emergency ward of Lincoln Hospital, 143d Street and Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, was injured and four detectives were painfully kicked and punched about 7 A.M. yesterday in subduing a 22-year-old Negro who sought refuge there after an alleged attack on the wife of a soldier as she neared her home a few blocks away from the hospital.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $53,110,336,926. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, non-interest bearing discount bills and notes, as follows:

METZ, France, Nov. 19 -- German forces were retreating tonight toward the Saar Valley ahead of advancing units of Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's American Third Army in what appeared to be a general withdrawal along the entire Twelfth and Twentieth Corps' front.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Communique 225:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Board of the National League of Women Voters has voted to cut its program from nine items to four to concentrate more on fields of Government which it considers most important at this time.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A move to streamline Congressional investigations by giving to one standing committee the powers of more than a score of special groups won new support today in the House.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- More realism in our lend-lease operations and return of this trade to private channels as soon as the war ends are demanded in the report of the Foreign Commerce Department Committee of the United States Chamber of Commerce made public today.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES in the Huertgen Forest, Germany, Nov. 19 (U.P.) -- Acres of dense woodland have been flattened as though by a hurricane and hundreds of enemy dead lie beneath the tangled branches, but the German is fighting like a wild man everywhere and there is no immediate decision in sight today in the battle of the Huertgen Forest.

The municipal, State and Federal Governments last year contributed $14,137,744 to educate the 32,549 boys and girls who attend City, Hunter, Brooklyn and Queens Colleges, according to a report yesterday by Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education.
ROME, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A communique:
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A supplementary communique:

When the cost of living committee of the War Labor Board was appointed early last November the President ordered that its report should be brought in within sixty days. The report now appears -- after an interval of more than a year.

New textbooks in history, literature, biology, mathematics and other school subjects are being planned by exiled German scholars residing in this country. Nearing completion is a book designed for the elementary and high school youth, containing excerpts of the best literature and writings of pre-Hitler Germany, selected to "teach appreciation for human ideals, family relationships, social responsibility, racial tolerance and religion."

UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in India, Nov. 19 -- A pipeline running all the way from Calcutta up the Brahmaputra Valley through Assam into North Burma is now delivering many thousands of tons of oil and gasoline monthly for motor vehicles and airplanes at American installations in the North Burma-Assam combat area.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- In the review of the Julius Rosenwald Fund just issued, Edwin R. Embree, president, reports that during the past two years, 1942-44, the fund expended $1,615,513 on its programs in education and race relations.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 19 -- El Wendie of Rockland does not keep records. Whether this champion boxer bitch has accumulated more points than any other of her breed in dog show history doesn't mean a thing to her. But Mr. and Mrs. Philip E. Crystal of the Rye Top Kennels of Harrison, N.Y., modestly admit that Wendie has been best in show something like twenty-four times.

Joseph E. Dyer, 24 years old, of 119 East 130th Street, who later was quoted as admitting that he had started the blaze himself, made the mistake early yesterday of stopping a Fire Department automobile to tell the location of a fire at 2101 Madison Avenue.

In front every step of the way, Jim Rafferty, veteran New York A.C. distance star, captured the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior cross-country championship over the six-mile Van Cortlandt Park hill and dale course yesterday. Rafferty, who holds the national 1,000-meter title, toured the distance in 32:13.9, to duplicate his 1940 conquest when he defeated Gene Venzke by inches.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 19 -- Steel-helmeted Belgian police, rifles slung over their shoulders, patrolled the streets of this capital tonight in the wake of a tumultuous demonstration by about 15,000 marchers shouting for the resignation of the Pierlot Government and singing "The Internationale."

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Meat packers report no change recently in the general situation of provisions, and supplies of both lard and cured meats available for sale are regarded as the smallest in many years. One large handler of hog products said he had been trying for three weeks to buy a small quantity of dry salted bellies and had been unable to get an offer in that period.

Japan may allow its American prisoners of war and civilian internees to send collect cablegrams home at the expense of the United States Government, John F. Cotton of Washington, American Red Cross Assistant National Director of Relief to Prisoners of War, told 500 next-of-kin meeting yesterday afternoon and evening in the New New York Chapter auditorium, 315 Lexington Avenue.

For women who like the unusual, there are several shops emphasizing originality in accessories and clothes. As most of the work is done to order, women may bring their own ideas to be interpreted. For example, one shop makes satin blouses with hand-painted panels forming a weskit front.

The recital given by Wanda Landowska last night in Town Hall was an extraordinarily stimulating and rewarding musical experience. For the event a noble and meaningful program had been arranged by this greatest of living harpsichordists and peerless exponents of the keyboard music of the eighteenth century composers and their predecessors.

Mayor La Guardia held out hope yesterday to the city's housewives that they may be able to get turkeys after all -- after Thanksgiving has passed. He suggested they might delay their turkey dinner for a week, while giving thanks next Thursday for their other blessings.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Nov. 19 -- This was just Nov. 19 to the rest of the world, but it was Christmas for little Forest (Nubbins) Hoffman, 3 years old -- a white one at that. Even nature joined in making what probably will be Nubbins' last Christmas on earth a happy one.

WITH THE AMERICANS AT BLAMONT, France, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Two platoons of noisy Americans, yelling like hogcallers and firing their weapons as fast as they could pull the triggers, chased more than 400 Germans from Blamont before daybreak today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Removal of some of the uncertainties in regard to the Government program to support the wheat market, imposition of the permit system to regulate the flow of cash corn to leading markets and revocation of the order compelling distillers to use 10 per cent of rye in production of industrial alcohol stimulated trading in futures last week on the Chicago Board of Trade.

For the first time the war has given manufacturers, particularly those making food and appliances, a chance to ponder long enough to collect facts and interpret them on the problems and solutions faced for many years, it is pointed out by Albert Haring, Professor of Marketing, of Indiana University.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 20 (UP) -- Russian troops, cracking an eighty-mile-long enemy defense line northeast of Budapest, yesterday captured the fortified communications center of Gyoengyoes, thirty-six miles northeast of the Hungarian capital and one of four major bastions guarding roads to Austria and Czechoslovakia.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- Assemblyman Frank J. Sellmayer Jr. of Penfield was re-elected to represent the new First Assembly District, a final canvass disclosed last night.

Civilians who might have use for an obsolete or used Army assault boat in the near future are invited by the United States Maritime Commission to buy 4,755 of the craft at a top retail price of $75 each. They may be purchased at various dates from Nov. 20 to Dec. 13 from depots in five cities.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 19 (AP) -- A big, experienced Motor Torpedo Boat squadron football team from Melville, R.I., today defeated a youthful Holy Cross College eleven, 13 -- 12, despite the college Crusaders' gallant bid for victory.

President Roosevelt opened the Sixth War Loan drive, in which the citizens of the United States are asked to subscribe for $14,000,000,000 of war bonds, by reminding the nation last night in a radio address from Washington that the war is costing us $250,000,000 a day.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- The National Conference on Palestine closed its two-day session tonight by adopting an eight-point program for Palestine and Jewish refugee problems.

The American Women's Association award for eminent achievement for 1944 was presented yesterday to Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, 85-year-old champion of women's rights, by Mrs. J. Borden Harriman at the eighteenth annual friendship reunion tea held at the Hotel Biltmore.

Uniforms of members of the armed forces will be much in evidence in the tier formerly known as the "Diamond Horseshoe" of the Metropolitan Opera House in the new season that begins next Monday night with Gounod's "Faust."

A chapel altar cross and twenty-one stained glass windows in memory of Adelaide Sheldon, who died in 1942, were dedicated yesterday at the 11 A.M. service in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

Two dead men were found within a few hours of each other in Brooklyn early yesterday morning under circumstances that indicated they might have been the victims of muggers. Autopsies diclosed that both died of asphyxiation.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- An avalanche of cash corn hit terminal markets last week, local receipts aggregating nearly 5,500,000 bushels, making about 12,000,000 bushels so far this month. The arrivals exceeded the ability of elevators to unload the grain, resulting in accumulations on track and necessitating the imposition of the permit system to regulate the movement from the country.

The Right Rev. Walter H. Baddeley, Lord Bishop of Melanesia, described yesterday in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine how the people of the South Pacific islands have become civilized "through the efforts of the Christian Church."

A positive program of education and institutional help, including "a normal and healthy approach to sex," consistent with Christian philosophy, is needed to prevent the breakdown in service men's marriages, Miss Florence M. Mason, assistant director of the Cleveland Catholic Charities Bureau, told 600 delegates to the Thirtieth National Conference of Catholic Charities at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn last night.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 19 -- Pacific Fleet forces of undisclosed size sped into enemy waters in the Volcano Islands nine days ago for a pre-dawn surface bombardment that set off explosions and started large fires, Fleet Headquarters announced today.
DETROIT, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Scoring four times through the air, the Lions carved out a topheavy 41-to-21 victory over the Chicago Bears today before 21,960 fans.

Upton Close's charges last week that he had been dismissed as a commentator for the National Broadcasting Company because of "pressure" by Communist or Government sources on the network were characterized as "completely false" yesterday by Niles Trammel. NBC president.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Monday, Nov. 20 -- The Japanese fought desperately in torrential rain yesterday in an attempt to break the American block across the northern end of the Ormoc-Pinamopoan Road, which has isolated their advanced forces in Leyte's Ormoc Valley in a pocket around the village of Limon.
The War Production Board has made a survey of the wants of 4,500 American families and prepared a list of household articles that homefolk yearn for most.
Seven new films, including Mexican and French importations, are scheduled to arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:
The great offensive in the West that has now been set in motion must meet and defeat at least three major obstacles to victory.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles today crushed the Washington Redskins, 37 to 7, to take first place in the Eastern division of the National Football League before a crowd of 35,540.

Clarence C. Van Blarcum has been appointed liquor sales manager for the eastern district of McKesson Robbins, Inc.; Paul W. Forrette, San Francisco; J.B. Wilson, Jacksonville, Fla., with Manly Leavell as assistant.

Among automobile manufacturers and dealers alike opinion is practically unanimous that the era of automobile purchase and use which will follow the end of the war will be by far the most active that the country ever has seen. The year 1941 marked the high point in passenger-car registration, when 29,507,133 were registered.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The reduction of the German fortress city of Aachen was delayed by a shortage of ammunition, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower said today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- An official spokesman for the International Civil Aviation Conference announced tonight that the final draft of the compromise agreement among the American, British and Canadian Governments on the kind of world organization to handle post-war commercial aviation should be ready tomorrow and should be presented to the conference at a plenary session the following day.

The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Church, Methodist, at Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, said yesterday morning that the post-war view of churches must be enlarged by world outlooks and unified by interdenominational programs.
The New York Americans defeated Brooklyn Hispano at Starlight Park yesterday in an American Soccer League game, 5 to 3, before 3,000 fans.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- The crisis in Belgium illustrates the prime political problem of every liberated country. It has been solved for the moment in France, where a Government decree ordering incorporation of the FFI in the regular army has met with remarkable if not total compliance.

Esmond Shaw, Professor of Architecture at Cooper Union, disclosed in an interview yesterday that girls now form more than 77 per cent of the school's total enrollment. Before the war only 15 per cent of those at the evening session were women, he said.

Mayor La Guardia acknowledged yesterday the authorship of the city's policy of refusing to employ realty men and architects who have given expert testimony against the city in certiorari proceedings for reduction of assessed valuations on real estate.

The Holden Realty Corporation bought the two-story store building on a plot 77 by 97 feet at 237-41 East 198th Street, near Valentine Avenue, in the Bronx, from a client of Joseph Howard Katz, attorney. The property is assessed at $67,000 and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $25,000 held by the Fifth Avenue Bank, as trustee.

Today the Sixth War Loan begins. Once again the American people will answer the question every fighting man has a sacred right to ask: "What sacrifice are you willing to make for freedom's sake?" Their response will be at least the $14,000,000,000 needed now to help finance the war.
This is it -- the decisive phase of the battle for Germany.

Today for the sixth time in these dark years of battle the people of the United States are starting once more to buy war bonds by the billion. But this drive is different from all the rest. On land and sea the great struggle has reached its climax. The war may last a long time yet, but the weeks or months ahead will decide its issue.

To authorize our international council member to vote, as the President's representative, for the use of force without recourse to Congress in every instance would be, it seems to me, a valid delegation of legislative power.

ROME, Nov. 19 -- After twenty-six years, during which the Fascists made great capital out of the "mutilated peace" that Italy received at the end of World War I, former Premier Vittorio Emanuele Orlando, who was primarily responsible for that peace, came out today in its defense.
The Giants penetrated Don Hutson's disguise yesterday, and once that happened the Packers' jig was go for it's an oft-proved adage what as Hutson goes, so go the Packers.

ROME, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The British Eighth Army, battling into the southeastern tip of the Po valley across innumerable rivers and canals, after breaking through the Gothic Line, has run up against a new delaying line along the Adriatic coast sector, Eighth Army Allied Headquarters said today.

MYITKYINA, Burma, Nov. 18 (delayed) (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Daniel I. Sultan, new American commander of United States and Chinese forces in India and Burma, said today that the fuel pipeline from Calcutta was "truly a steel link binding China to her allies, an artery through which we shall pump a transfusion into the sick body of China."

Declaring there is "ground for profound concern in some recent actions of the Office of Price Administration," the Economists Committee on Reconversion problems declared yesterday that such price policies during the reconversion period offer a grave threat not

Pointing to the Pope as "the only world leader before 1939 to speak against the triple evils of nazism, fascism and communism," the Rev. Thomas Lester Graham of St. Patrick's Cathedral staff, preaching there yesterday at solemn mass, warned that the Catholic Church will never cease to oppose any form of government that teaches deification of the state, the godless education of youth and the denial of family and individual rights.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Nov. 19 -- Geilenkirchen, northern pivot of the German line across the Cologne Plain, has fallen and yard by yard the infantry of three Allied armies, the American First and Ninth and the British Second, are winning the great battle for the Rhineland, a battle potentially more important than any fought in western Europe since the Allies' eruption from the St. Lo-Caen position.

Declaring that the Port of New York Authority through its constantly expanding activities "has become a distinct threat to private enterprise," the Broadway Association announced yesterday that it had asked the Board of Estimate to request the New York State Legislature to curtail the tax-exempt powers of the Authority.

The National Conference of Christians and Jews has started a $1,000,000 fund-raising campaign to meet the expenses of its expanded program, designed to "avert the calamity of post-war hate movements" in this country, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, president.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 19 -- Rumors that grave financial difficulties threatened Germany and some disappointment over the export plan calling for 4 cents a pound subsidy on foreign shipments were principal factors contributing last week to a softer tone in cotton futures on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange.

REMEMBER the old childhood riddle? If two trains on the same track are rushing toward each other at mile-a-minute speed -- this will simply slay you -- what are the names of the engineers? It is going to be a great deal easier to give the names of the engineers than it is to foretell what will happen when the Army and Navy unlimited expresses collide.

UNITED STATES NINTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, with the Ninth Army, Nov. 19 -- The Ninth Air Force taking advantage of a second consecutive day of superb flying weather, threw its full might at the Germans along this front today. Its attacking planes flushed Nazi transport and armor from hiding in villages along the roads between the front and the Rhine.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- Ed Raymond took the lead today in the sailing dinghy racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club. With the boat Zotom, he scored 93 points. Pat O'Gorman was second in his Felix with 90 points.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (U.P.) -- After a week of preliminary maneuvers, the expiring Seventy-eighth Congress tonight headed into the second week of its final session, facing a full legislative schedule, including initial steps toward extension of the controversial second War Powers Act.

One of the main post-war problems is the adaptation of the huge new steel mills built on the West Coast as a war measure to the supply of peacetime products. Its solution not only will foster the retention of equipment and labor that has flowed westward during the war but also will open up numerous new fields of production.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- The newspaper the Combat, which habitually is plain-speaking, said today that the Belgian crisis "should contain some lessons for us, especially since it involves the risk of Allied intervention."
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A United States Army Forces in China communique:
PARIS, Nov. 19 (U.P.) -- General de Gaulle said tonight that French troops had entered the lost province of Alsace, annexed by Germany twice in the last seventy-three years.

After a deluge of nearly half a hundred art shows, the list falls off for Thanksgiving Week, but the calendar includes several outstanding events. Among them is an exhibition of nineteenth and twentieth century American paintings -- landscapes, genre and still life -- at Knoedler's.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Sofia and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Price changes that occurred in the commodity market during the past week raised the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices (1926=100) about 0.02 per cent. This fractional gain brought the index to a new all-time high of 113.90.

ALBANY, Nov. 19 -- Supreme Court Justice Harry E. Schirick of Kingston, one of four district Supreme Court Justices accused of impropriety by Special Prosecutor George P. Monaghan in connection with Governor Dewey's investigation of Albany County affairs, struck back tonight.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- That American public opinion in its enthusiasm for private enterprise has failed to grasp to what an extent German National Socialism has made socialism in Europe inevitable, even where unwanted, has been inferred here from dispatches

Dr. Hans G. Henning has purchased for occupancy from the estate of Dr. William V. Pascual the four-story brick and stone dwelling on a lot 22 by 100 feet at 108 Eighth Avenue, near Carroll Street, in Brooklyn. The parcel is assessed at $23,000 and was sold through the Charles Partridge Real Estate Company, broker.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Japanese drive toward Kweichow Province is continuing, the Chinese High Command acknowledged tonight, with the invaders approaching Hwaiyunchen, fifty miles west of fallen Liuchow and less than forty miles from the Klangsi-Kweichow border.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- General de Gaulle said the liberation loan already was a success. "But," he continued, "mark my words well. What I want is a triumph, in the name of all and in the interest of all, a triumph for the confidence all French have in France."

Permitting their rivals a brief "hour in the sun" in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night, the Canadiens of Montreal got down to serious business in the third period and asserted their mastery. Guiding the puck through the inept New York defense with skill and smartness, the flying Frenchmen fired five shots into the local net in this final session, to gain a 6 to 2 victory.

The Kathryn Long Trust has given several scholarships and special awards this year to assist young musicians, particularly junior artists of the Metropolitan Opera company and seniors in high schools who show talent as singers, according to an announcement yesterday by Cornelius N. Bliss, chairman of the trustees.

Saint Thomas, who tips the scales at 204 pounds, ringside, and who is well over 6 feet, besides being a study in sartorial perfection, had a sudden attack of conscience yesterday morning. Thomas, by the way, is a follower of Father Divine. His real name is Thomas Reed, but he fights as Saint Thomas.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 19 -- A strike of telephone operators which already had affected twenty-four Ohio cities spread to the steel-making center of Youngstown today, with maintenance men joining the walkout.

BOSTON, Nov. 19 -- Today's communique concerning the sapless Brooklyn Tigers is, indeed, a familiar one. They lost again. This time it was to the Boston Yanks, newest entrant in the National Football League, and the score was 13 -- 6, as compared to the 17-14 setback they handed the Brooks at Ebbets Field several weeks ago.

With the exception of a marked improvement on Wednesday, cotton prices moved lower last week and a portion of the advance registered in the previous week was lost. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net declines of 5 to 17 points in contrast to gains of 28 to 40 points in the previous week.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The voice of a soloist today filled Washington Cathedral for the first time -- the tremendous voice of Miss Dorothy Maynor, Negro singer.

LONDON, Nov. 19 (U.P.) -- British troops of the Land Forces of the Adriatic, including paratroopers and Commandos who fought at Dieppe, have joined Marshal Tito's Yugoslav Army of National Liberation and Albanian patriots in the campaigns to drive the Germans from those countries, it was disclosed today.

WITH UNITED STATES NINTH ARMY in Germany, Nov. 19 -- Geilenkirchen, a mining and transportation center of about 20,000 population and the second largest German city yet taken by the Allies, was captured by an assault shortly before noon to day by combined British and American forces that scarcely paused in what now appears to be a major drive toward the Rhine and Ruhr valley.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Monday, Nov. 20 (AP) -- A communique:

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Wheat continues to show a relatively firm undertone, and although the market reacted last week about 3 cents a bushel from the early high marks, there was no material pressure, and the selling was due more to disappointment over the prospect of export business under a new Government export subsidy program than to any change in the general situation.

" The Streets Are Guarded," a phrase borrowed from the Marine Corps song, is the title of Laurence Stallings' new play, which opens tonight at Henry Miller's. In it the author again pays tribute to his gallant buddies, whose motto is "Semper Fidelis."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 19 -- Adolf Hitler paid a brief visit to Berlin on Nov. 8 to confer with Gestapo Chief Heinrich Himmler, a traveler from Germany said today. He asserted Hitler flew to the German capital from the south, presumably from Berchtesgaden, on a Wednesday and left the next morning.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs rallied for three second-period goals to defeat the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 -- 3, before 14,913 fans tonight and maintain their lead in the National Hockey League race. It was the sixth straight setback for the tail-end Black Hawks

We, the people as a whole, are more than merely indifferent. In respect to the rights of our people we are definitely ignorant and too lazy to even attempt to preserve the treasured rights we fortunately possess.

PARIS, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Within eight months France will show Europe "a grand army worthy of her" and by Spring it will be getting voluminous imports of raw materials from abroad with which to revive industry, Gen. Charles de Gaulle said today.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- At the week-end the stock markets here received a mild fillip from the news that the Allies had started a new, big push on the western front, but until traders have seen how this progresses anything approaching a real revival seems out of question.

Last minute Christmas needs and the desire to select outstanding items in Spring lines brought an influx of buyers to New York last week, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

WITH SIXTH ARMY GROUP in France, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Rapidly exploiting a break-through, Maj. Gen. Jean de Lattre de Tassigny's French First Army troops drove within three miles of historic Belfort tonight and, in a lightning flanking sweep, drove within ten miles of Mulhouse, one of the principal industrial cities in Alsace.

This year, civilians will have to forego traditional holiday purchases of boxes of Christmas cigars because of the huge shipments to various battlefronts and domestic service installations, the Cigar Institute of America announced yesterday.
The amount of latent, unused faith in persons is tremendous, but it should be applied to daily life, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of Riverside Church, said in his sermon yesterday.

A final decision that will resolve the behind-the-scenes jockeying for the post of Democratic minority leader of the State Senate, left vacant by the defeat of the veteran John J. Dunnigan of the Bronx, will not be reached until Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State chairman, returns from the South and confers with party leaders, it was revealed last night.
Your chickadee editorial was delightful and true in every sense. Let me tell you what I saw from my window, which faces a large, old, cut-leaf white maple.

A little known organization, through which fresh fruits and delicacies may be sent by wire to any part of the country, is the Fruit Telegraph Delivery Service. This season, when so many persons will be away from home for the holidays, it offers a practical way to send a useful gift to far-off relatives or friends.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 19 -- The steel industry had a clearer idea last week of its first quarter production pattern, according to trade reports. Although plate demand has been easing and will ease further as maritime demand decreases it was said that this has been offset by the influx of sheet orders.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The Economist's Index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 117.9 on Nov. 8, compared with 117.9 a fortnight and a month before, 113.8 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

The international Thanksgiving Day celebration of the Twenty-first Annual Women's International Exposition was broadcast by short wave yesterday from Madison Square Garden at the closing sessions of the six-day exposition.

ALEXANDER JANTA doesn't like the Germans any better than does any other patriotic Pole. He did not witness at first hand the agony that the Germans have inflicted upon his country through their calculated policy of ferocity and extermination, but he did see the Germans under prolonged, intimate and painful circumstances as a prisoner of war.

LONDON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- United States bomber formations from Italy, 1,250 strong, pounded Germany's southern supply bases today in rounding out a week-end that saw nearly 5,000 Allied warplanes loose a tornado of destruction on enemy front positions and rear areas.

BAUCHEM, Germany, Nov. 19 -- The new Allied push into Germany in this area is going so well that one British staff officer said today that the whole operation was "a dream." Everything is proceeding so well, he added, that it is almost like the execution of war maneuvers.

ROME, Nov. 18 -- On a wall of Giovanni Andreani's garage at 61 Via Panico in Rome hangs a framed certificate, of which he is very proud. It was issued by the National Liberation Committee and certifies that he was a volunteer worker "against the Nazi-Fascists from Dec. 1, 1943, through June 7, 1944."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Because industry-wide earnings are now better than during the 1936-39 period, ceiling prices of semi-vitrified china at the manufacturing level will not be increased, it was learned today.

LE MAGOUR, in the German-held Lorient Sector, France, Nov. 16 (Delayed) (AP) -- Seventy-nine American combat officers and enlisted men held by the Germans were exchanged for American-held Germans today during a six-hour armistice in this drab little fishing village within the German lines on the mudflats of the Etel River.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 19 -- The New York dress industry was asked to establish a fund starting at $1,000,000 to support disabled war veterans unable to resume their occupations in the trade in at proposal advanced today by Louis Rubin, executive chairman of the popular priced dress manufacturers' group, at the closing session of the three-day convention of the New Jersey Dress Manufacturers and Contractors Association at the Hotel Grossman.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 20 -Badly pulverized Manila was heavily attacked again Saturday, by carrier aircraft of the Pacific Fleet in the fourth major blow on the harbor area this month. Fighter, torpedo and bomber planes blasted shipping and harbor facilities, and airfields and installations around the city were subjected to withering attacks.

BARI, Italy, Nov. 20 -- The pigskin statisticians who are getting ready for their usual heavy Thanksgiving diet of touchdowns, tackles and times out, had better hold the books open for two more games that have this part of the world more or less on its ear at this moment.

A banking syndicate headed by R.W. Pressprich Co. and Phelps, Fenn Co. received yesterday the award of $1,115,000 of New York City Housing Authority refunding bonds on a bid of par for a combination of rates representing a net interest cost of 1.7782 per cent. The bonds will mature on Feb. 1, 1945 to 1980.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 20 (AP) -- With Twilight Tear scratched just before post time because of track conditions, J. Graham Brown's Seven Hearts sped to an easy two-length victory over Charles Turner's Bon Jour today in the nineteenth running of the $25,000 added Riggs Handicap at Pimlico.

The bone of contention, if there was one in the program that Leopold Stokowski conducted with the City Symphony Orchestra last night in the City Center, was Schoenberg's second "Kammersymphonie," which, followed by Strauss' "Death and Transfiguration," completed the concert.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- The feature of today's stock markets here was renewed support for French bonds, fresh buying of which has been encouraged by General de Gaulle's speech regarding French ecoonmic recovery, which has strengthened hopes that funds may be available to pay coupons of the railway bonds.

Persian dates, which have been unobtainable since the harvest of 1940, are to be imported again, we learn from an authority in the trade. The crops of the last three years have been bought in their entirety by Great Britain to help alleviate the shortage of other fruits.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- President Roosevelt called today for recommendations as to how wartime scientific research could be carried into the post-war world to create jobs and improve the national health and living standards.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -Clark Griffith turned 75 today with a still-aggressive eye on his fifty-eighth season in baseball.

CHUNGKING, Nov. 20 -- With China's military position becoming increasingly more critical, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek reshuffled eight Cabinet posts today, naming able Gen. Chen Cheng Minister of War, succeeding Gen. Ho Ying-chin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The National War Labor Board ordered today the immediate termination of the strike of telephone operators in twenty-eight Ohio cities, declaring the walkout "a threat to the effective prosecution of the war."

Just two decades after he and Maxwell Anderson wrote the best drama about the First World War, Laurence Stallings has set down a play about the second. To get on with the comparison, which is inevitable, "The Streets Are Guarded," which opened last evening at Henry Miller's, is no "What Price Glory?"

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- In the first five-to-four division of the present term, the Supreme Court held today that money spent by defeated political candidates in election campaigns could not be deducted as expenses from Federal income taxes.

The support of women, "not only as citizens but as mothers of young men" who would be affected by a system of military training, has been welcomed by Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson in a telegram to the Woman's National Committee for Universal Military Training, 342 Madison Avenue, Mrs. Ernest Barlow, chairman, announced yesterday at the group's first organization meeting.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- The German scorched earth policy in northern Norway is causing untold suffering to Norwegian civilians. Under the pretext of "voluntary evacuation,'' they have been driven from their homes by German troops and traitor police, who have also burned villages and towns.

GROTON, 1Vtass., Nov. 20---1Viore{ than 500 alumni, civic leaders, churchmen and students attended a funeral service in the school chapel today for the Rev. Dr. Endicott Peabody, founder and headmaster of Groton School for f/ftysix years.

The first flax released by the British Government for civilian export is just now reaching Irish linen manufacturers and will make its appearance here in the form of household linens and dress fabrics during the first six months of 1945, the Irish Linen Guild announced at a reception held yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Advertising linage in newspapers in fifty-two cities throughout the country dropped 4.1 per cent in October compared with the corresponding month last year, according to Media Records. Automotive had the largest loss with 10 per cent; classified was next with 9.4 per cent and department stores third with 7.5 per cent.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Concentrating on oil targets two fleets of United States heavy bombers lashed German supply centers hundreds of miles apart today. The Luftwaffe, usually so sensitive to such attacks, refused the fight anticipated in the sending of more than 750 fighters to escort 160 "heavies" from the Eighth Air Force in Britain.

The pipeline which American Army engineers are building across 2,000 miles of jungle, river and mountain into China is probably the most effective means of aiding that hard-pressed nation which we have yet devised. When Big Inch was rushed through here at home to relieve the Atlantic Coast oil shortage we considered it a remarkable achievement.

His boxing features signed for a schedule that will carry him into late December, and another in prospect pre-dated for January, Promoter Mike Jacobs was in Miami yesterday, for a rest and treatment for a back injury he suffered recently in a fall on his Rumson, N.J., estate.
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Sales of cigarettes have been halted in all United Kingdom post exchanges for United States Army personnel except combat soldiers, replacements and hospital patients.

Plans for a Wendell L. Willkie memorial building to house organizations and committees seeking to advance the causes that he served were made yesterday by the directors of Freedom House, 5 West Fifty-fourth Street.

"China should be treated with respect and realism," an American in Chungking remarked one day last year during a discussion of the quixotism and confusion of American policy. That remark seems to me one of the wisest I ever heard in China; I have quoted it repeatedly ever since.

The city hospitals and some voluntary institutions have eliminated certain desserts and cut down their use of sugar in other ways because of the growing sugar shortage, it was learned yesterday. Patients in some institutions have asked visitors to send them sugar instead of flowers.

MOSCOW, Nov. 20 -- The official Soviet trade union magazine renewed today its sharp attacks on the leadership of the American Federation of Labor for its refusal to meet with Russian labor organizations.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 10 per cent last week over the like week of 1943, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank also had reported a gain of 10 per cent.

WITH FRENCH TROOPS, Overlooking the Rhine, Nov. 20 -- French armored forces have reached the Rhine near Kembs, and all day their guns have been pounding out the message of France's revenge on the forts of the Siegfried Line.

LONDON, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- The Times of London advocated in a forthright editorial today that Germany be brought within a general security system after a limited military occupation by the Allies, but added that the Allies should maintain naval and air bases in the Reich indefinitely.
KANDY,' Ceylon, Nov. 20 (AP) -- A communique:

WITH ALLIED FORCES in Geilenkirchen, Germany, Nov. 20 -- After having decisively beaten off a German counter-attack southwest of Beeck and destroying at least six Tiger tanks out of a total of fifteen, American troops cooperating with the British Second Army in the present push into Germany were slashing today through Sueggerath, ferreting out Germans hiding in the ruins of Geilenkirchen and keeping on the alert against possible further counter-attacks.

LONDON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The German people were told tonight by their chief commentators that they must strive with all their might to prevent an Allied victory on the western front by Christmas, and a new "fight to the death" oath was prescribed for all German soldiers.

PARIS, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain, Pierre Laval and other prominent Vichyites have established a French puppet "government in exile" in the little south German city of Sigmaringen, traditional home of the Hohenzollern family, according to reliable information reaching here today.

Reporting on operations of the Philco Corporation for the first nine months of this year, John Ballantyne, president, informed stockholders in a statement released today that its shipments of radar and other electronic equipment and war material rose 52 per cent over the corresponding period of 1943.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 20 (AP) -- A United States Army Forces in China communique:

PARIS, Nov. 20 -- The first far-reaching labor reform proposed by the Provisional Government since the liberation -- a plan for workers' committees that employers would be obliged to consult once a month -- was outlined today by the Minister of Labor, Alexandre Parodi.

In battles which Berlin describes as of "hitherto unparalleled intensity," the Allied assault on the whole German Westwall is gaining momentum. A real break-through has not yet been made, for the Germans are fighting back with the courage of desperation.
