Some phases of the post-war period are pleasant to look forward to. A foretaste is the offer of the United States Maritime Commission to sell, now or in the near future, 4,755 obsolete or used Army assault boats at a top retail price of $75. The boats are not especially fancy. They aren't as big as the Queen Mary.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- Secretary Stimson has ruled that military considerations forbid withdrawing pre-Pearl Harbor fathers from overseas duty in the Army, it was disclosed today.

In an editorial on Nov. 17 entitled "Synthetic Rubber's Future," THE TIMES stated: "So far as the technical evidence goes, natural rubber is not likely to go the way of indigo or Chilean nitrate because research developed cheaper synthetic equivalents."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- Fort Slocum, the Army base on David's Island at New Rochelle, was transferred today to the control of the Second Service Command under an order from the War Department specifying that the fort was to become a rehabilitation center for United States soldiers imprisoned for violation of the Articles of War.

SANTA CLAUS may have more friends than Ernie Pyle, but surely no one else has. The most famous and successful war correspondent of his generation has won for himself more friends than Dale Carnegie ever dreamed of, not by deliberate efforts to do so, but through his own simplicity of character, his engaging boyishness, his obvious conviction that democracy means what it is supposed to mean, and that all men are indeed his brothers.

The old-time winter season baseball atmosphere was revived here yesterday, even if only transiently. Joe DiMaggio and Snuffy Stirnweiss, two noted Yankees, were here on visits which, a few short years ago, would have provoked arguments about contracts and salary terms. Conditions being what they are, these visits were purely social.

Protracted domestic quarreling over the disciplining of their four children resulted yesterday in the violent death of Mrs. Bella Gold, 49 years old, and the holding of her mild-appearing husband, Abraham, 44, on a charge of murder.

This story, like Tokyo's latest wireless sinking of fifty American heavy cruisers and 400 destroyers, is totally lacking in confirmation. It may carry a lesson just the same. It is the story of an intelligent young Soviet officer who set himself to mastering the English language in the interests of Soviet-American understanding.
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 20 (AP) -- The four-week deer season ended tonight for Adirondack Mountain hunters and unofficial reports indicated the number of deer killed was considerably lower than normally.

A program for the rehabilitation of millions of Jews in Europe will be adopted next week at the five-day war emergency conference of the World Jewish Congress in Atlantic City and submitted to the Allied Governments, it was announced yesterday at the headquarters of the congress, 1834 Broadway.

METZ, France, Nov. 20 -- Isolated pockets of resistance firing sporadically continued to hold out in this city tonight, but there was no organized resistance. Meanwhile units of the American Third Army fanned out north, south and east, leaving the city to its fate while they headed toward the Saar.
After holding within a narrow range all day, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 1 to 3 points net lower on the active months.

LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 21 -- Russian troops half encircled the Hungarian fortress city of Miskolc yesterday, cutting its last direct highway link with Budapest, while Berlin reported a new Red Army offensive in western Latvia against German divisions isolated for more than a month on the Courland Peninsula.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The difficuulties of wartime manufacture, and not supplies of flue-cured tobacco, are to blame for the current scarcity of cigarettes, the War Food Administration said today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- Three employes of the Rochelle Rest House on Bogtown Road in North Salem were held as material witnesses here today in an investigation by District Attorney Elbert T. Gallagher of the death at the institution Saturday night of Benjamin Sandel, 42 years old, a patient.
VUGHT, The Netherlands, Nov. 20 (AP) -- German civilian evacuees are living in comparative comfort in this huge concentration camp that was once a German slaughterhouse.

Six establishments, including the Hotel Delmonico at 502 Park Avenue, face suspension hearings on charges of failing to surrender the requisite number of meat ration points to meat wholesalers, the regional office of the Office of Price Administration said yesterday.

When the war in Europe ends, the War Food Administration will cancel every restriction that does not bear directly on defeating Japan, Lee Marshall, director of the Office of Distribution of the WFA, declared yesterday before the Grocery Manufacturers of America at its thirty-sixth meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Illinois Power Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan for the liquidation and dissolution of its parent, the North American Light and Power Company. The plan proposes to settle more than $26,000,000 in claims that Illinois Power contends is owing to it due to alleged mismanagement on the part of the parent.

The Fort Wayne Pistons and Philadelphia Sphas each gained triumphs in the professional basketball double-header held for the benefit of the Hearst Fund for Disabled Service Men before 3,500 persons at the Seventeenth Regiment Armory last night.

Notification to produce any unleashed dog for a rabies test within twenty-four hours is being issued along with a court summons to its owner, the Department of Health revealed yesterday when two offenders appeared in Yorkville Court.

Helen M. Harris, executive director of the Mayor's Committee on Wartime Care of Children, said yesterday that it was uncertain how long city and State funds would be available to neighborhood groups and settlement houses operating day care centers for the children of working mothers.

"The United States is on the oceans of the world to stay," Basil Harris, president of the United States Lines Company, asserted yesterday at a luncheon of the foreign marketing group of the American Marketing Association, at the Hotel Sheraton, Lexington Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

Stout Steve Owen, the portly mentor of the New York Football Giants, 24-0 upset victors over the ponderous Green Bay Packers last Sunday, was the most popular man in town yesterday. Throughout the day he was being congratulated for the defense he perfected and which his charges executed so effectively in stopping Don Hutson in the game at the Polo Grounds.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 20 -Maureen O'Hara, who has a screen contract with Twentieth Century-Fox and RKO, has been named by the former company for the lead in "Kitten on the Keys," a musical to be produced by George Jessel. This will follow the completion of her role in RKO's "The Spanish Main," which started today.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Nov. 21 (AP) -- "A large task force" of Superfortress bombers hit the island of Kyushu in Japan's homeland today. Flying from China, the big planes dropped explosives against industrial targets, said an announcement by Gen. H.H. Arnold.

Judging from the way Army and Navy coaches keep handing the Dec. 2 game back and forth to one another it must be a hot potato. They continued the tactics at yesterday's Football Writers luncheon at Toot Shor's as Major Andy Gustafson, Lieut. Col. Earl (Red) Blaik's right-hand man at West Point, tossed encomiums to Lieut. Comdr. Rip Miller, who is Comdr. Oscar Hagberg's left bower at Annapolis -- and vice versa.

As a realist I would like to edge in on the argument over compulsory training of our young males. I merely do this to prevent, if possible, civil war between the divergent groups. Unless some of the radio commentators clap a stopper on their jaw-tackle, somebody-will have to call out the Boy Scouts, and I notice with apprehension that my young grandson has been sharpening his hatchet.

AN AMERICAN COMMAND POST, near Saarebourg, France, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Rhine-bent United States Seventh Army, driving twelve miles in less than twenty-four hours, reached the approaches of Saarebourg today, thirty-two miles from the Rhine.

The President's letter to Dr. Vannevar Bush, director of the Office of Scientific Research and Development, raises the question of national security in terms of research. A future aggressor will move even more swiftly than Hitler did. Two oceans will not give us time to establish another OSRD. Continuous systematic research is an evident necessity.

IT looked for a while as though it was Stout Steve Owen's private party and that he was the host. Everyone approached the beaming Giant coach and congratulated him for the astounding victory over the Packers the day before. But it was only the weekly gathering of the Football Writers Association at the Toots Shor A.C. and Stout Steve didn't have to pick up the check after all.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Acting Secretary of State, gave out today a chart and a State Department review in questionnaire form which have been prepared for department officials in their countrywide educational campaign to enable the public to understand the structure of the international organization outlined at Dumbarton Oaks.

Retirement scrolls were presented to eleven former composing room employes yesterday at a special meeting of THE NEW YORK TIMES chapel of Typographical Union No. 6 held in the New York Times Building, 229 West Forty-third Street.

GUAM, Nov. 20 -- This story, which I am broadcasting, is the first newspaper copy sent over the new Navy public relations radio transmitter established Oct. 26 and used previously for radio copy only.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The special House committee to investigate executive agencies recommended today legislation to "modernize" Congress, with the object of saving money, keeping a closer check on executive agency activities and obtaining "greatly improved legislation."
CLEVELAND, Nov. 20 (AP) -- R.G. Pollock, president of the Ohio Federation of Telephone Workers, declined to comment tonight on the War Labor Board's telegraphed directive to end his union's strike.

Demonstrations of test techniques to determine the special equipment needed to enable crippled veterans to drive cars were given yesterday as a part of the program at the opening session of a two-day fall meeting of the Eastern Conference of Motor Vehicle Administrators at the Hotel New Yorker.

The city of Bogota, capital of the Republic of Colombia, has arranged to make an offer of adjustment to the holders of its 1924 and 1927 dollar bonds, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Gabriel Turbay, Colombian Ambassador to this country.

Arturo Toscanini will return to the podium of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society on Jan. 13 to conduct a gala concert for the benefit of the orchestra's pension fund. Maestro Toscanini will present the program with which he made his Philharmonic debut on Jan. 14, 1926.

With hearts grateful, despite war casualties, for the blessings of freedom and the impending downfall of Germany, New Yorkers will observe Thanksgiving Day on Thursday by giving thanks to Providence, by extending hospitality to service men and women and the needy and by traditional gatherings around the family board.
PARIS, Nov. 20 (AP) -- A communique:

The letter of John Groth as to the attitude of the GI's to V-day plans in America reminds me of the letter I received from my son in France. Perhaps the following excerpts from his letter will throw further light on the subject:

WITH AMERICAN FIRST ARMY, in Germany, Nov. 20 -Sloshing forward in a driving rain, our troops made substantial gains along the whole American First Army front today. They did not succeed in quite breaking the "hard crust" of the enemy's resistance on this critical sector, but they are rapidly overrunning his strong points and may fairly be said now to be astride his present main line.

Madison Square Garden's arena and most of its tiered seats were packed last night by 20,000 New Yorkers assembled to hear an all-star radio review staged by the Motion Pictures War Activities Committee in behalf of the Sixth War Loan Bond drive. The audience represented $100,000,000 in bond purchases.

There has been a fundamental change in the nature of the war, both in Europe and in the Pacific, Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, said last night in formally opening the Sixth War within drive in New York City. Irving as his authority, General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff, Secretary Morgenthau said that we now were closing in on the enemy's homeland, in the east and in the west.

KANDY, Ceylon, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- British troops in southwest Burma continue to clean up enemy positions on the west bank of the Chindwin River in their drive south, a Southeast Asia Command communique reported today, while Tokyo reported that one of the largest Allied aerial forces yet seen in southern Burma bit Japanese installations at the mouth of the Sittang River.

We cannot afford to relax our efforts. So long as the war absorbs half of our national production we must hold prices at their present level in order to preserve the purchasing power of the worker's pay envelope. * * * Our price and wage policies must aim for economic stability in war.

Twenty Philadelphia banks have formed the Bank Credit Group of Philadelphia, it was announced yesterday by Evan Randolph, president of the Philadelphia National Bank and chairman of the organization committee.

ROME, Nov. 20 (AP) -- A fierce German counter-attack has knocked Polish troops of the Eighth Army from Monte Fortino, a small peak overlooking two secondary roads to Faenza, about five miles to the northwest, Allied headquarters said today.

During the last few days there has been some commendable plain-speaking by the United States High Command on the necessity of a continued all-out effort at home to give our troops the weapons they must have. Instead of vague alarms and generalities, as has sometimes been the practice, we have been given definite information from which to judge the need and the urgency.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 20 -Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, commanding general of the Army Service Forces, praised today the "miracle" which the American Federation of Labor helped to achieve in war production, but he went "all out" in describing the shortages in material required by American fighting forces.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 20 (AP) -- A supplementary communique:

Tei Ko, dancer of Oriental dances, made her local debut last night in a recital at Times Hall. Miss Ko (or is it Miss Tei?) is American born, though her father was Mongolian. She has danced in the Far East for a number of years. Her program, accordingly, is sufficiently grounded in the Western point of view to make the Eastern material easy to take and pleasant in a theatrical way.

DIVISION COMMAND POST, on Leyte, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Infiltrating Japanese attacking an American detachment miles behind the front lines indicated today that the enemy might attempt to encircle United States positions on northern Leyte and cut our coastal supply road.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -Navy communique 555:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UP) -- The Abner Read, reported lost by the Navy today and commanded by Comdr. Arthur M. Purdy of King Street, Port Chester, N.Y., was a 2,100-ton destroyer. The vessel carried a normal complement of 250 men.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Tuesday, Nov. 21 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Following is the text of the questionnaire issued today by the Department of State designed to show the structure of the general international organization proposed by the conference meeting at Dumbarton Oaks:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The War Production Board has authorized the manufacture of civilian light trucks at the rate of 10,000 vehicles a quarter beginning in 1945, thus resuming production that was halted early in 1942.

With Army and Navy sitting it out for the final grand parade on Dec. 2, college football puts on its last full program this week. Except for the climactic, super-special meeting between the service academies, and the Notre Dame-Great Lakes game at South Bend the same day, this is the end of the tumult and the groaning in the East and the Middle West.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- To Comdr. Jack Dempsey of the Coast Guard only one person was responsible for all the fuss and furor that followed that "long count" incident in his fight to regain the heavyweight championship from Gene Tunney -- and that person was Jack Dempsey.

A Ninth Avenue meat merchant gave thanks yesterday for the presence of four policemen who kept eager housewives from stampeding through his plate glass window when word got around that he had several carloads of turkeys to sell within ceiling prices.

The Sixth War Loan is under way. Only by oversubscribing it shall we here at home continue to do our full part in winning the war. Our men and women in the armed forces are doing magnificently and we must not fail to back them up to our utmost.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces on the China-Burma border captured Mangshih on the old Burma Road, while other Chinese in north Burma penetrated Bhamo in a desperate race to open up the Ledo-Burma Road before the Japanese break through into western China, a Chinese High Command communique said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 -- F.M. Carhart, a member of the firm of Jackson Moreland, consulting engineers, said here today that a consolidated and recapitalized Buffalo, Niagara Eastern Power Corporation System should have post-war earnings of $7,500,000 annually on its common stock on the basis of the present 40 per cent corporate tax rate.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Tuesday, Nov. 21 -- A typhoon which destroyed bridges, turned roads into quagmires in which vehicles stalled and sank, and converted small streams into raging torrents brought the fighting on Leyte virtually to a stand-still on yesterday.

The dollar-and-cents price ceilings for fifteen types of raw furs, issued at the week-end by the Office of Price Administration, will have their chief effect on the new collecting season which is about to get under way, according to views expressed yesterday in the trade.

The opening of the Sixth War Loan campaign yesterday found little activity on the stock market, but late trading produced a moderately higher closing. A normal amount of investment buying coupled with some short covering was said to explain the slight recovery.

The GI overseas who buys a bottle of perfume "concentrate" for his girl in the belief that she will thus be supplied for life with Chanel No. 5 or Shalimar, is likely to be in for a shock, according to a report made yesterday by Caswell-Marrey Company, Ltd., chemists and perfumers.

ROME, Nov. 20 -- At least one enemy ship was destroyed on Saturday night in an engagement off the coast of northwest Italy which was so confused that for a time none knew who was the enemy, an Allied naval communique disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Smaller War Plants Corporation, which has advised and financed and collected technical assistance for thousands of small, independent war producers, is completing preparations to swing into the field of assisting war veterans who have suitable qualifications to establish themselves in business.

With a cast of 150, the Ice Follies of 1945 will open tonight at Madison Square Garden, where it will remain through the night of Dec. 3. The Shipstad and Johnson show, starring Roy Shipstad, Idi Papez and Karl Zwack, Frick and Frack, Heinie Brock and Miss Hazel Franklin, will make its ninth Garden bow and will be presented nightly, in addition to Sunday matinees on Nov. 26 and Dec. 3.
ROME. Nov. 20 (UP) -- A communique.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- George Meany, secretary-treasurer, and Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, decided today to resume consideration with the War Labor Board, of which they are members, of the demands for a wage increase presented by the United Steel Workers Union, CIO.

Summing up the results of the International Business Conference, Sir Peter Bennett, director of Imperial Chemical Industries, Inc., and a member of the United Kingdom delegation to the conference, declared yesterday that the "differences" displayed at the meeting attended by business men from fifty-two countries "were largely a matter of emphasis."
Yesterday's comnuntqud as broadcast /ror Berlin atd recorded by The Associated Press:

VATICAN CITY, Nov. 20 -- When United States troops landed on Leyte they caused things to happen as far away as Vatican City, for the Philippines, with their 15,000,000 Catholics, were a prime consideration in the Vatican's relations with Japan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The outlook for a trial soon of Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel and Major Gen. Walter C. Short on charges that they were negligent in preparing for the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor faded today when the Judiciary Committee of the Senate unanimously approved a resolution sponsored by Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan, to extend for another six months the statute of limitations in the case.

The net income of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad for 1944 will be about $22,275,300, or some $8,000,000 less than it was in 1943, Roy B. White, president, told some stockholders at their meeting held yesterday in Baltimore, Md. He estimated that gross revenues this year will approximate $388,338,600, an increase of $30,196,400 over 1943.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 20 (AP) -- "No sir, we can't do anyone any special favors. Mail a bond receipt and $4.80 to the Maryland War Finance Committee and you'll get a ticket to the Army-Navy game."

Beef stew from a can and baked cabbage made up the main course of a holiday meal served yesterday -- a sample of what our men in German prison camps probably will eat Thursday. No talk of the turkey shortage was heard around the table at Red Cross headquarters in Brooklyn, 57 Willoughby Street.

MOSCOW, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- The Red Army's objective beyond the borders of Russia is to "liberate peoples from their enslavers" and the Russians plan to "cure Germany, not with vitamins and medicines, but witih surgery," the newspaper Pravda said today.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The chiefs of Belgium's various resistance organizations agreed today to deliver all the arms of the resistance forces to the Allies by Saturday and concurred in the procedure by which the weapons would be surrendered.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Pressure from 18,000 salable hogs today cut the price on weights under 270 pounds as much as 20 cents below Friday's figure. the top dropping to $14.25, lowest since Nov. 3. Heavier grades and sows were steady at the $14 price.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Joseph Clark Grew, adviser to Secretary of State Cordell Hull on Far Eastern affairs and former Ambassador to Japan, has returned from a week of consultations at Amiral Chester W. Nimitz' headquarters in Pearl Harbor "impressed by the thoroughness of plans and conduct of operations in the Pacific," the State Department announced today.

ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Pacific Ocean Area, Hawaii, Nov. 20 -- If United States military and naval forces were not so busily engaged battering Japanese defenses from the Kuriles to the Philippines, this might be remembered as an anniversary, marking the turning point in the great war of the Central Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Sunday night on the farm by the Shenandoah is radio night, and last evening's audition brought unusual rewards in the form of interesting disclosures from the licensed industry about the capital city and the people to whom it dispenses government.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -Without visible opposition, Congress set out today to extend President Roosevelt's broad war powers.

Men's and boys' clothing deliveries for the spring season will be further delayed through a new invitation issued by the Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot for 3,100,000 so-called battle jackets, the quantity being in addition to the approximately 5,000,000 jackets already contracted for by the depot.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Oklahoma's community property law by which a man and his wife could split their total incomes and keep them in lower surtax brackets than if reported to the Federal Government as a single return, was rejected by the Supreme Court by a divison of 7 to 2 today.

ALBANY, Nov. 20 (AP) -- First steps were taken today to carry out Governor Dewey's recommendation for post-war improvement and expansion of facilities at State mental hygiene institutions which he had described as "overcrowded by 20 per cent."

Phil Terranova, Bronx ring favorite, chased Harry Jeffra, Baltimore veteran, with an unrelenting offensive through ten rounds last night in their battle of ex-feather-weight champions at the St. Nicholas Arena, but his reward was a draw decision that confounded not only Terranova, but the crowd of 2,900 which witnessed a rough battle.

ALBANY, Nov. 20 -- Justice Gilbert V. Schenck of the State Supreme Court, former member of the Appellate Division, third department, was told by the five sitting members of the Appellate Division today that he was free to tell the grand jury investigating alleged crime in Albany County everything that was said in their consultation room last January concerning a case which developed from the investigation.

In his first recital of the season at Carnegie Hall last night, Gyorgy Sandor, young Hungarian pianist, once more demonstrated to an enthusiastic audience his phenomenal keyboard technique and his remarkable gift of bravura playing. If his recital left something to be desired, it was probably due more to faulty programming than musical incompetence on the part of the artist.

ABOARD ADMIRAL FECHTELER'S FLAGSHIP, Leyte Gulf, Oct. 28 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The skipper of the escort-carrier Gambier Bay told today how some 750 of the ship's crew -- including Comdr. Fred Borries, famed Naval Academy football star of a few years ago -- had spent forty-two hours on rafts after their "baby flattop" had taken about twenty direct hits.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Communique 226:

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- A partial agreement among the United States, Great Britain and Canada, three of the most important countries in the field of post-war commercial aviation, was made public tonight after it had been presented to the other delegations at the International Civil Aviation Conference.

Any visitor at the Seamen's Church Institute in South Street in recent years must have marveled that one building could contain so many humane activities and so many human beings enjoying them. Here beneath a single roof, whose lighthouse sends its welcoming beams across the harbor and, indeed, across the oceans, is a home for thousands of sailor men.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Forty per cent of Army cargo moved overseas in the last fiscal year went to the forces fighting the Japanese in the Pacific, Lieut. Gen. Brehon Somerville, commanding general of the Army Service Forces, said today in his annual report.

PARIS, Nov. 20 -- The arrival of French troops on the bank of the Rhine is regarded here as another in the rapid succession of steps that France has recently taken along what Gen. Charles de Gaulle called last night "the road to power."

Mgr. John O'Grady, honored at a dinner last night for his twenty-five years of service to the National Conference of Catholic Charities, told the representatives of Catholic charities and welfare agencies that these must continue as independent agencies rather than depend solely on Government organizations.

Margaret Landon's "Anna and the King of Siam," published by John Day, is going into English and Swedish editions, and negotiations are under way for Spanish, Portuguese and Dutch translations. In this country, the American Red Cross is transcribing the book into Braille, and both the American Foundation for the Blind and the American Printing House for the Blind are making it into a "Talking Book."

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 20 -- Argentine Foreign Ministry officials frankly admit that the latest news from Washington and the other American capitals does not hold much promise for a meeting of Foreign Ministers in the form proposed by Argentina.

RENO, Nev., Nov. 20 -- William McKnight, district judge of Reno declared in effect today that the divorce decree granted here to Doris Duke Cromwell on Dec. 21, 1943, was valid and without taint of fraud. He declared invalid and fraudulent the divorce granted to James H.R. Cromwell in New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -The Chicago Sun described The Associated Press to the Supreme Court today as "a news-gathering organization with an actual and potential power that cannot be equaled."

Boston society, especially that part of it residing on Beacon Street, is satirized in "The Late George Apley," tonight's premiere at the Lyceum. Based on John P. Marquand's Pulitzer Prize novel of 1938, the play represents the combined product of Mr. Marquand and George S. Kaufman.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Tuesday, Nov. 21 (U.P.) -American and Japanese forces fought a battle of attrition today around the Limon pocket as military observers agreed that the first month of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's Philippines campaign had far exceeded expectations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- After a fifteen-minute session entirely devoted to eulogies of Senator Ellison D. (Cotton Ed) Smith, who died during last week's Congressional recess, the Senate adjourned today until tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Requests for post-season football games featuring service teams are flooding the War and Navy Departments, but the answer to all invitations tonight was "no." There was some indication, though, that the departments might soften their attitude in a day or two and allow some games to be played.

The destruction by planes from the United States Third Fleet of three enemy ships in Manila harbor and 126 aircraft on and above Luzon airfields shows that the Japanese still are pouring sand in their current rat hole and that the American fleet which the Tokyo radio has destroyed so many times on the air continues to rule the seas.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Buying of corn futures attributed to cash interests, presumably removing hedges against shipping sales of cash grain, gave that market a strong undertone today, with the close on the Chicago Board of Trade at about the top at gains of 3/8 to 7/8 cent a bushel.

The special House committee to investigate executive agencies has recommended legislation to modernize Congress. Its proposals are highly encouraging, and may prove the most fruitful part of that committee's reports.

Asserting that the world is looking to the British Empire and the United States for leadership in world reconstruction, John S. Dodd, M.P., president of the Association of British Chambers of Commerce, declared yesterday there must be no post-war division of world markets between the two leaders.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's assertion that the Wehrmacht intends to fight the battle for Germany west of the Rhine found an echo today in numerous German statements describing the Allied offensive there as an effort to smash the whole German front and finish the war in one gigantic blow.

By the slender margin of a single point, Marty (Slats) Marion, the 6-foot-2-inch beanpole shortstop of the world champion Cardinals, was named yesterday the most valuable player in the National League for 1944, according to official announcement of the Baseball Writers Association of America, which annually appoints a twenty-four-man committee to conduct a poll on the award.
LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Although business on today's stock market here was quiet, the general tone was firm.

GARY, Ind., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Thirty-nine striking cranemen at the Gary works of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation voted late today to resume work at midnight, ending a two-day walk-out which halted all steel production and put an estimated 5,500 men out of work.

Warning business and industry against overoptimistic expectations for the post-war period, Dr. Julius Hirsch, economist, said yesterday that, "our most dangerous inflation is a progressive inflation of forecast figures on national income and gross output."

Navy moved into the second slot behind Army in yesterday's Associated Press poll to determine the country's top-ranking football team -- thus adding the mythical national championship to the winner's booty in their clash at Baltimore Dec. 2.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, called tonight for a continuation of the present 2 per cent Social Security payroll tax, by action of Congress, to stop the automatic increase to twice that amount effective Jan. 1 under the Social Security Act. He spoke over the Columbia Broadcasting System.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in Japan and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Contrary to persistent rumors, the Cowles Broadcasting Company is not planning to start a network, it was declared yesterday by Gardner Cowles, president, at a meeting in the University Club of the vice presidents and station managers of the five radio stations owned by the concern.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- President Roosevelt said today that workers who quit critical war jobs were costing American lives on the battlefronts because it was necessary to ration shells hurled at the enemy.
PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 21 -- The total of enemy troops killed and captured in the Marianas and Palau operations is now more than 66,000, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz disclosed today.

One reader has been trying to distribute ninety million cigars a month among eleven or twelve million men and has run into trouble. That number of cigars, approximately, is the monthly Government purchase for the armed forces.
ROME, Nov. 21 -- The long expected reorganization of the Italian Cabinet appeared imminent today and it may be announced after tomorrow's meeting.

To mark the tenth anniversary of the Houghton Mifflin Literary Fellowships, that publishing house will offer, in addition to the reguar fellowships, a special award of $1,000, exclusive of royalties, for a book of poetry, either a complete manuscript or a work in progress.

The rain and sleet storm that has swept the New York area for the past two days will have given way by this morning to coldish, cloudy weather, the Weather Bureau forecast yesterday. Tomorrow, Thanksgiving Day, will be featured by partly cloudy skies, with perhaps some sunshine, and temperatures of between 45 and 50 degrees, the bureau added.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The House completed general debate today on a bill to revive the Federal crop insurance program which Congress killed last spring, and the expectation, was that the measure would be approved tomorrow. Quick Senate confirmation is believed certain if the House passes the measure.

Roy E. Larsen, president of the United Hospital Fund of New York, announced yesterday that a gift of $50,000 in Government bonds had been made to the fund by the Flora R. and Isidor M. Stettenheim Foundation as a memorial to Ivan M. Stettenheim.

The devotion of New York's opera lovers was clearly demonstrated yesterday when several hundred persons braved rain and sleet to be on hand for the opening of the Metropolitan Opera box office. Tickets for the first week of the season, which opens Monday with Gounod's "Faust," went on sale at 10 A.M., but long before that hour a sizable line had formed.

George Schwartz, 33-year-old hijacker, received a twelve-year prison term yesterday from Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz, and a statement from the court that the sentence would have been longer if the law permitted.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- The Rev. William C. Baxter, rector of the fashionable St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in Prospect Street here, was arrested today on charges of carnally abusing and impairing the morals of two brothers, 12 and 14 years old, who are members of his parish. His age is 41.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Maj. Gen. Wilhelm D. Styer of Niagara Falls, N.Y., Chief of Staff to Lieutenant General Somervell, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to have the temporary rank of lieutenant general in the Army of the United States.

The Sixth War Loan has got off to a flying start, with sales of Series E bonds alone up to the close of the opening day of the campaign amounting to $391,000,000, it was disclosed in Washington yesterday by Ted R. Gamble, director of the War Finance Division of the Treasury.

The concert given by Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall had exceptional features. The first of hese, and an unforgettable experience, was the noble thought and beauty of Sibelius' Seventh Symphony, of which Mr. Ormandy gave an excellent performance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- An open letter to "housewives of America" urging a drive on Congress to obtain essential clothing for war workers, children and the housewives themselves, was issued today by eight organizations known in Washington as the "Consumers Clearing House."

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 21 -- Meyer E. Ruback, counsel for James H.R. Cromwell, in a statement issued today commenting on the new divorce decree granted by Nevada courts to Doris Duke Cromwell, predicted that the United States Supreme Court "would be required to settle the conflict between the courts of Nevada and New Jersey."

Plastics are not merely substitutes for more familiar materials in the exhibition of decorative accessories created by Emile Norman of California that opened yesterday afternoon at the Pendelton Galleries, 57 East Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- An increased understanding of the Emergency Maternity and Infant Care program under which a half-million babies have been born to the wives of service men has resulted from a conference here, according to Dr. A.L. Van Horn of the Children's Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21--Donald M. Nelson, former chairman of the War Production Board, has become a "personal representative" of President Roosevelt, with status permitting him to sit in Cabinet meetings and authorizing him to call on Government agencies to assist him in carrying out Presidential missions.

OTTAWA, Nov. 21 -- A group of high-ranking Canadian Army officers, in an unprecedented breach of army regulations that intensified a crisis in the Canadian Government, went on record today with a statement that Canada's voluntary system of over seas enlistment was not feasible.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 21 -- Frances Rafferty and Paul Langton have been chosen by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the romantic leads in "The Hidden Eye," a sequel to Baynard Kendrick's "Eyes in the Night," in which Edward Arnold again will portray a blind detective.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 15, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:
LONDON, Nov. 21 (UP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

WITH THE NINTH ARMY, Nov. 21 -- United States and German tanks, aided by their artillery and abetted by anti-tank units, slugged it out today in muddy fields and before the solidly built brick and stone towns of Gereonsweiler, Ederen and Freialdenhoven in what may develop into the major armored battle of this war by nightfall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (U.P.) -- B-29 Superfortresses, blasting a path through the strongest fighter interception they had ever met, bombed the great Omura aircraft works in Japan's homeland today, attacked targets in Nanking and Shanghai, in occupied China, and shot down or damaged fifty-five enemy planes.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Sofia and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ON THE FRENCH-ITALIAN FRONTIER, Nov. 17 (AP) (Delayed) -- Thousands of Italian patriots are harassing the Germans who face the American and French troops on the right flank of the American Seventh and French First Armies here in the jagged Alps.

A nation-wide investigation of irregular pricing of men's shirts, pajamas, shorts and undershirts is being conducted by the Office of Price Administration, it was learned yesterday, with industry reports being made to the effect that "many" offenders already have been uncovered.

Last week we were told that the war expenditures of our Gov ernment from July 1, 1940, to date aggregated $229,600,000,000. Total United States Army casualties in World War II amount to 437,356 up to the beginning of this month.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 21 -- An appropriation of half a million dollars from liquor taxes to help rehabilitate drunkards and establish institutional facilities for their care was advocated today by Alfred E. Driscoll, New Jersey Alcoholic Beverage Commissioner, during a budget hearing.

A demand that an example be made of 100 persons who fail to separate waste paper from other refuse put out for collection was a major point in the program adopted by the advisory committee of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office to speed and integrate the waste paper salvage drive in the city.

Looking slim and trim, although he admitted illness rather than hard physical exercise had him down to his old time playing weight of 187, Joe DiMaggio, who once bludgeoned the Yankees to six pennants in seven years, renewed acquaintances with New York baseball scribes at Toots Shor's yesterday and revealed that, so far as he knew, his next point of destination would be Atlantic City.

Bazaine's surrender of Metz in 1871, Vichy's abandonment of the ancient city in 1940, have now been avenged, if not directly by French armies at least with French help. The fortress, never in modern times taken by direct assault, has been thus taken by troops of the Fifth and Ninety-fifth infantry divisions of the American Third Army.

PARIS, Nov. 21 -- On the eve of his journey with Gen. Charles de Gaulle to Moscow, Foreign Minister Georges Bidault told the Consultative Assembly today that the trip was "essential for the future of France and the peace of the world," and he asserted that France would never join an exclusive western European bloc.
Preparations were redoubled yesterday in New York City for the observance of Thanksgiving Day tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Challenger Welker Cochran of San Francisco cut 22 points from titleholder Willie Hoppe's lead today in their 1,500-point match for the world three-cushion billiard championship.

ABOARD A UNITED STATES CARRIER, off the Philippines, Nov. 11 (Delayed) -- This powerful carrier task force, retiring to more peaceful waters after having destroyed the Japanese air force on Luzon five days ago, reversed its course one black midnight and made a dramatic dash through a typhoon back to the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- At the request of the Liberian Government the Public Health Service announced today that it has designated an all-Negro mission of eleven American physicians, engineers, entomologists and nurses to develop a five-year health and sanitation program in Liberia.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 22 -- Against a desperate Luftwaffe, intense flak and adverse weather conditions with temperatures down to 43 degrees below zero, nearly 2,500 American planes pushed the offensive to wipe out Germany's oil supply to a new peak yesterday.

A new symphonic organization, the American Youth Orchestra, directed by the distinguished conductor Dean Dixon, will make its debut at Carnegie Hall on Dec. 16, it was announced yesterday. The new orchestra is made up of young professional musicians and graduates of music schools, and their average age is 20.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 22 (U.P.) -- Russian amphibious forces, renewing a drive to win control of the Gulf of Riga, have cleared all but a four-mile-deep enemy pocket on the 1,010-square-mile Estonian island of Oesel, Moscow announced last night, while 700 miles to the south Soviet forces advanced up to five miles in Hungary.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Senator Homer Ferguson of Michigan, Republican, introduced in the Senate today a resolution, already favorably acted on by the Judiciary Committee, proposing a six-month further extension of the statute of limitations in the projected courts-martial of Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel and Maj. Gen. Walter C.
Good heavens! Why must beans always be served with a Yankee accent? Even THE TIMES on Nov. 18 dished up an editorial bean-viand permeated with New England twang.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- President Roosevelt told his news conference today that he did say "damn" when the voting machine at Hyde Park got out of kilter on election day, but he added emphatically that he did not take the name of Deity in vain.
The letter of Thomas W. Lamont in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 19 is the most authoritative confirmation of the truth which the victims of the repeated German aggressions have been stating for years.
The Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company and its subsidiaries had net earnings of $1,507,455 in the quarter ended on Sept. 30, according to the report announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Members of the War Labor Board are hopeful of a vote tomorrow on the question of awarding shift differentials, increases to eliminate intra-plant inequalities, severance wages and additional vacation and holiday pay to members of the United Steel Workers Union, CIO, employed by eighty-six steel companies.

As a result of the record number of resignations and retirements in the New York City school system, fewer sabbatical leaves are to be given to teachers next term, Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday. In the future sabbaticals are to be granted for health reasons only.
The great Allied offensive in the west has started well.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- With a series of actions generally broadening the scope of Priorities Regulation 25, the War Production Board added electric and gas domestic refrigerators and washing machines today to the list of civilian goods which may be manufactured under terms of the spot authorization procedure.

Arthur Sampson, who used to help Lou Little coach at Columbia, came down from Boston yesterday to talk about the Dartmouth football team, which plays the Lions at Baker Field Saturday in the final local college game of the season.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 21--A vehement warning that "to get peace we have got to fight like hell" was given to the Western Allies today by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Supreme Commander of the Allied Expeditionary Force.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Swamped under what Chairman Frank W. Wrightson termed "literally tons of mail," the Maryland War Finance Committee declared today, just one full day after the mail-order ticket sale began, that the Army-Navy football classic on Dec. 2 was a sellout.

The commerce and industry division of the New York War Fund is still 30 per cent behind its quota, while the home-front borough organization is 28 per cent behind, it was announced yesterday at meetings at which workers in both divisions pledged themselves to continue their efforts until the city's $17,200,000 goal is reached.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton of this year's growth ginned to Nov. 14 totaled 9,488,233 running bales.

John J. O'Connor, back from a deer-hunting expedition to Wurtsboro, N.Y., in Sullivan County, reported all hotels and tourist camps around that way filled with sportsmen. As far as he and his companion, Joe Basta, were concerned, it turned out to be a case of "no venison."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- President Roosevelt said today that lend-lease operations would proceed as was until the war with Germany and Japan had ended. His statement was made in answer to a question at his news conference.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, On Leyte, Wednesday, Nov. 22 (AP) -- American troops slowly and painfully loosened the Japanese hold on northern approaches to the Ormoc valley today despite miserable weather and an apparent Japanese decision to sacrifice an entire division, if necessary, to hold their positions near Limon in the Philippines.

Enhanced by a remarkable second act, in which the pace quickened and the costuming and scenic effects left some 10,000 first-nighters breathless, the Ice Follies of 1945, ninth edition of the skating extravaganza, owned and produced by Eddie and Roy Shipstad, made an auspicious bow last night at Madison Square Garden.

Recommendations of a special committee of the Board of Higher Education to abolish the rank of tutor in the municipal colleges, to grant faculty members with permanent tenure the rank of assistant professor and to lower the number of members on the board from twenty-one to eleven were among the suggestions reported to the instructional staffs of the colleges by their presidents yesterday.

The Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., went on record at the closing session of their thirty-sixth annual convention yesterday as favoring the use of surplus foods for foreign relief, the remainder to be placed on the domestic market, with the manufacturer given opportunity to purchase trade-mark goods at a fair price.

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- Jacques Duclos, secretary of the Communist party and, pending the arrival of Maurice Thorez, the most important Communist in France, declared today that it was the de Gaulle Government's "own fault" if there still were disorders in some parts of the country and if the patriotic militia resisted giving up its arms.

METZ, France, Nov. 21 -- The tiny islands of Saulcy and Chambiere in the center of Metz were tonight the only points in the city not captured by the American Third Army. Heavy guns were brought up to handle the Nazi garrisons at these points, and their capture or capitulation was expected hourly.
ROME, Nov. 21 (AP) -- A communique:

WITH UNITED STATES INFANTRY, in Huertgen Forest, Germany, Nov. 21 (U.P.) -- A little GI from Johnstown, N.Y., and a big German non-com slugged it out with bare fists today with thirteen armed Nazis looking on.

The Thanksgiving turkey remained an elusive bird yesterday for most New Yorkers, despite belated shipments to market, with the short supply going mostly to those who had the determination and physical stamina to queue up in the rain and snow outside a few well-stocked markets, or were willing to pay illegal premiums or else were just plain lucky.

The stock market scored yesterday its best recovery of the last several sessions in expanded trading. Prices advanced 1 to 2 points, with wider gains for some preferred issues. The best demand appeared in the railroad section; measured by the averages, the high level of last July for the carriers almost was matched.
ROME, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Italian land campaign was bogged in the mud, snow and fog of the Apennines and the lower Po Valley today. Only a few minor engagements were reported.

Twelve hundred persons who ate turkey dressing at two dinners at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last Wednesday became mildly ill afterward, but "recovered promptly," Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins, Health Commissioner, said yesterday. Dr. Stebbins' announcement follows:
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission: ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The AFL Teamsters Union and Daniel J. Tobin, its president, asked today for dismissal of libel suits seeking a total of $400,000 as an aftermath of "the battle of the Statler."
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 21 (AP) -- A supplementary communique:

Most of the 1,600 Japanese-Americans who have been relocated in New York State will remain in the East after the war if they find they can make a living here, Harold S. Fistere, relocation supervisor of the War Relocation Authority for the Middle Atlantic area, predicted yesterday.

WITH THE AMERICAN FIRST ARMY, in Germany, Nov. 21 -- Our troops ground forward today for varying gains -- none spectacular -- on the whole of the First Army front. There are many indications that the enemy is withdrawing to fight again along the Roer River.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Brig. Gen. La Verne G. Saunders, the noted "Blondie" of West Point football, who was injured recently in a plane crash, has been flown from India to Walter Reed Hospital in fifty-seven hours, the War Department said today.

Almost perfect harvesting weather in the South continues to bring in enough hedge selling in the local cotton futures market to bring about an easier market at times. Such a condition prevailed yesterday and the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed near the lows of the day, or 6 to 10 points net lower than Monday's final prices.

ABOARD A CARRIER FLAGSHIP, in the Western Pacific, Nov. 21 (U.P.) -- Only a lack of wind and water can keep the Pacific Fleet's carrier striking force from going where it will, Vice Admiral John S. McCain said today, and Admiral William F. Halsey remarked that the Japanese were sending ships into the Philippines to be sunk just as were their "Tokyo Expresses" to the Solomons.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 21 -- President Roosevelt and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, in personal messages to the convention of the American Federation of Labor, paid tribute today to the part workers of the United States are playing in furnishing munitions and supplies to the armed services. Both urged continuation of unremitting effort.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Increased wage dividends for employes of the Eastman Kodak Company next March were assured today when the company's directors voted a common stock dividend of $2 for the quarter and the regular $1.50 quarterly dividend on preferred stock.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 -- Representatives of the New York Curb Exchange and the National Association of Securities Dealers discussed today in oral argument before the Securities and Exchange Commission the Curb Exchange's application to extend unlisted trading privileges to the common stocks of six companies.
Monday's communique, as broadcast in English by the New Yugoslav radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WITH AMERICAN FIRST ARMY, in Germany, Nov. 21 -- While our troops were slowly working their way into Eschweiler today under heavy artillery and mortar fire and in a cold drizzle, they met nine rain-soaked elderly German civilians dodging down a street toward the southern edge of the city.

The opinion that four creditor banks had violated their fiduciary obligations was expressed in an advisory report filed in Federal court here yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission, in connection with the reorganization of the Warner Sugar Corporation.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag denied yesterday a motion by former Sixth Deputy Police Commissioner William M. Kent to compel the Police Pension Fund to award him the pension of a chief inspector at $6,000 annually instead of retiring him at $4,500, the rating of a deputy inspector fixed when he resigned on Sept. 11.

Two chipper career girls, aged 66 and 69, respectively, spoke yesterday at commencement exercises for the fourth class of the Department of Welfare's household training project. Alumnae of seven months' standing, Mrs. Edna Harris and Mrs. Johanna Maisenberg outlined their progress in the business world to forty-eight new graduates at project headquarters, 325 East Thirty-eighth Street.

The importance of taking action now for the safety of pedestrians to prevent the expected increase in the post-war death and injury rate was emphasized yesterday at the closing session of the fall meeting of the Eastern Conference of Motor Vehicle Administrators at the Hotel New Yorker.

Celebrating its fiftieth anniversary, the Music School Settlement, 55 East Third Street, faces possible court action to settle a dispute that has arisen over the refusal to re-employ three teachers and the dropping of nine students. The attorney for the school, which enrolls 1,000 pupils, insisted that it was just an "internal issue" and that the school had done nothing to merit any criticism or attack.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- In the most important of several Cabinet changes announced tonight, Duncan Sandys, 36-year-old son-in-law of Prime Minister Churchill, has been appointed Minister of Works with responsibility for some of Britain's most vital post-war reconstructive planning.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- A separate American embassy to the Royal Yugoslav Government has Been established in London and it will be occupied tomorrow by Ambassador Richard C. Patterson Jr. and a small staff. When the war situation permits, the embassy will be transferred to Belgrade.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Nov. 21 (AP) -- British troops driving southward along the Myitkyina-Mandalay railway corridor on the right flank of the Allied North Burma offensive to clear a land route to China have been forced to withdraw slightly, Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's Command announced today.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Douglas Dodson, leading rider at Pimlico, suffered a broken collarbone in a spill that marked the third race today. Dodson was moving up boldly with Journeyman at the five-sixteenths pole when the 4-year-old appeared to slip sideways and went down, pinning Dodson beneath.

MOSCOW, Nov. 21 (UP) -- The projected security bloc of western European powers, advocated by powerful British quarters, was prominently reported in the Russian press today without Russian comment -- but antogonism to the proposal was evident nevertheless.

The crow is one of the noisiest birds in the woods, and his raucous voice is twice as raucous in late autumn. One reason is that he then has no competition, save that of his own kind. Another is that crows then gather in flocks and vie among themselves to see which can make the most noise.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Second War Powers Act, which must be renewed by Congress by the end of the year or lapse automatically, contains only one passage which is being subjected to critical scrutiny on Capitol Hill. But that paragraph is the most sweeping delegation of authority to the Executive in American history.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Wednesday, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A communique:

Remington Rand, Inc., has notified the New York Stock Exchange that it will redeem 46,675 shares of its $4.50 cumulative preferred stock on Jan. 1 and will use the list of preferred stockholders at the close of business Nov. 24 in selecting the shares to be redeemed.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Once-beaten Georgia Tech and twice-defeated Tulsa, which staged a thrilling football show in the Sugar Bowl at New Orleans last New Year's Day, will be matched again in the Orange Bowl here on Jan. 1.

For years the Goddard Neighborhood Center has been an oasis for children in a rather dreary part of Manhattan. At First Avenue and East Thirty-fourth Street, it welcomes little folk from many blocks of the thickly populated, low-income area round about. Its all-day kindergarten enables many mothers to take part in essential war work.

The sale of hardware in defiance of a Federal court order brought penalties yesterday to two persons operating wholesale businesses at 47 Ludlow Street. The culprits were Harold Frank, who was sentenced to thirty days in jail, and Mrs. Gladys Cohen, who was fined $5,000.

The directors of the Pere Marquette Railway Company decided yesterday at a meeting in Cleveland to defer the declaration of any dividend. The company announced that the decision was based upon the desire to conserve cash resources for property betterment and for further debt retirement, deemed necessary to assist in any refinancing program that may be arranged.

BOSTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Montreal's Stanley Cup Canadiens achieved a first place National Hockey League tie with the Maple Leafs by gaining their third consecutive triumph over the Bruins, 4 -- 1, tonight before a 12,000 crowd at the Boston Garden.

PARIS, Nov. 21 -- For the first time since liberation France turns from domestic problems to address herself to consideration of external policy. The debate on foreign affairs which was opened today in the Consultative Assembly by Foreign Minister Bidault and will be continued tomorrow by General de Gaulle signifies to all Frenchmen that France is back in the world.

Just two weeks ago today, while America was engrossed in the Presidential election returns, American guns in the region around Metz began to play the overture to what has become the greatest battle of this war -- an all-out effort to crush German resistance and end the war in Europe.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 21 -- German defenses are crumbling on the seventy-five-mile front from the Rhine south of Mulhouse north to Sarrebourg under a series of swift, bold advances by the doughboys and poilus of the American Seventh and French First Armies.

A UNITED STATES ARMY HOSPITAL, Somewhere in Belgium, Nov. 21 (AP) -- It was nearly 2 o'clock in the morning, but Lieut. Frances Slanger, a graduate of the Boston City Hospital, could not sleep. Carefully, so as not to disturb her tentmates, she eased out of her cot and by flashlight began writing down some of the things about American doughboys they had been discussing earlier in the night.

The New York Times Savings and Loan Association, with assets of $376,000, will be merged into the Railroad Federal Savings and Loan Association, with assets of $33,880,000, as soon as formal approval of the merger is received from the Federal Home Loan Administration.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Twentieth Air Force communique 22:
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS,Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Communique 227:

Two new films will open in midtown theatres today. At the Paramount, which is observing its eighteenth anniversary, the birthday offering will be "And Now Tomorrow," a Paramount drama starring Loretta Young and Alan Ladd, who is making his first screen appearance since his release from the Army.

ALBANY, Nov. 21 -- Supreme Court Justice Gilbert V. Schenck, who refused last week to tell the special grand jury investigating alleged crime in Albany what was said in the Appellate Division conference room concerning a case arising from the investigation, gave the grand jury the requested answers today.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- It will obviously be impossible to give to defeated enemy States "which must for a long period be subjected to special restrictions," the right to appeal to the charter of the new proposed world security organization against those States which are responsible for seeing that the restrictions are maintained, says a White Paper on the Dumbarton Oaks proposals issued tonight by the British Government.

DUBLIN, Nov. 21 -- Gen. Richard Mulcahy, Opposition leader in the Dail Eireann, created a stir in political circles here today when he publicly urged his United Ireland party in its annual convention in Mansion House to make the securing of a post-war defensive military agreement with Britain a new plank in the party's platform.

Savings of the American people now total more than $100,000,000,000, but statisticians are more interested in the fact that the wartime percentage gain in number of persons saving has far outrun the increase in the dollar volume, according to a study made by the Life Insurance Companies of America, an institutional organization.

A hundred members of the Museum of the City of New York and their friends, some in fur coats and some in rainy-day clothes, collected at the Museum, Fifth Avenue and 104th Street, yesterday to look at the styles they used to wear and those they may wear this year. It was a private preview of a special exhibition that will be opened to the public today. "Three decades of Fashion in New York, 1915-1945."
Prize-winning serigraphs, 1940-1944, by members of the National Serigraph Society (formerly The Silke Screen Group) are on view, until Jan. 1, at 96 Fifth Avenue, from 12:30 to 5:30 daily.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman for New York, predicted here today that Governor Thomas E. Dewey will be defeated if he runs for re-election to the Governorship in 1946.

Now that the Federal District Court in Wilmington, Del., has approved the plan of reorganization of the United Gas Corporation it is expected that the utility will proceed with its $100,000,000 financing program. Under the plan United Gas, a unit in the Electric Bond and Share System, will place $100,000,000 of first mortgage 3 per cent bonds privately with a group of institutional investors.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- The convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations reaffirmed unanimously today labor's no-strike pledge until victory is won, after a fervent appeal by President Philip Murray and an address by Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, chief of the Army Service Forces, telling about the many serious shortages now existing in essential war materials and urging increased effort on the production front.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21--The War Labor Board directed tonight that striking telephone workers in Ohio return to work immediately and gave their union officers until 10 A. M. tomorrow to abide by the order.
LONDON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- A later United States Strategic Air Force in Europe communique:

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,218, compared with 1,741 last week and 1,013 for the corresponding period last year, according to listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 417 against 1,147 last Tuesday.

WHEN war broke out in the far Pacific nearly three years ago, the Asiatic Squadron of the United States Navy consisted of only two cruisers, thirteen destroyers and an assortment of submarines, P-T boats and other small fry. A more powerful force had never been considered necessary because reinforcements could always be dispatched from Pearl Harbor in a hurry.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- President Roosevelt reiterated today that he, Prime Minister Churchill and Marshal Stalin hoped very much that their next meeting would be held as soon as possible, but he discouraged speculation as to when it would be.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Lieut. Comdr. James (Sleepy Jim) Crowley today accepted a contract to serve as commissioner of the All-America Conference, new professional football league, expected to begin operations next year.

A comprehensive report on wartime wages prepared by the four public members of the National War Labor Board, on which a Presidential decision on wage policies probably will be based, will be submitted to President Roosevelt soon, Theodore W. Kheel, executive director of the WLB, disclosed yesterday.

The board of directors of the Bankers Trust Company declared yesterday a dividend of $5,000,000 of stock to holders of $25,000,000 of its capital shares, payable on Dec. 29 to stock of record of Dec. 12 following appropriate action by stockholders and formal approval by the New York State Banking Department, it was announced yesterday by S. Sloan Colt, president.

Returning to the ring as a middleweight, Al Davis, Brownsville's former welterweight idol, last night knocked out Frankie Ross, Boston, in 2:31 of the second round of the scheduled eight-round feature bout at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn.
Private homes and former town houses altered into apartments figured in many of the realty deals reported in Manhattan yesterday.

The Brooklyn Savings Bank has sold the one-story building at 168 Montague Street, Brooklyn, to Benjamin Knobel, theatre owner and operator, who contemplates the erection of a motion picture theatre on the site. The property occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet and also fronts on Clinton Street between Montague and Remsen Streets.

If Negroes suffer economic hardship after the war and are not integrated into the community they may join radical and dissident forces in an effort to improve their lot, Professor E. Franklin Frazier, head of the sociology department at Howard University, warned yesterday.

The Central Savings Bank has sold to Solack Estates, Inc., the garage and lumber yard at the southwest corner of Fifty-sixth Street and Tenth Avenue. The property, measuring 200 by 100 feet, is assessed at $240,000. Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt Mosle acted as attorneys for the sellers and Benjamin Antin for the buyers. Joseph A. Polsky was the broker.

From the state of mind that exists at the other end of the New Haven Railroad, John P. Marquand and George S. Kaufman have fashioned one of the fall's cheerful and amiable evenings. "The Late George Apley," it is called, and it is a liberalized, or perhaps Broadwayized, version of the Pulitzer Prize novel which a few years ago sent Bostonians to looking reflectively in their mirrors.

BUFFALO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The house of delegates of the State Teachers Association adopted today, after spirited debate, a resolution approving any peacetime military training for the country's youth "that may be necessary for national security."

Overcoming sundry mishaps, "Rhapsody," said to represent an expenditure of more than $200,000, will have its delayed premiere this evening at the Century, after a series of eight previews. An 8:15 curtain is announced by sponsors Blevins Davis and Lorraine Manville Dresselhuys.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 21 -- A bonus of $300 each was voted today by the City Commission to city employes earning up to $5,000 a year. The bonuses, to be paid Dec. 15, will total approximately $1,500,000 and were suggested by Mayor Frank Hague in a letter to fellow-Commissioners as recognition for the extra work done by employes due to retirements and enlistments into the armed forces of other employes.

Still rankling under the sting of Noel Coward's reference to "mournful little Brooklyn boys" weeping over slight wounds, Brooklyn officials paraded indignant service men from their home borough before a public hearing of the City Council yesterday to give the lie to the story.

A new shop has just been opened by Barton's Bonbonniere, Inc., which operates three other candy stores in Manhattan and two in Brooklyn. The new establishment, at 2289 Broadway, at Eighty-first Street, replaces the original one a block away, at Broadway and Eightieth Street, where the company started in business in 1940.

Magistrate Anna M. Kross in the Bowery Court yesterday denounced as "fantastic" and "outrageous" the failure of Paul Moss, License Commissioner, to restore to Rosario Dieli of 15 Bay Thirty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, his license to serve customers personally in his barber shop at 125 Bowery.

ADVANCE HEADQUARTERS, United States Ninth Air Force, Nov. 21 -- Sixteen P-47 Thunderbolts of the Ninth Tactical Air Command attacked a flight of sixty Messerschmitt 109's near Duesseldorf this morning. Ten of the Nazi planes were shot down and two probably destroyed in a ten-minute battle at 12,000 feet. One P-47 failed to return.

Knowledge of artificial respiration that William Indrunas, 14 years old, of 505 East Seventy-ninth Street, obtained as a Boy Scout and while serving last summer as a junior lifeguard at a Maine camp, enabled him to save the lives yesterday afternoon of John Lloyd, 62, and his wife, Agnes, 51, who were overcome by fumes from a gas heater.

PARIS, Nov. 21 -- Courts of justice created to try collaborators with the Germans are now operating in all parts of France and many death sentences are being passed. Those reported today, for instance, include two in Toulouse, one in Auch, one in Marseille and one in Digne, all for denouncing patriots to the Gestapo.

David S. Meister has purchased the six-story seventy-three-family apartment house at 1975-79 Walton Avenue, near 179th Street, the Bronx, from a client of David Kassell, attorney. Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., were the brokers. The property is assessed at $225,000 and occupies a plot 150 by 100 feet.

To report that it rained yesterday would be the understatement of the season. Nor would it be newsworthy, because anyone who stepped out-of-doors, or even looked through a window, was well aware of the nasty mood old Jupe Pluvius was in all day.

MOSCOW, Nov. 21 -- Pravda on Sunday criticized the provisional governments of France and Belgium for their alleged failure to stamp out all fascist influences and for attempting to disarm the patriot resistance forces that played a big role in liberating their respective countries.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- A joint plenary session of three committees of the International Civil Aviation Conference was called today for tomorrow afternoon to consider the partial agreement made public by the American, British and Canadian delegations last night for the establishment of an International Air Administration to deal with post-war commercial aviation.
ATHENS, Nov. 21 -- As many as 5,000 persons are said to have disappeared in mysterious ways in the Salonika area since the city's liberation at the beginning of November.

When learned men get together to measure living costs they put out mathematical analyses that housewives may be unequipped to digest. However, some of us can simplify the picture in a more realistic way.

WITH THE SEVENTH ARMY, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Forty-fourth Infantry Division now fighting under the command of Alabama-born Maj. Gen. Robert L. Spragins, has been responsible for many gains in the stab of the United States Seventh Army toward the Rhine.

SOMEWHERE IN GERMANY, Nov. 20 (Delayed) -- We are sitting in the kitchen of what once was a fairly substantial house on a tree-lined street of this battered village on the Ninth Army front. Crouched over a seemingly disordered array of radio sets and wires is Lieut. Col. Joseph G. Focht of Reading, Pa.
One special offering and one secondary distribution were carried out successfully yesterday in Wall Street, adding to the rapidly growing list of such transaction.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Ray Edmundson failed today to obtain a court order to force his name on the United Mine Workers election ballot as a candidate for president. Rejecting his suit, a Federal District Court declined to enjoin the UMW from conducting
LONDON, Nov. 22 -- For the first time since 1939 British consumers have something that Americans do not have -- plenty of cigarettes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- An effort to increase the output by 25 per cent of truck tires, critically needed for war and civilian purposes, was the theme today of an emergency conference of officials with representatives of every tire company in the country.

PARIS, Nov. 22 (UP) -- One to two million American troops will observe Thanksgiving tomorrow with turkey dinners in six European countries, including Germany. Many of the men will attend divine services in cathedrals that they helped to liberate.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe regained his winning form tonight in his 1,500-point world championship three-cushion billiard match with Welker Cochran of San Francisco, defeating the challenger in the twenty-sixth block, 50-36, in thirty-three innings.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- A threat of a strike of Illinois telephone operators loomed tonight when a strike vote was ordered taken by Mrs. Anne Benscoter, president of the State organization. She authorized Edwin R. Hackett, attorney for the organization, to wire six Illinois division board members as follows:

The Texas Institute of Letters announces as its selection for the "best Texas" book of 1943-44, "The Magic of Limping John," by Frank Goodwyn. The book, published last July by Farrar Rinehart, is a story of American Mexicans in Texas by a Texas author who grew up in the brush country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The War Production Board extended its list of permitted lighting fixtures today, adding several new products of the fluorescent type to those which may be manufactured under terms of limitation order L-78.

Last of the lost provinces to greet the troops of liberation, Alsace stands first today in the heart of France. For it is there that the final hour of foreign conquest is running out. As General de Lattre de Tassigny marches his victorious army up the west bank of the Rhine he is closing the historic door through which German barbarism has poured again and again into Gaul.

OTTAWA, Nov. 22 -- A resort to conscription for overseas service now, on the eve of certain victory, would be dangerous to the Canadian war effort, and to the unity and strength of the country for generations to come, Prime Minister W.L. MacKenzie King said in Parliament today.
ADVANCE HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A supplement to today's communique:

Winston Churchill in a recent address in Commons condemned the assassination by alleged Jewish terrorists in Cairo of Lord Moyne. Alluding to himself as one of the "consistent friends of the Jews and a constant architect of their future," he declared that continuation of such acts might move him to reconsider his, what we are presumed to infer, favorable attitude toward Zionism.

Your editorial "The Treaty-Making Power" gives the same implication as your AP dispatch of the preceding day -- namely, that the only method by which the Constitution may be amended is by having the amendment proposed by a two-thirds vote of each house of Congress and ratified by three-quarters of the States.

ROME, Nov. 22 -- The desperate condition of the Italian Partisans in the north as a winter without help or hope is about to begin was vividly described in today's Italia Liberia by Capt. Ettore Sighieri, the commander of a Partisan brigade, who arrived last week from the German-occupied zone.

Men's straw hat manufacturers probably are oversold for the 1945 season, observers stated yesterday, because of a desire to accept maximum orders with the hope that larger supplies may be available later in the production season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- To be members of the Surplus Property Board, which will have upward of $100 billions in Government property to sell, the President has named one Democratic lame duck and intends to name another as soon as this second casualty of the last election is in a legal position to be designated.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 22 -- A special article in the Calcutta Statesman, one of the two leading British dailies in India, this morning regards the Cabinet changes in Chungking as a success for the progressive forces in China and suggests that it may pave the way for a settlement with the Communists.

Gasoline stocks in the United States at the close of last week amounted to 78,741,000 barrels, consisting of 13,055,000 of unfinished fuel, 39,440,000 of civilian grade automotive and 26,246,000 of aviation, military and blending supplies, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
Financial, commodity and livestock markets throughout the United States will be closed today in observance of Thanksgiving Day. British and Canadian markets will operate as usual.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Two guards -- Thomas B. (Tiger Tony) Smith 2d of Wyncote, Pa., and Capt. Macauley Whiting of Birmingham, Mich. -will play their final game for Yale Saturday when the Bulldogs attempt to keep their perfect record intact in a contest with the University of Virginia in the Bowl.
