You may be thinking the war is about over, and wondering why you should buy more war bonds.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Cold statistics, whether or not they are a good yardstick by which to measure ability, gave the Western division of the National Football League something to worry about today as the Packers, Western champions, scanned the Eastern horizon in an effort to determine which team they'll meet in the loop's play-off next month.

In its first change of ownership since its erection in 1926, the eight-story garage building on a plot 49 by 156 feet at 17-19 East Twelfth Street has been sold by the 17-19 East Twelfth Street Corporation to a client of Solomon Gilbert, attorney, for cash over a first mortgage of $145,000 held by the Harlem Savings Bank and a purchase money second mortgage of $30,000 for ten years.

Reports of sales in the Sixth War Bond Drive are encouraging. One-sixth of the E bond quota of $2,500,000,000 was sold in the first twenty-four hours. That is good. But no figure could be good enough.

General Motors has completed manufacture of the one millionth machine gun for the War Department, according to an announcement yesterday by C.E. Wilson, president. During the four years the company has been turning out machine guns prices have been consistently reduced, he pointed out.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Public hearings on the qualifications of former Gov. Robert A. Hurley of Connecticut and Lieut. Col. Edward Heller of California, who were nominated by President Roosevelt on Tuesday for two of the three posts on the Surplus Property Board, appeared to be a certainty tonight.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 22 -- The magnitude of last Saturday's carrier blow against Manila is even greater than at first reported, and later dispatches from Vice Admiral J.S. McCain, commander of the task force, now show that a total of sixteen vessels were either destroyed or left burning and badly damaged.

A spectacular two-alarm fire that enveloped the garment district with dense black smoke swept a row of stores at Thirty-ninth Street and Broadway and snarled heavy vehicular traffic for more than an hour yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Conceding that the Treasury Department's Procurement Division had made a mistake in acceding to the Army's request for a minimum of publicity in connection with the offering of some 22,000,000 surplus flashlight batteries from Army stocks, Nov. 4, witnesses from the department assured a Senate investigating committee today that the error would not be repeated.

LONDON, Nov. 22 (U.P.) -- Italy-based heavy bombers of the United States Fifteenth Air Force blasted strategic targets in southern Germany and Austria today after a giant armada of the Royal Air Force from Britain last night kindled tremendous fires among synthetic oil works in the Ruhr and rail targets east of the central Rhineland.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Communique 228:

MOSCOW, Nov. 22 (UP) -- Premier Joseph Stalin wishes to see a "strong, independent, democratic" Poland allied with Britain, France and the United States as well as the Soviet Union, the Soviet press said today in a Tass dispatch from Lublin.
" Button Up Your Overcoat" is not only the name of a popular song of yesteryear, it is also the timely advice given to bustling New Yorkers yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.

LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 23 -- Red Army troops yesterday thrust to within eighteen miles of the Danube River north of Budapest in a drive designed to isolate Pest, eastern half of the Hungarian capital, while twenty-two miles northeast of the city, Berlin said, Russian tanks broke into the strategic rail junction of Hatvan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- By the beginning of next year the postoffice hopes to put in the first-class offices 100,000,000 postal notes, a new and economical means of sending money orders not exceeding $10 through the mails, Postmaster General Frank C. Walker said today.

A stabilized tax program is vital to successful planning of post-war business and financial requirements and to encouragement of investment, Harry E. Taten of Wasserman Taten, certified public accountants, said yesterday at the meeting of the Uptown Credit Group at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
WRIGHT FIELD, Ohio, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Army Air Forces disclosed today it had developed a "good" robot bomb which could be used if needed and said the weapon had been in test flight since Oct. 11.

In a letter addressed to Max Jacquin Jr., assistant vice president of the New York Stock Exchange and an official of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, Thomas L. Norton, chairman of the New York War Labor Board, has clarified the policy of the National Labor Relations Board with regard to employe bonuses.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Among 440 casualties announced today by the Navy Department were the following from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Twenty-seven hundred members of the Washington Traffic Council, affiliate of the National Federation of Telephone Workers, voted at two mass meetings tonight to strike at 6 A.M. tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- A B-17 Flying Fortress, winging on in robotlike flight after it had been abandoned by its crew in mid-air, put aviators and civilians over a wide area of the Middle West on a four-hour alert today, before it crashed in a sparsely settled, wooded area near Duluth.

The New Jersey Governor's fishing tournament has exactly one week to run and it looks as though a $50 war bond is not going to be claimed. The bond was put up as a prize for the largest tuna caught. No tuna at all, to say nothing of a large one, has been entered in the tournament.

Five of a committee of friends of Carlo Tresca, the slain editor of the Italian language newspaper Il Martello, notified District Attorney Frank S. Hogan yesterday that the committee had added $5,000 to the $1,000 previously offered by the widow as a reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the man or men responsible for shooting the editor at Fifth Avenue and Fifteenth Street on Jan. 11, 1943.
LONDON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- By a vote of 254 to 16 the House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill to revive a Federal crop insurance system. The system, originally adopted in 1938, was killed last spring when the House refused to appropriate any more money for the project on the ground that it was not self-sustaining.

PARIS, Nov. 22 (U.P.) -- P.G. Wodehouse, British author, who was seized by the Nazis in their occupation of France and broadcast from Berlin in 1941, awaited release tonight from the Quai des Orfevres Prison, where he has been held since his arrest Monday night by French judiciary police handling treason and collaboration cases.

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- For the first time since the Allies brought their operations to French soil, the newspapers today print the fact that German prisoners of war are treated by American military authorities strictly in accord with the Geneva international convention.

Mrs. Laura Norman, 23-year-old wife of a merchant seaman, not only won her freedom in Kings County Court yesterday but she received also a Thanksgiving turkey and $25. She had been accused of third-degree attempted robbery, but Judge Louis Goldstein permitted her to plead to petit larceny and suspended sentence.

Of the five baseball units being readied for overseas shipment, one already has left this country for an undisclosed destination. This was announced yesterday by USO Camp Shows, which, in conjunction with the Special Services Division of the Army, is sponsoring the tours.

Lieut. Frances Slanger, an Army nurse at a hospital somewhere in Belgium, could not sleep. So begins The Associated Press account of her last days in service. Getting up in the early morning, she wrote down some of her impressions of the American soldier as she had seen him.

NEW ROCHELLE, Nov. 22 -- The conversion of Fort Slocum by the War Department into a prison camp for convicted soldiers was characterized by Representative Ralph A. Gamble of Larchmont as "stupid and a mistake," when he addressed a protest mass meeting of 200 residents of New Rochelle and vicinity held in Albert Leonard High School here.

Nofade Fabrics, long in the men's shirting field, has entered the women's wear market and will make summer sportswear, beach wear, children's wear and junior miss fashions, it was announced yesterday. Items will be released to thirty-seven stores throughout the country.

LONDON, Nov. 22 (U.P.) -- Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia, in a sweeping move to consolidate his war-shattered country, has granted full general amnesty to thousands of Yugoslavs who supported Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch, Serb leader and Marshal Tito's enemy, as well as to members of the Croat Regular Army, the Free Yugoslav radio said today.

An acute shortage in psychiatric manpower, with war neuroses expected to take a sharp swing upward, was characterized here yesterday as "constituting a national emergency," and as "the most critical manpower shortage in the country today."
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 22 -- The first move to repatriate Japanese diplomats was made yesterday.

The stock market made further small gains yesterday in a pre-holiday session that witnessed a natural contraction in business. Further strength was evidenced by the rail section, especially Southern Pacific, while a long list of specialties were traded in moderate volume and at higher prices.

MOSCOW, Nov. 22 -- A new law designed to broaden the purge of Polish traitors who assumed German citizenship to obtain special favors during the five-year Nazi occupation has been passed by the Polish Committee of National Liberation and already is going into force, it was announced in the Soviet press today.

BOSTON, Nov. 22 -- The Pacific Mills of Lawrence, manufacturers of woolen and worsted fabrics, paid to the Office of Price Administration today $2,165,842.02, the largest cash settlement for alleged ceiling price violations in the history of the Emergency Price Control Act.

New York City will observe today its third wartime Thanksgiving Day with family gatherings from which many loved ones will be absent because of the war and with religious services where prayers will include thanks for the successes of the United Nations. The city will extend hospitality to visiting service men and women and will remember its own sick and needy.

Pursuant to an order of the Court of Chancery of the State of Delaware, the class B stock of the Western Union Telegraph Company not yet distributed to the preferred and common stockholders of Postal Telegraph, Inc., in liquidation, has been converted into class A stock, Western Union announced yesterday.

Metropolitan students already have "gone over the top" in the war bond school football doubleheader expected to lure a throng of 25,000 to Ebbets Field in Brooklyn on Saturday. According to the latest figures released by the New York War Finance Committee of the Treasury Department last night, the quota of $250,000 in bonds and war stamps set for the twin bill has been reached.

Organization of a committee for extension and improvement of nation-wide farm telephone service in the post-war period was announced yesterday. The group, to be known as the Joint Committee on Rural Telephone Service, was formed to advance programs that various telephone companies had been working on individually.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Bolivian National Police announced today that seven high Army officers and politicians had been executed "thus far" for participation in Sunday's abortive revolt at Oruro, Bolivian tin mining center.

DON'T get alarmed. That's perfectly correct. Ed Kubale, now the co-coach of the Brooklyn Tigers, once played center for Centre College. In fact, he played an awful lot of center, sixty minutes of it, in the never-to-be-forgotten game between little Centre and mighty Harvard one bright October afternoon in 1921.

Dozens of new colonies where the best possible working conditions for creative artists can be provided should be set up after the war on the same financial basis as endowed universities, Mrs. Edward A. MacDowell, widow of the American composer, said yesterday.
Led by the strength in the December delivery the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, 7 to 13 points higher on active months.

War bond sales to individuals in the Sixth War Loan have already mounted to $482,000,000 in the nation and to $39,062,087 in New York City, it was announced yesterday. The national goal for individual sales is $5,000,000,000 and that in this city is $597,500,000.

An active legislation should prevent those responsible for "Rhapsody" from ever again listening to nice Viennese tunes as they sip their beer. Understanding clearly has gone from them. For the operetta which opened at the Century last evening they took a group of Fritz Kreisler's waltzing little songs and by dint of a top-heavy and weighty production turned the whole into as pretentious and dull a matter as can be imagined.

The religious fervor which led the Massachusetts Colony to inaugurate a day of thanksgiving in appreciation of God's material blessings should not be used, as was done by a radio speaker, to preface the erroneous notion that the Pilgrims were a tolerant people.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 22 -- Ezequiel Padilla, Secretary of Foreign Affairs, told Mexican reporters last night that Argentina should be allowed to explain her position and that the other Latin-American nations should meet to hear her viewpoint.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- America's fighting man at home and abroad will have his turkey on Thanksgiving Day.

Field Marshal Shunroku Hata was transferred yesterday from his post as commander in chief of Japanese forces in China to take over the Inspector-Generalship of Military Education in a move that the Tokyo domestic radio hailed as a promotion designed to utilize

ROME, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A dispute over the division of tolls has held up for a week the institution of a radio-message service for civilians between Italy and the United States and Britain, and there was no indication today that a settlement was in sight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Representative Compton, Republican, of Connecticut, pleaded today for the return to this country of a small group of Connecticut soldiers "marooned in the South Pacific area under constant attack" for more than two years without relief.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- Mayor La Guardia of New York, a member of the American delegation to the International Civil Aviation Conference, made a strong appeal at a plenary session late today, urging the conference to come to a complete agreement on post-war commercial aviation which the American, British and Canadian delegations have proposed for an international organization to deal with post-war commercial aviation.

DETROIT, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Mrs. Frances Smith, president of the Michigan Telephone Employes Federation, said tonight that a walkout of 2,000 Michigan Bell operators in war-vital Detroit would begin at 6 A.M. tomorrow "unless, in the meantime, the Government takes over the Ohio strike situation."

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Nov. 22 (AP) -- The National Grange, criticizing the Bretton Woods Conference, today recommended the absorption of the proposed international monetary fund and its functions by the proposed World Bank for Reconstruction.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 22 -- Premier Hubert Pierlot received a prolonged ovation in Parliament this afternoon when he announced his intention to remain at the head of the State despite the fiery opposition encountered in the past week.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 22 -- A freakish cold snap in central Germany, heralding an early and unusually severe winter, has inflicted extreme hardships on some 2,000,000 people still remaining in the ruins of Berlin. Sixty per cent of the population has no windows and 30 per cent has no means of heating premises, it is said.
Mrs. R. Jay Flick, who had been staying at the Ambassador after returning from Lenox, Mass., has gone to her Winter home in Palm Beach.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- A directive will soon be issued by Prime Minister Churchill and President Roosevelt, it is understood, continuing on a new basis the combined boards that have been administering production resources and raw materials during the war.

Boris Koutzen, Russian violinist and composer, was heard in a recital last night in Town Hall. The program featured his string quartet in B. No. 2, which received the 1944 award of the Society for the Publication of American Music. In this work he was assisted by Bernard Robbins, violin; Carlton Cooley, viola, and Harvey Shapiro, 'cello.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Thursday, Nov. 23 (AP) -- American fighter planes hammering at shipping to prevent Japanese reinforcements from reaching Leyte Iscland, destroyed or damaged four troop-laden freighters off Ormoc, headquarters announced today.
ROME, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A communique:

The restaurants of New York, from humble neighborhood eating places to the dining rooms of the plushiest hotels, are ready for a record-breaking Thanksgiving Day rush by families who were unable to get a turkey for the home oven.

Much of the vast amount of temporary emergency war housing erected with Federal funds in the last four years to serve war production centers throughout the nation appears destined to go abroad to fill critical building needs in devastated areas.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A program for permanent naval reserve officer training courses in fifty colleges besides Annapolis was outlined today before a Congressional committee.

It has remained for the visiting John S. Dodd, M.P., president of the Association of British Chambers of Commerce, to say one of the soundest and wisest things said by any of the British or American delegates to the International Business Convention at Rye. Britain, he declared, must increase its exports, not because it wants to take over other markets, "but because we have to pay for our imports."
SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, KANDY, Ceylon, Nov. 22 (AP) -- A communique:
Yesterday's communique, a broadcast from Moscow and reported by he Federal Communications Commission:

The election of Richard K. Paynter Jr. to the advisory board of the Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street branch of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, was announced yesterday by Percy H. Johnston, chairman of the bank. Mr. Paynter is treasurer of the New York Life Insurance Company.

PLYMOUTH, Mass., Nov. 22 -- A festive spirit was in the air today as Plymouth, scene of the Pilgrims' first Thanksgiving, prepared for its most elaborate observance of the feast day since the war began.
T. Kelly Pierce has been named general manager of the Duramold division of Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation, specializing in bonded wood and plastic construction.
CHUNGKING, China. Nov. 22 (AP) -- A communique from American Headquarters:

Many announcements of yearend dividends were made yesterday, and several of the declarations brought the annual payments well above the amounts received by stockholders last year. Among the dividend actions were the following:

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- The convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations unanimously adopted today a resolution making the CIO Political Action Committee its permanent political instrument and instructed the committee to begin immediately preparations for participation in local elections next year and the Congressional and State elections of 1946.

A plea for a program to aid women workers in reconversion adjustments and re-employment problems and to appoint qualified women as assistant administrators and members of technical staffs has been sent to James F. Byrnes, director of the Office of War Mobilization and Reconversion, by the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, Margaret A. Hickey, president, announced yesterday.

The human mind, like the human eye, can focus on just one spot at a time. Today that spot, for Americans reading war news, may be somewhere on the new western front. Awhile ago it was in the Philippines. Longer ago still it was in Italy.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 22 -- Robert Young, on loan from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, will have the lead opposite Larraine Day in the RKO-Radio version of Edward Chodorov's play "Those Endearing Young Charms," the screen rights of which RKO recently acquired from Samuel Goldwyn. Lewis Allen, who directed "The Uninvited" and "Our Hearts Were Young and Gay" for Paramount, will be the director.

WASHINGTON, NOV. 22 -- Leo T. Crowley, head of the Foreign Economic Administration, submitted his resignation last week to President Roosevelt but has now agreed, in response to the President's request, to stay until Germany is eliminated from the war.

Spurred by action of the Office of Price Administration in revising M-127 controlling the price of converted fabrics, 250 cotton converters meeting yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania sent a telegram of protest to OPA demanding a public hearing.

The first ballet by Antonia Cobos had its premiere last night at the International Theatre, where the Ballet International is now in the fourth week of its season. The work is entitled "Mute Wife," and takes its theme from Anatole France's "The Man Who Married a Dumb Wife."

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 22 -- Joseph D. Keenan, vice chairman of the War Production Board, urged today that American labor be permitted to send its experienced members to aid in the task of reconstructing Europe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Because of the brief time remaining in the present Congress, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee has decided not to hold hearings on the two major treaties pending before it. One is the Anglo-American oil treaty and the other a treaty covering regulation and distribution of the waters of the Colorado and the Rio Grande Rivers.

Organization of blood donor groups for the duration of the war, to make sure that increased supplies of plasma are sent to the fighting fronts, was urged upon industry and labor last night in the weekly broadcast over Station WMCA of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Office of Price Administration raised producers' prices of apples 15 cents for a standard box today for all growers in sixteen up-State New York counties and all or part of ten other New England and Middle Atlantic States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Spars, who are the United States Coast Guard women reserves, will celebrate their second anniversary tomorrow with nearly 10,000 women in the ranks, the largest number being in Washington, New York, Boston, Seattle, Cleveland, Miami, Long Beach, St. Louis and Norfolk.

Beside each young civilian in knickers or jumper dress sat a uniformed "parent-for-the-day" from the United States or British Army, Navy or Marines. Proxy parents and children became acquainted as they helped each other to holiday fare and exchanged stories of how they celebrated Thanksgiving with their own families.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Longchamps Farms' Leslie Grey easily won the Discovery Purse at Pimlico today. In a field of a dozen 2-year-olds Leslie Grey triumphed by four lengths under good handling by Ted Atkinson, leading rider in America for 1944.

After a three-hour session last night between representatives of the three New York branches of the Federation of Long Lines Telephone Workers and officials of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, it was announced a few minutes before midnight that the conference would be resumed again at 11 o'clock this morning.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 22 -- County Supervisor John F. O'Neill announced today he has called upon Donald Allan, superintendent of the Hudson County Bureau of Elections, to explain what Mr. O'Neill described as "the disenfranchisement of thousands of Hudson County citizens on election day, Nov. 7."

CAMP TAMBO, Angaur, Nov. 22 -- Angaur, once a Japanese possession in the western Marianas, now is operating on the American plan and under the auspices of the Navy's civil affairs authorities there has been a renaissance of native dancing, which the Japanese had banned as "heathenish."

Alice Orovan's midseason collection presented yesterday at the Hotel Pierre showed a variety of talents. Negligees, street clothes and evening gowns were shown. Laddie Northridge contributed hats that complemented the costumes, as did the jewelry by Lackritz.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 -Pennsylvania and Cornell will start another half century of football rivalry on Franklin Field Saturday and from the way it looks, the second fifty years aren't going to be any easier for the Big Red.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 22 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops in the Burma border area have driven forward nearly twenty miles from recaptured Mangshih on the old Burma Road and are converging on Chefang, twenty-five miles south of Mangshih, from two and possibly three directions, a Chinese communique said today.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 22 (U.P.) -- The success or failure of the Army-Navy football game on Dec. 2 as a bond salesman for the Sixth War Loan depended tonight upon the amount of bonds which will be raised for the 1,428 box seats in Municipal Stadium.

WITH UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY, in Germany, Nov. 22 -- Eschweiler, important industrial and transportation center, fell to Lieut. Gen. Courtney H. Hodges' forces today in a slashing attack that was begun daringly in pitch darkness at 3 o'clock this morning.
CANBERRA, Australia, Nov. 22 -- Acting Prime Minister F.M. Forde announced today the Government's intention to take over all interstate civil airline operations in Australia.
MOSCOW, Nov. 22 -- The Red Army newspaper Red Star published a sharp attack on THE NEW YORK TIMES military commentator, Hanson W. Baldwin, today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from, Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

Gold reserves in foreign countries at the end of September amounted to the unprecedented total of $14,385,000,000, compared to $20,825,000,000 in the United States. Together with official dollar balances of some $3,000,000,000, these reserves give foreign countries as a whole more than twice the gold resources they held on the eve of the great depression of the Thirties, according to the November Federal Reserve Bulletin.

In a letter printed in your issue of Nov. 20 a correspondent mentioned having desisted from the purchase of a pair of kid gloves because they were made in Argentina, and that the sales clerk, who had two boys fighting and felt bitter, wished that others would boycott those goods.

The Greek American Committee for National Unity, with headquarters at 152 West Forty-second Street, will sponsor a rally in the Palm Gardens, 302 West Fifty-second Street, next Sunday afternoon, beginning at 2 o'clock, when reports on conditions in Greece, contradicting recently published newspaper dispatches that have criticized the activities of the National Liberation Front (EAM) in that country, will be heard.

ROME, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The sluggish battle for the Apennine foothills just southeast of Faenza lumbered forward another mile today. British and Polish troops of the Eighth Army seized the fortified village of Castiglione and a few more ridges against stubborn opposition.

WITH UNITED STATES NINTH ARMY in Germany, Nov. 22 -- The most formidable tank force thrown into battle by the Germans since D-day, including forty-two new seventy-ton King Tigers, has been decisively beaten by United States Ninth Army armor on the plain west of the River Roer.

A plea was issued yesterday by the Synagogue Council of America that "all barriers against the full participation of the Negroes in the economic, professional, patriotic, industrial, educational, artistic and recreational life of our country be abolished." The council said that it represented all branches of Judaism.
Victor Spitzer acted as broker in the sale of the property at 662 Madison Avenue for the Bank for Savings to the Madison Midtown Corporation.

ABOARD A UNITED STATES CARRIER, off the Philippines, Nov. 14 (Delayed) -- Manila Harbor today looks as if a cyclone had struck it, with superstructures of sunken Japanese ships poking through oil-covered water, and a thick blanket of heavy, black smoke lying low over the beautiful city.

Although there is very little prospect that they will beat the football Giants, the Brooklyn Tigers are going about their preparations as though entirely confident there will be smiles on their faces Sunday evening after the Polo Grounds game.

An honorary degree of Doctor of Sacred Theology was conferred on the Right Rev. Walter Hubert Baddeley, Lord Bishop of Melanesia, by Columbia University at a special convocation held yesterday afternoon in the Low Memorial Library, on the campus.

The Aircraft Accessories Corporation in its annual statement for the year ended on April 30 issued yesterday to stockholders by Randolph C. Walker, president and general manager, disclosed net sales of $38,318,830, representing an increase of 85.7 per cent over the $20,631,469 volume for the preceding fiscal year.

Not that it will soothe outraged feelings in New York's premier borough, but it is just possible that when Noel Coward spoke about the behavior of Brooklyn's wounded soldiers at the front he was not thinking of Brooklyn specifically.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- Corn was the feature of the grain markets today on the Board of Trade. Prices moved up steadily on buying headed by cash interests and at times shorts and commission houses competed for the relatively small offerings.

The Board of Estimate closed yesterday its public hearings on the proposal of the City Planning Commission to amend the zoning regulations to impose additional restrictions on height and area of all new buildings throughout the city except those in unrestricted and general business areas.

" The Man Who Had All the Luck," tonight's opening at the Forrest, represents the initial venture for Herbert H. Harris, a manufacturer of cosmetics, and his well-known playwriting nephew, Joseph Fields, as producer and director, respectively.

The Board of Estimate voted yesterday, at a special meeting to add $100,000 to the $250,000 already allocated to the Park Department to meet the cost of removing from the streets the trees damaged in the hurricane of Sept. 16.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Thursday, Nov. 23 (U.P.) -- American heavy bombers have blown up a Japanese light cruiser and damaged another warship in the third raid in four days on the enemy naval base of Brunei Bay, in northwestern Borneo, and other United States warplanes have sunk or damaged seven other Japanese ships in the western Pacific, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- J.A. Krug, chairman of the War Production Board, announced today the membership of the re-constituted Aircraft Production Board. The board had been in partial eclipse since the loss of its chairman, Charles E. Wilson, who resigned as WPB executive vice chairman on Aug. 23.

A B-29 BASE IN WESTERN CHINA, Nov. 21 (Delayed) (AP) -- Superfortresses in strong force today made their third attack on Omura, key aircraft center on Kyushu, southernmost of the Japanese home islands.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Although business on today's stock markets remained limited the tone was firm and there was some selective buying of industrials. There was a demand for British Celanese and cinema issues.

MOSCOW, Nov. 22 -- The Soviet press announced today without explanation that Marshal Klementy E. Voroshiloff had been relieved of his duties as a member of the eight-man top Defense Committee of the Soviet Union and had been replaced by Army General Nikolai Bulganin, former Mayor of Moscow.

Grief and anxiety sit down at many Thanksgiving tables today as they did in 1943 and in 1942. Yet as we do not think it wrong to give thanks in normal years, each with their private tragedies for many thousands of families, we can still give thanks in a time of public crisis and tragedy.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- Major oil corporations are embarking on a program of operating post-war coast-to-coast chains of airports for selling petroleum products to aviators in the manner that roadside stations serve motorists, County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach said today after analyzing bids for the operation of Westchester's new $4,000,000 airport at Purchase.

Fond are all gardeners of their gardens, even in bleak November. But they seem to differ as to what constitutes a garden's chief glory. While one on this page last week rhapsodized over his last lingering roses of the departed summer, another sang of his cabbages that yet remain to comfort him in the approaching winter.

The Government has no desire to remain in the burlap business after the war in the Pacific is over, importers familiar with Washington opinion stated yesterday. Control will be relinquished just as soon as all ports of entry can be utilized, it was indicated, but until then traders cannot operate on a free basis because of the difference in price resulting from differentials in freight costs.
The strike of telephone workers became serious last night when operators in Washington voted to strike at 6 A.M. today in "the nerve center of the war effort."

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- The meat shortage is reaching an intensified stage that will last anywhere from three to six months, packing sources reported today. Reasons for the tightening up of civilian supplies, they said, were a larger Government "take" for the armed forces and inadequate receipts of live animals.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- In the last few weeks, following a call by the War Office for greater production, an increasing amount of British labor and plant capacity has been turned over to making shells and the production raise is rising so swiftly, the Ministry of Supply said tonight, that there will be no shortage for the British Army in any foreseeable circumstances.

Two new films will have premieres in midtown theatres today. At Loew's State and ten other first-run Loew neighborhood theatres the new attraction will be Metro's "An American Romance," a drama starring Brian Donlevy. Written, produced and directed by King Vidor for Metro, the picture, filmed in Technicolor, includes Ann Richards, Walter Abel and John Qualen among its supporting players.

Institution of a policy of "borrowing" key workers from non-essential or less-essential industry for "must" and "critical" tasks in war industry, including a vital radar program in New York City, was announced yesterday by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 22 -- The first phase of the vital Battle of the Cologne Plain reached a successful conclusion today, when weary, mud-stained doughboys of Lieut. Gen. William H. Simpson's American Ninth Army hammered their way to the Roer River, backbone of the first defensive zone built by the enemy east and northeast of Aachen.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- Denying charges of carnally abusing and impairing the morals of two boys of his parish, the Rev. William C. Baxter, rector of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church here, contended today through counsel that the District Attorney's office had misinterpreted his attempt to help children of the church with sex education.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The application by American Electric Securities Corporation, New York, to purchase 2,020 shares of its preferred stock from A.F. Ritter and Rudolph Fluegge was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Although the British people are determined to maintain private enterprise, for some time after the close of hostilities merchandising and price controls must be maintained, E. Mackenzie Hay, chairman of the British Federation of Commodity and Allied Trade Associations, declared yesterday in an address at the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.
Plans for a new bank building and two apartment houses in Manhattan were filed yesterday by architects, who estimated the total cost of the projects at more than $2,300,000.

For thousands of New York youngsters tomorrow is a great day -- the traditional day for making the first trip downtown to see Santa Claus. As part of the shop-early-for-Christmas campaign, toy departments in most stores have been decked out in holiday array for the last week or two, and some have even rushed the season by pre-Thanksgiving introductions of Santa Claus, dog circuses or carousels.
Thanksgiving services will be held today in churches, synagogues and missions.

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- Addressing the Consultative Assembly today, Gen. Charles de Gaulle said that the settlement of the German problem might permit the creation of the unity of Europe that the French desired and of which Moscow, London and Paris would be "the three poles."

METZ, France, Nov. 22 -- This ancient citadel, whose erstwhile impregnable bastions were no match for modern warfare, was considered liberated today after the last two pockets of resistance within the city had been liquidated.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Black Hawks, cellar occupants in the National Hockey League, dominated play most of the way tonight, but the best they could get from the Rangers was a 4-4 tie before 11,436 fans in the Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Complications surrounding the revocation and reoperation of American branch factories in liberated countries after the war are many, according to Louis Domeratzy, chief of the European unit of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Admiral William F. Halsey, broadcasting a Thanksgiving Day message from his Third Fleet flagship, urged America today to be grateful for the courage of its fighting men.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission instituted a proceeding today against Ellis L. Phillips, chairman of the board of the Long Island Lighting Company, and three corporations to determine whether any or all of them should be registered under the Holding Company Act.

Yesterday might have have been an ordinary day at the Holloway home on Emerson Hill, S.I., with Mrs. Bernard L. Holloway following her regular Thursday schedule as nurse's aide at the Staten Island Hospital at Tompkinsville. There was one important difference: First Lieut. William L. Holloway was home for Thanksgiving dinner.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Slammin' Sam Snead returned to tournament golf with a bang today when he hung up a 2 under-par 70 to lead the field in the first round of the 72-hole Portland Open that opened the winter season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Lend-lease shipments of food and other agricultural products to the Allies during October totaled 719,300,000 pounds, an increase of 177,000,000 pounds over September, according to the War Food Administration.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Dr. Boris M. Stanfield, Professor of Economics at Columbia University, asserted here today that he had found "a state of worry and insecurity" in the ranks of American labor, but declared that workers nevertheless were displaying "a great sense of responsibility and patriotism."

Dr. David Levin bought from Esther Cantor the one-family house on a lot 40 by 100 feet at 1259 Forty-eighth Street, in Brooklyn, through Slomka Bros., brokers. The parcel is assessed at $10,500. The same brokers leased the two-story business building at 2120 Eighty-sixth Street for a client to Jack Solov and John E. Cama, tailors and dry cleaners.

AN AMERICAN BOMBER BASE in Southwest China, Nov. 14 (Delayed) (AP) -- Maj. Horace E. Carswell Jr., pilot of the B-24 Liberator that sank a Japanese cruiser and destroyer Oct. 16 in one of the greatest bombing exploits of the war, gave his life eleven nights later in a selfless effort to save members of his crew.

DOVER, N.J., Nov. 23 -- Five children trapped by blinding smoke on the third floor of a four-story frame building on fire in the heart of the business section were rescued this afternoon when the mothers of two of them joined with firemen, policemen and neighbors to form a human chain and swing the youngsters thirty feet down to the street.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Communique 229:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Officers of the Ohio Federation of Telephone Workers suddenly called off tonight a week-old strike of Dayton operators and urged an ending of sympathy walkouts in the other Ohio cities as well as in Washington and Detroit.

Sycamore balls hang pendent in the November wind, buttons that might have fastened the shaggy coat of some legendary woods-wanderer. And small boys pause beneath the trees to gather ammunition for sham battles. It is an autumn sight that reminds the outlander of the Osage Orange hedgerows of the Midwest.

In anticipation of further relaxation of War Production Board controls, many furniture manufacturers reversed during October their past policy of limited order bookings and accepted an unusual amount of business for future delivery, the Seidman Seidman bulletin on the furniture industry reported yesterday.

ROME, Nov. 23 -- Serious riots occurred today for the fourth day in a row in Rome's chief jail, Regina Coeli. The fact that the authorities are unable to prevent these riots, accompanied each day by the prisoners' setting fire to a part of the prison, is a good indication of the lack of public order in Rome.

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- This is the story of the death of Helene Vagliano, who died that others might live and fight. It is a story of all those of the resistance movement who were caught and will never parade down the Champs Elysees with bands playing.
LAWSON GENERAL HOSPITAL, Atlanta, Nov. 23 -- Some 2,000 soldiers, including about 900 amputation cases, had Thanksgiving Day dinner in the wards and mess halls here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that his soldiers are making daily headway by courage and suffering but they need "myriads of shells and tires and guns and blankets and planes."

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, have written letters expressing organized labor's concern over the threat of tuberculosis to workers because of wartime conditions, Frank Kiernan, executive director of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association, disclosed yesterday.

Societies and individuals who were incensed over a reputedly proposed plan to auction dog veterans of the Army's K-9 corps were reassured when Dogs for Defense announced yesterday that, in cooperation with the Treasury Department, it had adopted a new program requiring formal application and investigation of proffered homes for the dogs.

I wonder if anything can be done to keep our esteemed City Council from continuing to make an exhibition of itself in the matter of a light and insignificant book that should have been allowed to die peacefully of its own inanition.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 23 -- One hundred and twenty-four Catholic priests have been arrested in Bavaria following last Sunday's services, charged with high treason for having condemned as meaningless Germany's continued sacrifice of men.

MADRID, Nov. 23 -- Spain, these past weeks, has been taking an unusually, keen interest in her international status. This self-analysis of the nation's role on the world stage has been going on constantly, of course, and has been subject to revision in ratio to the progress of the war.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Commodity prices at the primary market level were unusually steady during the week ended Nov. 18, with increases of only 0.1 per cent recorded in three groups -- farm products, fuel and lighting materials and chemicals and allied products.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 23 -- German military commentators are beginning to profess more confidence in the efficiency of the flying bombs. A communique issued in Berlin today states that the V-1 has now performed for 130 days, while the newly installed V-2 has now had thirty tryouts.
ROME, Nov. 23 -- Two former NEW YORK TIMES employes, now on Army publications, have just made combat flights in heavy bombers and both got back safely, although one almost did not.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill, making an unexpected appearance at a Thanksgiving Day ceremony held by the British in honor of their American allies, acclaimed the United States tonight as "the greatest military, naval and air power in the world."

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 23 (U.P.) -- Maj. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer confirmed today that the arrival of two members of the Women's Army Corps represented a change of a long-standing policy that had made China the "never-never" land for women in the American armed services.

Rapid Allied progress in Burma in the first month since the ending of the monsoon rains is tangible evidence of progress during the past year in eliminating some of the many difficulties that have hampered past operations in the Burma-India theatre.

Despite the war, mankind has many things to be thankful for -- for the progress toward victory of the forces of democracy and freedom, for the general feeling in favor of participation in a future international organization for the maintenance of peace, and for the likelihood, after the conflict, of a better way of life for all peoples, ministers declared in Thanksgiving Day sermons here yesterday.

LONDON, Friday, Nov. 24 (UP) -- Russian troops yesterday invaded the southeastern borders of the puppet Axis stae of Slovakia while Berlin reported that "major Soviet forces" had landed on the thirty-mile-long mid-Danube island of Csepel, which extends almost into the heart of Budapest.

UNITED STATES FIFTEENTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, Italy, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The German Air Force will have more planes next spring than it has this year through production by small and scattered underground factories, Fifteenth Air Force authorities said today.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 23 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces have advanced from Mangshih on the Burma Road to within three miles of Chefang, a Chinese communique said today, opening up almost twenty more miles of the land route to Burma.

ROME, Nov. 23 (AP) -- British and Polish troops, slogging forward in the hills south of Highway 9 between Forli and Faenza against strong German resistance, have captured a few more villages and ridges and cleared most of the Nazis out of the Cosina River loop southeast of Faenza.

ROME, Nov. 23 -- This morning for the first time since 1941 -- when the service was held despite imprisonment of the pastor by Fascists who believed him a spy -- Thanksgiving Day was marked in St. Paul's American Church on Via Nazionale which for sixty-two years before Pearl Harbor had stood as a symbol of Italo-American good-will.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 23 -- The assassination of Lord Moyne was condemned today at the twenty-first annual conference of Junior Hadassan, young women's Zionist organization representing 20,000 members throughout the United States, although its national president, Miss Naomi Chertoff of New York City, asserted that British Colonial Office policies were partly to blame.
WASHINGTON, Friday, Nov. 24 -- Tokyo was attacked today by Superfortresses in a daylight mission launched from bases in the Marianas Islands.
A new work of Arnold Schoenberg, his "Ode to Napoleon" after Byron, was heard last night at the concert in Carnegie Hall given by Dr. Rodzinski and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

LONDON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- In one of his gloomiest articles, Nazi Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels declared tonight that the Germans are fighting now "armed with stoicism" and that "history surely cannot be so unjust" as to let Germany lose.
DETROIT, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Red Wings came from behind in the last six minutes tonight on Bill Hollett's goal to tie Montreal, 3 to 3, in a National Hockey League game before 12,582 fans.

Five days ago Maj. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, the new United States Chief of Staff to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, announced that he had submitted a plan -- "simple and I hope sound" -- for disposition of Chinese forces to meet and defeat the Japanese and eventually drive them from the continent. Now he has announced that his plan has been accepted.

In the first advertising of its kind since the liberation of France, Colcombet Wines announces that its French stocks of wine have escaped war damage and will be exported to this country as soon as shipping space is available. It is emphasized, however, that production of the wine started in California after the fall of France will be continued.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Bruising straight football, reminiscent of the days of 1910 when they last played Kansas here, carried Missouri to a 28-0 triumph today over the Jayhawkers in their fifty-third annual scrap before 20,000 spectators in Ruppert Stadium.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- A review of the British technical position as to aircraft and their operation in commercial aviation, made available here today, indicates that the empire is by no means in the helpless state for competition on the air lanes which has been attributed to it in some quarters in Chicago.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The stock markets here were cheerful today and members reported more business in the industrial and gilt-edged sections.

Zelomek, economist for the International Statistical Bureau, Inc., asserted recently.

The cooperation of both has been more than the enemy can withstand, and these two old arms of our fighting forces have never been more brilliant than in the last week.

The theft of 200 cartons of cigarettes from a North River pier, where they were awaiting shipment to overseas troops, led to the arrest yesterday by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and New York City policemen of two longshoremen and a truck driver on charges of stealing Government property.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Consumers depending upon coal, fuel oil and wood to heat their homes during this winter will experience no appreciable relaxations in the availability of any of these commodities, according to the findings in a survey conducted by the Office of War Information and reported on today.

ARMY AIR FORCES HEADQUARTERS, Pacific Ocean Areas, Friday, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A large force of B-29's, probably the greatest number yet to attack Japan, bombed industrial targets in Tokyo today, as a Thanksgiving Day message to the Japanese.

PIKEVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 23 (AP) -- James T. Scales, 17, a trusty at the State Training and Agricultural School (reformatory) for Negro boys near here, was shot to death today by a crowd which took him away from the jail after the daughter of the superintendent of the school had been killed and his wife severely injured.

Epstein play, "Chicken Every Sunday," in New York, has been signed by Twentieth Century-Fox to play Mrs. Elise Rickenbacker, mother of Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker, in "First, Last and Always," the story of the aviator.

Favored by a 14-minute handicap, George Casper, representing the Mitchell A.A. of Philadelphia, crossed the finish line first in the thirty-fourth annual walking event from Borough Hall, Brooklyn, to Coney Island, yesterday. The race, conducted by the Walkers Club of America, attracted twenty-nine contestants, all but one of whom negotiated the entire distance.

Roland Harriman, manager of the North Atlantic Area, said yesterday.

Cost-plus fixed-fee contracts have cut the percentage of net profits to gross sales at the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation to a new low of eight-tenths of 1 per cent, Robert E. Gross, president, disclosed yesterday in an interim report to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- In a broad dual textile pricing action today, the Office of Price Administration set forth a list of dollars and cents ceiling prices for low-priced infants' and children's clothing and simultaneously made a sweeping revision of price controls over cotton and rayon finished piece goods.

SAIPAN, the Marianas, Friday, Nov. 24 -- The United States launched a mighty aerial weapon -- the brand-new Twenty-first Bomber Command of the Twentieth Army Air Force -- straight at the heart of Japan today. BALTIMORE, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Twenty thousand racegoers who wagered $1,676,492 watched a parade of upsets at Pimlico today. The surprises included a neck victory by Houghton P. Metcalf's Star Copy in the $7,500 added Lady Baltimore Handicap.
