It is difficult to realize the immensity of India's problems on the educational front. In a population of 389 million there are 179 languages and 544 recognized dialects. There are approximately 239 millions of Hindus, 78 millions of Moslems, 13 million Buddhists, plus many other smalle groups.

This week the Curtiss-Wright Corporation completed at Buffalo its 15,000th fighter plane for the United Nations -- a total of more fighter aircraft than have been built for this war by any other manufacturer in the world. It was a Curtiss P-40 Warhawk that rolled off the assembly line to set the production mark, scion of a long line of P-40's which have been flown to glory on every front.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 23 -- Matsuwa Island, in the Kuriles, was bombarded Tuesday by a Pacific Fleet task force, which started large fires and set off explosions among enemy defense installations. Enemy guns did not reply, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz said in his communique today, adding that none of of our ships was damaged.

Much praise is heard of the Wacs, the Waves, the Wasps, the Spars and the "Lady Marines," but not so much of their small sisters, the Girl Scouts. Yet many a young woman now doing her bit in the armed forces must have been a Girl Scout once upon a time and found some inspiration there that makes her the valiant woman of today.

Preparing for their meeting at the Polo Grounds Sunday, both the Football Giants and Brooklyn Tigers spent Thanksgiving morning working up tremendous appetites in full length workouts. The game is of vastly more importance to the New Yorkers than to their opponents, who have lost all eight National League starts.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 23 -- Some Belgian civilians, reduced to the barest necessaries of life during the German occupation, received a package of tea, chocolate and even clothing from Belgian prisoners of war in Germany. This reversal of things in one case was told to the writer by a woman who assured him the procedure was by no means exceptional.
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted to the Far East by the German Transocean Agency and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow and reported, by the Federal Communications Commission:
ROME, Nov. 23 (AP) -- A communique:

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 23 -- Capt. Felix G. Sharp Jr., who arrived home here today after having been imprisoned for two and a half years by the Japanese in the Philippines said the morale of Japanese troops almost broke when they saw rubber heels and tin cans in Red Cross packets.

BELGRADE, Nov. 20 (Delayed) (AP) -- The story of Belgrade's three and a half years of Nazi occupation was unfolded to the western world today, a month after the Yugoslav capital's liberation by the Red Army and Marshal Tito's Partisans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations has not met suggestions that it devise a definition of what is a treaty and what is an agreement with another nation or nations. The committee's failure to achieve this is not surprising.

LONDON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- A detachment of 150 Flying Fortresses of the United States Air Force, escorted by seventy-five Mustangs, jabbed the Nordstern synthetic oil plant at Gelsenkirchen in the Ruhr -- which normally produces 30,000 tons of fuel monthly -- with 500 tons of bombs today and a few hours later Royal Air Force Lancasters followed up with another blow at the same target.

PARIS, Nov. 23 (U.P.) -- P.G. Wodehouse, the British novelist, who hotly denied having German sympathies when he was questioned again this morning by French security police, will be taken and perhaps is already en route to the Pas-de-Calais area, where he will live in the town of Hesdin.

The formation of a National Clearing House Association to permit a nation-wide clearing of checks within twenty-four hours as a means of eliminating "float" has been recommended to the National Association of Bank Auditors and Controllers by Edwin G. Uhl, controller of the Land Title Bank and Trust Company of Philadelphia, the bank announced yesterday.

The taxpayer building at 151 East Eighty-sixth Street, near the Lexington Avenue corner, has been bought by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, as trustees for Pauline Astor Clay, from the Chemical Bank and Trust Company.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- The convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations voted today in favor of a hard peace for Germany.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- A special sub-committee, designated by Adolf A. Berle Jr., president of the international civil aviation conference, will hold its first meeting tomorrow in an effort to reconcile the remaining differences between the American and British delegations on the division of traffic in post-war commercial aviation.

A WEEK ago in this space the hockey folk received a chance to offer their explanation of the origin of the phrase, "hat trick," as it pertains to them. Apparently their reasoning doesn't sit well with a couple of dozen reformed cricket enthusiasts who have written here to protest that the cricketers had the "hat trick" operating long before hockey was invented.

In the news story appearing in THE TIMES of Nov. 21 regarding the Schenck case, Daniel H. Prior, appearing as counsel for Michael T. Smith, is reported to have said: "Never since the Code of Criminal Procedure was adopted in New York State have the people ever sought a change of venue. It is revolutionary practice."

Samuel J. Tilden and John Adams engaged in a scoreless tie in their annual football clash yesterday at Dexter Park in Woodhaven, Queens. The latter had two excellent scoring opportunities but in each instance was forced to yield the ball on downs.
LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Two schemes are well under way in Britain for training domestic workers and finding employment in households where conditions are good.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- During a 72,000-mile prowl of the Pacific, Navy Air Group Eight destroyed or damaged 691 Japanese aircraft and sank forty-four Japanese ships, the Navy reported today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 23 -- Strasbourg, a city that means as much to the Germans as would Concord, Mass., to Americans under similar circumstances, has been reached by French tanks of the American Seventh Army, and the Germans, leaving pathetically weak rear guards behind them, are retreating on the front from the Luxembourg frontier south to Mulhouse.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 23 (AP) -- The grim gray walls of this historic Military Academy were buzzing with excitement today following the 7-0 victory of the Engineers over the ill-fated Goats in their annual game on the Plain. Some 3,000 cadets and officers roared approval as Ken Paape of the Engineers intercepted a long forward pass by Jim Maloney and scooted 70 yards for the touchdown.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Friday, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A communique:...

Since hours at home have become few and far between for the average woman, the clothes for them have become in a sense, "occasion clothes." The designers have done well in combining comfort with beauty and soft wools feature bead trims, crepes have been quilted and a variety of silhouettes are on hand.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 187:

Speaking in justification of GI's who refuse to learn foreign languages, your Topics of The Times editor says that "understanding and misunderstanding between nations and statesmen are not primarily a case of a common language." This may be true. Still, the much-mentioned Mr. Churchill may be directly quoted to the contrary.

Lin Yutang's record of his experiences and impressions during his journey through China in its seventh year of war is told in "The Vigil of a Nation," scheduled for publication on Jan. 25 by John Day. "The book is Dr. Lin's attempt to explain modern China to Americans."

IN THE SAVERNE GAP, Nov. 23 -- Brig. Gen. Jacques-Philippe Leclerc's French Second Armored Division swarmed into Strasbourg from three sides and cleared the western port of the city by nightfall today after a spectacular and almost unopposed dash across the Alsatian plain from the Saverne Gap.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Friday, Nov. 24 -- Rain- soaked American infantrymen have captured the Japanese bastion of Limon and have driven 1,000 yards south in a sudden upsurge of a battle that has virtually destroyed the enemy's First Division.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 188:
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 22 (Delayed) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur is satisfied with the progress of the Leyte campaign and is completely confident of the outcome.

AT THE ALSATIAN FRONTIER, Nov. 23 -- Advance formations of Maj. Gen. Jean de Lattre de Tassigny's French First Army are tonight crouching less than two miles north of the Swiss-Alsatian frontier outside Basle for what promises to be one of the heaviest battles yet fought in the Belfort gap.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 23 -- A violent controversy over a teachers' report analyzing the desirability of using The Reader's Digest in the classroom broke up the opening session of the National Council of Teachers of English, meeting here for a three-day conference.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Paulo Pinto de Carvalho, a distinguished Brazilian exporter and a good neighbor, decided to celebrate the United States Thanksgiving today by buying a war bond.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Boxes seating six persons each for the Army-Navy football game here Dec. 2 were assured today for "several" persons who gave individual subscriptions for $1,000,000 in war bonds, War Finance officials announced.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 23 (AP) -- A supplement to today's communique:

ATHENS, Nov. 23 -- A committee composed of representatives of the Greek Government military liaison and the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration announced today a building program, to begin at once, whereby it is expected nearly 500,000 homeless persons in Greece, about one-fourteenth of the population, will have shelter during the winter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (U.P.) -- The United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration is shipping abroad blue ration tokens, no longer used by the Office of Price Administration, to serve as "a medium of exchange" in liberated areas.
TULSA, Okla., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Tulsa warmed up today for the Orange Bowl encounter with Georgia Tech by battering an old-time rival, Arkansas. 33 -- 2, before 16,000 Thanksgiving Day fans.

WASHINGTON, Friday, Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- Ten years after he gained fame as member of the aviation acrobatic team, "three men on a flying trapeze," Brig. Gen. Haywood S. Hansell Jr. yesterday achieved perhaps his greatest ambition -- the bombing in force of Tokyo by his newly created Twenty-first Bomber Command.

Troops of the French First Army have driven north from Colmar up the broad Rhine Valley to Strasbourg, one of the last of the great French cities to fall to the Germans in June of 1940. A juncture is promised too with the American Seventh Army, moving east from captured Saverne.

Mrs. Emma Van Coutren, New York's "twelve-star" mother, enjoyed "the biggest family reunion we've had for years" at Thanksgiving dinner yesterday when one of her nine sons in the service and two of her three Wac daughters were here to share the holiday meal.

ROBERT GRAVES writes books like a horseman charging at an eight-bar gate not knowing whether his horse can clear it or what footing may lie on the other side. Sometimes he soars over his hurdles with dash and style and sometimes he comes an ignominious cropper. A brilliant, erratic, eloquent writer, as stanch in his opinions as a Union Square orator or a whole college of Bishops, he has written some sixty books.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, Philippines, Friday, Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- They passed out the turkey with the ammunition on the fighting fronts of Leyte Island Thanksgiving Day and the American troops went back to their grim work of killing Japanese compressed into the Limon pocket.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- Normal persons eating the usual American diet are not noticeably benefited by taking vitamins, according to a study completed at Duke University School of Medicine, at the request of the Quartermaster General's office of the Army, and reported in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

Plans calling for an amendment to the Surplus War Property Act under which many surplus Diesel engines would be made available after the war to engineering schools and colleges throughout the country were discussed recently at a special meeting of the Diesel Engine Manufacturers Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Nov. 23 -- The play-off for the football championship of Nassau County's South Shore Class A League resulted in a 13-to-7 triumph for Hempstead over Lawrence High today as Coach Joe Fay's Tigers remained unbeaten for the season.

FREEPORT, L.I., Nov. 23 -- Tallying a touchdown in the final session and then missing the conversion which would have brought them victory, Oceanside High's players battled to a 13-all tie with South Side of Rockville Centre today. The game, played at Freeport Municipal Stadium, was to have decided Nassau County's South Shore Class B League crown.

Underdog in the classic for many years. Brooklyn Prep's powerful football machine provided Thanksgiving cheer for its cohorts by routing St. John's Prep, 21 -- 0, before 6,000 yesterday at Boys High Field. The meeting, highlight of the local scholastic holiday football program, was the twenty-seventh between the Brooklyn foes.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 23 (AP) -- A communique from American headquarters:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The shortage of cigarettes among overseas troops will be corrected as soon as possible, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson said today.

Except for the outstanding hit shows, yesterday's holiday matinee business was a bit below expectations. Of Broadway's thirty-one current attractions, twenty-four optimistically gave afternoon performances. Standee trade was enjoyed by "Oklahoma!" "I Remember Mama," "Follow the Girls," "The Late George Apley," "Anna Lucasta" and "Stars on Ice."

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- Jerry Lissner of Iona School, returning to the line-up for his final game, ran wild against Georgetown Prep of Washington before a holiday crowd of 5,000 at Haag Field this morning. Two backfield mates, Kenny McAleenan and Ray Morris, also found the muddy terrain to their liking with the result that Iona's undefeated eleven gained a 32-to-0 decision, racking up its sixth victory as against a pair of ties.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 23 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower expressed personal interest today in the cigarette problem which has bedeviled American forces and ordered military police to crack down on illegal sales, which in Paris have reached such an extent that one can buy a package of American cigarettes in any bar for the standard price of 135 francs ($2.75).
PARIS, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Censorship released today the names of the American officers and soldiers involved in a prisoner exchange in the German-held Lorient sector of France Nov. 16.

PACIFIC HEADQUARTERS, Twentieth Air Force, Nov. 23 -- Behind the news of the first Super-fortress attack on industrial centers of Japan lies an engineering saga ranking in sheer drama with anything in American building history.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Atlantic Coast Line Railroad will petition the Interstate Commerce Commission to reopen the Florida East Coast Railway reorganization case, the ICC was informed today.

The shortest of New York State's various deer seasons begins today. This one will extend the shooting into the southern tier and western counties and those comprising the central and eastern areas. It will close next Thursday along with the seasons in Westchester County and the so-called Catskill region.
Except for the usual exodus to the suburbs for Thanksgiving dinners, holiday travel yesterday, curbed by wartime restrictions, was light.

A large plot on the south side of Closter Dock Road, Closter, Bergen County, N.J., has been sold hrough the Alexander Summer agency of Teaneck for the Mortbon Corporation of New York to a client of Schneider Schneider, Englewood attorneys.

Henry Adams said in one of his letters, toward the end of his life: "Thank God, I never was cheerful. I come from the happy stock of the Mathers, who, as you remember, passed sweet mornings reflecting on the goodness of God and the damnation of infants."

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 23 -- Maj. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, head of the American forces in China and Chief of Staff to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, said today that American armies eventually will be employed in China for a continental campaign to knock out Japan.

LONDON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Some 4,000 American soldiers, sailors, nurses and Red Cross workers trooped into bomb-scarred Westminster Abbey today to offer hymns and prayers in this resting place of many of England's illustrious dead.

UBACH, Germany, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The fall of Metz for the first time in its 1,500-year military history meant more than a military victory for the pistol-packing Third Army commander, Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr., for it meant vindication of his free press policy as well.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast by the Chinese High Command from Chungking and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The War Department is "very definitely" of the belief that the National Guard should continue as a reserve component of the Army after the war, Secretary Stimson said today.

BOSTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Toronto's under-staffed Mapls Leafs, who dressed only eleven players, were out-played by a wide margin as the Bruins, paced by Herb Cain, romped to a 5-1 National Hockey League victory before a 12,000 crowd tonight at the Boston Garden.

Further plans to interpret the Dumbarton Oaks proposals to the American public were announced yesterday by Clark M. Eichelberger, on behalf of the Commission to Study the Organization of Peace and the League of Nations Association.

The first guarantee of a veteran's loan to be made in this area under the GI Bill of Rights was issued yesterday by the loan guaranty division of the Veterans Administration at 2 Park Avenue, which gave its initial certificate of this kind to Anthony R. Caparrella of Pittsfield, Mass.

B-29 HEADQUARTERS, Saipan, the Marianas, Nov. 16 (Delayed) -- It may now be disclosed that the B-29 that flew over Tokyo and Yokohama on the reconnaissance flights was the "Tokyo's Rose." Three flights, solely for reconnaissance, were made by the plane -- on Nov. 1, Nov. 5 and Nov. 7.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- President Roosevelt told Congress today that while lend-lease aid "should end with the war," the United Nations' partnership must grow stronger and "permanent" so that these countries could together provide for security against aggression, build "the economic foundations for a more prosperous world," and develop "wider opportunities for civilized advancement for the American people and for all other peace-loving peoples of the world."

BOSTON, Nov. 24 -- Seven civilian Army employes were arrested today in Searsport, Me., and Boston on charges of theft of several thousands of dollars worth of Government food stores of the War Shipping Administration. The Federal Bureau of Investigation said that six of the men were members of a lighter operating under Government orders.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Saturday, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- In addition to their losses at sea, the Japanese lost forty-two planes, thirty-five in air battles and seven to anti-aircraft guns, as the improving weather permitted a sharp increase in their air activity.

The physicist tears a bit of the universe apart and discovers that it is composed of atoms. He pounds atoms to pieces and discovers that they in turn are composed of protons, neutrons and electrons. He expresses in mathemetical equations why these protons, neutrons and electrons behave as they do.

The Christmas gift campaign of the Russian War Relief, of which Bishop William T. Manning is honorary chairman, will be opened with a special service tomorrow at 8 P.M. in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The purpose of the drive is to send to Russia a shipload of new winter clothing for girls and boys of devastated Soviet areas.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 -- The United Kingdom and the United States were the Argentine Republic's best customers in 1942 the country's annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today. The country's third best customer was simply listed as "other countries" followed in fourth place by Brazil.

Five poultry dealers were sentenced yesterday to two days in jail each for charging more than the ceiling prices fixed by the Office of Price Administration. The sentences were imposed by Magistrate Harry G. Andrews in War Emergency Court with a warning that dealers who take advantage of the holiday season to increase prices illegally, especially on turkeys, can expect no mercy from him.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark's Royal Archer, one of the largest timber-toppers in this country, won the $10,000 added Manly Steeplechase, a fixture since 1916, at Pimlico today.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Auburn rallied with a second half touchdown flurry tonight to overpower an awakened Miami football team, 38 -- 19, before 10,572 Orange Bowl Stadium spectators who were kept on their feet during most of the exciting game.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Spurred by the return to action of ace performers, Yale and Virginia eagerly awaited their intersectional football fracas in the Bowl at 2:30 P. M. tomorrow with the Elis, anxious to achieve their first perfect campaign since 1923, slight favorites in their final contest.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Florida Supreme Court ruled today that Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings' description in her book "Cross Creek" of a character who "cursed loudly" was an invasion of the privacy of Miss Zelma Cason of Island Grove.

JOLIET, Ill., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Prison tower guards shot and killed another guard and wounded four convicts as they fired on ten prisoners, two of them survivors of the 1942 Roger Touhy break, to halt an attempted escape over the wall of Stateville Penitentiary.

OTTAWA, Nov. 24 -- A dissident member of Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King's Liberal party, bolting to the Opposition, accused the Prime Minister of treachery today as an uproarious Canadian House of Commons met for the third day of an extraordinary session to consider the overseas conscription issue.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 23 (Delayed) -- The Secretariat of the Treasury and the Federal District Department made public today a decree whereby wholesale and retail ceiling prices on essential foodstuffs and other domestic articles will be enforced in the Federal District.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 24 -- A method of retarding the normal development of fruit buds through plant hormones and a system for obtaining riboflavin -- vitamin B-2 -- by the fermentation of sugars by yeast are among the 511 inventions listed as patented in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

BAINBRIDGE NAVAL vs. Camp Peary -- In its own quiet way -- and Bainbridge supporters wish it wasn't such a secret -- Bainbridge has been thumping everything in sight for the past two seasons until it now has a fifteen-game winning streak. On occasions Lieut. Joe Maniaci, its coach, must think he's back with the Chicago Bears, so plentiful is his material and so devastatingly does it operate.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 24 -- The International Association of Machinists, the largest union in the American Federation of Labor, which returned to the AFL last year after a lapse of considerable time, may again leave the federation, according to developments here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- A rise in department stores sales for the week ended Nov. 18, compared with the corresponding week last year, was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board. Percentage changes from corresponding periods a year ago are indicated in the following table:

WITH AMERICAN NINTH ARMY, in Germany, Nov. 24 -- Hampered by weather so foul overhead and underfoot that infantry, air and armor, was forced to mark time and let artillery pound the enemy, the American Ninth Army re-enacted today a page from the history of World War I.
OTTAWA, Nov. 24 -- In the House of Commons today Defence Minister General A.G.L. McNaughton was again subjected to a long process of question and answer.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A supplementary communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- A conference of Foreign Ministers of the American republics within a few weeks was thought virtually assured today when Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Acting Secretary of State, issued a statement indicating that the only questions awaiting final decision were the time of the meeting and details of the agenda.

The Walgreen Company, which operates a nation-wide chain of retail drug stores, reported yesterday in its annual statement covering the fiscal year ended with September, net income of $3,334,694 after all charges including $600,000 provision for contingencies.

Three residents of this immediate vicinity and a couple of others who live within a long hail of the city are sporting certificates from the State of Maine today as concrete reminders of last season's fishing exploits. They got the certificates because they became members of the State's "The One That Didn't Get Away Club," the rather unwieldy name for a select group whose catches met certain definite requirements for size.

The White Paper transmitted to the British Parliament by the Chancellor of the Exchequer in London yesterday revealed that the British Commonwealth of Nations provided $4,350,981,440 in reverse lend-lease to other members of the United Nations during the year from July 1,1943, to June 30, 1944, with $2,437,061,900 of the grand total going to the United States.

It is to be hoped that Congress may reconsider its plan to bestow the meaningless titles "General of the Armies and "Admiral of the Fleets" upon certain high ranking officers of our Army and Navy. General Pershing has the title General of the Armies. How many people in the country know what it means?

Directors of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, according to an announcement yesterday, have approved a program of research into the mechanical production of newspapers, to run for at least five years and to cost at least $175,000.

The Joint Committee on Religious Liberty of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America and the Foreign Missions Conference of North America, opening a broad educational campaign to protect the exercise of human rights, made public yesterday a report calling attention to threats to religious liberty at home and abroad.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A United States Army Forces in China communique:

The Bank of Montreal reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, 1944, record total resources of $1,526,734,000, compared with $1,313,065,000 a year previous. Deposits aggregated $1,420,811,000, a gain of $214,937,000; holdings of bonds and debentures, principally Dominion Government and high-grade provincial and municipal securities, amounted to $955,538,000, an increase of $156,075,000, and cash on hand and on deposit with the Bank of Canada totaled $184,473,000, a gain of $62,196,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Katharine F. Lenroot celebrated today her tenth anniversary as Chief of the Children's Bureau.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer's communique reported today that Hwaiyuanchen, fifty miles west of Liuchow on the Kwangsi-Kweichow railway, had been "bombed repeatedly" by American planes of the Fourteenth Air Force, indicating that the town had fallen to Japanese troops.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Navy's great line, rated by many the best in college football, will get its supreme test when Army meets the middies at Baltimore next week, but right now the Annapolis coaches are concerned mainly with a little item termed the T formation.

An otherwise successful robbery went awry last night because a taxicab driver temporarily deserted his cab to get a shave. When he emerged from the barber shop he found one of the robbers lying in the gutter on Canal Street just east of Eldridge Street, with a policeman's bullet in his back and the loot in the taxicab.

ROME, Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- British troops of the Eighth Army, advancing slowly northward toward Faenza, have stormed across the Cosina River and established five small bridgeheads on a two and a half mile front in the face of heavy German counter-attacks, Allied Headquarters announced today.

ROME, Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- Rioting at the Regina Coeli Prison subsided this afternoon as jailers removed a number of demonstrators in chains from a wing of the prison in which they had been barricaded and transferred them to other wings or other jails on the outskirts of Rome.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- The convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, at its final session today, criticized the War Labor Board for "poor administration and unfortunate policies" and called for immediate upward revision of the Little Steel formula to adjust wages to the cost of living

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 24 -- One hundred persons are believed to have drowned when the 539-ton Swedish passenger steamer Hansa, plying between Nynaeshamm and the Gotland isle port of Visby, blew up at 5 A.M. today in a forepeak explosion believed caused by a drifting mine or a torpedo.

LONDON, Saturday, Nov. 25 (U.P.) - Russian land and naval forces yesterday completed the liberation of Estonia. hurling the last German invaders from 1,010-square mile Oesel Island guarding Riga Gulf. In Hungary, meanwhile, other Red Army troops battled to within seventeen miles of the Danube River north of Budapest.

Delay of universal military training legislation until war emotionalism has subsided and peace terms are made public was urged yesterday by educators at first-day sessions of the fifty-eighth annual convention of the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools.
LONDON, Nov. 24 (UP) -- A communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

ALBANY, Nov. 24 -- Holding that he had no jurisdiction to declare the formation of the Tenth Judicial District unconstitutional, Supreme Court Justice Francis Bergan dismissed today the complaint of Ferdinand I. Haber, chairman of the law committee of the Nassau County Democratic Organization, who sought to have the legislative act declared unconstitutional. Justice Bergan said:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 24 -- Patricia Kirkland, 17-year-old daughter of Jack Kirkland and Nancy Carroll, may get the featured lead in the screen version of "Kiss and Tell," which George Abbott and F. Hugh Herbert are to produce for Columbia, it was learned today.

HEADQUARTERS AMERICAN FIRST ARMY, Germany, Nov. 24 -- The weather remained implacably against us again today. By the hardest kind of fighting in a cold downpour our men were able to make only small gains through dripping forests and over ground churned now to knee-deep mud.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Soviet Government has concerned itself keenly with the "purges" being carried out in France and Belgium. These "purges," as it conceives them, ought to include the prominent men who some day may recover enough authority to lead the attack against the semi-revolutionary regimes of today.

With 25,000 tickets already distributed to purchasers of war bonds and stamps, schoolboy football will do its part in support of the Sixth War Loan Drive at Ebbets Field today when four of the metropolitan district's crack elevens stage the Scholastic Bond Bowl double header.

After perusing yesterday's critical reviews, Herbert H. Harris, who made his bow on Thursday evening as a Broadway producer with "The Man Who Had All the Luck," has decided against continuing the play after tonight's performance at the Forrest Theatre.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Twentieth Air Force communique 24:

B-29 HEADQUARTERS ON SAIPAN, the Marianas, Nov. 24 -- The flash "bombs away" was received at this headquarters at 12:15 P.M., and the first reports said the initial planes over the target-- the sprawling and vital Nakajima factories that make a large part of Japan's military aircraft -- had found no clouds, moderate and inaccurate anti-aircraft fire and light fighter opposition. The reports added that the bombs were being dropped visually.

Vito Genovese, who had been described by the New York Police as one of six members of the Maffia, an Italian secret society, wanted in connection with the killing of a Brooklyn man in 1934 has been apprehended by Army officials in Rome, it was announced yesterday by Acting District Attorney Thomas C. Hughes in Brooklyn.
The football spotlight switches from Army and Navy to Columbus, Ohio, today on the last full program of the college season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ending Nov. 18 totaled 864,373 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 24,884 cars, or 3 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 17,914 cars, or 2 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 27,611 cars, or 3.3 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed holdings of United States Government securities and note circulation for the system as a whole to have increased $469,573,000 and $151,063,000, respectively, during the week.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The text of President Roosevelt's letter to Congress today on lend-lease and reverse lend-lease was as follows:

A wide market for the temporary war housing erected with Federal funds in war-production centers was indicated yesterday by the initial response to the announcement that the Federal Public Housing Authority had completed experiments for dismantling and packaging the buildings with a view to selling them for use on other sites here and abroad.

Handwrought silver jewelry, colorful tiles, handweaves and small pieces of sculpture are included in the annual exhibit opened this week by the New York Society of Craftsmen. Representing work of fifty-one members, the exhibit is scheduled to continue until Dec. 2 at the Argent Gallery, 42 West Fifty-seventh Street, where many of the articles have been placed on sale.

There is something about a train whistle. It is one of the links that bind a great, sprawling nation together. It is puzzling in these days of graphs, polls, and things laid end to end that reach so many times around the earth, that no statistician has figured out how many train whistles a day there are on our approximately 231,000 miles of railroad tracks.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 24 -- After a tumultuous night session the National Council of Teachers of English voted to disband its existing committee investigating the place of The Readers Digest in the classroom and to appoint a new committee to make a further study of the magazine and report to the council at its next annual meeting.

In the early days on Guadalcanal the Japanese bombers were accustomed to fly down from Bougainville and Rabaul between the hours of 10 A.M. and 2 P.M. each day to attack Henderson Field and other Marine installations. The regularity of arrival was conditioned for the Japanese by the hours of daylight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The three major Allied powers, the United States, the Soviet Union and Great Britain, whose representatives in London constitute the European Advisory Commission, have agreed to coordinate their policies when they occupy Germany and administer it militarily immediately after hostilities cease.

The veil of secrecy that has surrounded the Norden bomb sight since the accuracy of the first working model astounded Army and Navy ordnance officers in a demonstration in the fall of 1931 was partly lifted yesterday when newspaper men were permitted to photograph and inspect one of the famous instruments at the Museum of Science and Industry, Rockefeller Center.

A match shortage that will be more acute than the current shortage of cigarettes is in prospect because of heavy Government orders given match makers within the last four weeks, Herman A. Oriel, managing director of the Wholesale Tobacco Distributors of New York, Inc., reported yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Field Marshal Johannes Blaskowitz was reported today to have been removed from the German command in southeastern France.
ALBANY, Nov. 20 (AP) -- There will be fewer Christmas trees on sale in the State this year, but prices will be lower. And supplies, are expected to be ample.

ALSACE, France, Nov. 24 -- The principal problem facing the French Government as a result of the liberation of Alsace and Lorraine is that of relief, which may require the diversion eastward of a part of the trucks hitherto used to carry foodstuffs to Paris, officials of the Ministry of National Economy said today.

SAIPAN, the Marianas, Nov. 18 (Delayed) -- The new Superfortress base on Saipan is a symbol, better perhaps than any other island in the Pacific, for it demonstrates why American arms and brains are superior to those of the Japanese and why Japan's ultimate defeat is as inevitable as the setting of the sun.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- During the week ended Nov. 22, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, member bank reserve balances increased $162,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from increases of $534,000,000 in reserve bank credit and $3,000,000 in Treasury currency, offset in part by increases of $164,000,000 in money in circulation, $132,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $79,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.

WATERVILLE, Me., Nov. 24 (AP) -- The movement to give other nations that freedom of the press which America has "always enjoyed," William Dwight, managing editor of The Holyoke Transcript, said tonight, "is one of the most heartening things that has arisen so far in our plans for post-war peace."

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- Adolf A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, and Lord Swinton, Minister of Civil Aviation, submitted American and British counter proposals today in an effort to break the deadlock on freedoms of the air and traffic quotas which has blocked complete agreement on an international air administration for post-war commercial aviation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The National War Labor Board authorized its regional board in Cleveland today to proceed with the appointment of a panel to hear the dispute which resulted in a strike of telephone employes in Dayton and sympathy strikes in other cities.

The people of New York State have made an excellent initial response to the Sixth War Loan purchasing $9,000,000 more in series E bonds in the drive's first three days than were bought in a comparable period during the last campaign, Frederick W. Gehle, State chairman of the War Finance Committee, reported yesterday.

Jimmy Doyle, California welterweight, made his local ring debut last night against rugged Pete De Ruzza of Mamaroneck at the St. Nicholas Arena and satisfied a crowd of 2,467 fans that he will do as a Madison Square Garden card.

PACIFIC HEADQUARTERS, TWENTIETH ARMY AIR FORCE, Nov. 24 -- The man who directs and guides the Twenty-first Bomber Command of the Twentieth Air Force is Brig. Gen. Haywood S. Hansell Jr., whose youngish, quiet, almost-esthetic appearance and demeanor manage to camouflage the energy and drive that have brought him to one of the outstanding commands in the war against Japan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Announcing the closing of two magnesium plants and the curtailment of another, the War Production Board said today that its program for the production of magnesium metal in Government-owned plants will "virtually cease" by the end of this year.

Cotton futures developed some irregularity on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, coincident with the evening up in the December contract. December closed 2 points higher, and other months were 5 to 9 points net lower.

Good luck and shooting experience he gained while hunting coyotes in Montana as a boy were credited yesterday by Tech. Sgt. Henry Schauer, 26-year-old infantryman, of Scobey, Mont., for his feat of killing seventeen Nazis and wiping out three machine- gun-nests in Italy last May.
Your naturalist editor moved right down into my alley when he wrote that wildlife article entitled "Old Kaw Kaw," known otherwise as just plain crow.

Opposition to the City Planning Commission's proposed revision of the zoning statutes from a new and unexpected direction came to light last night, when it was learned that thousands of property owners had signed protests against the amendments and in favor of the alternate plan of Public Works Commissioner Irving V.A. Huie.

Once the scene of one of the country's largest rent strikes, the Sholem Aleichem Apartment House at 3451 Giles Place, the Bronx, was in the throes yesterday of another rent strike with the majority of the 236 tenants starting their second week of picketing in a move to get the landlord to renew an agreement with the tenants that expired Sept. 30.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Musashina airplane plant, eleven miles northwest of the heart of Tokyo, as well as other industrial targets of an attack by an estimated 100 or more B-29 Superfortresses, were still burning, with smoke going up "to great heights" in the factory areas, according to reconnaissance photographs, an announcement from the Twentieth Air Force revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Production of small-arms ammunition will be doubled and the making of mortar shells sharply increased as a result of a sudden new demand direct from Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for more infantry munitions, J.A. Krug, chairman of the War Production Board said today.

There have been times in this war when it seemed that the United States Army and Navy had learned every lesson except the important one of public relations. Tactics, weapons arid organization all were on the new World War model. Censorship often was as senseless as or worse than it had been in 1917-18.

It is apparent from a Thanksgiving Day broadcast over the Tokyo radio that the Japanese and the United States Marine Corps have come to a parting of the ways. Opinions formed on Guadalcanal, Tarawa and other islands seem to have been mutually unfavorable.

" A Handful of Rice," described as "an ethnic folk drama" produced in Siam and Sweden (with dialogue in the languages of those two countries) will open today at the Forty-eighth Street Cinema. Paul Fejos and Gunnar Skoglund produced the film, much of which was photographed in Siam and Camboldia.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- By a vote of 42 to 27, the Senate rejected today the amendment of Senator Josiah W. Bailey of North Carolina to restrict the Secretary of the Interior in the building of transmission lines for electricity generated at projects in the $1,000,000,000 flood control bill.
SAIPAN, Marianas, Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- American Superfortress raiders over Tokyo saw only a few enemy fighter planes and the Yanks, with itchy trigger fingers, fired their guns "just for fun."

Adolf Busch and his Chamber Music Players were heard in the first of two concerts devoted to the Brandenburg concertos of Bach last night in Town Hall. Three of the six works of the set formed the initial program, namely, the concertos in F major, No. 1; G major, No. 3, and B flat major, No. 6.

Most of us in this big city know that somewhere beyond ordinary sight there is a thing called grievous need, and that such need must look to charity for aid. But need, when not seen, tends to become a vague abstraction, as does the charity that goes to its rescue, though a better acquaintance with both would surely stir our hearts.

ABOARD A B-29 SUPERFORTRESS Over Tokyo, Nov. 24 -- I rode this Superfortress over Tokyo today and as we left the Japanese capital behind six violent fires were blazing up among the rectangular buildings of the great Nakajima aircraft factory.
Dartmouth and Columbia will bring the curtain down on their 1944 football campaigns today when they meet at Baker Field in their annual contest. The kick-off is scheduled for 2:30 P. M.

Dr. Isaac N. Steinberg, general secretary of the Freeland League for Jewish Territorial Colonization, said yesterday that the plan to establish a Jewish settlement in Australia was not in principle intended to be contrary to the policy of that country.

A Japanese Imperial Headquarters communique said yesterday that "about seventy" B-29 Superfortresses, based in the Marianas, had bombed Tokyo at noon and claimed that Japanese interceptors had shot down three, according to a Japanese domestic broadcast recorded by the Federal Communications Commission.

Election day is past, and it seems opportune to call attention to an issue of prime importance to the future political life of our nation. I refer to the question of financial contributions by organized labor to political parties and campaigns.

British manufacturers after the war undoubtedly will make greater efforts than in the past to produce for export here merchandise of the type this country wants rather than the type British manufacturers "enjoy making," according to a survey of post-war markets in the United States just completed by the British Empire Chamber of Commerce in the U.S.A., Inc.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Official Washington turned out tonight with members of the theatrical profession to pay tribute to Secretary Hull as "a great humanitarian.

Supermen, Lone Rangers and Daisy Maes dominated the scene but laurels went to the Batman and Robin, an Air Corps nurse and a Scarlet O'Hara as the Children's Aid Society's Lower West Side Center, 219 Sullivan Street, celebrated yesterday the collection of more than fifty pounds of comic books for soldiers at Halloran General Hospital, Staten Island.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- Veteran Mike Turnesa of White Plains, N.Y., tonight took a two-stroke lead over Slammin' Sammy Snead at the halfway mark in the Portland Open Golf Tournament, first big meet of the winter circuit.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The new Yugoslav federation of six provinces under a central government will have a planned economy based on private ownership and initiative. Outlines of what will probably become the leading Balkan State are emerging from statements made during the past few days by Marshal Tito and some of his Ministers.

With the Giants coming up to their eighth game (this one with the downtrodden Brooklyn Tigers at the Polo Grounds tomorrow afternoon) tied for second place in the Eastern half of the National Football League, people are beginning to change their minds about Coach Steve Owen.

Selling in the aircraft division broke out yesterday on the stock market as the recent moderate recovery effort faltered from lack of support. Even the rails ran into some difficulty although one of the carriers that paced the list in activity scored a major gain. Business on the Stock Exchange dropped to the lightest of the month with transfers at 677,880 shares, compared with 767,010 shares on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Edward J. Noble, former Under-Secretary of Commerce, declared today that in buying Radio Station WMCA in New York from Donald Flamm four years ago he had conspired with no one and Mr. Flamm had not been intimidated into making the sale.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTER, on Leyte, Saturday Nov. 25 (AP) -- A communique:
ATHENS, Ga., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Georgia, striving to improve its standing in the bowl football picture, found stubborn opposition in Clemson today, but punched out a 21-7 victory.
With Christmas trade now rising steadily, retail trade here continued active this week. Department stores had increases ranging to 18 per cent or more over the like week of 1943.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Communique 230:...

STRASBOURG, France, Nov. 24 -- The big guns of the Siegfried Line began firing sporadically across the Rhine into the center of Strasbourg this afternoon while Brig. Gen. Jacques Philippe le Leclerc's armored forces completed the town's liberation by mopping up isolated pockets of Germans in the southern and eastern outskirts.

Although broccoli had its origins in Italy several centuries ago, it is relatively new to this country. When introduced here it proved popular only with those of Italian and French descent. Then some years ago, as one story has it, an enterprising New York chef dressed up the cabbage-like vegetable with hollandaise sauce, served it in his hotel dining room for an exorbitant price and started a broccoli boom.
KANDY, Ceylon, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A communique

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- Rye developed independent weakness today on the Board of Trade and caused selling of other grains. Liquidation was on in December rye and the price at one time was off 1 3/8 cents, selling being induced by reports of a good demand for corn and grain sorghum for distilling purposes and purchases of 400,000 bushels of Canadian rye now in storage in Duluth.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Some members of Congress expressed a belief today that Assistant Attorney General Norman M. Littell would refuse Attorney General Biddle's request for his resignation. Mr. Biddle was reported to have given incompatibility as his reason for asking the resignation.

B-29 HEADQUARTERS, Saipan, the Marianas, Nov. 24 -- Brig. Gen. Emmett O'Donnell Jr., 38-year-old command pilot, whose home is at 175-06 Devonshire Road, Jamaica, Queens, today led the first mission against Tokyo by B-29 Superfortresses.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- The divergent tendencies shown by Argentina on continental solidarity since the Rio de Janeiro conference early in 1942 has "finally brought about the definite separation of that Government from other * * * American nations,'' according to a report sent American Governments today by the Inter-American Committee for the Political Defense of the Hemisphere.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 24 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, made today what was interpreted as a final appeal to the British Trade Union Congress to "stop, look and listen" before it irrevocably threw in its lot with the Soviet trade unions and the Congress of Industrial Organizations and took steps to form a new world labor federation.

Isidore J. Lipsky and Harry Lipsky, owners of the North American Warehouses, Inc., 1133-35 Tiffany Street, the Bronx, admitted in Federal Court yesterday that they had filed fraudulent documents with the Office of Price Administration.
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted in English by the Free Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Staff Sgt. Joe Louis, ending an exhibition tour while on leave of absence from the Army, floored Dan Merritt, 209-pound Cleveland Negro, four times in their three-rounder at the Chicago Stadium before a crowd of 8,905 tonight.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Nov. 24 -- The American Third Army smashed toward Saar-bruecken and the rich Saar basin today as the American threat to this area, second only to the Ruhr in the economy of western Germany, increased along a front stretching from Kesselingen in Germany on the northwest to Remering in Lorraine on the southeast.

TWENTY - FIRST BOMBER COMMAND, Saipan, Nov. 24 (AP) -- "We took them by surprise again," Brig. Gen. Emmett O'Donnell, commander of the Tokyo attack formations, said when he returned from the 3,000-mile roundtrip flight.

ROME, Nov. 24 -- Events in Palestine have been watched more closely by the Vatican since the assassination of Lord Moyne in Cairo and the moral authority of the Roman Catholic Church is behind Chaim Weizmann, president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, in his efforts to restore order in the Holy Land.

Great-grandmother's soup tureen has long been a favorite item with lovers of old-fashioned tableware. Usually it stood on a high shelf beyond harm's reach, to be dusted gingerly now and then, and otherwise left alone. Recently the tureen has come back to actual use.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Assurance that the sons of New Jersey farmers and other young farm employes would not be called by Selective Service except in cases of extreme necessity was given today to representatives of the County Farm War Board by Lieut. Col. Samuel L. South, chief of the Manpower Division of the New Jersey headquarters for Selective Service.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, who was thought to be the most likely person to be able to obtain an agreement between the Soviet Union and the Polish Government in London, resigned as Premier of Poland today after disagreement with his colleagues over the methods he proposed to follow in negotiating with Moscow.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved conditionally today a plan of the United Corporation whereby United would offer part of its portfolio securities and cash in exchange, on a voluntary basis, for outstanding shares of its cumulative preference stock.

On the subject of cigars for our fighting men we have been in receipt of considerable enlightenment. Commenting on the ninety million cigars a month which go to our armed forces, we said the other day that it was hard to visualize a cigar in the mouth of a man in the front line of battle.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved conditionally today a plan of the United Corporation whereby United would offer part of its portfolio securities and cash in exchange, on a voluntary basis, for outstanding shares of its cumulative preference stock.

On the subject of cigars for our fighting men we have been in receipt of considerable enlightenment. Commenting on the ninety million cigars a month which go to our armed forces, we said the other day that it was hard to visualize a cigar in the mouth of a man in the front line of battle.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Post-war unemployment rivaling that of the depression of the Thirties was predicted tdoay by House members debating the bill to appropriate $1,500,000,000 for post-war construction of highways.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Dr. Caroline Ware of the American Association of University Women and Mrs. Harriett Howe of the American Association of Home Economics hailed today the order by the Office of Price Administration to cut over-finishing and fancying-up of fabrics as an important move toward checking the rise in clothing costs.

LUXEMBOURG, Nov. 24 -- The notes of a grand Te Deum, accompanied by a paean of bells, swelled through the nave of the cathedral and merged into the familiar strains of "The Star-Spangled Banner." Played by a master organist in this faraway church for people who didn't know the words, the national anthem did not sound familiar.

Rose Pesotta, a Russian, is the author of "Bread Upon the Waters," a story of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, which Dodd, Mead will publish on Monday. The writer was vice president of the union for ten years and the organizer of some of the biggest strikes in this country.

PARTY regularity is a grand ideal. Theodore Roosevelt hated a Mugwump until he became a Mugwump himself. After that break with Taft, party irregularity became the grand thing for about six years. And then he sank his differences with the GOP, and party regularity became an ideal again. It was all highly confusing.

Representing 2,700 fraternity chapters on 200 college and university campuses, 300 delegates of the sixty national fraternities of the National Interfraternity Conference met yesterday at the Hotel Commodore to open a two-day convention on post-war plans.

Directors of the Armstrong Cork Corporation yesterday declared a year-end dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock, payable Dec. 22, increasing the year's disbursements to $1.50 from $1.35 paid in 1943. Also voted at the board meeting was a Christmas bonus to be distributed on Dec. 22 to employes, excluding directors or vice presidents, of 2 per cent of wages or salary for the year.

OTTAWA, Nov. 24 -- The Prices Board announced today Canadian deliveries of newsprint to the United States during the first six months of 1945 will be maintained at the same rate as in 1944 -- 200,000 tons a month -- but pulp deliveries will be reduced slightly.

During the post-war period advertising men will have to present intelligently contributions that their own concerns are making to the general welfare as "thoroughly and expertly as we present the desirability of the products we have to sell," C.C. Carr, director of public relations and advertising, Aluminum Company of America, said recently.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Action in this session of Congress on legislation to extend the interval in which veterans of this war may apply for reinstatement in their pre-war jobs was indicated today as the Senate Military Affairs Committee reported the measure out favorably.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Week-end influences had a quieting effect in today's stock markets, but there was renewed investment buying of gilt-edged issues and several gains were seen there was also some buying of home rails on dividend prospects and many of the junior issues showed gains up to a quarter.

ON AMERICAN THIRD ARMY FRONT in Germany, Nov. 24 -- Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr. received a Bronze Star today for his conquest of Metz. The medal was pinned on his tunic at Advanced Supreme Headquarters by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for the feat achieved only once before, and that back in 451 A.D., when the Huns captured the city by a frontal assault.

MOSCOW, Nov. 24 -- David Zaslavsky, whose satirical pen has been directed in the last year at the late Wendell L. Willkie, former United States Ambassador William C. Bullitt, the Vatican and Generalissimo Francisco Franco, emerged today as a champion of more nipples for bottle-fed babies.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Saturday, Nov. 25 -Low-flying American fighter planes destroyed a four-ship troopladen Japanese convoy, bound for Leyte Island, yesterday and brought to approximately 15,000 the toll of Japanese reinforcements killed before they could reach the embattled island.

While the Dumbarton Oaks proposals should be supported because they are "a beginning," they fall short of the Christian concept for a durable world peace because of the emphasis placed upon force, John Foster Dulles said last night in an address to 500 lay and clerical delegates to the conference on world order sponsored by the six Presbyteries of the metropolitan area.

MOSCOW, Nov. 24 -- The Red Army's newspaper Red Star declared today that the continuance of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's regime in Spain is an important international problem that must be dealt with by the United Nations at the earliest possible moment.

With a peace plan already outlined to work for and a public eager to discuss it, the League of Women Voters is finding a job made to its measure -- helping large groups of citizens to understand the Dumbarton Oaks proposals and to use their power to make a permanent peace, it was said yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Tomorrow's edition of The Times of London, which was issued from Printing House Square tonight, bore a modest seven-tenths of an inch of type in the upper right hand corner of the first page reading, "50,0000th issue."

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 24 -- The Supreme Allied Command must keep its hands off Belgium's domestic politics, Drapeau Rouge wrote today in a special article bearing the signature of Alice De Geer Communist Deputy. The article charged that Supreme Allied Headquarters had been hoodwinked by the Belgian Government.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Admiral William H. Standley declared tonight that right after the war the United States should supply Russia with consumer goods without expecting "great profits."

HARCOURT, BRACE has produced another two-in-one volume of demonstrations by Georges Simenon showing just how much can be done with the penny-dreadful when it is attacked by an adult intelligence, subtle and civilized.
Ten days of a general offensive in the west have resulted in definite but indecisive Allied gains after bloody fighting.

ROME, Nov. 25 -- Turin rather than Milan is a hotbed of Partisan activity in the north, one of the most famous patriots now in Rome said today. He goes under the nom de guerre of Franco Franchi and the Germans have put a price of 5,000,000 lire on his head.

WITH Fred Allen determined for the time being to abjure the toil that goes into a weekly radio program, it has fallen to Jimmy Melton of the "Met" to carry on the "Star Theatre" on Sunday evenings (9:30) over CBS.

Now that the leaves are gone even from the underbrush, one who walks through the woods can see, occasionally, far into the prehistoric past. It shines out in green and gleaming patches of club mosses -- running pine or snake moss, ground pine, ground cedar, humble evergreens which the botanists know as Lycopodiums.

MR. LLOYD SHEARER in his recent article, "Regarding Gag Writers," has made several statements which I, being one of those regarded, hasten to contradict. Mr. Shearer contends that "the prevalent lack of humor on so-called 'comedy' radio shows" is due to the fact that "since the best writers * * * are now in the Army, most comics have been trying to get by of late with old material."

UNIVERSITY, Miss., Nov. 25 (AP) -- An inspired University of Mississippi football team struck through the air to set up two touchdowns and upset favored Mississippi State, 13 to 8, in the forty-first renewal of their rivalry today.

THE Midwestern town of Nashiona is to have a tryout performance of a new play by a successful Broadway playwright, with his favorite actress in the stellar role. The other parts are to be played by members of the Nashiona Little Theatre.

Masterpieces by Fragonard and other artists of the late eighteenth-century French school brought high prices yesterday at an auction of paintings and other valuable art works that were the property of Mrs. Joseph Heine of this city. The receipts for the final session of a two-day sale held at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, were $247,365, which brought the total for 273 separate lots to $281,652.

The past seven days have been a week of hard-earned gains for the United Nations forces. Friday's spectacular B-29 assault on Tokyo has begun a softening-up process which is combined with operations at sea and in the Philippines. On the Western Front American troops are in Metz, French troops are in historic Strasbourg, large territorial acquisitions have been made in the South and smaller but strategically important advances have been made in the North.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- "Widespread war weariness in the enemy camp" was alleged by Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels in a speech in the chief town of a badly bombed district, DNB reported today.

Aachen, by the time you receive this letter, will be kaput, but not Germany! We do not complain. The job is hard, but, then, what else would it be? Our successes have been spectacular, and blessed with a touch of military genius -- now we are faced with the last Frontier and the fanaticism of a nation of mad dogs at bay.

Before an audience that filled Carnegie Hall and overflowed onto the stage, Fritz Kreisler yesterday afternoon gave his first New York recital this season. The audience arose when the violinist appeared to begin the concert. The enthusiasm of the audience was unbounded, and it broke into cheers during the encores at the end of the afternoon.

Because of the shortage of chickens and turkeys, the 300 members of the New Jersey Retail Live Poultry Dealers Association are contemplating a two-week "holiday," during which no sales would be made throughout the State, while similar action is also understood to be under consideration in New York City, it was learned yesterday.

U.S. EIGHTH AIR FORCE BOMBER BASE IN ENGLAND, Nov. 25 (AP) -- To Lieut. Alan J. Gould Jr., 23, of New York City, has been awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross "for extraordinary achievement while serving as navigator of a B-17 Flying Fortress during combat bombing attacks over Nazi Europe."

WASHINGTON. VISITORS to the Navy Department soon learn that in spite of all its deadly activity on all the oceans and seas our Navy has managed to retain its sense of humor. Throughout the department signs and notices written in the best tradition of the Navy's paper work offer tongue-in-cheek advice against home-front dangers such as talking too much and to the wrong people about military secrets.

One of our London correspondents reports an influential body of opinion in Great Britain which believes that the American public "in its enthusiasm for private enterprise has failed to grasp to what an extent German National Socialism has made socialism in Europe inevitable, even when unwanted."

DETROIT, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Red Wings, meeting the Black Hawks for the first time this season, smothered them, 7 to 4, before 9,022 fans tonight. The Hawks stayed in the game until midway of the final period when Murray Armstrong's two goals in 52 seconds put Detroit out of reach.

PEOPLE are incurable losers. On trains, on streets, in stores, in taxis, in theatres, they leave a trail of lost belongings behind them. War hasn't mended this mass carelessness but it has reshaped the picture somewhat.

Anticipating post-war personnel needs of industry and various interested community groups as well as of its own students, Syracuse University will open a Psychological Services Center as soon as remodeling on an Army-released building is completed. The center will supplement existing personnel facilities for students on the campus.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Big Tom Davis, Duke University's candidate for all-America, led the Blue Devils to a 33-to-0 victory over North Carolina, Tarheels today in the thirty-first renewal of the State's oldest football rivalry.

Two direct subsidies are now being paid on wheat flour. One subsidy is designed to keep down the retail price of bread as part of our wartime hold-the-line program. The other subsidy is paid on exports of flour and is designed to reduce export prices so that we can compete in the world market.

The Regional War Labor Board ordered yesterday a $5 weekly increase for meat truck drivers, whose two-day strike last month threatened the city's meat supply. At the same time the board announced that it had turned down a request of the Transport Workers Union, Congress of Industrial Organizations, for a 10 per cent increase for 2,000 employes of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company.

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 26 -- Berlin said last night that Red Army assault forces had captured the great Hungarian rail hub of Hatvan, keystone of enemy defenses northeast of Budapest, and reported that 30,000 Russian troops had landed on Csepel Island in the Danube River due south of the capital.

ROSITA FORBES has an established and dazzling reputation as "a traveler in the wild places of the earth, possessed of strange informations, astonishing acquaintances and momentous convictions." She has traveled all over the globe, recrdssing her own trails many times.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The United States apparently intends to withdraw its comparatively small contingent of combat troops from India and Burma when the Burma Road is reopened. It considers the Southeast Asia theatre essentially a sphere of British interest.

Spokesmen for Congressional fiscal committees have indicated that it is unlikely that any major changes in our Federal income tax laws will be made so as to become effective for 1945. Having placed individual taxpayers on a pay-as-you-go basis, the intent of which is to bar retroactive income-tax legislation, any tax legislation enacted n 1945 should not become effective until 1946.

WITH BRITISH SECOND ARMY FORCES, Outside Kasteel, the Netherlands, Nov. 25 -- The old, moated castle owned by Kasteel's Mayor, who is a Baron and a friend of Queen Wilhelmina, appeared tonight to be a place of certain death for a small band of stubborn German paratroopers who seized it twenty-four hours ago and have since been resisting all efforts to oust them.

College librarians will be faced with the task of directing the nation's thinking toward freedom and world peace during the post-war period, declared Herbert B. Anstaett, librarian of Franklin and Marshall College, speaking yesterday afternoon at the thirty-first conference of Eastern College Librarians in the Harkness Academic Theatre of Columbia University.

OTTAWA, Nov. 25 -- Canadian Home Defense soldiers billeted in British Columbia paraded in defiant protest last night after Prime Minister William L. Mackenzie King staked the life of his Government on his new policy of partial conscription for overseas service. The policy already had precipitated violent demonstrations and political defections in Quebec.
With the return of Gen. Chou En-lai from Yenan to Chungking, it is obvious that the Chinese Communist problem has not been abandoned as unsolvable.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Wheat was more active today on the Board of Trade than in some time and regained its old position as market leader. New crop months advanced 2 to 2 3/8 cents a bushel early on general short covering and commission house buying, selling at a new high since early October before the demand was satisfied.

ONE of the truly dramatic stories of this war that no American journalist has ever had the opportunity to report in great detail is the mass migration of men and machines from the Soviet Ukraine to the safety of the East.

Possibly the outstanding development at the recent Rye International Business Conference was agreement on the necessity for greater freedom of international trade and an irreconcilable conflict of ideas as to the methods for its accomplishment.

TY NEWYDD, LLANYSTUMDWY, North Wales, Nov. 25 (AP) -- David Lloyd George, Britain's Prime Minister in the first World War and doyen of her elder statesmen in this one, asserted in an interview today that the surest way of preventing a third world war would be "by America's acting differently this time."

ROME, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- Advance armored patrols of the British Eighth Army, smashing northward against "very fierce" German resistance, have reached the eastern outskirts of Faenza, vital road and communications hub on the Rimini-Bologna highway, Allied headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Associated Press told the Supreme Court today that, regardless of disavowals and technicalities of language, the basic aim of the Government's civil anti-trust suit against it was "to impose upon the AP obligations which in substance are public-utility obligations."

Moscow (By Wireless). TENS of thousands of Red Army men and women are getting acquainted today with the capitalist world -- and vice versa. It is an experience that is bound to have a lasting effect upon both. Which will be the more influenced by the other is the subject of animated conversation everywhere in the Soviet Union today, from the highest circles to the street corner.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- A hot argument has broken out in Britain over the question of creating a regional security organization after the war. The argument centers particularly on a proposal for military and economic alliance among western European democracies.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The National Broadcasting Company and the Blue Network do not have to employ musicians as "platter turners," except at Chicago, where the practice has existed for some time, under a ruling announced today by the National Labor Relations Board.

MOVIEGOERS can expect an increase in screen piracy and other forms of adventure on the briny deep now that Hollywood has learned figuratively to go to sea on dry land. The latest studio to join the new indoor maritime parade is RKO-Radio, where on last Monday color cameras started grinding on "The Spanish Main," a story of seventeenth century swashbuckling romance and buccaneering.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Gunfire broke out and hand grenades were thrown today during a street demonstration against Premier Hubert Pierlot's Government.

ROME, Nov. 25 -- Ever since the Allies first landed in Sicily a year ago last July and began the painful, costly liberation of Italy, this unhappy country has been taken as a sort of testing ground, both for the United Nations and as an example of what to expect in post-war Europe.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Iowa Seahawks, posting a claim to the national service football championship, won their tenth straight game today by touching off four second-half touchdown drives to down stubborn Iowa, 30 to 6.

Your editorial "The Black Market in 'Gas'" underscores two points essential to the extermination of this vicious racket -- refusal of the public to participate in this "dirty business" and criminal prosecution of guilty service-station operators.

There'll be great doings among the teams in the National Football League today, especially in Philadelphia, where the Chicago Bears meet the Eagles in a game the Giants will be watching with as much attention as they can spare during their engagement with the Brooklyn Tigers at the Polo Grounds.

HERE is an explosive little story of Alaskan life (military) and love (in both its lower and higher forms). Indeed, the sort of life and love is indicated by the quotation from which the title is taken, a passage from Joshua telling of spies and harlotry.

Retail trade continued active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors were crowded and children's and toy departments were busy.

Delegates to the National Inter-fraternity Conference, including several college presidents and deans at leading universities, with which sixty of the largest Greek letter chapters are affiliated, warned yesterday of the challenge in the post-war period affecting their relationship to the educational system of the nation.

A NORTH window where there is light but no sun is an ideal spot for a clear-glass bowl garden. A terrarium, equipped with a fitted cover, is successful in this often difficult spot.

AN executive housekeeper in a large hotel has the same problems with paint and painters as the average homemaker does. We never quite realized this before hearing the advice that Dr. J.S. Long, chemical director of Devoe Laboratories, gave members of the New York Chapter of the National Executive Housekeepers Association during the Women's Day program at the recent Hotel Exposition.

CHRISTMAS should find the gardener in a mood of great good-will this year, for among the presents bestowed on him by people mindful of his hobby there will probably not be a single three-in-one combination trowel, spring fork and pruning shears, nor a sign of a pair of hand-lotion-impregnated quilted garden gloves, nor a single gardener's folding chair accompanied by matching kneeling pad.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 25 -- The Christiana Stable of Capt. and Mrs. Harry Lunger of Wilmington reached its highest point in its best season today when Megogo, a 3-year-old, captured the $29,050 Pimlico Cup as the combined meeting of the four Maryland mile tracks ended the Eastern racing season at Pimlico.

While complex questions involving world flying have been under discussion at the International Civil Aviation Conference some important contributions toward clearing the air for the future of domestic aviation have been made at the second annual Aviation Clinic held in Oklahoma City.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Senator George of Georgia, chairman of the Finance Committee, said in an interview today he was "satisfied" both the House and Senate would approve freezing the Social Security tax if the question reached a vote.

An invitation preview of the exhibition of "Portraits of Warriors from 1776 to 1944," at Portraits, Inc., 460 Park Avenue, will be held' Dec. 6 to augment a special fund for war work in the New York Y.W.C.A. Mrs. H. Bartow Farr, chairman of the organization's war work committee, is in charge of arrangements for the exhibition and is being assisted by a large group of prominent women.

FOR several years Jose de Creeft, an untiring workman, has been able to hold a small annual show of sculpture. This time, at Georgette Passedoit's, there are seven pieces which together reveal much of de Creeft's range, from almost primitive to extremely sophisticated.
KANDY, Ceylon, Nov. 25 (AP) -- A communique:
An organizer of the International Chamber of Commerce, a founder member of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States and member of the Educational Committee of the National Foreign Trade Council.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 25 -- The Scarlet Scourge of Ohio State won its sixth Western Conference football championship today, concluding its schedule with a perfect record for the first time since 1920. It advanced its candidacy for a Rose Bowl bid and for national championship honors in rivalry with Army and Navy.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The assassination of Lord Moyne by two young Palestinian Jews has awakened the British public to the realization that ancient ambitions and aspirations of Arab and Jew are making for another period of upheaval and strife in the Holy Land. It is not a new struggle, but an old one that revolves, as it has for the last quarter of a century, around British rule.

Lack of oxygen, or anoxia, is a peril at high altitudes. At first it creates an illusion of exhilaration and well-being. In a short time vision becomes affected, so that instruments, maps and other planes are blurred. Other senses suffer too. The ears are affected and radio reception is fuzzy and indistinct.

From the records of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania comes the story of a fraud against a number of brokerage houses which might have been highly successful if its perpetrator had had a little better market judgment.

AMONG the functions of history, two appear to be of the greatest consequence: the artistic (or recreative) and the scientific (or predictive). The artistic function of history is to create, or recreate, in the reader a sense of what it was like to live in any past age.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- The "extremely critical" manpower needs of the vast Chicago industrial area are proving the Central West's most perplexing war production problem. This situation prevails at a time when WPB officials are issuing warnings that American troops on all battlefronts actually are being delayed and the war prolonged because there is an insufficient supply of essential equipment.
