About the late Sir Arthur Eddington, our brief special dispatch from London said, among other things, that the distinguished astronomer and physicist was a member of the Society of Friends and intensely fond of detective stories.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- British Labor Minister Ernest Bevin told a press conference in Leeds today that the American shell shortage had arisen "because immediately the Allies went through France and Belgium to the Netherlands the press and many responsible persons in industry in America assumed that the war was over."

With regard to your series of letters concerning compulsory military training on a permanent basis I should like to make a suggestion. Why not listen to some former educators who now serve as enlisted men? I think most of them would join me in voicing serious doubts as to the mental and spiritual effects of such training.

An announcement yesterday by John D. Reilly, president of the Todd Shipyards Corporation, revealed that the company's two large ship repair yards in New York Harbor, the Todd Brooklyn and Hoboken Divisions, have repaired or converted to war purposes 9,074 naval or merchant vessels from Pearl Harbor to the first of this month.

Superior height, speed and experience carried City College's basketball team to an easy 66-41 victory over Juniata College in its opening game last night at the Lavender gym. At half-time, C.C. N.Y. led by 35 -- 19.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 25 -- The manner in which the War Labor Board handled the "holiday" of truckers in the Greater Boston area has served to bring out a point of national significance. It showed that in strictly intra-union disputes the board would not bargain with the warring factions.

THIS is to be British week for the New York Philharmonic-Symphony. Artur Rodzinski will conduct a program made up entirely of works by English composers, including William Walton's huge choral work, "Belshazzar's Feast," and the first American performances of Vaughan Williams' Symphony No. 5 in D.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Representatives of the Polish Peasant party, of which M. Mikolajczyk is chairman, declined today to join a coalition government under the newly designated Premier, Jan Kwapinski, Socialist.
OTTAWA, Ont., Nov. 25 -- With a finality that it has been impossible to escape, the conscription issue has once more caught up with the Government and with the Canadian people.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- President Roosevelt's statement that the war is costing us about $250,000,000 a day gives some measure of the astronomical war costs which the Sixth War Bond Drive is designed to help finance. That daily expenditure figure is roughly equivalent to the cost of running the entire Federal Government in the years 1877 and 1886.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- The International Civil Aviation Conference, through action by a special joint subcommittee representing all fifty-two participating nations, approved today the preamble of the American-British-Canadian proposal pledging international cooperation for sound economic operation of trunk airlines on the basis of equality of opportunity for all nations, large or small, for the purpose of avoiding friction which might endanger world security.

A NEW series of weekly roundtable discussions, entitled "Let's Face the Issues," is scheduled to begin this afternoon at 5 o'clock over WOR and the Mutual Broadcasting System, replacing the dramatic show, "You Can't Take It With You."

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 25 (AP) -Japanese bases in the Bonin Islands -- along the B-29 route from Saipan to Tokyo -- were heavily hit by Seventh United States Air Force bombers both before and after the Superfortresses had made their first strike against the Japanese capital, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz disclosed today.

Luther Huston's article on the Presidency in THE TIMES Magazine is very illuminating. May I, however, point out an error. Mr. Huston states: "In the field of legislation his [the President's] powers are advisory and he can exercise authority over Congress only on extraordinary occasions."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Support of Dr. George W. Taylor and the "Little Steel" formula which he devised came from three of his colleagues on the National War Labor Board today in response to criticism by Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

HERE two provocative books which deserve more the professional attention of educators, to whom -- it might seem -- they are primarily addressed. ON THE SWISS-ALSATIAN FRONTIER, Nov. 25 -- Still poised for the coup de grace against the German-held bridgehead of Huningue on the west bank of the Rhine stretching about two miles north of here, advanced formations of Maj. Gen. Jean de Lattre de Tassigny's French First Army continued to consolidate their positions today and bring up materiel.

THE interest in Henry James steadily grows -- it is one of the more heartening events of our literary life at the moment. A few years ago James books were a drug on the second-hand market. Now they are so rare that it becomes a matter for surprise and comment that James' American publishers have not yet undertaken to give us a good cheap edition such as Macmillan of London gave England.

Although I doubt whether, at this date, even Mr. Krutch's eminently fair and discerning treatment of Johnson the writer will win new readers for "Rasselas."

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- While the Ministry of the Interior reported quiet in Haute-Savoie and other districts of France where the French Forces of the Interior reigned supreme before and immediately after the liberation, the former clandestine organizations are wondering where they stand.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 25 -- The ever-fighting football Irish regained a measure of the gridiron glory that once was Notre Dame's today, throwing up a barrier of denial before Georgia Tech's touchdown-minded Engineers to win the day's top intersectional feature, 21 to 0.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops have cleared the mountain passes leading to the Chefang Valley in Western China, which is transversed by the Burma-Ledo Road, and have taken four more strong points in Bhamo, North Burma, with the aid of American dive-bombers which blasted Japanese positions only 100 yards ahead of the advancing Chinese.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Scorning a soggy turf that took the edge off their speedy attack, a determined band of Oklahoma Aggies rode over the University of Oklahoma, 28 -- 6, today to gain their first victory in the intra-State football rivalry since 1933.
NEVER write a play that depicts the habits and modes of a certain group of people, for they will arise to confront you with a thousand accusations of inaccuracy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Any household mechanical refrigerators made as a result of "spot authorizations" in accordance with provisions of Priorities Regulation 25 will be added to the "frozen stockpile" of refrigerators, the War Production Board warned today.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- Albert Torek of Essex Fells, N.J., today captured the Good Hands Cup in the initial competition of the new series for that noted trophy during the first day of the annual indoor horse show of the Boulder Brook Club, held in the ring on Old Mamaroneck Road.
ROME, Nov. 25 (AP) -- A communique:

LIKE Hajj the beggar, the aircraft industry has, in a short time, been catapulted from the ranks of the lowly. Unlike Hajj, it will not plummet down. The construction, operation and maintenance of aircraft will easily remain one of our biggest industries.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Nov. 25 -- More and more, as action proceeds in the Pacific, it is apparent that this is a new kind of warfare, never seen before in the world. It is equally clear that the Pacific pattern, in both strategy and tactics, has taken definite shape.

Optimism over the possibility that some American Governments would recognize the Spanish Republican Government-in-Exile to be formed at a meeting in Mexico City on Jan. 10 was expressed by Diego Martinez Barrio, President of the Spanish Republican Cortes and chairman of the Spanish Committee of Liberation, on his arrival yesterday at La Guardia Field by plane from Mexico City.

IT turned out to be one of those weeks. Not a week of prodigious activity, like the week preceding, but one so diverse as to defy any effort to pull events together in retrospect to form a pattern of relationships.

Holiday trade forged ahead here last week despite bad weather. Department store volume ran well ahead of last year, the gain ranging to 18 per cent or more for some stores. While merchandise assortments are still favorable, shortages that are expected to be acute in mid-December are already making their appearance.

Leading cities in New York State have more than a reasonable expectancy of continuing their present importance and prosperity during the post-war years, according to Chester E. Haring, director of marketing research for the Committee for Economic Development.
MADISON, Wis., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Minnesota's Golden Gophers conquered Wisconsin's gallant Badgers, 28 to 26, today in their Big Ten football final, but only after a hair-raising offensive battle.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Slammin' Sam Snead came sloshing through rain, mud and murk today to gain a tie for first place at the fifty-fourth hole of the 72-hole Portland open golf tournament. He chalked up a three-round total of 217 to share the lead with Mike Turnesa, White Plains, N.Y., who started the day two strokes ahead of the field.

It has been found after years of experience that some of the young blind and particularly blind persons beyond middle age have difficulty in learning braille. One reason is that the braille dots do not stand up after constant use. They wear out and almost disappear.

Plans for a new religious center in Brooklyn were announced yesterday by the Rev. Hugh Dwight Darsie, president of the Brooklyn Church and Mission Federation. Headquarters of the federation will be moved some time next spring from 285 Schermerhorn Street, to the Ovington Studios Building, 252 Fulton Street, fronting on S. Parkes Cadman Plaza, according to the announcement.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- In the first detailed report by a United States Government Agency offering eyewitness proof of mass murder by the Germans, the War Refugee Board made public today accounts by three persons of organized atrocities at Birkenau and Oswiecim [Auschwitz] in southwestern Poland that transcend the horrors of Lublin.

A Stars and Stripes Tricolor Ball in tribute to France and to officers of the armed forces will be given on Friday night at the Roosevelt under the auspices of the Daughters of the American Revolution War Service Committee of Greater New York.

TORONTO, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Toronto moved back into first place in the National Hockey League and Rookie Goalie Frank McCool achieved his first shut-out tonight as the Maple Leafs scored a 2-0 victory over the Canadiens before 13,315 fans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The United Steel Workers (CIO) won some adjustments in wages today in a decision by the War Labor Board, but their demands for a guaranteed annual scale and for pay rises above the "Little Steel" formula were rejected formally.

PUBLISHED just after a bitter Presidential campaign, this opening volume of the memoirs of Josephus Daniels is like a winter wind blowing through a smoke-filled room. It is the story of a gentleman in politics. It offers proof, sometimes sorely needed, that men need not be craven or mean in order to become political leaders.

The soil-enriching powers of the earthworm were recognized by Charles Darwin a century ago, but only recently has the worm been harnessed and put to work. Ten worms in a cubic foot of earth, equivalent to 1,000,000 worms per acre, may increase the crop output from 100 to 300 per cent.

The seventieth birthday anniversary of Dr. Chaim Weizmann, president of the World Zionist Organization and the Jewish Agency for Palestine, who is also one of the world's outstanding chemists, will be observed here tomorrow afternoon by the Zionist Organization of America with a one-hour program at the West Foyer of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A COUPLE of wires from Eddie Cantor, now on the Coast, say he is very, very warm on the contemplated "Nellie Bly" that he is to co-produce with Nat Karson, the scenic designer. Sig Herzig is breaking fingernails in his rush to get the book into shape for what Mr. C. hopes will be a June 1 Broadway debut.

STRASBOURG, France, Nov. 25 -- In spite of intermittent German bombardment of the center of the city, the sacristans of the Strasbourg Cathedral were preparing today for the first mass held there since the Germans occupied Strasbourg four and a half years ago.

IF movie producers think that the critics are unduly harsh when they fail to go into rhapsodies over a picture, they should at least be thankful that Slavko Vorkapich is not a working critic. Hollywood knows Mr. Vorkapich and what he can do with a motion-picture camera when called upon to create "special effects."

The death of Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis in Chicago yesterday plunged baseball into its all-time No. 1 guessing contest last night as hundreds began to ask: Who is to succeed the 78-year-old jurist who for twenty-four years ruled the nation's foremost pastime with an iron hand?

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Nebraska sewed up fourth place in the Big Six football conference today by defeating Kansas State, 35 to 0, while rain, sleet and snow fell alternately on the crowd of 2,000.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Jubilation mixed with profound concern for the immediate future but with a determination to face the difficulties marked the mood in which the Congress of Industrial Organizations met here this week.

THE Chinese poet Laotzu, according to legend, was immaculately conceived by a shooting-star, carried in his mother's womb for sixty-two years, and born white-haired, in 604 B.C. In spite of the great distance between himself and the modern world, Laotzu might well be living today, so pertinent are his observations of life, which he held to be, incidentally, the total and inexhaustible possibility of existence, not merely a nightmare in a wasteland.
Baseball leaders throughout the United States and part of Canada paid tribute yesterday to Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis, commissioner of organized baseball, who died in a Chicago hospital.
IN a little while it will be a year since the many friends of Hendrik Willem van Loon were shocked and grieved by the news of his sudden and unexpected death.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 25 -- If the farmers of the Middle West continue to follow the course which they appear to have charted for themselves, they will come to the end of this war much better prepared to cope with their own reconversion problems than were the farmers of the first World War.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 25 -- Rutgers, winding up its war-curtailed five-game season, notched its third victory today by trouncing Lehigh, 15 -- 6, before an alumni day crowd of 3,000. Lehigh, which also closed its schedule, suffered its sixth straight setback.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The following Foreign Service changes, since Nov. 18, were announced today by the State Department:

WITH a record crop of nuts moving to market, this year is a good time to find out how satisfactory they are when assigned an important role in a menu. Walnuts that have been warmed slowly in their shells, for example, furnish a wonderful dessert when served with port or other sweet wine.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Veterans and men still in service who have experience or ideas which fit them for independent business operation found this week a new potent backer, as the Smaller War Plants Corporation began shifting emphasis in its operations to the finding of new American "enterprisers" in the ranks of the fighting forces.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -- The University of Pennsylvania, thwarted by Navy, Michigan and Army, was back in its own class today. From the very beginning it was obvious to a crowd of 50,000 persons that the Red and Blue would end its gridiron campaign on a happy note, with Cornell in for a most uncomfortable afternoon at Franklin Field.

PELELIU, Palau Islands, Nov. 21 (Delayed) -- It is difficult to talk glibly about the possibility of early Japanese surrender after seeing what is happening on this bloody five-mile strip of coral hell.

HOPE GONE: Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain has established three "capitals" since he and other prominent collaborationists fled from Vichy last August. The first, still on French soil, was Belfort near the German border. With the Allies' rapid advance, the "Government" fled into Germany, first to Baden-Baden and, last week, to the south German city of Sigmaringen.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 25 -- Howard M. Bernstein, Rutgers varsity guard, was forced to break his continuous playing record in the contest with Lehigh here today.

Columbia bade farewell to the 1944 football season yesterday and no tears were shed in the parting. For the Lions bowed to Dartmouth, 18 to 0, in the season's finale at Baker Field, which brought to an end a year almost as disastrous as 1943, when the Light Blues failed to chalk up a single triumph.

Under the auspices of the Greek-American University Club, Dr. Robert Chambers recently delivered an address on "The Reconstruction of the Basic Sciences in Post-War Europe." He pointed out that Europe today suffers not only from the ravages of war but from a scientifically systematic effort of the Nazis to lay low the culture of all Europe, outside of Germany.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The newspaper Expressen said today that opinion was developing that the Swedish steamer Hansa, sunk off Goteborg yesterday with a loss of almost 100 lives, had been torpedoed.

Four benefit performances of "A Bell for Adano" at the Cort Theatre will be given in the near future to aid various philanthropic enterprises. The play, adapted from John Hersey's novel, will open Dec. 6.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25 -- The biggest football crowd of the year, 90,019, saw Southern California smother U.C.L.A., 40 to 13, today and become the western nominee for the Rose Bowl against either Ohio State or Tennessee.

Calling for a guarantee of equality to all national minorities in the post-war world, representatives of business, religion and Government attending first-day sessions of the Ambijan National Conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday described such surety as the master key to unlock successful global peace.

JASCHA HEIFETZ will give the first performance of Louis Gruenberg's new violin concerto at the concerts of the Philadelphia Orchestra, under Eugene Ormandy, Friday afternoon and Saturday night in Philadelphia.

In a determined move to head off and stamp out overcharges in the sale of Christmas dolls and other toys, the Office of Price Administration instituted injunction actions yesterday in Manhattan and Brooklyn Federal Courts against seventeen manufacturers and dealers to force compliance with ceiling price regulations.

SEVERAL months after Margaret Bourke-White had left the Cassino Valley -- where she photographed the Fifth Army pushing its painful foot-by-foot war toward central Italy -- she received a letter from an Army major whom she had asked to check on the condition of young Cpl. Jess Padgitt of Des Moines, her assigned assistant on that photographic tour of the front.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 25 -- Postponed twice because of priority difficulties involving travel of foreign delegates, the World Jewish Congress begins its five-day war emergency conference here tomorrow, with 310 representatives from thirty-eight countries attending.

A crowd of 25,000 turned out at Ebbets Field yesterday to watch schoolboy football make its contribution to the Sixth War Loan drive and was treated to two games replete with action, despite the one-sided scores that resulted.

THIS afternoon the annual subscription series of the Y.M.H.A.'s Dance Theatre will get under way at Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street with a performance by Mia Slavenska, David Tihmar and company. The program will include the Cesar Franck "Variations," a scene from "Coppelia" and a series of divertissements.

In Quebec last week civilians paraded with placards, staged demonstrations, came to the point of riot. In British Columbia soldiers broke regulations to march through the streets shouting defiance of the Government. Army officers spoke out publicly against official policies.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Forces, Paris, Sunday, Nov. 26 -- Bayonet-wielding doughboys hacked their way out of the death-ridden Huertgen Forest to the Cologne Plain yesterday, breaking the enemy's fanatic grip on the approaches to the third city of the Reich while other Americans streamed eleven miles through dismembered German defenses north of Strasbourg.
CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (AP) -There were not enough hogs on sale today to make a market and prices were nominally steady. Cattle and sheep were steady. Salable receipts: Hogs 500 cattle 800, and 100 sheep.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 25 -- North Carolina's Methodists and Baptists, by far its most numerous denominations, have called formally for a referendum on the complete outlawry of whisky, beer and wine in the Tarheel State. Since Governor-elect Gregg Cherry is committed to such a referendum, it seems likely to be held, despite the fact that the Nebraska drys were heavily rebuffed this month when they held a similar election.

DOUG ALLAN, who conducts a television program called "Thrills and Chills From Everywhere," has talked to explorers, adventurers, soldiers and others who have faced danger in many parts of the world, and in this book he has retold the most thrilling experiences of a number of these people.

THIS is an important book. It puts the problem of peace-making on the level on which it belongs, beyond the discussion of grandiose blueprints, ingenious gadgets of peace machinery and "diplomatic shadow-boxing" into the very midst of the complex and dynamic forces of our international society.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The third Thanksgiving Day of the current war has passed into history, with thousands of families in American homes dining upon chicken, duck or other practical substitutes for the traditional turkey.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 25 -- Educators attending the final sessions of the National Council of Teachers of English conference warned that a tendency had sprung up in various areas of the country to reduce the time now allotted to English instruction in the high schools.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 25 -- Nowhere in the country has news of the shake-up in Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Cabinet been followed with greater eagerness than on the West Coast, with its more than 40,000 residents of Chinese ancestry, including San Francisco's Chinatown, the biggest Chinese settlement in this hemisphere.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 24 (Delayed) -- The Allied drives in Burma during the last six weeks have made such progress that the Japanese hold on all of northern Burma above Mandalay is threatened and the enemy's grip even in southern and eastern Burma is considerably less secure than it was six months ago.

LONDON, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- Aachen Cathedral, from which German emperors ruled medieval central Europe, will have to await restoration by Germany herself when that country is able to undertake the task, the United States Army monuments, fine arts and archives section of G-5 reported today.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 25 (AP) -- A United States Army Forces in China communique:

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 25 (AP) -- That dusky flash from the Illinois campus, Claude (Buddy) Young, combined with Don Greenwood today to hand Northwestern a 25-6 thumping in the Western Conference finale for both clubs.

GREAT LAKES, Ill., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Great Lakes' Bluejackets, striking for 21 points in the second quarter, whipped the Fort Francis E. Warren team from Wyoming, 28 -- 7, before 23,000 shivering sailors at Ross Field today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The arrests of more than 130 Union Pacific Railroad dining car waiters and stewards on charges of withholding receipts for meals were announced today by the FBI.

THANKSGIVING DAY ends a period of time. The leaves have fallen, autumn has gone and almost at once it will be cold enough for the heavy coat now hanging in the closet under the stairs. Out in the kitchen the bones are being rectified into a curious, watery soup for Sunday's supper, and tomorrow the Christmas shopping will move into its shrill and worried final phase.

Plans for an annual award to the New York newspaper reporter, editor, artist or illustrator whose work is adjudged outstanding for the year were announced yesterday by the Silurians, whose members served as New York City newspaper staff men twenty-five or more years ago, during a meeting at the New York Athletic Club.

Billy Jurges, shortstop and field captain of the Giants, yesterday underwent an operation for the removal of a torn cartilage in his left knee at St. Elizabeth's Hospital. The operation was performed by Dr. Francis J. Sweeny and Dr. Thomas Brennan, who said that Jurges would have to remain in the hospital ten days or two weeks.

Approximately 1,000 investment bankers from all parts of the nation are to assemble today at the Edgewater Beach Hotel, Chicago, in the biggest annual meeting of the Investment Bankers Association of America since the outbreak of war.

High school students of rural New Hampshire feel the need for more practical courses, a Colby Junior College social survey reveals. The survey was conducted in New London, N.H., by thirty-four Colby students under the direction of six faculty members to determine what post-war planning will be required in small New England communities.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The effort to drain Germany's war machine dry of oil was resumed by the United States Eighth Air Force today with an attack by more than 1,000 heavy bombers inside besieged Germany. More than 1,000 fighters escorted the Flying Fortresses and Liberators.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The extensive Cabinet changes announced in Chungking this week are the most comprehensive and sweeping that China has experienced since 1937. Taken together, they seem to point to a more effective conduct of military and political affairs.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte (Delayed) -- Patrol torpedo boats, America's "splinter navy," are probing ever deeper into enemy waters. They are running missions completely around Leyte Island and far to the south into northern bays and estuaries of Mindanao, seeking out enemy barges and small boat traffic.

HOUSTON, Te., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Texas Christian's mud-splattered Horned Frogs halted a desperate Rico drive that carried to the 1-yard line with 15 seconds to play today to beat the Owls, 9 -- 6, and win the Southwest Conference football championship.

The Baruch Committee in Physical Medicine, 597 Madison Avenue additional sum of $185,000, given by Bernard M. Baruch for the further advancement of the program in physical medicine and the physical rehabilitation of those disabled in war.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Japanese patrolling was reported today west of Hwaiyuanchen, 185 miles southeast of Kweiyang, amid indications that the enemy might be planning to drive from three directions on the capital of Kweichow on the Burma Road.

Trying to get delivery of goods already on order instead of placing orders for new goods was the major problem which last week occupied the attention of store buyers and local staffs, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

The development of India's shipping after the war is a matter of vital importance to the country -- no major industry in India has suffered more as a result of the war than the shipping industry and, although there is interest in expansion, the country is most anxious for the replacement of such tonnage as has been and will still be lost during the war, Gaganvihani L. Mehta declared here last week.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- Equestrian activities and golf are vying for first place in the interest of the Pinehurst winter colony this season. With the arrival of Capt. Dirk Van Ingen and his thoroughbred mounts from the Equinox Stables of Manchester, Vt., many riders have been joining the daily party ride.
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted by the MTI agency to the Hungarian press and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The women's committee for the benefit performance of the Ice Follies on Thursday night at Madison Square Garden, which is being sponsored by the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, will meet at a reception to be given Tuesday afternoon in the Pall Mall Room of the Ritz-Carlton by Mrs. F. Kingsbury Curtis, committee chairman.

RECONVERSION is in the air, but, in that respect at least, we of the Metropolitan are more fortunate than most other business concerns in this country. First, we don't want to "reconvert" to what we had before, even if it were possible; and, second, we are going ahead right now with what, basically, is our program for the future.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Senator Connally, Democrat, of Texas, proposed today that Congress delay defining the powers of an American delegate until the Senate approved an enabling treaty for a projected world security organization. Two Republican Senators backed him up.

NO new operas are scheduled for production by the Metropolitan Opera Association, whose season of 1944-45 opens tomorrow night. The opera for the opening is Gounod's "Faust." Why not "Aida" and be done with it? Well, "Aida" -- a magnificent masterpiece -- might be better than "Faust," but "Aida" comes on Thursday, not Monday.

BEATRICE LILLIE is here on a furlough. That mistress of sophisticated slapstick, who stamps every song she sings with her own brand of humor, has been dashing about the war fronts making GI's and Tommies pack up their troubles in their old kit bags and smile.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- Clark Shaughnessy's Pitt Panthers struck twice in the third period today to defeat their traditional rivals from Penn State, 14 -- 0, before 10,000 fans at Pitt Stadium.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- The news that the Tricolor flew again from the spire of the Strasbourg Cathedral was for the French another sign of that victory that signifies the recovery of France's strength and prestige.

The national board of officers of the Catholic War Veterans, Inc., meeting yesterday in the Empire State Building, adopted a resolution petitioning President Roosevelt Prime Minister Churchill, Marshal Stalin, the heads of other United Nations and members of Congress "to join with us in creating a long era of peace by passing necessary legislation memorializing representatives at the peace conference to strive for a peace without pacifism, a peace based on justice."
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 25 -- Proud of their achievements in labor's "production army" during the war, delegates to the American Federation of Labor annual convention are worried about the future.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The State Department said today that our "traditional policy of not guaranteeing specific frontiers in Europe" was not an issue in the resignation of Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, Premier of the Polish Government-in-Exile in London.

There was no general advance on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, but selected favorites rose and the close was irregularly higher. THE NEW YORK TIMES rail average gained 0.18 to 32.03, the industrial average 0.40 to 172.74 and the combined average 0.29 to 102.38.

Although establishment of manufacturers' sales branches by large producers of appliances has been taken as an indication that there will be some elimination of wholesalers in post-war distribution, a series of forums conducted by the National Electrical Wholesalers Association shows that during the war the position of wholesalers has been strengthened, Herbert Metz, general sales manager Graybar Electric Company, Inc., and chairman of the association's post-war planning committee, declared yesterday.

In a recent issue of THE TIMES Magazine Albert L. Wechsler takes you to task for listing "margarine" as pronounced with a soft "g." In that regard it may be interesting to point out that the National Association of Margarine Manufacturers and the industry has ruled that its official pronunciation is margarine with a soft "g".

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Sunday, Nov. 26 -- Hitting their second Japanese reinforcement convoy in two days as the enemy made persistent efforts to reinforce Leyte, American Thunderbolts and P-40's at dusk last night sank three troop-laden vessels out of four and left the fourth burning off Cebu.

Two General Electric engineers, Norman F. Barnes and S. Lawrence Bellinger, have devised a method which makes it possible, with a flashlight exposure of less than one-millionth of a second, to photograph the finest details of air disturbances and even to make an image of heat waves that rise from the palm of the hand.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 25 -- Duke University and Alabama were selected tonight to meet in the annual Sugar Bowl football classic here Jan. 1.

WITH THE AMERICAN SEVENTH ARMY, North of the Saverne Gap, France, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Germans, supported by about twenty Tiger and Panther tanks, were driving southwest in the direction of Sarrebourg today in an audacious attempt to smash across the Saverne Gap corridor.

FROM Stockholm comes official word that Sweden issued last month a series of stamps "illustrating the history of the Navy at certain vital epochs." Specifically this postal group commemorates the Battle of Femern on Oct. 13, 1644, when, as one incident of the Thirty Years War, a Swedish fleet under Commander in Chief Karl Gustaf Wrangel defeated the Danes -- a decisive naval victory which led to the Peace of Bromsebro in 1645.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 25 (AP) -- A supplementary communique:

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Tennessee's undefeated Volunteers closed the football season here today with a 21-to-7 victory over the Kentucky Wildcats and moved into a favorable position for a possible post-season bowl game invitation.

In a message from Leyte, in the Philippines, Lindesay Parrott, war correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, informed his office yesterday that he had been struck in the left chest by two bomb fragments. One of these, he said, has been removed, while the other is "presently inoperable."

B-29 HEADQUARTERS ON SAIPAN, the Marianas, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Superfortress men of Saipan today counted their raid on Tokyo a successful first move for an aerial knockout of war industry in the Japanese homeland.

B-29 HEADQUARTERS ON SAIPAN, the Marianas, Nov. 25 -A full assessment of yesterday's raid on Tokyo was still incomplete at noon today, but there was full agreement among fliers interviewed that more than half of their bombs fell in target areas.

A NEW climbing rose has to be good if it is to be worth introducing. The vivid Paul's Scarlet and the pale pink Dr. Van Fleet have been satisfactory in every respect for so long a time that they hold the honors in this popular class.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Allied military authorities have agreed to place at the disposal of the French Government, beginning Jan. 15, sufficient harbor facilities in France to permit the importation of 10,000 tons of civilian goods daily, it was learned today.

DURHAM, N.C., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Duke University athletic officials said tonight that if the necessary permission could be obtained the Duke Blue Devils would accept the invitation to play in the annual Sugar Bowl game against Alabama.

In the article "The Quick March Out of Khaki," which appeared recently in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine, the author wrote: "As soon as the ready-to-be-discharged soldier gets off the boat and is checked in at the port of debarkation, there's usually a pass waiting for him."

PRINGETON, N.J., Nov. 25 -- Two touchdowns by Ken Ludwig featured the 31-6 victory scored by the Atlantic City Naval Air Station eleven over Princeton today at Palmer Stadium. The contest ended an informal three-game football schedule for the Tigers.

A 12-CENTAVOS brown postage and a 25c green air-mail received from Mexico by Leon Monosson commemorate (as inscribed on the 25c) the "III Feria del Libro y Exposicion Nacional del Periodismo y de Cine y Radio" (Third Book Fair and National Exposition of Periodicals, the Cinema and Radio) held in October.

JOY departments may offer a limited choice of new Christmas playthings, but the baby won't care if he has a spoon and an old pie tin to bang on, a handful of clothespins (without springs) to shake in a box and dump out, and, for a doll, a stocking stuffed and tied to make a head and body.

TEN years ago, on the eve of his sixtieth birthday, Winston Churchill rose in the House of Commons from the seat just below the gangway, which he had occupied throughout his long exile in the political wilderness, in order to utter his most powerful warning about the ever more alarming speed and extent of German rearmament.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 25 -- Problems dealing with the school and college teaching of English, particularly during the war period and in the peace years ahead, were discussed here this week by 2,000 teachers and educators representing every part of the country, attending the annual convention of the National Council of Teachers of English.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Led by Fred Feiler, Drake University's cross-country team made a 1-2-3 finish of the sixth annual National Collegiate A.A. championship today, winning the team title with a 25-point total, lowest in the history of the meet.

BAINBRIDGE, Md., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Bainbridge's explosive Commodores moved within one game of their second straight perfect season today with a hard-won 21-to-13 decision over the pro-packed Camp Peary (Va.) Pirates, who several times late in the game threatened to pull an upset.

PACIFIC HEADQUARTERS, Twentieth Army Air Force, Nov. 25 -- The natural excitement and gratification that the Superfortress attack on Tokyo engenders in every American will make it extremely difficult to keep the operation in its proper perspective.

Holding within a narrow range, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 1 point lower to 7 points higher than Friday's final prices, with deferred positions relatively firm.

AN American girl traveling in Australia meets with an accident on a railway train. When she recovers consciousness she does not know who she is or why she is on the train. Helpful persons who have examined her belongings tell her that she is Cleo Ballister and that she is on her way to visit her Uncle Joe Ballister.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 25 -- Figures for the Argentine Government's revenue and expenditures last year, just published, show the largest deficit in Argentine history.

Further encouraging progress in E bond sales in both New York City and State was disclosed yesterday by the War Finance Committee which also promised the release today of a detailed analysis of the Sixth War Loan showing advantages in the drive to date over a comparable period in the last campaign.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 25 -- A stalwart Brown University eleven combined fifteen years of denial into fifteen minutes of vengeance today to defeat Colgate, 32 -- 20, for the first time since 1928, while 12,000 chilled fans cheered at Brown Field.

THIS book explains the fundamentals of the three major forms of religion in America. It is not, however, a book about differences. Rather its emphasis is upon their common belief in one God and as such is a contribution toward understanding and tolerance in a country which is waging a mighty war in their defense.

Five months after passage of the Service Men's Readjustment Act of 1944, generally known as the "GI Bill of Rights," returning veterans in this area are now able to obtain loans for homes, the first of which was issued here Friday, but as yet are unable to obtain advances under the law to start small business ventures, a check-up revealed last week.

DR. CUSHMAN is much more interested in the people she worked with than she is in herself; thus her book is less an autobiography than it is a record of these people. She appears unfamiliar with anthropology, which is a shame, for her descriptions of African tribes contain valuable sociological material.

An undertaking in behalf of the Children of France is the recital to be given by Fritz Kreisler, the violinist, on the night of Dec. 19 in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The event being arranged by Mme. Louis Jacques Balsan and a special committee.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The board of directors of the New Orleans Cotton Exchange said today in its annual report that the Government's parity price program has placed the cotton merchant "practically on a treadmill."

ARMY and Navy personnel on duty in the Middle East now have the rare opportunity of not only officially criticizing the movies they see but getting paid for it too! According to the Nov. 10 issue of The Stars and Stripes, service moviegoers can now "have a crack at 120 bucks to be split three ways in a contest sponsored by the Middle East Film Exchange."

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 25 -- Stung to the quick by the recent announcement that Louisiana stands forty-second among the States of the Union in literacy the people, backed by civic and business organizations as well as parent-teacher clubs, are demanding that there be strict compliance with the new compulsory school-attendance law passed by the Legislature in May.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 25 -- Yale's football team wound up its first unbeaten season in twenty-one years in the Yale Bowl today before a chilled crowd of 18,000, but the Bulldog wasn't able to keep the escutcheon quite spotless, for the Virginia Cavaliers achieved a 6-6 tie in the year's finale.

APPLE trees are acknowledged to be long-lived. The yearly pruning, however, is as important for the single tree in a backyard garden as for an orchard. The proper time for pruning is the winter months when the trees are dormant.

STOUT STEVE OWEN probably never thought the time would come when he would find himself cheering whole-heartedly for the Chicago Bears. But the well-upholstered coach of the Giants is a violently partisan supporter of the Monsters of the Midway today. Only for today, though. After this the Bears are strictly on their own and Stout Steve won't give a hoot what happens to them.

CHARLES MANN, for fifty-four years editor of The Enterprise of Lisbon Falls, Me., finds that the best way to report the news is to live it. He has always shared his experiences and his correspondence with his readers.

MADRID (By Wireless.) THE bullfight in Spain today is enjoying a renaissance, partly because of the presence of several excellent matadors and partly because of the present emphasis on all traditional and purely Hispanic manifestations in the life of the Spanish people. Abroad one is accustomed to hearing the bullfight spoken of as a lingering survival from the days of gladiatorial combats held by the tenuous thread of a cherished tradition.

THE NEW YORK TIMES has been requested by the Society of Automotive Engineers to ascertain from its readers their opinions on what improvements and advances should be incorporated into the bodies of post-war passenger cars. The findings of this survey will be analyzed at the annual meeting of the society in Detroit, Jan. 8-12.

THE trouble with presenting bouquets to theatre folk is that the public is apt to sniff suspiciously and regard the matter as a well camouflaged publicity effort. The orchid, bestowed too often and too indiscriminately, has made John Doe indifferent.

A BIG ship edges alongside a New York pier, the rails lined with the girls GI Joe didn't leave behind him. Eighty excited war brides are entering America for the first time and on the pier there is a flurry of preparation. A harassed naval officer says, "They're prettier than the last bunch"; a trim Red Cross official hopes her list of expected arrivals checks with the bright faces crowding the decks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The Army and Navy Journal suggested today that, as a result of the recent Court of Inquiry, Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel might never be court-martialed for the Pearl Harbor disaster and that his Army associate at Hawaii, Maj. Gen. Joseph E. Short, would be vindicated.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 25 -- The League for Human Rights, relief arm of the American Federation of Labor, started a campaign today to raise $1,000,000 in January to aid rehabilitation of trade unions in countries overrun by war.

Relaxing the secrecy that has surrounded its important ship commissionings since Pearl Harbor, the Navy permitted the public to attend yesterday at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn the formal placing in service of the Bonhomme Richard, its newest airplane carrier of the Essex type.

The story of a modern Esther who saved eighteen men by stealing into Germany, "marrying" them and accompanying them to Palestine was told yesterday. The girl, a German Jewish refugee, who could easily pass as a Nazi, entered her country on forged passports. The nineteenth time she did not return.

Manning praised last night the "increasing appreciation and understanding" shown by the Russian Government in its dealings with religion when he spoke at a special service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine opening a Christmas campaign for gifts of clothing for Soviet children.

ROME, Nov. 26 -- Eleanor Packard, United Press correspondent, arrived at an Italian airport aboard a Russian transport plane today after having been expelled from Belgrade on the complaint that she had violated Yugoslav censorship.

The United Negro College Fund has received $901,812 this year for the advancement of Negro higher education in twenty-seven colleges, it was announced yesterday by Walter Hoving, national chairman of the fund and president of Lord Taylor. He estimated that 71,000 persons, both whites and Negroes, had contributed to the campaign, which began in May with a goal of $1,500,000, to establish an academic community chest for Negro education.

The domestic cotton market was quiet last week, with day-to day price changes Which, for the most part were generally insignificant. At the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net changes for the week of an advance of 10 points to a decline of 16 points.

The second week of the Metropolitan Opera season will open next Monday night with a performance of Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde," with Erich Leinsdorf conducting here for the first time since he received an honorable discharge from the Army, and with Lauritz Melchior singing his 200th performance of the role of Tristan.

A syndicate of investors bought from the Chesebrough estate the seven four-story buildings at 664 to 678 Fulton Street, between South Elliott Place and South Portland Avenue, in Brooklyn. The property, measuring 178 by 128 feet, is assessed at $81,000 and was the last of the estate's holdings on Fulton Street.

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 26 -- For the fifth time in three weeks Pacific aircraft carriers attacked Luzon Island in the Philippines on Friday in major force, battering Japanese shipping and airfields in one of the heaviest blows of the month.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- By a shift in the British High Command in the Mediterranean announced tonight, Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark, who has commanded the United States Fifth Army since it moved from Africa to Europe, becomes Commander in Chief of the Allied Fifteenth Army Group of American and Allied forces in Italy.

OTTAWA, Nov. 26 -- Threatened with the secession from his majority of forty or more Liberal members from Quebec Province, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King is expected to tell Parliament and the country tomorrow the whole truth about the manpower muddle that has forced him to impose overseas conscription to fill the depleted infantry reserve at a time when other branches of Canada's Army and her Navy and Air Force have a surplus of volunteers.

PACIFIC HEADQUARTERS, Twentieth Army Air Force, Hawaii, Nov. 26 -- Lieut. Gen. Millard F. Harmon, deputy commander of the Twentieth Army Air Force, announced tonight that Central Pacific Superfortresses again blasted industrial targets in Tokyo on Monday (Tokyo time).

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 26 (U.P.) -- Slammin' Sammy Snead, the gent who was supposed to fold up under pressure, made good his big comeback attempt today, winning the $16,000 Portland open in his first crack at "big-time" golf since his recent discharge from the Navy.
LONDON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

The Beekman Estate added to its East Side holdings when it purchased from the Dry Dock Savings Institution the apartment house containing six stores and fourteen apartments at 825-27 Lexington Avenue. It now controls a frontage of 100 feet at this point, the parcel just sold by the bank having been held at $125,000.

AT AMERICAN SEVENTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS in France, Nov. 26 -- The battle of the Vosges was considered won today after the American Third Infantry Division broke through a breach in the valley of Vosges to link up with the Franco-American forces already in the Alsace plain and the Germans abandoned their counterattack north of the Saverne Gap.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Corn is attracting much more attention from speculators and cash interests than recently, and buying by cash grain concerns featured trading last week. Imposition of the permit system for regulating the movement of the cash article to eight leading terminal markets has slowed up shipments from the country considerably, and the congestion on tracks at elevators has been relieved to such an extent that permits are now being issued freely.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -There were indications today that James F. Byrnes had strong congressional support as a possible successor of Secretary Hull. Senator Harry S. Truman, Vice Presidentelect, was reported to be backing Vice President Wallace.

Dress buying was to the forefront last week, according to reports prepared exclusively for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. The chesterfield coat continued to hold a predominant position in the reorders being placed.
Mgr. William A. Scully, preaching yesterday in St. Patricks Cathedral, urged the congregation to "make ready each day through prayer and sacrifice" for the Day of Judgment.
ROME, Nov. 26--The long-expected governmental crisis broke today when Premier Ivanoe Bonomi presented his own and his Ministers' resignations to Crown Prince Humbert.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Liquidation developed in December rye last week on the Board of Trade and prices averaged lower, closing trades showing 3/4 cent lower to 1 1/8 cents a bushel higher for the week, with December at $1.08 to $1.08 1/8; May, $1,07 1/8 to $1.07 1/4; July, $1.05 to $1.05 1/8, and September, $1.04.

AACHEN, Germany, Nov. 26 -- American military police direct traffic on German roads, stand on guard under the crucifix so often found in the main platz of Rhenish villages and act as a "verboten" sign to shoo meek pedestrians off thoroughfares cleared for military convoys through the monstrous graveyard of Aachen.

The public, physicians and hospital administrators must cooperate in the recruiting drive for 10,000 Army nurses by substituting more non-professional care on the home front, Mrs. Elmira B. Wickenden, executive secretary of the National Nursing Council for War Service, 1780 Broadway, declares in a letter to be sent today to all State and local nursing councils.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 26 -- Lindesay Parrott, a war correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was wounded when fragments from a Japanese bomb struck him during an enemy night raid on Leyte Friday.
MELBOURNE, Monday, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Further socialization moves will follow the Australian Labor Government's nationalization of airways.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Interest in peace and the stake in world prosperity call for a definite, constructive policy by the United States toward the Jewish national home in Palestine, according to a study issued today by the American Council on Public Affairs.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Presenting the Army's viewpoint on the necessity of preparing for war during peace, Assistant Secretary of War John J. McCloy said here today that the security of the country for the next fifty years would demand universal military training and would call for industry and labor to be ever alert and ready for an emergency.

The 1945 edition of "Your Income Tax," by J. K. Lasser, has been published by Simon Schuster. The new edition has gone through two printings, totaling 400,000 copies. The first annual edition of this paper-bound guide to income tax computation appeared in 1937.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (U.P.) -- Income-tax time is rolling around again and 15,000,000 persons can beat the March 15 deadline by two months -- if they have the necessary cash.

ON SAIPAN, in the Marianas, Nov. 26 -- In further response to the need of our fighting men for morale-building reaction and home contacts in the forward reaches of the Pacific, the American Red Cross has just completed plans for expanding its programs on the islands of Saipan, Tinian and Guam.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Once again the currency circulation of the Bank of England is attracting considerable attention. Last week's increase of u3,100,000 was more than u2,000,000 less than it was in the corresponding week of last year, but the total, at a new high record of u1,180,500,000, is u161,500,000 above the figure for the corresponding date of last year, with big year-end demands for currency still to be faced.
Have you heard the story about Mayor La Guardia and the traveling salesman?

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Movement of hogs has not come up to trade expectations and with a good demand stocks of lard at leading markets are estimated to show little change during the current month. A few cars of lard have been sold by packers to the domestic trade, but the offerings are said to be so small that the Government has been forced to limit its orders for lend-lease purposes.

" Star Time" will wind up its stay at the Majestic on Dec. 9. On that night Paul Small's variety bill, which includes Lou Holtz, Connee Boswell and Benny Fields, will chalk up its 120th performance, having opened Sept. 12. The show is slated to go on the road, opening late next month in Boston.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Monday, Nov. 27 -- Enemy resistance in the Ormoc corridor appears to be lessening somewhat. Enemy attempts to reinforce and supply troops there have been broken up by our fighters. Our artillery, ground troops and aircraft are steadily pounding the Japanese corridor positions.

A campaign to educate civilians -- taxi drivers, elevator men, sales-people and families -- in proper attitudes toward wounded and disabled veterans was opened yesterday by the American Theatre Wing. After weeks of special training for a corps of fifty actor-speakers, the first meeting in the campaign was held at the Stage Door Canteen, 224 West Forty-fourth Street, to indoctrinate canteen hostesses and workers in the best way to help veterans rehabilitate themselves.
ROME, Nov. 26 (AP) -- A communique:

WITH THE BRITISH SECOND ARMY, in the Netherlands, Nov. 26 -- A new role has been added to the many played by dogs in wartime: They are working for the British Second Army as mine detectors. Dogs have served as sentries, dispatch runners, bearers of medicines and bandages to wounded men and even as front-line fighters.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Efforts to form a new Polish Cabinet made no headway today and the impression grew that the opponents of a conciliatory policy toward Russia who wrecked the former Cabinet of Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk had given a serious setback to hopes for an agreement with Moscow.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26--A recommendation that training courses be formed in colleges in the principal financial centers to train 5,000 to 6,000 securities salesmen and dealers for openings that are expected to develop after the war, will be presented here tomorrow to the annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America by Julien H. Collins, chairman of the organization's education committee and a partner of Harris, Hall Co., Inc., of Chicago.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Russian orders for machine tools for shipment under the lend-lease program were viewed today by spokesmen for the industry as helpful to both the war efforts now and the recon-version job in the future.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Premier Hubert Pierlot tonight called an emergency meeting of his Cabinet for tomorrow to consider the crisis arising from a bloody clash between anti-Government demonstrators and state police in front of the Chamber of Deputies yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 26 -- Establishment of an "effective" international agency by the United Nations to solve the refugee problem was urged here today at the opening session of the five-day war emergency conference of the World Jewish Congress.
This is the saga of Detective James Costello -- an inquisitive gentleman, naturally enough, and a strict custodian of the law -- and his encounter with four dummies early yesterday on Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Secretary Cordell Hull, because of illhealth, has informed President Roosevelt that he will not be able to return to his desk in the Department of State and the President is giving attention to the selection of a successor, it was learned today.

Not long ago the Army put up for sale at Albany a group of reconditioned trainer planes. It occurred to Robert Schwartz, 38-year-old Brooklyn aviation mechanics teacher, that it would be a good idea to get one for himself. Today he isn't so sure, and that goes for the Police Department, the Fire Department and doctors at Harlem Hospital, where Mr. Schwartz is now.
A BELGIAN TOWN, Nov. 26 -"Do you think we should leave here for the country?" the Belgian mother asked. "Because I am very afraid of flying bombs for the children."
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -The weight of President Roosevelt's re-election is being felt in Congress, and the first tangible result may be an increase in social security payroll taxes on Jan. 1.

The national executive board of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations was honored last night by officers, spiritual leaders and members of the thirty-three Reform congregations in this area at a dinner in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The sponsor was the New York Federation of Reform Synagogues.

The Greek-American Committee for National Unity, in a resolution adopted here yesterday, praised President Roosevelt for his aid to Greece but strongly criticized a section of the Greek and American press, including THE NEW YORK TIMES, for news dispatches on the Greek Liberation Front, the EAM.

ROME, Nov. 26 (U.P.) -- American infantry of the Fifth Army in a sudden three-mile advance across the rough Italian battlefield west of the Pistoia-Bologna road, has occupied Mount Belvedere, dominant hill feature twenty-eight miles southwest of Bologna, and held it against German counter-attack, it was announced today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- With Don Hutson scoring seventeen points, Green Bay's Packers closed their regular National Football League season with a 35-20 triumph over the hapless Chicago-Pittsburgh team on a soggy gridiron at Comiskey Park today.

If any evidence of Yehudi Menuhin's command of his public were needed, it was certainly provided by his recital last night in Carnegie Hall. Not only had he an audience that packed the place to the rafters, including some hundreds of men and women of the armed forces seated upon the stage, but Mr. Menuhin had asked this audience to listen to a program which was anything but a matter of light entertainment.

Bills to encourage the speedy modernization of thousands of old law tenement buildings in substandard areas of the city, thereby providing low-cost housing for families forced from homes demolished to make room for large public and private housing projects, will be introduced in the Legislature and the City Council early in 1945, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 26 -Championship competition featured the closing sessions of the annual two-day indoor horse show of the Boulder Brook Club today in the riding hall on Old Mamaroneck Road. The exhibition was given for the emergency fund of the Third Battalion, Fifty-sixth Regiment, New York Guard.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Ohio State's high-geered civilian team won four positions to dominate the 1944 All-Western Conference eleven selected today for The Associated Press by Conference football coaches and their aides. Ohio State's brilliant back, Leslie Horvath, was the only unanimous choice.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Japanese troops driving westward along the Kwangsi-Kweichow railroad in south central China are close to the Kweichow border, indirect reports indicated today, and simultaneously the enemy is believed moving southward toward the Indo-China border.

Martial Singher, French baritone of the Metropolitan Opera Association, gave his second New York recital last night in Town Hall, where he attracted a large and warmly responsive gathering. With Paul Ulanowsky providing excellent support at the piano, Mr. Singher presented a diversified and interesting list of offerings devoted to songs and arias of Gallic origin, ranging in date of composition from the seventeenth century to the present day.

Retail food merchants who habitually violate price ceilings soon will share with bawdy hotels and raided gambling rooms the stigma of having law-enforcement officers stationed full time on the premises.

The Schenley Distillers Corporation reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31, last, a consolidated net profit of $15,317,203 after charges, taxes and a special contingency reserve of $3,000,000. After deducting the dividend paid on the 5 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock, the balance of the net income was equivalent to $7.66 each on 1,890,000 common shares.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The House Military Affairs committeemen who are touring European battlefronts intend to investigate the shell as well as the cigarette shortage, Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey, and Matthew J. Merritt, Democrat, New York, acting as spokesmen for the group, declared at a press conference today.

Total war bond sales to individuals in New York State amounted to $92,600,000 through the close of business last Friday, compared with $84,000,000 at the end of the comparable day in the Fifth War Loan last June, according to an analysis released yesterday by Frederick W. Gehle, State chairman of the War Finance Committee for New York.
MONTREAL, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Montreal went into first place in the National Hockey League tonight by heating the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4 to 1.

Of the large number of men being discharged from the armed forces each month only a relatively few in the advertising field are returning immediately to their peacetime employers, it was said yesterday by placement officials. A strong tendency exists among these men, it was asserted, to seek advertising jobs offering higher pay, and many are obtaining them with little effort.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Fighter planes of the United States Eighth Air Force had their third biggest day of the war today when they shot down 110 German interceptors while escorting more than 1,100 heavy bombers on missions against oil and rail

It is not enough for a physician to tell Johnny's mother that Johnny should have a "good, well-balanced diet" or "lots of milk, meat, eggs, vegetables and fruits," says Dr. Julian D. Boyd of the University of Iowa's Department of Pediatrics.

The dollar value of production by the electronic industry on a wholesale basis, may reach and even exceed $1,000,000,000 annually after the war, or more than three times the pre-war figure, according to a study released yesterday by George S. Armstrong Co., industrial engineers and management consultants.

Urban expansion in the New York metropolitan area, halted by the war, will return with the end of hostilities, it was predicted by the Regional Plan Association in a bulletin released yesterday covering a recently completed survey of 5,500 square miles, with a population of 12,500,000.

The concert given by the New Friends of Music late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall featured the Budapest Quartet, which made its first appearance of the season in the series. Nan Merriman, mezzo-soprano, and Felix Wolfes, piano, were the assisting artists.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The University of Tennessee will play the University of Southern California in the Rose Bowl at Pasadena on Jan. 1, Arnold Eddy, chairman of the Rose Bowl committee of the Pacific Coast Conference, announced today.

WITH AMERICAN THIRD ARMY, in France, Nov. 26 -- Splitting the Maginot Line wide open with the seizure of ten of its forts, elements of the Eightieth Infantry Division continued right through the breaks today and tonight they were on three sides of St. Avold, a communications center.

The establishment of three branches of the Ambijan Committee in Canada, Mexico and Cuba to promote the organization's welfare programs for victims of Nazism was announced yesterday by Edward I. Aronow, secretary-treasurer, at a luncheon honoring twenty-two delegates from the three countries at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The Board of Trade index of commodity prices in October, based on 1930 as 100, was 166.7, compared with 167.1 in September and 162.5 in October, 1943. This is the second month in succession that prices have fallen 0.2 per cent.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 26 -Margaret O'Brien is to be starred by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in a remake of the old Austin Strong stage comedy, "Three Wise Fools," which was filmed in 1923 by Samuel Goldwyn. In the revamped version being written by John Mc Dermott the three oldsters who adopt the orphan will be played by Lionel Barrymore, Lewis Stone and Frank Morgan.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Nov 18 to 24 are given in the appended tabulation:

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 26 -This dry season's battle for Burma, now centered on the struggle for north Burma and the land routes into China, is now well under way. In this battle the Allied forces find themselves in a more advantageous position than ever before.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Ohio State's hope of competing in the Rose Bowl game at Pasadena, New Year's day was denied today when the board of faculty representatives of the Western Conference voted against waiving the circuit's rule prohibiting post-season games.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Prime Minister Pieter S. Gerbrandy of Holland, together with four of his Ministers, has returned to the Netherlands for the first time since 1940. In a broadcast to his people tonight, he told them that the Netherlands Government would not be transferred from London immediately, inasmuch as Holland still was a military zone.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Christmas tree supplies this season will be adequate to meet needs in the United States, according to the Office of War Information.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 26 (AP) -Frankie Sinkwich hurled three touchdown passes as the Detroit Lions surged from behind for two markers in the final period and defeated the Cleveland Rams, 26 to 14, today.
Folks from this community who receive one of those heartsearing telegrams of regret from the War and Navy Departments don't cry in the streets.

Among the art events scheduled to open today are an exhibition of recent oils and water-colors by John Marin, at An American Place; originals of illustrations by Angna Enters for her book, "Silly Girl," at the Newhouse Gallery; recent paintings by Robert T. Francis, at the Ferargil, and paintings and drawings by Fuller Potter Jr. at the Schacht Gallery.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Nov. 26 -- Infantrymen of Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's American Third Army, nearing the Saar Basin on a crescent-shaped front west and south of this important mining and industrial area, hammered out gains up to five miles today in what is currently the most promising sector of the Western Front.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, ON LEYTE, Nov. 26 -- Seventeen Wacs, who arrived today as the first contingent of their organization, behaved like veterans when an air raid occurred while they were being interviewed. All dived into their air raid shelter to remain while two Japanese planes were shot down.

Russell J. Fornwalt, vocational counselor for Greater New York's Big Brother Movement, a welfare organization that rehabilitated 20,000 delinquent boys, declared yesterday that youngsters without vocational objectives were more likely to become delinquent than those having definite occupational aims.

Dr. Chaim Weizmann, president of the World Zionist Organization and of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, is being hailed today on his seventieth birthday both as a scientist whose formulas materially aided the Allies in two world wars and as the leader of the world's Jews in setting up a homeland in Palestine.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- The men who have been operating airlines in the United States, and who are proposing to operate them throughout the world, described the British position in regard to the "fifth freedom" and other proposed regulative restrictions on future air traffic as "unrealistic and legalistic," here tonight.

Since Oct. 12, Mrs. Gladys Doherty of 272 Sixty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, the wife of a soldier, who is rather new at the landlord's trade, has been waiting to collect the first rent from the three-story, one-family house she bought last August at 508 Dean Street, between Sixth and Carlton Avenues, Brooklyn.

The establishment of a world order, by which peace may be maintained, is a primary interest to the Christian church, declared the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell in his sermon yesterday in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 26 -For the second time in succession. Ed Raymond, commodore of the deep-sea storm trysail club, led in the dinghy racing today at the Larchmont Yacht Club. Sailing the Zotom, he scored 94 points. In second place was Corny Shields with his boat Dainty, who made 87 points, one more than Shorty Trimingham in the Stinger.

THE football season is over for the little fellows. Only the big boys remain. Army and Navy, two teams in a class by themselves, will battle for the national championship at Baltimore on Saturday in a mighty contest which dwarfs anything which has transpired to date. Like the proverbial snowball catapulting down a mountainside, this fray has been gathering momentum and has been increasing in size as it thunders along to its rousing climax.

Almost every week I read that the waste paper collection is below what should normally be expected, and it always bothers me because salvaging paper, like donating blood, is such a simple and painless way of doing a patriotic duty.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks, without a victory since their second game of the National League hockey season, scored in the last two minutes of play tonight to break a 5-5 deadlock and defeat the Detroit Red Wings 6 -- 5.

Slowly, bitterly but surely, the most fateful battle of all history crawls toward the Rhine. The enemy, fighting for every inch of his Fatherland, resists furiously. He throws in counter-attack on desperate counter-attack from his precious panzer reserves. Here and there he recovers a few yards, only to lose them again in the steadily mounting pressure of the relentless Allied advance.

B-29 HEADQUARTERS ON SAIPAN, the Marianas, Nov. 26 -- One of the crews of the two B-29 Superfortresses lost in the Friday raid on Tokyo was safe today, none the worse for the nearly twenty hours the men had spent on rafts before they were picked up by a destroyer about 150 miles north of Saipan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -Stocks of crude rubber, vital to the production of much-needed heavy truck, bus and airplane tires, are at present so low throughout the Allied countries, that only increased production and utmost saving in the use of natural rubber can maintain "a delicate balance" between supply and demand in 1945, the Combined Raw Materials Board stated today.
Your correspondent John MacCormac's dispatch from London on Nov. 19, published in yesterday's NEW YORK TIMES, seems to call for some comment.

At the outbreak of war the fight against tuberculosis was making such progress that the more optimistic health officers were confident that in another generation the statistics would proclaim something that could be called a conquest. That optimism is chilled by the events which have occurred since Hitler occupied one country after another and disrupted life in the western world.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 26 -- With rumors circulating that spot firms were heavily short on cotton in the December contract and further drying up of spot offerings in the interior, cotton futures stiffened after a modest sell-off in the first part of the holiday week.
The strategic bombing of Japan started last week as Superfortresses from our bases in the southern Marianas Islands attacked objectives near Tokyo.

Another war-time football season has run its labored course for most of the college teams. The prize game of the year, one that compels attention as have few others in the history of American sport, remains to be played Saturday but, before committing ourselves to the maelstrom of debate on the merits of the colossal cadets and the stupendous midshipmen, it is in order to pause for a few animadversions in retrospect.

A FIFTEENTH AIR FORCE FLYING FORTRESS BASE, in Italy, Nov. 21 (Delayed) -- We have just landed in a B-17 called Stardust after a dry run, or theoretical bombing, of an important oil refinery near here. The thick blanket of white cloud beneath us was as impervious to the plane's regular bombsight as to our own eyes.
Syndicates and investors were active along the West Side in deals announced over the week-end.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Lord Swinton, Minister of Civil Aviation and chairman of the British delegation to the International Civil Aviation Conference, told a press conference today that if the "fifth freedom" of the air is granted to all countries as a general right, as the Americans insist, the international air organization to carry it out must be "effective" in the interests of fair play for all.
YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- A barber in no mood for conversation and particularly averse to discussing the weather wound up in City Court today for giving a fireman a harrowing shave.

Forty years ago we were told that the body is nothing but a living boiler plant and engine which had to be stoked with fuel in the form of food that contained enough energy. So we became enamored of calories. When the deficiency diseases were interpreted by the nutrition experts, we learned that though tables might groan with calories, we could starve to death.

Having reached in mid-October the highest since July and then declined steadily to the middle of November, stock market average advanced early last week with some rapidity. Only in week-end trading did the pace of recovery slacken and prices grew irregular.
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted in English by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
The board of directors of the General Candy Corporation has declared a year-end dividend of 60 cents on the common stock, or $1.35 for the entire year.

BOSTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Wiry Jim Cahill, who learned his first inter-collegiate football lessons last season while starring for Boston College's informals, returned to Fenway Park today to pace the Holy Cross Crusaders to a 30-14 triumph in the forty-first clash of those traditional Jesuit rivals.

BOSTON, Nov. 26 -- The Boston Bruins scored the first three goals and the New York Rangers the last three, but in between times the local National Hockey League representatives managed to whack in enough pucks to gain an 8-4 victory tonight before a 10,000 crowd at the Boston Garden.

BOSTON, Nov. 26 -- Orders received by Massachusetts factories during October show an indicated decline of 2.3 per cent compared with the previous month, and about 7.5 per cent less than a year ago, according to a study released today by the Associated Industries of Massachusetts.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 26 -- The general distribution of steel products has been going through a change in recent weeks, with indications that further differences in scheduled output will occur in the first quarter of 1945.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Transcontinental messages and special Army sleuthing have "unwound the sad and complex dislocations" in the life of Pfc. Charles J. Depew, officials of the Army Ground and Service Forces Redistribution Station here announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- A much greater than seasonal decline in the production of lumber took place in September, the War Production Board reported today. Output in the month was 2,731,863,000 board feet, a decline of 14.9 per cent from August, as compared with the normal seasonal decline of 5 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet Communique 190:

A recent statement by Arthur S. Flemming, United States Civil Service Commissioner, has highlighted an important measure which the Congress will consider. Mr. Flemming deplored the growing turnover among Federal civil service employes as an obstacle to the war program and urged remedial action.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Monday, Nov. 27 (AP) -communique:
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Nov. 26 (AP) -- A supplementary communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -The Redskins kept their title-winning chances alive in the Eastern division of the National Football League today by defeating Boston's Yanks, 14 to 7. A crowd of 35,450 witnessed the game.
Three films are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

The old soot-covered kettles are still in use on many farms. They are not so common today as a generation ago, when almost every farm had its kettle for boiling the small potatoes for the pigs. Or perhaps the farmer had a favorite formula for combining cooked corn meal, turnips and carrots for those last few weeks before butchering time.

LONDON, Monday, Nov. 27 (U.P.) -- Russian troops, breaking through enemy mountain defenses on a sixty-mile front in Czechoslovakia, yesterday captured the important communications centers of Michalovce and Humenne and drove into within twenty-eight and twenty-nine miles of the strategic cities of Presov and Koslce.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The stock markets here, although generally firm, again have drifted into an idle condition. Though all is going well on the Western Front, it is hard and slow going and public and professional investors consider this the time to adopt a waiting attitude.

The twenty-second annual massing and blessing of the colors of forty-five patriotic societies took place yesterday afternoon before the high altar of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine after a procession of members, clergy and choristers.
