SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Communique 232:

Last week was the sixth consecutive week that the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose. The price changes that occurred last week caused the index to rise 0.1 per cent to the new all-time high of 114.02.
The Giants have changed a word in the song: "Thanks to the Yanks," substituting the name Bears for Yanks.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- An example of legitimate American propaganda stood out conspicuously in the Paris press today when seven of thirteen morning newspapers published articles based on visits by reporters to prisoner-of-war camps made at the invitation of American Army authorities.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 26 -- Any blueprint for the future of what is left of the Jewish people should include an immigration rate into Palestine of 100,000 persons a year and their rehabilitation in this land must be undertaken by the United Nations as a measure of historic justice, declared Dr. Chaim Weizmann, president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine and the World Zionist Organization, in an interview today on the eve of his seventieth birthday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- They who go in for such things cast the Chicago Bears in the role of underdogs against the Philadelphia Eagles today, ignoring the fact that the Bears never had dropped a decision to the Eagles. They were wrong.
LONDON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

WITH AMERICAN FIRST ARMY in Germany, Nov. 27 -- The past twenty-four hours have gone well. Our troops have pushed the enemy back still farther at a half dozen points guarding the entrances to the Cologne plain and the roads to the Rhine.

Spencer Kellogg Sons, Inc., reported yesterday in the annual statement covering the fiscal year ended on Sept. 2, a net profit of $2,160,824, equivalent to $3.54 a share on 611,055 common shares. In the preceding fiscal year the company cleared $1,493,562, or $2.93 a share, on 509,213 common shares.

KUNMING, China, Nov. 19 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Nanning fighter base, seventh airfield to be lost by the United States Fourteenth Air Force as a result of the defeat of China's southeastern armies, was evacuated and blown up today. [Wrecking of the Nanning base was announced Monday.]

CHUNGKING, China, Tuesday, Nov. 28 (AP) -- All American and British nationals in Kweichow Province and the unoccupied portions of Hunan Province were ordered to leave as two Japanese forces surged today toward Kweiyang, capital of Kweichow.

A distinguished audience filled the Metropolitan Opera House last night for the premiere of the new season. Here was reflected, through the presence of leaders in society and other men and women prominent in diplomatic, military, civic and artistic circles, the heritage of the Metropolitan as the world's preeminent lyric theatre and the general glamour of New York's traditionally brilliant "first night."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- An angry protest by Senator Gurney, South Dakota Republican, against committee delay on promotions for Army officers serving at home delayed confirmation today for sixty-one generals overseas.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 27 -- The resignation of Elton E. Wieman as head football coach of Princeton University and the appointment to that post of Charles W. Caldwell Jr. was announced tonight by Dean Christian Gauss, chairman of the University Council on Athletics. Caldwell, a Princeton alumnus of the class of '25, was coach at Williams College for fifteen seasons.
LONDON, Nov. 27 -- An editorial warning to "trustee governments," European resistance forces and the Allies' military authorities will be published in The Times of London tomorrow.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Communique 233:
Army will defeat Navy in the football game of the season at Baltimore Saturday.

An epidemic of safe-cracking erupted in Manhattan and the Bronx over the week-end with more than $13,000 in cash, war stamps, postage stamps and a $100 War Bond taken from seven safes in the two boroughs, it was reported yesterday to the police.

If the Allied drive in Italy has shown signs of stalling, Gen. Mark Clark is the man to get it started again. A shift in the Mediterranean command puts him at the head of our Fifteenth Army Group, which includes the entire Allied force on the peninsula. General Eisenhower's faith in the dynamic leadership of his old friend should now be put to full test in the Po Valley.

The Brooklyn Chapter of the American Institute of Architects will celebrate its fiftieth anniversary at a dinner tonight at Michel's Restaurant, 346 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn. Speakers will include Irving V.A. Huie, Commissioner of the Department of Public Works of the City of New York; Thomas G. Grace, State director of the Federal Housing Administration, and Henry J. Davenport, president of the Home Title Guaranty Company and head of the Downtown Brooklyn Association.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 27 -- Delegates to the war emergency conference of the World Jewish Congress debated here today the Jewish problem created by the Nazi policy of extermination of racial minorities. Opinion ranged from a relinquishment of retributive demands by the United Nations to insistence on punitive action.

ST. AVOLD, France, Nov. 27 -- This town, which lies between the Maginot and Siegfried Lines and was the headquarters for a German Army, was captured this morning by elements of the American Eightieth Infantry Division after an advance patrol had discovered that the enemy had fled during the night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 ((AP) -- President Roosevelt, like many another cigarette smoker, is lighting up less often these days.
PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 27 -- Friday's major carrier air attack on shipping and airfields around Luzon was one of the most effective since the opening of the battle for the Philippines.
ROME, Nov. 27 (AP) -- A communique:

JERUSALEM, Nov. 27 -- Whether Palestine Jews are justified in maintaining a self-defense organization with illegal arms, a question that formed the principal issue at the illegal arms trials by a military court in Jerusalem last year, arose again today when two young pioneers, David Salomon and David Epstein, were sentenced to seven years imprisonment each.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Further evidence purporting to show that the Federal Communications Commission had before it and disregarded charges of coercion in connection with the sale four years ago of station WMCA to Edward F. Noble, was presented at today's Special House Committee Investigating the FCC by George Henry Payne, former FCC commissioner.
LONDON, Nov. 27 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Challenging the authority of the National War Labor Board to act in labor disputes involving non-war industries, the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers announced yesterday that it would not comply with a recent WLB directive from Washington.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 27 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

THE Judge is dead. Kenesaw Mountain Landis, the uncompromising martinet who ruled baseball with an iron hand for twenty-four years, is gone, and the sport is very fortunate that it had him to carry it through its most troubled times. He was a symbol of incorruptibility, honesty and integrity, who imparted his own characteristics to the game he loved.

ADVANCED AMERICAN HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Tuesday, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Leyte-based American planes dropped 235 tons of bombs on Japanese airdromes on Cebu and Negros and at Davao on Friday, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's communique said today.

The Canadian Bank of Commerce, Toronto, reports in its condition statement as of Oct. 31, total resources of $1,178,647,423, a new high record, compared with $1,003,183,539 at the end of the preceding fiscal year. Deposits amounted to $1,095,013,865, compared with $913,879,393.

A ray of hope pierced the gloom surrounding the metropolitan area's poultry shortage yesterday after seventy-five dealers in live poultry shut down their shops for want of supplies. The War Food Administration announced late in the day that baby chicks were coming from incubators in a "considerably stepped-up production" and that this should ease the poultry scarcity in eight to ten weeks.
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 27 (AP) -- George S. Stoddard, State Education Commissioner, asserted today racial and religious discrimination was "some kind of a failure in our system of education."

Reporting that individual purchases of war bonds in the Sixth War Loan reached a total of $810,000,000 as of the close of business Saturday, Treasury officials declared in Washington yesterday that the gigantic effort was proceeding close to schedule.

The volume of currency outstanding has reached a new high point of around $24,900,000,000. This has been increasing recently at a monthly rate of close to $600,000,000. The twelve Federal Reserve Banks must legally maintain gold reserves of 40 per cent against Federal Reserve notes in circulation, and must maintain reserves of 35 per cent in gold or lawful reserves against deposits.

Vincent Astor of Rhinebeck, N.Y., is listed as the new owner of two Manhattan properties in transfers recorded yesterday. One of the properties is at 60-66 East End Avenue and 533-35 East Eighty-second Street and the other is at 2309-27 Eighth Avenue and 300 West 125th Street.

Subject to Lee Shubert's nod of approval, "Laffing Room Only!" (Olsen and Johnson's collection of brand new high jinks) will have its premiere on Saturday night, Dec. 23, at the Winter Garden. Mr. Shubert will dispel all doubt on his arrival today from Chicago.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 27 -- The CIO United Steel Workers acted today to obtain concessions granted by the War Labor Board, scheduling a meeting of the wage policy committee here Thursday and Friday and listing the United States Steel Corporation as the first employer to be approached after the committee decides on procedure.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 27 -- Jack Haley has been named for the lead in "Follow Your Heart," a musical to go into production this week at RKO-Radio, featuring Marcy McGuire. Anne Jeffreys and Glenn Vernon also will have principal roles in the film, which will be directed by Anthony Mann.

Tenants, real estate owners, lending institutions and the general public may all take a favorable interest in the proposals outlined by Mayor La Guardia for modernizing some 12,000 old-law tenements in this city. These buildings are expected to be needed by renters displaced by new large-scale housing operations, public and private.

In spite of rainy weather, 400 persons were on hand when the Eastern States Antiques Fair at the Westchester County Center in White Plains opened its doors at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Manager C.J. Nuttall expects this fair to be one of the most successful of the nineteen he has conducted at White Plains, because of the growing use of antiques as household furnishings.

A joint campaign to find suitable accommodations here for young women will be conducted by the Young Women's Christian Association and the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, Mrs. William Harley Glafke, who heads the Y.W.C.A. emergency room registry committee, revealed yesterday.

Changed attitudes toward illegitimacy, generally upset living conditions that minimize social ostracism and the availability of jobs for women are causing more illegitimate children to be kept by their mothers, Henrietta L. Gordon of the Child Welfare League of America told delegates to the annual conference of the New Jersey Welfare Council yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 27 -- Deer have become so numerous in Westchester County that they constitute "a real and substantial menace, hazard and danger to life and property," the Board of Supervisors' special committee on deer reported today after a six-month survey.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Donald M. Nelson said today that his goal was to double China's war production in the next six months.

Capt. Robert F.M. Culver of the Marines, 27-year-old son of Mrs. Milton C. Whitaker of the Hotel Ambassador, was killed in action on June 16 at Saipan by a direct shell hit as he was being evacuated from a foxhole aid station after having been slightly wounded previously in the same action, it was revealed yesterday.

Why $14,000,000,000 more in war bond purchases by Ameri cans this year? We all like "inside facts." Here are a few; We whoop it up whenever we read about an American task force tearing the life out of a Japanese strong point.

The Guaranty Trust Company, in its current issue of The Guaranty Survey, asserts that the problems of peace, rather than the difficulties of demobilization, are the really critical problems that the country's economy will face as it moves into the post-war era.

ROME, Nov. 27 (AP) -- British Eighth Army forces were closing a pincers tonight on the important Po Valley highway junction of Faenza, thirty miles southeast of Bologna, which the Germans were apparently preparing to defend house by house.

Unless there is immediate relief from the shortage of tires needed for replacement on trucks operating in this area, there will be a serious delay in transportation of war materials here, T. D. Pratt, president of the New York State Motor Truck Association, said yesterday.

An estimate of $4,800,000,000 in new construction in the United States next year, an increase of 26 per cent over this year, was made public yesterday at the opening at the Roosevelt Hotel of the three-day semi-annual meeting of the Producers Council, the national organization of manufacturers of building materials and equipment.

Shura Dvorine, 21-year-old Baltimore pianist, made his New York debut last night in a recital at Town Hall before an audience whose enthusiasm at times burst into cheers. He played a "big" program, beginning with a Scarlatti Sonata in E major, which was followed by the Bach-Busoni Organ Prelude and Fugue in E flat major.
ROME, Nov. 27 -- Pope Pius received Lieut. Col. John H. Pollock, Allied Military Government chief of police, today to consult about the grave state of public crime, especially night assaults in Rome.
PARIS, Nov. 27 -- The news of Edward R. Stettinius Jr.'s appointment as Secretary of State reached here too late tonight for substantial comment.

E.R. Brach Sons declared yesterday an extra dividend of 37 1/2 cents a share on the common stock and one regular quarterly dividend of 37 1/2 cents a share, both payable on Dec. 27. With the current dividends, payments this year amount to $1.87 1/2, compared with $1.50 distributed in 1943.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Nov. 27 (AP) -- E. Samaha's James Acre, making his first start since being claimed for $1,600 at Pimlico, scored a smashing eight-length upset victory in today's featured allowance purse on the opening-day program at Charles Town.

Two bombings of Tokyo in strength in four days -- dispatches from Saipan said the force that attacked Sunday was in as great numbers as that which struck the first blow Thursday -- is a good start. In time the interval even will be shortened.
A communique, as broadcast yesterday from Tokyo and recorded and translated by the Federal Communications Commission:

The fourth wartime season of the Metropolitan Opera opened last night with a performance of Gounod's "Faust." Despite a steady downpour of icy rain, the venerable opera house on Thirty-ninth Street attracted the usual glittering throng of celebrities and the socially prominent.

Of more than 3,395,000 voters -- civilians and soldiers combined -- who cast ballots in New York City on election day, 65,548 or slightly less than 2 per cent failed to indicate a choice for President, an official canvass by the Board of Elections showed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Today isn't the first time that Edward Reilly Stettinius Jr. has earned the monicker of White-haired Boy.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- The net working capital of all American corporations, exclusive of banks and insurance companies, reached a new high of $44,300,000,000 as of June 30, 1944, an increase of approximately $1,300,000,000 or about the same rate as in the preceding quarter, the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today in its quarterly analysis.

DIJON, France, Nov. 27 -- An experimental program of mutual education known as the Franco-American Institute is now housed in the University or Dijon and is being closely watched by Army special service officers at Supreme Headquarters American Expeditionary Forces as a possible model for similar undertakings throughout France.

The house that Mrs. Gladys Doherty Bursky, wife of a soldier, owned at 508 Dean Street, Brooklyn, and lost when the city, without notifying her, razed it on Nov. 16 as unsafe, had "no notice of municipal violations" against it when she bought it, the Home Owners Loan Corporation, 2 Park Avenue, said yesterday.
Harold D. Pennington, Thomas McCance and Stephen Y. Hord will become general partners in the private banking firm of Brown Brothers Harriman Co. on Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday.

TWENTY - FIRST BOMBER COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Saipan, Marianas, Nov. 27 -- Bad bombing weather confronted the sizable force of B-29 bombers that hit at industrial Tokyo today for the second time in little more than seventy-two hours, Col. Walter C. Sweeney Jr. of San Francisco, leader of the mission, told correspondents tonight.

The Cities Service Power and Light Company, main utility unit of the Cities Service Company system, has contracted to sell its equity interest in the St. Joseph Railway, Light, Heat and Power Company to the Continental Gas and Electric Corporation, an intermediate holding company in the United Light and Power Company system.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- President Roosevelt announced today the appointment of Maj. Gen. Patrick Jay Hurley to be Ambassador to China.

State chairmen of American Women's Voluntary Services units in twelve States convened yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for the opening of a three-day conference to discuss the post-war AWVS program. Mrs. Alice T. McLean, president and founder of the AWVS, outlined a five-point program for the post-war era, offering training to volunteers in the following fields: veteran rehabilitation, job training and placement, public health, youth program and citizen responsibility.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Two editions of the Treasury Department's Surplus Reporter, one for the hardware and the other for the general products classifications, will be issued from regional offices tomorrow. Other editions, taking in furniture, machinery, automotive, textiles and wearing apparel, medical and surgical, and paper and office supplies, will be issued in pairs in following ten-day periods.

A consent order has been issued by the War Production Board against Literary Classics, Inc., 75 West Street, and Books, Inc., Clinton, Mass., whereby they agree to reduce their paper consumption quotas during 1944 and 1945, it was announced here yesterday by R.A. McGovern, regional manager, compliance division, WPB.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- The signs of encouragement in the economic outlook and a resolution to meet the problems ahead can bring the best period for investment banking in the history of the country, J. Clifford Folger, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, declared here today at its thirty-third annual convention in the Edgewater Beach Hotel.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick's bid for $20,000,000 to acquire forty-five acres of blighted land in downtown Brooklyn for reconversion into super-blocks was shouldered aside at an executive session of the Board of Estimate yesterday, although nearly $1,000,000 was shaved off the city's $198,000,000 capital budget for the coming year.

Reduction of the differentials on converted fabrics sold to cutters and retailers under M-127 as recently revised will cut the volume of rayon piece goods offered to retailers, according to converter's yesterday.

Prices of flue-cured tobacco going into cigarettes as of the end of 1943 were up 101 per cent from 1940, according to an article in the current issue of The Exchange, magazine of the New York Stock Exchange, by Harry M. Wootten, a tobacco authority.

The first conviction for a violation of the "bookkeeping rules" adopted under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 was obtained yesterday in Federal Court when Samuel S. Alexander, formerly of 247 Park Avenue, pleaded guilty to that charge and to mail fraud.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 27 -- Argentine hope for a meeting of American Foreign Minsters on the lines proposed by Foreign Minister Gen. Orlando Peluffo were revived somewhat today by the news that Cordell Hull had been replaced by Eward R. Stettinius Jr. as Secretary of State.

MOSCOW, Nov. 27 -- Well-informed diplomatic observers speculated today whether Mr. Mikolajczyk might follow up his resignation as Premier by returning to the liberated part of Poland, where, it is believed, he would be welcomed.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Westchester County Judge Frederick G. Schmidt ordered today the commitment to Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminally Insane of Mrs. Renee Guy Hatch, 31-year-old Navy wife indicted for first degree murder in the strangulation deaths of her two children.
ROME, Nov. 27 -- The Italian political crisis was far from being settled tonight, and, indeed, the differences had widened to a serious extent.

A 5-point proposal that is now being studied by the Treasury Department to speed up carry-back tax refunds to corporations during the immediate post-war period was described last night by Norman D. Cann, deputy commissioner of Internal Revenue, at a meeting of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accounts in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- President Roosevelt announced with great and deep regret today that Cordell Hull had resigned as Secretary of State because of illness and within three hours he nominated as his successor Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Under-Secretary of State, who is 44 years old.
Holding steady within an 8-point range all day, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 2 to 8 points higher than Saturday's final prices.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Following is the Allied battle team on the western front as it has been disclosed by Supreme Headquarters up to the present time:
ALBANY, Nov. 27 (AP) -- New York State's post-war reconstruction fund stood officially today at $163,060,680.89.
Oct. 16 THE NEW YORK TIMES published an editorial which rightly said: "Statistics plainly indicate that forest conservation is an important national problem."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The War Production Board soon will undergo another reorganization to make "more workable" its handling of cutbacks of war contracts, readjustment of all production as military needs level off, and other activities dealing with the general problem of reconversion.

A definite trend toward product-selling copy in business and industrial advertising since April is revealed in a study of the copy and illustrations used by 181 advertisers in The Wall Street Journal during September compared with the fourth month of this year.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Nov. 27 -- Allied armies pounded the stout German line from the Swiss frontier to the Netherlands today, winning small gains from stubborn opposition on the plains of Cologne and Alsace and making rapid progress in one sector of Lieut. Gen. George S. Patron's American Third Army front.

The National Orchestral Association, under Leon Barzin, gave the first concert of its fifteenth season last night in Carnegie Hall. Joseph Schuster was the soloist in the Dvorak concerto for 'cello in B minor on a program also containing the concerto grosso in B minor, Op. 6, No. 12, of Handel and Beethoven's Eighth symphony.

Plans for the establishment in Palestine of a Weizmann Institute of Science, as a tribute to Dr. Chaim Weizmann, scientist, who is president of the World Zionist Organization and of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, were announced yesterday on his seventieth birthday.
On the editorial page of the Thanksgiving Day issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES a letter appeared under the heading "Intolerance Still Present" and signed "Jerome Alexander."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Twentieth Air Force communique 25:

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Leslie M. O'Connor, the man most widely mentioned as the likely successor to the late Kenesaw Mountain Landis as commissioner of baseball, will decline that office if it is proffered him.
The commencement of strategic bombing from Marianas Islands bases against the Japanese mainland opens a new chapter in the war in the Pacific.

Surveys conducted for the National Physicians Committee for the Extension of Medical Service indicate that 83,000,000 persons, or 63 per cent of the population, believe "that an easier method of meeting the cost of unusual illness or surgery can be provided," while, on the other hand, "only 5 per cent of the people are concerned about the cost of ordinary illness."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The texts of the letters dated Nov. 21 carrying Secretary Hull's tender of resignation and President Roosevelt's reply were made public by the White House late today as follows:

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Headed by football's famous Harold (Red) Grange, the United States Football League today formally entered the professional gridiron ring, announcing plans for an eight-team loop starting in 1945.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Combined Raw Materials Board announced today the allocation of 146,000 cattle hides and other articles of raw leather, principally from South America, to liberated European countries for the last two months of this year and January, 1945.

Two eating places in the nation's capital were named yesterday by a former New York meat dealer as being responsible in part for the difficulty in which he found himself at an Office of Price Administration hearing here, where he was charged with having overdrawn his meat ration account by 446,000 red points.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- President Roosevelt's fourth inaugural address will last about four or five minutes, Senator Byrd said today after conferring with the Chief Executive on arrangements for the White House "back porch" ceremony on Jan. 20.

The stock market broke out of an indefinite drift in the final hour yesterday and, under the leadership of the rails and steels, closed irregularly higher. Trading continued, however, on the conservative side, and the late rally was not impressive enough to definitely mark an upswing.

DETROIT, Nov. 27 (AP) -- A Ford Motor Company spokesman said tonight that a strike of 2,637 employes in the River Rouge Plant had made more than 7,000 workers idle, closed the production and magnesium foundries and hampered production in the new steel foundry and foundry machine shop.

Development of a "national pattern" for post-war employment, including the reintegration of veterans into the industrial and business structure, is a cardinal problem requiring immediate action, but peacetime "jitters" are premature, Brig.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Nov. 27 (AP) -- A supplement to today's communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The two forces of about 200 Super-fortresses that bombed Tokyo and Bangkok, Thailand, today have returned to their bases without loss by enemy action, the Twentieth Air Force announced.

Not daunted and very little dampened, operagoers at the opening of the Metropolitan provided last night a panorama of evening fashions that was colored only slightly by wartime restrictions and taxicab shortages.

ALBANY, Nov. 27 -- Mrs. Elizabeth F. Pinckney, Albany County Commissioner of Jurors, is now engaged in "packing" jury lists for the benefit of the O'Connell political machine here, just as "her job was formerly to pack the crooked baseball pool" which operated in this city, Special Prosecutor George P. Monaghan charged today.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Tuesday, Nov. 28 (AP) -- A communique:
PUFFENDORF, Germany, Nov. 27 -- He is only a Brooklyn former patrolman, but to a battalion of German Tiger tanks on this front he was more trouble than a regiment of very angry Russians.

ROME, Nov. 27 -- Immediately after the end of the war, Pope Pius plans to proclaim a "holy year for the purification of the world" from all the crimes committed during the conflict, reliable Vatican quarters said today.

AT THE SWISS-ALSATIAN FRONTIER, Nov. 27 -- Unidentified formations of American paratroops struck this morning behind the German lines at Immendingen and Oberlauchringen, north of the Rhine River border of Switzerland, against the German feeder railroad line between Lake Constance and Loerrach.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 27 -- A trip to West Point, while always pleasant even on a wet day like today, is unproductive these days, for mum's the word as the cadets enter their final week's preparation for the battle with Navy at Baltimore Saturday.

The Senate is certain to give prompt and cordial approval to the President's nomination of Edward R. Stettinius Jr. as the new Secretary of State. The appointment is happily free of all political implications. It is plainly a reward of merit. Mr. Stettinius has made an excellent record as Under-Secretary.

Literary gossip paragraphs of the not-distant future, if some people have their way, will strike a decidedly fresh note. Speaking of the new Dr. Cronin or Somerset Maugham novel for 1949, scheduled for the Christmas season, the chat columns will report that arrangements have already been made for translations into a dozen languages.
WITH THE AMERICAN NINTH ARMY in Germany, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Americans wounded along the Ninth Army's front may have lost an arm or a leg, but not their spirit or their sense of humor.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 27 -- Rejecting overtures by the British trade union movement seeking to bring about a rapprochement between Russian trade unions and the American Federation of Labor, William Green, AFL president, criticized today the reported plan of the Soviet Union Government for the use of Germans to restore devastated regions in Russia.

Sumner Welles, former Under-Secretary of State, decried last night efforts "now being made to persuade public opinion here" that the United States should adopt a foreign policy aimed at obtaining more satisfactory governments in certain nations "not presently involved in the war."

"Meet Me in St. Louis," a comedy drama with music produced by Metro, will have its local premiere this morning at the Astor. Based on the book by Sally Benson, the picture, which was filmed in Technicolor, features Judy Garland, Margaret O'Brien, Tom Drake, Mary Astor, Harry Davenport, Joan Carroll, Lucille Bremer and June Lockhart. Vincente Minnelli directed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- A House subcommittee today unanimously approved a proposed constitutional amendment to end the Senate's control over treaties. It sent to the House Judiciary Committee a resolution which, if adopted by Congress and approved by three-fourths of the States, would provide that future treaties be ratified by a simple majority vote in both branches of Congress, instead of a vote of two-thirds of the Senate.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- Overwhelming support of the American as against the British proposal on the "fifth freedom" of the air was indicated today at the International Civil Aviation Conference in a debate in which twenty countries, besides the United States, Britain and Canada, took part.

Faint though it may be, the hope exists in the headquarters of the New York Football Giants that Al Blozis, mountainous lineman, will play for the local outfit in the team's game with the Washington Redskins at the Polo Grounds on Sunday. Blozis, now a lieutenant in the Army, is on ten-day leave, and is spending that time working out with his former team-mates whenever he has the chance.

Cronin Leventhal, lessees of the upper floors, have purchased the four-story store and apartment building at 2391 Grand Concourse, just south of Fordham Road, the Bronx, from 2391 Grand Concourse, Inc. The building occupies a plot 100 by 700 feet.
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 27 (AP) -- A heavy kill of deer is reported in the first open season on bucks and does in southern and western counties of New York. The season opened Saturday.

With backlogs ranging between six months and two years, manufacturers of light machine tools stated yesterday they expect that the opening of markets which have been cut off by wartime restrictions and heavy replacement and export needs will keep the tool industry busy "for several years to come."
LONDON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

Boxing fans who flock to the St. Nicholas Arena Friday night are in for a pleasant surprise, if credence can be placed in the word of the veteran manager, James J. Johnston. Fernando (Mighty) Menichelli, South American heavyweight, is to make his Gotham debut on that occasion, in a scheduled ten-round bout against Johnny White, Jersey City heavyweight.

Thirty-seven meat companies, said to be responsible for black market prices on corned beef and tongue in delicatessens throughout the nation, were sued yesterday by the Office of Price Administration for nearly $5,000,000 in treble damages.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 27 -- Outside the rain played tic-tac-toe on the beautiful Severn. It was not merely a wet rain, the type that leaves one with a feeling of exhilaration. Rather, it was the nasty kind of downpour, chilly, uncomfortable and unfriendly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The National Lead Company of New York and other corporations, said to account for approximately 90 per cent of the white lead produced and sold in the United States, were charged today by the Federal Trade Commission with a conspiracy to maintain "monopolistic and non-competitive" prices in connection with the interstate sale of this product.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Refusal of the Senate to accept an amendment today to the $1,000,000,000 Flood Control Bill which would have created a Missouri River Commission in the War Department, as recommended by Army engineers was interpreted in some quarters as indicative of sentiment favorable to the later consideration of a Missouri Valley Authority.
LONDON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

Boxing fans who flock to the St. Nicholas Arena Friday night are in for a pleasant surprise, if credence can be placed in the word of the veteran manager, James J. Johnston. Fernando (Mighty) Menichelli, South American heavyweight, is to make his Gotham debut on that occasion, in a scheduled ten-round bout against Johnny White, Jersey City heavyweight.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 27 -- Brussels faced the prospect of a general strike today as the aftermath of the political upheaval over the week-end.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- At the end of a day of continuous conferences the Polish Socialist party decided tonight that it would attempt to form a Cabinet tomorrow under the leadership of Jan Kwapinski and bring an end to the Polish Government crisis resulting from the resignation of Stanislaw Mikolajczyk as Premier.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 27 -- Outside the rain played tic-tac-toe on the beautiful Severn. It was not merely a wet rain, the type that leaves one with a feeling of exhilaration. Rather, it was the nasty kind of downpour, chilly, uncomfortable and unfriendly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The National Lead Company of New York and other corporations, said to account for approximately 90 per cent of the white lead produced and sold in the United States, were charged today by the Federal Trade Commission with a conspiracy to maintain "monopolistic and non-competitive" prices in connection with the interstate sale of this product.

OTTAWA, Nov. 27 -- Warning that a state of anarchy faced Canada unless her Parliament would give the lead in unity, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King gave notice in a three-hour speech this afternoon that he would remain in office and carry on the Government of the country if he had any majority for the step he has taken in ordering drafted men overseas as reinforcements.

I hear reports that Brooklyn is much offended because Noel Coward in his latest book, "Middle East Diary," says: "* * * but I was less impressed by some of the mournful little Brooklyn boys lying there in tears amidst the alien corn with nothing worse than a bullet wound in the leg or a fractured arm."

BALTIMORE, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Doug Dodson of Elk River, Idaho, who piled up an early lead at Pimlico's fall race meeting, topped the list of jockeys for the twenty-two day affair with twenty winners, despite the fact that he broke a collarbone four days before the meet ended.

LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Russian troops in a new six-mile penetration of northern Slovakia yesterday crossed the 2,700-foot Carpathian Mountains along the Polish frontier as other units in the south struck to within eleven miles of the big north Hungarian rail center of Satoraljaujhely, a Moscow communique announced last night.

"Faust," performed last night by the Metropolitan Opera Association for the opening of its 1944-45 season, is essentially an opera of great charm and romantic illusion. This holds true today, given effective interpretation long after its novelty has worn entirely off, and decades after the soldiers' chorus in Act IV seemed to Gounod's earlier audiences one of the most dramatic, fiery and brilliant episodes in operatic music.

The sugar shortage, that has been intensified this fall, is becoming a matter of some annoyance to housewives, to judge from inquiries received by this department. Indications are that supplies may remain tight, and that even though they are eased, they will still be smaller in 1945 than they were the first part of this year.

A telegram urging President Roosevelt to withhold his support "from any final settlement of the Palestine problem which does not accord full justice to the natives of the land," was made public here yesterday by Faris S. Malouf, Boston attorney, who acted as chairman of a two-day conference of Americans of Arabic-speaking origin in the Hotel McAlpin, which ended Sunday night.
LONDON, Nov. 27 -- The stock markets started the week on a quiet note, buyers being restrained by a desire to await more definite developments on the Western Front.

WITH AMERICAN NINTH ARMY, in Germany, Nov. 27 -- Doughboys of two combat-hardened infantry divisions of Lieut. Gen. William H. Simpson's American Ninth Army battled from house to house with stubbornly resisting German troops today in the towns of Koslar, Kirchberg and Altdorf, the last populated places of any importance west of the Roer River on this front.

Things were indeed "blue" at the weekly meeting of the Football Writers Association yesterday. The cerulean tinge permeated every corner of Toots Shor's caravansary but, strangely enough, nobody was sad. On the contrary, merriment abounded, and the 100 or so persons in attendance seemed to enjoy every minute of the two hours the session took up.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Louis B. Taylor, Haverford, Pa., treasurer of Investment Registry of America, Inc., Philadelphia, said today during a hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission that he was not familiar with the company's bylaws nor certain of his duties as treasurer.

A revised and enlarged edition of Charles J. Rolo's "Wingate's Raiders," bringing the story down to the Burma campaign of 1944, will be published Friday by Viking. It will include a foreword by Field Marshal Viscount Wavell.

The distributive and service trades, rather than production, are expected to provide much of the additional employment required during the post-war period, with retailing ranking high on the list of occupations preferred by returning service men, Dr. John W. Wingate, Professor of Merchandising at the School of Retailing of New York University, said yesterday at the luncheon meeting of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Sheraton.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 27 -- Charley Caldwell has resigned as head coach of football and baseball at Williams College to accept a similar position at Princeton, it was announced today.

SOMEWHERE IN THE NETHERLANDS, Nov. 27 -- Five members of the Netherland Cabinet, headed by Premier Pieter S. Gerbrandy, who arrived here on Saturday from London for an inspection trip of the liberated area and who expect to return to London soon, plunged today into the task of gathering first-hand information on which to build plans for their country's reconstruction.

LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 28 (UP) -- More than ninety persons were killed, scores were wounded, sixty were trapped underground and many were missing today after an explosion yesterday at Burton-on- Trent that obliterated a Royal Air Force munitions depot, rained bombs over the surrounding countryside and rocked houses sixty miles away.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 14 per cent last week over the like week of 1943, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the previous week the bank had reported a gain of 10 per cent.

The city of Houston, Tex., Independent School District will be in the market on Dec. 15 with an issue of $7,500,000 of school bonds, for which bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 2 1/2 per cent. The bonds, dated Feb. 1, 1945, will mature serially from Feb. 1 on each from 1946 to 1975.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Administration disclosed today it will present to the new Congress a proposal for vastly expanded social security coverage.

It will take most Americans a long time to get used to thinking of Cordell Hull as not being Secretary of State or of the Secretary of State as being other than Cordell Hull. Mr. Hull has held longer than any other man in our history the office from which he has just resigned. He has held it with a distinction that ranks him among the first half dozen of our great State Secretaries.

ABOARD A CARRIER OFF THE PHILIPPINES, Nov. 25 (Delayed) -- In another lightning carrier blow today Admiral William F. Halsey's Third Task Fleet continued blasting the roadway through which the Japanese must bring men and supplies against Gen. Douglas MacArthur.

SAIPAN, Marianas Islands, Nov. 27 (AP) (Delayed) -- In an obvious attempt to retaliate for the first B-29 attack on Tokyo Friday, Japanese fighters twice bombed and strafed the Saipan Superfortress base today [Monday, west longitude time] at a cost of at least thirteen Japanese.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- A complete reversal of the American attitude on imports will be necessary if this country is to make the most of post-war trade opportunities and to fulfill its obligations as the world's principal creditor nation, the National Planning Association declared today.

Rayonier, Inc., manufacturer of dissolving pulps, reported yesterday for the six months ended with October a consolidated net profit of $900,277, equal to 28 cents a common share, after all charges. In the corresponding period of last year, the net profit was $891,803, also equal to 28 cents a share.
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Although the stock markets were firm in tone today business in most sections was quiet.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 28 -- Tanks and infantry of Gen. George S. Patton Jr.'s Third American Army are closing in on the Saar Basin on a twenty-six-mile front east of the rich coal-mining area after a spectacular advance by the Ninety-fifth Infantry Division which covered six and a half to seven miles in the last twenty-four hours and sent doughboys across the German frontier in two places.

A crisis in fuel oil transport, brought on during the last few weeks by military events, will be reflected in a tight supply situation on the East Coast during December, John G. Neukom, director of the fuel and automotive rationing division of the Office of yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 29 (Reuter) -- In paying tribute to Cordell Hull, "this testy son of the Tennessee mountains" who "lays down his burden within sight of the promised land," The Times, in an editorial today, reviewed Mr. Hull's foremost political successes.

Representatives of the securities industry and of Federal and State regulatory bodies met yesterday in the regional offices of the Securities and Exchange Commission, 120 Broadway, to outline plans for the protection of the investor. It was the first gathering of the committee appointed in Philadelphia on Oct. 3 to erect safeguards around war-time savings of the public and prevent exploitation.

The National Physicians Committee held a conference in this city on Monday to discuss the need of wider and better medical care in the light of a survey conducted on its behalf by the Opinion Research Corporation. That there is a growing and insistent demand for this wider and better medical care the survey showed.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- With one nation after another coming over to the American point of view, the British position on rigid control of international air traffic was supported tonight by so few countries that the possibility of a new British proposal tomorrow involving further concessions, appeared likely.

W.E. Fish, manager of the central office truck department of Chevrolet Motor division of General Motors Corporation, has been appointed assistant general sales manager in charge of all the division's truck and commercial vehicle activities.

A veteran of every major carrier task force attack in the Pacific since the invasion of the Marshall Islands, Lieut. (jg) Cornelius N. Nooy, 23 years old, of Smithtown, L.I., told yesterday of some of the encounters with Japanese airmen that have won for him the coveted Navy Cross and three other decorations.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 28 (AP) -- The men who make golf a business foresee a tremendous post-war boom in the sport. They are preparing for it, too, not only from the standpoint of sale of equipment, tutoring of new players and construction of courses, but also in a long-range way.

Although their combined efforts failed by a single game to put the Tigers in a tie for the pennant, Hal Newhouser and Paul (Dizzy) Trout, winners of twenty-nine and twenty-seven games, respectively, finished a bang-up one-two for the American League's most-valuable-player award, according to the official announcement made yesterday by the Baseball Writers Association of America.
LONDON, Nov. 28 (Reuter) -- Capt Ludwig Sertorius, German Transocean Agency commentator and German High Command spokesman, tonight reported a big German withdrawal north of Strasbourg.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 28 -- The American Federation of Labor decided in annual convention today to renew its invitation to John L. Lewis and the 600,000 members of the United Mine Workers to return to the federation.

The 12,000 Jews who have escaped to Palestine during the last year from the war-torn countries of Europe were described as being in "appalling condition," disease-ridden from undernourishment and suffering from mental tortures, Dr. Haim Yassky, director of the Hadassah Medical Organization in Jerusalem, revealed yesterday upon his arrival in this country.

RENO, Nov. 28 -- James H.R. Cromwell had ulterior, financial motives in seeking a limited divorce decree in New Jersey from Doris Duke Cromwell, Judge William McKnight of the Second Judicial District Court of Washoe County ruled today in reaffirming the validity of a Reno decree previously awarded the heiress to a fortune made in the tobacco business.

LANGRES, France, Nov. 28 -- Few towns in France attract more sentimental Americans than Langres. It was known to the Romans, who built its noble walls, as Andematunum, and it has a history steeped in blood and glory. But that is not why so many American officers on the central French Front manage to pass through on one pretext or another.

New York State invested $26,000,000 in the Sixth War Loan yesterday. Controller Frank C. Moore announced in Albany that the State had purchased Treasury Savings notes, Series C, to that amount, in accordance with its policy of investing the State's surplus funds in Government obligations.
ROME, Nov. 28 -- The Italian crisis was aggravated today by a flat British veto of Count Carlo Sforza as Foreign Minister.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Roxy, the new attraction will be "Something for the Boys," Twentieth Century-Fox's adaptation of the Broadway musical comedy. Carmen Miranda, Michael O'Shea, Vivian Blaine, Phil Silvers, Sheila Ryan, Perry Como and Glenn Langan are among the featured players in the musical, which was filmed in Technicolor.

Edward R. Stettinius at the age of 44 years plus a few weeks -- one must be exact when we are dealing with this particular subject -- is the second youngest man to hold the office of Secretary of State.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- With the quarrel between Poland and Russia still the most crucial issue of inter-Allied relations, Prime Minister Churchill made a personal inquiry today into the causes of the Polish Government crisis that resulted in resignation of Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Cordell Hull received today from Prime Minister Winston Churchill and Henri Poppenot, representative of the French Provisional Government, messages of tribute to his services as Secretary of State for nearly twelve years, and expressions of hope for his prompt recovery from the illness which caused him to resign.

Improvement of a selective nature appeared again yesterday in the stock market, but restraining influences still were present. Switching operations tended to check many of the losses and gains, while the question of the length of the European conflict remained as the foremost factor in holding volume to its recent levels.
Speaking at a dinner here marking the third anniversary of the founding of Freedom House, Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican, of Minnesota, set forth last night his political and economic philosophy.

A proposal that an international "Department of Population" be created, to be attached to the United Nations in the same manner as the International Labor Organization was attached to the League of Nations, was made yesterday by Dr. Sidonia Furst of 27 West Eighty-sixth Street.

SANTA ANA, Calif., Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Harold O. Miller, fighter pilot of the Eighth Air Force, who hails from Santa Rosa, Calif., may have been the man who fatally wounded Erwin Rommel, Nazi field marshal. The pilot is resting at a convalescent center here.

The woman who "lost" her house at 508 Dean Street, Brooklyn, when city authorities condemned and razed it without her knowledge was hysterical yesterday after learning that she might be evicted from her present home in the Red Hook Houses, 62 Mill Street.

In its inconspicuous way boxing has been doing its part in the interest of the service man. In addition to contributing in whatever small way it can to relieving the tension of combat zones and training camps, the ring sport plans to carry right on with its work and aid the fighting men returned to this country for hospitalization.

There appears to be no possibility that wartime controls over civilian construction, which are keeping the industry virtually stagnant, can be rescinded prior to the ending of the European phase of the war, A.J. McComb, director of the new construction bureau of the War Production Board, told the members of the Producers Council yesterday at the second day's session of their semi-annual conference in the Roosevelt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- A panel of the National War Labor Board has recommended that the board order a wage increase of $5 a week for New York operators of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's long lines department.

If the United States uses the full power of its manufacturing and exporting machinery without the cooperation of Great Britain, the United States will find itself pitted in post-war trade against a sterling bloc which would include western and central Europe, C.B. Morrison, managing director York Shipley, Ltd., London, declared yesterday.
Cotton textile producers were urged yesterday to arrange now for binding agreements on V-E day and V-J day in order to effect fair, fast and equitable settlements on terminations of contracts.
KANDY, Ceylon, Nov. 28 (AP) -- A communique:

BRUSSELS, Nov. 28 -- Parades, mass meetings and demonstrations have been banned and strikes by public service employes have been prohibited, Premier Hubert Pierlot told the Chamber of Deputies this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today to authorize a basic engineering plan for the Missouri River Basin, to be developed and supervised by a Missouri Valley Authority. He transmitted with his letter the joint proposal of the Bureau of Reclamation and the Corps of Engineers, representing a reconciliation of features formerly incorporating divergent plans of the two agencies for that watershed.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 28 -- How the Nazis in occupied France were outwitted and prevented from deporting 5,000 refugee orphaned children to concentration camps in Poland and elsewhere was described today at the war emergency conference of the World Jewish Congress.

AT THE SWISS-FRENCH FRONTIER, Nov. 28 -- Not a single German train has moved on the north bank of the Rhine since late last night after an outbreak of coordinated sabotage attributed by the Germans on the frontier today to formations of parachuted Allied troops reported to have been dropped at Oberlauchringen and Immendingen early yesterday morning.

Floors will not be flat any longer if the Museum of Modern Art has its way. An advantage of the uneven floor, according to the museum, is that "it conserves the tactile sensibility of our feet, which flat surfaces and modern shoes have destroyed." Besides, says the museum, an uneven floor "might be more agreeable to sit on than a flat floor."

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 28 -- The Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America approved at the first session of its biennial meeting today a statement by its Commission on a Just and Durable Peace calling for a world organization, patterned after proposals made at Dumbarton Oaks, to maintain peace after the war.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Attorney General Biddle was accused today by Norman M. Littell, Assistant Attorney General, of intervening in a Justice Department case in behalf of Thomas E. Corcoran, onetime New Deal brain-truster now in private law practice.
The news from the eastern front yesterday still told of slow and painful Russian advances in Hungary and in the wild and tumbled highlands of Czechoslovakia.

WE live in an outspoken age. Reticence, decorum, taste and dignity have not been fashionable literary virtues for some years. Authors live in literary glass houses from choice, write their autobiographies young, sometimes in their twenties, often in their thirties, and determinedly tell all. The exhibitionist urge to expose oneself in print, to make literary copy out of personal intimacies that had better have remained personal, seems to be tough and strong in many individuals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Moving to start a non-Federal public works program to provide post-war employment costing up to $1,518,000,000 throughout the country, President Roosevelt recommended to Congress today that it appropriate $75,900,000 for loans and advances to encourage States, counties and municipalities to begin planning for such projects.
STRASBOURG, France, Nov. 28 -- Machine-gun fire rattled across the Rhine and the tenuous German bridgehead on its western shore this afternoon.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,092 against 1,218 last week and 937 in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals were 855 compared with 417 last Tuesday.

American Labor or Liberal party votes in New York City supplied the margin of victory for three candidates for Representative in Congress, three for the State Senate and five for the Assembly, a breakdown of the party vote contained in the official canvass of the Board of Elections disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Sponsored by twenty-two Senators, the O'Mahoney amendment to the flood-control bill, providing for greater local representation and participation in Federal projects, stirred lively debate today in the Senate without coming to vote.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- In the first complete tabulation of wartime shipping losses, thee British Government, acting through the Office of War Information, today revealed that 5,758 Allied and neutral merchant vessels, aggregating 22,161,000 gross tons, had been lost from all causes from the beginning of the war in September, 1939, through the end of 1943.

As an answer to the post-war problem of domestic help, a job-training program that emphasized the need for standards for domestic service was outlined yesterday to twelve State chairmen of the American Women's Voluntary Services currently meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The City Council was agreed to a man yesterday that city transit workers were underpaid and that something should be done about it, but it took ninety minutes of bitter wrangling before agreement could be reached on the proper way to petition by resolution to correct the situation.

Twenty-five per cent of the high school classes in New York City are "over-crowded," having forty or more pupils, Frederic Ernst, associate superintendent in charge of the secondary division, disclosed yesterday in a report to Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools.
LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Britain does not want loans from the United States, nor does she want to import lend-lease goods with which to resume her export trade.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 28 -- The nationalist press was jubilant today over Secretary of State Cordell Hull's resignation. It was less jubilant over the choice of his successor, for it regards Edward R. Stettinius Jr. as only one degree less uncompromising toward Argentina than Mr. Hull.

ROME, Nov. 28 (AP) -- British troops have cleared the Lamone River's east bank for five miles northeast of Faenza and have sent patrols lancing across the stream on the southwest in a gathering threat to that strategic highway city at the edge of the Po plain, Allied headquarters announced today.

LONDON, Nov. 28 (Reuter) -- A German rocket bomb, launched from a point northeast of Arnhem, the Netherlands, partly exploded in the air and fell back on the launching point with a second violent explosion. The incident was witnessed by two Canadian Royal Air Force men, Flying Officer Robert Fullerton, pilot, and Flying Officer Peter Castellan, navigator, both of Toronto, who told of it today.

BURTON-ON-TRENT, England, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The death toll from the explosion of an, RAF underground bomb depot, which devastated the countryside yesterday, will be more than 160, the Bristish Press Association estimated tonight.

Members of the Seventeenth Regiment, New York Guard, were praised last night for serving "perhaps without full recognition" by Lieut. Gen. Ben G. Lear, commanding the Army Ground Forces, who reviewed the regiment in its armory at Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

For eight weeks Manila has been the most bomb-battered city in the Orient. All the airpower Japan can assemble in the Philippines has been unable to shield it. Again and again bombers from Admiral Halsey's great flat-tops have swept in from the sea to deliver their attack, clogging the harbor with sunken hulks and choking the runways of near-by airfields with the burned-out skeletons of enemy planes.

Three hundred thousand books have been collected this year for the local Victory Book campaign by the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office. Mrs. Sidney C. Borg. cahirman, revealed yesterday. Officiating at the opening of a drive to collect 1,000,000 books by Christmas for the Second Service Command, held at a CDVO branch at 155 East Forty-fourth Street.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- The question for the next fifty years is whether the United States and Great Britain can find a motive force as strong as immediate danger to hold their present partnership together, the Earl of Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, said at the annual dinner of the Investment Bankers Association of America here tonight.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson notified Mayor Stanley W. Church of New Rochelle today that the Army had no intention of rescinding arrangements for converting Fort Slocum here into a rehabilitation center for the imprisonment of soldiers who violate the Articles of War.

One essential to the establishment of a lasting peace is a clarification of American policy toward Russia, Senator-elect J. William Fulbright of Arkansas declared last night at the annual dinner of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Your editorial "The Importance of Imports" on Nov. 23 raises the issue of the relative significance of imports and exports for our national economy in a way which calls for some further comments. You say that "the basic advantage of our foreign trade consists in our imports rather than exports," since the former satisfy needs, basic and otherwise, while the latter are merely means with which to pay for the imports.

Former Patrolman Carl C. Palm of Brooklyn is now a lieutenant in charge of an anti-tank platoon in Germany. His instinct is to deal firmly with evildoers in places like Prummern just as it was in places like Brooklyn and Manhattan. When five Nazi tanks and a swarm of Nazi infantry attacked his platoon he was only momentarily non-plused.

LONDON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill declared in the House of Commons today that Britain's armies have all "the necessary ammunition to fight their battles" and promised a more vigorous attack on Japan after Germany's defeat.

The directors of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad, at a meeting in Cleveland yesterday, authorized issuance of $42,000,000 of thirty-year bonds to be offered at competitive bidding. Proceeds of the sale would be used to pay off the $26,058,000 of refunding 5 1/2 per cent bonds of 1974, the $6,500,000 of Toledo, St. Louis Western 4 per cent bonds of 1950 and the recently arranged $10,000,000 collateral loan.

The first general meeting of the Catholic Institute of the Press, made up of men and women employed in the newspaper, radio, magazine, advertising and affiliated publishing industries in New York City, took place last night in Midston House, 22 East Thirtyeighth Street.

When Washington Irving returned to this country in 1832, after living for seventeen years in Europe, he made a protracted journey through the American West with an Englishman and a Swiss count. He kept a record of his experiences in five notebooks, the first completely annotated edition of which was published on Monday by the University of Oklahoma Press.

Returning to Carnegie Hall last night for his first recital of the season. Witold Malcuzynski, Polish pianist, showed once again that he has more than his share of technical virtuosity at his command. He played a program which included Cesar Franck's Prelude, Choral and Fugue; Chopin's B-flat Minor Sonata, three mazurkas of Szymanowski, Liszt's "Spanish Rhapsody" and three shorter works of Chopin.

Randolph Paul, tax expert and former general counsel for the Treasury Department, predicted last night that post-war Federal budgets would average $25,000,000,000, but said the manner in which these budgets would be covered could not now be determined clearly because of a complexity of uncertain factors.

There wasn't much action on the field at the Polo Grounds yesterday because it was altogether too muddy for the Football Giants to do their stuff, but, beginning today and for the balance of the week, it is a cinch that much stress is going to be laid on forward-pass defense in the final preparations for the game here Sunday with Washington.

ENGELSDORF, Germany, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Drinking rain water and treating their wounds with blood plasma dropped to them from Cub planes, two Ninth Army infantry companies, cut off from their battalion for two days and nights, held out heroically against superior German forces until another battalion fought its way to nearby Koslar and rescued them last night.

While forecasting a record peace-time market, William E. Holler, general sales manager, Chevrolet division, General Motors Corporation, yesterday emphasized the need for salesmanship during the post-war period at a luncheon of the Sales Executive Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command said tonight that the Japanese had been driven back in their push toward Kweiyang. A local success was claimed at Tashantang, seven miles north of Hochih and 140 miles southwest of Kweiyang.

ABOARD ADMIRAL KINKAID'S FLAGSHIP, off Leyte, Nov. 28 -- Fifteen enemy planes were shot down yesterday as the Japanese launched a determined major air attack on our shipping in Leyte Gulf, a communique announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Senate Interstate Commerce Committee unanimously voted to report favorably today the bill submitted in May by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, which is designed to end the domination of James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, over radio broadcasts of cultural and educational musical groups.

Some member of your staff is writing a most delightful series of editorials: "Baked Beans," "Down to Earth," "Red Banners" and "Long John Silver," but I think I liked best of all the one about "Plank Bridges." All my life I have lived in the country and have driven over hundreds of these plank bridges.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- Two Soviet armies, linking forces in a new crossing of the Tisza River, yesterday advanced seven miles along a ninety-mile front in Czechoslovakia and northeast Hungary, while Berlin said that Red Army tank columns were converging on the Hungarian fortress city of Pecs, 100 miles southwest of Budapest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- In anticipation of the restoration of world communications, the American Society of Newspaper Editors proposed today that the United States Government and all other Governments with all private channels of information make reciprocal declarations embracing the right of people everywhere to read and hear news free from censorship restrictions.

A campaign to emphasize the "security of spending" in the postwar era was started yesterday by Macfadden Publications, Inc., through Walter M. Swertfager Co. Copy will run in seventeen dailies and seven advertising and financial papers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Twenty-seven toughened enlisted men, veterans of front-line infantry and artillery units fighting inside Germany, have come to the United States as "special envoys" from Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to inform workers in war plants and manufacturers how urgently more ammunition is needed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Army called an emergency conference to discuss critical shortages in vital war materials today at the same time that the War Manpower Commission disclosed 90,000 workers were needed immediately in munitions plants. Fifty high-ranking officers of the Army Service Forces came here to confer with Gen. Brehon Somervell on the emergency.

This is one of the most unpleasant days we have had for a long time. It is raining hard and people are not lingering on the streets. But we who have to work in the Times Square district area nevertheless being subjected to the daily din of the War Bond drive. At the moment some leather-lunged male is expatiating via too-loud speakers on the investment value of War Bonds.
A year-end dividend of 50 cents was voted on the common stock of the Borden Company for payment on Dec. 20, bringing 1944 disbursements to $1.70, or 20 cents more than last year.

BOSTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Bill (Flash) Hollett, who dotes on humbling his recent Bruin teammates, registered two unassisted goals against Boston while pacing the Detroit Red Wings to a 6-3 National Hockey League victory tonight before 11,000 at the Boston Garden.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 28 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

THE Army and the Navy were locked in another of their many bitter football battles in 1925. The cadets had a tenuous 7-3 lead as the fray roared into the final quarter. On pressed the West Pointers to scoring territory only to be hurled back thrice by the aroused midshipmen. On fourth down Red Reeder drop-kicked a field goal for the points which insured an Army victory.

MOSCOW, Nov. 28 -- The Russian press published today a speech by Eduard Osubka-Morawski in which the President of the Polish Committee of National Liberation reiterated the willingness of his group to join forces with M. Mikolajczyk in expelling the Germans and building a new Poland.

GERARDMER, France, Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- The Germans burned and blasted thirty miles of the once beautiful Meurthe River countryside of eastern France early this month in an orgy of destruction planned as methodically as a military campaign, the Mayor of this ruined town said today.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY, in Germany, Nov. 28 -- For the second day in succession troops of Lieut. Gen. Courtney H. Hodges' First Army used night fighting tactics to bewilder strong German defenses and forged a little farther onto the Cologne plain.
LONDON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Individual Scotch meat pies, all ready to be served except for heating, are one of the most recent additions to the grocery department at Macy's. The small, round pies, which measure about three inches in diameter and an inch and a half in height, have a light, flaky pastry crust and are filled with a combination of mutton and beef, minced together.

Albert Johnson meant it when he said he would circumvent the booking jam by leasing a theatre off Broadway for his production of "Bonanza." He and two of his partners, Louis Singer and Martin Desmoni have done just that with the Superior Theatre, Third Avenue and Thirty-first Street, a venerable legitimate house now used for pictures.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company has sold the five-story building at 27-29 West 181st Street, corner of Davidson Avenue, the Bronx, to an investing client of the Dover Realty Company. Occupying a plot 100 by 100 feet, the property contains seven stores and thirty-nine apartments and is assessed at $140,000.

CHUNGKING, China, Wednesday, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Donald M. Nelson told the Peoples' Political Council today that the objective for the coming year must be to double or triple the weapons provided by Chinese industry for China's soldiers.
Again led by strength in the December delivery, the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday unchanged to 9 points higher on the day.
Here is something to think about tonight before you drift off into slumber:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 28 -- Lee Tracy has been signed by Universal for the lead in the forthcoming "Gift of Gab," a murder mystery with a radio station locale. Brenda Joyce has been named for the romantic lead and June Preisser for the principal comedy role.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Since appointment of Edward R. Stettinius Jr. to succeed Cordell Hull as Secretary of State, analysts of the news and editorial commentators have been active in presenting all possible reasons for and future implications of the President's choice.
Two deals yesterday, involving three properties, marked a sale and leases for purposes of light protection of adjoining structures.

Referring to a picture in THE NEW YORK TIMES, this correspondent was chagrined to see loads of New York State apples going to waste. I have seen the same kind of picture around Charlottesville, Va., and in Oregon. I have also read with dismay about condemnation of carloads of apples in New York by Federal inspectors who objected to bruises on fruit knocked down by a late fall storm.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The special House committee investigating the Federal Communications Commission today discontinued open hearings on allegations of coercion in the alleged forced sale of station WMCA in New York.

Although it is possible there were a few American League diehards with doubts that the National League actually won last October's world series, it is quite certain that by now they have been fully convinced. It also seems assured that the legions of baseball enthusiasts and players in the nation's armed forces have a genuine treat in store for them.

The Princess Alice, Countess of Athlone, was honored last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at the annual dinner of the English-Speaking Union at which Kent Cooper, general manager of The Associated Press, one of the principal speakers, renewed his plea for world-wide freedom of the press.

MOSCOW, Nov. 28 -- All the Moscow newspapers gave prominence today to a letter to Premier Joseph Stalin from the people of Tallinn, who declared the Estonian people know that "only in the Soviet Union can Estonia maintain her freedom, restore her shattered economy and raise her material well-being and culture."

'S HERTOGENBOSCH, Netherlands, Nov. 28 -- Attempts by the Nazis to convert school children to their ideology during the enemy occupation of the now-liberated part of the Netherlands were thoroughly sabotaged by parents, school teachers and clergymen and often by the children themselves, a school inspector said in an interview here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Office of Price Administration ruled today that its field offices may, under certain circumstances, take final action in fixing manufacturers' maximum prices for new items of durable goods under the fourth pricing method of the general consumer durable goods regulation.

A 'cello program of unusual interest in itself was given last night at Town Hall by Stefan Auber, who was assisted at the piano by Ernst Victor Wolff. The program consisted of an Adagio by Bach; Beethoven's Seven Variations in E flat, on a Theme from Mozart's "Magic Flute"; the Brahms Sonata No. 1 for pianoforte and 'cello in E minor, Opus 38; Three Fantasy Pieces by Schumann, and the D'Albert Concerto in C major.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Wednesday, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A communique:
LONDON, Nov. 28 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 22:

PARIS, Wednesday, Nov. 29 -- A Cabinet meeting that began at 5 P.M. yesterday and lasted until early this morning discussed the tendencies of local groups in France to take the law into their own hands.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- Professional pressure and scattered liquidation in December wheat and rye, combined with removal of the permit system for regulating she movement of corn, resulted in moderately lower prices in the early trading today on the Board of Trade.

The wildlife picture, past, present and on that nebulous day in the future "when Johnny comes marching home," will be given a thorough going over by many of the country's leading authorities during the New York State Conservation Council convention at Bear Mountain, N.Y., on Friday and Saturday.

The housewife who is finding it almost impossible to get poultry of any kind may find consolation in the promise that for Christmas she will stand a better chance of getting a turkey within the price ceiling than she did for Thanksgiving Day.

CHARLES TOWN, W.Va., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Hazel's Play, a brown 3-year-old filly owned by Mrs. C.P. Sowers, won the Graphic Arts Purse of six furlongs and forty yards today with a speedy stretch run. Bulrushes was second and Petes Bet third.

Benefits of $14,369,200 were paid to 42,707 persons by the church pension boards of twenty-one Protestant denominations and the pension systems of the Young Men's Christian Association and the Young Women's Christian Association, according to reports yesterday at the thirtieth annual church pensions conference in the Hotel McAlpin.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- To football coaches the grass invariably is greener in the pasture on the other side of the fence.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 28 -- Just when things were beginning to look bright for Navy and chances for an upset victory over Army at Baltimore on Saturday more rosy than ever, it appeared tonight, several hours after practice, that Bob Jenkins, ace middie tailback, might be lost for the big game.

ATLANTA, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Unbeaten in seven games, the Fort Pierce (Fla.) Naval Amphibious Training Base placed three players on the 1944 all-service football team selected by The Associated Press from Army, Navy and Marine elevens in South Carolina, Georgia, Florida, Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana, Tennessee and Kentucky.

The greatest public housing program in history is in the making for the post-war period, with 400 local housing authorities, including fifty-three in the New York region, now completing a national survey for the Federal Public Housing Authority on their three-year needs as the basis for an early request to Congress for an allotment of funds for the vast array of projects, it became known last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- A thorough study of the clothing price situation was recommended today by the Office of Price Administration to the Mead Special Committee to investigate the national defense program.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- To football coaches the grass invariably is greener in the pasture on the other side of the fence.

As the first step toward an urgent reform, a House subcommittee has unanimously approved a proposed constitutional amendment for the approval of treaties by a simple majority of both the House and Senate instead of, as at present, by a two-thirds majority of the Senate alone.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Nov. 28 -- Bob Ferri scored four touchdowns and paced the Eastchester High attack as the undefeated and untied Eagles smothered Edison Tech of Mount Vernon, 38 to 0, on a muddy field today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- James V. Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy, and Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the General Motors Corporation, both declared today that America must not again be caught unarmed and unprepared, should there ever again be a world conflict.
PARIS, Nov. 28 -- As Gen. Charles de Gaulle flew toward Moscow to meet Premier Stalin, he passed a plane carrying Maurice Thorez, long-exiled French Communist leader, from Moscow to France.

A streamlined system of distribution to match the country's vastly increased productive capacity, through application of the same "creative engineering methods" used in development of our production plant, was discussed last night at the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

ROETGEN, Germany, Nov. 28 -- This was the first German town of any consequence occupied by American troops. It stands out among similar conquered villages for three reasons: it is practically intact, the population of 2,400 was not evacuated and remains largely what it was, it has been under Allied rule for a longer term than any German community.
