OTTAWA, Nov. 28 (AP) -- French- Canadian troops drafted originally for home service and now liable to be sent to the Western Front staged anti-conscription demonstrations in Pacific Coast camps today.

Prevention of inflated prices on hides and leather will be the principal result of the "gentlemen's agreement" entered into between the Combined Raw Materials Board and four European countries for allocations of supplies to the latter, industry spokesmen said yesterday, providing the program is operable.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The United States has ample stocks of cured leaf tobacco, enough to meet demands for the next eighteen months, not counting the current crop, members of the House Agriculture Committee were told today as they began their inquiry into the cigarette shortage.

A program for educating children in citizenship was presented yesterday by the Parents League of New York and the Public Education Association at a joint meeting at the Junior League Club House, 221 East Seventy-first Street.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Communique 234:

A major step in the reorganization of the United Gas Corporation was completed yesterday with the sale of $100,000,000 of the company's first mortgage and collateral trust bonds to a group of fifty institutions. Insurance companies were the principal purchasers.

MOSCOW, Nov. 28 -- A Soviet automobile designer, A. Lipgart, announced today that designers and engineers are now working on plans for a post-war light automobile modeled on the famous Willys jeep and intended for use in villages.

When wartime legislation recedes from its present stage and other laws can be considered, there is a strong possibility that old plans for compulsory registration of all securities offered in the public markets may be revived. It is known that the Securities and Exchange Commission now can see its way clear to simplifying registration requirements and lightening the load of reporting.

AT THE RHINE, With French and American Troops, Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- A repetition of the pell-mell disintegration of the German forces that followed the Allied breakthroughs at Avranches and Caen in Normandy may develop between the Vosges and the Rhine.

"99 Park." headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc.,* offers a partial list of free amusements available today, through the generosity of the entertainment world. Afternoon tickets from 11 A.M. Evening tickets after 4 P.M. Apply 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street) for tickets.
UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Eastern Baseball League's 1944 all-star team honors went chiefly to the champion Hartford Laurels and Albany's second-place Senators.

Air cargo transport will accelerate the entire tempo of post-war merchandising, particularly in fields of fashions, specialty goods, perishable foods and exports, Maj. Benjamin H. Namm, head of the Namm Store and first vice president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said yesterday in an address before the New York Board of Trade at the Hotel Astor.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- A revolutionary type of coal-burning steam locomotive, powered by a direct-drive turbine engine, has been completed for the Pennsylvania Railroad and was on display in the yards of the railroad here today.

The Tokyo radio claimed yesterday that Japanese amphibious troops had reinvaded Morotai Island while Japanese planes sank eight United States warships and transports in the Philippines. The broadcasts were recorded by the Federal Communications Commission.

WITH THE UNITED STATES NINTH ARMY in Germany, Nov. 29 -- With the southern two-thirds of the Ninth Army line now resting on the Roer River and with the approaches from Merzenhausen southward to Altdorf acting as a pivot, Lieut. Gen. William H. Simpson today applied sudden and heavy pressure on the northern third of his line around Beeck, Wuerm and Lindern in an effort to swing it eastward and parallel with the Reef River.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Thursday, Nov. 30 (AP) -- A communique:
Accounts Zenith Stamp Company, dealers in stamps, to S. Duane Lyon, Inc. Stamp trade publications.

STOCKHOLM, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Gunder Haegg. Swedish distance star, and Hakon Lidman, hurdler, will go to the United States between Christmas and New Year's to compete in the indoor track season events, it was announced today by Torsten Tegner, sports editor of Idrottisbladet. Arne Andersson will not accompany them.

What the German radio describes as "the most terrible battle in the history of all wars" continues toward its bloody climax on the plains before Cologne, in the Saar Basin, through the snow-clogged passes of the Eifels and the Vosges Mountains. It has been under way now for two weeks.

When in the course of human events it becomes necessary for one column on a newspaper page to take issue with a statement put forth in a neighboring column, it is a duty, and sometimes a privilege, and occasionally even a pleasure, to do so, though not too often, we trust.

A dinner of liverwurst and potatoes at $36, a five-cent chocolate bar at $1 and other runaway prices for food got Corp. William A. Fagan so steamed up during his march through France, Belgium and Holland since D-day that he sat down, when he reached Paris, and wrote to the Office of Price Administration about it.

In conflict on virtually every other issue, attorneys for both principals in the James H.R. Cromwell-Doris Duke Cromwell divorce case agreed yesterday that there was little or no possibility of the case ever reaching the United States Supreme Court and thereby setting precedents that would settle conflicts in State divorce procedures.

Widespread interest of motorists in car bodies of post-war vehicles is emphasized by replies received to a series of questions being presented by THE NEW YORK TIMES at the request of the Society of Automotive Engineers. Owner analysis of requirements indicates that the driver and automobile manufacturer have yet to see eye-to-eye on specified phases of body construction.

Harry Sussman, who as former investigator for the Society for the Prevention of Crime caused the arrests of a number of persons for playing "bingo," "the numbers" and other games, was sentenced to eighteen months' imprisonment by Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell yesterday.

The Army and Navy, which are winning battles on more important fields, won seven of the eleven places on the 1944 all-America football team selected for The United Press yesterday by sports editors and writers from all over the country.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- While Francois de Menthon, Minister of Justice, flew to Marseille today in connection with the explosion at Pertuis that killed some forty members of the French Forces of the Interior, reports of other mysterious explosions came from several parts of France.
ROME, Nov. 29 -- The British veto of Count Carlo Sforza as Foreign Minister resulted indirectly today in a revolt against Premier Ivanoe Bonomi by the leftist parties.

UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Disabled veterans should be given preference in obtaining houses at low rent, Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, declared tonight in urging analysis of community housing problems.

Here are a couple of bear stories: J. Bruce Lindsley, County Clerk of Sullivan County, N.Y., spotted a bear while hunting deer at Tennanah Lake, above Roscoe, N.Y. He fired at the animal at 500 feet with a Savage 30-30. It reared up, sprawled back onto its paws and lumbered off.

With investment bankers, securities dealers and brokers concentrating their efforts toward successfully launching "The Wall Street Fleet" -- a forty-ship $600,000,000 symbolic objective of the financial community's effort in the Sixth War Loan Drive -- announcement was made yesterday that war bond sales by this group during the first subscription period amounted to $79,235,926, or 13 per cent of the goal.

Mozart's "Don Giovanni" was presented last night as the second offering of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House. The masterpiece, which was not given last year, was restored to the repertoire, with George Szell conducting it for the first time in this city. All of the male singers of the cast were familiar here in their respective roles, except Nicola Mascons as the Commendatore.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Senate War Investigating Committee declined today to assume jurisdiction at this time in the efforts of Attorney General Biddle to force the resignation of Norman M. Littell, assistant attorney general.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 29 -- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, "with its great influence in the American Federation of Labor," was "more responsible for the election of Roosevelt than any other influence in America," according to the current issue of The Teamsters Journal.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The United States will face a serious sugar shortage in 1945 unless all Government agencies take constructive action promptly, the Food Industry War Committee declared yesterday in a lengthy report. The committee made "six major recommendations" which it suggested would avert the threatened shortage.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Nov. 29 -- For what is probably the first time in British naval history an Empire naval officer has been court-martialed and dismissed from his ship for disobeying an American order, it was disclosed today.
LONDON, Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- Text of the international affairs section of an address by Prime Minister Winston Churchill before the House of Commons:

Charges that soldiers are dying for lack of nursing care while many New York hospitals are operating with staffs that would be considered extravagant even in peacetime were made yesterday at an emergency meeting called by the Nursing Council for War Service on Long Island.

At the age of 70, which he reaches today, Prime Minister Winston Churchill has already left a mark on history deeper and more creditable than that of his renowned ancestor, John Churchill, first Duke of Marlborough. It is obvious, of course, that there can be little indeed of John Churchill in a descendant born more than two centuries later.

Shipments in October by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company established a new high record for any month of this year with $75,028,866, compared with $63,113,578 in October 1943, A. W. Robertson, chairman, informed directors at a meeting held here yesterday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 29 -- The excitement and air of expectation that precede an Army football game are beginning to assert themselves at the Naval Academy. Until now the interest among the midshipmen was there, but on the subdued side.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Another dispute has arisen between the Office of Price Administration and the War Food Administration over the disposal of food supplies, and it appeared tonight to have ended in favor of the WFA.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- None of the anti-cold vaccines administered hypodermically or taken by mouth in capsule form has been proved to be of any value, and their uncontrolled use for prevention of the common cold should be discouraged, a combined report by the councils on pharmacy, chemistry and industrial health of the American Medical Association stated.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Japanese vanguards have made startling advances inside Kweichow Province toward Kweiyang, junction of a highway network linking Chungking, Kunming and other southwest China cities, a United States Fourteenth Air Force communique disclosed tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 29 -- Jesse L. Lasky, who recently severed a three-year association with Warner Brothers, is returning to independent production, having organized Jesse L. Lasky Productions in collaboration with Walter MacEwen, a former Paramount and Warner producer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- With the passing of another day the dispute between the American and British delegates to the international air conference at Chicago which has prevented agreement may be solved by our last compromise proposal. This dispute concerns the "fifth freedom" of the air -- of which more hereafter -- and if the Canadian compromise remains unacceptable to the British, there is some hope for the final American alternative.

ALBANY, Nov. 29 -- After he had sent word to the grand jury investigating legislative spending that he was too ill to appear, it was learned today that Senator John J. Dunnigan had made application to the State Retirement Board for retirement Jan. 1.

Housewives who have haunted stores hoping to pounce on one of the electric irons now putting in a shy appearance may as well save their energy if they live in a New York City area served by direct current. Thirteen manufacturers whose combined quotas represent 1,186,868 of 2,000,000 irons being produced under War Production Board authorization are making automatic models that work on alternating current only.

ON THE THIRD ARMY FRONT, Nov. 29 -- Battlefield surgery reached a new and spectacular high point during the Metz offensive when a 19-year-old medical aid man of the Fifth Infantry Division, working under intense shell fire, performed an extremely delicate throat operation, using as his only instruments a jackknife and a fountain pen.

DETROIT, Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- Production of engines for B-29 Superfortresses and parts for naval aircraft and amphibious tanks was halted today by strikes in the Detroit plants of the Dodge Company and the Graham-Paige Motor Company.

The current creeping advance by the stock market received yesterday a substantial thrust both from speculative and investment buying. In a stepped-up trading which pushed volume above the million-share mark, values were enlarged by fractions to 2 points.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- The statement of Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr. that the traditional policy of the United States still excluded American guarantees of any frontiers in Europe, which was made two days before Mr. Stettinius became Secretary and just when Gen. Charles de Gaulle was approaching Moscow, dumfounded many Frenchmen.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 192:

The city's proposal to induce the remodeling of old-law tenements has been officially considered at least half a dozen times in the last twenty-five years. On two occasions, once in 1920 and again in 1926, legislative committees rejected the whole idea as impractical.

Trading in the common stock of the Elastic Stop Nut Corporation of Union, N.J., was suspended on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday by an unprecedented Securities and Exchange Commission order issued after William T. Hedlund, president of the company, had been found dead by suicide at his home in Summit, N.J.

A trip through any city store these days gives ample indication that with Thanksgiving over, Christmas isn't far behind. The holiday spirit is well under way, judging by the crowds, and shops are offering many gift suggestions of food, such as the following:

The Senate Interstate Commerce Committee has unanimously voted to report favorably the bill submitted by Senator Vandenberg which would break the radio ban imposed by Mr. Petrillo, as head of the American Federation of Musicians, on the high school orchestras and bands which assemble annually each summer at Interlochen, Mich.

ARMY AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, Hawaii, Nov. 29 -- For the third time within six days, Superfortresses of the Twenty-first Bomber Command of the United States Twentieth Air Force have attacked Tokyo, in the heart of Japan, flying the long route from Saipan to strike the enemy capital in a surprise raid Wednesday night, Tokyo time, causing explosions and starting fires.
Major changes in the executive personnel of the Electric Bond and Share Company and its subsidiary, the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., were announced yesterday.

MYITKYINA, Burma, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Chinese troops who by-passed Bhamo in their southward offensive in north Burma were driving down a branch highway toward the old Burma Road today without meeting any organized Japanese resistance.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 29 -- Belgium rallied today after four of the most painful days since her liberation.

A test case that may have a wide bearing on future rents in many apartment and residential hotel buildings that have felt the effect of the current shortage of linens, laundry service and maids was disclosed yesterday. Daniel P. Woolley, regional head of the Office of Price Administration, announced that discontinuance of maid and linen service would be the basis for rent reductions.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--More than 1,500,000 combat sorties had been flown between Dec. 7, 1941, and Nov. 18, 1944, the United States Army Air Forces announced today.

Sentencing Fred Schmidt, 24 years old, an ex-convict, to sixty years to life for killing a storekeeper after a hold-up, General Sessions Judge Saul S. Streit remarked yesterday that, were it not for a quirk in the law, he probably would be sentencing him to die in the electric chair.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Vice President Wallace was said on excellent authority today to have received a choice of several Cabinet posts, but not Secretary of State, after he relinquishes his present office to Senator Truman.

The Red Cross will receive the major share, or 30 per cent of the $750,000 in war relief money which was gained at the recent nine-day Victory Meet at Belmont Park. The checks to this and other war relief and charitable organizations will be distributed Dec. 13 by H.B. Swope, chairman of the Turf Committee of America, under whose auspices the meet was run.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 29 -- Led by President William Green, speakers in the convention of the American Federation of Labor attacked the National Labor Relations Board today as an agency biased against the federation and favoring the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and demanded amendments to the Wagner Act guaranteeing "the maintenance of craft union integrity."

LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 30 -- Marshal Feodor I. Tolbukhin's Third Ukrainian Army, forcing the wide Danube River 100 miles south of Budapest and advancing twenty-five miles, yesterday captured the ancient fortress city of Pecs in a new offensive into western Hungary that has carried the Red Army to within 104 miles of Austria.

The butter shortage has made so many housewives change to oleomargarine that some retail food stores in this city are now finding it harder to get oleomargarine than butter, it was reported yesterday by Patsy D'Agostino, president of the Greater New York Retail Grocers Conference.

Bagpipes skirled merrily at the Biltmore yesterday as the Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York opened their twenty-fourth annual three-day bazaar for the benefit of the Victoria Home for aged British men and women at Ossining, N.Y.

In an attempt to control inflation in Puerto Rico, Hawaii and Alaska the Office of Price Administration is attempting to establish an export control procedure for shipments to these possessions, traders attending a meeting of the American Office Supply Exporters at the Hotel Commodore disclosed yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Gen. H.H. Arnold, commanding general of the Army Air Forces, told a Veterans of Foreign Wars meeting tonight that "we're going to bomb Japanese industry into a state of paralysis -- just as we're doing in Germany."

TRENTON, Nov. 29 -- Repeal of the State law providing for taxation of intangible personal property was urged today by the State Chamber of Commerce, the New Jersey Bankers Association and the Jersey City Chamber of Commerce at the first of a series of hearings by the five-member commission appointed by Gov. Walter E. Edge to make recommendations to the 1945 Legislature on the intangible tax problem.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The United States' synthetic rubber industry, developed in the wartime emergency, will provide well over half the rubber requirements of this country in the post-war years, Stacy May, chairman of the committee on international policy of the National Planning Association told a subcommittee of the Special House Committee on Post-War Economic Policy today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29--A new treatment for stiffness and weakness of muscles in such crippling diseases as arthritis and neuritis, through a new but unnamed drug, was described today by Dr. R. C. Williams, assistant Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, before a subcommittee of the House which is investigating aid for afflicted persons.

The Administration expects to request a vast expansion in the social security program early next year. In the meantime it opposes freezing old-age social security taxes at the present level. However, there cannot be an effective separation of the old-age social security taxes required to meet the present program and the taxes required to meet the expanded program.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Unexpectedly and without explanation, Senator William Langer, Republican, of North Dakota, interposed objection today to the immediate confirmation by the Senate of the nomination of Edward R. Stettinius Jr. to be Secretary of State, succeeding Cordell Hull.

In an appeal for city-wide support of the Police Athletic League's program for New York City's youngsters, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine emphasized yesterday that his department's principal concern was to prevent the youngster from "mounting the first step" onto the line-up platform at Police Headquarters.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Col. Elliott Roosevelt, 34-year-old son of the President, will take as his third wife Faye Emerson, 27, an actress, within a week.

ATHENS, Nov. 29 -- Conversations concerning ways and means of disarming the "private" armies of the resistance groups continue and some solution is expected within twenty-four hours, it was stated here today.

Philosophers have long pondered the problem of rise and fall among nations. Ingenious and logical hypotheses have been promulgated. There are those who believe that a nation's eating habits and its position among its peers have a direct correlation. We view with perturbation the decline of the beef stew.

Unless the War Production Board and the Office of Price Administration take steps to make more fabrics available for production of popular priced dresses, output this year may show a decline of some 30,000,000 units from the 80,000,000 produced in 1943, Louis Rubin, executive director of the Popular Price Dress Manufacturers Group, warned yesterday.

The next volume in International Publishers' "Builders of America" series will be "The Life and Writings of Frederick Douglass," edited by Philip S. Foner. It will include the nineteenth century Negro leader's autobiography, his speeches, articles and letters.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- The Allied air offensive against Germany continued in full force today, paced by an attack by more than 1,000 heavy bombers of the United States Eighth Air Force, with a fighter escort of equal strength.

ROME, Nov. 29 (AP) -- German troops, aided by continued rains that have widened the Lamone River to fifty feet northeast of Faenza, are fighting furiously from their new positions along the west bank of the stream.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- Grain markets on the Board of Trade here surged upward today after a mixed start, with corn in the lead. Buying of December corn by cash houses and reports that the Government was in the market for 400,000 bushels of cash grain resulted in the near-by month advancing 1 3/4 cents a bushel before the demand was satisfied.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29 -- Executives of The San Francisco Examiner, owned by William Randolph Hearst, were summoned before the State Railroad Commission today to show cause why they should not be punished for contempt, as the result of a story published on Aug. 12 dealing with a meeting of the commission the day before.

WITH THE UNITED STATES SEVENTH ARMY, at Batzendorf, Nov. 29 -- The jeep, with its partly covered trailer, was parked at one end of the main square of this forlorn Alsatian village less than four miles below Haguenau. From a gap in the soggy canvas atop the trailer a clenched fist protruded.

Air-conditioning of large buildings that contain many small rooms, such as offices, hotels and apartment houses, has attained greater efficiency at a reduced cost of installation as a result of final patents granted to the Carrier Corporation of Syracuse, N.Y., the company announced here yesterday.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Communique 235:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee recommended today that Palestine be reopened to the Jews for free entry and full colonization.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Thursday, Nov. 30--In a two-day air battle of American planes against Japanese ships, which ended yesterday, thirteen Japanese ships, including three destroyers, were officially declared sunk and at least 4,000 Japanese troops were drowned when the enemy made new large-scale attempts to reinforce Leyte, headquarters announced today.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 29 -- What might have been the first collision between a B-17 Flying Fortress and a speeding passenger train, imminent when the airplane crash-landed on the tracks just as the express was whistling its way around a bend was averted here today by a girl who remembered where to find a broom.

Opposition to the enactment of the proposed Wagner-Murray-Dingell expanded social security bill as obscure, difficult of interpretation and entailing excessive costs was expressed in a report made public yesterday by the Tax Foundation, 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

The nation's gasoline stocks at the close of last week amounted to 79,421,000 barrels, composed of 13,017,000 of unfinished, 41,484,000 civilian-grade automotive and 24,920,000 aviation, military, naphthas and blending supplies currently indeterminate as to ultimate use, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
LONDON, Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- Text of an address by King George VI at the opening session of Parliament today:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 29 -- A proposal made by a Harvard group headed by Prof. Warren A. Seavey, that German prisoners of war in the United States receive a fuller education on the ideals of democracy through a definite program, has been rejected by the War Department.
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
There has been considerable discussion of compulsory military training after the war. As a service man I desire to submit my viewpoint gathered over a three-year period of naval service.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Prime Minister Churchill warned, at the opening today of the sixth wartime session of Parliament, against the feeling that the war in Europe would soon be over. Once more he reminded Parliament that even after Germany was defeated another powerful enemy in the Pacific must be vanquished.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- The Investment Bankers Association of America adopted unanimously today a recommendation of its board of governors to submit to a nationwide referendum of members a proposal that headquarters of the organization be moved from Chicago to Washington because of the various ways in which the association's affairs were affected by the Government, and by legislative, regulatory and War Bond developments.

Boston, Mass. The First Boston Corporation and the Chemical Bank and Trust Company received yesterday the award of $5,000,000 of temporary loan notes of the city of Boston, notes at 0.42 per cent, plus a premium of $12. The obligations will become payable on Oct. 1, 1945.

Hal Hamberg, sharp passer and sparkplug of the Navy football team, is the only repeater picked on the all-Eastern college football eleven yesterday by The Associated Press after consultation with coaches and officials. Four of the all-Eastern first team wear the blue of Navy and five the gold and black of Army.
CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The United States Navy has virtually wiped Japanese naval aviation out of existence, and has shot down more than 4,000 of the enemy planes within the last year and a half, Vice Admiral Marc A. Mitscher, commander of a carrier task force of the Third Fleet in the Pacific for the last two years, said today at a press conference held by Secretary of the Navy James V. Forrestal.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- Japanese broadcasts said today that two separate B-29 fleets had hit Tokyo -- one at 11:55 P.M. on Wednesday and a second at 4:15 A.M. on Thursday.

Your editorial on the problem created by the new synthetic rubber industry here and abroad, with a yearly potential of 800,000 tons in America alone, to be superimposed in peacetime on the supply of natural rubber formerly regarded as itself adequate to world demand, may have underestimated one vast new demand.

To the other advantages which the Navy fighter planes in the Pacific have held over the Mitsubishi '00's, the Japanese Zero fighter plane, now has been added that of speed, so our correspondent Robert Trumbull reports from a carrier of Admiral Halsey's Third Fleet off the Philippines.
Yesterday's, communique, as broadcast from Chungking in English to the United States and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

After an absence of six years Frank Sheridan, the distinguished pianist, returned to the New York concert stage last night with a recital at Town Hall. Apparently this absence has not diminished Mr. Sheridan's stature as a musician, for his concert provided an evening of well-proportioned, cleanly executed readings.

It is regrettable that the Tigers are not to be the opponents of the Giants at the Polo Grounds instead of the Redskins, because there is blood on the Brooklyn moon and a return engagement would come close to being a grudge battle.

AT THE SWISS-FRENCH FRONTIER, Nov. 29 -- Following its declaration yesterday of a state of alarm along the Rhine from near Schaffhausen to across from Basle, the German High Command today proclaimed the entire Province of Baden a zone of war and ordered the immediate evacuation of the civilian population.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Amazing Don Hutson of Green Bay, who meant to retire three seasons ago, now virtually owns his fifth straight scoring title and fourth consecutive pass-grabbing crown in the National Football League.

Three burglars calmly took over a two-story two-family house at 978 East Twenty-second Street in Brooklyn's Midwood district from 5:30 to 6:30 P.M. Monday, bound and gagged three persons and finally left with jewels valued by the police at $17,000.

Mayor La Guardia's plan for legislation to give ten-year tax-exemption benefits to owners who remodel old tenement houses brought objections yesterday from several organizations and caused "misgivings" about its probable long-range effect on old neighborhoods here.
Lord Taylor demonstrated yesterday afternoon its new theme for resort wear, "slim as a reed," with emphasis on Chinese slenderness of silhouette.

OTTAWA, Nov. 29 -- Parliament reopened its doors to the press and public today in an atmosphere of sober realization of the fact that, while the reinforcement situation has been improved by the action and declared intention of the Government, the situation within the country has deteriorated.

New York City has attained 20 per cent of its goal in sales of Series E War Bonds and 30.1 per cent in all issues of Sixth War Loan securities to individual investors, it was announced yesterday by Frederick W. Gehle, State chairman of the War Finance Committee for New York.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- The American and British delegations submitted new proposals to the International Civil Aviation Conference today in what appeared to be the final drive to break their deadlock on the "fifth freedom" of the air -- the right of a long line to pick up and discharge intermediate traffic without restrictions.

Constantly astonished by the primitive working conditions and social organization in China, foreigners frequently describe it as a medieval country. Although China is obviously backward, the general culture has advanced beyond medievalism.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Norman Corbin's Ask Aunt Ads, a recent winner at Garden State and Maryland tracks, captured the featured Zoric Purse at Charles Town today by a length over. H. Susini's Mr. Pharned. Another length behind was Spring-brook Farm's Strolling On.

The national billion-dollar post-war public housing program reported in this newspaper yesterday by Lee E. Cooper is important both in bulk and in significance. It would be considerably more than enough, for example, to rehouse the entire population of Syracuse. The average cost of a post-war dwelling unit is anybody's guess, but if it could be kept down to $4,000, this city's proposed allotment of $150,000,000 would take care of 37,500 families.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Emperor Hailie Selassie of Ethiopia has given the United States full title to the realty and premises of the legation in Addis Ababa, as well as additional land for a permanent home for the legation, in recognition of the support this country has given Ethiopia.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 29 -- Members of the Nazi party in the New York and New Jersey area were summoned to the office of the German Consul in the fall of 1940 and advised as to methods of avoiding incriminating answers in their alien registration questionnaires, according to testimony today at the Federal court trial here of eleven men accused of failing to report their membership in the organization.

How the women of America can work toward bringing about an effective organization for world peace will be discussed at the Second Conference of Women at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, next Wednesday afternoon and evening.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange, after early steadiness, turned slightly easier yesterday on liquidation in December and closed 7 points lower to 3 points higher than on Tuesday.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- The first tentative pattern of the nationalization that the Government apparently intends to apply to the key industries of France emerged today when officials revealed the outline of the scheme for the coalfields of the north.

Churches should provide old-age security for their employes from budgets based on gifts rather than leave it to levies by the Federal Government, the Rev. Dr. Thomas J. Watts of Dallas, Tex., executive secretary of the Relief and Annuity Board of the Southern Baptist Convention, declared yesterday at the thirtieth annual meeting of the Church Pensions Conference in the Hotel McAlpin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Army and Navy announced today the suspension of all Christmas greeting messages by cable or radio to and from service personnel overseas between midnight Dec. 5 and midnight Christmas Day.
LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Business in most sections of today's stock markets was on the quiet side, but investment buying caused further gains of 1/16 to 1/8 point in gilt-edged stocks.

His furlough from Army life at an end, Sgt. Joe Louis yesterday reported at Camp Shanks, Orangeburg, N.Y., where for the next sixty days he will assist in the physical-conditioning program. Announcement to this effect was made yesterday by the camp public relations office.

Arnold Constable The Arnold Constable Corporation declared a dividend of 12 1/2 cents a common share for payment on Dec. 19 to holders of record of Dec. 9. Similar payment was made in preceding quarters.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Nov. 29 -- A new claim against the Duke endowment, involving an "omitted" 1943 assessment of $137,453,591 and bringing the tax claims against a total of $473,000,000 of assessments, was filed here yesterday by Tax Collector Christopher O. Horner of Hillsborough Township.

Four hundred persons attended last night a dinner in celebration of the thirtieth anniversary of The Menorah Journal, Jewish magazine, at the Hotel Commodore and heard former Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Proskauer, president of the American Jewish Committee, assert that "Zionist and non-Zionist, Orthodox and Reform, must see to it that each will show decent respect for the opinions of others and that all dwell together in unity."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- After hours of debate on flood control projects in the Connecticut River Basin, especially those in Vermont, the Senate approved this afternoon a compromise worked out between Senators Austin and Aiken of the Green Mountain State, on the one hand, and Senators Walsh and Weeks of Massachusetts and Maloney and Danaher of Connecticut.

Five firemen and a bus driver were injured at 9 o'clock last night when a truck of Hook and Ladder Company 45 collided with an Englewood bus of the Public Service Company of New Jersey at 178th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. Two firemen suffered possibly fractured spines.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Montclair High School tonight was awarded the Group 4, North Jersey, Section 2, football championship by the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association and with it gained unofficial rank as the No. 1 scholastic gridiron team in the State.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 29 -- The United Nations should insist in the peace negotiations on the abrogation of anti-racial and anti-religious legislation in all countries under Nazi influence and make sure of the restoration of the full legal status of minorities, the political committee of the World Jewish Congress declared in a report today to the 300 delegates attending the war emergency conference here of the organization.

" Inside France," the latest World in Action short subject, produced by the National Film Board of Canada and released through United Artists, will begin engagements today at the Trans-Lux Theatres at Broadway and Fortyninth Street and at Madison Avenue and Sixtieth Street.
KANDY, Ceylon, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A Communique:

A comprehensive advertising campaign outlining a six-point program to be undertaken by business to assure jobs and higher living standards in the post-war period was announced yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The War Production Board announced today that the lumber allotment for the first quarter of 1945 would fall 936,000,000 board feet short of stated requirements, while still measuring about 10 per cent above estimated supplies for that period.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- The House committee investigating the Federal Communications Comsion heard further testimony today, behind closed doors, on alleged "intimidation" in connection with the sale of radio station WMCA in New York City, and Representative Richard Wigglesworth of Massachusetts said he would take the floor tomorrow to ask the House to compel the committee to rescind its decision that all further testimony on the sale be heard in executive session.

RKO is becoming more and more interested in the Broadway phase of the entertainment industry. The latest development concerns Edward Chodorov's new script, "Common Ground." The film company has taken a six-months option on the play, which the author will direct, and has agreed to put up $40,000 to cover the cost of the stage production.
LONDON, Nov. 29 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Prominent Norwegians of this city attended last night's special dramatic presentation, "And Still They Fight," based on the life of Fredrik Ramm, Norwegian editor, who died a year ago after two years in a Nazi concentration camp, which was given at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, under the auspices of Moral Re-Armament, Inc.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- The report from Annapolis that Bob Jenkins is in sick bay with a toe infection brought forth the statement today from Col. Earl Blaik that every man Army is counting on should be in a sound condition for the game with Navy in the Baltimore Municipal Stadium on Saturday.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Prime Minister Churchill's announcement today that large convoys of oceangoing ships are now able to make use of Antwerp marks the end of one decisive phase of the campaign in the west and the beginning of another.
ROME, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A communique:

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Judge John Biggs Jr. approved today in the United States District Court for Delaware a modified plan for the reorganization of the Midland United Company and its subsidiary, the Midland Utilities Company.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- An underground leader and revolutionary of almost fifty years' experience, Tomasz Arciszewski, Premier-designate of Poland, assumed responsibility today for forming a new Cabinet and will announce his list of Ministers tomorrow.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 29 -- Opposition to the establishment of diplomatic relations between the United States and the Vatican was expressed by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America at its biennial meeting today on the ground that such action "would confer upon one church a special preferential status m relation to the American Government" and would be "contrary to the spirit of the American tradition."
Five billion dollars of the $14,000,000,000 our country needs to press the war against our enemies must come from individual investors.

IT had been a command performance, his third before the ruler of a nation, and at the end Willie Hoppe bowed politely to President Avila Camacho of Mexico in his shy, retiring fashion. The greatest billiard player of all time had just given another flawless exhibition of his uncanny skill and the Mexican President had been fascinated by it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- By a voice vote the House today passed and sent to conference with the Senate a bill authorizing the appropriation of $1,500,000,000 for a three-year post-war highway building and improvement program.

The Office of Price Administration asked yesterday, in effect, why the War Food Administration had not offered specific evidence of the allegedly widespread racketeering in poultry in this city to which the WFA has been making pointed references in its daily market reports.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- There's one more thing Col. Earl (Red) Blaik of Army can be happy about other than the fact that he's just been upped in rank. His days of grilling are over for another year.

" Enter Arsene Lupin." a melo drama from the Universal studios, will begin an engagement this morning at the Rialto. The cast includes Charles Korvin, Ella Raines, J. Carrol Naish and Gale Sondergaard.

The need for a service fund of $1,000,000 to enable officials of the Disabled American Veterans organization to assist war-disabled veterans in obtaining Government benefits and in becoming adjusted to civilian life was announced yesterday by the organization's executive committee, of which Percy C. Magnus, former president of the New York Board of Trade, is general chairman.

WITH UNITED STATES NINTH ARMY in Germany, Nov. 30 -- Patrols of the Ninth Army stand tonight virtually at the water's edge of the west bank of the Roer River on five miles of the seven-mile front that Lieut. William H. Simpson's men hold between the United States First Army and the British Second Army.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30 -- In this aircraft building center, which thinks it has the most comprehensive wartime child-care program in the country, the demand for centers continues to grow, while the number of women employed in industries is decreasing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The House Military Affairs Committee said in a report today that the German Government "in general" had endeavored to give to American prisoners of war the standards of treatment provided by the 1929 Geneva Convention, while Japan has only partly observed these terms.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 30 -- Communiques from Navy headquarters on the impending showdown with Army in Baltimore Municipal Stadium on Saturday made good reading today for both contending parties and for 66,569 fans who will see the football game of the year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- President Roosevelt stepped into the Biddle-Littell feud today and dismissed Norman M. Littell, assistant Attorney General, from Government service on the ground of insubordination to Attorney General Biddle.

The charge that United Nations vessels had been provisioned during the last twelve months at black-market prices for meat for their crews was made yesterday by the Office of Price Administration, which filed triple damage actions in Federal Court against three ship chandler concerns for $87,840.

LONDON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Relaxed press censorship, both in Britain and the United States, will become effective the day Germany is beaten. British press representatives already have approved the proposed revisions.

Release of pig strips and bacon rind for the production of un-rationed shoes will add approximately six to seven million pairs to annual production, Harold Quimby, secretary of the National Boot and Shoe Manufacturers Association, said yesterday.

Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of City College, and Dr. John L. Bergstresser, dean of students, agreed yesterday that "steps would have to be taken" to improve the Negro-white relationships in the vicinity of the college, Convent Avenue and 138th Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Edward R. Stettinius Jr. was confirmed as Secretary of State by the Senate in a roll-call vote of 67 to 1 today.

MONTREAL, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The New York Rangers celebrated their first appearance of the season on Montreal ice tonight by scoring their second triumph of the National Hockey League season, whipping the league-leading Canadiens, 7 -- 5, before a crowd of about 9,000.

HUNINGUE ON THE RHINE, Nov. 30 -- Strong groups of Maj. Gen. Jean de Lattre de Tassigny's French First Army, reinforced by French Forces of the Interior and supported by both French and American artillery, reached the Rhine at two points near the Swiss frontier just before noon today to surround and divide the German bridgehead at Huningue and free the last stretch of the Swiss-Alsace frontier from German domination.

The Board of Estimate adopted yesterday a 1945 capital outlay budget of $196,459,226, lopping about $1,858,367 from the total of $198,317,593 originally proposed by the City Planning Commission. Before adopting the 1945 budget the board rejected a proposal by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick to add $20,000,000 to acquire forty-five acres in downtown Brooklyn to make possible the rehabilitation of that area.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Nov. 30 -- A proclamation issued by Brig. Gen. Jacques Leclerc, commander of the Second French Armored Division at Strasbourg, has been modified and, by implication, criticized by a statement issued by this headquarters today, which declares that the American Expeditionary Force is operating in conformity with the Geneva Convention of 1929 and, in particular, with Article II of that convention, dealing with prisoners of war.

ALBANY, Nov. 30 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that the Standard Vacuum Oil Company was entitled to $557,561 deposited in the Yokohama Specie Bank, Ltd., and subsequently seized by the State Superintendent of Banks when the Japanese attacked Pearl Harbor.

The end of the "shooting war" in Europe will simply mean greater burdens to be carried, new tasks to be met and sharper morale problems to be faced by American Red Cross field workers on the Continent, Basil O'Connor, chairman of the organization, warned yesterday after presenting a detailed report of his recent trip to England, Italy and France.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Sam Snead, who hit golf's comeback trail in winning fashion last week, will be the sentimental favorite when the field tees off tomorrow in the seventy-two-hole San Francisco open, but hard-shelled observers picked the defending champion, Byron Nelson, as the man to beat for top prize.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Bruins, sparked by Ken Smith and Art Jackson, defeated the Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game tonight, 7 to 2, scoring five goals in a hectic final period. A crowd of 10,547 saw the Bruins take their third in a row from the Hawks.

LONDON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The sky over the Leipzig area was stained black with thousands of puffs of exploding flak today as German ground gunners claimed their biggest toll of the war. Today's was the largest loss in bombers since April, when sixty-three went down over Berlin to combined ack-ack fire and fighter opposition.

ST. AVOLD, France, Nov. 30 -- A few miles east of this town at an outpost of the Eightieth Division, is a little village that today became a "no man's town." For the past two days it has been about the hottest spot on the United States Third Army front, although it is hardly a pinpoint on the map.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 30 -- Assaulting divisions of the American Ninth Army have now hammered out a front of seven miles on the Roer River and despite violent counter-attacks the entire line of the Ninth and First Armies is slowly spreading eastward across the Cologne Plain.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Twentieth Air Force communique 26:

ROME, Nov. 30 -- Italy's serious political crisis appeared to be approaching a solution tonight, with the choice of Premiers narrowing down to Ivanoe Bonomi and Meuccio Ruini. Crown Prince Humbert, in fact, asked Signor Bonomi to form a Government this morning, but not all parties of the Committee of National Liberation recognize his right to do so.

The current controversy over alleged "rent gouging" in commercial and loft properties in New York moved into Supreme Court yesterday with the filing of a suit by a Madison Avenue jeweler against the landlord on the ground that the building owner took advantage of wartime renting conditions and "coerced" him into signing up at a much higher rental.

Flotations of new securities in November were off sharply from the huge total in October, but despite the virtual suspension of new financing from Nov. 20 on, when the Sixth War Loan drive was under way the month's offerings, nevertheless, were the third largest of any month so far this year.

Arm in sling, Lieut. Col. John F. McDonough, commander of the Second Battalion, 165th Infantry, New York's Fighting Sixty-ninth Regiment, attested yesterday to the businesslike cool-headedness of American soldiers on Saipan against the "biggest and best" of the Japanese Army.

The gradual removal of the barrier against the employment of the physically handicapped has made available to industry millions of productive individuals, most of whom could be employed usefully and many of whom could develop higher skills than persons not handicapped, according to a report presented yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- A generally firm tone was seen in today's stock markets and business showed an increase in activity.
ROME, Nov. 30 (UP) -- A communique:

There are ample constitutional provisions empowering the President to arrange for the use of force against acts of aggression without specific Congressional action, Representative Emanuel Celler declared last night.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Friday, Dec. 1 -- With Thunderbolts skip-bombing for the first time, slim, swift United States fighter planes heavily damaged another Japanese convoy bound for Ormoc Bay Wednesday night and yesterday morning. They sank a 9,000-ton troop transport, two small freighter transports, set fire to a destroyer and a 5,000-ton cargo carrier.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 30 -- After nearly a decade of service in a post which he accepted originally "for a few months," Dr. Arnaud C. Marts has resigned the presidency of Bucknell University, effective in June, 1945. His successor may be named Dec. 16 when the trustees receive a recommendation from a special committee which has been at work since June, when the president submitted his resignation confidentially to the board.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed holdings of United States Government securities and note circulation for the system as a whole to have in creased $142,059.000 and $114,738,000, respectively, during the week. The ratio of reserve declined to 49.4, the lowest figure touched since March 15, 1933, when it was 49.1.

The American Negro Theatre, whence sprang "Anna Lucasta," is turning its attention these evenings to another play it hopes may wander down town from 135th Street. It is "Walk Hard." by Abram Hill, director of the theatre, and after an opening a couple of weeks ago, it invited a few Broadway friends for a formal visit last night.

One of the great advantages held by an army defending its own frontiers is that of supply. Every withdrawal or forced retreat simplifies the problem, as the army then is moving ever closer to its sources. Every mile of advance made by the attacker, on the other hand, takes him that much farther from the factories making his shells and cartridges and tanks, and stretches even thinner his often thin lines of supply.

There's no doubt any more about "Dear Ruth" settling down at Henry Miller's on Wednesday night, Dec. 13. It's now official. All of which means that the Miller's current tenant, "The Streets Are Guarded" (John C. Wilson's production of the Laurence Stallings play), will vacate the house on Dec. 9 after twenty-four performances.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- Mayor Theodore R. McKeldin today took official cognizance of wide-open "scalping" of the limited number of tickets available to civilians for Saturday's Army-Navy football game and suggested that the Bureau of Internal Revenue investigate this "obnoxious form of profiteering."

QUITE a few correspondents have written in to express their misgivings at the comparatively small amount of bonds which will be sold in connection with tomorrow's Army-Navy classic at Baltimore. Some even have gone to the extent of saying that the public and the press have been victims of a "fraud," a very harsh word by any measurement.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Shortage of ammunition forced Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower to hold up his general offensive just as the armies neared the Rhine, Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War, announced at a news conference today in making a plea for greater production.

A series of differences, reportedly dating back several months, between the Warner Brothers and the Hays office came to a climax yesterday when the film company notified Will H. Hays, president of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, Inc., of its intention to resign from both the MPPDA and the organization's Hollywood branch, the Motion Picture Producers Association.

The theft, piecemeal, of twelve carbines manufactured for the armed forces brought a six-month jail term yesterday to George Milton Warren, 52 years old, of Brewster, N.Y. Warren and Oscar Flagler Howell, 26, of Poughkeepsie, pleaded guilty in Federal court last June 26 to the charge of conspiracy to steal the weapons, but yesterday Howell failed to report for sentencing.

As a spur to the Sixth War Loan drive, New York City will see its first demonstration of air-borne attack, along the lines made familiar in the invasion of Normandy, at La Guardia Field this afternoon. Under the joint sponsorship of the War and Treasury Departments, the demonstration will be staged at 1:30 and 3:30 P.M. today, tomorrow and Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The House voted overwhelmingly today to renew the Administration's broad war powers, but put a string on its approval.

" We're still looking at the pictures of the Giant-Redskin game of last year," said Stout Steve Owen yesterday, "but about all I can say is that I know Sammy Baugh still throws with his right hand and kicks with his right foot."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Justice Department announced that President Roosevelt had dismissed Assistant Attorney General Norman M. Littell because of "insubordination."

Fruit markets are relatively well stocked this week, with tangerines in larger supply, and consequently cheaper than they have been all season. The "kid glove oranges," as they are sometimes called, because the skin is so easily removed, are arriving from Florida, where, despite the hurricane earlier this fall, the crop is slightly bigger than usual.

The deer season closed in New York State yesterday and today may well be called the official beginning of the sportsmen's oratory and group dining open season. That's because the annual convention of the New York State Conservation Council will be held at Bear Mountain starting at 9:30 o'clock this morning.

The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and its subsidiaries, including National Theatres Corporation and Roxy Theatre, Inc., reported yesterday for the thirty-nine weeks ended on Sept. 23, consolidated net profit of $9,487,929, equal to $4.67 each on the 1,742,840 shares of common stock outstanding.

CHUNGKING, China, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- Maj. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, United States Commanding General in China, told a press conference today that the situation in China "continues unfavorable to us," and added that the Japanese column driving from Kwangsi toward Kweichow was a "good, strong force, definitely indicating offensive possibilities."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Speculative operators in commercial real estate in New York City have raised rentals in some instances to a point where they will net 100 to 200 per cent annually on the cash invested, according to Joseph Platzker, assistant commissioner of the city's Department of Housing and Building and chairman of Mayor La Guardia's Committee on Rents.
OTTAWA, Nov. 30 -- The announcement by former Defense Minister J.L. Ralston last night that he would support the Government has considerably eased the Parliamentary situation today.

Timidity returned yesterday to the stock market when profit-taking appeared. The gusty confidence of the preceding session was lacking, and, although the rails. were again the center of interest, there was a definite hesitancy in the bidding.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 (AP) -The South Carolina Power Company, Charleston, S.C., and its parent, the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan for refinancing South Carolina.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Cleveland Plain Dealer said today that Robert R. Young and Allan P. Kirby, chairman and president of Alleghany Corporation, top holding company of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad, have acquired approximately 40 per cent interest in the Cleveland Terminal Building Company.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Office of Price Administration will start tomorrow a drive to enforce ceiling prices on used passenger automobiles.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- United States troops have killed at least 277,000 Japanese at a cost of 21,000 American fatalities, the Office of War Information revealed tonight in a report that said that Japan already had 4,000,000 men in the field and could comfortably equip and train an additional 2,000,000.

ALBANY, Nov. 30 -- Carl Sherman, treasurer of the Democratic State Committee, reported to the election bureau of the Secretary of State's office today that receipts in the recent campaign were $424,259 and disbursements $391,304, with $503,110 in loans yet to be paid, listed as follows:

Maj. Dean Ivan Lamb, 58 years old, recently retired intelligence aide in Maj. Gen. Claire Chennault's Flying Tigers in India; author, aviation pioneer and soldier of fortune when not a professional soldier in the last forty-three years, was arrested yesterday in the theft of $19,000 in rare jewelry belonging to a dealer in Agra, India.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 30 -- By unanimous vote, the annual convention of the American Federation of Labor decided today to request the International Federation of Trade Unions "to convene a world trade union conference of the free trade unions of the world at the earliest possible time."

An acute delivery situation in late February and March was foreseen yesterday on women's spring apparel. Easter comes eight days earlier than was the case this year, adding to the difficult situation facing manufacturers.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, United States Ninth Air Force, Nov. 30 -- The constant hammering of German railroads, the destruction of rolling stock, the blasting of tracks, and the destruction of bridges by fighter bombers of the United States Ninth Air Force have forced the Germans to extremes of improvisation to keep their faltering rail traffic flowing to the front.

DETROIT, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- About 4,000 employes of the Briggs Manufacturing Company's Mack Avenue plant struck today, halting production of aircraft subassemblies in the third major labor dispute here in twenty-four hours.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Congress seemed headed toward a veto fight with President Roosevelt today as the House Ways and Means Committee voted 17 to 7 to "freeze" the Social Security tax.
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

With 3,000,000 boys and girls between the ages of 14 and 17 now working, the question of adequate schooling for these minors becomes serious. From 1920 steadily through 1940 the number of employed children had dropped and high school enrollment increased. Since Pearl Harbor, however, attractive salaries have lured away many secondary school students.

Not choice but bleak necessity directs the retreat of the Germans from their last corner of France into the valley of the Saar. It will be a bitter battlefield for them, for it is one of the richest and most thickly populated regions of the Reich. Even now General Patton's Third Army is crowding them back from its borders toward Saar-bruecken.

A collection of original drawings and rare prints of comics assembled by the American Institute of Graphic Arts opens today at the New York Junior League Clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, and will remain until Dec. 16. The exhibition will be free to the public from 10 to 6 daily including Sundays.

A total of $20,805 in fines has been collected in the two weeks since the War Emergency Court was set up as a special part of Magistrates' Courts to try cases involving violation of Office of Price Administration regulations, it was announced last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- During the week ended Nov. 29 member bank reserve balances increased $42,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 30 (AP) -- President James Donn looked up at a cloudless sky today, noted a nip in the air and increased to 25,000 or more his estimate of the number of spectators who will be on hand tomorrow when horse racing returns to long-idle Gulfstream Park, marking the start of the Florida turf season.

A "highly imaginative" 13-year-old girl who likes to write poetry and her 7-year-old brother, reported missing since Tuesday, were back home yesterday at 60 Featherbed Lane, the Bronx, after financing their adventure by posing as "collectors" for the Red Cross.
LONDON, Nov. 30 (UP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

LONDON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Commodore William A. Sullivan, chief of naval salvage for the United States Navy, has received the honorary Commander Order of the British Empire for skillful handling of American and British salvage forces in the African, Sicilian and Salerno operations.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange increased slightly last month over previous month despite the several holidays, but the volume of business was less than it was in corresponding month in 1943. The turnover for the year to date, however, is the largest since 1939, with the exception of last year.

Your editorial of Nov. 22 "Modernizing Congress," concerning the work of the special House committee to investigate executive agencies, directs attention to a subject important now because of wartime governmental controls, and of probable future significance because of regulations necessitated by post-war problems.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 (AP) -- A Marine-Navy crew won by half a length from the Army today in the first race of its kind on the Schuylkill River.

All draft registrants up to 38 years old, who have been granted deferments as seamen in the merchant marine, but have since left the sea, must return to active sea duty or "they will promptly be reclassified 1-A and processed for immediate induction," Col. Arthur V. McDermott, City Selective Service Director, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- Noncombat soldiers in the United Kingdom will be able to smoke about one American cigarette every four hours on the basis of the new weekly ration, which will be set up in Army post exchanges next Monday.

Walter H. Bennett, chairman of the board of trustees of the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, who has been in the banking business here for fifty-seven years, will retire as chairman on Jan. 1, but will continue as a trustee and chairman of the executive committee and ex officio chairman of the investment committee.

ROME, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- The Fifth Army front blazed into action today with German troops, supported by a heavy concentration of armor and artillery, lashing out at American positions and forcing Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's troops to withdraw from three strategic positions south of Bologna.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- A communique from the Twentieth Air Force today describing last night's attack on Tokyo said that none of our aircraft had been lost from enemy action during the 3,100-mile round trip from Saipan to Tokyo and back.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- German bombing has not only revealed the traditional qualities of the British character but has brought to light hitherto unknown remains from Britain's historic past, it was announced today by the Ministry of Works.

Charges that the Army's lack of nurses could be traced to extravagant staffing of some civilian hospitals were denied yesterday by Dr. Morris Hinenburg, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, speaking for the ninety-two voluntary hospitals in this group.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- To the framers of United States high economic policy, and, it is hoped, to Congress and the general public as well, since lend-lease was instituted the following principles have been basic:

During the first 1945 quarter the tightest civilian goods supply situation since the beginning of the war will develop in the woolen and worsted piece goods field, industry spokesmen declared yesterday. This will be due to the over-all demands of the Government for the armed services and relief purposes, with the situation to be further aggravated by an extremely critical manpower situation, it was pointed out.

Six GI's, members of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's "ammunition envoy corps," assigned to this area, voiced the General's plea for increased ammunition production yesterday to reporters at a press conference in Army Public Relation Headquarters, 90 Church Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Dean Acheson, assistant Secretary of State, gave the House Subcommittee on Foreign Trade and Shipping today the first comprehensive picture from official sources of what this Administration proposes by way of international organization and action in the economic field after the war.
CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Nov. 30 (AP) -- Goin Steady, 4-year-old brown filly from the Groton Stables, won the feature race today in a five-horse photo finish and returned $50.20 for $2.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 30 (AP) -- The jinx of Memorial Stadium, where no Texas Aggie team ever has triumphed, worked again today and Bobby Layne led the Texas Longhorns to a 6-0 triumph before a howling throng of 43,000 that thrilled to a brilliant battle of vicious goal line stands.
PARIS, Nov. 30 -- The newspapers of Paris protested vehemently today against a reduction of the paper supply by 25 per cent, which, they say, is contemplated by the Ministry of Information.

A tight situation in the money market in New York City which almost reached the proportions of a squeeze developed in the week ended on Wednesday, according to statistics covering the positions of the sixteen reporting members of the Reserve System of this city, as released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

PARIS, Nov. 30 -- A summary of the financial position of the French Government, which has just been issued by Rene Pleven, Minister of Finance, showed clearly in broad lines today the problem that France faced in the immediate future as he began to try to overcome the inflationary consequences of German exactions.

ANTWERP (Delayed) -- An American Liberty ship and a British merchantman led a convoy of Allied ocean-going freighters that stretched across the English Channel into the docks here today and opened the port to the use of the Allied armies.

PARIS, Nov. 30 -- With two members of the Cabinet on the spot to investigate the explosion at Pertuis, it is expected that in a few days the Government, which has said little so far, may throw some light on the mystery around which a good deal of political propaganda revolves.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Bullish sentiment was strong today in the grain pits on the Board of Trade, July and September wheat selling at new high prices for the season, corn making a new high on the current movement and December rye, which has recently been showing independent weakness, going from 1 cent under May to a slight premium over that delivery.

Wrestling matches, black-face comedians, plays like "Tobacco Road" and Hollywood actresses selling kisses for war bonds reveal Americans as "barbarians," Goro Nakano, one-time New York correspondent of the Tokyo newspaper Asahi, told the Japanese people in a broadcast reported yesterday by the Office of War Information.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Churchill's statement in Commons today on lend-lease:

BRUSSELS, Nov. 30 -- Every truck in Belgium that will roll is to be pressed into service to meet the need of the Allied convoys now being unloaded in the port of Antwerp. This afternoon the Cabinet ordered the mobilization of civilian vehicles to supplement military transport.
A communique, as broadcast Wednesday from Tokyo and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of commodity prices at the primary market level has remained unchanged at 104.1 per cent of the 1926 average for three consecutive weeks. During the week ended on Nov. 25 slightly lower prices for farm products, particularly livestock, were offset by higher prices for grains, certain fruits, vegetables and scrap steel.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Prime Minister Churchill read to the House of Commons today a joint Anglo-American statement about the future of lend-lease and explained that for Britain it would make possible more and better food, release of manpower to produce increased civilian supplies, the building of more emergency houses with help from the United States and the rebuilding of British export trade "without which we cannot live."

Funeral services were held in the Universal Chapel at Fifty-first Street and Lexington Avenue yesterday for Charles Victor Bob, who had been a fabulous figure in American finance before the 1929 debacle.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 30 -- Unless the manpower shortage is solved very shortly, the number of workers permitted to be employed in non-essential industries as well as in war industries not on the urgent list will be sharply reduced, Charles M. Hay, deputy chairman and executive director of the War Manpower Commission in Washington, warned tonight.

The resolution adopted yesterday by the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, on the increasingly important subject of post-war military training, is careful to point out that its authors "are not here pronouncing judgment for or against conscription." They would leave that question to a later day.
Mrs. Widener Dixon of Chestnut Hill, Pa., has come to the Savoy-Plaza.

LONDON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Leslie Hore-Belisha, former Secretary of State for War, urged the House of Commons today to consider "an offer by Belgium to give us some kind of strategic outposts and economic outposts as well, similar to those we gave the United States in the West Indies."
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 30 -- The Federal Council of Churches of Christ of America at its biennial meeting asked today that Congress delay action on peacetime military conscription until after the war.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- With an indirect appeal for application of the principles of the Atlantic Charter in Poland's quarrel with the Soviet Union, a new Polish Cabinet-in-Exile took office here today under leadership of a champion of Polish independence, elderly Tomasz Arciszewski.

Shortly before Mme. Chiang Kai-shek departed from Chungking on her present trip to the United States, Generalissimo Chiang and his wife met in Chungking with a group that included all the members of the Generalissimo's Cabinet, as well as a number of Americans.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 1 -- Russian troops yesterday captured the strategic Hungarian communications centers of Eger and Szikszo, northeast of Budapest, virtually encircled the great fortress city of Miskolc and expanded their new Danube bridgehead in western Hungary to 104 miles.

STRASBOURG, France, Nov. 30 -- Four and a half years of intensive Germanization of this capital of Alsace have made it externally purely a German town but have failed to win the Alsatians for the Reich.

Women shoppers want information about products that help them conserve in wartime, Dr. Walter Gaw of the Committee on Consumer Relations in Advertising, said yesterday. Citing a survey conducted by the committee at the instigation of Dr. Kenneth Dameron, its director, Dr. Gaw told members of the consumer education course sponsored jointly by the Board of Education and the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office the importance of educational material furnished by manufacturers to help the consumer.

The opening of the new session of Parliament this week took place under certain physical limitations. The debating chamber of the House of Commons, wrecked by an enemy bomb in 1940, cannot be used. Hence the Commons meet in the chamber normally occupied by the House of Lords and the Lords meet in the Robing Chamber.
LONDON, Nov. 30 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

One can well understand the indignation of the tolerant Mayflower Pilgrims, voiced by Ruth Lord Jenkins in THE TIMES of Nov. 28, at being classified with the intolerant Massachusetts Bay Puritans who came after Thanksgiving Day had been established at Plymouth (1621), and who did not make it an annual festival until about 1680, though they had celebrated it intermittently since 1630.
The American position in the Philippines was gradually improving yesterday despite bad weather, tenacious Japanese resistance and continued enemy air attacks.
KANDY, Ceylon, Nov. 30 (AP) -- A communique:

Denounced by the prosecutor as a traitor to his country and by the court as a former member of the Ku Klux Klan, the German-American Bund and other subversive groups, Edwin P. Banta, the 73-year-old pretended "patriotic investor,'' was sentenced yesterday to an indeterminate term up to three years in the penitentiary.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- More than 3,000 American and British bombers and fighters bombed and set fire to seven important oil plants in Germany today, but after the day's operations fifty-six American bombers and thirty fighters were listed as missing.

ROANOKE, Va., Nov. 30 (AP) -- The University of Maryland defeated Virginia Military Institute, 8 -- 6, in the anuual Thanksgiving game played at Victory Stadium today for its first triumph of the season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -Chief Justice Edward C. Eicher of theI Federal District Court, aged 65,] who presided over the mass sedition trial for the more than seven months since it began in April, died of a heart attack in his sleep last night or early this morning.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 30 -- The creation of a joint planning committee representing major Jewish organizations in the UnitedStates to present post-war needs before the United Nations and other international conferences and councils was recommended today by the World Jewish Congress at its war emergency conference, here.

In a message addressed to foreign workers in the Ruhr, Rhenish-Westphalian and Rhineland areas of Germany, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's headquarters yesterday asked that they "go into hiding'' as the battle approached them but in leaving the towns or villages in which they lived to "be sure to keep off the roads."

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Two Members of Parliament, Hamilton W. Kerr and Ronald L. Tree, who want to visit Paris, received considerable sympathy from fellow-members in the House of Commons today, but they failed to move Herbert Morrison, Home Secretary, from his decision that their journey was not really necessary.

The 2,200-ton superdestroyer Beatty, named in honor of the late Rear Admiral Frank Edmund Beatty, United States Navy, was launched in a heavy rainstorm yesterday at the Bethlehem Steel and Shipbuilding Company's yard at Mariners Harbor, S.I., in the presence of 100 invited guests and high-ranking naval officers, including Rear Admiral Frank E. Beatty, son of the late rear admiral and commander of all forces, Aruba-Curacao, in the West Indies.
Douglas M. Black has been elected chairman of the committee on buildings and grounds of the board of trustees of Columbia University to succeed Edmund A. Prentis.

The zoning amendments sponsored by the City Planning Commission, imposing additional height and area restrictions on all new buildings throughout the city, except those in general business or unrestricted districts, will become effective tomorrow as the result of action taken yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
ADVANCE HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Friday, Dec. 1 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The calendar said that Winston Churchill was 70 years old today and like all 70-year-olds in Britain he became entitled to an extra ounce of tea in his weekly ration. But politically and intellectually, as Lawrence Hunt, an American lawyer, wrote in The Daily Telegraph this morning, he "still remains a young man with a bright future."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Children's books were put high as an investment in happy childhood in a pamphlet, "For the Children's Bookshelf," issued today by the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor.

I read with keen interest your editorial approving the removal of our temporary defense housing en masse to Europe to relieve the post-war housing shortage in liberated areas and bombed England. However, your opinion that such defense housing units will have served their purpose here in the United States by-passes a serious housing situation now confronting farmers through past and present Congressional muddling.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today set Dec. 20 for a hearing to determine whether there has been a willful violation of the registration provisions of Section 5 of the Securities Act of 1933 by Ira Haupt Co., New York, and whether, if so, the firm should be suspended or expelled from the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., and its registration as a broker and dealer revoked.
