Figures were produced yesterday to explain the action of the Securities and Exchange Commission in suspending trading in the securities of the Elastic Stop Nut Corporation following the suicide of its president, William T. Hedlund.

The high winds that followed yesterday's rain caused so great a sway in the flambeau atop the right arm of Times Square's model of the Statue of Liberty that an emergency crew of six electricians worked for several hours last evening to reinforce the torch with heavy wire cable.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 25 were 768,730 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 95,643 cars, or 11.1 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, 51,102 cars, or 6.2 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 25,266 cars, or 3.4 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Consumer income of $131,000,000,000 in 1945 was forecast today by Dr. J. Frederic Dewhurst of New York, economist, in an address before the special wartime conference of the American Marketing Association.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- No. 1 item of the major league joint meeting on Dec. 13 in New York will be the replacement of the late Kenesaw Mountain Landis as commissioner of baseball, but the two circuits also will give special attention to the problem of players returning from military service.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- American assistance in helping Great Britain rebuild her export trade and a 43 per cent reduction in lend-lease aid to that country after the defeat of Germany are provided for under terms of the lend-lease agreement for the "second" phase of the war.
LONDON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Note circulation, as reported by the Bank of England in its weekly statement, reached a new peak of 1,189,525,000, a rise of 9,100,000 over the previous week.
Early hesitancy followed by a fair rally and a subsequent sell-off featured trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

The third wettest November on record blustered to a close amid snow flurries yesterday as winds reaching fifty-seven miles an hour swept the metropolitan area, disrupting railroad, ferry and air services. The tempestuous weather, the Weather Bureau predicted last night, would continue in strong to gale strength until some time today.

PARIS, Nov. 30 -- Fresh from Moscow and making his first speech in liberated France on the eve of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's arrival in the Russian capital, Maurice Thorez, French Communist leader, tonight called on his fellow-countrymen to form a "National Union at the side of our Allies to win the war and to reconstruct France."

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 30 -- The Nutrition Foundation, Inc., of New York, granted $127,750 for nineteen research projects in nutrition at universities and medical centers throughout the country at the annual meeting of its board of trustees today, according to George A. Sloan, president of the foundation.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Communique 236:

First performances of new works and a striking perspective of tendencies of the contemporaneous English school of composition were afforded by the all-British program given by Dr. Rodzinski and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Casualties for the armed forces of the United States have reached 536,950. From Pearl Harbor through Nov. 15 Army casualties were 461,058, Secretary Stimson said today. This was an increase of 6,878 in one week from Nov. 7.

Although dollar holdings of Indian exporters which have resulted from India's favorable balance of trade with the United States have been converted into sterling under "compulsion," India's creditor position will enable that country to be a good post-war market for American goods, Sir Chunilal B. Mehta, a director of the Reserve Bank of India and former president of the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry, declared last night.

The first performance of the season of "Aida" at the Metropolitan last night was, on the whole, a disappointing affair and one which reflects little credit on our leading opera company. As the most-often-performed opera at the Metropolitan, "Aida" deserves a production that is up to Metropolitan standards and in keeping with the Metropolitan tradition.

Winter resort styles, as we note by our favorite fashion page, are emphasizing the Chinese motif. From the book pages we gather, on the other hand, that the Henry James revival, which for some time has been under way, continues to gather force.

Reflecting the purposes for which much of the recent large new financing was issued, bonds called for payment in November before maturity aggregated $380,207,000, the largest monthly total since April, 1941, when $392,273,000 was redeemed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Office of Price Administration authorized today a 9.18 per cent increase in producers' ceiling prices for terry cloth products, huck and crash towels, and corded napkins in an action designed to bring these maximums into conformity with standards established in the Stabilization Act of 1944.

Miss Midori Satomi, member of the first Japanese-American family to take up residence, under sponsorship of the War Relocation Authority, at the New York Relocation Hostel, 168 Clinton Street, Brooklyn, will be married at 4 P.M. tomorrow to another Japanese-American, Dr. Irving Isao Odo, a native of Honolulu, Hawaii, and a resident dentist of the Sea View Hospital, Staten Island.

Strong faith in the "unity of the Americas," which he believes will be a "constructive aid to the organization of the peace" was expressed yesterday by Juan Carlos Blanco, Uruguay's Ambassador to the United States, when interviewed in his suite at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

PEARL HARBOR, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz's communique reported today that 1.300 fanatically resisting Japanese troops have been killed on Peleliu Island in the southern Palaus from Oct. 20 to Nov. 26 as doughboys of the Army's Eighty-first Division continue to dig out starving enemy remnants from entrenched positions in caves.
WITH UNITED STATES NINTH ARMY, in the Netherlands, Nov. 30 -- Netherland underground leaders disclosed today how a chubby-checked 2-year-old boy foiled three dozen Gestapo agents with two words.

Indications are that the sale of around $53,000,000 of new bonds by the Louisville Nashville Railroad will be among the first large pieces to be financed after the start of the year. The company is expected to file with the Interstate Commerce Commission on Dec. 15 a plan to carry out its refunding operation.

No basic change can be expected in toy production until V-E day, Carl Hedstrom Jr., president of the Toy Manufacturers of the U.S.A., said yesterday at the annual meeting of the organization at the Hotel McAlpin. He added that, while a large segment of the industry has been busy on war production, "more toys have been produced than was thought possible by the most optimistic two years ago."

War Bonds kill Japs. Dead Japs can't kill any more Ameri cans -- Americans who may be from your own home. Do you want any better self-interest reason for buying all the extra War Bonds you can possibly find money for above the bare cost of living necessities?

The second regional War Labor Board has set Dec. 15 as the deadline for employers' applications for permission to pay Christmas or year-end bonuses so that they may be acted upon in time for timely payment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- The Navy tonight revealed the names of four United States escort carriers damaged during the second battle of the Philippines as the Calinin Bay, the Fanshaw Bay. the White Plains and the Kitkun Bay.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- In a debate with Lord Swinton, British chairman, Mayor La Guardia of New York, a member of the American delegation, persuaded the International Civil Aviation Conference in plenary session tonight to make a final effort to reach a more complete agreement on post-war aviation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Army and Navy have found no evidence to justify a court-martial of Maj. Gen. Walter C. Short and Rear Admiral Husband E. Kimmel, commanders at Pearl Harbor, Dec. 7, 1941, Secretary Stimson and Secretary Forrestal revealed today.

Four of the thirty-seven meat companies, said to be responsible for black market prices on corned beef and tongue in delicatessen stores and all of whom are being sued by the Office of Price Administration for nearly $5,000,000 in treble damages, were convicted yesterday afternoon before Magistrate Jenkin R. Hockert in Long Island City Magistrate's Court of charges of violating ceiling prices on kosher corned beef and tongue.

Sylvan D. Broder, 51 years old, president and treasurer of Vitaplus, Inc., at 110 West Fortieth Street, and the corporation itself, were found guilty yesterday in their seventeen-day Special Sessions trial for using misleading advertising over the radio and by other means in the sale of a tablet they represented would decrease gasoline consumption in automobiles by from 20 to 39 per cent.

PARIS, Dec. 1 (AP) - Congress must start immediate consideration at its next session of compulsory military training legislation to raise a percentage Army of 1,000,000 men to help police Europe, Representative Overton Brooks of Louisiana said today.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 1 -- The Army-Navy game, football's most glittering spectacle, returns tomorrow as a public offering in a metropolitan setting for the first time since America's entry into the war.

With 170 bluebloods showing, the twenty-eighth Championship Cat Show opened yesterday in the Hotel Capitol. It was the largest show the Empire Cat Club, Inc., ever held here. But the preponderance of feline aristocrats did not faze Corporal Gussie, mere alley cat, who was hostess of the show.
KANDY, Ceylon, Dec. 1 (AP) -- A communique:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) - Pacific Fleet communique 194:

The first step in the post-war program of co-operation between the wholesale grocery trade and the Department of Commerce will be to make the National Wholesale Food Industry Advisory Committee permanent, it was learned yesterday.
DUBLIN, Dec. 1 -- Eire gave a practical indication of her sympathy with the distressed people of Italy when the Dail Eireann tonight voted 100,000 [$400,000] toward their relief.

Reporting on operations of the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation for its fiscal year ended with September, George W. Mason, president, informed stockholders yesterday that its deliveries of war products reached a record total of $274,436,332, an increase of $89,499,970 over the previous year, but earnings declined.

A ten-fold increase in price-maintenance within five years after the surrender of Germany was predicted yesterday by John W. Scott, retiring president of the American Fair Trade Council, at the annual meeting of that organization in the Hotel Roosevelt. His prediction, he said, was based on the large number of requests for information received by his office since "it became evident that the war in Europe was drawing to a close."

Just before 11 o'clock, two nights ago, Brother Lawrence, a robed figure, bent over a book in a pool of light in the darkened vestibule in the Franciscan Monastery in Thirty-first Street east of Seventh Avenue, heard the street door open and felt cold wind rush in.

A gay, pre-war France is recreated by Theodore Pratt, author of "Mr. Winkle Goes to War" and "Thunder Mountain," in "Perils of Provence," published Thursday by Duell, Sloan Pearce. Mr. Pratt writes of the four years he and his wife spent in the Mediterranean countries in the early Thirties.

Marvin Jones, War Food Administrator, has signed an order barring sales to civilians of all chickens produced and processed in the Delaware-Maryland-Virginia area until the Army has obtained 110,000,000 pounds for fighting men and casualties in hospitals and recuperation camps, the New York office of WFA announced last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Edward R. Stettinius Jr. took the oath of office as Secretary of State his afternoon and immediately afterward as his first official act issued a statement in which he appealed for the support of all people in the making of a peace that would endure.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Business in the stock markets today was on a small scale. A few industrial shares hardened in response to Prime Minister Winston Churchill's statement regarding changes in the lend-lease agreement with the United States which will help British exports, but generally there was not much activity.

LONDON, Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- Gerald Barry, editor of The London News Chronicle, charged today that Allied Army authorities had been responsible for the spread of a false "atrocity" story relating how four German youngsters were caught sniping at American soldiers.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- A short unhappy life is widely predicted for the new Polish Cabinet under Tomasz Arciszewski, Socialist elder statesman. The Cabinet held its first meeting today and began its labors without the blessing of the British Government which had been the main support of the Polish Government-in-exile here.

Unceasingly our own Air Force and the RAF hammer at the Nazi enemy with every weapon in the airman's arsenal. The spectacular raids with heavy bombers, aimed especially at the oil refineries and storage depots and the railroad marshaling yards of the Reich are clearly understandable to the layman as a means of breaking down the enemy's ability to make war.

The report of Controller Frank C. Moore discloses a surplus of $94,098,264.64 for the fiscal year ending March 31, and his last report states that some sources estimate that the surplus for the current fiscal year will reach $100,000,000, in spite of a decrease of $29,825,000 in motor fuel and other taxes which, the Controller said, were undoubtedly caused by the war.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 1 (AP) -- One thousand Japanese are hemmed in by Chinese forces surrounding the little Burma town of Bhamo, it was disclosed here tonight.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- A shipload of German troops was left struggling in icy northern seas this week when British Fleet Air Arm planes set fire to a troop transport in which the soldiers were being carried home from Norway, and smashed ten other vessels.

LONDON, Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- The question of why "ham actors" and American members of Congress may go to France while Members of Parliament must stay home boiled angrily in the House of Commons again today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The texts of the Navy and Army Department statements on the Pearl Harbor inquiry are as follows:
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The views of thousands of British housewives have been considered in the planning of the permanent houses to be built by the Government after the war.

In those other days whose memories return so often, when you built your house you set a hitching post at the curb. If you had any friends rich enough to own a horse and buggy, and they came to see you, they tied the horse and came in. In this progressive age they drive up in their car, blow the horn and wait in luxury for you to come out to them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Reconversion to civilian production in areas including more than 126 cities was halted abruptly today for a ninety-day period by a Government order, drastically modifying the program for a gradual return of parts of the country's war plant to civilian manufacture.

ROME, Dec. 1 -- Faced by the realization that the prolonged political crisis was discrediting Italy with the Allies and causing a dangerous paralysis internally within the country. Ivanoe Bonomi announced today that he would try to form a government.

BOSTON, Dec. 1 -- American armies are short 40 per cent in the items they need for war because thousands of workers are abandoning war production for unessential industries and manufacturers are turning to peacetime products, Lieut. Gen. Brehon Somervell, commanding general of the Army Service Forces, declared here tonight.

Metropolitan youth discussed the world's post-war problems yesterday at the second joint Secondary School Conference, held at International House, 500 Riverside Drive. And they agreed unanimously that they wanted permanent peace and security for all the peoples of the world, although they weren't quite sure how these aims could be achieved.

LONDON, Dec. 1 (AP) - Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels tonight ordered the German people to cease all public discussion of the war situation, saying the ban was necessary "to conceal from the enemy Germany's shortcomings."

Maj. Dean Ivan Lamb, 58 years old, who, up to his retirement because of age in 1943, had been attached to Maj. Gen. Claire Chennault's Flying Tigers in India as intelligence aide, entered a not- guilty plea yesterday in General Sessions to an indictment in the alleged theft of $19,000 in rare jewelry owned by a dealer in Agra, India.

High winds continued to sweep the New York area yesterday for the second day as temperatures for the most part remained in the low 30's and high 20's to give New Yorkers their first taste of winter weather. Relief was seen for tomorrow, which is expected to be fair and slightly warmer, with moderate winds.

WITH AMERICAN THIRD ARMY in Germany, Nov. 29 (delayed) -- Members of the German home army captured at Metz revealed that medical examination of men inducted had been dispensed with and German Army medical officers "offered no objection to physical defects," they said.

The Standard Gas and Electric Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended with September net income of $5,776,324, against $5,968,820 for the corresponding period of the preceding year. Consolidated gross operating revenues increased $6,124,468, or 5.53 per cent, to $116,891,352.

Trading in cotton futures yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange largely involved transactions etween houses evening up the December position, and final prices were unchanged to 4 points lower on the day. The market started with gains of 4 to 6 points on a little trade covering, but a little liquidation carried prices down again.

The college basketball season will get going in high speed tonight, when five games will be available to local followers of the court sport. Columbia, St. John University, City College, New York University and Brooklyn College all have action listed for their home courts.

Conflicting opinions as to whether a "racial problem" really exists in the district around City College, Convent Avenue and 138th Street, were voiced yesterday at the college and in the community surrounding.
Yesterday communique, as transmitted in English by the Japanese Domei agency to North America and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

With early Christmas shopping producing record volume for the month, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores in November rose 15 per cent over the like month of last year, according to a survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Twelve Office of Price Administration suits to compel toy dealers to comply with OPA regulations came before Federal Judge John Bright yesterday. In eight cases injunctions were granted by consent of the defendants, one motion for an injunction was withdrawn, one was granted by the court and one was denied.

NEARLY forty years ago the Tory candidate for North Manchester was A.J. Balfour, a very superior person. "Simply to break the monotony of his routine," he gave a fifteen-minute interview to Chaim Weizmann, a Russian Jew who was then teaching chemistry in Manchester. Why, he asked Weizmann, were the Zionists so opposed to the offer of Uganda?

The strange case of the vanished cigar was overlooked by Dr. Watson in his Sherlock Holmes memoirs, for the reason, we assume, that it did not arise until the late autumn of 1944. In any event, one reader is not satisfied with a statement quoted in this column the other day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Liberated industrial plants in France, Belgium and the Netherlands will be swung into action to supplement American factories in supplying the tremendous needs of our advancing armed forces in the European theatre, James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization and Reconversion, disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The War Production Board reported today that requirements for industrial alcohol for 1945 would approximate 548,000,000 gallons of 190-proof alcohol, comfortably below a potential supply of 594,000, 000 gallons.

The first Negro telephone operators to be engaged by the New York Telephone Company will report to work "in the next few days," it was announced yesterday by a spokesman for the company. The announcement followed publication of a Washington dispatch quoting Malcolm Ross, chairman of the President's Committee on Fair Employment Practices, as saying that hiring of the Negro operators grew out of complaints filed with the committee.
The best way to observe the defeat of Hitler is to buy an ex tra war bond. In thousands upon thousands of American homes today there is pride and sadness.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Dec. 1 -- The weightiest argument that could be advanced for increased production of all types of ammunition by the American war industry is the total number of casualties suffered by the four American Armies participating in the present offensive on the western front.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 1 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has named John Hodiak for the lead in the proposed screen operetta, "The Kissing Bandit." In the top singing role will be Marion Bell, a protege of Robert Z. Leonard, who will make her debut in the recently completed "Ziegfeld Follies. "
DETROIT, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Strikes continued tonight to keep closed two Detroit war plants and part of a third, making more than 11,000 workers idle.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Doubling of trade in the post-war period, bright prospects for 1945 and the likelihood of Government subsidies were predicted today for United States export business by Franklin Johnston, publisher of American Exporter, in an address in the closing session of the American Marketing Association's wartime conference.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- President Roosevelt was asked today to intervene in the deadlock between Great Britain and the Hebrew people over the question of Palestine immigration in an appeal addressed to him by the Hebrew Committee of National Liberation here.

AT TWENTY-FIRST ARMY GROUP HEADQUARTERS, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler now probably has about 6,000,000 troops to wage the climactic battle of Germany, including about 1,250,000 really fit men between the ages of 19 and 46, according to the best available information here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- An assertion that the advances in commercial rent sin the past year had averaged not more than 10 per cent in cities where increases had occurred was made by Herbert U. Nelson, executive vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, in testimony before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The greatest battleship ever built in the British Isles, destined to play a role in the Pacific war against the Japanese, has just been launched by Princess Elizabeth, it was announced tonight.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1 -- A southbound passenger plane of the Transcontinental and Western Airlines suddenly lost altitude this morning and fell, breaking several high tension wires and tearing through the tops of trees for more than a block in the Van Nuys district, near hear.

The eleven-story loft building at 34 Hubert Street and the five-story warehouse at 79 to 101 Laight Street covering the entire block bounded by West, Washington, Hubert and Laight Streets have been sold by Herbert A. Wolff, trustee, to an investing client of Adams Co., brokers.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company sold the four-story dwelling on a lot 16 by 100.5 feet at 461 East Fifty-seventh Street, near Sutton Place, to Mrs. William F. Kraemer for occupancy. Douglas L. Elliman Co. were the brokers.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- The Chinese press today expressed alarm over the enemy advance in south China and called for Allied landings on the coast to divert the Japanese drive.

Sales of gold and silver at levels far above the official prices in the United States have been reported in many parts of the area extending from Egypt to India for many months and at times have given rise to certain misunderstandings, according to the monthly review of credit and business conditions of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

ST. AVOLD, France, Dec. 1 -- A German officer who was captured while trying to hold a part of the Maginot Line as his battalion was falling about him told today what it meant to be on the losing side with the hard-hitting, fast-moving American Third Army on his heels.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Charges that Arnold Joerns and four former associates of Resources Corporation International defrauded investors of $7,350,000 were dismissed today by Federal Judge Elwyn R. Shaw at the second trial of the five defendants.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 1 -- The World Jewish Congress ended its war emergency conference here today with the adoption of a program designed to safeguard everywhere the rights of religious and racial minorities regardless of race or creed.

Asserting that a general salary increase for all New York City teachers is impossible at this time without Federal aid, James Marshall, Manhattan member of the Board of Education, recommended yesterday that school leaders work toward the principle of a "single salary schedule" for instructors on all levels of the system.

Success of current War Production Board programs for the manufacture of low-priced women's and children's apparel under M-385 will depend on adequate supervision by that agency to guard against abuses in the ultimate use of the cotton-piece goods allotted, Worth Street textile men asserted yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Americans like plain-speaking and ought to get more of it from the British, two members of Parliament declared today as one of them put his advice into practice by asserting that "America never has been 100 per cent in the war, as we have."

The French General Leclerc cast a shadow over a fine war record this week by announcing that for every French soldier killed in Strasbourg by snipers or guerrillas he would execute five German hostages. Among the hostages were some prisoners of war, so that General Leclerc was in danger of violating the rules of war on two counts.

WITH AMERICAN FIRST ARMY, in Germany, Dec. 1 -- Few days in the American First Army's campaign inside Germany have seen harder fighting than today, and few have brought less result. The First Army front remains deadlocked tonight, despite bitter efforts by our men in and around a dozen villages where the Germans are still contesting every yard.
LONDON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 1 (AP) -The directors of Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey's Circus, Inc., have approved the plan prepared and submitted by a special committee of the Hartford County Bar Association for settlement of claims against the circus resulting from the fire here on July 6.

STRASBOURG, France, Dec. 1 -American bazookas went to work on barricaded apartment houses forming the core of resistance in the German bridgehead across the Rhine here this afternoon after an all-night battle in which the Germans gradually were pressed back toward the northern tip of the dockyard sliver between the Bassin de Commerce and the Bassin de l'Industrie.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- An appeal for American support of the Spanish Republicans' intended attempt to re-establish the Republic in Spain by peaceful methods was made at a news conference here today by Diego Martinez Barrio, former President of Spain.

A delightful and moving performance of Puccini's "Boheme" took place last night in the Metropolitan Opera House. Not in seasons had the opera been given there with a like degree of vivacity, freshness of feeling and variety in characterization.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Saturday, Dec. 2 -- A series of violent Japanese suicide attacks has been made on the south end of the Ormoc corridor near Palanas, headquarters announced today. Elements of the Seventh Division with chattering guns repelled the hopeless Japanese attempts to break out of the corridor, inflicting heavy losses.
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted in English by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Winging into La Guardia Field at 135 miles an hour against the hazards of a steady wind that at times reached a velocity of fifty miles an hour, an Army pilot demonstrated yesterday the delicate "snatch pickup" of a glider which, except for an emergency, would rarely have been undertaken in a combat theatre with the type of weather conditions prevailing.

Architects filed yesterday numerous plans for new buildings and alterations to existing ones in a continuance of the rush to get the plans on the record under the present regulations. The projects include three apartment houses to cost a total of $420,000.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Notre Dame's Fighting Irish, defeated only by Army and Navy, will be trying for their first victory in four wartime meetings with Great Lakes in the season finale for both teams here tomorrow.

The rabies "scare" -- it was nothing else -- seems to be petering out, but the Mayor's and the Health Board's asinine regulations seem still to govern police action. The police cannot help that, although, as is usual in the case of hysterical action higher up, they are beginning to use discretion.

PARIS, Dec. 1 -- Shudders repeatedly ran through the audience crowding the Paris Court of Justice this afternoon as twelve Frenchmen were accused of deeds of horror outdoing even those of the German Gestapo, for whom they had worked.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Official "conversations" of the last few days may lead to the appointment of William L. Clayton, retiring Director of Surplus War Property Disposal, as Assistant Secretary of State in charge of foreign economic matters.
I received a summons for letting my dog out without a leash and was advised to take it to the A.S.P.C.A. for a rabies test before appearing in court.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Nine large railroads and several small ones operating lines in New Jersey paid today their 1944 main stem, local and franchise taxes to send $21,939,046 into the State treasury.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- Mark Fry of the famous Oakland golfing brothers, knocked three strokes off par today to take first-round honors in the fourteenth annual $14,500 San Francisco open golf tournament, posting a brilliant 69 after the skies cleared following a morning of heavy and steady rain.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 2 -- Red Army mechanized forces yesterday drove to within ninety-one miles of the Austrian border in a fifteen-mile sweep through western Hungary that carried them to within one and one-half miles of the strategic railroad linking Budapest with Zagreb and northern Italy.

Milk being among the most valuable foods, it is encouraging to learn from a report just issued by the National Dairy Council that our taste for it in simple fluid form is developing rapidly. Consumption has increased to the greatest extent in our history since 1941.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 1 -- An improved stethoscope designed to pick up every sound made by the human body and a new class of therapeutically active ferrihemochromogens are among the 567 inventions listed as patented in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Dec. 1 -- Columns on the left and in the center of Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's American Third Army battle line are biting into the rich industrial area of the Saar Valley and the battle for this region, second only to the Ruhr area in German economy, has begun.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Sale of all securities of the Glacier Production Company, Butte, Mont., to the American Power and Light Company, owned by Glacier's parent, the Montana Power Company, Butte, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Collectors of American Art will hold their final members' open house reception at the gallery, 106 East Fifty-seventh Street, from 5 to 7 o'clock tomorrow. All persons registered on or before this date will participate in the Christmas distribution of works of art. Charles Z. Offin, editor of "Pictures on Exhibit," will be guest of honor and will speak on "Art in Pocket Editions."

Because it may be necessary to dip into reserve stocks of food fats for industrial purposes unless the household fat salvage campaign meets the goals set for it, full responsibility for fat salvage has been transferred from the War Production Board to the War Food Administration, the Office of War Information announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- After two weeks of debate, the Senate passed by voice vote today and sent to conference the bill authorizing $1,000,000,000 for post-war flood control on the country's streams, reclamation and irrigation projects and hydroelectric power developments.

Argentina's Mighty Menichelli, yclept Fernando, made his New York debut last night at St. Nicholas Arena in a ten-round bout against Johnny White, Jersey City Negro heavyweight. While it was more an artistic than a competitive success, Menichelli, fighting valiantly in his awkward way against a bigger foe, earned a draw in the official ballot, which was split three ways.

Motor vehicle administrators of this area, who met here recently in their Eastern conference, are troubled by the continuing high traffic accident rate in the face of reduced automobile usage. They are particularly troubled by the growing hazards to pedestrians which the records reveal. The 1943 figures show that 9,700 pedestrians were killed and 295,000 injured, out of totals of 23,400 persons killed and 800,000 injured in all motor accidents.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The German High Command threatened tonight to abandon international rules of warfare as the result of what it charged was "increasing infringements of international law by our enemies."

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Denying that Britain had issued a "veto" on the inclusion of Count Sforza in the Italian Cabinet, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden charged in the House of Commons today that the former Minister Without Portfolio had worked against the Italian Government ever since it was formed under former Premier Ivanoe Bonomi.

Victor Payne-Jennings and Barney Klawans will produce "Happily Ever After," a comedy written by Donald Kirkley, drama critic of The Baltimore Sun, in collaboration with Howard Burman, Variety correspondent. Gene Lockhart, film actor, and his wife Kathleen have been lined up for the leading roles.

On the scent of a title they didn't dare hope for up to a couple of weeks ago, the Giants yesterday got in their last hard licks of preparation for tomorrow's crucial game with the Redskins at the Polo Grounds.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Army and Navy decisions against court martial proceedings or publication of findings on Pearl Harbor started wide Congressional discussion today.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 1 (AP) -A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Mayor La Guardia promised last night to "invoke all the powers I have as Mayor" to protect the health of the city's school children if leaders of the School Custodial Workers Union, an affiliate of the United Mine Workers of America, make good their threat to call a strike of 2,500 custodial workers in the city's 768 elementary and high schools this morning.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 30 (Delayed) -- More than 100,000 persons, more than half the population of the city, greeted Dr. Chaim Weizmann when he visited Tel Aviv today for the first time since arriving in Palestine two weeks ago. The demonstration was the greatest welcome ever given to anyone in Tel Aviv.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that department store sales showed an increase of 17 per cent for the week of Nov. 25 in Comparison to the corresponding period of last year. Percentage changes for indicated periods are listed in the following table:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Immediate investigation by the Federal Trade Commission of the cigarette shortage among civilians and members of the armed services was urged upon the commission today by Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana, chairman of the Committee on Interstate Commerce.

Spurred by the arrival of freezing weather, Government and industry leaders made a hasty survey yesterday of New York's fuel situation. They found that there was an adequate supply of coal and other solid fuels and probably enough household heating oil and kerosene, but that the outlook for gasoline and the heavy, residual fuel oils used by industry was far from bright.

Joseph I. Breen has been designated a vice president of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, Inc., and has had his contract extended for another three years, it was learned yesterday. Mr. Breen also will continue as administrator of the organization's production code, which he has directed since its inception in 1934.

Leslie Horvath of Parma, Ohio, who carried Ohio State to the Western Conference football championship with his feats as a ground-gainer and field general, was the choice of the nation's sports writers and radio broadcasters for the Heisman Memorial Trophy for 1944, according to Chairman Bill Prince of the Downtown Athletic Club's committee handling the votes.

Indications that Murray Frischling might have committed suicide on Nov. 29, 1943, were challenged yesterday by a Federal grand jury. The grand jury handed up an indictment accusing Frischling, who was president of a chain of dairies called Frischlings Farmery, 2331 Twelfth Avenue, and four other men, for an alleged conspiracy to possess illegally large quantities of food ration coupons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Senate Military Affairs Committee held a hearing today on the nominations of Lieut. Col. Edward Heller and Robert A. Hurley, former Governor of Connecticut, to be members of the Surplus Property Board, but deferred a vote to a date to be fixed at a meeting Tuesday.
LONDON, Dec. 1 (UP) -- A communique, as broadcast from Berlin:

Those who read carefully Secretary Stimson's Thursday statement on the supply situation on the Western Front, or those who this morning read Lieut. Gen. Brehon Somervell's address, made yesterday in Boston, will realize that some degree of responsibility for the length of the war and the number of resulting casualties rests on every citizen able to work and on every citizen able to buy war bonds.

Great victories have been scored in the Pacific. The Japanese Navy has been whittled down to a size that leaves it no longer a major menace. Our forces in the Far East are in a position to bring any point of the Japanese Empire under air attack, either by B-29's flying from land bases or Navy planes flying from carrier decks.

The Old Dutch Mustard Company, present occupant under lease, has purchased the commercial property at 60 to 90 Metropolitan Avenue, Brooklyn, from the 80 Metropolitan Avenue Corporation. The property, which has a frontage of 250 feet, includes a six-story factory building with several onestory connecting structures and is assessed at $86,000. Frank R. Fischer was the broker.

OTTAWA, Dec. 1 -- The opposition of French Canada to the principle of conscription remained firm today. The Quebec Provincial Government has passed an order-in-council which has been sent to Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King urging the Federal Government to respect and fulfill its past engagements and pledges that it would not send drafted men overseas.

Surrogate James A. Delehanty yesterday approved an order for the support and maintenance of Wayne William Lonergan, 2-yearold son of Wayne T. Lonergan, who is now serving a thirty-fiveyear-to life term for the murder of his wife, Patricia Burton Lonergan.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Viscountess Astor, the American-born woman whose twenty-five years in the House of Commons has made her an almost traditional figure in Parliament, announced today that she would retire from politics when her term ended.

Christmas shoppers who stopped to drop coins yesterday in the red chimneys and speak to the street Santas, were surprised to hear feminine voices say "thank you" from behind the long, white beards. For, although a sprinkling of women helped out last year, this is the first time in the thirty-five-year history of supplying street Santas that the Volunteers of America put women into Santa's red coat.

The tray-on-a-stand can solve a good many problems for the hostess who looks forward to holding open house over the holidays. A fortnight of entertaining that is informal, spontaneous and frequent calls for both large trays and small tables in good supply.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 1 (AP) -- A crowd of 10,446 breathed new life into long-dormant Gulfstream Park today and sent Florida's longest horse racing season off to a money-making start.
ROME, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Activity in the republican underground movement in Spanish Morocco and adjoining French territory has increased sharply, a Stars and Stripes correspondent reported today.

UNION TOWNSHIP, N.J., Dec. 1 -- The directors of the Elastic Stop Nut Corporation met here today without naming a successor to William T. Hedlund, president, who killed himself on Wednesday at his home in Summit. The session, scheduled before Mr. Hedlund's death, will be resumed at 10 A.M. Monday.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Communique 237:

The stock market muddled yesterday through the greater part of the session and then found itself in the final hour. Bolstered by strength in the sugars and an assorted list of specialties, prices firmed near the close, although not sufficiently to indicate a definite trend.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- Herewith are presented highlights of the stream of words that flowed at the start of the New York State Conservation council convention today before approximately 150 sportsmen.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 30 -- When Captain Gerdes, leading German Air Force test pilot, escaped to Sweden by plane nearly three weeks ago, he brought along a complete and perfect set of the latest German radar equipment, the first ever to fall into non-German hands. The apparatus is similar to the American radar.

ROME, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Germans appeared today to be pulling back from the mountains toward highway No. 9 between Bologna and Faenza against the threat of a British Eighth Army breakthrough from the east.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Pari-mutuel betting returned $27,847,314.40 to New York State this year, bringing the State revenue from that source since betting was legalized in 1940 to $69,445,916.20.

Technical experts of the major rubber companies and of the Government's Rubber Reserve Corporation estimate, according to an article in The Wall Street Journal, that high-grade synthetic rubber can be made and marketed immediately after the war on a commercially profitable basis at 15 cents a pound or less.

Promise of court action and expressions of hope for early reconsideration and correction by the City Planning Commission of "inequities" in the zoning amendments as approved by the Board of Estimate on Thursday were heard yesterday from those who had opposed the proposals.

While deaths from motor-vehicle accidents in this city decreased, the number of persons injured increased during the first nine months of 1944, as compared to the corresponding period of 1943, according to a report issued yesterday by Commissioner Clifford J. Fletcher of the Motor Vehicle Bureau.

LONDON, Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- Powerful forces of Royal Air Force heavy bombers blasted the German oil and rail center of Duisburg in the Ruhr last night, kindling blazes that cast a great circular glow of fire in the sky. A thick cloud cover that closed over the Continent limited air operations today.
ALBANY, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Unemployment insurance claimants last month totaled 10,400, a record New York State low.
J.K. Smith Sons, manufacturers of diamond tools and diamond wheels, to Doyle, Kitchen McCormick, Inc., effective Jan. 1. O.E.G. Snow is account executive.

GUERRILLA HEADQUARTERS, Near Canea, Crete, Nov. 30 (Delayed) (AP) -- Fifteen thousand German and Fascist Italian troops now are effectively bottled up in the northwest corner of Crete without hope of escape, it was disclosed here today.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Saturday, Dec. 2 (AP) -- A communique:

Someone of importance should answer Lloyd George. I am only a former Navy man and school teacher, but it is evident to me that Lloyd George, who was one of the fabricators of the tragedy of Versailles, is seeking a scapegoat. America is partly responsible for what happened there and thereafter.

The New York State Bar Association began an independent investigation last night into charges that a fair trial cannot be obtained in Albany County, authorizing appointment of a committee to check conditions as revealed by Special Prosecutor George P. Monaghan in affidavits submitted to the Extraordinary Term of the Supreme Court in session there.

A slight decrease in October under September was shown in the number of placements in manufacturing industries made by the United States Employment Service despite the acute State-wide shortage of 60,000 workers in "must" industries vital to the war, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission, disclosed yesterday.
An issue of $800,000 City of Yonkers (N.Y.) certificates of indebtedness due July 7, 1945, was sold yesterday to the First National Bank of Yonkers on a basis of 2.9 per cent.

LONDON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The press freedom campaign conducted by Kent Cooper, executive director of The Associated Press, was attacked today by a British weekly magazine, The Economist, with a suggestion that his program might allow American news agencies "to dominate the world."
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Belief that it will be impossible to provide employment for discharged war factory workers and returning veterans is not warranted, Dr. Marcus Nadler, professor of finance of New York University and research director of the Institute of International Finance, said yesterday at the concluding session of the annual convention of the Toy Manufacturers of the U.S.A. at the Hotel McAlpin.

WITH THE BRITISH SECOND ARMY, in the Netherlands, Nov. 30 (Delayed) -- Visiting British troops in the field for the first time since the Allied landings on the Normandy beaches, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today inspected all types of British Army weapons and those who man them.

MYITKYINA, Burma, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Japanese were falling back toward Mandalay today, burning bridges behind them and yielding the railway town of Pinwe without firing a shot at the British Thirty-sixth Division.

A new magnetic instrument that will enable American bombers to reach targets 100 miles or more beyond their present range, by providing the craft with a "magnetic tailwind," was described yesterday before the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
ALBANY, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Prominent lawyers and law school deans endorsed today proposals for relaxation for veterans of this war of rules governing admission to the New York Bar.

The recital given by Simon Barere, Russian pianist, last night in Carnegie Hall was an amazing exhibition of consummate technical skill. The sheer virtuosity of his performances would in itself have merited the extreme enthusiasm they evoked, for it worked with electrical effect and evinced a supreme command of the mechanics of the instrument equaled by few masters of the keyboard at the present time.

American bankers have been making remittances to civilians in France for about two weeks, but the volume of business has remained low. There are comparatively few persons in this country with relatives in France, so that the remittances steadily remain at about a tenth of the Italian business.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- American Liberator bombers, clearing the path to Tokyo for the longer-ranged Superfortresses, have made a new series of attacks on the Volcano and Bonin Islands between the United States bases in the Marianas and the Japanese homeland, a Navy communique disclosed today.

Investments in Government bonds by life insurance companies, which have been almost doubled in the last three years, will be further increased until the end of the war, James A. Fulton, president of the Life Insurance Association of America, told officials in this field yesterday at the organization's thirty-eighth annual meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Despite pronouncements by Army procurement officers that production cutbacks after victory in Europe will amount to no more than 15 per cent, business men should continue "to count on" an approximation of the War Production Board's estimate of a curtailment ranging between 35 and 45 per cent, Leo Cherne, executve secretary of the Research Institute of America, declared yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Reich Marshal Hermann Goering, whose disappearance from the news in Germany followed the dwindling of his air force, is reported suffering from a type of dementia that causes him to live in an atmosphere of regal pomp, garbed in a Roman toga.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Things look rather favorable for Army football teams to receive permission to play post-season games, the War Department said today. The "proposition is still in the mill," a spokesman said, and an announcement is "about ready to be made."

The third annual fund-raising drive of the Fifth Avenue Presbytrian Church for the support of service men's activities was started yesterday with a tea and reception at Church House, 7 west Fifty-fifth Street, attended by 500 guests and members of the armed forces of Canada, Great Britain, Australia and the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Three experts on the European food situation told a Food for Freedom forum this week that, far from piling up food surpluses, this country would not be able to meet the relief needs.
ROME, Dec. 1 -- A theft to surpass all thefts in this country where thievery has become tragically common was announced by the Allied Commission today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- The board of managers of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers ended its fall session here today with the adoption of a program designed to meet "critical needs" on the home front.

ROME, Dec. 1 (U.P.) -- Enemy forces, in the second day of continuous assaults on American Fifth Army positions, stormed southward from Mount Castellano, hill position eleven miles southeast of Bologna, and "extremely heavy fighting" is continuing, Allied headquarters announced today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, declared today "the most serious defect in the tax structure" was discouragement of the flow of venture capital, and offered a nine-point program of correction.

I WAS on my way from Hollywood to the Napa Valley for a much needed week-end. The last few days everyone had been asking me whether I had read the new novel by John Hersey that was just out, "A Bell for Adano." I had not read it and so decided it would be a good thing to take along with me.

OMAHA, Dec. 2 -- Farm agencies functioning under the War Food Administration have been canvassing the probability of meeting the food-production goals assigned the Middle West for next season and come up with the answer that the farmer will come through again as he has during the past three years.

A day spent at the Industrial Home for the Blind in Brooklyn watching sightless but confident workers operate complicated lathes yesterday sent 500 clergymen and high school students back to parishes and friends to spread the word among relatives of wounded veterans that blindness no longer meant the beggar's tin cup and pencils.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Dec. 2 -- Pleasant Days, the $1,000,000 twenty-six-acre estate of the late Joseph P. Day, real estate operator, broker and auctioneer, was sold at auction here today for $57,000. The purchaser was Charles C. Nicholls Jr of Vought, Campbell, Ward Nicholls, New York realty concern, in behalf of clients who were not identified.

Although praising American industry for its efficiency in meeting the emergencies of wartime production, Lieut. Gen. Brehon Somervell commanding general of the Army Service Forces, warned yesterday against any relaxation of that program.
MEMPHIS, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Memphis long distance operators voted to strike in support of their wage demands tonight and a tie-up of telephone lines over the country was threatened.

METRO-GOLDWYN-MAYER, which recently recognized exhibitor and theatre patron opposition to the expanding length of pictures by setting a hundred-minute running time maximum for the bulk of its future feature product, is launching another experiment in the interest of brevity. This time it is one-hour length dramatic films.

STRASBOURG, France, Dec. 2 -- One hundred to 200 German troops and several German civilians who are holding out in an old Maginot Line fort near Mutzig, thirteen miles west of Strasbourg may be heroes to Hitler but they and their fort are just guinea pigs to the Americans.

Advocating a new type of distribution cost accounting, based on unit costs rather than over-all or rule-of-thumb methods now employed, Ward Melville, president of the Melville Shoe Corporation and head of the Institute of Distribution, said yesterday that progress toward this objective would contribute to more scientific retail pricing, help to move merchandise faster through economic channels, and ultimately reduce the cost of distribution.

The first for this season of the Mayfair Assemblies, a series of two subscription dances arranged for debutantes and young women who were introduced to society the year previously, was given last night on the St. Regis Roof. The second dance will take place Dec. 30.

ON that fateful morning of June 6 the United States heavy cruiser Augusta -- the ship on which Winston Churchill and Franklin Delano Roosevelt had hammered out the Atlantic Charter nearly three years previously -- stopped her engines at 5:22 A.M. at her appointed place not far off the Pointe du Hoe, from which a battery of six heavy German guns frowned down.
MOSCOW, Dec. 2 -- Premier Stalin and Gen. Charles de Gaulle conferred late today a few hours after the general's arrival for a series of talks.

DETROIT, Dec. 2 -- Composers of the twenty-one Pan-American republics were invited today to write symphonies for a contest sponsored by the Henry H. Reichhold Award. Mr. Reichhold, industrialist and president of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, said the project would be "a gesture on the part of Detroit to prove that we have something in common with our sister republics other than commerce and industry."
I WONDER how many listeners share my reaction to Schoenberg's "Ode to Napoleon," performed last Sunday afternoon by the Philharmonic-Symphony.

THESE two volumes, consisting or some thirty-four addresses delivered at the second and third series of conferences of New York University's Institute on Postwar Reconstruction in the fall and winter of 1943 and the spring of 1944, constitute a valuable addition to the growing literature on the crucial readjustment problems which lie ahead of us.

STATIONED out in the Southwest, Private Anne Poor of the Women's Army Corps has managed to record some of the activities of Army fliers in training. These oils, water-colors and drawings, shown at 638 Fifth Avenue, depict the interior of planes on practice runs and the men who man them in moods of tension and of relaxation.

Big-time three-cushion billiards comes back to New York tonight after a lapse of ten years with the opening of the world championship tournament at the Hotel Capitol Eighth Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

With the exception of the Middle West, little change in the general business picture developed during November compared with the previous month, according to the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

LONDON, Sunday, Dec. 3 -- Russian troops, in a spectacular breakthrough on the Eastern Front yesterday, drove to within seventy-five miles of Austria and, in a new crossing of the Danube River in western Hungary, advanced along the west bank to reach points forty-eight miles south of Budapest.

Six months ago next Thursday Allied armies, disembarked from the greatest invasion fleet in history, won a foothold on the coast of France. Today, Allied troops are driving hard in a bitter winter offensive against the Rhine-West-wall defenses; the straining armies are at long last fighting again on ground blood-stained at the at the start of war five years ago.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- A statement was issued from 10 Downing Street tonight declaring that Lieut. Gen. Ronald M. Scobie's message to the people of Greece, pledging the support of British arms for the Government of Premier George Papandreou, had been published with the knowledge and approval of the British Government.

To the beauty-minded the fact that there is no method or product that can stimulate the growth of eyelashes is one of the harder ones to face. But lashes can be made to look longer, thicker, and darker by using mascara; and its skillful application can prevent the hard, unnatural look which makes many women hesitant about using this cosmetic.

A total of 151 applications aggregating $315,000 have thus far been applied for by veterans of New Jersey under that State's law which guarantees 90 per cent of loans up to $3,000 to enable them to go into business or a profession, a check-up revealed last week.

The General Education Board appropriated $2,584,276 for educational projects, demonstration experiments and research programs in schools and colleges of this country in 1943, according to the annual report made public yesterday by Raymond B. Fosdick, president.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Administration's oil compact with Great Britain seems to be doomed.

Licia Albanese, who replaced the indisposed Bidu Sayao, divided a triumph with Leonard Warren in the first performance of the season of Verdi's "La Traviata" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. Both artists won richly deserved ovations from the audience that filled the house.

LONDON, Dec. 2 (Canadian Press) -- West Ham United, playing the first game at its London home park since a buzz bomb struck the stands, fifteen weeks ago, lost ground in the League South soccer race today, when the Tottenham Hotspurs won by 1--0 before a paid attendance of 23,000.

A program devoted entirely to music by Spanish and Latin-American composers was presented by Emilio Osta, pianist, at his first New York recital last night in Town Hall. Although Mr. Osta was born in San Francisco, he is of Basque origin, with an inherent aptitude for the interpretation of the works in the specialized field indicated by his schedule.

ROME, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Two positions north and south of Faenza have fallen to the Allies, headquarters announced today as the German withdrawal through the mountains toward the Po plain continued in the face of threats against the enemy's eastern flank.

STRASBOURG, France, Dec. 2 -- The battle of the Strasbourg bridgehead ended during a fog-soaked night, and this morning P-47 Thunderbolt fighter-bombers began plastering German troops and gun positions rimming the German city of Kehl, no longer linked to Strasbourg save by the sagging and broken remains of three bridges.

TORONTO, Dec. 2 -- Paced by Nick Metz, Toronto fought its way from behind to a 4-3 victory over the New York Rangers at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight and rose to first place in the National Hockey League standings, one point in front of the idle Montreal Canadiens.

The European war has been expensive, but almost everything in the Pacific war will cost more. Because of the longer distances the same amount of freight costs 25 per cent more when shipped to the South Pacific than to Europe.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Playing heads-up football, the University of Virginia bowled over the University of North Carolina today, 26 to 7, to knot the count at 23 victories each and three ties in the forty-ninth game of Dixie's oldest continuous gridiron rivalry.

EVERGREEN cuttings, from which the gardener can increase his stock of trees, shrubs, and vines, are made any time during the dormant season, and many of us prefer late November or early December. Some of the easy plants to grow from cuttings are evergreens, though this is not true of all kinds.

STRASBOURG, France, Dec. 2 -- Seven Psychological Warfare Branch sound trucks circulated through Strasbourg today, spreading in French and German the glad news that the German bridgehead on the French side of the Kehl Bridge on the Rhine had been wiped out.

ON Nov. 12 you carried an article describing the new subscription radio which was presented to the Federal Communications Commission by Joseph L. Weiner, attorney, for me and my associates, Robert Hutchins, Beardsley Ruml, and Chester Bowles when he is available from his Government duties.

There were two outstanding reasons why attendance at the annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America at Chicago last week was the greatest in many years, and why there was more work and less play than at any similar gathering in the memory of the members.

Drew Middleton's mention of the German village of Eilendorf in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine makes me realize the vast existing gulf between the present inhabitants of that place and Americans whose ancestors, like my own, originally came from some such towns in Germany.

HOLLYWOOD. NO one needed to inform Ted Saucier, the technical expert, who had just arrived from New York, that Hollywood would have more than mild difficulties in re-creating the famed Waldorf-Astoria Hotel easily, almost ostentatiously, within the confines of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's 172 acres.

IF in the progress of this war we have had to learn many new techniques, we have also had to recover a few old truths, one of which is that the price of human life is not to be equated with the price of machines. In the discovery of our own value we have recovered the knowledge that great art, as the spiritual expression of human life, is beyond valuation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The consolidation of our positions in the Philippines, as we move slowly ahead, meanwhile checkmating Japanese reinforcement efforts, seems so positive that strategists pay closer and closer attention to the route by which we will invade the Japanese mainland.

The German transport Westphalen, which sank early last September off the Swedish coast after having been hit by a mine or torpedo, was carrying fifty Norwegian prisoners to a German concentration camp, and of the fifty only five survived, according to information just received in this country.

FAMILY pride can be a dreadful thing. The Brandons have more than their share of it, so much that their lives are haunted and more than one of them has come to an untimely end because of it. At the time this story opens the Brandons are three in number, Thayer and his two sisters, Effie and Anne.

PARIS, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Clare Boothe Luce, Republican, of Connecticut, commenting on reports received today by touring members of the House Military Affairs Committee at Allied Supreme Headquarters, said that American women "have not been doing their part" to the extent that British women have in supplying nurses.

WE always make a secret comparison between a part and the whole; the termination of any period of life reminds us that life itself has likewise its termination; when we have done anything for the last time, we involuntarily reflect that a part of the days allotted us is past, and that as more is past there is less remaining.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Sunday, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Aircraft traded vicious blows throughout the central Philippines, headquarters reported today, as blinding rains again halted the bitter ground battle for Leyte Island's Ormoc corridor.
May I enter a feeble protest from Washington in opposition to Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick's "The Super-Block Instead of Slums", in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine?

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 2 -- Lincoln High's football team came from behind in the third period to defeat Dickinson High today, 8 -- 6, to retain the Jersey City scholastic title before 3,000 shivering fans.

BOSTON, Dec. 2 -- The condition of the port of Boston and its postwar future is under considerable discussion in this area, and emerging from all the comment is the growing conviction that stern measures are necessary to enable the port to regain its former position as one of the world's leading trade centers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Commercial airlines of the United States can begin operating immediately three routes to Europe and Africa via New York and Madrid under an agreement signed today in the latter city by Carlton J.H. Hayes, the United States Ambassador, and Jose Felix de Lequerica, Foreign Minister of Spain.

WITH thirty-one film theatres in Paris playing to movie-hungry audiences and more theatres opening as electric power becomes available for civilian use, the French film industry now is busily engaged in cleaning house and setting up its production facilities, Richard de Rochemont, producer of The March of Time, reported last week on his return from a six-week tour of France.

THE manpower shortage has hit one of America's most cherished institutions -- the Santa Claus business. Although the age range for professional Santas runs from 45 to 75, there aren't enough men around to play the fat old saint. As a result, women are inching their way into the act.
BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 2 -- Little Jack Tittle completed passes all over the stadium today to lead Louisiana State University to a 25-to-6 victory over Tulane's Green Wave.
DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Southwest Conference football race ended on a sour note here today as Texas Christian's champion Horned Frogs were toppled, 9 -- 6, by lowly Southern Methodist.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 -- While the West Coast eagerly absorbed every published detail about the series of attacks on Tokyo this week by B-29 Superfortresses, it paused to consider the relationship between the war effort and several developing labor matters.

Mme. Valentina, New York designer, has created the costumes for the stars and the showgirls of Billy Rose's forthcoming production of "The Seven Lively Arts." Thus there will be in effect a fashion show in addition to the dramatization of the seven arts. Each outfit was individually designed for and made on its wearer -- dress, hat, jewels and all accessories.

The B.F. Goodrich Company of New York and the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company of Akron, Ohio, have announced that they are producing tires from the latex secured from the Russian dandelion -- kok-sagyz. These tires appear to equal Hevea tree rubber tires in quality.

Navy, whose football team lost to Army, got some consolation yesterday when the National Soccer Coaches Association of America, in its fourth annual meeting here yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, selected the Annapolis squad as the outstanding college team in the country, The Associated Press reports.

RICHMOND, Dec. 2 -- The upper South is the tobacco-growing and tobacco-manufacturing capital of the world, but there is no unanimity in this area concerning the reasons why cigarette smokers on both sides of the Atlantic are suffering acute shortages and debutantes and their grandmothers are puffing on pipes or "rolling their own."

BALTIMORE, Dec. 2 -- Col. Earl H. (Red) Blaik, coach of the unbeaten Army eleven, said today after his team's mythical national championship football victory over Navy: "I think it was just a case of the No. 1 team of the country beating the No. 2 team of the country."

Twelve bequests to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund are acknowledged by THE NEW YORK TIMES as the time approaches for its annual Christmas appeal. These gifts were made by men and women who desired to help even after death the work of mercy among the most distressed families and individuals in the city. The appeal will start next Sunday.

" ON the night of Aug. 23, 1939, I attended a particularly gay party." Thus, in the best romantic tradition, Jan Karski begins his "Story of a Secret State" with the account of a ball before the battle. Given by the son of the Portuguese Minister in Warsaw, the party was "carefree, festive, almost lyrical in mood."
PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 2 -- For the fifth consecutive day land-based bombers have hammered away at enemy airfields in the Bonin and Volcano groups, which lie between our B-29 base on Saipan and Tokyo.

PARIS (By Wireless). THREE years after Pearl Harbor it is more evident than it was then that the blow struck there shattered forever the great illusion on which American foreign policy has been based. The illusion was that if we minded our own business and kept trespassers out of the Western Hemisphere we were safe within our ocean frontiers.

IN following Sol Bloom's first campaign for election to Congress, his daughter Vera learned that "once you entered public life, there is no such thing as a small matter, a trivial occasion, an impersonal contact." Consequently, when she came to Washington in 1923, she took the social life she found there very seriously indeed.

STARTING when Pastor Swan lit a tree for his parishioners in Zion Church, Cleveland, in 1851, the author attempts to trace the history of the Christmas tree back through the centuries. We are told of Jenny Lind lighting a little tree for Hans Christian Andersen, of the princess who brought the custom to Vienna, and of young Wolfgang Goethe preparing a tree for his puppy in 1769.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 2 -- British and other Allied troops here are not in any sense the instrument of the Belgian Government, Maj. Gen. G.W.E.Y. Erskine, head of the Supreme Headquarters Mission to Belgium, explained yesterday to newspaper men who pressed him for a statement on the extent of military support given to the Cabinet of Premier Hubert Pierlot during the recent crisis.

LONDON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Under the German scourge, the citizens of northern Norway are starving, freezing, disease-ridden bands of wanderers, the Norwegian Minister of Justice reported today after a recent trip of investigation to newly-liberated portions of his country.

THE hurry and flurry of fall planting and spring sowing seldom leave time for considering those general factors which make such a difference to long-term success in the garden. Good drainage, for example, is widely recommended, and yet how many of us really understand what this phrase means or do anything to make it an actuality.

PARENTS say, "He knows better. I have told him again and again." In the first five years of life, as Dr. Arnold Gesell long ago pointed out, a child has more to learn than ever again in the same period of time.

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 2 -- Frank D. McKay of Grand Rapids, former Republican national committee-man, was indicted today with two others by the one-man States grand jury on charges of conspiracy to corrupt the 1943 Legislature.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The agreement between the United States and Spain announced today to permit the operation of three commercial air routes was described by delegates to the International Civil Aviation Conference as the "first of a series" of such arrangements being developed between the American Government and other countries.

THE most flattering, if not the most elaborate, Christmas present is the kind you take the trouble to make yourself. Something out of your own kitchen is sure to please that friend or member of the family who will be away from home this year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Surgeon General's Plan for Reconditioning Wounded has ended bodily and mental decay in patients brought to the Army's general hospitals from far-flung battlefields for prolonged treatment. Lay observers just returned from a tour of Army hospitals in the South were awed by the plan's results.

COLUMBIA has released the first American pressing of Dimitri Shostakovich's Sonata for Cello and Piano, Op. 40 (album M-MM-551, three twelve-inch records), as performed by Gregor Piatigorsky with Valentin Pavlovsky at the piano.

In the war with Nazi Germany Russians have made adroit use of space. For them space was first a defensive weapon; by retreating into the vastness of the Soviet Union the Red Army cushioned the Nazi onslaught, stretched Nazi supply lines and gained time to muster Russia's full force.

QUEBEC -- Despite the absence of ski trains and the rationing of gasoline, winter resorts in Quebec Province expect the 1944-45 season to be one of the best ever experienced. A heavy program of winter sports has already been drawn up for skiers, with practically all of the winter sports resorts in the Laurentians the locale of at least one important meet.

A three-point plan under which American foreign business and trade would be given a separate and independent status to participate in trade accords, agreements or similar cartel-like arrangements is being considered by the National Foreign Trade Council, Inc., for presentation to Government officials. It was learned yesterday.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, Leyte, Dec. 1 (Delayed) -- Rising from the mud and muck of a principal street in a town of this ain-soaked island is the Quezon club, named for the first President of the Philippine Commonwealth. It is a far cry from the Knicker-ocker Club or Century Club of New York or the Union Club of Cleveland or the Bohemian Club in San Francisco.

PARIS, Dec. 1 (Delayed) -- Emmanuel Celestin Cardinal Suhard, Archbishop of Paris, spoke today in favor of those social changes that the French call "reforms of structure" and that have been urged by the Resistance movement and by the Catholic Democrats, who are strongly represented in the Government.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 2 -- Faced with the alternative that military age groups up to 45 might be called "with serious inconvenience and dislocation in the business life of the community," the Assembly reinstated funds for the home guard for 1945 today.
