MRS. NATHAN STRAUS, wife of the owner of Station WMCA, is a lady in radio with whom to reckon. Without any to-do, she has started a program on her husband's station which easily seems the most difficult and different undertaking of the season on the air.
THE following poses a question that comes up constantly, but the average player seldom finds the right answer to it.

The League of Nations failed, it is commonly said, because it lacked an international police force to enforce its decisions. To correct this defect, the Dumbarton Oaks plan sets up as its key feature a Security Council with a military staff and armed forces having the power, in the words of President Roosevelt, "to act quickly and decisively to keep the peace by force, if necessary."

TAKE it from Fred Allen, Rembrandt's life was a snap compared to that of a movie star. "All Rembrandt had to do was to make some brush marks on canvas, hang it up and he had a picture everyone wanted to buy. But when a movie star makes a picture he has to sell it during interviews, hawk it up back alleys and practically beg people to come and see it."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The War Food Administration moved today to equalize the distribution of a record crop of burley tobacco, chiefly used in cigarettes, among manufacturers and dealers. It issued an order (War Food Order 4.8) allowing manufacturers to buy 5 per cent more burley than they used in the year ended Sept. 30 and dealers to obtain 4 per cent more than was allocated to them from the 1943 crop.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 2 -- The movement to better the educational facilities for Negroes is now growing tremendously in the Deep South. For the first time in the history of New Orleans public schools Negro teachers are receiving in theory, at least, the same salaries as white teachers.

HERE is one of those tales that take their place on the Christmas shelf to become, year after year, a part of the family Christmas. Ruth Sawyer heard the story from a friend named Anna, whose little girlhood was spent on a Hungarian farm, where, this friend avers, her own Christmas Anna Angel came to her.

A project to strengthen cultural and educational relationships between the United States and the Netherlands through a post-war exchange of scholarships among students of both nations will be advanced by the first Hendrik Willem van Loon Scholarship Concert to be given Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- An appeal by President Roosevelt to the people to continue without relaxation their "inflexible determination" and their efforts on the home front and for continued cooperation among the United Nations "for building a structure of peace" after the war is made in a letter to Col. John Callan O'Laughlin, publisher of the Army and Navy Journal

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Commander Crowley related how the eight survivors of the Flier had swum eighteen hours in Japanese-controlled waters to a barren island and lived for days on a pair of coconuts. The little band made its way on a flimsy raft to one of the Philippine Islands after days of vainly hunting food on one deserted spot after another, he said.

ROME, Dec. 2 -- A shipment of supplies from American Relief for Italy has just been discharged at Naples, it was learned today. Other ships with relief materials are being unloaded and supplies are flowing to the Provinces and communes for distribution.

OF the half million Jews who live in Palestine only a comparatively very small number, perhaps 15,000, live in cooperative agricultural settlements where the settlers have not only tried cooperative methods of production but also new ways of cooperative living.

Great strides made in the development of prefabrication -- both in assembly shop and in the open -- of large ship sections; the extension of the use of electric welding, and better planning and timing all along the production line have helped in establishing construction records, Lynn H. Korndorff, president of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, declared yesterday in reviewing his company's three-year war record.
MADRID, Dec. 2 -- The Spanish Foreign Minister, Jose Felix Lequerica, today reiterated the earlier suggestion of Generalissimo Francisco Franco that Spain should have a place at the peace table.

A vivid description of the work of the resistance movement in Belgium during the Nazi occupation was given last night by Dr. Emile Allard, one of its leaders, at a meeting in celebration of the liberation of Belgium, at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

" PITCHFORK BEN" TILLMAN was in some respects an important constructive statesman, but he was the father of all the egregious post-bellum rabble-rousers who have afflicted the South since the Civil War. He set the pattern of revolt in the late nineteenth century against the aristocratic and conservative elements which had been dominant in the Southern States, and he gave the resurgent yeomen, with their genuine grievances, a voice they had never possessed.

Since the end of 1939 the volume of money represented by bank deposits has more than doubled, and the volume of money represented by hand-to-hand currency has more than tripled. The latter rose from $7,600,000,000 to $23,800,000,000 at the end of September of this year.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Spokesmen for Middle Western farmers, surveying the agricultural situation throughout the nation, are predicting that total receipts from farm marketing this year may reach $20,000,000,000. This would be $700,000,000 more than in 1943 and twice as large as in the years immediately preceding the war.
WITH AMERICAN FIRST ARMY in Germany, Dec. 2 -- Something has happened in the German High Command and it is not to our interests either.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Grain markets made a firm start and a tame finish today on the Board of Trade. Short covering in December rye induced by the failure of cash grain to be delivered late yesterday lifted the price 1 7/8 cents a bushel over yesterday's finish, but the market ran into selling pressure and broke.

THE 1945 winter season at Miami Beach gets under way this week. Racing has already started, inaugurating what it is said will be one of the longest seasons (120 days) in the history of Florida's horseracing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- A half-billion-dollar building program to increase facilities for mortar ammunition production was disclosed today by J. A. Krug, chairman of the War Production Board, who told reporters that "excellent progress" was being made in overcoming the lag in production of critical items for the armed services.

THE age of Philip II of Spain, the first model of totalitarian world power to which Franco's Spain looks with nostalgia and hope, fascinated the German poet, Friedrich von Schiller. A German liberal, typical of the time before German unity and power destroyed German liberalism, he erected in his drama "Don Carlos" a monument to the struggle of liberty against totalitarian oppression.

ROME, Dec. 2 -- The Italian political crisis is insoluble under present conditions. A full week of crisis has demonstrated that beyond question. The mere fact that Italian political leaders could choose a particular set of names, tack ministerial titles on them and call it a government of Italy did not mean that the crisis was really over and that Italy could settle down to another six months of apparent stability.

Nitrous oxide, the gas given by dentists when teeth are to be extracted, was introduced a century ago. In a paper which he read before the American Society for the Advancement of General Anesthesia in Dentistry. Dr. M. Hillel Feldman branded it as unsafe because the amount of oxygen that must be delivered when it is administered is less than that contained in an equivalent amount of air.

TODAY the greatest number of words in history whizzes around the world via the telephone. Battles are planned, lives are saved, business is conducted, dates are made, some of the most trivial and some of the most momentous plans of our are made -- all over the telephone.

THE reading rehearsals of manuscript scores which Dr. Rodzinski inaugurated last season will be resumed this year, and will take place before larger audiences. The first of these is called for next Tuesday afternoon, and a limited number of tickets for it may be secured by written request sent to Carnegie Hall.

Chief Engineer Robert Walsh received the United Fruit Company's Gold Medal for "meritorious service at sea, beyond the call of duty," from H. Harris Robson, vice president of the company at a luncheon Friday in the Downtown Athletic Club.
ROME, Dec. 2 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's sharp remarks about Italy and his attack on Count Carlo Sforza yesterday were characterized by a prominent Italian today as "brutal but clear."

THEATRE folk, it seems to me, are not sufficiently stirred by the case of "Trio." Maybe it's the usual muddling-through complacency of the Sardi set, maybe the well-known attitude of shrug-and-too-bad. However, it's an idea to watch out for the boy who cried censor.

BROADWAY has taken to its heart, of all things, a tender play about the struggles and triumphs of a mother. Theatregoers, of late more susceptible to musicals, drawing-room comedies and thrillers, have capitulated to a show which is none of these things, and has a peculiar quality of its own.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 2 -- Notre Dame's Fighting Irish exploded with all the fury of their football tradition today to crush Great Lakes, 28 -- 7, and close their season with setbacks only by Army and Navy marring a ten-game campaign.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Strikes, riots and continuing political unrest in Belgium this week, despite intervention by the Allied Supreme Command in the interests of order, indicate that the revolutionary phase of this war has begun even before the war itself has been ended.

The major problem that will confront the new Congress when it convenes in January will be the extent of our participation in a world security league, which was provided for at the Dumbarton Oaks conference. However, unless the provisions of this conference are made more familiar to the general public, a great deal of resentment is going to be felt about any action taken.

The Treasury Department in Washington reported yesterday that the Sixth War Loan drive passed the five and a quarter billion dollar mark, with total sales reaching $5,364,000,000, as compared with $3,885,000,000 on the previous day, indicating that the nation is well on its way toward meeting the $14,000,000,000 goal.

Few of us, however, have realized the scope and critical value of photography in this global war.

PARIS, Dec. 2 (U.P.) -- Two major league managers, Frankie Frisch of the Pirates and Mel Ott of the Giants, and two top-flight pitchers of the 1944 campaign. Bucky Walters of the Reds and Emil (Dutch) Leonard of the Senators, began a six-week barnstorming tour of the European war front today, traveling through combat areas on a weapons carrier and trailer.

ONLY a few weeks after War Mobilization Director Byrnes threatened that such action might become necessary if other steps failed, reconversion has been halted for a ninety-day period in 103 producing areas of the country in order to relieve shortages of critical war material.

AS a relief from the prevalent insipidities of the official dance season, a visit to the Roxy Theatre is heartily recommended. There at the moment Pearl Primus, with a group of fourteen dancers, half a dozen drummers and a vocal chorus, is making her first appearance in a movie house, and doing a bang-up job of it.

THE central figure in this extraordinary novel is Eve Minary whose mind has been a complete blank for ten years. The physicians attending her have been unable to learn the cause of her sudden blackout; as the story opens they are about to try a new treatment which has been successful in some cases.

Transportation with moderate comfort and a curb on further ornamentation of vehicles are urged by the majority of motorists who have replied to a series of queries on post-war car body construction presented by THE NEW YORK TIMES at the request of the Society of Automotive Engineers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The attack of The Economist, British magazine, on the world news freedom campaign of Kent Cooper and others was called "a pity" today by Chairman Sol Bloom of New York.

Now thoroughly converted to a belief in the existence of Santa Claus, the Giants are in tip-top shape mentally and physically for today's clash with the Redskins, a game that is of vital importance to both teams, since a defeat for either one will spell disaster in case the Eagles win their two remaining home games with Brooklyn and Cleveland.

AFTER seven debuts during its opening week, the Metropolitan Opera is taking things a little easier this week, presenting only one new singer -- Regina Resnik, a blonde, 22-year-old soprano. Miss Resnik, a confirmed New Yorker, will make her debut with the juicy role of Santuzza in Saturday evening's performance of Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana," and she is looking forward to it with what might modestly be termed eager anticipation.

JOHN ROY CARLSON is now working on a sequel to "Under Cover," in which he will suggest ways of combating the home-front threats to democracy that he exposed in his first book. He's writing it between trips to Army camps. . . . Like the seafaring men he writes about, Edmund Gilligan sailed recently from Gloucester, Mass., on the last ship of the season bound for Newfoundland waters.

In this crucial war year the public is spending its inflated income for jewelry at a rate approaching $1,000,000,000 a year, according to data on the collection of Federal luxury taxes made public yesterday by the Tax Institute, 257 Fourth Avenue, a research agency maintained by tax accountants and economists.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 2 -- The first Saturday of racing at Gulfstream Park, witnessed by a crowd of some 5,500, fittingly was designated Florida Day in that W.A. Coleman, Florida breeder and owner, annexed the mile and a sixteenth Florida Purse today with his 3-year-old brown colt, Toolmaker. Mrs. G.H. Emick's Quarterback was second, a neck in front of the M. M. Stable's Top Reward.

Many new and startling innovations of chemical origin will emerge when the veil of secrecy is lifted at the end of the war, Walter J. Murphy, the American Chemical Society's editor, declared in an address before the Investment Analysts Club of Chicago. Chemistry is creating organo-silicon compounds from sand, brine, coal and oil which will greatly improve electrical insulation.

Railway shares at the close of yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange were at the best levels in more than seven years. The list generally closed active and higher and volume was the best for a two-hour session since July 22. The turnover was 705,650 shares, against 358,050 on the preceding week-end.

SEVERAL years ago this book was first published in a de luxe edition limited to 750 copies, sold out to the last copy at $15. It is romance in the high-flown tradition based on the historical records of an old Jersey family round 1815 to 1820.

PENNSYLVANIA -- Veterans' Course A special sixteen-month course for the benefit of returned veterans who feel they cannot devote a longer period to university studies in the business field will be established by the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce of the University of Pennsylvania. The new course will be open to veterans capable of meeting the usual requirements for admission.

In THE TIMES Magazine recently a correspondent, commenting on your reproduction of Picasso's paintings, asked: "Why is so much space given to such a shockingly silly lot of alleged 'art'?" I want to thank you for having given the space to these reproductions.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- French indignation at the high standard of living of German prisoners held by the Americans has not subsided as a result of visits to prison camps by French journalists at the invitation of American authorities.

PARSONS, Kan., Dec. 2 (AP) -- "This is the first time your daddy has ever written to you," wrote Capt. Gerald Marnell, 27, from Palau to "an important little lady," his 2-year-old daughter, Geraldine.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman yesterday morning called on students assembled at the annual pontifical mass in honor of St. Francis Xavier at St. Patrick's Cathedral to choose careers as missionaries.

Russian officials yesterday gathered at a Moscow railway station to welcome another visitor from the west. Gen. Charles de Gaulle, head of the Provisional Government of France, was arriving on the invitation of Premier Joseph Stalin. For Frenchmen the visit marked another step in the rejuvenation of France as a world power.

INTEREST in the history of science is a kind of sophistication. The performance of "Die Walkuere" yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House was mainly conspicuous, on the interpretive side, for the mature and authoritative conducting of George Szell -- despite some orchestral slips -- and the nobly conceived Wotan of Mr. Janssen.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, Ninth Air Force, Dec. 2 -- The daily air communiques that record attacks by fighter-bombers of the United States Ninth Air Force on "fortified towns" do not tell the whole story of the toughness of these targets.

WRITING recently in The Saturday Review of Literature, Struthers Burt had some cogent things to say about the contrasts between contemporary British and American fiction. He expressed the wish that the novelists of the two countries might, by a sort of literary lend-lease, pool the qualities which, generally speaking, now divide them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Posthumous awards of the Distinguished Service Cross have been made to four Army chaplains (two Protestants, one Catholic and one Jew) for surrendering their lifebelts to other men on a sinking transport at the sacrifice of their lives.

Exclusive publishing, selling and distributing rights in North and South America to all music by Soviet composers were acquired by the Leeds Music Corporation on Nov. 24, when that company signed contracts with representatives of the composers, it was announced yesterday.

Taking it for granted that directives will be issued in the immediate future for production of so-called battle jackets for the Army if the new procurement of 3,100,000 garments is not fully covered by bids, clothing manufacturers said yesterday that developments in the week in the piece goods field indicate that many who did not bid will more than welcome any mandatory production for their shops.

The musical education projects of the Turtle Bay Music School, 244 East Fifty-second Street, will be advanced by proceeds from the performance of "Harvey" at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre on the night of Dec. 15. The beneficiary for more than twenty years has been giving musical instruction at less than cost to children and young people of the city.

The expected adequate supply of blankets has not materialized because of excessive demand, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- A fleet of 250 Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Eighth Air Force screened by about 550 Thunderbolts and Mustangs, bombed today two rail yards at Coblenz and the yard at Bingen on the Rhine, traffic points for the Nazi's western front, through thick clouds.

FRANK CARRINGTON, who, as director of the Paper Mill Playhouse over in Millburn, N.J., makes SHort Hills 7-3000 one of those horrible -- albeit lucrative -- busy signals, has fashioned a book for an operetta. This is something new as far as contemporary Carrington is concerned.

OTTAWA, Dec. 2 -- There are deep and complicated factors of principle, politics and personality and of military miscalculation in the crisis that has so greatly disturbed Canada during the past weeks and done harm to her reputation abroad.

LONDON (By Wireless). IT IS in accordance with accepted ideas of the British character that the first woman to take her seat in the Imperial Parliament at Westminster should be a peeress. It is in accordance with these accepted views that she should succeed to her husband's seat.

The requirement of legal registration for engineers before they are permitted to practice has "made engineering a profession and has provided the public with the knowledge that engineers are competent and have integrity," Dr. Carl L. Svenson, past president of the National Council of State Boards of Engineering Examiners, declared yesterday.

Declaring "they're showing their paws for the cause," Phil Baker, radio star, yesterday presented a $100 check to the Mayor's Committee on Wartime Care of Children in behalf of the Empire Cat Club, Inc., as the club closed its twenty-eighth Championship Cat Show in the Hotel Capitol, Fifty-first Street and Eighth Avenue.

Revision of the Friedsam formula for State aid to education, to provide more adequate financial support to the schools, was proposed yesterday by John Cashmore, Borough President of Brooklyn, at the joint luncheon of the High School Teachers Association and the High School Principals Association, before 1,500 educators at the Hotel Astor.
Department store sales by Reserve districts, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, are listed in the following table which gives percentage comparisons with a year ago:

IT is a tribute to a new and distinctive talent that Edith Heal's "This Very Sun" merits serious consideration, for on the surface Miss Heal has written a book which lends itself easily to satirical comment. The whole story takes place in a desert resort town brimming with heat, sunlight and frustration.

OTTAWA, Dec. 2 -- The Canadian conscription crisis is virtually over. For the past seven weeks it has rocked the country and stirred up more emotion than any other issue for many years. For a while it looked as if it might wreck the Government.

The final formal meetings of the year of the American Kennel Club -- the monthly meeting of the board of directors and the quarterly meeting of the delegates from the member clubs -- will be held Tuesday, Dec. 12.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Driving for four touchdowns in the first half and then smothering an exploding Nebraska eleven in the second, the University of Oklahoma sewed the fringe on its second consecutive Big Six football flag today, winning 31 -- 12.

Working hand in hand on plans to sweep away outmoded slums from a vast area on Manhattan's lower East Side, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the New York City Housing Authority have acquired additional lands with the joint aim of creating an almost unbroken stretch of modern housing for about twenty-five blocks along the East River waterfront south of Twenty-third Street, it became known last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Stove dealers and distributors in most areas will be granted additional ration certificates to build up their stocks of oil cooking stoves and gas heating stoves, the Office of Price Administration announced today. Oil heating and gas cooking stoves are not included in the new ruling.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Edward R. Stettinius Jr. is expected to devote his energies primarily as Secretary of State during the first months of his administration in directing the nation's foreign policy to the completion of the world security organization projected at Dumbarton Oaks and in obtaining the full participation of the United States in that organization.

THAT part of the Army stationed at Fort Hamilton is leaning heavily on a touch of Broadway to make its orientation programs for troops going overseas through the New York Port of Embarkation just as painless and exciting as possible.

I WISH I could tell you exactly what goes on at a point of landing -- call it Sienna Beach. The activity is intense, for everything needed in the prosecution of the war or for the sustenance of life is coming ashore at this point -- a few hundred yards of beach.

SEVEN-YEAR-OLD CARL wanted to do something for his country, and what could be more helpful than to keep up the morale of its armed forces? So he selected a name from a byline in The New Orleans Times-Picayune, adopted its owner, Pvt. Alex Melancon of the American Air Forces as his Soldier Boy and began writing his weekly letters.

FOR some time close students of John P. Marquand have been watching that eminent citizen drift like a lemming to the sea of the theatre. There were traces of it in "The Late George Apley," when the memoir came out to win a Pulitzer Prize and to rock Boston back on its own North Shore.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 2 -- The Redskins are stalking through the underbrush with every tomahawk poised and ready to swoop down upon that old Oklahoma settler, Stout Steve Owen. But the large Mr. Owen grew up with Indians and knows their every trick and habit. There's a bit of the Kit Carson in him, too. The Red-men -- particularly the Washington variety -- don't fool him very often.

New York City school children are now preparing a manual of behavior which will provide a code to govern their everyday actions in the classroom, on the street, in the subways or in public places. Ideas on what constitutes "good" conduct and what is "unseemly" are being prepared by the boys and girls themselves, without interference or direction of their teachers.

It is now generally accepted that the universe is expanding like a soap-bubble, a conception which is an outgrowth of relativity. The only evidence of expansion we have is supplied by the nebulae which are rushing away, the outermost at the terrific speed of 15,000 miles a second.

WITH his current sponsor taking over the presentation of "Information Please" on NBC on Monday nights with the broadcast of Feb. 12, Raymond Gram Swing will discontinue his commentaries heard over the Blue Network at 10 P.M., Monday through Friday, after his broadcast of Dec. 28.

In an address which he delivered on the Army Hour Program Brig. Gen. Raymond W. Bliss, Assistant Surgeon General, said that when he visited Saipan last August about 8,000 Japs had been killed. That did not astonish him. What did astonish him was the total absence of flies and mosquitos.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (U.P.) -- Submarines usually take all aboard with them when they go down, but Comdr. John D. Crowley of Concordia, Kan., escaped to tell the first story of its kind to come out of the war.

The establishment by the Libary of Congress last week of grants-in-aid for studies in American history and civilization draws attention to the growing interest in these fields. Greater emphasis is being placed on the American tradition and heritage than ever before. A definite step in this direction was taken at the recent meeting of the English teachers at Columbus, Ohio, where a committee on American culture was formed.

THE controversy between "traditionalists" and "moderns" just doesn't exist in the Netherlands, we are told by Paul Bromberg, the Dutch architect who designed these interiors and also arranged the current exhibit at the Brooklyn Museum entitled "Modern Dutch Architecture and City Planning," of which they are a part.

The Berlin radio broadcast a communique from Field Marshal Gen. Karl von Runstedt's headquarters yesterday declaringthat the Allies probably had lost more than 50,000 men in dead and wounded on the Western Front in November, The Associated Press reported.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Imagine a job in which one was ordered to find markets for 22,000,000 flashlight batteries, a dozen live monkeys, 1,000 garbage cans, 10,000 carrier pigeons and half as many dogs, and one will gain a slight conception of the range and variety of surplus property which the Surplus War Property Administration will be called upon to market over the next several years.
ALBANY, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, State Selective Service director, expects the draft quotas in the State to continue at present levels unless there is "some great military necessity."

An acute and apparently growing labor shortage was among the difficulties listed last week as besetting both the War Shipping Administration and privately owned shipyards in their task of repairing 57 per cent of all the merchant vessels entering United States ports.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 -- The appointment of Ronald E. Kaehler as the first paid president in the history of the San Francisco Stock Exchange was announced today by the Exchange's governing board. He has been executive vice president and general manager of the Exchange since 1939.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Sunday, Dec. 3 (U.P.) -- Brig. Gen. Charles A. Willoughby, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's intelligence chief, said today in a review of the Leyte campaign that although it was tougher than anticipated, it had in no way affected the overall strategy and future operations had not been delayed by the enemy's ability to pour in many thousands of troops.

ATHENS, Dec. 2 (AP) -- A Greek Cabinet crisis over a British Army proclamation disbanding guerrillas came to a climax today with the resignation of all six Ministers belonging to the left-wing Eam [National Liberation Front].
ROME, Dec. 2 (AP) -- A communique:

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- The Fox was exonerated as a main predator on game birds and the soil was traced as the origin of all life, thus by logical conclusion the progenitor of the entire wild life movement, during the concluding session of the New York State Conservation Council convention today.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Politics is beginning to take a larger place in British thought as victory in Europe draws nearer. Prime Minister Churchill said recently that he would not wait until after Japan had been defeated before calling for a general election, although his speech last week and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's amplification left this country wondering whether a vote would come next spring or next fall.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Night baseball, stepped up considerably in the big leagues last season, will undergo a critical review at the joint meeting of the major circuits in New York Dec. 13, but chances are the arc-lights won't go out when the lights go on again all over the world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Following the action of the United Automobile Workers (CIO), the world's largest union, in filing with the Federal Communications Commission an application for FM radio station licenses in six large cities, R.J. Thomas, UAW president, was quoted in an article in the CIO News today as saying that the union was anxious to cooperate with all progressive elements in the field of radio in the furtherance of freedom of expression.

BASLE, Switzerland, Dec. 2 -- At least 50,000 foreign workers in Germany are reported to be making their way through the southern reaches of the Black Forest to reach Switzerland, according to information received here late this afternoon and corroborated by German deserters tonight.

" FOR half a century I have fished and hunted, dug or collected specimens in the waterways, forests, and scrub," writes Dr. Thomas Barbour in his introduction to this altogether salubrious book. "It is for these reasons that I feel qualified to describe the Florida that was and the Florida that is."

L. Metcalfe Walling, administrator of the Wage and Hour Division of the United States Department of Labor, announced yesterday that after nearly five years of litigation, the Endicott-Johnson Corporation, with plants in Johnson City, Endicott and Binghamton, N.Y., has agreed to the payment of $68,593 in back wages and overtime to 2,734 of its employes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 -- Sgt. Jim Ferrier of the United States Army, former Australian golf champion who took a short furlough just to see the professionals play, fired sensationally long drives and putted like a master today for a par-shattering 66 to take the lead at the halfway mark in the $14,500 San Francisco open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- A group of leaders in medicine, public welfare and allied professions will meet here Dec. 8-9 with representatives of national consumer organizations for a two-day conference on the problems of medical care as they affect the community, the individual and the physician.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 2 (UP) -- Communique 238:

Five finalists, one from each of the boroughs, were chosen yesterday in the Police Athletic League's singing contest for junior members to be decided at the league's all-star benefit show at Madison Square Garden on the evening of Dec. 12.

MOSCOW, Dec. 2 -- The Far East expert of Izvestia, official newspaper of the Supreme Soviet, warned today that the recent changes in the Chinese Government were not sufficient to insure real national unity and speed the defeat of Japan in the Pacific war.

TILTING against windmills still seems to be a popular sport with writers on art. The latest knight, to undertake the quest is I.J. Belmont, but I fear that his Rosinante is a hobby horse, his lance a well-worn goose quill, and that his saddlebags and knapsack are stuffed to overflowing with such ill-assorted oddments of esthetic opinion and prejudices that the jig-saw map of his knightly wanderings will never be fitted together.
The letters from readers published in your columns suggesting modifications of the Dumbarton Oaks proposals evidence a basic misunderstanding of the nature of the proposals.

Elisabeth Schumann sang lieder by only two composers at her recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall -- Schubert and Richard Strauss -- those of the latter in honor of his eightieth birthday, which he celebrated on June 11 of this year.

Holding within a 5-point range, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday unchanged to 7 points lower on the day. It opened with losses of 2 to 6 points and held under the previous closing levels all morning, being influenced by small selling orders from the South and continued evening up in the December position.
KANDY, Ceylon, Dec. 2 (AP) -- A communique:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The see-saw fight over portal-to-portal pay for soft coal miners reached the Supreme Court today.

Jewish leaders at the peace conference should seek establishment of a Jewish Commonwealth in Palestine and restoration of civil and human rights to the broken Jewish communities of Europe, Rabbi Louis I. Newman said yesterday in a sermon in Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.

ALLIED EXPEDITIONARY FORCE, Paris, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The threat by Maj. Gen. Jacques Leclerc of the French Army to execute five German hostages for every French soldier shot by snipers in Strasbourg was regarded officially as a closed incident today.

To overcome a raw material shortage now threatening the war effort newspapers in twenty-three pulpwood-producing States will continue to promote in 1945 the United States victory pulpwood campaign, the war activities committee of pulpwood-consuming industries announced yesterday.

EVEN with all the various wartime shortages and other difficulties involved, the Christmas shopper in the art field should be able to satisfy some of his desires. A number of shows have been specially arranged with a view to attracting the holiday gift-seeker; and in the matter of museum publications and holiday cards there is a vide choice.

The pace of Christmas shopping quickened here last week despite adverse weather. Substantial gains in sales were noted for department stores, some of which had increases of 15 per cent or more over the like period of 1943.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Home Guard soldiers, who will have their last and biggest parade through London tomorrow, got a royal pat on the back tonight from King George. In a special army order he told the Home Guard, which is being demobilized, "You have earned in full measure your country's gratitude."

WE came into Aachen a few hours after Colonel Wilck had surrendered with the last German soldiers in the Ruetscherstrasse Bunker. It was a dead city with none of the grace which time-made ruins have. Everything pointed to a hurried exodus of a frightened, terrorized population.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- V.M. Molotov, Soviet Commissar for Foreign Affairs, in a message to Cordell Hull made public today, expressed regret over his retirement as Secretary of State, bespoke the cause of collaboration between the United States, the Soviet Union and other United Nations, and conveyed a personal message of regards from Marshal Stalin.

IN the early days of the war in the Pacific you always could tell when you were in a combat zone. For there you saw the expendables, the over-age destroyers, the oldest, most-battered tugs, the PT boats, the barnacled and converted mine sweepers.

PARAGUAY'S Higinio Morinigo, like President Roosevelt his country's thirty-second President, has probably done more traveling to neighboring republics since taking office early in 1940 than any other chief executive in Pan-American history.

Germany last week was fighting her most desperate battles of the war. They were the first true battles of the Reich, a fanatical effort to keep the Allied armies from the arsenals of western Germany. The whole front, 450 miles from Switzerland to the Netherlands, was ablaze, but on the approaches to the industrial Ruhr and Saar the fighting was of unprecedented heat.

COMDR. DAVID (Wait for Me) McCAMPBELL, who, with thirty-four Japanese planes shot down, is tied with Marine Maj. Richard Bong for the title of America's ace of aces, is a little embarrassed by having such a high score because destroying enemy aircraft is only his secondary job.

Since the announcement of the Dumbarton Oaks Conference the majority of comments have been in favor of the establishment of such an organization, but a number have been simply critical without constructive counter-proposals.

THE woodcock is a bird highly esteemed by gourmets. They rate him way above the quail, the pa'tridge and the pheasant. They tell you it's because his is a diet of worms principally, instead of grain and berries and such like, which those other choice game birds affect.

The conquest of fire was one of the great achievements of man. Sit and watch the glow of a log, the slow flame curling upward on the hearth, and you are seeing in the embers many centuries of forgotten history.

Plans are being advanced rapidly for the annual Silver Spoon cocktail party and tea dance in behalf of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service to be held on Dec. 21 at the Stork Club. Mrs. A. Harris Gaines and Mrs. Kneeland L. Green are co-chairmen of the group in charge of the arrangements for the benefit.

Having assumed responsibilities during the war, women of the United Nations should be accredited delegates to future international conferences, female representatives of Canada, China, France, Russia and the United States declared yesterday.

A five-year experiment in education for citizenship will be initiated soon in Detroit, following acceptance by the Board of Education of a grant of $425,000 from the William Volker Charities Fund, Inc., of Kansas City, Mo.

THIS story has to do with the last appearance of Richard Winter, a famous actor. It is a post-mortem appearance, for Winter is found dead in his bath. Winter is known to have been a hard drinker, and the theory is that he stepped into his bath while drunk, passed out and drowned.
PARIS, Dec. 2 -- In announcing General de Gaulle's arrival in Moscow today all four Paris evening newspapers alluded to a French-Russian alliance.

The Columbia Midshipmen had an easy time defeating the Columbia University quintet at the Lions' gym last night. Off to a slow start, the naval students took command midway through the first half and went on to score a 70-to-54 triumph.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Dec. 2 (AP) -- American-trained Chinese troops tightened their hold today on the North Burma stronghold of Bhamo, where 1,000 encircled Japanese troops face annihilation.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Dec. 2 -- American troops entered two anchor points of the main defenses of the German Reich today -- flaming Saarlautern, important Saar basin industrial city into which they penetrated deeply, and Juelich, where they drove into the outlying part of the town on the western side of the Roer River.

BY way of London comes word that after the liberation of France the French Forces of the Interior overprinted "R.F." on 10-centimes, 30c, 40c and 50c in the Mercury design and on 60c, 70c, 80c, 1-franc, 1.20fr, 1.50fr, 2fr, 2.40fr, 3fr, 4fr and 4.50fr with portrait of Petain.

Christmas shopping moved at a faster pace last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floor departments were crowded and toy departments jammed.

At a celebration yesterday of the fifth anniversary of La Guardia Field, Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, assailed "political opposition" to the completion of Idlewild airport, now under construction in Queens. Its completion, he asserted, is necessary to enable New York City "to reassert her supremacy in aviation."

Archibald MacLeish, Librarian of Congress, was the speaker yesterday afternoon at the first Metropolitan Opera Victory Rally of the season, broadcast over the Blue Network from the Opera Guild's room in the Opera House. He said the speakers who would follow him in the weekly broadcasts, all discussing the question of making the peace, would differ on every subject but one.

THE human embryologist studies the development of man from the stage of the single cell to the moment of birth. From the one-celled stage to the 200,000,000,000-cell stage, a period at the end of which the average seven-pound baby has increased its weight some two billion times!

MILES of mud, days of rain and snow and cold, hours of savage fighting across ruined towns, slow, costly advances in the face of the strongest defense system in western Europe -- that is the pattern for the present battle in the west, a battle which began in November and may continue in all its great and somber scope until midwinter.
The quays and sheds of Antwerp, which thirty-six hours ago I saw deserted and overgrown with grass, are now buzzing with activity.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 2 (U.P.) -- The United States Embassy today advised Americans to evacuate parts of three central Chinese provinces, including the Kunming area, as Japanese forces continued their rapid drive on the communications center and air-base city of Kweiyang, between Kunming and Chungking.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- The International Civil Aviation Conference adopted a proposal today accepting the first and second "freedoms" of the air, the rights of transit and of technical stops. Action was taken without dissent at a meeting of a joint subcommittee representing all fifty-two participating nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, addressing the Pan-American Health Day gathering at the Pan-American Union today, made a plea for popular cooperation with the international authorities in their work for health and sanitation.

Three years ago next Thursday Japan's bombers struck at Pearl Harbor and in a few minutes every battleship in the harbor was damaged, many of the other vessels were put out of action for months to come. It was "the day of infamy," the worst blow our Navy had ever taken in its history.

THE amusing article by George S. Kaufman, "On Getting Mr. Apley Straight," prompts me to add my three cents' worth to the controversy. Mr. Kaufman may hurl "the brickbats" back at those, one or many, whoever they may be, that contended the Copley-Plaza Hotel was not in existence in 1912.

The threatened strike of custodial workers in the city's schools went into effect yesterday with reports of the number involved conflicting. School officials announced that all buildings would be open tomorrow as usual.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 2 (AP) -- "Our first objective is to win the war," says Senator Truman, Vice President-elect.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- A Japanese submarine crew devised a "terrible and murderous gantlet" for the torture killing of captured Americans from a sunken Liberty ship, a West Coast maritime union reported tonight.

Nearly one hundred debutantes of the season, who will be presented to society at the Allied Flag Ball and Debutante Cotillion on Dec. 21 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, will be guests at a large reception to be given Friday afternoon by Mrs. Chester L. Dane, a member of the patron committee, in her home at 720 Park Avenue.

ATHENS, Ga., Dec. 2 -- Georgia Tech's Yellowjackets, stinging with the pent-up fury engendered by going without victory here since 1893, won the Southeastern Conference football title with touchdowns to spare today, defeating Georgia's Bulldogs, 44 to 0, before 28,000 melancholy fans.

" I AM giving books for Christmas." I suspect I am not the only one who could truthfully write a meditation for which this resolution would be appropriate -- and not only in this year of shortages which affect books no less than other commodities. Year after year many besides myself have found books the best Christmas gifts, the most gratefully received, the most fun to choose, to buy and to give.

THIRTY miles outside Stalingrad, on the west bank of the Volga, is a home for children whose mothers died in the siege of Stalingrad and whose fathers are dead or at the front. About 100 children live there. On this page are the stories, told in their own words, of five of these children.

At a luncheon and meeting to be held tomorrow at the Ritz-Carlton, the general committee for the Grosvenor Debutante Ball will make final plans for the event, which will be given next Saturday night at the hotel in aid of Grosvenor Neighborhood House.

A general shutdown of slaughterers and retail meat and poultry dealers servicing the metropolitan area was threatened yesterday over an accumulation of grievances that was said to include unbearable Government food price regulation and unfair local enforcement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Members of the armed services now have ninety days after their discharge in which to look around and decide whether they wish to go back to their old jobs or seek new fields of opportunity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The latest of Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle's Tokyo raiders to be heard from, the five who landed in Russia, "escaped" across one of the world's best-guarded borders, and have returned safely to the United States.

THE First United States Army nurses in France went in with an evacuation hospital on D-day plus four (June 10). They wore field uniforms of trousers, Army jackets, leggings and high boots, helmets and gas masks. They waded ashore and slept that night in blankets on the beaches.

Ordinarily our labor organizations are alert to legislation which is directly or indirectly prejudicial to the interests of their members. They appear not to be aware, however, that if by operation of present law the social security tax rate is doubled on Jan. 1, workers will pay the major portion of the increase.

FELSBERG, Germany, Dec. 2 -- Through mine fields and machine-gun fire, American troops drove today into Saarlautern, second greatest city in the industrial Saar region and one of the foremost sources of coal for the German war machine. Saarlautern is the first large city in Germany to feel the crushing power of Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's American Third Army.

With this exchange of letters, Cordell Hull last week stepped down from his post in the State Department after the longest tenure in office of any Secretary since the department was established in 1789. One of the three remaining original Cabinet members of 1933 -- the others are Secretaries Harold Ickes and Frances Perkins -- the 73-year-old statesman has been in poor health for over a year, has been hospitalized since October.

Students of Finch Junior College will present this week, as their annual benefit in behalf of the Yorkville Civic Council, three performances of Maurice Maeterlinck's "The Blue Bird," in the Finch Theatre at 52 East Seventy-eighth Street.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle has gone to the Kremlin at Premier Stalin's invitation. No doubt he will take the opportunity of finding out at first hand how far France can go with her western neighbors without offending the Russians, who have shown a not surprising degree of hypersensitivity about the formation of a so-called "western bloc," which the British are busily fostering on the fringe of Europe nearest them.

UNLESS some of your best friends happen to be engaged in building bombers, the chances are that all you know of this widely pursued way of life is what you read in the papers -- information that tends to be general and statistical rather than detailed and personal.

Agreement exists among the educational leaders of the United Nations that international cooperation in the re-establishment of the cultural life of devastated countries in Europe is essential for the maintenance of world peace, Dr. Grayson N. Kefauver, acting assistant chief of the Department of State's Division of Cultural Cooperation, disclosed yesterday.

Thousands of miles of ocean between her and the blue Mediterranean where for fifteen long months she wreaked havoc among German installations on the coasts of Italy and southern France, the gray-coated light cruiser Brooklyn slowly steamed into friendly waters yesterday morning and dropped anchor at her berth in the borough for which she was named.

A spokesman for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower broadcast to German forces in the Netherlands yesterday a new warning that Netherland resistance units must be regarded as part of the Allied armies and that any perpetrators of atrocities against the patriots would be tracked down by the Allies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- In contrast to the surge of prohibitionist sentiment in the first World War which culminated in the enactment by Congress of a national prohibition law in 1917 and the subsequent Eighteenth Amendment, the United States within a few days will be entering its fourth year of the present conflict with no pronounced anti-liquor trend in sight.

An appeal to all residents of the State to buy Series E bonds, designed for individual investors, was made yesterday by Treasury officials, as they announced that half of the period set aside for the Sixth War Loan Drive had passed on Saturday, and pointed out that all investor quotas assigned to city and State had been under-subscribed thus far.

Donald R. Waugh has become personnel manager at the submarine shipyard of the Electric Boat Company, Groton. Conn., to succeed Arthur D. Barnes who will return to his former position as assistant to O. Pomeroy Robinson, vice president of the company and general manager of the Groton plant.

With Mayor La Guardia proclaiming a state of emergency in the schools, the city moved yesterday for a show-down today in the strike of school custodial workers that started Saturday. Today will be the first day of the strike when classes will be in session.

The Christian church is performing highly necessary work in the islands of the South Seas, despite "what skeptics have to say," the Right Rev. Walter Hubert Baddeley, English Bishop, of Melanesia, declared yesterday morning in a sermon at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

Mrs. Emilie N. Wanderer of Yonkers, has been appointed regional director of the Eastern District, National Association of Women Lawyers, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Lula E. Bachman of Detroit, president.

PENN crushed Army 48 to 0 in 1940 and two year later Red Blaik had a dreadful time rigging up defenses for Notre Dame's new T-formation. The net result of those two apparently unrelated incidents was the handsome 23-7 victory the fleet cadets scored over their traditional foes, the midshipmen, at Baltimore on Saturday.

WITH AN AMERICAN INFANTRY OUTFIT in Germany, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Germans' deep and almost unreasoning terror of American artillery, which is by far the most awesome weapon on the western front, was illustrated today in a diary taken from a captured German medical-aid man. Here is what he said:

With homage to God expressed in pomp of medieval splendor, the forty hours' devotion opened yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral with a solemn procession of the Blessed Sacrament after celebration of the mass of exposition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (U.P.) -- Today's mission was described as the toughest mission yet for the Superfortresses. In groups of three to six, the Japanese waited for the last planes at or above bombing level and attacked viciously.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 3 (AP) -Long distance telephone operators of Memphis remained at their jobs today, awaiting union authorization of a strike which a spokesman for the operators said might stop telephone service all over the country.

The pockets of an 86-year-old, shabbily dressed man yielded $1,900 in cash and three bank books with deposits totaling $23,000 after he collapsed in the street yesterday near the corner of Seventy-first Street and First Avenue.

Calling for a new revolt against paganism, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick told his congregation at Riverside Church yesterday that there was no hope for the world "save in the recovery and ascendancy of spiritual values."

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 3 (AP) -After being held to a seven-point lead in the first half, the Chicago Bears ran wild in the last two periods today and swamped the Car-Pitts, 49 -- 7, to make it ten straight defeats for the Pittsburgh-Chicago National Football League combine.

As a result of a better allocation of domestic whiskies by distillers and wholesalers to retail stores in advance of the second liquor holiday in January, consumers in the metropolitan area will have a wider choice in their Christmas liquor purchases than was the case a year ago, a survey of the situation disclosed yesterday.

There were relatively few changes in the commodity market last week. The changes that did occur, however, caused the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices to rise from the previous week's level of 114.02 to a new high of 114.07.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 -Brooklyn's tenth loss in an unprecedented all-losing season, which for the Tigers came to an end today on the frozen field at Shibe Park, was its worst of the year. Yielding in every period, the Brooks bowed to Greasy Neale's Eagles, 34 -- 0, after having been completely outplayed in every phase of the game.
The National Park Service of the Department of the Interior has just issued a schedule of "concession facilities available" for the "winter season 1944-45."

PARIS, Dec. 3 -- Some French collaborationists who fled to Germany, especially the group revolving around Fernand de Brinon, are displaying great activity, according to underground reports reaching here, and have accepted the German invitation to conduct propaganda against the Allies.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 3 -- The Chungking Government faced its gravest military and political threat of the eight-year war with Japan as enemy forces approached Tuhshan, eighty air miles from Kweiyang, and well-informed sources said that the next sixty days might determine whether China would be knocked out of the war.

The Army Nurse Corps needs at once 3,753 nurses for Army hospitals in this country and 1,000 for service abroad. Though September was designated as Army Nurse Corps month and a goal of 4,000 was set, only 578 actually responded. Since the Army sent out its appeal the battle casualties in both the Pacific and European theatres of war have been mounting.

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 4 -- Three Russian armies yesterday toppled Miskolc and Satoraljaujhely, last major German strongholds northeast of Budapest, pushed closer to the Hungarian capital along the west bank of the Danube, and drove to within seventy-two miles of the Austrian frontier.

According to the Securities and Exchange Commission, the net working capital of American corporations has reached a new peak of $44,300,000,000. Because of this highly liquid position it is often suggested that industry will be able to finance reconversion to peacetime production and to meet much of its needs for post-war expansion.

SOMEWHERE IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Dec. 3 (AP) -- A United States Army corporal was king for a day on a Southwest Pacific tropical island where the girls are really pretty, the Thirty-first Infantry Division announced today.

A blocked kick midway in the second period enabled St. Mary's High of Rutherford to eke out a 6-to-0 decision over Cardinal Hayes yesterday on Fordham Field. The contest marked the close of the campaign for both schools, St. Mary's finishing with a record of ten victories in eleven starts, its sole setback coming at the hands of the champion St. Cecilia team.

Warren Wright's 3-year-old filly, Twilight Tear, yesterday was voted the "horse of the year" in the annual poll of twenty-eight experts of Triangle Publications, publishers of The Daily Racing Form and associated newspapers, according to The Associated Press.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 117.9 on Nov. 22, compared with 117.9 a fortnight and a month before, 113.5 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

Reports of the nation's leading companies for the first nine months of this year show only moderate changes in net earnings from the corresponding three quarters of 1943. The important exceptions to the relatively steady trend are the petroleum industry, which showed a substantial increase in net income, and the steel industry, in which the decline, apparent since the end of 1941, continued.

Government competition, Federal and local, will be the greatest problem facing the public utility industry in the post-war era, according to a study Just completed by John C. Parker, vice president of the Consolidation Edison Company, for the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.

In the decade before this war the nation made important advances in various fields of conservation. Farmers began to realize the economic effects of soil erosion. National and State forests were enlarged. The Town Forest movement began to acquire momentum.

In contrast with last week, which was an inactive one for first-nighters, this week will have four premieres to command their attention. "Hand in Glove," opening tonight at the Playhouse, is the first of the quartet. In this case, the customary out-of-town break-in was dispensed with in favor of three invitation previews.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens regained the top spot in the National Hockey League tonight when they scored twice in the last period to defeat the cellar-dwelling Chicago Black-hawks, 2 -- 1. Boston's 5-4 victory over the league-leading Toronto Maple Leafs gave the Canadiens their first place standing.

LONDON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The official Communist party newspaper Pravda, in an article broadcast tonight by the Moscow radio, denounced the semi-official American Army-Navy Journal as "ugly looking" and accused it of "supplying pro-Hitlerite journalists with material."

When our men marched down those narrow English roads between the hedges and went aboard their ships on the night before D-day last June, they carried with them everything they needed to live and fight.

KANDY, Ceylon, Dec. 3 (U.P.) -- East African troops, advancing westward along the Myittha Gorge, have captured the town of Kalewa, on the Chindwin River invasion route leading to Mandalay, 145 miles southeast of Kalewa, a Southeast Asia Command communique announced today.

ALBANY, Dec. 3 (AP) -- State motor vehicle registration plates for 1945 go on sale Dec. 4 at all issuing offices of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles, although the plates are not to be displayed until Jan. 1.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved a plan whereby the North American Company will contribute to its subsidiary, the West Kentucky Coal Company, 115,675 shares of the latter's 7 per cent $50 par value cumulative preferred stock and 65,684 of its common shares valued at $11 a share.

DETROIT, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Some 5,800 striking workers of the Briggs Manufacturing Company's Mack Avenue plant voted today to return to their jobs tomorrow, concluding the second of three major strikes in Detroit in two days.
The Japanese invasion of Kweichow Province in southern China last week poses another grave threat to the Allied position in Asia.
GUATEMALA, Dec. 3 -- An announcement by President Osmin Aguirre y Salinas of El Salvador that a free Presidential election would be held next January appears to be his latest bid for recognition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The effect of a late autumn downpour on a field hospital in southern France is described by Dorothy Sutherland, Army Nurse Corps correspondent, in her last delayed report to headquarters here. The report follows:
The second Allied liberation of Strasbourg within a generation was hailed at a thanksgiving service in the French Episcopal Church du Saint Esprit, 109 East Sixtieth Street, yesterday afternoon.
LONDON, Dec. 3 (UP) -- A German communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
A demand for business properties, including garages and a warehouse, was indicated by deals reported in the Bronx over the weekend.

A dual message calling for a home front imbued with "courage, faith and loyalty" such as that displayed by troops at the front and for Christian unity was delivered here yesterday by the Right Rev. Henry Wise Hobson, Episcopal Bishop of Southern Ohio, on his return from a two-month trip to England and the Western Front.

Indications of definite apparel shortages for the spring season are pointed to in reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Many producers, it is said, continue on an allotment basis, while others have delayed the opening of their spring lines because of their inability to obtain sufficient fabrics from mills.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- Civilians who have been waiting for railroad travel congestion to ease so they could take a pleasure trip are going to have to wait a while longer, E.P. Burke, passenger traffic manager of the Pullman Company, said today.

TIRANA, Albania, Nov. 30 (Delayed) (AP) -- Prime Minister Enver Hoxha said today in an interview that his Government was rebuilding Albania as a democracy and also that he favored "a strong brotherhood" of the Balkan peoples.

TWENTY-FIRST BOMBER COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Saipan, Monday, Dec. 4 (U.P.) -- Heavy Japanese fighter opposition ripped into a substantial force of Superfortresses over Tokyo yesterday. Returning pilots told of fifty-minute fights with Japanese single and twin-engined fighters at a high altitude, but said bombs were seen to explode in perfect strings across the rectangular factory buildings in the target area.

The Israel Zion Hospital of Brooklyn celebrated last night its twenty-fifth anniversary with a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, at which contributions of $300,000 were made toward the $500,000 emergency campaign fund drive of the hospital.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 3 (AP) -- An increase of more than 400 per cent in the total tonnage of equipment carried over the hump during October for Burma Road engineers by the Air Transport Command was announced today. The statement said the rise was expected to be larger as work on the supply route to China from India bases was pushed.

PARIS, Dec. 3 -- The best art gallery in all of Europe is now located in a cave under St. Peter's Hill on the outskirts of the ancient town of Maastricht, Holland. It is oddly symbolic that old masters of the Dutch school, like living patriots, should have gone underground during the German occupation.

The Most Rev. J. Francis A. McIntyre, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, urged Catholic social welfare workers yesterday to take a greater part in formulating just and honest peace programs adhering to the principles of the Atlantic Charter.

Sammy Baugh's Special almost dropped the Giants into the Lilliputian class yesterday, but the one that was misdirected was the one that saved the day and gave the New Yorkers undisputed possession of first place in the Eastern half of the National Football League.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Monday, Dec. 4 (U.P.) -United States planes and light naval craft have sunk or damaged five Japanese merchant ships totaling 10,000 tons and destroyed or damaged twelve enemy planes in a series of widespread attacks against the Philippines and Borneo, it was announced today.

UNION CITY, N.J., Dec. 3 -Union Hill High, Hudson County, N.J., scholastic titlists, registered an upset today when they battled undefeated St. Cecilia High of Englewood to a scoreless deadlock. St. Cecilia, the New Jersey Catholic school champion, had a 25-game winning streak compiled over a three-year period.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Seven thousand members of the Home Guard, the youngest branch of Britain's armed forces and the first to finish its war service, paraded before their Colonel in Chief, the King, for the last time today. One of London's biggest wartime crowds lined three miles of the capital's famous streets to watch the forty-five-minute parade march past.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Monday, Dec. 4 (AP) -- A communique:

The Apostleship of Prayer, a Catholic organization better known in this country as the League of the Sacred Heart, is "not a small, exclusive, inner circle of mystics," the Very Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, declared yesterday in a sermon at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street, where a solemn pontifical mass was celebrated to mark the 100th anniversary of the founding of the group.

Anyone looking for an unusual delicacy for a Christmas gift, or for the home table, will be interested in a tokay wine date loaf made by Edna Cast of Mecca, Calif., and sold under the trade name of Garden of the Setting Sun. The confection resembles a fruit cake in appearance, but actually is an uncooked loaf in which no flour or shortening is used.
ROME, Dec. 3 -- The second week of Italy's crisis began today with no solution in sight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Four disposal agencies -- the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the procurement division of the Treasury, the Maritime Commission and the War Food Administration -- disposed of $26,772,000 of surplus war property in October at 64.7 per cent of cost or appraised value, W.L. Clayton, Surplus War Property Administrator, reported today.

GUAM, Dec. 2 (Delayed) -- In a bomb-shattered building under a near-by tent which two mornings a week serves as a produce market for the town of Agana, the young people of Guam are resuming their high school studies where they left off three years ago.
Your editorial of Nov. 26 "Inevitable Socialism?" seems to me very timely and I am moved to comment on it.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -Consumers mill pay about two cents a pound more for Swiss cheese and generally one cent more for brick and munster, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 -- The 10,000-ton light cruiser Atlanta, successor to the "Mighty A" which was lost in combat with Japanese forces in the battle of Guadalcanal, was commissioned at the Philadelphia Navy Yard today.

A UNITED STATES INFANTRY COMMAND POST, in Germany, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Infantrymen commanded by 29-year-old Lieut. Col. Edmund F. (Paddy) Driscoll of Lynbrook, N.Y., took the town of Luchem by storm today in pitch darkness at 6 A.M.

SAN FRACISCO, Dec. 3 (U.P.) -Red-hot Sgt. Jim Ferrier, the artilleryman from Camp Roberts, Calif., shot another blistering sub-par round of 70 here today to retain his lead in the fourteenth annual San Francisco open golf tournament.

MOSCOW, Dec. 3 (Reuter) -- A Pravda foreign observer charged today that Spain and Portugal, "despite their alleged neutrality, had increased deliveries of raw materials to Germany by one-third as against 1941."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Gen. George C. Marshall, United States Army Chief of Staff, had hoped earlier this fall that this country's "flood" of military power might beat Germany by the time of the third anniversary of Pearl Harbor and the nation's entry into the war.
ROME, Dec. 3 (AP) -- A communique:

Mayor La Guardia, whose Sunday broadcast from Chicago on Nov. 26 began with an appeal to his fellow-townsmen for $1 contributions to meet a bill of $107 for wire charges, revealed yesterday that the response was generous enough to warrant a refund of 84 cents on every dollar contributed.
New Yorkers might as well adjust themselves to the unavoidable fact that they will have to do without poultry "for some time to come," Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (U.P.) -William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, and Harry A. Millis, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, have arranged to discuss conflicts between the two agencies in the handling of labor problems, chiefly divergent policies on foremen's rights, union recognition and authority to inquire into the internal affairs of unions.

Every now and then some disclosure of a military secret serves to emphasize technical advances which seem certain to be translated into peacetime use. It is apparent, for example, from the recent lifting of a corner of the curtain on the use of radar in instrument-bombing that commercial and private flying will be largely, if not completely, liberated in the days to come from the throttling effect of cloud and fog.

In THE TIMES of Nov. 28 Ruth Lord Jenkins takes Jerome Alexander to task for inaccurate statements regarding the establishment of Thanksgiving. Yet in her own letter she states that Anne Hutchinson, ordered to leave the Massachusetts Bay Colony because of her doctrines, "returned and was hanged."

Wool printed in vibrant colors has been developed by Macy in a whole series of clothes and accessories designed to put new life into winter wardrobes. The store has imported from Mexico exclusive prints by the Tiller Brothers. These designs are bold in pattern and expressed in such color combinations as green and chartreuse, yellow, gray and black, fuchsia and black.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Soviet authorities in Rumania have already begun removing to Russia heavy machinery and other equipment from that recently defeated former Axis satellite.

PARIS, Dec. 3 -- In several parts of France housewives have begun parading as a protest against insufficient food supplies. Such parades are orderly and intended to remind responsible authorities of prevailing conditions.

A protest by the Queens County Bar Association against the recently announced decision to transfer the borough's War Emergency Court, dealing with Office of Price Administration cases, from Kew Gardens to Manhattan left Mayor La Guardia yesterday still standing pat -- or nearly so -- in his support of the shift.

A new type of "good-neighbor" policy was introduced recently in Greenwich Village, when 3,300 letters sent from Montgomery Ward's local buying office at 75 Varick Street disturbed that section's artistic atmosphere. Yesterday mail-order house representatives revealed the cause for it all -- a need for part-time workers for filing, packing and sorting.

WOOD-RIDGE, N.J., Dec. 3 -The family saw "Pop" or "Mom," or in some cases "Grandpa" or "Grandma," at work turning out the engines that power the B-29 Superfortresses that have been bombing Tokyo in "family day" at the Wright Aeronautical Corporation plant here today.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 3 -- Contrary to some predictions made earlier this year, steel activity last week was not far below recent peak loads. While it was said the high records in war steel output probably had been passed, events abroad have quickened the tempo in steel output and ordering.

Cotton prices in the domestic market last week moved irregularly within a narrow trading range. At the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 7 points to up 6 points from the close of the week previous.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Communique 239:

The Inde is an insignificant tributary of the Roer River on which the Germans are trying to stabilize their defense of Cologne. In this country it would be called a creek. On it, halfway between the towns of Juelich and Dueren, stands the tiny village of Inden. There are not a hundred houses in the whole village.

Axe-Houghton Fund's directors have declared a dividend of 55 cents a share, of which 10 cents comes from investment income and 45 cents from capital gains. The distribution brings the 1944 total to $1.04, against 59 cents in 1943.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 3 -Apolonio Salles, Minister of Agriculture, expressed today the opinion that the granting of subsidies on cotton exported from the United States affected Brazilian cotton planters deeply. He said he had hoped the United States would give deep thought to the measure.

Messages to foreign workers in Germany from Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's headquarters, broadcast during the last three days, were summarized yesterday in a fourth message by a spokesman of the staff of Supreme Headquarters.

WITH THE SECOND ARMORED DIVISION, in Germany, Nov. 28 (delayed) (AP) -- Many men and officers of this veteran division believe Germany's new "Royal" or "King" Tiger tank, with its "super-88" gun, is the best tank in battle today.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J, Dec. 3 -- To the mild relief of some Signal Corps officers here, the Army's famous pigeon-training school at Fort Monmouth, which has graduated untold numbers of military-minded birds, has been discontinued at the base and its personnel and students shipped to Florida preparatory to duty overseas, it was learned tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Widespread fires, whipped by strong winds, were started and stoked in an aviation factory by bombs dropped by a force of United States B-29 planes that flew over Tokyo today in the fourth smash at the Japanese capital in ten days. Results were reported as good, according to a Twentieth Air Force communique.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (U.P.) -The textile industry is preparing to meet an unprecedented export demand for 3,000,000,000 square yards of cotton cloth annually in the post-war period, Robert Sweeny, chief of the textile unit, Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, disclosed tonight.

Playing before a crowd that packed every available inch of space in the Oak Ballroom of the Hotel Capitol, Willie Hoppe, holder of the world three-cushion billiard championship, got off to a good start in the defense of his crown by defeating Miguel Marquez, youthful Mexico City expert, in the opening match of the title tournament last night, 50 to 43.

Activities of St. Augustine's Chapel, 105 East Houston Street, one of the several chapels of Trinity Parish, will be transferred on June 15, 1945, to All Saints Episcopal Church, Henry and Scammel Streets, and the chapel's congregation will worship with the parishioners of All Saints.

PARIS, Dec. 3 -- Further nationalization of key industries in France was indicated today by Robert Lacoste, Minister of Production, as he left for Marseille after two days in Lyon investigating conditions.

BAINBRIDGE, Md., Dec. 3 -Charlie (Choo-Choo) Justice, and Harry (Hippety) Hopp, playing their final games for the Bainbridge Commodores, gave a crowd of 15,000 sailors something to remember them by today when they paced the unbeaten and untied Commodores to a 13-to-3 victory over the Maxwell Field (Alabama) Marauders.

Julius Katchen, 18-year-old pianist, gave his second New York recital last night in Carnegie Hall before a large and enthusiastic gathering. Mr. Katchen was first heard in this city in 1937 as soloist at a Pension Fund concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The plight of the South's King Cotton may lead to a remaking of the agricultural map of the United States.

DETROIT, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Detroit Lions, scoring freely in the first three periods, routed the Boston Yanks, 38 to 7, today in the season's final National League football game at Detroit. The Lions' fifth straight triumph assured them of at least a tie for second in the western division.

A full-scale investigation of the New York City school system, to study the policies of the Board of Education and "to check the claims made by school officials that conditions here are satisfactory," was requested yesterday by the New York Teachers Guild, affiliate of the American Federation of Labor.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 3 (AP) -- The State Socialist party committee decried today proposed compulsory military training in peacetime, in a move to intensify its political activity.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Capt. Maurice L. (Footsie) Britt now has the Distinguished Service Cross to go with the Congressional Medal of Honor and the Silver Star.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 3 -- Every male worker in the Greater Boston area of forty-three cities and towns who quit a job in essential or non-essential industry, beginning next Saturday, must take a war job if he is found qualified and able, it was announced today by the Metropolitan Boston War Manpower Commission. The order contained six new manpower control items.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 3 -- The New Jersey Independent League, which functioned prior to the November elections as the New Jersey Independent League for Roosevelt, met at the Essex House here today to complete plans for a permanent organization.

A program of songs, "unfamiliar . . . old and new," and especially challenging, was given yesterday afternoon in New York Times Hall by Vladimir Dukelsky, the composer, and on this occasion accompanist, and Rose Dirman, soprano.

A large and diverse list of new art exhibitions, several of them heralding the holiday season, is scheduled for this week. Group and one-man shows, including work by many well-known artists, are on the calendar.

GRAND CANYON, Ariz., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Col. Elliott Roosevelt and Faye Emerson, a motion picture actress, were married in a glass-enclosed observation station on the rim of the Grand Canyon this morning. Snow and swirling mist obscured the view and the temperature outside was twenty-nine degrees.

The third week of the Metropolitan Opera season, beginning next Monday night, will be marked by the New York debut with the company of Blanche Thebom, mezzo-soprano, who will be heard in "Die Walkuere" as Fricka on Thursday night, Dec. 14.

MOSCOW, Dec. 3 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle defined the purpose of his Moscow mission today as tightening and clarifying Russian-French friendship not only for victory in the war but in order that the two nations might work together for a lasting peace.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- This is the week the Seventy-eighth Congress expected to close its books for keeps, but its docket contains the makings of a first-class battle with the White House and bulges with enough business to keep the session going for at least an additional week.

Braving the icy wind of the cold,t day of the season to date, 300 tardy souls visited the Statue of ,iberty on Bedloes Island yesterday. They were just a few of the ncreased number of visitors who rove shattered wartime attendance 'igures at the home of Miss iberty.
