CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- A consolidated draft of the proposed convention on civil aviation, setting up a world organization, was submitted to the International Civil Aviation Conference today by joint drafting committees.

Importers hailed yesterday the United States Supreme Court action in taking over jurisdiction in the two-year-old litigation over the dual rate system for the British pound sterling. Outcome of the case is awaited with interest, it was said, in that it is expected to set the pattern for currency control in import trade not only for Great Britain but also for the world as a whole.

Next Sunday will be known as Universal Bible Sunday. For several years past the observance of such a day has been a notable event on the religious calendar. This year the day will have increased significance, for it falls in a period of nation-wide Bible reading such as the country has not known in a very long while.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (U.P.) -- A shifting pattern of world food production and a trend toward increased output, if continued after the war, will create many problems in trade and competition among the nations, according to the Department of Agriculture.
You have done well in your editorial of Nov. 27 to point out that with war tuberculosis threatens us all again.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 3 -- The futures market on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange was quieter and narrower last week, with an uneven trend after midweek as December felt the effects of liquidation as tenders in that position were circulated.

WITH FILIPINO GUERRILLAS in Eastern Samar, Nov. 28 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Filipino fighters, in the first all-guerrilla operation since Gen. Douglas MacArthur's return to the Philippines, have driven back superior Japanese forces in this area and occupied the town of Taft, midway up the eastern coast of Samar.
LONDON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

ROME, Dec. 3 (AP) -- British Eighth Army troops advancing through the Po Valley on a broad front northeast of Faenza have driven within two miles of Russi, junction city astride the main Ravenna-Faenza highway, the Allies' command announced today.

Financial markets advanced again, but toward the week-end stocks became irregular. Possibly Churchill's speech in the middle of the week checked the advance by its hint at longer duration of the war than had been previously anticipated.

Employes of the city's unified transit lines in the lowest wage groups will receive a pay rise "not just now, but a little later," Mayor La Guardia indicated yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall. Pay increases for city transit workers, to offset higher living costs, are among the demands made upon the Board of Transportation by the Transport Workers Union, Congress of Industrial Organizations.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 3 -- The American Jewish conference opened its second annual session today and immediately took up the question of whether the conference should expand its work and become a permanent organization, or hold to its present three-point program of rescue, post-war rehabilitation of Jews and implementation of Jewish rights in Palestine.

MOSCOW, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The reorganization of the Polish Committee of National Liberation into the Provisional Government of the Polish Republic loomed today as Pravda attacked Tomasz Arciszewski, new Premier of the Polish Government in London, as "one of the worst enemies of the USSR."

The football team rated by numerous observers as the peer of any in the country will be seen in action at the Polo Grounds on Saturday, Dec. 16, when the Randolph Field Ramblers of Texas meet the Second Air Force Superbombers of Denver, in a Treasury Bond Bowl game.
Yesterday's communique as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The political crisis that has developed in Greece epitomizes a situation that exists also in varying degrees in Belgium, Holland, France and Italy. The present political problem in Greece is in microcosm the present political problem of Europe. This problem at best will be extremely difficult to solve; and unless we think clearly about it we may drift into courses that could lead politically to disastrous results.

Japanese Premier Kuniaki Koiso said yesterday that Japan must "by no means fail to achieve victory" in the Philippines, but warned that the "situation is critical" in a speech calling for an increase in Japanese "material fighting power" as the "most urgent of our national policies today."

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- Liquidation in December rye through commission houses was on last week on the Chicago Board of Trade, and traders continued to claim that there had been some selling against holdings of cash rye. However, the market showed considerable resistance to selling pressure and a disposition to rally quickly after breaks.

Darius Milhaud's string quartet, No. 4, was the special feature of the concert given late yesterday afternoon by the Lener Quartet in Town Hall as an event in the current "Mozart and French Composers'' series of the New Friends of Music.

The porcupine, or quill pig, as he is frequently called, is a blundering, phlegmatic fellow. In spite of his stolid disposition and his fearsome armor, he's really not a bad chap when one gets to know him. In lonely forests of the Northland the trappers find his hankering for salt makes him a nuisance around log cabins.

Reports last week that Warner Brothers had bought "Life With, Father" for the highest price paid up to now for the screen rights to a Broadway hit were confirmed yesterday in an announcement by Jack L. Warner, executive producer of the screen company.

The Bowery Savings Bank sold to Isidore Meyer, an attorney, the five-story apartment house containing thirteen suites at 1468 Amsterdam Avenue through Mark Rafalsky Co., brokers, who also sold to the Doren Holding Company the five-story apartment building at 159 West 102d Street.

LONDON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, Polar explorer who staked America's claim in the Antarctic, broke a long self-imposed public silence today to pay tribute to the Army's GI Joes and to urge on their behalf full production support by the folks back home for a war "a helluva way from finished."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 3 -- Paramount has announced the abandonment of Cecil B. DeMille's proposed picture, "The Flame," a story of the revolution in Mexico between 1913 and 1915. The estimated cost of $5,000,000 was given as the reason.

Combat photos, in 8-inch by 10-inch glossy prints, particularly suitable for advertising, can be obtained from the Coast Guard of the Fourth Naval District through the medium of a four-page clipsheet known as "Frontline Photo News."
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 3 -The German Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop, is about to be discharged, according to private information from an excellent Berlin source.

ATHENS, Dec. 3 -- At least ten persons were killed and sixty-one wounded, including six policemen, when members of the left-wing Eam [National Liberation Front], defying a Government ban, staged a mass demonstration in Constitution Square today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (U.P.) -- Sen. Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, tonight took issue with David Lloyd-George's assertion that the present world chaos resulted from the United States "backing out" of the League of Nations, countering that the chief trouble after Versailles was that the British and French failed to keep Germany demilitarized.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $49,667,056,926. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, non-interest bearing discount bills and notes, as follows:

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- New-crop deliveries of wheat are coming in for more general attention, and with background of prospective Government support for the duration of the war and two years thereafter prices have moved up steadily the last week, with the July and September selling at new seasonal high levels.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Dec. 3 -- The American Third Army has crossed the Saar River and has won a foothold in one of the principal towns of the Saar Basin.
One of the oldest and best-known social welfare organizations in America, the Salvation Army is conducting various activities directly contributing to the war.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- A shortage of labor at many packing points continues to operate against large production of hog products, although receipts were considerably larger last week. At the same time the make of lard is not up to expectations, and reports indicate that supplies of that commodity continue short and no change is anticipated for some weeks.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 3 (AP) -A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Heavy bombers of the Royal Air Force smashed up one of the gateways to the Ruhr last night -- an attack by 500 to 600 Bomber Command planes. The main target was Hagen, a city of 150,000, about fifteen miles south of Dortmund.

Even persons who have never thought of buying antiques for themselves or anyone else, may find the answer to this year's Christmas shopping problems in some of the shops along Third Avenue, where stocks of merchandise are not affected by shortages of manpower or materials.

WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 3 -A Scottish terrier, making his second appearance in a dog show in this country, raced through his breed and group today in the annual exhibition of the Worcester County Kennel Club in the Municipal Auditorium.

WITH THE UNITED STATES THIRD ARMY, in Germany, Dec. 3 -- In a daring maneuver that caught the Germans completely unawares, units of the Ninety-fifth Infantry Division crossed the Saar River at Saarlautern in darkness this morning and joined other forces in the city to capture an important bridge intact.
The country can now return to the normalcy of fighting the most terrible war ever inflicted upon mankind. The Amy-Navy game has passed into history.

Four thousand members of the National Association of Manufacturers will repledge their organizations to the production of war goods and also discuss ultimate re-conversion to civilian output when the three-day annual convention of the association opens on Wednesday in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, it was announced yesterday.

A biography of a man who went mad and then recovered without treatment has been written by a close friend of his, Carlton Brown, associate editor of Pic, in a book called "Brainstorm," to be published on Dec. 28 by Farrar Rinehart.

The shirt and pajama industry is in a "drying up" process, according to the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers, with piece goods on order with mills probably 25 to 35 per cent of pre-war levels. In a study released yesterday, the association states that fabric commitments as of the end of October were only 52 per cent of the 1943 level, far below a normal position.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- The City has had so much to occupy its attention in the past week that the stock markets have received scant notice. It is clear that the most significant of all these events from the business man's angle and therefore from the market viewpoint was Prime Minister Winston Churchill's statement on changes in the lend-lease program.

Member banks of the Wilmington (Del.) Clearing House Association have formed a $7,500,000 bank credit group to provide post-war credit facilities for small business in Delaware, it was announced yesterday by J. Gordon McMillan, president of the Delaware Bankers Association and of the Claymont Trust Company, Claymont, Del.

Plans for a two-story office building at 351-353 West Sixteenth Street for the National Maritime Union Realties Company, Inc., 126 Eleventh Avenue, of which J. Curran and M.H. Stone are trustees, were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The War Production Board took steps today to assure adequate supplies of fabrics for naval officers' uniforms by establishing a program for giving priorities to manufacturers seeking tropical worsteds and worsted gabardines.

A thinly veiled threat by Councilman Michael J. Quill that certain legislators might find themselves out of jobs unless they set about enacting anti-discrimination measures governing employment prompted a plea by Assembly Majority Leader Irving M. Ives, chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination, yesterday that politics be kept out of the commission's deliberations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 4 -- Vincent Price has been chosen for the lead, with Gene Tierney, in Twentieth Century-Fox's picturization of the Anya Seton novel "Dragonwyck." He will replace Gregory Peck, who withdrew from the tentative cast to appear in "Duel in the Sun" for David O. Selznick.

The State Athletic Commission will adjust its rountine to the convenience of the Sixth War Loan drive today. Because Lee Oma, Detroit heavyweight, is scheduled to participate in a rally the commission has advanced the hour of his physical examination for the ten-round bout in which he is to face Tami Mauriello.

"Meet Me in St. Louis," which has been playing to capacity business, will enter its second week at the Astor today. . . . "Dark Waters" begins a third week today at the Globe. . . . Revivals of "Roberta" and "Break of Hearts" start a week's stand today at the Ascot Theatre in the Bronx. . . .

After a doctor had pronounced her dead, Joan Rydell, 27 years old, a former showgirl and model, who was found yesterday morning lying unconscious in an overflowing tub of cold water in her basement apartment at 357 West End Avenue, was revived by a police inhalator squad.

The Giants must live the right sort of lives otherwise they wouldn't be where they are today, atop the Eastern division of the National Football League and within one game of a crack at the Green Bay Packers in the play-off for the championship here on Dec. 17.

KANDY, Ceylon, Dec. 4 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops besieging the Japanese stronghold of Bhamo in northern Burma isolated the airstrip yesterday from the enemy garrison, a Southeast Asia Command communique reported today.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Dec. 4 -- The battle for the Saar Basin on the American Third Army front reached a new phase today. With reinforced units of the Ninety-fifth Infantry Division holding half the city of Saarlautern on his left flank, Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr.

HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 4 (AP) -Cecil B. De Mille, movie and radio producer, said in a statement today that he would give up his weekly radio program "rather than pay one single dollar in political tribute which acknowledges that I am no longer a free man."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- By a voice vote the House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill amending the wartime anti-sabtage law to extend its coverage to certain activities not now covered. The measure has no effect on the law covering sabotage in peacetime.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Dec. 4 -- Land fighting on Leyte is deadlocked for the time being. The mud, like thin gruel, has forced the Americans momentarily to drop all-out attacks to smash the dug-in Japanese from the Ormoc corridor and secure this further base for future operations.

The health program conference, made up of a group of prominent physicians, economists and administrators, announced yesterday a new nation-wide health insurance program "that would insure good medical and hospital facilities to every man, woman and child in this country, regardless of ability to pay."

WITH BRITISH SECOND ARMY, in the Netherlands, Dec. 4 -- Once the Allies' armies have advanced deep into Germany, women auxiliary members of the United States and British forces will move into the rear areas, if the proposal meets with the approval of the Allies' Supreme Command.

ROME, Dec. 4 (AP) -- A United States Fifteenth Air Force bomber group that lost its bearings when its leader was shot down dropped 130 500-pound bombs across the city of Belgrade last April 16, Lieut. Gen. Ira C. Eaker revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Supreme Court reversed today conviction of Gustav H. Kann of Pittsburgh or charges of using the mails to defraud stockholders of Triumph Explosives, Inc., munitions manufacturer at Elkton, Md.

Industrialists and financiers should "put their shoulders to the wheel" to get out the additional war production needed on every front, Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker, president of Eastern Air Lines, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the annual convention of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners in the Hotel Commodore.

A well-adjusted performance of Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde," with a cast in the main familiar, and with some formerly weak places in it strengthened, was presented last night in the Metropolitan Opera House.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Dec. 4 -- With a preamble calling for extension of wartime cooperation into the post-war period, a three-year contract providing for no strikes and no lockouts has been signed by local warehousemen of Harry Bridges' Union and by San Francisco distributors.

The mere liberation of conquered countries will not solve the problem of the Jews in Europe, but action to save them must be begun immediately, speakers said last night at a meeting in Carnegie Hall under the auspices of the Emergency Committee to Save the Jewish People of Europe.

Among the most economical holiday baskets are those to be found at the Barricini shops, of which there are seventeen in the city. Yesterday at the newest store, a large and attractive establishment that has just been opened at the southeast corner of Cortlandt and Church Streets, we saw two that seemed especially outstanding.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Chester Bowles, head of the Office of Price Administration, endorsed today the Wagner amendment to the Price Control Act authorizing the OPA to control commercial rents.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 4 -- The German Foreign Office warned the French Provisional Government today that reprisal would be taken against "such members of the de Gaulle movement * * * as are at present in our hands, notably among conscript labor," unless what it termed "brutal, terroristic action" against German nationals and "pro-German elements" among Frenchmen ceased.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, chief of the Army Services of Supply, plans to renew his advocacy of a national service act if the current lag in war production is not taken up by the end of this month, he told the Mead investigating committee today.

Representatives of the Department of Commerce took under advisement the three-point program advanced by members of the National-American Wholesale Grocers Association at their meeting in Washington Saturday afternoon, it was learned yesterday. The Department of Commerce was asked to advise the grocers on the proper methods to be followed in urging ambitious and qualified young men to open their own grocery businesses.

LONDON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- One civilian of every 200 of Malta was killed and an average of ninety-nine tons of bombs rained down on every square mile of the rocky outpost during the twenty-eight-month siege, the Government revealed today.

Stars and Stripes is an Army newspaper that gives our men on the battlefronts the news and features of the day. One of its editors undertook to "josh" a contributor who wrote in to say that the average GI overseas wanted to go home as quickly as possible.
With the need for plasma ever on the increase, perhaps if letters from our fighting men were made public more civilians would be moved to make their contribution to the Red Cross blood bank.

Cotton trading quieted down yesterday, awaiting the outcome of the hearings before the subcommittee of the House Agriculture Committee. Final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were 2 points lower to 4 points higher for the active months.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 4 -- Ohio Democrats and the CIO Political Action Committee opened today a campaign to prevent the reseating of Senator Robert A. Taft as the Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections asked that ballots in the Taft-William G. Pickrel Senate race be impounded.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Miss Vivien Kellems said today that she knew how her correspondence with a German Count in Argentina fell into the hands of Drew Pearson, newspaper columnist, and Representative John M. Coffee.

The report of the West Indies Sugar Corporation and its subsidiaries disclosed yesterday in the annual statement for the fiscal year ended with September a net income of $4,126,643, after provision of $1,009,024 for post-war adjustments.

ALBANY, Dec. 4 -- John J. Dunnigan, Senate minority leader, is too ill to appear before the special grand jury investigating legislative spending, according to a letter from his physician made public today at Mr. Dunnigan's office in the Capitol.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- The Shell Oil Company of 50 West Fiftieth Street, New York, became today the fourth major oil corporation to collaborate in a bid for the leasing of the $4,000,000 Westchester Airport in Purchase, County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach announced after a conference this noon with Shell representatives.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 4 (U.P.) -- The entire Cadet corps of 2,300 men including all officers and instructors at the military academy traveled to Baltimore for the service football game with Navy on a War Department troopship, it was revealed officially tonight.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Adolf A. Berle Jr., still chief of the American delegation to the International Civil Aviation Conference described today his resignation as assistant secretary of State as part of Secretary Stettinius's efforts to reorganize the department and said that the President had honored him with a request that he assume another post of importance.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, Ninth Air Force, Dec. 4 -- One of the most courageous acts of the war on the Western Front was recounted tonight by a gunner of a Ninth Air Force medium bomber who was snatched from under the noses of the enemy behind the lines on Saturday after his plane had been forced down by a flaming engine.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz will lead a group of jurors, lawyers and court attaches this morning to the blood donor bank of the Brooklyn Red Cross at 57 Willoughby Street. He asked for volunteers yesterday while presiding in court.

Josef Lhevinne was at the height of his artistic powers when he died suddenly last Saturday night. Twelve days later he would have had his seventieth birthday. Yet it was as recently as the thirty-first of last July that Lhevinne gave a performance of Tchaikovsky's concerto at a Stadium concert that was superb for its technical mastery, physical virility and virtuoso spirit.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 4 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Although fiber-glass insulation within the last five years has made heavy inroads into the use of cotton and a bestos as insulating materials in electrical equipment, marketing plans of the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation call for a greater percentage-wise share in this market, officials of the company stated yesterday.
Yesterday's communique as transmitted by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The texts of exchanges between President Roosevelt and the resigning assistant Secretaries of State follow:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The North American Company asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to dismiss Illinois Power Company's application for approval of Illinois' plan for the liquidation and dissolution of its parent, North American Light and Power Company.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- British, Russian and American trade union representatives, including Sidney Hillman, representing the Congress of Industrial Organizations, met today to begin preparations for the world trade union conference that will open here Feb. 6.
Japanese forces pushed more deeply into southern China last week and American planes from the Marianas bases bombed Tokyo.

ATHENS, Dec. 4 -- An ultimatum to quit the Athens area was served on armed men of the Leftist Eam [National Liberation Front] today as the Greek crisis mounted with a general strike and open battle in one section of the capital. Violence spread after yesterday's bloody demonstration in which twenty-one persons were killed and 140 were injured.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Vice President Wallace asserted here tonight that his "most serious criticism" of American newspaper publishers "is that they fail to realize the deep underlying forces which are remorselessly pushing the world ahead." He charged that north of the Ohio River the vast majority of the publishers of newspapers are either reactionary or Republican or both.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Secretary of Agriculture Claude Wickard today proposed Government subsidies to cotton growers, at least for a while, as the key part of a post-war program to help the embattled cotton industry compete in the domestic and foreign markets.

Ralph Greenleaf went into the lead in the Centennial World three-cushion billiard championship tournament by defeating Joe Procita yesterday as play continued in the tourney at the Hotel Capitol. Clicking off points at a brisk pace in the early stages of the match, Greenleaf humbled his New York rival by the score of 50 to 18 in 28 innings.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 4 -- Army Liberators of the Seventh Air Force blasted Japanese air bases in the Bonin and Volcano Islands on Saturday (West Longitude time) on the seventh straight day of American atacks against the enemy's major air facilities that threaten our Saipan Superfortress station, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz reported today.

ROME, Dec. 4 -- The Italian political crisis will almost surely end tomorrow or the next day and Premier Ivanoe Bonomi will head a new government backed by all the parties of the Committee of National Liberation except the Action party.

ROME, Dec. 4 (U.P.) -- Katharine Cornell, who has played to packed Broadway houses and theatres and barns all over America, was equally popular in Rome today, when she rated number one on the "bathtub circuit," proving a bigger draw than fourteen generals, a king, seven Italian counts and a Sardinian acrobat.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 11 per cent last week in comparison with the like week of last year, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported a gain of 14 per cent.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Tuesday, Dec. 5 (AP) -- A communique:

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4 (U.P.) -- Byron Nelson of Toledo, the nation's top money-winning pro and most consistent player of wartime golf, won the $14,500 San Francisco open for the second straight time today, shooting a brilliant three-under-par 69 in the final round to edge out Sgt. Jim Ferrier of the United States Army by one stroke.

TWENTY-FIRST BOMBER COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Saipan, Dec. 3 (Delayed) (AP) -- A wounded B-29 Superfortress limped back from today's attack on Tokyo after knocking down two Japanese planes in a collision, fighting off strong enemy fighter assaults and probably shooting down three more Japanese planes.

LONDON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- In the most concentrated attack of the war on Germany's railway system feeding the western front more than 4,000 Allied planes today blasted eight enemy rail arteries with nearly 12,000 tons of bombs in twelve hours.

Tragedy yesterday engulfed the home of a destitute mother who had been deserted by her husband for another woman. Two of the children were fatally burned in a fire set by a third while playing with matches.

Estimating that there are 30,000 unfilled war production jobs in New York City, another 30,000 elsewhere in New York State and 40,000 in near-by New Jersey communities, Brig. Gen. Stewart E. Reimel, chief of the New York Ordnance District, declared yesterday at a press conference in his office, 80 Broadway, that "more manpower is needed at many war plants immediately if we are to meet General Eisenhower's demands for December production."

UNION, N.J., Dec. 4 -- William F. McGuinness, vice president and treasurer of the Elastic Stop Nut Corporation, whose president, William T. Hedlund, committed suicide last Wednesday, will continue as chief executive officer and with the other officers will direct the business of the company under the provisions of its by-laws.

ROME, Dec. 4 (U.P.) -- A sharp enemy counter-attack directed against the Fifth Army's positions was trdown back today by American troops at Mount Belmonte, eight miles south of Bologna, as the Germans maintained the initiative in this sector for the fifth consecutive day.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Japan, on the losing end of a war of attrition, has lost another light cruiser and a destroyer to the far-ranging United States submarine fleet.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Joseph Clark Grew, in becoming Under-Secretary of State, returns to a post he held for a time twenty years ago. He has served two-score years in the diplomatic service.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 4 -- This is the story of a Netherlands town told by an American who apologized because security regulations made it impossible for him to disclose its name and for the fact that his account came second-hand:

STRUTHOF, France, Dec. 3 (Delayed) -- It might have been a Civilian Conservation Corps camp. From the winding road to the bald hilltop, the sturdy green barracks buildings looked exactly like those that housed forestry trainees in the United States during the early New Deal.

The Central Savings Bank has sold the seventeen-story and penthouse apartment at 550 Park Avenue, southwest corner of Sixty-second Street, to an investing client of Samuel Fromberg and Irving Schneider, attorneys. The property, assessed at $1,270,000, occupies a plot 100 by 116 feet, and the building has thirty-three apartments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (U.P.) -- Archibald MacLeish, who was appointed an Assistant Secretary of State today, has been librarian of Congress since 1939. The son of a native Scotsman, he was graduated from Yale University, where he combined verse writing with football and water polo, and later from Harvard Law School.

When Rochester's basketball team faces N.Y.U. in part of a double-header at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, those who attend are expected to see a new playing style by the Yellowjackets. Coach Lou Alexander reports that a fast break attack and a man-to-man defense has been installed to take advantage of his new team's speed.

New York City, with a thousand schools, 200 hospitals and 10,000 doctors, still fails to meet the full medical and health needs of children because there is no over-all program for them, Dr. Leona Baumgartner, director of the Bureau of Child Hygiene of the city Department of Health, said last night at New York Junior League headquarters, 221 East Seventy-first Street.

Because of "unbearable" Government regulations, two meat-packing houses in the metropolitan area have closed and others soon may follow their example, it was declared yesterday by Anthony Lester, business representative of Local 5 of the Packing House Workers Union of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Dispatches from Chungking yesterday cited "well-informed sources" as authority for the statement that "the next sixty days might determine whether China would be knocked out of the war." The fact that Chinese censorship permitted the statement to be made is as significant as the statement itself.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Probably another 85,000 workers from an already inadequate labor supply will be needed to meet the $500,000,000 program of new mortar ammunition plants as announced over the week-end by J. A. Krug, chairman of the War Production Board.

Representing an expenditure of approximately $300,000, "Rhapsody," the operetta containing a score by Fritz Kreisler, failed to give a performance last night at the Century. At the theatre it was not known when the engagement would be resumed. Acting on instructions from Allan Attwater, company manager, and George Oshrin, house manager, the box office was busy making refunds yesterday.
Army's point-a-minute football machine set the pace in 1944 as college teams throughout the nation rolled up scores at a faster clip than they have in any season since the early Nineteen Twenties.

It was Exultation Day at Toot Shor's yesterday when the Football Writers held their weekly luncheon, Coach Steve Owen of the Giants and Herman (Kinfolk) Hickman, Army's equally stout line coach, exulting all over the place as a result of their teams' victories over Washington and Navy, respectively.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The low pay scale for children's librarians and the lack of appropriations for children's books, in large as well as small cities, was deplored before Mrs. Roosevelt's press conference today by Mrs. Helen Ferris, Director of the Junior Literary Guild.

The theatre turned its sinister eye on the pathological melodrama last evening when "Hand in Glove" brought a maniac, a Yard man and an assorted group of Cockney characters to the stage of the Playhouse. If the function of melodrama is to send its audience into a mass jump at the sudden opening of a door, the law-abiding citizens at the Playhouse were jumping in good order last night.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Forecasting that both the political and economic systems of the United States "will be on trial in the immediate period ahead as never before," Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, asserted tonight that farmers could be a powerful force in removing hindrances and obstacles to the successful functioning of the economic system of the nation.
Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, retired, formally took over yesterday as president of the Empire State, Inc., after forty-five years in the Army. He succeeds the late Alfred E. Smith.

ROME, Dec. 4 -- The battle of Ploesti was the "bloodiest single air battleground of the war," but the Mediterranean Allied Air Force won it and it was worth the cost, Lieut. Gen. Ira Eaker said today, reviewing the great accomplishments of the MAAF since January.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 4 (AP) -- The North Carolina, feature attraction at Gulfstream Park's first Monday at racing was won by Mrs. Lottie Wolf's 4-year-old bay gelding Romulus today. G.T. Strother's Rocket Gal gained the place, Double Brab taking show money. Romulus withstood a claim of foul.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Warning that oil reserves are rapidly dwindling, the House Small Business Committee today urged consideration of higher price ceilings on crude oil.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Federal Trade Commission is going to try its hand at finding out where the cigarettes have gone.
ROME, Dec. 4 (UP) -- A communique:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Ethel Beck, 21, testified today before a House Military Affairs subcommittee that the Government paid $1,540 an acre for sod used at Camp Shanks, in Rockland County, N.Y.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- A joint plenary session of three main committees of the International Civil Aviation Conference approved today a convention setting up an international civil aviation organization, an agreement for an interim council pending ratification of the permanent body, and separate agreements on all five "freedoms" of the air (both political and commercial) and on the first two freedoms (political only).

BARI, Italy, Dec. 2 (Delayed) -- Yugoslavia and Bulgaria, enemies in two World Wars are now bound in fledgling friendship the solidarity of which, based on their common Slav affiliation, may make it possible for them, with Russia's blessing, to dominate the entire Balkan Peninsula.

Travel restraints are still in effect, officials of the Office of Defense Transportation and the Civil Aeronautics Administration pointed out yesterday in commenting on the brochure issued by the Department of the Interior, listing to prospective tourists the attractions of its National Park Service.

Nestle's evaporated milk, which has been sold sectionally under three names -- Lion Brand, Every Day Brand and Alpine Brand -- will henceforth be sold under one name, "Nestle's Evaporated Milk," it was revealed yesterday in advertising circles. A newspaper campaign, doubling Nestle's former newspaper lineage, is now breaking in 224 newspapers.

This letter is prompted by the editorial appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 24, "The Telephone Strike." I represent most of the telephone labor unions and have had occasion to present to the National War Labor Board practically every one of their cases.

Gov. Dewey returned yesterday from a post-campaign vacation at Sea Island, Ga., ready to tackle State business at Albany that piled up during his absence. The most pressing tasks before him are the drafting of his annual message and the preparation of a State budget for submission to the Legislature, which convenes in January.

Your excellent editorial in the Nov. 27 issue, "Research and War," states very clearly the problems and objectives of the Research Board for National Security which the Wilson committee recommended to the War and Navy Departments for dealing with post-war research, except in one particular.

OTTAWA, Dec. 4 -- It looks now if a way had been found to allow conscriptionists and anti-conscriptionists in the Canadian Parliament to go on record in a vote without imperiling the position of the Government. A sub-amendment, moved by a Montreal member, Joseph Jean, has been allowed to stand in which the words "without resorting to conscription for service overseas" have been retained.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- The chief interest today in a generally quiet stock market was the renewed active dealing in the ordinary units of British Celanese. Following Friday's jump in dealings after official hours, prices went ahead today on the decision to pay a 15 per cent dividend.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UP) -- Pacific Fleet Communique 196:
While nation-wide response to the Sixth War Loan has put the campaign $2,000,000,000 ahead of schedule in the nation, bond sales in New York State and New York City are lagging badly by comparison.

PARIS, Dec. 4 -- Henceforth -- for an unspecified time -- Parisiennes will have less eccentric coiffures than in the past two years, although this will not exclude variety. For some time emphasis had been placed on volume, wave upon wave of curls, calling for such long preparation that many women did not undo their hair at night.

In setting up a post-war international monetary program "we need to start from sound premises,'' the monthly review of economic conditions of the National City Bank of New York asserts in commenting on various widely accepted statements on the past role of the United States in world finance.

Directors of the Simplicity Pattern Company authorized yesterday the declaration of a stock dividend of one share of new $10 par, 5 1/2 per cent convertible preferred stock for each five shares of common stock held.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- Red Army forces, advancing sixteen miles across western Hungary, pushed to within sixty-four miles of the Austrian frontier and 122 miles of Vienna yesterday. The Russians also sent a flanking column twelve miles up the west bank of the Danube River in an encircling drive against Budapest.

CHUNGKING, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, addressing the new Cabinet Minsters today, admitted that the present situation was "extremely difficult," but said it was "near the stage of final victory" and that 'military developments at the front are within our anticipation.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Dec. 4 -- In a raging sea and air battle lasting more than four hours Saturday night, American light naval forces, including destroyers, sank one of three enemy vessels, believed to be destroyers, and damaged another entering Ormoc Harbor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Supreme Court decided today three British investment concerns with an American office are resident foreign corporations that may pay income taxes lower than those on alien concerns. Justice Murphy delivered the court's unanimous opinion.
MOSCOW, Dec. 4 -- Commemorating the eighth anniversary of the US.S.R.'s "Stalin Constitution," Pravda declared editorially today that "Soviet democracy is the most consistent democracy in the world."

A temporary suspension of all current sugar ration stamps was urged upon the Office of Price Administration yesterday by the New York State Food Merchants Association as a means of preventing hoard-buying during the shortage of that commodity.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 4 -- Foreign Minister T.V. Soong, brother of Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, assumed the duties of Premier of China today in a popular move apparently paving the way for a working agreement between the Central Government and the Communists of North China.

Julia Marlowe, noted actress, will emerge from her long retirement this afternoon when she will present to the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue between 103d and 104th Streets, eleven trunks of theatrical material relating to herself, her husband, the late E.H. Sothern with whom she starred in Shakespearean productions, and his father, Edward Askew Sothern, also a notable stage figure.

MOSCOW, Dec. 4 -- The Worker, official organ of the Polish Socialist party in Lublin, today supported the demand that the Committee of National Liberation should be transformed into a provisional government in liberated Poland.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Communique 240:

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 4 (U.P.) -- Japanese invaders of Kweichow Province, bolstered by reinforcements, drove north along the Kwangsi-Kweichow railway to within seven miles of Tuhshan, seveny-seven air miles from Kweiyang on the Kunming-Chungking highway, a Chinese communique admitted today.

WASHNGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- While there was no definite information here today that a final agreement in principle had been reached by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and the Communist leader General Chou En-lai, it was generally assumed that any settlement would be along the line insisted upon by the Communists from the very first:
PARIS, Dec. 4 -- Genevieve de Gaulle, 20-year-old niece of Gen. Charles de Gaulle, is seriously ill in the Ravensbrueck detention camp in Germany, it was revealed today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 -- Mrs. Emma C. Bergdoll, mother of Grover Bergdoll, No. 1 draft dodger of the first World War and widow of the wealthy brewer, Louis Bergdoll, died of pneumonia here early today in Lankenau Hospital. Her age was 83.

Marking the first action of its kind since the start of the war, the Railway Express Agency yesterday suspended acceptance of express shipments for twelve States, mainly in the South, and thirteen cities in other parts of the country. Lack of facilities on the railroads to handle express shipments was given as the reason at the offices of the agency here.

PARIS, Dec. 4 -- Committees of the Socialist and Communist parties, meeting today, decided to "establish an atmosphere of comprehension and friendly cooperation" between the two groups and to urge the creation of a permanent "committee of entente" to seek the "political unity of French labor."

WITH AMERICAN FIRST ARMY in Germany, Dec. 4 -- Our victory at Lucherberg, which became almost wholly ours today after another day of intense fighting, has given us the greatest improvement in our positions since the capture of Aachen.

Leopold Stokowski and the New York City Symphony presented an all-Russian program at the City Center last night, opening with Deems Taylor's "Fanfare for the People of Russia," and having as its principal work Tchaikovsky's Sixth Symphony.

HERMAN HICKMAN and Steve Owen shook hands warmly. "Congratulations!" they exclaimed simultaneously. Comdr. Oscar Hagberg and Dud DeGroot also shook hands. "Too bad," they said simultaneously. It was pure coincidence that they paired off that way, the coaches of the two winners of the week-end's big games and the coaches of the two losers -- Army and the Giants, Navy and the Redskins.

MEMPHIS, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The threat of a strike by long distance operators in Memphis and Louisville was ended tonight when the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced it had agreed to meet the operators' demands for a $5 weekly wage increase.

NORFOLK, England, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Sir Eric Teichman, 60 years old, one of Britain's most colorful diplomats and an authority on the Orient, was shot dead on the grounds of his spacious estate, Honingham Hall, yesterday -- presumably by poachers.

Despite the current differences between their Governments, the Chinese people in general have a friendly attitude toward Americans. We have two important things in common. Chinese and Americans are both democratic by nature.

Last June a naval Court of Inquiry and an Army Board were appointed to investigate the circumstances of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. These inquiries were held and reports were made. The Secretaries of the War and Navy Departments, and their advisers, have studied these reports.

The strike of custodial workers in the city's schools conducted by Local 112 of the School Custodial Employes, an affiliate of the United Mine Workers, failed to develop any marked strength yesterday, the first day when classes were in session since the formal beginning of the walkout Saturday.
On Sunday Britain's Home Guard, 2,000,000 strong, closed their four-year record book. Then through all their battered home cities they marched out of service to the cheers of a nation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- When the Army's convalescence program gets under way in eleven convalescent hospitals, occupational therapy will play its part in the slow healing of long-time cases, just as it has in the reconditioning of men who have had amputation, Mrs. Winifred Kahmann, who heads the occupational therapy program, said today in an interview.

Ever since I started the Volunteer Prison League I have been in close touch with the families of men in our State and Federal prisons and have tried to bring to them help and cheer at the Christmas season.

A broad buying movement which developed on the stock market yesterday carried prices close to the high level set in mid-October and pushed the composite price for rails to the highest point since 1937. With demand spread out over a wide variety of groups, values were increased from fractions to 2 points on the largest volume in three months.

B.J. Van Ingen Co., and associates won yesterday the award of $1,713,000 of refunding bonds of Coral Gables, Fla., on a bid of par for the securities. Of the total, $1,198,000 were sold as 3's maturing from 1954 to 1973, and $515,000 as 3 1/2's due on July 1, 1979.

Emphasizing that "a successful store carefully and persistently devotes a large measure of its energies to the establishment of a cordial understanding with those with whom it does business," the vendor relations committee of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., New York, yesterday mailed a report to the manufacturers, jobbers and other suppliers with whom the store deals throughout the world.

This being a world in which there are still a few prejudiced men and a good many careless ones, it is to be hoped that Mayor La Guardia's statement suffers no distortion or misinterpretation. He was thanking his fellow-citizens for sending him a total of $668 to meet a telephone bill of $107 incurred in the public interest.
Yesterday's communique, as reported by the Federal Communications Commission from a Moscow broadcast to the Soviet Union:

Award of the Bronze Star Medal and the Soldier's Medal to First Lieut. Arthur I. Neuhauser for heroism in the battle of Normandy was disclosed yesterday by his wife, Mrs. Roslyn B. Neuhauser of 1671 Andrews Avenue, the Bronx.

George W. Spinney, president of the Bank of Montreal, said at the annual meeting of stockholders at Montreal yesterday that it would be a mistake to "let the Government do everything," despite the great magnitude of post-war conversion problems, "unless we are content to go along the road Germany followed to totalitarianism."

DARRELL GARWOOD'S biography of Grant Wood, "Artist in Iowa,"* is a singularly simple and unpretentious book. With no heavy esthetic theorizing about Wood's significance in art, with no unjustified speculations about the secrets of another man's mind and heart, Mr. Garwood has just put one word after another, arranging in proper order what he was able to find out about one of american's most celebrated persons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Federal District Court at Newark, N.J., today authorized eighteen oil companies to enter into agreements, making available to industry the royalty-free use of hydrogenation patents during the war.

Officials of Pan American Airways labored through the last week-end to complete a program to provide new capital for its postwar expansion plans in time for action by the board of directors at a meeting scheduled for tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- President Roosevelt began a sweeping reorganization of the State Department today with the biggest shaking up of high officials there in many years.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Dec. 3 (Delayed) -- Service men from the Aleutians took four of seven bouts last night to continue to lead the Alaskan boxing tourney.
LONDON, Dec. 4 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berin and recorded by The United Press:

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- The grain markets turned strong after an early dip today on the Board of Trade here. Corn, which led the decline Saturday, led the upturn today and closing trades were about the top with gains of 1 1/8 to 1 7/8 cents a bushel, December leading.

When General Somervell told a committee of Congress yesterday that he has always favored the enactment of a National War Service Act he was expressing the strong and consistent opinion of the War Department. Secretary Stimson went before another committee of Congress, nearly a year ago, to urge in the strongest possible terms the enactment of precisely such a measure.

Immediate American intervention in Greece "to stop further bloodshed" was urged yesterday by Basil Vlavianos, head of the Greek section of the International Editorial Board of the Free World Association, with offices at 724 Fifth Avenue.

New specifications for making cotton duck mildew-resistant are expected within the next ten days, according to Worth Street sources yesterday. The revisions will in effect confirm new types of chemical finishes that have been applied by most mills to duck produced in the last three months and will mean that tentage now being sent to tropical climates will have a substantially longer life.

AGANA, Guam, Dec. 3 (Delayed) -- The brightest Christmas in three years is in store for a score of pitifully undernourished children of Guam who have been saved from death by Navy medical care. There are about fifty children in the babies' ward and the second floor of the former United States Naval Hospital, much of which was damaged or destroyed when our forces liberated Guam.

AN AMERICAN COMMAND POST, Outside Mutzig, Dec. 4 (AP) -- American engineers sent a truckload of dynamite crashing against the castle fortress on a hilltop outside Mutzig today where a band of Germans have been holding out far behind American lines for nine days.

Times Telephoto Equipment, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and the men and women who work for it will receive the Army-Navy E for "high achievement in the production of war materiel," according to a letter received yesterday from Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War.

The Brooklyn Bond Bouts, a card of ten three-rounders among boxers representing Army posts of the New York Port of Embarkation and the training station of the Maritime Service, Sheepshead Bay, to be held at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, tomorrow night, are a complete sellout.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Johnny Grigas, who pulled stakes for home on the eve of the Car-Pitt finale against the Chicago Bears, told his coaches in a letter made public today that "in all justice it is for the best" that he leave the club.
PARIS, Dec. 4 -- Floods following persistent rains have complicated conditions in France.

The Thoroughbred Racing Associations, at their annual meeting yesterday, again pledged cooperation with war agencies, assured further war relief contributions in 1945, and repeated "unanimous opposition" to off-the-course betting. Harry A. Parr 3d of Pimlico, who was re-elected president, in stressing the opposition of the group to horse betting anywhere except within a race track, said:

To little Margaret Joan Erasmus the sights of New York seemed yesterday just a dim blur on her first visit here, but before she returns to her home in Vereeniging, South Africa, she will really see them. Through special treatments prescribed as necessary by the 11-year-old girl's doctors to prevent her from going blind, her sight will be saved.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Sticklers for diplomatic proprieties, the British were shocked tonight by the State Department's plain and forthright public rebuke of their Government's policy in Italy and, by implication, in Greece.
ALBANY, Dec. 5 (AP) -- President Roosevelt's New York State plurality over Governor Dewey in the Nov. 7 election stood officially tonight at 316,591.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Senator Wagner of New York, sponsor of the Social Security Law, declared tonight that the legislative effort to block a scheduled doubling of the payroll tax threatened to "undermine our present system."

The War Food Administration reported yesterday an increase of almost 4 per cent in national creamery butter production last week but warned housewives against undue optimism. National butter production for the week ended last Saturday was 19,600,000 pounds, against 18,900,000 pounds the week before.

Behind the personalities involved in the resignations and new appointments announced by Mr. Roosevelt there is evident a desire to find a place in the State Department for certain new activities of the Government which properly belong there. This is true, for example, of the office of Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs.
Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower bluntly informed the German people yesterday that they "cannot count upon food, fuel or clothing from the Military Government," but must rely upon their own resources.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Wednesday, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- Barges as well as airplanes are being used to supply American troops in some front-line areas of Leyte and the food and ammunition are going forward in sufficient quantity to keep Gen. Douglas MacArthur's ground forces on the offensive, it was disclosed today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Here is a summary of the Convention on International Cicil Aviation as adopted today by the World Air Conference.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Because of the removal of 26,000 tons of machinery and material from Rumanian oil fields to Russia, the weekly output of oil has fallen to 500,000 or 600,000 gallons instead of 2,600,000 gallons.

Feed bags and sugar sacks will soon be ripped apart and remade into towels and tablecloths, suits and pinafores. That is, if the textile bag manufacturers are successful in their current campaign to persuade women to see eye to eye with them on the use of 800,000,000 yards of this previously unproductive fabric.

The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank has sold the two-story building at 121 Westmoreland Avenue, White Plains, N.Y., occupied by the Laderle Laboratories, to a syndicate headed by Irving Brodsky, attorney. The property is assessed at $79,800 and was sold for cash above a ten-year mortgage of $70,000.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Bedding manufacturers were warned today by L. Gerald Koch, president of the National Association of Bedding Manufacturers, to cultivate the interest of the retailer in the sale of bedding products or fail to secure their share of post-war consumer dollar.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Army and Navy are spending millions of dollars for the production of rockets, which have developed as one of the principal weapons of this war, the Office of War Information disclosed today. Its report on American development and use of rockets hinted that new secret rocket projectiles might be in prospect.

Two dreams were realized yesterday in the United Nations Officers Club, 21 East Fifty-fourth Street, as 5-year-old Joseph Kulash and Louise Kalanz, 4, met their first war hero and Lieut. Lawrence E. Gilbert, LST commander who has received the Navy Cross, obtained tickets for the first opera he will have attended in three years.

Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker is a man of whom every American can feel proud. He is a very brave man, a man with an outstanding record in both World Wars, a patriot willing to make any sacrifice, a citizen completely earnest and sincere. But perhaps he ought not to venture into the fields of economics and finance.

The first film to be made by the recently formed Jesse Lasky Productions, Inc., will be the tentatively titled "Thanks, God, I'll Take It From Here," a forthcoming novel by Jane Allen and Mae Livingston. The story, for which the firm paid $75,000, will be published in book form and serialized shortly.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Wednesday, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Using powerful bazookas, American ground forces turned back a tank-supported Japanese attack Sunday night on the road block established on the Ormoc highway a mile and a half south of the Leyte River bridge below Limon.

The small towns where many war workers live are going into the "tunnel" for the fourth winter of the war. Those living twenty miles or more from the plants and using buses or trains and trolleys leave home in the dark and return in the dark.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 5 (U.P.) -- Protests from local merchants over the loss of business caused the House of Assembly to reverse itself today on the question of a curfew for American naval personnel because of alleged misbehavior.

Several of my shipmates and I would like to say to your readers that we were certainly not in favor of Noel Coward's passage from his recent book, "Middle East Diary," and we hope that you do not take this as the general opinion of the fighting men of Britain.
The strike of school custodial workers continued yesterday with diminished effectiveness as strikers returned to work in a number of schools.

Counseling services and educational programs must be made available after the war to at least 3,000,000 boys and girls who left school for war jobs, according to the annual report of the National Child Labor Committee for the year ended Sept. 30, issued yesterday by Mrs. Gertrude Folks Zimand, general secretary.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Secretary Stettinius said today that he was proceeding with a prompt revision of the organization of the State Department.

Net operating earnings of the Bank of Manhattan Company for 1944 are estimated at $4,800,000, based on figures for the first nine months, . . Stewart Baker, chairman of the board, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday.

The Associated Ship-Chandlers, three of whose member concerns are being sued in Federal court here by the Office of Price Administration for $87,840 treble damages in connection with sales of meat to vessels of the United Nations, declared yesterday that the suits involved a difference of interpretation of price mark-ups and should not be construed as implying willful wrongdoing or overcharging.
ROME, Dec. 5 -- Ravenna fell yesterday morning to a brilliant encircling movement by Canadians of Princess Louise's Dragon Guards, it was announced today.

WITH THE AMERICAN FIRST ARMY, in Germany, Dec. 5 -- The Germans made a determined effort today to retake the key village of Lucherberg and break our line where it bulges eastward along Adolf Hitler's motor highway toward Dueren, five miles away.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates will offer publicly today $4,500,000 of 2 per cent public improvement and funding bonds of Providence, R.I., at prices to yield from 0.50 to 1.65 per cent, according to maturity. The bonds mature serially from June 1, 1946 to 1965.

Who liberated the liberated nations of Europe? Was it the Allied armies or was it the Resistance, a name which has supplanted the former Underground but has retained its mystic connotations? A correct answer is highly relevant to the turmoil now boiling up in the liberated countries behind the Allied fronts.

Under-Secretary of State Joseph C. Grew and Henry P. Fletcher, former Ambassador to Italy and Mexico, will join the list of State Department officials and representatives at the Dumbarton Oaks conference who are now explaining the Dumbarton Oaks proposals at a series of regional meetings under the auspices of Americans United for World Organization, Inc., Dr. Ernest M. Hopkins, chairman, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- Russian armor rolled up to eighteen miles across western Hungary yesterday to reach the southern shores of Lake Balaton, great outer defense barrier before Vienna, while other spearheads drove to within fifty-two miles of the Austrian border.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Delegations of fifty-two nations participating at the International Civil Aviation Conference met in a plenary session tonight and adopted a "final act" which will be signed Thursday at the closing session.

WITH THE BRITISH SECOND ARMY, in the Netherlands, Dec. 5 -- British soldiers took a day off today wherever it was possible in honor of St. Nicholas, who comes to the Netherlands Dec. 5 with presents for children. On Dec. 25 Christmas will be celebrated in churches.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 5 -- The war, like time itself, has dealt gently with Prof. Jean Capart, jovial director of Egyptology in the Queen Elizabeth Foundation in Brussels and advisory curator of the Egyptian department of the Brooklyn Museum.

The railroads, to continue their progress in improving the transportation of the nation, need "a fair and equal chance to carry that part of the total traffic for which they are economically best fitted on the basis of true costs and services." Robert S. Henry, assistant to the president of the Association of American Railroads, declared here yesterday before the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

PARIS, Dec. 5 (AP) -- American Armies fighting along the German border face a tire shortage so serious it threatens to tie up 10 per cent of all Army vehicles by early February, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower declared today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The loss of five vessels of the United States Central Pacific Force, four of them by enemy action and the other by an accidental explosion, was announced today by the Navy Department. The ships were:

Mildred Waldman, Chicago-born pianist, who has studied with Ernest Hutcheson in this city, gave her Town Hall debut recital last night before a large and warmly responsive audience. In a program consisting of the Bach Partita in C minor, Beethoven's Sonata in C major, Opus 53 ("Waldstein"), a Brahms group and a closing group of numbers by Bloch, Prokofieff and Dohnanyi, she played with brilliance and zest.

Programs for promoting interracial relationships in the schools and colleges were discussed by 250 educators yesterday at an all-day "institute on intercultural education," sponsored by the Commission on Educational Organizations of the National Conference of Christians and Jews and held at the Biltmore Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Illinois Power Company asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to restrain the North American Company, the North American Light and Power Company and the Illinois Traction Company from soliciting proxies from holders of Illinois Power's publicly-held shares.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- A country-wide effort for family financial planning on a longer-range and more interesting basis than budgeting and bookkeeping is being started by the Extension Service of the Department of Agriculture.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 5 -- Twentieth Century-Fox will produce a musical next year based on the life of the late Oscar Hammerstein. The screen play for the biography, to be titled "Romance With Music," will be written by the subject's grandson, Oscar Hammerstein 2d, who will be the co-producer with Otto Preminger, the latter directing it.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Corn was again the market leader today on the Board of Trade. Prices were up 1 3/4 cents a bushel at one time on fairly general buying induced by continued small country offerings of cash grain for deferred shipment, reports that the Government was seeking additional supplies for lend-lease, and wet weather in the Central West.

A large and attentive audience listened to the National Symphony Orchestra of Washington, Hans Kindler conductor, assisted by Helen Traubel, soprano, and Egon Petri, pianist, at the concert they gave last night in the Metropolitan Opera House under the auspices of the Netherland-American Foundation for the benefit of the Hendrik Willem van Loon Scholarship Fund.

Distribution of exchange tickets for the "Treasury Bond Bowl" football game, between the undefeated and untied Randolph Field Ramblers of Texas and the Second Air Force Superbombers of Colorado at the Polo Grounds on Dec. 16, will begin tomorrow at New York City's leading department stores and all Manhattan banks and their branches.

LONDON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- American soldiers are paying with their lives for a Western Front shell shortage, a Daily Mail dispatch declared today. Noel Monks, correspondent with the United States Ninth Army, wrote:

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 5 -- The doughboys of Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's Third American Army fought their way through the town of Saarlautern into main Siegfried Line positions today, while the rest of the Third Army plunged northward toward Saarbruecken and Sarreguemines.

Net profit of the Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company and its domestic subsidiaries amounted to $1,509,657 for the first nine months of this year, after all charges, including $12,686,000 provision for estimated reconversion, renegotiation, taxes and contingencies, the report disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The entire program of amicable international commercial relations, to which former Secretary of State Hull had devoted the last twelve years, faces the danger of being wrecked by provisions for disposal of surplus cotton written into the Surplus Property Act by Congress in September, Dean Acheson, Assistant Secretary of State, warned a Congressional group here today.

Out of the welter of facts and figures at the New York State Conservation Council convention at Bear Mountain emerged a number of resolutions that will guide the group's policy for the ensuing year. These are presented today in digest form.

The Guaranty Trust Company has sold the three-story "taxpayer" and office building at the northwest corner of Burnside and Jerome Avenues, the Bronx, to a syndicate represented by Karelsen, Karelsen Rubin, attorneys. The trust company has occupied a large part of the property for a number of years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- President Roosevelt told Congress today that while the 100,000,000 people liberated in Europe "would produce themselves more than 90 per cent of the food and clothes they need," effective aid by the United Nations was necessary if "famine and pestilence" were to he prevented from sweeping across large areas, "taking millions of lives and endangering our victory."

ATHENS, Dec. 5 -- There is every sign of civil war here today. It has ceased to smolder and has come out into the open, raging in furious blasts of machine-gun and tommy-gun, mortar, grenade and small-arms fire. Armored cars advance toward the sections where the fighting appears severest and noisiest.

Advertising in all New York newspapers during November totaled 9,685,903 lines, a decline of 4.97 per cent compared with the 10,191,971 lines during the corresponding period of last year, according to a compilation of Media Records figures.

THE NEW YORK TIMES has rightly suggested on several occasions that "either the Administration or Congress should long ago have turned over the post-war unemployment compensation problem to a committee of experts for study and recommendations."

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- Grave political disturbances that have broken out in Belgium, Italy, Greece and in the liberated part of Holland cannot surprise anyone aware of the unendurable conditions of life in these countries. The only surprise is that they occur under Allied military occupation and are aggravated rather than allayed by Allied or, in the case of Italy, by British intervention.

Through the office of the International Red Cross in Geneva there has just passed a diplomatic protest against "executions without trials," "arbitrary death sentences" and other actions termed "brutal, terroristic and unwarranted." Can such a protest do any good?

As history goes, even the history of this war, six months is no long stretch of time. But it is long enough to have encompassed a great military campaign. Long enough too for a lot of men to have died. To us at home the days and months have seemed at times interminable. How much longer they must have been for the men on the battlefronts.

With the supply of children's shoes now some 25 per cent less than what the industry regards as minimum needs, easing of the situation is expected to be brought about soon by Government action to increase inventories, it was said yesterday by market spokesmen.
TWENTY-FIRST BOMBER COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Saipan, Dec. 3 (Delayed) (AP) -- Photographs of the fourth raid on Tokyo, carried out today, showed that the Nakajima aircraft plant was badly hit.

Sgt. Anthony Fox of the Elizabeth Street station, who once received official commendation for bravery in the arrest of two armed robbers, was himself arrested yesterday afternoon at Bellevue Hospital, charged with "suspicion of homicide" in the fatal shooting of a Bowery habitue.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- The Luftwaffe rallied its strength again today and put up hundreds of planes over Berlin to challenge American heavy bombers making their first attack on the German capital in two months. The foe lost at least ninety-one aircraft.

AN AMERICAN GENERAL HOSPITAL, in the Vosges Area, Dec. 5 -- Yvette Hamel cried against her pillow most of yesterday, and this afternoon she simply would not smile. When a girl is pretty and seventeen but with both legs amputated, that might not be unusual, yet her injury was not the cause of her tears.

With the exception of fiber shipping containers, the container supply situation will be improved considerably during the first quarter of 1945, H. Hunter Lewis, chief, containers section, forest products division, Office of Civilian Requirements, declared yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 5 -- Mrs. A.M. Sobel of New York, Mrs. Wilkinson Wagar of Atlanta, Ga., Mrs. Ralph C. Young of Philadelphia and Mrs. J.E. Folline of Richmond, Va., took the lead in the first session of play for the national contract bridge championship for women's teams-of-four at the Brighton Hotel here today, opening the eighteenth annual tournament of the American Contract Bridge League, which will continue through Sunday.

Contending that diapers have become increasingly scarce in the last sixty days because mills "are governed by price ceilings which presently yield an inadequate return," the National Institute of Diaper Services made public yesterday a resolution urging the Office of Price Administration to permit manufacturers to charge higher prices.

Authorities in the trade are expecting the arrival of a shipment of olive oil from Spain, the first to be imported from Europe since 1941. They anticipate that the new supplies, which will not be rationed, will be on retailers' shelves "some time in January."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- By a vote of 262 to 72 the House passed a bill today freezing the Social Security tax at the present rate of 1 per cent each on employer and employe for the calendar year 1945.

ROME, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The sinking of the unilluminated German hospital ship Tuebingen by planes of the Allied coastal patrol shortly before sunrise Nov. 18 was announced today by Allied headquarters. Regrets over the incident have been conveyed to the Germans, the communique said.

ALBANY, Dec. 5 -- The names of forty-three women are included in the list of 137 passing the October examination for admission to the bar, it was announced today by John Kirkland Clark of New York, Philip J. Wickser of Buffalo and John T. DeGraff of Albany, comprising the State Board of Law Examiners.

Olds, chairman of the board of directors of the United States Steel Corporation, said last night.

" Portraits of Warriors," an exhibition of paintings, many of them from public and private collections, is to open today at Portraits, Inc., 460 Park Avenue. There will be a reception this afternoon, with admission at $3, proceeds to go to the Overseas Service of the Y.W.C.A.

News of victory parades already being planned at home, the lack of ammunition and the shortage of cigarettes are foremost among the gripes of the average soldier, Lieut. Col. Ensley Llewellyn, director of the Army newspaper Stars and Stripes in the European theatre, said yesterday at the office of Yank, 205 East Forty-second Street.

After early slight easiness, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange firmed yesterday and closed 2 to 7 points net higher than Monday's final levels.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- J.A. Krug, chairman of the War Production Board, reported today that acceptance of new aircraft in November totaled only 6,747 planes, a figure which fell short of the month's schedule by about 300 planes.
A new printing of "From These Roots," Mary Colum's book on literary ideas and philosophies, first published by Scribner's in 1937, will be issued on Dec. 15 by the Columbia University Press.

The Legion of Merit Medal for service as Navy task force supply officer in the invasion of Normandy was presented yesterday to Capt. R.F. Batchelder of Worcester, Mass., by Rear Admiral W.A. Buck, director of material redistribution and disposal, in 342 Madison Avenue.

Robert Kitain, violinist, gave his first recital of the season at Carnegie Hall last night. Mr. Kitain's program opened with the Bach-Kreisler Prelude in E and included Brahms' D Minor Sonata, Paganini's Concerto in D Major, the Francaix Sonatine, and shorter works by Szymanowski, De Falla, Debussy and Stravinsky-Dushkin.

HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Cecil B. de Mille, radio and movie producer, announced through his attorney today that he would file suit tomorrow to prevent the American Federation of Radio Artists from removing him from his $5,000-a-week radio program because of refusal to pay a $1 assessment.

Dr. Waldo H. Mork, president-elect of the Dental Society of the State of New York, said in an address last night before the annual Greater New York Dental Meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania that the dental profession was confronted with "two gigantic problems that must be solved."

Leslie Horvath of Parma, Ohio, who guided the Buckeyes to an untied and unbeaten slate and the Western Conference football championship, last night received the tenth annual Heisman Memorial Trophy for 1944 at the Downtown A.C. Wilfred Wottrich, president of the Downtown A.C., which awards the trophy each year to the athlete selected as the outstanding college football player, made the presentation.
The Pacific war theatre bristles with Murphys and the mathematical chances of two Murphy brothers meeting in that blue expanse with its thousands of islands seemed insignificant.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Dec. 5 -- The Philippines desires independence as rapidly as the military situation permits, but is willing to grant the United States whatever naval and military bases are deemed necessary for joint security, and also wants the closest economic relations by a trade treaty when the Tydings-McDuffie act provisions expire, President Sergio Osmena, President of the Philippines Commonwealth, declared today.

Lieut. Comdr. Lincoln Ellsworth, USNR, told guests at the tenth anniversary meeting of the American Polar Society in Roosevelt Memorial Hall, American Museum of Natural History, last night, he plans to build a permanent weather station in the Antarctic.

WATERVLIET, N.Y., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Three of the newest Army Ordnance Department guns, made at Watervliet Arsenal, helped push the enemy back in Europe "farther than he ever expected to go," Brig. Gen. A.G. Gillespie, commander of the arsenal, said today.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 5 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Communique 241:

BOSTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Montreal's speedy Canadiens strengthened their National Hockey League lead by outskating the Boston Bruins for a 4-1 triumph, their fourth straight, tonight before 13,000 spectators at the Boston Garden. Toe Blake of the victors took over the circuit's point-making lead from Boston's Bill Cowley by collecting two goals and an assist for a total of twenty-six.

WITH UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY, Dec. 5 -- A German, who has just come into a First Army prison cage, is a walking history of the decline in the Reich's military power. He has been in every branch of the German armed services only to have it shot from under him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- On the ground that control of commercial rentals was a matter for State and local governments to handle, rather than the Federal authorities, the Senate Banking Committee today voted, 10 to 7, against submitting a measure which would have put control in the hands of the Office of Price Administration.

MYITKYINA, Burma, Dec. 4 (Delayed) (AP) -- Two American Air Force generals with commands in the China-Burma-India theatre believe that "the Japanese have written off Burma," but that Japanese suicide troops remaining behind must be destroyed in hard fighting before the country is recaptured.
I have no fault to find with ceiling prices. They are necessary though impossible to set fairly in all cases. May I present the poultry producers' problem:
GUAM, Nov. 21 (U.P.) (Delayed) -- Top military men on this war-ravaged American outpost envisage the eventual creation of a "Pearl Harbor of the western Pacific" on this island.

A capacity audience greeted Miss Julia Marlowe, noted actress, yesterday when she made her first public appearance since the death of her husband, E. H. Sothern, in 1933. Miss Marlowe opened an exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue between 103d and 104th Streets, comprising selections from eleven trunks of theatrical material that she has presented to the museum's theatre collection.

The stock market succeeded yesterday in surpassing the high marks of October and made headway toward the July peaks. With price gains of fractions to a point, against advances double the size on Monday, the list encountered some difficulty at times due to profit-taking.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Baltimore Ohio Railroad today submitted to the Interstate Commerce Commission details of its adjustment plan, which has already been placed before its bond-holders and for which it informed the commission it has received written assurances from at least 25 per cent of the aggregate amount of all claims affected by the plan as required by Chapter XV of the Bankruptcy Act.
