ON THE AMERICAN THIRD ARMY FRONT, Dec. 5 -- The great Saar Valley, one of the vital spots in the Reich's military and economic structure, was bright tonight in the eerie light of flames from some of its most important cities as troops of the Third Army moved relentlessly toward the Rhine.

ROME, Dec. 5 -- The State Department's declaration that the United States expected the Italians to form a Government "without influence from outside" dropped on Rome like a V-2 missile and temporarily scattered Premier Ivanoe Bonomi's almost-formed Government to the winds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 The War Production Board in effect returned the packaging of small articles to pre-war status today by lifting quota restrictions on the use of cellophane for the packaging, wrapping or sealing of cigarettes, cigars, chewing or smoking tobacco and bakery products.

In an introduction to a report on and a digest of the Bretton Woods Agreement, published here yesterday by the Citizens Conference on International Economic Union, Louis Heaton Pink, chairman of the conference, declared the agreement for currency stabilization and an international bank should be accepted now by the United Nations without waiting for the end of the war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Government's suit against The Associated Press was declared in the Supreme Court today by counsel for the news organization to be based on the "novel theory" that AP members must help their competitors to compete against them.

Paul Osborn's dramatization of John Hersey's best-selling novel, "A Bell for Adano," will be brought to the stage this evening at the Cort Theatre. Leland Hayward is sponsor of the play and Fredric March, who was last seen here in Thornton Wilder's "The Skin of Dur Teeth" (1942), is the star.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- John Lord O'Brian, general counsel for the War Production Board and its predecessor, the Office of Production Management, since February, 1941, has resigned, effective Dec. 20.

A.B. Block and Shampan Shampan have purchased the vacant plot 80 by 100 feet adjoining their present holdings at the northeast corner of Queens Boulevard and Sixty-eighth Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens. They now have a plot 300 by 100 feet on which they intend to erect a six-story apartment house.

ATHENS, Dec. 5 -- Fierce fighting continued in Athens today as the Elas, the fighting force of the left-wing Eam [National Liberation Front], laid siege to various police barracks and was dispersed by British tanks and Greek Mountain Brigade troops.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 5 -- Fresh Chinese troops, rushed to the defense of Kweichow Province from armies that have been blockading the Communist regions of northwest China for six years, have stemmed the Japanese advance and recaptured the town of Pachai, deepest enemy penetration point in Kweichow, a Chinese communique announced today.

Mink and silver foxes are meeting an active demand as the new raw fur collecting season gets under way, trade sources here reported yesterday. While a broad picture of the market trend will require several weeks to fully develop, it was pointed out, revival of retailer demand has improved sentiment in the manufacturing industry, while indications point to a smaller catch of several important domestic furs.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- The text of the major articles in the "Two Freedoms" document, accepted tonight by the International Civil Aviation Conference, follows:
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 5 -- The American Jewish Conference voted today against expanding its work to become a permanent group and act as over-all agency for Jewish organizations in the United States.

The problem of fighting infantile paralysis is essentially one of scientific research, Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, said last night at the Hotel New Yorker as members of the commerce and industry committee of the Greater New York Chapter of the foundation opened their annual drive.

Mayor La Guardia asked yesterday for a one-minute observance of silence and prayer at 2:26 P.M. tomorrow "in solemn tribute to the men and women of our armed forces who are giving their lives for their country."

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- A general rise in bank stocks caused wide comment in La Salle Street today. Northern Trust Company's stock extended its advance to $740 bid, a gain of $115 in three weeks. Chicago Title and Trust Company
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The roll-call by which the House voted to "freeze" the social security tax at 1 per cent, was as follows:

Reports are current in the financial community that the Chicago North Western Railway is considering refunding its first and refunding general mortgage 4 per cent bonds, due in 1989, of which about $57,000,000 is outstanding. The bonds were issued in exchange for old bonds in the reorganization proceedings that were consummated on June 1 last.
PARIS, Dec. 5 -- The French Government will take no instructions from the Germans.
LONDON, Dec. 5 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

NO one knew what catastrophe had taken place among the interplanetary spaces, what miracle had upset the immutable patterns of the stars in their courses. The earth was falling toward the sun. The newspapers clamored of the dreadful fact, but the people found it hard to believe. Yet it grew hotter. The crops withered in the fields and the fruit died on the limbs of the trees.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,424 compared with 1,092 last week and 1,284 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listing appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 695 against 855 last Tuesday.

Dr. Juan Negrin, the last Premier of the Spanish Republic, disclosed yesterday that he opposed a projected meeting of the members of the former Spanish Cortes in Mexico City next Jan. 10 unless the Cabinet, including himself, could participate.

Fines totaling $31,730 were imposed in Federal court yesterday by Judge Edward A. Conger on six persons and three corporations, following their pleas of guilty to charges of violating Office of Price Administration regulations covering sales of radios and radio-phonograph combinations.

BUFFALO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Minor league baseball adopted a "watching-and-waiting" attitude on the question of helping select a successor to Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis today, with most of the ten operating circuits meeting behind closed doors on the eve of their forty-third annual convention.

Making his second start of the competition, Welker Cochran, veteran of many a stirring billiard match, chalked up another victory for himself yesterday as the world championship three-cushion tourney at the Capitol Hotel entered its third day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The State Department by implication criticized Great Britain today for the way in which she has intervened in the Italian political situation. The department issued a statement broad enough to define the attitude of the United States toward not only Italy but the Governments in all the liberated territories of the United Nations.

ALBANY, Dec. 5 -- Assemblyman Irwin Steingut, Democratic minority leader, accepted today an invitation to testify Tuesday before the extraordinary grand jury investigating legislative spending. The invitation was extended by the special prosecutor Hiram C. Todd, who has been engaged for many weeks in questioning persons associated with Mr. Steingut and with Senator John J. Dunnigan, minority leader of the Senate.

The board of directors of Pan American Airways Corporation adopted yesterday a plan to sell additional stock and warrants to stockholders to provide a minimum of $25,000,000 of new capital funds in 1945, according to an announcement by Juan T. Trippe, president.
Here's straight talk by an industrial editor to his fellow war workers. It is worth thinking about after you get through reading the war news.

Beyond the turnstile and the bright blue picket fence chattering youngsters looked at the pretty pictures, then tried to paint their own. Behind the barriers at the annual Children's Holiday Circus, which officially opens today at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, adults were spectators.

The tragic events in Athens, which have led to bloodshed scarcely a month after the city's liberation and threaten to lead to civil war in a country already ravaged by a foreign foe, have brought to a head a fundamental issue that hangs over all of Europe -- the issue whether Governments are to be established on the basis of free elections or by the method of revolution.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Congressional action was completed today on legislation establishing pensions ranging up to $74 monthly for families of deceased veterans of the last war.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 5 -- Are the Japanese preparing to compensate for the loss of north Burma by occupation of the Burma Road terminus of Kunming? Japanese tactics recently in the battle for East Asia give many indications that this may be their intention.

ATLANTA, Dec. 5 (U.P.) -- Twenty-five long-term prisoners seized four guards at the Atlanta Federal Penitentiary yesterday and have held them as hostages in a segregation unit, it was disclosed today.
PARIS, Dec. 5 -- Popular outbursts against the courts, which seem likely to bring the whole purge issue to a climax soon in France, revealed today the extent to which public passions sway justice.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Figures were much larger at Gulfstream Park today, not only in attendance but likewise in pay-off prices. Sunny skies attracted an estimated 4,500 fans who found long shots dominating a thrill-packed program on which $238,278 was wagered.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, through L.V. Hoffman Co. and Maurice A. Pearson, co-brokers, has sold to an investing client of Goodman Mabel the twelve-story apartment building for forty-eight families at 895 West End Avenue, southwest corner of 104th Street.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Prime Minister Churchill assured the House of Commons today that, when the time came for the Greek people to express their wishes in a free election, it would be for them alone to decide whether their government should be leftist or rightist, republican or monarchical.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Business in today's stock markets generally was quiet. Among the industrials there was selective buying of textile shares based on export trade prospects and some gains were recorded.

James A. Burke, Borough President of Queens, told 950 members and friends of the Queens Chamber of Commerce at its annual dinner last night in the Hotel Commodore that his office had outlined a program for the expenditure of $82,000,000 for public and semi-public improvements in the borough to ease unemployment after the war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Maintenance of union membership in good standing consists of more than mere dues payments, the War Labor Board's Shipbuilding Commission ruled today in upholding an arbitration award which directed the discharge of thirty-four employes.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (U.P.) -- Two American sportsmen today took the lead in suggesting that international athletics, based upon the Olympic Games, could play a prominent part in re-establishing global peace, adding that the athletes of Germany and Japan should not be barred from the Olympics.

Everybody was happy at the Polo Grounds yesterday morning, even Len Calligaro and Hub Barker, and Stout Steve Owen was having difficulty keeping a smile from creeping over his face, as the football Giants took the field for their first limbering up exercises since last Sunday's thrilling triumph over the Redskins.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 5 -- German casualties in this war exceed 5,500,000, according to private information from an excellent Berlin source. This estimate is based on official figures covering a district in which about one-thirtieth of the Reich's population resides.

Army is the best football team in the collegiate world and the unbeaten Randolph fliers from Texas hold a similar honor among the service teams, a poll of 121 sports critics throughout the country decided yesterday.

Madison Suare Garden's eleventh college basketball season gets under way tonight at the Eighth Avenue Arena, where the first of eighteen double-headers will pit C.C.N.Y. against the University of Detroit and N.Y.U. against the University of Rochester. As in the past, all first games will begin promptly at 8:15 o'clock.

Wendell L. Willkie, former Presidential nominee and leader of the internationalist wing of the Republican party, who died in the Lenox Hill Hospital on Oct. 8, left his estate in trust for the benefit of his wife, Mrs. Edith Wilk Willkie of 1010 Fifth Avenue, and named his son, Lieut. Philip Willkie, USNR, to receive the trust after Mrs. Willkie's death.

The Dry Dock Savings Institution has sold to Mrs. Dolorita Fitzgerald Wallace the two-story taxpayer at 606 Madison Avenue, southwest corner of Fifty-eighth Street, subject to a mortgage of $165,000. The assessed valuation of the property, which measures 25.5 by 88 feet, is $330,000, of which $295,000 is on the land.

Taking a three-billion-dollar leap in one day, corporation purchases in the Sixth War Loan went over the top yesterday and increased the nation's total sales to $12,468,000,000, or 89 per cent of its quota of $14,000,000,000.
Louis B. Nelson, general manager of The Sweets Company of America, Inc., has been appointed executive vice president.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Willie Pep, recognized by the New York State Athletic Commission as world featherweight champion, won a unanimous ten-round decision over Chalky Wright at the Cleveland News nineteenth annual Christmas Fund boxing show in the Arena tonight before a capacity crowd of 13,288.

Ned Irish, acting president of Madison Square Garden, addressing basketball writers at a luncheon at Toots Shor's yesterday, devoted much time to what has been to him a most disturbing problem -- that of eliminating gambling at the Garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Some compromises of the principle of appointing the best qualified man to the job are visible in the first sweeping reorganization of the State Department for many years. This principle has been vigorously espoused by Secretary E.R. Stettinius Jr. in the confferences he has held on the subject with the President, with former Secretary Cordell Hull, with Harry L. Hopkins and others.

Among the decisive failures of the Axis Powers in this war was the failure of Germany and Italy to capture the island of Malta. The British Government has just told the story of the twenty-eight-month siege in a published booklet. There were 2,315 air-raid alerts, or an average of nearly three a day.

Frederick Brown has resold the fourteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 956 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Seventy-seventh Street, to an investing client of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., brokers, for cash above a mortgage of $240,000 held by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.

Edward V. Loughlin, leader of Tammany Hall, indicated yesterday that his organization would seek next year's Democratic nomination for Mayor. He did so by making public an analysis of the party vote in the Presidential election which shows Manhattan as the banner Democratic borough of the city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The costly, bloody fighting on the Western Front continued yesterday without decisive gain, while on Leyte Island in the Philippines, our troops were bogged down in a sea of mud.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Federal Power Commission announced today that it had suspended proposed increased rates for natural gas sold by the Allegany Gas Company and North Penn Gas Company, which would result in an annual estimated increase of $44,140 to the five northern Pennsylvania and western New York distributing companies served.

LONDON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- A British-American pact to prevent "unrestricted competition" in the world's export markets was urged in the House of Lords today while Prime Minister Churchill was disclosing in the House of Commons that Britain hoped to pay cash for American goods and raw materials imported outside the scope of lend-lease.

ROME, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Catherine Tekakwitha, Mohawk Indian who died in 1680 at the age of 24, soon may be recognized as a saint by the Congregation of Rites, which also is considering beatification of six other Americans and nine Canadians.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization and Reconversion, has appointed a group of deputies and aides to assist him in getting production from "the assembly line to the front line," readjust agriculture from war to peacetime output and obtain a maximum use of manpower.

After a brief ownership David S. Meister has resold the twelve-story apartment house at 270 Riverside Drive, northeast corner of Ninety-ninth Street, on a plot 105 by 112 feet. The name of the purchaser was not revealed. The house accommodates forty-nine families and is reported to have an annual rent roll of about $72,000. The assessed valuation is $565,000.

Asserting that contract termination, "unfortunately," has become identified too much with phrases like "post-war planning," Rear Admiral H.L. Merring, deputy chief, industrial readjustment branch, Navy Department, urged management last night to look upon terminations as "an instrument of war" and to spread this feeling throughout industrial organizations.

YENAN, China, Sept. 30 -- Although China has been virtually bisected as a result of this year's Japanese offensive, the chances of supporting a United Nations landing on the coast are not hopeless, in the opinion of Gen. Chu Teh, commander of the Chinese Communist armies.

UNITED STATES THIRD ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Representative Clare Booth Luce of Connecticut, touring the Third Army front with sixteen male members of the House Military Affairs Committee, took a hand today in firing a 155-mm. howitzer against a German position.

Six Months Brokers are pointing out that yesterday was six months after D-day and that today is six months and one day after D-day. They also are recalling that the securities market boiled furiously in the days immediately following the European invasion and that prices shot upward.

Housewives throughout the nation are being cheated of millions of meat and butter ration points by a "red market," the existence of which was confirmed yesterday by the Office of Price Administration with the rueful explanation that it constituted a very tough problem.

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 7 -- The United States Eighth Air Force and the Royal Air Force struck twin blows with nearly 3,000 planes yesterday at Germany, bombing two synthetic oil plants through a forty-mile belt of massed anti-aircraft batteries and three rail junctions serving the Nazis on the western front.

To make holiday cooking easier this year, we present today some sugar-thrifty recipes for candies and a fudge sauce, along with general directions for substituting corn syrup for sugar in puddings, gelatin desserts and custards, and also recipes for a sugarless cake and frosting.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 6 -- There is increasing evidence that the Japanese are giving up North Burma as a bad proposition. Some think they may be preparing to withdraw from all Burma.

ALBANY, Dec. 6 -- The alleged use by Irwin Steingut, Democratic leader of the State Assembly, of two sets of license plates on the automobile assigned for his use by the State is being investigated by Hiram C. Todd, special prosecutor, who is conducting an inquiry before a grand jury into expenditures by State legislators.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, told President Roosevelt in a letter today that there was "an imperative need for revising the national wage policy."

Accelerated depreciation for Federal income tax purposes, which has been favored by President Roosevelt and others as a post-war business stimulant, was criticized for several "basic weaknesses" in a special statement issued yesterday by Maurice Austin, chairman of committee on Federal taxation of the American Institute of Accountants.

The third annual exhibition of painting and sculpture by merchant seamen of the United Nations will be open Tuesday night under the auspices of the United Seamen's Service and the War Shipping Administration at the National Academy of Design.

The manufacture of 2,000,000 vehicles a year and the introduction of a new low-priced model were among the post-war plans outlined for the Ford Motor Company yesterday by Henry Ford 2d, executive vice president, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Midway through the conference between Gen. Charles de Gaulle and Premier Joseph Stalin, there was still no solid news today of what military and political results have been achieved in the meetings.
Three years after Pearl Harbor will be marked today at 1:30 P.M. by a military ceremony on the steps of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 6 -- The German grip on the Saar is loosening as the great battle for that key industrial area nears a climax.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Leaving open a place for Russia, delegates of the fifty-two nations participating in the International Civil Aviation Conference elected twenty members of a twenty-one-man interim council today as the executive board of a provisional world air body pending ratification of the permanent International Civil Aviation Organization.
LONDON, Dec. 6 -- The international political disturbances were mainly responsible for some of the uncertainty evident in some sections of today's stock market.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The climactic battle between the Redskins and the Giants at Washington Sunday may settle the Eastern team title in the National Football League, but it probably will only gild the lily as far as the prospective individual rushing and passing champions are concerned.

Patterned fabrics were in the ascendent over plain one in De Pinna's presentation of resort fashions yesterday at the weekly fashion luncheon held in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Cottons and rayons were alive and crisp with color.

The report of the Raytheon Manufacturing Company, makers of electronics products, for the year ended on May 31, issued to stockholders yesterday, shows net sales of $112,994,448, compared with $37,747,337 in the preceding fiscal year. The current figure is after deducting a $12,676,266 renegotiation refund.

A.C. Ingraham of the Harvard Club, seeded No. 6, was the only member of the select group to get into action as the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association invitation singles tournament got under way on the courts of the Yale Club last night. Ingraham defeated H.J. Rose of the Princeton Club, 15 -- 11, 15 -- 10 and 15 -- 13.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- At the moment that B-29's are dealing destruction on Tokyo, secret tests are under way on new air giants which may dwarf the performance of the Superfortresses.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Formation of a twenty-man Navy board, headed by Rear Admiral Laurance T. du Bose, to take up the problem of getting the best men of the Reserve Officers Corps to stay with the Navy after the war was announced today by Secretary Forrestal.

ATLANTA, Dec. 6 -- Twenty-five convicts, who have barricaded themselves in a building at the Federal Penitentiary with four guards as hostages, told an Atlanta Journal columnist late today they would surrender only if he published a story setting forth their grievances.

After the defeat of Germany in 1918 General Ludendorff predicted that one of the decisive battles of the next war would be fought around Lake Balaton. Balaton is the largest body of water in central Europe. It lies across western Hungary like a great moat guarding the approaches to Austria.

New York City's children's libraries, once famous the world over and models for many other municipalities, are being allowed to deteriorate through failure of the city to pay their personnel a living wage, Mrs. Frances Clarke Sayers, superintendent of work with children, charged yesterday.

WITH THE FIRST UNITED STATES ARMY, Dec. 6 -- D-day was just six months ago. The United States First Infantry Division, which was among those which stormed Normandy beaches on that day, observed it with a tribute by Maj. Gen. Clarence R. Huebner, its commander, to the heroic soldiers who made possible the division's proud battle record through France and Belgium into the Siegfried Line and its recent hard-won victories in the Aachen sector.
LONDON, Dec. 6 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Solveig Lunde, gifted young American pianist, gave her first New York recital last night in Town Hall. She was heard in a program featuring Prokofieff's Sonata No. 7, and containing as further principal offerings Schumann's "Etudes Symphoniques," Chopin's "Barcarolle" and Liszt's "Rhapsody," No. 15.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 6 -- A Liberty ship bearing the name of the late Isaac Mayer Wise was launched this afternoon at the St. John's River Shipbuilding Company yards, with his son, Rabbi Jonah B. Wise of the Central Synagogue of New York City, as the principal speaker on the christening program.
Loft buildings and a garage were among Manhattan business properties passing to new ownerships in deals announced yesterday.

Ben Bernie, "The Old Maestro" of stage, screen and radio, who died in Beverly Hills, Calif., on Oct. 23, 1943, left a gross estate of $435,999 and a net of $306,167, according to an appraisal filed yesterday. Mr. Bernie was a resident of Miami Beach, Fla., and his estate was held to be not taxable here.

Spinach prices are up and carrots are down in the new weekly retail ceiling price chart for fresh fruits and vegetables in this city, which becomes effective today. Changes from last week's ceiling prices listed by the Office of Price Administration include the following:

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A Japanese drive was in full swing today toward Kunming, the loss of which would cut the prospective India-China supply route and deliver the United States Fourteenth Air Force a crippling blow.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Negotiations are proceeding in Belgrade for the formation of an all-party federal government for Yugoslavia, which its organizers hope will obviate the civil disturbances and foreign intervention that have characterized the rebirth of the Belgian and Greek Governments.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 5 I read a letter entitled "Plea for Cadet Nurses" written by Miss Mollie Parnis, and would like to explain why women in the Cadet Nurse Corps are not eligible for any services of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee or of the various service clubs in this community.
The campaign of the New York War Fund to collect $17,200,000 for the thirty-one war-related member agencies is still lagging, it was pointed out yesterday.
With a limited volume of trading, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 8 points higher to 3 points lower than on Tuesday. The December was relatively firm.
WITH UNITED STATES SEVENTH DIVISION, on Leyte, Dec. 6 -- Trapped on the narrow nose of a ridge, a small American patrol jumped down a 300-foot cliff to escape superior numbers of Japanese.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- After an hour and a half of pungent debate the Senate sent back to the Foreign Relations Committee this afternoon the four nominations submitted by President Roosevelt for high posts in the reorganized State Department under Edward R. Stettinius Jr.

Fortified with three additions to their defense staff, the Rangers return to Madison Square Garden tonight in a National Hockey League clash with the Red Wings and for what Manager Lester Patrick and Coach Frankie Boucher hope will be the beginning of more favorable fortune for the Blue Shirts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Following is the roll call by which the Senate sent back to the Committee on Foreign Relations for further study the nomination of Joseph C. Grew and three others to State Department posts:

Acting on complaints from residential property owners and agents that they were being forced to pay excessive prices for building repair work and for supplies and services necessary for the upkeep of their houses, the Office of Price Administration has started a city-wide investigation aimed at stamping out the "black market" in this new field.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- In one of the most optimistic statements on the Chinese internal quarrel in months, the newly appointed Chinese Minister of Information, Dr. Wang Shih-chieh, disclosed today that Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Central Government and the Chinese Communist regime at Yenan had exchanged new proposals for the settlement of their long-standing differences.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The country's war plants will need more than 130,000 additional workers to meet the expansion of mortar and small-arms ammunition production "urgently needed at the front in Europe and the Pacific," Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, said today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast by the Free Yugoslav radio in Serba-Croat and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- Chairman Andrew J. May of the House Committee on Military Arfairs, a Kentucky Democrat, demanded today that the Department of Justice prosecute military and civilian personnel responsible for alleged irregularities during the construction of Camp Shanks at Orangeburg, N.Y.

NIAGARA FALLS, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Nine United States and Canadian subsidiary companies of the Moore Corporation, Ltd., incorporated in Ontario, will be consolidated Jan. 1 to form Moore Business Forms, E. G. Baker, company president, announced today.

Beginning today as part of the observance of the Pearl Harbor attack, blood donors will be able to honor service men and women overseas by dedicating a pint of their blood to them. The plan has been adopted by the Red Cross as a result of numerous requests by friends and relatives of those in the armed forces.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 -- A Soviet ship, by pre-arrangement, met a Japanese vessel seventy-five miles at sea off a Siberian port last month and transferred to it 2,010 tons of food, clothing, medical supplies, games and books for distribution among American prisoners of the Japanese.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 5 (Delayed) -- Thirty minutes of Christmastide spirit from Bethlehem are winging their way to Washington. Recorded by a United States Army crew of fifteen men and women, they consist of the pealing of Bethlehem's famous Church of the Nativity bells, Christmas music and interviews inside the church.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 197:

The Tokyo radio, foreshadowing a major propaganda campaign to mark the third anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor, declared that "the coming year is about to unfurl before us a total offensive for our nation," the Federal Communications Commission reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Supreme Court took under advisement today the Government's suit to force The Associated Press to change its membership admittance rules. A decision is expected early in 1945.

ROME, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- The Vatican has reached an agreement with the French Provisional Government by which Mgr. Valerio Valeri, Papal Nuncio in Paris, and several French Bishops accused of collaboration with the Germans will retire and normal French-Vatican diplomatic relations will be re-established, it was said authoritatively today.

The expanded programs for the production of heavy ammunition, heavy tires, telephone wire and rockets are lagging principally because of lack of machine tools and manpower, service and Government procurement officials and representatives of industry engaged in these programs declared yesterday at panel discussions held at the War and Reconversion Congress of American Industry.
Accounts Sterling Factors Company, to S. Duane Lyon, Inc. Newspaper and trade papers will be used.

There are two ways to fight a war. One is with men, as the Russians did the Germans, when they did not have the weapons. The other method is with guns, tanks, planes and battleships. There are two ways of breaching the Siegfried Line or any fortified position. One is to attack with so many men that the defender is not able to kill them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The invasion of the Philippines is two months ahead of the timetable and is proceeding well with excellent prospects for the liberation of the entire archipelago, Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, Resident Commissioner of the Philippines to the United States, said at a press conference today.

Emphatic support for the statement by Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr. affirming the United States policy of maintaining the democratic rights of liberated nations was voiced repeatedly yesterday by speakers at the Second Conference of Women, held in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, on the topic "No World War III -- A Challenge!"
ROME, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A communique:

Body sizes of the 1942 model automobiles have the approval of a majority of those readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES who thus far have answered queries presented at the request of the Society of Automotive Engineers. There is a considerable minority, however, that hopes for post-war vehicles that could be parked in smaller spaces than the present models.

The New York Stock Exchange has authorized seven security issues for listing but will not admit them to dealings until further notice. There are three issues now being offered to the public and four coming out of the reorganization of the Western Pacific Railroad Company.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Bottle Imp, sturdy son of Pompey owned by the Mayfair Stable and piloted by Apprentice Dick Meade, withstood a bold challenge by Good Going and Free Double in the final sixteenth to win the six-furlong New Jersey Purse at Gulfstream Park today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- Japan has formally notified the United States and Great Britain that she will "hold responsible" captured airmen who are "clearly found to have deliberately broken established practices of warfare," a Japanese Government spokesman announced today.

Walter S. Gifford was re-elected chairman of the board and Bayard F. Pope was re-elected president at the Community Service Society's annual board meeting yesterday at its headquarters, 105 East Twenty-second Street. It is the sixth time Mr. Gifford has been chosen board chairman.

The Japanese Domei agency reported that a formation of American Superfortresses had raided the southern sector of Japanese-occupied Manchuria today. The Domei wireless dispatch was recorded by the Federal Communications Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a plan filed by the American Gas and Electric Company and its subsidiaries, the Indiana Michigan Electric Company, and the Indiana General Service, whereby Indiana General will be merged into Indiana Michigan.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Oregon Gas and Electric Company's sale of its electric utility plant to the West Oregon Electric Cooperative, Inc., for $130,000 was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

OTTAWA, Dec. 6 -- Pressed by the Cooperative Commonwealth Federation leader, M.J. Coldwell, and others to clarify the position of the Canadian Government toward events in Greece, Italy and Belgium and the attitude of the British Government, Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King said that his first concern was not to add to the very confusing situations with which the armies of liberation had had to contend.

The nation's gasoline stocks at the close of last week were 80,426,000 barrels, of which 13,132,000 were unfinished, 41,318,000 civilian grade automotive and 25,976,000 aviation, military and blending stocks now indeterminate as to ultimate use, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

For the third time we look back to Japan's day of shame and our own day of consternation. Three years ago the United States had begun to prepare for war in a physical way. Psychologically its people were not ready for war. They had waked up to what was expected to be an ordinary Sunday.

Comprehensive material on the machinery and plans for providing job preference and opportunities for veterans is contained in "A Peace Program for Veterans," a twenty-four page booklet issued by THE NEW YORK TIMES, it was announced yesterday.

Prof. Irving Fisher seems to be s fearful of the "danger that we shall be swept off our feet and go along with the crowd on the road to serfdom, i.e., socialism, that he marshals ever shibboleth and cliche in defense of his uncontrolled version of "private enterprise."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A detailed draft for an eleventh executive department, that of foreign trade, is about ready for President Roosevelt's study, preparatory to submission to Congress. The plan, worked out by Government officials, provides for a Cabinet secretary to carry out the Administration program for expanded commerce abroad after the war.

UNION, N.J., Dec. 6 -- William F. McGuinness, vice president of the Elastic Stop Nut Corporation of America, whose president, William T. Hedlund, committed suicide last Wednesday, announced today that payment to the paying agent of the corporation.

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- The Renault automobile works, covering many acres at Billancourt, a Paris suburb, which was confiscated by the de Gaulle Cabinet after the founder's death on Oct. 24, would have become the property of his 40,000 workers under a will made several years ago, it was revealed tonight.

Henry Goelet, operator, has acquired from Alexander Rubin, trustee, the sixteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 104-10 West Eighty-sixth Street, between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, for cash above a mortgage of $405,000.

SARRE UNION, Dec. 6 -- In a daring tank action that may envelop thousands of Germans in a pocket on his left flank, Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton sent elements of his Fourth Armored Division crashing through a black loam valley east of the Saar River and tonight they were holding the upper hand in one of a series of violent tank battles.

Patrolman John H. Dukes, Brooklyn-born and educated, who is 47 years old and one of the most decorated men in the department, sat nervously yesterday with his wife, Margaret, and four children in the New York studios of the British Broadcasting Corporation, 630 Fifth Avenue, giving attentive ears to a broadcast from London.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Except for December corn, the grain markets had a heavy undertone today on the Board of Trade and most of the trading was below yesterday's closing quotations.
ROME, Dec. 6 -- While one must presume that Italy is much nearer to a solution of the political crisis, there were no outward evidences to that effect today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- The Veterans' Administration expects a peak need of 300,000 hospital beds "about 1975" to accommodate veterans of this war in a program that may cost as much as $6,000,000,000 a year before it tapers off, Brigadier General Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Veterans' Affairs, said here today.

While poultry for the table remained so scarce yesterday that many kosher shops were reported closed, 2,000 other fowl in sporting mood opened the fourteenth annual New York Poultry Show in the Ninth Regiment Armory, 125 West Fourteenth Street. Game birds were featured for the first time in the exhibition, which will close Sunday evening.

One of Billy Rose's most ambitious ventures, "The Seven Lively Arts," will be presented tonight at the Ziegfeld Theatre, which the showman acquired last September for $730,000 and which reverts to the legitimate field after operating as a film house for some years.

Directors of the Federal Motor Truck Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of 10 cents a share and another dividend of 10 cents, both payable on Dec. 23. Including previous dividends of 10 cents each paid in September, June and April, 1944, payments amount to 50 cents, against 40 cents last year.

Working on the assumption that lightning can and often does strike twice in the same place (lightning in this case being a synonym for Sammy Baugh), the Giants put in a heavy session at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

HEADQUARTERS, UNITED STATES FOURTEENTH Air Force, China, Dec. 6 (AP) -- United States Fourteenth Air Force P-51 fighters attacked Japanese troop movements today in the French Indo-China border region, where the enemy has poised a potential menace to China's Yunnan province.

Stockholders of American Airlines, Inc., voted at a special meeting held here yesterday to approve a two-for-one split-up of the common stock and to authorize 200,000 shares of new $100 par preferred stock and the reservation of 100,000 shares of the new common stock for sale to employes.

We can take it for granted that when the war is over, the American people will make certain that generous care is given to disabled veterans and that generous support is provided for the families of those men in the armed services who have given their lives for their country.

ALBANY, Dec. 6 -- Governor Dewey, back at his capitol desk from his vacation in Georgia, worked through a heavy calendar of business today and presided over a three-hour session of the State War Council.

Preliminary studies on human beings in which capsules of beef-bone flour added to the diet have been observed to reduce the incidence of dental decay, said to be the "most prevalent of human diseases," were described yesterday at the annual Greater New York dental meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

An easier and irregular trend was overcome yesterday by the stock market in the final hour, when a resumption of bidding permitted a firm closing. Active traders, apprehensive lest the strength of the two previous sessions might bring out heavy sales to realize quick profits, stood aside during the greater part of the day. When no appreciable volume of selling appeared, they re-entered the market, lending renewed support to the rail issues.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Secretary of the Navy James V. Forrestal sharply challenged today any possible existing American complacency on the question of air superiority over the Japanese when he declared that Japanese aircraft production was increasing and that our technical advantage now had become "very slender."

" Carolina Blues," a musical comedy produced by Columbia, which arrives at Loew's State, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Kay Kyser and his band, Victor Moore, Jeff Donnell, Georgia Carroll and the Christianis head the film's cast.
The prepared text of the address by Lieut. Gen. Brehon Somervell, commanding general, Army Service Forces, before the National Association of Manufacturers at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, follows:
The strike of school custodial workers, members of Local 112 of the School Custodial Employes, was apparently approaching its end yesterday as more workers returned to their jobs.

To get at the matter without undue red tape, this morning's bulletin from Broadway is eminently satisfactory. To the Cort last evening Leland Hayward brought "A Bell for Adano." In dramatizing John Hersey's novel, Paul Osborn has copied down the tones essential for a good show, and Fredric March and a huge cast are playing the roles, for the most part, as though they had lived them.

KANDY, Ceylon, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- The belief that the Japanese plan to withdraw from northern Burma was strengthened today by a southeast Asia Command communique that announced that patrols of the British Thirty-sixth Division had advanced nearly four miles south of Pinwe in the Myitkyina-Mandalay railway corridor without meeting enemy opposition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The sharp rebuke -- for it was that, and so understood in the United Kingdom -- which the State Department administered to the British Government on the basis of the Italian political situation accentuates the need for an early conference of the President, Prime Minister Churchill and Marshal Stalin.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden made it clear in the House of Commons today that he had no intention of budging from his opposition to Count Carlo Sforza's becoming Italian Foreign Minister.

Merwin K. Hart, president of the National Economic Council, Inc., told the State Commission Against Discrimination at its hearing in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street, yesterday that the proposed legislation to establish a State Fair Employment Practice Commission was Communist-inspired, "totalitarian" in character, and would, if adopted, "create discord."
NEW YORK Mrs. Theodore P Grosvenor and Miss Anita Grosvenor have arrived at the Carlyle from Newport.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Adoption of the bill, already approved by the Senate, to prohibit after 1947 the use for commercial purposes or otherwise of the Red Cross insignia and emblem by other than the American National Red Cross and the sanitary and hospital authorities of the Army and Navy, was advocated by Green H. Hackworth, legal adviser of the State Department, before the House Committee on Foreign Affairs today.
This is an appropriate day to think about the Sixth War Loan in terms of the personal score you have to settle with the enemy the Chinese call "the little dwarfs."
All of the complimentary things that are being said about the N.Y.U. basketball team -- that it will be the one to beat for local court honors, etc. -- apparently are not without grounds.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 6 (AP) -- One of the largest deals in lumber history, involving $11,000,000, was announced today by Archie D. Walker, Minneapolis, president of the Red River Lumber Company.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 6 -- After three years' delay, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will begin production next month on "The Harvey Girls," a musical with a background of the first Fred Harvey railroad station restaurant in New Mexico in the early Nineties.

The world three-cushion billiard championship in progress at the Capitol Hotel witnessed its first major upset last night when Willie Hoppe, defending titleholder, went down to defeat before Arthur Rubin of Brooklyn, 50 to 47. The setback toppled Hoppe from the list of unbeaten and marked his first reversal in a championship tournament since 1942, when Rubin also was the victor.

The packaged medicine industry is spending more than $7,750,000 annually in the maintenance of about 100 research laboratories for the development of new medicines as well as 225 control laboratories, according to the first survey of its kind presented yesterday before the mid-year meeting of the scientific section of the Proprietary Association of America at the Biltmore Hotel.

Fifty GI's got a preview of spring and resort fashions yesterday at a luncheon fashion show at the Hotel Pierre. The occasion was a show of Joseph Halpert clothes that are carried in the ready-to-wear department at Bergdorf-Goodman's and the appreciative group of men were chosen by their commanding officers from the companies of the Provisional Postal Battalion station at Army Hall, City College.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Petroleum Industry War Council made public tonight its substitute for the Anglo-American petroleum agreement which the domestic oil industry has denounced and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee has pigeonholed, thus accepting the challenge of Secretary Ickes to offer an agreement "in specific language."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 -- A Federal program of more than one billion dollars annually to provide adequate schooling for American youth after the war was advocated today by Dr. Alexander J. Stoddard, superintendent of Philadelphia schools, at the opening of the annual convention of the American Vocational Association here.

The six-story sixty-five-family apartment house at 850 St. Marks Avenue, corner of Brooklyn Avenue, Brooklyn, has been purchased for investment by Milton Kaplan from the Thirty-two Corporation, Zelda Schwartz, president. The property occupies a plot 150 by 125 feet. Sale was subject to mortgages of $308,000. Riker Co. were the brokers.

The returning Negro veteran is going to present a problem to social and Government agencies "that will demand great resourcefulness and courage," Edward S. Lewis, executive director of the Urban League of Greater New York, declared last night in an address at the Young Men's Christian Association auditorium, 144 West 138th Street, to members of the West Harlem Council of Social Agencies, an affiliate of the Welfare Council of New York City.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- A Reconversion Blueprint for Women, drafted by representatives of thirty-one women's and labor organizations, was made public today by Miss Frieda Miller, director of the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor.

WITH THE UNITED STATES NINTH ARMY, in Germany, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Despite a considerable improvement in Army supplies that has allowed full-scale operations, artillery still is being rationed on the Western Front.

It is greatly to be regretted, of course, that a full accord on all the points at issue was not reached by the delegations of fifty-two countries at the World Air Conference at Chicago. But disappointment at the lack of this should not blind us to the very great gains that were actually made.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 6 -- The complete collapse of Germany after the war and disintegration of the country's internal economy with a total lack of central authority for a long period, was envisaged today by Paul-Henri Spaak, Belgian Foreign Minister, in his first statement before Parliament on Belgium's foreign policy.

You have had many letters in your column both for and against peacetime conscription. One point I have not yet seen made, and which I think may well be considered, is whether the whole process of conscription has not become outmoded by the changing character of war.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Thursday, Dec. 7 -- The United States Seventh Division -- victors of Attu and Kwajalein -- have forced the Palanas River at two points, one near the sea and one near Ormoc, and are advancing northward toward Ormoc as Lieut. Gen. Walter Krueger's Sixth Army increased its pressure from north to south on the looping Ormoc corridor in which the Japanese are penned.

In our Magazine last Sunday Anne O'Hare McCormick vividly portrayed the perplexity of European peoples at the disparity between our military might thrown into Europe and our influence on European affairs. Indeed, this influence seems at some points to have developed in inverse ratio to the development of our power.

ROME, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Smashing stubborn German resistance, British and Polish troops have firmly established a bridgehead across the Lamone River, four miles southwest of Faenza, posing a new flanking threat to German troops in a bulge southeast of Bologna, the Allied command announced today.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Strong demands in Parliament today for an end to the "policy of appeasement" toward the United States in foreign trade arrangements brought a promise from the Government that British exports would be accelerated early in 1945.

College football attendance took a huge jump during the 1944 season. Even after allowance had been made for a number of schools which resumed the game after a season or two out of competition the over-all average showed a gain of 13.2 per cent.

Ernie Pyle's "Brave Men," the Book-of-the-Month Club's December selection, has topped all previous selections in the number of copies ordered during the first month of distribution. The print order for members alone stands at 415,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Office of Price Administration approved today an increase of about 4 1/2 per cent in the ceiling prices for all constructions of cotton duck "in the gray" in an effort to boost production of a fabric critically needed by the armed services.

After pledging full support yesterday to the call made by Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, commanding general of the Army Service Forces, for the speedy supply of critically needed battlefront items, the National Association of Manufacturers made public the results of a survey indicating that manufacturers would provide a post-war employment level 30 per cent above that of 1939.

On the eve of Pearl Harbor Day, as the total sale of bonds in the Sixth War Loan throughout the nation climbed to 93.5 per cent of the $14,000,000,000 goal, Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. issued an urgent appeal to the people of America to buy bonds as individuals, declaring that achievement of the over-all quota was "not enough."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- The War Labor Board tonight directed the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to promote operators within a district in its traffic departments on the basis of seniority if other qualifications were substantially equal.

Those hunters who failed to get deer during the recent season in this State (their name is legion) may find balm in the philosophy of George Frey of the Metropolitan Rod and Gun Club. Then again, they may not think it balm at all but a handful of salt in a gaping wound. Here is the philosophy as expressed when George returned from an unsuccessful trip to Schoharie County:

The Brooklyn bond bouts went into history last night at the Broadway Arena and realized at least $1,250,000 in sales for the Sixth War Loan. As entertainment for a capacity crowd of about 3,700, the bouts unmistakably satisfied those who had purchased bonds of $25, $100 and $1,000 denominations.

ROME, Dec. 5 (Delayed) -- The sojourn of Eugene Cardinal Tisserant, secretary of the Papal Congregation for the Oriental Church, in Paris is being extended so that he may see General de Gaulle on his return from Moscow, it was learned today.
LONDON, Dec. 6 -- The following are extracts from a series of two articles in The Times of London by its special correspondent in Athens.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Assurances that curbs on Japanese industry will be written into the peace treaties are needed before exporters of cotton piece goods can plan intelligently for a post-war expansion of sales, William C. Planz of New York, president of the Textile Export Association, said today to a special Congressional committee inquiring into the problem of post-war disposal of surplus cotton.
Fabien Sevitzky and the 14-year-old Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra paid their first visit to New York and Carnegie Hall last night. A big audience heard them in an effective program.
LONDON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Eight prizes were awarded yesterday at the American-British Art Center, 44 West Fifty-sixth Street, at the opening of the second biennial exhibition of the Art Workshop of the Dressmakers Union, Local 22, International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 6 -- Four top-ranking woman contract bridge stars won the national women's team-of-four championship in the American Contract Bridge League's eighteenth annual tournament at the Brighton Hotel here today.

One apartment seeker in every three from out of town wants to settle down in Greenwich Village; this according to Joseph Platzker, Assistant Commissioner of Housing and Buildings and Director of the City Vacancy Listing Bureau.
ATHENS, Dec. 6 -- Government and British forces battled the Left-Wing Elas all day in Athens and the situation was still serious tonight, a competent authority said.

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 7 -- Russian armored forces yesterday drove across western Hungary to within forty-four miles of the Austrian border and 110 miles of Vienna, while Moscow and Berlin indicated that strong Soviet land and air forces had launched an all-out assault to encircle Budapest with new blows from the south and northeast.

Sergio Osmena, President of the Philippines, in a speech recording heard by 800 persons at a dinner last night in the Hotel Commodore, said that the Filipinos and Americans were working together "in a new scene and under happier circumstances" in the liberated part of the Philippine Islands.

The stellar attraction of the season's first performance of Verdi's "Il Trovatore" at the Metropolitan last night was the debut, made on short notice, of Regina Resnik in the role of Leonora. Miss Resnik, who is still in her early twenties, was notified to appear just twenty-four hours before curtain time, when it was learned that Zinka Milanov was ill.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Plans are under way at the Capitol to guide the new Congress in enacting a compulsory universal training system for youth.

BUFFALO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Professional football was scolded by the International League today as, "unfriendly and unfair competition until after the end of the baseball season," but otherwise the opening of the forty-third annual National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues convention was just a routine affair for the minors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Capt. Kenmore M. McManes, commander of a destroyer squadron in the naval battle of Surigao Strait in the Philippines, made some significant observations on Japanese weaknesses in this battle at Secretary of the Navy James Forrestal's press conference today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed today the promotions of ninety-seven Army officers, headed by William D. Styer, who was elevated to the temporary rank of lieutenant general. General Styer is deputy chief of the Army Service Forces.

A nation-wide employment program for veterans was announced yesterday by the American Hotel Association, with a membership of some 5,500. The plan provides a detailed guide for hotel men by not only outlining requirements for hotel jobs but by showing how disabled veterans easily may be adapted to many of these jobs. It also provides for special training.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Thursday, Dec. 7 (U.P.) --American airplanes attacking over the Philippines and Netherlands Indies, destroyed or damaged sixteen Japanese planes and freight merchant ships.

Lord Halifax, the British Ambassador, declared here yesterday that "there is no single thing more important for the world's future than Anglo-American understanding" and expressed his belief that while differences might arise from time to time, the war-cemented friendship of Britain and the United States would endure.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The House Merchant Marine Committee adopted today an amendment to the Merchant Marine Act of 1936, designed to remove any doubt of Congressional intent as to the desirability of collateral air operations by ocean steamship companies where such service is deemed in the public interest.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 6 (AP) -- The thinnest thing ever made by man, a sheet of plastic two-millionths of an inch or about ten atoms thick, was announced today by the General Electric Company.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte. Thursday, Dec, 7 (UP) -- A communique:
May I express my appreciation of your analysis and criticism of the resolution adopted by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America on the subject of post-war military training.

Agreeing that New York's present system of welfare services is a "patchwork," needlessly complex in the number of separate programs, agencies administering them and financial provisions for them, officials of public and private welfare units in Nassau, Suffolk, Putnam and Westchester Counties differed yesterday on specific revisions to be suggested to the State Legislature.

Another bond "to slap the Japs" was added to the Sixth War Loan Drive yesterday when 11-year-old Vincent Molinari handed $18.75 to Laura Macagnone, also 11, representing Miss "Statue of Liberty," at the miniature War Bond rally of the Sullivan Street Center of the Children's Aid Society.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The United States ended three years of war today and started the last and hardest lap.

Substantial progress in the scientific work of the Research Associate, established by the Textile Color Card Association of the United States at the National Bureau of Standards, was reported yesterday by Margaret Hayden Rorke, managing director of the color organization, at its annual meeting here yesterday.

During the first three days of this week a record number of cows were slaughtered locally, the War Food Administration reports. The kill amounted to more than 3,200 head as compared with 700 head, which is the average for the same length of time from 1937 to 1941.

The Tchaikovsky program offered by the Philharmonic-Symphony under Dr. Rodzinski last night in Carnegie Hall and thoroughly relished by a large audience, had features which set it apart from customary programs of the kind.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, reported today that on this third anniversary of the Pearl Harbor attack American casualties amount to 552,018.

BUFFALO, Dec. 7 (AP) -- New barriers against anticipated big league expansion into minor league territory and higher draft prices were approved at today's meeting of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, but the majors still can say "no" at their Dec. 11-13 sessions.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 7 -- Mrs. A.M. Sobel of New York and Sidney Silodor of Philadelphia won the national contract bridge mixed-pair championship today by the widest margin ever recorded in play for this title in the American Contract Bridge League's eighteenth annual tournament, which is in progress at the Brighton Hotel here.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Confirmation of reports that the Commodity Credit Corporation has purchased 2,000,000 bushels of cash corn in the last few days here and in St. Louis and intimations that England might import over 30,000,000 bushels of that grain during the current season fell flat today as a market influence on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- American Superfortresses of the India-China-based Twentieth Bomber Command, appropriately celebrating Pearl Harbor Day, struck a hard blow at important military targets in Manchuria today and destroyed twenty-six Japanese fighters, the largest number ever shot down by B-29's on a single mission. In all, sixty-three Japanese fighters were shot down, probably destroyed or damaged.
The furniture, silver, china, glassware and other furnishings of the New York apartment of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alfred E. Smith will be sold at auction late in the winter, it was learned yesterday.

A plea to end segregation and sectarianism in women's groups and have them come together as women" was made yesterday by Mrs. Isaac Gilman, president of the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations. Addressing 300 members of its Manhattan Borough chapter, Mrs. Gilman urged the cessation of the terms, "Catholic women, Jewish women and Protestant women in favor of women's division."

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Dec. 7 -- Superior Judge Emmet Wilson ordered officials of the American Federation of Radio Artists, American Federation of Labor, today not to interfere with Cecil B. De Mille's radio program nor to oust him as a member in good standing.

O.F. Holing has sold the six-story thirty-seven-family apartment house at 4660 Spuyten Duyvil Parkway, the Bronx, to the Olinbark Realty Company for cash above a mortgage of $106,616. The house, built in 1938, occupies a plot 120 by 111 feet.

Lee Oma will have his second chance to make good on the big time tonight. The Detroit heavyweight, who was called in as a last-minute substitute to fight Tami Mauriello of the Bronx at Madison Square Garden three months ago, only to be knocked out in eight rounds after a thrilling battle, will fight a return ten-round bout with his conqueror at the Garden tonight.

The New York Academy of Medicine adopted last night an amendment to its constitution stipulating that both fee splitting and receiving a rebate are unethical and in violation of the constitutional regulations of the academy. The amendment further empowered the academy's council, by a three-fourths vote of its total membership, to expel any fellow found guilty.

As a further step to meet the call for increased supplies of heavy equipment, guns and shells in the war zones, the Navy has taken over the $33,000,000 aluminum plant in Maspeth, Queens, formerly operated by the Aluminum Company of America, and already has started producing ordnance material and reconditioning combustion engines for the Navy there, it became known last night.

M.C. Berg, operator, resold the five-story house at 1030 Park Avenue, near Eighty-fifth Street, to an investing client of Millard S. Bondy, broker. The parcel was sold subject to a ten-year mortgage of $20,750, held by the Bank for Savings.

Costume and home accessories vied yesterday for first place at the Georg Jensen Christmas gift showing at the Hotel Plaza. A procession of juvenile models displayed crisp organdy dresses trimmed with valle lace in delicate pastel shades, each little girl clutching a stuffed Santa Claus or cuddly toy horse.

Pearl Harbor Day brought its bitter reminders of the human cost of war. America's total battle casualties, as summed up in Washington, yesterday stood at 552,018, a sobering figure. They had increased in one week by 15,068, which approaches a rate of nearly 800,000 a year.

LONDON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The German people were promised freedom of worship by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower today, but he warned them that they would forfeit this right if they allowed religious gatherings to be used for political purposes.

Christmas shoppers went on a Treasury-approved spending spree on Lord Taylor's street floor yesterday -- Pearl Harbor Day. From 9:30 in the morning to 5:45 at night they crowded the jewelry and perfume counters, stood in line before displays of leopard belts and ermine tail muffs. They were after some of the best bargains the store had ever offered -- guaranteed merchandise, 25 per cent off -- United States war bonds.

TWENTY-FIRST BOMBER COMMAND HEADQUARTERS on Saipan, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Striking with one plane at a time, American Superfortress bombers from Saipan hit Tokyo last night and early today, setting large fires in the industrial area.

In an address "commemorating the third anniversary of the outbreak of the war of Greater East Asia" and reported by the Japanese Domei Agency, Premier Kuniaki Koiso warned yesterday that, "should the enemy in his blind bombing of Japan damage a remote corner of the sacred property held in reverence by the entire nation, the Japanese will take retaliatory measures that will be impossible for the enemy to forget."

The continued superiority of New York as a port will depend on its ability to withstand the increasingly vigorous competition of smaller, but active shipping centers, David L. Tilly, president of the New York Dock Company and former president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, warned 250 representatives of local business and civic groups and Chambers of Commerce yesterday.

James E. McMullen, formerly with the Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation of Denver, has been appointed controller of the Carborundum Company, Niagara Falls, N.Y. Edward A. Montgomery has been appointed resident legal adviser.

The National Association of Manufacturers questioned yesterday whether the victory by the United Nations would mean a true "victory for freedom" in the United States. As an answer, the association adopted a six-point program embodying principles which it presented as "the basis on which the enemies' ideas can be overcome following the overthrow of the enemies' armies."

To stamp out the "red market" in meat and butter ration points -operated here by retail butchers who demand coupons for unrationed cuts of meat sold as higher grades -- the New York area Consumer Advisory Committee of the Office of Price Administration urged yesterday that sides of meat be marked in such a way that every cut bears its rightful grade label.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 7 -- Many residents of the United States who have invested funds in Palestine, or who have been unable to get remittances from here on their blocked accounts since the outbreak of the European war in 1939, will benefit from a realization of the exchange control regulations published in the Palestine Government gazette today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (U.P.) -- The Giants, led by the unanimous selection of Bill Paschal, placed four men on The United Press 1944 allNational Football League team as Eastern clubs grabbed seven positions on the first eleven.

ROME, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Canadian troops, who captured the Adriatic city of Ravenna two days ago, advanced six miles northwest up the Ravenna-Ferrara highway and seized the important railway junction of Mezzano on the Lamone River, Allied headquarters announced today.

Directors of the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association are expected to consider at a meeting scheduled for next Tuesday a program of financing designed to raise at least $40,000,000 of new equity capital, it was reported here yesterday.

MOSCOW, Dec. 7 -- A brief press announcement that Boleslaw Berut, President of the Lublin National Council; Edward B. Osubka-Morawski, Chairman of the Polish Committee of National Liberation, and Col. Gen. Michal Rola-Zymierski, the committee's Director of National Defense, had arrived in Moscow yesterday did not give any indication of the topics they planned to discuss with the Soviet Government.

The Railway Express Agency stopped its pick-up service here at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, explaining it was forced to take this action because of congestion of its New York terminals. The service will be resumed as soon as the conditions in the terminals are relieved.

Hundreds of acts of heroism by every-day infantrymen rival any that have been told in history or fiction, Maj. Gen. Fred L. Walker, commandant of the Infantry School, Fort Benning, Ga., declared yesterday at a military ceremony on the steps of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
A violent earthquake, described by observers as "catastrophic," struck in the vicinity of Japan yesterday, third anniversary of Pearl Harbor, The Associated Press reported.

The first New York performances of "So Women Can't Take It," a new play for the Women's Army Corps, written to aid recruitment campaigns, was presented last night by the American Theatre Wing, at the Barbizon Hotel, Lexington Avenue at Sixty-third Street.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast domestically by the Free Yugoslav Radio in Serbo-Croat and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The latest rationing racket is the sale of ration-free meat by some butchers for red-point coupons. It is difficult for consumers to distinguish between utility meat, which is not rationed, and grades of meat which are rationed. By accumulating points from the sale of ration-free meats, many butchers apparently can make available the rationed choicer cuts for disposal in the black market at high prices.

"Seven Lively Arts" opened last evening with champagne, a $24 top -- and a bang. Into both it and the Ziegfeld Theatre he acquired as a home front, Billy Rose has piled a little bit of everything but the kitchen sink -- and if that could dance or were pretty, it probably would be there, too.

President Roosevelt again has dedicated his birthday to the fight against infantile paralysis, it was announced yesterday by the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis. The battle against the disease, said the President in a letter to Basil O'Connor, foundation president, "is a fight to the finish and the terms are unconditional surrender."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Because of a large increase in the percentage of youth that are being drafted, the Army has changed its policy and is now sending 18-year-old soldiers overseas as infantry and armored force replacements, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, disclosed today.

Maintenance of maximum employment by keeping production and consumption fairly balanced at a high level after the war will come within the jurisdiction of credit men to a large extent because, collectively, they have the authority and the ability to keep production from going into top-heavy and stagnant inventories, A.D. Whiteside, president of Dun Bradstreet, said last night.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- Tomorrow's debate in the House of Commons will be a sham battle. Labor has been forced into a position where it has to challenge its Conservative and Liberal partners, but it does not want to disturb the status quo in domestic politics.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Producers of certain types of blankets, blanketing and blanket robe cloth made entirely of domestic cotton may sell the merchandise on an adjustable pricing basis, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 7 -- The last of the six Japanese aircraft carriers that made the destructive attack on Pearl Harbor three years ago lies at the bottom of the sea off Luzon in the Philippines, where the ocean is three miles deep, Admiral Nimitz related here today in a war bond rally address to naval and civilian workers in the Navy Yard.

Unperturbed by reports in certain segments of the Washington press that the Redskins are preparing a massacre for his Giants in the capital city Sunday, Stout Steve Owen yesterday went calmly about the business of getting his mighty "palefaces" in condition, not only to retain their own scalps, but perhaps to take a few from their foes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- J.A. Krug, chairman of the War Production Board, told a Senate Committee today that while it was "too late now" for a national service law, some specific authority to enforce manpower regulations would help in meeting the needs of critical munitions programs.

Coming back with a smashing performance after his stunning defeat the previous evening, Willie Hoppe again provided a sensation in the world three-cushion billiard championship at the Capitol Hotel last night by defeating Andrew Ponzi, 50 to 20, in 20 innings.

Bank transactions in the United States rose sharply during the week ended on Wednesday with the Sixth War Loan drive in operation. Exceeding the peak touched in the week to June 28, the volume for all cities reached the highest mark in more than fourteen years, or since the week ended on July 3, 1930.

WITH UNITED STATES THIRD ARMY, Dec. 7 -- One of the strangest communities in the world has been discovered in Germany. Its population comprises 1,700 German civilians who refused to join the general exodus to the interior of the Reich and are now living in a huge cave on the estate of Franz von Papen, where they have merged their eight villages into one primitive community.
LONDON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (U.P.) -All post-season football games by Army Air Forces' teams, scheduled or proposed, have been canceled, with one exception. The exception is the contest between Randolph Field and the Second Air Force at the Polo Grounds, New York, on Dec. 16.
Residents of the Rockaway Branch villages in Nassau County will have chicken dinners this week-end as a result of the business strike of New York City's kosher poultry dealers.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- American soldiers who shared the ordeal of flying bombs with Londoners and gallantly helped rescue many victims of the robot "blitz" are now going to assist in emergency repair work intended to give bombed-out families a roof over their heads for the winter.

Skiers, whose enthusiasm has been running high recently, got some measure of satisfaction in the snow reports from the North Country yesterday. Most of the areas serviced by those ingenious labor-saving contraptions, tows, lifts and trams, are slated to start their seasons a week from tomorrow but, generally, skiing does not get under way in earnest until the Christmas holiday period.

The stock market made yesterday a further bid to test its ability to pass the seven-year highs for the combined averages set last July. The further recovery was selective, however, and business remained at a fast pace. Additions generally were within a fractional range, but the rails showed some major gains.

The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation will file soon with the Securities and Exchange Commission an over-all plan for corporate simplification and integration in compliance with the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

LONDON, Dec. 7 (U.P.) -- In the wake of the war's greatest single RAF asault on Germany, the non-stop Allied air offensive on communications, oil and industrial targets in the Reich went forward today as an hour-long procession of British planes was reported passing over Britain's east coast before nightfall.

The Buffalo Bolt Company announced yesterday the declaration of a year-end dividend of 12 1/2 cents a share on the common stock payable on Dec. 22, increasing 1944 payments to 40 cents, against 35 cents in 1943.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Adolf A. Berle Jr., president of the International Civil Aviation Conference and chairman of the American delegation, closed the international conference today with a statement declaring the agreements made here were "a foundation for freedom under law in air transport."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 7 -In his annual report today to the alumni of Yale University, President Charles Seymour expressed the conviction of the necessity of "a system of required military training for all able-bodied young men" as suggested recently by General Marshall.

Mark Steele, 46 years old, a six-foot, faultlessly dressed Westerner, was held in $15,000 bail yesterday in General Sessions for pleading next Monday as an alleged vice overlord in a new lure to compulsory prostitution among showgirls and models, catering to men in the armed services in the midtown district.

ALBANY, Dec. 7 -- Irwin Steingut, Democratic leader of the Assembly, stated today that he would introduce in the Legislature next month a proposed constitutional amendment permitting members of the merchant marine and Red Cross workers who are engaged in war work on foreign soil to vote by absentee ballot.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The population of the United States on July 1, including service men and women overseas, was estimated by the Bureau of the Census today to have been 138,100,874, a rise of 6,400,000 since the 1940 census.

In the elastic tax plan letter of Professor Haberler, published in THE TIMES Nov. 24, the principles which should govern the use of public funds, and especially the social security fund, are completely forgotten.

In consequence of the new zoning laws that became effective last Saturday, the Department of Housing and Buildings began yesterday the revocation of building permits it had granted prior to that date in cases in which the proposed structure fails to meet the more restrictive requirements of the new law and on which no substantial work has been performed.
