WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The War Production Board announced the allocation today of 2,000,000 more pounds of cotton yarn for the purpose of stepping up production of children's cotton undergarments and sleeping garments, of which there are "immediate shortages."

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Tony Penna's approach shots couldn't have been much better today if he'd used radar control, and the Dayton (Ohio) professional got off to a one-stroke lead in the first round of the $10,000 Miami open golf tournament.

After four weeks of continuous battle which began around Metz and soon engulfed the whole Western Front, the center of the Allied offensive has again shifted back near its starting point. It is now directed principally against the Saar, second only to the Ruhr as Germany's arsenal.

After the subject had first been raised in these columns in August, Lin Tso-han, the Chinese Communist delegate, discussed the possibilities of a coalition government at the People's Political Council in Chungking in September.

In October 919 nurses from one registry in New York worked a total of 17,881 days. Overseas the invasion has set Europe aflame, and the battle raging are the bloodiest in history. In America units are being sent over without nurses because, for one reason 17,881 days of special duty must be provided by one registry out of more than a hundred in the city.

"Sad little personal belongings are strewn all over these bitter sands." Thus wrote Ernie Pyle from a beachhead in Normandy. More than 2,000 bundles of these belongings, carefully collected and packed by the armed forces, are sent monthly from a Kansas City depot to homes throughout America.
ROME, Dec. 7 (AP) -- A communique:

NEW CITY, N.Y., Dec. 7 -Eight boys and men, high school students and working adults from 16 to 25 years of age, all members of volunteer fire departments in and around Clarkstown, Nanuet and Spring Valley, were under arrest here today on charges of third degree arson.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The possibility was suggested here today that British opposition to Count Carlo Sforza as Italian Foreign Minister might have had less to do with his present hostility to the House of Savoy than to his past record of backing down on agreements.

The importance of "Flying Boxcars" in warfare was emphasized by a large order placed by the Army Air Forces for this type of military cargo aircraft, and announced yesterday by J. Carlton Ward Jr., president of Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation.
LONDON, Dec. 7 (UP) -- A German commuique, as broadcast from, Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

The Conservation Department's estimate on Wednesday that something like 15,000 deer were killed during the recent six-day buckand-doe season in the southern tier and western counties of New York State and the report of game protectors that they "had never seen anything like it" focused attention on the deer problem.

Les Horvath of Ohio State, winner of the 1944 Heisman Award as the outstanding college football player in the United States, will play on the East eleven in the annual Shrine charity game at San Francisco, Jan. 1, General Manager William M. Coffman announced yesterday through The Associated Press.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, which sold the apartment building at 895 West End Avenue a few days ago, has now sold the twelve-story and penthouse apartment house for seventy-six families at 817 West End Avenue to the Macira Realty Corporation for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $370,000.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7 (AP) -Judge Arthur Crum dismissed today the assault charges against Tommy Dorsey, his wife, Pat Dane, and their neighbor, Allen Smiley, growing out of an alleged attack on Jon Hall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -The War Department announced today awards of bronze star medals to more than 740 infantrymen of one battalion of the First Infantry Division for "heroic achievement" on D-day in the invasion of Normandy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (U.P.) -In three years of war the United States Army Air Forces have flown 1,566,329 combat sorties, dropped 1,202,139 tons of bombs on enemy targets and destroyed at least 29,316 Axis planes, the War Department disclosed tonight in a Pearl Harbor day operations summary.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 2 were 808,260 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 39,530 cars, or 5.1 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 54,473, or 6.3 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 48,529 cars, or 6.4 per cent. more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- When some one of great but publicly unknown achievement leaves the official stage, the customary comment is that one day contemporary history will be written in true perspective and his contribution will be properly appraised. But sometimes a public servant does his work with resolute modesty and deliberately arranges to disseminate the best of it through others.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Communique 243:

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 8 (U.P.) -Red Army troops drove eight miles along the west bank of the Danube River yesterday to within twenty-three miles southwest of Budapest, while Berlin reported a thirteen-mile Soviet break-through of Nazi defenses northeast of the Hungarian capital in a four-pronged Russian offensive to encircle the besieged city.

MYITKYINA, Burma, Dec. 6 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Allied air blockade was credited today by[ Maj. Gen. Howard C. Davidson[ vqth the present serious deteriora-t tion of the Japanese position inl North Burma.

Opening the ninth annual toy campaign of the Police and Fire Departments, Metropolitan Opera stars Bidu Sayao and Alexander Kipnis yesterday presented a bundle of toys, including an express wagon, blocks, stuffed dolls and games, to Lieut. Thomas J. Sheehan of the Juvenile Aid Bureau Unit office, at the Thirtieth Police Precinct, 1854 Amsterdam Avenue.

ALBANY, Dec. 7 -- The special grand jury investigating legislative spending handed up a sharply worded interim presentment today charging that legislative payrolls were padded with useless employes and that appointments had been made to meet political and even personal obligations of many members of the Legislature.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 (AP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a plan of reorganization for the Portland (Ore.) Electric Power Company under which bondholders will receive 95 per cent of the company's assets and holders of prior preference stock will receive the remaining 5 per cent.

Someone resembling a once-conspicuous character, Adolf Hitler, has cropped up in Germany. This personage has had his picture taken. He has, it is said, sent a "handwritten letter" to congratulate Field Marshal von Mackensen on the occasion of the latter's ninety-fifth birthday.

Since Marshal Alexander's troops broke the Gothic Line all frontal attacks on the Germans in Italy have been beaten back. But from captured Ravenna it may be possible to flank the enemy completely out of the Po Valley. The British Eighth Army, which enveloped the ancient citadel, is hardly likely to stop there.

Christian F. Schultheis has purchased the three-story building containing a store and two apartments at 478 Eighty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, from Esther Lempert. The property is assessed at $35,500. Harry Mandell was attorney for the seller and Isidore Rivinson for the purchaser.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- UnderSecretary of War Robert P. Patterson, giving the Army's weekly war review in absence of Secretary Henry L. Stimson, emphasized today the difficult nature of the fighting that still lay ahead both in Germany and in the Pacific.

Industry response to needs of UNRRA for 22,000,000 yards of woolens, with a delivery deadline on March 31, 1945, have been much less than anticipated, it was learned yesterday. Original invitations for participation in the program called for deliveries of 8,000,000 yards by the end of this year, with an additional 14,000,000 yards to be delivered during the first 1945 quarter.

ROME, Dec. 7 -- Food riots occurred this morning in the poorer districts of Rome, with windows smashed and stalls robbed. It was predominantly a protest of Roman housewives against black market prices, and those who suffered were stores and vendors who charged far more than legal prices for foodstuffs.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed holdings of United States Government securities to have decreased $241,539,000 during the week, while note circulation for the system as a whole increased $106,704,000 to a new high level.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Meat shortages in New York and New Jersey brought together here today representatives of tthree levels of the trade -- packer, retailer and slaughter-house worker -- in the Office of Price Administration, where they warned of a general strike first in New Jersey, and subsequently in New York and Boston, if their demands for price and rationing revision were not met.

WHY is it that an amateur sports official will persist in opening his mouth and then promptly putting his foot in it? Two of them performed that anatomical feat the other day when Herman Fischer, president of the Central Association of the A.A.U., and Avery Brundage, president of the Olympic Committee, issued statements that "Japanese and German athletes will be accepted and welcomed" into the Olympics.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- There were few changes in the commodity markets for the week ended on Dec. 2, which caused the Bureau of Labor Statistics Index of prices in primary markets to rise 0.1 per cent to 104.2 per cent of the 1926 average.

ROME, Dec. 7 -- Premier Ivanoe Bonomi won his long, patient fight to reconstruct the Italian Government tonight and went to the Quirinal Palace shortly after 8 o'clock to announce to Crown Prince Humbert that he had succeeded.

Complaints about the alleged practice of segregating Negro firemen in connection with sleeping arrangements in a number of firehouses were heard yesterday by the city affairs committee of the City Council, which deferred action, pending the result of efforts now being made by Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh to straighten out the situation.
A communique, as broadcast yesterday by the Domei agency from Tokyo in Romanized Japanese to the Orient and recorded and translated by the Federal Communications Commission:

As the flood of black market food cases in War Emergency Court continued to swell, the Office of Price Administration made public yesterday a new enforcement procedure by which repeated violators of price ceilings will be put out of business.

The strain on the money market in New York City was lightened somewhat during the week ended on Wednesday, according to statistics covering the sixteen reporting member banks here, released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

HOLLANDIA, Netherlands New Guinea, Dec. 2 (Delayed) -- More than 1,000 Red Cross workers, most of them women, are getting ready in Australia and New Guinea for transfer to the Philippines to serve forward-area service men as soon as Gen. Douglas MacArthur gives the word.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 7 (U.P.) Rumors that the United States intended to abandon China were denied emphatically today by a high-ranking United States Army spokesman who pledged the full support of all American forces in this theatre to help crush the Japanese "knockout" offensive now overrunning a vast area of southwestern China.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- The outer defense works of Germany's arsenal of Saarbruecken shook today from United States Third Army tank assaults on the outpost of Forbach, three and a half miles to the southwest, and the United States Seventh Army joined the drive on the Saar Basin with attacks along a 35-mile front.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr., in a statement today again stressing our hands-off policy in respect to the internal politics of liberated countries, supported the position enunciated by Prime Minister Churchill to the effect that the Greek people had the right to decide what form of government they should have.

Establishment of a permanent Trusteeship Council of fifteen experts, to supervise administration of colonies taken from the Axis after the war and present mandated territories, is the pivotal point in a three-part plan to ensure the welfare of nonself-governing peoples released yesterday by the Commission to Study the Organization of Peace.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 7 (AP) -A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique :
Resolutions adopted yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers at its convention here follow:
LONDON, Dec. 7 -- Although business in today's stock markets was on the small side, the tone was firm in most sections.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The mass sedition trial, which has been in progress here for more than seven months, ended today with the declaration of a mistrial because of the recent death of the chief justice of the court, Edward C. Eicher.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- In a plan to safeguard the health of its future generation, the Netherlands Government has just completed plans with the British Government by which Netherland children suffering from malnutrition will be brought to Great Britain, where they will be nursed back to physical fitness.

Black-market operations in gasoline, while flourishing now, gradually are being choked off, according to reports from Federal and Westchester County authorities, who started criminal action yesterday against twenty-four Westchester dealers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Establishment of a free market for cotton, both on domestic and foreign sales, was urged upon a special Congressional committee here today by representatives of the New York Cotton Exchange, banking organizations and spokesmen for Anderson, Clayton Co., a leading cotton export house.

As the nation marked the third anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor yesterday with solemn ceremonies and rallies at which pledges to avenge the treacherous assault were linked with exhortations to buy additional war bonds, the Sixth War Loan took a great bound forward that almost certainly carried it past its over-all goal of $14,000,000,000.

Bizet's "Carmen" received a routine performance at its first presentation of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Neither the principals of the familiar cast nor Wilfred Pelletier, who conducted, neared distinction in their respective contributions, the most satisfactory work of the evening being accomplished by participants entrusted with lesser roles.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Cheers and applause echoed in the House today as Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, Philippine Resident Commissioner to the United States, gave a first-hand story -- on the third anniversary of Pearl Harbor -- of American troop landings in the Japanese-held Philippine Islands.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The House put aside today a pending $478,000,000 deficiency appropriation bill to pass an "emergency" measure authorizing increased allotments to each member of Congress for more clerks at about $3,000 a year each.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Friday, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A communique:

Three corporations and twenty individuals were named in a suit asking treble damages of $5,292,372, filed in Federal court late Wednesday, it became known yesterday. The plaintiff, Chester Bowles, national head of the Office of Price Administration, charged a conspiracy to sell liquor at prices exceeding those allowed under OPA regulations, and to conceal the overcharges.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 -- American schools must prepare to conduct a huge retraining program for 15,000,000 civilians and returning veterans who will need assistance in making a successful transition from a war to peace economy, speakers told the convention of the American Vocational Association, which has 2,500 educators in attendance.

This city is not likely to be bombarded by German rockets in this war, according to Alfred Africano, former president of the American Rocket Society, because a single flying bomb that could cross the Atlantic would cost an estimated $10,000,000 or more and would need an initial weight of 2,500 tons to carry one ton of explosive.

Despite tight fabric supply conditions and other difficulties, significant collections of summer dresses are being prepared by the members of the Fashion Originators Guild of America and will be shown during the market period beginning Feb. 5.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Government planners concerned with war production and reconversion are seriously considering a return to the 40-hour work week in all industries not directly connected with essential production, after the defeat of Germany, it was stated today by William Haber, who was appointed yesterday to the post of labor adviser to James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (U.P.) -- Economic stability at home is an absolute requisite of victory, according to Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr.

Henry J. Kaiser, whose shipyards and other plants have played an important role in turning out the sinews of war, appears virtually certain to turn his talents and resources to home-building when peace comes, with the aim of bringing costs down by large-scale production so that millions of more families can afford to own modern dwellings.

Trust funds throughout the country are shrinking and the movement may have important effects on the sale of investment trust shares, according to speakers who addressed the Boston Forum on Open-End Investment Companies, held yesterday at the Boston University of Law under the sponsorship of Vance, Sanders Co.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec 7 (AP) -Byron Nelson hung up a subpar 66 today to lead the field in the first round of the 72-hole Oakland open golf tournament. Favorite and winner of the San Francisco open only last Monday, the Toledo sharpshooter coupled 33s. Par for the Sequoyah course, short and slightly on the hilly side, is 35, 35 -- 70.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Friday, Dec. 8 -- The United States Navy lifted the Army from Leyte's mud Thursday and carried a strong force on an end run via Surigao Straits, landing the force three miles south of Ormoc to split the Japanese forces on Leyte and seal off Ormoc Bay.

LONDON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Tomasz Arciszewski, Socialist Premier of the exiled Polish Government, tonight asserted a belief that "all controversial matters between Poland and Russia will be solved on lasting, just and honorable terms, safeguarding the interests of both sides."
The need for conserving tin as a vital and increasingly scarce material for war production was emphasized in Federal court yesterday by United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Brosnan and Halley's Henry Knight, 5-year-old bay son of Teddy, turned back four other sprinters today to win the six-furlong Virginia Purse at Gulfstream Park in 1:11 2-5. Cream was second, a scant head behind, and Hoosier was a length back in third place.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Finance Committee of the Senate today voted 13 to 2 to report out favorably a bill freezing the payroll tax for 1945 at the present level. The measure is identical with the one passed by the House on Tuesday.

LONDON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The president of the British National Union of Manufacturers charged today that the Churchill Government had nothing to match America's well-devised planning" for post-war world trade while in the House of Lords a peer lamented that Britain's military action in Greece was willing an export market.

The cotton market turned slightly easier yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, and final prices were 2 to 14 points net lower. The market opened 10 points lower to 4 points higher, but turned soft on the issuance of thirty-eight December notices, all of which were stopped.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 7 (U.P.) -- The Japanese offensive to knock China out of the war gained momentum today with the disclosure by the Chinese High Command of the loss of Tuyun, some fifty miles southwest of Kweiyang, capital of Kweichow Province and strategic transportation hub in southwest China.

Voters of 107 communities in twenty-four States approved the issuance of municipal bonds in the aggregate amount of $235,814,700 in November, the largest number and volume of proposals approved by voters in any month in recent years, according to The Daily Bond Buyer.

A handsome white Wyandotte cock was decreed grand champion of the fourteenth annual New York Poultry Show, in the Ninth Regiment Armory, yesterday, and Elwood Taylor of Berwyn, Md., its exhibitor, received $75 in war bonds from William Hobbs of Madison, N.J., chief judge.

LONDON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The condition statement of the Bank of England for week ended Dec. 6, issued today, disclosed a new high for note circulation with an increase of 14,164,000, the largest gain for any week since April 9.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -Twentieth Air Force communique 28:

ATLANTA, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Morgan Blake, a columnist for The Atlanta Journal and a former Sunday school teacher at the Federal prison here, quelled the revolt of the twenty-five convicts this afternoon by carrying out his promise to publicize the prisoners' grievances if they would surrender themselves and their hostages without violence.
Carstens Linnekin have leased the entire building at 45 West Twenty-eighth Street to James Rutig.

CARTERET, N.J., Dec. 7 -While as many as 200 State troopers, municipal police and soldiers from Camp Kilmer were searching for him tonight in the woods near here, a man who had gone on the rampage with firearms and killed four persons and wounded two others this afternoon, walked into police headquarters in near-by Woodbridge and surrendered.

Leonard Isaacson, who had worked up considerable steam while wearing the uniform of a lieutenant commander of the Navy Air Service, turned up in a deflated and flabby condition yesterday at the United States Court House. He had, it was reported, attended one party too many, and got too close to a group of twenty real Navy men, ranging from ensign to captain.

Emphasizing the complete dependence of the country's fighting forces in all theatres of war on supplies brought to them by the merchant marine, the War Advertising Council issued yesterday an emergency call to business leaders throughout the country asking advertising support for an intensified campaign to recruit 43,000 badly needed merchant seamen.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Backstage rumblings over President Roosevelt's four appointees to high posts in the reorganized State Department continued in the Senate today as the Foreign Relations Committee was called to meet in special closed session tomorrow morning to decide how to review its previous recommendation that all of them be confirmed.

ATHENS, Dec. 7 (U.P.) -- British and Greek Government land and air forces have cleared troops of the Elas, military arm of the National Liberation Front, from about three square miles of the Athens area. Royal Navy warships, joining the battle for the first time, shelled Elas positions today at Piraeus, the port of Athens.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 7 -- Three men were convicted and three others acquitted last night of conspiring to defraud the Government by failing to disclose, when they registered as aliens, that they were members of the Nazi party. A jury of eight men and four women was out for twelve hours and brought in its verdict at 11:40 P.M. before Federal Judge Thomas F. Meaney here.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $504,800,970 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average price per share of all listed stocks on Nov. 30 was $36.14, compared with $35.84 at the end of October.

Nicholas Wreden, who left Scribner's last June to join the staff of E. P. Dutton, has been elected a director and vice president of the company. He will have charge of the editorial department. Mr. Wreden's autobiography, "The Unmaking of a Russian," appeared in 1935.

The Red Wings took advantage of the Rangers' lapses often enough to score three goals in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night, and these goals were just enough to enable the visiting aggregation to skate off with the victory, 3 to 2.

The family of the service man with facial injuries has a responsibility equal to that of the plastic surgeon in the job of reconstruction, Lieut. Col. James Barrett Brown, chief of the plastic surgery section, Valley Forge General Hospital, Phoenixville, Pa., asserted yesterday at the annul Greater New York Dental meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Greater New York Fund has already raised $4,620,275 in its 1944 drive, surpassing its minimum goal of $4,500,000, it was announced yesterday by J. Stewart Baker, chairman of the drive. The campaign has almost a month to go before the books are closed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -The Justice Department, moving swiftly following Congressional criticism, authorized today the impaneling of a Federal grand jury to hear evidence of asserted "irregularities" during construction of Camp Shanks, N.Y.
Katherine Dunham will bring her "Tropical Revue," now on tour, into New York for an engagement of three weeks at the Century Theatre beginning Tuesday, Dec. 26.

The Greyhound Corporation reported yesterday for the first nine months this year a consolidated net income of $8,207,637, after all charges including Federal taxes and reserves, equal to $2.90 each on 2,783,778 shares of common stock.

A detailed draft for an eleventh executive department, that of foreign trade, is reported to be about ready for President Roosevelt's study, preparatory to submission to Congress. The plan, worked out by Government officials, is said to provide for a Cabinet Secretary to carry out the Administration program for expanded commerce abroad after the war.

As another reminder of how life may go on under a hail of bombs we have the figures for civilian casualties in Malta. They help us understand why German war industry, though badly hurt, has not collapsed as soon as some enthusiasts expected.

The Occupational Therapy Committee of the New York Junior League will sponsor a Christmas sale of articles made by patients of eleven New York hospitals at the league's clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, from Monday through Thursday.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 7 -- The blacklisted anti-Democratic Nationalist organ Cabildo was suspended for eight days by order of the Ministry of the Interior. The measure was taken at the request of the Secretariat of Industry and Commerce, which objected to the way Cabildo commented on the choice of a well-known business man, Luis Fiore, for the chairmanship of the committee entrusted with exercising vigilance over Axis firms.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 (AP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today an application by the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey to sell $500,000 of Public Service Coordinated Transport's 4 per cent first and refunding mortgage bonds to the trustee under the mortgage securing the bonds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -Attorney General Biddle declared today that the twenty-five prisoners involved in the Atlanta Penitentiary revolt had been placed in solitary confinement and would be tried promptly and severely punished.

The Michael Todd Players, an experimental group designed as a showcase for bit players, walk-ons and other less-known performers in the theatre, will present this evening at midnight "Spook Scandals" at the President Theatre, 247 West Forty-eighth Street.

Industrial management must develop a "progressive attitude and an open mind" to win the nation's workers over to the idea that management is as great a friend of labor as are unions or Government officials, Herman W. Steinkraus, president and general manager, Bridgeport Brass Company, and director of the National Association of Manufacturers, declared last night.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Charging that the farmer is the victim of bad planning with respect to butter production, John Brandt, president of the National Cooperative Milk Producers Federation, today absolved butter dealers and farmers of responsibility for the current butter shortage.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- President Roosevelt repeated today his endorsement of the pending Senate bill to prohibit, after 1947, use of the Red Cross insignia and emblem by any other than the American National Red Cross and the sanitary and hospital authorities of the Army and Navy.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Saturday, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A communique:

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Dec. 8 -- The great French Atlantic port of Le Havre and the Seine River port of Rouen have been restored to a point where they are handling considerably more tonnage than before the war, Maj. Gen. Frank S. Ross, Chief of Transportation in the European Theatre of Operations for the United States Army, announced today.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Full and official details of the German rocket bomb were revealed by the Air Ministry tonight for the first time, with the conclusion that the weapon, while devilishly ingenious, is inaccurate and of doubtful military value.

A decision announced yesterday by the Regional War Labor Board denying a 10 per cent indirect bonus for 8,000 members of the Engineers and Salaried Employes Association, Inc., employed in the Wright Aeronautical Corporation's Paterson, N.J., plants, will be appealed to the national board in Washington, Simon J. Hauser, attorney for the independent union, said.

MOSCOW, Dec. 8 -- Boleslaw Berut, president of the Polish National Council, declared today there was no possibility of, and no use for, further unity negotiations with the new London Polish Government in Exile headed by Premier Tomasz Arciszewski.
The New York Stock Exchange membership of L.J.S. Brody has been transferred to Daniel E. Wade.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Income payments to individuals in October amounted to $13,669,000,000, which was almost 8 per cent higher than the $12,690,000,000 reported for the corresponding month of last year, Secretary of Commerce Jesse Jones announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Amendment of the pending Senate-approved bill to prohibit unauthorized use of the Red Cross name and emblem was agreed upon in principle at today's hearing before the House Foreign Affairs Committee, which will meet tomorrow to draft its report for presentation on Monday.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Prime Minister Churchill, one of history's greatest orators, obviously enjoyed himself today in his foreign policy speech, heckling his hecklers, swapping oral punches and spicing solemn declarations with touches of humor.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- A grim picture of life in northern Norway, after the Germans had retreated before the advancing Russian troops, was painted in London today by Terje Wold, Norwegian Minister of Justice, who has just returned from a visit to the liberated areas.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Western Conference today named a three-member committee, comprising Athletic Directors L.M. St. John of Ohio State, Kenneth L. Wilson of Northwestern and H.O. (Fritz) Crisler of Michigan, to guide Big Ten athletics until a successor to the late Commissioner John L. Griffith is appointed.

OTTAWA, Dec. 8 -- Ottawa infantry battalions of the Sixth Division and other unbrigaded infantry battalions are being sent overseas, in accord with the order recently issued by the Canadian Government calling for the use of home defense draftees as reinforcements for the Canadian Army in Europe, it was announced today.

The young Cuban pianist, Jorge Bolet, appearing in his uniform of a lieutenant in the Cuban Army, gave his first recital of the season at Carnegie Hall last night. Mr. Bolet is an immensely competent musician, playing most of the works on his program in a commendably direct, straightforward manner.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Policies designed to protect dairy income in the immediate and post-war period were adopted today in the closing session of the National Cooperative Milk Producers Federation convention. The program calls for:

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 8 -- Rachel F. Gimbel, widow of Isaac Gimbel, left the bulk of her personal property, with a value "exceeding $10,000," in trust to her two sons, Bernard F. Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., and Frederic A. Gimbel, managing director of the New York store, probating of the will in Greenwich Probate Court today disclosed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today a deficiency appropriation bill carrying $399,230,312, but a point of order defeated a motion to include funds for increasing clerk hire allotments of each member of Congress by $3,000 to a total of $9,500 a year.

The Hood River, Ore., post of the American Legion may have reflected a local prejudice when it recently removed from its war memorial the names of sixteen American citizens of Japanese descent who have served honorably in this war. In certain parts of the West the old and understandable opposition to Japanese immigration has survived in a dislike of native-born Japanese Americans because of the color of their skins.

Plans for post-war sales by the Ford Motor Company were outlined yesterday at a conference of salesmen and executives of the Edgewater, N.J., branch region with Henry Ford 2d, executive vice president of the organization at the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- President Roosevelt authorized Secretary Stimson today to seize and operate the plant of the Cudahy Brothers Company, meat packers, of Cudahy, Wis., and to end Government control within sixty days after determining that productive efficiency has been restored.

PARIS, Dec. 8 -- That Gen. Charles de Gaulle's visit to Moscow would result in a mutual assistance pact similar to that signed in 1942 between Great Britain and Russia was predicted in official circles here tonight, and more confidently than ever before.

ROME, Dec. 8 (AP) -- British and Polish troops, fighting forward through rain, fog and mud today, widened their bridgehead across the Lamone River southwest of Faenza to nearly five miles, virtually outflanking that highway town between Bologna and the Adriatic Sea.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The House passed a bill today to create eight five-star Army and Navy commanders.

Discussions on the merits of various mildew resistant finishes that are being applied to cotton duck tentage will take place today at a meeting in the Quartermaster General's office in Washington, it was reported yesterday. Results of the use of new copper salt solutions will be passed on to manufacturers with the view to getting the maximum effectiveness on duck yardage now coming off the looms, it was indicated.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Saturday, Dec. 9 -- Newly landed American troops drove to within one mile of Ormoc, main Japanese supply port on Leyte, yesterday, headquarters announced today. New Yorkers and others of the Sev enty-seventh Division, who landed Thursday on the west coast, advanced two miles through rice paddies despite stiffening Japanese opposition. They captured Camp Downes late yesterday and their impetus is still maintained.

Lumber production decreased 8.6 per cent last week, compared with the corresponding week a year ago. Shipments were down 12.7 per cent and orders up 12.5 per cent, according to reports received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

MARSEILLE, Dec. 8 -- The lights blaze on the Rue Cannebiere. Perhaps they wouldn't seem very bright to a New Yorker, but after the pinpoint lights of London, the dim corner lamps beginning to spot Paris and the pitch blackness of Brussels, Rome and dozens of gloomy towns, the eye is fairly dazzled by the first sight in months of a normally illuminated street.

Industry will meet successfully the challenge to put 3,000,000 veterans in post-war jobs, Harry L. Derby, president, American Cyanamid and Chemical Corporation, said yesterday afternoon, at a forum on Veteran Re-employment held in connection with the War and Reconversion Congress of American Industry, National Association of Manufacturers, in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 -- An extensive three-year program, to cost $10,000,000 and designed to develop closer cultural and educational relations between the United States and the Latin-American countries, is under way, Dr. Kenneth Holland, chief of the educational division, Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, disclosed today at the American Vocational Association convention.

New records were set in Christmas trade here this week as gift buyers thronged stores in an unprecedented wave of early shopping. The peak has not yet been reached, merchants said yesterday, predicting that still higher sales totals will be reached next Thursday or the following Monday if merchandise stocks hold out.

LONDON, Dec. 8 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister Churchill asserted in his speech today that Britain had not "in any way" broken away from a joint arrangement with the United States about Italy. He disclosed that he and President Roosevelt made plans at their Quebec conference for British occupation of Greece and that he told the President then that trouble might be expected from members of the Greek Leftist resistance movement.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 -- Formation of a $10,000,000 bank credit group in the Philadelphia Federal Reserve District for the purpose of financing small and medium-sized business concerns during the reconversion period was announced today by Evan Randolph, president of the Philadelphia National Bank, at the mid-year trust and banking conference of the New Jersey Bankers Association at the Federal Reserve Bank here.

The agreement reached at Chicago by the International Civil Aviation Conference is probably the best that can be hoped for in the present situation. Each country is still the sovereign of its own air, and for military reasons each will still designate the routes that aircraft must follow within its borders.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- By a vote of 47 to 19 the Senate adopted this afternoon the Social Security tax freeze for 1945 which the House passed overwhelmingly Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Seven railroads described today as "camouflage" and "political oratory" sections of a freight-rate complaint filed in the Supreme Court by Gov. Ellis Arnall of Georgia. The seven are among twenty railroads named by the Governor in the complaint, which seeks to force equalization of freight rates between the South and other parts of the country.
LONDON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The principal parts of Prime Minister Churchill's speech in the House of Commons today:

Just about the most artistic lacing he has ever received came to Tami Mauriello, the Bronx, last night in Madison Square Garden. Lee Oma, Detroit, fighting in a style that was altogether unorthodox, battered the rugged Italian in ten rounds of fighting that was a revelation as well as a distinct ring upset.

A committee representing 10,000 kosher and non-kosher retail meat dealers met with Mayor La Guardia and Henry M. Brundage, Commissioner of Markets, at City Hall yesterday and urged assistance in their fight for price and rationing revision by the Office of Price Administration.

HEADQUARTERS OF THE TWENTY-FIRST BOMBER COMMAND, on Saipan, Dec. 8 -- A B-29 force as large as any that has been operated from the Marianas dropped hundreds of tons of bombs on Iwo, Japanese air base in the Volcano Islands, today in retaliation for five enemy air raids on Saipan since Superfortresses began bombing Tokyo.

ATHENS, Dec. 8 (U.P.) -- British paratroopers and Greek Elas snipers played a deadly hide-and-seek on Athens rooftops and around the Parthenon today as the Elas fighters infiltrated city areas previously cleared. The civil war went on unabated despite reports of progress toward bringing it to an end.

William J. Gilliland, the new president of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards, who was inducted into office yesterday at a luncheon of the association in the Commodore Hotel, expressed the view that no more publicly owned housing should be built because banks and other private institutions are "saturated with funds" to finance private building work.

ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- Governor Dewey, speaking to the State Hi-Y Clubs as they opened their "Model Legislature" this afternoon, urged the delegates to use their "training in public affairs to lead our country into ways of permanent cooperation and lasting peace.

LONDON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- More than 500 Royal Air Force Lancasters spread 3,000 tons of bombs on the jammed freight yards of Duisburg today and several hours later another force of British bombers attacked a synthetic oil refinery at the strategic transportation center on the northern perimeter of the Ruhr industrial area.

The score of the "Ring" which releases the fullest flood of Wagner's unparalleled music, was given a very impressive performance last night in the Metropolitan Opera House. Miss Traubel's performance was beyond anything we had seen her accomplish before in the Bruennhilde role, of which she already had given admirable interpretation.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- William B. Barrett of 514 Pelham Manor Road, this village, secretary-treasurer-controller of the Hugo Stinnes Industries, Inc., at 420 Lexington Avenue, New York, was found dead last midnight on tracks of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad 300 feet north of the Pelham station.

The United States must look for markets abroad "in the neighborhood of $10,000,000,000," Dean Acheson, Assistant Secretary of State, declared yesterday. Such markets, he said, would mean nearly 3,000,000 jobs in industry and foreign outlets for the agricultural output of another 1,000,000 Americans.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A House committee said today that the Government came out a heavy loser in a ten-ship transaction between the Maritime Commission and the Southern Pacific Company.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Dec. 8 -- The Saar Basin, into which Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's American Third Army has now smashed, is, next to the Ruhr Valley, the most important industrial area in western Germany.

A solid demonstration of America's support of her fighting sons came yesterday on the third anniversary of the nation's entry into World War II with the announcement in Washington that the Sixth War Loan of $14,000,000,000 had been officially oversubscribed.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Four proposed changes in the Fish and Game Laws were submitted to the members of the Putnam County Fish and Game Association at the annual meeting in the County Court House, Carmel, N.Y., last night. They follow:

Smaller manufacturers of rayon hosiery will receive a more equitable share of rayon yarn under the proposed revision of M-37-d which allocates rayon yarn to the industry, according to sources in the trade yesterday.

ROME, Dec. 8 -- Premier Ivanoe Bonomi and leaders of the four parties who are joining his Government spent today drawing up a list of ministers. As it must be submitted to the Allies for approval it will not be published before tomorrow at the earliest.

Investment banking does not support any reported efforts to abolish the Securities and Exchange Commission and knows that the securities regulation adopted ten years ago "was necessary and is salutary," J. Clifford Folger, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, said last night in an address at the New School for Social Research.

As a major step in carrying out what has been described as "the greatest merchandising job on record," involving billions of dollars' worth of surplus war goods, equipment and property, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation will erect a vast chain of warehouses at key points throughout the nation, it was learned last night.

DETROIT, Dec. 8 -- One hundred and fifty delegates, representing 300,000 women members of the United Automobile Workers (CIO) were told today by Joseph Velosky, director of the UAW Veterans Department, that the cry of war service will not be used as a weapon to destroy women's seniority rights in any battle for jobs during reconversion.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 8 -- The warning that a continental war in Asia, lasting years, might have to be fought even after the complete conquest of Japan was sounded at the Aviation Trades Association convention here today by Grover Loening, aircraft consultant to the War Production Board.

A buying force unmatched in five months swept the stock market yesterday almost to the peaks for several years which were set last July. With a turnover of more than 750,000 shares in the final hour alone, prices were pushed ahead from major fractions to more than a point, while one of the prime investment issues gained almost 6 points.

CHUNGKING, China, Saturday, Dec. 9 -- Counter-attacking Chinese troops have virtually thrown Japanese invaders out of the south China Province of Kweichow, Gen. Chen Cheng, new Chinese War Minister, announced today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Tokyo and recorded and translated by the Federal Communications Commission:

ROME, Dec. 8 -- Gen. Sir Henry Maitland Wilson, on the eve of his departure from this theatre, described the Greek opposition forces as "irresponsible extremists" and asserted that "a number of deserters from the German and Bulgarian Armies have been found in a recent round-up, some of whom undoubtedly were 'planted' when the Germans retired."

Universal Bible Sunday will be observed tomorrow. Pastors of many churches will preach sermons exalting the place of God's Holy Word in modern life and particularly among the men and women in the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Rules to govern the guaranteeing of farm loans to war veterans, as provided in the GI Bill of Rights, were issued today by Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Veterans Affairs. The Department of Agriculture was designated cooperating agency in approving loans.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 (AP) -- President Judge Gay Gordon of Common Pleas Court dismissed today a petition by four transit workers, dismissed after Philadelphia's transportation strike last August, asking the court to order their reinstatement.

ROME, Dec. 8 -- More disturbances occurred in Rome markets this morning as irate workmen again attacked shops and stalls of black market food venders. This time the black market men fought back, but the authorities did little interfering.

There will be enough basketball around town this afternoon and tonight to satisfy the most eager court fan. Topping the list will be tonight's doubleheader at Madison Square Garden, where the Long Island University quintet will tackle the Valparaiso five and the Brooklyn College team will face Western Michigan.

Welker Cochran of San Francisco and a fellow-Californian, Jay Bozeman of Vallejo, continued unbeaten in the world three-cushion billiard championship yesterday to remain deadlocked for the lead at five victories apiece. Cochran last night beat Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia at the Capitol Hotel's Oak Room, 50 -- 38, in forty-one innings, while during the afternoon Bozeman topped the same Ponzi, 50 -- 49, in fifty-two frames.

The amphibious operation against the Japanese on the west coast of Leyte, where a landing was made without the loss of a man, gives dramatic emphasis to a military fact that becomes more evident with every such operation. America's amphibious forces have come of age.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week aggregated $19,242,124, compared with $8,743,500 for this week, according to the Daily Bond Buyer. The weekly average of offerings for the year to date now stands at $21,690,998.

The opportunities for senior cadets of the United States Cadet Nurse Corps who will serve the last six months of their three-year training in Federal and local hospitals were outlined yesterday by representatives of the United States Public Health Service, Army, Navy and local public health groups at a meeting sponsored by the Nursing Council for War Service on Long Island.

The City Center, civic playhouse, will receive the Margaret Webster-Carly Wharton production of "The Cherry Orchard," headed by Eva Le Gallienne and Joseph Schildkraut, on Jan. 1, it was confirmed yesterday by New-bold Morris, President of the City Council and chairman of the Center's board of directors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- A proposal that customs duties collected upon post-war imports be earmarked for distribution to export shippers to compensate them for sales below parity of agricultural surplus products in world markets was advanced here today by spokesmen for the National Association of Commissioners, Secretaries and Directors of Agriculture.

The Japanese admitted in cautiously worded broadcasts yesterday that Thursday's earthquake in the Pacific off the Japanese coast had set up tidal waves and that "factories and workshops" had suffered, The Associated Press reported.

Marked expansion of the use of standards for the post-war period in consumer goods and in the international field was predicted yesterday by Henry B. Bryans, executive vice president of the Philadelphia Electric Company, at the annual meeting of the American Standards Association in the Hotel Roosevelt.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed today the conviction of three of the country's largest tobacco companies on charges of violating the anti-trust laws. Fines aggregating $255,000 were assessed in the district court at Lexington, Ky., in October, 1941, after a trial lasting five and a half months.

Delaware State police and agents of the War Food Administration will be on duty beginning at midnight tomorrow to halt any attempts at transporting live poultry by trucks from the Delaware, Maryland and Virginia chicken farm areas, it was announced yesterday at the local office of the WFA.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture estimated today that this year's cotton crop was 12,359,000 equivalent 500-pound bales. Acre yield was estimated at 295.3 pounds, the highest on record.

Miss Gertrude Poyneer Sheppard, 20 years old, a convent graduate and daughter of William Martin Sheppard, the Argentine head of the Electric Bond and Share Company at 2 Rector Street, wept softly yesterday in General Sessions as Judge John J. Mullen suspended sentence on her.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 8 (AP) -- A Florida professional, Pete Cooper of Gainesville, stepped in front at the halfway mark of the $10,000 Miami open today while the field was bunching up for the wildest finish in the history of the 21-year-old golf tournament

Smooth teamwork among the nation's law enforcement officers, from Federal Bureau of Investigation division chiefs down to the rookie on the city beat, has kept negligible the amount of sabotage committed in this country since Pearl Harbor, according to John F.X. McGohey, United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York.

THE initials PAC are recent. Anyone puzzled about PAC can satisfy much curiosity by reading "The First Round,"* a fat volume by Joseph Gaer. In this he puts together "the story of the CIO Political Action Committee."

PARIS, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The American people have a false impression of the western front situation, which is far tougher than is realized at home, Representative J. Parnell Thomas of New Jersey, one of the seventeen touring members of the House Military Affairs Committee, said today after a week's visit to the front.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Saturday, Dec. 9 -- The National contract bridge open team-of-four championship was won by Charles J. Solomon, Mrs. Benjamin Golder, Simon Becker and Stanley O. Fenkel of Philadelphia and Miss Ruth Sherman of New York in play that ended here early this morning. They topped a field of twenty-five teams which had started play Thursday afternoon.

Red cabbage, now coming to market from New York State gardens, is a favorite of Northern Europeans, who generally serve it with sour sauce. The sauce does double duty, the United States Department of Agriculture points out, for aside from adding flavor to the vegetable, it also intensifies its color.

Darryl F. Zanuck, production chief for Twentieth Century-Fox, will arrive here this morning from Hollywood. Mr. Zanuck will be a speaker tomorrow evening at the American Nobel anniversary dinner at the Hotel Astor. He intends to remain in New York until after the opening of "Winged Victory" at the Roxy on Dec. 20.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 8 -- Still unaware that he had failed to kill his wife, Daniel Molnar, 25 years old, of 60 Christopher Street, Carteret, who surrendered after killing four persons and wounding two others while holding police at bay, told authorities today he had planned for a year to "kill my wife and her whole family."

Warning that even stiffer penalties are in store for persons who smoke in crowded shops during the holiday season, Magistrate Charles E. Ramsgate, in Municipal Term Court, yesterday increased the usual fine on eighty-five smokers. He raised the penalty from $10 to $15 for sixty-two persons who admitted smoking in department stores and from $15 to $25 for twenty-three who pleaded guilty to smoking in factories.

TOLEDO, Dec. 8 (U.P.) -- Production of jet-propelled, robot bombs, an American counterpart of the Nazi V-1 "buzz bomb," has begun in the aircraft division of. Willys-Overland Motors, Charles E. Sorensen, president, announced, today.

A revolutionary aircraft gunfire-control system that has made the Boeing-built B-29 Superfortresses the deadliest aerial weapon in the United States air fleet was demonstrated publicly yesterday for the first time.

Except for the secondary sale of some tax-exempt bonds, registration of several new corporate issues with the Securities and Exchange Commission and the purchasing of several small lots of municipal bonds, investment bankers last week again were inactive in the market for new issues, with-holding offerings of securities while they continued to solicit subscriptions for war bonds.

In rather quiet trading, cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday irregular, 4 points higher to 5 points lower than Wednesday. Fourteen December notices were issued and were stopped. Certificated stock rose from 20,241 to 21,628 bales.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Senate Foreign Relations committee decided almost unanimously in closed session today to begin public hearings Tuesday on President Roosevelt's appointments to four high posts in the reorganized State Department under Secretary Edward R. Stettinius Jr.

If health is to become a matter of Congressional concern some basic principles must be accepted at the outset. Medical care must obviously be of the best, but doctors and hospitals must be adequately compensated for their services. The private practice of medicine must be preserved, but patients must have the right to choose the kind of approved medical care that they want.

BUFFALO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Trade- minded baseball folk had only rumors to talk about today as the minors ended their forty-third annual National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues convention with post-war committee hearings and headed for New York to "kibitz" on next week's major league confabs.

LONDON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Ordinary German criminal courts will function under Allied authorities' control after they have been purged of Nazi officials, a spokesman for Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower said today in a message broadcast to the German people.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 8 -- Dennis Morgan is to have the lead opposite Ann Sheridan in "When Old New York Was Young," a musical with an 1850 political background, which has been scheduled for production in Technicolor early in January.
KANDY, Ceylon, Dec. 8 (UP) -- A communique:

Britain's intervention in Greece was attacked last night by Earl Browder, president of the Communist Political Association, as "the first serious departure from the Teheran Concord" in an address before 3,000 Communists at a meeting of the association at the Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street near Eighth Avenue.

When you read of pickets from the Custodial Workers Union parading in front of schoolhouses you find yourself wondering if some quick-witted teacher here and there seized upon the opportunity. A strike picket is, of course, one of the outstanding social phenomena of the times, and in the schools they are laying more and more stress on bringing the child in close touch with the social environment in which he will grow up and live.
Austin R. Zender, director of sales of the Bridgeport Brass Company, has been named vice president in charge of sales.

Rain driven by a forty-mile-an hour wind, with gusts up to sixty-nine miles an hour, fell in New York yesterday, causing damage to cornices, signs and copings, and the cancellation of seventy-five flights at La Guardia Field.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 8 -- Yesterday's coordinated naval and air attack on Iwo was the heaviest made on an island of this size. Considerably more than 200 planes of the Army and Navy took part in the raid and the tonnage of bombs alone may have neared 1,000.

Mrs. Madline Dunnigan of 422 First Street, Brooklyn, blonde, 22-year-old wife of a Navy Yard worker, whom District Attorney Frank S. Hogan referred to as "a Lady Robin Hood, but not of Sherwood Forest," was arrested yesterday afternoon in the prosecutor's office in her alleged thefts of between $30,000 and $40,000 since last January from the Gropper leather goods concern, at 685 Fifth Avenue, where she was the bookkeeper.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 8 (AP) -- There was a familiar ring to open tournament golf today as a bulky field completed the second round of the $7,500 Oakland event. In front, tied at 138, were the "Gold Dust Twins," Byron Nelson and Harold McSpaden.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Dec. 8 -- It took the Japanese twenty-seven hours to destroy the first Liberty ship sunk by the enemy in the Philippine campaign. Japanese fliers have made persistent attempts to sink these supply craft and they lost at least three planes to sink the one ship.

HEADQUARTERS OF TWENTY-FIRST BOMBER COMMAND, on Saipan, Dec. 8 -- A B-29 of the Twenty-first Bomber Command, flying alone on a weather reconnaissance mission, dropped incendiary bombs early this morning on brightly lighted Shizuoka, rail center 100 miles southwest of Tokyo, starting four fires.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The War Production Board today ordered put aside for military use all production of French Knitting yarn made from wool or other fibers in the two-month period Dec. 17 through Feb. 17, 1945.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 7 (Delayed) -- As a link in the plan to keep nazism alive after its overthrow, the Himmler-Goebbels clique is reported by reliable sources in Berlin to be making ready even now to pin responsibility for Germany's defeat upon Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, Reich Marshal Hermann Goering and Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop.

The six-story building containing three stores and thirty apartments at 330 East 187th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by the Nocor Corporation to Joseph Silva for cash above mortgages of $36,740. The property occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet. D.A. Parrone was the broker and Michael Giordano was attorney for the seller.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The War Manpower Commission is convinced that it can achieve its immediate critical objectives without new legislative help, but concedes that statutory penalties to enforce its regulations would simplify the problem provided such penalties could be enacted quickly, Charles M. Hay, executive director, asserted today at a hearing of the Special Senate Committee investigating the war program.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 8 -- Claims in the field of marine construction and operation, an improved vaccine for hog cholera, and lubricants of special interest are among the 554 patents listed as granted in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

SOME news travels mighty slowly these days and hence a rather ancient column on Lord Burghley which appeared in this space has just been digested, commented on and the comments returned. The letter writer is Trevor Wignall, once of The London Daily Express and at one time Britain's most famous sports writer. His digressions from the main topic are even more interesting than his remarks on his Lordship, now the Governor General of Bermuda.

Establishment of a dental health commission to cooperate with the professions in war-torn countries for development of a service program was advocated yesterday by Dr. Walter H. Scherer of Houston, Tex., president of the American Dental Association.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 9 (U.P.) -- Russian mechanized forces yesterday advanced to within nine miles of the twelve-way road and rail junction of Szekesfehervar, keystone of Nazi defenses southwest of Budapest, while Berlin reported that Soviet tank forces had reached the area of Vac, Danube River fortress sixteen miles due north of the Hungarian capital.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission released jurisdiction today over fees and expenses incurred during the issuance and sale of $10,000,000 principal amount of Birmingham (Ala.) Electric Company's first mortgage bonds, due 1974.
The text of the President's message to the War and Reconversion Congress of American Industry, the National Association of American Manufacturers' forty-ninth annual meeting follows:

How you handle your war wages and salaries will determine the time it will take to destroy Japan; how you handle your money also will decide whether you get victory out of the ruins of Tokyo and Berlin.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- By 279 votes to 30, Prime Minister Churchill won a fresh mandate from the House of Commons today to continue a foreign policy in the liberated countries of Europe that a considerable body of British opinion regards with distaste, even with distrust.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- After a conference today with Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr. on the Greek and Italian situation, the Earl of Halifax, British Ambassador, said to newspaper correspondents, "There is substantial understanding as always, between the two Governments."

Their homes broken by illness or the war, 400 children -- constituting an "overflow" from approved shelters -- are living from day to day confined to cribs in city hospitals or creating additional tensions in overcrowded apartments of neighbors or relatives, it was disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Grain markets made a strong start and an easy finish today on the Board of Trade, an early advance carrying July and September wheat to a new seasonal high, showing around 3/4 cent a bushel over the previous close, while December wheat equaled the highest price in six months or more and December corn went into new ground in over a month.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Communique 244:

Yielding to the persuasion of the directors of the National Hockey League, in session yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt, Mervyn (Red) Dutton consented to remain as president of the league until the annual meeting next June. Dutton's decision to retain the post was made only after Lester Patrick, manager of the New York Rangers, had agreed to continue as managing director.

An airborne radio broadcast unit designed for high-speed transportation by plane into a captured enemy city, another unit to be ready in a "few days" to relay oral accounts of battle from close behind Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's Third Army to American radio networks and other near-miracles of wartime communications were related here yesterday at a press luncheon given by the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company, 67 Broad Street.

Samuel and Gabriel Nelson, who occupy the three-story building at 406 Broadway for their cotton and rayon textile business, Crown Textile Mills, Inc., has purchased the structure through the Charles F. Noyes Company.

SIOUX CITY, S.D., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Ten soldiers at the Sioux Falls Army Air Field were killed late today when one of two planes which met in mid-air crashed into a barracks. Seven men in the other plane parachuted to safety.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 8 (AP) -- America's biggest handicap on Dec. 7, 1941, was not its lack of guns and war implements with which to answer the Pearl Harbor attack, Lieut. Comdr. Carl Olson told the delegates to the fifty-sixth annual National A.A.U. convention today, but rather its lack of physical preparedness.

David Meister has sold the four-story apartment house at 158-60 South Second Avenue, Mount Vernon, N.Y., to an investing client of David Rapoport, attorney. Sale was subject to a first mortgage of $113,000. Carstens Linnekin, Inc., were the brokers.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Business in today's stock markets as a whole was not active. The general tone, however, was firm, and there were a few good features among industrial securities.

PARIS, Dec. 7 (Delayed) -- France continues to be divided on the question of the purge, as well as on judicial methods generally. While everyone agrees that traitors should receive swift punishment, there is much criticism of the special Courts of Justice created by the de Gaulle Government for the trial of collaborators with Germany.

Palestine is anxiously awaiting political decisions that will determine her future, Mordechai Bentov, editor of the Palestine Hebrew daily Mishmar, who came here by airplane to attend the recent Emergency Conference of the World Jewish Congress in Atlantic City, said yesterday.

WITH THE AMERICAN FIRST ARMY, in Germany, Dec. 8 -- The hard, slugging fighting of recent days and weeks is beginning to pay American troops more dividends in improving their positions for the eventual crossing of the Roer River and an advance to the Rhine.

Plans for consolidation of the Texas properties of the Electric Bond and Share Company system so as to bring about unified operation and meet the requirements of the Public Utility Holding Company Act are being considered, it was announced yesterday.

HOLDEN, Mass., Dec. 8 -- The Christmas "doings" of this town of 4,000 persons is being recorded by the Office of War Information for rebroadcast in forty foreign lands to acquaint the peoples of the world with a typical American yuletide.

Two 18-year-olds share honors with two United States Military Academy plebes and two stalwarts from Ohio State's undefeated civilian eleven, on The Associated Press 20th All-America team, which was released yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Next to the problem of achieving a permanent peace in the post-war era, the greatest problem facing the American people in the immediate future is how to devise means for a more equitable distribution of medical care, leaders in medicine and public health declared today at opening sessions of the National Conference on the Problems of Medical Care.

Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's Third Army's motorized advance against Berlin was stopped around Metz by insufficient supplies of gasoline, Frederick C. Crawford, board chairman of the National Association of Manufacturers, disclosed last night.

Col. Byron E. Brugge, chief of staff to Brig. Gen. Emmett O'Donnell Jr., is missing in action after serving as wing commander on the fourth Superfortress bombing raid on Tokyo, according to word received last night by relatives in Queens.

Air Group 26, numbering many New Yorkers among its pilots and air crewmen, has returned to the United States on leave, the Navy disclosed yesterday, after amassing a record of thirty-one enemy planes shot down, thirty-four destroyed on the ground and thirty-one damaged in strikes in the Philippines.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 8 -- Paul Kronacker, soft-spoken sugar millionaire, who served as Belgian military attache in London during the later years of the German occupation and is now in the Senate, will become a member of the Cabinet, charged with the heavy responsibility of coordinating Belgium's demands for food and raw materials with Allied means of supplying them.
ABOARD ADMIRAL STRUBLE'S FLAGSHIP, Ormoc Bay, Leyte, Dec. 7 (Delayed) -- The Japanese are not likely to shout banzais on the third anniversary of their Pearl Harbor attack.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Publication of the three St Louis newspapers was resumed this evening, but a shutdown of theatres spread to include about two-thirds of its moving picture houses.

Whether for peace or war, progress or disaster, the future of America is bound inextricably with the rest of the world, Erling M. Hunt, Professor of History at Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday at the opening of a social studies conference in the Horace Mann-Lincoln School, 520 West 120th Street.

The nine-story and penthouse apartment building containing twenty-eight apartments at 138 to 142 East Thirty-sixth Street has been purchased by a syndicate of operators headed by Alexander Hirsch, attorney, through L.V. Hoffman Co., brokers. It is assessed at $235,000 and was bought subject to mortgages amounting to $198,000.

Directors of the American Foreign Investing Corporation declared yesterday a year-end dividend of $1.75, payable Dec. 21 bringing dividends this year to $2.50, compared with $1.75 distributed in 1943.

There may have been a time when "Jiggers, the cops" was the average city youngster's reaction to the approach of the law. Of recent years the trend, both within the Department and among the children of the city streets, has been to consider the policeman on the beat as a friend and adviser.

With the work clothing industry operating at best at about 20 per cent of normal on civilian lines, industry spokesmen stated yesterday there is little indication of any easing for several months, and that the first quarter of 1945 is expected to be even tighter.

THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Nov. 19 published an article, "The Future of Europe as President Benes Sees It," which states: "True peace will not be achieved until there is a rebirth of sound ideological and spiritual values." Everybody would agree with that. Unfortunately, there is little evidence in President Benes' article that Czechoslovak foreign policy will be based on such desirable and lofty objectives.

Appealing for support of his Health Insurance Plan for Greater New York, Mayor La Guardia described it last night as a formula benefiting both patient and physician by providing some assurance to the latter of an income.

ADVANCE HEADQUARTERS, NINTH AIR FORCE, Dec. 8 -- Maj. Gen. E.N. Harmon, commanding the Second Armored Division, today sent a letter of commendation to a pilot of the Ninth Air Force Thunderbolt group for knocking out a Panzer threat against units in his command near Juelich on Nov. 28.

Police Sergeant Anthony J. Fox was held without bail in Homicide Court yesterday for a hearing on Dec. 22 on the charge that, before dawn last Tuesday, he shot and killed Michael Condon, 52 years old, a Bowery habitue, in front of 7 Chatham Square when Condon aroused his anger by asking. Fox, who was in civilian's clothing, for a cigarette.

ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- Governor Dewey disclosed today that John Foster Dulles was acting as his personal representative in talks with Secretary Stettinius on peace problems and renewed his pledge to keep the proposed world security organization out of partisan politics.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 7 (Delayed) -- Russia's policy, in the event of the final disintegration of Germany, is a subject for deep thought in Belgium today. The possibility of a Communist German State growing out of the debacle is one that is not ignored.

Knowing better than to count his chickens before the hen hatches them out, Coach Steve Owen is still pretty confident over the Giants' chances of beating the Redskins at Washington tomorrow and sewing up the Eastern title. This would give the Giants another crack at the Packers in the National Football League's play-off championship game here one week hence.

Accused of extortion, Patrolman James J. Costigan, 33 years old, attached to the West 123d Street station, was suspended from duty yesterday and later arraigned in Felony Court, where he was held in $1,000 bail for a hearing next Tuesday.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Howard Dobel and Norman Skinner paced Columbia University's basketball team to a 43-42 victory tonight, after a nip-and-tuck battle with Union College. Al Dingley and Bill Fisher kept Union ahead until the last four minutes of the first half, when the Skinner-Dobel combination lifted Columbia from an 18-12 deficit to a 21-20 lead.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Allied campaign in the west slowed down materially last week as fanatical German resistance, mud, rain and exhaustion hampered the progress of our troops.

LONDON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Boring through blinding snowstorms in 54 degrees below zero weather, more than 700 American warplanes reached the German industrial center of Stuttgart in perfect bombing formation today, blasted congested freight yards there with 1,500 tons of explosives, and also battered a strategic Nazi airdrome at Boblingen, ten miles southwest of the city.

ATHENS, Dec. 9 -- Col. Euripides Bakerdzis, in charge of the Elas [fighting forces of the Greek National Liberation Front] in the Salonika area, has declared that henceforth Greek Macedonia will be independent of Greece, according to a report reaching the British Ministry of the Interior today.

Importers can look for little encouragement to expanding volume unless there are broad changes in the manner in which administrative sections of our tariff act are construed, George B. Herzog, vice president of S. Stern, Stiner Co., Inc., foreign traders, declared in an interview yesterday.

Last week China was stirred as it had not been for many months by the mounting threat posed by the seven-months-old Japanese offensive. The enemy's drive to cut China in two had succeeded when columns pressing from north and south had joined in vital Kwangsi Province.

One of the principal charities of St. Paul's School in Concord, N.H., -- the summer camp maintained in Danbury, N.H., for under-privileged boys from the larger eastern cities -- will be the beneficiary of the annual hockey game between the teams of St. Paul's and the Kent (Conn.) School, which will take place Thursday afternoon at Madison Square Garden. Francis A. Nelson Jr. is chairman of the sponsoring committee.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- The build-up has begun for transforming the Soviet-sponsored Polish Committee of National Liberation in Lublin into a Provisional Government of Poland to the exclusion of the Polish Government in London, which is recognized by the United States and Great Britain.

Details of the construction of LSM's (Landing Ships, Medium) for the Navy by the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company's Port Newark, N.J., plant, hitherto an item on the Navy's "secret" list, were disclosed here yesterday by company officials.

ATHENS, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Eam (National Liberation Front) made a blanket denial today of British Prime Minister Churchill's charges that the Eam and its military auxiliary, the Elas, were seeking to seize power in Greece and terrorize the countryside, but said the present battle would continue until the Government of Premier Papandreou resigned.

Retail trade was very active last week in the three major test markets of New York. Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors of stores were jammed as Christmas trade expanded.

Mayor La Guardia and the butchers' union called upon the War Food Administration yesterday for immediate action to solve the meat supply problem in this area. Joseph Belsky, vice president of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workers of North America, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, requested the WFA to urge President Roosevelt to direct the Army to take over and operate the meat industry in New York and New Jersey.

PARIS, Dec. 9 (AP) -- German prisoners are neither pampered nor persecuted -- and they are not receiving any American cigarettes. members of a United States House Military Affairs Committee reported today after a visit to a camp at Chartres, forty-five miles southwest of Paris.

Forbes of the Seabees, who writes from abroad, protesting against political partisanship manifested in the billing of an orchestral program given in the Royal Opera Theatre in Rome under the auspices of the British Army Education and Welfare, when Wagner's "Ride of the Valkyries" was played.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Fears held by many service men that the best peacetime jobs will have been gobbled up before they get out of uniform appear to be groundless, in the view of a battery of experts who spent most of this week here studying reconversion and the veterans' place in it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Selective Service will resume induction into the armed forces of men in the age group 26 through 37, acting in response to a request today from James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization and Reconversion.

The Japanese domestic radio reported that three B-29's, flying separately, appeared over Tokyo and the Inland Sea area during an eight-and-half-hour period early yesterday, but said that only the first one, flying over the capital about 3 A.M., had dropped bombs, "a few incendiaries."

Marcial Mora Miranda, the Chilean ambassador, will speak on "The Continuance of Hemispheric Solidarity" at the fifty-ninth annual dinner of the New York Southern Society at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel next Friday evening, Dec. 15, it was announced yesterday by George A. Sloan, president.

Nimitz for transporting fuels for the operation of the Navy fleet in the Pacific areas.

MERELY as a by-product of its primary business, Bell Telephone Laboratories, Inc., has become one of the largest book publishers in this country. In the last year it has brought out about 400 new titles, with total printings of somewhere between 1,250,000 and 1,500,000 copies.

IT seems like a fine year to give delicacies as Christmas presents, for the experts say that as a result of rationing Americans are more interested in food than they've ever been. Even the most conservative Joe Doakes -- the meat-potato-and-apple-pie man -- is reported to be developing an awareness of seasonings, combinations of flavors, and so on.

BOSTON, Dec. 9 -- It is significant that most of the plans submitted in a local contest designed to focus public attention on the possible post-war future of Greater Boston laid special stress upon types of manufacture which call for quality rather than quantity.

THOSE were great days when Chautauqua came to town bringing its array of talent to dazzle and to instruct. Much of the glamour which it brought to small-towners and country folk three and four decades ago is reflected in this story of a young performer making her first trip on the circuit.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 9 (U.P.) -- Well-trained an well-equipped Chinese reinforcements commanded by Gen. Tang En-po, continuing an offensive that has pushed the Japanese back sixty-five miles in five days, have recaptured Limingkwan, mountain pass on the Kweichow-Kwangsi border 110 miles southwest of Kweiyang, a Chinese High Command communique announced today.
