Confronted by the rather momentous task of setting up machinery whereby the office of high commissioner may continue to function without the immediate naming of a successor to the late Kenesaw M. Landis, the sixteen club owners of the major leagues go into session here tomorrow with the eyes of the baseball world focused sharply upon them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Like a man who extends one foot gingerly forward to test the strength of the ice on a skating pond, Stout Steve Owen will rest his 270 pounds on various sections of the Griffith Stadium field tomorrow and he won't do it very gingerly, either. It will be a solid planting of two large brogans on the turf.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- German submarines have been equipped with new technical devices enabling them to penetrate into areas "denied to them for the past three years" and the enemy has "by no means" abandoned his underseas warfare, President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill jointly warned tonight ir the monthly Anglo-American statement on submarine and antisubmarine operations.

It was an all-losing night for the metropolitan teams at Madison Square Garden as Brooklyn College and Long Island University dropped from the ranks of the unbeaten college basketball squad before 16,422 persons last night. However, neither the Kingsmen nor Blackbirds, toppled respectively by Western Michigan, 58 -- 52, and by Valparaiso, 64-59, lost prestige.

The game bird season was "most unsatisfactory" and the fishing season "only fair" in Westchester County, according to reports submitted by committees to the Southern New York Fish and Game Association.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 9 (AP) -- More than two-thirds of the area's theatres were closed tonight as a strike of film exchange employes and a sympathy walkout of union projectionists slowly paralyzed the motion-picture industry here.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Sunday, Dec. 10 (U.P.) -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur today released a message paying tribute to Lieut. Gen. Walter Krueger's United States Sixth Army, Vice Admiral Thomas C. Kinkaid's Seventh Fleet and Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney's Far Eastern Air Force for the success of the Ormoc amphibious landing, which was taken to indicate that good progress was being made toward a final cleanup of Leyte in preparation for larger Philippines operations.

BERTITA HARDING has always offered us the primrose path to historical education. Production of steel ingots and castings in November was 7,258,534 tons, compared with a revised figure of 7,615,553 in October and 7,371,975 in November, last year, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. For the first eleven months of this year steel output was 82,199,288 tons, against 81,581,222 in the similar period of 1943.

New York State passed its $4,226,000,000 quota in the Sixth War Loan yesterday and voluntarily assumed the responsibility of selling an additional $1,000,000,000 worth of bonds before the end of the drive next Saturday.

In the large, any December woodland is a gray and lifeless place, the trees standing naked to the winter and the underbrush a dry and leafless tangle. But only in the large and at a casual glance. Even now there is life, and there are blossoms and leaves, on bough and twig.

MOSCOW, Dec 9 -- The Communist party newspaper Pravda charged today that William L. White, correspondent for The Reader's Digest, had violated Soviet hospitality and confidence as the traveling companion of Eric Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, and written a book about Russia that is the "usual standard production of a Fascist kitchen with all its smells, calumny, unpardonable ignorance and ill-conceived fury."

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 9 -- Dr. Karl Goerdeler, former German Price Commissioner and Mayor of Leipzig, who was arrested Sept. 8 on charges of leading the conspiracy to kill Adolf Hitler July 20, was still alive, undergoing "questioning," in a Berlin suburb Monday, according to information received here.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Fast-breaking Huddersfield, with only two more matches to be played in the English League North soccer championship, retained a one-point lead today as games throughout the country produced heavy scoring and better than average attendances.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Fifty MP's kept a German general prisoner, but it took some doing.

LONDON, Sunday, Dec. 10 -- Russian troops, reaching the Danube River due north of Budapest in a thirty-seven-mile deep breakthrough of enemy defenses, encircled almost two-thirds of the Hungarian capital yesterday and smashed to within five miles of the city on the south.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- This week while the war continued to take money out of the United States Treasury by the millions of dollars a day a $6,000,000,000 trust fund held by the Government became for Congress a problem child of no small concern.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Industrial users of sugar face another cut in their sugar quotas, candy manufacturers reported today. However, they stated that the reduction probably would be effective for the first quarter of 1945 and would not alter supplies available during the holiday season.

None of the so-called vaccines for the prevention of the common cold now available has been proved to be of any value, none can be recommended for industrial groups or for individuals, it is declared in a report on "The Use of Vaccines for the Common Cold," authorized by the Councils on Pharmacy and Chemistry and Industrial Health of the American Medical Association and published in The Journal of the association.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 -- Although the war is still to be won, leading vocational educators, representing every region of the country, this week mapped out long-range programs designed to bring about reconversion of the school plants from war to peace with a minimum of disturbance and maladjustment.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 9 -- A transfer tax appraisal filed here today with Surrogate Leone D. Howell shows that Walter P. Chrysler, automobile manufacturer, who died at Kings Point, L.I., on Aug. 18, 1940 left a gross estate of $9,844394 and a net estate of $8,854,761.

Stocks ended yesterday the most active week in six months with prices at the best levels in four and a half to seven years. On the New York Stock Exchange THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average went through the July levels as prices extended their gains and closed a shade below their best in the largest Saturday session in six months.

John W. Davis, former Ambassador to Great Britain and Democratic candidate for President in 1924, speaking at the second Metropolitan Opera Victory Rally of the season yesterday afternoon, urged American acceptance of the Dumbarton Oaks proposal for an organization to be known as the United Nations, whose aim would be to prevent future wars.

OTTAWA, Dec. 9 -- Out of the controversy that has disturbed this country for the past two months, as to whether or not drafted men should be sent overseas as reinforcements, three things are seen to have emerged. They are:

THE first American showing of sculpture by Dario Viterbo, at Wildenstein's, is of work done in this country by a Florentine, now a French citizen who came to this country after the Nazis invaded France. Viterbo, is an accomplished eclectic who has progressed from the objective and traditional in the direction of simplification and the psychologically expressive.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 9 -- School problems that have grown into chronic complaints press for attention throughout the Middle West. While there is a present disposition to coast along with local makeshifts until the shape of things post-war becomes clearer, educators are growing insistent and State Legislatures are faced with having to deal with the subject in a comprehensive way.

THE problems which may be expected to confront returning service men and women in the immediate post-war era are not being ignored by film producers. At least fifteen pictures dealing with this subject, in one form or another, are currently in production or in various stages of preparation.

It has been increasingly obvious during the past week that we have reached a stage of the war at which certain differences of opinion and policy have developed among the United Nations. In all but one instance we have reached this stage by military victories. There is an Italian situation because Italy has been so largely liberated, a Belgian situation, a Polish situation, a Greek situation for the same reasons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A recommendation that preference be given to discharged war veterans who needed telephone service for business enterprises which they substantially own and operate, and to widows of veterans living alone except for small children not more than 10 years old, has been made by the Telephone Operations Industry Advisory Committee to the War Production Board.

AMERICANS who are worrying about the future of their free institutions in the highly centralized state of tomorrow should be able to learn something by studying a bureaucratic crisis which has been shaking their neighbor, Australia.

Rise in the purchasing power of India will enable it to buy more consumer goods than ever before, preventing accumulation of any large exportable surplus of cotton textiles after the war, Sir Chunilal B. Mehta, Indian industrialist and chairman of the Indian delegation to the recent International Business Conference at Rye, N.Y., declared in an interview yesterday.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Economic conditions in Belgium are going to get much worse before they possibly can get better, Premeir Pierlot said today.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- When Prime Minister Churchill declared that he did not become the King's first Minister to liquidate the British Empire it was not mere rhetoric. He meant it. And it is in the light of that declaration that the present trend of British foreign policy in Europe must be viewed.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 9 -- The policy committee of the Belgian Communist Party has launched another assault on the Government. A statement today in the Drapeau Rouge, a newspaper Prime Minister Hubert Pierlot threatened to suspend if it incited the public to commit disorders, announced that the Socialist Party had been approached to form a popular front dedicated to the overthrow of the present regime.

SAIPAN, The Marianas, Dec. 9 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Millard F. Harmon, newly appointed commander of the Strategic Air Force of the Pacific Ocean Areas, today named four officers who will get new assignments as the result of the formation of the new command.

Featured by fairly aggressive buying credited to Southern mill interests, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 8 points higher to 3 points lower than on Friday, with near months relatively stronger than distant months.

Fortified with nine former professionals and a host of other players who have appeared in bowl games and were named as all-sectional designees in their college days, Randolph Field's mighty Ramblers will move into the Polo Grounds Saturday afternoon well prepared for its Treasury Bond Bowl contest against the Second Air Force.

Last week the question of what to do about the liberated nations of Europe as they readjust to new conditions came sharply to the fore. It was a question filled with political and social dynamite. Involved in it were complex problems which had increasingly pressed for solution during months of victories while the Allies continued to concentrate their main efforts on the destruction of Nazi Germany.

The seventeenth annual benefit for the Near East College Association, Inc., will be an opera party for the matinee performance of "La Traviata" on Dec. 28 at the Metropolitan Opera House. Tickets at regular box-office prices are now available at the headquarters of the association, 50 West Fiftieth Street. Many boxes and seats already have been taken.

ACCORDING to reports from tobacconists in New York, Chicago and other leading cities, where the cigarette shortage is acute, women have taken to pipe smoking. This surprising trend has received official recognition from Cabinet Secretaries Jesse Jones, Henry Morgenthau Jr. and Henry L. Stimson, who constitute the Foreign Trade Zones Board.

FOR the Hundred Neediest Cases of New York City, THE NEW YORK TIMES today -- makes its thirty-third annual appeal. On these pages you will find the stories of these Neediest -- stark and simple stories, such stories as might be told of any of us struck down by misfortune, stories of neighbors who need our helping hand.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Dec. 9 -- The German Army in the west has recovered in a surprising fashion from the stunning defeats of July, August and September, and seven Allied armies in the west now face approximately seventy German divisions from the North Sea to the Alps.

MR. PERRY offers a highly dramatized story of the unsuccessful drive to end the poll tax in Tennessee. The newspaper of which he is editor, The Nashville Tennessean, is a crusading one, and Mr. Perry would hardly be happy in any role other than that of the knight errant.

THE thing about musical pictures which so few producers recognize is that zest and originality are essential to their charm. And charm, in the last analysis, is the principal thing in musical films. Just think of the pictures in this line which have come along over the years with nothing to recommend them except a package of mediocre songs.
CHEYENNE, Wyo., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Woman's suffrage in the United States is 75 years old tomorrow, the anniversary of a law guaranteeing equal voting rights for women in the Territory of Wyoming.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Explosion of an oil stove was believed to have caused a fire which swept two private barns last night, to Oaklawn Park late last night, destroying at least eight race horses and injuring Eddie Smith, 65-year-old stableman. Smith was retaken to a hospital with severe burns about the face, arms and hands.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Secretary Forrestal said today in re-endorsing universal military training that the airplane and the robot plane might "dry up the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans." They "already have dried up the English Channel," he said.
Ta Kung Pao, Chungking newspaper, said yesterday that Gen. Chen Cheng, Chinese War Minister, planned to train thirty Chinese divisions with modern weapons next year with the aid of the Allies.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 9 -- One hundred and twenty pairs began play in a four-session contest for the national contract bridge open pair championship in the eighteenth annual tournament of the American Contract Bridge League here today. It is the largest field to compete in a national bridge tournament this year.

Although the nation is unified on winning the war, there is disunity when winning the peace is considered, a panel of ten children, 9 to 13 years old, agreed yesterday at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street. An audience of 500 in the same age group agreed with them.

Eugene Istomin, 19-year-old pianist who won the 1943 Leventritt Award which gave him an appearance last year with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, made his second appearance with that organization last night in Carnegie Hall, Artur Rodzinski conducting. He played the Beethoven Fourth Concerto in G major, Opus 58, and he received an ovation at the end for an excellent performance of a great work.

IT was midnight in the charnel house and the monsters all were there, gathered for a late bedtime snack among the dismembered papier-mache cadavers, skeletons, stuffed bats and rubber spiders, in the dankest dungeon of old Castle Frankenstein.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 9 -- The Government issued a decree today appointing a committee to elaborate the so-called "Statute of Political Parties." Under this statute, political parties, dissolved soon after the revolution of June 4 of last year, will be allowed to resume their acivities, though subject to certain restrictions.

Leaving the disposition of Japanese air power to the ministrations of Maj. Richard Bong, his rival for honors as the country's leading fighter ace, and to a host of eager Army and Navy pilots with fewer victories to their credit, Comdr. David McCampbell, topflight naval aviator, has returned to the United States after ten months of active duty in the Pacific.

It is imperative that our schools instill a real appreciation of the historical and cultural background of Latin America if the Good Neighbor policy is to bear fruit, W. Harry Snyder and Frank Tannenbaum, Professors of History at Montclair State Teachers College and Columbia University, respectively, told history teachers yesterday at a conference meeting for the second day at the Horace Mann-Lincoln School, 520 West 120th Street.

" THIS is a dangerous book, full of disturbing possibilities," says Robert C. Miller, director of the California Academy of Sciences, in his foreword to "One Day on Beetle Rock." "Should it fall into the hands of the young, it is extremely likely to make naturalists of them.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY IN GERMANY (Wireless). TIME after time, since American troops first went into action in this war, generals, Government officials, touring Congressmen and newspaper men have praised the fine, well-tempered sense of proportion of the GI's under stress and attested that their sense of humor was never far beneath the surface.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 -- In order to assure peacetime jobs for all workers Federal, State and local funds on a "greatly expanded basis" must be provided for vocational training and retraining programs, the American Vocational Association declared at the closing session of its four-day convention here.

The first five-game basketball program of the season was held at Madison Square Garden yesterday when the local high school teams exhibited their passing finesse and shot-making ability to an enthusiastic crowd of 6,000 onlookers, most of whom were students at the various institutions which competed.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 9 -- Overcoming a nine-point lead that Swarthmore held early in the second half, the Princeton basketball team today scored its first victory of the season, 50 to 42. Ray Winch, center on the Garnet quintet, made 18 points to take the scoring honors.

Last week in Washington workmen were busy in the State Department. They had some redecorating to do in the large, spacious room in the south wing which, since 1875, has been used continuously by Secretaries of State. The files, maps and long oblong desk of the new Secretary of State, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., were being moved in from the office he had as Under-Secretary.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Arrangements for the tenth annual Metropolitan Miami fishing tournament, opening Jan. 7 and continuing through April 15, 1945, will get under way on Friday, when officers of the tournament executive committee will be opened and a meeting of the weighmasters will be held.

With their biggest task the winning of the war, it is a dismal sight to see Washington and London getting at loggerheads. It is a regrettable thing, and great efforts should be made to prevent its continuance and its repetition.

Wives of high-ranking officers in the armed forces head a large committee for a novel fashion show entitled "You Bring It, We Style It," in which young matrons and debutantes of this season and former years will model costumes of their friends.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- On the scent of their first Eastern title since 1941, the Giants, led by Coach Steve Owen, arrived in the capital late this afternoon to await tomorrow's all-important game with the Redskins at Griffith Stadium. A capacity crowd of more than 35,000 is expected to attend.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- With practically no lamentations from any source, the mass sedition trial came to an end here this week.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- The British Government was reported today to be seriously considering proposals made in the House of Commons during yesterday's debate on foreign policy that a Cabinet Minister be sent to Athens to attempt to effect a compromise between the warring Greek factions.

City College had little trouble in scoring a 60-34 victory, its fourth of the season, over an outclassed Lafayette five last night at the Lavender gym. Although Paul Semko of the visiting Leopards was high scorer with 13 points, his team-mates were unable to match his ability to penetrate the Beaver defense.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Big Six Conference today discarded its anti-proselyting rule and approved a modified athletic scholarship plan which faculty representatives said would permit its members to emphasize to prospective athletes advantages of their schools.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 9 -- Governor Colgate Darden's call for a special session of the Virginia Legislature next week to set in motion machinery for amending the State Constitution so as to enfranchise the 230,000 Virginians in the service for the duration, includes no reference to poll-tax repeal.

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- With the announcement today that the Vatican had finally granted official recognition to the de Gaulle Government, it was confirmed in official quarters here that this recognition had been delayed by the refusal of the French Government to accept as Papal Nuncio Mgr. Valerio Valeri, who had represented the Pope at Vichy.

THE bird, however hard the frost may be, flies briskly to his customary roosting place, and, with beak tucked into his wing, falls asleep. He has no apprehensions; only the blood grows colder and colder, the pulse feebler as he sleeps, and at midnight, or in the early morning, he drops from his perch -- dead.

WITH AMERICAN NINTH ARMY in Europe, Dec. 9 (U.P.) -- Large-scale German violations of international law were reported recently along the American Ninth Army front and American troops have been alerted against the German misuse of United States uniforms, white flags and Red Cross emblems.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Sunday, Dec. 10 (AP) -- A communique:

AWINTER cutting garden, with flowers from December through March, is not as wild and fantastic a thing as it might seem. If several of the prerequisites are listed immediately it may become more credible.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 9 -- Sentiment is sharply divided in Louisiana on the question of draining thousands of acres of marshlands in the State.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 9 -- Lanky Johnny Revolta posted a magnificent 66, husky Staff Sgt. Dutch Harrison matched it today and the two veteran golfers went into the final round of the $10,000 Miami open tournament all square and with a two-stroke lead over their nearest pursuer.

TETERBORO, N.J., Dec. 9 -- Production of aircraft precision instruments and accessories at the Eclipse-Pioneer division of the Bendix Aviation Corporation here was halted at 7:30 A.M. today when more than 2,000 employes walked out in protest against a new company policy to reduce the maximum work week from sixty hours to fifty-five.

WITH AMERICAN THIRD ARMY in France, Dec. 9 -- Fort Driant, the most stubborn and certainly the most formidable of all Metz fortifications, has at last fallen and has given up its secrets. Except for the lack of supplies and food this fort probably could have defended itself indefinitely because it had its own shell-manufacturing factory within its walls.

As a further indication that wood furniture manufacturers can expect considerable competition from concerns utilizing other materials, the Aluminum Cooking Utensil Company, a subsidiary of the Aluminum Company of America, is planning to make a line of kitchen furniture as soon as manpower and materials are available, it was confirmed yesterday.

FOR years college girls have had a fashion law unto themselves, and for years newspapers and magazines have been publishing their pictures in their curious haberdashery. Recently views of the unphotogenic backs of two Wellesley students dressed in men's shirts and shabby dungarees made the nation's jaw drop and set tongues clucking round the country.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A $1,000,000,000 postwar flood control bill was approved by a conference committee today, accepting all projects added by the Senate to the House bill.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Sunday, Dec. 10 -- United States Seventh Division veterans of Attu and Kwajelein drove north three miles along the coast in western Leyte yesterday, tightening the trap on thousands of Japanese caught between this force and the Seventy-seventh Division, which landed on the coast Thursday.

NORMALLY the ebb and flow of movie personalities out of and into New York is almost as regular as the tides down in the bay. But last week a tidal wave of visitors swept the town, swamping press agents and interviewers and leaving Broadway knee-deep in reclame.

A "sizable demand for the modernization of practice" and a redefinition of the bar's attitude toward professional advertising were disclosed in answers to a questionnaire prepared by William M. Wherry, as chairman of the Committee on Professional Ethics of the New York State Bar Association, it was said yesterday.

Americans must be as willing as the people of Great Britain to "pay the full price for peace," Dr. Lena Madesin Phillips, president of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women, told fifty members and guests of the Goucher College Club of New York at its second quadrennial meeting this season yesterday in the Biltmore Hotel.
CHICAGO. "THE VOICE OF THE TURTLE" has been received cooingly in this middle land.

THE authors and producers of melodrama are born only to suffer. Theirs is the thin, sharp end of the lash and the thick, heavy end of the club. Whatever they do is wrong, and the world forever is at them because of it.

While Northern sportsmen no longer can go afield with their dogs for a day's shooting and during the months immediately ahead must be content to recount past pleasures and adventures before the open fire, sport goes on in the southland and some of the most important fixtures of the field trial year are not far distant.

THE Radio City Music Hall merrily continues to set records and its management is facing with no visible qualms the arrival of its thirteenth year come Dec. 27. Since the year now closing saw all sorts of marks topple, a brief glimpse at them would, perhaps, be in order.

MADRID, Spain, Dec. 9 -- Spain, to many of her closest and most competent observers, has just about reached the crossroads of international commerce. A year or possibly less, they agree, will chart her future for many years in world trade and the resulting graph undoubtedly will have an all-important bearing on her internal political, as well as her external commercial, structure.

Geographical problems confronting automobile manufacturers are revealed in some of the replies to queries on car bodies presented by THE NEW YORK TIMES at the request of the Society of Automotive Engineers. Among the letters received yesterday there were two that emphasized the scope of consideration to be exercised in vehicular construction. One came from Florida, the other from Minnesota.

GREENSBORO, N.C., Dec. 9 -- The Southern Conference, void of all eligibility rules since August, 1943, will return to its strict regulations governing athletes gradually, and the first step will go into effect with the 1945-46 school year, next football season.
I welcomed in THE TIMES Magazine the pictures of a Spanish bullfight. They give me courage to think that the expression of a long-held conviction might be pertinent.
The International Free World Association, 724 Fifth Avenue, of whose executive committee Count Carlo Sforza is a member, deplored yesterday Prime Minister Churchill's attack on Count Sforza.

At least 60 per cent of the estimated $500,000,000 of financing that will be required by domestic airlines in the first stage of their contemplated post-war expansion can be provided in the form of medium-term serial loans by banks and insurance companies, it appears from preliminary data gathered in a thorough study of the field by four financial institutions.

NO matter how old she is -- 'teen-ager or a grandmother -- there are bound to be gifts at the cosmetic counter to delight her this Christmas, for those little extra luxuries she would never dream of buying for herself will, nevertheless, give her pleasure to own.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Dec. 9 -- A United States Third Army Division broke through the Maginot Line today and joined another division east of the Saar River for a concerted drive from the south on the industrial Saar basin -- already invaded and hotly beset from the west.

ARTURO TOSCANINI will conduct the final Philadelphia Orchestra Pension Fund concert of the season early in the spring. Date and program will be announced later. The series opens Dec. 22 at the Academy of Music with a program by the Philadelphia Orchestra, under Eugene Ormandy, assisted by Yehudi Menuhin, violin, as soloist.

THE first winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature since 1939, Johannes V. Jensen a Dane, is not very well known in this country, partly because of few and humdrum translations and partly because he fits into no easily advertised category.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 9 -- A seven-point physical fitness program was recommended to the National A.A.U. today by a committee headed by Avery Brundage of Chicago, after the delegates had voted approval of thirty-seven national records and rejected twelve others.

The Congress has unmistakably spoken again in favor of freezing the Social Security tax rate. If the President exercises his prerogative and vetoes the freezing bill, and if the Congress should fail to pass it over his veto, the payroll deduction for account of Social Security will have been doubled but the employer's share, in effect, will have been increased only slightly.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Prompt selection of a successor to Judge Kenesaw M. Landis as baseball high commissioner is necessary to prevent deterioration of the sport, believes Clark Griffith.

DOMINICAN REPUBLIC will celebrate on Jan. 6 the centenary of the signing of the first Constitution, and Albert F. Kunze, chief of the philatelic section of the Pan American Union, is advised that one-half centavo, 1c, 2c, 3c and 10c commemorative stamps will be issued.

WITH the sessions of the National Association of Manufacturers serving as a sounding board here last week, the Army emphasized and dramatized its urgent call for making up the shortages which have developed in war production.

Regina Resnik, the young soprano who made a short-notice debut as Leonore in "Il Trovatore" at the Metropolitan Opera last week, sang the role of Santuzza in "Cavalleria Rusticana" last night, when the Mascagni opera was presented with Leoncavallo's "Pagliacci."

" Transatlantic rockets are unlikely in this war, but rocket planes making flights from London to Paris will materialize in the not-too-distant future," reports Alfred Africano, former president of the American Rocket Society, to the Metropolitan Section of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.

In as game an exhibition as the squash courts have known in a long time, Andrew C. Ingraham of the Harvard Club and Providence, stayed in the fight after receiving a cut under the right eye and went on to a five-game victory over H. Williamson Pell of the Princeton Club yesterday at the Yale Club.

Following close upon the recent survey to determine just what means of transportation and what localities would be visited by the American post-war traveler; the Shipbuilders Council of America yesterday launched a new survey that is aimed at ascertaining what type of ship is desired by the more than 80 per cent of those queried who specified steamship travel as a definite post-war preference.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 9 -- Riding home on the strength of a sensationally low first nine and a piece of luck on the home stretch, Harold McSpaden, Philadelphia, grabbed undisputed lead of the 72-hole Oakland open golf tournament today when he posted a three-round total of 207.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A plea to the American public to save every piece of Christmas wrapping for salvage was made today by J.A. Krug, chairman of the WPB.

THERE are more than 500 conflict gangs of boys in New York City, boys banded together to fight other gangs. Every day somewhere in the city there are street battles between them. Often boys are stabbed, occasionally shot, sometimes killed.

ALL autobiographies, as this department has observed before, are to some extent misleading, since it seems to be impossible for any person, however candidly inclined, to give a completely truthful picture of himself. It is an inability that fixes itself upon saints and sinners alike.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Secretary Stimson said today that "no country need ever fear a United States Army of occupation -- our boys want to get home."

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 -- The start of a sixty-day drive to channel workers into high priority war plants on the West Coast and the temporary stoppage of all industrial reconversion moves in eleven Coast labor-shortage areas caused Washington, Oregon and California to take inventory of their position this week, three years after the Pearl Harbor attack.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 9 -- The Apheim Stable's Okapi Lancer won the featured sixth race, named the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Purse, at Gulfstream Park today. Romulus, racing for Mrs. Lottie Wolf of Detroit, leading owner of the meeting, was second and W.A. Coleman's Toolmaker third.

SURELY it was Grandmother's sky bed, brought down from the attic for a Christmas gift to the twins, Sigrid and Gerda, which gave them the dream of the trolls, on the longest night of the year. It was a dream which gave new meaning to the Norwegian Christmas pictured here with all its breathless preparation and activity.

Two Californians, Welker Cochran and Jay N. Bozeman, yesterday went into a deadlock for first place in the world championship three-cushion billiard tournament at the Capitol Hotel, each scoring has sixth straight triumph, with no losses.

THE 1944 edition of the Landmans catalogue of the postage stamps of Europe reached New York from Milan, Italy, last week, and a perusal of its pages discloses that approximately 200 postal items were issued in 1943 of which American collectors have had no inkling.

ATHENS, Dec. 9 -- A general of the Elas forces, whose conflict with the Greek Government and British troops turned Athens into a civil war battleground, was reported to have surrendered tonight. Liberals who have been acting as mediators indicated that peace might be restored to the capital by tomorrow or Monday.

Declaring that "military unpreparedness invites war -- reasonable military readiness renders attack unlikely," members of the Citizens Committee for Universal Military Training announced yesterday the formal opening of a nation-wide campaign in support of "a continuous year" of military training for high school graduates 18 years old.

The hoary notion somehow persists that a great city like this one is a heartless place where neighborliness is lacking and people are indifferent to misfortune and misery. That notion is continually exposed as a fallacy. New York is warmhearted and quick to pity.

FOR the last three and a half years Alfred Gruenwald, who used to think up books for musicals by such luminaries as Franz Lehar, has been inspecting us, as well as the town. Having completed this private sightseeing excursion. Mr. Gruenwald confesses he has an idea of just what we folks like in the way of musicals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Alaska is reported by Territorial officials just arrived here as being alarmed over policies of the Department of Interior which they say have "stirred up the racial issue" in the Territory and created disagreement within the department.

IF the sofa needs a new slipcover if the walls haven't been painted for two years, if the lamp-shades are shabby and you have heard the same answer -- "unavailable," "no more orders," "delivery in ten months" -- so many times you have given up hope, you might start thinking about pictures.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Although nothing has been said officially about the German rocket offensive against Britain since Prime Minister Churchill made his recent announcement in the House of Commons, newspapers here continue to print stories and pictures of recent "V-bomb" incidents.

PITTSBURGH, Calif., Dec. 9 -- Thirty-five hundred workers employed at the Columbia Steel Company's plant here stayed away from their jobs today in sympathy with a handful of riggers who quit yesterday in protest against new Sunday work orders.

Reading the article "The Navy Laughs While It Works" in the Magazine Section of THE TIMES reminded me of my own office. It's not the Navy, to be sure, it's part of Army Air Forces; but it's like any typical government office today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The White House statement on the manpower situation today was as follows:...
ROME, Dec. 9 -- Pope Pius ended the week of special services to combat the "moral ruination" of the Vicarate of Rome with a short address today.

THE American Youth Orchestra, a brand new musical organization, will make its debut at Carnegie Hall Saturday evening, under the watchful eye of its founder and director, the talented young American conductor Dean Dixon.

BALLET INTERNATIONAL will present the world premiere of Salvador Dali's "Mad Tristan," with choreography by Leonide Massine, on Friday night at the International Theatre. It is subtitled "the first paranoiac ballet," a claim which might be a little difficult to substantiate.

TORONTO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Bruins tightened their hold on fourth place in the National Hockey League standings tonight by defeating Toronto, 5 to 3, before 12,490 fans. It was the third victory for the Bruins over the Leafs in four starts this season.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, Ninth Air Force in France, Dec. 9 -- P-47 Thunderbolts of the Nineteenth Tactical Air Command of the United States Ninth Air Force dropped containers of blood plasma and medical supplies to advance units of the ground forces of the American Third Army today. The supplies were carried in belly tanks.

DESPITE the tremendous and enduring importance of Roman civilization for our own, the educated public of recent years has been prone to lose sight of this heritage and to spurn knowledge of the Romans as "ancient history" which can be of no "use" to our day and age.

AS the Yuletide jingles its bells the tardy shopper gives a despairing glance at a long list of presents and makes for the nearest department store. Time was when a week-end cruise made a highly prized gift for a favorite niece or nephew.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Management and labor in the tire industry today joined in an all-out effort to provide 472,000 extra tires which the armed services will require through the first quarter of 1945.

THIS is a story about the age of the Immortals -- the men who have won the Congressional Medal of Honor in this war. It is gleaned from the Army and Navy citations of the 120 Congressional Medalists whose records had been published up to the time this was set down.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Convincing evidence appeared this week that Central Westerners are devoting considerable public discussion to proposals for peacetime conscription, the Dumbarton Oaks program for maintaining world peace and other post-war plans.

JUST one thing kept Andy Ripple from going home openly to the inlet and blowing wide open the report of his death twenty years before. Andy knew that his father, Big-Footed Ed, would be pretty mad at the way it would make him look, after he'd invested all that money in a handsome tombstone.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 -- A nitroglycerin line exploded today on the Hercules Power Company's reservation near Pinole, twenty-five miles northeast of this city, killing two persons, injuring at least thirty, wrecking two buildings and shattering windows in towns near by.

DANNY KAYE has completed the cast of his new comedy show which is scheduled to make its debut at 8 P.M. Saturday, Jan. 6, over WABC and the Columbia Broadcasting System. It will take over the spot now filled by Kenny Baker.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Attorney General Francis Biddle, testifying before a hearing of the Senate Immigration Committee today, asserted that Norman N. Littell, his assistant who was removed by Presidential order last month, had been dismissed for no other reason than personal disloyalty to his chief "in circulating vicious stories about me for months."

Dartmouth College will observe its 175th anniversary on Wednesday. On Dec. 13, 1769, King George III, through Gov. John Wentworth of the Province of New Hampshire, granted the royal charter which has governed Dartmouth ever since. If the college were following peacetime procedure, this would undoubtedly be an occasion for formal celebration.

An epidemic of afternoon apartment house robberies in Astoria, Queens, over a three-month period apparently was solved yesterday with the arrest of two men who the police say confessed to having committed twenty burglaries. Their loot was estimated at $15,000 in jewelry.
ATHENS, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A communique:

You may be wondering what one man can do to help win a war. We refer you to the late Pvt. John W. Dutko of Homer City, Pa. German guns had his battalion pinned down in a trench on the road to Rome. Armed with an automatic rifle and hand gre nades, he advanced toward an 88-mm. cannon and three machine-gun nests.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The National Conference on the Problems of Medical Care wound up its sessions today with discussions stressing the need for improving the quality of medical care and for the creation of more favorable facilities for medical research that would encourage individuals gifted with originality and imagination to enter the field.

From reading how an optical application of radar enables a bombardier to see his target through clouds, we drift on to thinking of people we know who seem to have radar-equipped minds. You can't tell them or sell them anything phony.

The American Third Army, striking multiple blows into Germany's strategic Saar Valley, was the focus of attention last week in the hard-fought battle of the Reich frontier. For the second time in the great Allied offensive from the west, General Patton's forces were in motion while other Allied armies held the Wehrmacht's largest concentration in a bitter battle of position.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Thomas Gardner ("Tommy-the-Cork") Corcoran came back to the news again this week in the same role of alleged lobbyist in which he was cast when he voluntarily appeared as a witness before the Senate Defense Investigating Committee in 1941. Even the same case was involved.

A LITTLE while back this sector was telling of an unread manuscript, by Antoine de Saint Exupery, which Reynal Hitchcock has under lock and key. Now Doubleday, Doran reports that it, too, is standing guard over a secret -- well, reasonably secret -- MS.

The New York Rangers will tackle the Chicago Black Hawks in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. Although the local skaters disappointed their followers in their last game at home, when they dropped a 3-to-2 verdict to the Detroit Red Wings, Frank Boucher's athletes are confident that they will make a better showing when they cross sticks with the Chicago outfit.

MR. ANDERSON has written a long book, not so much about Notre Dame Cathedral as a hymn to it. He has been a voluminous writer in the past, a regular contributor to the popular periodicals, something which may have been of advantage in composing this wordy, detailed, eloquent and interesting book.

AT last the gardener who has had winter covering of plants on his mind can get to work. This is a job which many of us are impatient to do as soon as we see leaves blackening or withering under the first light frosts.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 9 (AP) -- New York's "model Legislature" went on record today in favor of establishing a State Health Department Research Institute to study the cause of poliomyelitis and other virus diseases.

Post-war plans for colleges and universities in Ohio are being formulated by the Ohio College Association through the elaborate study being made by the War Service and Post-War Adjustment Committee as brought out in the recent State-wide planning conference for delegates and college presidents at Columbus.

A three-in-one celebration was held at the home of Mr. and Mrs. George Borger of 4221 Snyder Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday as the golden wedding of Mr. and Mrs. Ivan Steenberg, parents of Mrs. George Borger, was celebrated with the silver anniversaries of their two daughters, Mrs. Ebba Borger and Mrs. Elly Borger.

THE need for private social work is just as vital in wartime as in peacetime. Working in close cooperation with the public welfare agencies, the voluntary organizations play a major role in keeping the home front strong.

ROME, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Count Sforza declared in a statement today that he had abandoned a pledge given to the United States State Department to support Marshal Badoglio because the former Premier had been unable "to revive a military spirit" and because under his regime a new form of fascism has been created in Italy.

ROME, Dec. 9 -- Premier Ivanoe Bonomi presented his new list of Ministers -- divided into four posts for each of the four parties in his Government, plus himself as an independent and one technician -- to the Allied Commission this afternoon.
The letter of Joseph E. Ridder upon the necessity for international law and judicial interpretation lifts the debate upon world peace above power politics with clarity for which I am grateful.

ATHENS, Dee. 9 -- On almost every housetop in Athens, day or night, a man or woman waits, ready with pistol, rifle or even tommy-gun, to wreak vengeance on passers-by in the street below. Policemen and regular soldiers naturally are game for any sympathizers of the Elas [fighting arm of the Eam, or National Liberation Front], while for the police anyone suspected of Elas sympathies becomes an immediate target.

ON three successive days death strikes three members of the Forrester families at a small settlement in New Guinea. Two of the deaths are declared by the only doctor present to be from natural causes, and the other might well be accidental, but coming as they do after threats have been made against the Forresters it is more likely that a human agency is responsible.

New high sales records for Christmas trade were hung up last week by a number of department stores here. Macy's had volume in excess of $1,000,000 on Thursday, a peak for a day without strong promotional pressure. The increase for the week was estimated as running 15 to 20 per cent, or possibly more, ever the like week of 1943.

PROBABLY the most difficult non-combatant job in a combat area is that of a chaplain, who is called, variously, "the padre," "the sky pilot" and, by the less reverent, the "Holy Joe." If he is a sincere and reverent man he takes to the battlefields of blood and hate a compassion and gentleness of spirit that serves as a bridge for the fighting man from days of war to days of peace at home.

A NARROW wedge of harsh, white light sliced into the solid midnight blackness and spotlighted a rutted muddy road as the door of a small stone house opened and a man stepped into the night. The light disappeared suddenly and all at once as the man quickly slammed the door behind him.

Amaryllis may be planted in pots from November to March for indoor bloom. The same bulbs may be grown year after year, repaying minimum care with large, bright blossoms. Flowers, as many as four or six on one stem, will open in a window without any sunshine.

" WARSAW, Poland, Sept. 1. 1939 -- Hitler's Luftwaffe is giving Warsaw the first bombing of the war. I am standing on a balcony of the Globe office, here in the heart of Warsaw, watching them come in. I can see them now.

How are we to explain the striking contrast between the attitude of this country toward Britain compared with that which it takes toward Russia? To appreciate the significance of this contrast, as it must appear to Englishmen, certain facts are to be kept in mind, not as the basis of censure to our Russian ally but as the ground for at least equal indulgence to the British ally.
The Statue of Liberty will be relighted in a new radiance as a victory signal when Germany or Japan surrenders, George A. Palmer, superintendent of the monument, announced yesterday.

Several debutantes of the new season were formally introduced to society last night at the annual Grosvenor Debutante Ball in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton. The young women making their debuts were guests of honor at dinners given in the Oval Room of the suite before the ball.

LITTLE children hum and make up chants as they play; they tap blocks together, trail toys along radiators, and in dozens of ways express the rhythm they love and that is natural to them. All children have music in them. But we can take it out of them, and we very often do.

Headquarters of the Yokosuka Naval Station largest Japanese home base, announced yesterday that thirteen Japanese admirals had died in unspecified South Pacific actions, thus bringing to sixty-seven the number of flag officers of Japan's Navy listed as dead or killed in action in Tokyo announcements since May 7.

Standardization on a nation-wide scale of bedding production is being sought through two channels, one of which calls for voluntary acceptance of a single set of standards and the other for passage of a Federal law applicable to the manufacture and sale of this product, it was learned last week.
ROME, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A pincers was steadily being tightened about the northern Italian highway coastal point of Faenza today by British Eighth Army forces in bitter fighting.
A CORRESPONDENT asks the proper card to lead against a five-diamond contract when he holds K-10-6-4 in the suit his partner has bid.

In his speech of Nov. 29 opening the new session of Parliament Prime Minister Churchill said that as glowing war headline succeeded glowing headline, all of them perfectly true, "the end seems to recede before us." He was speaking particularly of the war in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The first American Liberty ship to unload its essential war materials following our invasion of the Philippines succeeded in discharging its cargo despite at least fifty-six bombings and strafings while its crew of merchant seamen and Navy gunners was shooting down two Japanese planes and possibly four others, the War Shipping Administration disclosed today.

Charges that "co-ops" are benefiting unfairly from tax privileges or through cheap Government credit were labeled a "smoke screen" hiding efforts to destroy the "co-ops" through restrictive legislation. Wallace J. Campbell, assistant secretary of the Cooperative League of the United States of America, said yesterday in an interview here.

A CHILDHOOD in Trinidad, school days in England, a holiday in ancestral Scotland, all these were a part of Janet Laidlaw's growing up. So was the silver pencil, Father's understanding gift to a little girl who devoured books and wrote bad poetry.

After protracted interference proceedings in the Patent Office to determine priority of invention -- proceedings in which there were several contenders -- patents have been issued to Harry W. Thomas and William Dubilier for a nylon window screen which may well displace screens of metal wire after the war.

Cautious retail buying plans for spring have been knocked into the proverbial "cocked hat" because of the chaotic conditions in the primary and secondary markets, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

" THERE'S more of a story than you would think in a glass of milk for Jack to drink," says Mr. Scott, having triumphantly proved it in this adaptation of one of the most fundamental of Mother Goose's rhymes.

PARIS, Dec. 9. -- Dr. Dominico Russo, president of the Italian Committee of Liberation here, will go to Rome in a few days, and may return with at least a basis for formal discussions between France and Italy, which technically are still at war.

Fritz Kreisler's violin recital to be given the night of Dec. 19 in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton as "a Christmas gift to the French children" has received such a large advance subscription that already a fund of $10,000 has been sent to the American Friends Service Committee for the purchase of urgently needed food and supplies to aid the youngsters in war-ravaged France.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Dec. 9 -- Williams vanquished the Columbia five by 32 to 24 tonight, coming from behind late in the game to triumph. The visitors led, 12 -- 11, after a closely fought first half and maintained a slight advantage for a time in the last period.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The American Federation of Labor members of the National War Labor Board said today that the board's approval in principle of dismissal pay in the steel case meant that "all other workers will be able to insulate themselves partially against the shocks of reconversion.

MULHOUSE, France, Dec. 9 -- For eighteen days, since the French First Army burst through the Belfort Gap to free Mulhouse, the people of southern Alsace have lived the mingled joy and pain of suddenly becoming French again.

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- Paradoxically, although France cannot in any way yet be considered to have been re-established as one of Europe's great powers, her future favors and potential position are already important factors in the continental diplomatic scene.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- There are a number of reasons why a majority of the Senate declined to confirm the new State Department appointees without open hearings and, by that action. required the Foreign Relations Committee to hold them.
ALBANY, Dec. 9 (. -- The cigarette shortage is hitting the State treasury from two sides.

AT A UNITED STATES OBSERVATION POST, in the Vosges Mountains, France, Dec. 9 (AP) -- In an 800-year-old Germanic castle a group of American artillery observers -- as cozy as eagles in their nest -- are getting revenge for what the Germans dished out to them at Anzio in Italy.

One of several men the police said they discovered robbing a dress shop in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn early yesterday morning was shot and another was seized by policemen responding to an alarm telephoned by neighbors.

" Veritable nation-wide hysteria" is attributed by Prof. John Haldi of Emory University to the false notion that every food must be loaded with vitamins to safeguard health. That vitamins are indispensable Professor Haldi concedes, but he insists that a properly balanced diet contains an adequate supply.

DETROIT, Dec. 9 -- Walter P. Reuther, vice president of the United Automobile Workers (CIO), told 150 delegates to a national UAW-CIO women's conference today that the answer to their postwar job problems lay not in special privileges but in creation of 60,000,000 peacetime jobs in America.

War restrictions on financial information are beginning to worry Wall Street. There is a feeling that, if the bans continue, investors will be operating in blindfolds during the period of cancellation of contracts which faces war industry.

A large subscription has been! reported for the performance of l I"The Seven Lively Arts" on the night of Dec. 21 at the ZiegfeldI Theatre, which has been taken over] to raise funds for the Riverdale] Children's Association. lIrs. Ed-i ward C. Delafieid heads the executive committee for the party, and Mrs. Robert De Vecchi is chairman of the program committee.

To stamp out "tie-in" sales that again have become a major problem for retailers in the current shortage of lettuce, Western carrots and lemons, an intensified drive is being made against produce wholesalers in Washington Market, Israel H. Mandel, acting chief deputy sheriff in charge of enforcement in the Sheriff's Office, disclosed yesterday.
THERE is a curious nostalgia about contemporary history. In its studied pages and researcher's footnotes we see the shadows of ourselves -- the dim remembrance of things gone.

Several times in the course of the last few days Ethelbert Smith has found himself confronted with the same unanswerable argument, the subject under consideration being the present state of unrest in the liberated countries of Europe.

In thirty States where an official or unofficial tally was made of votes cast by members of the military services, a total of 3,094,042 service ballots was received, according to a tabulation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES on the basis of reports from correspondents in State capitals.

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- Miguel Maura, a leader of the Spanish moderates who was Minister of the Interior in the first Republican Government in 1931, was on his way to Spain from Paris today, according to his associates here, in the hope of being able to establish a democratic regime at Madrid to replace the dictatorship of Gen. Francisco Franco.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration figures $60,000,000 as rock bottom for the probable annual cost of the wage awards recommended by the WLB for the CIO steel workers. Its top figure for the extra pay is $150,000,000.
A good demand for residential property on the East Side was indicated by transactions reported in the area over the weekend.

ROME, Dec. 10 -- In two months France has made giant strides toward recovery. The French story is always a story of improvement. Day by day there is a little more light, a slight extension of railway service, power for a few more factories, a trickle of food and goods from one town to the next.

Crowning his nine-day visit to Moscow with a success that must have met all his expectations, General de Gaulle has just signed a new pact of alliance and mutual assistance between France and Russia which represents a new personal triumph for himself and a new triumph for France.

For the first time the curtain has been lifted in part on the magnitude of the production program which revolves around the B-29 Superfortress and the position of vital priority which the Air Forces gives to it for the defeat of Japan. Before the plane ever took the air millions of dollars had been invested in it.

The William H. Nichols Medal of the New York Section of the American Chemical Society, one of the highest distinctions in chemistry, has been awarded to Prof. Vincent du Vigneaud, head of the Department of Biochemistry, Cornell University Medical College, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Rovert Calvert, chairman of the jury of award.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Domestic demand for lard continues active and all offerings by packers are taken readily. Brokers say the supply of lard is not large and that the bulk of business is being done first through packers' distributing agencies, leaving relatively little produce available for sale through brokers.

Two groups of songs by Darius Milhaud, the French composer, now living in the United States, were sung by Herta Glaz, Metropolitan Opera contralto, in her recital at Town Hall last night. Mr. Milhaud's songs are heard all too seldom here.

The northwest corner of 164th Street and College Avenue, in the Bronx, consisting of a vacant plot fronting 200 feet on the avenue and eighty feet on the street, has been sold by the United States Trust Company to the Levrich Realty Corporation, Max Levey, president.

One of the oldest governing bodies in sports, the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association, brought its sixty-second annual meeting to an end on a note of optimism yesterday at the Hotel Edison.

An AP dispatch in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 3 stated that the Hood River (Ore.) Post of the American Legion had erased the names of sixteen Americans of Japanese ancestry from the county war memorial. The secretarial council of the Foreign Missions Conference of North America has requested that I convey to you its feeling that this action is both un-Christian and un-American.

In a sermon yesterday in the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue, the Rev. Dr. Frederick May Eliot of Boston, president of the American Unitarian Association, deplored the recent refusal of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America to admit the Universalist Church to membership.

A conference on post-war problems of American women in business and industry will be held in the Hotel Pennsylvania on Friday, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Thomas G. Evans, president of the local branch of the American Association of University Women and chairman of the conference committee.

DETROIT, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Red Wings, with their Bruneteau brothers, Modere and Eddie, accounting for four goals, defeated the Boston Bruins tonight for the fourth time this season, 7 to 6, in a National Hockey League game before a crowd of 12,929.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Reorganization of the Republican party machinery on a four-year basis with a full-time director is advocated by party leaders in the Senate.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Floyd W. Reeves, Professor of Education at the University of Chicago, believes that the Veterans Administration and other Washington agencies have underestimated greatly the educational ambitions of men in the armed services.

OUTSIDE NIEDERBRONN, Germany, Dec. 10 (U.P.) -- A battery of 155-mm. American howitzers had a busy time this afternoon sniping at individual Germans from a four-to-six-mile range with the help of a captured German telescope that magnified the target seventy-two times.
PARIS, Dec. 10 (U.P.) -- Informed French sources believed tonight that General de Gaulle's next immediate objective would be an early meeting with President Roosevelt.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Harold Macmillan, Resident Minister at Allied Headquarters in the central Mediterranean, has returned to his post after a visit to London. He is expected to appear soon in Athens in the role of peacemaker.

The Mesivta and Yeshiva Rabbi Chaim Berlin, a seven-story building renovated at a cost of $1,000,000 and housing two synagogues, a Jewish religious school, regular high school and dormitories, was dedicated yesterday at Stone and Pitkin Avenues, Brooklyn.

The Bible stands pre-eminent among all the books that illuminate life, giving new vision both of its darker depths and of its splendors, the Very Rev. Hughell E.W. Fosbroke, dean of the General Episcopal Theological Seminary, declared yesterday in a sermon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Dec. 10 -- A goal of 2,000,000 members for the Girl Scout movement during the coming year was announced here tonight by Mrs. Paul Rittenhouse of New York, national director, at the opening of the national staff conference of the organization in the Hotel Chelsea.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The massive strength of undefeated Randolph Field overpowered the aerial trickery of the Fourth Air Force of March Field today, giving the Ramblers a 20-7 victory.

As the local art season points toward the holidays, several outstanding events are on the calendar. The Whitney Museum's annual exhibition of contemporary American painting, which was to close Wednesday, has been extended for two weeks, through Dec. 27.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Willard N. Greim, head of Denver's school and municipal physical education and recreation facilities, was elected president of the national A.A.U. today and immediately promised the organization would work with kindred groups to Improve the country's well-being.
John A. Zellers, vice president of Remington Rand, has been elected chairman of the international trade section of the New York Board of Trade, 291 Broadway, it was announced yesterday.
A communique, as broadcast domestically from Tokyo yesterday and recorded and translated by the Federal Communications Commission:

Morton G. Bogue, New York lawyer and member of the Deepdale Club, Great Neck, L.I., has been renominated for the presidency of the United States Golf Association, it was announced yesterday. In addition to Bogue, former Columbia coxswain, all of the past year's officers are slated to be re-elected at the annual meeting to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Saturday, Jan. 13, at 11 A.M.

ROME, Dec. 10 -- For the second time in his Pontificate, Pope Pius XII walked down the central aisle of St. Peter's today without a tiara or other sign of papal rank. He walked alone at the end of a long procession of Cardinals, canons and other Church dignitaries, holding aloft a large black crucifix.

An auto-stealing escapade that began in Washington more than a week ago ended just before midnight Saturday at the Manhattan entrance of the Holland Tunnel when Harvey N. Byrd, 21-year-old Washingtonian, was arrested by New York police as a fugitive from justice, with the possibility that he will be prosecuted on seven or more charges by New Jersey and District of Columbia authorities and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 -- Their Eastern championship hopes shattered by periodical reports from Washington, the Philadelphia Eagles had little incentive against the Clevelond Rams in the season's finale at Shibe Park today. There never was a doubt concerning the outcome, though, and the Eagles, despite the fact that three touchdown runs and a safety were recalled, conquered Buff Donelli's outfit, 26 -- 13.

MULHOUSE, France, Dec. 10 -- German and French shells still whine over Mulhouse, but its 100,000 inhabitants have come up out of the cellars, one by one, during the past twenty days and have gone back to work, and even play.

Not all of us have kinfolk in the war. Some of us saw the draft lines of other people's sons and brothers, and then the men were gone; and since their training areas were far away in Southern swamps and Western deserts, their battlefields beyond wide oceans even more remote, the natural law of "out of sight, out of mind" operated for a while to keep us from taking the war as a serious reality.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Kweichow railroad town of Hsiassu, twelve miles from the Kwangsi Province border, has been recaptured by the Chinese in their counter-offensive, which virtually has cleared Kweichow Province of the invaders, the Chinese High Command announced today.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Recording of two earthquakes stronger than the shocks in the near-by Long Beach area in 1933 "but not as strong as the recent Japanese quake," was announced today by Dr. Beno Gutenberg, seismologist at the California Institute of Technology.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Buying of around 2,500,000 bushels of cash sworn last week by the Government for lend-lease shipment to England resulted in that market developing a very firm undertone with prices advancing around 4 cents over the close of the previous week at one time and went to a new high in over a month.

LONDON, Dec. 10 (Netherlands News Agency) -- Children in the liberated areas of the Netherlands are dying for the lack of proper food, Dr. H.P.J. Damen, Netherland children's specialist said at Eindhoven today.

OUTSIDE JUELICH, in Germany, Dec. 9 (Delayed) (UP) -- For eighteen days one full division of American infantry -- the crack Twenty-ninth -- had been fighting with dogged fury to set the stage for this attack.

Leather and shoes are among the products which the armed forces will require at undiminished or increased rates until V-E day, spokesmen for the related industries declared, indicating there is little hope that civilian goods production will increase until at least after V-E day.

The Japanese radio reported that "small formations" of B-29's had appeared over Tokyo for the second time last night and this morning (Japanese time), "dropping some bombs" that started fires in the city.

Continued and increased help by our Government for Italy is necessary "unless the American people wish Italy to be in a state of anarchy by February," Justice Juvenal Marchisio, president of American Relief for Italy, declared yesterday at a breakfast in the New York Athletic Club, Fifty-ninth Street and Seventh Avenue, after the sixth annual communion mass of the Notre Dame Club of New York in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday a net income of $6,004,909 for the first ten months of 1944, comparing with $5,696,248 in the like period of 1943, with October profit $582,942 against $405,034 a year ago.

The fourth week of the Metropolitan Opera Company's present season, beginning next Monday, will be featured by the revival of "Lohengrin" after a year's absence. The Wagner music drama will be presented on Wednesday night, Dec. 20.
ATHENS, Dec. 10 -- Elas forces fired shells into Omonia Square, a residential district, as the Greek civil war continued today. Damage and casualties have not yet been assessed.

Women who are worn out after a long stretch of ironing are probably using ironing boards that are too low, according to a study by Elaine Knowles of the New York State College of Home Economics at Cornell University. Results of this study, which is part of a general inquiry into the reasons for fatigue in household tasks, will be the subject of a forthcoming Cornell Bulletin for Homemakers.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 10 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

WITH AMERICAN THIRD ARMY, in Germany, Dec. 10 -- There was one part of Sarreguemines today that sounded and looked like a Coney Island shooting gallery. The proverbial bull in the china shop was a well-mannered lamb compared with the GI's and two companies of Germans battling for the possession of a ceramic plant.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- The Franco-Russian alliance announced tonight in Moscow was warmly welcomed by the British Government. Since this country has a twenty-year treaty of alliance with the Soviet Union, the new pact was seen as the renewal of the historic triangle against Germany, with only the formalities of an entente cordiale remaining to make it complete.

Although it was the expressed wish of the late Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis that there be no memorials in his honor, baseball is determined to pay at least one lasting tribute to the man who ruled the game for nearly a quarter of a century.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- James F. Byrnes, by the "produce or fight" edict of yesterday, in which he called for new drafting of men in the age bracket 26 through 37, has signalized his assumption of full policy control in the home-front war effort.
LONDON, Dec. 10 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- President Roosevelt is willing to name a new Secretary of Labor to replace Frances Perkins if the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations can agree upon a candidate for the post, it was learned today. Miss Perkins, it is reported, is not anxious to continue in office.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The little-man-who-wasn't-there played a mighty important part in the crushing defeat the New York Giants inflicted on the Washington Redskins before the usual packed house in Griffith Stadium today. Sammy Baugh twice fed the ball to the little man and the little man wasn't there. Two phantom handouts to phantom backs were officially registered as fumbles.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- Nine protests, seven in the fifth race, marked the most active day of winter dinghy sailing at the Larchmont Yacht Club in three years as seventeen of the small craft, all but five of the entire fleet, competed in six races in a varying wind this afternoon.
The Association of Pulp Consumers, Inc., has contributed $10,000 to the War Activities Committee's campaign to stimulate production of pulpwood.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Monday, Dec. 11 -- In a fast one-day drive downhill from Camp Downes, high on a plateau just south of Ormoc on the west coast of Leyte, the Seventy-seventh Division attained its immediate objective yesterday by capturing the town, four days after the latest Philippine landing.

Tonight's premiere is "Dark Hammock" at the Forrest. It represents the second play by Mary Orr (actress) and Reginald Denham (director) to reach Broadway. The other one was "Wallflower," a comedy seen here last season. Totally unlike their previous collaboration.

Christmas gift shopping orders from service men have tripled this season, swamping voluntary organizations and department stores, it was disclosed yesterday. At the Navy League, 8 East Sixty-first Street, Mrs. J. Truman Bidwell, who heads its Service Men's Service shopping bureau, said daily orders ranged from 700 to 900, with many arriving from men stationed in Germany.

LONDON, Dec. 10 (U.P.) -- Vernon Bartlett, Independent Progressive member of Parliament, who has just returned from Spain, said today that, while General Francisco Franco was intensely unpopular, a change of regime at Madrid in the near future was likely only if done bloodlessly.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Monday, Dec. 11 (UP) -- A communique:

An investor bought the four-story apartment house on a plot 50 by 125 feet at 102-34 Forty-second Avenue, near 104th Street, in Corona, Queens, from the Carillon Corporation and insured title with the Home Title Guaranty Company.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 10 -- Cotton futures worked modestly higher in a narrow range last week on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange as the industry awaited details of a program of purchasing of cotton for lend-lease and possible developments of importance at the Pace conference in Washington.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 8 (Delayed) -- Calling for fair play and denouncing the black market and speculators President Getulio Vargas has declared drastic measures await those who deplete the market of products or hide them to pocket large profits.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 10 -- Attention in the steel industry last week was centered on output of war items, mostly shell steel. No doubt was expressed in the trade that increased demand for munition steel would have the effect of sidetracking some tonnage which might have gone for civilian needs had the war in Europe taken a different turn last month.

Nikolai and Joanna Graudan, 'cellist and pianist, respectively, gave their season's first recital of duos at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. The large audience present heard a concert which was remarkable for its high standard of musicianship.

In adopting a substitute for the Anglo-American petroleum agreement the Petroleum Industry War Council called last week upon the Senate in a resolution not to ratify the agreement as submitted by President Roosevelt and at the same time set forth certain basic principles previously recommended in regard to a foreign oil policy for the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Off to a flying start when they counted twice in the first six minutes of today's crucial game, the Giants gained their seventh eastern championship, decisively trouncing the Redskins, 31 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- As the War Production Board reported that not one of the major munitions items met its schedule in October, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, made a radio appeal today to workers on the home front to keep war production the first order of business.

ROME, Dec. 10 (U.P.) -- British Eighth Army forces have advanced ten miles up the Adriatic coastal area north of Ravenna to Casal Borsetti and fanned out along the southern shore of the Valle di Commachio in contact with German forces, Allied headquarters disclosed today.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Although the Moscow press kept notably quiet, authoritative Soviet circles here indorsed last week's American criticism of British policy in Italy and the liberated Allied countries. At the same time the suspicion in some sections of the American and British press that the State Department's declaration was also intended to apply to Russia did not escape their notice.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 10 -- The disorganized distribution of foodstuffs and industrial raw materials throughout the Reich owing to recent Allied bombings was officially admitted by Berlin over the weekend in a series of posters now being placarded in principal sub-divisional centers.
It is a pity they have to make their first public appearance as numbered "cases." Actually they are all people, just as human as any of us, subject to the same wants and necessities as all of us.

PARIS, Dec. 10 -- Jean Angeli, regional prefect under Vichy, sentenced to death by the Lyon Court of Justice for treason and intelligence with the enemy, is to have a new trial. As announced this evening, his conviction was quashed by the Court of Appeals on technical grounds, but the decision went far beyond technicalities.
Allied troops of the "forgotten front" continued last week to inch ahead on the slow and difficult road into the Po Valley.

John Selby, author and critic, will join Farrar Rinehart on Jan. 2 as associate editor. His duties will include the handling of public relations. For the past twelve years, Mr. Selby has been arts editor of The Associated Press, for which he wrote "The Literary Guideposts," a daily column on books.

In a series of "million-share days," last week's advance in stocks exceeded July, which was not touched, by 'THE TIMES' compilation, since May 13, 1940. Presumably the inference drawn, in speculative quarters, was that a long war was ahead.

The All-America Football Conference granted a franchise to Miami, Fla., it was announced last night through The Associated Press as the Conference, which hopes to operate in 1945, closed a two-day meeting. Other cities are Los Angeles, San Francisco, Chicago, Cleveland, Buffalo, New York and Baltimore.

Welker Cochran, San Francisco, took undisputed possession of first place in the world championship three-cushion tournament at the Capitol Hotel as a result of last night's play, when he defeated Ralph Greenleaf, the many times pocket billiard champion, 50 -- 31, in thirty-six innings after Willie Hoppe had beaten Jay Bozeman to go into a tie for second place with the latter.

Thompson Products, Inc., and subsidiaries, makers of auto and engine parts, report a consolidated net income of $1,777,260 for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, equal after preferred dividend requirements to $5.37 a share on 299,737 common shares, comparing with $1,516,532, equal to $4.76 a share on 298,419 shares, in 1943.

Tendencies toward a lowered moral level in entertainment offered the armed forces make the pledge of the Legion of Decency more important this year than at any time since its origination, Mgr. Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared yesterday in leading the congregation of 3,000 at solemn mass in renewing the pledge to stay away from "indecent and immoral" motion pictures and theatrical productions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The purple-ink stamp marks indicating the grade of meat must be placed so that they appear every two inches along all primal cuts, the Office of Economic Stabilization announced today. The action was taken to protect the public against the upgrading of inferior quality meat by retailers.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Sgt. Jim Ferrier of Camp Roberts, Calif., put the United States Army on the golfing map today when he charged home with a final round 68 to win the Oakland open with a 72-hole total of 277.
