An improved New York Ranger sextet managed to earn a tie with the Chicago Black Hawks in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. A second-period goal by Ab De Marco equalized a first-chapter accomplishment by Fido Purpur of the Hawks, and matters thus stood until the end.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 10 -- Ralph Hirschberg and Ambrose Casner of New York won the national contract bridge open pair championship tonight to wind up the week-long tournament of the American Contract Bridge League here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The War Labor Board moved today to give independent unions a greater part in its machinery.

A UNITED STATES EIGHTH AIR FORCE BOMBER STATION, in England, Dec. 10 (AP) -- His right arm nearly severed recently by flak over Germany, Lieut. Frederic T. Kiessel of Los Angeles, a Flying Fortress bombardier, regained consciousness in time to aim his bombs at the target.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- With the year-end approaching, the stock markets here are inactive. They are not, however, entirely without interest and the general character of the war news keeps sentiment firm despite the anxiety caused by the increasing political ferment in the liberated countries.

The concert of the New Friends of Music at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon was devoted to modern French songs by Debussy and Ravel, sung by Jennie Tourel, mezzo-soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company, and to the Mozart Clarinet Quintet in A major, K. 581, performed by the Gordon String Quartet and Ralph MacLean, clarinetist.

TWENTY-FIRST BOMBER COMMAND, Saipan, Marianas, Dec. 9 (Delayed) (AP) -- Tokyo is blacking out at night now. The Japanese capital was brightly lighted during the early B-29 attacks and the Japanese radio boasted that there was nothing to fear.

The Carnegie Corporation of New York has increased the endowment of the Carnegie Institution of Washington by a grant of $5,000,000, it was disclosed in the report of the corporation for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, made public yesterday.

ATLANTA, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Charlie Trippi, ex-Georgia Rose Bowl star, ran, punted and passed the Second Air Force Superbombers dizzy today, and his team, the Third Air Force Gremlins, came off with a well-earned 14-7 victory.

Service on two main Bronx subway divisions, the Seventh Avenue-Bronx Park line and the Lexington Avenue-White Plains line, was halted at the Manhattan Bronx boundary and also north of the Prospect Avenue station at 11:53 o'clock last night when one "lay-up" train crashed into another on the center track of a three-track division 200 feet north of that station.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Dec. 2 to 8 are given in the appended tabulation:
Although it may still come as a surprise to a few owners in the circuit, the National League, when it convenes at the Hotel New Yorker today, will face the important detail of electing a president.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- A new British Pacific Fleet, which according to some London newspapers is capable of challenging the entire surviving combined fleet of Japan, has been formed to operate in the Far East, the Admiralty announced tonight.
LONDON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Those who foment race or minority hatred of any sort are sponsors of efforts to replace democracy with fascism, Senator Elbert D. Thomas of Utah said last night at the sixteenth annual dinner of Yeshiva College in the Hotel Astor.

PARIS, Dec. 10 -- France's struggling mushroom press, with three times as many newspapers as in 1939 utilizing one-fifth of the paper allotment because of the strangled pulp industry and the lack of shipping space, faces complete strangulation within six weeks through lack of newsprint unless something is done to alleviate the situation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Dr. Gemma Barzilai, a major in the United States Public Health Service who has been lent to the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration for maternal and child health work in her native Italy, said today that she saw a great future for women in post-war democratic Italy because they were less smirched by fascism than the men.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Cash oats continue in active demand at substantial premiums over December and there have been no tenders on December contracts so far this month.

For the first week since Oct. 21, 1944, the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices (1926=100) has failed to rise. Although a relatively large number of individual price changes occurred the affects of price increases for grains and price decreases for livestock offset each other completely, so that the all commodity index remained unchanged at 114.07.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Alted Expeditionary Force, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Communique 246:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 10 (Reuter) -- Reports from Germany, quoted today by the Swedish newspaper Aftontidningen, said four British secret service members who parachuted into Germany and posed as foreign workers to obtain information about V-motors, deluded the Germans so successfully hat they received special privileges and were assigned to special Nazi propaganda duties.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 10 (Reuter) -- At St. Pierre Hospital here today, British, American and Canadian consultants and surgeons pooled their knowledge and experience for saving soldiers lives.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Dr. Ivan Subasitch, Premier of the Royal Yugoslav Government, returned to London today to report to King Peter, his Cabinet and British and American authorities on his negotiations in Italy, Yugoslavia and Moscow for the creation of a unified government to sit in liberated Belgrade.
This begins the last week of the Sixth War Loan drive. Thousands of New Yorkers have responded willingly to the appeal of their Government for funds to conduct the war.

Strong demands were in evidence last week for last-minute seasonal merchandise, with buyers of many lines arriving in unexpected numbers, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in Serbo-Groat by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

PARIS, Dec. 10 -- Official circles here tonight seemed positive that the treaty between Russia and France signed today in Moscow followed the lines of the mutual assistance pact made between Great Britain and Russia in 1942.

Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr. appealed yesterday to Americans to oversubscribe the $5,000,000,000 quota set for individuals in the Sixth War Loan drive, so as to provide the "overwhelming superiority of equipment which our forces must have to win victory."

An iron lung credited with saving at least one life was presented yesterday to the Jewish Memorial Hospital, Broadway and 196th Street, by Liberty Post, No. 22, of the American Legion. The gift was accepted on behalf of the institution by its president, Milton M. Goldsmith.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Removal of hedges against fair sales of flour to Govenment agencies and the domestic trade combined with reports ceiling prices on wheat would be advanced 4 cents a bushel within a few days sent May, July and September wheat into new seasonal ground last week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- No increase in the civilian gasoline rations would be possible as long as Germany remained in the war, the Petroleum Industry War Council was informed today by its Committee on Petroleum Economics.

King Gustaf V of Sweden and President Roosevelt joined yesterday in hailing the significance of the occasion as six residents of the United States -- five Americans and a Dane -- received Nobel Prize awards at a precedent-shattering ceremony in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, arranged by the American-Scandinavian Foundation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 10 -Willard Parker, who recently received a medical discharge from the Army, has been scheduled by Columbia for the name lead in "The Fighting Guardsman," an adaptation of the Alexandre Dumas story, "The Companions of Jehu," which will go into production tomorrow.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 10 -- A former Brussels newspaper reporter who heads the resistance movement in Belgium is challenging the leadership of Premier Hubert Pierlot on six main issues.

PARIS, Dec. 8 (Delayed) -- Paris stores were permitted to use electric light until 6:30 o'clock this evening instead of closing at dusk. Permission was granted because the Paris Chamber of Commerce had arranged with the merchants to invest all their revenue today in Liberation loan bonds. Most stores were thronged with people intent on making Christmas purchases early.
Yesterday's communique from the Mediterranean theatre, as reported to the Office of War Information:

MOSCOW, Dec. 10 -- France and the Soviet Union today signed a pact of alliance and mutual assistance that was hailed as a new and powerful blow against a common enemy and a safeguard against future aggression in Europe. The treaty, capping Gen. Charles de Gaulle's visit to the Soviet capital, was signed at 4:40 o'clock this morning, immediately after a gala banquet in the Kremlin given by Premier Stalin.
LONDON Dec. 10 (AP) -- Nearly 1,200 American warplanes saturated the congested rail yards of Coblenz and Bingen on the Rhine today with 1,500 tons of explosives.

Trading in the domestic cotton market was quiet last week with prices continuing to hold within a narrow range. At the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net changes for the week of an advance of 10 points to a decline of 11 points.
A city-wide meat holiday, which its planners hope will close 10,000 retail shops beginning on Christmas Day, was voted yesterday by 3,500 store owners.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The War Production Board has begun a series of conferences in an attempt to improve production of farm machinery which, chiefly because of manpower shortages and the present crisis in military production, is far behind schedule, it was announced today.

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 11 -- Russian tank forces broke through deep enemy fortifications north of Budapest yesterday in a seven-mile smash down the east bank of the Danube River to within seven and one-half miles of the city as two Soviet armies tightened their siege of the Hungarian capital.

In Scandinavian countries one of the traditional holiday foods, served either on Christmas Eve or on Christmas Day, is lutfisk. A sundried fish, it may be any one of several varieties, but that offered at Nyborg Nelson, 841 Third Avenue, is cod. This Swedish delicatessen has barrels of the lutfisk in readiness for New York's Scandinavian population, as well as for those Americans who have become devotees of the dish.

WITH THE AMERICAN FIRST ARMY, in Germany, Dec. 10 -- Troops of Lieut. Gen. Courtney H. Hodges' American First Army jumped off today in a coordinated attack on a ten-mile front across open country almost to the bank of the Roer River.
MOSCOW, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The text of the communique announcing the pact follows:

J.P. MORGAN the elder and the little boy across the street who collects match folders, the Borneo headhunter and Casanova, all belong in the same goodly company, the ancient and honorable brotherhood of collectors. The instinct to collect is as old as the human race and the variety of things collected is beyond computation. If one man collects amorous conquests and another twigs shaped like letters, they have something, at least, in common.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 10 -The formation of a Women's Army Auxiliary for the Wehrmacht, which may be designated as one of the last steps in the Reich's total war mobilization, is now nearing the final stage, according to German reports today.
The decision of the War Labor Board on the wage dispute under the Little Steel formula created a brief stir, but its effects have not been explored.

GUAM, Monday, Dec. 11 -- Today, four months exactly since Guam was declared secured by American forces, this island is taking shape as the new United States headquarters for future offensive moves against Japan.

For a metropolis with a population of 7,500,000, statistics sometimes conceal as much as they reveal. We have figures enough of all kinds for the city as a whole, but not enough for specific districts. Statistics good for one district are not necessarily applicable to another a mile away.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Staff Sgt. Dutch Harrison of Wright Field, Ohio, survived a brilliant stretch battle today to win $2,500 first money in the Miami open golf tournament over five other players who had a chance to snare victory on the final nine holes.

Jacqueline Cochran, noted aviatrix, has been elected a director off Northeast Airlines, Inc., it was announced yesterday in Boston. She will succeed Robert F. Bradford, who resigned from the board upon becoming Lieutenant Governor-elect of Massachusetts.

A basis for post-war planning in health and welfare is provided, through a compilation of data on pre-war living conditions throughout New York City, in the new Statistical Reference Data Handbook issued yesterday by the Neighborhood Health Development, Inc.

TETERBORO, N.J., Dec. 10 -The 6,000 employes of the Eclipse-Pioneer division of the Bendix Aviation Corporation here agreed through their representatives at a union meeting this afternoon to call off a strike for one week. The strike began yesterday in protest against the company's "arbitrary action" in reducing the work week from sixty hours to fifty-five.

ATHENS, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Several mortar shells fired from Elas positions fell near British headquarters on the eastern outskirts of the Greek capital today. Snipers' bullets hit the upper floors of the Grande Bretagne Hotel, temporary seat of the Greek Government on Constitution Square, in the center of the city.

It is not possible for us to live in spiritual or religious isolation these days any more than we can live in political or economic separation from the world, declared the Rev. Dr. Allen S. Claxton in his sermon yesterday in Broadway Temple-Washington Heights Methodist Church, 174th Street and Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Official comment on the Franco-Soviet alliance and mutual security treaty signed in Moscow was withheld today pending complete reports of the treaty's context and a study of the treaty's implications.

More than 700,000 copies of "Your Next Kitchen," a guide on kitchen planning issued by Edison General Electric (Hotpoint) Company, have been distributed to people sending dimes with coupons clipped from consumer advertising media or obtained from dealers, according to H.E. Warren, advertising director.

By many labor leaders, Government officials and even some industrialists it is frequently asserted that the responsibility for achieving the post-war goal of "full employment" falls upon industry. The ability of business to provide the jobs required to reach this objective is examined in the current issue of the National City Bank Bulletin.

Trailing by a goal with less than half a period remaining, the Philadelphia Falcons rallied to defeat the New York Rovers in the Eastern Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden yesterday, 5 to 3, before the largest matinee crowd of the season -- 12,468.

Temporary patrolmen in the Police Department were warned yesterday by Mayor La Guardia that they would be throwing their money away if they responded to an appeal by the Temporary Patrolmen's Association for contributions of $100 each to finance a campaign to get the 1945 Legislature to give them permanent status.
Six new films, including an importation from Mexico, are slated to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Dec. 10 -- Doughboys of the American First Army smashed forward through the snow and rain today to hammer out gains of up to one mile on a ten-mile front in a series of sharp attacks that bit through the stubborn German defenses shielding Dueren, southern bastion of the German line on the Roer River.
Six new films, including an importation from Mexico, are slated to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Dec. 10 -- Doughboys of the American First Army smashed forward through the snow and rain today to hammer out gains of up to one mile on a ten-mile front in a series of sharp attacks that bit through the stubborn German defenses shielding Dueren, southern bastion of the German line on the Roer River.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- President Roosevelt has accepted the resignation of Harry Slattery, administrator of the Rural Electrification Administration, whose policy and differences with Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard, his superior officer, have caused Congressional inquiry and prompted recommendations that the REA be returned to the status of an independent agency.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 11 -Counter-attacking Chinese forces, rushed from the northwest, have completely cleared the Japanese from Kweichow Province and recaptured the railway town of Liuchai, just inside the Kwangsi border, a Chinese High Command communique announced today.

The first group of Wacs to train as occupational therapy aides entered a new special training course yesterday at Halloran General Hospital, Staten Island, as part of the Army's program to recruit and train 20,000 women medical technicians.

A proposal that Germany and Japan be invited to participate in the next Olympic Games was howled down by more than 100 representatives attending an executive committee meeting of the U.S.A. Sports Federation at the New York Athletic Club last night.
UNITED STATES NINTH AIR FORCE BASE, France, Dec. 11 -A squadron of former night-fighter pilots based at this field is prying from the enemy secrets hitherto covered by darkness.

PARIS, Dec. 11 (U.P.) -- Representative Clare Boothe Luce of Connecticut declared today that privations suffered by the French in occupied Paris were no worse than those suffered by the British in bomb-blasted London.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Foreign Economic Administration advised exporters today they may resume immediately commercial shipment of specified lists of automotive replacements and repair parts to French West Africa.

Counsel has advised the United States and International Securities Corporation that cash distributions on its first preferred stock during 1944 represent a return of capital for income tax purposes and are not taxable as ordinary dividends. Accordingly, the company will apply to the Treasury Department for a ruling to this effect after the close of the year, and notice of the ruling will be sent to stockholders as soon as possible thereafter.

Two exhibitions will open with previews at 8 o'clock this evening at the National Academy, 1083 Fifth Avenue. One of these is the Academy's own first annual exhibition of drawings and the other is the third annual made up of work by merchant seamen of the United Nations, sponsored by the United Seamen's Service and the War Shipping Administration.

A fraction derived from the clotting substance in blood plasma has been effective in stopping the hemorrhages resulting from hemophilia when other methods have failed, Prof. Edwin J. Cohn of the Harvard Medical School, reported yesterday at the annual scientific award ceremony of the American Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Seventythree basic steel companies petitioned the War Labor Board today for a reconsideration of its order in the steel case, made public on Nov. 25 and affecting about 400,000 employes of eighty-six concerns.

MELBOURNE, Dec. 11 (Reuter) -- Admiral Sir Bruce Fraser, commander in chief of Britain's Pacific Fleet, gave his views today on the part his new command will play in that area. He said that he would hoist his flag in the great battleship zone.

Members of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc., representing 750 shops employing 10,000 workers, met last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania and voted unanimously to declare a lockout in the industry in the event of a strike called in any one or more shops by the International Fur Workers Union, affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- The household furnishings here of Thomas F. Manville Jr. were placed on the auction block today at the New Rochelle Woman's Club, with clubwomen, show girls, business men, curio dealers and Christmas shoppers bidding prices higher than the auctioneers had ever heard for such objects.

The expected arrival in Athens of Harold Macmillan, Resident Minister at Allied headquarters in the central Mediterranean, will bring to that troubled city a British official of Cabinet rank. The purpose of Mr. Macmillan's visit, as described in our London dispatches, will be to see whether a formula can be devised under which all Greek factions can be induced to lay down arms and accept a truce until an election can be held.

Miss Perkins, it is said, is not anxious to continue in office, and President Roosevelt is reported willing to name a new Secretary of Labor to replace her if the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations can agree upon a candidate.

ROME, Dec. 11 (AP) -- A fierce see-saw battle raged today on a four-mile front southwest of Faenza as the Germans threw in crack, rested veterans to save the highway center from the British Eighth Army's hammering offensive.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 11 (AP) One thousand wounded marines and sailors, 1,600 other veterans of the Pacific warfare, a group of missionaries and Red Cross workers and some Chinese and Australians arrived here today by transport.

ROME, Dec. 11 -- Count Carlo Sforza, in a formal statement replying to the attacks on him in the House of Commons, charged today that Prime Minister Churchill had spent most of his time during their interview in October, 1943, in trying to persuade the Count to support King Victor Emmanuel.
LONDON, Dec. 11 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange held steady within a narrow range in yesterday's trading, and closing prices were 3 points higher to 3 points lower than Saturday's final levels. Throughout the day there was just enough price-fixing to absorb the limited amount of liquidation and hedge selling.

Dorothy Danzig, young American pianist, made her debut at the Times Hall last night, playing a lengthy and ambitious program. On the whole, Miss Danzig acquitted herself with honor, though she is not as yet the possessor of the technical or interpretive powers that come with maturity and experience.

"Little Women" hasn't been seen hereabouts since 1932. That oversight will be rectified tonight when Eddie Dowling and the New York City Center jointly escort the Marian de Forest dramatization of Louisa May Alcott's novel into the municipally operated house for an engagement of only twenty-one performances -- ten at night and eleven in the afternoon.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 11 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Charles D. Millard, who played a leading role in Westchester politics for forty-five years, plunged to his death at 9:40 A.M. yesterday from the Henry Hudson Bridge, over the Harlem River, to the rocky crags 150 feet below.
PARIS, Dec. 11 -- Food continues to be the chief factor in France's internal situation. Supplies still depend on transportation.

In Carnegie Hall last night Joseph Szigeti, violinist, began with classics -- Brahms of the D minor sonata for violin and piano; Bach of the Grave and Fugue from the unaccompanied A minor sonata -- and then proceeding with modern compositions of exceptional interest, which he set with exceptional cogency before his audience.

PARIS, Dec. 11 -- French children suffered grievously during the four years of German occupation and but for the spirited efforts of the French Government during that time might now be in a critical state.
Operations of the Rath Packing Company in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 resulted in a net profit of $1,821,667 after all charges, according to the annual report announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, ordered local draft boards today to apply deferment yardsticks "in the light of the immediate urgencies" for men on the fighting and industrial front and to reclassify for immediate military service men with occupational deferments who leave their jobs without permission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -The House voted 178 to 107 today to abolish the Jackson Hole National Monument which President Roosevelt created by Executive Order on March 15, 1943. The resolution now goes to the Senate.

J. William Fulbright, Senatorelect from Arkansas, declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Bond Club of New York in the Bankers Club that he saw "no insuperable obstacle to the success of a policy of collective security" after the war.
LONDON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 11 -- As a complement to the recent Swedish expulsion of a German diplomat and declaration of two German officials in Sweden as personae non gratae, a housecleaning has been undertaken in the Swedish Legation in Berlin aimed at clerical employes with personal German connections.

Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin has ordered the assessed valuation of the Bartholomew Building, twenty-story office and store structure at 205 East Forty-second Street, reduced from $3,700,000 to $2,970,000 for 1943-44. Assessment value of the land was reduced from $1,000,000 to $770,000 and that of the building from $2,700,000 to $2,200,000.

The proposed meat holiday by New York City retailers calls dramatic attention to the difficulties experienced by butchers as a result of wartime regulations and shortages. But a strike by retailers at this time can be no more justified or tolerated than a strike by workers.

PARIS, Dec. 11 -- Miguel Maura, leader of the Spanish Republican moderates in Paris, continues to assert that his private information reveals that General Franco has resigned, and declares that he is prepared to form a Provisional Government.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The White House revealed that President Roosevelt has accepted the resignation of Harry Slattery as REA administrator.
LONDON, Dec. 11 -- A firm tone was seen throughout most sections of today's stock markets, although business was on the small side.

The records of the Hundred Neediest Cases are sad evidence of the cruelties life can inflict upon innocent people: upon children denied a normal family home; upon people in middle life struck down by illness; upon the elderly who sometimes do not know where to turn for help after many years of faithful service to their families and to their community.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 10 (Delayed) -- The Russians have expelled a four-man American Office of Strategic Services team from Bulgaria for the second time since Bulgaria's surrender.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 11 -- It is entirely false to picture the Belgian Government as fighting against the resistance forces -- a conception generally held abroad -- because one element of the former underground organization has waged a relentless campaign for the removal of Premier Hubert Pierlot.

TINIAN, Marianas Islands, Nov. 28 (Delayed) -- Four Japanese who had hidden in the bush since the capture of this island in July committed suicide last week by blowing up a Ventura bomber, and themselves with it, on the west field landing strip here.
Before military operations "can bring the war lords of Japan to their knees," much additional money and material will be needed, Secretary of the Navy James V. Forrestal warned last night.

WITH THE AMERICAN THIRD ARMY, in Germany, Dec. 8 (Delayed) -- A German captain, recently captured, who was an interrogator of American and British prisoners of war told today how the captives were persuaded to talk. The system was a clever combination of psychology, intimidation and deception.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 11 -- Leonard Sillman, who recently signed a contract with Republic to produce an annual screen review under the master title of "New Faces" is scheduled to launch production of the 1945 edition on Dec. 27.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Canadian Government has submitted to Washington and London an amendment to the Dumbarton Oaks Security Plan which is designed to increase the authority of middle powers, like Canada and the Netherlands, without reducing the effectiveness of the proposed League or destroying the special authority of the big powers.

May I offer a constructive criticism of the letter from Prof. Irving Fisher you published Dec. 4. It seems to me that he properly warns of the genuine imminence of socialism in this country, so great that one economist has adopted an attitude of economic fatalism on the subject, although Professor Fisher says socialism is not inevitable "on condition that we are willing to fight it by marshaling convincing evidence" against it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Mass exclusion of persons of Japanese ancestry from the Pacific Coast area will continue only as long as the commanding general of the West Coast area considers it a military necessity, John J. McCloy, Assistant Secretary of War, told an unofficial House committee today.

Henry Goelet, operator, has purchased the six-story fifty-four-family apartment house at 87 West 169th Street, near Shakespeare Avenue, the Bronx, from the Radmar Realty Corporation. The property, which occupies an irregular plot 125 by 136 feet, was sold subject to a first mortgage of about $191,000 held by the Irving Savings Bank.

Major league baseball, as of today, goes under a three-man commission rule but with the emphasized understanding that a return to the one-man form of commissionership will be effected as quickly as a new major league agreement can be drawn up and a successor to the late Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis can be agreed upon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The first wartime press tour of the White House took place today, with Mrs. Roosevelt serving as guide. Reporters even saw the kitchens, which were last displayed nine years ago, when modern electrical equipment and work-engineering were installed.

The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York announced yesterday that Mayor La Guardia had officially proclaimed today as "Federation Day" and that 10,000 volunteer money raisers will take the field in a city-wide house-to-house and office-to-office canvass to raise $1,000,000 by nightfall as part of the appeal program in behalf of 116 medical and social welfare agencies connected with the organization.

Drafting of a relatively few highly skilled workmen is one of the important contributing causes of the present munitions shortage, Samuel J. Kornhauser, president of the National Tool Company, said yesterday, advocating the release from the armed forces of key shopmen.

ATHENS, Dec. 11-- Elas forces sent mortar shells crashing into the heart of Athens today, setting fires near Constitution Square as Royal Air Force Beaufighters returned to the battle, strafing a National Liberation Front troop concentration reported to have been massing for an attack a mile from the center of the city.

Members of a youth panel which discussed post-war problems the other day in Times Hall were between 9 years of age and 13. On the other hand, we all remember the homeless "children" of the Depression era; in a good many cases they turned out to be 20 years and over.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Twelve railroads told the Supreme Court today that Gov. Ellis Arnall of Georgia should go to the Interstate Commerce Commission -- not the high tribunal -- with his complaint about freight rates.
LONDON, Dec. 11 -- The war's greatest single bomber fleet, more than 1,600 Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Eighth Air Force, attacked Germany today.

Michael Todd yesterday confirmed a report that he had purchased the screen rights to "Great Son," a new novel by Edna Ferber, which is scheduled to be published next month by Harper. The selling price agreed upon by the author and Mr. Todd was $200,000, equaling the record price paid by Metro for "The Green Years," by A.J. Cronin, and "Forever Amber," the Kathleen Winsor bestseller, which was bought by Twentieth Century-Fox.

MONTREAL, Dec. 11 -- Camillien Houde, former Mayor of Montreal, who was sent to an internment camp in 1940 for anti-war activities and released only a few months ago, was today elected again to be Mayor of this French Canadian city.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Communique 247:

Technical developments made during the war will produce many changes in civilian life of the future, Dr. Gerald Wendt, science editor of Time Magazine, told members of the New York Junior League yesterday. He spoke at the second luncheon meeting in a postwar planning series.

Cautioning against the "over-enthusiastic forecasts by some industry spokesmen" on public post-war buying of television receiving sets, Lewis Allen Weiss, executive vice president of the Don Lee Broadcasting System, told 1,000 delegates to the first annual conference of the Television Broadcasters Association yesterday that "sets will face brisk competition in the consumer market against new model refrigerators and indoor plumbing."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -While American officials are hoping that the British will make peace with Greek resistance forces quickly, this Government's attitude is that it has no military responsibility in that area.

Out-of-town college basketball coaches and officials were the principal speakers at a luncheon at Toots Shor's yesterday. Henry Iba of the Oklahoma Aggies, who, led by the 7-foot Bob Kurland, will oppose N.Y.U. in the feature game of the double-header at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night; Loren Ellis of Valparaiso, Vidal Peterson of Utah, Alvin Julian of Muhlenbeg, Howard Hoboson of Oregon, on Sabbatical leave, and Legs Hawley, West Virginia director of athletics, spoke.

Concerted opposition of the coal industry in the fields of both management and labor to continued expansion of the Federal Government in the hydroelectric power business has developed to the point where many members of the coal industry are petitioning Congress to reject such proposed legislation as the Flood Control Bill and the Rivers and Harbors Bill.

Jose Iturbi's piano recital last night in the New York City Center celebrated the first anniversary of that institution, and this in a manner nobly representative of the occasion. Always a brilliantly gifted interpreter and virtuoso too, he surpassed in that part of the program this writer was able to hear any previous playing of Scarlatti or Mozart or Beethoven that we had heard from him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- A delegation representing many leading Greek-American societies and organizations in the United States today visited the State Department to protest British intervention in Greece and to urge United States mediation to end bloodshed in Athens.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 (AP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a plan of recapitalization for the York County (Pa.) Gas Company, a subsidiary of Pennsylvania Gas and Electric Corporation.

The American Negro can be proud of the figures just given out by the War Department as to his part in this war. He has contributed 701,678 men to the Army, of whom 411,368 are overseas. There are 5,804 commissioned Negro officers, including dentists, nurses and other medical corps officers, and chaplains.

OMAHA, Dec. 11 (AP) -- District Judge John W. Delehant ruled today in favor of five New York music publishing houses or composers in their copyright infringement suit against eleven Nebraska hotels and entertainment places.

SARREGUEMINES, France, Dec. 11 (U.P.) -- A thousand Allied soldiers who were captured by the Germans in eastern Europe, including a young Polish lieutenant taken at Warsaw more than five years ago, were freed today when elements of the American Thirty-fifth Infantry Division overran their prison camp on the outskirts of Sarreguemines.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -Representative Charles Halleck, Republican, of Indiana, has accused the Rural Electrification Administration of spending "many thousands of dollars" on what he terms "Federally-financed Rube Goldberg devices."

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- The British Labor party decided today at the opening session of its annual conference that its Ministers should remain in Prime Minister Churchill's coalition Government until the war in Europe is won, but that the party should fight as a political entity again in the next general election.

The most recent addition to the ice cream mixes now on the market is one called Tis, to be introduced in city stores within the next few days. It is made by Dairylea for Homix Products, Inc., which devised the formula. Homix is the same company that used to put out Tis eggnog and that now manufactures the delicious Chantilly dessert sauces.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (U.P.) -Representative Hamilton Fish, Republican, of New York, in his farewell speech in the House, attacked Governor Dewey today and proposed that Republicans abandon their party name in 1948 to unite with "real Democrats" in a new party alignment.
The jubilant Giants, Eastern champions of the National Football League, enjoyed a well-earned and much-needed rest yesterday following their triumph over the Redskins at Washington Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -Heeding advice of the State Department, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today shelved by a 12 to 8 vote a resolution advocating unrestricted entry of Jews into Palestine.

PARIS, Dec. 11 -- Writing in the newspaper Paris-Presse today, Philippe Barres, biographer of Gen. Charles de Gaulle, said that the French-Russian treaty signed in Moscow yesterday was a hedge against a possible weakening of the sea powers of the West in regard to control of Germany in the future.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Atlantic Coast Line Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for permission to operate the Florida East Coast Line on grounds that such a course was in the public interest.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Two British business men's delegations reported today on the result of negotiations with American business men and Government officials for the resumption of Anglo-American trade in manufactured articles and raw cotton after the war.

Post-war independent grocery stores may be as standardized in appearance as the chain food store of the present day if proposals of the New York State Food Merchants Association and manufacturers of store equipment are adopted, A.F. Guckenberger, executive secretary of the association, said yesterday.

WITH AMERICAN THIRD ARMY, in Germany, Dec. 11 -- The first group of American Third Army soldiers, part of a cavalcade of heroes that will leave soon for the United States on a thiry-day furlough there, assembled today at a replacement center for the last briefing before starting the happiest journey of their lives.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Having hurdled numerous obstacles and landed on the right side of the ledger during its first eight days, Gulfstream Park today ushered in its second full week with a card that filled better than usual and which contained twin features.

Billions of your war bond dollars go into saving life. No armed force in the world's history has ever had the amount and kind of medical care that goes along with our fighting Yanks to the combat zones.

The Metropolitan Opera Guild yesterday honored several former members of the company, covering almost six decades of service, at its first luncheon of the season attended by 1,200 persons in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Nine adjoining buildings, including the ten-story manufacturing structure at 88-90 Gold Street, have been purchased by William T. Hunter from the International Projector Company in an all-cash transaction. As part of the transaction, the buildings were leased to the projector company which will occupy them until after the war.

The dispatch published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 2, which carried an account of the divergence of views of The Economist of London and Kent Cooper, Executive Director of The Associated Press, touched on one of the most important problems of the post-war world.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Tuesday, Dec. 12 (AP) -- A communique:

Stockholders of Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., will vote at a meeting on Jan. 8 on increasing the preferred and common stock. This would permit an offering of 50,429 shares of convertible preferred stock to holders of common stock at the rate of one preferred share for each twelve common shares held.

Welker Cochran, San Francisco veteran, moved a step closer to the three-cushion billiard championship of the world last night by conquering Jay Bozeman of Vallejo, Calif., 50 -- 39, in a forty-seven-inning encounter at the Hotel Capitol.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Forces, Paris, Dec. 11 -- Three columns of tanks and infantry punched their way across the muddy Cologne Plain to positions within two and a half miles of Dueren, southern citadel of the German line on the Roer, today, as the American First Army under Lieut. Gen. Courtney H. Hodges continued its drive in face of fierce resistance from crack German troops.

Germany and Japan must be defeated so decisively that for hundreds of years their people will not want to wage war again, Under Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson declared last night at the 150th anniversary dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel of Ecole Polytechnique, French military and engineering school.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
FRAULAUTERN, Germany, Dec. 11 (AP) -- A 20-year-old lieutenant from Queens knocked out three Siegfried Line pillboxes today with his tongue -- and an amazing amount of coolness and courage.

IT may have been coincidence to have encountered two polo enthusiasts on the same day, particularly since each of them had a significant contribution to make on Tommy Hitchcock. The first person was a former polo expert, who remarked, "I've just learned how Tommy Hitchcock was killed. He was experimenting with blind dive-bombing, hitting targets while above low clouds.

The possibility that New Yorkers might become unwilling vegetarians dwindled yesterday as Mayor La Guardia promised that the citizenry would get its full share of meat even if the retail industry carried out its threat to shut down 10,000 markets for an indefinite "business holiday" in protest against Office of Price Administration regulations.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- Lumber manufacturers today expressed optimism over post-war prospects of the industry with no reconversion problems, surplus disposal threats or shrinking markets for their products seen. But manufacturers attending the wartime conference of the National Lumber Manufacturers Association here said that two problems faced the industry immediately after the war.
On the opening day of the annual major league baseball meetings, a convocation dubbed by the dozens of tired standees as the "Flatfoot Derby," the Yankees were the first to make a player deal.

Japanese Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu, in a speech on the third anniversary of the signing of the German-Italian-Japanese military alliance, said yesterday, "There is no doubt that the war is definitely in our favor," adding, "There is not an inkling of doubt in my mind that Hitler and Mussolini will save Europe."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Increased demands for war production flattened today any possibility of Army Air Forces football teams playing post-season games.

Word of the death in France on Nov. 24 of Lieut. Col. Seaton Sailer of the Army Medical Corps was received yesterday from the War Department by his father, Louis F. Sailer of Ridgewood, N.J. The father is president of the Commercial National Bank of Paterson.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Changing a lower court decree, the Supreme Court, by five to one, today ruled that an affiliation of six chain motion picture theatre corporations in the South had violated the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.

The Blue network advised its affiliated stations yesterday that they were confronted with the possibility of a network strike because of the row between James C. Petrillo's American Federation of Musicians and the National Association of Broadcast Engineers and Technicans.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- Blazing a new trail for the profitable operation of airports built for home defense, the Westchester County Board of Acquisition and Contract recommended today to the Board of Supervisors that the new $4,000,000 Westchester airport in Purchase be leased to the North American Airport Corporation for fifteen years on a basis that promises $899,050 to the county in cash and $833,400 in new buildings.

HEADQUARTERS OF TWENTY-FIRST BOMBER COMMAND, Saipan, Marianas, Dec. 11 (U.P.) -- Striking Tokyo seven hours apart, two Superfortresses kindled fires in the Japanese capital that could be seen for eighty-five miles, and set off explosions in the harbor area, returning crewmen reported today.

Officials of seven municipalities announced over the week-end that they planned to sell this month and early in January new bond issues amounting to more than $6,000,000. Roanoke, Va., invited bids on Jan. 3 for $1,585,000 of water bonds.

ROME, Dec. 11 (AP) -- More than 3,000 assorted American, French and British GI's, Wacs, nurses and brass hats saw the first two elimination sessions today of the second annual Mediterranean inter-Allied boxing championships. The Americans won six bouts to lead the British by one and the French by four.
Nadia Reisenberg, pianist, was acclaimed last night by a large and enthusiastic audience that filled Town Hall, where she had last been heard in February.

CANTON, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- Many operators of farms in St. Lawrence County are combating a water shortage resulting from a change in water channels caused, they believe, by more than a score of earthquakes in the last few months. The worst tremor was felt Sept. 5, but major and minor shocks have been felt since then, including a few in the last week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Office of War Information is reducing its overseas staff in Washington and New York by about 350 employes in a reorganization following the liberation of several European countries.

The stock market registered yesterday another major forward push under the stimulus of a sustained heavy demand. The recent familiar pattern of first testing the list's structure, absorbing profit-cashing and then an orderly resumption of bidding again was adhered to rigidly.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- Although July and September wheat broke around 1 cent a bushel in the early trading today on the Board of Trade as the result of selling induced by favorable weather and crop reports from the Southwest and Central West, the old crop deliveries were firm on buying by millers.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 11 -- With lines of communication from Budapest already thoroughly clogged with military transport going in and industrial evacuation transport going out, the Szalasi puppet Government threw another load on the exhausted Hungarian transport system today by decreeing the immediate evacuation of an estimated 800,000 "non-essential" civilians from the capital.

After a campaign of encirclement lasting more than a month the Russian armies have now launched their final assault on Budapest. Berlin admits that the battle for the Hungarian capital is approaching its climax. From the north, east and south, and on both sides of the Danube, Russian forces are closing in on the city.

A jail term of nine months was imposed by Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz yesterday on Samuel Nicoletti, 23 years old, for the possession of counterfeit gasoline ration coupons. Nicoletti, who formerly operated Sam's Service Station, 25 Lincoln Avenue, Mount Vernon, was found guilty by a jury.
DETROIT, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Four Montgomery Ward Co. stores in this area remained open today despite a strike by members of the United Retail, Wholesale and Department Stores Employes, CIO.

A nonprofit book club, the Labor Book Club, Inc., has been established by the United Automobile Workers and Reynal Hitchcock, to distribute books of all publishers among automobile and aircraft workers and their families. Reynal Hitchcock will serve as consultant and advisor on technical and professional matters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Short-ages of coal for domestic use will become "critical" after the first of the year, partly as a result of the publics failure to use abundant supplies of lower-grade fuel, Dr. Charles J. Potter, Deputy Solid Fuels Administrator for War, warned today.

A rush of gifts to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday showed that old friends realize, with only two weeks remaining before Christmas, the great importance of a prompt response to the annual Christmas appeal in behalf of the most distressed families and individuals in the city known to seven leading private charity organizations.

ABOARD LCT 999, in a Pacific Lagoon, Nov. 29 (Delayed) -There's a submerged tenth in the Navy of men who work anonymously and unthanked on vessels so obscure and so plentiful that they have no names, only numbers. This correspondent happened to come on board one such craft because there was no other way to reach an aircraft carrier sailing at dawn from an atoll.

The National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters has granted a reduction of 50 per cent from the former manual rates for owners' protective liability in the insurance covering the construction of public housing financed under the State housing program, Herman T. Stichman, State Commissioner of Housing, announced yesterday.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Tuesday, Dec. 12 (UP) -Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced Monday that the troops caught southeast of Ormoc were "many thousands" strong, and while details are lacking, it was believed that a very considerable number was destroyed between the Seventy-seventh, pushing southward from its beachhead; the Seventh, advancing north, and other American forces pushing westward through the mountains.

The Office of Price Administrstion's export control procedures for United States territories has "virtually" gone into effect with the approval by the Bureau of the Budget of a system which requires of individual exporters the filing of specific price schedules on certain shipments to United States territories, Joseph A. Sinclair, manager of the foreign trade bureau of the Commerce and Industry Association, declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (U.P.) -- Overcoming the numerous handicaps of wartime athletics, the professional National Football League celebrated its silver anniversary by drawing 1,234,750 fans during its regular 1944 season, an all-time high with nearly a five per cent increase over 1943, official league figures revealed today.

EAST ALTON, Ill., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Western Cartridge Company approved today the merger of that company with the Olin Corporation and the formation of a new parent corporation, Olin Industries.

Mary Orr and Reginald Denham, who contributed "Wallflower" to another season, now have turned their collaborative attentions to the art of melodrama. "Dark Hammock," they call it, a tale of slow murder by poison in the Florida wilderness of 1910.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies in November showed a rise of 13 per cent over the same month last year, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The increase is the second largest this year, the rise in August having been 13.6 per cent.

More than 2,000 years ago King Solomon wrote in Proverbs: "Where there is no vision, the people perish." I say where there are no nurses the patients perish, and when these patients are our heroic boys and girls who are fighting all over the world today in the greatest cause in history, the defense of God, humanity and civilization, then indeed it is a tragedy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Senator Guy M. Gillette, Democrat, of Iowa, deplored today what he called the "precarious and dangerous" role which this country was playing in world affairs.
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted in English by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
Edward R. Rutledge of Stewart-Warner Corporation, has been appointed regional manager of the Eastern territory of the radio division.

About 855,000,000 contamers will be used annually to pack electrical, radar and radio equipment, and instrument parts and novelties valued at wholesale at an estimated $480,000,000 and at retail at $895,000,000, according to a post-war survey of the industry by the National Paper Box Manufacturers' Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -The War Labor Board upheld today an order of July 26 by the Daily Newspaper Printing and Publishing Commission in Chicago granting standard maintenance of membership to the American Newspaper Guild in its contracts with The United Press.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The orders relating to clothing which the War Production Board issued recently are only the beginning of much more stringent textile controls which will cut in on luxury types and some essential adult garments so that growing children and users of work clothing will have what they need.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Tuesday, Dec. 12--Troops of the United States Seventh Division, driving northward in western Leyte, made a junction on Sunday with the Seventy-seventh Division which, late on Saturday, took Ormoc town, and whatever enemy troops were trapped between the two American forces have been destroyed, it was announced today.

KANDY, Ceylon, Dec. 11 (U.P.) -Maj. Gen. Francis W. Festing's British Thirty-sixth Division troops, pushing south from Naba on the heels of the retreating Japanese in the Myitkyina-Mandalay corridor, have occupied the railway city of Indaw, 150 air miles north of Mandalay, and have also captured Katha, important Irrawaddy River city twelve miles southeast of Naba, a Southeast Asia Command communique reported today.

Urging support of proposals for the establishment of a general international organization as set forth in the preliminary draft of the charter of the United Nations by the Dumbarton Oaks conference, the trustees of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace warned at their semi-annual meeting yesterday that the alternative would be "the threat of a third World War."

A new branch of the Metropolitain Museum of Art, to be known as the Costume Institute, will be established as a major step in a program to emphasize the position of fashion as an art and to aid the creative efforts of American fashion designers and industries, it was announced yesterday by William Church Osborn, president of the museum.

An institutional campaign urging manufacturers to place orders now so as to be ready to obtain their proper share of civilian consumption and to speed reconversion will be started immediately by the Heppenstall Company, Pittsburgh, Pa., steel forgings.

The New York County Republican Committee redesignated David B. Costuma at a meeting at Manhattan Center last night for another two-year term as a member of the Board of Elections, a post he has held since 1934. By its action, the committee completed the slate of board members that the City Council will seat today.

The Battle for Leyte is more than a battle for an island, the Japanese propagandists are telling the Japanese people. It is the Battle for the Philippines and more than that. It is the battle, they say, for Greater East Asia. If that were wholly true, there should be dancing in the streets today, for it appears the Battle for Leyte is nearing its successful conclusion.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 12 (UP) -- The Red Army hammered a wedge into German lines eleven miles northeast of Budapest yesterday by seizing the fortress town of Veresegyhaz and the village of Szada as unconfirmed dispatches reported that the Germans were putting the Hungarian capital to the torch.

Irving W. Karpf, operator, has purchased the six-story eighty-six-family apartment house at 157-11 Sanford Avenue, Flushing, Queens, from the Mar-ted Management Corporation. Known as the Hamilton Arms, the building occupies a plot 200 by 100 feet.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Premier Pieter Gerbrandy of the Netherlands said today after his return from the liberated portion of his country that it was possible that his Government might have to face there difficulties similar to those in Belgium and Greece, but that it was not probable since measures were already being taken to avert them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Until the Japanese brought the United States into formal war by their attack on Pearl Harbor there were non-interventionists in this country whose position never was that which came to be conveyed by the term "isolationist." They were neither as stubbornly blind nor brutally indifferent to the menace of German, Japanese and Italian aggression as others with whom they were lumped under the same term.

Mayor La Guardia's radio rebuke administered to the Temporary Patrolmen's Association for appealing for funds to finance a campaign in the 1945 session of the Legislature for permanent status resulted yesterday in the "dropping from the rolls" of Conrad Mandel, head of the organization.

SOUTHEAST FRANCE, Dec. 7 (Delayed) -- The German Army has not been beaten and the battle west of the Rhine may be followed by the true battle of Germany, in the opinion of Gen. Henri-Honore Giraud, who is living quietly here in his family home.

ALBANY, Dec. 11 -- Jackson A Dykman, president of the State Bar Association, made known today the five-member committee of the association which will investigate conditions in Albany County relating to the administration of justice.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -The Senate Military Affairs Committee heard testimony today in support of two nominees to the Surplus War Property Board.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 21 per cent last week over the like period of last year, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. On Thursday, sales of leading stores here set new high records for a single day.

Sumner Welles edited and wrote an introduction to "An Intelligent American's Guide to the Peace," which will be published by the Dryden Press on Jan. 5. The book is a discussion of eighty-six independent nations and major dependent peoples and their stakes in the post-war world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The War Production Board announced today that its Woolen and Worsted Industry Advisory Committee, acting to meet doubled Army needs for wool clothing, has recommended the use of worsted yarn only for military fabrics and the most essential civilian clothing for a period of five months.

A special appropriation for developing a nation-wide recreation program among volunteers working with disabled war veterans has been made by the Association of American Playing Card Manufacturers. Association representatives will visit organizations engaged in community service activities for veterans' hospitals and will instruct volunteers in card games and simple tricks.

GUAM, Dec. 12 -- A fantastic opera bouffe goes on here involving negotiations between the island command and the leaders of several hundred Japanese still at large in the caves and jungles of northern Guam.

Concluding their separate meetings with a swift flourish and a display of cooperative spirit such as they have seldom revealed, the club owners of the National and American Leagues yesterday completed the business of setting up the machinery whereby baseball will move from the rule of the late Kenesaw M. Landis to that of a new commissioner as yet unnamed.

Dr. Pedro G. Beltran, Peruvian Ambassador to the United States, warned yesterday afternoon against a return to "the follies of the inter-war period," during which, he said, a high tariff and other "artificial barriers" to trade had been set up.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Merchant Marine Committee of the House reported today that a shipyard in Providence, R.I., for which the contract was $6,050,000, cost the Government nearly $27,000,000. The contractor was the Rheem Manufacturing Company.

The three remaining Axis partners, Germany, Japan and Mussolini's outlaw clique, have been celebrating the third anniversary of the signing of their military alliance. It was a macabre festival in honor of an event which today must strike all Axis nations as a ghastly folly.

The Treasury Bond Bowl football game at the Polo Grounds next Saturday between two of the nation's foremost service elevens, the Randolph Field Ramblers of Texas and the Second Air Force Super-bombers of Colorado Springs, already has attained its goal, the sale of $79,750,000 in war bonds.

For months the military news from China has been depressing. This week it is more cheerful. Fresh Chinese divisions, hitherto held in reserve against the Communists in the northwest, have now cleared the Japanese completely from Kweichow Province, ending for the time being enemy threats both to Chungking and the eastern terminus of the Burma Road.

A UNITED STATES BOMBER STATION, England, Dec. 12 (U.P.) -- Crew members of the crippled Flying Fortress Homesick Angel, who charted their course from inside Germany to the American Third Army's front lines with a newspaper map, received an "all out" welcome from Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr., they related today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 12 -- It occurred today to agents of the Office of Price Administration in New York that the sale of garbage cans at $60 a pair and electric trains at $195 might be a violation of ceiling prices, even though the objects bore the fingerprints of Thomas F. Manville Jr. and were steeped in Manville tradition.

The first eight altar pieces for eight French armies in the field were presented last night to Gen. Brisson de Sandidier, chief of the French mission to the United States, by Mrs. Junius S. Morgan at the headquarters of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, 36 East Thirty-sixth Street.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 12 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

HEADQUARTERS OF 20TH BOMBER COMMAND, in India, Dec. 12 (UP) -- The Twentieth Bomber Command this week ends its first six months of operations against the enemy, a period during which, Maj. Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, the Twentieth's commanding officer, believes, the Super-fortress has proved to be "the best airplane that's ever been built by anyone."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Failure of the Narragansett Machine Company to produce a single acceptable locker under a contract it held with the Navy prompted the cancellation of a contract for 1,572 lockers given to the Pawtucket company, according to testimony given today before the Senate's Military Affairs Committee.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Wheat futures continued to move upward today on the Board of Trade, with December in the lead. That delivery advanced 1 cent a bushel to a new eight-month high and the deferred deliveries went into new seasonal ground.

The Federal courts have exclusive jurisdiction in suits in equity and actions at law under Section 16B of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora ruled yesterday in dismissing five actions brought by the American Distilling Company and a minority stockholder against five officials of the company.

An apparent paradox emerged from Maine as a post-mortem to that State's 1944 deer season. It was the conviction of officials that the Maine law which allowed the taking of one deer of either sex was a sound one because the deer population had increased greatly in recent years and those taken during last season were unusually large and rugged.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Describing the corporation income tax as a concealed sales tax and labeling certain new tax proposals as "mathematical abstractions," Enders M. Voorhees, chairman of the finance committee of United States Steel Corporation, said tonight at the annual dinner of the Illinois Manufacturers Association here that taxes and regulations were "setting back the moral clock" and inducing "the moral degeneration of evasion."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (U.P.) -- The National War Labor Board, moving to avert a threatened general CIO strike in Detroit, issued an order tonight for the union and the company to appear Thursday to explain why the four-day-old Montgomery Ward strike in Detroit had not been ended and why Government directives had not been complied with by the company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Newspaper support of the Sixth War Loan has been "truly magnificent," Ted R. Gamble, National War Finance Director, declared here today.

Formal public offerings of new corporate securities were halted abruptly with the launching of the Sixth War Loan Drive on last Nov. 20, but in underwriting and bond-dealer circles activity continued unabated as preparations were made for the resumption of private financing on a large scale early in the new year.

Dorothy Thompson disclosed yesterday that she had resigned as president of Freedom House, but declined to provide any reason for having taken this action before the end of her term, which was scheduled to run through this month.

Governmental control of business rents in New York through State action early in 1945 appeared likely last night as a means of halting increases and stabilizing tenancy conditions for the 100,000 business houses, manufacturers and individuals who lease commercial quarters here.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 12 -- Kathleen Winsor, the author of the best seller "Forever Amber," has been signed to a Twentieth Century-Fox "three service" contract calling for writing, technical advice and acting. She will work on the screen play of her novel with producer William Perlberg and scenarist Jerome Cady and advise on technical matters during production.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- The plan for a unified Yugoslav federal government which Dr. Ivan Subasitch, Yugoslav Prime Minister, brought back from conferences in Belgrade and Moscow was reported among Serbian politicans today to have met strong objections from their leaders.

Cautious but cheerful, Christmas tree dealers agreed yesterday that their supply so far is "pre-war normal," with prices lower than last year's. Wholesalers and retailers warned, though, that the large-scale dumping brought about by the flooding of the market a year ago might result this season in a tighter supply picture.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Philip Murray, president of the United Steel Workers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, told the War Labor Board today that the petition of steel-producing companies for reconsideration of the board's recent decision calling for wage adjustments had provoked unrest among the workers, and requested the board to dispose of the petition quickly.
ROME, Dec. 12 (AP) -- A communique:

Inasmuch as all of us cannot give to all of the Hundred Neediest Cases it is well that there is a quick way to choose the one or two to whom our help can go. It is an almost automatic way of choosing. It consists in finding in the list the case or cases that present as nearly as possible a suggestion of some personal experience either endured or escaped in years gone by.

A FEW years ago a successful etcher from the Dakotas, Levon West by name, succumbed to the fascination of photography, bought himself a camera, began specializing in color pictures and in no time at all became an acknowledged expert in his new profession. His pictures were featured attractions in The Saturday Evening Post, objects of envy and admiration among camera enthusiasts from Nome to Key West.

While shirt manufacturers submitted bids on 558,000 flannel O.D. shirts for the Army yesterday at an industry mass meeting here called by the Philadelphia Quarter-master Depot to get quick market-wide action on 2,900,000 units urgently needed for delivery through March, it was indicated that the full quantity will be covered by the end of the week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Foreign Policy Association asserted today that Great Britain and the United States had shown in the Caribbean area that "it is possible to adjust common problems on a regional basis."

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Wednesday, Dec. 13 -- In another raging sea and air battle, lasting forty-eight hours off the northwest coast of Leyte, another Japanese convoy was cut to pieces. An American convoy, attacked off Ormoc by Japanese planes, suffered less serious losses.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Athletes and other prominent persons now in the Army may have a hard time securing discharges in the future.
A distinction long delayed came yesterday to Lieut. Comdr. Benny Leonard, Recreation and Morale Officer at the Maritime Service Training Station, Sheepshead Bay.

ATHENS, Dec. 12 -- Miltiade Porphyrogenis, a leading Communist and former member of Premier George Papandreou's Cabinet, met Lieut. Gen. Ronald M. Scobie, British commander in Greece, today and received the latter's terms for cessation of hostilities in Athens, which was shelled again by Leftists outside the capital.

Three recipes for the holidays -- one for a white plum pudding, one for fruit cake and one for cookies -- appear today. These things may be made now, then stored for later use. In stowing the pudding, keep it in the molds, tightly covered, and then before serving let the dessert steam for about an hour.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- An advanced picture of naval aviation, in which fighter planes will operate at speeds upward of 700 miles an hour, radar devices will play a spectacular part and robots may profoundly affect air tactics, was presented today to the House Naval Affairs Committee by Rear Admiral De Witt C. Ramsey, Chief of the Bureau of Aeronautics.

As part of the holiday celebration, as well as that of its own first anniversary, the City Center last evening opened a revival of "Little Women." The Marian DeForest adaptation of Louisa May Alcott is perhaps not now aimed, at the followers of Sinatra, juke boxes and normal Broadway, but they have parents and younger sisters -- the one to remember, the other to learn of one of the classics.

The 1.057 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $100,449,974,298 of par value as of Nov. 30, had a total market value of $101,377,604,946, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of Oct. 31 there were 1,058 issues, aggregating $101,088,301,686 of par value which had a total market value of $101,801,493,498.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The action taken by the House Foreign Affairs Committee on the Senate-approved bill to prohibit commercial use of the Red Cross name and emblem which was reported favorably with amendments yesterday, was criticized in the House today by Representative John M. Vorys of Ohio, a member of the committee, and defended by Representative Everett Dirksen of Illinois, both Republicans.

Early pressure became more insistent yesterday on the stock market, but the final-hour rally which has been characteristic of recent sessions permitted a firm closing. The day was marked by individual rather than group movements, although the rails and tractions as such acted well.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, the Westminster Choir, and five leading singers of the Metropolitan Opera Company raised $1,400,000 for the Sixth War Loan drive in a gala concert last night in the Metropolitan Opera House.

Harold J. Laski in the opening address at the British Labor party conference drew a distinction between two Winston Churchills. There is the national leader, "the resistance leader of 1940 and 1941," and there is the Conservative party leader of today, as revealed in Italy and Greece, but no longer, as Mr. Laski believes, "the leader of Britain."

BOSTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- After being deadlocked twice, the Bruins set off a three-goal scoring blast in the final period to top the New York Rangers, 7 -- 5, in a wide-open National Hockey League clash tonight before a 9,500 crowd at the Boston Garden. Herb Cain and Kenney Smith each tallied twice for the victors.

BEFORE DUEREN, Germany, Dec. 12 -- First Army troops, caked with mud and stiff with cold, pushed on to the Roer River today and closed in on the western approaches to Dueren. The capture of the city itself, however, must wait upon our crossing of the river, for the main part of it lies along its eastern bank.

In your issue of Dec. 7 you print a letter from Bernard L. Mazel in answer to mine of Dec. 4 in defense of private enterprise. I hope he is right in thinking that I exaggerate the menace of the attacks being made on our American way of life in the sphere of private enterprise.

The War Bond Drive is lagging seriously among small investors. In New York City we have subscribed to only 51 per cent of the Series E Bond quota. The national record is about as poor. The demands of total war are greater than ever. The fighting on the battlefronts reaches new peaks of fury and intensity.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Dec. 13 -- Saipan-based American Super-fortresses today attacked industrial targets on the main Japanese island of Honshu, on which Tokyo is located, the War Department announced.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Premier Stalin and Gen. Charles de Gaulle have done much more than agree on the terms of a treaty of mutual assistance against Germany.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Col. Francis V. Keesling, Selective Service legislative office, told a Senate committee today that the manpower program should be extended to compel youthful 4-F's to accept war work wherever possible.
SARREGUEMINES, France, Dec. 12 -- Pfc. Edmund La Liberte of Gerdener, Mass., press camp jeep driver extraordinary, almost qualified for an Oak leaf cluster for his Purple Heart today.

IF they were a little rusty from lack of practice since the season closed, the baseball men didn't show it yesterday. They attended to their lobby sitting chores with the elegant expertness of many years' practice, draping themselves over divans until they seemed to blend into the furniture, the true test of a high-grade lobby sitter.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, entering almost at the last minute into litigation long drawn out, has become a party to a suit scheduled to be argued before the United States Supreme Court this week, which may set the pattern for foreign exchange leadership throughout the world, it was revealed yesterday.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 13 (U.P.) -- Russian tanks and infantry yesterday cracked the last major fort guarding the northeastern approaches to Budapest, capturing the nine-way road and rail hub of Goedoelloe, nine and a half miles from the Hungarian capital. Moscow and Berlin radio broadcasts said that the Red Army had entered the city's suburbs
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Communique 248:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- President Roosevelt was urged today by a delegation of school children from New York under the sponsorship of the Rally of Hope Committee to expedite the rescue of Jewish children in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Secretary Stettinius presented to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today the six men whom he and President Roosevelt have chosen to complete "the team" in the reorganized State Department.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- A ship carrying supplies of medicines, and soap and food parcels, like those supplied for prisoners of war, will shortly leave Lisbon, Portugal, for the German-occupied Channel Islands, it was announced today in the House of Commons by Home Secretary Herbert Morrison.

Possibly no single midweek day since the season opened means so much to the Giants as today, for it is expected to provide the answer to a question that has been bothering the squad since last Sunday, when Bill (Bazooka) Paschal had to be assisted off the field in the Redskin battle.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Leopold S. Amery, Secretary of State for India and Burma, repeated in the House of Commons today his pledge that Britain would help Burma to dominion status as soon as possible after the war. He said he believed that Burmese would welcome Britons as liberators.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 13 -- Bombers of the United States Eighth Air Force and the Royal Air Force made multiple attacks in Germany behind the western front yesterday and last night in their sustained campaign to choke off supplies from the enemy's Rhineland defense line.

Erie A. Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, has been elected national chairman of the American Cancer Society's campaign next April for a fund of $5,000,000 with which to start a large-scale offensive against cancer, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Frank E. Adair, president of the society. Dr. Adair also announced the election of Mr. Johnston as chairman of the society's newly created executive council.

Urging support for the modification of the indeterminate sentence law proposed by the Federal Corrections Act now pending in Congress. James V. Bennett, director of the United States Bureau of Prisons, deplored yesterday the present wide diversities in sentencing that "appear to arise merely from local prejudices or variations in the social attitudes of individual judges."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 6, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Notice was given the liberated countries today that Allied war needs must take priority over their appeals for materials to restore their shattered economies.

Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine shared the spotlight last night with stage, screen, radio and sports celebrities before 18,000 persons in Madison Square Garden at the third annual benefit of the Police Athletic League, "Stars Shine for P.A.L."
The New York Stock Exchange has suspended from dealings Nabco Liquidating Company on word that stockholders have approved a final liquidating distribution and dissolution of the company.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 12 -- The Schaffhausen Arbeiter Zeitung reported tonight from its special German correspondent that, after a riot in Cologne early last week during which six high Nazis were lynched after an air raid, the special tribunal for the defense of the Reich had condemned thirty civilian residents to be publicly hanged.
J.R. Hutchinson, who formerly directed the sales policy of The Sherwin Williams Company and subsidiaries on Kem-Tone, has been appointed manager in charge of sales.

Hailing the Dumbarton Oaks proposals as a long step forward in the substitution of law for force, Frederic R. Coudert, president of the American Society of International Law, warned the members of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York last night against the illusion that any treaty could assure permanent peace.
