WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Navy School for Air Evacuation of Casualties, which will introduce flying Navy nurses for the first time, will be organized at the Naval Air Station, Alameda, Calif., within the next few days. Vice Admiral Ross T. McIntire, Surgeon General of the Navy, announced today.

A prediction that "there will be plenty of furs to go around" despite fears of a short catch for the new season was made last night by Benjamin H. Herzig of Herzig Hart, Inc., at the annual meeting of the American Fur Merchants Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- The development of a new synthetic wool fiber from peanuts, readily adaptable to mixture with real wool, cotton and rayon for the manufacture of inexpensive textiles, was announced today by Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd.

ROME, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Three of four defending titleholders showed their stuff tonight in the second annual inter-Allied boxing tournament and when they had finished there appeared little reason to believe they couldn't go right on being bosses.

A young man is cheered up when the girl he has found he can't get along without tells him he won't have to. Almost anybody, skating along on the verge of bankruptcy, would be pleased to learn that his lamented great-great-uncle has left him a million dollars in his will.

Six months ago this week the first of the B-29's set the night afire over the Japanese home islands with the first attack on the steel-making city of Yawata on Kyushu. It was almost five months later before they appeared over Tokyo. Now to the almost nightly wailing of the sirens the Japanese have begun, according to the Berlin radio, a mass evacuation of their capital city of over 7,000,000 persons.

Miss Phyllis Anne Adams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Adams of 4 East Seventy-second Street, was married to Alexander Kirkland, actor, producer and director, yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents by the Rev. Cyrus R. Pangborn in the presence of relatives.

Although the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange lacked a trend yesterday and the volume was rather small, months that usually are traded in most actively closed 7 points higher to 17 points lower than on Monday, with the March, 1946, position showing the most loss.

Declaring that sober contemplation of the greatness of television's future had made him "get serious for the first time in my forty-three years on the stage and radio," Ed Wynn yesterday told 1,000 guests at a Television Broadcasters Association conference at the Commodore Hotel that the new art can be a "thing more dangerous than dynamite or the quintessence of good, depending upon how it is managed."

Resort clothes held the spotlight in yesterday's fashion shows. The special talent of Mrs. Rosette Pennington to select dresses that have genuine style and are in the medium-price range was evident when she presented her new Southern wear collection at her shop, Chez Rosette, 10 East Fifty-sixth Street.

Japanese workers at a Tokyo war plant have organized special units to increase production, in emulation of the Japanese suicide attack corps, the Japanese Domei agency said in a wireless dispatch reported yesterday by the Federal Communications Commission.

Willie Hoppe's reign as three-cushion billiard champion of the world came to an end last night at the Hotel Capitol as the perennial Boy Wonder bowed to Welker Cochran, San Francisco veteran, 50 -- 44, in a keenly contested thirty-one inning match.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- The Labor party executive committee shelved a half-dozen resolutions offered by powerful trade unions today condemning the Government's action in Greece and concocted one that would probably encounter little opposition at a convention of Prime Minister Churchill's Conservative supporters.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 12 -- Local investment companies or capital pools to supply, with Government cooperation, the funds needed for small business and new enterprises in the post-war period were proposed here today by Ferdinand Eberstadt, New York investment banker and former vice chairman of the War Production Board.

MOSCOW, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Boleslaw Berut, peasant-born president of the Polish National Council, predicted today that the new year would be ushered in by the formation of a Provisional Government of Poland dedicated to satisfying the land hunger of 8,000,000 landless peasants.

By excluding Newfoundland from the agreements reached at the recent International Civil Aviation Conference at Chicago, Great Britain has retained a "possible stranglehold" over the Atlantic, while the United States released its hold over the Pacific, Jack Nichols, vice president of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., charged yesterday.
PARIS, Dec. 12 -- After a ten-day trial, the Paris Court of Justice this evening sentenced to death Henri Lafont and Pierre Bony, leaders of the "French Gestapo," and seven of their principal aides.
CHARLES TOWN, W.Va., Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Charles Town Jockey Club announced late today that racing would be suspended until Friday because of snow and cold.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Senate, by a roll-call vote of 56 to 25, defeated this afternoon the St. Lawrence seaway proposal, which was offered as an amendment to the Rivers and Harbors Bill. Action followed reading to the Senate of a personal statement from President Roosevelt urging prompt adoption of the measure, which was submitted for the record by Senator George D. Aiken of Vermont, the principal proponent of the project.

Bernard M. Baruch declared yesterday that capitalism had proved itself the best economic system in the world "in peace and in war" and urged the support of private charity as the best means of preserving it.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Wednesday, Dec. 13 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Following is the text of the statement read by Secretary Stettinius before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today, also excerpts from James C. Dunn, Archibald MacLeish, Nelson Rockefeller and William L. Clayton, nominees for top positions in the department:

ROME, Dec. 12 -- Alongside the political contrasts between Italy and France are certain similarities which stand out conspicuously because the status of the two Governments and the two nations is so different. The French regime, while provisional, is not only completely independent of foreign powers but is acting with the definite authority of a duly elected and permanent Government.
LONDON, Dec. 12 -- The stock markets here generally were quiet today. Industrials were steady, but with the absence of support some of the leaders eased a few pence.

A banking group headed by the Bankers Trust Company received yesterday the award of a new issue of $4,903,000 State of Minnesota rural credit bonds on a bid of 100.40 for 1.10s. The bonds, dated Dec. 15. 1944, will mature on June 15, 1954. The bankers announced that subject to formal award, the bonds will be reoffered to the public at 101 1/4.

It will be possible for the United States to cut its debt burden by one-half during the next generation even if no payment on the principal is made, provided economic and tax policies are followed which will stimulate new enterprises and the largest possible total payroll,
LONDON, Dec. 12 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Ber lin and recorded by The United Press:

The annual report of the Outboard, Marine and Manufacturing Company disclosed yesterday a net income of $1,087,013 for the year ended with September, after taxes, provision for post-war adjustment and renegotiation of war contracts.

ROME, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Eighth Army offensive aimed at the north Italian road-hub town of Faenza was brought to a standstill today as floods from the Apennines turned the Lamone River into a torrent. Capture of Faenza would unlock the entire German defense system behind the river.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- While members of the French Government awaited details of the French-Russian alliance signed in Moscow on Sunday and the entire Paris press welcomed it enthusiastically without awaiting details, the most authoritative comment today came from a special correspondent of the official French news agency who accompanied Gen. Charles de Gaulle to Moscow and is the semi-official spokesman for the General.

Crowns and brims of many shapes and sizes fill the highly decorative cases that line the walls of the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. A hundred hats from three centuries and many countries constitute the exhibition, "Hats and Headdresses," which is the first that the institute has shown under its new name.

The American Power and Light Company, a unit in the Electric Bond and Share Company system, concluded yesterday arrangements for the sale of its Nebraska subsidiary, the Nebraska Power Company, to a non-profit corporation organized by citizens of Omaha.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 12 -- With Australia the base for Britain's Pacific Fleet under Admiral Sir Bruce A. Fraser, as Pearl Harbor is for the United States Fleet, naval authorities here are planning to accommodate many thousands of Royal Navy personnel, it was declared today.
GUATEMALA, Dec. 12 -- A well-armed revolt against the Government of Col. Osmin Aguirre y Salinas is under way, according to a broadcast by the clandestine radio Voz de la Liberacion in El Salvador.

Richard Manning, the young tenor who joined the roster of the Metropolitan Opera this season, made his recital debut at Town Hall last night. Mr. Manning has a pleasing stage presence and a competent voice, though little of his singing was either particularly distinguished or unusually proficient.
The regional Office of Price Administration made a temporary change in its regulations yesterday to increase the shipment of dressed turkeys to New York and other Eastern cities.

A resolution calling on the War Production Board to allocate low-priced goods immediately to the popular-priced dress industry was adopted yesterday at a special meeting of the Popular Priced Dress Manufacturers Group at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

Yesterday's announcement of the institution of thirty-day furloughs in the United States for outstanding veterans of our soldiers in France marks a new Army policy. It is a policy that is long overdue and as yet incomplete, but for understandable reasons.
ROME, Dec. 12 -- Premier Ivanoe Bonomi, in the presence of his Ministers, took the oath of office before Crown Prince Humbert this afternoon in the same terms as those employed last June.

By an act of Congress, April has been designated as "Cancer Control Month." The American Cancer Society seizes the opportunity to press its educational work on a new scale and with new energy. A campaign to raise $5,000,000 is to be directed by a board of which Eric Johnston is the chairman and which numbers among its members representatives of labor, business, the press and Congress.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- In another effort to raise the output of lagging munitions the War Production Board has quietly undertaken a "tightening up" of its own scheduling procedure. With this it hopes to assure delivery of critical component parts, engines and other essential elements of war equipment to the most urgent programs.
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted in English by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Federal Water and Gas Corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan for the recapitalization of Scranton-Spring Brook (Pa.) Water Service Company, and for elimination of the Pennsylvania Water Service Company parent of Scranton-Spring Brook.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Chinese troops, advancing a dozen miles into Kwangsi Province down the Kweichow-Kwangsi Railway, captured the railway town of Nantan and the near-by town of Mangchang today, the Chinese High Command announced.

A well-known American woman, now visiting France, reports that she "saw fat, happy, healthy little children playing in Paris parks and they all seemed to be wearing fur coats, while the British just don't seem to be able to get enough to wear for winter." This observation was made in order to support the argument that Parisians are no worse off than the Londoners.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 12 -- Judge J. Wallace Leyden in Bergen County Court here today handed down a ruling authorizing the Hartford Accident and Indemnity Company and the Hackensack Trust Company to sue a bookmaker for $25,813, the amount the bookmaker took from a former employe of the bank and wagered on horses.

Cooperation of the Association of Customers' Brokers in the joint educational campaign of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the securities industry to protect war-bond investors was sought yesterday by Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, in an address before the association, which met in the Governors' Room of the Exchange.

Four ubeaten basketball teams, a novelty even if the court campaign still is in its early stages, will be seen in action tonight at Madison Square Garden, where the third of the season's college doubleheaders will be presented. The pairings send St. John's against Utah and N.Y.U. against the Oklahoma Aggies, with the former contest listed for an 8:15 P.M. opener.

Charges that the La Guardia Administration was discriminating against the war veteran who seeks to return to his city job were made yesterday by members of both the minority and majority when the City Council adopted three measures offered as "minimum proposals" for the protection of the rights of city employes now in the armed services.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
Increasing sales of Series E bonds, which the Treasury has been emphasizing as the most important in the Sixth War Loan, were recorded yesterday in the nation, New York State and New York City.

As the threat of a retail meat shutdown spread from New York to other cities, the Office of Price Administration sought yesterday to meet one of the principal demands of the embattled butchers by deciding to offer a new proposal for livestock price ceilings to Fred M. Vinson, Director of Economic Stabilization.

LONDON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- President Raczkiewicz appointed tonight an Acting Deputy Premier and three Cabinet Ministers inside Poland as the Government here sought from the underground army a new guide on policy to strengthen its shaky standing.

The appointment of Supreme Court justices by the Governor with later approval by the electorate after they had served a short trial term on the bench, was advocated yesterday by Samuel Seabury, former member of the Court of Appeals, and was supported by other leaders of the bar.
Jimmy Dykes, pilot of the White Sox, completed two trades yesterday, to add to the deal he made with the Yankees Monday.

There are times when an incoming attraction is preceded by glowing reports from the tryout centers, arousing the interest of one and all. In that category place "Dear Ruth," which Henry Miller's will welcome this evening after a series of transient tenants.

An old-fashioned nor'easter, severe in its effects, although this city experienced only high winds and a sprinkle of snow, blanketed sections of the East from Canada to Georgia with snow yesterday, and left parts of the West and Middle West still buried in drifts piled up in the preceding twenty-four hours.
Champions come through in a pinch. Americans hit hardest when a blow is needed most. That's why our military men confidently expect you to do your best in the tight spot your country is in now.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 12 -- A swift seven-mile advance toward Karlsruhe "corner" by doughboys of Lieut. Gen. Alexander M. Patch's American Seventh Army has created a new threat to the rich German industrial region along the Rhine from Karlsruhe north to Mannheim and Ludwigshafen.

Eugene Ormandy gave the most interesting concert that this writer has heard from him last night with the Philadelphia Orchestra in Carnegie Hall. In the past he has been so solicitous of tonal and technical detail and of a properly respectful approach to the music, that his readings were of the middle-of-the-road and sometimes of the negative order.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Secretary Perkins urged today the consolidation with the Department of Labor after the war of labor agencies now outside.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- The provision of food for the people of liberated Europe has become not only an urgent necessity on compassionate grounds but a political factor of overriding importance that may even decide between peace and civil war.

ALBANY, Dec. 12 -- The grand jury investigating crime in Albany County asked Supreme Court Justice Parton Swift today to hold in contempt Donald V. Lynch, 29-year-old deputy county treasurer of Albany County. Justice Swift held off a decision until Monday.

An editorial in THE TIMES on Thanksgiving Day stated that our custom of observing an annual National Thanksgiving Day was inaugurated by President Abraham Lincoln. This is incorrect. The first National Thanksgiving Day was set by act of the First Congress.

Need for periodic examination of automobile drivers as a post-war safety measure was urged yesterday at the tenth annual regional conference on highway and motor vehicle problems sponsored by the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation and the Council of State Governments at the Hotel Roosevelt.

"The Climax," which arrives at Loew's Criterion, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The Technicolor musical melodrama, produced by Universal, stars Boris Karloff, Susanna Foster and Turban Bey. Produced and directed by George Waggner, the film has a supporting cast including Gale Sondergaard, Thomas Gomez, Jane Farrar and June Vincent.

I have read with surprise and sorrow about the agitation in New Rochelle over the occupation of Fort Slocum by the Rehabilitation Center established by the Army. The United States has done a wonderful thing.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday were 1,014 against 1,424 last week and 696 in the similar period in 1943, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 398, which compared with 695 last Tuesday.

ROME, Dec. 12 -- The fact that the geography of the Italian campaign makes the country peculiarly susceptible to the work of spies was emphasized again today with the announcement that eight men, ranging in age from 20 to 27, have been executed by shooting.

LONDON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- American proposals for "complete and ruthless" abolition of German war industries and strict control of the country's future economy were reliably reported tonight to be under discussion by the European Advisory Commission as a part of a tough Allied plan to suppress Germany's aggressive powers forever.
Goodrich K. Murphy, formerly with the Matson Navigation Company, has been appointed district sales manager of the Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company.

A banking group headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and including Kidder, Peabody Co., F.S. Moseley Co. and Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc., received yesterday the award of an issue of $950,000 of city of Boston, Mass., municipal relief and public ways construction bonds on the basis of a net interest cost to the city of 0.87435 per cent.

Service men and women in this area who are eligible for six-day furloughs during the Christmas and New Year holidays will be prohibited from using public transportation on three days during each of the holiday periods, it was learned yesterday.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres today. At the Radio City Music Hall, the new attraction will be "National Velvet," Metro's adaptation of the Enid Bagnold novel, starring Mickey Rooney and Elizabeth Taylor. The drama, filmed in Technicolor, was directed by Clarence Brown and includes Donald Crisp, Jackie Jenkins, Arthur Treacher and Anne Revere among its supporting players.

Shipments of live poultry to this city are only one-twentieth of what they were at this time last year, the market news service of the War Food Administration reported yesterday. Total receipts for Monday, Tuesday and yesterday were 106,237 pounds, compared with 2,099,160 pounds for the comparable three-day period last year.

Rudolf Firkusny, the young pianist whose healthy and spontaneous musical instinct and substantial musicianship have gained him a very considerable following in this city, gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Coach Harold G. Olsen of Ohio State University, chairman of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's basketball tournament committee, announced today the N.C.A.A. 1945 final would be held in New York's Madison Square Garden on March 27. The final will match the winners of the Western and Eastern division play-offs.

WITH THE UNITED STATES SEVENTH ARMY Near the Siegfried Line, Dec. 13 (AP) -- One of the Maginot Line forts passed today by the Seventh Army in its drive toward the Palatinate had concrete walls from four to six feet thick, but the Germans made no use of it.
LONDON, Dec. 18 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

LONDON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Britain's largest metropolitan area -- London -- is big enough, and further expansion should be prohibited while its factories and 10,000,000 inhabitants are reshuffled for a more reasonable and decent standard of living, it was recommended tonight.

A total of $764,231.58 in eleven checks was distributed to nine beneficiaries yesterday as New York racing's contribution to charities from the Victory meeting held in November by the State's five racing associations and the United Hunts at Belmont Park under the auspices of the Turf Committee of America.
Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that he would declare a state of emergency in the city if the shutdown by meat retailers of their shops, scheduled to start Christmas Day, made such action necessary.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cottonseed crushed in the four-month period, Aug. 1 to Nov. 30, totaled 1,591,991 tons, compared with 1,885,885 tons in the corresponding period a year ago.

OPA is reported to favor the imposition of ceilings on livestock to meet the complaints of butchers that they are being squeezed. The War Food Administration has consistently opposed the adoption of such ceilings. A little over a year ago, however, OPA attempted to set ceilings indirectly without WFA approval by relating subsidy payments to designated price ranges for various grades of cattle.
PARIS, Dec. 13 -- The trial of Jean Angeli, former Prefect of Lyon accused of intelligence with the enemy, will begin tomorrow.

PARIS, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The United States Army newspaper Stars and Stripes talked back editorially today to the Army and Navy Journal's criticism of British war policy with a recital of Britain's war record, summing up:

The nation's gasoline stocks at the close of last week were 80,880,000 barrels, of which 41,170,000 were civilian-grade automotive, 12,969,000 unfinished and 26,741,000 aviation, military and blending stocks indeterminate as to ultimate use, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- An official spokesman for the Army Air Forces, questioned today about reports issued by the Japanese late last month in which they claimed to have landed troops on Morotai, an island in the Halmahera group that we wrested from them prior to the Philippines invasion, said the enemy claims were absolutely without foundation.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Nazi preparations to prolong German resistance by guerrilla warfare and propaganda after the collapse of the Wehrmacht were reported by American Army channels today as Heinrich Himmler predicted that "this war will end in victory for us" and Dr. Joseph Goebbels expressed confidence that "we shall master the air war -- our worst headache."

Confidence in China's ability to cope with the serious military situation that has developed as a result of recent Japanese advances war voiced yesterday by Dr. Mai Chi-chen, counselor of the Chinese Embassy, in an address in Town Hall.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Four million temporary and permanent houses in five years were among the demands made by 600 women, representing thousands of housewives and war workers from all parts of England, Scotland and Wales, who marched to the House of Commons today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Senate Committee on Military Affairs approved today President Roosevelt's first two nominees for the task of disposing of an estimated $100,000,000,000 of surplus war property.
William O'Neil and Associates, industrial designers, to S. Duane Lyon, Inc. Newspapers and trade publications will be used beginning Jan. 1.

Seated in a reception room of the Thomas P. Madine Funeral Parlor at 650 Tenth Avenue, Thomas Gleason, 45 years old, a stevedore, of Bogota, N.J., was shot dead yesterday afternoon by an unidentified person who entered a few moments after Alfred Cristie, a caretaker, who had been talking with Mr. Gleason, left the room.

No thoughtful American will offer as excuse for non-participation or minimum participation in the Sixth War Loan that he has bought war bonds in previous drives or has fulfilled his obligation by buying a minimum amount of this gilt-edge security.

ROME, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Canadian units of the British Eighth Army quickly took advantage of newly won Lamone River bridgeheads northeast of Faenza today to drive a wedge almost three miles deep into the German defenses.

ATHENS, Dec. 13 (U.P.) -- Greek Elas officials were reported today to have prepared counter-proposals to British peace terms as violent fighting continued in the capital. It was understood that the Central Committee of the Eam, the political arm of the National Liberation party, had debated for hours over Lieut. Gen. Ronald M. Scobie's peace conditions without arriving at a definite decision.

The man who caught a world record black drum of ninety-two pounds, Herschel P. Layton of Cape May, N.J., will receive the Governor Walter E. Edge Trophy, chief prize in New Jersey's fourth annual Governor's fishing tournament, at the State House in Trenton today. Announcement that Layton entered the outstanding catch of the tournament, along with the names of other winners, was made yesterday.

CHUNGKING, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Gen. Fang Hsien-chueh, commandder of the Chinese Tenth Army, accused the Japanese today of ruthlessly slaughtering several Chinese prisoners after the fall of Hengyang, and personally voiced his shame over failing to hold the city or take his own life following his defeat.

With the Sixth War Loan drive scheduled to end on Saturday, sales in the nation reached $15,874,000,000 at the close of business on Tuesday, it was announced yesterday by Treasury officials in Washington. This was far past the goal of $14,000,000,000 originally set for the drive.
New York's wartime housing shortage has reached a critical stage, with the prospect that it will become more acute in the next two months.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 13 -- Police Capt. John Sinnott and Detective Lieut. James Menge of the First Precinct were even up today with detectives of the Prosecutor's office in the matter of gambling arrests in the precinct.

I have just read your column of summary entitled "Consumer Pinch," and wonder if it isn't about time to reveal to the American public where our food supply actually is going. Even for a nation so gullible and indifferent as we are, Americans have been too readily satisfied with the explanation that "the armed forces are taking it."

Uneven movements in pivotal sections gave the stock market a ragged appearance yesterday. The steel issues eased, but selective strength ruled elsewhere. Those stocks which attracted the best interest were able to show moderate gains, but industrial news and developments tended to limit activity in other sections of the list.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The War Labor Board upheld today its newspaper commission's order that union membership maintenance, hours and overtime provisions be included in a contract between The Associated Press, New York office, and the American Newspaper Guild.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The Times, London, dissents editorially from the Government view that Premier George Papandreou and the British forces in Greece are opposing only a left-wing minority that will be overcome soon. In comment to be published in Thursday's edition, the newspaper says "the battle, which is not going too well, threatens to become a war."

HERE is good news: an edition of Henry James' notebooks, which run from 1878 to 1914 and contain 150,000 words, is being prepared by F.O. Matthiessen and Kenneth B. Murdock. This fact is mentioned in Mr. Matthiessen's new volume, "Henry James: The Major Phase."*

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The production of rockets which can be used to blast the Japanese off their beachheads and out of their fortifications will be increased by the Navy "nearly 300 per cent" within a few months, Rear Admiral George F. Hussey Jr., Chief of the Bureau of Ordnance, said in a statement released by the Navy today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Norman Armour, career diplomat and former Ambassador to Argentina, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to be Ambassador to Spain in place of Carlton J.H. Hayes, who has resigned. The nomination was quickly approved by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Soviet Russia is understood to favor establishing the permanent secretariat of the proposed United Nations Security Organization in Vienna after the war.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 13 -- Armed with an injunction, agents of the Office of Price Administration brought to an abrupt end here tonight the lavish bids being made at auction for the household furnishings of Thomas F. Manville Jr. The sale continued with prices restricted to OPA ceilings.

The Bank of New York sold to the Fifth-Thirty-second Street Realty Corporation the four-story building or a plot 38 by 138 feet at 319 Fifth Avenue, at the northeast corner of Thirty-second Street. The property is assessed at $340,000 and was sold through Ames, Cunehan Newman, Inc.

Ganson Purcell, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, told the New York section of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers last night in the Engineering Societies Building, 33 West Thirty-ninth Street, that "the end of the job of integration of holding-company systems is in sight."

ALBANY, Dec. 13 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein ruled today that the 1944 Todd law prohibiting pay discrimination because of sex was not enforceable against the State and municipalities and was not intended by the Legislature to be so enforced.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 13 (AP) -- As Chinese troops scored still further gains in Kwangsi Province, P.H. Chang, Cabinet spokesman, announced today that the High Command was considering how to meet possible new emergencies and plans for making the best use of every opportunity to take the military initiative.

Disabled veterans of World War II should file their claims with the Government immediately on being discharged, Dow V. Walker of Portland, Ore., chairman of the finance committee of the Disabled American Veterans National Service Fund, declared yesterday on a tour of the Veterans Administration Hospital, Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx.

KANDY, Ceylon, Dec. 13 (U.P.) -- British East African patrols, advancing into central Burma along the Kalewa-Ye-u road, have entered Shwegyin, five miles southeast of Kalewa, under fire from Japanese positions east and north of the village, a southeast Asia command communique announced today.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- A voluntary plan of liquidation has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the American Utilities Service Corporation, the SEC disclosed today.

Directors of the American Bantam Car Company declared yesterday a 30-cent dividend on the preferred stock, payable on Jan. 31. Preferred shareholders received an initial dividend of 60 cents on Aug. 31. Francis H. Fenn, president and chairman, revealed that during the last few months the company had changed from the manufacture of high-precision, high-cost units to the mass production of small-cost units.
KANDY, Ceylon, Dec. 13 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Twentieth Air Force communique 31: Nagoya, home of the Mitsubishi aircraft plant and one of Japan's four principal industrial manufacturing centers, was the target of a sizable force of Twenty-first Bomber Command B-29's today, Gen. H.H. Arnold, in his capacity as Commanding General of the Twentieth Air Force, announced at the War Department.

No one knows better than a sailor or a soldier how lonesome and alone one can be in the midst of great throngs. It is not surprising, then, that the response to the Hundred Neediest Cases has been so spontaneous among service men and women as first reports of the Fund indicate.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 13 (UP) -- Communique 249:

Virtually all of the estate of Louis Ferguson, furniture manufacturer, who died on Jan. 6, 1941, goes to charity. This was disclosed yesterday in a transfer tax proceeding, which showed that he left a gross estate of $2,715,862 and a net of $2,224,855.

The A.O. Smith Corporation, producer of military equipment and airplane parts, reported yesterday in its statement of operations for the quarter ended on Oct. 31 a consolidated net profit of $1,386,534 after all charges, including $8,502,113 for State and Federal taxes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Construction of enough new plants "from the ground up" to provide the armed forces with an additional 4,000,000 tires a year and expansion of present facilities to increase production another 6,400,000 tires have been ordered to satisfy sudden military demands for "the most critical of all" munitions programs, Hiland G. Batcheller, chief of operations of the War Production Board, disclosed today.

HEADQUARTERS OF 21ST BOMBER COMMAND, on Saipan, Marianas, Dec. 13 -- Published estimates of the damage wrought by Superfortress raids on Tokyo reveal an overoptimism that is not shared by airmen here, where these flights originate, because weather conditions have permitted little photographic reconnaissance over Tokyo.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Business was quiet again in today's stock markets, with price changes small and irregular.

WASHINGTON, Dec. -- Forty- eight hours after seventy-three "basic" steel companies had requested the War Labor Board to reconsider its directive in the steel case, the board denied the petition. The vote today was 8 to 4, with public and labor members voting against the industry members.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 13 -- Columbia has named Lee Bowman to be co-starred in "Dear Mr. Private," a story of the romantic complications which ensue when a 12-year-old girl corresponds with a soldier in the name of her older sister. The screen play by Joseph Hoffman will be directed by Charles Vidor after he finishes the forthcoming "Over Twenty-one."

The same British State Secretary who turns a granite face toward Mr. Gandhi was almost casual this week in reiterating his promise that Burma would be given dominion status as soon as possible after the war. The contrast is the more interesting because Burma was ruled as part of India until 1937.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Dec. 13 -- William T. Smith, industrial financier and manager and building consultant at 39 Broadway, New York, was found shot through the head at 8 A.M. today in his home here. His wife, Mrs. Gertrude H. Smith, found his body after hearing a revolver shot. Mr. Smith was 60 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The sustained questioning to which Will L. Clayton was subjected by Senators, in contrast to the perfunctory interrogation of some other major State Department appointees, justifies the belief in the press gallery, when the Senate re-committed all these nominations, that Mr. Clayton was the chief cause of that action.
ROME, Dec. 13 (UP) -- A communique:

Benefits assured to post-war projects of New York and other municipalities through the extension of Federal aid funds in acquiring rights of way for city thoroughfares were outlined yesterday by Thomas H. MacDonald, Federal Public Roads Commissioner, at the tenth annual regional conference on highway and motor vehicle problems sponsored by the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation and the Council of State Governments at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Many of us, before the European invasions began, probably thought of a wave of abundance moving over the liberated lands as the armies advanced. Martyred nations had been hungry. Now they would eat. They had been cold. Now they would have fuel, good houses and warm clothing.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 13 -- Eighteen hundred employes of the International-Plainfield Motor Company quit work or did not report for work today in a renewal of a dispute with the management over seniority. Production of parts for Army trucks was reported at a standstill tonight.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Assuming his share of responsibility and defending the Government, of which he is a member, Ernest Bevin, Minister of Labor, told his Labor party colleagues today that the British action in Greece had been taken with the knowledge and approval of Russia and the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The War Production Board reported today that supplies of two formerly critical items of industrial equipment, fractional horsepower motors and industrial diamonds, should be adequate to meet essential civilian demands throughout the next several months.

Recent changes in the Zoning Law have caused "doubt" and "confusion," resulting in a complete stoppage of plans for postwar building in retail areas of the city, the Citizens Zoning Committee charged yesterday in a letter signed by Robert W. Dowling and addressed to the City Planning Commission.

Among the many gift suggestions to be found at the Schrafft stores is one that combines gastronomical goodness with practicality. It's an attractive pottery casserole that holds the company's famous fruitcake in a one-and-a-half-pound size.

In a letter to Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Secretary of State, the Union of Democratic Action declared yesterday that the world organization projected at Dumbarton Oaks "cannot be realized unless the great powers reach common agreement on the democratic reconstruction of Europe," and called upon the United States to act as mediator in the conflict in Greece.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 13 (AP) -- When materials and manpower become available building contractors will face a huge task constructing and rehabilitating State-owned buildings, highways and other facilities, State Public Works Superintendent Charles H. Sells said today.

Now that "Little Women" is on the stage and in the movies, while Poland continues in the forefront of the news, we have one more proof that this is One World: or, as we used to say formerly, that this is a small world.

Small concerns now heavily engaged in war production are in such a precarious working capital position that they may succumb to relatively minor difficulties resulting from cutbacks, renegotiation, termination and discounting of inventory, even before they are confronted with the difficult problems of financing reconversion, according to detailed analysis of the balance sheets of 125 small companies issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

The No. 1 service football team of the year, Randolph Field's Ramblers of Texas, flew into New York yesterday for the Treasury Bond Bowl game at the Polo Grounds on Saturday with the Second Air Force Superbombers of Colorado Springs.

At the beginning of the sixth week of their offensive the Allied armies which have been hammering the Germans along the whole western front have launched a new assault. The southern wing of the American First Army, which fought its way through the Huertgen Forest, has now swept beyond it in a drive toward the Rhine city of Bonn.

GUATEMALA, Dec. 13 -- A broadcast from the Salvadorean rebel station "Voice of Liberation" reported yesterday that immediately following the occupation of Ahuachapam by the "liberating" army, unidentified planes made a reconnaissance flight, followed by a merciless bombing that lasted from 7:15 A. M. to 9:50 A. M.

Wide fenders, slanting windshields and shiny surfaces are criticized in letters on automobile construction from readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES in answer to queries compiled by the Society of Automotive Engineers. The perils of sunlight were outlined yesterday by a California motorist and another in New Mexico.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Board of Incorporators of the American Red Cross elected as new members today at the annual meeting Basil O'Connor, whose reappointment by President Roosevelt as chairman was announced; Aaron M. Frank of Portland, Ore., and Mrs. Stuart Chevalier of Pasadena, who wrote the official history of the American Red Cross Nursing Service.

Last night's performance of "Lucia," the first of the season at the Metropolitan, was generally a lacklustre affair, with little more than competence on the stage and some uninspired playing in the pit. It had neither pace nor style, and the elaborate Metropolitan sets and costumes did not help to detract attention from the fact.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were quiet yesterday. The more active positions closed 6 points higher to 9 points lower than on Tuesday.

" The Holiday Parade," an exhibit of Christmas gifts that also offers fresh ideas for displaying Santa's shipment at home, opens today in the gallery of America House, 485 Madison Avenue. Since all the gifts are hand-made, representing a cross section of the work of America House craftsmen, some of the simpler items might suggest make-it-yourself ideas to the home-maker.

Norman Littell, whom President Roosevelt recently dismissed as assistant United States attorney general, charged yesterday that Attorney General Francis Biddle "lied when he said my testimony before Congress had nothing to do with my discharge."

ROME, Dec. 13 -- Many Germans who hope for a gentler peace than they can expect from the Allies directly are believed to be pinning at least tentative hopes on the Papal Nuncio in Berlin, Mgr. Cesare Orsenigo.

All production of worsted goods will be frozen for five months beginning on Jan. 1, it was learned yesterday, with mill output to be reserved for "rated" orders exclusively. The War Production Board is working on the order which, it is said, will be issued within the next few days.
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted in English by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Announcement of an advance of 4 cents a bushel in the ceiling price for cash wheat late yesterday by the Office of Price Administration was in line with trade expectations and had comparatively little effect today on futures.

Although the railroads had opposed a further suspension of the freight-rate rise, it had been anticipated generally that because of the opposition of Government agencies and several State regulatory bodies their plea would not be granted. For more than a year the net income of the Class I carriers has been declining, reflecting wage rises and other operating costs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Senate action on a bill to revive and expand the Federal crop insurance program was delayed today by an effort to tie on a rider amendment.

If technical prowess alone were the standard of comparison, Jakob Gimpel, who gave a recital in Town Hall last night, would rank among the foremost pianists of the day. For there are few who could give a better account of the Brahms Variations on a Theme of Paganini, Books I and II, with which the Polish-born artist finished a rather strangely put-together program.
LONDON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden declined to confirm or deny today reports that Germans and Bulgarians had been serving with Elas forces battling British troops in Greece.

The spring color combination of the Men's Fashion Guild of New York will be blue and gold, it was announced yesterday at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel, where the twenty-nine members of the group displayed their offerings. The merchandise bears the guild crest, and will be featured entirely separate from regular spring lines.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Thursday, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A communique:

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 13 -- Navy forces today occupied refineries belonging to the state petroleum monopoly in La Plata, the capital of the Province of Buenos Aires, which were threatened by a strike called suddenly by the workers yesterday.

In spite of the prospects for the end of the war m Europe, 1945 food goals for the nation have been set as high as in 1944, the year of the greatest agricultural production in American history, Dr. William C. Ockey, chief of the Civilian Food Requirements Branch of the Office of Distribution. War Food Administration, announced yesterday.

Moving with alacrity to wind up their three-day conclave, the club owners of the National and American Leagues, sitting in joint session at the Hotel New Yorker, yesterday, decided to continue their program of unlimited night ball for 1945, voted to bar football games from major league parks until all baseball engagements scheduled for those parks have been played and passed sundry other legislative matters swiftly and according to general expectations.

Little Annette Frustace, wearing her best black velvet dress with red bows, admitted that she thought her golden tiara fitted very well as she was crowned queen of the show at the eleventh annual little sister beauty contest, held yesterday in the auditorium of the Boys Club of New York, Avenue A and Tenth Street.

Catholic, Jewish and Protestant young men and women students at Barnard and Columbia Colleges in Columbia University learned about the similarities of their religious beliefs at an informal dance held in Earl Hall on the campus to celebrate Christmas and Hanukkah, Hebrew Festival of Light and Dedication.
A communique, as broadcast in English to North America by the Japanese Domei Agency yesterday and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Mankind's failure throughout history to develop a workable peace machinery should constitute the basis for study in setting up a new world security program of the kind proposed at Dumbarton Oaks, Joseph C. Grew, former Ambassador to Japan said here today.

WITH UNITED STATES ARMY, Dec. 13 -- Fort Jeanne d'Arc, last of twenty-two major fortifications ringing Metz, fell today. This garrison of 502 Germans held out for twenty-one days in a hopelessly isolated position.

ROME, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Paced by Pvt. Ezzard Charles of Cincinnati, who was considerably better than a green hand in civilian life and now looms as the classiest clouter in this competition, American service men dominated the third day of the Mediterranean inter-Allied boxing championships by winning nine bouts, five in international competition.

NINTH U.S. AIR FORCE ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, Dec. 13 -- Five members of the crew of a Ninth Air Force B-26 Marauder bomber were forced to jump from the frying pan into the fire when their plane, riddled by flak, began to lose altitude over a field where a fierce artillery battle was progressing between United States guns and those of the Germans.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Criticism of Great Britain and Russia provoked debate in Congress today, with Democrats in the House warning against discussions which might spread disunity among the Allies and give aid to the Axis.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, after delving into the diverse problems of cotton and poetry, deferred action today on the nominations of six men to high posts in the State Department pending a search by Senator Joseph F. Guffey, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, for diplomatic reports on the Spanish civil war, which, he contended, appeared to have been withheld from President Roosevelt and former Secretary Hull.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission, by a vote of 7 to 2, decided today to suspend for another year the freight rate increases granted in March, 1942, and subsequently twice held in abeyance. The decision allows the present rates to continue until Jan. 1, 1946.
Secretary Perkins, speaking before the National Conference on Labor Legislation, said:
PARIS, Dec. 13 -- The Lyon City Council has warned the central authority in Paris that, in its view, the ration of fats is so small that resistance to disease is dangerously reduced.

The Empire State Warehouses Corporation has purchased the eight-story warehouse at the southwest corner of Nostrand and Gates Avenues, Brooklyn, from the Manufacturers Trust Company, as trustee. A portion of the premises, at 372-78 Gates Avenue, is leased to Frederick Loeser Co., which has sublet three floors to the United States Army Air Corps.
PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Another complaint about the treatment of German prisoners by the Americans appeared in the newspaper Ce Soir today.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Thursday, Dec. 14 -- Troops of the United States Seventh Division in Ormoc, on the Leyte Island west coast, are cleaning out pockets of Japanese resistance to the east of American positions, while the Seventyseventh Division maintains pressure to the north, Gen. Douglas MacArthur said today.

Although sales of surplus materials located in foreign countries have been insignificant as yet, the Foreign Economic Administration has developed a procedure to handle what it believes will be a swelling volume of such business abroad, it was learned yesterday.

GUAM, Dec. 13 -- Ten members of Congress, composing a subcommittee of the House Committee on Naval Affairs, viewed some of the tremendous military projects here today before departing for Manus in the Admiralty Islands.

A letter in THE TIMES of Dec. 3 from Miss Claire E. Fischer expresses fear that our citizens will not try to understand or realize the importance of the Dumbarton Oaks proposals for a general international organization to keep the peace, but will begin to object when the charter for such an organization is ready to be adopted.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- One European Government in exile that is determined to avoid any clash with the resistance forces in its country or any calling in of Allied armies to keep the peace is that of Czechoslovakia.

The question Giant football fans have been asking ever since a prowling Redskin injured Bill Paschal's ankle, viz., whether the league-leading ground gainers will be able to play against the Packers in Sunday's championship game, won't be answered at least until today.

Income tax refund checks are being sent out as quickly as possible and interest at the rate of 6 per cent will be included in the amount of each refund, James W. Johnson, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Third District of New York, with offices at 110 East Forty-fifth Street, announced yesterday.

The Home Front Mobilization Division of the New York War Fund has raised 83 per cent, or $4,736,982, of its quota of $5,647,000, Newbold Morris City Council President and home front section chairman, disclosed last night at a dinner held in the Murray Hill Hotel for volunteer workers to hear reports on campaign progress.

BUFFALO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Buffalo Arms Corporation plant in Cheektowaga, employing 2,000, will suspend the manufacture of machine guns for Army planes on Feb. 1 to release workers for the production of munitions, such as heavy shells, which are more urgently needed.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- A battle of specialists seems likely Sunday when the Packers invade New York to tangle with the Giants for the National Football League championship.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Miss Mabel Boardman retired today from the Central Committee of the American Red Cross after forty-four years of service and received a unique Red Cross gold medal at a testimonial luncheon.

The War Production Board's allocation of 10,000,000 yards of cotton fabrics in the first quarter of 1945 for over-the-counter sales in small town stores will hardly begin to satisfy demand, wholesalers in the primary market asserted yesterday.

MOSCOW, Dec. 13 -- New reports of political assassinations in Poland reached Moscow from Lublin today coincidentally with further progress in carrying out land reform and new outward manifestation of popular demand that the Polish Committee of National Liberation transform itself into a Provisional Government, thus ending further chances of unity talks with the London exiles' Government.

James F. Roe, who is believed to have defrauded Ellis Island deportees and war internees of $200,000 in the last ten years, was sentenced yesterday to a Sing Sing term of four to eight years for what Judge John J. Sullivan in General Sessions described as "the most amazing duplicity I ever have heard of."

In what must be regarded as the first major upset of the local college basketball campaign, New York University's highly rated quintet suffered a 44-41 setback at the hands of the Oklahoma Aggies last night at Madison Square Garden. Before the Violets, who had won their first three starts, dropped from the unbeaten class, St. John's of Brooklyn overcame some faulty shooting and defeated Utah, 39 -- 36.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- A writer in the newspaper Aurore, edited by Paul Bastid, long a member of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Chamber of Deputies, gave two striking interpretations of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's journey to Moscow today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- A greater shortage of cigarettes than the present one faces civilians next year because of the industry's inability to expand production as the demand rises, representatives of manufacturers and distributors told a Senate committee investigating the situation today.

Soccer will make its contribution to the Sixth War Loan when New York's four professional clubs of the American Soccer League and the four outstanding amateur teams participate in the indoor War Bond tournament at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory tonight, starting at 8 o'clock.

The Office of Price Administration gave Thomas F. Manville Jr. formal recognition as a "personality" yesterday and got out a Federal court order restraining him and a squad of auctioneers from violating OPA regulations. The order was signed by Judge William Bondy after the OPA had made representations that the asbestos heir, in selling the contents of his Bon Repos estate at New Rochelle, was endangering the fight against inflation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The two-thirds vote rule in the Senate on treaty ratifications threatens a shift of power from Congress to the President, the House Judiciary Committee said today, as it approved legislation to offer a constitutional amendment authorizing the ratification of treaties by simple majorities of both Senate and House.

December is low twelve of Nature's day. No hope now of a period of Indian summer. From now on it's simply an occasional spell of warmer weather. The venerable Turn Key, Winter, has inserted his implement in the padlock, and snapped the combination. Snow covers the northland; the woodchucks, bears, turtles, frogs and toads are dug in for the long siege.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 13 -- Strong forces of Lieut. Gen. Courtney H. Hodges' American First Army have opened two initially successful attacks north and south of the Roer dams, while other divisions of the First Army hammer stubborn German rear-guards back into the Roer River and move closer to the defenses of Dueren.

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 14 -- Red Army tanks and infantry yesterday smashed two vital forts within Budapest's inner defense ring, capturing the suburban towns of Kisalag and Isaszeg, six miles north and eight miles east of the Hungarian capital, and unconfirmed enemy reports said fires were raging out of control in the city.

SIERENTZ, Southern Alsace, Dec. 13 -- Sister Elizabeth of the Congregation of Teaching Sisters of Ribeauville stood in front of the blackboard of a classroom in the Town Hall of Sierentz this morning and recited in French, "Hail Mary, full of grace * * *"

Senator Robert F. Wagner declared last night that it was "crucial" to the success of the proposed world security council that the United States representative on it have authority to commit a predetermined number of troops for use against aggression.

LONDON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- A German spokesman commented with "biting irony" today, the Berlin radio said, on Mayor La Guardia's statement that New Yorkers would not deal with the Germans for 100 years if New York were bombarded with V-3 weapons.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The War Production Board indicated today that a further cut in newsprint allocations may be necessary by the second quarter of 1945, if not before.
LONDON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:
ROME, Dec. 13 -- The Allied Commission is having its own crisis now that the Government's is over.

DETROIT, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Heads of more than 100 CIO local unions of the Detroit area flung their support behind the strike at four Montgomery Ward Co. stores tonight, promising "fullest moral, financial and physical" aid to the walkout.

Twenty-five hundred blind men and women employed on Government orders since 1939 have earned wages exceeding $4,000,000 by their manufacture of brooms, mops, pillow-cases and similar items for the armed services, M.C. Migel, president of the American Foundation for the Blind, announced yesterday in his annual report, submitted at the organization's headquarters at 15 West Sixteenth Street.

LONDON, Dec. 13 (U.P.) -- A powerful fleet of Royal Air Force heavy bombers last night set great fires burning in the Ruhr industrial center of Essen, site of two German coke plants, while other British planes attacked the four-way rail hub of Osnabrueck.

HEADQUARTERS OF 21ST BOMBER COMMAND, on Saipan, Marianas, Dec. 13 -- Superfortresses rained bombs today on Nagoya, Japan's third largest city, centering their attack upon the largest aircraft factory. Numerous explosions and fires were observed.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today permitted Federal Light and Traction Company to withdraw an application proposing the sale of its interest in the Springfield (Mo.) Gas and Electric Company to R.H. Teed of Hot Springs, Ark.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commissions:
ATHENS, Dec. 13 -- The Elas has increased the weight of its offensive during the last twenty-four hours to force a decision before the arrival of British reinforcements.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 13 -- American Army and Navy commanders of the Central Pacific and Aleutian war areas have just concluded secret conferences with Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander of the Pacific Ocean areas, dealing with future operations against Japan.

In giving to help the neediest of all the families in the city disrupted by sickness or misfortune, the aged ill, the frustrated and lonely individuals, the abandoned children, some of the warm-hearted donors give through joy, and others from sorrow. But every gift carries joy and hope to these neighbors who are the neediest, in material aid, in wise and friendly guidance.

While the cause of rheumatic fever is still unknown and the symptoms follow varying patterns that make diagnosis difficult, greater strides against the disease could be made in this city if one "efficient and potent organization" were formed to integrate the efforts of all interested agencies, Dr. Charles R. Messeloff of the Cardiac Consultation Service of the Department of Health declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The annual National Labor Conference today adopted a resolution unanimously recommending that "all States move as rapidly as possible to extend the benefits of legal minimum wage rates of not less than 65 cents an hour to all workers."

Pointing out that the carpet and rug industry expects an increase of 53 per cent in sales in the post-war period over the average of five pre-war years, T. Hart Anderson Jr., president of Anderson, Davis Platte, Inc., advertising agency, outlined last night five steps that home furnishings departments should take now if they wish to realize their full potentialities after the war.

In giving to help the neediest of all the families in the city disrupted by sickness or misfortune, the aged ill, the frustrated and lonely individuals, the abandoned children, some of the warm-hearted donors give through joy, and others from sorrow. But every gift carries joy and hope to these neighbors who are the neediest, in material aid, in wise and friendly guidance.

While the cause of rheumatic fever is still unknown and the symptoms follow varying patterns that make diagnosis difficult, greater strides against the disease could be made in this city if one "efficient and potent organization" were formed to integrate the efforts of all interested agencies, Dr. Charles R. Messeloff of the Cardiac Consultation Service of the Department of Health declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Here are the votes by which the Senate Foreign Relations Committee recommended confirmation of five State Department appointees the six State Department appointees:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The American Light and Traction Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to a plan to construct a $70,000,000 natural gas pipeline from the Hugoton gas fields in Kansas, Oklahoma and Texas to Detroit with a branch extending to within Wisconsin.

ROME, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Germans flung all available reserves of armor and infantry into a furious attempt today to contain a Canadian bridgehead over the Lamone River and to save the nearby road center of Bagnacavallo, ten miles northeast of Faenza in the Po Valley.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Friday, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A communique:

FORT WILLIAM, Ont., Dec. 14 -- Higher by more than 70,000,000 bushels than the record made in 1928, shipments of Canadian grain this year from the twin lakehead ports of Fort William and Port Arthur amounted to 455,964,182 bushels, E.A. Ursell, statistician of the Canadian Board of Grain Commissioners, reported today. The mark for 1928 was 385,061,444 bushels.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Budget Message, scheduled for delivery to the new Congress early next month, is already in the stage of preliminary drafting for President Roosevelt, although Army and Navy estimates will not reach the Bureau of the Budget for a day or two.

Of the various ways open to those persons on the home front wishing to aid the war effort none is quite as direct and personal as to give of one's own blood for use in treatment of the wounded. Nearly everyone has some friend or relative who today is endangering his life in fighting for our way of life.

WASHINGTON, Friday, Dec. 15 -- Acting early this morning to avert a strike of 800 firemen on the Seaboard Air Line, set for noon today, President Roosevelt appointed a three-man emergency board under the Railway Labor Act to investigate the dispute and report back to him within thirty days.

RICHMOND, Calif., Dec. 14 (AP) -- While the big name golf professionals were struggling to control their shots in a brisk wind, Jimmy Walkup Jr., dark horse entry from San Antonio, slipped in with a subpar 68 today to become the first-round leader in the 72-hole Richmond open golf tournament for $7,500 in war bonds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Farm officials foresaw today no change in the Government's present two-price wheat system. Under the current program domestic markets are supported near parity levels, with wheat being offered abroad at a lower price and the difference being absorbed through Federal export subsidies.

Black market operations and hoarding practices are indicative of a breakdown in the business ethics of the nation, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager-on-leave of the National Association of Credit Men, said yesterday. The "curse" of such practices, he declared in his monthly business review sent to association members, is not condoned because most of the gouging takes place in so-called luxuries or services.

Investment by savings and loan associations in multi-family housing as a means of financing expansion of building projects in this area was proposed yesterday at the conference of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations held at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Application of the zoning law amendments dealing with building bulk and land area restrictions will help business in New York City and not hurt it, Edwin A. Salmon, chairman of the City Planning Commission, told the New York Metropolitan Association of Real Estate Boards at its ninth annual conference yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.

In your listing of brother teams in Congress no mention has been made of the three brothers who were members of the House of Representatives at the same time. They were the Washburns, born at Livermore, Me.

The tight situation in the New York City money market was lightened and returned almost to normal during the week ended on Wednesday, according to the statements of the sixteen reporting member banks in this city as released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Superfortresses of the Twentieth Bomber Command, based in India, striking in major force at the southern extremity of Japan's stolen empire, attacked transportation centers at Bangkok, Thailand, and Rangoon, Burma, today, twenty-four hours after the record blow of the Twenty-first Bomber Command on Nagoya, Japan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- During the week ended Dec. 13 member bank reserve balances decreased $92,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $56,000,000 in money in circulation, $11,000,000 in Treasury cash, and $245,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks, offset in part by an increase of $181,000,000 in Reserve bank credit and a decrease of $39,000,000 in nonmember deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 14 -- Ambassador George S. Messersmith will leave tomorrow aboard an Army plane for Washington and he is expected back in Mexico City on Dec. 22, the United States Embassy announced today. He will discuss several pending matters affecting Mexican-United States relations with President Roosevelt and State Department officials, it was said.

Sales of Series E war bonds that have been the principal source of concern to Treasury officials since the nation went over the top last week in its over-all drive to dispose of $14,000,000,000 in war bonds during the Sixth War Loan have mounted to $1,535,000,000, or 60 per cent of the $2,500,000,000 objective in this category, it was disclosed in Washington yesterday.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
MAASTRICHT, Holland, Dec. 14 -- Romances between liberated Dutch girls and liberating United States soldiers are discouraged diplomatically in Limburg Province, without reflection upon either.

Postmaster Albert Goldman bowed yesterday to an institution as firmly established as the postage stamp and let a waiting press and public in on the contents of the season's batch of children's letters to "Santa Claus, North Pole." It seems that this year, among children who would like to know Santa best, the trend is toward blind optimism.

Establishment of a new chemical department and appointment of three new vice presidents were announced yesterday by Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company. Dr. Zay Jeffries, technical director of the company's lamp department, will be general manager of the new chemical department and becomes a vice president.

ON THE CHINDWIN FRONT, Tuesday, Dec. 12 (Delayed) (Reuter) -- A forward air strip in central Burma, cut out of the jungle, surrounded by mountains, handles air traffic at the same rate as a regular airdrome, it was disclosed today.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange opened yesterday at the best levels of the day, 3 points higher to 2 points lower than the previous close, and then broke to losses of 10 to 27 points, and closed barely steady 7 to 17 points net lower. Eight December notices were issued.

The Dumbarton Oaks proposals to create a new international organization, outlaw aggressive war and establish peaceful procedures for the settlement of disputes among nations have come two years too late, Senator Joseph H. Ball of Minnesota declared last night.

Peace will bring about a gigantic reshuffling of the nation's labor force and the country must start immediately on a program to take care of the 22,000,000 persons -- almost half of all those at work in 1940 -- who will be changing jobs, Charles A. Myers declares in a survey just completed for the Committee for Economic Development.

Johnny Greco will have a chance to do it again tonight. The Montreal welterweight, who won the decision from Bobby Ruffin in a ten-round bout ten months ago, will be called on to repeat his triumph over the Long Island City ring harlequin at Madison Square Garden tonight.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- The Rev. William C. Baxter, 41 years old, rector here of the fashionable St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, pleaded guilty today in City Court to a charge of indecent exposure, committed "willfully and lewdly" in the presence of two boys of his parish last July 15.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- What the American consumer spends on the average and in the aggregate for everyday items of clothing was estimated by the War Production Board's Office of Civilian Requirements today on the basis of the second survey of consumer requirements, covering the first three months of this year.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- LeRoy Griffin, veteran house father at the New York State Training School for Boys at Warwick, N.Y., was shot and critically wounded at 6 o'clock tonight by one of four boys who escaped from the institution before dawn and obtained a shotgun, a rifle and ammunition by breaking into a summer home at Southfield, N.Y.

One hundred and fifty-three years ago today the Bill of Rights became a part of the Constitution of the United States. It is a short text, easily read in a few minutes. And no better use of a few minutes could be made today by any American than to read again the simple words which guarantee the liberties we cherish.

MONTREAL, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Maple Leafs, who were two men under normal strength, held Montreal's league-leading Canadiens to a 2-2 tie tonight before a crowd of about 12,000 National Hockey League fans.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Employers' manpower requirements will be classified and met according to urgency under a uniform nationwide system, Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, stated today.

I would like to add a few words to the current discussion concerning the proposed increase in Social Security tax rates. In general, I have no quarrel with the viewpoint expressed in your various editorials, and in the letter of Henriette C. Epstein, published Dec. 6, that the provisions of the law governing tax rates, benefit payments and the size of the reserve require re-examination.

Although a seasonal increase in supplies of eggs starts about this time of year, and large receipts were expected here this week, stocks are actually lighter than ever, according to representatives of the trade. Heavy snowstorms in the West, especially in the producing areas of Iowa and Minnesota, prevented packers from getting out their shipments.

The Standard Oil Company of California has added materially this year to its proved oil and gas reserves. In addition to two new gas fields in California, it has discovered a deeper producing sand in Buena Vista Hills, Calif.; a new field in Lincoln County, Miss., and recently has brought in a new well in the Princess field, Alberta, Canada. The Canadian well is an area from which only gas previously had been produced.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- In one sense the crisis through which Prime Minister Churchill rode so smoothly last week is unique. It is the first time since he became Prime Minister that the country has stayed aroused after he had made a speech defending himself.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Fred M. Vinson, Director of Economic Stabilization, today ordered distributors of fresh fruits and vegetables to alter their method of computing ceiling prices in a move to reduce retail levels of "important everyday items in the American consumer's food bill."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Senate adopted this afternoon by voice vote the Federal Crop Insurance measure which had already passed the House, revising the protection for growers of wheat, cotton and flax planted for harvest during 1945.

Amateur soccer teams made a clean sweep against the professionals of the American Soccer League opposed to them in the preliminaries of the tournament among eight clubs, seven on a side, staged last night for the benefit of the Sixth War Loan drive at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory.
LONDON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The condition statement of the Bank of England for the week ended Dec. 13 reported an increase of 22,011,000 in note circulation to the record total of 1,225,700,000.

ATHENS, Dec. 14 -- Artillery of the anti-Government Elas forces opened fire on the center of Athens this afternoon, ending a lull in the fighting that had extended through the morning, and Greek Government sources reported they would insist upon the unconditional surrender of forces in arms against the regime of Premier George Papandreou.

It is news when a name like Miltiades Porphyrogenis turns up in the dispatches from the Greek civil war. The name Miltiades is news because it is only 2,434 years old, to be exact. Miltiades was the Athenian leader who commanded at Marathon in 490 B.C. and wiped out the first Persian spearhead launched against the freedom of the Greek peoples.

George Szell made his first appearance as guest at a Philharmonic-Symphony subscription concert last night in Carnegie Hall. He played a program of accepted "classics" -- even Strauss's "Eulenspiegel" has that position today -- and his performances were exceptional for their vitality, virility, musical authority and orchestral command.

Kings County Judge Louis Goldstein sentenced yesterday James D. Gordon, 37-year-old bus driver, to Sing Sing for two to five years, and Gadson Goodson, 48-year-old trolley car motorman, to a year and three months to two and a half years.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Charlie Chaplin's counsel failed today in efforts to end without formal trial the suit which seeks to establish the comedian as the father of Joan Berry's child.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- What is called the first National Assembly of the Departmental Committees of Liberation will hold its opening session in Paris tomorrow. These committees are local bodies, much like those that sprang up during the great French Revolution, and they became a loose kind of underground movement during the German occupation.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 14 -- Pacific Fleet carrier forces blasted harbors and airfield installations throughout the northern Philippines yesterday, breaking the three-week lull that followed the destructive bombing and strafing raids of Nov. 24.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The United States expressed its approval today of the new Bonomi Government that took office in Italy yesterday. Our attitude was announced in the light of reports from Alexander Kirk, American Ambassador in Rome, and, it was emphasized, was in accord with the British position.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Justice Department told the Supreme Court today that it saw no reason why the tribunal should send back for lower-court trial the Government's civil anti-trust suit against The Associated Press.

Fifty captured high-ranking German officers, headed by Field Marshal Friedrich von Paulus and Gen Walther von Seydlitz, called on the German people last night in a broadcast from Moscow to "rise for the act of salvation against Hitler, Himmler and their baleful system," declaring that so far as Germany was concerned, the "war is lost."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (U.P.) -- Thomas G. Corcoran, Washington attorney and former Presidential adviser, denied today that the White House had a hand in the sale of the New York radio station WMCA.
Operators were active yesterday over a wide area in Manhattan. They figured as buyers and sellers in several leading deals involving business and housing properties.

ATHENS, Dec. 14 -- In the port of Piraeus area, an Elas attempt to win back territory on the peninsula came to nothing, while the British increased the cleared area, which will facilitate the unloading of ships. There has been a comparative lull, in fact, except for sniping, which continued in all parts of Athens.

While retail meat dealers and independent slaughterers continued their threats yesterday of a "business holiday" in protest against Office of Price Administration regulations, some of the major packers took matters into their own hands and refused to buy choice grades of livestock at the prices that have been prevailing.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (U.P.) -- The Republican party has $350,000 as a surplus left over from campaign funds "to carry on the fight against the things in Washington which we don't like," James S. Kemper, chairman of the finance committee, reported tonight.

Public-spirited groups who have an intimate knowledge of the problems and needs of their neighborhood were urged in a talk last night at the Hotel Astor by Edgar Nathan, Borough President of Manhattan, to bring them to the attention of city officials.
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted in English by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
Home for Christmas -- and it's time to celebrate with frequent parties, holiday reunions. And time to deck tables and sideboards with signs of the celebration.
LONDON, Dec. 14 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

If, as was reported, a petition to close the New York Stock Exchange on the Saturday before Christmas was being circulated on the floor, its sponsors must have grown discouraged at its reception and withdrawn it, for governors of the Exchange said yesterday that they had not seen it on the floor and that it had not "come upstairs."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Efforts to effect a 50 per cent decrease in post-war Federal taxes will be continued by the unofficial House Republican Post-War Tax Committee in the next Congress, that group decided today.

No one wants boys and girls to read the comics, no one has been able to stop them, and the comics are here to stay, in the opinion of the Journal of Educational Sociology. In its December issue, published today, the Journal brings together facts and views of outstanding specialists in an effort to look calmly at the "amazing cultural phenomenon" of "Superman," Dick Tracy."
