Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Strand the new attraction will be "Hollywood Canteen," an all-star musical produced by Warner Brothers. Delmer Daves wrote and directed the romance, which features sixty players.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The War Labor Board served notice today on Montgomery Ward Co. that unless it complied by Monday with the board's directives concerning wages and other adjustments at four company stores in Detroit, the case would be referred to Fred M. Vinson, Economic Stabilization Director.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Lupe Velez, Mexican film actress, took her own life today. Beside her pajama-clad body was found a partly filled bottle of tablets used to induce sleep but fatal if taken in quantities.

Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Newburger Hano were the successful bidders yesterday for an issue of $180,000 of Johnstown (Pa.) school district bonds, receiving the award on their bid of 100.4299 for 1 1/4s. The bonds will mature serially from Jan. 1, 1947 to 1955.
Two of the finest football squads to put cleats to the Polo Grounds worked out there yesterday.

The theatres in which two forthcoming attractions, each graced by a star, will play became known yesterday. With Katina Paxinou in the stellar role, "Sophie" (originally called "Sophie Halenczik, American") will come to the Playhouse on Christmas Night. Late next month the Fulton will get "Hope for the Best," starring Franchot Tone.

Disclosure by the Navy Department that since last July four Coast Guard cutters have been waging a successful but unpublicized war in the icy sea wastes around Greenland, to prevent the Germans from setting up weather stations there, reaffirms the seldom realized fact that there is little of the world's surface that is free from the possibility of becoming a battleground, even at this stage of the war.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) Army casualties for all theatres now total 483,957.
PARIS, Dec. 14 -- There are at least two large and important organizations in France already in operation to keep women banded together and teach them how to use their newly acquired vote.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 14 (AP) Veteran Chinese troops under Gen. Lee Tao, spearheading the Allied drive toward Mandalay, have taken the town of Tonkwa, 120 airline miles north of Mandalay, it was announced today.

The Army is stressing the need for an immediate increase in the production of cotton duck to meet urgent requirements of the men on the fighting fronts. Shortages of duck and other textiles are so acute that WPB Administrator J.A. Krug has suggested that sheet metal might be shipped to Germany and elsewhere to substitute for ordinary tentage.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 -- Agitators against any wartime resettlement of Japanese-Americans in West Coast States were denounced today by Robert B. Cozzens, assistant director of the War Relocation Authority, in a letter to the Hood River (Ore.) American Legion Post, which removed the names of sixteen Japanese-American soldiers from its county honor roll.

The first three volumes in a new series of mystery reprints, called "The Black Widow Thrillers," will be published next month by Knopf. They are Dashiell Hammett's "The Maltese Falcon," Raymond Chandler's "The Big Sleep" and Eric Ambler's "A Coffin for Dimitrios." The new editions will be pocketsize.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Except for minor fluctuations in prices for agricultural products and higher prices for cigars, there was very little movement in commodity prices at the primary market level during the first week of December. The Bureau of Labor Statistics' all-commodity index remained unchanged at the highest level since the war began:
PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 14 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced tonight that he would soon establish headquarters in the forward area to be nearer the actual fighting zones in the war against Japan.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- Imposing police forces were arrayed outside the law courts in Lyon this morning when Jean Angeli, regional prefect under Vichy, came up for retrial on charges of intelligence with the enemy, for which the lower court early this month sentenced him to death.
AT SIXTH ARMY GROUP HEADQUARTERS, in France, Dec. 14 -- As winter settles in on the southern part of the European front the Germans are fighting a delaying action.

Expressing the view that inter-American relations were at their lowest ebb in a decade, the Foreign Policy Association said in a bulletin issued yesterday that nations south of the border may increasingly seek the friendship of the Soviet Union.

Resignation of John Dassau as first vice president of the Stock Clearing Corporation, effective Dec. 31, to become a partner in Ungerleider Co., has brought three shifts in the top executive positions of the New York Stock Exchange, Emil Schram, president, announced yesterday, following approval by the board of governors.

Frank W. Kridel and associates, lessees since 1939 of the seventeen story Hotel Martinique, at the northeast corner of Broadway and Thirty-second Street, have purchased the property from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- A Senate subcommittee, inquiring into possible gaps in the surplus war property disposal law, heard today how the Government bought hydraulic jacks at $78 to $80 each and sold more than 10,000 of them later to the manufacturers for $45 to $46.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 14 -- Soon after wage negotiations were opened here today with the United States Steel Corporation and its five subsidiaries the CIO-United Steel Workers broke off the conference, charging that the steel concern would not bargain in good faith.
A year-end dividend of 20 cents a share was voted by Altorfer Brothers for payment Dec. 20, bringing 1944 dividends to 40 cents, or 30 cents more than last year.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
In the Pacific and in Europe, Allied air power struck heavily yesterday against the will and the capacity of the enemy to resist.

In response to a request for a ruling on the taxability of shaving creams, the Toilet Goods Association, Inc., has been advised by the Treasury Department that if the cream is advertised or "held out for use" for toilet purposes, a sample of the product together with labels, packagings and advertising matter should be submitted to the department for consideration and a specific ruling.

While the American members of the Middle East Supply Center have done the "best they could under the circumstances, they have brought in insufficient supplies to the Middle East," R.C. Thompson, export manager, the Electric Auto-Lite Company, declared yesterday.

A SUPERFORTRESS BASE, in India, Dec. 14 -- In a shakedown mission for new crewmen, B-29's in medium strength today attacked the big Rama railway bridge over the Chao Phraya River in Thailand and railway marshaling yards in Rangoon.

Responding to the appeals of American commanders in every theatre of war for more materiel, employer and worker representatives met yesterday under the auspices of the regional War Production Board and formed a New York area council of labor-management committees for the exchange of mutually useful ideas to speed up production.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 14 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will make a sequel to its film version of Marion Hargrove's "See Here, Private Hargrove." The new picture, to be produced in the spring with Robert Walker again in the name role, will be "What's Next, Corporal Hargrove?" Harry Kurnitz is writing the screen play and George Haight will be the producer.

Wild mink had a top of $25.50 at the fur sale conducted yesterday by Lampson, Fraser Huth. Demand was good. Ranch mink sold up to $30.50, down 15 per cent from the levels of December, 1943. For the account of the American National Fur Breeders, ranch mink brought a top of $23.50, firm compared with the previous sale last month.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 14- An uneventful electoral session of the Swiss Federal Assembly this morning named, by 122 votes of 227, Max Petitpierre, Radical Democrat States Councillor and Senator from Neuchatel, to succeed Marcel Pilet Golaz as a member of the Federal Council.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The National Conference on Labor Legislation endorsed today the principle of an annual wage and urged the Department of Labor to survey the experiences of those companies which have set up such systems.

ROME, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Marcel Cerdan, French sailor, reached the final of the Mediterranean zone inter-Allied boxing championships tonight in defense of his professional middleweight crown, but Larry Cisneros, only American defending title holder, was eliminated by a decision which the capacity crowd booed fully ten minutes.

For many decades now Geneva has stood in people's minds as an international symbol. Perhaps it will no longer do so to the same extent. The Russians, who have taken a chilly attitude toward Switzerland in recent months, are said to oppose Calvin's old capital as the head city of the proposed United Nations Security Organization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Four Coast Guard cutters, penetrating into Arctic waters only a few hundred miles from the North Pole, destroyed three German expeditions to establish weather-reporting stations on the northeast coast of Greenland, the Navy reported today.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 14 -- Soldiers are being taken from Army camps to help alleviate the shell shortage by working in steel mills.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- W. L. Clayton, Surplus War Property Administrator, stated today that 6,239 surplus planes have been sold as of Dec. 1 out of a total of 23,391 planes which had been declared surplus by the Army, Navy and other Government agencies.

Blanche Thebom, young American mezzo-soprano, scored an immediate success at her debut appearance last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, where she was heard as the Fricka in the season's second performance of Wagner's "Die Walkuere."

Assemblyman Jane H. Todd of Westchester and Senator Alexander A. Falk of New York, who introduced the 1944 Todd law prohibiting pay discrimination because of sex, said yesterday that it had been their intention that the equal pay law should apply to State and municipal as well as private employment.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 14 -- Home builders of the nation were warned here today that they must prepare now for a quick upsurge of activity in their field as soon as the European phase of the war is over.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- S.L. Solon, London News Chronicle correspondent in Brussels, Belgium, cabled his newspaper tonight that he had investigated the "putsch" against the Pierlot Government which, according to Prime Minister Churchill's statement in Parliament, had been organized by Belgian resistance forces at the end of last month, and had found no evidence that anything of the sort had ever taken place.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A $23,000,000 cutback in production of machine guns for Army planes was officially approved tonight. The move, it was explained, would release manpower for more critical ordnance items, including ammunition.

Showing its full might in the final period, when it drove home five goals, the St. Paul's School hockey team of Concord, N.H., defeated the Kent School sextet of Kent, Conn., at Madison Square Garden yesterday, 8 to 1. An enthusiastic gathering of 2,000 fans witnessed the battle, which marked the annual appearance of the St. Paul's team in this city.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- Much obscurity veils the activities of the various Spanish factions exiled in France, all of which express their readiness to replace the Franco regime, but up to the present only in words.

In the belief that many school failures and behavior problems are linked to troubles in the home, a city-wide school effort to help pupils who "don't get along" has been started by the Board of Education in cooperation with eight private family welfare agencies, it was learned yesterday.

Promising that the War Production Board will supply the yarn needed, Curtis E. Bowne, chief of the Cotton Thread Unit and Cordage Section, called yesterday for a step-up in production of mildew-resistant thread for sewing tents for the armed forces.

ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- State Controller Frank C. Moore was told today by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein that he lacked authority to comply with a request by Hiram C. Todd, special prosecutor in the grand jury investigation of legislative spending, that he withhold action on the retirement application of Senator John J. Dunnigan, minority leader.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Apart from support for a few popular industrials, there was little activity in today's stock markets.

Presentation to Congress by industry and business of a definite plan to make possible "the vast post-war production required for 60,000,000 jobs" was urged yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in an address at the seventy-first annual meeting of the New York Board of Trade at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Having risen in a half century from the job of porter in the New York Eye and Ear Hospital, Thirteenth Street and Second Avenue, to the post of bacteriologist and serologist at the same institution, Edgar B. Burchell was honored for his achievements last night by fellow-scientists at a dual celebration there.

Because the petroleum transportation crisis which developed suddenly last month has not yet abated, the Office of Price Administration and the Petroleum Administration for War acted jointly yesterday to tighten controls on the civilian use of heavy industrial fuel oil on the East Coast.
ROME, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A communique:

The Prison Association of New York, observing this week its 100th anniversary, looks back over a century of wonderful accomplishments. One of the greatest of these is the breaking down of the hard-held notion that a man who has once done time in prison is to be regarded ever after as an outcast.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Dec. 14 -- A column of American Seventh Army Infantry smashed northward through the snowy passes of the Vosges Mountains within seven miles of the Wissembourg Gap today and Marauders of the First Tactical Air Force hammered the Siegfried Line defenses around the town in Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's bid to break the German defenses at a comparatively weak point and reopen the war of movement in the west.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Tennessee Gas and Transmission Company announced that it has petitioned the Federal Power Commission for permission to connect its new $54,000,000 Texas-West Virginia natural-gas pipe line with eleven oil and gas fields in Texas now having no outlet.
With 131 members and guests gathered last night in its world famous model room, the New York Yacht Club held a centennial dinner at its clubhouse, 37 West Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Extreme importance is attached by officials high in aviation circles to the recent monster strikes by the United States Army Air Forces and the Royal Air Force against German war targets. Some authorities here declare that the performance of the week demonstrates the reaching of a new peak of efficiency by Allied air power.

THOMASVILLE, Ga., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Lieut. Vereen McNeill Bell, son of State Supreme Court Chief Justice R.C. Bell and the author of the novel, "Swamp Water," and many short stories, died when his ship the Gambier Bay was sunk Oct. 25 in the second battle of the Philippines.

Ralph A. Bard, Under-Secretary of the Navy, declared yesterday that Japan is fighting for a stalemate and that the necessity for delivering her a knockout blow must be made crystal clear to every American.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Mgr. Michael J. Ready, retiring general secretary of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, which he served for fifteen years, was consecrated today in St. Matthew's cathedral Church of the Washington Archdiocese as Bishop of Columbus, Ohio, by the Most Rev. Amleto Giovanni Cicognani, Apostolic delegate to the United States.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Some slender hopes of alleviating the cigarette shortage in 1945 were held out today by Government experts, appearing before the Mead Senate Committee investigating it.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 14 -- The Elas Partisans are more anti-monarchist than Communist, and it is almost certain that they are not receiving help either from the Russians or the Germans, says Dr. Christian Callmer, a member of the Swedish Commission for Aid to Greece, who has just returned from Athens.

Word was received here yesterday that $235,000 of the $387,000 stolen last year by Ralph M. Wilby, 40 years old, a Canadian ex-convict, from the William T. Knott Company, Inc., 128 West Thirty-first Street, had been found buried beside a house in New Westminster, B.C., that Wilby had bought after he became a fugitive.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Still seething with smothered indignation over the Churchill Government's conduct in Greece, the House of Commons is expected to demand tomorrow an accounting of the part Britain has played in the coming partition of Poland.

A six-point international bill of rights designed to serve as a postwar guarantee of individual liberties throughout the world, and modeled upon the American Bill of Rights, was advocated by 1,326 distinguished Americans of all faiths in a statement made public yesterday by the American Jewish Committee, through its president, former Justice Joseph M. Proskauer.

The stock market resumed yesterday its upward climb as the railroad issues reasserted their leadership. Trading in the carriers, where gains ranged from 1 to 2 points and carried the composite price through the previous seven-year highs, dominated the session almost to the exclusion of other groups.

Isidore J. Lipsky and Harry Lipsky were sentenced to jail terms of three months each yesterday by Federal Judge Edward A. Conger for filing two false statements with the Office of Price Administration. North American Warehouses, Inc., 1133-35 Tiffany Street, the Bronx, was fined $2,500 for the same offense, and Certified Carpet Cleaning Corporation, another concern operated by the Lipskys, was fined $1,000 for failure to file a base-period price record with the OPA.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Selective Service System ruled in regulations distributed to State directors today that the extension from forty to ninety days of the time in which a veteran might request the return of his civilian job should be retroactive for all men who had been discharged within the ninety-day period to Dec. 8.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Friday, Dec. 15 (U.P.) -- The Japanese suffered an estimated 82,554 casualties in the first fifty-five days of the Philippine campaign, including dead at a ratio of at least thirty-one to every American killed, it was announced today as the United States Seventy-seventh Division hacked out a mile advance north of Ormoc against the flank of the main enemy defense line in western Leyte.

Five National League players, including the veteran Don Hutson, are unanimous choices for the All-Pro football team selected yesterday by The Associated Press and newspaper sports writers all over the circuit.

The Sixth War Loan campaign ends tomorrow but the war con tinues. Even if the cease firing order were given on all the world's battle-fields, your war financing obligations would be with you for a long time to come.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Senate and its Committee on Foreign Relations have been so unpredictable in dealing with the President's new appointments to the State Department hierarchy that, until they are safely by the vote to confirm, none of the nominees can be certain of his job.

Opportunities to get in a bit of "swinging" on ski slopes and trails this week-end are promising and a large number of the major areas will launch their seasons tomorrow. Encouraging is the fact that a good base prevails at several points which do not have sufficient depth to cover underbrush.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 14 (U.P.) -- The Japanese threat to the United States Fourteenth Air Force Headquarters at Kunming has not yet been eliminated, Maj. Gen. Robert B. McClure, United States Army Chief of Staff in China, warned today, despite a Chinese High Command announcement that Chinese troops were pursuing the retreating enemy southward in Kwangsi Province.

A drive to raise $500,000 to support a five-year post-war program for the improved treatment and prevention of leprosy, was opened yesterday by the American Mission to Lepers. The new program, announced at a luncheon attended by medical leaders, missionaries and lay workers at the University Club, provides for the establishment in eight countries of Asia and Africa of training centers at which native personnel will be taught to care for the afflicted.

The Allied Military Government in Germany will restore to their rightful owners all works of art and objects of scientific or historical value that have been looted by Germany from Allied countries, a proclamation issued in the name of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower said yesterday.
Lupe Velez started her stage career as a dancer in Mexico City at the age of 13 and from that early beginning won an important place in motion pictures and also on the stage and in vaudeville.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed holdings of United States Government securities and note circulation for the system as a whole to have increased $266,128,000 and $65,827,000, respectively, during the week. Ratio of reserve declined to 49.6.

MOSCOW, Dec. 14 -- Sharply accusing the French Ministry of Information of distorting facts when its military spokesman estimated the number of German and Hungarian divisions on the Soviet-German front at 132 in December, the newspaper Pravda asserted today that there were 220 divisions on the Eastern Front on Dec. 1, including thirty-two divisions that had been moved eastward from other theatres, including Italy.

The discovery of a hitherto unobserved form of the germ causing tuberculosis, which opens up important new clues in the search for a lethal weapon against this killer of man and animal, was reported last night at the 127th annual meeting of the New York Academy of Sciences at the American Museum of Natural History.

Men on the fighting fronts in the Pacific and in Europe, witnessing sorrow and suffering and destruction on a vast scale, somehow have remembered the annual Christmas appeal in behalf of the Hundred Neediest Cases of New York City. Their gifts, coming truly from the heart, were among the 561 received yesterday.

The assaults of our Superfortresses against Japan have now become so sizable and so frequent that they may be said to have passed the experimental stage and to have opened up in the Orient the same kind of strategic air war against the centers of Japanese power that the British air force began against Germany in 1940.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The nominations of the six appointees to high posts in the State Department will be taken to the Senate floor tomorrow with widely varying votes of the Foreign Relations Committee asking for their confirmation.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 14 -- Declaring that the war has developed a greater appreciation of a home supply of meat among urban as well as rural families, William Skelley, Professor of Animal Husbandry at Rutgers University, said today that packers are now working on a program to supply packaged meat ready to be put in home freezer units through retail stores.

The New York Rovers scored a surprise triumph over the Boston Olympics in an Eastern Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. While 4,155 fans looked on, the home sextet fashioned an 8-to-5 success over the league leaders.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Communique 250:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 9 were 793,554 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 14,706 cars, or 1.8 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, 29,757 cars, or 3.6 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week of last year, and 49,371 cars, or 6.6 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

MAURAGE, Belgium, Dec. 12 (Delayed) -- When seen from any angle, this is gently rolling farmland, whose inhabitants plod over the cobbled roads in wooden sabots. It is sprinkled with towering black pyramids of slag cast up from the coal mines -- much out of place against the background of fields and the small clusters of trees.
The Paschal ankle becomes more and more of a mystery as the day of the Giants' rendezvous with the Packers for the National Football League championship draws nearer and nearer.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UP) -- Twentieth Air Force communique 32:

Sylvester A. Miniter, 52-year-old chairman of the Sixth War Loan Drive for the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn and also of Selective Service Local Board 170, was arrested by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents yesterday and accused of "aiding and abetting a registrant of his board to evade service," according to E.E. Conroy, local FBI chief.

Benjamin Franklin, when in France, was appealed to by a stranded American for passage-money home. He answered, in effect, "I cannot afford to give outright the help you ask. But I like to keep a bit of charitable money at work. I don't expect it to come back to me, but I do expect it to be a sort of revolving fund, continuing to do good as it passes from hand to hand.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 15 (U.P.) -- Russian troops yesterday drove to within five miles of snapping a trap on thousands of enemy troops in the Bukk Mountain mining area seventy-five miles northeast of embattled Budapest, while the Nazi-controlled Budapest radio called on Hungarians to make their shelled and burning capital another Stalingrad.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Widespread criticism in the House of Lords today of the alleged failure of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration to fulfill the function for which the public thought it was designed, brought from the Earl of Selborne, Minister of Economic Warfare, the admission that the food crisis in liberated Europe had grown worse since D-day.

The Liquid Carbonic Corporation reported to stockholders in the annual statement released today that net sales for the year ended with September totaling $22,739,767 were the largest, with exception of 1941, for any year on record and compared with $20,733,543 in the preceding fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The current Allied offensive in the west is placing Germany under a "terrific strain" and is depriving her of the winter breathing space she needed desperately to complete her "last-ditch mobilization plans" and to train the green manpower she now is rushing to the front, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson declared today.

With the temperature what it is, the kind of fisherman who doesn't mind a touch of frostbite in order to catch a few pickerel is thinking of ice-fishing. He can go now, as far as the law is concerned, because the season is open. To avoid adding drowning to frostbite, however, it's wise to see that the ice is thick enough to support his piscatorial activities.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 14 -- Appointment of Wesley E. Fesler of the Wesleyan sports staff as head coach of basketball and assistant in baseball and football at Princeton was announced today by Dean Christian Gauss, chairman of the Princeton Council on Athletics.

On behalf of the many officers and enlisted personnel of the Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard, who have read and enjoyed the thousands of copies of THE NEW YORK TIMES contributed by your Honolulu representative and distributed in the Pacific Ocean areas by the Fleet Recreation and Morale Officer, I extend my sincere appreciation and gratitude.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Few tears were shed for Poland in London tonight, but there was a high state of alarm over the disintegration of Allied unity implied in Prime Minister Churchill's speech on Russo-Polish relations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- As Selective Service headquarters announced today that a much larger proportion of older men would be inducted after Feb. 1, War Department officials disclosed that 4,700 soldiers had been furloughed to work in critical war industries until "civilian workers come forward to fill vacant jobs."

ABOARD VICE ADMIRAL McCAIN'S FLAGSHIP OF THE FAST CARRIER FORCE, off the Philippines, Dec. 14 (Delayed) (AP) -- Employing new sea-borne airplane tactics, Vice Admiral John S. McCain's great air armada by day and by night pinned down the Japanese air force on Luzon Island and held it there while others of his Hellcats sank their claws into Japanese military targets.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Dec. 15 -- Three divisions of Lieut. Gen. Alexander M. Patch's American Seventh Army swept up to the German frontier today on a seventeen-mile front from the Vosges Mountains to the Rhine, smashing into the Reich at two places, occupying two towns on the frontier and engaging Siegfried Line positions in a mighty bid to break through onto the Rhenish plain.

Invitations were issued by the Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot yesterday for 33,239,074 yards of various types of wool piece goods, with bids to be made not later than Dec. 21. Deliveries will run from Jan. 15 to June 30. Leading in the procurement, Neg. 194, are 19,194,074 yards of cloth, wool, serge, 18-ounce, O.D., 56 inches. Another 2,000,000 yards of the 18-ounce serge is wanted for war aid.

Two Houghton Mifflin authors, on round-the-world assignments, met recently in London. David L. Cohn, author of "Combustion on Wheels," was on his way to Rome, Cairo and Palestine. And Roi Ottley, who wrote "New World A-Coming," was en route to Naples, Algiers and Liberia, where he will gather material for a book on race relations.

Another heavy schedule confronts the local basketball fan today. Led by the double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight, the slate will present an assortment of clashes that will maintain interest in the court sport all over the metropolitan area.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, in the twelfth of his series of broadcasts to the German people, promised German labor today that if their country surrendered they would regain their old right of free association in the trade unions abolished by the Nazi party.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Saturday, Dec. 16 -American troops were landed without the loss of a man on Mindoro Island, just 155 miles south of Manila, at 7:30 yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Office of Price Administration today ordered reductions in the sugar allotments of most industrial users for the first quarter of 1945 in a move reflecting low sugar inventories and "uncertain" military demands.

WITH THE BRITISH 15TH CORPS, Arakan Front, Burma, Dec. 14 (Delayed) (AP) -- This was D-day for British regiments recruited from three continents that have smashed forward from three to seventeen miles in the opening phase of a two-pronged drive to reclaim the Arakan district.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 -- Edward Hopkinson Jr., a member of the investment banking firm of Drexel Co. of this city, declared today at a hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission that adoption of retroactive straight-line depreciation as recommended by some regulatory bodies would "ruin every public utility company in the country."
BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 15 -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels, in an article in the weekly Reich, blames "Western plutocratic democracy" for the world's troubles. Democracy, he warns, will be the first victim.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 16 (U.P.) Russian troops northwest of beseiged Budapest yesterday captured the Czechoslovak stronghold of Sahy [Ipolysag], gateway town to the wide Bratislava plains leading 116 miles westward to Vienna, while Berlin said that the Red Army possibly had opened its winter offensive in southern Poland.

Your editorial of Nov. 26 "Inevitable Socialism?" and Prof. Irving Fisher's comment on it Dec. 4 are timely, but both seem to evade the real issue -- full employment after the war. Many conservative business and professional leaders decry the "growing danger of socialism," when what they are talking about is not socialism at all.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia, chairman of the Joint Committee on Reduction of Non-Essential Federal Expenditures, presented to the Senate today a report on unexpended balances and contract authorizations on the Treasury's books with the recommendation that Congress pass legislation to eliminate all unnecessary balances six months after the war's end.

The impression that English women appear dowdy in these trying war days was corrected yesterday by Hugh Beresford at a luncheon given in his honor by the Millinery Division of the Fashion Group. On the contrary, he feels that they are better dressed than in the past.

BHAMO, Burma, Dec. 15 -Troops of the Chinese Thirty-eighth Division captured Bhamo unexpectedly at 2 P.M. today after the trapped Japanese garrison made a desperate attempt to fight its way south along the Irrawaddy River last night.

The bold amphibious jump from Leyte to Mindoro, which lies only ten miles across the Verde Island Passage from the main Philippine island of Luzon, and only seventy miles from Manila, opens the second and penultimate phase of the Battle for the Philippines.

Carol Stone has been chosen for the chief feminine role in "Dark of the Moon," the "legend with music" by Howard Richardson and William Berney, which Lee Shubert is producing. Miss Stone has been a leading candidate for the part she created when the play was tested last August at the Cambridge (Mass.) Summer Theatre.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 -- Hamilton Hicks, a director of the Elastic Stop Nut Corporation of America, Union, N.J., indicated at a hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission today that at least part of the company's present financial condition was attributable to a "wholly injurious and completely unnecessary" meeting of the board members, bankers and underwriters Nov. 3.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- High officials indicated today that there would be no immediate response to the appeal made by Prime Minister Churchill in the House of Commons for a meeting as soon as possible with President Roosevelt and Premier Stalin to consider tangled European problems.

Reports of renewed interest in cooperative apartment ownership were confirmed yesterday by real estate men, who gave various reasons for the renaissance of the tenant-owner arrangement that suffered a severe setback from the 1929 depression.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Grain markets on the Board of Trade had a firm undertone most of today and although local selling caused a reaction at one time the strength in securities and cotton brought in short covering and the finish was about the top.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A big New Year's Day Navy football game somewhere in the Southwest Pacific, probably Pearl Harbor, appears in the making.
Yesterday's communiqu, as transmitted in English by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Commission:

Patrolman William Descovich, radio patrolman attached to the Central Park Station, plunged into the icy waters of the Seventy- second Street lake on the west side of the park and rescued two public- school youngsters yesterday.

What the well-dressed man will wear may be briefly summed up from one angle. He will wear clothes that cost not quite as much as those of his women-folk but not so far away. Estimates by the War Production Board's experts on civilian requirements show that in the first three months of the year just drawing to an end American women spent for street dresses something over $280,000,000.

Today marks the official close of the Sixth War Loan. New York State and New York City have surpassed their over-all quotas. The job has been well done and is directly attributable to the spirit and devotion of the thousands of volunteer bond salesmen from every walk of life.

The three winners of the Statewide Green Thumb Contest, sponsored by the National Victory Garden Institute, received awards for the most successful victory gardens of 1944 yesterday at a ceremony that was broadcast over Station WNYC from the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office at Pershing Square.

ALBANY, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Reduced bus fares, which it is estimated will save customers in the Buffalo- Niagara Falls area $432,300 annually, will become effective next month, the Public Service Commission announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The House passed today and returned to the Senate a slightly amended version of the Maloney-Monroney bill, providing for a bipartisan study and recommendation on the streamlining of Congressional procedure.

The unlucky thirteenth element in an ingenious scheme brought trouble yesterday to Walter Forlenza, 26 years old, of 231 East 117th Street. The scheme was described by United States Attorney John F. X. McGohey as the most novel yet discovered for the counterfeiting of ration coupons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Senate action on the six State Department nominations was blocked today by Senator Albert B. Chandler, Democrat of Kentucky, who forced the Chamber to take up instead the appointment of former Gov. Robert A. Hurley of Connecticut and Lieut. Col. Edward Heller for two of the three places on the Surplus War Property Board.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Senators voted themselves today an additional $4,020 to $5,040 yearly for clerk hire in passing a $564,000,000 supplemental appropriation bill.

ON THE ROER RIVER FRONT in Germany, Dec. 15 (AP) -- An unusually high price in American blood and human misery was paid for ancient, moated Mullenark castle, near Schophoven, one of the last two knots of German resistance this side of the Roer, northwest of Dueren.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A group of manufacturers of railroad cars, comprising an advisory committee to the War Production Board, has accused the War Department of canceling war contracts by resolution without giving adequate advance warning, and by so doing, forcing inefficient use of critical manpower supplies.

While a temporary ending of price control on cotton duck will eliminate financial loss for high cost manufacturers and thus create more incentive to produce, cotton textile mills will not be able to meet the full quotas for the Army unless they can obtain sufficient labor, according to Worth Street textile men yesterday.

Plenty of deer are reported in nearly all parts of the State for New Jersey's open season which will run for four days starting Monday. If they are not exactly waiting for the swarm of hunters expected to seek them out, at least their presence is promising.

WITH THE SEVENTY-NINTH INFANTRY DIVISION Inside Germany, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A battallion of hard-slugging doughboys fought without sleep through three nights, saved bridges in the path of the Seventy-ninth Infantry Division and made possible one of today's three penetrations of Germany.

The world premiere of Salvador Dali's "Mad Tristan" by the Ballet International last night at the International Theatre proved to be a great disappointment. From the advance notices of its treatment of the theme and music of Wagner's opera it sounded as if it might be pretty objectionable and something you could really work up a rage about.

In a "Just-Before-the-Battle" atmosphere, the Giants yesterday went through their next-to last practice before tomorrow's all-important National Football League championship game with the Packers. The kick-off time at the Polo Grounds is scheduled for 2:05, twenty-five minutes earlier than previous games.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 15 (U.P.) -- Maj. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley, new United States Ambassador to China, today challenged pessimistic predictions that China is in danger of being knocked out of the war.

The Good Neighbor policy is the only workable guide for inter-American political and economic relations and it is certain to survive the present war in the opinion of Marcial Mora, Chilean Ambassador to the United States, who spoke last night on "The Continuance of Hemispheric Solidarity" at the fifty-ninth annual dinner of the New York Southern Society at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Brooklyn College scored a lopsided victory over the Fordham basketball team on the Kingsmen's court last night. Held pretty closely by their uptown rivals in the first half, the home athletes flashed a wealth of speed and scoring power in the second half to roll up a 64-to-34 success.

ROME, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Canadian troops fought hard tonight to expand a newly won bridgehead across the Naviglio Canal, west of Ravenna, as the Germans threw more reinforcements into a fierce defense of the eastern Po Valley.

Bellini's "Norma" received its first performance of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The presentation was smooth, had atmosphere and vitality, and ranked among the most commendable achievements the company has offered during the season's opening weeks.

Big news breaks and intensive war news continue to increase readership throughout the entire newspaper, it is revealed by the seventy-third study of the continuing study of newspaper reading based on The Cleveland News, the results of which will be released today by the Advertising Research Foundation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President Roosevelt signed the bill creating the ranks of General of the Army and Admiral of the Fleet and nominated Generals Marshall, MacArthur, Eisenhower and Arnold and Admirals Leahy, King and Nimitz for the promotions.

Unless Christian churches open their doors to all races they "should cease to proclaim the doctrine of the fatherhood of God and the brotherhood of man," according to a statement to white churchgoers by 106 Negro leaders of Protestant faiths made public yesterday.

ROME, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Pope Pius XII received the touring United States House Military Affairs Committee today and at the conclusion of the audience asked Representative John M. Costello, California Democrat, to convey his greetings to President Roosevelt.

Women's organization leaders and industrial managers held an all-day conference on post-war problems yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, as one of thirty similar meetings in as many States called by the National Association of Manufacturers within the last year.

ROME, Dec. 15 -- The tragic developments in Greece represent a crude compound of all the problems of a desperate Europe. The idea that Europe will emerge from the war stronger than before or the same as before seems nonsense to anyone who walks over the shaky ground of this materially and morally devastated Continent.
With increased price fixing, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 3 to 9 points yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A Securities and Exchange Commission hearing on the retirement of American Light and Traction Company's 6 per cent preferred stock was adjourned abruptly today after the commission upheld Trial Examiner W.W. Swift's ruling that evidence on the construction of a $70,000,000 pipeline was pertinent to the case.

Directors of the First National Bank in St. Louis declared yesterday a dividend of $l a share, 60 cents of which is an extra, payable next Friday, and 40 cents payable Feb. 28. Also authorized was the transfer of $700,000 from undivided profits to surplus, bringing the total surplus to $6,500,000.

Football's DD-Day is here! It's all-America Glenn Dobbs of Tulsa against all-America Bill Dudley of Virginia as the Second Air Force Superbombers from Colorado Springs play the Randolph Field Ramblers of Texas in the Treasury Bond Bowl game at the Polo Grounds today.

" Boom" and "crash" periods for business and industry after the war can be avoided providing there is more rather than less Government regulation, Jerome L. Udell of Max Udell Sons Company, declared last night at the annual dinner of the National Association of Uniform Manufacturers at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

American Superfortresses hit three Japanese areas, including Tokyo, yesterday, the Tokyo radio said, labeling the forays "nuisance raids" and reiterating threats against American airmen, according to The Associated Press.

ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- George P. Monaghan, special prosecutor, filed an affidavit today purporting to show that Daniel H. Prior, an Albany lawyer long active in local Republican politics, was really acting in the interests of the Democratic machine of Daniel P. O'Connell in representing defendants in the extraordinary term grand jury investigation of crime in Albany County.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 15 -- The New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards heard public housing alternately condemned today as a menace to private enterprise and defended as a necessary step in social progress, in a debate which may set the pattern for national discussion of the issue when the Government's post-war program in this field is presented shortly.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 15 -- Thirteen members of a bootleg alcohol ring who recently pleaded guilty to operating four illegal stills in New Jersey were sentenced today by Federal Judge Thomas F. Meaney to serve a total of thirty-five and a half years in Federal penitentiaries and pay minimum fines and penalties aggregating $78,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Covering the last stages of his return journey from China in record time, Donald M. Nelson, personal representative of the President and former chairman of the War Production Board, arrived in Washington late last night.

Like two ferocious wildcats, Bobby Ruffin, Long Island City welterweight, and sturdy Johnny Greco, from Montreal, fought ten rounds last night at Madison Square Garden in one of the greatest battles the arena ever has held.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Official of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) announced here today that two of the nation's large crude-oil pipe line systems, now operated by the Standard Oil Company of Louisiana and the Oklahoma Pipe Line Company, will be consolidated on Dec. 31.

May I express commendation of your editorial of Dec. 11 on the Russo-French alliance. The event is the first piece of really good news from the diplomatic front in a long time. Despite the blundering, political cowardice and the ideological moonshine of these years of anarchy, the tide of history has at last produced the Franco-British-Russian defensive combination.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Authority of the Secretary of the Treasury in ordering collectors of customs to use only an "official" rate in converting British pounds sterling into American dollars for duty purposes who challenged today before the Supreme Court which took the matters under advisement when arguments ended.

The four-story building containing five stores and apartments above at the northwest corner of Sixth Avenue and Fifty-third Street has been purchased by the Jerome Agency from Frederick Brown, who acquired it several days ago.

Spurred by frequent warnings about shortages and mail delays, the city's Christmas shoppers are breaking sales records for almost every type of merchandise, store officials recalled yesterday. Careful selection, however, has superseded the "crazy grab-buying" so evident a year ago, it was said.

ROME, Dec. 15 -- Riots that resulted in one death and injuries to three took place in Catania yesterday and simultaneously in other Sicilian cities and continued in the same localities today, causing a situation officially characterized as "grave but not alarming."

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Archbishop Damaskinos may become regent of Greece or head a regency council in addition to carrying out his ecclesiastical duties, according to rumors that demand a certain degree of credence.
The Philippine campaign has reached a new crisis.

A banking syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., submitted yesterday he best bid for an issue of $7,500,000 city of Houston, Tex., Independent School District bonds, naming a price and a combination of interest rates that represent a net interest cost to the city of 1.9046 per cent.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Meeting in the Hotel de Ville today, delegates representing the Liberation Committees of virtually all of France's districts formulated their demands that the committees continue with broader powers and that the Government recognize an obligation to consult them.
LONDON, Dec. 15 (UP) -- A communique, as broadcast from Berlin:
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 15(AP) -Burley tobacco sales on twenty of Kentucky's twenty-one markets yesterday amounted to 9,931,224 pounds, the State Agriculture Department reported.

BOSTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Sal Bartolo of Boston put on an artistic display of boxing skill tonight to gain a unanimous decision while defending his National Boxing Association featherweight championship against Whistlin' Willie Roache of Wilmington, Del., in a fifteen-round bout at Boston Garden.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 15 -- The blacklisted anti-United States Nationalist newspaper Cabildo reappeared today after its week's suspension and promptly challenged the Government by repeating in even more positive terms the very same criticisms that had called down official ire upon it on Dec. 7.

In his first recital of the season at Carnegie Hall last night, Sascha Gorodnitzki, the distinguished pianist, gave his audience an evening of music played with limitless assurance, competence and poise. It was music-making of a thoroughly experienced artist and one to whom technical problems are not only surmountable, but appear to be almost non-existent.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Dec. 15 (AP) -- The body of Lupe Velez will be laid to rest in Forest Lawn Cemetery in Glendale Monday following a non-denominational church service.

Unlike many other sections of the country, the New York financial district had no set quota in the Sixth War Loan Drive. The reason was that, to a large extent, much of the nation's quota in the drive centered around Wall Street, since the financial community, as in corporate financing, serves as the hub of the wheel.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Prime Minister Churchill's action in the House of Commons today in supporting what he termed Russia's "just and reasonable" demands on Poland was termed tonight "a cruel and revolting crime" and "an ill omen for the world" by Charles Rozmarek, president of the Polish- American Congress, which claims to represent 6,000,000 Americans of Polish descent.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- France intends to integrate liberated Alsace and Lorraine with the rest of the country more closely than ever before, according to responsible French Government officials, by the progressive narrowing of the special status of church educational and social institutions that prevailed there before the war.

With victory may come our "final opportunity" to prove that men differing in belief and race "not only can, but do and will work to achieve a common purpose," Maj. Gen. Frederick E. Uhl, commanding the Fourth Service Command, Atlanta, Ga., warned 600 members of the National Conference of Christians and Jews in a speech yesterday describing the Army of the United States as "the greatest demonstration of unity with diversity ever offered."
PARIS, Dec. 15 -- The difficulties attending the purge of collaborators with Germany were well exemplified today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President Roosevelt today approved and thereby made law the bill opening the pension rolls to nearly every widow and minor child of men who served in the first World War.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The republics of this hemisphere will meet March 15 at a conference to plan their post-war economic policies which may prove to be a preliminary to the international conference on commercial policies which was projected at the international financial and monetary conference in July, officials said today.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 15 -- A preparation held of value in treating ulcers, a method of prospecting through seismic surveys and developments in protective coatings for fruit and vegetables are among the 553 patents listed as granted in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 16 (U.P.) -- American heavy bombers broke a two-day lull in the air war yesterday by attacking rail and industrial targets in the Reich from both Britain and Italy, while Royal Air Force heavies hit Ijmuiden in daylight and strongly attacked Ludwigshafen last night.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The feature in today's stock markets was the fluctuation in diamond shares following the announcement of cuts in dividends and reduced profits of the De Beers and Consolidated diamond companies. However, selling was not heavy, and with support later forthcoming prices began to climb, but without reaching yesterday's level.

RICHMOND, Calif., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Slammin' Sam Snead, the man with the biggest punch in golf, staged a garrison finish today to tie darkhorse Jimmy Walkup Jr. of San Antonio for the lead at the halfway mark of the 72-hole Richmond open golf tournament for $7,500 in war bonds.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Sewell Avery, as board chairman of Montgomery Ward Co., addressed "to all Montgomery Ward people" tonight a statement saying:

ABOARD ADMIRAL STRUBLE'S FLAGSHIP OFF MINDORO, Dec. 15 (U.P.) -- Japanese planes attacked this convoy of 150 ships for two days as it steamed through the Mindanao and Sulu Seas on its way to spill American infantrymen ashore on the southwest coast of Mindoro Island this morning.

ALBANY, Dec. l5 -- The Continental Bank and Trust Company, 30 Broad Street, New York, has received permission to establish common trust funds under the titles "the first legal common trust fund of the Continental Bank and Trust Company of New York" and "the first discretionary common trust fund of the Continental Bank and Trust Company of New York," the State Banking Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Proposing a joint Allied resolution making crimes against Jews in Europe punishable as war crimes, Senator Guy M. Gillette of Iowa in a speech on the Senate floor urged today all possible steps to rescue the 1,500,000 persons who he said were still in Axis territory.

The surest proof that Americans know "the war is not over" came yesterday from the Treasury Department in Washington, which reported that the closing days' sales in the Sixth War-Loan, which will end today, were outmatching the closing phases of previous campaigns.

Some recent events in liberated parts of Europe -- and notably, of course, those in Greece -- are obviously not what most of us had hoped for and expected. We had thought of liberation as a honeymoon. If it is that, it too often resembles the honeymoon in which bride and groom have their first quarrel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The National War Labor Board ordered Montgomery Ward Co. today to comply with its directives in six more cities by Monday or the matter would be certified to Fred M. Vinson, Director of Economic Stabilization, for possible recommendation that the President order seizure of the properties.

The possibility that New York City's 10,000 retail butchers might forego the planned meat "holiday" scheduled to begin on Christmas Day vas held out yesterday. It was indicated by the dealers' representatives that a postponement in the date might result if officials of the Office of Price Administration and the War Food administration in Washington sit with them and discuss livestock ceilings "on the hoof."

The German trawler Externsteine, captured by the Coast Guard off the coast of Greenland, arrived safely in Boston but only after a thirty-day struggle against icy seas that her prize crew of twenty-eight men and three officers all agree were overcome with the aid of a kind Providence.

While resumption of manufacture of civilian appliances has been stalled in some companies, other companies are meeting early production schedules allotted them by the War Production Board before emphasis again was shifted back to war output, announcements by three companies indicated yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A Congressional committee accused the Maritime Commission today of showing favoritism to a private company, East Coast Shipyards, Inc., of Bayonne, N.J.

A Pre-Christmas observance will be held on Thursday at 12:30 P.M. in the form of a Solemn Pontifical Mass in the recently consecrated temporary Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Victory at 23 William Street, on which site after the war a permanent edifice will be erected.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 15 -- The first eyewitness account to reach Sweden of the latter days of the battle for Budapest was given today by a Swedish engineer, Ernst Elgerus, who has just arrived here from the beleaguered Hungarian capital.

For the seventh time this year, but the first time since July 5, trading on the New York Stock Exchange crossed the 2,000,000-share level yesterday. Stocks advanced on a broad front and closed at the best levels of the movement.

Junior riders were in their element last night at the opening session of the Brooklyn winter horse show in the Teevan Riding Academy. The exhibition will be concluded today, with afternoon and evening performances.

In issuing its December list of 100 recommended books yesterday the Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee made special note of "Freedom Through Education," by John D. Redden and Francis A. Ryan; "Love One Another," by Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen; "Lee's Lieutenants," by Douglas S. Freeman, and "The Scarlet Lily," by Edward F. Murphy.

In its first "concrete steps" to help relieve the serious lag in foster home placement the Welfare Council of New York's child-care committee submitted yesterday a series of recommendations which were accepted by representatives of sixteen public and private child-placement agencies.
Marian Kalayjian, pianist, made her New York debut in a recital last night at Town Hall. She played a program of Bach, Scarlatti, Beethoven, Chopin, Khatchatourian, Philipp and Dohnanyi.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Prime Minister Churchill misquoted the Atlantic Charter during today's debate on Poland and was accused by K.M. Pickthorn, Conservative member for Cambridge University, of not having read it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan, suggested wage increases today as a partial solution of persistent manpower shortages in critical branches of industry, such as foundries.

A children's librarian in the New York City libraries must be a college graduate, with an additional year's training in a recognized library school. She must love children and possess the imagination and enthusiasm which will make her successful in dealing with them.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 15 -- Ferenc Szalasi, puppet Premier, and what remained in Budapest of his Government, "surrendered" on Monday what was left of the Hungarian capital to German SS General Winckelmann and fled to Kitzbuehel in the Austrian Tyrol, according to a neutral diplomat who arrived in Berne today en route to a southwest European country.

Aggregate short positions on the New York Stock Exchange jumped last month from 1,373,540 to 1,436,271 shares, the highest figure since June, 1933. Neither figure includes short positions in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers, which were 37,079 on Nov. 30 and 39,836 on Oct. 31.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 15 -- Heralding The Chattanooga Times and THE NEW YORK TIMES as monuments to the genius and journalistic craftsmanship of Adolph S. Ochs, speakers at ceremonies commemorating today the seventy-fifth anniversary of the founding of The Chattanooga Times, declared that the secret of the success of these publications could be found in the principles laid down for them by the publisher.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Parisians who are looking forward eagerly to their first free Christmas in four years will have to do their celebrating on less than the same slim diet they have had since liberation. There will be no turkey for supper after Christmas Eve mass and few bonbons for the children.

Probably the most important news for the Eastern ski world this season, apart from the favorable weather thus far, and the reopening of resorts, hitherto closed, came from Big Bromley in Manchester, Vt., yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Chinese forces, counter-attacking against the recent Japanese drive into Kweichow Province, made further gains today. They now are closing in on and outflanking the town of Hochih in Kwangsi Province on the Kweichow-Kwangsi railroad, ninety-five miles northwest of the former American air base at Liuchow, the Chinese High Command announced.

Two sisters -- one a former riveter -- were arrested here yesterday and accused of serving as distributors of marijuana, after seizure of what was described as the largest shipment of the narcotic yet discovered here. A brother of the women was arrested, with his wife, on a farm near Cape Girardeau, Mo. Marijuana valued at $238,400 was confiscated here and in Missouri.

Last April housewives salvaged about 18,000,000 pounds of kitchen fats. Now the monthly rate has decreased to approximately 13, 000,000 pounds. Unfortunately, the slump in collections has come at a time when, according to the American Fat Salvage Committee, which supplies us with these figures, "the position of this country with respect to supplies of fats and oils is rapidly becoming more serious than at any time since the beginning of the war."

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins yesterday upheld Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine, who had denied a "taxi-dance" hall license to John J. McAndrew of 150 East Fourteenth Street, and in another case overruled License Commissioner Paul Moss, who had refused an employment license to the Society of Models, Inc., of 1 East Forty-fourth Street.

Although War Production Order L-260-A, which limits the amount of materials furniture producers can use in any quarter, has not been amended or repealed, manufacturers appealing for more materials under the order are now being told to apply under Priorities Regulation 25 (spot authorization), it was learned yesterday.

At exercises commemorating the 153d anniversary of the ratification of the "charter that gave us our four freedoms," in historic St. Paul's Church, Eastchester, the national shrine of the Bill of Rights, Kent Cooper, executive director of The Associated Press, warned last night against the dissemination after the war of foreign propaganda in the guise of news by the United States Government.

ROME, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The line-up for tomorrow's finals in the second annual Mediterranean inter-Allied boxing championships was completed today with nineteen United States fighters in the running for the sixteen titles -- eight each in the amateur and professional divisions.
KANDY, Ceylon, Dec. 15 (UP) -- A communique:
Thursday's communique, as broadcast domestically from Bucharest and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed during November was 836,541 bales of lint and 122,304 bales of linters, compared with 795,379 of lint and 125,722 of linters in October, this year, and 858,877 of lint and 109,679 of linters in November, last year.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 21 (Delayed) (AP) -- Air smuggling -- fabulous by comparison with the most notorious exploits of the old sea-runners -- is estimated to have netted Americans $4,000,000 in two years of flying over the "top of the world," it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Permission was granted today for the removal of a parrot from a kitchen in Canada to a living room in the United States, all in the same house.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Communique 251:

Speaking at length yesterday in the House of Commons on another of the several difficult and pressing political questions which have arisen to plague Allied policy, Mr. Churchill laid before Parliament what he described as "the grim, bare bones of the Polish problem."

The people of this busy, bustling city have come by the reputation, rightly or wrongly, of living in their stone structures without ever giving a thought to the man who lives upstairs or down, or across the corridor. New Yorkers hustle in and out of their burrows, each one engrossed in his own concerns.

WITH AMERICAN NINTH ARMY, in Germany, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Already plagued by shortages of ammunition and tires, American forces on the Western Front now are confronted with the problem of obtaining trained infantry replacements.
Mrs. T.G. Townsend Phillips has come to the Pierre from Newport, R.I.

DETROIT, Dec. 15 -- State police helped to maintain "law and order" at the Royal Oak store of Montgomery Ward late today after an employe was injured and scores of customers were prevented from entering the store as a result of strike disturbances.

Representatives of four agencies that offer a variety of services to returning veterans described yesterday the work of their organizations to 200 leaders and workers in the welfare field at the first of a series of open information meetings sponsored by the Welfare Council of New York City at the Friends Meeting House, 221 East Fifteenth Street.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Prime Minister Churchill, exposing in the House of Commons today "the grim, bare bones" of the Polish problem, ranged Britain at Russia's side in her demands for that part of Poland east of the Curzon Line, including Vilna and Lwow.

WITH LANDING FORCES ON MINDORO, Dec. 15 -- American assault waves went ashore this morning on Mindoro Island without meeting a single enemy rifle shot on the beaches, and ninety minutes thereafter the most forward elements have driven more than a mile inland through dry sugar cane and rice fields and scattered coconut groves.

ROME, Dec. 15 -- Allied headquarters today took off the lid from the program of converting non-combat troops from all branches of the service into front-line infantrymen. The program, now centered at one of the best training sites in Italy, has already turned out hundreds of brand-new doughboys and a peak enrollment of more than 10,000 is expected within sixty days.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, Dec. 15 -- Pacific Fleet carrier forces have carried the heavy air strikes against the northern Philippines into the second day and have destroyed another 133 enemy planes, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced this morning.
ATHENS, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Regency question was discussed today by Ambassador Leeper, Mr. Macmillan and Themistocles So phoulis, Greek elder statesman, among others.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Saturday, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A communique:

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, Ninth Air Force, France, Dec. 15 -- Unreserved appreciation of the part being played by the United States Ninth Air Force in crushing the German Army was expressed today by Lieut. Gen. Omar N. Bradley, commanding general of the Twelfth Army Group.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Senate approved unanimously today the nomination of four top-ranking Army officers as Generals of the Army and three Navy leaders as Admirals of the Fleet. The promotions were sent to the Capitol soon after President Roosevelt signed the five-star commander bill authorizing the new ranks.

Christmas trade here reached its peak this week. Although sales of leading 'department stores here on Thursday failed to exceed the record highs of the preceding Thursday, the week as a whole is expected to run 22 per cent or more !over the comparative week of 1943.

What can be done by the veteran himself and how should the civilian population be prepared to receive him," are the two outstanding problems facing Governmental veterans' agencies, Maj. Gen. T.A. Terry, commanding general of the Second Service Command, asserted yesterday at a luncheon opening the national drive of the Disabled American Veterans to collect $10,000,000 to aid wounded soldiers of this war.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Finland offered today to pay her $235,445 war debt installment, but apparently it will not be accepted.

WITH THE FIRST UNITED STATES ARMY, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Convalescent patients in the First Army's hospital in Belgium, plus several hundred other GI's, saw the official American League film of the 1944 world series last night and then heard brief, entertaining talks by Mel Ott, Dutch Leonard, Bucky Walters and Frankie Frisch.

As the director of medical science of the Rockefeller Foundation Dr. Alan Gregg stepped forward at the recent National Conference on the Problems of Medical Care to emphasize not only the importance of research but the handicaps under which medical research is now conducted.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The text of Prime Minister Winston Churchill's address on Poland in the House of Commons today follows:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Controversy over an amendment affecting California's Central Valley threatened tonight to kill the $500,000,000 post-war Rivers and Harbors Bill.
HEADQUARTERS OF TWENTIETH BOMBER COMMAND, in India, Dec. 15 (Delayed) -The experimental phase of B-29 operations is over. The Superfortress has proved itself as an airplane and as a weapon of war.

While 400 Boy Scouts stood with American flags and their own troop colors massed in a V formation, forty-six Scouts-at-War Minute Men banners were presented to Scout troops yesterday at a Boy Scouts Sixth Bond Rally. The presentation was made by Willard K. Denton, executive manager, New York War Finance Committee, at the base of the Statute of Liberty copy in Times Square.

Alexander Kerensky, leader of the provisional Government in Russia in 1917 arid long exiled by the present regime, drew applause at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday afternoon when he told a luncheon of the Foreign Policy Association that he supported Russia's War aims and her claims to the Baltic States and eastern Poland.

Saipan Island presents a different appearance today from that viewed by sailors and marines during the invasion four months ago, according to a report, by Capt. John F. Jensen, master of the Cape Fear and veteran United States Lines' skipper, which was released here yesterday by the company.

MANY students at the Straus Junior High School, Dumont Avenue, Brooklyn, participate in a Movie and Radio Appreciation Club under the instruction of Samuel G. Gilburt. Recently, a group of 14-year-olds received an assignment to write compositions entitled "Radio in 1980."
The live steer that went to market without a ceiling price seemed this week to have kicked up trouble along a wider front than did Mrs. O'Leary's cow in 1871.

UPON a green, sharp-edged hill a plume of white appears, then another and still another. Soon the hill becomes a mass of billowing smoke and licking fire. Tiny observation planes dart in and out, spotting and locating the enemy. The clatter of light arms begins from hidden positions.

Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was rather quiet yesterday. The market closed 5 points lower to 16 points higher than on Friday. Distant months showed particular strength during the late trading.

Four welfare projects of the Juvenile Service League will gain materially from a benefit performance of John van Druten's comedy, "I Remember Mama," on Tuesday night at the Music Box. The committee for the party is under the chairmanship of Mrs. Joseph Jacobs, with Mrs. Norman P.S. Schloss and Mrs. Jeffrey Feis as co-chairmen.

TO philately's expanding gallery has been added, during the year now closing, approximately a hundred persons not previously associated with the hobby. Portraits or full-length figures or statues of men and women, some renowned in literature, music, religion, painting, sculpture, etc., or famous as rulers or statesmen, and others whose place in the world's history is relatively obscure, have been postally introduced by twenty-three countries.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Roosevelt approved today the bill to freeze the Social Security tax at 1 per cent for the coming year, but said he did it "reluctantly."

THIS substantial volume celebrates the completion of a century of fruitful activity by the oldest national medical organization in America, the American Psychiatric Association. Founded in Philadelphia in October, 1844, the American Psychiatric Association has played a prominent role these last hundred years in bringing about much needed reforms in the treatment of the mentally ill, and in organizing the medical practice of psychiatry on a scientific footing.

Inaugurating the 1945 dog show year, the American Spaniel Club will give its twenty-eighth annual specialty exhibition at the Hotel Roosevelt Saturday and Sunday, Jan. 6 and 7. Complete plans for the event are announced by Mrs. W. Morgan Churchman, chairman of the show committee.

The first week of the thirty-third annual appeal for the Neediest Cases Fund was completed yesterday with a total of 3,131 contributors, who have given $130,489.36. This generous response gives assurance that the families and fragments of families, the aged ill, homeless children and lonely individuals whose stories were told in the first 100 cases published last Sunday will have their needs met.

With replies received from readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES in thirty-one States, the District of Columbia, Mexico and Canada to a series of questions on car bodies compiled by the Society of Automotive Engineers, this article, based upon some of the motorists' views, will conclude observations on a survey aimed to obtain opinions on vehicular construction.

For their heroic action and disregard of personal safety on April 24, 1943, in towing the blazing, munitions-laden S.S. El Estero down the Hudson River to an area where an explosion would do the least damage, four tugboat captains, and through them their crews, were honored yesterday by the War Shipping Administration in a ceremony at the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue.

ROME, Dec. 16 -- The detonating fists of Marcel Cerdan provided the expected thunderbolt at the wind-up of the Allied boxing championships in the Brancaccio Theatre tonight, but it was the incredible courage and surprising skill of a 22-year-old Yank from Philadelphia which provided the second biggest thrill.

To develop adequate teachers for the post-war era, colleges and other training institutions must stress the broader aspects of a student's education and his relationship to the community at large. The teacher of tomorrow will need to do more than master a given subject and direct the learning of a specific group of young people.

I MAY as well begin at the beginning. I was 22 years old and social director of a camp on Lake Champlain in Vermont. I was directing a rehearsal of "The Emperor Jones," to be given the following evening, in which I was playing the Emperor, and things were not going well.

THERE is a huge stack of not-too-green magazine fodder from the past years, selected for your bedside benefit. If your taste in fiction coincides with the editor's -- and if you prefer to read yourself to sleep with a boy-meets-girl formula rather than the last chapters of a whodunit -- "The Bedside Bonanza" should earn a place on your night table.

ROME, Dec. 16 -- The situation in Sicily, where rioting occurred in a number of cities, especially Catania, yesterday and Thursday, was obscured today by an almost complete news blackout. Even the Ministry of the Interior had no information this evening and Under-Secretary Enrico Mole, who had originally called a press conference, had to cancel it, since he had no news to give out.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 16 -President Getulio Vargas' open condemnation of high protective tariffs and customs barriers to act as stimulants for post-war trade has served as food for much discussion here. As the tempo of war increases and victory comes closer, Brazil is watching world-trade policies increasingly.

Plans for post-war functioning of new "super" buying set-ups in the department store field are being actively pushed and will stress actual economies derived from joint development and promotion of staple merchandise in close cooperation with manufacturers rather than merely huge combines of buying power, according to views expressed in retail quarters last week.

MOSCOW, Dec. 16 -- It is only objective reporting for this correspondent to say that Alexander Korneichuk's satire on American life, "Mr. Perkins' Mission to the Land of the Bolseviks," is not a good play.

A day no one expected to arrive is here. It's the day of the National Football League's championship play-off game between the New York Giants, Eastern titleholders, and the Green Bay Packers, holders of the Western crown.

In west and east, the slow but steady pressure upon Germany was maintained last week. The offensive in the west, and particularly that part of it in the Cologne Plain area, continues to be the most important of the two principal land campaigns of Europe which are now merging into one.

The conflict in Greece that has drawn to the coalition Government the support of British armed forces was attributed yesterday by Nicholas G. Lely, Minister in charge of Greek Information Services in the United States, to a "coup d'etat" by a minority Communist faction aided by the Elas army.

Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National Chairman who has st returned from a month's vacation in Arizona, will confer tonight ith Governor Dewey at the Hotel Roosevelt on strengthening the national party organization in preparation for the 1946 Congressional selections.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 16 -- Owing to public sentiment, prison reform is gaining headway in the Deep South.

OTTAWA, Dec. 16 -- While New York is threatened with a shortage of turkeys and beef at Christmas, Canada finds herself plentifully supplied and at ceiling prices that somehow manage to satisfy the producer, the wholesaler, the retailer and the consumer.
