Rallying in the final period, the Andrew Jackson High School basketball team managed to squeeze out a one-point triumph over Jamaica High yesterday at Madison Square Garden. Holders of the P.S.A.L. championship and a decided favorite to beat their south Queens rivals, the Jackson players had to fight down to the final whistle to record a 32-31 triumph.

The marriage of Mrs. Eugenia Howard Lewis, daughter of Mrs. John Roy of 111 East Forty-eighth Street and Scarborough-on-Hudson, and the late Eugene Howard Lewis, to Col. Robert P. Glassburn, USA, retired, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Glassburn of Chicago, took place yesterday afternoon in the Episcopal Chapel of St. Cornelius the Centurion on Governors Island.

IN her two novels Mrs. Cooper used wit and perception to apply a fresh coat of paint to the tired old community of Suburbia. Now, in a collection of short stories introducing little Mrs. Findlay, she works further transformation.

ROME, Dec. 16 -- Prime Minister Churchill's speech yesterday in the House of Commons was likened to a death knell for Poland and the Baltic States in comments today of the representative Polish and Baltic colonies here.

Helen Keller, noted deaf-blind author, now on a coast-to-coast visit of military hospitals, has won high praise from Army officers as a morale-builder, it was reported yesterday by the American Foundation for the Blind, 15 West Sixteenth Street, the organization sponsoring the tour.

FOR eight years now Alice P. Hackett of Publishers' Weekly, the trade journal, has been digging up facts about best sellers, which she will incorporate in a sort of reference book on the subject, "Fifty Years of Best Sellers, 1895-1945," to be published early next year by R.R. Bowker Company.
BURCOTE BROOK, England, Dec. 16 (AP) -- John Masefield, poet laureate, said today that he believed that Russia would be one of the strongest forces for peace in the post-war world.

THE inner crisis in our civilization must be resolved before the outer crisis can be effectively met. Our first duty is to revamp our ideas and values and to reorganize the human personality around its highest and most central needs.

THE New York City Center of Music and Drama is turning to thought of Christmas these days, and will celebrate the holiday with a musical pageant entitled "Children's Christmas Story.'' Sixty children from New York and New Jersey schools will reenact the nativity and there will be a musical program supplied by the New York City Symphony directed by Leopold Stokowski, and the Collegiate Chorale conducted by Robert Shaw.

A PROGRAM commended to all listeners is the Jewish Theological Seminary's presentation of "The Eternal Light" at 12 noon Sundays on WEAF and at 11 A.M. on other stations of the NBC network. Technically, it is listed as a "religious program," but that is to do it a gross disservice.

Preparing for an increasing number of contract terminations, controllers are now studying the special amortization features which may be applied to facilities acquired for war production with the aid of "necessity certificates" no longer needed in the war effort, it was learned yesterday.

DETROIT, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Montgomery Ward Co., confronted by picket lines of striking CIO unionists at its four Detroit area stores, sought a second injunction today against violence and interference with its non-striking employes

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The expected confirmation by the Senate next week of the nominations of an Under-Secretary and five Assistant Secretaries of State will clear the way for Secretary Edward R. Stettinius Jr. to proceed with the reorganization of the State Department he has planned with the view of placing it in a position to discharge our international obligations in the new world that is emerging out of the war.
ANTWERP, Dec. 15 (Delayed) -- The first ship to enter the port of Antwerp flying the Belgian flag since the liberation steamed up the Schelde River this week.

The largest offering of shares of a bank since 1929 has been announced for tomorrow. Involving more than $40,000,000 at current market prices, it consists of 800,000 common shares of the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association, whose principal offices are in San Francisco and Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Families of soldiers who have died in service, members of the armed services and veterans should inquire carefully into new provisions governing National Service Life Insurance.

The seventeen hundred colleges of the United States are involved, along with hundreds of thousands of commercial and industrial enterprises and millions of farms, in the problem of military training during peacetime in the future. This is the week of the winter solstice, time when astronomical calculations find the sun at its southern nadir and declare that winter is upon us. The night governs the skies, a night of nearly fifteen hours in this latitude; and the day has but a little more than nine hours of sunlight. Thus winter comes.

NO one in touch with the people of this country has any doubt that there is a deep and sincere intention to make the present sacrifice of our soldiers a permanent accomplishment for American ideals. They do not intend to bestow posthumous honors on military heroes and then allow the sons for whom they died to be drafted for a third World War.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Superfortresses of the Twentieth Air Force's two bomber commands now are hammering Japan and occupied territory every fourth or fifth day, and sometimes more frequently, in contrast with the time lag of two to three weeks that prevailed in the opening period of this new air war.
Sgt. Frank Parker of the Army Air Forces, stationed at Muroc Field, Calif., heads the national tennis rankings for the first time after appearing in the top ten for the past eleven years.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Dec. 16 -- The Germans drew an armored division from another front and hurled it today at the United States Seventh Army, which poured more troops into the Reich's Palatinate after having smashed the enemy stand in the French frontier cities of Lauterbourg and Scheibenhard.

WHILE the well selected exhibition of work by the late Marsden Hartley at the Museum of Modern Art continues on into January, illustrating the range and chronological development of the artist, three new exhibitions centering in Hartley's paintings and drawings have opened in galleries.

British manufacturers of printing equipment already have resumed exports to Latin America, Louis A. Lara, export manager, J.M. Huber, Inc., printing-ink manufacturers, disclosed last week. American producers, however, have not been able to make similar shipments, he said.

Bridge House, the city's retreat for alcoholics seeking to span the gap between habitual drunkenness and sobriety by means of a "mental diet" designed to restore self-respect, was officially opened yesterday afternoon by Mayor La Guardia.

Greater emphasis upon inclusion of science and humanities subjects in both professional and liberal courses of study, and on the use of extra-curricular activities for educational purposes were approved by the Pacific northwest conference on teaching the arts and sciences held at Washington State College.

The first and only Junior Assembly for this winter takes place Saturday night the Ritz-Carlton, which has been its locale for many years. This will be the fourth consecuive year there has been but one dance, instead of the traditional three, of the "Juniors," the most exclusive of all subscription dances for debutantes.

For the second time in eight days Prime Minister Winston Churchill last week appeared before Parliament to explain British policies concerning the liberated countries and the future of Europe. RICHMOND, Calif., Dec. 16 -Slammin' Sam Snead, home-run hitter of the golfing world, kept up his sub-par golf today to lead in the 72-hole Richmond open tournament with a 54-hole total of 208.

The Allied Stores Corporation and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $2,020,818 for the three months ended on Oct. 31 after a provision of $4,900,000 for Federal excess profits taxes, normal taxes and surtaxes on income, according to a report issued yesterday.

THE story of collecting can be profitably regarded as a large part of the story of man himself. Douglas and Elizabeth Rigby open their book with a brief discussion of the motivations of the collector, their analysis being sociological rather than biological.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- A familiar stage has been reached again in the air warfare in the west. Since Dec. 4 British and American heavy bomber forces have attacked every main railway leading from the interior of Germany to the Western Front and every important marshaling yard on these routes.

The liberation of a nitrogenous substance by injured cells may offer an explanation for the development of fever that comes with inflammations, according to recent discoveries announced in Science by Dr. Valy Menkin of the Department of Pathology in the Duke University School of Medicine.

WITH THE SEVENTY-SEVENTH DIVISION, on Leyte, Dec. 14 (Delayed) (AP) -- The battle of Coconut Grove, north of the fallen city of Ormoc, was nearing its end tonight after three days of some of the most bitter fighting of the Leyte campaign.

CACTI have come a long way from the desert and mesas surrounding the ancient home of the cliff dweller in the Southwest to the window sill of the modern cliff dweller in an Eastern apartment. These diverse locations -- the desert and the window garden -- have in common, however, a dry atmosphere tolerated only by plants capable of storing up a reserve of moisture to carry them through drought.

N.J., disclosed today at a hearing before the Securities and Exchange Commission that H.V. Coes of Ford, Bason Davis of New York, consulting engineers, had recommended that the late William T. Hedlund be removed as president of Stop Nut.

LONDON, Dec. 16 (U.P.) -- American and British heavy bombers attacked rail targets near Stuttgart and Cologne today in continuance of the campaign to knock out German communication lines to the Western Front. American bombers from bases in Italy roared over the Alps and attacked an oil center in the Sudetenland and Innsbruck, Austria, rail center on the north of the Brenner Pass line.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Production of civilian goods in the first quarter of 1945 will be held to the levels now prevailing under an order by the War Production Board.

IN the latest volume of the "Humanizing Science" series, Percy A. Morris, chief preparator of the Peabody Museum, writes for the lay reader of the "cold-blooded" creatures -- snakes, lizards, crocodiles and alligators, turtles and tortoises, frogs and toads, newts and salamanders -- that make up a little-known and much-maligned branch of the animal kingdom.

IT is just ten years since a book by two young London rare book dealers, John Carter and Graham Pollard, with the colorless title "An Enquiry into the Nature of Certain Nineteenth-Century Pamphlets," turned out to be -- to say the least -- sensational.

ROME, Dec. 16 (AP) -- British and Polish troops and tanks, closing a ring around strategic Faenza, on the edge of the Po plain, gouged out a foothold today on a dominating ridge two miles west of the city as heavy fighting flared abruptly along almost half the Italian front.

Advocating international agreements to stabilize "fair prices" and to provide economic security for the Latin-American nations, Frederick E. Hasler, president of the Pan-American Society, declared yesterday that the United States and Great Britain must keep a higher standard of living in the countries of Latin America or risk their insecurity and revolution.

In response to a plea posed by a University of California professor, a group of Thirteenth Armored Division soldiers have formed what is believed to be the first GI committee to study the problem of post-war education for war veterans.

THE fire crackled on the hearth of the Bear Mountain Inn. Steve Owen shivered slightly, and it was not from the chill of an early September night. The fire made the room comfortable. His thoughts gave him the shivers. Turning to Red Smith, his right-hand man, Stout Steve made a confession. "Red," he drawled slowly, "I honestly don't see how we're going to win a game this season."

DISPATCHES from the White Mountains tell of plans for a lively winter. Heavy snows are putting all sports into high, and good skiing in some places raises hopes of perfect skiing in all runs as the new year approaches.

LONDON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Norwegian Government reported today that sabotage had broken out "throughout the length and breadth" of the homeland in the path of the Germans retreating from northern Norway before the Russians.

MAY 31 -- It has been said of Sgt. Zeke Manners that when he found he couldn't keep up with some of his younger colleagues in the matter of accelerated marching, he at least had the fortitude to develop what he called the fastest limp in the Army.

SHALL the United States demand new overseas ports and bases at the close of this war? Anybody who has been among American soldiers and sailors in New Caledonia, the New Hebrides and the Solomons, or in the Mediterranean and Red Sea areas, knows they have debated the subject furiously for two years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, declared today that in the Detroit strike Sewell Avery, president of Montgomery Ward Co., had "drawn a veil" over its "refusal to increase its substandard wages" by "repeating his misstatements regarding maintenance of membership."

The stuff of a real conductor was manifested when Dean Dixon, the Negro batonist, appeared with the American Youth Orchestra, the orchestra then making its debut, last night in Carnegie Hall. If Mr. Dixon fulfills the promise of this concert, he is going to be one of the leading talents among our young conductors of the present day.

ROME, Dec. 16 -- A midnight mass will be celebrated this Christmas Eve by Pope Pius XII for the first time in his pontificate and the whole of Rome will be lighted for the occasion, it was announced here today.

DOWN below the equator in the far-flung islands of the south Pacific, among the numerous qualifications which might entitle you to be called "island happy" is hearing voices like the voice of your girl whispering to you in the evening.

IF it is sunshine they seek New Yorkers who are accustomed to head South when the snow flies might consider staying home this year. They will have to go a long way to find much more sunshine than they will probably get right here in New York.

APPARENTLY the temptation was too strong to resist. Months ago, when those in the theatre who are supposed to study such matters noted that New Year's Eve would fall on a Sunday night, there was consternation in the ranks.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, Dec. 16 -- The greatest air attacks yet sent against enemy harbors and land installations around Luzon went into its third day yesterday as powerful American carrier forces continued large-scale operations in support of the Mindoro landings.

Wall Street wants the Securities and Exchange Commission to protect investors against the uncertainties of Government cancellations of contracts with manufacturers. Sentiment is growing for an immediate move, for investment banking and Exchange circles see an unfair situation about to develop.

OMAHA, Dec. 16 -- With the sale this week of the Nebraska Power Company by its New York owner, American Light and Power, to a local non-profit corporation, private-power ownership and operation for profit virtually came to an end in Nebraska.

BOSTON, Dec. 16 -- The beginning in January of a new course to study racial and minority-group problems for the police of Boston, Cambridge and the Metropolitan District has brought favorable comment from almost all leaders in community life in this region.

AN analysis of the auto age is neither the pretty story the advertisers tell nor the vicious mechanistic one that Aldous Huxley sees. As David Cohn works it out, it is like a balance sheet incorporating so many American stockholders that it embraces almost all their character debits and credits.

A SURPRISING, extremely pleasant and important event is beginning to take shape in America: people with neither special talent nor special training are turning to painting. Some years ago adult art classes were having hard sledding. Now people in relatively large numbers flock into art schools and workrooms whenever there is a teacher and an invitation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Department of Interior, in a brief filed with the Civil Aeronautics Board as an intervenor in the proceedings on the certification of new air routes, attacked the "stultifying effects" of Pan American Airways' "monopoly" in air service to Puerto Rico.

Improvements in child health through the administration of certain synthetic vitamins to malnourished infants and children were outlined recently by Dr. Tom D. Spies, associate professor of medicine of the College of Medicine, University of Cincinnati, and director of nutrition at the Hillman Hospital, Birmingham Ala.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 16 -- The New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards pledged its members today to safeguard the rights and interests of veterans purchasing homes and other property under the GI Bill of Rights.

CHRISTMAS traditionally is the time when homes and streets, towns and cities, put on holiday dress and reflect a festive spirit. Of the customs maintained in this country, none is more heart-warming. Many communities have already started to display their Christmas decorations.

Exceeding by three showings her previous high in New York, Sonja Henie will open an all-time record personal appearance of eighteen performances in Madison Square Garden, Wednesday night, Jan. 17. The former Olympic champion will once again be the star of the newest version of her Hollywood Ice Revue.

It will be the Canadiens of Montreal against the Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Flying Frenchmen, holders of the Stanley Cup and the championship of the world, always attract a large crowd when they display their skating ability in this city, and their appearance in the Garden tonight is likely to draw more than 15,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- A new responsibility assigned to draft boards under the revised manpower program this week carries special significance for about 4,264,000 men, 18 to 37, who are carrying II-A and II-B (essential occupation) cards in their wallets.

Christmas trade was extremely heavy last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors were jammed in many instances, and gift departments generally were crowded.

GENE KELLY has never had much use for bar bells, Indian clubs or boxing gloves. The only athletic equipment he acknowledges are his dancing shoes. That's why he startled the Army doctors who commented on the ruggedness of his build when he was summoned for his pre-induction physical examination.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- Tenders of 200,000 bushels of cash wheat on December contracts in Minneapolis resulted today in old crop months developing a weaker undertone on the Chicago Board of Trade. There was no aggressive buying here, and closing sales were about the bottom, with losses as of 7/8 to 1 cent a bushel.
Benito Mussolini spoke yesterday from his Government's puppet headquarters in Milan, asserting that his regime faced "unbelievable and ever-increasing difficulties" in the shifting fortunes of war.

In the United States and in Britain, experience with the psychoses so far encountered in this war shows many of them to be of a benign and rapidly recoverable type, Col. John H. Baird, Army Medical Corps, Washington, pointed out yesterday in an address before the Association for Research in Nervous and Mental Disease at its twenty-fifth annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Sybil Copeland, 16-year-old violinist from East London, South Africa, was the soloist yesterday at the Christmas concert in the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's series for young people, led by Rudolph Ganz. Miss Copeland played the first movement of Lalo's "Symphonie Espagnole" for violin and orchestra, Allegro non troppo.

In Washington last week attention was focused for a time on the huge, old-fashioned caucus room of the Senate Office Building. There under the ornate crystal chandeliers, seated around a square of tables replete with microphones, note paper and ash trays, members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee were presiding over a public hearing on nominations for State Department posts.

" HAVING selected Cagnessur-Mer," says Mr. Pratt, "because we believed it must be from its name, directly on the Mediterranean, as the place we would live in Provence, we promptly discovered it was located on a formidable hill a mile and a half from the water.

SIGNALIZING the return of its irreplaceable treasures of books, manuscripts and works of art, which for more than two years have been in safekeeping elsewhere for wartime protection, the Morgan Library has opened an exhibition, "The Written Word," which includes more than a hundred of the choicest examples in the great collection.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- An attorney for the National Association of Broadcast Engineers and Technicians (NABET), said tonight that the union had given notice on National Broadcasting Company and the Blue Network that a strike would be called on seventy-two hours' notice unless they agreed promptly to give NABET jurisdiction over turntable operations in the studios.

In wartime, by special provision of law, producers of war materials have been induced to invest in emergency facilities by granting to them amortization allowances by which the cost of such facilities is recovered by deductions from taxable income within a shorter period of time than the depreciation period.

RICHMOND, Dec. 16 -- The only public comment in the Upper South concerning the Southern Regional Council's seven-point program for better race relations, adopted last week at its annual meeting in Atlanta, appears to have been favorable.

HERE in vivid, accurate story form is Hannibal's incredible invasion of Italy, with emphasis on the part played by the elephants. The narrative is told by Agenor, the elephant boy, who becomes Hannibal's secretary. With Agenor and Scarba, head keeper of the elephants, we live through the early anxious days when they feared their charges were to be left behind.

MONROE PILLAR has sold newspapers on the northwest corner of Forty-fifth Street in the Square the past twenty-two years. He balances on a crutch behind a low stand in front of the oval Mayflower Doughnut Shop window from twilight through 3 o'clock in the morning in all weather.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- In a resolution adopted unanimously late tonight, the convention of Liberation Committees, representing France's former underground, demanded of the Government authority to participate directly in the action of the Courts of Justice created to handle the cases of collaborators with Germany.

Outweighed and pretty much outplayed. Columbia's basketball team opened its Eastern Intercollegiate League season last night by bowing to Cornell, 50 -- 35, at the Lions' gymnasium. A group of about 1,000 fans watched the contest and cheered vainly for the Lions.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Communique 252:

THIS is a book about a great and vital matter. Do not be misled by the title, which mentions wings; nor by the author's eminence as a military airman. It is true that you will find instructive and entertaining passages in this book dealing with aviation as a thing in itself -- technical discussions, tactical and strategic appreciations, anecdotes and some biography.

In an effort to develop a sales organization to match the company's production, which has increased 60 per cent over pre-war capacity, the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company has launched a campaign "to reconvert selling" in the company's 34,700 outlets, Lee R. Jackson, executive vice president, stated last week.

Frederick A. Walker, a name that may have an unfamiliar ring until it is explained the fellow is known far and wide as Dixie, captured the individual batting championship of the National League with a mark of .357, according to the official 1944 averages released for publication today.

LONDON, Sunday, Dec. 17 (U.P.) -- The Red Army, shifting the weight of its offensive in southeastern Europe to Czechoslovakia, yesterday converged on the big Hungarian-annexed rail center of Kosice from three directions, driving to within twenty and twenty-two miles of the city on the southeast and southwest.

Walter Soltow of New Utrecht turned in something of an upset in the feature of the thirty-eighth annual Stuyvesant High School track and field meet at the 102d Regiment Armory last night. Running in the Appleton A. Mason Memorial one-mile event for schoolboys, he beat two youngsters who were highly regarded, Phillip O'Connell of Bishop Loughlin and W'illiam 1VicGuire of George Washington.

THIS monumental survey of the history of warfare consists of some 300,000 words of text. A book about peace through the ages could, undoubtedly, be written more economically. In the period from 490 B.C. to 1944 -- the temporal scope of this study -- the longest interlude of tranquillity was the Pax Romana, a peace enforced by sword and javelin.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Agreements for commercial air transport services between the United States and Denmark and Sweden were concluded today through an exchange of notes here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Pacific Fleet communique 206:

WASHINGTON. OUTWARDLY, as one visits the State Department these days, it is much as it always was. The old, ornate gray building still brings up memories of a bygone era. Erected shortly after the Civil War ended, it has been the center of our foreign relations since those days when a newly laid cable carried messages to Europe and when two weeks were considered a short time to cross the Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A large American tanker, the Jacksonville, carrying supplies to the European theatre, went down in the Atlantic several weeks ago following a "terrific explosion." There were only two survivors.

The impact of air services is expected in all maritime circles to have severe effects on the passenger-carrying revenues of steamship companies, and with this in mind the American South African Line has completed plans for a comprehensive air service as a supplement to its regular ship services to Africa, James A. Farrell Jr., president of the line, disclosed yesterday.

Last week in the Pacific the Americans staged the most daring amphibious operation of the whole war against Japan. A technique born of World War II, under the necessity of carrying the battle to hostile shores and there winning victory, it has been employed many times.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Aided by President Roosevelt's unexpected action in signing "reluctantly" the measure to freeze the Social Security payroll tax at its present level of 1 per cent, Congress recessed tonight until Monday with a prospect of quick adjournment then for the holidays.

A City College quintet that missed enough shots to alter the complexion of the struggle suffered its first defeat last night at Madison Square Garden. Their own worst enemies, as it were, Nat Holman's Beavers fell before the taller Razorbacks of the University of Arkansas, 59 -- 47, after St. Francis College of Brooklyn had succumbed to Muhienberg College, 56 -- 18.

NOW that we are approaching the end of another bout at our national pastime, the creation and crucifixion of heroes, it is time to see what is left in China. With their usual foresight of exactly this hour, the Chinese are endeavoring to maintain their equilibrium.
ROME, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A communique:

SIR ALEXANDER KORDA, Metro's British production chief, came over from London the other day on one of his periodic visits armed with the prediction that "in about five years 50 per cent" of the pictures shown in Great Britain would be stamped "Made in England."
Russian Premier Stalin to call a United Nations conference.

In the course of a dispatch to this newspaper explaining the political situation in Italy. Herbert L. Matthews, our correspondent at Rome, remarked that: "Britain, Russia and other European nations see war as an instrument of politics, but for the United States it is something purely and narrowly military -- to win the war and then go home."

WITH THE UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY, Dec. 16 -- Generals can plan their intricate campaigns down to the last wide river to cross and the last battalion to cross it. If they and their staffs are good enough, they also can provide for every chance with almost mathematical certainty.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Indications today were that some misconceptions arising out of Prime Minister Churchill's blunt speech in the House of Commons on Poland would be corrected when the expected statement was issued here, probably very soon, setting forth the attitude of the United States toward that question.

TODAY is just another day in the hard, wet, cold, slow-moving battle of Germany. Up a little ahead of us our infantrymen are fighting doggedly for petty gains, as they have been doing every day since we bit into the Siegfried Line way back in September.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Commercial vehicle operators will receive only about one-half of their estimated tire requirements in the first quarter of next year, Col. J. Monroe Johnson, Director of the Office of Defense Transportation, predicted today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Chile, India and Iran have signed the international air services transit agreement (the "two freedoms" document) since the close of the World Aviation Conference at Chicago, bringing the total to twenty-eight.

ATHENS, Dec. 16 -- Conversations concerning a possible solution of the political and constitutional questions that are at the heart of the Greek controversy and that led to the civil war were continued today. While one is cautioned against optimism, there are indications that some way will be found to bring about peace by negotiation at a date not too far off.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- A report on post-war readjustment made public today by the United States Chamber of Commerce stresses the point that the danger for America's future does not lie in objectives, on which most persons agree, but on the means to attain those objectives.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 16 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

IN what appears, to a non-linguistic reviewer, as an exceptionally smooth translation, the original documentary play offers plausible hints for the resuscitation of Broadway. Brecht, poet and exiled dramatist of Berlin's revolutionary theatre, presents as his tragic hero, Germany: time, 1933-38.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- So far this year the campaign of the Office of Defense Transportation against unnecessary travel in the various recreation periods has succeeded very well. Despite mounting wages, only 5 per cent more men, women and children packed themselves into Pullmans and passenger coaches on Washington's Birthday, the Fourth of July, Thanksgiving Day and other holidays in 1944 than did so last year.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower told the German people yesterday in the thirteenth and last of a series of proclamations that "all educational institutions except boarding schools and orphanages will be closed" in conquered Germany "until nazism has been eliminated."

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- Truck manufacturers, with an eye on pent-up demand in the post-war period, are doing a great deal of "thinking" about the commercial vehicle of the future, but leaders in the industry fairly well agree that it will be at least two years after the end of the European phase of the war before trucks of advanced design will be available.

VERY gradually, in the course of the last two decades, the music of Hector Villa-Lobos, the leading composer of Brazil and of South America, has become known in our concert halls. In a period of prevailing musical sterility it has served significantly to refresh our orchestra programs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Senate Public Lands Committee today reported that if the Jackson Hole Monument was not disestablished the proclamation under which the President created it would constitute "a dangerous precedent."

BOTH author and artist have lived in that part of California known as the Gabilans, a chain of mountains in the great Coast Range which runs along the Pacific. Out of their love and knowledge of horses and of ranch life they have made a book so vigorous and authentic that it will promptly take its place as a welcome addition to American cowboy literature.

Signs were multiplying last week that Spain faced a change of government. One rumor persisted that Gen. Francisco Franco, Caudillo (leader) of the nation and head of the Falange (Fascist) party, had resigned. Another report said that Franco and his aides had been on a "hunting trip" in southern Spain, with special attention to the hotels.

STOCKHOLM, Dec. 16 -- With the approach of winter, Germany is in a tighter spot than she has ever been in before during this war. So every report received here indicates, but the Goebbels-run Reich radio steadfastly refuses to recognize that the situation is bad.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 16 -- Fordham's basketball team held Princeton to a 31-28 lead in the first half today, but the second period saw the Tigers score 42 points to register a 73-51 victory.

Retailers expect to close the year with the smallest stocks on hand in many years, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. The new worsted freeze order, the report pointed out, caused still more difficulties in the placing of spring business.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Dec. 16 -Deep concern over the British intervention in Greece and the subsequent developments was expressed by more New Zealand labor unions today. The National Carpenters Union declared that the British Government policy and Prime Minister Churchill's statements seriously endangered the Allies' united front in the fight against fascism and affirmed the belief that the Greek situation could be solved only by the Greeks ther selves and not by British bayonets.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 (AP) --Dartmouth, seeking its eighth straight Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League title, romped over Pennsylvania tonight by a 50-35 score.

" SYMPHONIES for Youth," featuring the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Alfred Wallenstein, begins a weekly music series over WOR-Mutual on Saturday, Jan. 6. It will be heard from 1:30 to 2:30 P.M.

The initial reaction of American labor to Winston Churchill's announcement that England would support Russia's demands in Poland came yesterday at the American Labor Conference on International Affairs as William Green, conference chairman and president of the American Federation of Labor, expressed the hope that "our own country will say 'no' to those who seek to apportion the territory of Poland."

AMONG several apt observations on the homemaker's art which New York's Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia made at the opening of the two-day homemaking clinic sponsored by the New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office was a pertinent dig on the matter of books.

CANTERBURY, England, Dec. 16 (U.P.) -- The Dean of Canterbury, the Very Rev. Hewlett Johnson, said today that Prime Minister Churchill's policy in handling the Greek crisis was "perilously fascist" and that he had done "irreparable damage to British ideals and morals which we are supposed to be fighting for."

To compensate blind school children for the lack of the stimulation that comes from visual illustrations in textbooks, the American Foundation for the Blind, 15 West Sixteenth Street, is now utilizing long-playing phonograph disks of the Talking Book to bring "illustrations" to the sightless youngsters in the medium they can comprehend -- that of sound.

LITTLE girls said they liked dolls and tea sets, little boys chose balls, cars and marbles, when, in a recent survey of children's play interests, pupils in primary grades were asked "What are your favorite toys?" Girls in fourth and fifth grades voted for cut-out paper dolls; boys for marbles, wagons and bicycles.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16 -West Coast opinion appeared to have swung around this week to the view that Congressional delegations, State Senate committees, the California Native Sons' organization, various Legion posts and Hearst and McClatchey newspapers were fighting a losing battle to keep persons of Japanese ancestry out of Coast States before the end of the war.
TO the community theatre director today, confronted by shortages, etc., the production of plays can often fall under the general classification of "Headaches on the Home Front."

NEXT Tuesday evening Duke Ellington and his orchestra will give what is described as a "swing concert'' at Carnegie Hall. Whether it be called a swing concert or a jazz concert, or just a concert of good music, is not important.

The final combination of American and British naval power in the Pacific, long dreaded by the Japanese, is near at hand. Admiral Sir Bruce Fraser's fighting fleet, headed by the great new battleship Howe, is moving into Australian waters. It will be based on Sydney and other east coast ports which not long ago served our Navy.

On a gusty morning forty-one years ago today, from the crown of a series of sand dunes called Kill Devil Hill, a few miles outside the little North Carolina seacoast town of Kitty Hawk, an American-designed and built airplane made the first powered flight by a machine heavier than the air through which it flew.

OTTAWA, Dec. 16 -- Scores of French-speaking Canadian officers of the Canadian Army, all volunteers, parachuted into France before D-day to help organize and command the Maquis in special tasks, it was revealed here when some of these heroes arrived home for Christmas leave.

MOSCOW, Dec. 16 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister Churchill's speech on Poland was understood today from the Russian viewpoint to have put a highly welcome end to the wrangling over the Polish question and to have opened up a perspective toward new methods of dealing with it.

Dep't of English, Darthmouth College IT is less than a year since the death of James Boyd, known to a wide public for his "Drums" and other novels based on American history. But, as Mr. Boyd's friend of many years, Paul Green, tells us in a warmly appreciative foreword to these poems, "a poetic feeling * * * is sensed all through his novels.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday ended the most active week in six months. Closing prices were mixed and volume crossed the 1,000,000-share level for the twelfth consecutive session. Turnover was the second largest for a Saturday since June 17, running to 1,021,340 shares, against 1,044,800 a week earlier.

THIS Christmas is going to be a lean one for those wishing to give brand new recordings as gifts. Thanks largely to the recently lifted record ban the output has been unusually small, and unusually poor.
LONDON, Dec. 16 -- Britain is having a difficult time right now in adjusting her foreign policy to fit her own needs and suit the wishes of her principal Allies.

ONE of the most gratifying innovations of its long career is the National Academy's first annual show of contemporary American drawings, which opened last week and is to remain current through Jan. 10. Hitherto in the exhibitions presented by this venerable organization chief emphasis has been laid on paintings, sculpture, prints, with bows now and then to the architects.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The total number of employes in nonagricultural establishments in November was about 1,500,000 smaller than a year ago, while enrollment in the services expanded by 1,750,000, Secretary Perkins reported today.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 16 -- Two brothers were drowned today when the sled on which they were "belly-whopping" in the company of half-a-dozen other youngsters crashed through the thin ice of Old Butchers' Pond in West Paterson.

AN unheralded stamp from Argentina is a 5-centavos blue which commemorated "10 de Diciembre" as "Dia del Reservista" (Reservists' Day). Dec. 10 is set aside each year as a day on which army and navy reservists congregate around the republic's flag and resolve anew to defend their country if called upon.

WITH AMERICAN FIRST ARMY, in Germany, Dec. 16 -The Germans took the offensive today on much of the American First Army front. It was a new and violent move in the enemy's campaign to delay and harass us and make every yard of our advance as costly as possible.

AUNT SOPHY FELL'S voice is described as "fooffly," a word which appears to have escaped the attention of the lexicographers, but which seems to mean something not easily expressed in other words. If it does not eventually find a legitimate place in our language it will not be the fault of Patricia Wentworth, who is quite fond of it and of the corresponding verb, "fooffle," both of which she uses repeatedly.

Dewey as the GOP's titular leader and to frustrate whatever aspirations the New York Governor may have of becoming the party's Presidential candidate in 1948.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Three railroads, the Louisville Nashville, the Baltimore Ohio and the Gulf, Mobile Ohio, asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to sell refunding bonds and notes to cover the cost of new equipment.

Douglas MacArthur announced today.

THE buffet supper has always proved one of the most pleasant and popular means of entertaining, both for the hostess and the guests. This holiday season, when many of the foods usually associated with such parties -- turkey, ham, and so on -- are hard to come by, the Scandinavian smorgasbord, or sandwich table, offers a delightful variation on the theme.

IN his speech here a week ago this evening at the American Nobel Anniversary "do," Producer Darryl F. Zanuck had some sharp and significant things to say about the job of American motion pictures in "educating" the post-war world for peace.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- Severe criticism of American visitors to France, who are accused of refusing to see France's handicaps, and of the American press for giving too optimistic a picture of the war appeared today in the newspaper France Libre.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Dec. 16 -Happy Issue, game, stretch-running filly, owned and trained by C.H. (French) Pinon, who picked her up in a $1,500 claiming race, today won the fifth running of the $75,000 added Hollywood Gold Cup in the track record time of 2:01 3/5 for one mile and a quarter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Justice Department's demand for immediate trial of three concerns on charges of cartel conspiracy brought from The Army and Navy Journal today this comment: "Common sense would call for no interference with deliveries (of munitions) while the war is on."
The Randolph Field Ramblers completed their season with a perfect record yesterday to stand as the champions of the Army Air Forces, with eleven successive victories.

Postponement of the city "meat holiday" scheduled to begin on Christmas Day appeared still more likely last night, with the announcement by Daniel P. BY this time the birds have stripped the berries from their favorite dogwoods and viburnums, but who begrudges them this? They eat harmful insects, in winter consuming eggs, grubs and other potential trouble-makers and in summer catching the pests at their kinetic worst.

At her first New York recital, given in Town Hall last night, Tatiana Pobers, Russian soprano, was heard in an all-Russian program. The second half of the schedule was devoted to twelve compositions by eight Soviet composers, all of which received their initial American presentation.

MADRID, Dec. 16 -- Spain has just experienced what may be termed an "electrified week," charged as it has been with an almost continuous current of political rumors.

Albert Torek, clever horseman from Essex Fells, N.J., entered the second day of the Brooklyn winter horse show at Teevan's Riding Academy yesterday afternoon and rode away with a number of blue ribbons and the championship of the horsemanship division.

MR. NICHOLS, an experienced novelist and essayist, knows how to write. His last book, the report of one year of contact with India, has a good chance of becoming a best seller. It is a breezy book, full of provocative thoughts and vivid images which will hold the reader's interest from cover to cover; and it offers an approach to the Indian problem rarely heard in the popular literature.
TOMORROW, in the capitals of all the States, Presidential electors will meet to elect a President who already has been elected.

The Sixth War Loan drive came to a triumphant close yesterday as Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., in a nation-wide radio report, announced that when final tabulations had been made bond sales would exceed $19,000,000,000, or $5,000,000,000 more than the over-all quota set when the drive began on Nov. 20.

At last week's meeting of the American Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association in New York, Dr. Edwin J. Cohn announced that one of the fractions which he has separated from blood plasma stops the bleeding to which hemophiliacs are subject when they are scratched, pricked or cut.

ABOUT four years ago I found myself becoming more and more interested in Henry James, and it was with mixed feelings that I presently realized that I was not alone in this. All fashions are suspicious, and I ask myself if we are seeing James as a guiding star only because we are using him as a refuge.

PHILADELPHIA. Dec. 16 (AP) -- The American public liquid savings during July, August and September totaled $10,600,000,000, the highest on record, according to a Security and Exchange Commission savings study made public today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- All production of wool tops except to fill rated orders during the period Dec. 31, this year, and May 1, 1945, was prohibited by the War Production Board today through an amendment to Direction No. 3 to General Conservation Order M-73.

Freezing of large wool mill production during the first five months of 1945 for "rated" orders will not mean extensive disorganization in the production of men's and boys' clothing, manufacturers stated last week in discussing the directive.

IMPLAUSIBLE but still consistent within itself, exaggerated but still recognizable because of its old Scottish roads and houses, its old Scottish characters who would have been at home in the company of Sir James Barrie, Mr. Linklater's story offers us a dream world where strange new principles are in operation and conspire to bring about strange, bewildering events.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle returned to Paris from Moscow today bringing with him a twenty-year alliance against Germany that is independent of the world security organization outlined at Dumbarton Oaks.

THIS is the best picture book on the war that has been published to date. Editor Tom Maloney and his associates of U.S. Camera have had the highly appropriate idea of devoting their entire Annual for 1945 to photographs of Americans at war.

THE Mississippi River has been a major problem in this country since the Middle West was settled. Periodically it goes on rampages, bursting its banks, drowning people and livestock, ruining farm lands. For years attempts have been made to curb it, more or less successfully.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

OPENING nights vary. Some of them take place in a sad half gloom, with the paying part of the audience haggard and the professional part wishing to heaven it were somewhere else. Others are bright, with pretty clothes, mounted policemen and Hollywood visitors looking for autograph hunters.

Too much emphasis is being given to certain post-war slogans. "Full" employment and a $140,000,000,000 national income are two such slogans which have been overworked. The latest to be added to this group is 60,000,000 post-war jobs. This goal in effect represents the quantitative measurement of what its users deem to be necessary to achieve "full" employment.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The Polish Exile Government's intention to ask for Allied guarantees of Poland's sovereignty and independence before discussing a border settlement with the Soviet Union was disclosed today as an aftermath of Prime Minister Churchill's suggestion yesterday that the border issue be settled immediately on the basis of the Curzon Line.

Hot meals, quickly prepared in battle areas of the war, are being served to America's fighting forces by means of a three-ounce wax cake of fuel developed and perfected by Socony-Vacuum Oil chemists for the United States Army Quartermaster Corps. The cake is good for half an hour.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Important aspects of the nation's wartime problem of dealing with aliens and immigration were brought out at a recent hearing before the Senate Immigration Committee by Attorney General Biddle. Among the facts presented were these:

THE freeze of civilian goods production, announced at the week-end, marks a final drastic step in the succession of moves aimed at relieving certain critical war shortages. The first action several weeks ago was the shutting down of reconversion under the "spot authorization" plan in some 120 producing areas.

Freezing of large wool mill production during the first five months of 1945 for "rated" orders will not mean extensive disorganization in the production of men's and boys' clothing, manufacturers stated last week in discussing the directive.

Charlotte Bergen, 'cellist, gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The program comprised two Bach-Kodaly chorales; the Sonata in A minor by the eighteenth century German composer, Johann Ernst Galliard; Brahm's Sonata in E minor, the Saint-Saens concerto in A minor, and shorter pieces by Faure, Ravel and Cassado.

THE battle for the Italian town of San Vittorio is to be re-enacted, this week on the forty-acre backlot of the RKO-Pathe studio in Culver City for Lester Cowan's production, "Story of G.I. Joe." It should be quite a realistic affair, for more than 200 fully trained infantrymen, some of them veterans of European fighting, will be "working" under the watchful eyes of Army officer technical advisers.

LONDON, Dec. 14 (Delayed) -- Differences in American and British labor standards and methods of production that so long have been learnedly compared by economists were put to practical test on adjoining building sites in London this week.

Ariel La Torre and Marco Herrera, two husky young men described by the police as "carpet-creepers" and "dinner-hour burglars," are in jail today spending their time thinking glumly of the 8-year-old girl who helped put them there.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Monday, Dec. 18 (AP) -- A communique:

The Metropolitan Museum will give a special holiday exhibition, entitled "Seven Joys of Our Lady," at the Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park, beginning on Wednesday. A suitable setting has been provided with the aid of flowers, greenery and other decorations to lend background for the paintings, sculptures, carved ivories, manuscripts and related material assembled.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- Women of Great Britain, who may poll the deciding vote in the next election, are taking keener interest than ever in parliamentary discussions, and are receiving more and more consideration from party leaders, who realize that their success may depend on the appeal they make to women through support of legislation bearing on women's own postwar prospects.
ALBANY, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Preventive action against discrimination should be left solely to government agencies, the State Catholic Welfare Committee declared today.

ROME, Dec. 17 -- Acting on instructions from the British Government, Maj. Gen. Fitzroy H.R. MacLean, head of the British Military Mission in Yugoslavia, has protested officially to Marshal Tito in Belgrade against an alleged unneutral attitude in the Greek civil war.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- Although corn futures failed to get into new high seasonal ground last week on the Board of Trade here, the market showed considerable early strength, only to weaken later under the weight of offerings of cash grain for deferred shipment from the country.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Dec. 17 -- Brig. Gen. William C. Dunckel is in command of the United States ground forces on Mindoro after having led them ashore although suffering from shock and wounds on hands and arms after having been bombed the day before the landing.
A SUPERFORTRESS BASE, India, Dec. 17 -- In the recent raid on the Omura aircraft factory near Nagasaki, the Superfortress Heavenly Body was attacked by fighters as it headed for home.

With the nation's $14,000,000,000 Sixth War Loan drive successfully concluded, the investment banking industry is looking forward to record activity in the field of corporate financing. Over the next few months, according to estimates, this new financing may well approach $1,000,000,000.

ALLIED LAND HEADQUARTERS, Southeast Asia Command, India, Dec. 17 -- For the first time since the capture of Myitkyina from the Japanese last May, American combat troops are in action again in North Burma.

TWO articles in THE TIMES of Dec. 11 make extremely discouraging reading. I refer to the front-page item quoting The Army and Navy journal to the effect that complete victory in the European phase of the war is being deferred by Russian and British self-interest in other areas while our men do the fighting on the western front.
ROME, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The honor of flying the United States Twelfth Air Force's 350,000th combat sortie went to a 22-year-old major who feels old "seeing all these kids come in" to replace his mates.

White-collar employes are apparently due for a shock when the first withholding is made in 1945. At the time of the passage of the Income Tax Law for 1945 statements were made by the Treasury Department and by Senators and Representatives that only slight increases were involved in the "simplification."

One impact of war conditions on home management is shown in the fact that 25 per cent more men are now doing the family marketing, according to the managers of several large grocery store chains in the metropolitan district. They have taken over the job because their wives are busy in war production or other outside work.

If you're planning to go out of town for Christmas and are faced with a train trip involving meals, you're probably wondering what to do about the diner situation. Preference, as should be, is given the military, while the host of civilian travelers must fight the battle of fortitude if they want to be served.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 17 -- A heavier influx of steel orders featured by greater demand for war steel and an increase in the raw steel rate were high points in news of the industry last week. The increment in the weekly flow of orders was due mainly to the increased tempo in demand from the armed forces. Shell steel was still the most important item but other steel products were also in demand for war purposes.
ATHENS, Dec. 17 -- Establishment of a regency, with Archbishop Damaskinos as regent, seems to be the only solution to the Greek civil strife that would have the slightest chance for success.

Robert Willman won from Max Pavey in a Gruenfeld defense lasting sixty-two moves yesterday and tied at 5 1/2 -- 1/2 with Albert S. Pinkus for the lead in the annual tournament for the championship of the Manhattan Chess Club. Pinkus had a bye.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 17 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week receded slightly from the peak reached in the week ended Dec. 2, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Fractional declines were reported in steel mill operations, bituminous coal production and freight shipments.

Mayor La Guardia hinted strongly yesterday that he would ask the 1945 Legislature to take the dog licensing power away from the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and vest it in the city.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 17 -- Widening of the discounts on the far-distant positions as the market was called upon to absorb heavy liquidation of the 1945 positions, particularly by commission houses, highlighted an otherwise quiet week in cotton futures here.

In general orders issued yesterday 202 members of the Police Department received recognition "for meritorious conduct performed in the line of duty." Three patrolmen were cited for honorable mention, eighty-one members of the force received commendations and 118 were listed for excellent police duty by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine in the first awards since last June.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 17 (U.P.) -- K.P.S. Menon, India's agent general to China, and a party of twelve servants have completed a 118-day land journey from India to Chungking across China's new "front door," the vast Province of Sinkiang.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- Large-scale demonstrations in London and Manchester and speeches by Labor members and party officials in other parts of the country today condemned Prime Minister Churchill's policy in Greece and demanded its reversal.

The following is the text of the treaty of alliance and mutual assistance between the Provisional Government of the French Republic and the Union of Socialist Soviet Republics, as transmitted today by the French Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commisison:

Chiding an "undisciplined, sophisticated generation whose flouting of God's law has brought the world toppling down about our heads," the Rev. Thomas A. Barry, Superior of the New York Archdiocesan Apostolate, called upon the world yesterday "to make straight the way of the Lord or perish in the darkness that engulfs creatures deprived of the all-powerful help of God."
The pace-setting Brooklyn Wanderers blanked the New York Americans by a score of 6 -- 0 in an American Soccer League game at Starlight Park, the Bronx, yesterday.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Monday, Dec. 18 -- Army and Navy fliers have almost cleared the Philippines of Japanese planes and continue to harass enemy shipping.

When the last item has been ticked off on the Christmas list of the shopper who has followed all the instructions to shop, wrap and mail early, he is likely to feel a warm glow. But as the last days before the twenty-fifth come along, he may feel a bit let down. He'd rather like to share in the good-natured last-minute rush. So he searches his memory for someone he's overlooked.

With only a week before Christmas, the Neediest Cases Fund started the second week of its thirty-third annual appeal in behalf of the most distressed families and individuals in the city known to seven leading private charity organizations with 312 gifts totaling $8,343.60 received yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 17 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Labor members of the National War Labor Board have concluded that employes should avoid private arbitration of wage issues so long as the WLB reduces awards exceeding ceilings but refuses to increase those falling short.

The Rev. Dr. Otto H. Bostrom discussed yesterday "The Crisis of the Christian Church" in a sermon in the Gustavus Adolphus Lutheran Church, 151 East Twenty-second Street. He declared that the church in America had been lulled to sleep by a sense of immunity to the catacylsmic changes that were reshaping other parts of the world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Secretary Forrestal, who once was a sea-going sailor himself, has ruled that it is now all right for Navy vessels to carry beer and ale for their crews, provided the men drink it ashore.

PACIFIC HEADQUARTERS, USAAF, Dec. 17 (AP) -- "We expect that Japan will be on her feet and fighting in 1946," Lieut. Gen. Millard F. Harmon, commander of the Strategic Air Force, Pacific Ocean Areas, said today.
BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 17 -- German reaction to Prime Minister Churchill's week-end speech fluctuated between jubilation and resentment, according to information received here from Germany.

It is reassuring that the President, no matter how "reluctantly," has signed the bill to freeze the Social Security tax at 1 per cent for the coming year. The arguments in favor of this action have already been stated at length, and need not be repeated here. But the problem of financing our social security program is extremely complicated and badly in need of expert study.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- Prime Minister Churchill's statement to the House of Commons that the failure of Poland's exiled Government to reach an agreement with Russia on post-war frontiers jeopardized the unity of the grand alliance against Germany has served to lift the curtain on what happened when he met Premier Stalin and President Roosevelt in Teheran a little more than a year ago.
LONDON, Dec. 17 -- The approach of Christmas and the year-end is leaving its usual mark on the stock markets here. Business has dwindled and the trend of prices usually has been downward.
Military and political developments in Europe last week make it clear that the coming three-power conference will be of fundamental importance to our time.
A fresh call for new toys, mittens and socks to go into Christmas stockings was issued over the week-end by the Community Service Society at 105 East Twenty-second Street.

Negro soldiers operating tank destroyers in the front lines, constructing airfields in forward areas, baking bread under enemy fire and moving supplies to enable our armies to advance without a "hitch" have won high praise from star rank officers, according to War Department announcements yesterday making public the award of Bronze and Silver Stars to twenty-nine men and the Purple Heart decoration to 188 aviation engineers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- New seasonal high prices were established for deferred deliveries of wheat futures last week and December went into new ground since early last April as a result of a revival in commission-house interest in the market, removal of hedges against flour sales and short covering.

One of the opportunities, all too rare, to hear Arturo Toscanini conduct opera has been afforded by the NBC Symphony Orchestra, soloists and chorus, who have given on two successive Sunday afternoons the first and second acts of Beethoven's "Fidelio," in Studio 8-H in Radio City.

The John Harms Chorus with Margaret Harshaw, the Metropolitan contralto, gave a concert last night in Town Hall. The assisting participants were John Baker, Metropolitan baritone, and a solo quartet composed of Iiona Harms, soprano; Dorothy Weaver, mezzosoprano; Earl Palmer, tenor, and William Scully, bass. Milton Kaye presided at the piano, and George William Volkel at the organ.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue, said in his sermon yesterday that it would be a tragedy if the high ideals espoused by the United Nations a few years ago should degenerate into a stampede for national advantage in commerce or territory.

WITH AMERICAN FIRST ARMY, in Germany, Dec. 17 -- The German counter-offensive that started yesterday moved forward several more miles into our lines today and with increased power. It looks like the real thing.

T.K. Quinn, whose resignation as general director of the War Production Board's war production drive division becomes effective Jan. 1, announced last night that he would finance publication of "The Labor and Management Committee Manual," to be issued next month.

A SUPERFORTRESS BASE, in India, Dec. 16 (Delayed) -- Superfortress fliers are using a much better airplane today than those who took the B-29's out to bomb Japan for the first time six months ago. They have much more "know how" about handling the big bombers as a result of the experience accumulated in operating the Superfortresses under combat conditions in the last half year in this theatre.

The Tokyo newspaper Asahi declared editorially yesterday that "the military situation in the Philippines has become of the utmost importance" with the American landings on Mindoro, the Japanese Domei agency reported.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 17 -- Mass exclusion of persons of Japanese ancestry from West Coast States was ended today by Maj. Gen. H. Conger Pratt, Western commander, in a proclamation effective on Jan. 2.

Although the Sixth War Loan formally closed on Saturday, Lieut. Gen. Ben Lear, commanding Army ground forces, issued yesterday an appeal to the public to continue bond purchases. He said that trained military observers could find no factual basis for the wishful hope that the end of the war was in sight.

PARIS, Dec. 17 -- The text of the French-Russian alliance, published here tonight, shows that the treaty commits the two powers to carry the war to final victory over Germany and then to "take together all measures necessary to eliminate any new menace from Germany."

WITH THE SEVENTH INFANTRY DIVISION on Leyte, Dec. 9 (Delayed) (AP) -- Laddie, a big German shepherd has a keen nose for Japanese -- so keen in fact that he flushes them every time he goes out and twice he has saved American patrols from ambushes.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Dec. 17 (Delayed) (UP) -- A communique:

Wartime should make personal religion more vital, simple, real, more genuinely the inward and intimate possession, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared yesterday in his sermon at the Riverside Church. He said that wartime should make personal religion more urgent.

The Protestant Council's six affiliated organizations in the city will begin on Jan. 31 a campaign to raise $800,000 for their work during the coming year, Cleveland E. Dodge, president of the council, announced yesterday. Charles H. Tuttle, attorney, was named chairman of the drive.

Off to a flying start in their game with the Canadiens at Madison Square Garden last night, the New York Rangers soon found their proper level and bowed to the leaders of the National Hockey League by a score of 4 to 1.
The Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices (1926=100) advanced last week by 0.05 per cent, mainly due to higher prices for farm products.

Four four-story apartment houses and a two-story dwelling at 3230 to 3236 Broadway and 580 West 130th Street have been sold by the Property Liquidation Corporation to a client of Lawrence H. King, attorney, who immediately resold the property to a client of Morris A. Halpern, attorney.
On the home front nowadays there is never a shortage of rumors of shortages. One week it is sugar, another week meat, a third week cigarettes. Now it's matches.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- A program to obtain jobs for 2,500 men in the Amphibious Force of the Navy when they return to civil life has been undertaken by the Daughters of the American Revolution, it was announced today by Mrs. Julius Y. Talmadge, D.A.R. President General.

In the Dec. 3 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, commenting on the shortage of nurses for military service, is credited with saying: "Perhaps there is something wrong with our method of training and recruiting nurses, but in this phase American women have not been doing their part as well as the British. American women have done wonderfully, though, in industry."

Two pictures published in this newspaper over the week-end showed views of the former German concentration camp at Vught, now in Allied hands. Vught is a little town in southwestern Holland, on the way to 's Hertogenbosch. The Germans built a concentration camp there for hostages and other prisoners of the Gestapo.

Heavy consumer buying as well as shortages in replacements are operating to reduce store inventories to a very low point, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Stores expect to close the year, it is pointed out, with the smallest stocks on hand in many years.

AN AMERICAN FRONTLINE CLEARING STATION, Belgium, Dec. 17 -- Muddy and shivering survivors, weeping with rage, reported today that German tank men with machine guns had shot down captured Americans who were herded into an open field.

HEADQUARTERS OF 21ST BOMBER COMMAND, Saipan, Marianas, Dec. 17 (U.P.) -- A single B-29, unable to reach Nagoya with its formation for the Dec. 13 attack on the Mitsubishi plane works, sought out a target of opportunity and bombed and probably destroyed a Japanese war plant in Hamamatsu, about fifty-five miles southwest of Nagoya and situated in Hikisahoso Bay on Honshu Island, it was revealed today.

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 18 -- Red Army shock troops, in a sudden thrust through deep enemy fortifications, yesterday hammered to within five miles northeast of besieged Budapest by capturing the suburban town of Fot. Mogyorod, inside the Hungarian capital's inner defense belt, also was seized.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in Serbo-Croat by the Free Yugoslav Radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Junior members of the American Women's Voluntary Services have used their ingenuity in designing Christmas articles for service men in hospitals throughout the country, Mrs. Alice Winslow Meade, who heads the junior auxiliary at the Greater New York AWVS, said yesterday.
KANDY, Ceylon, Dec. 17 (AP) -- A communique:

The Busy Bee Grocery, Inc., tenant in the one-story taxpayer containing a single store at 792 Lexington Avenue, has purchased the property from the Bank for Savings for cash over a purchase-money mortgage of $32,000 for ten years.
MANHATTAN, Kan., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Lieut. Walter Ehlers, aged 23, and winner of the Congressional Medal of Honor, came home today to spend a thirty-day leave from fighting on the western front.

Mayor La Guardia is to fly today to Washington -- three days before the scheduled trip on a similar mission by Daniel P. Woolley, regional head of the Office of Price Administration -- to seek the help of the top men in several Federal agencies for the meat retailers and consumers of this city.

HAVANA, Dec. 17 -- Latin American countries have agreed to contribute about $45,000,000 to the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration. Laurence Duggan, chief of the UNRRA mission that visited about fifteen Western Hemisphere nations, said tonight.

Mao Tse-tung, chairman of the Chinese Communist party, was quoted yesterday by the Chinese Communist radio at Yenan as saying that negotiations between the Communists and the Chungking Government had not "attained the least result." The dispatch was recorded by the Federal Communications Commission.

There aren't many producers who would risk doing a dramatization of a best-seller, especially after it had been transformed into a highly successful film counterpart. In the first place, there's the screen competition to be reckoned with and, what's more important to the producer, the stage adaptation would not bring in any revenue for the picture rights.

AN AMERICAN B-25 BASE, East Bengal, India, Dec. 16 (AP) (Delayed) -- The Arakan skies were full of United States medium bombers today, striking at Japanese supply lines and ammunition dumps in support of the British land offensive to regain the strategic Akyab corner of southwestern Burma.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Black Hawks scored goals in the first and second periods tonight to win their third game of the National Hockey League season, 2 -- 1, with third-place Detroit the victim. A crowd of 15,021 saw the Hawks take a one-goal lead, lose that and then break the 1-1 tie to hand Detroit its fifth loss of the year.

A new agency known as the Trade Development Corporation has been opened in the Field Building, Chicago, with the Graham-Paige Motors Corporation of Detroit as one of its principal accounts. Other accounts include the Club Aluminum Products Company, G. Barr Co. and the Victor Manufacturing and Casket Company.

White pine and blue balsam branches littered improvised work tables yesterday at the Horticultural Society of New York at 598 Madison Avenue, as thirty members of the society fashioned wreaths and swags for Halloran General Hospital in Staten Island.

FLORENCE, Dec. 17 (U.P.) -- Representative Paul Shafer, Republican, of Michigan, a member of the House Military Affairs Committee and a former newspaper publisher, expressed the belief today that Army censorship of news dispatches was giving Americans at home an unduly optimistic picture of the war.

IT was an extraordinary game, the play-off between the Packers and the Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday. For almost three quarters Green Bay dominated the fray so completely that the wonder of it was that the Ponderous Pachyderms didn't have an invincible lead as they pounded into the home stretch.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Communique 253:

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Monday, Dec. 18 -- Pushing inland on Mindoro another six miles, American troops have seized key mountain peaks beyond the town of San Jose, establishing a fan-shaped perimeter eleven miles from the coast.

ROME, Dec. 17 -- Benito Mussolini's long and carefully reasoned Speech in Milan yesterday, with its attendant demonstration, came as a shock to Romans who happened to hear it on the so-called Republican radio. Today the PWB monitoring service published nearly the full speech and news of it has been spreading.

Three goals in the last period enabled the New York Rovers to register a 5-to-3 victory over the Baltimore Blades in the Eastern Hockey League game that featured the afternoon double-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday. The New Yorkers, who suffered a 15-to-1 defeat at the hands of the Boston Olympics on the latter's ice on Saturday night, showed little effects of that setback and waged a careful battle to outscore the Monumental City sextet.

Christmas week, the fifth of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House, will feature two first seasonal performances, Mozart's "Le Nozze de Figaro," on Wednesday night, Dec. 27, and Rossini's "Il Barbiere di Siviglia," on the next night. Richard Bonelli will appear in the company for the first time this season, taking the part of Figaro in the Rossini opera, and Patrice Munsel will appear as Rosina.

Despite assurances of legislators that all opinions wil be given sympathetic study, political considerations will continue to dictate cotton policy for many years to come to the detriment of the cotton textile industry and the consumer, it was asserted yesterday by Worth Street textile men home from the recent Page committee hearings on the cotton question.

A Christmas week campaign to obtain musical instruments for hospitalized service men, in cooperation with the Metropolitan Opera Guild, will be opened today at the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office's Pershing Square Information Center.

By Jupiter, what in thunder are sweet potatoes doing in beef stew? Little wonder beef stew is in bad odor and not listed on the Olympian menus. Jupiter must have gagged on the first mouthful of beef stew a la TIMES and forever banished it as unworthy of the gods.
This is in acknowledgment of the letter which appeared in Letters to THE TIMES, "Fault Found With Ration Books," by Thomas G. Morgansen.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- No immediate increase in the average weight of hogs received at leading markets is anticipated by packers although the ceiling price on heavy-weight hogs was raised last week 75 cents to a top of $14.75 a 100 pounds, the top on hogs weighing 270 pounds and under.
ATHENS, Dec. 17 -- The following directive, issued by the United States War Department and affecting American Army personnel assigned to military liaison in Greece was made known today:

There is a vogue for functional architecture, and in the main it has much to commend it. Doubtless our housing styles have much of the Topsy philosophy, although experience has held a restraining hand. As we read of glass-sided houses, heat under the floors and flat roofs for sun bathing, the future seems destined to be a period of change in house styles -- as in cars, planes and robot bombs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Capt. Luis de Florez of the Navy, inventor of many synthetic training devices credited with saving the lives of a large number of combat pilots and their crews, today received the Robert J. Collier Trophy, one of aviation's highest honors.

ROME, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Premier Ivanoe Bonomi in a broadcast to the nation tonight held out little hope of improved economic conditions before the end of the year and appealed to Italians to "fight to win the war without party distinctions."

Eduard C. Lindeman, Professor of Philosophy at the New York School of Social Work, Columbia University, assailed yesterday as "futile and mischievous" present demands for uniformity in values such as "those of President Robert Hutchins and Mortimer Adler of Chicago University and, again, of much lower sources."

BHAMO, North Burma, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Daniel I. Sultan, successor to General Stillwell in Burma, visited captured Bhamo yesterday and went on a five-hour inspection tour of the former Japanese "teakwood fortress," where an enemy garrison held out for two weeks in this Irrawaddy River town.

Thirty women patients and as many visitors in a ward at Bellevue yesterday saw an enraged husband slash his ill wife three times. Women in their beds and visitors screamed for help as he darted out of the ward and escaped.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Frank P. Graham, public member of the War Labor Board, declared today that Montgomery Ward Co. was "blasting at the foundations of maximum production" at a time when "General Eisenhower is calling for more production."

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved lower last week with spots and near-by deliveries firm, while the more distant deliveries were lower. At the close of trading on Saturday, the near-by futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 3 to 8 points, but the more distant positions were off 5 to 28 points.

ROME, Dec. 17 -- Another notable step in the British Eighth Army's tortuous drive along the general axis of the Rimini-Bologna road has been taken by a New Zealand division that, after bitter fighting, has captured Faenza, eight and a half miles farther along Highway 9 from Forli, which was captured on Nov. 9.
ROME, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark today assumed command of the Fifteenth Army Group in Italy.

Back in 1932 Alfred Cowles, president of the Cowles Commission for Research in Economics and a leading statistician, reported to the American Statistical Association on a four-and-a-half-year study of the performance of professional stock-market forecasters.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 17 -- Ann Dvorak has been signed by Paramount for the second feminine lead, supporting Dorothy Lamour and Arturo de Cordova, in the forthcoming "Masquerade in Mexico". It will be the second screen role for Miss Dvorak since she returned from England, where she appeared in several pictures.
