The millionth copy of "The Robe," by Lloyd C. Douglas, to come off the presses of Houghton Mifflin was presented to the author recently by a member of the publishing house in California. Mr. Douglas, who is recuperating from a severe illness, is at work on his next novel about Simon Peter, "The Big Fisherman."

An All-American Conference on Hebrew Music was held yesterday afternoon in the Assembly Hall of Temple Emanu-El as one of the chief events in the current celebration of the centenary of Congregation Emanu-El. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson was honorary chairman and Saul F. Dribben chairman. Dr. Joseph Yasser, musicologist and organist of Temple Rodeph Sholom, led the discussion.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The All-East football team -- minus All-America Les Horvath of Ohio State -- headed toward San Francisco tonight, where players from fourteen schools in eight States will meet the pick of Western intercollegiate football in the Shrine benefit game New Year's Day.
LONDON, Monday, Dec. 18 (UP) -- The Russian Sunday Midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

Further details were made public yesterday concerning the offering which will be made today of 800,000 shares of common stock of the Bank of America National Trust Savings Association, subject to approval of stockholders at a meeting scheduled for Dec. 28.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- In a westerly, chilly breeze, with a slight southerly twist to it, sweatered sailors on Long Island Sound gathered at the Larchmont Yacht Club today for the dinghy racing. Skippers and crews of eleven craft finally manned ship.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 9 Constantin Fotitch, former Yugoslav Ambassador, writes a tendentious letter against Marshal Tito, Yugoslavia and its interests. With the object of supporting his misleading statement Mr. Fotitch says: "The Minister of Interior of the Subasich Government in London, probably to offset the bad impression created by those appalling figures, reduced them to 4,800 in a radio broadcast recorded by FCC on Dec. 1."

There is abundant evidence on every fighting front that our airpower is able to hit the enemy hard. The box score against the Luftwaffe and the Japanese is ample proof of that. But one of the astonishing things about the air war is the amount of punishment which our aircraft can take and still live to fight another day, or at least get their crew home to base.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Dec. 17 -- A German offensive against the southern flank of the American First Army bit several miles into Belgium today and crashed across the Luxembourg frontier in two areas.

MOSCOW, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Soviet resentment at asserted foreign depreciation of the scope of the Red Army's Hungarian offensive boiled over today in another attack by Pravda on the American Army and Navy Journal.

There is abundant evidence that the liquid position of American industry has improved considerably during the war. Despite this general improvement, a study by M.R. Gainsbrugh, published by the National Industrial Conference Board, indicates quite clearly that small business may be faced with financial difficulties at the end of the war.

Twilight Tear, 3-year-old darling of the turf, yesterday was picked the "best horse of 1944" in a poll of 154 sports and turf writers conducted by The Turf and Sport Digest, Baltimore, The Associated Press reported.
CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Leslie Horvath, Ohio State's great All-America back, is the Western Conference's most valuable football player of 1944.
RICHMOND, Calif., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Samuel Jackson Snead, the Comeback Kid, won the Richmond open golf tournament today with a seventy-two-hole total of 278.

ATHENS, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Royal Air Force Spitfires and rocket-firing Beaufighters attacked Elas forces in Athens today after the Left-Wing troops had resumed heavy artillery and mortar fire in the city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Cars ran dry of fuel by the hundreds on Washington streets today and the District Health Service planned to ask the help of the Police and Fire Departments in maintaining medical services.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Swift Co.'s sales reached a new high of $1,573,992,504 during the fiscal year ended on Oct. 28, John Holmes, president of the company, reported today, but he added that net earnings declined $1,768,737 to $15,662,635, or 1 cent per dollar of sales.

Nine hundred and fifty-two sons and fourteen daughters of unpaid Selective Service workers in the city have enlisted or been inducted into the nation's armed forces, Col. Arthur V. McDermott, New York City Director of Selective Service, revealed yesterday.
Six films, including an importation from Mexico, are scheduled to arrive in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

An old holding in the heart of Brooklyn's "automobile row" changed hands in a deal announced over the week-end when the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, as trustees, and others sold the one-story taxpayer at 8602-10 Eighteenth Avenue and 1770-74 Eighty-sixth Street to a client of Slomka Brothers, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Monday, Dec. 18 -- Saipan-based Superfortresses struck at Japanese war factories at Nagoya on the main island of Honshu yesterday while China-based B-29's struck at enemy installations in the Hankow area of occupied China, the War Department announced today.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 17 -- In her alleged second suicide attempt within a year, Mrs. Nellie Kroeger Mann, 46, wife of Heinrich Mann, German writer, and sister-in-law of Thomas Mann, Nobel Prize winner, died today at General Hospital from what police believe was a self-administered overdose of sleeping tablets.

ROME, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The House Military Affairs Committee began touring the Italian front today after a "briefing" in which Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark, commanding the Allies' ground troops, told the members that they might go close to the front but warned them that it would be "tough."

PARIS, Dec. 17 -- The convention of the local Committees of Liberation, after two days of harsh speeches and revolutionary ardor, ended today on notes of "reason and prudence," to quote the moderate newspaper the Paris-Presse. None of the resolutions adopted was adverse to the de Gaulle Government.

For the first thirty minutes of yesterday's play-off game with the Green Bay Packers for the National Football League championship, the Giants were like a ship on the run to Murmansk without rudder or guns and you can guess what their fate was.

Another series of "million-share days" brought last Friday's trading on the Stock Exchange to the first two-million-share market since July 5, 1944. Friday's 2,135,780 shares were not equaled since the 2,435,770 of that date, and only in five other days of 1944 has business exceeded the 2,000,000 mark.

A WEEK before Christmas the same questions keep coming in more and more frequently: "What book would make a good present for my niece who is a Wave stationed in Norfolk, Va.?" "For my son who is convalescing in an Army hospital?" "For my uncle who is 90 years old and hasn't enjoyed a book since he read John Fox Jr.'s 'The Little Shepherd of Kingdom Come'?"

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Heavy bombers of the Royal Air Force last night attacked Ulm, south German industrial and railway center, following daylight American heavy bomber strikes from Italy over Austria and a tremendous outbreak of air combats over the western front.

WILDWOOD, N.J., Dec. 17 -- In a jealous rage, Patrolman Edwin G. Broseman of the Philadelphia Police Department, 41 years old, killed his estranged wife, Marguerite, 37, and her friend, Michael Semsey, 32, a discharged marine wounded on Guadalcanal, and then killed himself this morning in the home of his mother-in-law, Mrs. Hattie Mutzer, 229 East Young Avenue, here, according to Cape May County Prosecutor A.J. Cafiero.

First to reach the visiting team's dressing room at the Polo Grounds yesterday, after the Packers had captured their sixth National Football League championship, was Bill Kuusisto, the 230-pound guard from Minnesota, but one needed more than a second look to identify the player.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Dec. 18 -- The German counter-offensive against the American First Army has changed the tactical situation on the northern and central sectors of the Western Front. The strength of Field Marshal Gen. Karl yon Rundstedt's blow has increased, rather than lessened, in the last twenty-four hours and the Twelfth Army Group is now faced with a large-scale enemy attempt to split its front.
WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Dec. 19 (AP) -- China-based Superfortresses attacked the Japanese mainland today less than twenty-four hours after their strike at Hankow, China.
KANDY, Ceylon, Dec. 18 (AP) -- A communique:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The War Department declared tonight that circumstances were forcing it to increase its January and February calls on Selective Service from 60,000 to 80,000 men for each month.

The Sixth War Loan has gone over the top substantially as measured by total sales. Final sales are expected to be $5,000,000,000 in excess of the $14, 000,000,000 goal set by the Treasury. An army of volunteers has given generously of its time and efforts to achieve these results.

The sugar shortage, whose victims already include some coffee and tea drinkers and restaurateurs, became serious yesterday to New York's vast army of pastry lovers. The continuing scarcity of butter and an increasing tightness in the local supply of other shortenings formed an added threat to pastry.

WITH THE AMERICAN SEVENTH ARMY in Germany, Dec. 18 -- Against resistance increasing hourly, and in an endless drizzle of cold rain, the American Seventh Army continued today to exert pressure against Siegfried Line defenses from Bundenthal, north of Nothweiler, to Lauterbourg, southeastern extremity of the American line that has been pushed across the Lauter River at a number of points.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 18 -- About four-fifths of New Zealand's bomber and fighter-bomber formations have now shifted from security duties in the south Pacific to combat duties with Gen. Douglas MacArthur's command in the southwest Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, appealed to President William Green of the American Federation of Labor today for a united front in order "to forge a broad program of action which can be accepted by all members of the American labor movement."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr., in a statement today giving the United States Government's stand on the Polish problem, reiterated our position in favor of deferring border settlements until after the war but said that if a mutual agreement were reached by the United Nations directly concerned this Government would raise no objections.

A steady but material improvement not only in the values of securities but also in technical and internal conditions on the New York Stock Exchange is reported in a statistical summary of 1944 made public by the Exchange yesterday.

Jean Monnet, who is on a special mission for the French Government to make arrangements with the American and British Governments for supplies so that French industry can be revived and France's contribution to the war be increased, arrived yesterday afternoon at La Guardia Field on an air transport command plane.

Sponsored by a group of industrial, commercial and professional men, formation of the Air Force League, a national civilian organization designed to work for permanently strong and efficient United States air force, was announced yesterday by Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, who was elected its first president.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -Chairman May of the House Military Committee announced today that hearings would be called by his group next month on peacetime compulsory military training.

WITH THE AMERICAN SECOND DIVISION, Dec. 18 -- Here and elsewhere on a front of sixty miles the Germans are throwing what looks like a Sunday punch at American forces. For two days I have been watching the greatest German counter-attacks since Normandy against forward elements of this division.

National sales of E bonds in the Sixth War Loan drive have reached $1,820,000,000, with "hundreds of millions of dollars yet to be tabulated,'' Ted R. Gamble, War Finance Director, reported yesterday in Washington. He said the E bond quota of $2,500,000,000 "undoubtedly'' would be exceeded when final totals were announced on Jan. 2.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Dec. 18 -- Dr. Herbert L. Spencer, a graduate engineer who has been president of Pennsylvania College for Women for the past ten years, has resigned to become president of co-educational Bucknell University, Lewisburg, Pa., effective July 1, 1945.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 19 (U.P.) -- Red Army forces, advancing as much as twelve miles, drove two new invasion spearheads into Slovakia from northeastern Hungary yesterday as they hammered up to the southern frontier of that Nazi puppet state on a sixty-eight-mile front.

Mr. Stettinius' statement makes it clear that our Government agrees with Britain that the difficult problem of Poland's eastern frontier ought never to have been raised until the war was over. "It has been the consistently held policy of the United States that questions of boundaries should be left in abeyance until the termination of hostilities."

Known now as "Marge" to the American fighting men in Australia, Marjorie Lawrence, Metropolitan Opera soprano whose career was threatened three years ago when infantile paralysis crippled her legs, laughed off yesterday the difficulties she encountered during her six-month, 50,000-mile camp-concert tour of her native Australia from which she returned Sunday.

Pangs of hunger finally bringing to a halt an all-day session of the owners and representatives of National Football League clubs at the Hotel Commodore yesterday, the 1944 professional season may be safely called officially closed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The constitutionality of the wartime regulations under which American citizens of Japanese ancestry were evacuated from Pacific Coast areas in 1942 was upheld by a vote of 6 to 3 in the Supreme Court today, but in another decision the court ruled unanimously that Japanese-Americans of unquestioned loyalty to the United States could not be detained in war relocation centers.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The housewife's chances of buying a turkey for Christmas are 10 to 25 per cent better than they were at Thanksgiving, the local office of the War Food Administration said last night. The WFA prediction was based on trade advices, including the arrival yesterday of several carloads of Texas and Colorado birds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- In two unanimous decisions, the Supreme Court today reversed lower court rulings and held that Negro employes on American railroads are protected by the Railway Labor Act against management-labor pacts seeking to drive them out of their jobs or deny them promotions.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Tuesday, Dec. 19 (UP) -- A communique:
ALBANY, Dec. 18 (AP) -- A one-day postponement of his scheduled appearance before the grand jury investigating legislative spending was granted today to Assemblyman Irwin Steingut.
PARIS, Dec. 18 -- Newsboys on the Paris boulevards at dusk today shouted: "Buy the Monde, new afternoon paper!"

City Stores Company today will purchase for approximately $3,500,000 cash all the assets except cash and Government securities of the R.H. White Company, Boston department store, a wholly owned subsidiary of Wm. Filene's Sons Company, it was announced yesterday by Sal Cohn, president.

In mass demonstration of the borough's spirit, 847 men and women employes of the city administration staged a blood donor's parade in downtown Brooklyn yesterday. Headed by Borough President John Cashmore, the employes marched to chapter headquarters of the American Red Cross at 57 Willoughby Street to open Brooklyn's Blood Donor Week.
May I join this note to many others which I am sure you have received, in appreciation of the editorial entitled "One Generalization Too Many," which appeared in your issue of Dec. 13.

With three shows on the boards ("Mexican Hayride" and "Catherine Was Great" in New York, and "Star and Garter" in Chicago) and another offering ("Central Park") about to be launched, Mike Todd is just getting his second wind. Without batting an eyelash, the ambitious producer yesterday promised to put on two more plays right after the opening of "Central Park," which is expected here the week of Jan. 22.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Dec. 18 -- The American Ninth Air Force and the British Second Tactical Air Force dived through sleet and fog today to hammer the tank-tipped German columns pressing deeper into Belgium and Luxembourg as Field Marshal Gen. Karl von Rundstedt's counter-offensive continued to move westward for the third day.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The instinct to hoard when a shortage is rumored was blamed tonight for a scarcity of gasoline which has left hundreds of Washington automobiles stranded.
Archie Moore of San Diego, Calif., celebrated his local ring debut last night at the St. Nicholas Arena with a hollow victory over Nate Bolden, Chicago light heavyweight, in the feature bout.

Louise Meiszner, 20-year-old St. Louis-born pianist who lived when a child in Budapest and later studied here with Ernest Hutcheson at the Juilliard Graduate School, gave her New York debut recital last night in Town Hall She played a program of Bach, Beethoven, Liszt, Chopin, Griffes, Debussy and Dohnanyi, and her performance was enthusiastically received by the audience.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Foreign Economic Administration advised exporters today that approximately 20,000,000 yards of cotton textiles will be allocated for export to the Middle East in the first half of 1945.
LONDON, Dec. 18 -- The Berlin radio claimed tonight that the northern part of Luxembourg "has been crossed on a broad front and German troops are nearing the Luxembourg-Belgian frontier."

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 18 (AP) -- A newspaper advertising budget for 1945 "many times greater" than for the previous year has been adopted by the H.J. Heinz Company, the Pennsylvania Newspaper Publishers Association said today.
LONDON, Dec. 18 -- With the approaching holiday restricting business, price movements in today's stock markets here wereI small.

KANDY, Ceylon, Dec. 18 (AP) -- British Fourteenth Army troops, who now hold a line roughly from east to west between the Irrawaddy and Chindwin Rivers in upper Burma, have cleaned out the last vestige of Japanese domination in a rugged jungle area containing 2,000 inhabited localities, an Allied communique said today.

Widespread planning for postwar improvements in machinery and appliances through addition of electronic controls and devices is indicated in the requests for copies of "Can Electronics Improve Your Product?" a new thirty-two-page booklet now ready for distribution by the Operadio Manufacturing Company, St. Charles, Ill.

The adventures of Belle Boyd, the famous woman spy for the Confederacy during the Civil War, are recounted by Lieut. Col. Louis A. Sigaud in "Belie Boyd, Confederate Spy," published last week by the Dietz Press, Richmond, Va. The author, now living in Brooklyn, was in command of counter-espionage in France for two years.

MYITKYINA, Burma, Dec. 18 (AP) -- For more than two and one-half years, 5,000 fierce Kachin tribesmen of northern Burma have been parachuting into the hills, killing Japanese and rescuing American pilots who were forced to bail out over enemy territory.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- The Cities Service Power Light Company today filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan for the sale of all of its interest in the St. Joseph Railway, Light, Heat and Power Company to the Continental Gas and Electric Corporation for a base price of $2,200,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Navy communique 559:

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 18 -Widespread damage inflicted on shipping, airfields and defense installations on and around the island of Luzon last week shows that the three-day series of air strikes may have caused the enemy more than any previous attack in the West Pacific.

Time was in simpler days when you knew who were the neediest in your home town. You did not have to be told. They were the folks down the street, around the corner in the alley, or up the road a piece. The children did not have warm clothes like more fortunate children -- your own, for example.

ALBANY, Dec. 18 -- Formation of a New York State Youth Service Commission, authorized by statute to assist local communities in the prevention of juvenile delinquency, was recommended by the Interdepartmental Committee on Delinquency, in an interim report made public today by Governor Dewey.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Communique 254:

FIFTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Italy, Dec. 17 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Representative J. Parnell Thomas, Republican, of New Jersey, ranking opposition member of the House Military Affairs Committee, announced today that he would lead an investigation into six basic shortages on the western front affecting the progress of the war, the casualty rate and soldier morale.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- Paul Chack, a 68-year-old retired captain of the French Navy with a fine record in the first World War and a writer of patriotic books, was sentenced to death this evening by the Paris Court of Justice for intelligence with the enemy.

The annual report of the Cessna Aircraft Company for the fiscal year ended with September disclosed yesterday a net income of $1,102,039 after all charges, including $2,881,290 provision for Federal taxes.

With beachheads on Mindoro firmly established and airfields under construction, the present phase of the Battle for the Philippines probably will develop into a race to see which side can pour into Mindoro the men and supplies to decide the issue. The Japanese report of another big American convoy moving through the Sulu Sea would indicate that our men are getting the reinforcements they will need.

With Christmas shopping at its peak, retail trade in New York and in many other sections of the country last week shattered all previous records for dollar sales, reports in retail circles here yesterday indicated.

ROME, Dec. 18 (AP) -- American fliers knocked down forty-eight of more than 100 German planes attempting to intercept Fifteenth Air Force heavy bomber formations that attacked synthetic oil plants in German Silesia yesterday, Allied headquarters announced today.
ROME, Dec. 18 -- The ascendency of Left-Wing movements sympathetic to tthe Soviet Union is now clearly discerned in liberated Balkan areas from the Aegean Sea to the Danube River.

Betty Field went into the cast of "The Voice of the Turtle" last evening, replacing Margaret Sullavan and ending the discussion about whether any but members of the original company could play John van Druten's comedy. Miss Field can. She has one or two of her predecessor's mannerisms and a great quantity of charm of her own.

" 3 Is a Family," a comedy produced by Sol Lesser for United Artists release, will open this morning at the Gotham Theatre. Heading the cast of the film, which was adapted from the Broadway play, are Charlie Ruggles, Fay Bainter, Helen Broderick, Marjorie Reynolds, William Terry, Cheryl Walker and Fred Brady.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Starting for the first time since election day at Belmont Park, Mrs. J.F. Bragg's Gallant Chance drove to a head victory in the featured Connecticut Purse as the final week of the Gulfstream Park meeting got under way today.

Miss Ann Curtis, statuesque San Francisco miss who holds a national swim record for each of her 18 years, was named the woman athlete of the year yesterday by the country's sports editors who were polled by The Associated Press.
LONDON, Dec. 18 (Reuter) -- Nearly 5,000 crippled aircraft have landed safely on the three huge "hush hush" Service of Supply airfields specially built in great Britain for planes in trouble.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, in the Philippines, Tuesday, Dec. 19 -- Enemy planes numbering 742 were destroyed or seriously damaged during the week ended Sunday night in the battle for the Philippines, Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced last night.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Police Detectives Ernest Harrison and Billy Beaver reported today that the body of Brig. Gen. Berkeley Enochs, 69-year-old retired Army officer of Union Valley, Carmel, N.Y., and Miami Beach, was found on the floor of a gas-filled room of his winter home today.
LONDON, Dec. 18 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

The 50 per cent cut in the allotment of tires for civilian commercial vehicles for the first quarter of 1945, forecast yesterday by the Office of Defense Transportation, will prevent the maintenance of even minimum essential transportation, according to Theodore D. Pratt, president of the New York State Motor Truck Association.

Felicio Torregrosa, coach of the Puerto Rico University -- E1 Universidad de Puerto Rico -- basketball team, which is to clash with unbeaten St. John's Saturday night at Madison Square Garden, yesterday told basketball writers of the advancement of sports in general, and of the court game in particular, in Puerto Rico.

With the Green Bay Packers, winners of the 1944 National Football League championship, now back in their Wisconsin home, preparing to break up for the season, and the New York Giants either en route homeward or making preparations to leave, the professional season is now in the record books.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Crop production in the United States in 1944, in spite of severe difficulties will about equal the record high set in 1942, the Agriculture Department said today in its annual summary.
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted in English by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- President Roosevelt's foreign policy and its relation to current political events in Europe had the spotlight in Senate debate today on the half dozen nominees for whom the President has asked for confirmation as "a team" for Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius.

Governor Dewey is "much concerned about critical developments in foreign affairs," Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National Chairman, declared yesterday in disclosing the topics he discussed Sunday at a dinner conference with the defeated Republican Presidential nominee.

Approval of the plans of the War Advertising Council to continue its work after the war has been expressed by President Roosevelt, it was revealed yesterday when the council made public a letter sent by the President to Harold J. Thomas, chairman of the council.

All concerns in the metropolitan area who employ men living in New York City will be asked to report to local draft boards or to Selective Service headquarters at 1 East Forty-fourth Street the names of men up to 38 years old who left war work for unessential jobs "in recent months," it was announced yesterday by Col. Arthur V. McDermott, city Selective Service Director.

The six-story building at 245 East Eleventh Street, northwest corner of Second Avenue, containing seven stores and fifty-five apartments, has been sold by Retford Associates, of which Irving Brodsky is president, to Sophie Sander, Cele Weinstein, Frances Sklarin, Mortimer J. Schachter and Bella Schachter.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- A third ten-day suspension of trading in the common stock of the Elastic Stop Nut Corporation of America was ordered today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company has sold the fifteen-story building at 1 East Fifty-third Street to the Walmil Realty Company, which obtained a first mortgage loan of $100,000 on the property from the Manhattan Life Insurance Company.

SEATTLE, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Prison sentences aggregating more than 200 years were given tonight to twenty-seven Negro soldiers found guilty by a general court-martial board of rioting against an Italian service unit at Fort Lawton Aug. 14.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Information from Bolivia is that the Government of that country, beset by wretched economic conditions among the tin-workers and by competitive undergrounds controlled by Argentine influences on the one hand and Soviet Russian on the other, now feels the United States has added heavily to its burdens and intruded on its independence by a conditional offer concerning the price of tin.

PARIS, Dec. 17 (Delayed) -- Undisciplined and disorderly elements of the French Forces of the Interior, pretending to have the backing of the resistance movements, were criticized by some members of the military commissions of liberation who met today in Paris at the conclusion of the national Committee of Liberation Congress.

Two German-born entertainers were among 300 aliens who received citizenship papers yesterday in the Naturalization Court at Columbus Avenue and Sixty-second Street after taking the oath of allegiance from Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 18 -- Republic has bought "The Silver Fox," an original screen story by Ralph Dietrich and Elaine Ryan, as the basis for an ice-skating picture to star Vera Hruba Ralston. The film, with a Canadian silver-fox farm and a large indoor ice-skating palace as locales, is scheduled for production following Miss Ralston's appearance in "The Healer'' on which Stephen Sekely will begin production and direction in February.

THE glaring weakness of the National Football League schedule was exposed completely on Sunday when the well-rested Green Bay Packers vanquished the battle-worn New York Giants for the championship. This was the silver anniversary of the play-for-pay circuit and it still hasn't gotten around to arranging its dates in the proper big league manner.

ALBANY, Dec. 18 -- The New York State Electoral College, in a colorful Senate Chamber ceremony, cast its forty-seven votes lay for President Roosevelt and Senator Harry S. Truman after Thomas J. Curran, Republican Secretary of State, who opened the session, said that this method of electing a President might soon be ended by constitutional amendment.

ATHENS, Dec. 18 -- Now in a position to make their force the deciding factor in the battle of Athens, British troops swept up from Phaliron Bay last night and by morning had cleared Syngrou Boulevard and areas 200 to 300 yards deep on each side of this principal line of communications.

When your family gathers for breakfast on Christmas morning you might offer them fare with an international flavor. As an accompaniment to your usual meal, one of the many delicious breads designed in foreign countries especially for the yuletide will lend a festive note to the table.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- United States submarines were credited today with their greatest single reported bag of Japanese vessels when the Navy Department reported that twelve enemy warships -- the largest number ever listed in a regular communique -- and twenty-one other ships had been sunk in Pacific and Far Eastern waters.

The War Production Board has served notice on the underwear industry that unless it produces the quantities of lightweight underwear needed by the armed forces for the first six months of next year, all production, without exception, will be frozen, it was learned in the trade yesterday.

ROME, Dec. 18 -- Statistics recently issued here bear sharply on the ammunition shortage that has led to the appeals by Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and others and in connection with which Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell has reported that the United States Army is shooting 6,000,000 artillery shells a month in Europe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Plans for seizure of some Montgomery Ward Co. properties or for sanctions against the company were virtually completed tonight as William H. Davis, chairman of the National War Labor Board, announced that at the close of the business day no word had been received from the company indicating it would comply with the board's directives covering its affiliates in seven cities.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18 -While some public officials voiced bitterness over the Army's decision, supported by a Supreme Court ruling, to permit all "loyal and harmless persons of Japanese ancestry to come back to West Coast States, the machinery of law enforcement and educational agencies was being prepared today to grapple with the problems expected to accompany the return of evacuees in any numbers.

An invitation from the Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot for bids on 1,375,000 Army overcoats, received in the industry yesterday, is regarded by observers as indicative of several new procurements on uniform items, following the worsted freezing order as well as the freeze on civilian goods production in overcoat shops.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -The Supreme Court agreed today to review a Railway Mail Association protest against a New York finding that it is a labor organization which may not deny membership because of race, creed or color.

BEHIND THE ITALIAN FRONT, Dec. 17 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The House Military Affairs Committee visited a sector immediately behind the front lines today in a tour conducted by Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark, new commander of the Allies' ground forces in Italy.

Reflecting last week's low turnover of spot cotton, the smallest his season, trading in cotton futures also slowed yesterday. The various months closed 2 points lower to 5 points higher on the New York Cotton Exchange.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 19 -- Eight German rail shipping points that supply the counter-attacking Nazi forces on the Western Front were attacked Sunday night and yesterday by 1,800 British and American heavy bombers in pursuance of the Allied master plan to clog the enemy's military transport system.

Eight industrial properties in Manhattan owned by the Borden Company were sold at auction yesterday for a total of $248,400. About 100 persons attended the sale, which was conducted by Stephen A. McDonald, vice president of Joseph P. Day, Inc., in the Vesey Street salesrooms.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -The text of Secretary Stettinius statement on Poland follows:

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- If Prime Minister Churchill was hoping that his speech on the Russian-Polish crisis would evoke a statement from Washington that would knock the props from under Premier Tomasz Arciszewski's exiled Government, the pronouncement by Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr. must have been disappointing.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- The French-Russian alliance, which, some predicted, would be supplemented by a similar treaty between France and Britain, thus re-establishing the Triple Entente in far more concrete form than before, was regarded in both French and Allied circles today as contributing a new element of definiteness to the shape of post-war Europe.

David Meister has sold the two recently acquired six-story apartment houses at 1975 and 1979 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, to Fosterport Realty Corporation, an investing syndicate. The property, assessed at $230,000, occupies a plot 150 by 100 feet and contains seventy apartments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -Mayor La Guardia conferred today with Fred M. Vinson, Director of Economic Stabilization, and other price and food officials on New York's threatened meat store "holiday" and after the meeting declared that his time here had been "very usefully spent."

A concert of contemporary Polish music was given last night in Times Hall. The composers represented were Antoni Szalowski, Felix Labunski, Karol Rathaus, Karol Szymanowski and Jerzy Fitelberg. These composers were represented by various forms of chamber music, and Szymanowski by five piano compositions, and there was a high level of performance throughout the evening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- What might be called a "consumer speak up" movement has been started by Miss Mary Rokahr, home management economist, and Miss Alice Sundquist, clothing specialist, of the Extension Service Department of Agriculture.

Thousands of manufacturers and business firms in New York City will be "outrented" on Feb. 1 and have no place to continue operations unless the Legislature passes a bill early in January to control commercial rents, spokesmen for the Joint Rent Action Committee and the American Business Congress declared yesterday at a press conference in the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue.

It may take longer on Christmas Eve to tie individual ornaments to the tree instead of clipping them in place, or to drape slippery strips of colored paper and cellophane instead of throwing clinging metallic tinsel, but no tree should have to go untrimmed this year for lack of materials, a survey of tree trimming departments in several stores indicated yesterday.

The National Association of Colored Graduate Nurses is deeply concerned lest the public misunderstand the reason for the small number of Negro nurses in the services. We do not want the impression given that in a crisis, and at a time when nursing service is vital to the needs of the military, the Negro nurse had failed her country.

The city's problem of "orphan" coal consumers, which caused hardship last winter to thousands of families between November and the end of March, has been so well-handled this year that there are now only a dozen calls a day for help and they are quickly taken care of, it was disclosed yesterday by Brig. Gen. Bryce P. Disque, president of the Coal Consumers Protective Association, Inc.

Cornelia Otis Skinner and Emily Kimbrough, authors of "Our Hearts Were Young and Gay," which Paramount adapted into the film of the same name, have instituted an action to restrain Paramount Pictures, Inc., from making a purported "sequel" titled "Our Hearts Were Growing Up."

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- A group of American scientists, including a Nobel prize winner, who were flown overseas to help solve the problem of the rocket bombs, has contributed to the Allies' domination of the skies over Europe, it was disclosed today.

LONDON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Moscow's Pravda, official organ of the Communist party, printed an article today by Dr. Stefan Yendrikowski of the Lublin Polish Committee declaring that Prime Minister Churchill and Gen. Charles de Gaulle's French Government support Poland's claim to German territory as far west as the Oder River, within thirty miles of Berlin.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 18 (AP) -A Government anti-trust suit against the Bendix Aviation Corporation, charging conspiracy with various foreign concerns, was ordered to the active trial list today by Federal Judge Thomas F. Meaney.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 18 -- Reporting more damage caused by the mounting number of deer in this area, 118 residents of Putnam and northern Westchester Counties petitioned the Westchester Board of Supervisors today to seek an open season for shooting the animals.

As a result of the War Production Board's "freeze order" on the production of civilian goods, the Office of Civilian Requirements and individual manufacturers who had been given as far back as last August "stepped up" production schedules for 1945, will have to revalidate all such programs, Lewis S. Greenleaf Jr., regional WPB director, said yesterday.

The largest supply of counterfeit coupons ever found here, and enough genuine tire ration certificates for 800 tires -- more than enough to exhaust a month's quota for New York City -- were taken into possession early yesterday by special agents of the Office of Price Administration.
Withdrawal of buying in the face of unsatisfactory war news, rather than selling pressure, brought moderate declines on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Some military observers here today suggested the possibility that the Germans may have been fearing a new offensive on our part when they launched their determined counterattack against the southern flank of the American First Army.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Publicly reported cash dividends in the United States amounted to $122,900,000 during Navomber, a decrease of 4.9 per cent from the $129,200,000 paid in November a year ago, the Department of Commerce announced today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -The Supreme Court decided today that the National Labor Relations Board could reverse itself after certifying an independent union as an exclusive bargaining agent.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- In a message to the War Labor Board, bristling with criticism of the agency and its chairman, William H. Davis, Sewell Avery, chairman of Montgomery Ward Co., said tonight that the company "cannot in good citizenship" obey the board's demand, that it comply with WLB directives in the case of four Detroit stores, where employes are on strike, and at properties in six other cities, including Chicago.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The War Production Board was reported today to be planning tentatively to reduce production of aircraft engines by 14 per cent after the defeat of Germany.

THIS is not only the age of total war, of mass armies of many millions and of whole populations in conflict; it is also the supreme age of personal heroism and of nearly incredible individual adventures. Around the entire globe at this precise moment many thousands of men and women are enduring the most fantastic experiences, displaying the most extraordinary heroism, meeting suffering and death with faith and courage, skill and resourcefulness.

Morris J. Solomon, who recently was selected as Brooklyn's outstanding citizen for 1944 because of his activities in behalf of the war bond drives in the borough, was sworn in yesterday as Federal Commissioner of Jurors for Brooklyn and Long Island.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The golfing grapevine carries rumors that the United States Golf Association may revive the national open championship in 1945 -- it has been a war casualty since Pearl Harbor.

SOMEWHERE IN THE PHILIPPINES, Dec. 18 -- One reason why our troops on Mindoro had no Japanese air attacks this morning although there are "bogies" in the area and why Vice Admiral Thomas C. Kinkaid's convoy got through to Mindoro and back with only little damage was the presence of dawn-to-dusk patrols by marine night fighters.

The manpower shortage being what it is and the WMC urging folk to remain at their defense jobs, I'm submitting this letter, the theme of which could appropriately be entitled, "Keep Up the Good Work, American Manufacturers."

ROME, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Patrols of the British Eighth Army probed German defenses across the Senio River only five and a half miles from Imola today in preparation for a renewal of the Po Valley offensive that is slowly rolling the enemy back along the Via Emilia toward Bologna.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- Traders expressed surprise late today when a final estimate on grain production in 1944 by the Department of Agriculture showed a reduction of around 30,000,000 bushels for wheat and a like amount for corn, as compared with earlier returns.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 18 -- A bill which would keep Delaware children in school until they are 17 and restrict child labor is now being drafted, with Wilmington school teachers leading in the movement.

HEADQUARTERS OF 21ST BOMBER COMMAND, Saipan, Marianas, Tuesday, Dec. 19 (U.P.) -- Columns of dense smoke which could be seen for seventy miles billowed from an important district of Nagoya's waterfront to a height of 5,000 to 8,000 feet after yesterday's B-29 raid, Lieut. Col. Frank L. Davis of Cornwall, N.Y., reported on his return from the flight.

An endless stream of persons flowing in and out of the General Postoffice at Thirty-third Street and Eighth Avenue gave substantial backing to the forecast of Postmaster Albert Goldman yesterday that New York mailing centers would handle a record-breaking total of Christmas mail this year.

Completion of seventy-five years of industrial and investment banking by Goldman, Sachs Co. was observed last night by a dinner at the Hotel Pierre attended by partners and employes of the firm. The business was founded by Marcus Goldman in 1869 with the opening of a small office in the basement of an old four-story building on the site of the present banking house, at 30 Pine Street.

Rayon producers and weavers who met with Army Air Force procurement officers at the offices of the National Federation of Textiles have lined up the material phase of the new delivery parachute program, according to trade sources yesterday.

Marian Anderson's War Bond recital last night in Carnegie Hall brought more than $1,679,000 and at the close of the final encore Miss Anderson thanked "from the very bottom of my heart" the audience that filled the house.

MOSCOW, Dec. 18 -- The United States Government's first Russian-language publication, a small digest-like text-and-picture monthly magazine entitled America and designed to explain the American system and war effort to Russians, was delivered today to the State Publishing House for distribution throughout Russia.
BOSTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Col. William J. Bingham, chairman of the Intercollegiate Football Rules Committee, today accused his critics of being "afraid of the pros."

Philip Guedalla wrote about Queen Victoria in the early Nineteen Thirties and he wrote about Mr. Churchill in the early Nineteen Forties. He did not write enough, for he was only 55 when he died, and there were undoubtedly more books in him and maybe better ones.

When his books are closed on the the year 1944 with two fistic shows he has remaining, Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S.C. will reveal the biggest year he has enjoyed since Staff Sgt. Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, forsook the ring to enter the Army.
Today the bitter pains of this war were stressecl to a group of Grs.
An underwriting group headed by Smith, Barney Co. and McDonald Co. will offer to the public today 60,000 shares of common stock of Thompson Products, Inc. The stock will be priced at $47.50 a share.

An underwriting group headed by Lehman Brothers and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will make a formal offering today of $7,500,000 city of Houston, Tex., independent school district bonds. The bonds, carrying 2 1/2 and 1 3/4 per cent interest rates, will mature in amounts of $250,000 on Feb. 1 of each year from 1946 to 1975.

A resolution denouncing the strike against the Montgomery Ward stores in Detroit as a violation of the no-strike pledge and as injurious to the war effort was adopted last night by the 500 members of the general council of Local 65, Wholesale and Warehouse Workers Union, CIO, a left-wing controlled local of 12,000 members, the largest in the union.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -Chief Justice Stone recalled today the late Justice George Sutherland as a jurist who saw danger in "ill-considered experimentation in Government." The chief justice spoke at a ceremony in the Supreme Court chamber in honor of Justice Sutherland, who died July 18, 1942.

" Its spirit is Christmas," wrote a suburban friend of the Neediest Cases appeal, sending $25 in memory of loved ones. "I, among many, am grateful to THE NEW YORK TIMES for giving us this chance to share in the true meaning of Christmas year after year."

When a new holiday show was needed by the director of the Globe Theatre, Southwark, London, in Good Queen Bess' day, the available authors were mobilized. They promptly whipped up a real thriller or a rollicking comedy in a couple of days, calling the piece "Macbeth" or "The Taming of the Shrew," as the case might be.

The arrest of fifteen men at the Brooklyn base of the United States Army Port of Embarkation yesterday brought to light a Federal Bureau of Investigation inquiry into alleged "kickback" rackets in the carpenter department and marine repair shop there.
Each day, I am convinced, presents at least one "salient," were we sufficiently watchful to recognize it in the swift panorama of scenes and events.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Circuit Judges Paul D. Barns and Marshall Wiseheart ruled The Miami Herald and its associate editor, John D. Pennekamp, guilty of contempt of court today as the result of the publication of two critical editorials and a cartoon.
Sunday's communique, as broadcast domestically from Bucharest and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

SEVILLE, Spain, Dec. 18 -- Royalty flowered again in the pomp and pageantry of Spanish tradition here today at the marriage ceremony of the Princess de Esperanza, younger daughter of the House of Bourbon-Orleans, and Prince Pedro de Alcantara, son of the Brazilian-born Prince Pedro, in Seville's world-famous thirteenth-century cathedral. The civil ceremony was performed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Seventy-eighth Congress expired at 8:22 o'clock this evening with the adjournment sine die of the Senate, only thirty-eight members answering to a final quorum call.

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- Frenchmen, or at least Parisians, do not approve the American attitude toward France but are satisfied with that of Britain; they want to execute Pierre Laval but not Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain; they are against French intervention in Spain; and they are yearning for chocolate more than any other food.

Blue Star Brigades in the thirteen district war bond organizations of the Manhattan Community Sales Division have raised their collective sales to a record of 163,831, or 109.2 per cent of their original goal of 150,000 transactions, Willard K. Denton, executive manager of the War Finance Committee, announced yesterday.

The trial of Vito Rizzi for the murder of an elderly recluse grocer nearly four years ago for a mythical "pot of gold" was interrupted frequently yesterday by emotional outbursts of a woman witness. Rizzi is a veteran of the New Guinea fighting with the Japanese.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Texas Railroad Commission today elected Olin Culberson chairman for 1945, succeeding Beauford H. Jester. It also heard testimony upon which to base its oil allowable production order for January.

An Army clerk generally is inside, out of the weather. He has to be. He has papers to type and files to keep. But the comparative comfort of his job doesn't raise his social standing among his infantry or his artillery brothers. "That paper pusher" is one of the milder epithets with which they describe him.
Clifton Daniel, reporting from London to THE TIMES of Dec. 11, asks if the United States "can serve as a balance of power between the Soviet Union and Great Britain, moderating the actions of each."

Ed Heusser, 35-year-old veteran right-hander who spent most of his career in the minors before establishing himself with any degree of permanency in the majors as a relief hurler for the Reds in 1943, was the National League's most effective pitcher for 1944, according to the official averages announced yesterday.

The New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad Company awarded yesterday an issue of $42,000,000 of refunding mortgage, Series D bonds, due on Jan. 1, 1975, to an underwriting group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., on a competitive bid of 100.529 for a 3 3/4 per cent coupon rate. Subject to the approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission, the underwriting group immediately reoffered the bonds at 102.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 19 -- Vice President and War Minister Col. Juan D. Peron inaugurated today the first Argentine factory dedicated exclusively to airplane production.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The big Omura aircraft factory on the Japanese home island of Kyushu came in for another blasting from American Superfortresses today while other B-29's hit targets at enemy-held Shanghai and Nanking on the Chinese mainland.

Carl L. Norden, Inc., Theodore H. Barth and Ward B. Marvelle, officials of the corporation, and Comdr. John D. Corrigan, USNR, were indicted yesterday charged with conspiring to defraud the Government by restricting to the Norden concern production of the famous Norden bombsight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The special Senate committee investigating war production declared today that, while the nation could be proud of the "miracle" of production and supply, imperfections such as accumulated surpluses had hindered balanced war supply. Some of these could have been prevented or reduced, the committee found.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 19 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower called on Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle's Eighth Air Force for tactical air support in an effort to halt the German onslaught in Belgium today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 19 -Paramount has announced plans to star Bing Crosby and Barry Fitzgerald in "O'Halloran's Luck," a short story of railroad building in the West, by the late Stephen Vincent Benet. The picture is expected to be produced next autumn after Crosby finishes "The Bells of St. Mary's" for RKO-Radio, and "Blue Skies," an Irving Berlin musical, for Paramount.

Duke Ellington and his orchestra gave a concert at Carnegie Hall last night and the occasion was one which showed clearly why Mr. Ellington is one of the most imposing figures in the world of jazz today. Like most jazz concerts, this one was too long, for it is highly questionable whether listening to swing music in the constraining atmosphere of a concert hall for well over two hours is a pleasurable experience.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 19 (U.P.) -- In an angry four-minute session at tonight's regular "briefing" here, war correspondents demanded that Army public-relations authorities release to the American public the details of the German counter-offensive that has been going on for four days.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- With unwonted independence, Labor members of the House of Commons met after today's session and decided to demand that the Government provide an opportunity for another debate on the British policy in Greece before Parliament rises for the Christmas recess tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota, in a farewell address today after twenty years in the Senate told his colleagues that they alone stood between the United States and another World War.
" They are our own and we must not let them down," wrote a contributor to the Neediest Cases Fund whose $20 was one of 644 gifts received yesterday. "May we again go over the top."

" This is a shrewd, conniving woman." Judge John J. Sullivan commented yesterday in General Sessions as he held Mrs. Helen G. Hines, 44 years old, a divorcee, in $3,500 bail on the charge that, since 1941, she stole $42,000 from the Baker-Raulang New York Corporation, at 250 West Fifty-seventh Street, where she was the bookkeeper.

LONDON, Dec. 19 (U.P.) -- The Italy-based United States Fifteenth Air Force struck with its heavy bombers today for the fourth time in as many days against German oil installations, with Blechhammer in Silesia again the target. Rail yards in Germany, Northern Yugoslavia, the Vienna area and elsewhere in Austria were also bombed, nearly all the attacks being by instrument through clouds.

In an attempt to eliminate one of the most "discouraging" factors in Irano-American trade, business men from Iran are establishing a "semi-permanent office" in this city at which direct contacts with Iranian merchants can be made, Dr. Ali A. Akhavi, member of the Iranian delegation to the recent International Business Conference, disclosed yesterday.

The Department of Health is endeavoring to bring all nurseries in the city up to approved standards of health, sanitation and housing, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Leona Baumgartner, director of the Bureau of Child Hygiene, charged since February, 1943, with licensing nurseries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -Dr. Charles F. Kettering, head of the research laboratories of the General Motors Corporation, was elected president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science today. He succeeds Dr. Anton J. Carlson, physiologist of the University of Chicago.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Herbert H. Lehman, director general of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, announced today that most of the UNRRA mission in Greece had been withdrawn under a decision taken by the military authorities there because of the fighting in Greece.

In an apparent effort to speed War Labor Board action on a wage Increase of $5 a week recommended several weeks ago by a board panel, 6,000 long-distance telephone operators employed by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company began voting here yesterday on whether they should strike if the increase is not granted.
ROME, Dec. 19 -- High praise for the Italian war contribution was contained in a report by general headquarters of the British Eighth Army, published today.

LONDON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Berlin claimed tonight that the United States First Army had been "cut in two" by the German counter- offensive employing "more than two divisions" on the Western Front and asserted that the attack was planned personally and was being directed by Adolf Hitler.
WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 19 (AP) -- John (Ox) Da Grosa was appointed head football coach at Holy Cross College today to succeed Anthony J. (Ank) Scanlan, whose resignation was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- Evening up of December grain contracts was accelerated today, as trading in them will cease at the close of business tomorrow and uncompleted contracts thereafter can be closed only by delivery of cash grain.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- The view that the British Government is obligated to guarantee Poland's frontier's against Russia in the same way as against Germany was advanced today by Count Edward Raczynski, the Polish Ambassador in London.

Members of the Uptown Chamber of Commerce joined yesterday with representatives of civic, educational and religious groups from other sections of the city in initiating a program to solve problems caused by friction among racial groups.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- High ranking officials are telling inquirers that the liberated peoples of Europe are not getting the adequate relief supplies that were promised because of an acute strain on Allied shipping resulting from the prolongation of the war in Europe beyond the time contemplated by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill when they met in Quebec early in September.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (U.P.) -- The Navy revealed today that the 23,000-ton naval auxiliary oiler ,Mississinewa had been sunk by enemy action in the central Pacific recently, but that almost 80 per cent of the crew had been saved by heroic comrades, including an unnamed Navy pilot, who braved a sea of flaming oil to effect the rescues.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- How the German Gestapo tried to suborn his servants, watched his own movements from an adjoining house, stirred up riots against the British Embassy and then photographed its broken windows was described in the House of Lords today by Lord Templewood, retiring Ambassador to Spain.

Like most other conservationists, Dr. Ira N. Gabrielson, director of the Fish and Wild Life Service, anticipates increased hunting and fishing pressure when the war is over. How to meet that pressure and its attendant problems is concerning many States and there appear to be as many plans as there are States.

The Office of Price Administration is looking into the matter of proposed conversions of privately owned apartment houses in New York City into cooperatives with a view to determining whether a new rent problem is being created, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- A proposal that Congress act quickly to aid small business firms during reconversion was unanimously approved today by the business, labor and agriculture committee of the National Planning Association.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 -- A committee of holders of preferred stock of the Buffalo, Niagara and Eastern Power Corporation asked today that the Securities and Exchange Commission seek power from Congress to order the payment of dividends during corporate reorganization proceedings.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 20 (UP) -- Two Soviet armies hurled a fifty-mile are around the Hungarian-annexed Czechoslovak rail city of Kosice and drove to within nine miles of the key junction yesterday as the Red Army's active fighting front in Czechoslovakia was widened to 100 miles.

Civilian leather shoe supplies will be even scarcer during 1945 than was be case this year, industry spokesmen said yesterday. They stated also that progressively lower inventories of rationed shoes will mean definitely larger quantities of non-rationed types, in which substitute materials are used.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Communique 255:

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Pearl Harbor, Dec. 19 -- Pacific Fleet Headquarters disclosed officially today that discussions were under way here between Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz and the staff of the new British Pacific Fleet.

IN BELGIUM, South of Monschau, Dec. 19 -- Veteran American doughboys, flung into one of the war's weirdest battles on a moment's notice, brought the German attack on the northern flank near here to a bloody halt today in a welter of wrecked tanks and dead men.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- An airplane in full flight can now snatch a person off the ground by means of a nylon rope and loop arrangement and reel him into the cabin without harming him, the War Department said today.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Wednesday, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A communique:

DETROIT, Dec. 19 -- Montgomery Ward Co. notified employes of its four strike-affected stores in the Detroit area today that it was putting in effect a minimum basic wage scale which it first offered in 1943 and similar to one which the War Labor Board recommended in May, 1944.

ROME, Dec. 19 -- One effect of the British declaration regarding Poland is to weaken British political influence in Europe in relation to Russian influence. Both Churchill and Eden were obviously unhappy in explaining to the House of Commons why they had agreed to a Polish-Soviet boundary fixed by Russia without the consent of the Polish Government which Britain continues to recognize.

Losing no time in facing the stark reality that major league baseball will have to contend with another northbound and frost-bitten training season in 1945, the Yankees, through their president, Edward G. Barrow, announced yesterday that they again will do their spring exercises amid the invigorating ocean breezes as provided at Atlantic City.

The Arkansas Natural Gas Corporation declared yesterday a 30cent dividend against arrears on the 6 per cent, $10 par preferred stock, payable Dec. 30. Payments on the stock during the year will aggregate $1.45 against $1.10 in 1943.

Stimulated by more active Southern mill buying, quotations for cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday at about the best levels of the day and with net gains of 4 to 9 points. The market held within a narrow range all day, but there were periods of moderate trading.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 19 (AP) -- A.E. Munyer's Peppy Miss, a smart 2-year-old in 1943 but unable to win this season until November, ran in top form at Gulf-stream Park today when she defeated eleven other 3-year-olds in the seven-furlong Delaware Purse.

The twenty-year treaty of alliance which General de Gaulle bought back with him from Moscow is intended to prevent Germany from starting a Third World War. This is also one of the major purposes of the plans made at Dumbarton Oaks for a new league of nations.

LONDON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Orvil A. Anderson, United States Eighth Air Force deputy commander for operations, has been promoted to major general, and Walter E. Todd, deputy chief of staff for operations, has been made a brigadier general, it was announced today.

The New York Rovers battled to a 2 -- 2 tie with the Philadelphia Falcons in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League encounter at Madison Square Garden last night. A crowd of 2,312 saw the last-place Rovers twice come from behind to pull even.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 19 -- Sixty-one thousand residents, all of Japanese descent, in the eight relocation centers of the West showed great uncertainty today about their future plans, despite the Army's decision to let them return to the West Coast States after Jan. 2.

That three-inch snowfall which blanketed the city and environs early yesterday upset the State Athletic Commission's routine. Because he was snowbound at his training camp, Rocky Graziano, East Side welterweight who is to battle Harold Green of Brooklyn in a return ten round bout Friday night at Madison Square Garden, could not appear for the customary examination.
Surprise, one of the elements most important and yet most difficult to achieve in modern war, was still playing a major role yesterday in great battles in Europe and in the Pacific.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 19 (AP) -The German counter-offensive on the Western Front assumed the proportions of an attempted major break-through tonight as the first front-line dispatches trickling through a news blackout disclosed that the United States First Army was massing infantry and armor in s_ effort to stabilize t_he front.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- A tremendous number of Australian women are mobilized for war in proportion to the population, so that Melbourne is more peppered with women's uniforms than Washington is, according to Lady Lavarack, a feminine leader in her own land, who has just joined her husband, Lieut Gen. Sir John Lavarack, head of the Australian military mission here.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Wednesday, Dec. 20 -American troops, smashing north and south, have cut the main highway running north and south through western Leyte's Ormoc corridor at two points, dividing the Japanese troops in the corridor into three segments.

When millions are in pain and sorrow all over the world it is hard to believe that any generous act one person can do can be of much importance. Yet there never was a time when it mattered more that we should be kind to one another. One individual cannot rescue a million people, but he can help to rescue at least one neighbor in dis tress.
LONDON, Dec. 19 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Canada's exports this year may be expected to approach the all-time high figure of $3,500,000,000, according to the December review of the Canadian Bank of Commerce of Toronto. Actual figures for ten months were $2,860,600,000, giving the Dominion a favorable balance of $1,405,400,000, including re-exports, to which should be added net exports of $93,700,000 of non-monetary gold.
Yesterday's Allied Mediterranean communique, as transmitted in English to Europe by the Allied Press Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A United States Fourteenth Air Force communique:

The Coordinating Committee of American-Polish Associations in the East, headed by Joseph H. Kaszubowski, sent a telegram yesterday to President Roosevelt pleading with him to intervene against the dismemberment of Poland as proposed by Prime Minister Winston Churchill in compliance with the demand of Russia.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The city's meat muddle was further complicated yesterday by the question whether establishment of livestock price ceilings -- which has been urged by the retail and wholesale trade, the Office of Price Administration, Mayor La Guardia and consumer groups -- might entail an increase in the retail ceiling price of some meats.
Your editorial "Whom the Secretary Serves" is a very fine statement of one of the weaknesses of our political organization.
WITH UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY, Dec. 19 -- Powerful German columns pushed farther into Belgium today in what has become by far the greatest battle in American history.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 13: Increases of $426,000,000 in loans, $485,000,000 in holdings of United States Government obligations, and $1,037,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Of the nine Government salvage drives started since the beginning of the war, those for tin and waste paper will require continued intensive effort at least until victory in Europe.
The Tool Division of CareyMcFall Company, Philadelphia, makers of tungsten carbide custom-made precision tools, to Gray Rogers in the same city.

LONDON, Dec. 19 (U.P.) -- Only some 1,000 of about 15,000 British brides of American service men applying for entry into the United States have received visas, an embassy official revealed today, but he added that this was in no way a reflection on British girls.

LONDON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Japanese forced more than 60,000 white prisoners to labor under worse-than-slavery conditions to speed through the Thailand-Burma railway and road and then left a monument to 25,000 men who died along the way, the British War Office charged today.

John McDonald, used-car dealer, of 433 West Forty-second Street, who conducts his business as "The Happy Irishman," was a bit on the gloomy side yesterday when he learned that Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Gavagan had granted to Leland Holzer, his former boss, an injunction restraining "The Happy Irishman" from doing business on the premises formerly occupied by Mr. Holzer, who is better known as "The Smiling Irishman."

The formation of the Independent Citizens Committee of the Arts, Sciences and Professions, to function as a "political force," was announced yesterday by Jo Davidson, chairman, at a conference in the organization's temporary headquarters in Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Distinguished Service Crosses were presented posthumously to the families of four chaplains who lost their lives in the Atlantic after giving up their lifebelts to soldiers when the troopship Dorchester went down.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Merlin E. Gher of Shiremans-town, Pa., who did a lot of fighting for the Navy before he did a lot of football playing for Yale, received the Air Medal here today for shooting a Japanese fighter plane into Simpson Harbor, Rabaul, New Britain.

F. Eberstadt Co. will offer today 75,000 shares of cumulative convertible preferred stock and 33,600 shares of common stock of the Aeronca Aircraft Corporation. The preferred stock, which pays 55 cents a share, is to be priced at $10, plus accrued dividends, and the common stock is to be offered at $5 a share.

There is no immediate prospect that holders of common stock of the South Porto Rican Sugar Company will get an early distribution from the Puerto Rican Land Authority's condemnation of the 19,000 acres of land on the island belonging to Russell Co., a subsidiary. The authority has moved under the law limiting individual holdings to 500 acres.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- The latest war news, coupled with the approaching holiday, was responsible for continued dullness in today's stock markets. There was, however, little disposition to sell and prices remained reasonably steady.
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted in English by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Great Britain will withdraw her military forces except in certain border areas of Ethiopia, according to the terms of an interim agreement signed with the Ethiopian Government and issued here today by the British Information Services. It also opens the air fields there to Allied forces.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The United States Circuit Court here granted today to the State of New Jersey a stay until Jan. 8 in proceedings which opened today in Newark to determine whether the Federal courts should rule on a railroad's appeal from a State court's railway tax decision.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- A new basis of taxation for British motor cars that will permit them to compete in world markets on more even terms, but at the same time continue to protect their home market against American competition, was announced in Parliament today by Sir John Anderson, Chancellor of the Exchequer.

The New York State Liquor Authority has opened an investigation into complaints of Nassau and Queens County tavern keepers that they are compelled to buy quantities of rums and brandies to obtain scotch and bourbon whiskies for their Christmas trade, it was disclosed yesterday.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY, Dec. 19 -- For months now some of us have been living in a pleasant, friendly Belgian city, and it had become home to us. It is near the German border and is one of those towns that our troops liberated on their march into the Siegfried Line last September.

New York householders this Christmas can, without too much difficulty or expense, "deck the halls with boughs of holly," evergreen wreaths and mistletoe. If their tastes run, instead, to roses or poinsettias they may have them too, but they must order early and pay higher prices than last year.

The Alhabb Realty Corporation, represented by Chambers Chambers, lawyers, has taken title to 246-8 West Forty-second Street and 243 West Forty-first Street for cash above mortgages of $280,000, according to the Title Guarantee Trust Company, which insured the titles.

Thanks to the bravery of their fighting men and in large part to the American production miracle which helped to equip all their armies, the United Nations have become so accustomed to victories that the present German counter-offensive in western Europe, with its dangerous potentialities, has come as a severe shock.
Taking the lead at the outset and never relinquishing it, Marshall College of West Virginia handed Brooklyn College its first home defeat, 57 -- 41, last night.

Max Jordan, newspaper man and radio commentator, is the author of "Beyond All Fronts," published today by Bruce, in which he dwells with special emphasis on the fate of the "good" Germans who have attempted, sometimes through the underground, to thwart the Nazis.

Discouraged by recent experience in attempting to do business with countries and possessions in the British sphere of influence, textile machinery dealers in this country are evading inquiries from such countries, it was learned yesterday.

SOUTHEAST ASIA COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Kandy, Ceylon, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Two Chinese armies, seeking to establish the first overland route to China since 1942, now little more than eighty miles apart, are encountering comparatively light Japanese resistance in their drive to join along the Chinese-Burmese border.

BOSTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- After pulling into three deadlocks, the speedy Detroit Red Wings rapped in four goals in the final period to gain their eleventh consecutive National Hockey League victory over the Bruins, 6-3, tonight before 12,000 fans at the Boston Garden. Eddie Bruneteau caged a pair of unassisted tallies during the last minute.

HEADQUARTERS OF 20TH BOMBER COMMAND, China, Dec. 18 (AP) (Delayed) -- Huge fires were left blazing along almost the entire length of Hankow's three-mile-long Yangtze River front area today following a perfectly coordinated assault by virtually every type of operational airplane in the China Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Officials of the War Labor Board said today that if Montgomery Ward Co. was raising the basic minimum wage to 46 cents an hour in its Detroit stores and making the increase retroactive to September, 1943, as reported, this action would not comply fully with the board's directives, even considering wage issues only, as the board had directed the retroactive date to be December, 1942, nine months earlier.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Basil O'Connor, chairman of the American Red Cross, recruiting agency for the Army and Navy Nurse Corps, today warned that the 10,000 nurses needed immediately by the Army and the 4,000 needed by the Navy "must be drawn at the risk of inconveniencing civilians land curtailing all except the most essential nursing care."

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- During his talks with Gen. Charles de Gaulle in Moscow, Premier Stalin said that he would insist on drawing Germany's eastern frontier along the Oder River, authoritative circles here said tonight.

Alexander S. Webb, president of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, declared yesterday that the charges made by Mayor La Guardia in his Sunday broadcast about the manner in which the society handled the dog quarantine were given "either in ignorance of the facts or in a deliberate attempt to embarrass the society."

CHUNGKING, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Japanese withdrawal in Kwangsi Province in south China appeared to be slowed down tonight as a Chinese High Command announcement said that Chinese forces advancing southeastward along the Kwangsi-Kweichow had taken Pushan, an important height west of Hochih.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 19 (U.P.) -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Pacific Commander in Chief, today issued a revised tabulation of Japanese shipping losses in the first three days of a Third Fleet carrier plane attack on Luzon, raising the total of enemy ships destroyed or damaged from ninety-four to 102.

For almost three years Broadway has been biding its time to see "Good Night, Ladies," one of the most phenomenal road successes of theatrical history. For instance, the Chicago engagement alone created a record of 100 weeks. The long-awaited arrival of the Howard Lang-Al Rosen presentation will take place at the Royale the week of Jan. 15. The opening is tentatively slated for Jan. 20.

Your editorial "The War Comes First" and the reports of your correspondents on the needs of Europe have put me into a reminiscent mood. They recalled the hectic days of 1940 and 1941 when the American people vigorously debated the issue of sending supplies to the starving European victims of German conquest.

Army's explosive unbeaten and untied football team that rolled up 504 points in gaining the mythical national championship was picked yesterday as the 1944 team-of-the-year in the annual Associated Press year-end poll, while Washington's Senators, chosen to win the American League pennant but finishing a badly beaten last, were named the "flop of the year."

Two films will arrive in midtown theatres today. "Winged Victory," Twentieth Century-Fox's adaptation of Moss Hart's Army Air Forces play success, will have its world premiere at the Roxy. The drama with music was produced by Darryl F. Zanuck, directed by George Cukor, with the screen play written by Mr. Hart.

A good heading for the remarks that follow, if space permitted, would be The Strange Case of the Upper Case and the Lower Case, with special reference to Liberals and liberals. Upper Case in the printing business is the technical name for capital letters, thus Liberals.

The record sum of $100,000,000 has been raised by the United Jewish Appeal for Refugees, Overseas Needs and Palestine since 1939, the three national chairmen reported at a meeting of the Executive Committee yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel.
