LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Now that the war has started again for the third time since 1940 for the people of eastern Belgium, what happens to the sign over the town hall of Eupen, German-speaking Belgian border town, the sign that said in German, "Welcome to our Liberators"?

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 19 -- The Deutsche La Plata Zeitung, pro-Nazi newspaper, which was closed by the Argentine Government Oct. 17 but appeared the next day in Spanish as the Gaceta del Plata, only to be closed in a few hours, reappeared yesterday and today as the Zeitung in German.

Net profit of the United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company for the first eleven months of this year amounted to $1,884,937, equal to 73 cents a common share after the requirements of the preferred stock, it was reported yesterday. In the eleven months ended with November, 1943, the company made $2,625,386 or $2.13 a common share.

Phil Terranova, Bronx, former N.B.A. featherweight ruler, last night knocked out Leo Francis, Panama, in the second round of their scheduled eight-round feature bout at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn. The finish came after 2 minutes 50 seconds of the second session.

ROME, Dec. 19 (AP) -A savage counter-attack mounted by the Germans in an effort to hold their positions on the west bank of the Lamone River northeast of Faenza against a British flanking drive has forced the Eighth Army's troops to fall back to the northern edge of the town, Allied Headquarters disclosed tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A story of how nineteen steamship lines made profits averaging $300,000 a voyage hauling war cargoes was filed with Congress today.

ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- Supreme Court Justice William H. Murray dismissed today indictments against twelve persons voted by the special grand jury investigating alleged crime in Albany County, and George P. Monaghan, special prosecutor, declared later that he would swiftly appeal the decision

When the President presents his new budget next month it will reflect, in the overwhelming main, expenditures made imperative by the war. But if it follows the pattern of our past war budgets it will continue to include a substantial amount of non-military expenditures originally undertaken under the influence of pump-priming theories.

Fifteen thousand poor children in a Sicilian port will have an American-style Christmas, thanks to bluejackets of the Navy and the New York Red Cross Chapter's camp and hospital committee. Mrs. Frank R. McCoy, vice chairman of the committee, announced yesterday that seventeen tons of presents for the children were shipped in time to reach them by Christmas Eve.
Work-bound New Yorkers battled three inches of snow and biting winds yesterday. The snow fell throughout Monday night, and so did the thermometer, which touched 17 degrees at 5:30 A.M.

FRED RUSSELL is a very pleasant young man who has been a watcher on our athletic scene for some fifteen years as sports editor and columnist of The Nashville Banner. During that decade and a half he has been everywhere, has seen plenty and has written about things that both amused and appealed to him.

BARI, Italy, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Members of the House Military Affairs Committee, who agreed that their twenty-five-day tour of the Western and Italian Fronts had given them a realization that the war is not likely to end soon, were bound for home tonight by plane.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- President Roosevelt returned today from Warm Springs, sun-tanned and a few pounds heavier.

THE second novel of Vardis Fisher's projected many-volume panel about the rise of primitive man from a completely animal existence to something remotely human is called "The Golden Rooms."* The title refers to the discovery of fire, whose golden rooms gave Neanderthal men warmth and protection in a monstrous world.

A banking group headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., received yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,800,000 of school bonds of Olmstead County, Minn., independent school district No. 1. The syndicate's bid was 100.009 for $1,560,000 as 1 1/4s, and $240,000 as 1s, representing a net interest cost of 1.198 per cent.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The German High Command has increased the strength of its western offensive in a gigantic effort to retake Aachen and drive Allied forces from German soil, the Berlin correspondent of the Basler Nachrichten of Basle said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- President Roosevelt, tanned and looking much rested after a three-week vacation interspersed with work at "the Little White House" in Warm Springs, Ga., returned to Washington today and held his first news conference since he

No recently acquired American citizen can be more welcome than Ellen Schwanneke, who has taken the oath and received her final papers in this city. It is not so much that Miss Schwanneke is a good actress, although in the leading role in "Maedchen in Uniform" she proved her abilities when she was only 15.
PARIS, Dec. 19 -- Coinciding with the German counter-attack in Belgium, a number of enemy parachutists have been dropped in central France by at least one airplane.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Labor circles here were analyzing today the effects of the decision handed down yesterday by the Supreme Court, holding that Negro employes on railroads are protected by the Railway Labor Act against agreements between management and labor organizations seeking to oust Negro firemen or bar them from promotion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Half the families in this country cultivated home gardens last year and more than two-thirds preserved foods, contributing much "toward easing the food situation during the war," according to a Department of Agriculture survey.

An Army nurse lieutenant who won the Distinguished Flying Cross, highest distinction ever given to a woman in uniform; a war worker who has saved 35,000 man hours by clever ideas, and a 19-year-old who found an answer to juvenile delinquency, were among the ten recipients of merit awards for 1944 announced yesterday by the magazine Mademoiselle.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The German High Command has increased the strength of its western offensive in a gigantic effort to retake Aachen and drive Allied forces from German soil, the Berlin correspondent of the Basler Nachrichten of Basle said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- President Roosevelt, tanned and looking much rested after a three-week vacation interspersed with work at "the Little White House" in Warm Springs, Ga., returned to Washington today and held his first news conference since he

American business, "to win the peace," must face challenges of major importance, including development of new concepts in foreign trade, improved methods of domestic distribution, and greater efficiency, so that the costs of Government can be met at minimum expense, John B. Glenn, president of the Pan American Trust Company, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Senate confirmed this afternoon all six of President Roosevelt's nominees as aides to Secretary Stettinius. The settlement providing a climax to the final legislative day of the year on Capitol Hill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -Senator Guffey declared today that James C. Dunn "and his friends in the State Department" had worked for the Franco regime during the Spanish Civil War and "have been following a pro-Franco policy ever since."

Some good counsel on the subject of losing weight through diet is given in two recent publications, one issued by the Community Service Society and the other by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. Both of these, unfortunately, are unavailable to the public.

The snow that struck the metropolitan area and made walking difficult for pedestrians brought encouraging news for skiing devotees, who now look forward to lots of outdoor recreation during the Christmas holidays. While city dwellers were busy clearing off walks, ski areas in the North Country were tramping down the extra snowfall to assure perfect conditions for the record throngs expected to test their "christies" and "stones" this week-end.

A step-up in the drive against black marketing by meat wholesalers was disclosed yesterday by the Sheriff's office, which reported that of 108 Magistrates Court summonses issued from Dec. 2 through Dec. 15 against fourteen food wholesalers, seventy-seven charges involved meats and provisions, thirty-four involved dairy products, six were for fish sales and one was fruits and vegetables.

First Lieut. Edward H. Costello, 30 years old, has been killed in action in Germany, according to word received from the Army yesterday by his mother, Mrs. Mary Costello, of 80-30 Eighty-seventh Avenue, Woodhaven, Queens.

Debate over the extent to which the State should invoke commercial rent control in New York marked the all-day hearing of the Joint Legislative Committee to Investigate Commercial Rents held yesterday at the Bar Association Building. Suggestions ranged from a proposed rollback to January, 1943, rent scales to a complete "hands off" policy by the State.

Conceding that "some intensive work has to be done" on formulating a national policy in the month before the meeting of the Republican National Committee around Feb. 1, Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican national chairman, said yesterday he was sanguine over the prospect of agreement among party leaders.

ATHENS, Dec. 19 -- Efforts to apprehend former puppet Premiers Jean Rhallis and George Tsolakoglou, who, with other alleged collaborators, are believed to have escaped from the Averof Prison after it had been attacked and set afire by the Elas forces yesterday, still were unavailing this evening.

ROME, Dec. 19 -- The first of the entirely new provisional governments to be formed in the liberated Balkans, breaking tradition with the past, is that of Marshal Tito in Yugoslavia. De jure this is not yet recognized by the Allied powers as the legal government of the country and they still maintain relations with King Peter's London group and the Subasitch Cabinet.

Your editorial on Mr. Churchill's speech concludes with the statement: "It is disappointing * * * to have the position of our own Government, in a matter of such great importance, portrayed as that of an inactive and ineffective bystander on the sidelines."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (U.P.) -Former Assistant Secretary of State Adolf A. Berle Jr. denied today that Count Carlo Sforza had been compelled to write a letter to the State Department pledging his support of Premier Pietro Badoglio's regime as a condition for being allowed to return to Italy.

Many draft registrants who believe their 4-F classification has permanently excluded them from military service may soon learn they are mistaken, it was disclosed yesterday by Col. Arthur V. McDermott, Selective Service Director for this city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The War Production Board, in another move to provide the Army with ample winter clothing, today ordered larger clothing producers to manufacture between Jan. 1 and April 30, at least as many Army overcoats as they made in the period July 1 through Sept. 30, 1944, or 25 per cent of their output of all types of coats, whichever is greater.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The War Department gave warning today that any war-goods manufacturers whose prices or profits might be too high that, under the scrutiny of a new company-pricing program for the coming year, would have to set closer prices and tighten their control of costs.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 19 (AP) -The Los Angeles Turf Club today announced that ninety-six thoroughbreds had been nominated for the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap, to be run March 3 as the world's richest race. It hasn't been run for three years.

LEYTE, Philippines, Dec. 18 (AP) (Delayed) -- Navy PT-boats today rescued twenty-three American soldiers from a fishing boat in which they had fled with seventy-three Spaniards and Filipino guerrillas after having been surrounded by Japanese.
CHEYENNE, Wyo., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Forest "Nubbins" Hoffman, 3 years old, came home like a conquering hero today, but his attitude was a little more prosaic: He wanted to wash the dishes.

The statement of President Roosevelt that there is no such thing as a formal, signed and sealed document called the Atlantic Charter, coming on top of present political difficulties in Europe, has been a windfall for scoffers and cynics, and especially for our isolationists, who are once more pointing with alarm.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- Louis Saillant, president of the National Resistance Council, praised the Radical-Socialists' resistance role during the occupation in an address at their convention here today. Later speakers said his statement was "comforting."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- With "pride and with humility, with anguish and with joy," President Roosevelt, in special Christmas greetings, expressed today the gratitude of the country to the members of the armed forces, while the top commanders of the Army and Navy, extending their greetings, stressed the changed nature of the war situation and voiced general confidence that the enemy would receive heavy blows during the coming year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 -- Spokesmen for farm organizations, which showed no regret over the departure from the West Coast, in 1942, of farm operators of Japanese descent, spoke up today in criticism of the Army order which permits the return of evacuees to California and other Coast States after Jan. 2.

OTTAWA, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Approval by the Canadian Parliament of inclusion of a freedom-of-news clause in world peace treaties appeared certain today on the basis of statements to The Canadian Press by the leaders of the four major parties in the House of Commons.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 20 (AP) -"Mr. Baseball" -- Connie Mack, who will be eighty-two Saturday -leaned back in the December sunshine and told a reporter his Athletics might "surprise the splendid Philadelphia fans" next season.

" I am sorry that I am not able to send more, for I know the meaning of being in need," wrote Mrs. Jennie Dettinger, sending a $5 note to aid this Christmas appeal for the Neediest Cases in New York City.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Two Government departments -- the Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Labor -- have got together on the problem of providing home help in cases of sickness and emergency. As a result, local authorities all over the country have been asked to proceed at once with the recruitment of women for the organization of a home help service.

Faced with the lack of sufficient facilities to cut and sew 600,000 delivery chutes, Army Air Forces officers have revised the program for an initial procurement of about 200,000 to be delivered in the next five months, with additional contractors for the balance to be sought in the meantime, it was learned yesterday.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 16 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Strong pro-Russian demonstrations were reported from the northern provinces of Iran today, and it was reported here that Sergei I. Kavtaradze, Soviet Ambassador to Iran, had asked Premier Mustafa Qoli Kahn Bayat to suppress five Iranian newspapers on the ground that they were anti-Russian.

Furniture manufacturers, who as late as last month were extremely optimistic about sufficient production to meet demand, are again alarmed because of recent War Production Board controls on hardwoods and the reported pending action on solfwoods, a spokesman for the industry said yesterday.

Today's events: "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "I Pagliacci," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:15 P.M.; concert, Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, George Szell conductor, Artur Schnable assisting artist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Children's Christmas Story, with New York City Symphony, Leopold Stokowski conducting, and Collegiate Chorale, Robert Shaw conducting, Augustin Duncan narrator, City Center, 3; piano recital, Marie Wilson Voss, Times Hall, 8:30.
The Germans were still striking with great fury at the First Army lines in Belgium yesterday, but news was sparse and the issue still in doubt.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Army Air Forces revealed today a revolutionary method of training its air crews, a device which, employing a Norden bombsight, a strip of film and a mirror, enables a bombardier to simulate almost any situation of combat.
Beruffled frocks specially designed for samba dancing were typical of the array of holiday fashions presented yesterday in the Young New Yorker Shop at Lord Taylor's.

Trading in the new shares which were to be issued by the Long Island Lighting Company, under a plan of recapitalization approved by the stockholders on April 25, was suspended from dealings by the New York Curb Exchange when officials of the market received notice that, acting upon an application of the Securities and Exchange Commission, a Federal Court here had issued a temporary order, returnable today, restraining the company from consummating its plan.

Possible Second Thoughts You find yourself wondering how H.G. Wells in London is reading the news from the Belgian fighting front. Only a few days ago Mr. Wells called upon Prime Minister Churchill to retire upon his laurels, "before we forget the debt we owe him."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- President Roosevelt and his retiring Vice President, Henry A. Wallace, conferred for nearly two hours today at a luncheon meeting. It was assumed widely tonight that Mr. Wallace's future status in the Administration received consideration if it was not actually decided.

American Sugar Refining Directors of the American Sugar Refining Company yesterday declared a year-end dividend of $3 a share on the common stock, payable Feb. 2. The previous payment was a $2-year-end in February, this year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The trail of the aggressor nations has been so bloody, the vile atrocities of the barbarians have been so monstrous and have lasted so long, that it would not be surprising if we had become to some extent numb to the horrors around us. There would seem to be a limit to the punishment our sensitiveness can take.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Business in today's stock markets was again on the small side and price movements again were small.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- Subscriptions to the French Liberation Loan floated Nov. 6 closed tonight with unofficial intimation that the result has proved very satisfactory. Estimates of the proceeds range from 120 to 150 billion francs.

LONDON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Flying Fortress and Liberator bombers of the United States Fifteenth Air Force, based in Italy, smashed at strategic targets in Czechoslovakia, Austria and Germany for the sixth consecutive day today as bad weather strangled the Allies' British air-based fighters and bombers, sorely needed to combat German armor in Belgium.

After consultation with wholesalers and retailers the Office of Price Administration announced yesterday that flat dollar and cents ceiling prices on butter and most common cheeses would apply starting today in the metropolitan area.

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 21 (U.P.) -- Soviet motorized infantry smashed forward seven miles in Czechoslovakia yesterday to within seventeen miles of the big communications center of Lucenec, while Berlin said that Russian tank forces northwest of Budapest had launched strong assaults to break through into the Bratislava Plain leading to Vienna.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Capitol the new attraction will be "Music for Millions," a musical produced by Metro featuring the child actress, Margaret O'Brien; Jimmy Durante, June Allyson, Jose Iturbi, Marsha Hunt, Hugh Herbert and Harry Davenport.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- Mgr. Eugene Tisserant, French Cardinal of the Curia at the Vatican, who has been in France for six weeks surveying church affairs before reporting to the Pope, was received today by Gen. Charles de Gaulle before returning to Italy.

Wavering tendencies present in the first two sessions of this week broke out yesterday into a full-scale retreat on the stock market. While extreme losses were reduced during the final hour under selective recovery, the list still exhibited the widest retreats in more than a month.

Despite a general price increase by all of the twenty-six Broadway attractions that will give performances on New Year's Eve and notwithstanding the fact that the holiday falls on a Sunday night, a survey revealed yesterday that two shows already had sold out, while a good many others had few tickets available at the box offices.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Mislabeling of the drug "Doryl" was charged against Merck Co., Inc., manufacturing chemists of Rahway, N.J., in indictments handed down at Trenton, N.J., it was stated here by Attorney General Francis Biddle.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange dwindled yesterday to the usual year-end volume. Prices at the close were 3 to 10 points net lower than on Tuesday.

The move to unload Latin-American types of distilled spirits in the current holiday season continues with some jobbers yesterday announcing price cuts up to $10 a case of twelve bottles. New York City tavern owners admit that they have been forced to buy rum or brandies if they wanted Scotch or bourbon whiskies for the Christmas season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Indictments charging Carl Emil Ludwig Krepper of 68 James Street, Newark, N.J., with conspiracy to aid the eight Nazi saboteurs of June, 1942, were handed down in Newark today, Attorney General Francis Biddle announced here.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- The German offensive has sharply diverted French attention from the purge, political maneuvers and even Gen. Charles de Gaulle's diplomacy to the war that is being fought on France's own frontiers.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Thursday, Dec. 21 -With the Yamashita line smashed, the remaining Japanese forces on Leyte are retreating in the direction of the island's northwest peninsula. Thus the battle for the Ormoc corridor is effectively ended.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- President Roosevelt signed today the bill appropriating $1,500,000,000 for Federal aid in building State highways and called the enactment "a challenge" to the States, counties and cities which must originate specific road-building projects to get the program ready for construction after the war.
It doesn't seem to make sense, but when there is a housing shortage for dogs in the city the only place a desperate dog can go to find a room is a hotel.

Senator Nye has chosen to celebrate his exit from public life by one last outburst of irresponsibility. In his farewell address after twenty years in the Senate he predicts that within the next twenty, even perhaps ten, years this country will be called to war with Russia.

Ceremonies attending the opening of "Winged Victory" at the Roxy Theatre yesterday were featured by a parade of almost 2,000 soldiers and Wacs on Broadway and Seventh Avenue and a brief speech by Mayor La Guardia, who reviewed the parade from a small stand in front of the theatre at Seventh Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

In answer to queries as to ski equipment this season, a survey was made yesterday of the leading sporting goods firms and department stores, and the conclusion reached was that there is a scarcity of the cheaper grade of skis, boots, harnesses, toe plates and ski poles.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The roads immediately behind the German attacking front are lined bumper to bumper with enemy transport of every description, defended by unbelievable quantities of anti-aircraft guns massed especially for this offensive, a United States Ninth Air Force flier said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Victor Andrade praised the Dumbarton Oaks conference and the Good Neighbor Policy when he presented his letters of credence as Ambassador from Bolivia to President Roosevelt today on the first anniversary of the Bolivian revolution.

While fragmentary pre-reconversion planning to meet post-war car output problems has been undertaken with full governmental approval, the automotive industry has set a new peak in the production of war materials during the last month, according to George Romney, managing director of the Automotive Council for War Production and general manager of the Automobile Manufacturers Association yesterday.

The nation's gasoline supplies at the end of last week were 82,747,000 barrels, consisting of 42,039,000 of civilian grade automotive, 13,157,000 of unfinished and 27,551,000 of aviation, military and blending stocks indeterminate as to ultimate use, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

The Central Savings Bank has sold the five-story dwelling at 10 East Seventy-fifth Street to a resident of London for occupancy. Assessed at $63,000, the house contains an electric elevator, a billiard room and a solarium. It was the home of Carl Schoen before it was acquired at foreclosure by the bank.
LONDON, Dec. 15 (Delayed) (AP) -- The stockings of British children will bulge as usual on this sixth Christmas of the war -- but the grown-ups who fill them will have tired feet and light purses.

Professional nurse registries here denied yesterday that their offices could be held responsible for the lag in recruitment in the Army Nurse Corps. Most of them are operating with the same number of professionals as were enrolled a year ago, or less, they said, with those who have left for military service replaced by older women returned to their profession, and all of them working on much heavier schedules than before.

Advertising supporting the war effort in daily and Sunday newspapers throughout the country aggregated $2,164,372 in September, bringing the total for the first nine months of this year to $36,507,142, the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, announced yesterday.

ROME, Dec. 20 -- The intention to fight against Sicilian separatism was contained in a strongly worded communique of Premier Inanou Bonomi's Government, meeting for working purposes for the first time today.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 20 (U.P.) -- Urgent warnings to Chinese civilians over a vast area to be ready to evacuate their cities at a moment's notice were broadcast by the Chinese Government radio today in view of an American aerial offensive, spearheaded by Superfortresses and developing with growing force over East Asia.

The worsted goods freeze will bring men's clothing buyers into the market here about a week earlier than usual, intent upon finding out at first hand what the exact delivery situation will be on spring lines, manufacturers said yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Chinese troops, advancing southeastward along the Kwangsi-Kweichow railway, continued attacking Japanese positions outside Hochih, making slight gains, the Chinese High Command announced today.

The old Madison Square Hotel, a landmark in the Madison Square neighborhood, and occupied in former days by a number of well-known New York families, has been purchased from the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank by Dr. Marion Reich, former Polish oil executive.

CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 20 (AP) -British troops, opening up two new drives in Burma, have slashed fifteen and eighteen miles through Japanese defenses under strong Allied air support, front dispatches disclosed today.

IT was the last Sunday in October and the Giants were making ready for their clash with the Philadelphia Eagles. Steve Owen walked across the dressing room, stared at an open locker and sadly shook his head. "Hank's gone, I guess," he said. "The United States Army is the only power strong enough to keep him away from a football game."

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Sophocles, flying the Bobanet Stable silks of R. Bruce Livie of Baltimore, just lasted to earn a head triumph in the Illinois Purse at Gulfstream Park today. The victor was an entry with Alfios, who was virtually left, and paid $4.80 for $2.

HEADQUARTERS, SIXTH ARMY GROUP, France, Dec. 19 Delayed) -- Heinrich Himmler, deputy Fuehrer of the Reich and master of the peoples of Germany and the occupied countries, was reported tonight to be in the Neuf-Brisbach area of lower Germany, near the French city of Colmar, where he has taken up a position to "bolster" the morale of both the citizens of that region and the Wehrmacht facing the French Army on the plains of Alsace.

Wanda Landowska and Yehudi Menuhin made their first appearance together last night at Town Hall in a joint recital devoted to four of Bach's sonatas for harpsichord and violin. The event was a feature of the season's Town Hall Endowment Series and attracted a capacity audience.

Reporting on operations for the fiscal year ended with October, the Marathon Corporation, producer of food packaging, informed stockholders yesterday that net sales had risen to a new high record of $29,856,031.

Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins disclosed yesterday that the Board of Health recently rejected a proposal by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals that the six-month quarantine on unleashed dogs be modified for the benefit of dog owners.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Smart Bet, galloping winner of his two Gulfstream Park starts, has drawn top weight in Tropical Park's $7,500 Inaugural Handicap, Racing Secretary and Handicapper Francis Dunne announced today. Mrs. M.J. Wolfson's fleet gelding is asked to pack 124 pounds in the six-furlong Christmas Day feature.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 20 -- The Trenton Transit Bus System, the city's only method of public conveyance other than taxicabs, was tied up today by the refusal of drivers and mechanics to work overtime without time and a half pay.

The countryside yesterday was mantled for a white Christmas. In the city stores were jammed with shoppers. Common carriers were prepared for capacity holiday travel. But the joy of yuletide preparations was dimmed by sombre news from the European war theatre and the absence of millions of young Americans of fighting age.

The report of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation for the first nine months of this year, issued yesterday by Sosthenes Behn, president, shows a consolidated net income after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $6,184,191, compared with $3,294,542 in the 1943 period.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The State Department will wait until the new Congress convenes before taking any steps in making interim agreements on problems involving international aviation, according to Joseph C. Grew, who gave assurances to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee this morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, received notice today that the American Federation of Labor was receptive to reaffiliation of the miners' union, but there was nothing to indicate that the letter, signed by President William Green of the AFL was anything more than a formality, implementing the action of the convention in New Orleans last month.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 20 (AP) -It is a real distinction to have been named athlete of the year for 1944. Viewing it from a broader picture it is a source of great satisfaction to me and to my fellow-golfers to consider that the game of golf has been accorded this recognition.
RAHWAY, N.J., Dec. 20 -Merck Co., Inc., has issued this statement:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- A new headquarters, Continental Air Forces, to be situated at the Camp Springs Army Air Field, eleven miles southeast of Washington, has been established for the purpose of decentralizing command functions over the four continental air forces and the First Troop Carrier Command.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 20 -- The great German counter-offensive in Belgium and Luxembourg is still mounting in intensity. Five or six tank divisions and eight or nine infantry divisions are rolling through a hole forty-five to fifty miles wide in the American defenses, although reports from the front indicate that American resistance is stiffening on the flanks of the enemy drive.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The United States and Ecuador are now discussing the terms of a military-financial agreement looking toward mutual cooperation in both spheres during the present and post-war eras.

The evidence is beginning to mount that parts of New York State are blessed with entirely too many deer. Now the citizens of northern Westchester and Putnam County are clamoring for an open season because of crop damage and highway accidents caused by the animals.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Superfortresses in substantial force today pummeled industrial targets in Mukden, Manchuria. Up to sixty B-29's of Maj. Gen. Curtis E. LeMay's Twentieth Bomber Command participated in the daylight 'strike against the Japanese dominated puppet State. The War Department said a communiqu would be issued on the mission when operational reDorts were received.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Forces, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Communique 256:

The Guaranty Bank and Trust Company of Lafayette has purchased an issue of $385,000 public improvement bonds of Lafayette Parish, La., on a net interest cost basis of 1.48 per cent, it was learned yesterday. Other price details were not available. The bonds will mature Jan. 1, 1947 to 1965.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The War Production Board ordered manufacturers of knit underwear to produce during January at least as many men's heavy-weight union suits as they made in the same month this year. The ruling was necessitated, it was said, by the need to provide civilians with adequate supplies of this essential article of apparel for the current winter months.
LONDON, Dec. 20 (UP) -- A German communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

The Choir Boys of Trinity Church assisted the Down Town Glee Club at its Christmas concert last night in Carnegie Hail, conducted by George Mead, who also is Organist and Master of the Choristers at Trinity. Another feature was the playing by Stuart Ross, the accompanist, of a group of three piano solos by Rachmaninoff, Raff and Chaminade.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 20 -- The positions of the Allies' and the German armies, in the future, will be made public once daily, it was announced today, after a sufficient time lag to make sure that the enemy will reap no benefit from the information.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 20 -- The arrest of Carl Emil Ludwig Krepper, former Lutheran minister, was made here by special agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation this morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The National Labor Relations Board established today a precedent closely related to the efforts of professional workers to form unions when it ruled that the General Motors Corporation was guilty of an unfair labor practice and of anti-union discrimination when it transferred employes from a salaried classification to an hourly wage basis because they had chosen a collective bargaining representative.

EVERY layman has his own ideas about crime, and there is much to excite ideas in a truly fascinating and disturbing book, "Crime and the Human Mind,"* by Dr. David Abrahamsen, a Norwegian psychiatrist who, after work at the front, came here to pursue research and practice in public institutions five years ago.

A 4 1/2-year-old Santa Claus, in full costume, but minus a beard, yesterday accepted Christmas presents for other children, brought by guests at the annual Christmas luncheon of the Fashion Group, held at the Murray Hill Hotel. Gaily wrapped gifts, marked for boys and girls of different ages, were piled high around a Christmas tree by Santa's assistants, two little girl elves.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -Representatives who inspected American battlefronts in Europe "found things in excellent condition," Representative John M. Costello, Democrat, of California, said tonight.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Goals by Hank Goldup and Kilby Macdonald in the second and third periods enabled the New York Rangers to break a tie for the National Hockey League cellar with the Black Hawks tonight as they came from behind for a 3-to-1 victory before 8.881 fans.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Disposal of equipment used in some overseas Army and Navy installations which was designed for that purpose and is not suitable for employment in other theatres of war has been authorized by James F. Byrnes. Director of Mobilization and Reconversion.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Foreign Minister T.V. Soong denied today that the United States had threatened, after the recall of Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell from the China theatre, to withdraw its establishment in China, including the United States Fourteenth Air Force.
LONDON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The text of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's statement on Greece in the House of Commons today:

WITH THE UNITED STATES SEVENTH ARMY, in Germany, Dec. 20 -- German forces continued today to resist viciously constant American pressure all along this front, contesting our advance every yard. In a sharp counter-attack the enemy succeeded in forcing United States units out of Bundenthal northwest of Wissembourg.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- A survey of the Army in the United States and overseas has revealed that 500,000 of about 6,750,000 enlisted men are definitely planning to return to full-time school or college attendance after the war, the information and education division of Army Service Forces noted today.

The controversy in the Senate over what Mr. Stettinius described as his new "team" has ended in the unexpectedly swift approval of all six nominees. And this is just as well. For if there was ever a time when the State Department needed a full team, and not bench-warmers waiting for the Senate's signal, that time is now.
ROME, Dec. 20 -- Formally and with regrets, Count Carlo Sforza declined today to go to Washington as Italian Ambassador.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 20 -- Final tribute was paid today to the Most Rev. Maurice F. McAuliffe, Bishop of Hartford, who died Friday night at the age of 69. Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York was present as Archbishop Richard Cushing of Boston presided at the pontifical mass of requiem celebrated in St. Joseph's Cathedral by Auxiliary Bishop Henry J. O'Brien, administrator of the Hartford diocese, seventh largest in the country.

MOSCOW, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Russian Army newspaper Red Star said today that German agents were attempting, "through reactionary circles in the United States and other countries," to block the formation of an international peace organization and were preparing for a third world war.

Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, commanding general, Army Service Forces, in an address last night before the metropolitan section of the American Society of Civil Engineers on the achievements of Army engineer troops, reported that "the worst natural barriers" in the new Burma Road to China from India "lie behind us" and that the completion of that vital road is expected "before too long."

Service men and a small number of women of the Alaskan Division, which comprises the chain of Aleutian Islands and the line of airfields and bases from Minneapolis to Nome, Alaska, are restive over home-front morale and labor disturbances, according to several clergymen who have just returned from a 12,000-mile tour of the area.

Few of us would complain about small annoyances -- one can scarcely call them hardships -- caused in this country by the war if we were fully and emotionally aware of what is going on elsewhere. To take a trivial instance, we are having trouble getting cigarettes. Most of us do get our normal quota, but we have to do some digging.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Irwin Steingut, Democratic minority leader of the Assembly, testified for three hours today before the grand jury investigating legislative spending and was requested by Hiram C. Todd, special prosecutor, to return tomorrow for further questioning.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Slightly train weary but otherwise fit, the twenty-three-man squad of Eastern football stars arrived today and began practice for the East-West charity contest, New Year's day.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Technical delays prevented the papers in the Montgomery Ward Co. case being certified to President Roosevelt today.

AN AIR TRANSPORT COMMAND BASE, in India, Dec. 20 -Air Transport Command planes on the India-China run continue to deliver an ever mounting tonnage of supplies to China over the "hump," it was disclosed here today.

IN THE STAVELOT SECTOR, Belgium, Dec. 20 -- American troops bearing the brunt of an attack by at least thirteen German divisions are suffering and inflicting their greatest single-battle losses of the war on the Western Front.

As Mayor La Guardia admitted yesterday that he had told Federal agency heads in Washington that "it would be better" to increase the retail ceiling on choice beef two cents a pound than to have housewives paying black market prices, consumer groups joined the city-wide meat emergency committee in demanding that present retail ceilings be undisturbed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 20 -Producers Releasing Corporation will use color photography for the first time in "The Enchanted Forest," a fantasy dealing mainly with animals of the western forest region. A camera crew is scheduled to start filming the picture in the Redwood forest of California on Jan. 4.

The quickness with which the new issues of both bonds and stocks have been absorbed in the investment market since the formal closing of the sixth War Loan Drive emphasizes the broad investment demand for new corporate material.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Views of newspaper men, specialists in political science and authorities on business management, in addition to those of members of Congress, will be sought by the new House-Senate joint committee on "modernization" of Congressional procedure when the committee begins hearings on the subject next month.

Yesterday one of the oldest food companies in the city, Acker, Merrall Condit, which operated a number of stores in the metropolitan area and elsewhere from 1820 to 1933, resumed its retail food business with the opening of a new shop at 2357 Broadway, near Eighty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The importance of the Senate in the task of ratifying the peace treaties and creating an effective international security organization has produced an interesting and significant race for five vacant positions on the Foreign Relations Committee.

ATHENS, Dec. 20 -- In a message addressed to the civil population of Athens and dropped from planes, Lieut. Gen. Roland M. Scobie, the British commander in Greece, warned today that "an attack by all available British and Government forces and the means at their disposal to knock out rebel artillery wherever it is found will be launched tomorrow."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (U.P.) -Two Superfortresses started big fires in the industrial area of Tokyo early today, carrying on a steadily intensifying aerial offensive against Japan and occupied China, as official reports disclosed that the giant United States air fleet that bombed Hankow on Monday destroyed or damaged eighty-eight enemy planes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -The nation may he headed for another billion-bushel wheat harvest in 1945, according to a report today by the Department of Agriculture that the winter wheat crop has gotten off to such a favorable start this fall that harvest next summer may total 761,951,000 bushels.

A new weapon in the war against black marketing was devised yesterday by produce buyers in the city, who decided to try it out against the big fruit and vegetable receivers on or about Jan. 15. The new weapon -- the "blitz boycott" -- consists of a well-timed and concerted refusal to buy certain perishable produce, letting it rot until the first receivers reduce their prices to the legal ceiling and end forced tie-in sales.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden assured the House of Commons today that Britain's motives in Greece were purely altruistic, although he conceded that stability in the Mediterranean was to the interest of this country and its empire. The Churchill government, he insisted, is neither opposing the regency nor trying to force an unwelcome king on an unwilling people.
A SMALL ALSATIAN VILLAGE, Dec. 20 -- There will be a bright Christmas for the children of this war-torn village.

ROME, Dec. 20 (AP) -- American forces south of Bologna are engaged in bitter fighting with German troops in the Tossignano area, while Polish and Indian troops have virtually wiped out all enemy resistance south of the Senio River on the eastern end of the Italian front, the Allies' command reported today.
Three reminders for service men and women seeking furlough rations of gasoline were issued yyesterday by Daniel P. Woolley, regional head of the Office of Price Administration.

After a brief ownership, David S. Meister has resold to an investing client of Julian Bernstein, lawyer, the six-story apartment building at 1975-9 Walton Avenue, near 179th Street, in the Bronx. The house is on a plot 150 by 100 feet and accommodates seventy-two families.

Establishment of the Wendell L. Willkie Awards for distinguished writing on any question of general public interest published in Negro newspapers and monthly and quarterly magazines was announced yesterday. They will be presented annually in October at a public meeting or dinner.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- While in no sense deprecating the seriousness of the German counter-offensive, Washington military observers still are inclined to take the long view in regard to the situation. They maintain that, while the immediate results may be costly to us, the end results may be more costly to the Nazis.

Retail liquor stores in the metropolitan area are enjoying the greatest Christmas boom since repeal of prohibition in 1933, according to a survey of dealers yesterday. Business in most taverns, however, has slowed down, as customers pay more attention to completing their holiday shopping.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Dec. 20 -Muhlenberg's undefeated basketball team chalked up its eighth straight victory tonight but got a real scare before nosing out Columbia University's Lions, 34 -- 33, before 2,000 spectators.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Imports of American films into England have been steadily increasing since the war and are now "on such a scale that they must be a matter of concern to the British Board of Trade," it was announced in the House of Commons today.

As the outgrowth of a recent letter by the Citizens Housing Council to Mayor La Guardia citing the possibility that the Mayor's plan for legislation to encourage rehabilitation of old-law tenements might "tend to perpetuate substandard dwellings and neighborhoods," a committee of the council has met with Commissioner Robert Moses and has helped to work out a plan to avoid that trouble.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, On Leyte, Dec. 20 -- Many Filipino guerrillas are extremely sentimental. They have rollicking war songs not unlike our "Bless 'Em All" but they also have some that, although rendered into English have a strongly Spanish touch.

Santa Claus, in the person of rationing officials, is coming early to New Jersey gasoline dealers who are being encouraged by the Office of Price Administration to qualify for replenishment of inventories depleted through spillage, waste, carelessness and even through the penalty debiting of counterfeit coupons found in their ration accounts.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 (AP) -Records of the Elastic Stop Nut Corporation of America, Union, N.J., presented to the Securities and Exchange Commission today, [ reported that a $470,000 loss suffered by the company last August was attributable to overspending, inability to reduce manufacturing costs, fewer sales, failure to supply orders in time and cancellations of contracts.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- Evening-up operations continued today in December grain contracts on the Board of Trade. Short covering late in the session advanced December corn 2 1/2 cents a bushel to a new seasonal high and to within 1 7/8 cents of the ceiling.

ROME, Dec. 20 -- To establish his provisional government on the widest possible popular basis, since it is no secret that there have been various groups in Yugoslavia strongly opposing him, Marshal Tito is paying considerable attention to propaganda.

Lord Templewood, formerly Sir Samuel Hoare, who has just completed his mission as British Ambassador to Spain, will be accused by no one of sympathy with Communists, or of being a rabble rouser, or of being especially liberal in his sympathies. It was Sir Samuel Hoare who negotiated with Pierre Laval the famous agreement by which Italy was to be satisfied by a slice of Ethiopia.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: So many questions have recently been propounded regarding patents by people, ranging from justices of the Supreme Court of the United States to laymen, that it would seem proper to ask some questions as follows:

Contrary to expectations held by exporters, the Soviet Union will seek large quantities of consumer as well as industrial goods from this market, informed observers stated yesterday. Present plans for a permanent industrial exhibition in Moscow call for the demonstration of several thousand different American-produced consumer items, it was said.

LONDON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Pledging the support of his organization for an "honesty in news between nations" program, Christopher Chancellor, general manager of Reuter, asserted today that a world-wide system of free news agencies would do much to make permanent the coming peace.
The feat of the St. Louis Browns in winning their first American League pennant yesterday was proclaimed the biggest sports surprise of 1944 in the annual year-end poll by The Associated Press.

The Vought Corsair is to be used extensively from the decks of carriers in the infighting against Japanese land-based planes from now on, according to an announcement yesterday by United Aircraft Corporation, with Navy permission. Though originally designed for carrier service, the Corsair from Guadalcanal on has made its chief record as a land-based plane in the hands of the marines.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Carl Snavely, head football coach at Cornell since 1936, accepted appointment today as head coach at the University of North Carolina, where he was mentor in 1934 and 1935. The contract is for five years.

The fifteen-story building containing eighty-three apartments at 310-16 West 106th Street was sold by the Travis Realty Corporation, Morris Metz, president, to a syndicate headed by Leo S. Margolin. It is on a plot 84 by 100 feet and was sold for cash over a mortgage of $475,624 held by the New York Life Insurance Company.

Forty-three Sanitation Department workers who appeared yesterday morning at the Red Cross Blood Donor Center, Thirty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue, became charter members of the department's "Gallon Club," which is eventually expected to enroll 4,000 persons who will contribute eight or more pints to blood banks.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY, Dec. 20 -- It is still forbidden to mention most places around which the fighting of the past four days has revolved because the Germans may not know where all their units are.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- The impression that stiffening resistance by the American First Army had slowed down the Germans' counter-drive into Belgium was reinforced tonight by German radio dispatches, which said American divisions had been rushed from both the Aachen and Saar fronts to oppose the German advance.

The Japanese commander on Guadalcanal, in a message to his troops in late December, 1942, told them he knew they had been through a terrible ordeal from the shelling and bombing of the "cowardly" Americans, who chose to fight with those weapons instead of coming out in the open for hand-to-hand combat, but that in the end the brave methods of the Japanese would prevail.

Arturo Toscanini will conduct the NBC Symphony Orchestra on Feb. 19 at Carnegie Hall in a concert to aid the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis. Vladimir Horowitz, Mr. Toscanini's son-in-law, will play the Beethoven Fifth piano concerto in E-flat major ("Emperor").

Miss Henrietta Szold, the American-born founder of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, is critically ill of double pneumonia in the Rothschild-Hadassah-University Hospital in Jerusalem, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Moses P. Epstein, national president of Hadassah.

The Belasco's next tenant still remained a bone of contention yesterday. Max Jelin, the theatre's lessee, and Lee Sabinson, producer of "Trio," each insisted that play would be presented there on Friday night of next week. They said so in no uncertain terms, despite objections from other quarters.

Former collaborationists are using the slogan "law and order" to block reforms and retributive justice in France, Richard de Rochemont, national president of France Forever, declared yesterday at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel of the French-American Club, which is affiliated with the Provisional Government of the French Republic.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The State Department was organized today on the basis of the new alignment of functions arranged by Secretary Stettinius when the new Under-Secretary of State and four of the five new assistant secretaries were sworn in.

LONDON, Dec. 20 (U.P.) -- The body of a Gestapo agent who had been awaiting execution in the Tarbes prison was found at dawn today riddled with bullets, the Paris radio reported. Last night the prisoner was kidnapped by unknown men who entered the prison by masquerading as police.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -Reports that thefts of gasoline and food from supply lines have been a serious problem for the American armies in Europe brought talk of a Congressional investigation today.

One of the stories of the genesis of the Christmas tree is that on a snowy December night long ago a woodsman in the Black Forest heard a noise at his door. Opening it, he found lying on the sill a baby in swaddling clothes. He took the child in, fed and warmed it and made a place for it by his fire.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- Both Gen. Charles de Gaulle and his Foreign Minister, Georges Bidault, assured the Assembly today that neither they nor the Soviet Government had any idea of separating themselves from Britain or the United States, but rather of fitting their new alliance into a system of security in which the Western powers could participate.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 -- Declaring that it was not satisfied that competitive conditions had been maintained or that the price to the company and the underwriters' spread were proper, the Securities and Exchange Commission refused today to release jurisdiction over the proposed issuance by the Capital Transit Company of Washington of $12,500,000 face amount of first and refunding mortgage bonds, 4 per cent series, due Dec. 1, 1964.

As a rule, theatrical producers obtain their backing from various sources, and only a few of the wealthy ones take all the risks themselves. To save the rank-and- file from wear and tear. Sherman Krellberg and John Wildberg have devised a short cut.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- German commentators claimed tonight that their armies had made a breach sixty miles wide in the center of the Allied front and that the number of prisoners taken had risen to 20,000. They added that American troops holding out in the Eifel range had been killed or captured.
ATHENS, Dec. 21 (U.P.) -- British and American relief agencies began the distribution of sixty tons of meat to the hungry Athens population today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Using the CIO-textile industry dispute as a pilot case, the public members of the National War Labor Board proposed tentatively today a new high level of 55 cents an hour for the correction of substandard wage rates.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21 -- In a building constructed especially for the purpose at a community center in a working men's section of San Francisco, "a training center for parents," with nursery-age children as the source of tests, is in operation as a project of the city education system.

A convicted violator of Office of Price Administration ceiling prices pleaded in vain yesterday for postponement of a thirty-day jail sentence so that he could spend Christmas with his bride. In rejecting the plea, Magistrate Matthew Diserio, sitting in the War Emergency Court, declared he had "no consideration for those who are profiteering out of the agonies of this war."

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Friday, Dec. 22 -- Six days after the United States landing on Mindoro American planes were operating from a quickly constructed airfield there, within easy range of Manila for fighters as well as bombers

ROME, Dec. 21 (UP) -- British Eighth Army forces, in a powerful three-pronged punch into the Po Valley, seized two towns northwest of Faenza, crossed the Lamone River northeast of the city, and cleared the east bank of the Senio for three miles north of the Rimini-Bologna highway, Allied headquarters announced today.
Winter made its debut at 7:15 o'clock last night accompanied by a Weather Bureau forecast of cold temperatures for today.

Two blocks bounded by Sheridan and Sherman Avenues between 161st and 163d Street the Bronx, have been purchased by Joseph T. Donahue from the New York State Realty and Terminal Company, a subsidiary of the New York Central Railroad.

Advertising clubs throughout the country have been asked by the Advertising Federation of America to work closely with the better business bureaus in their communities to maintain high standards of advertising.

A total of $55,000 has been donated or pledged for the acquisition of a Wendell Willkie memorial building, Charles Evans Hughes Jr., president of the Willkie Memorial Building Fund drive that is being sponsored by Freedom House, announced last night at the official opening of a general appeal for contributions.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 -- A high-ranking Army officer, who went unnamed, was quoted today by Maj. William L. Naftzger, assistant chief of the contract termination section for the Eastern district of Army Technical Services, New York City, as declaring that the probability was that there would be no Superfortresses flying today save for the production output of the Elastic Stop Nut Corporation of America.
The Browns failed to triumph in their first world series but they are making a virtual monopoly of The Associated Press' year-end poll.

ROME, Dec. 21 -- Prices in German-occupied Italy are about one-half those in the Allied zone, it was learned today from a report covering the northern zone. This aspect of the matter, which coincides with a mild resurgence of Benito Mussolini and his Fascist Republicans, is causing much anxiety to the Italian Government.

ATLANTA, Dec. 21 (AP) -- An Oklahoma newspaper man, a Negro, told a group of Southern editors and writers today that removal of voting restrictions in the South would not be accompanied by any attempts at domination of elections by members of his race.
DENVER, Dec. 21 -- The State Supreme Court ruled today that two sections of the so-called "labor peace act" of 1943, requiring incorporation of labor unions, were invalid.

The New York money market was subjected to a fairly heavy drain during the week ended on Wednesday, although the combined statement of the sixteen reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in this city revealed no radical alterations, according to Statistics released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
